column2: Accounts from Kansas continue to speak of outrages and robberies by MOATGOMERY'S band of outlaws. Several stores and the nost-office at Willow Springs were robbed on the 11th. Heavy robberies are also reported in different parts of Johnson County, and three hundred families are said to have been driven out of Lynn County.

As a matter of course. great interest was felt Sunday and yesterday to ascertain whether the news of peace in Utah, which we made public on Sunday, was correct or not. Some had their doubts, who had really no interest in the matter; while those who had such interest, were hopeful that it would turn out to be incorrect.

WARREN-WARD.-In this City, on Wednesday, May 12, at 7 P.M. at the Norfolk-st, Baptist Church by the Rev. Dr. Thomas Armitage. CHARLES J WARREN TO MARY E., May all the happiness this world can afford Be showered upon this one who once was Mary Ward. And when this day of life is wholly spent.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Can you inform me, through the columns of your valuable paper, whose duty it is to attend to tile repairs of streets ?-for, whoever that officer is, or may have been, his duty is most shamefully neglected. at least in some cases.

SWILL-MILK.--The Swill-milk stables are generally undergoing a very wholesome whitewashing, and at some-not the smallest of the establishments-the cows are being seat into the country to recuperate, while the Swill-milk war rages.

From the National Era. This Association, which has its head quarters in this city, had a full and spirited meeting at their rooms on Saturday night last. Senator SEWARD, of New-York, being present was invited to address the Association; which he did in an able and telling speech of about an hour's length.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. Broadway and Broome--AMERICANS IN PARIS--THE FROZEN LAKE. NIBLO'S GARDEN -- FLEUE DE MARIE--THE SECRET MARRIAGE--TIGHT ROPE--BOEEAS. LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE--THE ITALIAN WIFE--A LADY AND GENTLEMAN IN A P. P. P.--THE WILLOW COPSE.

In the Senate on Tuesday last, Mr. GWIN introduced a joint resolution, which was referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations, and which, in part at least, we sincerely hope will be passed by both houses of Congress.

A letter received from Maj. MCCARTY, Delegate from Arizona, from Mesilla, April 21, says that great excitement exists there in consequence of a party of thirty-five Mesilla volunteers, who pursued a band of marauding Indians, and killed seven of them in sight of Fort Thorne, being captured by Lieut. WOOD, in command of that post, and all imprisoned.

The American Tract Society, it will be remembered, at its lae anniversary meeting, refused to reaffirm a resolution passed by the Body in 1857, which directed the Executvie Committee to publish and circulate tracts on the moral duties of slave-in Asters, and cordemnatory of the evils which the Slavery system is known to promote.

On Friday morning last a resident of this village having employed two men, one named TOWNLEY, a whlite man, and ISAAC MILLER, a colored man, to do some planting, , called them, and asked them to take a drink before breakfast, at the same time producing a stone jug. stating that he did not know what kind of liquor it contained.

REMOVING ALL SHACKLES FROM OUR COMMERCE.-The most radical and sweeping measure that has yet been brought before Congress, was the report of the Select Committee, made by Mr. BOYCE, of South Carolina, on Wednesday, recommending the total abandonment of "protective" laws of all kinds, and a resort to direct taxation for a revenue for the support of the Government.

The Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, General NYE in the Chair. General NYE presented a memorial, signed by Messrs. Peter Cooper, Pelatiah Perit, Anson G. Phelps, Daniel Lord and one hundred and nine others, asking that the crying of newspapers on Sunday might be prevented.

We have received files of papers from Melbourne to the 16th of March. The Argus, in its issue of that date, gives the following interesting summary of the condition of the gold-fields: "In our last summary we had to notice that the yield of the gold fields was below the average. This is still the case, but to a less extent.

What has become of the Kansas question? Is it dead-or only sleeping ? For the present, at all events, it has disappeared from the field of political controversy, greatly to the relief, we doubt not, of the great mass of newspaper readers, without distinction of party, throughout the country.

The Boston Traveller sets at rest a rumor our rent in Boston, to the effect that Wm. S. Tucksmann. before going to the State Prison, made restitution to the Eastern Railroad to the extent of $200,000. All that was ever realized from Mr. Tuckermas was by the sale of his real estate, for which by the judicious management of the President, Mr. Howe, good price were obtained.

DOUBLE MURDER IN NEW-ORLEANS--The Picayune of the 13th says: "A fearful tragedy was this morning perpetrated on St. Philip street, in the Second District. A young man named VICTOR GARCIA, who is charitably supposed to he insane, attacked his father with a knife, at his residence on St. Philip-street, and stabbed him so that he died immediately.

To the Editorof the New-York Times: Your article of yesterday, on " The Tehuantcpec Isthmus," presented some of the strongest reasons why this, as one of all the several feasible routes of communication between the Atlantic and Pacific States of our Confederacy, should be made available at the earliest day.

The funereal solemnities of the late ANSON G. PHELPS, Esq., were conducted yesterday afternoon, at the Presbyterian Church in Mercer-street. The Church was full. The service commenced by the performance of HANDEL'S solo, "I know that my Redeemer liveth," sung by Miss FLINT, to the organ accompaniment.

There are in the port of New-Bedford, according to the Shipping List, the following whalers: 30 ships and 14 barks. In Fairhaven, 5 ships and 2 barks. A list of whalers expected to arrive in 1858 embraces 32 ships and balks, which had on board when last heard from, an aggregate of 16,473 bbls Sperm, 19,245 bbls.

Senator HAYNE, of South Carolina, tool his seat. The time of the Senate was occupied until 12 o'clock in the presentation of pension and other private memorials. Private bills were passed for the relief of Commodore McAuley, J. Horsford Smith, Jeremiah Prendergast, George Phelps, Joshua Shaw, Wiillam D. Moseley, Joseph Hardy, Alton Long, and Benjamin C. Edwards,

Iowa City was on Tuesday last the scene of a mob, and of a horrid murder. The facts, as we gather them from the Reporter and the Duboque Herald, are as follows: "A personal animosity existed between two men named WILKINSON and PHILLIPS. On Monday night PHILLIPS' barn was burned, and his partisans suspected WILKINSON of setting it on fire.

In steamship Black Warrior, from New-Orleans and Havana--P. Van Honton, Buckner, Capt. Slater, Mrs. Forbes and child, McVicker, Mrs. Leavitt, W. H. Elliott, wife 2 child and servant. A. O. Dowd wife, child and servant, Battles, Mrs. Stephenson Thomas Mrs. Beck, M. Dulong, Capt. McConnell, wife and 2 children, Mrs. Root Choppan, Clay Thomas, Pierce, Mrs. Mills, Croots, Deynoodt, Bergarot, wife and child.

The Albany Knickerbocker revives the story of the "last Bournon" A lot of old cash books belonging to the A bany firm if B. J. R. Bleecker, extending from the years 1799 to 1882, have recently been examined, from which it appears that firm were the bankers of a French gentleman, named De Jourdin, who arrived in Albany in 1799.

The Trustees of the New-York State Inebriate Asylum held their meeting for locating the Asylum May 19, 1858, at No. 150 Nassau-street. In the absence of the President--the Hon. BENJ. F. BUTLER--the Vice President, the Hon. WM T. McCOUN, presided.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. A resolution was referred to the Committee on Fi. nance, that the Comptroller be directed to pay the inspectors of all streets employed by the late Superiutendent of Street Improvements, Chas H. Ring, upon their presenting him with proper vouchers.

ORSINI DEMONSTRATION IN CHICAGO.-The Red Republican demonstration in Chicago, in honor of ORISINI and PIERRI, came off after long preparation, on Monday night. Like the one here, it was a torchlight affair, with abundance of burning pitch, plenty of banners, a general turn-out of the German Turnners. and a catafalque surmounted by raven plumes.

There is no sadder sight in France than one of those long processions of orphan girls, (enfants trouvees.) preceded and followed by their guardians and protectors, the Sisters of Charity. They are recognized by a light blue ribbon which passes over both shoulders and joins in front at the waist.

BURIGLARIES.--A burglary was committed at an early hour yesterday morning. at the iron foundry of Charles Davis, No. 110 West Eighteenth-street. A light was seen in the upper part of the building by a person passing by, who immediately mistrusted that something was wrong, and notified two policemen near by.

THE EXPRESS LIBEL SUIT.-This case, which has been on the Calendar for a long time, was finally brought to trial in the Circuit Court, before Judge LOTT, yesterday. The suit is brought by Mr. PETER K DEYO against the Messrs. BROOKS, editors and proprietors of the Express, to recover $5,000 damages on account of alleged libelous articles in the Express during tile Fall of 1856.

ANOTHER GREAT CASK TO BE LITIGATED.-The late CHARLES McMICKEN. of Cincinnati, bequeathed a handsome sum to the City of Cinoinnati, for the foundation of Free Colleges for Orphans. A portion of the property so devised lies in Louisiana.

JAMES AIKINS, second mate of the clipper-ship Mandarin, which is lying in the stream where she was hauled out, preparatory to starting for China, was killed about 6 o'clock yesterday morning, by a sailor named WILLIAM SOMERS. The second mate had mustered the men to wash the decks.

The Senate received communications from the Secretary of War, covering information respecting the A??alo Expedition ; also, recommending the expenditure of $100,000 for breech loading fire-arus for a portion of the Army. Mr. SEWARD introduced a bill for the removal of the Revenue Buildings at Quarantine Station, New-York. Reterred to the Committee on Commerce.

SUDDEN DEATH OF A CINCINNATI GROCER.-T. S. GAYLORD, of the firm of GAYLORD, SON Co., extensive grocers in Cincinnati, fell dead on Thursday evening at the corner of Canal and Church streets. He was conveyed directly to the Fifth Ward Station-house and detained to await the Coroner's inquest. On his person were found a draft for $10,000, a check for $4,900, and $141 79 in money.

We may expect within a day or two, some confirmation or correction of the reports concerning the surrender of the Mormons. It is scarcely possible that official representations upon a subject of so much importance should not be made, and it is time in due course of mail for their reception.

PERRY.--In this City, on Thursday, May 20, Mrs. JANE PERRY, widow of David Perry. Jr. The friends of the family, and of her brother-in-law. Thomas Owen, and of her son, Theodore Perry, are invited to attend her funeral, on Saturday, at 3 P.M., from No. 203 Henry-St., New-York, near Clinton St. BOYD.--In this City. In Friday, May 21, ROBERT B. BOYD. aged 52 years and 6 months.

From the Boston Ailas. Wednesday was a red-letter day for Amherst college, The Occasion was the dedication of two new buildings for college purposes. One of them, Wolliston Hall , was erected mainly through the liberalicy of Samuel Wolliston, of Easthampton, at a cost of $15,000.

We have Rio de Janeiro papers to April 13. There is no political news. The papers were discussing Mr. MEADE'S propositions to the Emperor; and while some of them look upon the projected closer alliance with the United States favorably others violently oppose it.

CHARITABLE MATINEE.--The matinee to be given at 1 o'clock to-day, at the inauguration of the new Nursery and Child's Hospital, In Fifty-first-street, is rendered attractive by the promised appearance of CARL FORMES, Mad. CHOSNE, APTOMMAS, and other popular artists. Aside from the charitable intent of this entertainment, the proceeds being for the benefit of the institution, the programme is a temptation.

From the Albany Kinckerbocker. SIR: If the following remarks are considered of importance in the investigation you are prosecuting respecting the history of Monsieur ELEAZER WILLIAMS, you are perfect liberty to make use of them as you please: Among the reminiscences of early days, I have always recollected with much interest being taken by my ?? to visit a family who arrived here in 1795, direct from France, consisting of four individuals.

STEAMER BAY STATE ASHORE.--The steamer Buy State, of the Fall River line, wentashoreat 7o'clock, yesterday morning, on Hallett's Point, L. I., in consequence of having been run into by the schooner Philadelphia, of Barnstable, from Boston, bound to Albany,-which, in stopping her engines to avoid the collision, occasioned her going ashore.

THREE PAWNBROKERS IN LIMBO.--Zion Bern stein, pawnbroker at No. 415 Broome-street, Isaac Bernstein, his son, who keeps a pawnbroker's establishment at No. 103 Prince-street, and Jacob L. Phillips, also a pawnbroker, whose place of business is at No. 197 Grand street, were committed yesterday to the City Prison to answer a charge of a conspiracy to defraud the firm of Wm. Chas. Hodges, of this City, out of $20,000.

The Late Common Council Command. KINGS COUNTRY COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER-May 21. Before Judge Lott. and Justics Kmmons and Sohoomaster The Grand Jury came into Court this Morining and made the following remarkable presentment: To the Honorable court of year and Terminer of the county of King:

Any one who reads Jenkins' accounts of the various festivities to which he is invited in Washington, ot the grace and beauty of the women, the high-souled courtesy, and unadulterated wit and valor of the men, and the enormous cost of the wines and ice-cream, would suppose that all who had the entree of those fairy scenes. had CHRSTERFIELD'S manners and SYDNEY'S heart.

Mr. CHARLES MATHEWS, the famous actor, and Mr. A. H. DAVENPORT (of Wallack's Theatre,) came in collision about 7 o'clock last evening, in front of the New-York Hotel, Broadway. The latter assailed the former with a cowhide, and a secuffle ensued, which was stopped by some citizens and the police.

The Rev. Dr. S. H. COX has received a call from the Spring-street Church, in this City, to become its Pastor. Dr. Cox has long been known as an able and eloquent man, and although quite advanced, " his eye is not dim nor is his natural force abated." It is not yet known whether Dr. Cox will accept or decline the call.

" THE SANDS OF LIFE" "PLAYED OUT."--Those who have for a long time swindled people in all pats of the country, by promising to send cures for all diseases, and means whereby large fortunes were to be made, for very small considerations, have met with a serious obstruction to their business.
In yesterday's TIMES we published a preamble and resolutions adopted by the New York State Temperance Society on Thursday last, in a meeting or convention held at the city of Auburn.

Since the order from the Secretary of the Navy was received, changing the destination of the Wabash from the Mediterranean to the Gulf of Mexico, extraordinary activity has been manifested at the Navy Yard, in preparations to have that frigate in readiness to depart at an hour's notice.

The Mayor's Office in New-York was the centre of some activity yesterday morning. About a fortnight ago His Honor bad dispatched the Chief of his own Police squad, Sergeant BIRNEY, to Georgia,armed with a communication to the Attorney General of that State, a copy of which, and of the entire correspondence.is annexed. The authorities of Georgia bad erroneously supposed that their lotteries were in accordance with law.

From the Washington Union. We have St. Louis papers up to the 18th inst., detailing all the news from Utah to the latest dates. Great anxiety is naturaly felt to learn the exact nature of the actual state of things having relation to the settlement of the difficulties between the Mormons and the United States.

The body of JOHN AIKINS, the second mate of the ship Mandarin, who was killed, on Thursday, by WM. SUMERS, one of the seamen, was buried yesterday forenoon at Greenwood. Capt. DUNOIS, of the California clipper-ship Queen of the Pacific, who had only a slight acquaintance with AIKINS, ordered a nice coffin, gave the directions as to the disposition of the body, and paid all the expenses.

A NOVEL VIEW OF THE BRITISH OUTRAGES IN THE WEST INDIES--The Evening Post has an exceedingly sensitive organ for scenting out a political plot. Its quickness to scent a budding thunder-storm in the ambient air approaches the marvellous.
The Health Commissioners promise to enter upon the performance of a long-neglected duty. They have agreed with Mayor TIMES that the swill-milk nuisance must be abated.

The pressing duties of his position here, has caused the postponement of Lord NAPIER'S visit to Virginia. The wife of the Minister has gone. The correspondence between Lord NAPIER and Gen. CASS shows that the Minister is not so forward to assunse the responsibility in efforts to prevent and punish outrages upon our flag in the West India seas as he was lastFall to cooperate in the capture of WALKER and the fillibusters.

MEATS. The Meat Market is well supplied with Beef, Veal and Pork, for each of which the demand is only moderate. Prices have not varied much for a week or ten days, though choice pieces of Beef are some what dearer. Mutton and Lamb are not quite so plenty, and they are a trifle higher. The demand, however, is not brisk. Smoked and pickled meats are in good supply and limited request.

THE EXTENSION OF OUR EMPIRE SOUTHWARD An article which we copy, this morning, from the London Times, will attract attention as an expression of English sentiment in regard to the extension of our control over the Spanish-American Republics. The idea that Great Britain would interpose objections, as we have frequently said, has no foundation in fact.

WIGHT-PLATT- In this city, on Thursday. May 20. at the Madison square Church by the Rev. William Adams D. D. Mr. George W.WIGHT to miss HARRIETT L. PLATT all of this City. FORMAN-DALLARD-In Brooklyn on Thursday May 20, at the church of the Trinity by the Rev. Dr. Lewis GUIDS FURMAN, M.D. of New York to MISS ELVIRA H. BULLARD of the Former City.

ANOTHER MAN OVER NIAGARA FALLS --The Rochester UNION says a man went over Niagara Falls on Wednesday. He came from the Canada side at Chippewa, in a sail-boat, nearly to the American shore, and was in the not of remaining. When he went into the rapids. It was thought by those who saw turn from the shore,

The Oskaloosa, (Iowa,) Herald says of the reports of gold mining in Iowa: It is positively asserted by those who have visited the unless in warren county, that the diggers are making from three to ten dollars a day. In this county, we are credibly informed that gold has recently been found in two or three different localities, but not, as yet. in sufficient quantities to justify the expense of washing it.

JACOB RAHM, Marshai of Chicago left this City last evening for home, taking with him the remains of the murdered female which arrived here about two months ago, packed in a barrel of whisky, and which for a time created so much excitement, owing to the deep mystery surrounding the case.

To THE HON. CHARLES P. AVERY--Dear Sir: I present you my sincere thanks, for your kind and liberal letter. It partly caused me to forget my present horrific position, and carried me back through long years of unknown suffering, to our first acquaintance, and the days of my boyhood, when hope was bright, and ambition powerful.

Judge SHAW'S decision, that a nuisance can be abated after a fashion that amounts to a virtual codification of the Lynch code, has hearifly frightened some good people, who have looked upon the supreme court as the last barrier, in these degenerate days, against the ever-surging waves of radicalism. They hold it to be the organization of anarchy.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Chorch met in this city yesterday. One houndred and sixty-six delegates were in attendance. The Rev. M. R. THOPSIN, of Buffalo, was elected Moderator. A communication was received from the Presbytery at Harmony, Ky., announcing its withdrawal on account of the slavery question.

The mails by the Niagara from Boston, reached this City last evening. We obtain from our European files some additional intelligence of interest. The Times announces, an authority, that her majesty has intimated her intention of raising Sir COLIN CAMPELL to the peerage. The new title of Sir Colin is not given.

Before Judge Sutherland. Charles P. Butler vs. George W. Brown.--This was an action brought by the owner of the brig George Albert to set aside a mortgage on the brig given by him for a part of the purchase money.

Yesterday was an industrious day in the United States Senate. An unsually large number of private bills was disposed of, and the private calendar nearly cleared-a thing which seldom happens in Congress. Little business of public interest, and none of special note, was performed.

The entire Session was employed to-day in fillibuateling against the Minnesota members, with a prospect of repeating the same thing to-morrow. On Monday the Paraguay resolution will be called up in the House and put upon its passage. It is not improbable that a similar resolution, authorizing the President to employ sufficient force to prevent a repeti ion of the outrage by the British, will be reported from the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of this morning you say, in the article on "Wholesale Corruption," in which you refer to the disgraceful and criminal proceedings of the Legislature of Wisconsin, in the matter of the La Crosse and Milwaukee Railroad Company: "We have very little doubt that every Western State would present a picture equally infamous, if the facts could be ascertained with equal fullness"

GENERAL ORDERS--No. 14. It is with deep sorrow that the General-in-Chief announces to the Army the death, early in the morning of the 17th instant, at Fort heaven worth, of one of America's most distinguished commanders and ornaments--Brevet Major General PERSIOR F. SMITH while preparing to march with the reinforcements destined for Utah.

The most piquant and readable volume that has been published during the present year is Trelawney's Recollections of the Last Days of Shelley and Byron, which has just been presented to American readers by TICKNOR FIELDS, of Boston.

A BOGUS REPORTER IN THE ROGUES GALLERY. --The fellow HOWARD, who has cheated so many people out of money, ball-tickets, good dinners and expensive suppers, by representing himself to be a reporter, Mayor's clerk, , extended his philanthropic labors, the other flay, so far as to carry a carpet-bag for a stranger.

The screw-steamship City of Washington, which sailed from Liverpool at about 9 o'clock on the morning of the 12th of May, arrived at this port last evening. The Cunard steamship Africa, from New-York, arrived out at Liverpool at 10 1/2 P. M. on Sunday, the 9th inst.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I see in the NEW-YORK TIMES that one DE JOURDIN, of the French Court, arrived in Albany in 1799, with a boy said to be a son of the King of France. This box is supposed to be LOUIS XVII.

We were very much surprised and gratified this afternoon by the arrival in our midst of ABEL GILBEST, Esq.. of the established firm of GILBERT GERRISH, late merchants in Salt Lake City, from California, by way of Salt Lake City.

In steamship Jamestown, for Norfolk. Richmond, P. Morgan, J. D. Bartholomew, B. Rice, J. Rice, J. Aldridge, J. Richards, J. F. Goodson, J. Rogers, J. P. Underhill, J. Halsey, Miss H. Green Mrs. Dayres, Miss Va. Biddich, Miss M. Riddich, Miss Disosway, B. B Ward and lady, J. Hersman, James Irwin and servant.

Since my communication of the 20th ult., nothing of any special interest has transpired. The work of receiving the Atlantic Telegraph Cable on board having been completed, so far as regards that portion deposited here, we are only waiting the arrival of the propellor Adonis, from London, which is due with 350 or400 additional miles of newly made cable.

The trouble among the miners of the Ashland coal district, near this place, has assumed a serious pect. The workingmen struck for higher wages several days ago, alleging that, at the rate received, they could not support their familes. As thsir em overs refused to make any concessions, the miners ent off in a body to their collieries to obtain higher wages, or compel the workmen to make the striKe a general one.

We noticed, the other day, with intimations of incredulity, the publication in the Albany Slatesman of a pretended disclosure of a new secret order among the Roman Catholics of this country, Archbishop HUGHES at their head, formed for the purpose of controlling the civil and political action of the members of that Church.

HORRIBLE MURDER BY BOYS.--The murder of ??GH DOWNIE, the drover, in St. Louis, last week, by three boys in a barber shop, is one of the most extra-ordinary instances of crime on record. It will be remembered that a few days ago the body of DOWNIE was found in a celiar, bearing evidence of murder and robbery. A train of circumstances after a few days investigation, were developed, which fastened suspicion upon three boys,

COURTNEY--RODGERS.--In this City, on Friday, May 21, at the house of the bride's brother. No. 310 Bowery. by the Rev. J. Thompson. D. D., JAMES COURTNEY. Esq., of Scranton, Penn., to Miss JANE RODGERS third daughter of William Rodgers. late of Newry. Ireland.

The fashionable season died out this year with the advent of leaves and flowers. The French love of out-door life manifests itself with the appearance of the first verdure, and then the hot-bed life of the Winter must give place to promenades and the study of the Spring fashions.

We are at length in possession of reliable intelligence from the seat of war in Utah, and the rumors which have lately reached us from that quarter are only in part confirmed. Our correspondence from Fort Bridger, extending to the 9th ult., and published in another part of this morning's TIMES, will be read with the deepest interest.

Mr. HAYNE has been appointed on the Military Committee, instead of Mr. IVERSON. Mr. HUNTER, from the Committee of Finance, introduced a bill to authorize the loan of $15,000,000, which was read the first time.

The following is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 15th day of May to the 22d day of May, 1658: Men, 97 ; Women 80; Boys, 123; Girls, 102. Total, 402*. Adulis, 177; Children, 225; Males, 220; Females, 182; Colored persons, 6.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: SIR: In an editorial in Wednesday's TIMES, alluding to the bill for the admission of Oregon, and the clause in her Constittion excluding free negroes and Chinese, you say:

The Montgomery Convention did nothing, so far as measures are concerned. Measures were discussed-the condition of the South was considered in its political, which control its commercial, relationS. A large number of Southern men of influence arid consideration, from different portions of the South, had an opportunity of conferring with each other, and of giving information as to the opinions and temper of the people of the South.
WALLACK'S THEATRE.-There will be no performance here to-night-the house being closed for the purpose of rehearsing the new piece called "Deseret Deserted," which is to be produced tomorrow night.

A SOUTHERN VIEW OF THE SOUTHERN CONVENTION.-We copy a sombre article on the recent Montgomery Convention, from the Charleston Mercury. It strikes us that our South Carolina contemporary makes itself needlessly unhappy.
The New School Assembly of the Presbvterian Church met a Chicago on the 20th inst. The Dr. FISHER, of Cincinnati. preached the opening sermon; and the Rev. Dr. THOMPSON, of Buffalo elected Moderator.

A PIECE OF DISINTERESTED ADVICE.-We respectfully advise Mr. CHARLES MATHEWS, the English comedian, to go home-as soon as he can make it convenient. Both profession ally and personally, he is " played out."

Mr. John Tyler Jr., has written a letter to the Washington Star about his father. He says: "John Tyler, before he was President, never was a bankrupt. Besides paying as surety for others, $40,000, the day never had been from the day of his manhood, that the had not ample means always at hand to meet every obligation resting upon him.

At 12 1/2 o'clock this morning, a fire broke out in the Hollister Elevator, on Ohlo-street, which, with two dwelling houses, the Elevator office, and a saloon adjoining, were totally destroyed. The Elevator was owned by GEO. W. TIFFIT, valued at $20,000, and partially insured:
Every day or two some Committee of the Common Council or Head of a Department comes out with a ponderous report showing how, and when, and by whom the City has been swindled.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: As an old subscriber and constant reader of your paper, may I be allowed to have a word therein respecting the present state of affairs in the Gulf of Mexico ? I, of course, allude to the action of the English cruisers.
The Select Committee, of which Hon. W. W. BOYCE, of South Carolina, is Chairman, appointed to consider the several subjects of a reduction of the expenditures of the Government, the Navigation Laws.

The bark John Howe, Captain NICHOLS, which has already been referred to in this journal, as one of the vessels boarded in the harbor of Sagua la Grande arrived at this port on Saturday evening. Captain NICHELS has communicated to our reporter the particulars of his being twice boarded by British Cruisers.

Hon. CHARLES SUMNER sailed again for Europe, in the Vanderbilt, on Saturday. The following letter, addressed to his constituents, explains the reasons of his departure:-- To the People of Massachusetts: Two years have now passed since, while in the enjoyment of perfect health, I was suddenly made an invalid.
NEWSPAPERS AND BOOKS.--Speaking of newspapers, the NEW-YORK TIMES is "spreading itself" in an establishment such as no newspaper in this country has ever attained to before.

The President has announced his determination not to make the New-York appointments before the adjournment of Congress, unless the session is extended until the last of June, in which case they may be made.

TWO MURDERERS EXECUTED.--Two murderers were hung last Friday; WILLIAM WILLIAMS, at Harrisburg, for the murder of DANIEL HANDRICKS, and DENNIS SULLIVAN, at Oswego, for killing JOSHUA HIBBARD. Both culorits died without manifesting fear.

PERSPICACITY OF THE ORGAN. -- What a delightful and useful institution is a Government organ! As a medium of communicating with the public at large, without the formality and responsibility of official documents, it is certainly invaluable.

The New-Orleans Picayune of May 16, publish es a supplement containing a view of the great cre vasse at BELL'S plantation, and a statement of the con edition of the waters. According to the Picayune figures, the damages occasioned by this disaster, will reach four or five millions of dollars. It says:

To the Editor of the New- York Times: In your article this morning on " Wholesale Corruption," as displayed in the La Crosse swindle, you remark: "If there is anybody left in Wiscousin who has notbeen bought, or who cares a straw for the honor of the State."

The last mail has brought us full details of the storming and capture of Lucknow. Mr. RUSSELL, of Crimean celebrity, the special correspondent of the London Times, sketches with photographic fidelity the wondrous and terrible scenes which characterized the sack of the fallen city-the plunder of the palace

Our correspondence from Fort Bridger, Utah Territory, published in another part of this morning's paper, is of the highest importance. We now learn, from a reliable source, to what extent the late rumors from Utah are founded on fact.

BURCHARD -In this City, on Saturday, May 22, at 11 A. M. ADELINE PHYFE wife of Gurden Burchard, and daughter of John Phyfe. in the 33d year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her father, No. 85 West 20th-st., at 4 o'clock on Monday afternoon.

A dispatch dated Leavenworth, 22d, says that Doniphan County gives about 450 majority for the Leavenworth Constitution. In several precincts the polls were not opened, and not half the vote of the county was polled.

The proceedings in Congress, yesterday, were of considerable interest. In the Senate a report was made by a majority of the Judiciary Committee in favor of the right of Messrs. BRIGHT and FITCH, of Indiana, to their seats. Mr. DOUGLAS introduced a bill in reference to foreign aggressions. The fifteen million loan hill was debated at length.

EMBARRASSING.--The Evening Post, a two since, in a letter from its Wash Correspondent, demonstrated that the Southern oligarchy, which rules the Federal Government, was resolved upon the utter destruction of our Commerce;--that the repeal of the Fishing Bounties was the first step towards this consummation,

The Southern Aid Society held its annual meeting this evening, F. O. WATTS, Esq., presiding. The Treasurer's report for the year ending October, 1857, shows receipts of $11,298, expenditures $10,131. The following resolution was adopted: Resolved, That the Southern Aid Society is entitled to cordial support, because it fosters a broad and genial zeal for the promulgation of the Gospel.

The weather yesterday might have been better, and, again, it might have been worse. Altogether, there was nothing, or next to nothing, to complain of, considering the state of the elements for the last six weeks.

YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION--The monthly meeting of the Young Men's Christian Association was held at the University last evening. One hundred and thirty five new members were ejected, and the names of forty eight others were proposed. The Essay was read by E.S.RIDDLE subject "Wait and Labor."

FIRE IN WATT.STRHET-SUPPOSED ARSON AND ARREST.-Shortly after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a fire broke out in the attic of the two-story frame building No. 85 Watt-street. JAMES RILEY occupied the lower portion of the building, as a liquor-store and boarding-house, and the upper part was occupied by JAMES McCARTY. Mr. MCCARTY sustained a

VICTORIA'S BIRTHDAY.--The British Consul, (ARCHIBALD,) gave an entertainment last evening at his residence in Eighteenth-street, in honor of Queen VICT0RIA'S birthday. There was a large number of invited guests present, who enjoyed themselves after the manner customary on such occasions.

Mr. GWIN, of California, presented a memorial from Captain COLLINS, asking compensation for his survey of the Amoor River. Mr. CLAY, of Alabama, from the Committee on Commerce, reporeted a bill for the improvement of the Dismal Swamp Canal.

COURTNEY--RODGERS.--In this City, on Friday, May 21, at the house of the bride's D. D., JAMES COURTNEY. Esq.. of Scranton, Penn., to Miss JANE RODGERS, third daughter of William Rodgers, lands of Newry, Ireland.

A horrible tragedy was enacted at Green Island, a small village opposite this City, on Saturday evening; one of the most startling that has occurred in this vicinity for a long time. A dispatch dated Independence, 21st, says that the Santa F6 mail arrived to-day. The news is unimportant. Tne grass on the plains was very good. The outgoing trains were progressing finely. JAMES M. HUNT, an old and prominent resident of Santa F6, died April 16.

Under foreclosure, Mr. LUDLOW sold, on Friday last, house and lot No. 552 Pearl-street, 25x100, for $21,000. Messrs. RAYNOR BLACKWELL have sold a gore plot of ground north side Fifty-seventh-street, 425 feet west of Sixth-avenue, 100 feet on the street, 59 feet on the east by 43 feet on the west, divided into 4 lots, averaging 25x51 feet, for $5,200, all cash, say $1,300 for a half depth lot.

Agreeably to the orders from the Naval Department, the steamer Arctic was brought up on Sunday from Quarantine, where she has been stationed, under the charge of Lieut. DRAKE, as a guard-ship for the Susquthanna, and yesterday morning a large gaeg of men was set to work to get her in readiness for immediate service on the coast of Cuba.

The Wisconsin Legislature has just adjourned--Without taking any steps to redeem the State from the ineffaceable brand of infamy which the wholesale purchase of its Government last year has fastened upon it.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--The Ronzani Ballet Troupe--the best we have ever had in this county--made its appearance last night at this establishment in a "New, Grand Historical Ballet, in three acts and seven tableaux, called Theresa, the Orphan of Geneva."

The remains of General SMITH arrived yesterday morning, in charge of Aid-de-Camp Lieutenants DRUM and WHEATON, who will accompany them to Philadelphia. The body lay in state in Fort Leavenworth on Monday and Tuesday, and was visited by the whole army, and a large number of the citizens of Leavenworth.

THE LIBEL ON JUDGE THOMPSON.--Recorder BARNAED yesterday gave his decision in the suit o Judge THOMPSON, of the Marine Court, against Mr. WILLIAM A. HARDENDROOK, an attorney of this City, for libel. The preliminary investigation of the case has occupied the Recorder's attention for some time past, and a large number of witnesses have been examined by him. His decision is very lengthy and elaborate.

We have papers from Rio de Janeiro to April 17. The packet from the Northern Coast reported that a pilot-boat out of Maranham, had fallen in with the English bark Juniata, deeply loaded with coal, and abandoned by the crew. There was nothing at all the matter with the vessel, which was taken into Maranham. The last entry on the log book read as follows:

George W. Morgan, of Ohio, minister resident of the United States in Portugal. James M. Buchanan, of Maryland, minister resident of the United States in Denmark. Thomas H. Dunn, of Mississippi, consul-general of the United States at Havana. Felix E. Foresti, of New-York, consul of the United States at Genoa.

The bill introduced yesterday in the Senate by Mr. DOUGLAS, which will be found under the Congressional head in this morning's TIMES, clothes the President with extraordinary powers for prompt action in emergencies not admitting of delay, when there shall be committed any flagrant violation of the law of nations, by outrages on our flag, our soil, or our citizens, or upon the property of Americans.

In steamship Columbia, from Charleston--A. F. Tift and daughter. Mrs. Brodson Miss Johnson. Miss Hamanan. Miss J. J. Bell. Miss M. Ryatt. Miss J. J. Wilson. Miss E. W. Ravenel. Mrs. Kenerts. Miss Barnard, L. S. Wood and lady. 2 Misses Edmonds. Mrs. W. S. Patten, J. H. Patten. Capt Williams, Dr. G. L. Collins. Miss Wood. Mrs. Pitzpatrick. Miss Kneeland. Rev. J. Wayland and lady. J. D. McGill. H. J. Middleton.

FLOUR in good demand at unchanged rates: sales of 2.200 bbls. at $3 75@$3 871/2 for choice Iowa, Michigan and Indiana, and $4 25@$4 75 for double extra and favorite brands. WHEAT dull and lower: sales of 14,000 bushels Chicago Spring at 69c. CORN a shade easier: sales of 28,000 bushels at 53c.@54c. for fair illinois. OATS dull and unchanged: sales of 5,000 bushels Upper Lake at 32c.@321/2c.

The proclamation issued by the GovernorGeneral of India to the inhabitants of Oude, to which we referred yesterday, has brought on a Ministerial Crisis in England which may result in the overthrow of the Derby Government. The matter is somewhat complicated. In anticipation of the fall of Lucknow,

The Board met yesterday at 3 P. 3., Mayor TIEMANN in the chair. Petitions from Drs. FRANCIS GRISOOM and others, were presented, setting forth the injury to the public health which would result from the continuance of the swill milk business, and asking that the Board would take speedy action for its suppression.

OUTRAGEOUS.--Some of our skippers appear to have evinced almost as strong a desire to be outraged by the British of the West Indies, as the old ladies alluded to by Lord BYRON in his wicked "Don Juan." The report furnished by Captain NICHOLLS respecting the outrage committed on board the Clarendon at Sagua la Grande is really terrific.

Brooklyd Board of Aldermen--An Injunction. The Aldermen met at 5 o'clock last evening, as a Board of Canvassers, to canvass the late returns of the election in the Twelfth Ward. As the roll was called, ALEXANDER McCUE, Esq, handed the following papers to the President, restraining them from canvassing the vote:

About three weeks since a paragraph, it will be remembered, was published in the TiMES, announcing that a young Englishman named JOHNSON CHAEFFER took passage on the steamboat Hrro, from this City for Albany, and that on the arrival of the steamer at its destination be could not be found. As he had drafts for $15,000 in his possession, and was a young man of the strictest temperance and regularity of

We have a public officer whose official designation is City Inspector. His duties are to inspect the sanitary condition of the City, and the pay he receives for his services is the very handsome salary of five thousand dollars a year. Among his specified duties is that of overseeing the markets and keeping them in wholesome and decent condition.

DUNCAN.--In this City, on Monday, May 24. HELEN COCKBURN, wife of George Duncan. aged 31 years The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from her late residence No.28 Perryst., on Wedneday, May 26, at 1 o'clock. without further notice.

PRESIDENT MONROE.--The Legislature of Virginia, at its last session, passed an act appropriating $2,00?? for the purpose of defraying the necessary expenses ore removing, in a suitable manner, the remains of Ex-President JAMES MONROE from the City of New-York to that of Richmond.

We published, a few days ago, a correspondence which passed between Generals VIDAURRI and HENNINUSEN at Monterey, in which Col. LOCKRIDGE, who had offered his services to the former, was spoken of in rather disparaging torms.

The forty-fourth annual meeting of the American Tract Society assembled this afternoon at Meionaon Hall. Tickets were required for admission, and the meeting was quite fully attended. JOHN TAPPAN presided. The Treasurer's report shows that the receipts of the year, including a small balance from last year, cover the expenditures.

All the old scores between Democracy and Americanism were ripped open to-day, in a long and exciting discussion on the bill to organize the Washington Fire Department. The ball was opened by HENRY WINTER DAVIS, who found a match in BURNETT, of Kentucky.
The sessions of the Presbyterian General Assembly, (Old School,) now held in this city, are attracting much attention, and are, in many respects, of exceeding interest and importance.

SALES OR STOCKS AT PHILADELPHIA.--Monday--First Board--$400 Pennsylvania 5s. 89 1/2; $200 City 6s 96 3/4; $1,500 do, 97; $4,000 do., new, 102; $2,000 City Railroad 6s, 97; $3,000 North Pennsylvania Railroad 6s, 50 5/8; $1,000 Camden and Amboy Railroad 6s, 70, 80; $1,000 Reading Railroad 6s, '86, 68 3/4, 150 Reading Railroad, 22; 365 do.. 21 7/8; 388 do., 21 3/4; 6 Camden and Amboy Railroad, 95; 32 Pennsylvania Railroad, 42;

OUR TRADE WITH CANADA.--Under the Reciprocity Treaty our trade with Canada has become important. In the year 1857 the importations of Canada by sea amounted to $16.-164,000, and the importations through and from the United States to $28,646,081.

THE AMERICAN SHIP JOHN AND ALBERT FIRED INTO NEW ORLEANS, Monday, May 21. The ship John and Albert, which arrived here on Sunday from Geneva, reports having been fired into five times by an English man-of-war.

You may or may not be aware, Mr. Editor, of the fact that this section of country just now abounds With wild pigeons in unheard-of abundance. Here, we are all alive with the one great idea-pigeons. Something like fifty or sixty nets are in careful operation hereabout, the present week, decoying the birds to destruction; after which the good housewives help the men-folks pluck them, in the cool evenings,

The Southern Convention, instead of uniting the South, has had a directly contrary effect. Virginia is effectually alienated by the prominence given to the Slave-trade question; and, if we may credit the Richmond Enquirer, a paper which for forty years has been the organ of opinion for that State, she begins seriously to consider whether, in case of dissolution, the Northern, rather than the Southern, confederacy would not be the proper place for her.

The Chicago Harbor Improvement bill was debated. The bill creating two additional Districts in Washington was passed. The joint resolution authorizing the President to sell public property in Philadelphia, was also passed. Mr. SEWARD then called up the Chicago Harbor Improvement bill, which was discussed during the morning hour.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The most infrequent attendant upon our Courts cannot have failed to notice that there are wrongs of witnesses which require to be redressed. And your advocacy of their rights will be most gratefully recognized by this much-abused class of our fellowcitizens.

From the Evening Journal of yesterday. Yesterday afternoon the city was once more disgraced by a wild riot. This was no less than a conflict between the military and a posse of police officers, in the Fifteenth Ward. It appears that the Philadelphia Lafayette Rifle Company, under command of Capt. BALLIER, went to Lemon Hill for the purpose of celebrating Whitsuntide Monday, by a sham battle and a pic-nic.

To the Editor of the NeW-York Times: It was wisely recommended by WASHINGTON and the early Presidents to avoid foreign territorial expansions and entangling alliances. But our present position is wholly changed, and our obligations to our policy must conform to our new condition.

A NEW CONSTITUTION FOR MARYLAND.-That most conservative of States, Maryland, determines to-day, by a popular vote, whether she shall call a Convention to revise her Constitution. Opposition is made to this movementon the ground that the present Constitution provides for such a vote every tenth year, and it is claimed that the question can be submitted at no other time.

LECTURE BY men, E. OAXES SMITH. She said she was not one of those who would overlook the benefactions of the Roman Catholic religion in past ages, for her monasteries, while they

Several hundred of our liquor-dealers had a meeting on the evening of the 20th, and talked strongly about Judge SHAW's decision. They mean to carry up the matter to the federal tribunals, and, failing there, to resort to the Dallot box. At the polls they will be most tremendously" licked." They acted so foolishly after the law of 1852 was passed, that no political party, as such, has any sympathy with them;

Commodore VANDERBILT comes to the rescue of the American Mail Steamship Marine. It is announced that, " seeing the discredit into which it has fallen by the discontinuance of the Collins and other lines, and that the ocean is fast becoming monopolized by foreign steamers," he intends to run a weekly line of steamships, "at his sole expense and risk," between the Old World and the New.

WILLIAMS-McFALL-in this city. on Monday. May 3. by the Rev. J. S. Inskip. Mr. THOS WILLIAMS to Miss CHARLOTTE McFALL of New York City. DERRY MESSENGER-In this City on Thursday May 6 by the Rev J. S. Inckip Wm T. DERRY M.D. to miss MARY L. MESSENGER of Brooklyn.

WARD'S bill for a railroad through ennsylvaniaavenue passed the House to-day. It gives the privilege to BAYARD CLARKI, GILBERT VANDERWERKEN, ASA P. ROBINSON, and their assigns, and is understood to be a good thing. The project was started by W. C. WETMORE, GEORGE IRVING, and other parties in NewYork, whose names it was thought advisable to withdraw.

Mr. F. P. BLAIR, the old editor of the Globe,has published a long letter upon Col. BENTON's sentiments concerning the Southern Nullifiers and their projects for dissolving the Union. Mr. WM. CAREY JONEs had made a statement that Col. B. never expressed, in his presence, any ill-feeling or disapprobation of BUCHANAN's Administration, and he gives a certificate from Mr. JACOB HALL to the same effect. Upon this point

The Republican learns that Capt. MONTGOMERY'S band of robbers, in Kansas, have in contemplation the robbery of the Indian Agent, TIMONY, who is about distributing annuities to the amount of $40,000 among the Sac ana Fox Indians. The robbers are now concentrating on Orange River, about six miles from the Sac and Fox Agency.

WEST.-In this City, on Tuesday morning. May 25. suddenly. Mrs. MARGARET WESTERVELT ACKERMAN, wife of William West, in the 38tb year of her age. The funeral services will take place at her late resi dence, No. 50 West 12th-st., this (Wednesoay) evening, at 71/2 o'clock. The relatives and friends ot the family will please attend without further invitation. BIANCHI -In this City on Tuesday. May 25, WILLIAM H. BIANCHI, aged 22 years.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of this morning, you say that the old Saengerbund says, the new confederation (meaning the Independent Singing Societies) separated from them " because they didn't toe the mark squarely last year on the question of expenses,"-and in your issue of Monday you have an article containing in substance the same.

Some unknown persons in the town of Painesville, O., on Friday night made a practical illustration of the law laid down by Judge SHAW, that any one has a right to abate a nuisance. A liquor dealer has lately come into Painesville, and the women of that village waited upon the new comer and begged of him to abandon his project. The women were treated with rudeness. From the Cincinnati Daily Times, 22d. In the case of WM. M. CONNOLLY, this morning, Judge LEAVNT said that the highest penalty for the offence prescribed by the statute was a fine of $1,000 and six months' imprisonment, but the Court did not consider it necessary in this case to inflict the extreme penally-there were circumstances which would make it proper to impose the slightest punishment consistent with the proper enforcement of the law.

Proposed Severance from the New-York Society. More than ordinary interest attaches to the meeting of the American Tract Society in Beston this year on account of the action taken in this City at the recent meeting. An unusual number of members was accordingly in attendance at the meeting in Boston on Monday last.

The most prominent characteristic of the late Southern Commercial Convention was, perhaps, the strong disunion sentiment which pervaded it. During the five days which it occupied, not a sentiment or expression did I hear applauded, save a disunion sentitiment. This feature is more striking in view of the high order of intelligence and ability which it combined.

There is an unmistakable intention on the part of the Government to make a very considerable increase in our naval force, and the slight flurry created by the "outrages" on our commerce in the WestIndies will be taken advantage of to consummate the measure.

The Peoria (111.) Transcript gives a vivid description of the recent fearful tornado in Illinois, as it swept over that place, where its power was severely felt. The hurricane commenced just before 6 o'clock in the afternoon, and lasted about three-quarters of an hour:

In the Senate, yesterday, the morning hour was principally occupiedin a discussion of the Chicago Harbor Improvement bill, but without any result. The Fifteen Million Loan bill was then debated until 6 o'clock in the evening, but no action was taken. In the House of Representatives, Mr. GRow failed in an effort to introduce a resolution that the next session commence on the 4th of November.

There are a considerable number of Free-State men here from Kansas. They furnish a very candid answer to the complaints of the other sloe, about the operations of Captain MONTGOMERY and his band of Regulators in the Fort Scott district. They say the outrages of the people congregated in and around the village of Fort Scott have become intolerable, and made it necessary to " clean out" the country round about.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR I observe in your issue of the 2lst proximo what purports to be the first of a series of letters, under the signature of " Viator del Occidente," concerning the proposed acquisition of Cuba. In this your correspondent labors to demonstrate that the measure, said to be a darling project of the Administration, is really a modern Pandora's box, without the presence of Hope.

The Troy Times of Monday, has additional particulars of the terrible tragedy enacted at Green Island, reported by our Troy correspondence yesterday: Neighbors, attracted by the shriek of CAROLINE, and by Mrs. MOWERS' screams of "Murder !" soon reached the house. The first man at the snot, GEO. H. LAWRENCE, had but a few rods to run.

THE SAMUEL CHURCHMAN SPOKEN BY A CRUISER. The brig Samuel Churchman, Captain AUKERS from Cienfuegos, on the 4th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. Captain AUKERS reports that when off Havana, on the 11th, he was spoken by one of the British men of war in the Gulf. An officer on the cruiser Inquired where the brig was from, but he did not attempt to board her.

ARREST OF A YOUNG AND) DESPERATE OFFENDER -A HERO OF MANY ESCAPES.-CALEB ABRAHAMS, alias GUNION, a young but noted offender, was arrested on Monday by Officer BENNETT, of the Detective Police,at Conrad's Garden, in Ninetieth-street, where the Saengerbunde festival was being held. The prisoner made a desperate attempt to get out of the clutches of the officer, but did not succeed.

COLONEL DEVOR'S LECTURBE.-Colonel THOMAS DEVOE, in compliance with the invitation of a large number of respectable citizens, repeated his lecture on the "History of the New-York Markets," Monday night, in the Cooper Institute. The assemblage was numerous, and comprised a large representation of those for whom the essay had a peculiar interest,-to wit, the butchers.

By private letters received from the army at Fort Bridger we receive some items of information, in addition to those we have published from our correspondents now with the Army of Utah. Gov. CUMMING left Bridger on Monday, the 5th of April, for Great Salt Lake City, with the expectation of recurring on the 15th.

The steamship Tennessee, from Vera Cruz, arrived here to-day, with dates to the 21st instant. Admiral ZERMAN, of the Mexican navy, came passenger in her. We learn from the Tennessee's advices, that communication between the Interior and Vera Cruz had been opened again.

Considerable excitement has been created during the past two days, by the announcement that Mayor TIEMANN had succeeded in obtaining the indictment of BENJAMIN WOOD, of our City, by a special Jury, at Augusta. Georgia, as one of the owners of an alleged illegal scheme known as the "Sparta Academy Lottery."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Your London namesake informed its readers, some three weeks ago, that, "As far as the paying-out machinery is concerned, all that mechanical skill can effect, in aid of the great undertaking, has been accomplished," this favorable view of the subject being based on the assumed infallibility of APPOLD'S self-regulating brake.

THE TELEGRAPHIC CABLE.-A letter from Captain ERICSSON, which we publish in another part of this morning's TIMES, makes some important suggestions concerning the machinery which is to be used in the second expedition for laying the Telegraphic wire in the bed of the Atlantic. To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your Washington dispatch of 20th inst., and published in the TIMES of 21st inst, has the following: "A letter received by Major McCARTY, Delegate from Arizona, from Mesilla, April 21, says that great excitement exists there in consequence of a party of thirty-five Mesilla volunteers. who pursued a band of marauding Indians, and killed seven of them in sight of Fort Thorne, being captured by Lieut.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: In my very brief note which you published yesterday, I did not intend to charge, nor did I think that you intended, by your comments upon the late railroad accident, to divert travel from the NewYork CentralRailroad to other routes-only that they were well calculated to produce that result, even though other routes might be less secure.

Santa Fe papers of May I are received. On the 17th of April a party of Mexicans from the Mesilla Valley attacked the camp of the Apache Indians near Fort Thorn, butchering indiscriminately men, women and children. Lieut. HOWARD, of Fort Thorn, subsequently captured the Mexicans and held them prisoners at the Fort.

NEW-YORK ORPHAN ASYLUM -This Asylum enjoyed on Tuesday its fifty-second anniversary, at Bloomingdale. The Rev. TUEODORE L. CUYLER read the report. Mrs. JIABBA BETHUNE, for fifty years associated with this Christian institution, had been compelled by age to withdraw from its management. Mies P. W. THURSTON, twelve years a Trustee, had died during the year. None of the children had died.

PARSON BROWNLOW'S METHOD FOR ANNEXING CUBA.-The redoubtable Parson BROWNLOW, who is at present attending the "General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South," at Nashville, says: "Another most i impertant report has been adopted by this Conference, which came from the Committee on Missions, and was unanimously recommended by its members.

TION.-The Archbishops and Bishops of the Catholic Church, who recently assembled in provincial council in Baltimore, have issued a pastoral letter to the clergy and laity of that denomination. Among other subjects to which it refers is the slavery question, iu regard to which the clergy are cautioned to preserve a non-committal attitude. The letter says:

Sabbath-School fleeting in Williamsburg. The annual gathering of the friends of the Sab bath-schools in Williamsburg, at the ReformedDutch Church, corner of South Second and Fourth streets, Brooklyn, Eastern District, last evening, was quite a large one "in spite of the weather." Hymns were sung, prayer was offered, and then the Rev. Dr. RUFUS W. CLARK was introduced.

CORRUPTION IN CANADA -It is certainly no consolation to us, under the odium of the legislative corruption so rife among ourselves, to learn that similar rascalities are discovered elsewhere; vet as our Provincial neighbors have a weakness in the line of Pharisaical horror, when they hear of naughtiness in " the States," we may be permitted to mention that even Canada is not wholly free from official sin.

MASSACHUSETTS CRIMINAL LAW. - The second trial of the woman GARDNER, at Plymouth, Mass., for the murder of her husband by poison, has resulted in verdict of murder in t he second degree. This is the first conviction in Massachusetts under the new law, passed at the last session of the Legislature. The Crime of murder is divided into first and second degrees. The punishment of the first is death;

THE RUNNER SYSTEM ABOLISHED IN THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--There was a large meeting of firemen at Firemen's Hall a few evenings since, which was presided over by the Chief Engineer, and at which the "runner system" was discussed, Mr. HOWARD spoke highly of the action of the Board of Fire Engineers--that of voting unanimously to put down the "runner system."

The gentle breeze which rustles through the pear tree by my window, and the quiet light which rests upon the distant meadow, and the singing of birds, are so many indications of the calm and composed spirit in which I view and judge public questions. You may guess, then, with what surprise and wonder I read the following paragraph in the correspondence of the NEW-YORK TIMES:

BULKLEY,--In this City, on Wednesday, May 26, after a lingering illness which he bore with Christian resignation. CHARLES H. BULKLEY, aged 35 years. From the London Times. The touch of war, like the angel's spear. caused Russia to start up in her real shape four years since. INTERNAL IMPROVEMENTS.-The bill for the improvement of the harbor of Chicago, which passed the Senate yesterday by a vote of 27 to 17, loses most of the importance which naturally belongs to it, from the fact that the session is so near its close. It can scarcely receive the consideration of the House during the ten legislative days which remain.

QUAKERS YEARLY MEETING.--The Yearly Meeting of the Hicksite branch of the Society of Friends was concluded yesterday in the meeting-house in Twenty -seventh-street, near Sixth-avenue. The session commenced at a pretty early hour in the morning, and adjourned soon after noon.

THE OHIO CONTESTED ELECTION CASE.-Mr. CAMPBELL, of Ohio, has lost his seat in Congress-a vote of the House having awarded it to his opponent in the canvass, Mr. VALLANDIGHAM. The contest turned upon the "nigger" question, as all political contests are apt to do now-a-days.

After some unimportant business the Senate passed the bill for the improvement of the harbor of Chicago by 26 against 17. The vote being a test as to internal improvements, numerous other estimates for the maintenance from decay of public works will follow.

FREE-SOIL IN TEXAS.-The New-Orleans Bee, a watchful guardian of Southern interests, scents "danger ahead," in respect to Texas. That danger consists in the probability that no more Slave States can be carved out of the Texan territory.

Judge LEAVITT charged the Jury in a recent mercantile case before the United States District Court in Cincinnati, that a writ of replevin could not issue from the Federal Courts against goods legally in the possession of an officer of the State Courts, and that the Court which first obtained jurisdiction of the property held it. SWINDLING IN HOBOKEN.-- Or several months past there appears to have been a concerted system by which persons in Hoboken and vicinity have been swindled out of small sums, by means of plausible stories, invented by persons who appear to be conversant with the affairs of the place.

THE CHURCH POR DEAF MUTES.-The Episcopal Clergy of the City, and persons interested in the welfare of the Deaf and Dumb, have seton foot measwes for establishing St. Ann's Church for Deaf Mates upon a firmer basis. A meeting was called a few days since, at which Bishop POTTER presided, to take this subject into consideration.

MENDELSSOHN UNION. - This meritorious and excellently conducted association gives its third concert to -night at the new Hall of the Union, Cooper Institute, Astor-Place, MENDELSSOHN'S 95th Psalm and RESSINI'S "Stabat Mater" will be performed.

DISMAL INCONSlSTENCY.-Senator CLAY, of Alabama, having succeeded in forcing his fdvorite measure through the Senate, for the repeal of the Fishing Bounties Act, has since given a singular proof of his opposition to national legislation for sectional interests.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: I live just perused in your paper of the 17th inst., an obituary notice of Dr. ROBERT HARE, of Philadelphia. I know not who penned that article, but it is certainly very singular that, like some other superficial thinkers, the writer should indulge in conclusionls directly adverse to those which any deeply investigating mind would arrive at.

Mr. TAYLOR, of New-York, accomplished a good thing to-day in getting reinstated in the Naval Appropriation bill, in Committee of the Whole, the item of $50,600 for filling in at the Navy-Yard in Brooklyn previously stricken out by the Committee of Ways and Means.

The Board of Governors of the Almshouse met at the Rotunda on Thursday, the President, WASHINGTON SMITH, Esq., in the Chair. This being requisition day, the usual demands were presented, and, with slight modification and correction, allowed and passed. Several communications were read in reference to matters of routine detail.

The Persia, which sails from this port this morning for Liverpool, carries out intelligence which will deeply affect the public mind of Europe. Mr. ROBERT TOOMBS has declared in the Senate that he was "ready for a war with England." He went further.

Rear-Admiral MOHAMMED PASHA and suite were entertained last night at the Revere House by a grand banquet tendered by the City Government. Abou eighty plates were laid. It has always been supposed that President BUCHANAN. has had especially at heart the purchase of Cuba. After his nomination, he caused it to be understood that, if elected, this should be the leading measure of his Administration. He even assured Senator BROWN, of Mississippi, that if he could only accomplish this object, he would cheerfully resign his office and retire ,to private life.

A CURIOUS LAWSUIT.-A case has just been decided in the Supreme Court at Albany which grew out of a rather curious state of facts. JOHN WOOD WORTH was appointed Justice of the Supreme Court March 28, 1819, while, the Constitution fixed his term of office during good behavior or until the age of 60, and under a law which fixed his salary at $4,500.

The Royal Mail steamship Africa, from Liverpool on the 15th inst.. with three days' later news from Europe, is now due at this port. She had not been seen at Sandy Hook at a late hour last night. A bundle of documents inscribed "CHARLES JUENNER--Private Papers," has been found by the Joint Committee on Accounts in a safe in the Comptroller's office, deposited there, it is said, in the beginning of the Street Commissioner's controversy.

In demolishing the walls of the old GoshenhOPpen Church, Dear Norristown, Penn.,' week before last, the corner-stone was found in the northwest corner building. It is a sandstone about one and a half fect long, and fifteen inches in breadth. It contained two small coins, one dated 1695 and the other 1652. This was one of the oldest churches in the country, having been erected in the year 1744.

The large hall of the Cooper Institute was inaugurated last night for musical purposes, by the Mendelssohn Union, and from that circumstance, or the patriotic inscription over the portico, was dubbed with the title of the "Hall of the Union." Mr. SLIDELL, of Louisiana, introduced a bill to grant a pension to the widow of General PERSIFOR SMITH. It was laid over. The General River and Harbor bill was then brought up and debated. Mr. SEWARD gave notice thai he would introduce a resolution extending the Session until June 21, to permit the business to be done, especially with reference to the Homestead bill and Harbor Improvements.

A great Anti-Lecompton Union meeting was held in this city to Right, at St. James' Hall. The spacious hall, which is built out of the Eagle-street Theatre, and holds three thousand people, was crowded to its utmost capacity, while hundreds of people remained outside. At a later hour over a thousand persons gathered on the walk outside the theatre, unable to obtain admission.

NOTHING, NEW UNDER THE SUN.-We had supposed that the enormous villanies of the Wisconsin Legislature were without a parallel in history, that such wholesale bribery and corruption could never have been practiced anywhere but in the Great West, where rascality even is developed on a larger and grander scale than in the more circumscribed parts of the earth. But we were mistaken.

We publish, this morning, the report of the Select Committee in the House upon the expenditure of $87,000 by certain manufacturing establishments to secure the passage of the bill reducing the duties on Wool. This matter, it will be remembered, was brought to public notice by the appearance of this item in the accounts of the Middlesex Company, when that concern failed last Fall.

SAD AFFAIR AT ALBION.-We are pained to hear of an unfortunate occurrence at Albion, yesterday, which resulted in the sudden death of an estimable lady of that village, Mrs. HIRAM SICKELS lost her life In consequence of taking poison by mistake for wine. As we are informed, Mrs. SICKELS went to a closet and poured from a bottle what she supposed to be wine, and drank a considerable quantity.

SUNDAY DISTURBANCES.--Last Sunday was rendered memorable by the entire cessation of the crying of Sunday newspapers, which had become so decided a disturbance of the rest of the Sabbath. How much of this most welcome quiet was due to the vigilance of the Police and how much to the voluntary efforts of the parties concerned, we do not know, nor is it necessary to inquire.

THE FLORIDA WAR.--Col. LOOMIS, commanding the Department of Florida, has issued his protermation declaring the Florida war ended, and says the people can now return to their homes and usual avocations without fear of molestation. Captains W. H. KENDRICK'S and DURRANCE'S companies of mounted voluteers have instered out of the United States service, as also Captaians JOHNSON'S, MICKLER'S and C. T. KENDERICK'S Companies.

The name of Dr. THEODORE GAILLARDET has been connected with an affair of which the published accounts have been singularly incorrect and exaggerated. They alluded to it as nothing less than an attack, made without provocation, and with deliberate intention to murder. A simple exposition of the facts will place the matter in a correct light, and will give to all parties their due in this lamentable affair.

A PLUCKY SENATOR.--The Hon. WILLIAM CHAPPELL, a member of the Wisconsin Senate, received $10,000 of the La Crosse and Milwaukee Railroad bribe two years ago, and was active in corrupting his legislative associates. The Senate, at its recent session, voted, 21 to 5, that he was guilty, and 18 to 9 that he was unworthy of a seat in the body. He, however, retained his seat.

ANOTHER LITERARY LORD.--To Queen VICTORIA belongs the praise of being the first British monarch who raised an author to the peerage as a mark of distinction for his services to literature, and there seems to be a probability of her bestowing another coronet upon one of the eminent authors whose genius has shed a brilliant lustre upon her reign.

The funeral of General SMITH took place this afternoon, and the display on the occasion by the First Division of Militia, under Gen. CADWALLADEH, was very imposing. The Scott Legion held the left of the line, and after them came a detachment of Marines and the Dequesne Grays from Pittsburg.

Several ineffectual ballots for Assistant Bishop were taken this morning. Dr. VINTON, of Boston, was replaced on the nomination list, when, on the eleventh ballof, the vote stood : For BOWMAN, 69 ; VINTON, 69 ; STEVENS, 3. The last ballot stood--VINTON, 70 ; BOWMAN, 69 ; seatlering, 4. The Convention then adjourned till evening.

To do honor to the lionne of the moment, I must commence to-day with the Queen of Holland. Her Majesty arrived in Paris last week, and is now the guest of the Emperor and Empress at the Tuileries. This lady is the daughter of the present King of Wurtemburg, the oldest monarch of Europe, and of the Princess PAULOWNA, daughter of the Czar PAUL of Russia.

The Parish of St. George, of which the Rev Dr. TYNG is the Rector, presents a record of which any pastor might be proud. Its Anniversary-the thirteenth since the present Rector took charge of the Palish-has just been celebrated. The contributions the past year have reached the sum of $25,611 46. The additions to the Church have been 83.
