SAILING OF THE WABASH.-The United States steam-frigate Wabash steamed from the Navy-Yard yesterday morning, and anchored at Quarantine. COLLISION.-The frigate Wabash, as she was leaving the dock at the Navy-Yard yesterday morning, came into collision with the Savannah. The quarter-boat and captain's gig of the former, and a boat belonging to the latter, were crushed.

Every one hopes for, and nine-tenths of the community believe in, a perfectly peaceful and satisfactory settlement of our pending differances with Great Britain. It seems impossible that any British Ministry should, under existing circumstances, be disposed to plunge into a war with the United States, even if the suppression or continuance of the Slave-trade

THE RIGHT OF VISIT AND THE RIGHT OF SEARCH--The Evening Post has a very elaborate editorial article in vindication of the proceeding of the British cruisers in the Gulf of Mexico. It takes the ground that nothing has been done by them which they had not a perfect right to do ;-that British cruisers have a perfect right to arrest vessels on the high seas carrying the American flag,--compel them by

A merchant of this City, some ten days since, wrote to General CASS, Suggesting a method by which a satisfactory arrangement could be made with Great Britain for inquiring into the nationality of suspicious vessels. He recommended that an American Lieutenant should be placed on board of every British cruiser,

FAREWELL MISSIONARY MEETING.--The Rev. Messrs. mcQueen, of the Corisco, and Bushbelt, of the Gaboon missions, except to sail next week to return to their respective fields of labor in West Africa. In connection with their departure a meeting will be held TOMORROW (Sabbath) EVENING, the 30th inst., in the Madison-square Presbyterian Church. (the Rev. Dr Adams) for prayer for Africa.

A communication was received from the president, covering the correspondence respecting the arrest of WILLIAM WALKER, which was laid over, and ordered to be printed. Mr. SEWARD, of New-York, presented a resolution to extend the session till the 21st of June. Laid over.

The Jefferson City correspondent of the Republican states that a petition has been received by Gov. ernor STEWART, from a number of citizens of Bates arid Cass Counties, Mo., asking that measures be taken for their protection against MONTGOMERY' Kansas banditti, who had invaded Missouri and committed various robberies and outrages in the abovementioned counties, and were preparing for a more extensive foray into the State.

PENNSYLVANIA EPISCOPAL CONVENTION.-This body is in session at Philadelphia, and unusual Interest is felt in its proceedings, owing to the fact that an Ass stant Bishop will probably be elected, pursuant to ,the request of Bishop POTTER, made last month in a letter addressed to the Standing Committee of the Diocese. A resolution was adopted unanimously that a salary of $3,500 a year shall be paid to the AssistantBishop, without any diminution of the salary

News from Kansas. PREPARATIONS FOR THE COMING ELECTION--RUMORED BATTLE ON THE SOUTHERN BORDER. LEAVENWORTH, Wednesday, May 26. The Board of Commissioners appointed under the act of Congress of May 4, convened at Lecompton on the 24th. Present, J. W. DENVER, Governor; HUGH S. WALSH, Secretary; C. W. BARRACK, President of the Councit; GEO. W. DEITZLER, Speaker of the House; AND Wm. WEIS, District-Attorney.

Mr. HAYNE, of South Carolina, introduced a resolution to appoint ten naval cadets. Referred to the Naval Committee. Mr. SEWARD, of New-York, presented a petition of E K. COLLINS and associates, asking payment of the money due them on the mail contract. Referred to the Committee on Post Roads.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--A short opera season commences here to-night and will probably extend through the month. Signora GAZZANIGA is the prima donna, assisted by BRIGNOLI, AMODIO and GASPARONI. These are artists who have been duly tested and approved by the public. DONIZETTI'S excellent opera of the " Favorita " will be played to-night.

APPEALS BY MURDERERS.--The Troy Budget says that "the evil no longer exists" of appeals as a matter of right, by convicts capiitally convicted, as that right was abolished by an act of the present Legislature. This statement is not altogether correct. In respect to Courts of Oyer and Terminer it was abolished, but it still exists for criminals who have suffered capital conviction in the General Sessions of New-York City.

Long Island College Hospital. BROOKLYN, Friday, May 28, 1858. To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Long Island College Hospital received a notice in your yesterday's paper, the implications of which, "important, if true," were, in fact, somewhat lacking in the latter particular. The intimation which the first paragraph contained, that no "competent Hospital for the suffering poor,

DEATH BY ABORTION.--Corner PERRY, on Saturday, held an inquest upon the body of Mrs. Amelia Weber, who died on the 19th inst., at the house of Dr. CObel, No. 57 Second-street. The deceased was buried in Green wood Cemetery, butfrom the privacy of the banal and other mysterious circumstances surrounding the case, the body, six days after interment, was ordered by the Coroner to be exhumed for medical examination.

BOWER[Yen] vs. MULBERRY-STREET.---BILLY WHITE, a Bowery Boy, and TOBY LANGDON, of the Mu1bery-street gang, met on the banks of the East River in the outskirts of the City yesterday morning for the purpose of having a prize-fight. The principals and their backers, of whom there were a large number, went to the place in boats.

Report of the Senate Commmittee on Foreign Relations. The following Report from the Committee on Foreign Relations was presented in the Senate, by Mr. MASON, on Friday: The Committee on Foreign Relations, to whom was referred the resolution of the Senate instructing them "to inquire whether any legislation is necessary to...

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of this morning, there is a letter from your Washington correspondent, in which he says, " Commodore PAULDING is so prompt and decisive an officer, that he ought to be dispatched at once to the West Indies, with directions to overhaul the Buzzard, "

We learn with regret that our countryman, BARTHOLOMEW, the Sculpter, died suddenly at Naples on the first of this month. We have no further particulars in relation to the melancholy event. Mr. BARTHOLOMEW was a native of Colchester, Connecticut, and about thirty years old. lie went to Rome some eight years ago, where he has industriously followed his profession and gained considerable celebrity by his works.

The United States mail steamship Moses Taylor, with the California mails of May 1, and $1.575,991 in treasure, arrived at this port on Saturday afternoon. By this arrival we receive important and interesting news from California and Oregon, the Sandwich Islands, Central America, New-Granada and the South Pacific.

The war sentiment here is greatly on the increase, and has been very much accelerated by Senator WILSON'S resolution and the debate upon it on Saturday. War has suddenly become the absorbing topic in the hotels and elsewhere, and there will doubtless be a great rush to hear the debate in the Senate to-morrow on the subject.

HOW TO ACQUIRE CUBA.--The Washington Union calls upon the British Government, if it is sincere in its desire to stop the Slave-trade, to influence Spain to cede Cuba to the United States. It adds, rather mysteriously, "we know of a process by which this can be effected." If the Union knows, why doesn't it tell? But we are inclined to believe it is putting cause

By the arrival of the schooner William L. Richardson, Captain R. O. BAYLEY, we have papers from Porto Rico to May 12. The Captain-General Was engaged making a tour of the Island, inspecting the public works, laying corner stones of hospitals, opening roads, etc. The official reports stated that he found everything in a satisfactory condition.

THE OUTRAGES IN KANSAS.--The Albany Evening Journal, denouncing the proceedings of a "gang of robbers and thieves under the lead of one MONTGOMERY, going about Kansas pluadering the settlers and defying law anti authority," rebukes with great severity the attempt of Democratic prints to hold the FreeState Party in Kansas responsible for these outrages.

By the arrival of the Moses Taylor at this port on Saturday, we have received late and important news from the Central American States and from New-Granada. It was reported by the last mail that the Yrissari treaty had been ratified, but this report was incorrect.

A letter in the Chicago Tribune, intimates that the Mormons did not burn the Government trains on the Plains last Fall, but that the army contractor did, in order to realize a larger profit. It is stated that all the wheels of the wagons were first carefully remove, which fact (if true) is considered to be strong evidence against the contractor.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The prompt action of the Police Commissioners on the memorial against Sunday news-crying, and the consequent order of the Superintendent, deserve universal commendation. Twenty-one years' continuance of such an unpardonable nuisance ought to to suffice. Everybody wonders now that it should have been endured so long.

The following is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 22d day of May to the 29th day of May, 1858: Men, 113; Women, 85; Boys, 116; Girls, 128. Total,442*. Adults, 198; Children, 244; Males, 229; Females, 213; Colored persons, 10.

After flying about the East river nearly all day, we are at length fairly off, every one wondering in what corner, among so many persons, he can bestow himself in so small a craft. I presume we are nearly the smallest vessel which ever carried both a battery and a steam engine. We are 230 tons burthen, and 30 horse power.

HEYATON-SMITH.--In this City, on Thursday, May 27, at St. Luke's Church, by the Rev. Alexander S. Leonard, JOHN KEYATON to KITTY SMITH. Poughseepsie papers please copy. BUSH--HALLOCK.--In this City, on Wednesday, May 26, by the Rev. J. P. Wakeley, GEO W. BUSH to AMY ??. HALLOCK, daughter of Isaac Hallock all of this City.

SUNDAY NEWS CRIES.--Yesterday the City enloyed another quiet Sunday,-so far as the cries of newsboys were concerned. Every person approves the change, and we are glad to see that even the sunday newspapers, which were at first most violent against the order to discontinue the street-cries of news-venders on Sunday, are beginning to concede its propriety.

SIR: The accompanying dispatch from Rear Admiral Sir FREDERIC GREY to the Admiralty, inclosing one from Commander MORESBY, of Her Majesty's ship Sappho, lately employed on the coast of Africa, is communicated to you by order of Her Majesty's Government. The report of Commander MORESBY conveys a narrative of the wreck, which was abandoned by her crew and exposed to destruction with hundreds of slaves on board, under circumstances of peculiar atrocity.

KNOX--In this City, on Friday, May 28, of consumption MARY C. KNOX, daughter of Joseph Knox, deceased, aged 20 years, 3 months and 4 days. Lovely in life. Serenely she welcomed death. The funeral will take place from the residence of her mother, No. 545 Greenwich st. on Monday, May 31, at 10 o'clock. The friends and relatives are respectfully invited to atend, without further invitation. The remains will be taken to Bronxville for interment.

The last Presbyterian split has hatched a brood of troubles. The Old School Assembly having flatly refused union with the Seceding Southern Synod, the latter body is left alone, to do as it pleases. It has just made an attempt to secure from the New-School body a portion of the Church funds.

The foreign policy of the United States, durig the Administrations of Presidents PIERCE and BUCHANAN, has been a shame and disgrace to the nation. Our Government, absorbed in party schemes and moving Heaven and earth to obtain a party triumph, has neglected the honor and interests of the country, in almost every quarter of the globe where action and statesmanship were needed.

To the Editors of the Daily Delta: GENTLEMEN--My attention has been called to a letter from S. A. LOCKRIDGE, published in Brownsville, Texas ; that is to say, to a letter which he has certainly subscribed, and probably caused to be written, his own ??aided lucubrations being characterized now only by bad taste and bad grammar, but by an utter disregard of orthography. He mentions a " wanton attack," and alludes to satisfaction.

Saturday's debate in the Senate, upon the recent outrages of British cruisers in the Gulf, indicated a remarkable degree of unanimity in regard to this subject. Men of all parties concurred in the position that they must be stopped, in the most summary manner possible,--and that effectual means must be taken to prevent their repetition hereafter.

From the Lawrence (Kansas) Herald of Freedom. A body of men, called the "Southwestern Pioneer and Mining Company." are to leave Westport, Missouri, on the 10th June, under the lead of the infamous Col. THUS. for Arizona. A party of about fifty men are organized in this city having the same Territory in view , and expect to start on their journey very soon.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: How does the proof stand on this question? Every chemist that has ever analyzed lager-bier, including our own DOREMUS and CHILTON, certity, declare and swear, that it contains a fraction less than three per cent. of alcohol ; and the eminent Dr. REESE testifies that it contains the nearest to nothing of alcohol of any known beverage

We are glad to perceive that, in both Houses of Congress, the Ocean Mail service is attract ing attention. We hope it will be fully discussed, and that, even if no general system adequate to the necessities of the country be at once adopted, something may be done to prevent the absolute surrender of that service to English steamers, which seems to be impending. It is so late in the session that we

What a miserable month of May ! Usually, we have here, at this season, pleasant gatherings on the green sward, under the shade of forest trees, with a profusion of ripe strawberries, and such excellent cream as is supplied by the metropolitan milk maids, who bring it to our doors in the veritable milk pails. But this year a crevasse seems to have been opened overhead. and a sunshine is a most desirable novelty.

The recent developments of fraud and rascality in connection with the affairs of the offices of the Comptroller and Secretary of State present a state of facts of the most painful and startling character, The result of the investigations of the Legislative Committee has not been officially announced, but its gen eral features are generally understood in this city, and lave been made public already in the columns of a cotemporary.

THE DEFEAT OF GARZA AT TAMPICO.--The Pensacola Observer furnishes the annexed important intelligence, obtained from the Purser of the U.S. steamship Fulton. Lieut. Commanding ALMY, which vessel arrived off Pensacola Navy - Yard, May 21st., from, Tampico : "The Mexican war steamer Guerrero, Capt. SANCHEZ, was dispatched by ZAMORA with two hundred and eighty-seven boxes of ammunitions of war from Gen. GARZA, at Tampico.

Brooklyn Common Council--Streets Repaired by Contract--Brooklyn a Port of Entry--The Health Officers' Difficulty--The Swill-Milk Stables--Interesting to Tax Payers. A FIGHT IN THE ROTUNDA. The regular weekly meeting of the Brooklyn Common Council was held last evening, President KALBFLEISCH in the Chair.

The schooner Kestah, of Wilmington, Delaware, Capt. BAYLISS, cleared from this port on Saturday night. Since then several slaves have been found to be missing, and a steamer was sent to overhaul the Kestah, which she did below City Point. Five slaves were found on board.

OBSEQUIES OF GEN. PERSIFOR F. SMITH AT PHILADELPHIA.--The obseques of Gen. PERSIFOR F. SMITH were celebrated on Friday at Philadelphia. The scene was impressive. The city was the General's birthplace, and a large concourse of citizens attended the remains to Laurel Hill. Minute guns were fired, at the Navy Yard, during the march of the procession.

THE FIRST DAY OF SUMMER.--" It is not always May," as the poet sings, and if all Mays were like the one we have just passed through, we should be very glad that it is n't. The "merry month." has been as cold and dreary as April,and great coats and furs have been needed all through it.

A GOOD SUGGESTION.--In view of the controversy which has arisen in Burlington, Vermont, concerning the proper place for the monument to ETHAN ALLEN, ordered by the Legislature, a Vermont correspondent suggests that it should be erected on the ruins of the old Fort at Ticondero ga.

Our dispatches from Washington this morning relative to the exciting topic of the day will be found highly interesting and important. Lord NAPIER, it is stated positively, has forwarded instructions to the Commander-in-Chief of the British naval forces on the West India station that the visitations of American vessels must be discontinued.

THE MEN'S BRANCH. Last night, pursuant to previous notice, the " Journeymen Cordwainers, on the Men's Branch"that is, those members of the trade who are employed in making men's boots and shoes-held a meeting at the Fourteenth Ward Hotel, corner of Grand and Elizabeth streets. The attendance was not very large, but the room, which was a small one, was full.

Our present difficulties with New-Granada and Nicaragua, render it a matter of great importance that a communication should be established between our Atlantic and Pacific States by way of Tehuantepec.

The Sessions of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church have just closed; the members are now separating for their homes. The last two days have been mostly occupied with cases appeal from the decisions of the lower courts.

CONFLICTING REPORTS OF THE OUTRAGES--MEASURES OF GOV. DENVER TO RESTORE ORDER, ST. Louis, Monday, May 31. The Kansas correspondent of the Democrat gives many rumors and conflicting accounts of the recent troubles in the southern part of that Territory.

NEW-HAMPSHIRE. --The annual session of the New -Hampshire Legislature commences tomorrow at Concord. Three -fourths of the Senators and three- Fifths of the Representatives are Republicans.

The Swill-Milk Committee of the Board of Health met yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock, in Room No. 8, City Hall, and proceeded to take testimony concerning the swill-milk establishments, Aldermen TUOMEY' TUCKER and READ, and Councilman HaSWELL were Present. H. L. CLINTON Esq. appeared as Counsel,

FIRE IN BOWERY--SUPPOSED INCENDIARISM.--At 41/2 o'clock A. M. Yesterday a fire broke out in the boot and shoe store of SAMUEL BECK, No. 92 1/2 Bowery. When the alarm was given the interior of the store was in flames. An officer of the Fourteenth Ward discovered the fire through the cracks between the shutters. The entire stock of Mr. Beck, valued at $2.510, Was destroyed.

We understand that General HOUSTON, immediately after the adjournment of Congress, contemplates and expedition into Mexico with a company of four or live thousand men, who are anxious to follow the hero of the Alamo to new conquests.

THE NEW SENATOR FROM RHODE ISLAND.-We have never known a more general and hearty outburst of " first-rate notices," than have been elicited by the election of ex-Governor ANTHONY as the successor of Mr. PHILIP ALLEN in the Senate of the United States. These commendations

Lord NAPIER has sent instructions to the Commander-in-Chief of the forces on the West India Station, to have the visitation of American vessels discontinued. This may be relied upon.

ALLEGED TICKET SWINDLING.--CASWELL WITT, of iowa, arrived in this City with his family from Philadelphia, on his way to California, Sunday evening, and hired a hack and told the driver to take him to Savery's Hotel. The backman took him to a low place in Cedar-street instead.

The London Gazette contains a general order announcing the promotion of Sir Colin Campbell to the rank of General in the army. His elevation to the Peerage and promotion to the rank of Field-Marshal--the highest in the service--will follow immediately.

FLOUR in fair demand , unchanged; sales 16,000 bbls, at $3 75 for choice Wisconsin; $3 87@$4 12 for extra do, and Ohio and Michigan WHEAT steady, and in good demand; sales 70 000 bushels at 70c for Chicago Spring; 10 1/2c, for Milwaukee Club; 85c, for White Wisconsin; 87c. for White Indiana. CORN closes out; prime offered at 56c,; 3 000 bushels Ohio sold at 55c.,

The United States have an interest in the Isthmus between North and South America which they cannot afford to forego. Our right of transit must not be defeated by the caprices or bad faith of Nicaraguan Presidents.

REPORT OF THE CITY MARSHAL.--City Marshal ELLIS reports that for the month ending yesterday, 124 persons were committed to the City Prison, charged with the following criminal offences: Drunkenness, 79; assault, 6; picking pockets, 1; vagrancy, 9; playing ball on Sunday, 4; felonious assault, 1; attempt to rescue prisoner, 1 ; fighting, 4 ; perjury 1;

Commodore THOMAS AP CATESBY JONES, of the United States Navy, died last night at his residence in Georgetown, D.C. Commodore JONES was of Welsh descent. He was a native of Virginia, and was born in the year 1789. He entered the Navy as a midshipman in the year 1805, and received his commission as a Captain in 1829.

The summer of 1857 will be rendered famous in the annals of New York by the fierce contest which was waged for nine weeks between the Mayor of the City and the Police authorities. The "British outrages" f the past month or two have not created half the excitement here that the outrages of Mayor WOOD did then.

A resolution providing for an evening session was adopted. Mr. HEUSTON, of Texas, made an ineffectual attempt to have the Mexican Protectorate resolution taken up. The resolutions on the subject of British aggressions were considered.

The state of inoperation into which the Excise LAW has fallen renders the duty of the Excise Commissioners a very light one, but, as they say, rather an unpleasant one, inasmuch as they do not wish to meet every day, pro forma, with nobody but the reporters for an audience. For several meetings past,

The Board of Councilmen met on Monday afternoon, the President, CHAS. H. HASWELL, Esq., in the Chair. Several petitions were referred. They had reference to the filing of sunken lots on Twelfth avenue; to the building of sewers in Fourth-street, and for ?? among one hundred and Tenth-street.

The advocates of the British side of the pending controversy with the United States, especially the Tribune and Evening Post, lay great stress upon the alleged difference between the right of visit and the right of search, and upon the absolute necessity of conceding to British cruisers the exercise of the former, in order to prevent the abuse of the American flag.

GENERAL WALKER MAKING NEW SPEECHES.-The adjournment of the Southern Convention has left WALKER at liberty to resume his speech-making trips. He is last heard of in Dallas County, Ala. A large meeting of sympathizers with fillibusterism was held on the 17th May, at Cahawba Court House, and the Selma Sentinel says of WALKER'S speech:

Senator JOHNSON'S bill to grant a quartersection (160 acres) of Government land, free, to every actual settler, although not so beneficent a measure as its partial originators suppose, is yet better than its opponents have been willing to admit. It is, however, beaten for this year, to be revived, and very possibly passed, hereafter.

Numerous uninteresting memorials and reports were presented. The Miscellaneous Appropriation bill was then taken up. Mr. MAFON, from the Committee on Foreign Af fairs, reported a bill authorizing the Executive to employ force to protect the rights of our citizens from outrages by foreign nations, having especial reference to Central and South America.

Four sailing craft set sail for Europe, two of which were schooner-rigged and two were brigantine. The schooners bore the names of D. B. Sexton and Correspondent, and the brigantines those of H. D. Hone and D. C. Pierce. Two of these vessels are laden with black walnut timber, in square bolts, designed for the English market; one is freighted with

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--VERDI'S Opera of the "Traviata" will be produced to-night, with GAZZANIGA, BRIGNOLI and AMODIO in their original parts. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Mr. C. W. CLARKE, an actor who has been long before the public, and who in almost every walk of the drama has performed his duties faithfully, has recently met with a severe misfortune-so severe that it may incapacitate him from further exertion.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: The writer of the obituary notice of the late Dr HARE, of Philadelphia, and your correspondent " Nassau," make conflicting statements, with regard to the appearance of the venerable and learned Doctor, before the American Society for the Advancement of Science.

WHAT HAS HE DONE WITH IT?-Nothing So piquantly exercises the general mind as a problem which nobody can solve. An inquiry in relation to the explosive properties of saltpetre will amuse the public for months, and even an attempt to identify the mysterious individual who smote Mr. W. Patterson, for a much longer period.

Dispatches from commodore JOSIAH TATNALL, of the East India squadron, dated 15th of March, state that the United States ship Portsmouth, Commander A. H. FOOTE. sailed for the United States on the 5th. She was to go to the Kittery, Me., Station. Midshipman J. C. MOSELEY, transferred from the Minnesota and Lieutenant COLVILLE TERRITT and 8 seamen, invalids, are sent home by her.

A POLICEMAN IN DIFFICULTY -A few mornings ago a policeman was discovered in the act of stealing several articles from a store in Atlantic-street. When charged with the offence he returned the stolen property, and immediately handed his resignation to the Deputy superintendent. Whether the Boardof Commissioners will accept it, and the proprietor of the store will consider this a sufficient punishment for the offence. remains to be seen.

From the Charleston Mercury. Is the apprentice system-that is, importing Africans or Asiatics, as apprentices, into the West Indies or the United States-a Slave-trade? If it is, then Great Britain commenced it-France adopts it: and all the regulations and treaties to suppress the African Slavetrade are a ridiculous and costly farce..

A DETERMINED SUICIDE.--As the 6 P. M. train on the Hudson River Railroad was passing near Seventy-ninth-street, Monday evening, a man named James Johnson threw himself upon the track. Officer Wilson, of the Twenty-second Ward. happened to see him. and succeeded in pulling him off the track just in time to save his life.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES AND SOUTHERN CONVANTIONS.--The New-York Times is edited by a corps of men whose knowledge is evidently Cyclopaedianic--or, perhaps we should say, Cyclopean--so wonderful is its extent, so awful its profundity and so brilliant are its seintillations in the process of being worked up into double-columned editorials.

By the arrival of the Hammonia at this port yesterday, and the Indian at Quebec, we have advices from Europe to the 18th ult.-four days later. The news is not of an important character. The debate in Parliament on Mr. CARDWELL'S resolution of censure against the Government was continned during two days, and was finally adjourned to the 20th, when the vote would probably be taken.

THE PROPLE'S PARTY.-New parties spring up like mushrooms now-a-days. Every new grievance is made the occasion for a new party. The latest programme is that of "The People's Party," issued at Washington. The Declaration is very well written and the principles very good; but nobody signs it and nobody seems to be responsible for it.

SHARP FEMALE PRACTITIONERS--LOOK OUT FOR BEG?ING FEMALES.---A middle aged woman, plainly but neatly dressed, called at the residence of Mr. John Griswold. No. 20 Union square, yesterday forenoon, and asked to see the lady of the house. The woman was shown into the parlor and requested to be seated.

We publish this morning a continuation of the debate in the British Parliament, on Mr. CARDWELL'S resolution of censure against the Government of the Earl of DERBY. We have devoted considerable space to this debate, because it is, in reality, the most important one that has been heard for many years within the walls of the House of Commons.

The steamship Hammonia, from Seathampten on the l8th May, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The steamship Indiana, from Liverpool on the 19th inst., arrived at Quebec yesterday. The news by these arrivals is four days later The unusually lengthy passage of the Indiana is explained by the following:

To the Editor of the New- York Times : The announcement of the Barnum-Lumley Opera speculation which you published some days ago, and which the Herald (knowing nothing about the matter) promptly pooh-poohed, turns out to be correct. Mr. BARNUM'S card is before the public; and the Musical

STATE POLITICS.--The principal point of discussion in the Republican ranks is whether the State Convention shall consist of one, two or three delegates from each Assembly District. The Tribune advises two, in order that the Americans, "who are sincere in their hostility to Slavery," may have a fair representation.

The bill making appropriations for the Ocean Mail and other Postal services, which passed the House without twenty members knowing its details has been subjected to scrutiny in the Senate Committee, which reveals very objectionable features.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have just read two articles in your paper of May 21. entitled "Wholesale Corruption," and "Smooth Phrases." Now, Mr. Editor, I am a Wisconsinner myself, and though my sins consist in no part of bribery, given or received, I beg leave to say a word in extenuation of the facts you have commented on; for facts they are, I have no doubt.

Before Judge Ingersoll. Ann Kelly, Administratrix. , vs. The New-Jersey Mail Transportation Company.--The Jury in this case came into Court ?? is morning with a sealed verdict, which they were directed on Saturday to bring in this morning. The verdict was in favor of the plaintiff, for the sum of $1,000.

THE BOARD OF ALDERMEN. The Street Commissioner Proposes a Reorganization of ?? Department--Condition of the Bureau of Lamps and Gas. The Board of Aldermen met last evening--President CLANCY in the Chair.

TICEKT-SWINDLING LING.-A French Canadiall named BRUGEME, complained that he had been swindled out of $140 in gold and a valuable watch chain, at J. W. RAYMOND'S office, No. 177 West-street, for which he received only a steerage ticket. He had been purposely misled by the swindlers, who made him believe teat the place where he was cheated of his money was in the regular office of the steamer.

To BYSINESS MEN.--Several prominent and distinguished gentlemen, highly intelligent and accomplished, are willing to take houses in Washington during the next session of Congress, and explain to hungry members the wants of the country,-provided the parties to whose benefit this will inure will pay the expenses of such a proceeding.

Letters received here a day or two since from a gentleman of this City, at present traveling in Italy, bring the melancholy announcement of the death of E. S. BARTHOLOMEW, one of the most promising of our American Sculptors. Few better illustrations are afforded of the indomitable energy of genius when combined with the earnestness of the American character, than that we have in Mr. B.'s history.

We extract in another column a pair of articles, one of them on the Slave-Trade and the other in reply to our observations on the Montgomery "Commercial Convention," which are certainly as racy specimens of " Southern literature" as any we have lately met with.

DUER--In this City, on Sunday, May 30, at the residence of his son-in-law. A.G. King, WILLIAM ALEXANDER DUER, in the 78th year of his age. The friends of the family are requested to attend his funeral at the Church of the Redeemer. Morristown, N. J.. on Wednesday, June 2 at 10 3/4 o'clock 103/4 O'clock A.M. without further invitation. The Railroad train leaves at 3 1/2 o'clock A.M.

The steamship Tennessee, Captain FORBES, arrived here yesterday from Vera Cruz. which sue left on the 21st inst., to which date we have files of papers thence. The Tennessee brings Admiral ZERMAN as passengers, and six others in the steerage. Her freight consists of five cases of vanilla, consigned to BRUGIERE Co., and $11.880 in specie.

UNION COURSE, LONG ISLAND.--Great Trotting Tuesday, June 1. Match $500, mile heats, best 3 in 5, in harness. GEO. SPICER b. g. Lantern, received forfeit. H. WOODRUFF, br. g. Tartar, paid forfeit. The people were disappointed in consequence of the race not taking place. The forfeit was paid on Monday. The parties who made the match, as a matter of course, should have informed the public.

PROGRESS IN RUSSIA.-The emancipation of the serfs by the Emperor ALEXANDKER is a remaykable event. We are not surprised that it has attracted so much attention here, where we are in the habit of regarding Russia as an icy despotism which no civilization has power to melt. But one or two loading facts will somewhat diminish the wonder.

MONTGOMERT'S Mounted corps at Sugar Creek are undoubtedly a small band of highway men-and we hope that no respectable New-York or St. Lourts journal will undertake to apologize for their acts upon the Free-State men of the Territory is simply absurd. They Area few congregated bad men who levy blackmail indiscriminately.

Considerable uneasiness is felt at the British Embassy lest a collision should occur in the Gulf between the English and American war-vessels before the British Admiral receives Lord NAPIER's dispatches, which he has requested to be sent in a special steamer from Halifax to Bermuda.

Anniversary Week went off very well. There was much work done, and some excitement had, but not enough to alarm people. The Abolitionists held their meetings, which, as usual, were spirited, but were of even less practical consequence than the late Southern Convention at Montgomery.

How THEY MANAGE DUELS IN FRANCE.-As we borrow so many of our ideas on the proprieties of life in the higher walks of society from France, it is of considerable importance to us when a new mode is inaugurated in Paris, whether it be in the shape of a bonnet, the color of a coat, the composition of a salad, the arrangement of a quadrille, or the method of fighting a duel;

From the Washington Union. The Postmaster-General has given an order to convey the great Southern mail, leaving New-York in the morning, over the Central route, diverging from the seabord route at Richmond, and then, vid the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, through Knoxville and Dalton, Georgia, to the grand junction, 50 miles cast of Memphis, and thence vid Jackson to New-Orleans.

MORRIS--COOKE.--In this City, on Wednesday. June 7, at St. Bartholomew's Church.. by the Rev. Dr. Cooke, WILLIAM HENRY MORRIS to MARIA WALDEN, daughter of Joseph P. Cooke, and niece of the officiating clergyman. ROGERS--DOWLING--in this City, on Wednesday, June 2, by the Rev. John Dowling. D. D. Mr. ROBERT ROGERS to Miss CORNELIA MARIA, second daughter of the officiating clergyman.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Since the success or failure of this, the second attempt to lay the Atlantic Telegraph Cable, is the subject of much interest and comment among all classes of people, it has occurred to me that the plan of paying out the cable over the stern or bide of the vessel is entirely wrong, as the parting of the cable last Summer fully demonstrated.

A brief dispatch from Augusta, Ga., which will be found elsewhere, contains a partial confirmation of the tumor which prevailed in Washington on Tuesday, and mentioned in the TIMES of yesterday morning, to the effect that a collision had actually taken place between an American and a British war-vessel.

The business was of no public interest until 1 o'clock, when Mr. MASON procured the consent of the Senate to make the resolutions concerning the British aggressions the special order for Saturday noon. Mr. HOUSTON, of Texas, tried to bring up his resolutions in reference to a protectorate over Mexico

The Senate has added about three millions of dollars to the Miscellaneous Appropriation bill, of which nearly the whole is for the improvement and embellishment of Washington City. The Capitol, the Aqueduct, the Treasury Department, the Public Grounds absorb the golden streams constantly setting towards the Treasury, as the sands of the Ethiopian desert swallow up the waters of the Niger.

DISGRACEFUL AFFAIR.--The usual monotony about the City Hall was interrupted yesterday in a disgraceful manner. A girl 16 years of age, named CEEGG, whose mother resides in Carlton-avenue, a few weeks ago was induced by some means not yet made public, to take up her residence in a house of questionable repute in the City of New-York, kept by a Mrs. BROWN.

Intimations received to-day by telegraph warrant the belief that the steamers from England brought important dispatches, which will arrive here to morrow, and there are also intimations that they will be pacific in character.

Senator MASON, from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, introduced a very extraordinary bill in the Senate on Tuesday. We print it in another column. It proposes a complete revolution in the whole method of making war, and proposes, in effect, to place in the hands of the President-not temporarily or in an emergency, but permanently,-the absolute power of waging war,

We have a large budget of correspondence from Kansas, for only part of which, in the crowded state of our columns, can we make room this morning. The outrages, in a portion of the Teritory, seem to be extending, and growing more and more bloody in their character.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: At the Judicial election in this City last Fall, the Democrats elected their whole ticket by a sweeping majority of over 15,000 votes. Many of the judges thus elected are of the highest order of character and talent, and reflect credit upon the party machinery that nominated them for their positions;

GENERAL HOUSTON AND MEXICO.--Some words which fell from General HOUSTON in the Senate, yesterday, give color to a recent rumor that, after the adjournment of Congress, he intends to lead a body of armed men into Mexico.

* * Concerning the movements and manocuvas of that most worthy and gallant knight of the road, Captain MONTGOMERY it is difficult to get reliable information. My intelligence is derived from one of the members of the Lecompton Convention and a conspicuous manipulator in the Oxford Precinct frauds whom I met at Westport about a week ago,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--A perfectly excellent performance of VERDI'S " Traviata" was given last night to a fine and fashionable audience. If there had been some preliminary puffing in the case of Mme. GAZZANIGA, with an elevation of prices to five dollars on her arrival here, it is probable the attendance would have been larger.

An American vessel has been fired into by a British cruiser off Pensacola, Fla., and one man killed. The name of neither vessel is given. The U. S. steamer Fulton was in chase of the vessel which committed the outrage, no other vessel being in company.

The Commissioners paid a visit of inspection, accompanied by several invited guests, to the Institutions on Ward's Island yesterday. The number of immigrants now there is about 1,100, of whom about 700 are in the hospitals. The conduct of the Institutions appeared to be exceedingly judicious, and the result is shown in the greatly improved appearance of the grounds and the still more marked improvement in the finances of the Board.

From the Argus of Monday. According to announcement, a large number of our citizens assembled in Ashland Hall, Friday night. to take action relative to certain individuals suspected of running off slaves to the North. The discovery of the missing negro ANTHONY, belonging to Mr. SCOTT, of Smithfield, on board the schooner Francis French, caused this prompt action.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The following resolution was adopted: Resolved, That the Commissioners of Central Park be requested to open the transverse roads laid down on the map of Central Park, as adopted by them, so as to afford thoroughfares across the same.

There was a meeting of the Swill-milk Committee of the Board of Health,in Room No. 8 City Hall yesterday afternoon. The time set down for meeting was 2 o'clock; and at that hour the main room of the Clerk of the Common Council was nearly filled with men strongly impressed in favor of the milk crawn from the stump tailed animals that abound in the various swill-stables in this City and in Brooklyn.

The Royal Mail Steamship America, Captain MILLAR, which sailed from Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of May 22, arrived at Halifax at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. The America, May 22, passed steamship Arabia from New-York for Liverpool. The North Star, from Southampton on the 19th ult., arrived at this port yesterday.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am glad to see the letter of " An Opera Goer," in your paper of this morning, criticizing the projected operatic enterprise. All that I desire is to learn the opinions of the people upon this subject, and to conduct operations accordingly.

DEAR SIR: You have heard what reception I have met with in America. They have bored me with triumphant entries, and invitations, and addresses: but by submitting to this annoying part of my mission, I had the opportunity of drawing their ?? to their foreign policy. I have spoken to the masses, and with the leading men, with those now in office, and with those who are to go into office:

FRANKLIN'S REPUTED DISCOVERY OF A NORTHWEST PASSAGE CONTROVERTED. Tuesday night the New-York Historical Society held its regular monthly meeting. The attendance was large. A spirited portrait of ELKANAH WATSON by COPLEY, which had been deposited with the Society for temporary exhibition, was much admired.

Before Judge Ingersoll. The United States vs James Burns.--The evidence of the Manslaughter for which the defendant was indicated was so overthrown by the evidence for the defence that the Jury rendered a verdict of acquittal without leaving their seats.

The telegraph brings us startling news from New-Orleans-more important by far than all the reports of British outrages which have engrossed public attention for the last few days. The people of New-Orleans-alarmed

SMITH, M.D., of Waukegan, Illi-ois, called the meeting to order, and was elected permanent Chairman. WM. E. PAYNE, of Bath, Maine, was chosen General Secretary, and E. T. RICHARDSON., M. D., of Brooklyn, Provisional Secretary. Five censors were appointed for the ensuing

CRUEL TREATMENT OF AN ORPMAN GIRL.--A case of alleged barbarous treatment of a young orphan girl has just been brought to the knowledge of Justice QUACKENBUSH. The girl, who gives her name as Elizabeth Simpson, and her age as sixteen, states that in the Fall of 1854 she was taken from the Orphan Asylum and indentured to Mrs. Ward of No. 2 Abingdon-place, until she became of age.

We have received from Washington nearly two hundred pages of the testimony taken before the Congressional Investigating Committee in the case of the Willett's Point purchase, of which we give on another page some extremely interesting and very curious extracts. Enough is given to Show that Secretary FLOYD has a fatal facility for falling into the hands of gentlemen who have a marvelous knack of getting good bargains out of him.

The following companies turned out: First Regiment--Highwood Guard, Captain Newkirk; National Guard, Captain Van Houghton; Artillery Company, Captain Heximer; and a Dragoon Company. Second Regiment-Jersey Continentals,

To the Editor of the New - York Times: On Wednesday evening during the discussion the Bible Question, before the Board of Education , a statement was made that the Israelites were opposed to having the Holy Volume read in the Public Schools This I deny. As a general thing, I sincerely believe that the whole community of the above people wish it to be read in our institutions of public instruction.

FOR CALIFORNIA.-The steamer Empire City, which sailed on Wednesday, took twenty-five passengers for Havana and 200 for California, besides $100,000 for New-Orleans. The Moses Taylor sails tomorrow. The Deputy-Superintendent of Police reports that the ticket-swindle is carried on in a new way.

The Lecture-room of the Clinton Hall Building was crowded last night with stock holders and bondholders of the New-York and Erie Railroad, to hear the semi annual statement of the business of the road made by the President. CHARLES MORAN, Esq., and to discuss its present financial condition. A sufficient abstract of this statement will be found in the Money article of this morning.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--VERDI'S delightful opera of the "TRAVIATA" will be played to-night for the second time. The splendid performance on Monday justifies the expectation of a fine night's pleasure. BENEFIT OF THE HUNTER WOODIS SOCIETY.

KIP--BRADY.--In this City. on Wednesday, June 2. by the Rev. Samuel Cooke. D. D. ISAAC L. KIP, M. D., to CORNELIA, daughter of William V. Brady, Esq., all of this City. RICE--BELL--In this City. on Wednesday, June 2 by the Rev. Thos. H. Hastings. JOHN S. RICE to CORNELIA W. youngest daughter of David Bell, Esq, all of this City

SWINDLlNG PASSENGERS.--Officers HOLLAND and LBE,of the Harbor Police, on Wednesday boarded the ship Fudelia, at the request of some passengers who had been cheated by ticket-swindlers. Two of them bad been sold tickets which were represented as for the steamer for Hamburg. on full fare; but they found themselves on board a packet-ship bound for Liverpool.

PORTER.--In this City, on Saturday morning, June 3, suddenly at his residence Doctor HENRY H PORTER. His feneral will take place from his late residence No. 216 Fulton St., on Saturday, the 10th inst., at 10 o'clock A. M. His remains will be taken to Cypress Hills Cemetry. The friends of his family are respectfully invited to attend: likewise, the members of the Veteran Corps of the War of 1812.

Captain JAMES H WARD has been ordered to and assumed command of the United States receiving-ship North ?aralina at he Brooklyn Navy Yard, Vice Captain FINDLAY SCHENCK, who has leave of absence for six months. The United States steamer Arctic, Commander HARTSTIEN, hence for the Gulf, was spoken on the 31st ult., ten miles north of Hatreras,

THE ABDUCTION CASE.--Mrs. BROWN, charged with having attempted to abduct Miss MELVINA CLEGG from Brooklyn, on Wednesday last, was yesterday morning brought before Justice CORNWELL for examination. She waived her right, and gave bail to appear for trial at the Court of Sessions, if wanted. The bail was fixed at $2,000, and ex-Captain NORRIS, of the New-York Municipal Police, became her bondsman.

A dispatch from Leavenworth, the 1st, says that intelligence from Camp Scott to the 6th of May, had been received at the Fort. On that day two Mormons came into the Camp from Salt Lake City, having dispatches from Governor CUMMING for Secretary CASS. The troops were expected to move towards the Valley by the end of May.

The annual Regatta of the New-York Club. which took place yesterday, surpassed in interest any of the preceding celebrations which have taken place. The growing taste for yachting, tile entry of several first-class boats hailing from New-York, together with others of fame and name from other ports, conduced to give a prestige to the contest, and render the result an object of exciting interest.

The scenes peculiar to San Francisco during the prevalence of the Vigilance-Committee excitement there, are now being enacted in New-Orleans. A revolution is in progress there. The long series of outrages which have, of late, disdisgraced that city have at length driven the citizens to the desperate remedy of taking the law into their own hands.

A revolution broke out here last night. A Vigilance Committee in large numbers took possession of the Arsenal, Jackson-square, and the prisoners. This morning the Executive Committee calls for all law-and-order people to join them, and announce a determination to carry out their measures.

Mr. SEWARD'S resolution to extend the session until the 21st inst, was voted on, and carried by 33 against 20, but Mr. HAMLIN'S amendment to terminate the session on the 14th was then voted on, and adopted by 39 against 17.

A dispatch from Leavenworth, dated the 31st ult., says that no further outbreak had occurred at Fort Scott. A detachment of troops was there to be replaced by companies from the Second Infantry. The fourth column, under Col. MORRISON, marched this morning, and the fifth and sixth columns are in readiness to move and will be pushed forward immediately.

The United States Mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCK, Commander, from New-Orleans vid Havana, has arrived at this port, having left the latter place on the 30th ult. From Havana we learn that the arrest of the English officer so conspicuous in his boarding operations, and who has been sent to Jamaica. gives general satisfaction, and the impression is that we will hear no more of "British aggression."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The vexata questio of the "right of search" once more has become the topic of universal interest and discussion from its recent and repeated as well flagrant exercise by British cruisers upon unarmed American merchant vessels.

In the Protestant Reformed Dutch Synod, of North America, this morning, the Standing Committees for the ensuing year were announced, and several reports of Committees acted upon. The Committee on Education reported in favor of Parochial Schools as a means of strengthening the denomination.

Those clauses of the bill just introduced into the Senate by Mr. MASON, which authorize the President to make reprisals on private individuals, are certainly not in accordance with the spirit of the age. Reprisals, though authorised by the " law of nations," are but one of the hundred barbarities which find full sanction in the same code.

The famed sermon of the Rev. Dr. F. WAYLAND, on the " Moral Dignity of the Missionary Eaterprise," was originally preached by him whea he was settled as pastor over the First Baptist Church in the city of Boston. The church then worshipped in the plain wooden building in Salem, the same house that the Rev. Dr. STILLMAN preached in so long and with such success.

The revolutionary movement in New-Orleans, commenced on Tuesday night, resulted yesterday afternoon in the complete triumph of the Vigilance Committee, the Mayor having resigned the Municipal authority into their hands. Our dispatches, dated at different hours throughout the day, will give an idea of the progress of affairs previous to this consummation.

Our Southern brethren do not make great progress in reopening the Slave-trade. The Charleston Standard, which distinguished itself by being the first to advocate this policy, has not only failed in its effort but has been ruined by it.

People naturally suppose that the fountain head of all information in regard to Police matters is at the metropolitan Head-quarters in Broomestreet, corner of Elm. If a child is lost, a friend robbed, a neighbor murdered, they fancy that the place to learn the particulars and start the search from is the Head-quarters.

Secretary FLOYD to-day received a special dispatch from General HARNEY, fully cornfirming the late hostile Utah news, and asking that the reinforcements be hurried forward. Three carriages stood before the City Hall at 10 o'clock Thursday morning, and shortly after that hour the Committee of the Board of Health, recently appointed to examine into and report the condition of the melting establishments and piggeries, against which complaints have been male, entered them.

ADJOURNMENT OF CONGRESS.--The House would consent o postpone the adjournment only three days, and the Senate, which desired a week, has concurred. Thursday of next week, the 10th inst., is, therefore, the day upon which the session will close.

BENDIROK--In this City, on Thursday morning, June 3, Mr. EDWARD J. C. BENDIROK, in the 23d year of his age. His friends, and the members of the Press, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Sunday at 3 o'clock P. M. from his late residence, No. 137 West 17th-st. SCATLIFF--In this City, on Thursday morning June 3, of apoplexy, JAMES SCATLIFF, in the 45th year of his age.

AMERICAN GENERAL COMMITTEE--THE BIBLE IN THE PUBLIC SCHOOLS.--A regular meeting of the American General Committee was held last evening at the corner of Broadway and Lispenard-street. There was a full attendance. The evening was occupied in hearing the report of the Printing Committee, in reference to the exclusion of the Bible from some of the Public Schools.

The famous liberty pole which, for twenty-six yearspast, has stood at the junction of Franklin-street and West Broadway, was taken down, yesterday, in pursuance of an older issued from the Street Deapartment. It was found, on examination, to be in tog advanced a state of decay to allow it to stand longer without jeopardizing the lives of people passing by a sudden tumble down on their heads.

In our edition of yesterday we gave a summary of the results of the regatta, to which we deem it necessary to make a brief addenda. The annual regatta of the New-York Club has now become one of the institutions of the country.

A very fine performance of the " Traviata" was given last night, to a good and thoroughly appreciative audience. To-day there will be a Matinee, commencing a 1 1/2 o'clock, when ROSSINI'S comic opera of the " Barber of Seville" will be performed.

Within two months past numerous letters have been received by Mayor TIEMANN complaining of certain bogus lottery and gilt concerns in New-Hampshire, in which the name, schemes and location of each are fully set forth.

Mr. HASKIN has been ready to report in the WILETT'S Point case since last Monday. Messrs. WOOD of Maine, and HALL of Massachusetts decline signing the statement he has prepared concluding with resolutions censuring the Secretary of War and Mr. SCHELL, the Collector, The Democrats will of course present resolutions supporting the officers involved in the affair, as a duty to party.

The bill introduced by Mr. KENNEDY, to establish a mail steamship line between New-York, Philadelphia. Baltimore and Europe, was read twice, and referred to the Post-Office Committee. Mr. DOUGLAS, from the Committee on Territories repotted against the present organization of Dacotah.

The President told a member of the House today that the question of the Right of Search, or Visitation, must now be settled definitely between the United States and England; and he farther declared that the British Government would be obliged to abandon its pretensions. The rumor of the British Admiral's action in the Gulf created a general sensation in both Houses, and went round like wildfire.

The Mayor's forces are yet unorganized, and all remains quiet. Great preparations are being made by both parties. The forces of the Vigilance Committee are under command of Major F. K. DUNCAN, late of the United States Army, and are well organized and drilled. A crisis is expected to-day.

SATANIC THEOLOGY.--Yesterday being Sunday, the Herald waxed didactic. It gave its readers the benefit of its views of Church discipline and Christian morality, which, like its views on most subjects, are peculiar. The text from which the Herald discoursed was the trial by a Church of one of its members on a charge of adultery.

The Milwaukee and Superior Railroad Company was incorporated by an act of the Legislature, in March, 1856. In the following April it was organized, and C. R. ALTON, H. HAERTEL, EDWARD BUTTON, D. P. HULL and JOSHUA STARK, of the city of Milwakee; JULIUS WHITE, of Madison, and GEORGE REED, of Manitowoe, were chosen Directors. This Board of Directors then elected C. R. ALTON President; II. T.

ITALIAN OPERA.--The performance of the Barber on Saturday was very enjoyable; more particularly because it reintroduced two favorites, Miss ADA PHILLIPS and Sig. GASSIER; the lady making her first appearance of the season in the role of Rosina, and GASSIER exerting him facetiously and vigorously as Figaro, a part in which he is excellent.

We are on the eve of a fresh excitement. Inflammatory placards have just been issued by the socalled American Party, calling upon the Americans to resist the authority of the Vigilance Committee. More than one-half of the American Party are on the Vigilance Committee, and many of the leaders of the Committee are well-known Know-Nothings.

The Hon. T. L. CLINGMAN, recently member of Congress from the Eighth District ot North Carolina, has addressed a letter to his constituents on, the occasion of accepting the appointment from the Governor as United States Senator in place of the Hon. ASA BRIGGS, resigned.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : I hare just witnessed what only the evidence of my own senses would have made me believe possible, even in your wretchedly-governed City. In other countries, I have seen both the inhumation and the exhumation of victims, in the one case of the cholera, in the other of the plague.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: From the recent conduct of the Directors of this Road, one would be led to the conclusion that they were doing everything in their power to destroy what little popularity they ever enjoyed, and at the same time sacrifice the interest of the stockholders. By performing the farce of annually electing themsalves they have become emboldened, and think

The trouble in New-Orleans is not yet over, and it is to be feared that a great deal of blood is to be shed before quiet can be restored. Inflammatory placards against the Vigilance Committee were issued on Saturday evening, purporting to come from the American party, though it is said that more than one-half of that party are enrolled as members of the Committee.

TWO BOATS CAPSIZED-SIX LIVES LOST. Friday afternoon four men, named HENRY CEASER, JOHN BOGERT, FREDERICK SCOTT, and WM. PAYNTON, took a sail-boat at Penny Bridge and proceeded to the lower Bay on a fishing excursion.

Te the Editor of the Ne- York Tivnes: The subject of Milk has of late occupied so much public attention, and is inherently of so much importance, that any scheme which looks to furnishing pure country milk is worthy of examination, and if adopted with successful results, is a public benefaction.

It is known to most, that in the office of the detective force of the Metropolitan Police in this City. a collection of ambrotype "counterfeit presentments" of the most noted criminals who have brought themselves within the ken and custody of justice, is kept on exhibition for the public good.

George P. McCulloch, Esq., a distinguished citizen; of New--Jersey, died in Morristown on Tuesday, aged 83. He was born in Bombay, his father being a Scotch officer in the East India service. He was emplayed during the first Consulate of Napoleon, in various financial negotiations for the East India Company, and caine to New-York in 1806. He settled soon after at Morristown, where he has since resided.

NEW USURY LAW IN PENNSYLVANIA.--An act making important changes in the law of interest has recently been passed by the Pennsylvania Legislature. It was signed by the Governor on the 28th ult. This law makes six per cent. the legal rate in all cases where no lower rate is agreed upon. But when a rate higher than six percent.

DISTURBANCE AMONGST FEMALES.--About 2 o'clock, yesterday morning, desperate fight occurred between MARY McCARTY and CATHARINE McNULTY, residing on the same floor in a house on Railroad-avenue. rear Monmouth street. The females had been drinking freely during the fore part of the night, and the liquor had the effect of raising Mrs. McNULTY'S jealousy, and she accordingly concluded to seek redreas for her real or imaginary wrongs.

THE PRESBYTERIANS ON MARRIAGE.--The New. School Assembly of the Presbyterian Church has decided the case of the marriage of the Rev. Mr. SHIELDS, of Des Moines, adversely to that gentleman. The case has been already stated, but as this decision settles a point in Presbyterian discipline, it is worth while to give the story complete:

THE DIFFICULTY IN THE SIXTH-STREET METHODIST COLORED CHURCH.--The troubles at the Church in Sixth-street have not yet been brought to peaceful termination. On Saturday Justice BRENNAN issued warrants for the arrest of several of the members charged with creating a disturbance at a meeting held at the Church on Friday evening.

The House Committee on Foreign Affairs tomorrow will have under consideration the general subject of the British aggressions, and will endeavor to come to a resolution thereon. It is the intention of the Government to call out the volunteer regiments in a few days.

There could hardly be a better proof of the degradation into which the French public and French society have fallen, than is afforded by the proceedings consequent upon the recent duel between M. PENE, a contributor to the Figaro, and an officer of the army.

The notations ot the mercury were made at 6 o'clock A. M., from a thermometer hanging on the north side of the main building, (of Bloomingdale Asylum,) which stands on high ground on One Hundred and Seventeenth street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues.

The late Mr. Bartholomew, the sculptor, left Rome at the end of march, in company with the artist Osgood. Among the unfinished works which he leaves is a monument for a child of Col. Colt, of Hartford. On the morning of his departure from Rome, he received an order from Mr. Stevens, of Boston, for a copy of his "Calypso." and another for any statue he might choose, at a cost of $1,000.

The United States sloop-of-war Constellation, Capt. C. H. BELL, arrived at this port on Saturday from Genoa, which port she left April 17. The following is a list of her officers: Captain, CHAS. H. BELL; Lieutenants, J. P. Bankhead, Charles M. Fauntleroy, Wm. F. Spicer, Edward Barrett, R. L. Law, C. F. Stanton; Surgeon, John A. Lockwood; Purser, John Johnson;

There are three distinct State Loans now advertised for, and for which proposals will be received to the 24th inst., as follows: 1. The Comotroller advertises for a loan of $100,000 at 5 per cent., reimbursable July 1, 1875, to make good the deficiency in the annual contribution from the Canal Revenues of $350,000 to the General Fund Debt Sinking Fund, required by section 2 of article 7 of the Constitution.

After the Zuloaga Government, what next ? is substantially the question which most people, interested in Mexico, are curious to hear answered. That Government, or rather dictatorship, still nominally exists, and we are looking for its overthrow by every mail; but it is impossible to indicate the Presidential successor of ZULOAGA, or to decide whether it is the destiny of the country to have one at all.

JAMES GRAHAM, one of the four firemen injured by the falling of a wall at the fire in Monroe-street, last Friday morning, died at 5 o'clock Saturday morning, at the City Hospital Coroner Hills being notified of his death, proceeded to the Hospital Saturday forenoon, to hold an inquest, but after impaneling a jury, was obliged to postpone the examination on account of the absence of necessary witnesses.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Mr. P. T. BARNUM, in answering the "OperaGoer," does not establish a case against a position not to be overthrown. Mr. P. T. BARNUM intimates that English opera-goers pay willingly sixty per cent. more than would be imposed upon the public of NewYork at the price of five dollars.

New-Orleans is, unquestionably, the most un-American city in our whole Confederacy. The French and Spanish population, though less than the Anglo Saxon in point of numbers, do, nevertheless, give the dominant tone to the morals of the people.

A STATE LOAN or $1,800,00.--An article which we copy from the Albany Atlas and Argus of Saturday, furnishes the particulars of three loans advertised by the Comptroller, for which proposals will be received up to the 24th inst., amounting in the aggregate to $1,800,000, though one million of it is not new.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Regarded in any light, the British search of our vessels in the Gulf is at once a subject of mystery and curiosity. Just when our relations with England are of the most friendly character, the bonds of commercial union drawing closer and closer, and ships of war of both nations are engaged in taking on board what it is hoped will be the means of

By an arrival from Hamilton, Dermuna, we learn that, on the 26th ult. the particulars of the recent aggressions on our commerce by British cruisers were known in the Island. As the Admiral, Sir HOUSTON STEWART, was there at that date, it is probable that he took measures at once for the suppression of outrages committed by persons under his immediate command.

Summer may now be said to be fairly inaugurated with us, and is giving us good promises as to the future. Our corn, which the cold wet season of '57 obliged us to replant, is coining on finely from the first seed; the fruit trees are blooming very fullyindeed more so than in any season for some years;

THE RUTGERS FEMALE INSTITUTE--A question of the removal of this important institution to the upper part of the City has been, for some time, under consideration. It had been understood that parties up town were ready on this condition to pledge themselves for a large sum, ($35,000,) to be added to the proceeds of the sale of the present buildings, and overtures and negotiations have been going on for some months.

A CARD TO THE PUBLIC. The purchase of the land for the Central Park is believed to be the largest appropriation ever made by a single city for a public place to be devoted to health and pleasure, and is a striking evidence, not only of the wealth and liberality of the City, but of tje high .appreciation of the necessity which demanded its creation.

SCHOTT--In this City, on Sunday, June 6, WALTER, son cf Cath-rine and the late George W. Schott, in the 8th year of his age. I he friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend the funeral. on Tuesday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from the residence of his grandfather, No. 103. Greenwich-st.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me to call your attention to a few important facts, from which the public have long suffered. I refer to the state of the Ferry-boats plying between this City and Brooklyn, during wet weather. During a rain-storm, or even a shower, the passengers crossing on these boats are compelled to suffer more wet than they receive outside.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: SIR: In your paper of the 28th, I find this expression: " One thing is quite sure, a very different sort of argument was used after he (WOLCOTT) went to Washington, from that which Mr. STONE had employed, and with very different results.

The NewJersey Railroad and Transportation Company held their annual meeting yesterday in the new dpeot in Jersey City. The structure is an excellent one-spacious, convenient and well-devised. Its whole length, including as well the wooden Dornon which rests on piles, as the brick-work which stands on solid earth, is 500 feet by 103 wide;

In response to an inquiry from Secretary COBB, Attorney-General BLACK to-day sent in a communication, to the Treasury Department, giving his opinion in reference to certain cases arising in the office of the United States District-Attorney of the Southern District of New-York. Certain actions were brought against collectors and others, in which Mr. McKEON appeared for the defence, but gave place to Mr. SEDGWICK, while the actions were still pending.

The report of the firing into all Ameican ship near Pensacola by a British cruiser, was a canard. It caused the Government the price of a telegraphic dispatch to establish its want of truth. It provoked the House of Representatives to receive and refer a resolution authorizing the President to repel and to punish attacks upon American vessels by force.

The Chicago papers have full particulars of the fearful devastation of the village of Ellisoa by a whirlwind. A brief account of this disaster was given in our telegrams on Wednesday. The number of persons killed, so far as known, is twenty five; and from fifty to sixty others are badly injured. The following are the names of killed and wounded :

To the Editor of the New- York Times: In the TIMES of to-day, I see several letters on that vexata question. One of them, that signed " Jus," contains an extremely forcible remark, only I think it might, with more propriety, be used as an argument in support of the other side of the question. He quotes Sir ROBERT PEEL'S speech in 1842.

Though it is decorous that Congress should pay proper respect to the dead, we see no good reason why a day of the session should be lost, whenever the demise of a member is announced. The custom which makes an adjournment obligatory on every such occasion might advantageously be abolished.

New-York is the paradise of newspapers. Everybody has his pet paper, and it forms a prominent part of his morning or evening meal. Breakfast is incomplete at a New-York hotel without a morning journal; and one might as well be out of the world as not read the papers--no wonder they pay.

CLARK--COON.--In this City, on Friday, May 14, by the Rev John Quincy Adams, Mr. CHAS C. CLARK. Jr., to ANNIE AELLEN MARIA, youngest daughter of John H. Coon, both of this City. RICHARDSON-GILES--In this City, on Thursday. June 3 at St. Thomas' Church. by the Rev Win. F. Morgan JOHN R. RICHARDSON to AMELIA GONZALEZ. youngest daughter of the late William and Sophia ?iles, all of this City.

BOARDING OF THE BRIG LILLIAN. The brig Lillian, Captain NICHOLS, arrived at this port from Black River, Jamaica, on Saturday morning, with a cargo of logwood, and reports that he was boarded by a British war-steamer on the 23d ult., when ten miles east from Sombrero Key.

The Republican learns from a gentleman who left Fort Leavenworth on the 2d inst., and who had read all the letters from Camp Scott to May 6, that the news that Governor GUMMING has been driven from Salt Lake City is discredited.

THE CENTRAL PARK.--It is unavoidable that differences of opinion should arise, both in the Commission and in the community at large, concerning the details of such a work as the Central Park. But when they arise they should be carefully and dispassionately consid: ered, and special pains should be taken to reconcile conflicting opinions, and, if possible, bring about unanimous decisions.

The trades at the West are making demonstrations, this Summer, similar to those which have taken place from year to year t the East. The wages of mechanics generally were reduced during the prevalence of the panic last Fall. and. having been reduced, failed to come up when the panic sub slded,-the usual course. A strong movement aptears to have been commenced, aiming at a restoration of former prices.

The Detroit Free Press has the following: "There remains no doubt, we believe, that Belknap, of Ann Harbor Government Stock Bauknotoriety, is, or was when it collapsed the other day, the chief owner of the Bank of Macomb County.

The U. S. sloop Plymouth came out of the dock at the Gosport Yard, on Thursday at 12 o'clock, and at 8 o'clock P. M., as we learn from Capt. GEOBOE WRIGHT, pilot in charge, she was ten miles at sea. This was certainly rapid work, and shows an active and commendable effort to execute orders with disnatch. and prevent unnecessary delay.

Mr. HUNTER, of Virginia, from tile Finance Committee, reported a bill making appropriation for carrying the transatlantic mails. Mr. HUNTER also introduced a resolution relating to the expenses of the next fiscal year, the purport of which was that the Executive shallinstruct the Heads of Departments to confine their estimates within the limits of sixty-four millions of dollars.

THE DUEL WHICH DIDN'T TAKE PLACE.-The country regards with mingled derision and disgust the duels which so frequently almost happen between members of Congress. Of these, the latest was the Hughes and Harris affair, which was settled on Saturday or Sunday last "by the intervention of friends."

The Mayor is at the rooms of the Vigilance Committee, having placed himself under them protection. No attack has as yet been made by the mob, and Colonel CHRISTY has withdrawn from the leadership of the movement on account of the legal position of the Vigilance Committee. The Recorders are engaged in swearing in special policemen. The Vigilance Committee invite all citizens to join their ranks.

Mr. P. R. WILKINS sold under foreclosure four lots on the north side of Thirty-ninth-street, 200 feet east of Second-avenue, 25x98.9 each, subject to a mortgage of $2,400, with interest from Dec. 1, 1857, for $500--say, together, $3,000. We understand there was a mortage of $1,000 back of the second mortgage of $3,000 under which they were foreclosed.

It is believed that the Senate are voting on measures expressly to prevent the adjournment on Thursday, there being a strong disposition in the House to adjourn then, and an equally strong disposition in the Senate to compel them to stay.

SUDDEN CONVERSISON.-The Southern journals follow the lead of Senator MASON, and are now as earnest against a war with England as they were originally in favor of it The extraordinary eagerness of Senators HALE, SEWARD, WILSON and other Northern men for immediate hostilities, is supposed to have abated their ardor. Even the voice of Mr.

DESTITUTION AND SUICIDE..-A young Prussian. who has lately been boarding at No. 23 Mercer-street, was found yesterday morning hanging by his cravat, in his bedroom, to a heavy nail in the wall, dead, He had been missing since Saturday last. At an inquest held on the body it was shown that lie had been out cf employment for some time, and very lowspirited in consequence. The Jury rendered a verdict of "suicide by hanging."

NOT SO BAD AS WE SEEMED.-Since the terrible time of last Fall, when the foundations of our commercial credit seemed to have been hopelessly undermined, there have been a good many proofs that there was more soundness in our commercial constitution than we had credit for.

MY DFAR SIR : I have received your favor of the 17th inst., and hasten to reply. I have written no letter to the editor of the Chicago Journal, or any other paper, favoring the reflection of Judge DOUGLAS; but, on the other hand, I wrote a letter to the said editor. and to several other persons, favoring tile election of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. Your informant must have been strangely mistaken.

WRIGHT--In this City, on Sabbath afternoon, June 6, after a short illness, MARGARET FINNIE, wife or John Wright, Esq Funeral this afternoon. at 2 1/2 o'clock, from her late residence No. 108 West 15th-st. Friends will please accept this invitation. Glasgow,(Scotland,) London and Liverpool (Eng.) papers please copy.

Becoming greatly enraged, and being under the influence of liquor, Hall drew a sheath-knife and stabbed his opponent in the neck, inflicting a severe wound. The two hundred and twentieth anniversary of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company was celebrated to-day with the customary exercises and display. The sermon was preached by the Rev. JOHN COLTON in Chauncey Church, followed by a dinner at Faneuil Hall, and a public parade on the Common. Hon. FRANCIS BRINLEY was chosen commander for the ensuing year.

The most important matter in the Senate yesterday was a very interesting debate on the proposed increase of our Naval force by the addition of new steam sloops-of-war. The debate will be found reported quite fully elsewhere. It was participated in by all the leading Senators, and included in its range the late outrages committed by the British cruisers in the Gulf.

A famous pair of pistols which belonged to Gen. Putnam, and previously to Gen. Pitcairn, of the British army, are now in possession of Mr. John P. Putram, of White Creek, Washington County, in this State. Madame Ida Peiffer is on her way home, having sailed from the Mauritius in March.

The following is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 29th day of May to the 5th day of June, 1858: Men, 82; Women, 73; Boys, 120; Girls, 99. Total, 374*. Adults, 155; Children, 219; Males, 202 ; Females, 172; Colored persons, 9.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I regret to notice, in the columns of your paper, under date March 2, 1858, a statement regarding books and papers, property of General WALKER, as having been found in the yard of a house occupied by me ; that I was under surveillance, a probability of my being shot,

At Norristown, Pa., Friday, a young married man, named PHILIP BROWER, cut his thread of life by swallowing arsenic. Cause, the infidelity of his wife He left a letter, telling her to go and live with the man she loved better. In Morris County, Pa.,' on the 19th ult., a farmer, ISAAC VAN DUYNE, hung himself in his barn. Cause. disgust, because his daughter received the attentions of a young man whom he hated.

Brooklyn Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum The building recently erected on Bedford avenue for the Brooklyn Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum for boys, was opened to the public for the first time last evening. JUDICIAL CLEMENCY TOWARDS MURDERERS--ITS EFFECTS.--The Rochester Union says: "The recent order of judge WELLES, staying the execution of the sentence of death against IEA STOUF, has not only prolonged the life of the prisoner for a year, giving him hope for an ultimate pardon or commutation, but it has doubtless saved the lives of other felons condemned to the gallows for the highest of crimes.
