To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of the 4th instant I notice quite a lengthy communication from a citizen of Kansas Territory, (over the initials J. M. W.,) in reference to the present difficulties there, the great effort, end and aim of the writer being to exonerate one Captain MONTGOMERY from all blame, and to throw upon Governor DENVER the responsibility of the recent outrages committed in Southern Kansas. I too.

THE COMMEICIAL CRISIS-SECOND NOTE FROM GEN. URQUIZA-YELLOW FEVER-SHIPPING INTELLIGENCE. By the arrival at this port of the ship Parana, we have papers from Buenos Ayres to April 15, thirteen days later than previous advices via England. The principal topics of interest when the Parana sailed were the commercial crisis and the difficulties with the Argentine Confederation.

THE ARMORY OF THE NEW-YORK CITY GUARD - Among the other noticeable changes that have been made in the City, since the 1s-t of May, has been that of the New-York City Guard to their new Armory, at No. 654 Broadway, formerly PERACHIO's Dancing Academy. Their new rooms are far more commodious than those they formerly occupied, and are very handsomely fitted up.

Our elective judiciary is a great institution. The blessings it confers upon the community have only just begun to be appreciated. It is only the broadest and most salient features of the system which have thus far forced themselves upon public notice.

LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--A dramatic version of EUGENE SUE's high-pressure mulatto novel of "Mathilde" was produced here last night. The piece being limited to three acts, many of the incidents of the story are necessarily omitted, and the plot is sometimes precipitous. But Miss HERON, who has made the present version, displays good judgment in retaining those scenes which best display her own talents. "Mathilde " is decidedly spasmodic,

ETHAN ALLEN'S REMAINS.-- The Montreal Advertiser states that the remains of ETHAN ALLEN were brought to Montreal by his sister, and they were interred in the old burying .ground of the Parish Church. The locality is probably lost. It will be quite useless to search for ETHAN ALLENS'S remains Montreal.

We see it freely stated that the Republican members of the Willett's Point Committee of Investigation acquit Secretary FLOYD and Collector SCHELL, of all censure in regard to the fraud practiced upon the Government in that transaction. It has been remarked, also,

During a severe thunder-shower this noon, the new schooner Prairie Flower, with thirty five passengerson board, was capsized in our harbor. Two men were drowned, and a boy is missing, but the latter was probably picked up, as he was near one of a number of rescuing vessels, who saved the remainder and brought them to the city. The schooner belonged to Salem, and the passengers were taking a pleasure trip to Boston.

UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT. Before Judges Campbell and McCaleb. The United States vs. General Wm. Walker ?? al--The case being called, the District-Attorney asked for the severance of the indictment, and the defence not objecting. General WALKER and Colonel ANDERSON there place together on their trial, charged with the violation of the Neutrality law.

THE COLLINS STEAMERS.---We are glad to see indications that Congress will pay Mr. COLLINS the arrears hitherto withheld, of dues on account of mail service. We understand the difficulty grew out of the fact, that after the loss of the Arctic and Pacific, Mr. COLLINS was obliged to perform the service in slower and inferior vessels.

GERARD STITE, the American candidate for Mayor, has 290 majority, but many of the principal names on the same ticket are defeated. The city is quiet. The Vigilants broke up their camp last night and disbanded. They are not disorganized, however, and say they are ready to carry out their principles at any moment.

Recorcer BARNARD, in his charge to the Sessions Gra??d Jury yesterday, alluded to the great evil of the custom of shirking jary duty. It has become almost impossible of late, he says, to obtain honest, respectable, impartial and intelligent jurois.

Gen. WEBB has suffered another defeat in the matter of the appropriation to GALES SEATON for publishing the American State papers. WEBB is left out, and they are to divide with WENDELL--the latter doing the work. The House Committee on Foreign Affairs came to no conclustion this morning,

A slave belonging to Mrs. NANCY DAVIS, who lives near Westport, Mo., was sold to another party on Tuesday last, with his mother. Another son of the old negress head of the sale became very much engaged at it. went to Mrs. DAVIS' house. and snapped a gap at her. A son of Mrs. DAVIS interfered,

The impanneling of jurors in the Supreme Court Circuit for the trial of GANGEMI, was resumed yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. The five jurors obtained on Monday were in attendance, with about 400 indiviouals summoned to appear and serve. The hot weather excluded a multitude of spectators, but the room was uncomfortably crowded notwithstanding.

A NEW RADICAL DEMONSTRATION.--Circulars are out, bearing about a hundred signatures, for a "Free Convention," to be held at Rutland, Vt., on the 25th, 26th and 27th of this month. The movement has been kept quiet, so far; the Vermont newspapers not having been favored with advertisements, the faithful depend for their knowledge of it upon circulars privately distributed.

BROWN--SANDS---In this City. on Tuesday. June 8, at Trinity Church by the Rev. Dr. Berrian JNO GARNISS BROWN, of New Jersey, to MATILDA C., daughter of josh ua R. Sands. U.S.A. SPOTTEN--O'NIELL---In this City, on Sunday, June 6,, by the Rev Joseph B. Price, D. D., Mr. THOMAS SPOTTEN to KATE B. O'NIELL, both of this City. Boston Papers Please Copy.

The telegraphic dispatches received from day to day purporting to give us news from Utah are of so contradictory a character as to render it impossible to fix upon anything as reliable. A dispatch which we publish this morning, for instance, is in direct contradiction of one published a day or two since, though fully confirming one published previously.

Elihu Burritt, Corresponding Secretary National Emancipation Society: DEAR SIRE: You have my thanks for your letter, communicating the design of the Emancipation Society, for which you act, I need not tell you that my most cordial sympathies are enlisted in favor of the object you seek to accomplish.

VALUE OF GOOD WEATHER. -- The present warm June weather is as favorable to vegetation as is ever witnessed in this latitude. Every agricultural product is urged to its most rapid growth. The fields are gorgeous with verdure and flowers.

On motion of Mr. BIGLER, the Senate voted to extend the session to Monday the 14th instant, by ayes 43 pays 16. The credentails were presented for the next Senatorial term of six years. by Senaters HUNTER, CLAY and BROWN.

TREATRICAL.--A new Comedy, in three acts, originating in New-York, is underlined for immediate production at the Howard Athenaeum, in Boston. The author is understood to be a well-known gentlemen of literary reputation in this City. The scene is laid in a theatre in France, so that the play includes a play, and the two are made to play one against the other.

From the London Leader. In America, a simple machine called a cowcatcher, precludes such an accident as occurred on out Trent Valley Line this week. As the locomotive rushes along its single rail, passing through whole counties of pasture. or diving through a narrow lane in wide forests, it is liable every hour to find cows. with their stupid honest faces, staring at the advancing engine.

MARINE TEMPERANCE SOCIETY.-The twentyfifth anniversary of the Marine Temperance Society was observed last evening at the Mariners' Church, corner of Catharine and Madison streets. The attendance was large. Capt. EDWARD RICHARDSON presided. After an ode by the choir, addresses were made by R. G. PARDES, Esq.,the Rev. CHAS. J. JONES, JAMES B. DUNN, and others. NEW MATERIAL FOR PAPER.--Another new material for paper has been discovered in a preparation of the remains of the Beet Root after it has been used in sugar-making and distillation. The process of preparation has been patented, and the experiments made with the material in England are described as having been highly satisfactory. Besides various other advantages claimed

For the purpose of giving the public a plan, unvarnished history of the horrible murders committed in Linn Counity recently, I have obtained a statement from two of the wounded men who arrived in town on Saturday, and the wife of Mr.READ who accompanies them. Their statements are given generally in their own language.

On Friday last the Senate considered the treaty recently made with the Indians of the Dacotah district for the cession of their lands along the Missouri River, and it was defeated for want of a two-thirds vote, and from the absence of Senators. The vote was Ayes 18, Noes 16. Mr. BELL made a long speech against the treaty, which told with effect, because no one interested in the subject was prepared to reply.

PURSUIT OF A SUSPECTED SLAVER.--Mr. D'ANGELIS, Deputy United States Marshal, has been for some days watching the schooner Moravia, Captain WILLIAMS, which he suspected was fitting out for the slave-trade. The vessel, however, during a temporary intermission of the officer's vigilance, contrived to escape from her dock, at one of the upper piers of the East Piyer, and got under way for sea.

That the true sailor never forgets a kindness has found at least one verification among the crew of the Susquthanna, or at least that portion who es aped the ravages of yellow fever on board of her, and who, by the self-forgetting generosity of a surgeon in the English Navy, reached their native homes in good health, after that vessel had lauded a large number of her crew at Port Royal, Jamaica. in March last.

The Ancient and Honorable Ar??illery Com pany, of Boston. Once a year, the famous old military Company which bears this very long name, indulges in a celebration that always makes a great day in Boston. This year the ceremonies received additional importance, from the simultaneous occurrence of two events.

The Board of Music Trade, comprising all the principle Music Publishers of the United States, held their annual Convention at the Spencer House yesterday. Representatives from fourteen publishing houses were present.

We are surprised to find the Courrier dcs Elats Unis joining in the senseless outcry against a church organization for expelling a member for adultery. That paper treats this proceeding as a high-handed, tyrannical inquisition into the private life and habits of individuals, and calls upon the party concerned to invoke the civil law for his protection.

WATSON--In this City, on Monday. June 7, SARAH WATSON wife of Merideth Watson aged 61 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral on Wednesday June 9 at 1 o'clock, from her late residence. No. 178 West 16th st. Her remains will be taken to New-York Bay Cemetery for interment. VALENTINE--At Yonkers, on Monday, June 7, ABRAHAM VALENTINE, in the 85th year of this age.

RAPE IN NEW-HAVEN--FLIGHT OF THE ALLE?ED P?PETRATORS, AND THEIR ARREST IN THIS CITY.-- A telegraphic dispatch was received on Monday morning, at the Police Head-quarters, in Broome-street, from the Chief of Police Of New Haven, Conn.. announcing that two young men named George G. Webber and Benjamin Brown, had taken passage on the steamboat Elm City, for New York, and asking that they be arrested.

The Republican's Leavenworth correspondent learns from a man who left Camp Scott on the 8th of May, that the troops would be out of beef oy the sixteenth, but that their other rations would last till the first of June. No dispatches had been received in the Camp from Governor CUMMING, and nothing had been heard from Captain MARCY. The latter was expected to reach the Camp about the first of June.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--DONIZETTI'S " Opera of the " Favorita" will be played to night for the last time. BURTON'S THEATRE.--A new grand ballet, called Salvator Rosa," or the " Carnival of Rome," was produced here last night by the Ronzani Troupe.

SWILL-MILK DEVELOPMENTS IN CINCINNATI.-The Cincinnati Gazette has commenced an exposure of the swill-milk trade in that City. The published statements show a state of things in the milk trade which is a match for New-York. The Gazette makes an elaborate calculation to demonstrate that only one quart in ten, sold in Cincinnati, is Sure milk. The remainder comes from swill-fed cows, of which there

The difficulty between the Buffalo division of the Erie Railroad, and the New-York Central Railroad at Batavia, is assuming a threatening character. The former, to make a connection with another road, is obliged to cross the track of the latter in Batavia. This the Central Railroad Company appears determined to prevent, and they have placed a train of freight cars directly on the crossing, and chained to the track four heavy locomotives.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It cannot have escaped any newspaper reader that there has been much brave talking in Congress of late. Mr. TOOMBS tells us he has been pining for war these ten years. Mr. SEWARD advocated the sinking of British cruisers.

The Republican Senators in caucus, last night, resolved to adhere to the rule of rotation in office, which is adverse to the reelection of the Hon. JOHN P. HALE. Tne indications are favorable to the election of the Hon. T. M. EDWARDS, of Keene, to the Senatorship.

There is unusual activity at the Navy-Yard. Every officer is on the alert, and the head of each department watches the arrival of every mail from Washington for some new and starting order. The monotonous routine of years past has given place to bustle and activity, and nothing can now be too quickly core.

THIS IRISH RELIEF FUND.--The Irishmen in Georgia who contiouted to the famous Relief Fund in 1848, have become very indignant at the summary manner in which certain of their number have disposed of the money. A public meeting of the contriouors was held a Savannah on the 2d inst., at which the facts of the case were set forth.

COMMISSIONER OF JURORS.--The board appointed by the act framed last Winter with power to appoint a Commissioner of Jurors, have finally, after several meetings, agreed upon WILLIAM H. CAMPBELL, the present County Clerk. The Commissioner is required to give bonds in the sum of $5,000 for the faithful discharge of his duties.

CAPTURE OF BURGLARS. -- Yesterday afternoon Officers AYRES, CHASE and O'DONNELL arrested two well-dressed. genteel appearing fellows for feloniously entering the house of Mr. BAILEY, in Warren street, near Grand. The family were out at the time, and some of the neighbors seeing the fellows go up and unlock the door and enter, gave information to the Police.

LADIES' UNION AID SOCIETY.--The Ladies Union Aid Society, of the Methodist Eolscopal Church, for the benefit of aged and infirm members, held a donation party at the Institution in Forty-second-street. near the Eighth-avenue, yesterday, at 4 o'clock. The institution is designed to accommodate one hundred inmates, and there are at present but thirty old ladies in the house.

The State Convention of the Administration Democracy assembled here to-day. Two hundred and sixty three Delegates, representing forty-eight counties, were in attendance. JOHN DOUGHERTY was nominated State-Treasurer, and Ex-Gov. REYNOLDS Superintendent of Public instruction.

A PROCLAMATION. Whereas, the Territory of Utah was settled by certain emigrants from the States and from foreign countries. who have for several years past manifested a spirit of insubordination to the Constitution and laws of the United States. The great mass of those settlers, acting under the influence of leaders to whom they seem to nave surrendered their judgment, refuse to be controlled by any other authority.

Our reporters refer to these regular markets. Irregular sales are estimates?? made at Berges Hid, N.J., and from HUDSON River Boats. The great sales day at the Washington Yard is on WEDNESDAY of each week.

The war with England is over. We have conquered a peace by brave talking. Lord NAPIER has sent a message to Halifax, and a swift vessel, conveying pacific instructions, proceeded thence to the British Admiral, at Bermuda. We now hear very little of outrages. In fact, the demand for newspaper consumption is greater than the supply.

The opening meeting of an intended series of Temperance meetings of the Metropolitan Police in the eastern section of the City was held last evening in the Allen-street Church. Captains DE CAMP, of the Fourth Precinct, STEERS, of the Eleventh Precinct, and HARTT, of the Seventeenth Precinct, and about one hundred and fifty Policemen were present, besides several hundred other persons interested in the movement.

This trial was continued, yesterday before Judge WEIGHT in the Supreme Court Circuit. There were not many persons present, and there was no excitement. The public interest in the case seems nearly to have died away. Ex-Judge PHILLIPS, in a temperate but impressive speech, opened the case for the prosecution.

The miserable death of Dr. J. P. Holmes, the distinguished English physician who breathed his last in abject poverty at Evansville, Ind., a few weeks ago, has brought out some interesting statements concerning his previous life.

The management of the Michigan Southern Railroad seems to be equally at fault with that of the New- York Central, in the construction of its line of travel. An accident which happened on that Road near Adrian, on the 1st inst., narrowly missed the chance of being recordedd among the list of frightful oisasters.

CELEBRATION OF THE SABATH SCHOOLS--The annual celebration of the Sabbath Schools of Hoboken belonging to the Sunday School Union, took place yesterday afternoon, and were well attended. The Schools belonging to the following named Churches participated: First Baptist Presbyterian, Dutch Reformed, Methodist, and German Reformed Dutch.

CONVICTION OF A MURDERER--JAMES KELLY, indicted for the murder of his wife, ROSE KELLY, on the 16th of April last, at a house corner of Navy and Prospect streets, was tried in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday, before Judge STRONG, and found guilty as charged. He will be sentenced this morning.

The screw-steamship Kangaroo, from Liverpool at 9 o'clock, on the morning of Wednesday, the 26th of May, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The steamship Arabia, from New-York, arrived out at Liverpool at 10:15 P. M., on the 23d of May.

Mr. BAYARD, from the Judiciary Committee, to whom was referred AMOS KENDALL'S and other memorials against the American, Newfoundland and Atlantic Telegraph Companies, asked to be discharged from further consideration of the subject, also to be discharged from the consideration of TAL P. SHAFFNER'S Transatlantic Telegraph memorial;

The ship Courser, of Boston, which the foreign news announces lost on Prata Shoal, was 1,035 tons burden, built in Medford, Mass., in 1851, and rated A 1 1/2. She was in command of Capt. BERRY. The vessel was owned by WM. APPLETON Co., Boston, and with her cargo was valued at $300,000--fully insured in Boston and New-York.

The steamship Kangaroo, with four days' later advices from Europe, arrived at this port yesterday morning. Intelligence, taken out by the Arabia. of the outrage on the Mobile, off Key West, by the Styx, had reached England, but the London press makes no comment on the affair.

The proceedings in New-Orleans, violent and unjustifiable as they are, convey an important lesson. They show that the people have no confidence in their municipal Governnent. Such a state of things does not easily occur without some grave reason.

The House, to-day reelected Hon JOHN P. HALE United States Senator, giving him 189 votes, against 111 for JOHN S WELLS AND 7 scattering. CONCORD, Wednesday, June 9--P.M. The Senate Republican Caucus, this afternoon, nominated JOHN P. HALE for Senator. The vote on the nomination will be taken to morrow.

From the London Leader. The new act is severing marriages with a smoothness and rapidity that may alarm men of the old school. There have been about a dozen dissolutions of marriage already. But after looking carefully into the facts of all the cases, as reported in the papers, we can see no grounds for supporting that the divorces will be worse scandals than the illegitimate estrangements they succeed.

The undersigned, one of the members of the Special Committee appointed by the House of Representatives to investigate the circumstances connected with the sale and purchase by Government of a certain plot or parcel of land on Long Island, in the State of New York, commonly known as Wilkins' Point being unable to agree with the other members of the Committee, respectfully asks leave to present his views to the House.

The intelligence received at Boston, on Wednesday, firm St. Domingo, and published under the telegraphic head in this morning's TIMES, is of considerable importance. It appears that a civil war is raging. The Dominican Republic has two rival statesmen, SANTANA and BAEZ.

The City has been exulting for some months in the prospect of having a CENTRAL PARK, worthy of the City, and affording means of recreation and of health to the millions who will, ere long, inhabit this Island. The initial steps towards it were successful.

TROUBLE OF THE DEMOCRACY--A SPICY, TOUGH SLIGHTLY MALIGNANT LETTER.--Mr. STEPHEN D. DILLAYE, a prominent Democrat, formerly from the interior of this State, has lately been removed from the office of United States Appraiser in our Custom-House.
The proceedings of the morning hour were unimportant. The Indian Deficiency Bill was passed. The Post-Office Appropriation Bill was then taken up.

The receipts continue large, though they are less than last week. They embrace all the kinds of Lumber usually sold in this market, and the quantity on hand is heavy, with a good assortment. The demand continues active for Spruce and Hemlock, and these, with Chemung Boards, are in least supply, Prices have altered but little, though there is manifest considerable anxiety to sell, and for some kinds our quotations are merely nominal.

The proceedings in Congress yesterday will be found important. In the Senate, after the passage of the Indian Deficiency bill, the Post-Office Appropriation bill was taken up. On motion of Mr. JOHNSON, of Arkansas, it was voted, 19 to 15, to increase the rates of postage to five cents under 3,000 miles, arid ten cents over that distance. Twenty-nine members were absent.

THE BLASTING DISASTER IN THIRTY-SEVNTHSTREET.--To call the terrible disaster in Thirtyseventh-street, which was caused on Wednesday last by blasting rocks, an "accident," as some have done, is a shocking abuse of language. There was nothing accidental about it. The disaster appears to have been the result of the most reckless and stolid ignorance.

The Government has notified President MARTINIZ that the Yrissari Treaty will be insisted upon, notwilbstanding his refusal to sign the ratification, and that the transit will be protected by the Army and Navy, if necessary.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As a constant reader of your valuable paper, I have observed with pleasure your late congratulations over the supposed, abatement of along endured annoyance. I may truly say nuisance, to which all Sabbath-loing citizens of New-York have been many yers subjected, viz the crying of newsooys on that most sacred day.
THE WILLETT'S POINT AFFAIR.-- We publish, in another part of this morning's TIMES, the report of Mr. WOOD, of the Commitee appointed to investigate the sale of Willett's Point.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.- To night the opera of "Linda" will be played, with all the leading artists in the principal Poles. Mme. GAZZABIGA is, of course. the heroine, and the part is peculiarly adapted to her high dramatic talents.

THE CITY MULCTED--The City Court jury, in the case of Charles Thompson vs. The City of Brooklyn, rendered a verdict, yesterday, for plaintiff, awarding him $2,000 damages. The action was brought to recover damages for injury to plaintiff's business, through the negligence of the authorities, while constructing a sewer of Stenben-street, to drain the low lands known as Jackson's Hollow, in East Brooklyn.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: My brother, ABRAHAM MACK, of Cincinnati, with his family, consisting of his wife and six children, were among the passengers on the Cincinnati Express train at the time of the late disastrous accident at the Sacucit Creek Bridge, when two of his children were killed, and the rest more or less hurt, and he himself was seriously and perhaps permanently injured.

Our neighbors of the Sunday Press have suddenly discovered that the ringing of Church bells on Sunday is an intolerable nuisance. Tile Herald rings as many chmes on this subject as come pealing from an Old World Cathedral, albeit they are a little cracked and time-worn.

SWILL-MILK AS A MEDICINE--Mr. HUSTED, of Brooklyn, proprietor of the Skillman-street stables, and of a distillery in Myrtle-avenue, was examined before the stump-tail Committee on Thursday. He could hardly be regarded as a disinterested witness,

The Niagara is now fully prepared for her departure on an experimental trip. The purpose of this trip is to practice the payirg-out of the cable, test the power of the brakes, and experiment upon the availability of the new electrical machinery which has been introduced. Probably we should have dropped down to the lower harbor to-day, but for the uupleasant state of the weather.

Senator GWIN has challenged Senator WILSON, growing out of their colloquy last night in the Senate. On a former occasion, (in the Brooks affair,) it will be recollected that Mr. WILSON said he would not fight a duel, but would protect himself if attacked. This is his position now. Senators SEWARD and WADE are endeavoring to effect an adjustment.

A GRATUITOUS PIECE OF INFORMATION.--The Philadelphia Press favors its readers occasionally with a piece of very circumstantial and positive information in relation to the English politics, which none but persons intimately connected with the ministry could possibly know, and which such persons would not be likely to reveal.

The mission of M. BAILEY (BELLY) to Costa Rica and Nicaragua may be that of an authorized French GOVERNMENT Agent; but it is more probable that he is an employee of some company of French and German speculators in transit routes, which, in the old world and the new, have become subjects of an extensive and regular trace.

The journals of the week will give you a very fair notion of the incredible confusion in which the politicians of England are now twisting arid turning about, seeking vainly for some ray of light to lead them safely out of this year of transition into some intelligible future. But the journals are "journalistic," and that, you know, is quite another thing from "photographic."

THE YRISSAIRI TREATY TO BE INSISTED UPON. -It is said that our Government will regard the Cass-Yrissari Treaty as valid, notwithstanding the refusal of President MARTNEZ to sign it; and that the rights of transit specified in that instrument will be maintained by force if necessary.

WRONGS UPON SEAMEN--We understand that the Constellation will sail this morning for the Gulf. She takes out a large portion of her old crew, who shipped on the 30h of July, 1855, and whose term of service will consequently expire in two or three weeks. We have already alluded to this act of gross injustice committed upon poor Jack.

A MELANCHOLY OCCURRENCE.--The quiet and pleasant village of Feltville, N. J., has been the scene of a very sad accident . Two girls, ANNA H. GUEST and ELLEN McCAFFREY, employed in the factory, and each about 10 years of age, went into the upper lake, on Tuesday evening, the 8th inst., to bathe, when they were both drowned. They were unusually cheerful,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--There will be a matinee to-day when the "Traviata" will be played. In this beautiful ?? Madame GAZZA?IOA is seen and heard to the greatest advantage. BRIGNOLI, AMODIO and GASPARONI are also in the caste. Admission fifty cents to all parts of the house.

AN ALIEN WINDOW NOT ENTITLED TO DOWER.-Under the head of Law Intelligence, in a recent TIMES, mention was made of the case of Greer vs. Sankston et al., in which the Supreme Court of this district decided that the widow of SANKSTON had no right to dower in the lands of her husband.

THE WILLETT'S POINT INVESTIGATION.--We complete the history of this affair this morning by publishing the Report of Messrs HOPKINS and FLORENCE, who take substantially the same view of the case as Mr. WOOD, whose report we published yesterday.

Committees of Conference were appointed on the four appropriation bills, to amendments of which the House has disagreed. The Indian election cases were considered. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. WASHINGTON, Friday, June 11. Mr. HARRIS, of Illinois, moved to take up the Maryland contested election case of WRITE against Harris Negatived, 86 against 97.

THE LEMMON CASE IN THE CURT OF APPEALS -The case of JONATHAN LEMMON, appeliant us. The People of the state of New-York respondents. Case up this morning in the court of Appeals upon the application of counsel for its hearing as a preferred position of counsel for its hearing as a preferred cause.

THE MARINERS' FAMILY ASYLUM.--The anniversary of the Mariners' Family Asylum, on Staten Island, came off yesterday. This valuable Institution has been founded and is managed by a Committee of ladies. Its primary object is, to assist destitute families to help themselves,

Capt. FICKLIN, who left our camp last Fall, in charge of a scouting party, for the purpose of endeavoring to obtain from the Flathead Country,in Washington Territory, cattle, horses and mules, for the use of the command. returned on the 11th inst., without bringing any a animals except those which he used.

This reply is so inconsistent with Mr. COOPER'S character that I cannot doubt it was prepared by some other person who has abused his confidence by including him to put his name to it. HACK-DRIVERS TO WEAR BADGES--THREE HUNDRED THOUSAND DOLLARS APPROPRIATED FOR CENTRAL PARK--INTERESTING FROM THE STREET DEPARTMENT. The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The following message was received from the Mayor: MAYOR'S OFFICE: New-York, June 11, 1858. To the Honarable the Common Council:

Our correspondence from Fort Bridger, to which we devote a large portion of our available space, throws additional light upon the late important news received from Utah. The reception of Governor CUMMING in Salt Lake City appears to have been as respectful and loyal as any one could wish.

Both of the lines leading South were prostrated by the storm yesterday afternoon, and such reports of Congressional proceedings as we have been able to obtain, came via Peiladelphia, Pittsburg, Cleveland and Buffalo, traversing a distance of over a thousand miles, and are necessarily imperfect.

Intelligence has been received of another accident on the Lafayette and Indianapolis Railroad, by which the engineer and fireman were killed, but no passengers were seriously hurt. Particulars have not come to hand, but it is known that heavy floods had occurred, and some of the bridges had been swept away.

ESCAPE OF FOUR PRISONERS FROM BEDFORD COURT HOUGE-OERSOUS LEAP AND ESCAPE OF TWO OF THE FUGITIVE-Between 2 and 3 o'clock on Thursday afternoon four prisoners, confined in the court house at Bedford, Westchester County, worked their way through the ceiling of their cell to the roof, and jumped to the ground, a distance of 40 feet.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Your attention is earnestly solicited to bringing into notice the following state of facts, with some of its fearful consequences: ANTHONY DEY contracted to furnish scows to remove the contents of sinks, , which he has done for some two years or more; he now refuses to do so any more, unless paid for so doing.

THROWING AWAY THE MASK.--The attempt to stop the newsboys from shouting on Sunday has had one effect which might perhaps have been anticipated. It has converted the whole tribe of Sunday newspapers into open, rancorous assailants of Religion and the Church.

FRIDAY'S PROCEEDINGS CONCLUDED. Mr. YULEE, of Florida, from-the Committee on Post-Offices and Post-Roads, to which was referred the memorial of the trustees of A. G. SLoo, contractor for carrying the mail between New-York, New-Orleans, Havana and Chagres, for additional compensation for extra mail facilities on that route, reported a bill for the relief of the trustees of A. G. SLoo.

THE CROMWELL MURDER MYSTERY IN CONNECTICUT.--This case is getting into an extraordinary sparl. The offer of $100 by certain citizens of Rocky sill, Conn., for the proof that the young man ?? is full alive, was noticed a day or two ago. The Hartford Times adds that "BENBON, the perjured witness, has just been tried at Haddam for perjury, and found guilty.

SIR : I arrived here safely to-day for coal. All well on board. I leave to-morrow for Havana, where I shall find H.B.M. steamer Devastation, which has brought instructions from admiral SEYMOUR to the cruisers upon the coast of Cuba. H.B.M. steam gunboat Jasper, commanded by Lieutenant WILLIAM H. PYM. Came into this harbor this morning in search of the Styx, to deliver dispatches from the Admiral.

LAURA KEFNR'S THEATRE,-An article appeared in our issue of last Friday, detailing certain parttculars disclosing the cause of the sudden and untimely closing of LAURA KEENE'S Theatre under the management of Mr. SOTHERN. The story we gave was based necessarily on the rumors of the moment, which have been utterly without foundation.

The Collegiate Dutch Church are now gathering the fruits of their harvest. The Clergy, the Revs, Dr. DE WITT, VERMILYE AND CHAMBERS, met the Consistory at the Church corner of Lafayette-place, on Wednesday night. Twenty-four persons were examined and approved, among whom persons from 13 to 60 years of age.

The U. S. Mail Steamship Star of the West. with the California mails of May 20, and $1,446,175 in treasure, arrived at this port on Saturday morning. We have no news of any special importance from California. Agricultural and mining reports are both encouraging.

A New Way to recover Stolen Goods--Thirty Thefts by a Model Servant Girl. Saturday evening last, Officer WILSON, of the Third Precinct, arrested a girl named MARGARET NOLAN, alias MARGARET HOLLAHAN, on complaint of ELLEN COLLINS, NO. 57 Washington-street, New-York, for larceny.

Eighty-two seamen, 20 ordinary seamen, 6 landsmen and 8 boys-total 116--were detailed from the North Carolina, on Friday and Saturday, to the sloop Constellation,, to make, to make up for discharges of seamen whose time had expired, and for desertions. Fourteen altogether have absented themselves while ashore on Liberty. The penalty for desertion is a forfeiture

EMBEZZLEMENT.--FREDERICK BECHT was brought from Albany, on Saturday, by Officer SHANGLE of the detective police, who had arrested him on charge of embezzlement, the complainant being JOHN KRAYMER, city contractor, residing at No. 784 Third-avenue.

ACCIDENT ON THE ERIE RAILROAD.--Shortly after 10 o'clock, on Saturday evening, as the mail train of the Erie Railroad was passing through Bergen cut, about three miles from Jersey City, on its way to the ??, an accident occurred which occasioned a slight detention. The rain had washed away the earth from under one length of the rail; the locomotive passed over this safety, but the tender sank down and stuck fast.

THE STORM.--A series of heavy thunder showers, which succeeded the exceedingly warm weather of Friday morning, settled finally into a steady rain, which lasted all day Saturday. What was peculiar and almost unprecedented about the storm was the fact that the wind during the showers suddenly veered around to the east, and continued to come from that quarter until yesterday,--an unsettled, cloudy day,--when the storm had ceased and the wind was in the northwest.

The rejection of the Treaty for securing the Nicaragua Transit in American hands, through the exceedingly active operations of M. BELLY, has produced a very vivid impression upon Mr. BUCHANAN and the State Department. Instructions were sent by the

THE CASS-HERRAN TRKATY---Recent advices from Bogota render it probable that New-Granada may yet ratify the Cas Herran treaty without any substantial alterations. Strong efforts are making by President OSPINA and other enlighted public men at Bogota to induce the legislative body to forego its objections, and with a fair prospect of success.

Important from Mexico. A LOAN IMPOSED ON FOREIGNERS-- GLOOMY CONDITION OF AFFAIRS--DEFEAT OF THE ZULOAGA FORCES--SUPPRESSION OF THE NEWSPAPERS, ETC. The steamship Tennessee has arrived from Vera Citiz 7th instant, with important news from Mexico.

Inquiry in the British House of Commons Relative to the Late Agressions--Amicable declarations of the Government--Sailing of the Atlantic Telegraph Fleet--Important from India. [The following appeared in a portion of our morning edition of Saturday.] ST. JOHN, N. F, Friday, June 11.

ILLINOIS.--The Buchanan State Convention met at Springfield on the 9th inst. Hun. JOHN ?? of Union County, who presided, was put in nomination for the office of State Treasurer, and Ex-Governor REYNOLDS received the nomination for the Superintendency of Public Instruction.

It appears that some three weeks since Mr. SHAFFER commenced to suffer from an intense neuralgic affection, involving the teeth, face and sympathetically the whole nervous system, so as to depive him o sleep, and produce the most intense physical sufferin, during which time he has been under the treatment of Dr. PARSONS as his physician.

I have recently visited the neighborhood of the late murders in Linn County, and find the whole country under arms. All work and other business is suspended for the protection of life. Both night and day are they in service, and they have not seen a night of quiet sleep for two weeks.

A market ought to be as clean as a church, for at the best, when in use, it is not a place to tempt one for delicious odors, nor per se is it a lovely place for promenade. To enjoy a stroll through stalls of dead meats, past tables set with lard and dubious butter, tubs of tripe and slaes of fish that Ethiotans are dressing, is rather a matter of education than of instruct.

SENATORIAL EPITHETS.--When members of Congress begin to call each other thieves, it is time for the Session to close. The difficulty in the Senate, on Thursday, between Mr. WILSON and Mr. GWIN, was the coarsest which has yet occurred, and can be regarded only with disgust. It is even below the standard of pothouse brawls.

ALLEGED RAPE ON A CHILD.--A beastly outrage took place last evening in the Fifth Ward. A little colored girl, named Emma Black, about 11 years of age, was returning to her house, No. 23 grand-street, about 10 1/2 o'clock, when three young men met her, and one of then gagged her month while the other two carried her to a lumber yard in West-street near Canal, and all three in succession violated her person.

Our dispatches by the Nova Scolian bring news of the death of Sir WILLIAM PEEL, at Cawnpore, on the 27th of April. Sir WILLIAM was young, but had seen much active and perilous service. He was the third son of the late Sir ROBERT PEEL and ?orother of the present Baronet. He was born in 1824,

The revelations of Saturday in the Cangemi case were edifying. One of the principal witnesses against the prisoner swore that since the prisoner's trial two men had offered him $2,500 to leave the country-that one of these men was now the prisoner's counsel, and the other was on the Jury !

The Cbairman of the Committee of. Ways and Means states that the five million increase of the Loan bill was on account of extra appropriations mace by Congress. In fact, Congress has cut down the regular estimates considerably more than this increase.

WISCONSIN MORTGAGE LAW.--The Legislature of Wisconsin, at its recent session, had recourse to a species of legislation that is apt to be popular at the West in times of pecuniary hardship. It passed a stay law, which was approved by the Governor on the 15th of May.

The annual exercises at West Point were diversified on Friday by an address to the Cadets from a member of the Board of Visitors, Mr. MCCREERY, of Kentucky. That gentleman, it appears, is now making his first visit to the East. and frankly acknowledged, in opening his speech, that his position was new enough to be very embarrassing.
DESCENTS UPON DISORDERLY HOUSES.--The public is edified about once a week by flaming reports of a police descent upon some disorderly house. Sundry members of the Police are detailed for this duty.

The Mormon war is over, and although the fanatical clan show small symptoms of cordial submission to the law and authority of the Federal Government, they are effectually broken up, and will scarcely be able for many years to renew the compact strength and formidable position from which they have just been driven.

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West, A. G. GRAY, Esq., commanding, from Aspinwall on the 3d of June, with the California mails of May 20, and $1,446,175 in treasure, arrived at this port on Saturday morning. The Pacific Mail Steamship Company's steamer John L. Stephens, W. F. LAPIDGE, Esq., Commander, arrived at Panama, from San Francisco, June 3, at 10 A.M. Found the port of Manzanilla blockaded by Mexican ships-of-war.

Dispatches have been received by Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT from Gen. JOHNSTON, Commander of the Utah Army, five days later than those from Gov. CUMMING, which throw a doubt on the sincerity of the Mormons in their peaceful professions.

General JOHNSTON seems not to be convinced of the peaceful intentions of the Mormons. His dispatches seem to be of a very different tenor from those of Governor CUMMING. He informs General SCOTT that instead of surrendering, the Mormons are fortifying themselves at every point ;-that instead of submitting quietly to the federal rule, they are prepared to give battle to the troops, and are still determined to resist their entrance at every hazard.

The Hargous, La Sere and Benjamin Tehuantepec Company any have made the discovery that getting the contract to carry the mails across the Isthmus is very far from a triumphant termination of the war between them and SLOO, the latter having possession and ownership of the road over which they have agreed to carry.

The Senate met at 11 o'clock. Several unimportant reports were made and bills introduced. A resolution was received from the House that Congress adjourn at 2 1/2 to-day which the Senate amended by substituting noon, to-morrow, to which the House does not agree, but insists on 6 o'clock to night.

THE NEW-YORK LEDGER AND ITS EDITOR.-Mr. BONNER, of the New-York Ledger, is indeed a prodigy among editors. in his own way he is supreme, and his way is a very great way. he has astonished the country by the munificence and the magnificence of his expenditure in the advertising of his Ledger.

The United States steamers Water Watch and Fuiton arrived off this port on the morning of the 5th buy only the former entered to communicate without consul and the Captain-General. Commander RODGERS called on His Excellency, General CONCHA, and after the usual complimentary greeting, the conversation naturally turned upon the recent outrages committed on the American and Spanish flags by the British cruisers that were sent out exclusively to capture slavers.

THE CITY DEMOCRACY.-Collector SCHELL'S confirmation gives a decided triumph to the wing of the Democracy with which he has always acted. It is considered a very favorable omen for the movement which aims at making Ex-Senator DICKINSON the Presidential candidate in 1860. It is rumored from Washington,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A communication which appeared in your paper of this morning, under the head of " A City Scene," reminds me of a sight which I witnessed in the upper part of your City last Saturday, P.M., the equal to which, for gross indelicacy and brutality, on the part of City officials, I have never witnessed or even heard of in this or the Old World.

UNLIMITED EXPENDITURES.-In the Appropriation bill, which war rushed through Congress on Saturday evening, were certain sums " for the completion of certain Custon-Houses" with the very remarkable proviso that " except in the cases of New-Orleans and Charleston the money shall not be expended until it shall have been ascertained whether it will be sufficient to complete the works for which it has been appropriated."

General SCOTT is in the receipt of dispatches from General JOHNSTON, dated at Camp Scott, and five days later than those from Governor CUMMING, though sent by the same express. General JOHNSTON arrives at conclusions directly opposite to those of Governor CUMMING, touching the intention of the Mormons, who, he says, are now arming and fortifying at every point.

A dispatch from Leavenworth dated 11th inst., by express to Booneville, says that the sixth column of troops will not march until to-morrow, the 12th inst. Gen. BAKNEY and staff with an escort of forty-five men of the Seventh Infantry, under Capt. M. LAWS, leave the day following, a diversion from the dates already fixed for their denarture, owing to the heavy rains which have occurred there and fresheis in all the small streams.

The accounts from Europe by the mail represent the state of affairs there as still being anything but settled or assuring. LOUIS NAPOLEON'S difficulties, far from being settled, seem to be still on the increase, and the cloud that has arisen between England and Naples, though now no bigger than a man's hand, is one that may end in a tornado.

From the New-Orleans See, 7th. Rumors of an attack by the Vigilants upon the City Hall position (Fort Defiance) kept a considerable force under arms there until after daylight yesterday. while every avenue of approach to the spot was most strictly guarded and a number of persons passing that way were arrested as suspected vigilants.

Congress has adjourned at last. The Senate were obliged to recede from all their amendments to the Post-Office Appropriation bill. as the House resolved not to submit to any further Senate legislation. The Senate has usurped more legislative power during the session just passed than ever before.

ONE NEIGHBOR MEXICO.--The country next South of as is certainly in a condition as deplorable as can well be imagined. ZULOAGA continues to sustain himself, in some sort, at the capital; but from the expedients to which he is driven he must be near the end of his rope.

The steamship Pennsylvania exploded her boilers on Sunday morning, at 6 o'clock, at Ship Island, some seventh-five miles below this City, and was burned to the water's edge. There were 350 passeagers onboard, and it is believed that 100 of them were killed or are missing. The Diana Imperial and Rate Frisbee took all they could find on the water on shore. Dispatches from Cairo state that on Saturday afternoon a crevasse opened on the Mississippi side of the town, through which the water poured at a fearful rate, filling up the whole space between the levees, and it is now running over the embankment on the Ohio side about a thousand feet.

WEST POINT GRADUATES.-Cadets at West Point are appointed on the equitable principle of Congressional representation, so that every section of the country is insured its just portion of appointments in our great National University; but, in graduating, the still better principle of personal merit is solely attended to, so that the talent of the country, irrespective of sectional considerations, is represented in the army. This is precisely as it should be,

THE BRITISH OUTRAGES.-The excitement about the British outrages has entirely sub sided. From every quarter come evidences that the reports have been exaggerated, and that, so far as any aggressions upon our flag have been committed, they have been in violation or excess of instructions, and will be promptly disavowd by the British Government.

HENRY DWIGHT HELD ON THE CHARGE OF PERJURY.-The arrest of HENRY DWIGHT, on the 11th of May, upon six warrants, was mentioned in this paper at the time. The warrants alleged various acts of perjury, embezzlement and fraud. They were issued by the Hon. A.D. RUSSELL, City Judge, upon affidavits by S. M. BLATCHFORD, SEADURY BREWSTER and STEWART BROWN.

ENCOUNTER WITH A DESPERATE CUSTOMER--STEALING LIVE TURKEYS.--About 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, officer Bates, of the Twellth Ward, encountered a man coming over the bridge this side of Mott-Haven, with two live turkeys in his possession The officer commenced questioning the stranger about the turkeys, when the man suddenly released his hold of them and started on a run over the bridge.

ESCAPE OF A THIEF FROM AN OFFICER.--At a late hour Sunday evening, as Officer Roberts, of the Eighth Ward, was passing through Greenwich street, dear Canal, he saw two fellows, named Bryan Bradv and William Dugan. whom he recognized as thieves, carrying between them it basket.

THE TRACT SOCIETY--FOR AND AGAINST.--The South Carolina branch of the American Tract Society has held a meeting since the anniversary of the parent Society here, to indorse the measures of the Executive Committee.

Seventy-Second Birthday of General Scott--The Boston Light Infantry and the National Guard ?? at the Astor House-- Twenty-fifth Anniversary of the City Guard. The Seventy-second anniversary of the birth of General SCOTT was duly celebrated yesterday.

THE BIBLE IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS.-The citizens of the Seventeenth Ward assembled in large force at the Norfolk-street Methodist Church last evening to express their sentiments in regard to the expulsion of the Bible from the Public Schools. JOHN R. BIGELOW M. D., was chosen President by acclamation, WM. A. SMALLEY and J. P. COOPER were elected Secretaries,and allong list of Vice Presidents was read.

IN STONE-STREET.--Between 12 and 1 O'clock A. M. yesterday, a fire broke our on the fourth floor of No. 16 Stone street, occupied by MATHEW LANE CO, book binders and stationers. They estimate their damages at $700, which is covered by insurance. The second and third floors were occupied as offices which were considerable damaged by water.

The steamer Imperial first arrived at the wreck of the Pennsylvania, and took a large number of passengers to New-Orleans. The Diana arrived here at 11 o'clock, on Sunday night, with a large number for Louisville. A meeting of citizens has raised $1,000 for the suf ferers, ana committees were appointed to collect further aid.

WHOLESALE SWINDLING.-The following correspondence sufficiently explains itself. His Honor the Mayor has instituted inquiries at the place indicated, No. 202 Fulton-street, where the imposter is not known even by name. The proper officers were promptly placed on the track, when it was found that numbers of letters had been taken from the Postoffice in this City, and handed to a suspicious individual in the street who was instantly arrested.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Among the numerous laws by which we are, or ought to be governed, there are some good, some defective, some paltry, some ridiculous; but whatever the intrinsic merit of the law, it is right that is appointed guardians should see to its being obeyed.

The interest which has attached to Kansas for some years past seems to have in no degree abated. This "distracted Territory" still continues to be the apple of discord over which statesmen and politicians wrangle, and the chief object of political interest to the whole country.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I presume the columns of an independent journal are open to both sides of every question in which the public are supposed to be interested. Therefore I desire, with your approbation, to occupy a portion of your space as follows: A dispatch appeared in this morning's TIMES, from Washington, purporting thus:

END OF THE BRITISH OUTRAGES.-It may be very gratifying, but it is certainly a little mortifying, to see with what provoking coolness and common sense John Bull treats our boisterous complaints about his visiting our ships. After the splendid and heroical passion we had worked ourselves into, it is rather humiliating to be " letdown " so quietly.

ANOTHER CASE OF OFFICIAL CORRUPTION-- The Select Committee appointed by the Iowa House of Representatives, to investigate the charge of fraud in the location of the State Capital at Des Monies, has made a report. The evidence shows that the Commissioners received, as a personal and private bribe, upwards of $50,000 worth of property.

At Walworth, N. Y., last week, Mrs. GANNETT drank strychnine. Cause--aberration, resulting from ill health. At Bullville, Orange County, N.Y., a few days ago, a young lady named Nuck took arsenic. Cause--desertion by her lover.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I observe that you and your brother chips are greatly exercised, just now, upon the subjects of swillmilk and squealing newsboys, and I think the occasion is a fitting one to draw your attention to a nuisance which has a sort of connection with both the others.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I regret to see in your paper of this morning one or two articles of rather loose censure, which I think a newspaper of high standing should not en courage. The public does quite enough already in that line.

We have bad our share of the storms which belong to the country and the season. For several days preceding the 11th, arid down to the close of that day, the weather was sultry as August, with scorching sun, high winds, and clouds of dust.

The proclamation of the President convening the extraordinary session was read, and a committee appointed (Messrs. ALLEN and SEWARD) to inform the President that a quorum is assembled, and the Senate is ready to receive any communication he may be pleased to make. Mr. A1LEN subsequently reported that they had performed that duly.

WHAT PARTY REQUIRES OF THE PRESS.--The Chicago Tribune--a prominent Republican journal--experiences a sensation of "gratitude to Providence" that it can at least speak its mind freely of General JIM LANE, on Kansas; and says the reason why it could never do so before was its fear that " a righteous cause would suffer by the exposure of a vagabond."

THE AFFAIR AT THE NEW-YORK HOTEL.--NO arrests have yet been made in the matter of the assault at the New-York Hotel on Monday night, when a distinguished literary character was severely beaten by a distinguished fillibuster. The disturbance grew out of what was deemed an unwarrantable interference on the part of the literary gentleman with the exhibition of some tricks with cards by a third party.

The War Department laid Gen. JOHNSTON'S dis-. patches before the Cabinet to-day. The President is much perplexed by the contradiction these dispatches give to those received from Gov. CUMMING, and expresses his regret at what he now considers his premaure message to Congress, announcing the end of the Mormon Rebellion.

The Boston "Tigers" roared us yesterday their fareweil. May their parting be a brief one. May the reunion be speedy. May we meet them in the jungles of Broadway soon again ! At the invitation of Mr. STETSON, of the Astor House. the " Tigers" repaired thither yesterday morning to partake of breakfast. In the afternoon,

DOWNER, of the ship Stephen Baldwin, has received from the Department of State the following reply to an inquiry which he had addressed to Mr. secretary CLASS: DEPARTMENT OF STATE,, WASHINGTON, June 1, 1858, SIR: I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ult., inquiring whether an English man-of-war has the right to compel an American vessel to heave to and examine her papers.

By the arrival of the Arago at this port and the Europa at Halifax we receive important news from Europe. The recent aggressions committed by British cruisers upon American vessels in the Gulf of Mexico had attracted considerable attention in Parliament. The replies of the Government representatives to the questions propounded to them, must be considered, so far, as satis factory.

THE PERMANENT EMPLOYMENT OF THE LEVIATHAN.-The company that have the misfortune to be the owners of the monster steamer Leviathan have determined, it seems, that " she shall be permanently employed in the traffic between England and America," nothing more being necessary to her completion than the trifling sum of a million of dollars.

The Debate in the Senate Yesterday. Mr. MASON called up the resolutions heretofore reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations, in regard to the question of British aggressions. It seemed to him a matter of moment that the judgment of the Senate should be passed upon them, because of the probable beating they may have on any negotiation now pending.

Colonel THOMAS L. KANE, from Camp Scott May 16, passed Booneville this evening. He reports Governor CUMMING having returned to Salt Lake City, after making an ineffectual attempt to stop the Mormon hegira t the South.

A horrible murder was committed on Tuesday in the town of Mill River Point, Macomb County, near the line of this county. It appears that two brothers and a sister were living in that town. They were French. The sister was the housekeeper of the brothers.

CAIRO IN DANGER OF BEING ENTIRELY AWAY--MOUND CITY UNDER WATER. CENTRALIA, Ill., Monday, June 14. Reports from Cairo are of a most alarming character. The water is still rising, and is now running over the Ohio levee in several places. Mr. ASHLEY, Chief Engineer of the Illinois Central Railroad, gives -the opinion that one foot more rise wilt sweep Cairo entitely away.

CHARLES SEYMOUR, who, with "Sailor Dan," escaped from Sing Sing Prison a few days since, was captured about 6 1/2 o'clock last evening, by the crew of River Police-boat No. 4, at Red Hook, Brooklyn. CITY POST-OFFICES -- The Attorney-General of the United States has given an opinion to the effect that private letter-deliveries in cities are illegal, as they conflict with the exclusive functions of the Post-Office Department. If this ground is taken, the Government is in duty bound to establish a thorough and efficient system for delivering City letters, and to inform the public how they can make use of it. To the Senate and House of Representatives: I feel it to be an indispensable duty to call your attention to the condition of the Treasury. On the 19th day of May last the Secretary of the Treasury submitted a report to Congress " on the present condition of the finances of the Government."

THE FRACAS BETWEEN GRUND AND SCHADE AT CHICAGO.--The Cincinnati Press gives the following account of this affair, previously alluded to: " FRANCIS J. GRUND has various commissions to execute in this State, one of which is to start an organ to supersede that of Col. DIVERSEY.

From the Troy Budget, 14th. No little excitement was created yesterday by the elopement of a female from Albany with her paramour; the following of the guilty parties of this city by the husband of the woman, and the circumstances attending the capture of the child, which the mother had taken along with her.

CUIP--In this City, on Monday morning, Jane 14, THEophilus CULP, aged 41 years. His relatives and friends, and these of the family. also the friends of the firm of Clark, Wilson Co.. of which he was a member, are invited to attend his funeral, with out further notice. from his late residence, No. 156 East 11th st. this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock.

FIRE IN ROCK ISLAND, ILL. ROCK ISLAND, Tuesday, June 15. A brick block on Washington and Illinois streets, occupied as liquor stores, was destroyed by fire this morning. The loss on the building and goods exceeds $30,000, and there is insurance to the amount of $15,000.

The Steamship Arogo, from Southampton on the 2d of June, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The R. M. steamship Europa, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the afternoon of the 5th inst., arrived at Halifax at 12 1/2 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, bringing three days later news than the Arags.

The annual gathering of Baptists in Connecticut took place on the 9th, 10th, and 11th of this month in the pleasant village of Southington. One hundred and seventeen churches belong to the Connecticut Baptist Convention, in which there are about nineteen thousand communicants.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. A communication was received from James W. Wallack, in consequence of his having been assessed as worth $20,000. He states that he is not worth anything over and above what would meet his indebtedness.

Last evening the members of the Republican Central and Young Men's Committees met at No. 618 Broadway, for the purpose of receiving and entertaining the members of Congress who have arrived in this City on a temporary sojourn, previous to their departure for their respective residences. Mr. JOHN A. KENNBDY presided. A considerable delay occurred between the hour announced and that at which the proceedings commenced. So un eason.

It is just thirty years since a double sensation was created in the literary world by the nearly simultaneous appearance of two brilliant works of fiction, which, though published anonymously, were hailed as the first fruits of two new children of genius who were to be the successors of BYRON and SCOTT in furnishing amusement for English readers.

The action of the General Assembly, recently convened at Chicago, in the case of the Rev. JAMES H. SHIELDS, of Iowa, has attracted much attention, on account of the civil and ecclesiastical laws, supposed to be involved in the decision of the Assembly. Only partial reports of the facts of the case, and of the minute of the Assembly, have been published in the Eastern secular journals.

SEDUCTION.--Miss CAROLINE HALLER, in the City Court, yesterday, obtained a verdict of 2,000 against CHARLES BALANDER, for seduction under promise of marriage. MILITARY.--The 14th Regiment, Colonel WOOD paraded yesterday and were reviewed by Mayor POWELL. The regiment made a very creditable ap. pearance.

In 1843, a number of gentlemen, impressed with a sense of the important results following the researches in Assyrian Phoenician Sanskrit and Chinese literature, formed themselves into an association for the systematic prosecution of these studies, and obtained an act of incorporation from the Legislature of Massachusetts under the title of the "American Oriental Society." The promised speech of the Hon. FREDERICK P. STANTON, in opposition to the English bill, was delivered here this evening, before a large and very attentive audience. Mr. STANTON began his speech by calling the attention of his hearers to the fact that the 2d of August next would decide the question of the rejection or acceptance of the Leconnpton Constitution.

Return of Governor Cumming to Camp Scoit--Everything Quiet in the Mormon Capital--No News of Captain Marcy, ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, June 16. A dispatch dated Leavenworth, the 13th int. brought by United Stated Express to Booneville, says that two gentlemen, named MOLSEN and NIOKEHSON, arrived there last night, in 20 days form Camp Scott. They left Fort Bridger on the 14th of May, eight days subsequent to the last Express.

The Weather has been fine since Saturday, but the river is still rising. The water in the channel now measures 41 feet. All the railways are in order. CINCINNATI, Wednesday, June 16. The river still continues to rise,. The water in the channel now measures 44 feet. Weather fine. Thermometer 76 [degree].

BRITISH AGGRESIONS--UNANIMOUS ADOPTION OF MR. MASON'S RESOLUTIONS-ADJOURNMENT OF THE SENATE.-The Senate closed its special session yesterday. Previous to the adjournment the resolutions relative to the British aggressions, reported some time since from the Committee on Foreign Relations, were taken-up and adopted by an unanimous vote.

Our respected and venerable United States Consul, Colonel ROBERT MONROE HARRISON, died at this place yesterday, aged 80 years. Col. HARRISON was a cousin of your late President of that name, was born in Virginia in 1768. He was appointed to the navy by WASHINGTON, and the date of commission was the same as that of Commodore RODGERS. He was the friend and associate of TRUX.

WORKING THE TELEGRAPHIC CABLE.--A private better received from a practical telegrapher, who witnessed, on the 29th ult., at Plymouth, the formal tests of the electricians in telegraphing through the entire Length of the Atlantic Cable, states that Professor HUGHES, with his wonderful Printing Telegraph machines, was able to write through the 3,000 miles of cable at the rate of thirty two letters per minute.

A letter in the Newark Daily gives some interesting statements concerning American artists abroad, Powers' collossal statue of Daniel Webster, recently lost on the voyage to Boston, is now in course of reproduction from the original model. The process will require another twelvemonth. Mr. ?? memorial of Mr. Clay, for the ladies of Virginia, is in progress, and will probably be completed during the year.

No dispassionate person, whatever his political partialities, can fail to see that the various enterprises undertaken by Mr. BUCHANAN do not seem to prosper in his hands. He has meddled in nothing, suggested nothing, entered upon nothing, since he entered the White House, which has not ended in confusion worse confounded.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The reproduction of Linda last night, in obedience to the generally-expressed desire of a public which found itself unexpectedly drowned out in the drenching rain of Friday, gave intense satisfaction to a large and amiable audience. The performance was excellent. Mad. GAZZANIGA was a captivating Linda, and achieved a fresh triumph. Signor BRIGNOLI performed his part

The Board held a regular meeting list evening, at the Hall, on Grand-street, the President in the Chair. The sum of $2.500 was appropriated to furnish a school-house on Forty-fourth-street, in the Twentysecond Ward, with warming and ventilating apparatus.

The Pacific Mail contract was extended to-day one bear from the 1st of October next, at $340,000 per annum. The Mail contract with the Le Sere and Benjamin Tehuantepec Company for one year was signed ten days ago, but was suspended until the production of two sureties. The pay is to be $285,000. The principal partners will go to New-York to-morrow to raise $150.000 on this contract.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I noticed in the TIMES of the 8th inst. an article headed, "A Short Lecture to our Judges upon the Improvement of their Time," and signed " Humphrey." Who or what " Humphrey" is I know not, but he certainly does not understand what he is lecturing about.

TROUBLE IN THE DUDLEY OBSERVATORY.--There is trouble at the new Dudley Observatory at Albany. Dr. B. A. GOULD, Jr., a young gentleman from Cambridge, who was appointed to the Directorship of the Observatory, has been virtually requested to resign, in consequence of his inability to agree with the Trustees. The Board of Trustees consists of THOS.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The reports for and against the decision of the Fire Commissioners, disbanding Engine Company, No. 5, were called up and debated at great length, on a proposition to refer the subject back to the Commissioner. The proposition to refer back was finally referred back to the Fire Commissioners.

The U. S. mail steamship Vanderbitt, Capt. HIGGINS, which left Havre on the morning, and Cowes at at 12 minutes past 7 o'clock on the evening of Wednesday, the 9th inst., was boarded off Cape Race yesterday (Wednesday) morning, at 5 o'clock.

NEWS FROM EUROPE IN SEVEN DAYS AND A HALF.--Captain HIGGINS, of the steamship Vanderbilt, delivered European advices to the news-yacht of the Associated Press, off Cape Race, in seven days and ten hours, and the news was placed upon the wires in less than six days and twenty hours from Southampton.

One Mr. BABCOCK has recovered the sum of $20 from Mr. RAYMOND, publisher of the NEW YORK TIMES, for a communication furnished to that paper, and published in September, 1856, giving statistics showing the great popularity of Col. FBEMONT.Washington Union. We beg to assure the Union that Mr. BABCOCk has done no such thing. He sued for that amount and was non-suited in a Justice's Court.

A Buchanan Convention at St. Louis, last week, nominated Mr. JAMES B. EADS for a seat in the Legislature. That gentleman having supported Buchanan for President, it was imagined he would stand the Domination; but it turns out that Mr. EADS is a free-labor man, and therefore opposed to the principles of this party.

Their claim, we are told by those who have been in the office for years, is a little ahead of anything ever received even in that department.

THE BATAVIA RAILROAD TROUBLES--THE CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY DEFEATED.--The Court o Appeals has dismissed, with costs, the two appeals taken by the New-York Central Railroad Company, from orders of Supreme Court, appointing Company, sions of appraisal, and from the order confirming their approval on the ground that the Court of Appeals had no jurisdiction of the matter.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: The cost of the Central Park will exceed that of any single Park in the World. It is to be paid for by the industry and labor and profits on the commerce of the City, but principally by the laboring classes of our community. The appropriations are levied chiefly upon the real estate of the City, and that is made valuable by the tenants, the working classes.

MARCY was on the -Cherokee trail, two hundred miles from Fort Bridger Colonel HOFFMAN had reached Big Sandy Creek seventy-eight miles from Fort Bridger.

LAWRENCE,--In this City, on Thursday. June 17. EMMA LOUISE, daughter of Wm. P. and Sarah L. Lawrence, aged 5 years and 9 days. The friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, at 10 1/2 o'clock this (Friday) morning, from the residence of her parents, No. 751 Greenwich st. Her remains will be taken to Yonkers for interment.

A COMPLMENT DECLINED.-A few days ago the New-York Herald, in floundering attempt to excuse the extravagant expenditures of the Buchanan Administration, and the large National debt which it is accumulating, conceived the happy idea of carrying back the blame to previous Presidents.

The " reorganization " movement, set on foot by by Republicans and Americans, in Erie County, will soon, it is now understood, be seconded in several other counties, with the view of making it general throughout the State. The squabble which certain journals, here and elsewhere, are having over the abstract point whether one name or another shall be given to it, is likely to have no visible effect on the movement itself.

The Ocean Postage bill, passed just at the close of the late session of Congress, introduces a radical change into the mail service between New-York and European ports. The new law abrogates the long contract system, and establishes in its place a plan of compensation based entirely upon the receipts of sea and inland postage.

Our curiosity respecting the mysterious movements of M. FELIX BELLY in Central America, and his influence over the Executives of Nicaragua and Costa Rica, has been at length gratified, though we have received our information of the nature and success of his mission from a rather unexpected quarter.

VIRGINIA OYSTERS IN PERIL FROM YANKEE ENTERPRISE.--The Richmond Enquirer makes the following melancholy statement: A gentleman from Isle of Wight informs us that opposition to the oyster-tax has, to a very great extent. abaled throughout that portion of tide-water.

RAILROAD MISMANAGEMENT.-It is really astonishing that Railroad Stocks have any market value whatever. The recklessness with which the roads are managed, the disregard of the interests of stockholders which is evinced, and the ruinous policy which is frequently adopted for the purpose of gratifying the feelings, or promoting some incidental interest of leading Directors, continue to render them anything but safe and reliable investments.

Rev. Dr. McLeod, of this City, has been appointed Professor of Systematic and Practical Theology in the Reformed Presbyterian Theological Seminary at Philadelphia. Rev. Dr. Black, of Pittsburg, is appointed to the Chair of Blolical Literature in the same institution. The Hon. Nathan Clifford, the new United States Judge, made his first appearance on the Bench in Bostonton Wednesday.

Trial of Palrick Lally for the Murder of George H. Simonson. The Verdict--Manalaughter in the Second Degree. FOURTH DAY. KINGS COUNTY COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER-JUNE 17. Before Hon. Selah B. Strong, Judge, and Justices Schoonmaker and Emmous.

A GOVERNOR IN QUEST OF HIS SUBJECTS.When Governor CUMMING, of Utah, was last heard from he was in full pursuit of the Mormons, with very poor prospects of success. They had gone South, leaving His Excellency to reign over deserted fields and empty houses. Not relishing this sort of dominion, the Governor started in pursuit of the runaway peo. pie, hoping to bring them back to enjoy the blessings of his paternal sway.

A WRIT OF ERROR DENIED IN A MURDERCASE -One ISAAC L. WOOD was recently convicted at Geneseo, Livingston County, of murdering his sister-in-law, Mrs. RHODA WOOD, by poison. He had been previously tried for that offence, when the jury failed to render a verdict owing to the unaccountable recusancy of a single juror.

STRIKE OF LOWELL OPERATIVES.--A large number of the operatives at Lawrence Mills, in Lowell. were on a strike yesterday, and threatened violence to those who continued work. The difficulty arose from some changes, whereby the spinners are required to do the additional work of doffing. About 100 marched out in a body, and others followed their examdle. From the Washington Union. Instead of receiving a cordial support, no Administration has ever had to withstand so many assaults from an opposition House than the present Democratic Administration has had to withstand from a Democratic House ; and it is a remarkable fact that every assault that has been made upon the Administration by the present Congress, though seconded, of course, by the opposition, has been instigated, directed and stimulated by Democratic members .

The mails by the Cunard steamer Europa reached this City yesterday afternoon. Our files from London and Liverpool, by this arrival, are to the 5th of June inclusive. The most interesting feature of the news will be found in the extracts from English papers, given below, on the recent proceedings of their cruisers in the Gulf of Mexico. The English press is unanimous in disavowing the aggressions committed on American commerce.

CLOSING EXERCISES AT VANNORMAN'S FAMALE INSTITUTE.--The drawing-rooms of the Rev. D. C. VAN NORMAN'S Institute for the education of young ladies, No. 79 East Fourteenth-street, was filled with the pupils, their parents and friends, yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock.

" HAVE THE BODY."--The writ of habeas corpus is a good thing when really required and properly used. It has relieved many a poor fellow from illegal duress, and checked full off the lard course of oppression. Occasionally, too, a runaway slave has found it his only means of escape from the grasp of his pursuers.

THE NEW STEAM SL0OPS-OF WAR.--The Secretary of the Navy has a delicate duty to perform in making an apportionment among the various Navy yards, of the eight new steam sloops of war authorized by Congress.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Mrs. J. H. ALLEN, the most beautiful woman on the New-York stage, and a lady who in a short time has assumed a prominent position as the leading actress at the principal New-York Theatre, takes, her benefit to-night.

It is not quite easy to understand the motive which has impelled the Mormons to abandon Utah and seek a new home in the wilds of Mexico. The rumor that they have merely withdrawn from the city in order to fortify themselves elsewhere, is clearly absurd-for if they were resolved to fight they would have done it in advance of their settlements and for their protection, rather than after having abandoned them to the enemy.

Artisans, mechanics, and laboring men generally, will not serve on Juries, if they can avoid it, because it costs them too much.
