To the Editor of the New-York Times: I send you an article from the Albany Atlas and Argus, of the 9th Inst., which I trust will relieve me in the minds of your readers from being classed among a band of swindlers who have awakened the attention of the Post-Office Department to their disreputable acts, and as published in your issue of the 8:h inst. The Argus says:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I desire to correct a writer under the name of "A Sufferer," in the TIMES of 14th inst., who has taken the liberty to state that " ANTHONY DEY contracted to furnish scows to remove the contents of sinks, , which he has done for some two years or more ; he now refuses to do anything more unless paid for so doing."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The to be of the Sunday newspapers reflects little credit on Editors or readers. Sunday cries are sufficiently offensive; but if it is understood that they are employed to give circulation to slanderous journals, public sentiment will demand their suppression with resistless unanimity.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your correspondent," N. R.," a day or two since, says: " Our most essential City regulations are constantly disregarded; our streets are left in poisonous filth; bales and boxes are permitted to encounter the pavement, and to encroach on the lights of the passengers; indecent interments, dangerous to health.

There are some interesting matters here besides what take place in Congress, and I propose from time to time to touch upon them. An expenditure of $60,000,000 per annum does not cover all the pickings and stealings that "prevail" in our hereabouts.

Our remarks a few days ago on the decrease of our City population have occasioned considerable comment, and some of our cotemporaries have questioned the correctness of our statement. But the evidence of its correctness is too strong to be doubted.

The New-York Times editorially pronounces the vote of the Senate approving Mr. MASON's resolutions against British aggressions, "Under the circumstances, peculiarly significant." The Washington correspondent of the same paper telegraphs so as to appear simultaneously with the above, that "Mr. MASON's resolutions were passed today in the Senate: unanimously, not because they were considered of the slightest importance, but lest their failure o pass might be misconstrued by the British Government."

MAN KILLED BY A WOMAN IN DEFEUCE OF HER HUSBAND. On Saturday night the Platte, (Mo.,) Argus says the City Marshal of Weston was aroused from bed to go to a house on the northern extremity of Leavenworth-street, by the report that a man had been probably killed. He promptly repaired to the spot, attended by several of his friends.

Additional telegraphic advices from Utah. which we publish this morning, inform us that 70 Mormon families had come into Camp Scott and claimed protection, which had been accorded to them. We also have details or news previously received by telegraph, in reference to the arrival of Col. KANE'S party at St. Louis.

The accounts of the floods at the West become more alarming. The Alton Courier has the following: "The levee at Cairo, on the Mississippi River, gave way on Saturday afternoon, and the entire place was soon flooded to the depth of several feet, causing the greatest consternation and alarm.

The Rev. Mr. WEBB, of Augusta, Me., has been called, by a unanimous vote, to the pastoral care of the Bowdoin-street Church, in Boston. This is one of the most liberal churches in Boston. At the close of the labors of the Rev. J. B. WATERBURY, about one year since, the Church gave him, as a present, $5,000. The salary to Mr. WEBB is $3,000; $1,000 more than was paid to Dr. WATERBURY

SUNDAY NOISES.--The Herald, a day or two since, stated that the names of JAMES HARPER and R. M. HOF. were appended to the memorial against crying newspapers in the streets on Sunday, without their authority. We are requested to state that this is untrue, and that no names were signed to that paper without the assent, either written or verbal, of the persons themselves.

THE EUCLEIAN SOCIETY of the New-York University held its annual meeting last evening. The Annual Address was delivered by the Rev. FRANCIS N. ZABRISKIE, a graduate of the University and of the Society, the subject of whose remarks-very interesting and forcibly enunciated--was " True Greatness." He did not consider NAPOLEON a great man.

From the London Times. There is a proverb current in Calcutta which determines the exact difference between the temperature of that languid city and the heat of a place the name of which we may not print. The popular adage does not make the margin very wide.

Arrival of seventy Mormon Families at Camp Scott. ST. LOUIS, Friday, June 19. Additional details by the Salt Lake mail say tha seventy Mormon families had arrived at Camp Scott Asking protection, which was given. Capt. HARRIS, with 250 head of beef cattle, was met at Harris' Fork, 15 miles this side of Camp Scott.

DECIDEDLY UNREASONABLE--North Carolina, it seems, has had awarded to her, as her share of diplomatic plunder, a prize in the shape of the Sardinian Embassy, at which, it is stated, the North Carolinians flare up in a state of disappointment. They had looked for a fail mission.

From the London Times. We cannot pretend to follow the labyrinthine windings of a Peelite mind, and so we shall make no suppositions concerning Mr. GLADSTONE'S motives for declining to take office under the Earl of DERBY. All that we can presume is, that his reasons were something perfectly unlike anything that would influenee ordinary minds.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: "The Rev. Dr. HAMILTON, of Albama, whose and fall and deposition from the ministry gave such pain to the whole Church, has been fully restored to his former position in the Presbyterian Church. He has been one of the most talented and eloquent men in all South."

The condition of affairs is hourly becoming more gloomy in this poor country. In truth we no longer deserve the name of a nation. The tottering step and the bleared eyes of the present Government indicate most positively a sudden fall. Hourly reports are received of the advance of the Liberal party.

DELUGE OF THE LOWER MISSISSIPPI.--Another disastrous crevasse occurred at the Yazoo Pass, in the State of Mississippi, on Thursday night, which, it is said, will submerge the entire valley of the Yazoo River.

A libel suit of somewhat unusual interest has just been decided at Poughkeepsie. Suit was brought by Mr. M. SANFORD, against the Editor of the Dutchess Democrat, for a libel contained in an article in that journal, reflecting upon plaintiff for expresssions employed in an Oration delivered by him at Red Hook on the Fourth of July, 1850.

Mayor TIEMANN's late attempt to break up the Lottery establishment of SWAN Co., of Augusta, Ca., is creating a good deal of excitement here in political circles. The power of the Press, for good or evil, has not been for some time manifested so markedly as in the perverted and, in some respects, positively false statements ot this matter that have gone out to the world.

DISINFECTING THE STEAMER SUSQUEHANNA.-Since tile frigate Susquehanna arrived from Jamaica with the yellow fever on board, nearly two months since, she has been lying under the charge of the quarantine authorities in the lower bay with the seeds of pestilence in her, a source of apprehension to our citizens;

Before Judge Betts. The United States vs. One package contaming dismonds- This case was put on trial this morning , for the second time, the Jury having failed to agree on the former trial. It is an action to forfeit the diamonds as being sinuggled. Messrs. Randall and Barmore are the Claimants,

Numerous friends of Collector SCHELL, together with that portion of the Democratic Party of this City known as the Regulars, formed in procession last evening-a portion at the City Hall Park, (where they were called together by a gun,) another portion (the Regulars) at No. 163 Bowery, and another portion (his friends) at Union-square.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In general I disregard all comments in the public papers on the management of this Company, but as your editorial of this morning, headed " Railroad Mismanagement," will be read by every one who sees your widely-circulated paper, and as it is calculated to prejudice the directors and officers of this Company in the opinion of those who are unacquainted with the facts.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The World is proverbially slow to believe in new discoveries, and therefore you are properly cautious in giving an opinion as to the value of Dr. COLLYER'S invention of "an improved mode of preparing the residue of beet root, mangel-wurtzel, , left after sugar-making and distillation, to be used as a material in making paper."

THE MIDDAGH-STREET SHOETING CASE.--Mr. JOHN COOPER. VAIL, who attempted to shoot JOHN LAIDLAW in Middagh-street, Thursday evening, was yesterday brought before Justice CORNWELL for examination. By advice of counsel he waived an examination and gave bail to appear for trial in case the Grand Jury should find an indictment.

The Supreme Court of this Territory met on Tuesday last, at Lecompton, and sat during one day, disposing of three cases, all that were before them. It then adjourned to July 12. The friends of LANE report his condition as being critical.

The Committee of the Common Council on the removal of President MONROE's remains met on Saturday. Mr. SCOTT, Mayor TIEMANN'S private Secretary, was appointed private Secretary of the Commit tee. He read a letter from a house in Broadway, offering a metal burial-case. The offer was accepted by the Committee, and the letter was ordered on file. The Secretary next read the following, which was forwarded by the Richmond Committee:

The steamer Black Warrior, Capt. SMITH, arrived from Havana on Saturday evening with about 150 pasSENGERS. At 7 o'clock last evening she was still detained at quarantine on account of sickness on board. Coming from a port where yellow fever prevails to a considerable extent, she would naturally be detained a reasonable time that she might be inspected, fumigated and cleansed;

In March Gen. SANTA ANNA departed from his charming retreat at Tubbaco, in New-Granada,where of for two or three years past he has been enjoying the felicities of repose and cock-fighting, and took up his line of March for Mexico. He was encouraged by the disturbed condition of that Republic to believe that he might once more put himself at the head of affairs.

Presentation week is he carnival season of college life. In its different exercises it presents a prefect epitome of the student's existence at Yale. First or all, in order of time, comes "Wooden--Spoon Exhibition." For the benefit of the uninitiated, it ma be well to state that the system of appointments at Yale excludes all but those who are superior in scholarship from displaying their elocutionary powers at Junior Exhibition.

For a lill-blown absurdity, commend us to the Charleston Mercury. The columns of that paler appear to be kept, open for the reception of articles which have the look of waifs from an insane asylum. All the lunatics of the Palmetto State seen to use the Mercury as a ventilator of their whimsicalities. It generally comes to us charged with cottonade of the most fearfully explosive character.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You will oblige me by stating that I neither signed nor authorized my name to be signed to the Sunday memorial. But from a conversation and explanations had with the gentleman who caused my name to be attached to the document I am satisfied that it was done through a misunderstanding, and that he believed he had authority to use my name.

The afternoon meetings of the Sabbath School connected with Dr. HUTTON'S Church, on Washington-quare, closed yesterday. The school will assemble as usual every Sunday morning until the close of July. ARRIVAL OF THE BLACK WARRIOR--MOVEMENTS OF THE AMERICAN SQUADRON--SHIPMASTERS MEETING AT HAVANA--THE SLAVE-TRADE. The mail steamer Black Warrior, J. W. SMITH, Commander, from New Orleans the 12th and Havana the 15th, arrived at this port on Saturday evening. The United States steamers Fulton and Sea Witch the had been cruising for the Styx and Buzzard, but had not fallen in with them. At last report they had touched at Cardenas and resumed their cruise.

At 11 P. M., on Friday, JOHN LYONS, residing in the tenement house No. 494 Greenwich street, came home intoxicated and commenced abusing his wife and beating her. Seizing her by the arms he flung her two or three times around the room and then let her fall upon the floor, after which he kicked her with great violence several times in the right side.

Before the Hon. Judge Wright. The Judge resumed his seat oil the Bench at 10 o'clock on Saturday morning. The Jurors were then called into Court. In reply to the question whether they had agreed, The Foreman said there was a difficulty with regard to the testimony of Rollins, on the point as to whether he testified that he had seen two men running from the corner of Grand-street.

UNFORTUNATE--Mr. PATRICK LALLY, who has just been convicted, in Brooklyn, of manslaughter, and sent to State Prison, indites a farewell epistle in which he attributes his conviction to a "prejudiced community," and hopes no reliance will he placed on the "malicious charges" that have been made against him. Mr. LALLY is an unfortunate individual.

The usual monthly expenditure at the Yard is from forty-five to fifty thousand dollars, making over half a million annually. The State Department has received dispatches from Minister REED, announcing his intended resignation and return from China. A report has been received by the War Department from Lieutenant l??ves, setting forth the entire success of his exploration so far as he has gone. The navigation of the Colorado is entirely safe for large steamers. The health of his men is good.

A young German, giving his name as Frederick W. Koehler, about ten days ago made some trilling purchase at the jewelry store of Tiffany Co., in Broadway, and gave in payment a counterfeit five dollar bill on the John Hancock Bank, of Boston, Mass. The spurious character of the bill not being detected, the right change was given to Koehler, and he left chuckling over his success.

Illinois Republican State Convention. The Republican State Convention of Illinois met at Springfield on the 10th inst. Ninety five counties were represented, and the proceedings were animated and harmonious. Hon. GUSTAVUS KUERNER of St, Clair, presided, and made a speech reviewing nominations were made: For State Treasurer JAMES MILLER, of McKean County; for Superintendent of Public Instruction-NEWTON BATEMAN. A State Central Committee, ten members.

They are on widely different subjects, but, like all matters bearing on human civilization and progress, they converge to a certain abstract truth, which it may be well to put upon record.

THE BRITISH OUTRAGES.--MISSTATING THE QUESTION.--It must be a very great misfortune always to have a "nigger" in one's eye. The Tribune suffers from it and has our sympathy. It sees nothing but negro in all the controversies of the day. Whatever the question may be at the outset, it inevitably runs into the African issue.

At Albany, last week, an old lady of 72, Mrs. McCotter, hung herself. Cause--derangement. At Perry, Ohio, Lewis Putnam, a young man, shot himself in the head. Cause unknown. At Augusta, Ga., Miss Laura Ingraham drowned herself. Cause not stated.

CHURCH OF THE PURITANS.-lt has been stated in various papers, that the protesting members of the Church of the Puritans are about submitting their grievances to an Ecclesiastical Council. Those members, we are authorized to say, have come to no de cision as to the remedy against the repeated wrongs which they believe themselves to have suffered at the hands of the present majority of the Church.

SALARIES OF CITY OFFICERS.-The Common Council of Jersey City have fixed upon the following salaries for the year 1858 and 1859, for the principal City officers; Recorder, $600 ; City Clerk, (no fees) $2 000; City Marshall, $500; Comptroller, $1,000; Treasurer, $500; City Printer, (besides extras) $600;

OUR OWN HEATHEN.--Those who are in danger of overlooking the heathen at their own doors, in their far-reachig efforts to do good to mankind at large, may learn a useful lesson by reading the testimony of one of the witnesses in the trial of CUNNINGHAM, which is now progrcssing at the City Hall.

In the debate, published in yesterday's TIMES, which occurred in the House of Commons on the 8th inst., upon a motion to introduce the ballot in English elections instead of the viva voce vote, reference was made by several gentlemen to the system of elections in the United States. Tile proposition was rejected by a large majority.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You ventured to punch some of our Aldermen and newspapers the other day, with DOUGLAS JERROLD'S pen. They tried to escape on the plea that "Clapstick" went into ecstacies about Sabbaih bells, in spite of the humorist who made "Clapstick" and "Jem" too.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Why cannot the Battery be finished? If we cannot have it completed in any other way, Let us have beach there, and let the unsightly mass of filth that it now is be graded, laid out in walks, and grassed.

I lave said Presentation Week is an epitome of College life. In a four years' course at Yale there is much of joy and merriment. Doubtless, it predominates over the melancholy, but there is another side to the picture, and to understand thoroughly the philosophy of student life, one must have a glimpse at this as well.

There is strong colorable ground for helieving that the operations of Mons. BELLY in Nicaragua were prompted by the French Emperor, who has long contemplated Central America as a quarter in which France might establish a protectorate.

Free Love has not died out. It is more lively now than it was at the time of Capt. TURNDULL'S famous descent upon the Socialists at midnight of the 18th October. 1855. That violent demonstration had the simple effect of withdrawing the subject from the public gaze for a time. The commanders, like good seamen, reefed sail, seadded under bare poles, and made haste for a quite harbor.

Hon. Edward Brooks, of Boston, who has just returned from Europe, has brought with him a highly valuable original portrait of Benjamin Franklin, which it is his intention to present to the City of Boston, to be placed in the Public Library Building. The portrait, Which is remarkably correct and lifelike, was painted in 1779 by the eminent Frenck painter, Duplesse.

A FERRY FROM PECK-SLIP TO FULTON-STREET BROOKLYN.--The Aldermanic Committee on Ferries met on Saturday afternoon for the purpose of considering the propriety of leasing at public auction the slip between piers Nos. 25 and 26, (Peck-slip,) East River, with the right to run a ferry therefrom to Fulton-street, Brooklyn. There were several prominent citizens of Williamsburg present.
THE AMERICAN EXPRESS COMPANY.-The building of the American Express Company, fronting on Hudson, Jay and Staples streets, was formally opened yesterday afternoon, and the occasion was duly celebrated.

MY GOOD OLD FRIEND: I write to urge you to come out as a distribution Democratic candidate for the Legislature. The triumph of this principle by electing a Legislature favorable to this measure. insutes two Senators to aid in relieving us of the burden of taxes.

GENERAL WALKER AGAIN IN COURT.--The New Orleans Bee, of the 12th says: General WALKER, in person, and Colonel FRANK ANDERSON, by counsel, were in Court yesterday before Judges CAMPBELL and McCALEB, upon the rule taken on them to show cause why they should not furnish security for their future good conduct towards Nicaragua.

THE LITTLES TRIAL.--It is said that there will be no delay in the case of SARAH LITTLES. It is reported that she is ready to come in with any pleashort of murcer. but she will doubtless be brought before a Jury to have a verdict pronounced upon the evidence.

David Banks vs. John Dalley et al.--Judgement for plaintiff on demurrer, with costs. Samuel Brown vs. John Biehn.---Motion for new trial denied.

Business having required my attention in the Northwest and West, I am on a tour through Illinois, Wisconsin, , and thence by way of tile Queen City homeward. Looking after "lame ducks," "prospecting" for business, and some personal adventure, have been the subjects of my experiences.

FLOUR quiet and unchanged; sales of 400 bbls. at $4 06@4 25 for extra Wisconsin and Illinois, WHEAT unsettled; sales of 600 bushes Milwaukee Club at 78.@80c. CORN quiet; sales of 500 bushes Indian at 61 1/2c. OATS unchanged, and salable at 39c. on the spot. WHISKY lower; sales of 300 bbls. at 21c., for future delivery. FREIGHTS--10c.

HIS SPEECH ON EANEAS AND THE BRITISH OUTRAGES. The constitnenis of the representative in Congress of the Sixth District latst night expressed their approbation of his course in Congress, and gave him a welcome home, by serenading him at his residence, No. 133 Est Twelfth-street.

The Milwaukee Free Democrat of last Wednesday evening says: " At about 4 o'clock this afternoon, without any premonition whatever, the large and new brick fourstory wholesale grocery store of JOSEPH H. CORDES Co., situated on Detroit-street, south side, between East Water and Main streets, fell with a tremendous crash, partly out into Detroit-street, and partly inward, the whole building being lazed almost to the ground.

Poets and painters will never be done with Niagara; as long us its waters are green, and a rainbow hangs like a halo in its mists, there will be poets to ?? it the subject of their verses. and painters to copy its entrancing grandeur. The last "Niagara" is a companion picture to CHURCH'S chef d'a'Hure, painted by GIGNOUX.

MELANCHOLY AFFAIR-TWO TOUTHS UROWNED WHILE BATHING.-Between 2 and 3 o'clock on Sunday afternoon, WILLIAM OATS and FRANCIS PERRY HAYCOCK--the first 17 years of age, and the latter four years younger, went to take a bath in the North River. OATS went into the water before his companion had finished undressing, and being unable to swim, the force of the tide soon carried him beyond his depth. His comrade seeing him struggling in

WHITHER WILL THE MORMONS GO?---Once more the disciples of JOE SMITH are afloat in the world. Four times have they abandoned their abodes to seek a new home. From Western New-York they went to Ohio, thence to Missouri, and when driven by violence from that Zion, they found a resting-place at Nauvoo.

THE GREAT MONOPOLIZER.--Frenchmen ought to be grateful to LOUIS NAPOLEON for his determined efforts to make Paris the centre of the intellectual world, and to store it with such moral magnets that all the rest of the world will be attracted to it.

A singular case of simulation has just been developed in the Massachusetts State Prison. A conviel, 43 years of age, who was sentenced at the of 1851. for a term of eight years, has been an inmate of the Prison Hospital for the past seventeen months, ostensibly in consequence of a weakness of the back and limbs, which prevented him from standing.

The first quarter of the present century possessed a great wealth of composers, and so far as Italy was concerned, it may be regarded as the most fruitful of her modern times. ROSSINI was delighting the world with his bright and happy inspirations; DONIZETTI, with more poetic grace and scarcely less inspiration, struggled manfully for that position which be afterwards attained;

We arrived on our cruising-ground on the morning of the loth inst., having spent twelve and a half days of hard driving, with both steam and sail, under the most favorable circumstances of wind and weather, in getting 1,240 miles, or 100 miles per day.

BIRD.--In this City. on Sunday, June 20, at his residence No. 1 East 17th st., GEORGE BIRD. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, on Tuesday. June 22, at 9 o'clock A. M. from Calvary Church, without further notice. EMERSON-- In this City, on Monday, June 21. FRANK DRADLE?. infant son of W. H. and Elizabeth T. Emerson.

Mr. LUDLOW, on Saturday, sold, under foreclosure apiece of improved property on the north side of Twenty-fourth-street, 375 feet west of Ninthavenue. 25 by 98 feet 9 inches, for $3,500, bought by the plaitiff in the suit.

The editor of the Chicago Union (Mr. LOUIS SCHADE. has withdrawn from the paper, and the proprietor retracts and apologises for the article which appeared some time ago, reflecting upon Mr. FRANCIS J. GRUND. The publication of the article led to the rencontre between SCHADE AND GRUND, of which we gave an account the other day.

SUPREME COURT--SPECIAL TERM. -- JUNE 21. Before Judge Ingraham. Thomas T. Ferris vs. Francis Ferris et al. -- In this case the plaintiff seeks to foreclose a mortgage where the interest has remained unpaid for more than 30 days, and the principal was made payable in 1859, with the condition that it should become payable immediately after the expiration of the said 30 days.

THE KNIFE ASAIN.-A main named MICHAEL FAGAN stabbed his brother, JOHN FAGAN, seven times with a pen-knife Sunday night, in New Brooklyn. The wounds are all on the left side, but are not considered dangerous. The brothers were quarreling when the knife was used.

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West, Captain GRAY, sailed yesterday at 2 o'clock P. M., for Aspinwall, with the mail, and about 400 passengers for California. Among them were the Hon. JOHN C. McKIBBIN, M. C. from California; Captain CUNNINGHAM, ordered to the command of the Navy Yard at Mare Island; Lieutenant NICHOLSON, ordered to the command of the frigate Saranac;

STREET COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE, No. 4 Hall of Records. NEw-YORK, Monday, June 21, 1858. To THE PUBLIC: Notice is hereby given that the Street Department has nothing whatever to do with either paving or cleaning the streets. There are many applications made daily at this office by citizens, making complaints or asking for information in regard to both the above subjects, thereby losing their own time, and unnecessarily interfering with the legitimate business of this office.

WM. F. COLCOCK, Collector of the Customs at this port, in reply to our application for a clearance for the ship Richard Cobden.

The Cunard steamship Persia, from Liverpool on the 12th of June, arrived at this port last evening. A brief summary of her news was telegraphed from Cape Race, but we obtain from our file some additional intelligence of interest.

A German Military and Turnverein Annual Festival was held at Yorkville Park yesterday. It was the occasion of the first anniversary celebration of the New-York Schutzen Corps, 150 men, commanded by Hauptman H. D. BUSCH. The Turner Schutzen companies of New-York, Brooklyn and Williamsburg accompanied them. The festival is to continue tc-day and to-morrow.

the Tornado--A Word from under the Ruins. The hurricane of Monday afternoon, among other evidences of its awful power, blew from the stone foundation and utterly demolished the beautiful new building erected in Fifty-fourth-street, for the free church of Good Shepherd.

THE WASHINGTON UNION ON POLYGAMY.-The President's newspaper organ is opposed to polygamy. In its issue of yesterday it informs the public that it was aware " that the plurality-wife system prevailed at least among the Mormon Priesthood,"-a fact which the Union " regretted." "But," says the organ, "we did not send the army to Utah even to beat down polygamy."

The Evening Post has a way of its own, and a very peculiar way it is, of viewing the "British Outrages." When tile first reports were made of the outrages in the Gulf on our commerce, tile Post attributed the stories to the inventive genius of the President or his friends, who had trumped them up as an apology for demanding an increase of our military defences.

If we were in the place of President BUCHANAN, just now, we would make public proclamation to the sound of the trumpet, solemnly conjuring our supporters not to write articles in our defence or glorification. We commented, a few days ago, upon the singular amount of misfortune which has attended all that gentleman's undertakings ever since he entered the White House.

A GOOD OMEN.--Among a small batch of vetoes which Mayor TIEMANN sent to the Common Council, on Monday, was one in reference to the grant of a piece of land in the Park, fronting on chambers-street, for the purpose of erecting upon it a house for a steam fire engine.

THE FIRST MAD DOG.--On Sunday morning that odious brute, " the first mad dog: of the season," suffered death in Broadway from the club of a Policeman. But the "season" had been previously inaugurated by our provident City authorities. The dog-pound has been in

Lord NAPIER had a protracted audience yesterday with Secretary CASS, and, I learn, announced that his Government would not again attempt to search or visit vessels bearing the American flag' though she would continue to claim the abstract right of visitation. The position of our Government

GETTING OUT OF DEBT.--The New-England Congregational Society's Church in Williamsburg is one of the largest and pleasantest buildings for Church purposes in Brooklyn. It was completed in 1853, at a cost for Church and lots of $40,000. On the 1st of January, 1855, there was still owed on this $27,000.

The activity of the friends of free rum has caused a corresponding activity among its enemies. A league is to be formed here to act against all candidates for city offices who shall not be pledged to enforce the Maine Law. Though nominally confined to local objects, such an association cannot be indifferent to general politics, and the effect of its exertions will be favorable to the Republicans in both State and Congressional elections.

The trial of a Catholic priest, the Rev. DANIEL DOWNEY, for the murder of a man named MULLINS, has just been concluded in the Superior Court of this town, having occupied nine days and a half. It resulted in a disagreement of the Jury--nine being for a verdict of murder in the second degree and three for acquittal.

THE POLICE PARADE.--The following ronte has been agreed upon for the Police parade to-day. At 121/2 e'clock the New-York policemen form in line in front of the Police Head-quarters in Broome-street. thence march down Broaw way to the Park, where at 2 P. M. they will be reviewed in forat of the City Hall, by Gov. KING, the Mayor, and Common Council.

Died, on Monday, 21st inst., at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. BENJ. F. THOMPSON, in Hempstead, L. I., the Rev. ZACHARIAH GREENE, in the 99th year of his age. The venerable man whose death is here announced, combined every attraction to make his life useful and his death triumphant. First a soldier of his country

The citizens of the Ninth Congressional District, without respect to party, congregated last evening at the principal hall in Morrisama, for the purpose of expressing their approval of the course of the Hon. JOHN B. HASKIN, in the House of Representatives curing the late session of Congress, The popular interest in the proceeding was unusual.

WHITEHOUSE HOSPITALITIES.--It be will recollected that Mr. J. GLANCY JONES, a leading Administration representative in Congress from Pennsylvania, charged a Republican member, in debate, with hostility to the President by reason of not having been invited to dine at the White House.

There are symptoms of rebellion in the South against the insane treason of the ProSlavery fanaties, which has so long passed current as statesmanship in that section of the country. Virginia--which has generally controlled the political action of the South-begins to perceive the inevitable tendency of the Disunion movement, and refuses to permit herself either to be used or sacrificed to its accomplishment.

The Telegraph a the Highlands reported, early yesterday morning, a hermaphordite brig in the offing in a crippled condition, making her way slowly towards Sandy Hook. A nearer view of the craft showed that she had evidently been in collision with some vessel and had been badly damaged.

APPORTIONING THE GOVERNMENT PATRONAGE. It has been announced from Washington that two of the eight steam sloops-of-war, authorized to be built at the last session of Congress, are to be given to the Philadelphia Navy-Yard. The announcement is not official, and

The parades of the New-York and Brook Police yesterday, was highly creditable to them, and evinced a degree of good discipline which those who witnessed it, considering the comparatively brief period within which it has been attained, were not prepared for. Every one was taken by surprise who saw the precision with which they executed their manoeuvres, and the excellent style in which they marched.

CHEAPER FARES.-The Hudson River Railroad Comany are arranging to sell excursion tickets to sundry points on their read every Wednesday and Saturday during the Summer. On these days passeigers can go to and return from Yonkers, Dobbs' Ferry, Tarrytown, Sing Sing, Peeskill and Garrison at half price.

FIRE IN DUANE-STREET.--About 10 1/2 o'clock last night, a fire broke out in the building No. S1 Duane street, between Broadway and Elm-streets. It originated on the third floor, occupied by S. W Bush. patent makes, whose loss amounts to about $500. The principal damage, however, was sustained ?? H. W. WOODS. silversmiths, whose loss will probably amount to $2.000.

ACCIDENT AT THE NOVELTY WORKS -- JOHN HIGGINS, a young man employed at the Novelty Works, accidentally fell the top of a large boiler upon which he was at work, and was dangerously injured. He was taken to the city Hospital.

LANE'S TRIAL -The trial of General LANE, Commander- in-Chief of the Kansas militia, for the murder of JEBJUBS, was commerced at Lawrence on the 14th instant, and we give in another column, from our own reporter, a report of the testimony taken during the first two days.

My last letter was written on the eve of our departure upon an experimental trip, undertaken far the purpose of testing the Submarine Cable, previous to laying it in: mid-ocean. The trip has been accomplished, and we have returned to this harbor, in stead of proceeding to Cock, as was originally intended.

EFFECTS OF FOLLOWING BAD ADVISERS.--The London Daily News is instructing its English readers on the subject of the British outrages. It informs them, with the utmost gravity, that all these stories were concocted by the President, to divert attention from kansas, and quotes WENDELL PHILLIPS and the Evening Past to prove it.

Milk and the Berry Business -- A Brooklyn Market Needed. A party of about forty gentlemen, prominent citizens of Brooklyn, on Tuesday last visited the daily farms in Queens County, at the invitation of Messrs. RUSHMORE KIPP. milk dealers.

JUSTICE OSBORNE ASSAULTED IN A RAILROAD CAP.--Justice OSBORNE, of the Lower Police Court, was riding in a Third avenue car on Tuesday evening, when a number of Germans--they had a good deal of lager on board, having just returned from a jubilee at Comad's Garden, in Yorkville--commenced abusing some women and children in the cars.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your account of the assault, last evening, upon Mr. WEBB, by the notorious " BILLY MULLIGAN," at the Metropolitan Hotel, scarcely did justice to the two energetic policemen who were called in to see fair play.

ALLEN--In this City, on Wednesday evening, June 23, MARIA ANTOINETTE wife of Geo. C. Allen. and daughter of the late Dr. Talmadge Sutherland. Friends of the family are invited to Attend the funeral, at No. 130 Bladisch-av., on Friday, 25th inst, at 3 o'clock P. M., without further notice.

FRANCE is evidently preparing for WAR ; and the nations' of Europe may well be excused for asking one another, with an anxiety not very different from alarm, upon which of them tile thunderbolt is likely to fall.

CANAL TOLLS -Business on the Canals of the State continues to be satisfactory. Up to the 15th instant the total receipts of the sea-son exceed those of the corresponding period last year by $143,384. We learn from Western

THE REMOVAL OF MONROK'S REMAINS.--The Virginians met at Metropolitan Hotel last evening, for the purpose of hearing the report of their Committee, in relation to the arrangements for the removal of the remains of Ex-President MONROE. Major H. HILL presided.

The quarrel which has arisen between tile Unitted States and England, and which has been caused by the overhauling of American shills in the Gulf of Mexico, will not certainly be attended with any serious consequences. England always gives evidence of an exemplary moderation in her relations with tee young republic, her own offspring.

The Trial of SARAH LITTLES for the murder of her husband, CHARLES W. LITTLES, in connection with her brother, IRA STOUT, who has already been convicted, commenced at Rochester on Monday, and a Jury was impanneled in Tuesday.

Important intelligence of the movements of the Mormons reaches us from our Special Correspondent at Fort Bridger. A company of one hundred and fifty Mormons had arrived at the Army Headquarters, having been permitted by BRIGHAM to leave the City, in accordance with the pledge he had given Governor CUMMING

In the House of Commons, last night, a very serious question was opened by Lord GODERACH, who asked what the Government knew of the actual state of the French "emigrant ' trade on the Coast of Africa.

The trail of General J. H. LANE for the murder of Mr. GAINS JENKINS commenced to-day before Justice LADD, assisted by Justices SOULE and OTTERSON. The counsel for the prosecution are Messrs. SAPFORD, (Country-Attorney,) COE, LAWMAN, WOOD, COLLAMORE AND STANTON; for defendant, Messrs. YOUNG, T. EWING. HUTCHINSON, CHRISTIAN and H. EWING.

The ship Castilian, of Newburyport, GRAVES, from Liverpool May 3 with 1,473 tons of coal to the Monhatian Gas Company, arrived yesterday. She reports, may 26. Off Cape Sable, she saw the ship Jenny Lind, bound for Boston. May 1. lat. 50 55 long. 15' 45', they saw an American ship on fire, ?? for her, and upon approaching near, saw a ship that was lying by her, fill away and stand to the castward.

The War Cloud was dispersed yesterday. A supplemental and conformal meeting of the Cabinet was held, at which dispatches from Mr. DALLAS and Lord MALMESRURY, through Lord NAPIER, were read, a??ologizing for the late outrages, and offering indemnity.

The German branch of the Societe internationale celebrated last evening in Harmonia Hall. Essex-street, the anniversary of the Red Republican socialistic outbreak which occurred in Paris on the 23d of June, 1848, and which, it will be remembered, was suppressed by General CAVAIGNAC, after a three days' struggle.

The Telegraphic Squadron are now engaged in laying the Cable. In common with the whole world, we earnestly hope the attempt will be successful ; but we are compelled to confess that our advices are not encouraging. We fear this second experiment will prove a failure.

The Special Correspondent of the NEW-YORK TIMES reached Camp Scott, near Fort Bridger, in Utah Territory, on the 27th of May; and by the mail which left the next morning, he sent us a very interesting letter, which will he found in another part of this morning's sheet. No VERDICT IN THE CUNNINGHAM CASE.-The disagreement of juries has come to be a serious hindrance of justice. Yesterday the trial of CUNNINGHAM for killing PAUDEEN came to a conclusion in the Court of General Sessions, the Jury reporting themselves unable to agree. After being out all night.

RUTGERS' INSTITUTE COMMENCEMENT.--The Commencement of this well-known Institution wilt take place at Dr. KAEBS' Church, in Rutgers-street, on the lot of July. The preparations made for the public exercises are always such as to render these occasions among the most interesting of their kind; and the present one will be more interesting than usual.

The frigate Savannah will be nearly ready for sea by the middle of July, and the officers have been ordered to report for duty on the 1st prox. Lieutenant WORDEN, long known as the First Lieutenant, and one of the most industrious and efficient officers at the Navy-Yard, has been ordered to the Savannah as her First Lieutenant.

THE DEAP AND DUMB ASYLUM INJURED BY THE STORM.-During the hurricane on Monday last, the wind blew off the temporary roof of an unfinished tower of the Institution for the Deaf and Dumb in One Hundred and Sixty-second-street, and the roof, in its course, broke through the slate roof of the main edifice in several places, and completely de. molished a large circular sky-light directly over the lecture-room. We recently published a letter from the Hon. EDWARD EVERETT, concerning the Boston testimonial offered to Mr. SUMNER, after the Brooks affair. We now publish the following letter from Mr. SUMNER. written at the time, on the same subject: WASHINGTON, June 13, 1856.

The High Court of Errors, in Mississippi, has made an important decision upon the subject of the rights of free negroes in other States to property bequeathed to them in that State. The case was that of James Brown, a slaveholder, who died, leaving a wilt by which his property was to be sold,land and slaves, and the proceeds, after paying his debts, to be subject to the draft of Jerome and Francis Brown.

In the Seventh Ward of Brooklyn there is a valley stretching from Fulton-avenue to the Wallabout, known as Jackson's Hollow. To its very ??erge the City has marched up on either side, the best quality of improvements having been perfected and a most desirable population occupying the property both east and west of it.

The following letter contains information of interest to persons intending to visit France : LEGATION OF FRANCE IN THE UNITED SRATES: GEORGETOWN, June 7. 1858. SIR: I received the letter which you have done me the honor to write to me, dated the 4th of this month, and in which you ask me for information in regard to our regulations relative to vises of passports.

THE FlNISHING TIMES.-When we gave a description of the TIMES Building a few days since, we made no allusion to the very beautiful decoration of the arched ceiling and walls of the Publication Office for that accomplished artist, Mr. GUIDICINI, not having then commenced operations with his embellishing brush, we could not safely describe an object which was not in existence.

The steamer Black Warrior has been thoroughly fumigated and cleansed, and will be discharged from Quarantine to-day, and come to the City. Her passengers, after two days' comfortable residence at the " St. Nicholas," in the Quarantine limits, were allowed to come to the City. They expressed themselves well pleased with their accommodations while detained below.

Secretary COBB will issue proposals early in July for loans under the new Loan Law. It is rumored that Judge ROOSEVELT, of New-York, will succeed Mr. DALLAS as Minister to England. Gen. JOSEPH LANE left here for New-York this morning. Commander BOUTWELL's defence will be read tomorrow morning. Q.

The Commencement exercises of the General Theological Seminary took place yesterday in St. Peter's Church, in Twentieth-street, before a large congregation. In the chancel were Bishop POTTER, of New-York; Bishop DELANCEY, of Western NewYork ; Bishop WHITEHOUSE, of Illinois ; Bishop UPFOLD, of Indiana, and Bishop DOANE, of New-Jersey.

THE CUNNINGHAM HOMICIDE.-We publish a communication dissenting from our strictures upon the opinion of the four jurors who were for CUNNINGHAM'S absolute acquittal. The writer is mistaken when he says the law definingjustifiable homicide is not as we stated.

The Richmond Enquircr, of the 22d inst., says that the Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals " has lately decided the most important case to the institution of negro Slavery that has been adjudicated since the times of Lord MANSFILD." "It is," the Enquirer says,

A new journal has just been established in London, only the second number of which we have seen, called the London Cotton Plant. Its avowed object is to disseminate information in relation to the cotton-planting interests, but the principal motive of its conductor is, apparently, to oppose Anti-Slavery principles, or, as the editor expresses himself, "The free-negro theory of WILBERFORCE, BROUGHAM and CLARKSON."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I cannot forbear stating a startling incident of the storm of last evening. A few yards from my dwelling a child was returning from school in the height of the tempest.

Officer HICKS and Constables TINDALL and HEGRMAN have made affidavits that LALLY, sentenced for participation in the murder of Mr. SIMONSON, did on leaving the Court room, say to HICKS, that if he lived to get out of prison he would kill him.

AN INFANT SMOTHERED TO DEATH BY A DRUNKEN MOTHER.--Coroner McANALLY held an inquest yesterday, at a tenement-houss in Monmouth street, near Railroad-avenue, upon an infant 5 months old. which had been smothered by its mother, MARY McCARTHY, while in a state of intoxication.

JOSEPH GADD, ESQ.-My Dear Sir: Your kind better informing me that my enemies were industrieusly circulating a report, that I intend, if I am not neminated to be an independent candidate, has been received and read with some surprise. I am sine that none but the most reckless would give currency to such a statement.

THE LIQUOR LICENSE LAW.-Some of the Democratic journals charge the Republicans, as a party, with the design of enforcing the License Law in the spirit of the recent decision by the Court of Appeals, evidently regarding the accusation as of a very damaging character.

The Psi Upsilon Fraternity, now more than a quarter of a century old, is holding its Annual Convention in this City. Yesterday morning the Conven. tion was organized at the hall of the Historical Society, Second-avenue,corner of Eleventh-street. The Society is a secret College organization, and has chapters at most of our large Universities.

The Joint Committee of the Common Council on preparations for celebrating the Fourth of July met again yesterday afternoon, Alderman STEPHENS in the Chair. Alderman BooLE moved to reconsider the resolution passed by the Committee at the previous meeting, appropriating $250 to tile Veterans under Col. Ray mond.

The returns issued in London by the Board of Trade show that British commerce has not yet recovered from the shock of last Autumn, the exports of April showing a decline In value of about half a million sterling, and those of the four expired months of the year. of nearly six millions, as compared with those of the corresponding periods of last year.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Please permit me. through your valuable paper, o call the attention of the above-named gentleman and his "constituents" to the fact that the residents for several blocks around No. 133 East Twelfthstreet, (Mr. COOHRANE'S residence,) were greatly annoyed last night by the so-called "serenade."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As a peaceful man, and one entirely indifferent to the result of the Cunningham trial, I must dissent entirely from your remarks to-day, on the course of the four Jurors who favored that individual's acquit tal. PAUDEEN was a notorious bully, who had frequently shown himself entirely reckless as to the result of his acts, and whose hand had already been imbrued in the blood of his fellow-man.

The statement that Mrs. COWLWS' affidavit was supported by other testimony is incorrect.

REMOVAL OF THE MONROE REMAINS.-The Joint Committee on this subject met on Thursday. Mr. SAMUEL L. GOUVERNEUR addressed the Committee. He remarked that, owing to some misconception, the citizens of Virginia labored under the idea that the remains of the deceased had been interred ignominously in a public burial ground.

Dr. EDWARD SELS, late of Coesfeldt, in the Prussian Province of Westphalia, died suddenly, of apoplexy, in Brooklyn, on Monday last, the 21st inst., aged 35 years. Dr. SELS commenced his education in the College of Coesfeldt, and afterwards graduated with distinguished honors at Halle and Berlin. His attainments in Philosophy and Mathematics placed him foremost among the students of his day.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: On this subject: the Courier Enquirer of last Saturday had a sensible and vigorous editorial, with a view of showing the practical wisdom of the British and the shortsightedness of the American Govern. ments in their respective policy in regard to Ocear. Steam Navigation.

ALLEN.--In this City, on Wednesday evening, June 23, MARIA ANTOINETTE wife of Geo. C. Allen, and daughter of the late Dr. Talmadge Sutherland. Friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral. at No. 130 Madison-av. on Friday. 25th inst. at 3 o'clock P. M. without further notice.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You propose to abate the Sunday nuisances o newsboys', milkmen's and bakers' cries, That they are a nuisance no one will deny, whose senses are not deadened-that they ought to be abated is the conviction of every citizen who wishes one day of peace. If even the Sabbath must be made a bedlam,

A large number of the friends of Marshal RINDERS very quietly arranged to give him a serenade last night, at his residence, No. 52 Henry-street. It was intended principally as a friendly visit, and partly to congratulate him upon his confirmation.

It is understood in Washington, on what is believed to be reliable authority, that the President has determined to send an armed force to Nicaragua, or at least to make such a display of our nail vessels in the adjacent waters as will convince the English and Prench Governments that no interference will be allowed in our right of way across the Transit.

The signal flags which show that the Houses beneath them are in session had not been pulled down ere the members began to leave, and there has ever since been a general excdus.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The British Ministers pretend to be determinedto put an end to the Slave-trade. To extinguish the Spanish trade Britain gave Spain two million of dollars or so, and she by treaty agreed to do so.

The Eastern hemisphere it assigns to Russian dominion, while the Western is to be all Virginia, and be ruled according to the peculiar institutions of that State. In calculating what we.

BOOROM'S ROCKET GUN.-This is an ingenious invention of Mr. J. D. BOOROM, the gunner of the ship North Carolina, for the purpose of firing sky or signalrockets, and is also adapted for war purposes in the discharge of congreve rockets. It consists of a chamber to receive the rocket, and a stave, below which is a barrel containing a spiral spring.

The American Telegraph Company, owners of the Hughes' Printing Telegraph Instruments, have just opened the first section-between this City and Philadelphia-of their seaboard line to New-Orleans vid Washington, Charleston, Mobile, The line nas been placed under the superintendence of W. P. WESTERVELT, Esq., long and favorably known as the Superintendent of the Magnetic Line between this

THE TROURLES AT THE DUPLEY OBSERVATORY -The difficulty at the Dudley Observatory in Albany to which brief reference was made a day or two ago, has assumed serious proportions. A belligerent correspondence has appeared in the Albany Arges, in which the history of the affair is fully given.

It is just a year ago since our municipal Cataline entrenched himself in the City Hall and bade defiance to the Metropolitan Police, whom he decided to be an unconstitutional force which all law-abiding citizens were bound to despise and knock on the head.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: In your editorial remarks in this day's TIMES, giving the close of the Cunningham murder trial, you reflect somewhat severely upon the four Uurors who insisted on rendering a verdict of " Not guilty," as they believed it to be a case of justifiable homicide.

TRINITY COLLEGE, HARTFORD.--The commencement exercises of this College have been brought forward and occur hereafter the first of July. This year they are arranged as follows: TUESDAY, June 29.--Examination of candidates for entrance. In the evening an Address in Christ's Church, before the Athenaeum and Parthenoc Societies, by HENRY C. DENNING, Esq.

SIR: Your letter of the 11th inst. submits two questions: 1. Can a person who files a written proposal for carrying the mails withdraw it before it is accepted by the Department ? 2. Is a bidder bound by a proposal in his own handwriting without his signature ? I. An offer to make a contract is not itself a contract. It takes two to make bargain.

The schooner Sciota, from Carthagena, NewGranada, on the 27th ult., which arrived at this port on Thursday last, has brought intelligence of considerable importance from Bogota. Our readers may remember that, by the last Callfornia steamer, no late intelligence was received from the interior of New-Granada.

The General Association of Massachusetts held its annual session in Dorchester, on Tuesday, June 22. About 50 clergy men were cresent. The Western Delegates from the Congregational Association were quite united In their opposition to the late action of the Tract Society. The Rev. Mr. HOLBROOK, of Iowa, was particularly revere. lie said the Congregationalists were unanimous In withholding all contributions to the society.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The letter signed " Justice," published in your paper to day, gives a very fair statement of the grounds on which four of the Jurymen, in the case of CUNNINGHAM, indicted for the murder of McLAUGHLIN dissented from the opinion of the remaining eight, who were in favor of finding a verdict, involving more or less of punishment.

HOW TO HEAD OFF POLYGAMY--A BACHELOR IC VIEW OF THE FAMILY.-The Washington Union is very greatly exercised just at present with the plurality wife system, existing among the Saints at Salt Lake. After due and deliberate reflection, that judicious organ of the Administration is satisfied that no man should have, or desire, more than one wife;

SPEECHES OF MESSRS. BENEDICT AND HOFFMAN. Thursday, about noon, in pursuance of a notice to that effect, there was a meeting held in the Circuit Room of the Supreme Court, to pay a tribute of respect to the memory of the late JONATHAN MILLER, Esq. Owing to the extreme heat, probably, the at tendance was very small, and there appeared to be but little interest in the proceedings.

The Eighth Regiment Washington Greys is to be the escort and guard of honor in the City of New-York, on the removal of the remains of President MONROE. On the day the obsequies take place, which will be on Friday, July 2, the Committee will give the remains in charge of the Eighth Regiment.

A. D. Scarl, sworn--I have filed a diagram with the Court this morning; it is one I made of the various localities, the ground and objects described about the premises of J. H. Lane and Gains Jenkins; the distances are correctly taken with instruments, and noted on the diagram. The diagram was here produced to the Court.

The Richmond (Va.) Enquirer of June 22 contains a long article upon the position of the Democratic Party, from which we extract the following portions: "We hold that any professed Democrat who attempts to strike down the great leader of the Northwestern Democracy. for the sake of Derpetuating dissensions, is himself recreast to the interests of the party.

EXPERIMENT WITH BUNKER'S LIFE-PRESERVER.-An experiment was successfully made yesterday, at the foot of Wall-street, in the construction of a raft useful in cases of shipwreck, the raft being formed from several of BUNKER's Life-Preservers joined together by a few strips of board.

PHYSIOLOGY IN THE PUBLIC SCHOOLS.--A Committee of the Board of Education has recommended that a lecturer be employed to teach Physiology in the Common Schools. At the first hearing, one is disposed to beg the Board of Education to do nothing of the sort.

FRENCH PASSPORTS AND AMERICAN TRAVELERS.-The Moniteur, in its article of the 25th of March last, on the new French Passport regulations, said : " French Diplomatic and Consular agents have retained the power of demanding the appearance of the bearers of passports to which their visa is necessary.

II.--THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH--Results of the Experimental Trip-The Cable Parted on both Ships-Interesting Letter from our Correspondent on board the Niagara.

THE QUARREL WITH URQUIZA--TERRIBLE SHIPWRECK AND LOSS OF LIFE--BUSINESS PROSTRATED. By the arrival of bark Dawn, Capt. CHASE, we have Buenos Ayres papers to May 13, ten days later than previous advices. The quarrel between URQUIZ and Buenos Ayres remained in status quo.

SUMMERS and BROWN, were brought up at the Police Court, Cardiff, on remand, charged with a series of brutal outrages upon the crew, consisting chiefly of negroes and colored men.

Douglas Jerrold's Wit. DOUGLAS JERROLD did not first become known to the world as a wit, nor as a humorist, but as a reformer, and a philanthropist. The biographical sketch of him published some years since by the author of "Orion," represented him as a very different sort of person from what his biographers and eulogists have presented him to the world since his death.

The mail contract between New-Orleans and Vera Cruz, has just expired, and will not be renewed. The law now limits the pay to the postage received, and this will not secure the service. Senor MOLINO returned to Washington yesterday, improved in health.

As yet the number of visitors here is unusually small, less even than last year. It is expected, however, that in some measure, at least, the deficiency will be made up from the South, where, it is agreed, the late rains and floods will produce a state of things that will drive northward those who can leave.

The yachts all passed Montauk Point at 20 minutes before 12 o'clock, yesterday; the Rececca and Madjie being side and side. The fleet took the floodtide in the Race, through which they rapidly passed, notwithstanding the light breeze from the southward. Abreast of New-Haven the Rebecca, Minnie and Una had so far the start as to virtually decide the race.

THE GRAD MUSICAL FESTIVAL at the Academy of Music comes off to-morrow-at least the musical part thereof. The programme is all that could be wished on such an occasion. On Monday the picnic will take place at Jones's Wood, where an open air concert, with 1400 performers, will be given.

The camp has been filled for several days with Indians belonging to the different bands of Utes, Bonnacks and Sho- sho-nees, who have assembled in the neighborhood at the request of the Superintendent of Indian Affairs, in order that they might see and appreciate the strength of the Government.

The Psi Upsilon Fraternity was in session in the morning and afternoon yesterday, anti finally adjourned to meet next year again in this City with the Lambda Chapter of Columbia College. At 8 o'clock in the evening the members of the Fraternity sat down to a groaning board, at the Lafarge House. After substantial justice had been done to the substantial, toasts and speeches were the order of the night.

OSTRANDER.--In this City, on Thursday evening. June 24, after a short illness. which she boro with Christian fortitude and resignation, HARRIET OSTRANDER, in the 63d year of her age. Her friends, and those of her brother-in-law. John De Lamateur, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, this (Saturday) afternoon, at 5 o'clock, from No. 205 10th av., without further notice.

I have rarely read a more interesting document than the message of the President, under the date of 21st April, to the Senate, communicating the correspondence between the American and British Governments, on the African SlaveTrade. The public were first apprised, through

To the Editor of the Evening Post: DEAR SIR My attention has been called to two articles published in you paper within a few days, and reflecting upon both my personal and my scientific character The student of science and investigator of nature has, in our present organization of society, but one recompense, outside of his own conscientiousness. This is his reputation.

The stately stars are proud and cold, And walk for aye apart. Nor know the joys they feel who clasp Their kindred heart to heart. O, bitter proud and cold are they They nightly hear our cries Of pain ascend; but nevermore Look down with dimmer eyes.

The arrest of Captain JUDKINS,, of the Cunard steamship Persia, on the complaint of a Custom-House officer, who was prevented from returning to the Quarantine dock after boarding the ship on her last voyage to this City, has been made the subject of inquiry in the Imperial Parliament, and has also elicited considerable comment in the English papers.

NAVAL.--The United States sloop-of-war Saratoga, Commander Lu?er, sailed on Thursday from Hampton Roads, for the Gulf. She touches at Key West for orders, and to communicate with Commodore Meintosh. The Saratoga takes the young Midshipmen, who have recently passed their examination, and who are to be distributed among the vessels attached to the Home Squadron.

INCREASE OF TAXATION--APPLICATION FOR SEPOYS FOR AGRICULTURAL LABORERS, ETC. By the arrival of the bark Princeton, we have a Demarara Royal Gazette of the 8th instant. Tile Colonial Legislature had adjourned. They Imposed no new taxes in the place of the old Registration Tax, but materially increased some of those previously in existence;

Canadian papers report the occurrence of a dreadful fire, caused by the clearing of lands, in the County of Chicoutimi, which has been carried, by a strong wind springing up at the time, over the greater part of the townships in that County. consuming all before it and rendering desolate and houseless over one hundred families, equal to seven hundred souls.

CHINESE IN CALIFORNIA.--Recently a law has been passed by the Legislature of California, absolutely prohibiting the immigration of Chinese or Mongolians into that State. This statute takes effect on the 1st of October next, and has been printed in the Chinese language for distribution in Asia, in order to prevent future emigration.

AGASSIZ NOT GOING TO PARIS.-We stated a few days since, on the strength of an announcement in the London Athenaum, that Professor AGASSIZ had been induced by the liberal offers of the Emperor of the French, to consent to go to Paris;

In consequence of repairs about to be made in the building No. 175 Broadway, the second floor of which was opened for a business men's daily prayermeeting on the 4th of April last, and which has been uninterruptedly devoted to that purpose with, It is said, great religious benefit, up to the present time, the closing meeting was held yesterday afternoon at 3 3/4 o'clock.

ANOTHER BRUTAL OUTRAGE.--A Stage driver, employed on the Lafayette-avenue line, was arrested yesterday for committing an outrage upon the person of a little girl less than 11 years old. It seems that, on Thursday evening, three girls were playing on the corner of Fulton and Lafayette avenues, when this driver, named JOHN DOLAN having no passengers, induced them to take a ride

Dates from Galveston are to the 14th inst. The corn and pecan crops are said to be very large. Cotton looks fine, and wheat promises an abundant return. By a private letter received from New Mexico, the Texan learns that there is great excitement in that section of the country in regard to the new mines of gold and silver lately discovered there, Many will amass fortunes in a short time.

The whole of Europe, and we might add, the whole of America, is on the tiptoe of expectation to know what Louis NAPOLEON means by his armaments. Half a million of soldiers, seventy thousand sailors, and a steam fleet as large as England's, were never got ready for mere show.

THE SHIP THAT RAN DOWN THE ISAREL BEURMANN-The whaling ship Spartan, Capt. TURNEAD which was in collision with the Label Seurmann, an took off her passengers and crew, arrived at Edgartown of the 22d inst., with 1,400 barrels sperm oil Another report mentions her arrival at Nantucket on the same day, and altudes to the collision with the brig, but says nothing about the crew.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am persuaded that the many friends of that indomitable and worthy man, the Rev. RALPH HOVT, will rejoice to know that his late great misfortune, the destruction of his church by the tornado, has in no degree disheartened him, or caused him to abandon the pious enterprise in which he had unreservedly embarked nearly all of his own earthly mean.

SPEEDY RETRIBUTION.-One of the most deplorable results of that practical immunity from punishment which various causes concur in securing to criminals, is the disposition of peaceable men to assume the right of speedy retribution. By this is meant the prompt shooting down of any assailant, which forcible measure, it is claimed, is the only eflicacious preventative.

Everything connected with the laying of the Atlantic Cable possesses a peculiar interest at this particular time. Lieutenant the Baron BOYE, who is now on board the Niagara, presented to Captain HUDSON the following letter of introduction from the Hon. THOMAS H. SEYMOUR, our Minister at St. Petersburg:

THE CASS -HERRAN TREATY TO BE RATIFIED. By an arrival from New-Granada, with later dates than any yet received from Bogota, we learn that there is a strong probability that the Cass-Herran Treaty will be ratified at last. The New-Granadian House of Representatives bad accepted the Convention in its original shape, and though the Senate had not receded from its amendments, it was expected that upon a joint ballot the liberal party would triumph.

By the arrival at this port of the schooner Sciota, from Carthagena, we have received later intelligence from Bogota than that brought by the last mail steamer. We learn that the New-Granadian House of Representatives has accepted, without alteration, the Cass-Herran Treaty, though the Senate had not yet receded from its amendments.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your comments on the management of the Erie Railroad, in your notice of Mr. MORAN'S note on Saturday, and in the Money Article of Monday's TIMES, appear to me so hasty, and so unjust to the Erie Company, that I am induced to ask space for a few remarks in reply.

STABBING AT BLANCARD'S HOTEL--JEALOUSY THE CAUSE.--Shortly after midnight yesterday morning, quite an excitement was occasioned among the guests at Blancard's Hotel, corner of Broadway and Twelth street, by the announcement that Edward J. Anderson, a young lawyer boarding at the hotel, had stabbed Captain Thomas Dunham, an elderly gentleman, also a boarder at the house.

We have already published the call for a Convention of Railroad officers to be held at Buffalo on the 30th inst. Such Conventions have been held at Buffalo and elsewhere, we know not how often. No great trouble is generally experienced among the delegates present in coining to an understanding.

The Vanderbilt steamship Ariel, Capt. LUDLOW, from Bremen, rid Southampton 16th inst., passed Cape Race at 4 P. M., yesterday, the 25th inst. She was intercepted off the Cape by the newrs-yacht of the New-York Associated Press, which arrived here today, with a synopsis of her neews.

JOHN COCHRANE ON COMMERCE AND FILLIBUSTERING.-The Committee of a Democratic Club in the Seventeenth Ward, presented an address to JOHN COCHRANE on Friday nigtt, indorsing his Congres sionlal career from the start to the end.

JAMES B. SWAIN ARRESTED CHARGED WITH LIBEL BY ARCHBISHOP HUGHES.--Archbishop HUGHES, last Tuesday, procured a warrant to be issued for the arrest of JAMES B. SWAIN, editor of the Albany Statesman, charging him with libel in publishing in his paper a letter in which it was asserted that the Archbishop was connected with " the Circle of Jesus," a secret society in this City.

The United States Mail Steamship Moses Tay lor, JOHN MCGOWAN, Esq., Commander, from Aspinwall, June 19, with the mails, treasure, and passengers, from San Francisco June 5, brought down by the Pacific Mail Steamship Golden Age arrived at this port at an early hour yesterday morning. The United States steam frigate Colorado, Commodore McINTOSH, arrived at Aspinwall on the 17th inst. at 4 P. M., from the City of San Domingo.

THE MUSICAL FESTIVAL.--The opening Concert of the grand Musical Festival now in progress, took place last night at the Academy. It was an unfortunate necessity that compelled the selection of the Sabbath for the opening entertainment-and we were not surprised, although sorry, to see a slim attendance in the lower part of the house.

The death of Edward Moxon, the poet's publisher, is announced in the London papers received bv the Persia. He was the friend of Charles Lamb, the elder Disraeli, Samuel Rogers, Barry Cornwall, Sheridan Knowles. Fanny Burney, Alonckton Milnes, John Forster and Tennyson. He was universally respected.

The arrival of the Richmond Committee of Conference, in relation to the removal of the remains of President MONROE, was expected on Saturday, but instead of that the following dispatch was received from them by the Common Council Committee: RICHMOND, June 25-4 P. M. SIR. Circumstances hitherts unforeseen render it impossible for us to say at what time we may be able to arrive in New-York. WILLIAM MUMFORD.

The Tribune lives in a chronic state of alarm lest there should be a war. Justly regarding war as among the most dreadful scourges that can among the world, it forgets that there can be any other evils, and spends its days in exhorting our Government never, under any circumstances, to do anything which can possibly give other nations provocation or excuse for resorting to its fearful chances.

The chief incident at the Convention to-day was the introduction by Mrs. JULIA BRANCH, of NewYork, of the following resolution: Resolved, That the slavery and degradation of woman Proceeds from the institution of marriage; that by the marriage contract she loses the control of her name, her person, her property, her labor, her affections, her childran, and her freedom.

DISAPPOINTMENT AND SUICIDE.-The chambermaid at the Westchester House, on going her rounds yesterday morning, found one of the room doors locked and key inside. As no response could be obtained from the occupant, the door was burst open, and CHARLES S. BENERY, who had taken the room the previous evening, was found lying dead in the bed, and an empty bottle which had contained laudanum, on a table near him.

ARCHBISHOP HUGHES IN THE FIELD.--The Roman Catholic Archbishop has prosecuted the proprietor of the Albany Statesman for the statements made in letters from New-York, published in that paper, professing to give the details of a secret organization among the Catholics, of which the object was said to be to control the political action of the country.

EMBEZZLEMEN.-WILLIAM EDMINDS, formerly a clerk in the employ of DANIEL C. ROBBINS, druggist, No. 91 Fulton-street, New-York, was arrested Saturday by Captain SMITH, of the First Precinct, on a charge of stealing from his employers. About $250 worth of the stolen property was found at the residence of the accused, in this City. He was sent to New-York for examination.

Tile steamship Moses Taylor, with the California mails of June 5th and over $1,700.000 in treasure, arrived at this port yesterday morning. We receive by this arrival later intelligence from Central and South America as well as from California and Oregon. The Central American news is important.

The Republican has just received intelligence that the Salt Lake mail, with Camp Scott dates to June 5, was received at St. Joseph on the 22d. Mr. H. F. MAYER, who accompanied the mail part, furnishes the following memoranda of the trip: Encountered a heavy snow-storm, lasting three days, from Independense Rock to Platte Bridge; met Col. HOFFMAN twenty, and Capt. MARCY fifty miles from Camp SOOTT.

A CASE FOR TMK UNDERGROUND RAILROAD-SLAVERY OF WOMEN.-Mrs. JULIA BRANCH, of this City. struck a blow for Freedom at the Rail and Reform Convention, on Saturday, by the introduction of the following resolution: Resolved, that the slavery and degradation of woman proceeds from the institution of marriage ; that by the marriage contract she loses the control of her name. her person, her property, her labor, her affections, her children, and her freedom.

THE YACHT RACE.--Our neighbor of tile Herald not long ago bought a yacht ;-and no child of two years old was ever so tickled with a plaything. The flickering energies of his decaying newspaper have been devoted to crowing over it ever since. Poor BENNETT was compelled on Saturday morning to get the TIMES in order to learn that his yacht had won the great race around Long Island.

UNREQUIRED LOVE.--The Erening Post and the Tribune have our sympathy. Their championship of the British cruisers has been zealous and wholesale-but it seems not to have been appreciated either at home or abroad. Both those journals have insisted that the British had a perfect right to visit and overhaul our ships at pleasure.

SMALL-POX ON SHIPBOARID.--On Saturday last the ship Republic, from Bremen, Capt. BROOKMAN, arrived in port, bringing with her about 300 immigrant passengers, and several cases of small-pox. The sick were sent to the Small-Pox Hospital, and the well were vaccinated and removed from the ship to the St. Nioholas,

THE MAYOR'S POLICE.--Sergeant BIRNIE has returned from a very successful raid upon the bogus lottery schemes. He relates that he left on the 14th of this month, and proceeded to look after the promothers of the North Carolina State Lottery, which was to be drawn on the 26th. He proceeded to Jersey. After live days, the officer stopped the inter.

By the British Mail Steamship Bogota we have dates from Valparaiso to May 16, and from Callao and Lina to the 27th. There is no news from Ecuador, and not much of importance from any part of the South Coast. PERU. The public press is almost completely occupied in discussing the merits and demerits of the candidates for President, the two principal being General CASTILLA, the present Dictator, and Don DOMINGO ELIAS.

By the Moses Taylor, which arrived at this port yesterday from Aspinwall, we receive important news from Central and South America. The Nicaragua transit grant was signed on the 8th of May last in favor of Commodore VANDERBILT and his associates, and an " act of incorporation" places them on the footing of a corporate body.

It seems to be necessary for a certain set of uneasy spirits, thinly scattered over the country, to assemble once or twice a year, for the purpose of uttering their notions and theories.

M. FELIX BELLY AND T. F. MEAGHER AMONG THE PASSENGERS--COMMERCIAL NEWS. The United States mail steamship Empire City, S.P. GRIFFIN,Esq.,commanding, arrived this morning from New-Orleans and Havana. Her dates are from New-Orleans the 20th inst., and Havana tl.e 23d. The Granada, from Aspinwall, delivered her mails duly to the Empire city at Havana.

THE PRESIDENT'S CARE OF PHILADELPHIA.Mr. BUCHANAN has sent three members of. his Cabinet on to Philadelphia to make choice of a suitable location for a new Post-Office. We wish he would extend a similar proof of his fatherly care for this City, provided that the Secretary of War be not one of the men he sends.

CENTRAL AMERICAN AFFAIRS--The Washington Correspondent of the Journal of Commerce writes as follows : "The Executive Government is engaged in this heated term, in preparations for settling in our own way, all matters pending between us and Nicaragua.

The greater part of the vessels of the Home Squadron have already reached our coasts, and are cruising diligently about the Gulf in search of the offending Britishers. The Wabash saw the Vice-Admiral. In Jamaica, and received from him every assurance of the speedy cessation of further visits from Her Majesty's cruisers, accompanied with the positive denial of said cruisers having received orders to search any American vessels.

A VERY MELANCHOLY CASUALTY--A SON OF JUDGE SELDEN DROWNED.--We were deeply pained this morning on the receipt of a telegram announcing the melancholy fact that the eldest son of Judge SELDEN, of the Court of Appeals, aged 12 years, was drowned yesterday in Irondequoit Bay, near Rochester, where the Judge resides. He had gone to the bay, in company with his father, for the purpose of learning to swim.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-The overpowering heat, the German Festival, and other things interfered with Signor AMODIO'S benefit last night. The house was poorly attended, the performance very excellent. It is now announced that Wednesday will be the last appearance of all the artists. All the miscella. Deous benefits are postponed sine die, and with this one performance the season comes to an end.

The time for awarding the prizes to the winning yachts, was 10'clock. yesterday morning. The ?? was awarded the first prize, for sloops, and the slivie the first prize for schosners. The sum made up by the regular entries was abour $400, and an equal amount was subseribed by outsiders, It has been equality divided between them.

Our controversy with England on the Right of Search is at an end. According to our Washington advices the British Government concedes, in its fullest extent, the doctrine asserted by tile United States, and abandons every pretension to the right of, visiting, searching, detaining or arresting American vessels for any purpose whatever.

POLICE DEPARTMENT.-The Police department of the Mayor's office was unusually busy on Saturday. JOHN KREGI was charged with keeping an inteiligence office at No. 1 Greenwich-street, without license. Eight persons were variously fined for a violation of City ordinances.

On Saturday morning, the trial of Mrs. SARAH LITTLES, at Rochester, came to a close. It will be recollected that she was indicted for participating with her brother, IRA STOUT, already convicted, in the murder of her husband, CHARLES W. LITTLes, on the 30th of December last. The case occupied a special Oyer and Terminer five days.

STEALING A GOVERNOR'S HORSEAND BUGGY.-At 2 1/2 o'clock Saturday afternoon Governor Pinckney, having occasion to visit Blackwell's Island, left his horse and buggy standing at the ferry foot of Fiftyninth-street. A young Irishman, named James Ryan, took a fancy to the establishment, untied the horse, jumped into the buggy, and whipping up the animal, started off at dashing speed.

THE GERMAN MUSICAL FESTIVAL -Beneath a burning sun, and amid orchard trees unstirred by a single breeze, the Germans held another of their peaceful Festivals, yesterday. Thirty thousand persons, of all ages and of both sexes, sweltered in the hot air, and felt themselves free and happy.

A tent has been pitched on an open space of ground in Rutlaud, to receive the members of the "Free Convention." A medley of people, of all sorts of shades; of heterodox notions; white, black, partially black, badly sun-burned and fair in face, have come up to have sweet counsel together. The gathering is free in all ways.

The Board of Health met yesterday afternoon, Mayor TIEMANN in the Chair. A resolution was offered by Councilman BRADY, to the effect that, as the keeping of swine in the City in large numbers is a nuisance, the City Inspector be authorized to remove all swine congregated in larger numbers than four on a single lot of ground.
