THE MYSTERIOUS AFFAIR AT THE DEPOT STILL A MYSTERY.-Yesterday, Coroner HILLS, of NewYork, in company with Coroner McANALLY, of Jersey City, made a partial examination into the circumstances attending the depositing of the body of "Grannie CLARKE" at the Jersey City Depot, and caused an examination to be made by Dr. OLCOTT.

AESOP'S labored and brought forth a solitary mouse; the swill-milk mountain brings forth two--in the shape of two reports. To the Editor of the New-York Times: DRAR SIR: Perit me, through the columns of your wicely-circulated journal, to call the attention of the Tax-payers of the city of Brooklyn, to a subject which, at the present time, should greatly interest them-I refer to the subject of sewerage.

RECEPTION AT PUBLIC SCHOOL No. 11.-The pupils and teachers of Mr. MoMURRY's Sixteenth Ward School, No. 11, gave a reception to their friends yesterday. The exercises were spirited, and several novel features were presented in the methods of instruction and management of the school, The number of pupils was 1,856.

THE REPORTED WIFE-MURDER.--An inquest was held on Monday, by Coroner GAMBLE on the body of SUSAN MEIGHAN, whose death was reported in Monday's TIMES as caused by violence at the hands of her husband. The evidence showed that the deceased and her husband were very intemperate in their habits, and that they frequently quarreled.

The U.S. sloop-of-war Decatur will sail to-morrow for Paita and Callao, and after remaining at each of those ports for a short time will proceed to San Francisco, where the ship will go out of commission. The Merrimac and Saranac are also expected to leave Panama shortly for the South. The Vandalia will remain at this station in place of the Decatur.

Noll's Band occupied the orchestra, and played several popular airs.

DATH OP TWO DISTINGUISHED PHILADELPHIANS. The Hon. ROBERT T. CONRAD died at his residerive in West Philadelphia, on Sunday evening. His illness was short and its fatal termination quite unexpected. Judge CONBAD was a native of Philadelphia, his birth having occurred about 1807.

McGEE, or McKIE, who killed Mr. WALKER, at the Charlestown State Prison, eighteen months ago, was hanged yesterday in Suffolk County Jail, at two minutes past 10 o'clock A. M., precisely. There was a select party of four hundred persons present to see the "spectacle," and I must suppose they enjoyed it, for no one not forced by duty to "assist" at such a proceeding would attend it unless his nature is essentially brutal.

A HINT TO THE AMERICAN COLONIZATION SOCIETY--Among our foreign intelligence, we presented, the other day, an account of the seizure of Africa. Her cargo of African apprentices, who had mutinied, were landed, it will be remembered, at Monrovia, and were allowed to go their ways.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The Summer season at this house came to an and last evening, when the third act of "Masanlelio," and the second and third acts of "Traviata," were performed to a good audience. All the artists were warmly received, and the entertainment was calculated in very respect to make us lament the absence of so many good artists.

The science of contracting a national debt was neglected in the old political schools. FLORENTINE MACHIAVELLI was obviously at fault in the business; and, indeed, pursuing the track of investigation from his down to more recent times, we are pained to discover how confused are the most respectable authorities regarding this difficult specialty.

A SCHOOL OF SCIENCE--President KING announced, at the late Commencement of Columbia College, that in October next a "Post Graduate," or University course, would be instituted in connection with and under the auspices of the veritable College of which he Is the head. This Course is to embrace a "School of Science," a "School at Leisure" and a "School of Law."

The Detroit Free Press gives an account of the recovery of a woman who had been enticed into the Berlin Free-Love "Cure." Some two weeks since a married man, occupying a good position amount the respectable and intelligent of Detroit, applied to a magistrate for assistance in finding his wife, a young and lovely woman, who had disappeared a day or two before.

LATEST INTELLIGENCE FROM PLUM GUT--Poor BENNET is trying to go through Plum Gut again! With rather more than his usual sensitiveness, he insists that he was not on board the Rebecca during the race,--a fact which makes her conduct explainable only OR the principle that "blood will tell."

Lee-Avenue Jubilee--5,000 People Out. All East Brooklyn turned out yesterday in its holiday dress to the greatest festival of the season--the "Jubilee of the Lee avenue Sabbath-School." For this grand occasion extraordinary preparations had been on foot many days. The School, which with its weekly "boys meeting" is one of the best known and most wholesome institntlons that Long Island boasts, now numbers some 1,500 scholars, and about 100 teachers.

The counsel for the prosecution contended that the report was partial and distorted, and calculated to prejudice the public mind In reference to the facts in the case.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Of all the sources of systematic plunder in this plundered City, perhaps there is none more extensive and burdensome than the fabulous amounts Paid to Referees, It is a burden the party bears alone. The abuses that have sprung up with the system, and grown with its growth, are in their results enormous.

The Rochester Democrat mentions that on Friday and Saturday of last week, two hundred and seventy-nine cars loaded with fat cattle passed that city eastward on the New-York Central Railroad. The Democrat says: " All this makes lively business in that particular line, and few think of the amount of suffering which has to be endured by the poor brutes while on the route.

FIRE IN ST. MARK'S-PLACE.--Shortly after 9 on Wednesday night a lire was discovered on the third floor of the dwelling house No. 74 St. Mark's-place, owned and occupied by HENRY SPEAR. The firemen were promptly at the scene of the fire, and prevented the flames extending beyond the floor on which it was discovered. The furniture is damaged by fire and water to the amount of $800;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Why should our citizens be heavily taxed for a grandd "Central Park," when the parks we now have are kept in such a miserable condition ? The public authorities seem not to know or care that there is such a place a Toralkins-square under their charge, and yet this square is the largest in the City and the most frequented.

The "Art Exhibition," now open in the Alumni Hall of Yale College, has assumed such proportions as to call for something more than the casual notice it has already received. The anticipated arrival of the antiques recently executed by the lamented BARTHOLOMEW for the Linonian Society, it was expected would mark an era in the development of the love of Art among us.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The TIMES of this morning contains an editorial which does great injustice to President BENSON, and reflects generally on the operations of the Government, in regard to emigrants to the French Colonies. A brief history of the circumstances, so far as they relate to the ship Regina Clay, and so far as they have come under my observation, may not be inappropriate.

A last accounts from Trinity Bay, there were no signs of the steam frigate Niagara, now due there. The weather was represented as favorable for the Telegraph enterprise. MIKE WALSH arrived in Washington, yesterday, from Mexico, where he has been as the Special Agent of the Government.

CELEBRATION OF THE FOURTH.--The Committee of the Common Council of Jersey City have made arrangements for the celebration of the Fourth of July on Monday next, as follows: At sunrise the Continentals will fire a salute of thirteen guns from the Cunard dock; at noon, thirty-two guns will he fired and the church bells rung.

The great mountain chain, extending from the Russian possessions to the Straits of Magellan, contains gold in all its parts. Not indeed in such abundance as to dispense with the employment of capital and industry. Both have found full scope in California, and the field for their profitable operation is continually enlarging.

MORRISON.--In this 'City, on Tuesday, June 29, Mrs. ?? Morrison, relict of the late John Morrison, aged 79 sears and 8 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 86 Jane st., on Friday afternoon, July 2, at 3 o'clock, without further invitation.

THE RECENT HOT TERM--We have just had a remarkably hot period, following heavy rains. In the Middle and New-England States, where neither the gain nor the grass were far advanced, the heat of the past forts night has done wonders. Indeed, without it the superabundant moisture must have proved quire injurious.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I wish to call the attention of the public and of the Directors of the Hudson River Railroad to a state of affairs on that Road which, sooner or later, will lead to some frightful accident.

Second-Lieutenant R. A. WITTIER, U. S. Marine Corps, and Lieutenant E. C. STOCKTON, U. S. Navy, were lately tried before a Naval Court-Martial at Panama, found guilty, and sentenced--WITTIEE to be dismissed from the service, and STOCKTON to be cashiered. The President yesterday approved both sentences.

FIGHT BETWEEN TOM HYER AND AN ENGLISH BULLY.-A desperate fight took place, near 12 o'clock last Fight, at EZRA WHITE'S drinking saloon, in Broome-street, near Broadway, between TOM HYER and an English buffer named JIM DUNN, alias STEWART, said to have been recently released from the State Prison.

The great Gulf of Fonseca, so well known to navigators, and considered by them as the best and safest harbor on the Pacific coast, is always greeted with pleasure by travelers entering It from the ocean, It has been so often described that it seems there is little left now to be added to the accounts of its beauties.

BELLY-COSE. -- THE Paris correspondent of the Commercial Advertiser writes as follows concerning the operations of M. BELLY in Central America: "However this may be, I have just seen a letter written by M. MARCOLETTA, late Nicaraguan Minister at Washington, now at Paris, to an official here, in which he enters into explanations in regard to the Millaud and Belly contract for the construction of the interoceanic canal.

THE FRENCH EMIGRATION SCHEME IN LIBERIA.-- A letter in another column, from one personally familiar with the facts of the case, corrects the statements of Mr. BRULAIS, which we noticed yesterday morning, in regard in the emigrants found on board the Regina Call It seems that they were not from Liberia--that they could neither read nor write, and that they were not persons originally sent out to Liberia from the United States.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: will you permit me, through your paper, to call the attention of the Christian public to the fact that the discontinue of the up-town mid-day prayer-meeting has been a great deprivation to many. It is no doubt true that 12 o'clock is not the proper hour for the present sultry weather, but is a wise to cease these meetings altogether?

The Secrctary of the Navy, it is said, has decided to have the new vessels ordered by Congress built at Government Navy-Yards, and not by private contract. The eight propellers will be built respectively at the seven different Navy-Yards on the Atlantic coast, and the side-wheel steamer at one of the California ports.

COMMENCEMENT OF PACKER INSTITUTE.--The animal commencement of the Packer Institute, in Jor?iemon-Street, held last evening, was a pleasant occasion, as it always is. The gradnating class numbered thirty young ladies--the largest company that have ever received diplomas at one time in this Institution. The reports in the Academic and Collegiate Departments were read by Dr. BELL and the Rev. Dr. BUDDINGTON.

A FENCE CRACKED.--On Wednesday night last, a hardware store in Bayard-street was broken open and robbed of a large amount of property. The Sixth Ward Police who were deputed to ferret out the thieves, obtained, yesterday, certain information by which they were induced to search the premises No. 18 Mott-street, occupied by two Polish Jews, named Abraham Schaffer and Morris Levy.

It is located on Fourteenth-street, with entrances there and on the Sixth-avenue. The Nineteenth Annual Commencement of the Rutgers Institute, was held yesterday at the Rutgersstreet Church. A CONVICTED AND REPENTANT F.F.V.-The Hon. JOHN LETCHER, a prominent member of Congress from the Old Dominion, has been detected in a crime of no ordinary magnitude, and in a spirit of penitence has humbly made confession thereof. His sin consists in the fact that some ten years ago he was not altogether sound on the Slavery question.

CHAMBER OF COMMERCE--The monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held, yesterday (Thursday) afternoon, at the rooms corner of Pine and William streets the President in the Chair. Communications were received from the Light-House Board, and also from the Philadelphia Board of Trade, on the subject of inland transportation and the commerce of the Lakes. They were placed on file.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Appended to a late report, made to the Board of Education by the Committee on Normal Schools, is a schedule of the qualifications required of the Public School teachers. It is to be presumed that this document is a fair exponent of the character of the instruction given to the 60,000 scholars annually educated at the public expense.

The Greenwich-street Prayer Meeting closed its services for the Summer on Tuesday last at noon, under the lead of the Rev. Mr. SMITH. This has been one of the most marked meetings of the City. It has been sustained, mostly, by the merchants and shipmasters of South-street and vicinity. The meetings have been distinguished Dy a spirit and pathos quite remarkable.

COMMENCEMENTS--SOCIETY MEETINGS. The commencement of Trinity College, Hartford, took place on Thursday. Twelve students graduated. The following honorary degrees were confirmed : M. A., ad eundem, upon the Rev. ANDREW OLIVER, of Vermont, and the Rev. R. M. ABERCROMBIE, of Hartford. M. A., in hunarem, upon Mr. CAUSTON BROWN, of Boston, and Mr. WM. D. SHIPMAN, of Hartford.

The remains of JAMES MONROE, fifth President of the United States, which have lain twenty-seven years in the Second-street Cemetery, in this City, were early yesterday morning disinterred, and taken quietly to the Church of the Annunciation, in Fourteenthstreet.

THREE BURGLARIES--At an early hour yesterday morning, a young boy brake into the dwelling house No. 38 Bond-street, and stole a lady's workbox, containing $25 and a quantity of jewelry. He was seized just as he was making off with his booty and given in charge to an officer.

CALVIN W. PHILLEO, author of "Twice Married," "Akin by Marriage," and other magazine articles, well know n to readers of Putnam's and tile Atlantic, died at Suffield, Conn., on the 30th ult. Mr. PUILLEO was an active politician as well a popular writer.

The steamship Indian Empire, the pioneer of the new ocean line between Galway, in Ireland, and this port, via Halifax, which was reported by the Arabia as having been run on the rocks in Galway harbor on the 18th, left that port on the evening of the 19th, and arrived at Halifax at 11 o'clock on Wednesday night. She will probably reach here on Sunday night or Monday morning.

WANTON MURDER IN PHILADELPHIA. --Shortly after 1 o' clock this morning a murder was committed at Second and South streets, in the Fifth Ward. A young man, named CHARLES BRAY, Jr., was sitting on a chair in the market-house, with one or two acquaintances. A person named WILLIAM II. SMITH, with a companion, passed along, when BRAY made a remark that they were "tight."

NAVAL INTELLIGENCE.--The United States frig we Cumberland, which we announced at the Island of Madeira some time since, set sail for Santa Cruz, Teneriffe Islands, on the 8th of May, reaching that port on the 11th of the same month. The Cumberland remained at Santa Cruz until the 15th of May, when she left for Port la Grande, in the Cape de Verde Islands, and reached there in safe y after seven days' sail.

THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE IN THE BROOKLYN PUBLIC SCHOOLS.--The Brooklyn Board of Education adopted a resolution last year that the Declaration of Independence should be read in all the schools on the last school-day before the Fourth of July of each succeeding year, the reading to be accompanied with such other appropriate exercises as the teachers might choose to select.

Mrs. ROSE, whose disclaimer we published yesterday, is not alone in her refusal to accept the ex treme doctrines advanced in the Rutland Convention of "Reformers. Mr. GEORGE SENNOTT, of Boston, desires it to be understood that he did not take part in the proceedings from any love for the anti-marriage party, in which he has no faith.

An attempt has just been made to organize a Vigilance Committee at Richmond, Va. It was not, however, successful. There was indeed, a call for a meeting on the evening of the 30th ult, but the Mayor and the Governor warned the persons at the bottom of the movement to desist, which monition they judiciously obeyed.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Why is not a fenced pathway, rendered compulsory on all persons erecting or altering ?? in great thoroughfares, like Broadway? At the present moment it is absolutely dangerous to walk there. Why are merchants allowed to block up the foot paths with bulky goods, ds, causing the pedestrian to walk out into the muddy or dusty street 14 passing?

EMIGRATION OF FREE NEGROES TO JAMAICA.A public meeting was held at Kingston, Jamaica, on the 23d of April last, to devise measures for inducing the free colored population of our Southern States to emigrate to that Island. The meeting appears to have embraced the leading men of Kingston.

Prior to the last Congress, the practice existed in the House of Representatives of members voting themselves extensive libraries of valuable works published at the expense of the Government, This abuse was corrected at the last Congress, and the books were ordered to be deposited in some School, Association or Public Library, to be designated in each Congressional District by the member thereof.

Captain HENRY DE RIVIERE, who figured in this city some months since, as a lecturer on the Sebastopol Campaign, has turned up again, under very suspicious circumstances. Having met with indifferent success in his public appearances here, he left for the South, where he presently got into trouble. Only a few weeks since, we published an account of a duel in which he was engaged at New-Orleans.

Mrs. MARY FOLGER, widow of the discoverer of Pitcalm's Island, died at Massillon, Ohio on the 28th ult, aged 81. She was born in Nantucket. Her husband, Capt. MATHEW FOLGER, died in 1828. Wm. Z BEALL, a wealthy Maryland planter, died at Prince George's County last week. He left an estate of four large plantations, and one hundred and fifty slaves, twenty of whom are liberated by his will.

The Chicago Press and Tribune have been united under the combined title of the Press and Tribune. The polities continue Republican. The deposed Editor of the Chicago Union, Mr. LOUIS SCHADE, has resumed his seat.

" N, i, ni, c'est fini, L'affaire du Cagliari!" So says a French journal, rejoiced at the termination of this monotonons affairs. Two thousand pens rest suspended in air, a hundred cabinets, a thousand journals, have suddenly had the chairs pulled out from under them. And every man asks his neighbor why there was so much fuss about the Cagliari?

We heard no newsboys, but in every direction, from an early hour throughout the day, torpedoes, crackers and pistols kept up an incessant series of explosionsThe noisiest outbursts of patriotism by a desperate self-denial were probably postponed until to-day, when bonfires, the ringing of bells, the firing of cannon, and the explosion of all manner of detonating compounds, will celebrate the day.

MUNSELL--In this City, on Saturday, July 3, at the residence of her son, J. E. Munsell, Mrs. ABBY T., widow of the late Rev. Jabez Munsell, of Norfolk, Va., in the 82d year of her age. FALL OF A SIDEWALK--INJURY TO SEVERAL PERSONS.--A temporary plank sidewalk, erected in front of some new buildings in process of erection in Houston-street, near Avenue A, suddenly gave way, on Saturday evening, precipitating several persons Who were walking over it into tile cellar, a distance of nearly twenty feet.

Messrs. A. A. LOW BROTHERS' clipper-ship Great Republic, after several years' absence, has arrived at this port, bringing a light assorted cargo. She is still commanded by Captain LIMEBURNER, and the noble ship looks none the worse for the long and arduous service in which she has been engaged.

The British ship Grotta, Capt. NICHOLS, which sailed from Sagua La Grande on the 25th of June, with a cargo of Sugar, bound to Liverpool, was yesterday towed into Quarantine by the steamtug Huntress, Capt. BAGGS, who fell in with the ship ten miles East of Fire Island early yesterday morning.

The State Normal School, at Trenton, under the Principalship of Prof. WILLIAM F. PHELPS, closed its sessions for the Spring Term of 1858, on the lst of July, for a vacation of eight weeks. This institution wes established by an act of the Legislature in 1855.

FRANK AND UNBLUSHING.-Captain DE RIVIERE, upon his own showing, is a contemptible scoundrel. In a letter designed to smooth over one piece of villainy he confesses another. He has been persuading a young lady to marry him. Her father, having discovered that he had been previously married in this City, refuses his consent and discards his acquaintance.

Three vessels have arrived at Quarantine within the last two days from Cuban Ports, all of which have lost more less of their officers and crews from yellow fever. The name of the Captain of the ship Grotto, who died after reaching port yesterday, was DUNLEVY not NICHOLS, the latter being the first mate of the ship. Captain DUNLEVY belonged to Richmond, Me.

The Hell-Gate pilots, with their families, numbering in all about three hundred, under the management of Messrs. STEPHEN HORTON, HENRY and NOAH F. MASON, (pilots,) chartered the steamboat Jacob Bell, and proceeded to City Island, on yesterday, the 5th--one of the most charming spots on the East River-where they passed the day most pieasantly, in sailing, fishing, and roving about the fields.

The 4th of July, which came this year on Sunday, was celebrated yesterday in the usual style, and with no less enthusiasm than is usual. The day was fine, not too hot, considering the month, and the evening was cool, delicious and cloudless, giving excellent opportunity for the display and appreciation of the fireworks.

VIRTUOUS DECREPITURE.--Nothing so promotes virtuous sentiments as weak knees, a lame back and a general decay of the faculties. Our dilapidated contemporary the Herald illustrates the general fact. While it was enterprising and able to get about, it used to report public meetings of all kinds, with great fullness and accuracy.

EMIGRATION OF FREE NEGROES TO JAMAICA.-A public meeting was held at Kingston, Jamaica, on the 23d of April last, to devise measures for inducing the free colored population of our Southern States to emigrate to that Island.

Mrs. MARY FOLGER, WIDOW of the discover of Pitcairn's Island, died at Massillon, Ohio, of the 28th ult., aged 81. She was born in Nantucket. Her husband, Capt. MATHEW FOLGER, died in 1828. WM. Z BEALL, a wealthy Maryland planter, died at Prince George's County last week.

A HINT TO SUCKLING RAREYS.--At the present moment John Bull is sucking the nob of his crabstick in an ecstasy of big-eyed wonder at the achievements of Mr. RAREY, the American horsetamer. Johnny cannot make out how it is done, although there is so little of trickery in the business that Mr. RAREY teaches the art for a consideration.

An accident occurred, last evening, on the Hudson River Railroad at Sixty-eighth street, which resulted in the death of two men named JAMES MOSHAFFER and GEORGE, W. GIDNEY. As the 6 P. M. Express train, from New-York,was passing Sixty-eighthstreet, Mr. GIDNEY, who was on the track, was run against by the locomotive and thrown several feet in the air.

Yesterday all passed off quietly in this city-no accidents of consequence occurring. In the morning, the Continentals fired a salate on the Cunard Dock, as per programme, and paraded for a short time in the morning. The city was then left to the control of the juveniles, so far as outward celebration was concerned, and they, as usual, made most of the license given them.

The screw-steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 23d ult., passed Cape Race at 11 o'clock yesterday (Friday) forenoon. She was intercepted by the news yacht of the Associated Press, which arrived here this afternoon with a summary of her news. The R. M. steamship Africa, From New-York on the 9th, arrived at Liverpool on the 20th of June.

THE FIRST STEAMBOAT UNDER HIGH BRIDGE.A novel and somewhat adventurous exploit was yeslerday performed by the steamboat Rattler, Capt. P. MABIE, which has been running as an excursion boat on the Harlem River to McComb's Dam. Being a day for great achievements, Capt. M. conceived the bold idea of pushing his discoveries above his old stopping place, and steamed through the Dam, passing beneath High Bridge, and stopped at a landing below Kings's Bridge.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Why is not a fenced pathway, rendered compulsory on all persons erecting or altering buildings in great thoroughfares, like Broadway ? At the present moment it is absolutely dangerous to walk there. Why are merchants allowed to block up the footpaths with bulky goods, causing the pedestrian to walk out into the muddy or dusty street in passing ?

The University of Pennsylvania held Commencement Day on Friday, The graduating class numbered 16. Honorary Degrees were conferred as follows; Doctor of Medicine on BENJANIN R. CARMAN, of Pennsylvanta: CHESLEY MARTIN, of Virginia; GEO. P. COGGESHALL, of South Carolina; J. HAYES SHIELDS, of Pennsylvania. Master of Arts on D. BETHUNE McCARTER M. D. Doctor of Divinity on the Rev. AHRAM N. LITTLEJOHN.

The troubles at the Dudley Observatory are coming to a point. On Saturday the Board of Trustees dismissed the Scientific Council, empowered President OLCOTT to take legal possession of the property of the Observatory, in the name of the Trustees, and appointed Professor O. M. MITCHEL, of Cintinnati, as Director of the Observatory, in place of Dr. GULD.

The intelligence from Mexico, which we published on Saturday, demonstrates once more the necessity which has long existed for placing our relations with that Republic on a new footing.

The remains of Ex-President MONROE arrived here at 8 1/2 o'clock this morning, and were received by an immense throng on the wharves, including the military of Richmond. The Governor and Mayor went on board immediately, and were introduced to the guests.

The Board of Supervisors met on Monday, for the purpose of considering the assessments, and again yesterday afternoon, with Supervisor PURDY in the Chair. The following was submitted, and after the transaction of some other business, the Board adjourned.

THE LOCOMOTIVE DIFFICULTY.--In the absence of a British outrage, it is gratifying to know that we have one of a domestic origin to keep us going through the Summer months. The question of right of search seems to be in a fair way of settlement ; the question of bringing the locomotive down below Fortysecond-street is not altogether in such a favorable condition.

The world has seen instances of learned blacksmiths and poetic shoemakers; men bred as lawyers have before now set a parish on fire by their vivid preaching, and painters have mortified the whole order of inventers by their startling inventions. Still it remains generally true that a man performs the duties of a profession best who has been bred to them.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Miss CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN completed her season here last evening, playing Lady Macbeth, one of her greatest impersonations. Every one regrets that the engagement of this talented lady should terminate so abruptly, and as far as the public is concerned, unnecessarily. But Miss CUSHMAN is inexorable, and departs to-day in the Persia.

Capt. HENRI A. DE RIVIERE, the French adventurer,w hose varied exploits since his arrival in this country, as detailed in the TIMES of Monday, have gained him considerable newspaper notoriety, and whose connection with the Blount family, of Mobile, has recently brought him to the notice of the Police Authoritles of this City, was arrested on Sunday evening, at the Hotel Napoleon, Hoboken, N. J.

WATERMAN.--In this City, on Tuesday evening. July 6, at the residence of her son in-law, E. D. Morgan, Mrs. LYDIA WATERMAN. in the 73d year of her age. Her remains will be taken to Hartford for interment. McCoMB --n this City, on Sunday, July 4, Mr. JOHN McCoMB, in the 60th year of his age.

The weather at Newfoundland was very stormy all day yesterday, and unfavorable for the success of the Atlantic Telegraph enterprise, though at the date of our last dispatch from Trinity Bay-7 o'clock P. M.--the skies were brightening, and clear weather was promised. Nothing had been heard of the Telegraph fleet.

The steamship City of Washington, Capt. PETAIE, which sailed from Liverpool on the 23d June, arrived at this port yesterday morning. A telegraphic abstract of her news has already been given. We append additional particulars.

THE PROPOSED NEW STATE ON LAKE SUPERIOR.--We have, heretofore, adverted to the proposed formation of a new State from portions of Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota, adjacent to Lake Superior, and including the mining region.

By the brig T. M. Mahew, from Bermuda June 27, we have late papers, but they contain little news of importance. The Government steam yacht Syren, Captain SMITH, which dispatches from the British Admiral to Lord NAPIER, arrived at Hamilton on the 20th ult., having been absent about twelve days.

The arrival within a few days past of several vessels from Cuban ports, with their whole crews sick with yellow fever, and of others which have lost a large portion of their number by this disease at sea, has awakened considerable anxiety in the public mind, and has furnished the health officer with fresh arguments for the rigid enforcement of the Quarantine regulations for protecting the health of the port.

Before Judge Beats. This being the last day of June Term, and July Term commencing to-morrow: The Court convened to receive the return of recognizances and ordered the continuance over of those not forfeited.

TAKING TIIE PLUM GUT ROUTE AGAIN!-The Herald is endeavoring to make its readers believe that the TIMES is an obscene and improper paper,--that it publishes licentious and improper matter. This is disinterested on poor BENNETT'S part, we must confess,--for if he should succeed in convincing his own subscribers of that fact he would lose two-thirds of them in a week.

The 4th of July, which came this year on Sunday, was celebrated on Monday in the usual style, and with no less enthusiasm than is usual. The day was fine, not too hot, considering the month, and the evening was cool, delicious and colorless, giving excellent opportunity for the display and appreciation of the fireworks.

The Secretary of the Interior has decided the great contest for the title to "Superior City." The claim of BRISSETT, WARREN, DENNIS and RAY is rejected, because it is shown that they are Chippewa Indians of mixed blood, and have no right to preempt.

RUT LAND CUM PLUM GUT.--The spectacle of a public print and that print the Herald, blubbering over the depravity of the age, is at once imposing and memorable. It can be compared only to the lamentations of a pickpocket who, finding himself in the daguerreotype collection of the "Rogues Gallery," bemoans the progress of art.

BOOKS OF ACCOUNT.--No thrifty businessman neglects to keep an account of his expenditures, and if he finds the figures enlarging from year to year, the fact makes an impression upon his mind, if not a change in his habits. The same course should be pursued by a nation. Comparisons may be odious, but they are often salutary.

The Washington Union says Baron Wetterstedt presented his credentials to the President on Saturday, and was received as Minister Resident of his Majesty the King of Sweden and Norway. We also learn that the Chevalier de Sibbern, who for a long time so creditably represented his Government in that capacity in the United States, has recently been appointed Swedish Minister at the Ottoman Porte.

The yacht Wanderer arrived at Charleston, S. C., in seven days from New-York, beating against head winds all the way. Capt. CORRIE was saluted on entering the harbor, from a party on Sullivan's Island. and also by the Revenue Cutter Aiken.

My next communication will be dated on the march towards Salt Lake--for the present week has brought in all the supplies and troups for which the army of Utah have been postponing its advance. First came Colonel HOFFMAN with his supplies of provisions, clothing and forage ; and on the 9th instant Captain MARCY came into camp with over 900 mules and about 150 horses of the stock which he went to New-Mexico to purchase.

DEATH OF A CANAL COMMISSIONER.--The lion. SAMUEL S. WHALLON, whose death at Erie, Penn., on Tuesday afternoon, has been announced by telegraph, was elected to the office of Canal Commisstoner In November, 1855. His term would accordingly expire on the 31st of December next. Mr. WHALLON was a merchant, and resident of Maysville, Chautauque County, where he was greatly esteemed.

The President sent the following letter to the Demceracy of Philadelphia, in response to an invitation to attend their celebration of the Fifth: WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 3, 1858, GENTLEMEN: I have receivedd your very kind invitation to be present at the meeting of my fellowcitizens in Independence Square, to celebrate the approaching anniversary of our National Indopendence. Would that it were in my power to accept this invitation. This, however, is impossible.

POLICE APPOINTMENTS.---The following Police appointments were made by the Common Council on Tuesday evening: First Ward--Fisher, Callahan, Carroll, Harley, Chace and Valoid, Second I Ward--Shields, Murphy and Strong. Third Ward--Chazotle, Jordan, Moles, McLaughlin. McNamara, Duffy, Ayres.

THE NEW MAYOR OF NEW-ORLEANS.--Mr GERARD SMITH, the new Mayor of New-Orleans, transmitted his inaugural message to the Common Council of the city on the 29th ult. Mr. STITH, being a printer, knows the virtues of brevity and conciseness. His message does not exceed half a column in length, but it says a great deal in that space.

INDEPENDENCE DAY OF A SUNDAY.--In this letter to the Boston committee upon the celebration of Independence Day, the Hon. ROBERT C. WINTHROP recommends, that hereafter when the anniversary occurs on Sunday, it shall be observed on the day before, rather than upon the day ensuing.

From crinoline to pants is a vast collapse. Yet there are women who covet the change. We have before us a paper called The Sybil, published at Middletown, New-York, which purports to be " devoted to dress reform." Its head bears, as a pictorial embellishment, the figure of a woman in the full Bloomer costume.

EMANCIPATION SENTIMENT IN MISSOURI.--We final in St. Louis papers letters from several persons nominated for the Legislature of Missouri by "Free Democratic Conventions," in which ground is taken distinctly and strongly in favor of emancipation.

It is reported that Commander PAGE will command the vessel soon to be dispatched to Paraguay. The Commissioner of Indian Affairs, with the approbation of the Secretary of the Interior, has taken prompt measures with a view to preventing further Indian depredations on the Sioux agency.

The office of City Judge is likely to be invested with an odor that will have anything but the effect of a stimulant upon the minds of lawyers to make them ambitious of filling that judicial position.

The American Gulf Squadron are now busily engaged in cruising in search of her Britannic Majesty's gun-boats, and show themselves before the Moro Castle nearly every day. The Dolphin, Water Witch and Vixen entered the harbor, but after a brief stay, suited again to join their companions.

CAPTAIN DE RIIVIERE.--Captain DE RIVIERE remained yesterday at the Hotel Napoleon, in Hoboken--not once showing himself outside its door. Mrs. BLOUNT remains there, also; but both she and the proprietor of the house deny that Miss BLOUNT is there.

No news of the Telegraph Fleet had reached Trinity Bay, N. F., at 8 o'clock last night. The weather was favorable during the entire day. LEITCH promised twenty-four hours' notice of her time of departure, so that dispatches to the latest moment can be sent out by her.

THE PROPOSED TERRITORY OF NEVADA.--It was apparent that a very strong feeling prevailed in Congress, before its recent adjournment, in favor of creating some previsional form of government, either by the grant of a territorial act or otherwise, for the settlers in Carson Valley, but the pressure of business during the few last weeks of the session prevented any action on the subject.

A conflict between the State and City authorities has arisen in Philadelphia. The North American explains the origin of the difficulty: For the past two days the vicinity of the First District Station house, at the old Moyamensing Hall, has been in a high state of excitement, consequent upon the belligerent proceedings of the Health Officer, Mr. ARTHUR HUGHES on the one side, and the city police occupying the Hall, on the other.

EFFECTS OF ADVERTISING.--The New-York Ledger is a weekly paper of but few year's experience, but its publisher has expended about a quarter of a million dollars in advertising it in the columns of this and other journals--$100,000 of it within the last year. The results have justified this magnificent outlay The Ledger now issues some 320,000 copies regularly; keeping eight single-cylinder power presses during on its weekly edition from Monday morning till Saturday night.

From the Red Wing (Mm) Republican, July 1, This morning, at about 1 o'clock, as the U.S. Mail packet Galena landed at out levee, a fire broke out about her smoke stacks, which soon spread, and resulted in her total destruction. The origin of the fire no one is able to ascertain, though it is supposed it was communicated to where it was first discovered from the furnaces of the boilers below.

The scandalous romance of Capt. DE RIVIERE and the BLOUNTS, mother and daughter, continues to enliven the shades of Hoboken, and the Hotel Napoleon is besieged by a crowd of curious visitors. As was expected, the Captain declined the preliminary examination yesterday, on the charge of larceny preferred by Col. BLOUNT, and gave bail in the sum of $1,000 to await the action of the Grand Jury in October.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-The promised series of Promenade Concerts is announced for Monday evening next, under the direction of Messrs. ANSCHUTZ and MUSARD. The parquet of the Academy will be floored over, in order to afford room for pro menades; vases of flowers are to decorate the building, and refreshments are to be furnished as becomes Summernight festivals. The music is to be of the light order,

VACANCY IN THE OFFICE OF CANAL COMMISSIONER.-The death of the Hon. S. S WHALLON makes a vacancy, which it devolves upon the Governor to fill. Mr. WHALLON'S term of three ears would expire on the last day of December next, and consequently the person appointed in his place will hold the office till that date.

From the Spirit of the South, Nashville, We have great pleasure in placing before out readers the following "extract of a letter" to Mr. C. W. FARRINGTON, from his uncle, Mr. J. S. RAEEY, the celebrated horse tamer, now in England. It has been forwarded to us by Mr. F., with the following P. S. as a guarantee of its genuineness:

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Your Albany correspondent alludes, in the TIMES of this date, to the course pursued by the Hon. GIDEON .J. TUCKER at the last session of the Canal Board, at Albany and in this connection defames and falsely impeaches the character of the Canal officers In this City.

REGATTA AT NEWBURG.-The Newburg people having saught the regatta infection, and not be ing favorably situated for sailing, tried their hand at rowing on Monday last, and had an exciting. race among the skiffs and fishing boats. The race began at 2 P. M., the distance being 5 1/4 miles. It was won by Factory Belle, of Newburg.

THE LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.-The receipts of fare from passengers who passed over this road on the 3d inst., amounted to about $3,000-about onehalf of which sum was taken at the ticket-office in Atlantic-street, and the balance by the conductors on the trains. There was a large quantity of freight passed over the road the same day. This is the best day's work this road has ever had.

The scandal has been very widely discussed, and interests very large numbers of people.

If the world were governed according to the ideas of Mr. BRIGHT and his Manchester friends, the most sanguine dreams of the millennarian would be realized, but then a world of millenarian saints would he required to realize them. The reign of peace principles will only be supreme when the bulk of mankind are pacific; the era of good-will may be anticipated when all men will and do good.

THE MINNESOTA IN CHINA.--A letter from an officer on board the United States frigate Minnesota, off Woosung, China, dated April 10, 1858, to the Philadelphia Evening Journal, states that nothing had yet been accomplished towards the treaty.

The meeting of the Republican Central Committee, which was held at Congress Hall to-day, is an event of some considerable Interest. The question whether the call for a State Convention should be for one or two delegates, had already come to be discussed with considerable warmth.

The 5th of July could not have been a better day, in point of weather, if man had had the making of it-and he is conceited enough to think he can improve all things. The day was sunshiny and breezy, and with as little dust about it as ever shows itself in Summer.

The following letter has been addressed to R. A. HARRISON, Esq., Acting Consul at Kingston, by the whole body of the mercantile interest of that city, We have already recorded the death of Colonel HARRISON, his father, whose death is so deeply lamented.: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Wednesday, May 26, 1858.

SUICIDE BY DROWNING.--An aged and highly respectable lady, named SUSAN RENNIA, residing at Nyack, came to the City a few days since on a visit to a daughter residing here. At 10 o'clock, Wednesday evening, Mrs. RENNIA proceeded to the pier foot of West Sixteenth street, took off most of her clothing, carefully tied them in a pocket handkerchief, and then plunged into the dock.

About noon on Tuesday last, five men and two boys ascended the shaft at the Thomastown colliery, in a car resting on a cage. When within a few inches of the top, a pin upon which the cage rests when it reaches the top, was pulled out too soon, and the car was not on a level with the platform sufficiently to permit it to be rolled off the cage.

The declared value of British manufactures and produce exported from the United Kingdom during May was less by a million sterling than in the corresponding month of last year; but even this decline was an improvement upon the average of the five months, the falling off on the exports of which period amounted to about seven millions, as compared with 1857.

DEAR SIR :--Your kind favor of the 14th is received. I hardly agree with you that a general movement can be made that will clean out the Augean Stable. If the Democracy were overthrown, it would result in giving place to a greater and hungrier swarm of flies.

Brooklyn Items. THE LIQUOR CASES.--The parties Convicted some months ago in the City Court for selling liquor without license, and who appealed to the General Term, had their case argued yesterday before Judges BROWN, EMOTT and LOTT.

The recent discoveries on Fraser's River are peculiarly interesting to our Canadian neighbors, as being within British territory. Accordingly the provincial Press anticipates with a good deal of confidence the sudden upspringing of an important colony in that region, after the manner of California.

COLLISION BETWEEN TUG BOATS--ONE OF THEM SUNK.--The tug-boat Sarah Brown, while proceeding up the North River, about 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon, was run into by the tug-boat McDenald, which had just left one of the slips near the Battery, about 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and so seriously damaged that she almost immediately sank.

The Hon. HENRY C. DEMING, of Hartford, delivered a very interesting discourse in the College Chapel, last evening, commemorative of the lamented sculptor BARTHOLOMEW. He began by observing that the life of a true artist must be studied in his works, for his life is but an attempt to project his soul upon the canvas or into the marble or bronze with which he labors.

The New-York Tribune is sorely grieved by the prevalent desire for increase of territory. It groans in spirit over " the acquisition of foreign provinces and States," and regards protectorates for Mexico and Central America as a "swindling imposture."

The Leavenworth Daily Ledger, of the 2d inst, announces the acquittal of General LANE of the charge of killing JENKINs. The decision of the Court was to this effect: "In making out a case against the defendant, it was necessary, first, to prove that a murder had been committed; and, secondly, by General LANE.

A TAILOR'S EMBEZZLING CLERK TURNED ITINERANT PLAYER-ABRUPT TERMINATION TO A DAZZLING PROFESSIONAL CAREER. Officer Bower, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, brought to the city yesterday, from Norwalk, Conn,, a young man named Thomas W. Bond, for whom he has been searching several days.

To the Editors of the Evening Post : DEAR SIR : You have published in your journal the letter of a Washington correspondent of the St. Louis Republican of June 21, giving what purports to be a statement of the origin and adjustment of the difficulties between Mr. GWIN and myself.

RAILROAD ABSORPTION.--There is no little excitement just now in the usually staid city of Rochester, respecting the transfer of the Genesee Valley Railroad to the control of the New-York Central. Some years ago a Company was formed to build a railroad from Rochester to Mount Morris, a distance of fifty miles or thereabouts.

WILLIAM MULLIGAN, known to his confreres, and the public In general, by the familiar appellation of "Billy" MULLIGAN, was seated, yesterday morning, in the Court of General Sessions, in the immediate vicinity of his counsel, Ex-Judge PHILLIPS and Mr. TAEODORE E. TOMLINSON.

STEAMBOATS VERSUS CAI.S.--The railroads which skirt the Sound, and pass through the various populous towns along the shore from Harlem to New-Haven and Hartford, find, during the warm season, strong competitors in the steamboats which ply on those routes--the, traveling public showing a decided preference for the pure air and quiet repose of the large steamer, over the packed cars and the stifled and dusty road.

JUDICIAL PRECEEDINGS ON THE HABEAS CORPUS--NEW WARRANT ISSUED FOR THE ARREST OF DE RIVIERE ON A REQUISTION FROM THE GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF NEW-YORK--THE CAPTAIN ABSCONDED FROM THE HOTEL NAPOLEON AND HIS WHEREABOUTS UNKNOWN.

It would be impossible to-day to escape a reference to the British outrage question; for here, as well as at home, it is the predominant topic of discussion. The French have been dragged into the question through their African apprenticeship system and the irritability which already existed against England, and it would not be surprising if the last word in this dispute should pass between France and England.

From the Providence Journal. We have seen a letter from Guaymas, in the State of Sonora, to a gentleman in this city, wherein mention is made of the contract, or "grant," as it has been called in New-York, of large portions of the States of Sonora, Chihuahua and Durango, to a company in New-York, about which much has been said recently.

THE NEW-YORK YACHT CLUB. There was a general meeting of the Yacht Club on Thursday, at which it was resolved that the several yachts should rendezvous at White stone on Wednesday, August 4, and await the order of the Commodore for their Summer cruise.

TRYON.--In this City, on Friday Afternoon, July 9, ?? A., wife of Frank W. Tryon, and daughter of Alexander Clark, Bsq. Particulars of the ?? in the evening papers. HOLLY. Relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from the Church of the Ascension, 5th av., corner of 10th st., on Saturday, July 10, at 3 1/2 o'clock P.M., without further notice.

MURDER IN SOMERVILLE, (MASS.)--The Bosto post says: A murder occurred in the town of Somerville on Monday afternoon under the following circumstances: WILLIAM MCNABB visited the house of JOHN MCKENNA, corner of milk and Poplar streets, Somerville, to obtain a drink, and while there had some conversation with a Mrs. HEFFRAN in regard to a scythe snaith belonging to her husband.

RECEPTION OF THE SEVENTH REN IMENT.--Be. low will be found an order of the 71st Regiment, who are to receive the 7th National Guard on their return from Richmond. The National Guard return by the Camden and Amboy Railroad, and land at pier No. I North River, at 6 1/2 o'clock.

Another Philadelphia city official is in trouble. Charges have been brought to trial against Supervisor McEntel, for the following offences: Using the horses and carts of the public for his own private work; expending money in grading streets not 30 feet in width; spending more money for grading than was authorized by Councils, and having a payroll for over ??4,000 for a period of 25 days; and of being guilty of a misdemeanor in office.

Mr. Benjamin H. Miles, brother of John Miles and Franklin Miles, of Rochester, was killed in a duel at Tueson, Arizona Territory, on the 27th of April last. The circumstances of the affair appear to be. that Edward Miles, a brother of the deceased, got into a difficulty with a man named Curry, and challenged him.

Alter traversing a goodly section of the country , let me give you a summary of what I have seen and heard of the crops. You see I am judicious, for my attack is upon the stomachs of your readers, by telling of stomachic productions. Touch the stomach, and you have the head and heart secure enough.

The late Indian war of Oregon and Washington proves to be a canker upon the public Treasury. The Secretary reports that upwards of six thousand dollars were paid to J. ROSS BROWN alone, for salary and travel, during the year 1857,while examining into these "War debts.

From the Boston Transcript. Letters have been received in this city, dated Sebastopol, May 24, by which we learn that the work of raising the sunken Russian fleet progresses rapidly and with remarkable success. We make the following extract from the letters; "We have raised whole tile 16-gun vessel-of-war Smelya, and brought her down to the Admiralty, slung between the caissons, last night.
The steamship Edinburgh, from Glasgow on the 26th of June, arrived at this port yesterday. Her advices are no later than those by the Africa, which left Liverpool on the same day.

RECKLESS BUILDING--SEVERAL LABORERS INJURED.--On Saturday afternoon a tier of beams in the new building being erected in Fifty first-street, near Seventh-avenue, suddenly gave way, injuring six laborers who were at work on the building. JOHN BRADY had three ribs broken, PATRICK SHERIDAN his left arm fractured, PATRICK HENE?AN his head badly cut, and OWEN LOVILL.

The true philosophy of political parties is simple. An Administration in power with of-course, have supporters. If its acts are substantially right the whole country should uphold it, so that there would be, in fact, but one party. Patriotism and good sense require that any Administration which does well should receive general support. Opposition in such a??, from any quarter, would be factions.

TAN WOMAN'S OWN HOSPITAL.--The third annual Fair for the beautiful of the New-York infirmary for Women and Children, will be held early in December. The success of this young institution, which is, emphatically, a Woman's Hospital, is such as to encourage its brands in further efforts for its permanent establishment. Its funds have been managed with great economy, and,

OVID, N. Y., Thursday Morning, July 8, 1859. To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article, starting from Syracuse, and which has found its way into other papers, reflects unjustly upon the Agricultural College enterprise and the Board of Trustees. The impression is given that there is some difficulty likely to interfere with the prosecution of this great work, whereas there is not the least reason for any such statement.

The officers to be chosen in November next, on a general State ticket, are a Governor, a Lieutenant-Governor, a Canal Commissioner, and a State Prison Inspector. On Thursday last the Republican State Committee met at Albany and inaugurated the campaign by designating the 8th of September as the day, and Syracuse as the place, for holding the Nominating Convention of that party.

It was due to the National Guard and to the august ceremonial which occasioned their absence during the last week from this City, that on their return they should be worthily received by their brother citizen soldiery. And a great reception they had,-somewhat impaired, it is true, by the circumstance that they did not arrive till about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, whereas they were expected by 9 o'clock on Saturday evening.

The Case of Michael Cangemi--Motion in Arrest of Judgment. SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM--July 10. Before the Hon. Judges Davis, (presiding,) Ingraham, Wright and Sutherland. On Saturday, according to the announcement of the Judge at Circuit, before whom Michael Cangemi was tried and convicted for the murder of Eugene Anderson, the prisoner was brought before the General Term of the Supreme Court for sentence.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Sir: I have noticed in your paper of the 7th Inst., under the head of "Telegraphic News from Washington." a synopsis of certain Indian treaties made in the Territories of Oregon and Washington in 1855.

SUSPENSION OF THE ERIE CANAL ENLARGEMENT.--We regret that it has become necessary, for want of funds, to suspend work on the Western Division of the Erie Canal. Contractors must be paid heavy damages, and there will be wholesale waste for years. Tile gentlemen who anuually assemble at Albany to govern the State, think little and know less about the Canals.

LATER FROM MEXICO.--A sailing vessel which arrived at New - Orleans on Friday, brings Vera Cruz dates to the 6th inst. The intelligence imports that the British and French Ministers had succumbed to the forced loan imposed by ZULOANA, and advised their countrymen to pay it. We can scarcely credit this state meet, and we glad to see that the American Minister is not included in it. Mr. FORSYTB is represented, truly, no doubt,

A CONVERTED ACTOR.--According to announcement in the City papers, a sermon was preached at the Baptist Chapel, Harlem, by the Rev. Mr. STRICKLAND, lately belonging to the sock and buskin, but who has been converted, baptized, and ordained as a preacher, in connection with the Baptist Church. Tile congregation was a very numerous one, as might have been expected from the novelty of the circumstance of an actor turned preacher.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am New-Yorker, and, as a matter of course up to the eyes in business. Not a day can I spare all the year round (except the Fourth of July and New-Year's day) to take a trip into the country with my family and enjoy the sweet uncontaminated air.

The United States Mail steamer Fulton was boarded off Cape Race on Friday by the Associated News Yacht, and her news, four days later, transmitted from St John's by telegraph. She reports an improved market for cotton and breadstuffs. The news from India, by telegraph from Malta, is highly important. Sir HUGH ROSE had captured Calpee, with a large amount of ammunition and military stores; there had been serious disturbances in the Bombay Presidency;

MORE MORTALITY ON SHIPBOARD.-AFFAIRS AT Or?? --The brig Mary Alvira, of Boston, Captain DALY, (late Captain WYMAN,) arrived at Quarantine on Saturday, from St. Jago de Cuba, which port she left on the 19th of June. She had a cargo of sugar and tobacco, consigned to H. D. BROOKMAN, a crew of seven, and six passengers. Shortly after leaving port the yellow fever made its appearance on

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Pursuant to a call of the Presidents of all the Base-Ball Clubs belonging to the National Association of Base Ball Players, a meeting was held, and the following brief will give you all the particulars, which will be of considerable interest to the public.

Correspondence Cincinnati Commercial. It will be remembered that, a short time ago, several gentlemen visited J. G. BRESLIN, Esq., Ex-Treasurer of State, at his present abode in Canada, for the purpose of obtaining some information of the financial transactions between himself and the outside Treasurers of State with whom he was known to have been connected. But by their efforts but little was learned of the affairs of the office during his administration.

MICHAEL CANGEMI, who has been tried three times for the murder of EUGENE ANDERSOS, and twice convicted, was brought up on Saturday in the Supreme Court to receive sentence of death, pursuant to the verdict rendered on the 19th of last month. The Attorney. General and the District-Attorney, appeared in behalf of the people, and for the prisoner, his counsel, Messrs.

Description of a Journey through the Interior of Salvador. To Captain DOW--Dear Sir : According to my promise I intend devoting a leisure hour or two to a short description of another journey I have made through the interior of Salvador, and which will no doubt prove interesting, as it led through districts seldom traveled by foreigners.

Correspondence of the St. Louis Intelligencer. FORT LEAVENWORTH, Friday, June 18, 1858. Left Fort Leavenworth, K. T.: First Column, March 18.1858, seven companies, under command of Col. HOFFMAN. Second Column, May 20, 1858, seven companies, under command of Lieut. Col. MONROE. Third Column, May 28, 1858, seven companies, under command of Lieut.-Col. MAY.

The warm weather has its effects on the Theatres, but it is a mistake to suppose that they are deserted. For the time of year, we have more than our usual share of amusement. Wallack's Theatre, with the versatile and lively FLORENCES, opens its doors nightly to eager and appreciative audiences, Artists of this calibre are well fitted for the desultory performances of Summer. Their pieces are light and laughable.

THE ARCTIC MYSTERY.--We publish in another part of the TIMES, this morning, a later from Mr. PETER FORCE, of Washington, in relation to the supposed discovery of a Northwest passage by Sir JOHN FRANKLIN.

THE HEAT AND THE PUBLIC HEALTH.--Notwithstanding the excessive heat of the past ten days, there appears to have been an actual improvement in the state of the public health, as indicated by the reports of the City Inspector.' The deaths during the week ending on Saturday were but 442, being a decrease from the week before.

Hobart College Commencement. Correspondence of the New-York Times. The Annual Commencement of Hobart Fren College, at geneva, took place last week. On Sunday morning the Raccalaureate Sermon was preached in the College Chapel by the Rev. Dr. JACKSON, President of the College. On Tuesday afternoon the judges reported on the merits of the White Prize Essups assigning the first prize to C?/ D. VAST of ?? City; the second to JOHN II: POST OF Batavia.

The lion. L. D. CAMPBELL has issued the follow. lowing circular to his late constituents: Since the United States House of Representatives placed me on their "retired list," I have not addressed my late constituents, who have so repeatedly honored me, In regard to the recent exercise of the Federal power, by which their sovereignty, as well as the right of the people of Kansas to govern themselves, were trampled down.

MICHIGAN. The Detroit Advertiser, of July 9, says: "In the southern and western counties, our Wheat harvest has commenced, and from all the accounts we receive, the crop will be secured in most excellent condition, and as a whole the yield will be large.

THE ROCHESTER MURDER--MRS. LITTLES ON HER WAY TO SING SING.--Sheriff BABCOOK, of Rochester, passed through the city this morning with Mrs. LITTLES, on her way to Sing Sing, to live out her sentence of seven years for having been cognizant of the murder of her husband by her brother, IRA STOUT. she appears young, and has not a vicious look;

RETAINING OTHER PEOPLE'S LETTERS.--The rights and wrongs pertaining to letter correspondence have of late received a good deal of discussion from the Press. Mayor TIEMANN'S well-meant endeavor to break up swindling and prohibited trades by the seizure of correspondence in the Post-Office, appears to have awakened the public to an inquiry into the whole subject; and the question whether the power exercised by the Mayor is a lawful one admits of more than one opinion.

To the Editor of the New-York Times; When through your paper, attention was called to the great misfortune of the Rev. RALPH HOYA in the destruction of the "Church of the Good Shepherd," a though stuck me that possibly a considerable sun night be realized towards its reconstruction by the sale of a new edition f Hayt's Poems.

Correspondence of the St. Louis Democrat. LEAVENWORTH, K. T, July 2. --JACK HENDERSON arrived in town on Thursday morning, and put up at the leading hotel. He was immediately arrested on a bench warrant, issued by Judge GARDINES, of the Probate Court. An application was made by his counsel, to Judge LECOMPTE, for in writ of habeas corpus. It was granted, and HENDERSON was released.

HOT AGAIN.-Yesterday and Saturday were exceedingly close, hot days. There was little air stirring, and that little seemed to be about as hot as the rest. Several cases of sun-stroke were reported: HENRY LAIFRINK, a German, 32 years of age, was sun struck on Saturday afternoon while at work in Water-street. He was taken to his residence, No. 333 Madison-street, but died in a few minutes.

PLYMOUTH CHURCH SABBATH-SCHOOL. Sabbath-School attached to Plymouth Church yesterday closed its sessions for a Summer vacation, and the occasion was improved to afford the children, their parents and the friends of the school a chearful time at parting. Bouquets of the most beautiful flowers bedecked the room,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of June 9, under the column headed "City Items," was an article in relation to the Ladies Union Aid Society, giving some statistics of its origin, progress, liabilities, , but as it contains some errors of tact, at a regular meeting of the Board of Managers, held July 2, it was resolved respectfully to request that they may be correct through your columns.

The United States storeship Relief, JAMES H. STRONS, Lieutenant-Commanding, arrived at this port yesterday, from Aspinwall vid Key West. She brings the invalids from the Pacifie Squadron. The departure of the Relief left Aspinwall without a man-of war, and was regarded with regret by the white inhabitants, as they are under continued apprehensions of a riot among the negro and native population.

From the Boson Post, 7th. The fine ship Joseph Whitney, from Baltimore, Capt. S. HOWES, was making for this port on the day of the celebration of the nation's birth, and among an unusually brilliant array of passengers from different parts of the country was the distinguished Senator, JEFFERSON DAVIS, of Mississippi. The patriotic suggestion of the captain

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Believing that you would publish willingly anything having for its object the relief of the suffering, I am emboldened to address a few lines to you on the condtion of the work-women of New-York, hoping that these lines, though simply written, may serve to awaken a little public interest in regard to them.

The railroad interests in Virginia, Tennesce and Kentucky, which initiated the project of a transatlantic steamship line by sending the lion. WM. BALLARD PBESTON to Europe to negotiate upon the subject, still strongly entertain the hope of effecting their purpose. The only obstacle in the way of its final consummation is the raising of $1,500,000, required by the San Nazaire and Orleans Railroad Company of France as a condition of their cooperation in that project.

BOGERT.---In Brooklyn, at his late residence, No. 330 Fulton st., on Saturday, July 19, Mr. JAMES BOGERT, in the 93rd year of his age. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully initiated to attempt his funeral, from the North Dutch Church, ?? Falton and William st., this (Monday, morning, at 11 o'clock, without further invitation.

The United States Mail steamship Fulton, Capt WOTTON, from Ilavre and Southampton 30th ult., passed Cape Race at 8 o'clock yesterday morning. She was intercepted by the news-yacht of the Associated Press, which arrived here shortly after noon to-day with the following summary of her mews : The Fulton has 110 passengers for New-York. She had strong westerly winds to the Banks, but reports having seen no ice.

From the Washington Star. The affidavit of JAMES J. DICKINS. Esq., which we print below, effectually puts at rest the last batch of aspersions upon our fellew-citizen, W. W. CORCORAN, Esq., growing out of circumstances connected with his domestic affairs, in which he has the hearty sympathy of the parents of all properly regulated families in this community.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I beg permission to call your attention to the following article from the Tribune: THE GUARD OF HONOR.-Company C of the Eighth Regiment, we believe, was detailed last night to act as a Guard of Honor to the mortal remains of Presi. dent MoNRoe, which were lying in state in the City Hall.

Somewhat more than a year since, the Press of New-York called attention to the fact that a large number of powerful screw-steamers were building on the Clyde, and at other European ports, intended as freight and Passenger ships between Germany and the Baltic ports and New-York, and predictions were made by intelligent merchants that this class of ships would,ere long, drive our sailing vessels and more expensive steamers from the ocean.

The steam-tug Blue Jacket, just from Liverpool, in twenty-eight days' passage, reports having seen, on the 24th of June, a large and small steamer, both British, in lat. 51 32' north, ion. 32 west. They made signals, but the Blue Jacket had no code, and could not understand them. That same evening, saw a large steamer bearing down upon the others, but could not make out whether they were English or American.

The body of young HAMILTON arrived here from Richmond yesterday morning at 6 o'clock, per steam. er Roanoke, in charge of a Committee composed of one member from each of the Companies of the Richmond Regiment. It was received by a few of the friends of deceased, and conveyed to Trinity Church, where the funeral will take place this after noon, with appropriate ceremonies.

THE BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--There being no quorum, last evening, the Board of Alderman adjourned over to this afternoon. RUN-AWAY ACCIDENT.--A horse of Mr. WM. FARM attached to a buggy, ran away yesterday morning, in First avenue. In passing Forty fourth-street the horse ran against CAROLINE GRUNLET, a child five years of age.

We publish in this morning's TIMES the speech of Senator DOUGLAS in full, on reaching Chicago. His entry to the chief city of his own State was well calculated to gratify him. A very large concourse had assembled to do him honor, and listen to his words.

PUBLIC NUISANCES-.-Every man in the City appears to be better informed in relation to the nuisances which endanger the public welfare, than the officers whose special duty it is to abate them and remove them. All the reforms of abuses in the administration of the affairs of the City originate among outsiders.

To the Editor of the New- York Times : SIR: I observe in your excellent paper of Wednesday, 29th June, 1858. an article copied from the Springfield Republican in relation to the rapid extension of the Canadian "Grand Trunk Railway" towards the Pacific Ocean at Vancouver's island. We in the West are rejoiced that the attention of the country is beginning to be aroused to the importance of this subject.

JAMES WILSON, Commandant, were in readiness on the arrival of the 5 P. M. train from Philadelphia at Elizabeth to give the regiment a salute, A field-piece was placed near the depot,

REDUCTION OF OFFICIAL SALARIES IN CANADA.-On Tuesday of last week the Canadian Government announced to Parliament that a general reduction of salaries has been resolved upon, commencing with those of the Ministers of the Crown, and extending to the whole body of Government employes.

It is very natural that the enormous trade of New-York, and the rapid growth of the City as the commercial centre of the New-World, should excite the wonder and envy of other great towns in the Union, and particularly our old rivals in the race of prosperity, Philadelphia and Boston.

The Secretary of the Interior, says the Washington Star, left the capital on Friday, accompanied by his family, for a short visit to his home in Mississippi. Since his accession to his present position, in March. 1857,. Mr. Thompson has not before been absent for an hour from his post, except on one occasion, when be went to New-York and was away two days. He is expected to be absent from Washington for three weeks.

The Board of Councilmen met on Monday, the President, C. H. HASWELL, Esq., in the chair. A resolution was adopted that the Harlem Gas Light Company be directed to lay mains in One Hundred and Twenty-third-street, from Eighth to Sixth avenues.

Col. TITUS turns up once more in Southern Kansas, at his old trade of horse-stealing. With a party of about 30, he took 15 horses from the vicinity of Humboldt last week, and the Sheriff of Allen Co. pursued them to Titus Camp, but finding the bandits too strong, he returned for a reinforcement.

The increasing tide of travel during the past week has contributed to fill the hotels at Niagara to such an extent as fairly to inaugurate the season. The International and Cataract exhibit healthy prospects, and this influx of visitors has given an impetus to all the subordinate enterprises of traffic.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: We observe with some surprise, in your issue of this morning, a notice of a reprint of a work published by us last year. The name being but slightly changed from the title of our work, it is assumed that the parties therein mentioned, TAYLOR, HARTSHORNE KING, have received the approval of the Board of Under. Writers. Permit us to say that this is a great mistake:

We have at last received some news, though brief and unsatisfactory, of the Atlantic Telegraph fleet, which left Plymouth in England on the 10th of June. The steam-tug Blue Jacket arrived at St. Johns, N. F., on Sunday, in twenty-eight days from Liverpool, and reports having seen in latitude 51 32' N. and longitude 32 W., a large double-deck frigate, with cog-wheels fore and aft, and a large paddle steamer-both English.

The Probable ground on which the Scientific Counsel of the Dudley Observatory retain possession of tile property of the Institution, and upon which they will resist even legal process, is the contract, which they claim, was entered into between themselves and the Board of Trustees in January last.

SELLECK.--In this City, on Monday, July 12 JULIA, only child of Salathiel T. and Emma E. Selleck, aged 2 years. 1 month and 13 days. Relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her parents No. 32 Henwick-st., on Wednesday, July 14, at 1 o'clock P. M. McNAUGHT--In this City, on Sunday, July 11, JESSIE, wife of Andrew McNaught. aged 61 years and 2 months.

The Trustees were wrong at the outset in removing Mr.GouLD,without first filing their charges against him, conferring with the Scientific Council as to the effect of the removal upon the business of the Observatory, and as to the possibility of at once securing a competent successor.

By the arrival of the British brig John Butter, Capt. PARK, we have papers from Santiago de los Caballeros (San Domingo) to June 23. They contain a confirmation of the advices already received, that the revolution had finally ended, and the city of Santo Domingo had been unconditionally surrendered to the legitimate authority of the country.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: On the 5th, while the cannon were roaring which spoke of liberty for the white races, the colored people were assembled to discuss the project of emigrating the Central America, Hayti, or some land o. freedom where they can enjoy true liberty. Spring. street Hall was the place designated, and a respectable meeting was charmed with several very eloquent speeches on liberty, and against proscription.

JEFFERSON DAVIS AT SEA.--The fiery Senator from Mississippi has so far conquered his sectional prejudices as to select Portland, in Maine, for his retreat during the dog days. This, certainly, is one of the most sensible acts of Mr. DAVIS' life, and deserves the especial notice of his biographers.

PORCELAIN PAINT.-In noticing, a short time since, the ornamentation of our publication office we inadvertently omitted any mention of the new porcelain paint with which part of the woodwork has been covered.

From the Chicago Press and Tribune. Mr. DOUGLAS said: I can find no language which can adequately express to this vast assembly my profound gratitude for the magnificent welcome which you have extended to me on this occasion. This vast sea of human faces indicates how deep an interest is felt by the people in the great questions that agitate the public mind, and underlie the foundations of our free institutions.

The Secretary had decided that it did not belong to the Chippewa Indian claimants, because they were not American citizens, and were not preempting in good fait.

What with the heat of the weather, and the absentees in consequence thereof, we are now entering upon the height of the dull season of the Real Estate business. There is little disposition to operate, and very few sales either at auction or otherwise, unless under compulsion of Court.

A paragraph containing the list of appointments by the Faculty, Commencement exercises, , has been going the rounds of the Press for some time, and inasmuch as it abounds in mistakes and inaccuracies, I am induced to send you a correct list of the appointments, for the benefit of the Alumni of the College and your numerous subscribers here.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: While all the scientific and unscientific world are or will be variously exercised in relation to the actual or anticipated approach of yellow fever, and other malaria, will you allow me to contribute my mite, such as it is, to the common stock ? That I can but glance at the subject is evident from its extent, and the limited space and time at my command.

Whatever consequences of an international character may flow from the affair of the Regina Coeli, it is evident that the transaction is to form an era in the history of the French colonies. There is the liveliest dissatisfaction at Paris with the cool treatment of the subject by Lord MALMESBURY.

ARREST OF THE ALBANY MURDERESS.-The Albany Statesmant of Monday says: Mrs. HARTUNG, against whom at indictment is pending for the murder of her husband, EMIL HARTUNG was arrested yesterday by Sheriff' BHRAYTON, about 3 miles west of Fort Lee, in New-Jersey.

A Correspondent from Kirtland, Ohio, gives the following, His letter dates from a small township situated in Lake Country, about twenty miles east of Cleveland, The town is somewhat celebrated for being the first settlement of JOE SMITH and his followers in United States.

The friends of Mr. F. S. COZZENS (Sparrowgrass) will learn, with pleasure, that he has so far recovered from his late severe Illness as to be able to travel. He has gone to the Catskill Mountain House for a few days, in quest of mountain air.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.-Mr. BROUGHAM'S excellend extravaganza of " Columbus" was revived here lair night, with complete success. Few works of this character are so excellently written as this, the latest of Mr. BROUGHAM'S comic productions. it is full of hearty fun, and bristles with alliterative puns which resist the action of time.

It seems now to be an admitted fact, on all lands, that the next Presidential light will be upon " Treasury statistics," and that "niggerism " will be overslaughed. Such being the case, it will be a matter of importance to both the Democracy and the Opposition to have correct data upon which to build their platforms.

The steamship Empire City has arrived, with California advices of the 20th ult. She connected at Havana with the Grunada, from Aspinwall. Which vessel reports that the steamer Sonora brought down 400 passengers and about $1.500,000 in treasure.

The Memphis Appeal has a letter from Helena, Ark ,written under pressure of the last crevasse: "On Saturday, about 1 o'clock P. M., the levee gave way one mile below Helena, and in a short time the crevase was 100 yards wide. I went to see it, as I had heard so much about 'crevasses,' and the devastytion produced by them.

From the Charleston Courier. We have referred to the interesting researches of Prof. S. HENRY DICKSON, K. D., concerning the statistics of stature and weight of the population of the Southern States, and the gratifying conclusion thence derived that the physical conformation and development of the race were not degenerating in America or in the Southern States, as has been hinted by some philosophers.

Yesterday afternoon the funeral obsequies of LAURENS HAMILTON, the private who was drowned on the late excursion of the Seventh Regiment to Richmond, were celebrated in Trinity Church, which was crowded to its utmost capacity. In accordance with the wishes of the family of the deceased, there was no attempt at military display.

A CARD --The undersigned, Trustees and Stewards of the M. E. Church in Greene-street, New-York City, here by certify that they have caused a through investigation of the reports in circulation against our pastor, the Rev. WM. P. CORBIT, and find them false and unfounded; and they believe that his character as a minister and Christian is unblemished.

The total receipts of Common School moneys in Canada in 1857 amounted to [Pound]322,524 Os. 7d., being an increase of [Pound]33,601 18s. on the receipts of the year 1856. The amount of Legislative School Grant apportioned to the Municipalities in aid of Common Schools in 1857 was [Pound]32,951 13s. 4d.
