The United States Mail steamship Fulton, JAMES A, WOTTON, Esq., Commander, arrived at this port from Cowes and Havre last evening. Her dates are from Sonthampton, June 30. The Fulton reached Sandy Hook at 4 A. M. yesterday morning, but was detained six hours and more by the fog.

Judge HUGHES, M. C. from Indiana, made a speech to his constituents the other day, in which he said : "I challenged HARRIS, not because I wished to fight, but to bring on an honorable settlement-and I should have done the same in Indiana. Congress has its rules and customs.

THE HOMICIDE OF MR. SOHL--KILLING A MAN FOR SIXPENCE.--PETER McGINNESS, arrested on a charge of fatally stabbing Mr. SOHL, was examined yesterday by Coroner GAMBLE. He stated that he was 45 years of age, was born in Ireland, and followed the sea for a living.

M. MARCOLETA is the accredited agent of the Nicaraguan Government to the Courts of the Tuileries and St. James.

RESIGNED.-Mr. OLIVER G. CARTER, a Fire Commissioner in the Western District, has tendered his resignation. He was elected for five years.

The Royal Mail steamer Tamar, carrying the Brazilian mails, arrived at Lisbon on the 28th ult., bringing dates to the 7th June. Her advices we find telegraphed to the London Times. Exchange at Rio on London was 25 1/2. Coffee 4,700 to 4,800 reis.

We are a restless people. With infinite labor and enthusiasm, once in four years, we elect a President ; and hardly is he warm in his seat before we cast about for his successor. As a candidate, he is a most interesting personage; but when sworn in and the appointments made, he dwindles to a mere obstacle in the path of the coming man.

From the Journal of Last Evening. Since Sunday noon the, "Storm Eing" has been hovering about in this section of the county, deluging the earth and doing much damage to the crops, On Sunday much damage was done in the vicinity of the Shaker Road.
REMARKABLE CASE OF CIRCUMSTANTIAL EVIDENCE.--A case of considerable interest has occurred in Monroe County, Ark., which shows how strong a chain of circumstances can arise against an innocent person.

MYSTERIOUS AFFAIR NEAR PITTSBURG.-The Pittsburg Gazette has a disconnected and confused story of the discovery of the body of a woman, ap parently a German, in Chartiers Township, PennThe body lay by the roadside, in an advanced stage of decomposition. A discharged pistol was found four feet distant, and a bullet-hole was discovered over the woman's left eye.

From the Evening Post. Two years ago Doctor PETER WILSON, of the Seneca nation, went to Franklin County to aid in the prevention of the difficulties usually occurring at the payment to the St. Regis Indians, of their portion of the annuity from the United States.

ARREST OF SUPPOSED BURGLARS.-Officer BROPNY, of the Hoboken Police, early yesterday morn ing discovered three persons, named HENRY LEGGETT, GEORGE WOOD and JOHN THOMAS, secreted among a pile of stones in the outskirts of the city, and supposing that they were there for no good purpose, attempted to arrest them, when LEGGETT fired a pistol at, his head, the ball passing very near him, but doing no damage.

The United States storeship Relief, JAMES H. STRONG, Lieutenant Commanding, sailed from New-York on the 23rd of March, bound to Aspinwall with stores for the Home and Pacific Squadrons. The crew consisted of 40 officers and men. She arrived at Aspinwall on the 15th of April, making 22 day's passage.

A slave, Paul, in Savannah, has been found guilty of manslaughter, and sentenced to receive five times 39 lashes well lain on, at intervals on three days. Justice Connell dissented from the sentence, believing that the prisoner ought to be turned over to the Superior Court for a more severe punishment.

FRAZER'S RIVER GOLD MISES--GREAT EXCITEMENT IN CALIFORNIA.--By the Star of the West, which arrived at this port yesterday, we have intelligence of a very exciting character from California. The discoveries of gold in the British territory prove to be of the riches description, fully equating the most productive diggings in California or Australia.

Yesterday the Thirteenth Annual Commencement of the students of the above Institution came off under a canvas tent in the magnificent lawn fronting the College. The attendance was very numerous notwithstanding the gloomy visage which Jupiter Pulvius assumed in the early part of the morning. The Archbishop, Bishop LAUGHLIN and several distinguished clergymen, and literati were present on the occasion.

It is in vain for the New-York Tribune to attempt to show any distinction of principle between the acquisition of Louisiana in Mr. JEFFERSON'S time, and the purchase of Cuba or of Sonota now. No such distinction exists. Louisiana may, for the reasons which the Tribune specifies, have been more important to us than Cuba is.

WHITEWASHING THE DISTILLERY STABLES.--The Board of Health yesterday adopted the majority report of the Swill-milk Committee of the Board of Aldermen, thus giving the official approval of the City authorities to the stump-tail nuisance.

The United States mail steamship Philadelphia, GUSTAVUS HARRISON commanding, left New-Orleans on the morning of the 5th inst., and arrived off Havana at sunrise of the 8th. She sailed again for New-York on the night of the 9th, having awaited the arrival of the Granada from Aspinwall. she arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Philadelphia did not enter the harbor of Havana, but remained out at sea during her detention.

Sergeant Berney, with eight of the Mayor's squad, and eighteen of the Fourth Ward Police, made a descent about 11 o'clock Tuesday night upon the disorderly dance house of Peter Dawson, No. 58 Cherry-street, arresting the landlord, his bar-keeper, musicians, female inmates and visitors--in all thirty-three men and fifteen women.

SUSPECTED BERGLARS AND A RECEIVER ARRESTED--PRACTICAL AMALGAMATION.--A few weeks ago, the dwelling-house No. 32 Macdongal-street was broken into, and about $700 worth of jewelry and silver-ware stolen. Two policemen saw two colored men come out of the house, and attempted to arrest them, but the burglars, it will be remembered, discharged their revolvers--probably not loaded, as no harm was done--frightened away the officers, and then made good their escape.

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West, ALFRED G. GRAY, Esq., Commander, from Aspinwall 5th inst., with the mails,treasure, and passengers, from San Francisco June 20, brought down by the Pacific Mail steamship Sonora. arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Pacific Mail Steamship Company's steamer Sonora left San Francisco June 21, arriving at Panama July 5, 8 A M.

REMARKABLE EVENT-In the City court, yesterday, Mr. JOHN BENNETT, livery stable keeper, South Sixth street, Claimed that he had been damaged to the amount of $ 3,000 by the overflowing of a cistern under an engine house, which undermined his premles. He brought suit,. and the Jury rendered a verdict for defendants.

At 4 1/2 o'clock on Tuesday afternoon an explosion of a Gas Reservoir took place at the Manufactory of the New-York Car and Steamboat Gas Company, No. 8 Gold-street, killing instantly a man named JOHN W. SHARP, and injuring several others; fracturing the ?? of MORTIMER LEE. and slightly injuring BARNEY ELLSLER and THOMAS BENT.

THE GAS EXPLOSION IN GOLD-STREET.- An inquest was held yesterday at the Second Ward Station-house upon the body of JOHN W. SHARP, who was killed by the explosion at the manufactory of the New-York Car and Steamboat Gas Company. No. 8. Gold-Street, The evidence showed that there were not as many pounds of steam used as the dimensions of the cylinders with which the experiments were made admitted.
Our advices from Porto Rico are to the 26th ulitme. They are devoid of interest. M. GOTTSCHALK was performing there, and had just given a charity concert in behalf of the Hospital of San Ildefonso.

Before Judge Ingraham. DECISION. Maria H. Metcalf vs. Thomas S. Metcalf and others.--The plaintiff brings this action to compel the defendants to transfer to her certain stocks and securities held by them as trustees under the will of her father. The testator, at the time of his death, and the executors and two of the trustees resided in Georgia, and Collins, the other defendant, re-ides in this state.

Yesterday was Commencement Day at the Institution for the Deaf and Demb; for the new establishments is of imposing dimensions and may as well rank among the Colleges, and enjoy its Commencements as well as they, The occasion was peculiarly interesting because it was the first performance of the kind in the first performance of the kind in the new establishment on Washington Heights.

By the Star of the West we have advices from Aspin wall to the 5th inst. The New-Orleans, Havana and Aspin wall steamship Grunada, on her last trip, landed D. B. ALLEN, son-in-law of Com. VANDERBILT, and his brother; also, W. R. C WEBSTER and Mr. GOTTEL, their interpreter, with $80,000 in hard cash, at San Juan del Norte, on the 28th ultime.

THE NEW - JERSEY BLACKBERRY TRADE.-- It is said that the blackberry crop promises to be unusually large this yea. Few people are aware of the large business done in these and other berries in this and the adjoining counties along the line of the railroads. Over uplands supply a great abundance of the finest kinds.

Strangely enough, and shockingly inopportune in view of the present state of affairs in California, the last Legislature was somehow led to enact a most stringent law to enforce the observance of the Sabbath. It went into operation on the 1st of June. Being regarded as too oppressive

I have it from a reliable source that the State Department has issued instructions to Mr. FORSYTH under no circumstances to abandon his post, but to enter a protest against all improper acts of the Government of Mexico towards citizens of the United States. These acts will be regarded by the Administration as so much capital invested towards the purchase of Sonora and Cinaloa.

A man named ROBERT COONS, married, and respectably connected, and obtained a very unenviable notoriety last Spring by running away with another man's wife, was tarred and feathered at Crawfordsville last night. It seems that the gay Lothario has been in correspondence for some mouths past with a respectable young lady of that town, and had proposed an elopement to which she consented.

The trade-returns which we published a few days ago for the fiscal year 1858, ending by regulation of the General Government on the 30th of June, are suggestive of a few remarks, of a practical rather than party nature. That the Government is deprived, by the result of the year's business in foreign merchandise, of twenty-two or twenty-three millions of revenue, will, of course, be readily ascribed to the late crisis.

The Colorado, bearing the flag of Flag-Officer McINTOSH, arrived here on the 30th ult., from Aspin. wall, after communicating with the Plymouth and the steamer Fulton, off the harbor of Havana. She (the C.) did not go into that port in consequence of yellow fever and small-pox among the shipping.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, whose news was published on Tuesday morning as telegraphed from Cape Race, has not yet arrived at Halifax, at which port she has been some time overdue. The weather is reported as very thick. We have nothing new to report with reference to the Atlantic Telegraph enterprise. There were no signs of the Niagara at Trinity Bay last night.

PETER DAWSON AND HIS TROUBLES.-PETER DAWSON'S" place" in Cherry-street was visited last night by many curious people, drawn there by the reports caused by the proprietor's arrest It had a deserted look, the female boarders being all incarcerated, but PETER was on hand with lights to show his visitors the sights to be seen.

POLITICAL MOVEMENTS.--On Wednesday, a "People's Union Convention" met at Harrisburg, in Pennsylvania, to nominate candidates for Judge of the Supreme Court and for Canal Commissioner. For the former office the Hon. JOHN M. READ, of Philadelphia, was designated, and for the latter WILLIAM E. FRAZIER, of Fayette County.

We give, in this morning's TIMES, several important documents from Utah. A dispatch from Gen. JOHNSTON to the War Department, dated at Bear River, June 16, states that the Army, which was on its march from Fort Bridger to Great Salt Lake City, would probably reach its destination on the 22d.

The audience assembled to hear the Hon. ABRAHAM LINCOLN, on Saturday evening, was, in point of numbers, about three-fourths as large as that of the previous evening, when DOUGLAS held forth; and, in point of enthusiasm, about four times as great.

The Jew Bill, which has so often met its fate at the portals of the House of Lords, has at last managed to secure a majority of forty-six on a second reading, and all doubt as to its ultimate triumph may now be considered at an end. No measure, since the Reform bill, has met with so many reverses, and has had so little reason arrayed against it.

The Republican candidate for United States Senator, the Hon. ABRAHAM. LINCOLN, was present, on Saturday evening, when Mr. DOUGLAS made his address, published in Tuesday's TIMES, to the crowd assembled in honor of his arrival at Chicago. On Monday evening Mr. LINCOLN replied to his distinguished competetor ; and we give his speech in full this morning.

FOUND DROWNED.--An inquest was held yesterday, on the body of ANTHONY McGROY, a boy nine years of age whose body was found at the foot of JACKSON street, East River. The deceased had been missing since Monday, and it is presumed he fell into the dock while playing.

The Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners met yesterday, Gen NYE in the Chair. The business transacted in public session related chiefly to charges against members of the force. Henry S. Cook, of the Fifth District, for being absent from his post, was sentenced to lose 5 days' pay. The charges against Abraham Harrington, for sleeping on his post, and F. Wilson, for making an improper arrest, were dismissed.

The Board of Commissioners of the Central Park met yesterday, at 1 o'clock. Present, Commissioners GREEN, DILLON, RUSSELL, GRAY, ELLIOTT, STRONG, BALMONT. Various communications and reports were received and referred. It was ordered that the minutes of the Board be open at all times to the reporters of the Press.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article appeared in your paper of the 13th infant, headed "The Guard of Honor and Monroe Remains," in which your correspondent, who signs himself a "Retired Member," says, "I beg permission to call your attention to the following article from the Tribune."

The Albany Atlas and Argus having " taken no little pains to ascertain the convictions of sensible men and leaders of public opinion, irrespective of partisan association, in all parts of the State," has come to the conclusion that the people will vote at the November election in favor of a convention to revise and amend the Constitution.

THE " FORTY-ACRE BOYS" AGAIN-THE SIMONSON MURDER.-A party of the men known as the "Forty-Acre Crowd" made another attack yester. day afternoon upon PATRICK DOWNEY, as he was going to his work in the Navy Yard. This is the same DOWNEY, who was attacked by them on Tuesday morning last. Yesterday, he saved himself from a beating by getting inside of the Navy Yard gate.

HARPER'S WEEKLY.-We have not the least intention of entering into a controversy with a publication of the character of Harper's Weekly, on a question of veracity; but the unparalleled impudence of that paper, in attempting to make the TIMES responsible for a fabricated opinion in relation to the Editor of the Herald, demands a prompt response.

In the way of diplomatic novelties, and new and nice points in governmental science, we are likely to be more extensively indebted to the Buchanan Administration than to any of its forerunners. It is always pleasant to see venerable forms, with age alone to recommend them, dispatched to the shades. There is no more exhilarating spectacle than that of generous youth spurping veteran delusions, and overriding troublesome prescription.

Ulhnann, Edward Mallory, Allen and others.-A motion to remove the trial of the indictments against the defendants from the Court of Sessions to the Oyer and Terminer, was granted, by consent of the District-Attorney.

EMANCIPATION.-The Cleveland Plaindealer has the following: " JAMES BANES, Esq., an eminent member of the Bar at Fayetteville, N. C., is in the City, stopping at tile Bennett louse. He comes to carry out the will of the late Mrs. PERRY, who appointed Mr. BANKS to see that her six slaves, CAROLINE PERRY and her five children have their freedom and $10,000 as soon as tile estate is settled.

The Panama, which sailed on the 12th June, took up a great many merchants, bankers, speculators, contractors, boss-mechanics, and representatives of all pursuits and professions, whose purpose was to prospect the new field of enterprise, opening up in the north, and make report thereof; many only intending a trip of observations and to return at once, others projecting multifarious operations of incalculable profit.

The Age of Freedom, the organ of the Free Love Community at Berlin Heights, Ohio, devotes its issue of the 8th ist. to an account of the suicide of one CHARLES LATCHA, a member of that community, whose demise was made the occasion of a general expression of blasphemy and ribaldry. LATCHA appears to have been a young man, born of pious parents, and bred in the ways of orthodox propriety.

Per bark Rocbuck, at this port, we have the Journal do Comercio of Rio to June 9, two days later than the news received vid England. The Comnany for the construction of the railroad between Nitherohy and Campos, near Rio, had been formally authorized and incorporated, and the first installment on the subscriptions called for.

THIRD BRIGADE N. Y. S. MILITIA -- BRIGADE ORDER.-The Court of Inquiry, instituted by Brigade Orders of July 6th, 1658, has rendered the following opinion, which is hereby promulgated for the infornation of this Brigade, and ordered to be read with this Order before each regiment thereof, on occasion of its next Regimental Parade.

A correspondent of the Boston Traveller writes of the gold fever in Vermont: "The gold is found upon the farm of Mr. Amos Pollard, which is situated on the east side of the sheet of water familiarly known to the disciples of Izaak Walton as Plymouth Pond, and about ten miles from Lendlow, the nearest railroad station. As yet, there has been no systematic mining commenced, but very fair "prospects" have been made.

The Quartermaster of this Department yesterday received dispatches from the War Department at Washington, conveying the particulars of the retreat of Col. STEPTOE before an overpowering force of various tribes of Indians in Oregon, and directing arrangements to be made forthwith for dispatching six Companies of recruits to the Pacific.

Tufts College, in Massachusetts, a Universalist Institution celebrated its second commencement a few days ago. Dr. Hospa BALLOU, Jr., is President. The grasuating class numbered nine ; the degree of D. D. was couiarred upon Rev. THOMAS WHITEMORE. GEORGE SUMMER was the orator of the Literary Societies and Rev. JOHN PIERPONT, the Poet.

Much alarm is felt in the towns adjoining Middletown, Conn., on account of the prevalence of the small-pox in that city. As usual, there is a great deal of exaggeration in the reports. In Middletown papers we see a statement from the Board of Health, that only ten cases of variolaid and small-pox are known in the town, and some of these are very slight.

From the London (Canada) Free Press. The first trace of the gang was obtained through the arrest of an accomplice named SMITH, who was passing bogus money at Beverley. On his person was found a letter addressed to him by R. W. SOPER, Jr., of London, which gave a clue that lea to all the subsequent arrests and discoveries. The London police at once went to SOPER'S house, and searched It.

NORTON-In this City, on Friday, July 16, after a long and suffering illdess PIERRE NORTON, son of the late Jas. Clinton Norton, in the 34th year of his age His funeral will take place from the house of his uncle, Saml Bradurst, NO. 44 East 25th st on Sunday, at 2 P. M. His frie ds and relatives are requested to attend without further notice.
UNFAVORABLE NEWS FROM THE TELEGRAPHIC FLEET.--By the arrival of the ship Alice Munroe at Boston, yesterday afternoon, we have news from the Telegraphic Fleet, but of a mature by no means encouraging.

A number of octogenarians and nonogenarians took part in the jubilee celebration of the fifth, at Woburn, Mass. In response to a sentiment in honor of Washington, Jefferson and the other leading spirits of the Revolution. Mr. Joshua Converse recited some verses of "Burgoyne poetry," which he had committed to memory 75 years ago--when he was 16 years of age.

THE "TIMES" BUILDING.--The improvement that most immediately and favorably struck me, on my first walk abroad, was the substitution of an elegant pile of buildings for the antique brick church, that had for nearly a century been a landmark, on the square made by Beekman and Nassau streets, Park row and City Hall Square.

The Government will probably proceed at once to make its arrangements for the transportation of the mail to Europe without regard to the Collins ships. The Postmaster General has no authority to change the eastern ?? of the line, and will not do so, because among other reasons the route to Southampton is occupied by two other lines of American steamers.

By the arrival of the bark Brilliant, at New-Orleans, we are placed in possession of advices from the capital of Mexico, to the 30th ult., and from Vera Cruz to the 6th last. The news is important The Extrordinary informs us that LUIS G. OS LLO, the most conspicuous in??tary men of Mexico at the present day, died at San Luis Potosi on the 18th of June, in the thirtieth year of his age.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Our attention was called to a letter in yours of the 13th inst., making gross misstatements in reference to our second edition of the Register calculated to inflict on us great injury; permit us to state the following facts:

The Buletin Oficial at Fulpinas linds occasion in replying to some statements of the Singapore Straits Times, to present some facts in regard to the visit of the United States Commissioner to Manila. The Times attributes the release of SHEPHERD and PORTER, the two Americans imprisoned at the capital of the Philippines, to apprehensions of the naval squadron which attended Mr. READ.

From a communication presented to the French Academy of Sciences. by M. ARNAUDON, we learn that the wood of the taigu tree, which grows in Paraguay, contains a peculiar acid called by the discoverer taigutic acid. The wood, when fresh saved. is of a grayish brown color, but by exposure to the air it turns to a yellowish green, in consequence of a sort of crystalline efflorescence which appears on its surface.

Every day produces some restatement, apparently from official sources, of the actual attitude assumed at Washington touching the Mexican question. It might be supposed that, alarmed at the reception of the first niaiserie of Judge BLACK, the thing was undergoing successive modification, in the hope of finally adapting it to the popular temper.

Lumber is accumulating on the vards, the re?? on account of low freights continuing large, while sales have been dull. There is a good assortment of Lumber in market. As river freights are low and dealers are desirous to sell, this is a good time purchase stock and some of the large customers are vailing themselves of these circumstances and are having for their Winter stock.

The Demarara Gazette publishes information relating to the temporary opening of the parts of the Venezuela Republic, for the import of the more important articles of food, free of duty. No doubt some of the merchants of Demarara will take early advantage of the remission of duty, more particularly as it is only for a short time:

The Atlantic Telegraph Fleet has again been heard from, and under circumstances which augur banly for the success of the enterprise. The ship Alice Munroe arrived off Boston harbor yesterday, and her captain reports that on the 27th of June, in latitude 52[Degrees] 5', longitude 33? 15' west, she fell in with the steam-frigate Niagara and Her Majesty's ship Gergon.

STORMY WEATHER ON THE ATLANTIC. Vessels are daily arriving at this port from Europe, having passed over the route of the telegraph fleet, which confirms the reports hitherto received of unusually boisterous weather for the month of June. These facts, taken in connection with the delay in hearing from the Niagara, augurs unfavorably for the success of the enterprise.

From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser. The publication of the account of the slide on the Lewiston Railroad in the NEW YORK TIMES, a few days since drew out a positive denial from Mr. Superendent COLLAMER, and that in turn has drawn out the following letter from Mr. SKEELS, who feels called upon to indicate his own veracity, although be was as not the author of the letter in the TIMES.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Capt. LANG, left Liverpool at noon of the 3d inst., and arrived at Halifax at 91/2 A. M. of Friday, the 16th inst., having been detained fifty-five hours by fog off Halifax harbor. The Canada experienced strong westerly winds during the entire passage. Saw nothing of the telegraph fleet.

RESCUED.-At the foot of Beach-street, yesterday, a man fell overboard, and would have drowned but that Mr. P. W. KING, chief officer of the Washington, jumped overboard and rescued him. Mr. KING is the man who rescued the Winchester's crew and passengers. to the number of 507, in 1854, for which the merchants of New-York presented him a handsome gold medal and $500 in cash.

I am one of a party of excursionists to the Mountains. On course the only mountains in our geography are the white Mountains. I am here inhaling the breeze which sweeps delightfully through the valley. Ah! it is so delicious to feel it! Day before yesterday I was in Boston broiling in the sun, getting over the 5th of July---the fire-crackers and CHOATE'S oration.

THRILLING ACCOUNT BY A PASSENGER. M. O. EVENTS, a passenger on board the Galena, recently burned on the Mississippi River, near Redwing, gives a graphic description of the scene in a letter to the Chicago Press and Tribune, from which we clip the following extract: "About 1 o'clock, to give my own experience, some one caught my foot and shouted, 'The boat is on fire' My suite-room door was left party open for ventilation.

ANOTHER MAN HANGED BY A MOB IN MISSOURI, It was stated recently that a man named KESSLER had been hung by a mob in Gentry County, Mo., for killing another, named TIMMONS. An accomplice, named MILLIGAN, was arrested at the time, but his case was laid over until the next term of Court. A letter from St. Joseph, July 6, says:

The most serious accident that has ever oc curred on the Eric Railroad, happened to the Express train (which leaves Jersey City at 5:30 P. M.,) on Thursday, six miles east from Port Jervis, at about 9 o'clock P M. Tile train consisted of a locomotive, six passenger cars and one baggage crate.

To the Edition of the New-York Times: SIR: I have promised your readers some suggestions of my own connected with my proposed change of policy by the Government in its management of our Indian affairs.

The Republican General Committee of Albany adopted the following resolutions, among others, on the 12th inst.: Resolved, That the Republican Party of this County is ready to waive all differences of opinion on other subjects and cordially unite with citizens of all parties who sympathize with its views on the Slavery question, and elect a candidate who will truly represent them in the next Congress of the United States.

A circular from Mrs. HORATIO GREENOUGH has issued from Cambridge. Mass., inviting contributions in aid of the Mount Vernon purchase. Mrs. GREENOUGH says: " From the Millionaire to the laborer. from the octogenarian to the child, let not one deaf ear be turned, one hand be closed.

THE CASE OF DE REVIERE.---About 4 o'clock yesterday morning MISS EMMA J. BLOUNT arrived in New-York form Philadelphia, and went at once to the residence of Dr. DEWEES, on Broadway. She has been quite unwell for some weeks past, and it is supposed that she will accompany her parents to some watering-place previous to their departure for Mobile.

Mr. BARNES' SCHOOL CONCERT.--One of the pleasantest affairs lately coming off in East Brooklyn was the concert given at the DeKalb-avenue Methodist Church on Wednesday evening, by the Senior Music Class of Mr. SAMUEL C. BARNES' public school.

We publish this morning the harrowing details of another terrible disaster on the Erie Railroad, near Port Jervis, by which ten or eleven lives were instantly lost, and some forty or fifty passengers badly injured.

The HON. JOHN N. WILDER, a prominent citizen of Albany, died suddenly, of apoplexy, on Thursday, at the Delavan House in that city. He was a retired merchant, and resided at Baliston Springs, devoting his time to ?? and literary pursuits. He was the President of the Board of Trustees of the University of Rochester, and was one of its first and principal donors.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Permit me, through your columns, to inquire if the laws of this State do not require each Court within the jurisdiction of said State to try or examine each case on its calendar in turn, and how it is that a person indicted for murder can be set at liberty without a trial, and either be acquitted or condemned as in the case of BAKER.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : If any of the great Capitals in Europe-say London, Paris, or Berlin--could boast of such an excellent accommodation to the public as the City Railway cars in New-York, how differently from here would such cars be managed in those cities; how strict would be the police regulations, to prevent the proprietors' cupidity from encroaching on the passengers' comfort!

At the meeting of the Commissioners, on Friday, the following communications were received: THE SHIP GROTTO. To the Mayor and Commissioners of the Board of Health: SIRS: The ship Grotto, from Sanua la Grande, came into port on the 5th inst., reporting having lost several persons with yellow fever on the passage, and with nearly all hands on board sick or disaoied from the same disease.

BURGLARIHS.--For some few nights past ourglars have been busily engaged committing depredations upon houses in Jersey City and vicinity. Wednesday evening a house in York street was entered during the temporary absence of the family, and robbed of property of considerable amount, but, as the family are absent, the value of the goods taken could not be ascertained.

We have private advices from Montevideo to May 28. Our correspondent says: " Business is very dull. Many houses have failed; and, although the crisis seems to have passed, it will be some time before trade is active. The Government appears to be firmly seated in power, and the late revolutionary party perfectly quiet.

There are unmistakable indications that DOUGLAS' Chicago speech is producing a powerful impression upon the Democratic Party. It was not a shot thrown away. The honorable Senator, in all his long experience on the stump, never made a bolder or an abler effort. His position is one of the most difficult which a political man can be called to occupy,

HURRY TO THE COUNTRY--There were 111 deaths more last week than the week before in this City-making 553 in all. Of these 228 were in the cases of Cholera infantum--they being 167 last week against 49 of the week preceding. The fatal cases of intantile conversion were 57, against 27 of the week before.

A telegram announces the death of Gen. JOHN ANTHONY QUITMAN, at Natchez, Miss., on Saturday. General QUITMAN was by birth a New-Yorker; by education, long habit and political affinity, a Southerner. He was born at Rhinebeck, Dutches Country. In this State, on the 1st September, 1799. His father, the Rev. FREDERICK H. QUITMAN, Pastor of two Evangelical Churches in Dutchess County, was a Prussian by birth.

The first hundred miles of country traversed by the Erie Railroad abounds in beautiful and varied scenery. The Summer fugitive, fresh from the heat and din and cares of the bust City, looks with revivifying pleasure on the shifting panorama of verdant slopes, shady dells, snug farm-houses and thriving villages, with their beautiful back-ground of misty hills,

RUFFIANLY ASSAULT AND PROBABLE MURDER. -At 8 o'clock, Friday night, Rinaldo De Long, C. La Monx, and two other persons, were sitting on an old sled in Gansevoort street, when they were attacked by two ruffians--John Quinlan, alias " Corky Jack," and the notorious James Irvin. As Quinlan came up he shook his ist in De Long's face, who, resenting it, struck him a violent blow.

The bark Phantom brings dates to June 18 from Rio. but papers only to June 11, which was Saturday The port was considered healthy, though yellow, fever prevailed to some extent. The hospital report, from June 4 to June 9, was sixty-five cases of yellow fever, of which, however, only tour terminated fatally.

SUICIDE CAUSED BY DESTITUTION.--On Saturday afternoon, JACOB SCHOFER, a copper-plate printer, who resided at No. 234 West Thirty-ninth-street, committed suicide by taking laudanum. He procured the poison at the drug store No. 463 Ninth-avenue, and directly after it was handed to him by the clerk asked if there was enough to kill a man.

On Friday, after my dispatch of that date had been forwarded, the President, in conference with Secretary CASS and Attorney-General BLACK, determined to recall Mr. FORSYTH at once; and, counter-manding their previous orders, Captain HENRY was dispatched the same evening, via Charleston and Havata, as an express to Mr. FORSYTH, with instructions for him to return.

SHIP-BUILDING OF THE TYNE.--On Saturday evening an immense concourse of people crowded the shores of the Tyne, in the neighborhood of Jarrow, and some hundreds were also on board of steamboats and other craft on the river, to witness the launch of the Hudson, from the building yard of Messrs. PALMER, BROTHERS Co., the largest iron Steamship yet built on the Tyne.

By the arrival of the steamship Austria, of the Hamburg line, we have one day's later advices from England, namely, to the 4th inst. The intelligence is unimportant. A severe accident had occurred at the Atlas Iron Works, Manchester. The explosion of a boiler caused the death of six peopie. The sales of American stocks were moderate.

From the Boston Traveller. At the present time, the fleet of homeward bound ships from India is not large, only numbering twenty sail from the Pacific, Calcutta, Manila, Batavia, Pedang, Samatra, Many of these will not be home for three months. But few (only some half-dozen) are now due. One hundred and twenty-seven ships arrived at this port last year from the East Indies and Pacific.

NEW - YORK. The Niagara Falls Gazette, July 14, says: "That the wheat crop in this county is an entire failure no longer admits of any doubt. Intelligence from various parts of the country is all alike; wherever a field has been sowed, and however well it has looked while growing, it is now certain that it is doomed to destruction by the weevil.

The arrival of the steamer General Rusk, at New-Orleans, from Brazes Santiago, furnishes advices from Monterey to the 28th ult. VIDAURRI was to start for San Luis Potesi on the 10th inst., with 2,000 men, eight pieces of artillery and ammunition, and to take command of the Army of the North. ZUAZUA was leaving Zacatecas with about 4,000 to attack San Luis Potosi, and would not wait for the arrival at VIDAURRI.

During the past three months, Mr. RHODES the Democratic Inspector, has been in charge of this Institution, he was of course, strongly beseiged by the faithful, who made strenuous demands for the prison fleshpots. Our tiles by the Phantom at this port contain some additional items of Interest. Our latest date is to the 8th ult. The Brazilian Senate was discussing the address in reply to the speech from the Throne. The majority appeared doubtful. The leader of the Op. position is EVSEBIO DE QUEIROS COITINHO MATTOBA CAMARA.

FIGHT.--Saturday night, a fight occurred at a wedding in South Third-street. The groom was about fifty, and the bride about fifteen. He was so rejoiced at his good fortune that he furnished whisky to his friends, and, as soon as that began to work, the fight commenced. No bones were broken. DUDDEN DEATHS.-PAUL TOWNSEND, recently appointed on the police of Jersey City, died suddenly, on Sunday, of apoplexy.

The Pacific mail steamship Star of the West, Captain GRAY, will leave to-day for Aspinwall, with a full complement of passengers and the California mails. The effect of the Frazer River gold excitement is already beginning to be felt in the increase of emigration to California; there was quite a number of Canadians among the crowd on board this steamer.

WISCONSIN. HEALTH COMMISSIONERS.- At a meeting of the Health Commissioners, in the Mayor's Office on Monday, the following communication was received from Dr. Thompson, Health Officer at Quarantine: To his Honor the Mayor and commissioner of Health, City of New-York;

THE OTHER ALTERNATIVE.--If, as the Coroner's Jury have said, the accident upon the Erie Railroad was through no fault or negligence of the Company, we are then brought necessarily to the conclusion that a train going at a proper rate of speed, upon a good track, is liable any moment to be thrown off and smashed.

FIRE SOUTH WILLIAM STREET--BOY BURNED TO DEATH--The alarm of fire for the Sewventh District at 2 o'clock yesterday, was caused by an explosion and fire in the wine and liquor store of GEORGE GODFEEY, No.10 South Williams street. The fire was sedialy pat out, when the body of DENS CRROAN, an office-boy in the store, was found on the floor burnt to a crisp.

The completion of the contract for the extension of the Dom Pedro II. Railroad gives a new bold to your countrymen upon the internal improvement system of Brazil. In fact the prejudices against the Yankees is rapidly vanishing. Only a few years ago the Emperor, with all his enlightenment, shared in the vulgar prejudice.

It would afford us sincere regret to do injustice to the Erie Railroad Company at any time; and, certainly, had we at this moment any private resentments to indulge, we could find no mode so sufficient as to be scrupulously just to that concern.

The mails from Europe, by the steamship Canada, at Boston, reached the Now-York PostOffice yesterday morning. We add to our already extended notices by telegraph a few interesting items. The Greenock Advertiser of the 30th ult, says, "A gang of divers were at work last week at the wreck of the steamer New- York, and about one-half of the box and bale goods have been saved.

The Fourth of July remark of Mr. EVERETT, that he finds nothing in this broad, free land to complain of, has greatly exercised the unhappy spirit of the Tribune. He seems equally concerned, also, that the TIMES should favor the future or vindicate the past acquisition of territory.

Since the "compromise" which took place between Colonel Blount and his wife, at Bergen Court-house on Thursday last, and which brought the proceedings upon the habeas corpus to a sudden terminatior, ad sorts of tumors have been afloat as to tile terms of the settlement between the parties their movements since that time, and their future intentions.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: OCEAN, Saturday, July 17, 1858. I am accused to time the speed at which Railroad Companies usually run their trains--and am certain that at the time of the accident at Shin-Hollow, the train was running a speed of at least 55 miles per hour.

A new element was developed at Stapleton, Staten Island, yesterday, by the rumor that the wife of a lighterman, living in the town had died of yellow fever. The authority for the rumor was the statement of the attending physician that the woman died of black vomit.

The manufacture of tile style of work known as Woven Iron began in this City about nine years ago. From small beginnings, it has grown into dimensions of imposing character, employs large numbers of operatives, enlists the aid of heavy capital, and furnishes the country with designs which are unique and beautiful.

A Yankee captain and his crew were tried in Virginia a few days ago for the offence of nigger-stealing, and all acquitted except the black cook, who pleaded guilty, and made a full and free confession.

Mr. Albert Smith purposes starting for China about the 8th of next month. He will go by the Peninsular and Oriental Company's route, via Marseilles. Professor Owen has been elected Fullerian Professor of Physiology at the Royal Institution. The salary is about [Pound]100 per annum ; the duties the delivery of twelve lectures annually.

We regret to record the death of WILLIAM T. PORTER, which occurred yesterday morning at 9 1/2 o'clock, at his residence, No. 51 Bleecker-street. Thirty-two years ago Mr. PoRTER was foreman of a printing office in this City, and employed HORACE GREELEY as a compositor.

BOGUS UNCLES ABDUCTING SCHOOL GIRLS.--The Tribune set the hearts of lots of good mothers to palpitating fiercely a few days since, by two stories of the abduction of children from school. In one case a bogus uncle came and wanted two little girls to go home with him-only to get the reward that the agonized parents would offer.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your editorial article of this morning, headed "The Erie Railroad Massacre," you say: "We are instructed, that in the prosecution of its recent retrencbments, the repair-gangs were cut down to a point quite made quate to the security of the track, and that t this fact the presence of a defective rail at the point of calamity is attribatable.

The letter from our Special Correspondent in Utah, which was published in yesterday's TIMES, scarcely sustains the sanguine expectations expressed by the Peace Commissioners, Messrs POWELL and MCCULLOCH. Appearances certainly indicate anything rather than a cordial and honest submission on the part of the Mormons to the authority of the United States.

A meeting of the citizens of Kent County was held here to-day, at which those of adjoining counties were also present, to take in to coinsideration the proper measures to be adopted to promote the better security of their slave property, , The particular circumstances which led to the meeting are fully detailed in the remarks of the various speakers as given below. eeting was numerously at.

At the Philadelphia Navy Yard the mechanical and laboring force now numbers eleven hundred. Discharges of chip carpenters and joines to the number of a hundred took place last week for want of timber. The work on the Lancaster is not progressing rapidly, for the same reason. The alternations and repairs to the frigate Congress are nearly finished.

In a biographical sketch of Mr. BENNETT. the editor of the Herald, a laudatory paragraph is quoted and charged upon the NEW-YORK TIMES. MURRAY-in this City, on Monday, July 19, MICHAEL MURRAY, in the 30th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the fuLeral on Wednesday, July 21, at 2 O'clock P.M. from his late residence. corner of Rector and Greenwich ste. The Funeral services will take place at st. Peter's Church, and his remains will be taken from therce to calvery Cemetery.

Before the lion, Judge Hall. Benjamin De Wolf et al. vs. 266 hhds. and 31 tcs. Molasses and Thomas R. Gordon effal.--This was a libel for freight and demurrage by the owners of the brig Europe. HALL, District Judge--As against Herrira, Meyer Co. the libelants in this case had no lien upon the cargo of the Europe beyond the amount of the freight mentioned in the bill of lading;

We continue to-day the publication of condensed extracts of letters received at the Commercial Agency of Messrs. MCKILLOP WOOD, No. 5 Beekman-street (in the Park Bank Building.) These extracts are prepared exclusively for the TIMES.

PRODEEDINGS OF THE COMMON COUNCIL. MICHAEL, MURRAY, Alderman of the First Ward, died at his residence in Greenwich-street, yesterday morning, after an illness of a few days, contracted during a visit to Richmond. Va., oil the occasion of the removal of the remains of President MONROE to that city. His disease was cholera morbus,

Though it is too early to speculate generally upon the effects of the Frazer's River discoveries, some of the results may be predicted with reasonable certainty. Assuming that the mines in that region are equal to any found in California--and that they are richer cannot be supposed--they will allure for the time almost the entire gold-digging population of North America. On Monday evening the Hall of the Union, in the Cooper Institute, was thronged to its utmost capacity by a select auditory met to hear the "prize speaking" of the pupils of the Free Academy. Dodworth's Band was in attendance, playing selected music at intervals. Professor WEBSTER presided. and after preliminary music, prayer was offered by the Rev. Mr. GILLESPIE.

A VERY LIKELY STORY.--The Daily News says that Mr. WILLIAM B. ASTOR has determined to build three large steamships, at a cost of about a million of dollars each, for the philanthropic purpose of giving employment to our idle mechanics;

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Coming from the West, I hare passed over the Erie Railroad since the accident of last week, or rather the last accident. At one of the western stations, while the employes of the Road were supplying the train with wood and water, I inquired of them as to the extent of the accident. One said, "It is not much."

The match between the nine selected from the Knikerbocker, Gotham, Empire, Eagle, and Union Clubs on the part of the Heboken and New-York Clubs, and the nine selected from the Putnam, Excelsior, Atlantic, and Eckford Clubs, on the part of the Brooklyn Clubs, which was adjourned over from Tuesday, the 13th inst., on account of the rain, took place yesterday, on the Fashion Race Course, Long island. LYNCH-LAW IN TEXAS. The Dallas (Texas) Herald says: "Last week a party of three men went to the house of Mr. GRAVES, on Pin Oak, Navarro County. Mr. GRAVES and wife were absent, the children, the oldest a girl 12 years old, being at home. They demanded of the girl her father's money, of which he was supposed to have received a considerable sum from the sale of a lot of cattle.

A PRIVATE WATCHMAN SHOT BY BURGLARS ARREST.--A little past 1 yesterday morning. Private Watchman, PATRICK BUCKLEV, attempted to arrest two burglars, just after they had left the house of Mr. GEORGE CAREV, on Smith street, between Fulton-avenue and Livingston-street, when the burglars discharged a pistol at him and made their escape.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: In your paper of the 10th July, inst., the juicy letter from Rutland, of July 3d., and taken from the Burlington Daily Times, has one letter too much (g) in the name of the writer. It should have been J.

The following communication, which we copy from the Sandusky Register of the 17th inst., shows that the Free-Lovers who have established themselves at Berlin Heights, intend to hold their position, regardless of the sentiment of the community about them. It also presents some of the means by which a portion of their neighbors hope eventually to expel them.

A dispatch from St. Joseph, of the 17th instant, says the Salt Lake mail has arrived, with dates to the 26th ult. General JOHNSTON entered Salt Lake City on the 26th ult. Captain MARCY was with the head-quarters in the city.

THE VALLEY OF THE PECOS--The Pecos Valley is a far distant portion of Texas. It is situated about 250 miles west of Austin, and its sources rise in the spurs of the Sierra Blanca mountains, at a distance of five or six hundred miles in the Territory of New-Mexico. East of this river.

BOARD OF PILOT COMMISSIONERS.--At a meeting of the Board of Pilot Commissioners, held at their office on the 20th inst., a letter was read from His Honor the Mayor, asking the cooperation of the Board in relation to the Quarantine Regulations and the Pilots.
Before Judge Ingersoll. The United States vs. Wm. Fuller.--The defendant was indicted for forging acceptances on the General Post-Office, was arraigned to-day, and pleaded not guilty.

OUTRAGEOUS ASSAULT UPON AN OLD MAN.--On Sunday morning, an old named THOMAS DONNELLY, aged 66 years, residing on the Greenkill-road, near Wilbur, Ulster County, was assaulted by a party of five men, who came upon his land and commenced picking berries. Mr. DONNELLY first requested them not to take his berries, but, they paying no attention to his request, he ordered them off his premises.

We have advices from Georgetown to the 19th ult. The Combined Courtof Demerara had concluded the session. The Registration tax had been abolished, and the deficiency thereby occasioned in the revenue made up by increased duties on several articles of import.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Under the above caption, in your paper of the 2d inst., after copying an article from the Rochester Democrat, on the way fat cattle are transported from the West to New-York City, you say:

The United States Mail Steamship North Star, A. G. JONES, Esq., commander, having sailed from Havre on the 7th inst. and from Cowes the same evening, at 5 o' clock, arrived at Sandy Hook yesterday morning.

The telegraph fleet has returned to England, after another unsuccessful attempt to lay the cable. There is one consolation in connection with the news-though it will cause universal grief and regret, it will cause no surprise.

The testimony in this case was continued before Jude OGDEN, at Bergen, yesterday morning, according to adjournment. The announcement that Miss BLOUNT was to be put upon the stand drew a large number of spectators, among whom were a good sprinkling of ladies. Miss BLOUNT arrived in Court about 10 1/2 o'clock, accompanied by her father and Mrs. BURR, from Jersey City.

From the St. Louis Democrat. Carr Place was filled to overflowing last night by a multitude of the freemen of St. Louis, who came to welcome their gallant chiefs, in obedience to a call first issued yesterday morning. Mr. BLAIR made one of his very best efforts.

The Farmers' Club resumed its bi-monthly meetings on Monday, Mr PARDEE in the Chair. The Session was opened by Judge MEIGS reading extracts and translations from foreign agricultural journals. One from the Rerue Horticole announces that the leaves of plants do not-cannot absorb dew, their function being simply a respiratory one.

In writing from Niagara, I gave you rather an encouraging prospect in regard to the crops of Western New-York, and better times among all classes. Since then I have traversed the principal agricultural regions of Northern and Middle Ohio, and the prospects of an abundant harvest throughout this entire region will fully sustain the application of my New-York impressions to the State of Ohio.

Our complications with Mexico are constantly increasing and evidently tend to war. Sooner or later, but probably at no distant day, the sword will be put in requisition to settle the growing difficulties between us and that Republic.

BUNNELL.--In this City, on Tuesday, July 20, of bilious colic. JOHN, son of John H. and Harriet B. Dunnell aged 14 years, 7 months and 8 days. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral, from the residence of his parents, No. 53 London Terrace, West 23rd st., at 2 P.M., this day,

There was no meeting of the Board yesterday, as stated, and therefore the Board could not have done what was represented,

A relic of Mungo Park's travels in Africa has been discovered by Lieutenant Glover, of Balkie's West Coast Expedition. The incident is thus related by the Cape Literary Magazine: "Lieutenant Glover, one of the officers under the command of Captain Balkie. has stumbled upon a valuable relic of Mungo Park, and has of course secured it.

SICKNESS AT SAGUA LA GRANDE.--The brig Maria, Capt. J. D. INGRAHAM, arrived at this port on Tuesday afternoon, last from Cuba, having sailed from Sierra Morena on the 28th ult., and Sagua la Grande on the 30th. Capt. INGRAHAM reports that the yellow fever, black vomit and small-pox were raging to a fearful extent among the shipping at Sagua la Grande.

A SLIGHT MISAPPREHENSION.--A correspondent calls our attention to what he supposes to be an inaccuracy in our statement of the amount of money expended by the Erie Railroad, according to the report of the President, in putting the track, road-bed, , in order.

PRIZE FIGHT NEAR NEW-ORLEANS.--The New-Orleans Delta of the 13th says: " A prize fight for $100 aside came off, yesterday, in Rickerville, between two bruisers named DANIEL. CUNNINGHAM and JOHN HOOLY. It was one of the longest affairs of the kind which has ever occurred in this vicinity. The two men were new to the ring, this being their first exhibition, yet, it is said, they went in and came out like old hands.

An accident occurred on the Central Railroad near Clyde, about fifty miles west of Syracuse, on Friday night, between a and 10 o'clock, which, was caused by the misplacing of a switch. The train had just left Clyde, and for fortunately at the time was not under full headway.

Captain Seth M. Barton, of the United States Infantry, has been tried by a Court-martial at San Antonio. Texas, for ordering Joseph Heid, a citizen, not attached to the army, or subject to military duty, to be tied up and flogged with wagon whips, by the United States soldiers.

The London Times, in its issue of the 9th inst., repeats its suggestion that Eagland should expressly sanction the acquisition of Cuba by the United States, and fortifies its position bY reasons of undoubted force.

The Academy of Music was fully crowded last night, at the Commencement of the New York Free Academy. As usual on all such interesting occasions, the ladies, mothers, sisters, cousins, and "sympathizers." were in the ascendant, but there was also a large gathering of fathers and Brothers, and in this way the great building was filled to the ceiling, and there was not comfortable standing-room.

The steamship North Star, of the Vanderbilt line, from Havre and Cowes on the 7th inst, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She brings intelligence of the failure of the second attempt to lay the telegraphic cable.

The sad calamity at Springfield, by which GEORGE E. DUNHAM, of Hartford, a member of the Junior Class in Yale, lost his life, has cast such a gloom over college as has not rested upon it for years. In anticipation of the approaching Union Regatta, which was to have taken place on Friday, a picked crew of Yale students went up to Springfield
We have received a copy of the bill creating a new Colony in British America, which has been presented in Parliament by Sir BULWER LYTTON, the new Secretary for the Colonies;

The remarkable social transformation now being initiated in Russia, deservedly draws all watchful eyes to the observation of so striking a historic phenomenon. It is certainly both a solemn and a sublime spectacle.
There seems to be still a misapprehension in the public mind as to the manner in which the question of the "right of search" has been settled between England and the United States.

The North Star reports having experienced a heavy westerly wind, which continued two days after she left Southampton, with a head beat sea. But for this she would have made the run inside of twelve days. She brings over 600 tons of valuable goods, but only a small number of passengers, owing to her sailing on an irregular day, and her departure was not generally known.

KNOCKING AT EVERY MAN'S DOOR.--There is a great deal of cholera morbus about. Some attribute it to the cucumbers, some to the soft huckleberries, some to the excess of currants they eat. one family in Brooklyn, as they rolled about the foor "in a maritime agony." yesterday, laid their gripings to their hearty meal of cabbage and beet tops.

Intelligence from the Windward Islands reaches us to the 11th ult. At Barbadoes, the House of Assembly had held one sitting, but no business of importance was transacted. The Colonial Secretary, Mr. WALKER, comes to England by this packet on a short leave of absence, Mr. J. HAMPDEN KING acting as his locum tenens. The health of the island continued

STEAM ON THE ERIE CANAL.--A new steam canal boat, called the Charles Mack, left Buffalo last Saturday evening with a full load of flour for this City. Her departure was regarded with much interest in Buffalo. Sooner or later canal boats are destined to be propelled by steam.

THE WILL OF PETER THELLUSSON. It is now sixty-two years since PETER THELLUSSON took stock of his worldly possessions, and found that he had ??600,000 in money, and land of the annual value of ??4,500. PETER THELLUSSON had satisfied the ordinary ambition of an English bourgeois--he had founded a family.

The investigation into the truth or falsity of the return to the habeas corpus, made by the proprietor of the Hotel Napoleon, was continued before Judge OGDEN, yesterday, according to adjournment. Monsieur Huncke had recovered from his sudden attack of Tuesday, and was on had with his counsel at the opening of the Court.

GENERAL ORDERS, No. 18.-1.--The older for the march of the 2d Cavalry to Fort Leaven worth has been countermanded. That regiment will remain on duty, in the Department of Texas, and will return to its former stations, subject to such changes, however, as, in the judgment of the Department Commander, the state of the service, or our Indian relations, may require.

To the Director of the Atlantic Telegraph Company London: Gentlemen: The Telegraph fleet, consisting of the United States steam frigate Niagara and her Majesty's steamers Agamemnon, Valorous and Gorgon. left Plymouth on Thursday, June 10, 1858.

The St. Paul (Minnesota) Daily Times contains a report of the purple meeting held in that city on the 7th Inst., to consider the relative advantages of three overland routes from Minnesota to Frazer's River. Celonel WM. H. NOBLE, of St. Paul, presided, Mr. JAMES W. TAILOR, from a Committee appointed at a preliminary meeting, made a report on these overland routes. We copy portions of this report:"

The Sabbath School of the First Methodist protestant Church-Attorney-street-of which the Rev. RUEL HANKSLIS pastor, started yesterday morning on an Excursion to David's Island. The clouds of the early morning possible diminished the crowd somewhat, still the number that turned our could scarcely have been less than 1,000- they filled the steamer Jacob Bill and the barge Cedar hill, which had been chartered for their conveyance.

Mr. DOUGLAS proceeded South from Chicago, after his speech in that city, and was greeted throughout by applauding crowds. At every station where the train stopped, though but for a few seconds, music, cheers and the discharge of artillery signalized his reception.

ARRIVAL OF THE SPANISH FRIGATE BERENGUELA.-Her Catholic Majesty's steam-frigate Berenguela, Commander J. B. TOPETE, from Havana, put into this port yesterday, for fresh provisions. The Berenguela has been cruising in the Gulf.

MY DEAR SIR: I returned to Albany yesterday, to fill the vacancy in the Canal Commission caused by the death of SAMUEL S. WHALLON, but found so many good names presented for my selection from the Western Division as to render a choice among them very embarrassing. In this contingency,

A wealthy Venetian has just left [Pound]24,000 in trust. to Count CAVOUR, for public instruction in Piedmont. He was one of the many Italians who look upon Piedmont as the main instrument in the future liberation of Italy. A movement was being made in favor of a telegraph from Galway to Halifax, N. S., on ALLAN'S submarine principle.

Things are dullish here, in all respects, save that there is some life from political movements. Business there is next to none, though most men seem to be at work. The bank loads are not much different from what they were a year ago, when business was good; and but a small amount of those loans have been absorbed by helping to supply the yawning chasm presented by the national treasury.

THE SOUTH-STREET BURGLARY.-EDMOND GRIFFITH, who was arrested for attempting to rob Mr. CAREY'S house, on South-street, Tuesday morning, and shooting private-watchman BUCKLEY, was yesterday formally commotted to the Kings County Jail by Justice CORNWELL, on the affidavit of BUCKLEY, who charges him with an attempt to Bill.

POLICE.-CHRISTOPER MEYER was fined $10, yesterday, for having. on Monday, stolen a child's hat out of the sitting room at the Jersey City Ferry. In default of payment, he was sent to jail for ten days. ACCIDENT.-JAMES WORTMAN, while passing up Montgomery-street, on Tuesday evening, in a state of intoxication, ran against a lamp-post with such force as to fracture his collar bone. He was taken to his boarding house in South Third-street.

The precise manner in which this much desired object is to i.e accomplished, is not state.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.-The FLORENCES at this house are still the attraction, and have grown so much in public favor that the attendance is better now than it has been for many months. A constant succession of new pieces, too slight for criticism but not for commendation, keeps up the interest of the campaign, and the energy and painstaking of the FLORENCES does the rest.

WESTWARD BOUND.--Yesterday afternoon, a company of children left the City for the West, under the charge of Mr. C. C. TRACY, agent of the Children's Aid Society. The majority were under 14 years, and the children of poor parents. Mayor's Police--WEDNESDAY.

ACCIDENT TO THE "AURORA."--Yesterday afternoon about 12 1/2 o'clock, as the Coney Island and Fort Hamilton ferry-boat Aurora was taking in passengers at the foot of Spring-street, she was run into by the British screw-steamer Kangaroo, just arrived from Liverpool, which caused great excitement among the passengers, during which a lady and child in attempting to rush ashore got overboard.

Mr. PETER DAWSON, of the Fourth Ward, has pleaded guilty to the charge of keeping a disorderly house. His sentence is deferred until Saturday. In the meantime a budget of affidavits has been presented to the bench in mitigation of the rigor of the law, the deponents being chiefly the Inspector, sergeants and patrolmen of the Ward Police.

CANAL COMMISSIONERS.--In the absence hitherto of any response from Mr. RUGGLES, it has been doubted whether that gentleman would accept the office of Canal Commissioner for the balance of Mr. WHALLON'S term, tendered him by Governor KING. That doubt is, however, happily extinguished by the correspondence which we publish in this morning's TIMES.

In another column we compile from the report of the British Commissioners of Emigration a statement of the outward movement from the British Islands, down to April 1, 1858. The results are interesting. During the latter months of last year, and the earlier ones of the present, the flow towards America had steadily declined, while the reflux from this country had as steadily augmented.

NEW PLANS FOR LAYING THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH.--We are deluged with communications suggesting new methods for successfully laying the Atlantic Telegraph, many of which undoubtedly show good inventive genius, and might be of essential service if another attempt were to be made to complete that undertaking. But no practical good can result from publishing any of these plans now.

The testimony showed that the parties were grossly intemperate, and were constantly quarreling and fighting.

Justly concerned, perhaps, at the cavernous sounds emitted by a naturally vigorous pair of lungs, which explosions have an ominous resemblance to voices from the tombs, my friends have sent me to the established homeopathist of the place, and he very candidly advises me to get out of this New-England air with all convenient speed, which advice I shall certainly take before this inquisitive northeast wind shall further lacerate my too susceptible bosom.

A monument is to be erected to the Pilgrim Fathers at Plymouth. It will cost from $300,000 to $400,000. The design is by BILLINGS. It will be built of granite, 153 feet high, 80 feet at the base, with sitting figures from 38 to 70 feet high. It is to be completed in 12 years from August, 1856.

THE DEAF MUTE KILLED ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD.--An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner HILLS, at Fort Washington, upon the body of PAT. HINES, the deaf mute and pupil, in the Deaf and Dumb Institution, who was run over at One Hundred and Sixtieth-street on the 20th inst. by a Hudson River Railroad train and instantly killed.

About 9 A. M., yesterday, a young colored woman was discovered lying dead in the forecastle of the schooner Medad Platt, by Captain IRELAND, the master of the vessel. Her body was lifted out on deck, and Captain IRELAND then notified the Police of the Second Precinct of the circumstances.

Harvard College is embarrassed by the very richness of its resources. Among the donations which add to its revenues, extend its piles of buildings, and elevate it to the standard of the best endowed of universities, it is reported that it suffers hunger. It is clothed; and fed, and arrayed in sumptuous apparel, but with all its growing outward grandeur, its intellect is stunted.

These extracts are prepared exclusively for the 'TIMES. It should be stated that these accounts are from intelligent observers, who are not Interested in selling produce, and who only allude to the state of the crops

GERRIT SMITH MEETING IN MADISON COUNTY. -Twenty-live individuals have issued a printed handbill "earnestly inviting" the people of Madison County to come together at Peterboro, the place of Mr. SMITH'S residence, on tile 28th inst., for the purpose of sending several hundred delegates to the Syracuse Convention of the 4th of August, which is to nominate that gentleman for Governor.

The funeral of the three young ladies who were drowned on Wednesday last, at Devid's Island, while on 2 picnic excursion, connected with the SaboathSchool of the First Methodist Protestant Church in Attorney street, took place from that e?? yesterday afternoon. The bodies, inclosed in handsome mahogany coffins, with glass plates,

DRIFT OF MEXICAN POLITICS.--The history of the rise and fall of a Mexican revolution seldom extends beyond half a year. That term the usurpation of ZULOAGA has reached, and we accordingly hear that VIDAURRI has captured San Luis Potosi, and the concentration of the Constitutionalists upon the capital is so imminent, that the Dictator is preparing for flight.

A KING IN THE PENITENTIARY.-PETER DAWSON , of cherry-street, who rejoices in the title won on many a political battle-field, of "king of the fourth Ward," was Sentenced on Saturday by Justice CONNOLLY, in the Special sessions. Pursuant to his own plea of Guilty PETER confessed to keeping a disorderly house, but he did not admit that he kept its female inmates in durance.

From the Providence Journal We are glad to learn, by letters from New-Mexico, that the party from Providence which accompanied Colonel W. B. SAYLES on a scientific expedition, reached El Paso in Safety early in June, and would soon proceed to the silver districts of Arizona, about 300 mites distant from the Rio Grande.

The United States sloop-of-war Savannah went in commission on Thursday, at 12 O'clock. Her crew, consisting of two hundred and thirty men, were taken from then receiving ship North Carolina. Her marine guard number 43 men, A. J. HAYS, Commander, and will sail for the West Indies about the 1st of August. she now lies in the stream. The U.S. steamer Arctic, from key West, arrived at Washington on Saturday morning.

The Canadian screw-steamer Indian arrived at Quebec, from Liverpool, on Saturday afternoon. Her news is to the 14th inst. The most interesting item is the return of the Agamemnon to Cork, and the renewal of the attempt to lay the telegraphic cable. The squadron was expected to sail for the mid-ocean station on the 17th.

From the charleston Mercury. Yesterday we saw a very beautiful monument to the memory of our lamented BROOKS, which is now completed and at the marble yard of Mr. W. T. WHITE, of this city. This monument is of the obelisk form. pure marble, of the finest quality, and finished in the most artistic and workmanlike manner.

Two remarkable fetes, equally exclusive, perhaps, in character, but in all other respects most dissimilar, mark the history of the current week in London. We began on the 5th with a flaming celebration of the Fourth of July, by an association of "successful rebels" in the capital of the grand daughter of GEORGE III., and under the very eyes of a counterfeit presentment of that gracious princess.

Clergymen are commonly supposed to be grave upon principle, yet, as we read, they manage to do their part to keep the world in a pleasant mood. The following graceful piece of pleas entry, found in the Boston Recorder, is from the pen of the Rev. PARSONS COOKE, now sojourning at Saratoga:

CHRONOLOGY AND GENEALOGY OF THE REPUBLICAN PARTY.-The discussion in the Republican journals respecting the time when the party of that name was begotten, whether it had one father or more, and if but one who, is by no means exhausted. On the contrary, it increases in interest, and draws within its circle new topics of great moment-as,

From the Louisville Journal. We are rather sunprised to see a Virginia paper, edited by one of the artstocracy, attempting to dislarage Cain, the eldest son of Adam and Eve. If Cain, instead of Delonging to the first family in the would had belonged to one of "the first families in Virginia," his memory would, no doubt, have been treated with more respect.

REFRESHING WEATHER.--We are now in the enjoyment of all the comforts of the season, so far as the weather is concerned. What more could reasonably be looked for in July than a bright sun, unclouded skies and a temperature cool as may consist with perfeet comfort ? For more than a week this delightful weather has uninterruptedly prevailed. The storms which afflicted other localities passed us by.

The Board of Councilmen met Friday evening the President, C. H. HAHWELL, Esq., in the Chair. A petition was presented for the rebuilding and extension of Pier No. 51, North River. Another, asking that Astor-place, from That to Fourth avennes, might be paved with Relgian pavement. A resolution was adopted authorizing the Central Park Commissioners the receive the manure from the various dumping boards on the East River.

From the New-Orleans Delta. It was last March, we think, MIKE was going to Mexico, and came to New-Orleans from Mobile in the Same steamer with DE RIVIERE. They were made acquainted, No doubt MIKE read his new acquaintance like an open book in an instant. No doubt he bad many a time had to deal with similar specimens of human nature, and knew exactly where to place him, morally and intellectually.

The City Physician of Boston in his last report says: "I have only to report a single death from Smallpox during the year, and there is good reason to hope that for the future the disease will never again prevail to any extent in our city, so long as vaccination is attended to so generally by the profession and the people themselves."

A FIGHT PREVENTED--AN IMPORTANT QUESTION TO BE SETTLED--The police were duly noticed, (as usual,) on Saturday, that a light was to take place between two "roughs," in the Eight Ward, some time during Saturday night. Capt. SHANNAN, of the Third Precinct, accordingly made arrangements to prevent any of the participants from getting injured accidentally or otherwise, by stationing a surlicient force in the vicinity of the battle-ground.

The last European mail was an interesting one, politically, for this country. The incidents in the British Parliament are significant of the best possible feeling toward the United States. A late telegraphic dispatch from Quebee is confirmatory of this sentiment. The present Ministry, who are proving themselves able and practical men, are earnestly bent

SUPREME COURT-CHAMBERS-SATURDAY, July 24. Before Judge Sutherland. This morning Michael Cangemi was brought into Court, and Mr. Blankman, his counsel, applied to have the certificate of Judge Wright to the fact that during the trial a juror was withdrawn. He was heard at some length, and the Judge stated that he would decide the matter as soon as he had conferred with the other Judges.

A MOTHER AND HER CHILD BURNED TO DEATH. --Corner PERRY an inquest Saturday, at the comer of Forto-first-street and Eighth avenue, upon the bodies of Mrs. THOMAS RYAN and her daughter ELLEN RYAN, 9 years of age, who died from ourns. The mother used some camphene to start the fire, and the flames extended to the can containing camphene, an explosion, scattering the contents over ner clothing and enveloping her in flames. es.

The special telegraphic dispatch from our Washington correspondent which we publish this morning gives some highly interesting information respecting the Dominican Republic, which embraces the eastern portion--more than half--of the Island of Saint Domingo, the western part of which constitutes the negro empire of Hayti.

FIRE IN PHILADELPHIA.--This morning, at a few minutes past 9 o'clock, a fire broke out in the building No. 15 Howard-street, running south from Market, above Fifteenth, in the Ninth Ward. The flames originated in the garret, and were caused by a small boy communicating fire to a bed while playing with incifer matches. This house is one of a row of two and a half story brick dwellings

The National Union, a Ghicago daily paper, which started four months ago as an Administration paper and then turned against the Administration, and finally came back to its first love. has wound up Its weathercock performances by expiring outright. Col. DIVERSY, the owner, Is also proprietor of the National Demokrat, the leading Democratic German paper of Northwestern Illinois.

The American Journal of Science and Arts, published here bi-monthly under the supervision of Profession- SILLIMAN, senior and junior, and Prof. DANA often contains intelligence of popular interest. Readers, generally, are so discouraged by the formidable mathematical and chemical formulas with which the pages of the valuable publication abound.

Lately their ambition has taken a fighting turn, and after a great deal of preliminary talk , a genuine fight, a la Tom (Over and Yankee Sullivan, was agreed upon between them the time, between midnight and 1 o'clock yesterday

Mr. BIRDSALL, the Naval Officer, has made the following removals and appointments within the last week; THOS. A. HODGKINSON, removed from a clerk-ship, and GUSTAVE LANDSMAN appointed in his stead; JAMES A. RICH, clerk, removed, and HENRY MORRNLL appointed; WM. TOOPER, removed, and W. H. KING promoted to his post; PLINY S. MILES appointed in lieu of KISG, promoted;

THE CLEVELAND RAILROAD CONVENTION.The object of this body would appear to be a war of extermination against the Erie Road, on the part of half a dozen Western corporations, led or driven on by the New-York Central. But in punishing the Erie they are compelled to damage themselves, and the end of the war must be reached before the dead and wounded on either side can be accurately counted.

NEW-YORK. Advices from nearly all parts of the State speak very favorably of the corn corp. It never looked better, and never promised as well. Rye is also arriving, and will give a fair yield. Wheat in some districts has suffered serious damage from weevil, as oats have from rust. They turn out abundantly.

THE MAMMOTH FESTIHAL.--The arrangements for the grand Musical Festival at Jones' Wood, on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of next week are progressing in the most favorable way. Already the Secretary of the late festival has published a card to say that he has nothing to do with the present one. Everybody will be delighted to hear it.

HOBOKEN WATER WORKS.-For some months pant the Hoboken Land and Improvement Company have been engaged, under their contract, in laying the necessary pipe for the distribution of the Passaic water into the City of Hoboken. Arrangements have been made with the Jersey City Water Works Company to tap their pipe near the foot of Bergen Hill, and thus take the Passaic water.

To the Directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Company: GENTLEMAN -- We beg to make the following report relating to paying out of the telegraph cable from this ship. We sailed from Plymouth in company with the steamers Agamemnon, Valorous and Gorgon, on Thursday, June 10th inst., but did not meet the Agamenon at the appointed rendezvous, (latitude 52 02', longitude 33 18',) until the 26th inst.,

The Literary Cabinet says of the Prince of Wales: "To all present appearances, our future monarch's choice of a wife is positively limited to exactly seven ladies of royal blood-unless, indeed, he selects a consort much older than himself. This will doubtless appear startling to some of our readers, but it is nevertheless true.

Of course they were unable without assistance to comprehand what the minister was saying Mr. LEWIS PEET. one of the instructors at the Dea and Dumb Institution, accompanied them and interpreted the sarmon to them.
