WHAT OF UTAH?--She is still, as invariably heretofore, setting a goodly example in strict obedience to the just requirements of the Constitution and laws of the United States, in peace and goodwill to every law-abiding resident and traveler within her borders and throughout the world, in industry, in sobriety. in good order, and in every department and channel of true political, social and moral advancement.

KETCHAM.-In this city, on Sunday, July 25, after a short illness, ELLA AUGUSTA, only child of Jun. 8. and Phebe J, Setcham aged 1 year, 7 months and 27 days. Her remains will be taken to Northport L. I. Long latent papers please copy.

It will be remembered that the brig America owned by Mr. CUSHING, of Salem, and commanded by Capt. ROBBINS, on her way from Philadelphia, with a load at coal, for New-York, ran ashore on Wardell's beech, New-Jersey, about three weeks ago, in a dense fog, where she remained hard and fast. Capt. ROBBINS, it is alleged, contracted with Messrs. WARDELL and WILSON, who make a business of wrecking,

The Canadian Company's screw steamship Indian, which left Liverpool on Wednesday, the 11th inst, passed the station at River du Loup at an early hour this morning, and arrived at this port about 4 o'clock this afternoon. The steamer Northern Light was to leave Southampton on the 14th inst. for New-York.

THE PHI BETA KAPPA--PROF. AGASSIZ-THE DUDLEY OBSERVATORY C. The Phi Beta Kappa Festiva! at Harvard, this year, was the occasion of an uncommonly fine time. The dinner and the speeches came off last week. First in order was the Annual Business Meeting, at which a number of honorary members were added to the roll of the Fraternity.

One of those periodical explosions of Mahometan bigotry, which we are obliged to record ever and again, has just occurred at Djidda, on the west shore of the Red Sea. The Population, rising upon some inspiration, as yet not defined, fell upon the Christian population of the town, and slaughtered a score of them,

PRIZE FIGHT AT NEW-ORLEANS.--The New-Orleans papers of the 14th, bring accounts of a great prize fight which came off in that city between two divisors named DANIEL CUNNINGHAM and JOHN HOOLY. The two men were serv to the ring, this being their first exhibition: yet, it is said, they went in and came out like old hands.

DESPERATE SUICIDE BY A FEMALE,--Yester-morning, about 11 o'clock, as the Johnstown train was approaching Denuy's Curve, two miles from the city, one of the passengers observed a woman come out of the bushes about twenty feet ahead of the locomotive, and deliberately throw herself across the her eyes.

By the arrived of the steamer D. A. January, at Booneville, we have Leavenworth dates of the 23d inst. Mr. LIVINGSTON, an old trader on the plains, arrived there last night, from Salt Lake City, with dates of June 30.

FAIR OF THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE.--The 30th annual Fair of the American Institute will open at the Crystal Palace on the 15th of September and close on the 29th of October. The Palace will be prepared for the reception of goods from Tuesday, the 7th. Heavy articles from a distance will be received any time after Aug. 1.
In other columns of the TIMES will be found the entire series of official dispatches which have been received at the British Colonial Of free in regard to the gold discoveries in New-Caledonia.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: SIR: Allow me to call the public attention to a matter, which though small in itself, is deserving of censure. In many American public institutions you find a strange impoliteness shown to visitors and strangers. The clerks at these places receive you unkindly, deign hardly to answer your polite questions and serve you with reluctance.

The Vanderbilt steamship Northern Light. Captain TINKLEPAUGH, arrived last evening from Bremen, Harve, and Southampton, with 200 passengers, and fight of D To BANCE. She brings the same advices as the Indian at Quebec.

SIR: I am somewhat mortified and disappointed to report the arrival of the Niagara at this port on the laying down the telegraphic cable. My last dispatch, of the 10th ult., informed you that the squadron were off Plymouth harbor bound to the appointed rendezvous for among and running out the re egraiphic cable.

The University of Rochester has conferred the following honorary degrees: A.B. upon J. D. BHADLEY and J. A. DRAKE. D D., upon the Rev. HENRY C. FISH. of Newark, New-Jersey; the Rev. JOHN C. BURROUGHES President of the University of Chicago; and JOHN C. HARRISON, of -----. L. L. D., upon JUSTIN R. LOGMIE, President of the University of Lewisburg.

PETER DAWSON has some reason to complain, yet has he at the same time much consolation. It is certainly a case of peculiar hardShip, that out of the vast mob of respectable gentlemen engaged in the innocent little commerce, of which he has confessed his guilt. he should be chosen, and the rest be permitted to go scatheless.

We have highly important advices from Utah. which would appear to leave little doubt as to the settlement, at least for the present, of the difficulties with the Mormons. Dispatches received in St. Louis, and telegraphed to us, state that news from Salt Lake City to the 3d inst has been received.

The German emigration which has been pouring into this country in such a volume for so many years, has at last begun to alarm the authorities. A committee was recently appointed by the Frankfort Diet to examine the whole question, and advise upon the best means of preventing the exodus.
Before Judge Ingraham. Peel vs. Elliott.-The action may be brought in the name of the plaintiff. The statutes of England vest the property in the officer, and give him authority to sue for it.

THE LATE ASSAULT ON D. WEMYSS JOBSON--The examination, in the case of the complaint of assault and battery preferred by D. Wemyss Jobson against Mr. John Hennessy, of No. 87 Franklin street, took place, yesterday, before Justice KELLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court. The hour assigned for the examination was 3 o'clock P. M. Mr. Jobson made his appearance somewhat earlier.

SMOTHERED IN A TRUNK.-- A boy, 10 years old, named GEORGE PRICKNEN, the son of a German widow, residing on Dodworth-street, near Broadway, suddenly disappeared on Friday last, and was missing until yesterday morning. when his dead body was found in a large trunk or chest in the house of his mother.

You will, doubtless, before the reception of this, have learned of the triumphant entry of Senator DOUGLAS into the State of Illinois, and the enthusiastic welcome given him in every place through which he passed, up to the time of his reaching the capital of the State, where his reception amounted to a perfect ovation. Notwithstand.

CERTIFICATES OF ELECTION ISSUED TO THOSE ELECTED UNDER THE LECOMPTON CONSTITUTION. From the Kansas Herald. By reference to a letter from Gen. ISACKS, it will be seen that Gen. CALHOUN has issued certificates to all those elected under the Lecompton Constitution.

EDITOR OF MOBILE REGISTER:--Sir : On returning to this city a day or two ago I read in your journal an extract from the Washington Union denying certain statements which, it was reported. I had lately made in a speech delivered at New Orleans.

Our Parlimentary session draws near its close. and people are beginning to count up the political gains and losses of the last few months. Nationally considered, the balance is undoubtedly to be set down on the cheerful side of the ledger.

CAPTAIN GALTON'S REPORT ON AMERICAN RAILWAYS.--There was delivered, to both Houses of the British Legislature, on the day the last mail left London, the supplement to the report to the Board of Trade on the Railways of the United States, by Captain GALTON, Civil Engineer, containing lithographic drawings explanatory of the construction of the rolling stock in use on our railroads.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The following interesting and important petition was received, and together with an accompanying message from the Mayor, was referred to the Committee on Wharves, Piers and Slips.

PALMER-In this City, on Monday, July 26, suddenly WILLIAM PALMER, in the 33d year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral on Wednesday. July 27. at 2 o'clock. from the residence of his brother, Gilbert Palmer. No. 47 East 31st st.

We have received numerous letter from citizens of Berlin Township, which we would cheerfully publish, had we space for them all. As it is, they are so lengthy, and there are so many of them, that we find it impossible to give them an insertion at length. Below, however, we give the substance of some of them, reserving notice of the remainder for another time.

While the public waits patiently for the promised vindication of the Trustees of the Dudley Observatory, a manifesto from another quarter takes it by surprise. It comes from a "Committee of the citizens appointed at a public meeting held in Albany, July 13, 1858."

DEMOCRATIC STATE CONVENTION.--The Democratic State Central Committee will meet at the Delavan House in Albany, on the 4th of August, to arrange for calling their State Nominating Convention. The American State Council will meet at Albany on the 24th of August.

The barks West Wind and Stampede., from Cienfugos, arrived to-day, and were ordered to the Lower Quarantine. There have been three arrivals at the station since yesterday from infected ports. The clipper-ship Competitor, Captain WHITE, from HAVANA, which port she left 14th inst., touching at Key West 15th for Provisions.

At Rondout, N. Y., on Friday, a fire broke out in a frame building, nearly opposite the Methods Church. The buildings on either side were seriously damaged. The fire originated from matches in the hands of children, at play on the premises. A child, eighteen months old, was missing and is supposed to have perished in the flames.

SUB-ALPINE TUNNEL.-An intersting communication on the Sub Alpine Tunnel has been received by the Academy of Sciences from M. MENADES, one of the most distinguished members of the Piedmontese Parliament. It was stated several ?? ago that the immense work of boring a tunnel under the Alps, between Modane and Barooneche, had commenced.

The bark Cadet, Capt. GUIDE, hence for Belize, Honduras, was lost about July 1, on the Keys, north of Belize, Honduras. The Cadet was built at Cherry held Me, in 1852, was 248 tons, rated A 2, and is w?? in this City by Mr. H. JEX.

From the Bulletin of Last Evening. A shocking murder took place between 2 and 3 o'clock this morning at a building known as the Philadelphia Institute, in Lombard-street, between Seventh and Eighth. A fight took place between several colored men, during which one of them, a young man named PETER MILLER, a barber, who resided at Germantown, was snoskingly butchered.

DEATH CAUSED BY A FRIGHT.--EMMA EVANS, a girl 14 years of age, who resided in Thirty-fifth-street, near Sixth-avenue, with her parents, died Sunday evening, from the effects of a rupture of a blood vessel of the brain, caused by excessive fright.

We are enabled to lav before the readers of the TIMES, this morning, a detailed official history of the discovery and working of the new auriferous fields in British America. It is contained in the correspondence of Governor DOUGLAS, of Vancouver's Island, with the British Colonial Secretary, and with the officers of the Hudson's Bay Company.

The bill for the government of India, which has passed the House of Commons, and gone to the House of Peers, effects a formal change in the administration of that empire. Divesting the East India Company of all political authority, it is transferred to the Crown, which is to exercise it through one of the four principal Secretaries of State.

The first article contains the gist of the instrument. As framed by Messrs.

By the arrival at the schooner California, Capt. WEST, we have received advices from Puerto Plata to July 14. Business was very dull. The market was over-stocked with all kinds of merchandise. Supply of provisions on hand sufficient to last four months.

One of the most curious features in our social progress is certainly the commanding position in public affairs which is being taken by prize-fighters and their bottle-holders and backers. The varied fortunes of this class of the community would certainly form a racy chapter in social history.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, which passed Cape Race on Sunday, arrived at Halifax yesterday, on her way to Boston. We receive by telegraph, from Halifax, further details of her news, including a resume of the latest advices from India, which will be found anything but favorable to the idea of the ultimate success of the British arms.

M. steamer Styx, on Friday last, and demanded to see the commander of that now somewhat celebrated cruiser.

By the arrivals at San Francisco we have files of Oregon papers as late as tile 24th ult. The news is very important, inasmuch as we are informed of a general gathering of the Indian tribes in that part of the world, in our northern border, with the evident intention of proceeding to hostilities.

The intelligence by the Moses Taylor shows the excitement caused by the new gold discoveries to be unabated in California. Every ship which could be made available for the conveyance of passengers to Victoria was engaged in that business. The mines and towns of the interior were nearly deserted.

The R. M. steamship Europa, Captain LEITCH, which left Liverpool at noon on the 17th inst., and passed Cape Race at 3:30 P. M. on Sunday, the 25th isnt., arrived at Halifax at 6 A. M. of Tuesday, the 27th. The Europa had moderate weather, with light westerly wind, during the passage.

The launching of the United States steam sloop-of-war Brooklyn took place from the Westervelt Ship-yard yesterday morning. It was an occasion of unusual interest to the ship-builders of New-York, as well as to the thousands of citizens, male and female, who assembled to witness the spectacle.

GRAHAM.-In this City, on Tuesday morning. July 27, FMILY MARION GRAHAM, only daughter of William and Mary Graham, aged one year. 2 months and 24 days. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her parents, 126th.st, between 3d and 4th avs., at 3 o'clock, this day, (Wednesday.)

ARREST OF AN EX-POLICE CAPTAIN.--Ex Captain Halpin, of First Ward, on Monday night violently assaulted an emigrant named Patrick Finn, striking him over the head with an iron wrench and seriously injuring him. Finn was taken to the City Hospital, and the ex-Captain was arrested to answer for his conduct before a Police Magistrate.

ALL FOR LOVE.--A German shoemaker, named THEODORE NEUHMAN, residing in Smith-street, near Dean, attempted to take his own life yesterday, by planing the muzzle of a loaded pistol near the region where the heart is supposed to be located, and pulling the trigger. He fell to the floor,

FIRE IN WEST FORTIETH-STREET.--About 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in the frame stable of JACOB SCHAZZER, in West Fortieth-street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues. The stable, and a horse belonging to Mr. SCHAZZER valued at $100, were consumed--no insurance. The fire communicated to two frame dwelling-houses on each side.

The British mail steamship Valparaise arrived here on the 6th, bringing dates from Valparaiso to June 16, and Callao and Lima to the 27th. The V. brought 60 passengers 1,000 packages of goods and $300,000, principally in silver. There is no news from Ecuador of importance.

Our advices from the Hawaiian Kingdom are to the 29th of May. The news is interesting. On the 27th May there was born an heir to the insuiar throne. A royal salute from Punchbowl Fort immediately announced to the expecting public the welcome intelligence that her Majesty had been safely delivered of a son.

CAR ACCIDENT.-WM. SMITH, a German, while returning, Monday, from the festival at Jones' Woods, in jumping off the forward platform ofa Third-avenue cal stumbled and fell under the forward wheel, which passel over his left leg, severing it nearly in two. He was talken to the Seventeenth Ward Stationhouse, and Police Surgeon MeTT dressed the injured limb.

Higham, Sharp, Marsh and Willey, of the New-York Club Brigham, Waller, H. Wright and Lang. of the St. George's Club; Senior, of Philadelphia, and Jefferson and Hallas, of Newark.

"Wrong again !" might the readers of the TIMES exclaim on perusing the last effort of your able and ingenious correspondent 'A," to reconcile his figures with the Congressional appropriations for the present fiscal year.

FREE PUBLIC BATHS.--The plan proposed to the Mayor by a Committe of German citizens for the establishment of free salt-water baths, is a good one, and we are pleased that in transmitting it to the Common Council the Mayor gave it the sanction of his decided approval.

The recent sneers of a portion of the English Press at the novelist leaders of the Derby party. strike us, at this distance, as quite gratuitous. The administrative ability of DisRAELI is of no ordinary character. His sagacity and promptness as a Parliamentary leader prove quite equal, if not an overmatch, for the acknowledged head of the Opposition, Lord PALMERSTON.

On the 4th of July, died in the harbor of Havana, WILLIAM WALSH JONES, aged 16, a son of the Captain; June 16 ALFRED NORRIS, of England; July 5, WM. NICHOLS, of Philadelphia;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Please shed a light on the signification and pronunciation of the word Dalles, which occurs so frequently in the Oregon and Washington correspondence, and oblige, among others, R. W. K. "The Dalles" is a name given to a narrow passage on the Columbia River.

We arrived at this inland station early on Saturday, after a very favorable passage of nine days from Key-West. Having southerly winds and the Gulf Stream in our favor during the whole passage, we were enabled to average 120 miles per day, which may be termed a good performance for a vessel that was built expressly to stand still.
Can ELEVEN MEN COMPOSE A JURY?--This novel question is likely, through the luck or the ingenuity of CANGEMI'S junior counsel, to receive an authoritative decision from the Court of Appeals.

The " conquering game " of a Home and Home Match, between two of the leading clubs of the National Association of Base Ball Clubs, took place on Wheat Hill, Williamsburg, yesterday afternoon, in the presence of over fifteen hundred spectators, a large number of whom were ladies.

The Howard Athenaeum will close to night, to be reopened by Mr. BARROW on the 6th of September. Nearly all the old company are to remain, and some additions will be made to it. Among the latter will be MISS LAURA HONEY, who should be attractive, considering her sweetness.

A drama of moving interest has just been unrolled before the tribunal of Caen, the chief town of the department of Calvados, a hundred miles west of Paris. Twenty-no individuals men and women, were place at the bar of the Court for murder and robbery--in other words a an organized band of assassins and robbers.

On Wednesday, the 4th of August, the NewYork Yacht Culh, rendezvous at Whitestone under the command of Commodore EDGAR. The destination of the fleet is not positively known, but they will probably visit New-London and Newport, where they will decide as to further movements.

AGENT AT FRASER'S RIVER--A telegram from Washington states that the President has appointed Mr. NUGENT, editor of the San Francisco Herald, an Agent of the Government to proceed to Fraser's River for the purpose o preventing, by influence and advice, anp difficulties which might be likely to arise between American miners and the British authorities.

To the Editor of the New York Times : GENTS.: In your issue of the 12th instant, your correspondent at, Lynchburg, alluding to the Old Sweet Springs in Virginia, makes statements which are incorrect, designed evidently to mislead the public, and injure the proprietors of that establishment.

The language of the Secretary of State to the Nicaraguan President respecting the Yrissari treaty, as set forth in the letter of our Panama Correspondent, published in yesterday's TIMES, is characterized by a degree of directness which is eminently refreshing.

To the Editor fo the New-York Time : In looking over the paper of this morning, my attention was attracted to an account of a fearful riot at Fort Lee yesterday. In justice to those who were there, allow me to correct your statement and give a true version of the affair.

SUNDAY NEWSPAPERS AND SUNDAY CRIES.The movement to suppress the vociferous hawking of newspapers on Sunday, although very moderate in its character and sustained by manifest considerations of public policy, has excited the ire of the Sunday journals, some of which openly defy the authorities to abate the nuisance.

Yesterday, a small party of New-Yorkers made the ascent of Mount Wahsington through a thick mist. Towards evening the skies cleared for an hour and afforded us magnificent views We spent a cosy night around the fire of the "Tip-Top House;" but soon after midnight a violent storm set in.

The Government of the United States has sent a Consul to this place. He has been here some two moths, but as yet they have not granted him his exequatur, and from present appearances they will refuse it to him, on the ground that the Government of Nicaragua complain of his acts while residing there during the Walker War.

Yesterday afternoon the corner-stone of a new Academy was laid at Bergen, with appropriate Masonic and religious ceremonies. The new building is on the site of one that has been occupied for educational purposes since the year 1668. The old building has recently been demolished, in order to give place to the present structure.

From the Montgomery (Ala) Confederation. Pursuant to a call, a meeting of citizens of Montgomery was held in Estelle Hall, last evening, for the purpose of forming a League of Southerners for said city. On motion of Mr. THOS, C. POE, Col SAMUEL L. ARRINGTON was called to the chair, and W. A. GUNTER requested to act as Secretary.

Arrival of the Empire City. The United States Mail steamship Empire City, Capt. GRIFFIN, from New-Orleans July 20, touching at Key West July 22, and Havana July 23, arrived at this port early yesterday morning. She brings 116 passengers.

STEAMBOAT BURNED AT RONDOUT.-About 7 1/2 o'clock on Monday night, the steamboat Olive Branch was discovered to be on fire. The alarm was instantly given, and the firemen were quickly upon the spot, but the flames had by this time made such headway, that the upper works were one mass of flames.

The relatives and friends or the family, also those of Allen ??rswell, Fsq.. are respectfully invited to attend his funeral. from his late residence, No. 252 West 13th st. this (Thursday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, without farther invitation. His remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

IN GREENWICH STRRFT.--At I A. M., yesterday, a fire was discovered in the unoccupied basement of the building corner of Greenwich and Canal streets. It was speedily extinguished with but trifling damage. An attempt had been undoubtedly made to fire the building.

In New-York, during the week, the principal de. mand has been for Domestic Wool, especially for the finer qualities. The receipts have been moderate, and supplies have not increased much. The disposhion to sell is not very urgent, and holders are not disposed to make any concessions in prices. Tne arrivals of new are being prepared for market,--in anticipation of an improved inquiry when the leading buyers shall have returned from tne interior.

Major JOHN SANDERS, United States Engineers, died at Fort Delaware, on the 29th July, 1858, after a short illness. Major SANDERS was a native of Kentucky, a grandson of the celebrated GEORGE NIOHOLAS, of that State, and brother of GEORGE N. SANDERS, of this City.

Raynor and others, owners of property on Forty-fourth-street, between Sixth-avenue and Broadway, asking that there streets might be paved with Belgian pavement. Referred to the Committee on Streets.

THE WHALING BUSINESS AT NEW-BEDFORD.--The New-Bedford Mercury states that in the shed of Messrs. HASTINGS Co., of that city, are stored 22,000 barrels of sperm and whale oil, being the largest quantity ever stored in any one shed in New-Bed-ford.

To THE WHITE MOUNTAINS.-The Norwich and Worcester line of steamers and Railroad to Boston have perfected arrangements for carrying tourists directly to the White Mountains, ticketing them through and return. The well-known and elegant steamers Commonwealth and Connecticut ply upon this route. The former, Capt. WILLIAMS, leaves Pier No. 18, North River, every Tuesday, Thursday.

ENTRACE OF THE ARMY INTO SALT LAKES CITY. A Society has been organized in Boston for the publication, upon a new plan, of the valuable historical manuscripts which exist in our various public libraries and in the hands of individuals. The plan of publication embraces not only the particular action of the United States in which the Society has originated, but includes the early history of all the Colonies;

THE HEALTH OF THE CITY.-The greatest danger to the public health is during the hot month of August, upon which we are now about to enter. Happily for the welfare of New-York, which could ill afford the disaster of an epidemic just after the terrible commercial revulsion which we have passed through, the City thus far has been remarkably free from disease.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: My letter on the abuse in City cars has been re. plied to in your issue of the 23d. in an article headed " An Advocate of Stancers," and signed " E. P." I am sorry that "E. P." considers my remonstrance, though "supported from time to time through the Press," both unjust and ridiculous, and my ideas on the subject altogether wrong.

We are rapidly nearing port, and shall find ourselves, on waking in the morning, at anchor in the Mersey. There is less exultation than usual occasions, and I verify believe there are some among the passengers who would not greatly grieve if they were to be suddenly told that, through some error in the reckoning, we were still two or three days from the end of the voyage.

Forty-one vessels, of various description, arriving from ports characterized as infected with yellow fever, are now lying at the Lower Bay of this City, and nearly the same number are undergoing Quarantine at the upper anchorage. The ship Competition, from Havaia, Key-West, came into port on the 26th in ballast, having no sickness on board.

On Thursday, the corner-stone of the magniticent Masonic Temple to be erected in Ciacinnati, was laid with imposing ceremonies. The site is at the northeast corner of Walnut and Third streets, a central part of the city. An immense concourse of People witnessed the ceremony, and the masons marched in great numbers in the procession.

We publish this morning a long and extremely interesting letter from our Special Correspondennt in Utah, giving an account of the actual state of affairs among the Mormons. The account furnished by our correspondent is anything but encouraging for the future, or flattering to the wisdom of the measures adopted by the Administration for the pacification of Utah.

THE STOLEN COUPONS. Before Commissioner Bridgham. The United States vs. Louis Stern. In this case --that of the conpons alleged to have been stolen--the Commissioner held Louis Stern to await the action of the Grand Jury. In the case of Adolf Isaac New, charged with aiding and abetting, the testimony will be taken before U. S. Commissioner Belts.

To the Editor of the New York Times: In the Herald, of yesterday, I notice a remonstrance from a Hospital steward regarding the anomalous position he holds in the army. The writer of the article certainly discloses great ignorance in the fundamental principles of a military establishment.

Great are the mysteries of Chivalry. We do not mean our native Chivalry of the South --which, however chivalrous, is not at all mysterious, but most permeable to the most common eyes--but the ordered Knighthood of the elder world, and particularly of our mothercountry.

FOUND DROWNED-The body of young ESTABROOK, who was drowned some days since, at Long Dock, was recovered on Thursday evening, and Corner McANNALLY held an inquest yesterday. A verdict of accidental drowning was rendered. FIRE DEPARTMENT CONCERT.-The entertainment of the Hoboken Fire Department in aid of their Fund came off on Thursday evening, and was quite successful.

CHANGEABLE TEMPERATURE.--The weather yesterday underwent a sudden and remarkable change. The day opened intensely hot. A close, suitry atmosphere rendered existence in town nearly unendurable, and but for tile overcasting of tile sky towards noon, and the fall of heavy showers, thousands of wilting citizens would have been driven to seek cooler shelter at the seaside, or among the hills.

A capital advantage over other representatives of our Government abroad is enjoyed by Mr. FORSYTH, Minister to Mexico. He has a home organ, which lie call now and then furnish with early information from the seat of his mission, and which always stands ready to do fierce battle for all his official acts, blunders, shortcomings and excesses.

From the Evening Post. The following call was posted through the principal towns in Madison County last week; ORBIT SMITH FOR GOVERNOR; To the People of the County of Madison; You have seen the call for a mass Convention in the city of Syracuse on the 4th of August next. This call had its origin out of he county of Madison.

THE SHOWERS YESTERDAY were just what half the people In the City were wishing g for when they came. The preceding night and the morning were exceedingly sultry; pedestrians panted, and those who rode sweltered. Suddenly, when the streets were full of people, large drops-far apart at first, but rapidly increasing in number-began to dot the pavements, soon covered them, and, uniting, flowed in waterfalls over the curb-stones and in torrents down the gutters.

THE SWILL-MILK INVESTIGATION-THE LIBEL SUIT AGAINST FRANK LESLIE.-An examination took place yesterday at 3 P. M., before Justice QUACERNBUSH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, in the case of the libel suit instituted by Alderman REED, against FRANK LESLIE, for the publication of a woodcut which appeared in one of the late numbers of FRANK LESLIE'S paper.

The United States steamship Granada, Lieut. BERRYMAN, arrived, on Thursday evening, from Aspinwall, which port she left on the 19th, via Greytown on the 20th, and Key West, where she called on the 25th. She brings only a small number of passengers, among whom are Messrs. WEBSTER, ALLEN, and GOTTEL, agents of Commodore VANDERBILT, who went to Nicaragua to obtain the ratification of the contract for the possession of the Isthmus transit route.

The topic of the hour, as you will perceive by the papers, is the proposed visit of the Queen of Great Britain to the French Emperor, at Cherbourg, which is now announced in the Moniteur as a definitely settled thing. The alarmists in England are not by any means silenced by this apparent refutation of all their anxious assertions.

We are indebted to Purser SATTERLEE, of the steamship Granada, for late advices from Key West, The United States brig Dolphin, Lieutenant J. N. MAFFIT, commanding, was to sail on the 26th, for a cruise on the north side of Cub. The frigate Colorado left Key West, on the 25th, for Boston. She was towed out by the steamer Matagorda, of New-Orleans. Her officers and crew will be transferred bodily to the Roanoke.

An old Negro was kidnapped in this place on Wednesday morning last, by some man from Evansville, on the allegation that the African was from Kentucky. The man from Evansville, it appears, followed the Negro up from some point on the Evansville and Crawfordsville Raliroad, and arrested him, as he said, "on suspicion" of being a fugitive, Immediately after the train arrived in Terre Hauto.

SCENES AT A MORMON MERTISO--SPEECH OF A REPENTANT APOSTATE. The services on Sabbath morning last, at the Bowery, in Provo City, furnished a striking picture of Mormon customs. The exercises of the day were opened by the Postmaster. who read from the preach her's stand a list of letters remaining uncalled for, and which were handed out to the parties present en titled to them.

AN INTERVIEW WITH BRIGHAM YOUNG.--The letter of our Special Correspondent in Utah, which we publish this morning, gives, an interesting account of an interview with BRIGHAM YOUNG. In the course of conversation, the Prophet gave a full exposition of his view.

A meeting favorable to the nomination of GERRIT SMITH for Governor, was held on Wednesday, at Peterboro, the village where Mr. SMITH resides. A sketch of its proceedings will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES. It will he seen that the sentiments of Mr. SMITH'S friends were not harmonious. Strange as it may be, the spirit of party expediency was not altogether wanting.

The People vs. Michael Cangemi.--In order that a motion for a writ of error, and stay of proceedings, might be made, Cangemi was brought into Court again, to-day. His appearance was not perceptibly changed.

At the present time we look with interest to each fresh arrival from the north, expecting news thereby from the field of diplomatic action in the Gulf of Pechcle. To that portion of the hidden kingdom is the eyes of every foreign resident in the South turned, and every ear is listening intently to catch the cadences of voices from the North, where the great problem of Chincse destiny is being worked out.

THE HARLEM RAILROAD COMPANY AND THE CITY AUTHORITIES-Judge HILTON, of the Court of Common Pleas, has refused the injunction, which was asked by the Harlem Railroad Company, against the Police and Municipal authorities, who were proceeding to stop the use of steam below Forty-second-street.

Mr. NUGENT leaves on the steamer with instructions from the State Department, to proceed to the Fraser River country and closely observe the current, and report the same to the Government here. He is to give every assurance to our people now pouring into that country, that their rights will be cared for and protected, if they, on their part, strictly abstain from all violence and disorder.

Among the highly important and interesting intelligence brought together in the TIMES of this morning, will be found an announcement of the final ratification of the Cass-Yrissari Treaty. THE CASS.YRISSARI TREATY.-Our Washington correspondent telegraphs that the Secretary of State has received official notification from Senor YRISSARI that the treaty which has hung fire so long between this Government and that of Nicaragua has been delivered to him by General JEREZ.

" HON." PETER DAWSON.-This brute of a fellow, now in the Penitentiary in New-York for keeping a cen of depraved females, was actually a member of the State Legislature in 1858. He was elected as a Democrat, and it is a reproach to the Democrats of the metropolis that they disgrace the party and the whole State by yearly sending men to Albany, as legislators, not a whit better than PETER DAWSON.--Rochester Union.

A company,of formidable means and appointments, has been organized in Cincinnati this season to operate in the silvery lands of Arizona. The last of the company left Cincinnati for Tubac. Arizona, on Tuesday and the whole party will rendezvous at Port Lavacca, Texas, and thence proceed together. Their train will consist of six wagons, a drove of 130 mules, and thirty persons on horseback. Each man will be armed with a Sharp's rifle and revolvers.

A report of the post mortem examination of the State Prison murderer, Magee, lately hang in Boston, Published in the Medical and Surgical Journal, suggests the idea that Magee was not killed by the hangmen's rope, but by the scalpel of the surgical operator: that enough life remained after the hanging for proper appliances to have fanned into an active name.

The steamship Vanderbilt, from Southampton July 22, arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her news is of secondary importance. The United States Mail steamship Vanderbilt, P. E. LE FEVRE, Esq., Commander, from Havre, on the 21st, and Southampton on the 22d ult., arrived at this port yesterday morning at 5 o'clock. She brings 245 passengers, an unusually large cargo and the European mails. The weather throughout the passage was quite favorable to laying the Atlantic cable.

Our advices from the Dominican Republic are of considerable interest. The elections have resulted in the choice of Don JOSE VALVERDE to the Presidency, white Don DOMINGS ROJAS is chosen Vice-President. SANTANA, who took no part in the election, but is encamped before the capital with 7,000 men, participated in the ceremonial of inauguration.

The last few days have been of the most varied interest. In my last, I think I mentioned that Calpee had at last been taken. Just after the departure of the mails, the particulars of the fall were received, and one of the great secrets of the Indian War solved-i.e., where the rebels got so many guns, and how they managed to keep so well supplied with gunpowder and other ammunition.

OENERAL VIEW OF THE SALT LAKE VALLEY. There has been no other time, during many years, probably, in which the valleys of tile mountains could have been viewed by a stranger to so great an advantage as tile present. You are already aware that your correspondent emerged from the Wasatch Mountains to the great table overlooking Salt Lake in the midst of a severe rain storm.

The United States Marshal having reason to suspect certain parties, as being engaged in the manufacture of counterfeit coin, detailed two of his, deputies, Messrs, LORRIZO DE ANGELIS and THEODORE RYNDERS, to ferret out the matter. These officers set themselves to work, and, meeting with the parties, managed to gain a knowledge of their movements.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT-AUGUST 3,1858. Before Judge Ingersoll. The Clerk presents his monthly money report, which, being read and approved, ordared that it be filed. RETURN OF PROCESS, VIZ.: United States vs. one case (diamond) 325, containing 200 pieces Plate Glass.-Monition returned, goods attached and notice given. Mr. R. B. Cainpbell appears for claimant, who is allowed fourteen days to answer.

The Royal Mail steamer Persia, C. H. E. JUDKINS, Esq., commander, from Liverpool at 9 o'clock on Saturday, the 24th ult., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The steamship City of Baltimore, from Halifax on the 11th July, arrived out at Liverpool at 11 o'clock P.M. on the 22d.

On Saturday evening a dreadful accident occurred on the Housatonic Railroad. The train which left Bridegport on that evening ran off the track near Lanesville, three miles from New-Milford. Mr. L. A. MILLS, of Fairfield, Conn., formerly a well-known auctioneer and commission merchant in this City, was instantly killed. Four others were badly injured,

Lord NAPIER held a protracted conference with Secretary CASS today, and altered slightly his dispatches to Governor DOUGLASS, to be forwarded by Mr. NUGENT. His lordship also inquired anxiously after the new Minister from Nicaragua, who is now closeted with Gen. YRISSARI in Brooklyn. Lord NAPIER leaves here tomorrow for Newport.

OUR OLD MILITARY POSTS.-From time to time our military posts, consisting of forts, barracks, and, in each case, more or less of valuable land, cease to be occupied by the army, as the exigencies of the service call the limited regular force of the United States to other portions of our extended territory.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT TO A PICNIC STEAMER.--Yesterday morning the steamer Flora carried about 150 persons--a picnic party--to Pleasant Valley. The party enjoyed the place and the occasion well, and last evening they embarked on board the Flora to return home. For some unexplained reason the Flora delayed starting for some time, and when she did start instead of letting on the steam slowly, as is the custom, the engineer.

THE SIXTH WARD MURDER--MORE ARRESTS--CORONER'S INQUEST.--The Police are still earnestly engaged in endevoring to discover the parties implicated in the murder of Cornelins Rady, the old in an who was killed on Saturday night, at the corner of Worth and Centre streets. John Quinlan, Jarnes Hines, Bernard Dwyer and Charles W. Glogan, have been arreted on suspicion.

The death of Mrs. Loudon, the authoress, is announced. She was the widow of John Claudius Loudon, author of the Agricultural Encyclopedia. The lady herself wrote The Mummy, a novel, published in 1827; The Lady's Flower Garden, The Lady's Country Companion, Gardening for Ladies, and The lady's Companion to the Flower Garden. Mrs. Loudon enjoyed a pension of [pound] 100 per annum from the civil list.

LATEST FROM THE LOWER BAY--THE SHIP SWALLOW AND HER CAPTAIN.-The ferry-boat Cinderella did not make her regular trip yesterday to the Lower Quarantine, in consequence of the storm and heavy sea in the bay. There are now 50 sail of vesEels at that station, conspicuous among which are the splendid clippers Swallow and Competitor. The Swallow arrived at this port from Havana, July 22, in ballast, having been absent from the States since June

The steamship Persia, of the Cunard line, from Liverpool on the 24th ult., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The intelligence she brings is of interest. The bill admitting Jews to seats in Parliament, had finally passed the House of Commons, and ere this has become a law. The India bill had passed through the House of Lords.

The annual meeting of this Board was held last evening in the County Jail, Raymond-street. This being the annual meeting the following officers were elected for the ensuing year: Chairman-SAMUEL SMITH, Tenth Ward. Clerk-A. H. OSBORN, reelected. There were two ballots for Jail Physician when the election was postponed.

The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, without further invitation. on Wednesday, 4th inst., at 10 o'clock A. M. from his late residence, No. 215 Chrystie-st. DEVOE.--In this City, on Sunday, Aug. 1. EUNIS, wife of the late Frederick Devoe, aged 91 years, 10 months and 8 days.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: You allow one George HOLBROOK to assail us in your columns with the charge that, in a recent publication on Horse-Taming, we have plagiarized from a little book of which he is the publisher. The fact is, that in his book, which is generally a poor one, there are certain very good passages.

A detachment of Lieutenant IVES' commission sent last year to explore the Colorado River, arrived in town this morning, direct from Santa Fe. The detachment consists of G. H. PEACOCK, Train-master; B.MOLLHAUSAN, Artist; F. W. EGLOFFSTEIN, Topogrupher: Dr. J. S. NEWDENRY, Surgeon and Geologist, with their servants and attendants. They are all looking well, and appear healthy and in good spirts.

MAMMOTH FESTIVAL.-In consequence of the extremely unfavorable state of the weather the mammoth Festival had to be again postponed yesterday, Although a very heavy loss has been entailed on the management, we are persuaded that it acted judiciously in deferring any further effort until Monday of next week. It is most desirable that the Turkish problem should be solved peaceably, for solved in some way it is sure to be before very long. The Russian war, far from settling the question, has evidently only developed all the causes which were previously working the overthrow of the Empire.

The intelligence of the movements of the allied squadrons on the coast of China, is of the utmost importance. On the 20th of May, the French and English vessels attacked the forts defending the entrance of the Pei-ho, and after a severe conflict captured them, thus opening the passage to the capital of the Chinese Empire.

The "Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union" has been incorporated by the State of Virginia, and the necessary powers have been given to it, in is corporate capacity, to purchase and hold two hundred sores of the Mound Vernon Estate, including the Mansion and Tomb of Washington, the garden, grounds, and landing on the Potomac Ricer, The sum to be raised for the purchase and future improvement of the property, is limited to $500,000.

Mr. WM. CARRY JONES, Son-in-law of the late Col. THOMAS H. BENTON, publishes the following assault on the BLAIRS, IN THE St. Louis Republican of Saturday last. This letter raises the direct issue of veracity between Messrs. JONES and BLAIR in a more serious style than any of the former communications that have appeared in print.

FINAL PASSAGE OF THE OATHS BILL-Henceforth Jews may sit in Parliament. The Oaths Bill from the House of Lords has passed in the Commons, and is the law of the realm. A Jew may now qualify without swearing to uphold the Christian religion. The final passage of the measure took place on the 21st alt.

The Hon. JOHN DUEB, Chief Justice of the Superior Court of this City, who has been suffering for some months past under serious illness, occasioned by the fracture of a limb, was ? low last evening that no hopes were entertained of his recovery. He is at the residence of a relative on Staten Island. Judge DUER is advanced in years, probably 72. His long life has been active, useful and honorable.

THE NEW CANADIAN MINISTRY.---Although Mr. GEORGE BROWN succeeded in forming a "clear-grit" Ministry, there are strong doubts as to the ability of his Cabinet to sustain itself. It was announced on Monday morning: in the afternoon a resolution of "want of confidence" passed the Legislative Council. and in the evening was under discussion in the House of Assembly.

Hon. HUGH S.WALSH, Acting Governor K.T.Dear Sir: Inclosed, you will find the certificates of the members of the Legislature elected under the Lecompton Constitution, except those for the counties of Leavenworth, Atchison, Doniphan and Johnson, which I have been requested to retain and distribute, by General CALHOUN, in a letter of the 2nd July, 1858, from Nebraska City, received this day.

The Hon. Abraham Lincoln has returned a sharp answer to Senator Douglas' letter touching the public discussion in Illinois during the canvass. He says: "Protesting that your insinuations of attempted unfairness on my part are unjust, and with the hope that you did not very considerately make them, I proceed to reply.

A DETERMINED SUICIDE-GEORGE TRENCK, book-keeper in the store of A. WESSON Co., Nos. 9 and 11 Park place, yesterday afternoon attempted to commit suicide, by throwing himself into the dock at the foot of Robinson street. Officer DEVOE, of the Detective Police, jumped into the water, an , with great difficulty, succeeded in rescuing him.

The Canadian papers are filled with accounts of the Ministerial overturn. The resolution adopted in the Legislative Assembly on the 28th ult., which upset the Cabinet, was the following, offered by Mr. PICHE, as an amendment to one proposed by Mr. DUNKIN: "That it is the opinion of this House that the City of Ouawa ought not to be the permanent seat of Government for the Province."

The sailing of the Pacific Mail steamer Moses Taylor,to-day, for Aspinwall, is an occasion of more than ordinary interest, as, in addition to the large number of enthusiastic gold-seekers on board, several gentleman distinguished in the scientific world take passage by her, who are bound to Peru under the auspices of the Smithsonian Institution, the entire patty having been favored with a free passage to go and return. This match, which stood on Tuesday--when the stumps were drawn--26 runs for Canada, with the loss of 4 wickets, was resumed yesterday morning; the Canadians having succeeded in scoring the large number of 101 runs before their last wicket fall. The Canacians were unfortunate in having to go to the wickets in the evening and it resulted in the loss of Heward, the great gun of the previous day,

Brooklyn Items. BOARD OF HEALTH,--A meeting of this Board was held yesterday. Several nuisances were reported and ordered to be abated. An application for permission to land bales of cotton from ship Constantine, for immediate shipment to Liverpool, was refused, because the Health officer's certificate at Quarantine was not produced.

WANT OF CONFIDENE.-We mentioned yesterday that a want-of-confidence resolution in respect to Mr. GEORGE BROWN'S Ministry, had passed the Legislative Couneil on Monday. A like resolution passed the House of Assembly the following day. These proceedings were, of course, in advance of any action on the part of the new Cabinet.

The German population in Philadelphia, at the present time, says the Inquirer, is estimated by those most conversant with it, at 80 000 souls. About one half have arrived in this country since the revolutions in Europe of 1848. About 10,000 of the number of the number are voters, and over 1,000 more have taken the preliminary steps in order to become naturalized.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS. Before the Hon. Recorder Barnard. The Court-room was crowded again yesterday, when Mr. ASHMEAD. counsel for STEPHEN II. BRANCH, commenced his address to the jury for the defence. He spoke for about an hour and a half, and spoke ably. For the prosecution, in reply, Mr. JOHN McKEON addressed the Jury for about the same time.

No where do we show such lamentable lack of reason as in our railroad economy. Periodically the community is throwninto dismay at the occurrence of some frightful casualty on one of our iron roads. For a few days the most intense excitement prevails; but no sooner does the horror of the occasion wear away than the public lapses into somnolent apathy, till again startled by some new thunder-clap.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.-The Success of the FLORENCES is a thing beyond mere compliment. During the dullest season they have, by their vivacious talents, succeeded in attracting large crowds to Wallack's Theatre; and last night, on the mere promise of a farce, the house was filled as well as it ever was in the palmiest days of the season.

We had a pleasant evening at CRANFORD'S, and were up bright and early on Friday for our mountaian-ride. The "fixing " occupied much time, but we were on the ponies by 8 o'clock, or thereabouts. Such a grotesque and jolly party cannot be described. We men were well wrapped in woollen jackets and heavy plaids, while the ladies had broad straw hats, and any quantity of shawling.

Some of the residents of Aikin and Kalmia, South Carolina, have found a better way to dispose of their peaches than drying and sending them North. Two years ago a single individual in that locality tried the experiment of sending a few boxes to this City for sale, which, coming quite in advance of the Delawares and Jerseys, found ready parchasers at high prices.

MONTESQUIEU'S rule that it is "the duty of nations in time of peace to do one another the greatest possible amount of good, and in time of war the least possible amount of evil, consistent with a due regard to their own real interest," is that which should unquestionably regulate national intercourse, but, like every other rule, it has limits to its operation.

The Pillsburg Free Press Says; "It is said that desperate efforts will be made to save SHAW (the alleged kidnapper of GEORGE W. FERRIS) from the penitentiary. The case will turn upon the point as to whether FERRIS was a slave of free-born. A late number of the Richmond South contains an article from which it appears that one MILES OWEN is using every means is his power to prove that FERRIS was a slave.

I am writing you from a place situated 140 42' 58" east of Greenwich. I have passed the whole Summer in surveying the route of a projected railroad. While near the Bay of Castries I have quartered in a tent, in a virgin forest, in the midst of swamps, surrounded by swarms of gnats, mosquitos, and other insects more or less interesting to the naturalist.

The Washington Union has abandoned all idea of finding ally fault with DOUGLAS for differing with the Administration upon Lecompton, or any other subject. It simply objects to the manner of his doing so. It is sorely grieved at his having differed openly, and brought scandal upon the brotherhood.

LOUIS.--We copy articles in respect to the result of the election in St. Louis, from the Democrat (Emancipation and Republican.,) and the Republican (Buchanan Democratic,) from which some idea of the contest may be formed. Mr. BARRETT would have been beaten by about 4,000 votes had the Republicans and Americans united on a single candidate.

The New-York State Teachers' Association convened this morning for the thirteenth time, in Ringueburg Hall, with a full attendance. Many distinguished educators, both of this and other States, among whom is the State Superintendent of Kansas, are here, and teachers are flocking in by every train.

The greatest excitement was created yesterday among all classes of people by the unlooked-for news of the sate arrival of the Niagara at Trinity Bay, and the successful laying of the Telegraphic Cable. The tele. graphic wires have never thrilled with a more important message, or one that will be so universally hailed with unalloyed satisfaction,

PECK-SLIP FERRY.-At a special meeting, held in the Eastern District Wednesday night, Messrs. Geo. W. Field, Grahams Polly, Daniel Manger, Anthony Waller, A. K. Messerole, James Hall, and Richard Ten Eyck, were appointed a Committee to urge upon the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund in New-York, the propriety of leasing at once in a regular and legal way the Peck-slip Ferry.

A NEW GAS COMPANY IN HOBOKEN-CHARGE OF OFFICIAL CORRUPTION.--At the meeting of the Hoboken Council ol Wednesday night, a petition was received from Mr. GRISWOLD and associates, asking permission to open the streets for the purpose of laying down gas-pipes, and also asking the City to enter into a contract with the above-named parties for lighting the streets and public buildings for five years,

From the Albany Evening Journal of yesterday. After our report closed yesterday the following proceedings were had: Rule 13 amended, by adding "No counsel shall occupy more than one hour in summing up, unless by permission of the Judge presiding," Also, amended, as to the "standing" provision, giving Justice power to dispense with the requirement at circuit.

THE GERRIT SMITH STATE CONVENTION.-When Mr. SMITH remarked to his friends at Peterboro', on the 28th ult., that he had no stomach for "shams," he evinced a premonition of the character of the Convention called to nominate him for Governor. That body,skeleton is, perhaps, a better word,--met in Syracuse on Wednesday.

There are actualities under our very eyes more wonderful than the wildest romance. Here, now, is a Corporation--the Hudson's Bay Company-which for two hundred years has kept locked up as a private preserve a territory larger than the whole of Europe, and that, too, with hardly any authority in law or justice.

University of Vermont. The commencement exercises at Burlington, Vt. began on Sunday last. President PEASE delivered the Baccalaureate sermon. The anniversary exercises of the Society for Religious Inquiry occupied Sunday evening. The discourse was by the Rev. SAMUEL HARRIS. D. D., of Bangor Theological Seminary.

The political alembic has already began to work, and already have the elements of party strife begun to emit their gases. The first Convention of the season took place here, at Syracuse, to-day. The movement which originated with some of the radical Anti Slavery and Anti-Liquor people of this State, for the purpose of securing the nomination of GER?? SMITH for Governor, has reached its climax.

The wonderful event that has made the coast of the North Pacific and the courses of Fraser's River the theatre of a great concentration of population seems to be but one in a series of conspiring causes destined to throw open a mighty and magnificent region to the commerce and cultivation of the world.

Had pleasant weather for two weeks--wind easterly. March 12, passed to the westward of Christmas Island--fell to the leeward on account of the westerly current, and had to beat up.

The past week has been one of considerable suspense and anxiety to those interested in trade, in consequence to the numors respecting the wheat crop, the harvesting of which is just now commencing. Were we to give credence to half the unfavorable statements that are made, we should almost anticipate a famine;

We are enabled to lay before our readers, this morning, the gratifying and somewhat unexpected intelligence of the success of the Atlantic Telegraph Enterprise. The Niagara and the Gorgon arrived at Trinity Bay on Wednesday, and yesterday the work of landing her end of the cable was proceeded with. The entire fleet, as will be remembered, sailed from Queenstown on Saturday,

After a live-and-twenty years' wrangling the admissability of tile Jews to Parliament has been conceded. The Lords have no mind indeed to let the circumcised take their seats upon tile crimson cushions of the gilded Chamber, should the Crown ever be induced to create an earldom of Jericho or a barony of Bethsaida.

A correspondent writes to the Boston Traveller: "The work at the Hoosae Tunnel is done by common drills, and the progress is about twenty feet per week. At the eastern end, eighty men are employed in three parties, laboring alternately, so that the work goes on day and night without interruption. The entire progress at the eastern end is about one thousand feet: at the western, not more than two or three hundred.

The serious accident to Senator Chandler, of Detroit, before reported, is described by the Detroit Advertiser: Finding that the gas escaped from a pipe in the ceiling, the steeped on a chair for the purpose of closing it. He had no sooner raised the light to enable him to see, than the gas ignited and instantly exploded, throwing him down from the chair, and very badly burning his face and hands.

THE HOUSATONIC RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--The Jury in the case of Mr. LEVI A. MILLS, killed on the Housatonic Railroad on Saturday, have returned the following verdict: "We find that the darkness was such as to render it impossible to discern an object on the track at a very great distance, and that the employes of the Company on the train used ordinary precautions, and all due and proper exertions to prevent the catastrophe.

WOULD PRESIDENT BUCHANAN ACCEPT A RENOMINATION ?--The Journal of Commerce takes special umbrage at an opinion, expressed by an occasional Washington correspondent of this paper, to the effect that President BUCHANAN is not unwilling to accept the Charleston nomination in 1860.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I find upon reading the different City journals that their impressions are alike on one subject, " The effect which the Subrrarine Telegraph will have on Speculalion." The impression is that if speculation is not entirely annihilated it will, at least, be brought down into so small channel as will leave little room for " wide margins" either way.

A very little cool reflection has evoked an inquiry in our city that bids fair to call into very critical review the appliances used by the Nationals for exhancing so mysteruiously their vote in St, Louis, vong to the frightful extent. the use of dead's men papers, and inserted tickets, and barricaded palls, all show themselves from the background of the National Democratic thumph.

ATTEMPT TO KILL.--Mr JAMES DAY, butcher, corner of Atlantic and Hamoden streets, complained to the Deputy Superintendent of Police yesterday afternoon that a neighbor, named JAMES MYERS, had attempted to kill him. The parties have had some misunderstanding, and yesterday MYERS rushed at DAY with a loaded musket and attempted to free it, when he was seized and the dangerous weapon with difficulty wrested from him. An officer was dispatched to secure the desperate man.

The Association convened again this morning at 9 o'clock, and after listening to a song from the choir, proceeded to the transaction of business. The Board of Editors of the New-York Teacher, the organ of the Association, presented their annual report, stating that the paper was in a fair way to clear itself of its indebtedness, and urging all present to come forward to its support.

THE MAMMOTH FESTIVAL.-With weather like the present to make us yearn for green fields and cool breezes, the mere promise of a pic-nic is something with which to invigorate the wilted fancy. Our readers must not forget (it is scarcely likely that they will) the Mammoth Musical Festival which stands good for Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of next week.

The election news from the West takes the tremors off the Democrats here, and puts them is the good humor of assured triumph. FRANK BLAIR is defeated, which is especially gratifying to the President, with whom the ex-candidate was at some pains to create a personal issue relative to the moribund sayings of Mr. BENTON.

AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY.--The stated meeting of the managers was held at the Bible House Astor-place, Thursday, at 4 1/2 o'clock P.M., WILLIAM FORREST, Esq., in the Chair. Eight new Societies were recognized, of which four are in Missouri, two Michigan, one in Kansas, and one in Illinois.

FIGHT AND STABBING.--Patrick Burns and Daniel Denovan, who reside in the First Ward, have been at swords points for some time On Thursday they met at Weehawken, New-Jersey, having gone there to attend a boat race.

Rawlins had landed a cargo of 450 African somewhere on the coast and say: "The above dispatch appeared in the Augusta papers of yesterday, and perhaps it may be expected that we should make some allusion to the subject.

The extension of the electro-magnetic telegraph between the Old World and the New forms an era in the history of mankind at which we may with great propriety pause, and contemplate the work accomplished. The transmission of matter across the inter-continental ocean, thanks to the development of steam machinery, has been brought within the compass of nine days and a few hours.

CANADIAN POLITICS--RESIGNATION OF THE BROWN MINISTRY.--Mr. BROWN enjoyed the Premiership but a very short time. On Monday his Ministry was announced. A no-confidence motion passed the Legislative Council the same day, and the House of Assembly on Tuesday.

A correspondence of the Journal of Commerce, writing of the paper-mills at Gardiner, Mc., says: "Yesterday I Visited. In company with Mayor WOODS, (of Gardiner,) the two principal paper factories, and I was astonished in looking at the millions of pounds of rags piled up in warehouses or spread over acres of ground, to find that a portion of them has recently arrived from Alexandria in Eggpt.

The orders of the Associated Press to hold open the lines between New-York and Trinity Bay, N. F., last night were received and complied with as far as this Province, but from some unexplained cause the Newfoundland Line closed, or at least ceased to work early in the evening, thus cutting off all communication with the cable at Trinity Bay.

BEGINNING RATHER TOO EARLY.-The Herald has made a slight mistake in supposing that the Atlantic Telegraph is to be laid through that famous strait called Plum Gut, or at least the editor of that paper appears to be bent on receiving his dispatches in the Plum Gut fashion.

The screw steamship Prince Albert, Capt WATERS, from Galway at midnight of July 27, arrived off Halifax harbor yesterday afternoon, and reached her dock here at 9 o'clock this (Friday) morning. The advices by this arrival, by mail are to the evening of the 26th all., from Liverpool, and by telegraph from Liverpool and London to noon of the 27th.

The charge is made by the St, Louis Democrat, on the part of Mr. BLAIR, and denied by the Republican, that he has been defeated by spurious voting, and a lively controversy has arisen on this point, the drift of which may be gathered from articles copied in this morning's TIMES from these papers respectively.

It is now near midnight, and in order to be read for the morning's mail train, I have been compelled to leave as exceedingly pleasant gathering of the Alumni, with their "wives and sweethearts." at the mansion of the Rev. JOSEPH CUMMINGS, D. D, the new President of the University, of whose election I informed you a year ago tonight.

On account or the interruption of telegraphic communication with Trinity Bay, where the Niagara landed her end of the great Atlantic Cable, we are unable to lay before our readers, as we had hoped, any later intelligence in reference to the actual success of the enterprise than that published in the TIMES of yesterday morning.

The officer was laughed at and defied. JAMES BROGAN, who appeared to be the ringleader, was arrested by the officer

A SECOND EDITION OF THE RUTLAND CONVENTION.-A call is in circulation for a "Philanthropic Convention, to overcome evil with good"-to be held at Utica on the 10th, 11th and 12th of September, It is understood that tile purpose of this gathering is similar to that of the demonstration at Rutland, Vt., held in June.

The complete success of the Atlantic Cable is placed beyond all doubt. Signals are now being made through the whole extent of the Cable, but it is uslikely that the Cable will be opened for business for several days, or perhaps weeks, as the elec triclans will require time for a series of experiments with their recording instruments.

Before Judges Bosworth, Hoffman and Pierrepont. Thos. B Stillman vs. the Pacific Mail Steamship Co -New trial granted, unless parties consent to modify judgment as to $4,300. Wm. H. Adams vs. the Mayor, affirmed, with costs. George St. John vs. the Mayor, affirmed, with costs.

We continue to-day the publication of condensed extracts of letters received at the Commercial Agency of Messrs. McKILLOP WOOD, No. 5 Beekman-street (in the Park Bank Building,) These extracts are prepared exclusively for the TIMES.

The bark C. P. Alexander, of Harpswell, Me., Capt. MERRIMAN, 21 days from Cienfuegcs, arrived yesterday at Lower Quarantine. She reports that STEPHEN P. MORRELL, of Penobscot, Me., the Second Officer, died in that port on the 22d of June. A seaman, named JOHN SMITH, also died at sea, both presumed of yellow fever.

THE RETURN OF THE MORMONS. The week closing to-day has been a busy one in the valleys. I informed you in my last that the people were beginning to return to their homes, abandoned upon the approach of the army by order of their Prophet and Priest.

A correspondent at Baden-Baden sends us, says Galignani, the intelligence that two players at the gaming-tables of that place won so much money two days back from "the bank" that the latter was obliged to give up play for the night. This is a rare occurrence, although it does occasionally take place.

Mr. BROWN and his colleagues yesterday tendered their resignations to the Governor-General, by whom they were accepted. The cause of the step was, a refusal by His Excellency to dissolve the present Parliament, in compliance with a request preferred by the Ministry, on the ground that a majority of the members now in the House do not possess the confidence of the country.

THE BENNETTONTAN SYSTEM.-It is a very great misfortune for an individual, but doubly disastrous for a newspaper, when its past career has been so devious and doubtful that it is always forced to bring forward a witness to prove the truth of its assertions.

SAILING OF THE VANDERBILT STEAMER NORTHERN LIGHT-RIOT AMONG THE COAL PASSERS AND FIREMEN.-There was considerable disturbance at the dock upon the departure of the Nurthern Light on Saturday, occasioned by a strike among the coalpassers and firemen, whese wages had been suddenly reduced by the proprietors of the line-the firemen from $25 to $20 per month, and the coal-passers from $20 to $17 per month.

COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH.--At the meeting of the Board on Saturday, Mr. Corlies, Superintendent of Repairs and Supplies, made a report and submitted a plan for the erection of a pier and sheds at Quarantine : also, for a series of warehouses two stories high, with a railway running from the end of the pier.

The first hour of this morning's session was frittered away in quibbling about points of order and the expediency of striking out a trifling clause in the minutes of yesterday. This important point having been settled to the satisfaction of the majority, a song was sung by the quartette and the Association proceeded to hear the reports of various committees.

The House of Lords, it seems, has paired off with itself, as it were, by conceding one national demand of the people and refusing another at the same time. The Jews are to be permitted to enter the House of Commons, it they can get in, but a sister in-law is not to be allowed to enter the house of her deceased sister, as her successor, however desirable and desired such an arrangement may be.
MY DEAR R.: The little clearing where we staid last night is destined, in my opinion, to be as well known in a few years as Catskill Mountains or the White Mountains of New-Hampshire.

The fifth and last of the course of lectures upon Art which have been given in connection with the exhibition of paintings in the Alumni Building, was delivered on Saturday afternoon, by DONALD G. MITCHELL, Esq., (Ik Marvel.) A seleet audience assembled in the elegant hall of the " Brothers in Unity," listened with great delight, while in familiar style he discoursed about pictures and how to look at them.

The following is his letter of resignation: PARIS, July 9, 1858. To JOHN BIGELOW, Esq.-My Dear Sir. I learn through the newspapers that I have been elected, by the New-York Legislature, a Regent of the University. I will not affect to undervalue the favorable

The state meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Nos, 115 and 117 Nassan-street, on Thursday, the 5th inst., at 4 o'clock P.M., the Rev, Dr. WELOH, President of the Society, in the chair. After the usual opening preliminaries, the correspondence for the month was pesented,

The screw steamship Prince Albert, whose advices, as telegraphed from Halifax, we published on Saturday morning, arrived at this port last night, about midnight. We find nothing of importance in the papers brought by her, additional to what was comprised in the dispatch.

ARRIVAL OF COAL FROM THE INTERIOR OF PENNSYLVANIA.--We noticed, a day or two since, the arrival at Rochester, on route for this city, of two canal boats loaded with coal from the Pittston mines, Wyoming Valley. The boats arrived here yesterday morning , and are now unloading in the Erie Basin, at the foot of Genesee street, alongside the yard of Messrs., DEFOREST MILLER.

On Thursday the Directors of the New-York Central Railroad met at Albany, and declared a semi-annual dividend of four per cent., being the same amount paid in February and August for several years past. Before this was known in Wall-street on Thursday morning Central shares sold at 83 1/2, sellers 60 days ; and immediately afterwards at 85.

LATER FROM UTAIL.-The news from Utah which we publish this morning, although a week later than previous advices, reports no change for the better in the condition of the Territory. The Mormons, so far from being satisfied with a quiet return to their homes, which they had again occupied in peace, continued to evince a determined hostility to Federal interference.

MAMMOTH FESTIVAL.--To-day, if it be fine, belongs to the Jones' Wood Mammoth Festival--an entertainment which can only blossom in the open air and the gay sunlight. The arrangements, as we have many times stated are of the most ample kind, and we are sure the pic-nic will be one of the pleasantest affairs of the kind ever given in the United States.

KNOX--In this City, on Sabbath, Aug, 8 of cholera infantum ANNASELLA GRACE, infant daughter of Andrew and Annabella G, Knox, aged 7 months and 11 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her parents, No. 273 ?? this (Monday) afternoon at 3 o'clock.

FOUND DROWNED.-The body of an unknown woman, apparently not more than 16 years old, was found, yesterday morning, in the water at the foot of Sedgwick-street. The body has evidently been in the water only a short time, and has on a black silk basque, plaited, quilted skirt and Morocco gaiters.

BRUCE, Ex-Commissioner HINDS, a large delegation from Buffalo, Acting Mayor PARSONS and many of our prominent citizens, took passage, yesterday morning, on the new canal steamer Sternberg, for Lockport.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: The City of New-York and the County of Westehester are divided, as all the world knows. by a little Tiber-like stream, of no very distinguished reputation, called the "Harlem River." At no very distant period this little stream, which is now almost unknown, except as the northern boundary of New-York City, is destined to a wider fame and a better reputation.

SHOCKING ACCIDENT AT HASTINGS--TWO LADIES KILLED AND ANOTHER SERIOUSLY INJURED.--On Saturday morning last, about 10 o'clock, a melancholy accident occurred at Hastings, about twenty miles up the Hudson River, by which two ladies were instantly killed, and another seriously injured.

SUICIDE OF AN UNKNOWN MAN.--The body of a man about 30 years of age, apparently a German, was found lying in the woods at West Hoboken, on Sunday afternoon, shot through the heart. A pistol which had been discharged was lying by his side. Justice HAGUE held an inquest, and a verdict of death by suicide was rendered.

PRIZE FIGHT.--On Saturday evening, information was received at the Police Headquarters that a prize fight was to take place on Sunday morning, at 3 o'clock, in Jones' Wood, between BILL. DUFFY and JAMES GILMOR, two old customers in a general fight, but novel aspirants for distinction in the ring.

The delegation of State Officers which left Albany by the 11:30 A. M. train on Thursday, reached Rochester early the same evening. Meetings of the City Authorities and citizens had been held during the day, to concert arrangements to give the State Officers a suitable reception, and consequently the depot was filled by an immense crowd when the train arrived. The feeling ran high:

Two bales of the new crop were received at New-Orleans, July 25, from Texas, and sold at 15 cents ; last year the first receipts were five bales, also from Texas, on the 15th August, about three weeks later than the present year.

The following, from a well-informed source, relates to the Illinois Central Railroad, in which the English public are interested to the amount of some few millions. The writer complains of a recent inference that, if this work should prove to be a delusion, the fact must be held established that under no conceivable circumstances can American railroads be made to pay.

The Hon. THOMAS CORWIN, having been spoken of as a candidate for Congress, was invited in address a political meeting at the village of Morrow, warren County, Ohio, on the 6th inst. He complied with this request, and the speech which he delivered on that occasion will be found, as copied from the Cicinnati Gazette, in this Morning's TIMES.

MY FELLOW-CITIZENS: I see but very few men among you who could more appropriately address you by that endearing title of fellow-citizens, than the humble man who is now called upon to make a few remarks to you. If a residence in the county of half a century can authorize any man to use this language, I may very appropriately address you by that title.

No. 210 Gold-street, Brooklyn, when JAMES McCLOEKEY was shot by ALEXANDER JAMES McCLOSKEY was taken to the City Hospital, and singered until the 6th inst., when he dies.

A catalogue of Dr. VALENTINE MOTT'S Surgical and Pat?clogical Museum has been published. It is a pemphlet of 80 pages, made up of a list not, of course, of the operations the Doctor has performed, but of the game he has bagged in his fifty years' of surgical excursions into the microcosm, and from it one may guess how well our great Surgeon's fame is bottomed on facts.

SHAW and S. WARD, The second prize of $25 was won by boat Extra, entered by C. J. JUNE, and rowed by owner and JOHN LEARY.

To the Editor of the New-York Times; SIR : You will oblige me by publishing the following, in reply to an article which appeared in the columns of a daily paper, marking inquiries as to my intentions, and on what conditions I intended to donate to the City of New-York the building now known as the Union, for the advancement of science and art.

By the steamship Arage, which arrived at this port yesterday morning, we have received European advices to the 25th ult. An important debate in the House of Lords, in which Lord LYNDHURST and the Fail of MALMESBURY were the principal speakers, took place on the 26th.

MORMON AFFAIRS.--An interesting letter from a citizen of Utah, which we publish this morning, gives a clear view of the practical workings of Mormonism. The writer was formerly a Mormon, but, having become disgusted with the treachery and licentiousness prevalent among the people of the Territory, dissolves connection with them, and gives utterance to some startling statements.

Every great victory must have its hero. Wherever there is a Waterloo there must be a WELLINGTON. and in such a victory as has been achieved in the Atlantic Telegraph there must have been a leader to whose courage and generalship the world is indebted for the completion of that stupendous work.

The Transatlantie Telegraph will afford means by which the difference of longitude between observatories in this country and Europe can be determined with the same accuracy as latitude is determined, which is a matter of paramound importance both to the astronomer and navigater. It is consoling to the former, because the transportation of chronometers to Europe and back will be done away with,

Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. WASHINGTON, Monday, Aug. 9. The bids for the Ten Million Load of Treasury Notes were opened this morning at 12 o'clock. The whole amount of which bids were received is $38,557,000. BELMONT and Boos put in a bid for the whole amount at 3 77 100 per cent., which was to low, and they got nothing.

COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH.--The Board met on Monday. A petition was received from the Danish brig Res??, which arrived here from Porto Rico on the 6th inst., to come up to the City and discharge cargo, Granted for the 11th inst.

The steamship Arago, on the 28th July from Southampton, arrived at this port yesterday morning. A brief summary of her news has been already telegraphed from Cape Race. The London Post says that the Marechal Due DE MALAKOFF will accompany Her Majesty in her visit to Cherbourg.

The news from China, of which we gave full particulars in yesterday's impression, was in many respects both interesting and important. The capture of the forts at the mouth of the Peiho by English and French gun-boats establishes, we think beyond a question, the power of the Allies to compel the Emperor of China, sooner or later, to accede to their demands.
