To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: You are in error in your editorial, of this morning as to the seene you speak of occurring in court--- when Justice Osbern was holding Court. This is not so, It was after the Magistrate had made the announcement that, until Mr. ASHMEAD (LESLIES' counsel) arrived, no further proceedings would or could be taken.

DEATH OF WILLIAM RAWLE, Esq.--Our columns to-day contain the announcement of the decease of WILLIAM RAWLE. Esq.. an old and esteemed member of the Philadelphia bar. Mr. RAWLE was the son of the late distinguished WILLIAM RAWLE Esq., who resided on Third street, near Soruce. He was married to 3 daughter of the late EDWARD TILGMAN, Esq. He had emered his 71st year when he died.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In October, 1856, the Guatemala forces under General ZAVALA, assisted by a few Nicaraguan serviles, attacked the city of Granada, besieged the American Minister in his house, tone down the United States flag calming upon the United States representative to come out that they might kill him, and drink his hearts, blood.

JUDGE DENIO'S MARRIAGE-Among the personal items of the TIMES, on tile 6th inst., was one announcing the marriage of Judge DENIO to a daughter of the Honorable TIMOTHY PILKIN. The news was perfectly true, and yet its announcement very naturally took the happy couple by surprise.

The proceedings in the House of Lords last evening, on the subject of the Right of Search, will be read with interest on both sides of the ocean by all who wish well to the peace and freedom of the world

The fifty-fourth Commencement of the Universi ty of Vermont took place at Burlington, from the 4th to the 7th. The weather was fire, and tile people assembled in crowds from the adjacent towns The exercises commmenced by a Baccaleureate Sermon by President PEASE, Sabbath afternoon. Ills text was "Ye are the light of the world."

CONVENTION OF COLORED PEOPLE.-The Pres. byterian and Congregational Convention will meet, agreeably to adjournment, in the Talott street Congregational Church, in the City of Hartford, Connecticut, on Wednesday, the 18th day of August, in the year of our Lord, 1855, at 8 o'clock P. M., and will be opened with a sermon by the Rev. AMOS N. FREEMAN, moderator of the last Convention.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It has often occurred to me, and the more I reflect upon the subject, the more I am convinced of its salutary influence upon the floating rascality of the whole United States, that a penal colony in the Pacific Ocean would he the grand safety-value for all the convictions for criminal offences, such as manslaughter. arson, burglary, rape or other heinous crimes.

PORTRAIT OF SUPERINTENDENT TALMADGE.An elegant portrait of General TALMADGE, Superin. tendent of Police, has just been painted at the expence of members of the Police Department. It is designed to present it to the Superintendent on behalf of the Police force, as a token of their high regard for their Chief. It is an excellent likeness.

We have received a printed circular containing the correspondence between GERRIT SMITH and Messrs. IRA H. COBB, ABRAM PRYNE and WILLIAM GOODELL, the Committee appointed to apprise him of his nomination for Governor.

Messrs, Cobb, Pryne, Goodell: Your letter is before me. My years have been spent in seclusion. My habits are all formed to private life. It is emphatically true that public employments are not to my taste. Nevertheless, gentlemen, I accept the nomination. More than this--I shall, if it succeed, rejoice in the opportunity of wielding large official powers and influences for the removal of wrongs, which are my most intense abomination.

From four letters, which you have accepted and published, you will perceive that one who travels from Paris to Pekin, by the direct route of New-York, Independence arid Astoria, traverses these physical divisions: 1st. The Atlantic Ocean. 2d. The Atlantic Maritime Slope. 3d. The Alleghany Mountains. 4th. The Basin of the Mississippi. 5th. The Cordillera of the Sierra Madre.

HATTERS' BANK OF BETHREL, CONN., ROBBED OF $86,000-No CLUE TO THE BURGLARS,-Between Standay night and Sunday morning some burglars broke into the Hatters, Bank of Bethel, Conn, blew open the safe and carried a way $86,000, in bills and specie, belonging to the Bank.

MISSISSIPPI LAWS IN WANT OF REMODELING. GOVERNOR McWILLIE, of Mississippl, has summened an extra session of the State Legislature, to assemble on the first Monday in November next, In this State, as in others which have adopted the system of biennial sessions of their Legislatures. the plan has not been found to be the best for the interests of the people.

The Cunard Steamship Niagara, with three days' later news from Europe, is now fully due at Halifax from Liverpool. There were no signs of her at 11 o'clock last night. The arrangements for working the Atlantic Telegraph are now probably entirely completed, in which case the message of Queen VICTORIA and the response of President BUCHANAN will be transmitted some time to-day.

The steamship St. Louis, W. H. HUDSON commanding, from Aspinwalls Aug. 3, arrived at this port last evening. The St. Louis has made a rapid passage, arriving in advance of the regular California mail steamer, and bringing San Francisco dates to the 20th ult.

(who is the lessee of the Cape Cod and Island Telegraph,) in repairing the cable across the Vineyard Sound, in order to make his Nantucket Cable available.

The third day passed off, as it was expected to pass off, triumphantly. The contest between the various song societies excited a great deal of Interest and was altogether an extraordinary event. It says little for various largely-organized clubs that, lacking confidence, or for a meaner motive, they declined to take part in the battle.

At 12 o'clock, yesterday, a large number of the members of the New-York Bar gathered in the General Term room of the Superior Court, for the purpose of giving a formal expression of their appreciation of the loss the Bench and the Bar have sustained in the death of Chief-Justice DUER. The meeting was called to order by Ex-Judge BRONSON, who nominated for President, Judge BOSWORTH, now Chief-Justice of the Superior Court.

The Steamship St. Louis, from Aspinwall on the 3d inst., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, bringing California advices to the 20th ult. The St. Louis reports that the mail steamer Star of the West was to leave Aspinwall on the 3d with $1,500,000 in treasure for New-York. Among the treasure brought down form San Francisco by the Golden Age were some $25 000 in dust, destined for England.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, Captain MILLAR, from Liverpool at noon July 31, arrived here this afternoon at 1 o'clock, having been detained off the harbor eight hours by foggy weather. The steamship Borussia arrived at Southampton on the evening of the 28th ult., and the City of Washington at Liverpool at 5:30 P. M. on the 29th.

VERY LATE FROM COSTA RICA.--The "intelligent and spirited" correspondent of the Herald, gives, under date of San Juan del Norte, July 20, the following, among other equally correct items: "Costa Rica would have tenfold the foreigners if this road had been established before. She has in fact now the largest population in the Central American States--as many as all the other four together."

The Cincinnati Commercial says: We are permitted to copy the following from a letter just received by a gentleman in this city from the gallant and estimable Colonel HOFFMAN, who is well known to our citizens as recently Commandant at Newport Barracks. The letter is dated " Fort Bridger, U. T., July 12, 1858; Before this reaches you, you will have heard of the amicable adjustment of the Mormon troubles.

WASSINGTON MARKET FILTH.--When the Harbor Commissioners called the attention of the City authorities to the filthy condition of Washington Market Pier and its surroundings, there were over 7,000 cart.loads of manure and City filth deposited there. This has been ascertained by actual measurement. A portion of this mountain of manure has been removed. but it is still resorted to by gentlemen who use the freedom of the City.

The negotiation for the loan of ten millions dollars by the Secretary of the Treasury is, of itself, a simple financial event of little interest beyond the limited banking circle to which the stock is firs distributed. Less than Sixty persons, it seems, out of a population of twentynine and a half millions, applied to the Secretarv for a portion of his newloan.

LETTER PROM THE HON. J. T. HEADLEY.-We copy this morning from the Albany Statesman a letter of the Hon. J. T. HEADLEY, on the relations, duties and prospects of the Americans and Republicans. Mr. H. is, as is well known, an influential member of the American Party, by which he was elected Secretary of State in 1856.

HUTCHINGS.--In this City, on Tuesday, Aug. 10, Mr. RICHARD D. HUTCHINGS, in the 59th year of his age. The friends and relatives of the family, members of National Lodge. No. 30. I. O, of O. F., Knickerbocker Union. No. 15, and Daughters of Samaria. No. 1. are repectfully invited to attend the funeral. on Thursday, 12th inst., at 10 o'clock A. M , without further Invitation, from his late residence, No.159 West 30th at.

To the New York Associated Press : On the Wednesday before I left London, the Directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Company unanimously decided that after the cable was laid and the Queen's and President's messages transmitted, the line should be kept free for several weeks, solely for the ue of Dr. WHITEHOUSE, Prof. THOMPSON and other

Mayor TIEMAXN did no more than conform to the general desire of our citizens in recommending the Cummon Council to adopt some method for celebrating in a becoming manner the completion of the Atlantic Telegraph, and both Boards exhibited a most commendable desire to respond to the public wishes in their action on the Mayor's message.

The Bridgeport Advertiser gives full'partic. ulars of the robbery of the Hatters' Bank. The $86,000 stolen consisted of $6,000 in gold and silver, $1,300 in bills of other banks, and $78,700 in bills of the Bethel Bank. The vault lock was opened before the manufacturer arrived from NewYork, when it was discovered that the bottom of the vault was gone, and so was all the money left in it on Saturdav night.

THE HELTH OFFICE CONTEST-A COU??'ETAT, -It is well known that since May last there have been two medical gentlemen, Dr. SAMUEL k. BOYD and Dr. WARREN CLEVELAND, who claim to held the important position of Health Officer to the city of Brooklyn, The former gentleman has been backed in his claim to the office by the Common Council.

Judge DOUGLAS made a speech, the other day, which was reported in our columns on Friday, to a deputation of Germans which waited on him in Chicago, in which he treated his auditors to a few energetic fallacies on the subject both of negro equality and of the rights of foreigners.

The death of the Most Rev. WILLIAM WALSH, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Halifax, N. S., is announced under telegraphic head, as having occurred at his residence, in Halifax, on Tuesday night. The Alchbishop,-who was of Irish parentage,-was in the fifty-fourth year of his age at the time of his death. He had been actively identified,

MOB-LAW IN ILLINOIS. A correspondent informs the Hennepin Tribune that, on the night of the 29th ult., a band of Regulators, numbering near thirty, destroyed the house of an Irishman, known in that community as "Gib," leaving nothing but the hare walls standing. They then tied the proprietor to a tree, inflicted a severe castigation, and threatened to hang him unless he confessed to some thefts that had been committed within the past year.

The following Degrees were conferred at Bowdoin College last week: MASTER OF ARTS--In Course-W. W. Brookings, S. C. Burnham, S. S. Gardner, Edward Hawes, B. F. Haves, T. B. Hood, T. H. Little, J. A. McIntosn, F. v. Norcross, W. L. B. Putnam, Ezekiel Ross, T. B. Sherman, B. P. snow, L. W. Stanton, Peleg Tailman, Charles Tilcomb, G. C. Vose.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your exposure of Mr. GERRIT SMITH'S slight inconsistencies struck me as timely! If that worthy gentlemen answers the question as to "shams" truly, he will be likely to say that he considers a sham one of the aliases of a certain candidate for Governor. GERRIT is ambitious. He puts away the kingly crown until he gets some one to offer it, and then he snaps at it.

JANES--In this City, on Thursday morning, Aug. 12, at her residence, No. 67 West 20th st., MARY ANN, wife of Samuel James, aged 38 years. The funeral will take place this day(Friday) at 1 1/2 o'clock, from 16th st. Baptist Church, (near 8th av) The friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend. WILLS--In this City, on Wednesday, Aug, 11. suddenly WILLIAM WILLS,

From the Columbia (Penn) Spy. We have received a hasty message from York Penn, conveying the sad and alarming intelligence that the most mightful contagious disease, Psora, is raging in that borough, defying the skill of the most experienced physicians and carrying off, in a very few-hours, all whom it attacks.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: This distinguished gentleman is now among us; a Commissioner sent here by the Liberal or Juarez Government of Mexico. General TRIAS is a native of the City of Mexico, and a cousin of President ZOULIOAGA. He is about forty and engaging countenance, denoting high cultivation, great energy and courage.

Mr. HENRY V. POOR, known to the public as the editor of a respectable weekly newspaper in this City, devoted to Railroad interests and information, has addressed a communication to the London Times in deprecation of that journal's unfavorable remarks upon American Railroads as an object of English investment. The letter of Mr. Poon, together with some observations thereon by the Times, were published yesterday in the Commercial columns of this paper.

From the Cincinnati Enquirer. 10th. Major McCULLOUGH--one of the Commissioners upon the part of the United States Government to negotiate with the Mormons in Utah-passed through our city yesterday, on his way East, and honored us with a call at the office of the Enquirer. The Major was in the enjoyment of excellent health, and came through from halt Lake City to Leavenworth (Kansas) in thirty-three days, by an overland journey across the plains.

From the Boston Journal. The friends or Mr. GEORGE W. SIMMONS assembled at his splendid residence, at "Little Nabant." yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of writing with Mr. SIMMONS and his estimable lady in the observance of the 25th anniversary of their wedding day. The arrangements for the celebration of this silver wedding were made on the most liberal scale.

The letters of our correspondents in Great Salt Lake City and at the camp of the Army in Cedar Valley, bring news from Utah one week later than previous advices. Our latest dates are to the 17th of July, at which time the city had resumed its wonted aspect, nearly all the refugees having retur' ed to their homes and the pursuit of their avocations.

The result of the late election in Kansas will give rise to a great deal of speculation as to its political effects. No doubt great efforts will be made to revive the excitement which has heretofore disturbed the public peace and tranquillity. That all such efforts will signally tail we entertain no shadow of a doubt. Upon recurring to the causes which

To the Editor of the New-York Times. Your correspondent, W. A. H., in yesterday's paper, brooched a subject, second in importance to one now claiming the attention of the public. The rapid increase of crimes, far beyond that of our population, and not merely in the number of the offenders, but in their audacity and ferocity;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The readers of the TIMES have, doubtless, been greatly surprised to find that the late Board of Ordnance Officers, which was convened at West Point for the purpose of testing the several competing moles of altering United States muskets, etc., to breech-loading arms, have recommended the " Morse gun"

A dispatch from Fredericton, N.B., says that gold has been found in a brook at the west end of the town, supposed to have been washed down from a hill behind the town, as no gold has been found more than a foot below the surface.

This popular and favorite resort for inva lids and pleasure-seekers during the warm season, has two distinct and separate histories-one as a watering-place and the other as a military post, but neither dating back half a century. In 1814, the English, having landed here, established a rendezvous on this point, then a comfortless sand-bar, covered with sea-grass, scraggy live oak and clam shells.

From the Daily Saratogian, 10th. The trial of skill between several distinguished billiard players, heretofore announced, came off at AINSWORTH'S saloon, in this village, on Monday. Messrs. DUDLEY CAVANAGH, BARNEY CHRYSTAL and JOSEPH N. WHITE, of New-York and CHRISTOPHER BIRD, of Philadelphia, were present and took part.

From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser. We have made a visit to the Gipsy Eacamoment, near the old Indian Church. Within the church inclosure were several wagons, dilapidated carry-alls and a sort of car, similar to those used by itinerant dagnerreotypists. Most of the vehicles were covered with blankets or cloths like those of Western emigrants. A glance at their contents displayed a very miscellaneous assortment of trumpery of unimaginable uses.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Through the columns of your valuable paper, I notice, in regard to the celebration of the laying of the Atlantic Telegraph Cab!e, which is to be celebrated by the leading offcials of this City, that the rising generation, which is to be benefited in future by this enterprise, is entirely left out in the programme of the celebration.

THE TAX ON OFFICIALS.--We see it reported, we do not care upon what authority, that a tax is levied upon the persons employed in the Government service, and the payment thereof exacted. We are quite ignorant of the authority upon which this payment is dernanded, or the purposes to which it is applied when received. We trust, however, that Whatever may be thus collected may be wisely and

The Raleigh Standard says: "The Democrats have elected their candidate for Governor, JOHN W. ELLIS, by some fifteen to twenty thousand majority, and have carried both branches of the Legislature by large majorities. Judge ELLIS has gained in all the counties thus far heard from, arid that upon the vote for BRAGG and GILMER, the majority for Governor BRAGG in the State in 1856 being 12,594.

A NOVEL WAY TO KEEP A WIFE AT HOME.-Mr. FITZGERALD resides in Congress-street, and is married to a woman who takes snuff and is fond of spinning street-yarns. Yesterday afternoon Mrs. F. announced her intention of visiting Mrs. DUNLAP, and getting her daily supply of rappee. Mr. F. issued positive injunctions against such a course; but, as the wife insisted, the husband adopted a novel method of keeping her at home.

The New-York Bar bids fair to become, very shortly, a very disgusting institution. We do not share in the belief that a lawyer is bound by any moral law to behave beetled than men of any other calling; but there are temptations in his position which call for vastly greater care and circumspection in his language and behavior.

It has long been known that several emiment persons had been buried for more than a century past beneath the.floor of the Chapel of WilIam and Mary College; but so long a time had elapsed since there had been all inspection of the premises, that all was doubt and uncertainty on the subject. The Joint Committee of the Common Council of the City of New-York on celebrating the laying of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable, having determined to celebrate that event by a salvo of one hundred guns and national salutes, with ringing of all the church bells, immediately upon the transmission of the reply of the President of the United States

One can't help feeling a kind of interest in a Pretender, however down-at-the-heel or outat-the-elbows he may be. Let us hope that it is because there is more good nature in human nature than cynics are willing to allow. The Old Pretender, JAMES III., or the Chevalier DE ST. GEORGE, or what you will, was a dull, besotted, abased old creature enough, out of all doubt;

We learn by the steamship St. Louis, that Oregon has elected JOSEPH LANE and DELAZON SMITH to represent her in tile Senate; and although she is not yet admitted into tire family of States, and therefore can strictly have no power to appoint Senators, we suppose the irregularity will be overlooked in her case, as similar flaws have been before,

THE GALWAY LINE OF EUROPEAN STEAMERS.--The proprietors of the Galway line of ocean steamers very correctly set forth the advantages of this route of European travel. It is the intention of the company to place six steamers on the line, four of which--the Prince Albert the Indian Empire, the American Empire, and the British Empire--have already commenced running.

THE GREAT CELERATION.--The Joint Committee of the Common Council are likely to have ample time to complete all necessary arrangements for the grand civic display in honor of the completion of the Ocean Telegraph. The Queen's message has not yet been received, and it, probably, will not be in several days.

THE SECOND CITY OF THE TERRITORY. The City of Ogden, for years past known as the second city of Utah Territory in point of population and wealth, lies only forty miles to the north of this place. Several years ago, when a population of ten thousand was first claimed for Great Salt Lake City, Ogden was said to be its equal in that respect;

My DEAR R.: The rain is raning in torrents--the mountains around are draped almost to their' feet in clouds-the distant islands, with their tall, blasted, leafless pine trees, loom dimly through the mist, and all is damp and drear and desolate. Last evening I saw a young man jump into one of the boats. and push off across the late I hailed him, and asked him where he was going. He replied, "after butter."

NATTONAL THEATRE.--The usual excellent attractions of this popular place have been varied during the present week by the introduction of a novelly of decided interest. This is none other than a complete ballet troupe composed entirely of juveniles educated under the special direction of Mons. ZAVISTOWSKI. Children have been used for this sort of thing before, but generally in masses, and for the effect of groups.

General JERTZ, the special representative of Nicaragua, with his suite is expected in this city tomorrow morning from Bedford Springs, where he has been to have an Interview with the President in relation to the affairs of his country. The policy of the Administration in reference to the Nicaragua Transit has been thoroughly and definitely settled.

A CALL TO THE CAPTAIN'S OFFICE.-The Washington Union has "seen it reported," but is, of course, " quite ignorant of the authority," that the clerks and employes in the Departments are required to pay political taxes for the support of the Democratic Party. But it hopes it is true, and that the money will be faithfully applied.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your facetious correspondent, J. B. NONES, of yesterday, on the "Capture of the Algerine Admiral," clearly proves himself better qualified to capture Algerines than familiar with the Chronological History of our country-from its discovery by COLUMBUS in 1492-which clearly defines that, "The Dey makes peace on terms advantageous to America July 4, 1815."

From the Philadelphia Press. An instance of day-dreaming--termed from the persistent form the vagary has assumed, monomania--has been chronicled in this city. A man, calling himself JOHN J. ACTON, and who claims to have recently returned from California, where the had accumulated vast wealth, has been elating our business men with promises of princely purchases, but only to depress them with a disclosure of his actual circumstances.

The present position of the English in India is critical; if we may believe all the intelligence brought by the last Indian mail. The fall of Lucknow has neither ended the war, nor broken the rebellion which, now more than a year old, seems holler, stronger, and more confident, of ultimate success than ever. Agra, Delhi, Cawnpore, Lucknow, Allahabad, and all the important fortresses in the rebellious districts are held by British troops;

Before Commissioner Morren. Samuel Shottock, who was arrested a few weeks ago, charged with having taken a letter from the Post-Office and appropriating its contents to his own use, was, upon examination this morning, honorably discharged, there being no evidence against him.

It is said that President BUCHANAN intends to hasten his return from Bedford Springs, and certainly he is needed at the Capital, if for no other reason, to check the indiscretions of his newspaper organ. When Kansas rejected the English bill by so overwhelming a vote, prudence would have suggested to the Washington Union a degree of quiet reserve.

In the absence of the Chairman, Supervisor BERGEN, of the Eighth Ward, was called to the Chair. After the usual preliminary business was disposed of, communications were declared to be in order. One was received from Sheriff REMSEN,

We rather think old BLOUNT, tile lawyer, has been too sharp for the hero Miss EMILY is now in Alabama,

The United States Mail steamship Star of the West, A. G. GRAY, Commanding, from Aspinwall, Aug. 3, via Key-West, Aug. 8, arrived at this port last evening. The Star of the West has brought the mails, passengers and treasure brought down by the Golden Age, which left San Francisco on the 20th ult.

The Health Commissioner met ?? Thursday. Present--The Mayor, Drs. ROOKWELL, MELLIR and THOMPSON, together with Mr. MESTON. The bark Ocean House was allowed to proceed to the City on the 17th inst. The brig Faustina was allowed to proceed on the 18th inst. The brig John Stevens was allowed to proceed on the 26th inst. The bark Celia petitioned for permission to proceed to the ?? CRONIN, of Albuquerque, New-Mexico, formerly of Galena, we gain some facts which may not be uninteresting to our readers :

Money matters, about these days, occupy the minds of the people of Kansas more than politics or fighting. Notwithstanding the exaggerated reports in circulation a few weeks since, relative to murders, robberies, , in the South eastern portion of the Territory, the mass of the people of Kansas have paid but little attention to affairs there, and, as a consequence, everything now is peaceable and encouraging.

We have been furnished with copies of an interesting correspondence between the Secretary of the American Geographical Society and Sir RODERICK MURCHISON in relation to the accusation of Dr. RINK against Dr. KANE'S integrity. Mr. Jay to Sir Rodcrick Murchison. ROOMS OF THE AMERICAN GEOGRAPHICAL AND STATISTICAL SOCIETY, NEW-YORK, May 8, 1858.

FOUND DROWNED.--Coroner DeForest held an inquest yesterday, at Staten Island, upon the body of an unknown man, who was floating near the south beach of Staten Island, near the house of Stephen Kettletas, Esq The body was perfectly nude, had light brown hair, was five feet six inches high, with a very high forehead, and had been but a short time in the water. Verdict, death by drowning.

No such thing as government remains to Mexico. Authority is dead ; administration effete ; justice departed. The spectacle is presented of a great nation ianimate. There is no hope of resurrection.

A DISPATCH FROM EUROPE AT LAST.--With the last arrival at this port from Europe, there came a gentleman whose friends called him, "My Lord," and who deported himself like an English nobleman. He is, indeed, a peer of the Queen's realm, It is said. He "put up" at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

The Hon. ISAAC TOUCEY, Secretary of the Navy, had a public reception at Hartford on Wednesday, The Times says: "Nearly an hour before the cars arrived, thousands of people flocked to the depot, and the number were constantly augmented till Gov. Toucey arrived.

The renewed festivities commenced here yeserday, and considering that a repetition of a success is always a dangerous thing to attempt, and still more difficult to consummate, the attendance was good. At all events it was not expected that it would be better.

The Board of Commissioners of Health met on Friday. It was reported to the Board that Miss Susan Cross, residing in a cottage near the beach below Townsend's Dock, on the east side of Staten Island, died of yellow fever on the 11th inst.

GENERAL ORDERS, NO. 19. The General in Chief learning of the arrival the troops under Brevet Brigadier General JOHNSTON at their destination in the Salt Lake country; after their detention in the valley of Green River during the last Winter, takes occasion to commend them in General Rivers--as be has already Gone through their commander--for their exemplary conduct under the trying circumstances in which they have been placed.

From the New Orleans Bee, 7th. Some weeks ago the new mail contract, in virtue of which the Great. Eastern mail was to be transported by the Mississippi Central and Jackson Railroads from New-York to New-Orleans in four days and seventeen hours, went into operation.

It is a genuine refreshment, one that heals the bones and takes the soreness out of bruised flesh, to attend, in the spirit of it, a genuine New-England Commencement. Indeed, I am moved to rebuke you for calling "Commencements" those floral exhibitions which you give at Niblo's and the Academy of Music.

There has been considerable by-play of an interesting character at the State Half within the last few days. Early last Spring, OL HARTWELL, Engineer on the middle division of the Elie Canal, was suspended by State Engineer RICHMOND, who was desirous of filling the vacancy with O. C.

The long agony is over, and the last spark at ??, galvanized into the Lecompton Constitution by political quacks, is "crushed out" by the heavy beel of the people. The election passed off very quietly, and the indications are that a heavy vote has been polled.

From the Joliet (Ill.) Democrat, 7th. On last Saturday evening we were visited by one of the most terrific thunder-storms we have ever witnessed. The rain poured down in perfect torrents for hours, and the heavens were in a perfect blaze of lightning, the thunder rolled incessantly in deafening peals, and appeared to shake the very foundations of the earth.

A detachment of United States Marines arrived here to-day from Boston, Mass. They are destined for the Sabine, and have been transferred to the North Carolina until the 1st proximo, when it is expected their ship will go in Commission.

To the Editor of the New- York Times. The farmers in our region are now nearly over their "haying and harvesting," unless it is some lowland grass which may yet remain uncut. And there has not been, I will venture to assert, for a series of years, so universal and uniform good crops in our locality as the present.

From the London Saturday Review. In most cases it is right to let evil of a certain kind alone. Blasphemy and obscenity are not cured by being talked a bout ; and simply to review the literature of Holywell-street does no good. But this is because it is at our own doors; and, morcover, it illustrates nothing.

About 1 o'clock on Friday William P. Hilliard, one of the Mayor's Police, had an altercation with Ex-Recorder James Smith, in the Mayer's Office, when Hilliard struck that gentleman a violent blow in the face. The facts may be partly gathered from the evidence of Marshal Stephens, who was present.

Yesterday evening, in accordance with public notice, a meeting was held at Peck slip, for the purpose of giving expression to the views of those citizens who are opposed to the suppression of the Ferry from Peck.slip to Williamsburg--a project now before the Board of Aldermen, on a resolution which has been offered to that effect.

AN OPERA HOUSE FOR BROOKLYN.--A meeting, small in number, but composed of highly respectable citizens, was held in Musical Hall, on Thursday even ing, the object of which was to devise means to erect an Opera House in Brooklyn. Mr. GEORGE F. H. YOUNGS occupied the Chair, and remarks appropriate to the occasion were made by Messrs. A. J. SPOONER, RODMAN B. DAWSON, EDWARD T. WOOD, and Col. T. B. THOBPE.

A RESIDENCE IN TWO STATES AND THREE COUNTIES AT THE SAME TIME.-- At a place called "College Corner," an individual occupies a place that is rather singularly situated. One half of the house is in the State of Indiana and the other half in Ohio. The boundary line between Butter and ?? countries, in this State, runs ?? through the house; ;

A new and interesting question is soon to come before the House of Lords for decision-to wit: whether a right to a seat in their Chamber can be claimed by reason of the ownership of a particular piece of landed estate ?

The Baltimore Patriot of Thursday has the following particulars of the attack upon the office of the Exchange, reported yesterday by telegraph: " About 11 o'clock this morning considerable excitement was created in the neighborhood of the coiner of Baltimore and North streets, by an attack upon the office of the Exchange newspaper.

East of Boston proper, and about one-third of a mile distant from it, lies what was once known as Noddle's island, for some two centuries after the settlement of the present city only a huge ?? occupied by a single family, and a favorite pasturage ground for horses and castle. Such it was, indeed, as late as the year 1833--one quarter of a century ago.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It was stated a few days since in your paper that V. CONSIDERANT, the old and tried disciple of FOURIER, had abandoned the ideas of the master. Allow me to correct this mistake. Mr. CONSIDERANT is engaged in organizing a colony in Western Texas, where, with the means he can control, it is useless to think of realizing FOURIER'S magnificent ideal.

From the Newark Advertiser. The semi-annual meeting of the Editorial Association of New-Jersey, was held yesterday at Paterson, and was largely attended, nearly every press in the State being represented, and a number of Editors from other States being present, together with several non professional guests.

In my letter, yesterday, I have the readers of the TIMES a brief historical sketch of Old Point Comfort, as a Summer resort for invalids and pleasure-seekers. I now propose to glance at it as a military post and fortification It was stated that in 1814 the British troops landed here and established their rendezvous, white they burned the town of Hampton and laid waste the surrounding country.

From the Toronto Colonist. The contest in Toronto goes on bravely. At the moment we write, the Catholics are divided. They are half disposed to start a candidate of their own, which is perhaps really the best thing they can do. Mr. CAMERON states his views with a bluntness almost amounting to a fault.
THE ATLANTIC CABLE NOT YET IN WORKING ORDER.-It is a week since the end of the Telegraphic Cable was landed at Trinity Bay, but no message has yet been transmitted across the wires.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: It is undoubtedly a very fine thing to have a large Police force in a city to protect life and property, but unfortunately, in that large town just over the river from here, policemen are never to be found when wanted.

DOINGS AT THE PHILADELPHIA NAVY-YARD.--Upward of 1,200 men now constitute the mechanical and laboring forces at our Nay-Yard. The former is composed of 600, consisting of ship carpenters, joiners, blacksmiths, sparmakers, sailmakers, gancarriage makers caulkers, roamers, oakum sptaners, plumbers, cost builders and painters.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A few weeks since the public ear was shocked by the report of an accident on the New-York and Erie Railroad near Port Jervis, by which several lives were lost, and many other passengers seriously injured.

The Cunard steamship Niagara, from Liverpool on the 31st ult., arrived at Boston yesterday morning, and her mails, dispatched South in the early train, reached this City last evening. The European journals contains but little news in addition to the telegraphic summary forwarded from Halifax.

The Cunard steamship Niagara, with London and Liverpool advices to the 31st of July, arrived at Boston yesterday morning, and her mails. dispatched south in the early train, reached this City in the afternoon. Some details of the news telegraphed from Halifax, will be found elsewhere, but we find little additional intelligence in our foreign files.

Preparations are being made tor the organization of an efficient military staff for Washington and Oregon Territories, preliminary to the contemplated operations against the hostile Indians, and to prevent a repetition of such defeats as were experienced by Colonel STEPTOE.

A letter has been received in Hartford from a young Connecticut mechanic, who left Hartford on the 24th of March last. He was sent out to put up 40 cars built in Springfield, Mass., and sent to Egypt all marked ready to put together on their arrival. He writes: I am getting along finely with my work.

The Albany Atlas and Argus discourses of steam on the Canals: "A tug of very moderate size might, by the use of several wheels adapted to the occasion, by a very simple mechanical contrivance, acquire a tractile power sufficient to draw a train of Canalboats as numerous as the cars that follow a locomotive on a railway.

CLOSING THE PUBLIC LIBRARIES.--There is a very large class of literary laborers in this City composed of students and writers, men who depend directly upon literature for their means. It is to this class that the large public libraries are as much a necessity as banks are to merchants.

Every person has heard of the "Regents of the University" in this State: but few persons are aware of the duties which devolve on that Board. The position has been regarded as a mere compliment bestowed by the Legislature from time to time on some retired politician or literary man.

MILDEBERGER-In this City, on Friday, Aug 13, JOHN A. MILDERBERGER, Esq., in the 8th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 3 Hammond-st, on Sunday tomorrow) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, without further, invitations.

By the brig Wm. Wilson, we have the Diario Rio de Janeiro of June 27. The Diario has a long article vigorously urging a " political alliance with the United States, which should extend even to the formation of a principle of intervention in such cases, and of such character as might be judged proper, in order to control the interests and protect the rights of the various States in the two Americas."

RICHMOND COUNTY STATE AND CONGRESSIONAL DELIGATES.--The Republicans of Richmond, on the 14th inst., in Convention, appointed SAMUEL L. HOPPING, of Westfield, and JOSEPH EOBERT, of Southfield, as Delegates to the Republican State Convention; and HARMON B. CROPSEY and JOHN C. THOMPSON, as Alternates.

The general rejoicing over the great telegraphic triumph seems to have momentarily rendered the public incapabel of devoting any attention to any other subject. And we are not disposed to quarrel with its temporary abstraction from all other topics, for the laying of a cable across the Atlantic Ocean is certainly a theme large enough for all the wonder over the reflection which even a nation can for the time bestow on it.

The Constitutionalists are triumphant at every point; Guanajuato, Guadalajara and Zacatecas have been conquered; and President ZULOAGA is preparing to defend the Capital, where, before long, the final battle must be fought. SAILING OF THE VANDERBILT.--The steamship Vanderbilt. Capt. LEFEVRR, sailed on Saturday for Southampton and Havre, carrying 210 passengers. The usual row among the coal-passers and firemen, which occured also upon the departure of the North Star and Northern Light, took place on account of the reduction of their wages by the agent of the line.

Immediately on the adjournment of the Contracting Board yesterday, Mr. RICHMOND proceeded arbitrarily to exercise the authority vested in him as State Engineer, and a second time suspeaded Engineers GOODSELL and CLARK, (who had just been restored by the Board,) and appointed Mr. O.W. CHILDS in the place of Mr. GOODSELL as Divison Engineer on the Eastern Division.

Of all modern sciences Geology is certainly the most imperfectly developed. With immense accumulations of observation, it is still utterly devoid of any of those grand generalizations that alone give meaning and measure to facts. The mighty results to be derived from researches into the chemistry of Geology have been almost wholly neglected.

Yesterday was a memorable day for New-York The City was depleted. It presented only a beggerly account of empty streets. It approximated to that condition which. according to the medi?eval philosphers, was so abhorent to Nature ; it was almost a vacuam. Fromlearly morn tillate in the afternoon the cars on the east side of the City were laden with visitors to Jones? Wood.

BAPTISM OF A SPIRIT-RAPPER.-MISS MARGARET FOX, one of the notorious family who originated the Spirit-rapping dispensation, was yesterday baptized, at St. Peter's Church, Barelay-street, into the Roman Cahtoloc Church, and the Catholic authorities having uniformly denounced Spirit-rapping as an invention of the devil, it is to be presumed that Miss Fox has made full confession and unreserved renunciation of her share in the Rapping business.

Mr. Lewis Bradley, of Orange. Conn, has, for the last three years, assembled all the relatives of his family, in the month of August, at lline's Grove, where a sumptuous table is spread, history of the past year given, and the number present on each anniversary. In 1855 there were 70 present; in 1856, 112; in 1857, 108; in 1858, 91.

From the Albany Evening Journal. A large meeting of the citizens of Auburn was held on Wednesday evening to make arrangements for celebating the success of the Atlantic telegraph. Mayor BRIGGS presided, with STEPHEN VAN ANDEN, DANIEL HEWSON and EDWARD E MARVINE, Esqs., Vice Presidents. GEORGE W.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: The laying of the Atlantic Telegraph between Valencia Bay, in Ireland, and Trinity Bay, in Newfoundland, being now an accomplished fact, the next step I suppose will be the connection between North and South America, via the West Indian Islands.

REPORTS FROM TRINITY BAY.---We have a glimmer of light from the electricians at Trinity Bay, though nothing of a very satisfactory character. The chief operator sends a dispatch to the effect that "signals" are constantly passing over the Cable, but from some unexplained cause no message has yet been transmitted.

THE AVENUE A HOMICIDE--FOUR PERSON COMMITTED TO ANSWER--Coroner Connery yesterday, at the Seventeenth Ward Station house, concluded the inquest in the case of CHRISTIAN MATHEWRACHER, the German who died from injuries received in a row on Thursday night at the grocery store, No. 20 Avenue A. Several witnesses were examined, but no new facts of importance were elicited.

The Savannah Republican of the 13th has the following: "Some of our cotemporaries, in writing of this curious romance, seem to think the object of the Zouave is to marry the subject of his adoration, Miss BLOUNT. This is a mistake. The young lady asserts unqualifiedly that they were lawfully married before they made the tour to New-York, and had lived as man and wife for weeks before the separation.
From the Washington Union, 14th. In speaking a few days since of the recent vote in Kansas, we said that "the vexed question of Slavery had little or nothing to do with the result."

ALLIGATOR BRANCH--WRIT OF ERROR GRANTED.--In the Supreme Court yesterday, on motion of Mr. ASHMEAD, Mr. Justice CLERKE, at Chambers, granted a writ of error in the case of STEPHEN H. BRANCH, recently convicted of libel against Mayor TIEMANN, and now serving his term in the Penitentiary, pursuant to his sentence in the General Sessions.

DEATH OF A SAILOR FROM SUPPOSED VIOLENCE--JAMES REYNOLDS, the sailor formerly of the ship Gallatm, of Boston--a report of whose ante-mortem examination appeared in Monday's TIMES--died yesterday at the City Hospital. An inquest was held yesterday on the body. JOHN JONES, employed as a seaman on beard the same ship at the time of alleged violence towards the deceased by BAKER, the first mate, corroborated the statement made by REYNOLDS,

We copy resolutions adopted on Friday last by the Canadian Parliament, respecting the Hudson's Bay Company. They were introduced by Mr. LORANGER as a Government measure, and passed after discussion, though the session was about to close. In his speech supporting them, the mover made some interesting statements of fact and history bearing upon the position of the Company.

In a speech at Winchester, III., delivered on the 7th inst, Mr. DOUGLAS said: "Twenty-five years ago I entered this town on foot, with my coat upon my arm, without an acquaintance in a thousand miles, and without knowing where I could get money to pay a week's board. Here I made the first six dollars I ever earned in my life, and obtained the first regular occupation that I ever pursued.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The undersigned requests the public to suspend judgment with respect to the charge brought against t him until the facts are fully known. He has parted with Bonds to a very large amount, receiving notes purporting to be FREDRICKS' in payment, which, with the exception of the one delivered by himself to, and now in the hands of the magistrate, are in his own possession still.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: From your valuable paper I am glad to see that public opinion is beginning to awake to the great and important subject of steam on the Erie Canal. That some change in the manner of transportation must be attained, is no longer a doubt.

The Commissioners of Health met at the City Hall on Monday. Previously to the meeting it was said it can now be proved that Miss Cross, Who died recently from yellow fever, visited one of the intected vessels below Townsends clock for the purpose, as is alleged. of obtaining a draught of water.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: The insured should know the facts and experiences of the much-abused class called insurance brokers, and they will well and truly judge which would stand the hardest loss and go through the safest in a great conflagration.

A. H. COLE, of Newport, Ky., furnishes the Cincinnati Commercial with an interesting account of the freaks of a streak of lightning in his house, during a violent thunder-storm, a few nights ago. We quote: "He says that during a violent thunder-storm a ball of electric fluid struck the chimney of his residence, and shattered it from cap to base, and likewise split completely the coping of the building.

The people of Virginia feel in no way disappointed or chagrined at the result of the late Kansas election ; and if the truth were fully known, I question if it would not be found in conformity with the sentiments of fully three-fourths of them.

The Message of Queen Victoria to President Buchanan. To the Honorable the President of the United States. Her Majesty desires to congratulate the President .upon the successful completion of this great international work, in which the Queen has taken the deepest interest.

The Waterbury (Coun) American Says: "The sad termination of the life of Mr. WILLISUPSON, of this city, by his own hand, on Saturday afternoon of last week, struck his fellow-citizens with astornishment, and awakened universal sympathy--for he was a usefull man, of upright character, and a good citizen and father. Before Judge Clerke. In re Augustus Limberger, on writ of Habeas Corpus---In this case Limberger's friends had sued out a will of habeas corpus addressed to Colonel Harris, the commandant of the Marine Barracks at Brooklyn, claimbig his discharge form the service of the United States.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. In an article of the TIMES, 11TH inst., on the results of negro emancipation in the British West Indies, you remark; " All we know is derived from the results of the flying visits and cursory observations of fiery partisans."

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Capt. LEITCH, from Boston, via Halifax, for Liverpool, arrived at this port at 1 P.M. to-day. She was run foul of on Saturday, 14th inst., at 10 1/2 P. M., by the Royal Mail steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 7th inst., bound to New-York. The Arabia, it appears, mistook the lights of the Europa for Cape Race light.

Mr. PEABODY, the eminent American merchant and capitalist, gave one of his usual grand banquets at the Star and Garter Hotel, at Richmond, in honor of his Excellency Mr. MASON, the United States Minister to France, and Mrs. MASON, at which nearly one hundred English and American ladies and gentlemen were present.

Gen. HARNEY is not yet ordered to the Pacific. A command will be assigned to him to-morrow. Gen. CLARK may continue to conduct the Indian War. Senator BRIGHT left to-day for the West. He thinks the Democracy will unite and sweep Indiana. It is understood that the Hon. RICHARD W. THOMPSON, of Indiana, will stump Illinois in support of a bargain between the Fillmore Americans and DOUGLAS.

STRANGK PROCEEDING--MURDERER TURNED LOOSE--The Pittsburg True Press says: "Some of our readers may recollect the cold blooded murder of a Pittsburgher, named JOSEPH McINTYRE. on board the steamer Vicksburg, near Baton Rouge, La., on the 31st of May last, while he was on his way to this city--having been to New-Orleans upon a coal-boat trip.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The pleasures of a country life are fully realized in the village of Madison, New-Jersey--a village of superior attractions, situated on the Morris and Essex railway, within an hour and a half of New-York. The beanleods mountain scenery in its vicinity is superbly grand, and reminds one of some or the choicest in the Tyrol.

The Indian Bureau has received a communication from BRIGHAM YOUNG, in which he says he will give to Dr. FORNEY, and close his office as Superintendent of Indian Affairs for Utah. He asks for an allowance of $1,300 to reimburse him for food and presents to the Indians, in order to conciliate and keep them in check until the peaceful results following the advance of the troops could be explained to them.

A shocking case of murder and suicide occurred in the seventeenth Ward about 11 1/4 o'clock last night. Dennis instantly drop.
At a stated meeting of the Board of Directors of the Manhaltan Life Insurance Company. held at the office of the Company on the 10th inst.,

The Board of Governors of the Almshouse met on Tuesday afternoon at the Workhouse, Blackwell's Island, Governor W. T. PINCKNEY in the Chair. Present, also, Messrs. H. F. PINCKNEY, GUNTHER, MOLONY. McELROY, DUGRO and OLIVER. The usual semi-monthly requisitions were read and with some corrections allowed and passed.

BARNUM'S MUSEUM. --Thiodon's Theatre of Arts commenced here on Monday, and gained a decided success This kind of exhibition is we believe new, or comparatively so, in New-York. A miniature stage, filled with miniature scenery, beautifully printed. and animated with mechanical figures, so exquisitely constructed that they mimic life in a way perfectly wonderful-these constitute the elements of Thiodon's Theatre of Arts, and give a peculiar interest to a pleasing exhibition.

New-York resounded with the firing of cannon, yesterday, at intervals, from daybreak till dark. The streets were gay with the banners and with the flags of all nations. At night the City blazed with illuminations, from tallow dips, gas jets, rockets, and all manner of pyrotechnic displays,-all in honor of the Cable that connects ours and the Mother Continent.

MURDER IN CHICAGO IN DAYLIGHT. The Chicago Times says: "Seven or eight years ago Mr. C. T. BOGGS, a well-known builder of this city, purchased ten feet of ground from the north side of a lot, fifty feet wide, on State-street, near the corner of Van Buren-street, fronting cast. The land was described in his deed by metes and bounds.

THE CELEBRATION LAST NIGHT.-The crowd of people assembled last night in front of the City Hall to witness the celebration in honor of the success of the great Ocean Telegraph, was, probably, the largest ever collected in this metropolis. There were, at a reasonable calculation, about 100,000 persons present.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Permit me to say a few words about those two wonderful Messages which have just passed through the Atlantic Telegraph. First--As to their general style and composition. Any school-boy of twelve years old could have produced something far more pithy and suitable to the occasion.

The Board of Supervisors met yesterday afternoon, President PURDY in the Chair. Soon after the Board had organized the Tax Levy was called up again, and Supervisor BELL offered a resolution to add an appropriation of $300,000 for the Commissioners of Records. doing so he admit.

There were a number of arrivals from infected ports at the lower station, yesterday, among which were the three masted schooner Queen of the South from Cumberland Harbor, who reports, 4th inst.' HENRY WILSON, of Sweden, a boy, died. The British bark Flying Eagle, from Trinidad de Cuba. had lost three men--DANIEL LINDSAY, of Scotland, died June 6; GEORGE WILLIAM, of Wales, died.

The public must have been surprised yesterday, when they read in the morning newspapers what purported to be the long and eagerly-expected Message from Queen VICTORIA to the President of the United States. The few words published yesterday were in fact but the opening paragraph of Her Majesty's Message; and it was no wonder that the people were dissatisfied with its brevity.

NON-ARRIVAL OF THE NIAGARA--The non-arrival of the Niagara at this port has caused some uneasiness, and was the only circumstance that marred the brilliant celebration of last evening. The report made by the steamer Saxonia, which arrived yesterday, does not tend to dispel altogether the anxiety felt for the Niagara.

DEMOCRATIC PROSPECTS IN ILLINOIS.-The Washington Union, in its issue of yesterday, gravely holds Senator DOUGLAS responsible for the " gloom and doubt" which it cannot but admit overcloud the "prospects" of the Buchanan Democracy in Illinois. Up to his Chicago speech "a consolidation and reorganization of the Democracy of Illinois" was entirely "practical."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Some remarks in Monday's TIMES having done gross injustice to Miss MARGARETTA Fox, space for correction is asked in her behalf. She renounced Spiritualism, and separated herself from all association with Spiritualists five years ago, when she was but sixteen years of age.

NOMINATION OF TOM CORWIN FOR CONGRESS.--The telegraph announces the nominationof Governor CORWIN for Congress, by the Republican Convention of the Seventh District in Ohio. The present member is the Hon. AARON HARLAN, a Republican. We recently published a political speech by Mr. CORWIN, in which he expressed his diregard of party ties, as such.

This exciting contest took place yesterday, between the New-York and Brooklyn Nines, and after a most lively game, it terminated in favor of Brooklyn, the score standing 29 for Brooklyn, and only 8 for New-York. The morning was extremely warm, but soon after play was called it became cloudy, and accompanied with some slight showers, which made it exceedingly pleasant.

POLITICAL MOVEMENT.--A mass meeting of Republicans. Americans and Anti-Administration Democrats, is to be held to-morrow, in the village of Kingston, Ulster County. Among the speakers who are to address the meeting are the Hon. J. T. HEADLEY, of Newburg, the Hon. HORACE GREELEY, of New York,

MURDER AT RONDOUT.--A man named BERNARD McDERMOTT was murdered a few nights since at Rondout, Two men named McCOY and BARRY were arrested on suspicion of being participators in the crime, and stand committed. Another man, named Jos. LYNCH, has disappeared, and a reward of $100 has been offered for his arrest.

SUICIDE.-NATHAN FINN, barkeeper for JOHN LAOSTAFF, on Myrtle avenue, committed sulcide Monday night, by taking a dese of laudanum. JOINT BOARD.--The Joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisers met yesterday afternoon, when, without transacting any business, they adjourned till Friday next.

The screw-steamship Saxonia, from Southampton, on the 4th of August, arrived at this port last evening. Her advices are four days later than those received by the Niagara at Boston, though not so late by three days as those received by the Arabia and telegraphed from St. Johns, N. F. The Soxonia passed the United States steamfrigate Niagara on Sunday morning, 290 miles east of Sandy Hook.

The celebration of the success of the Atlantic Telegraph, yesterday, was one of the most enthustastic demonstrations in the City for a very long period. Without suspicion of the calamity that was in store, as the final illumination, all was joy and gladness during the day and evening. One of our reporters carried the news over to the Hall. Sergeant OWEN told him that they knew it, but that they would have no difficulty in getting it under.

STARE.--In this City, on sunday morning. Aug. 15. ELIZA, widow of John L. Starr. and daughter of Ralph 1. Westervelt. in the 45th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, from the Dutch Reformed Church in Kinx st., On Thursday morning, at 9 o'clock.

The valuation of property in the city of Boaton has just been completed, and shows the fol. lowing results: Real estate, $153,578,700; personal, $101,142,700; total, $254,721,400. As compared with the valuation of last year, there has been a decrease of about three and a third millions, as the valuation then was $258,111,900;

About 97 discharges had been made, and when the gunners had just prepared for the ninety eighth round, a premature explosion took place,

Stock. For the fourteen millions of the former, put up by the Secretary for the best award for the Government, about three-fourths the offers were from New-York.

THE NATIONAL GUARD AND THE TRIP TO RICHMOND.--A Committee of the Board of Officers of the Seventh Regiment, on behalf of the Guard, has sent three letters, beautifully written and in rich gilt frames, to Governor WISE, Mayor MAYO, and Colonel THOMAS P. AUGUST, of Richmond, Va., expressing their thanks for the cordial reception extended to them when they visited that city as a guard of honor to MONROE'S remains.

Postmaster-General BROWN has declined a jubilee dinner tendered him by the citizens of Memphis, but writes an interesting letter on Post-office affairs in reference to the invitation: GENTLEMEN: I am here in your beautiful and prosperous city, on a rapid visit to Arkansas, where my private affairs require my attention.

MORSE expressed his astonishment, ard offered to get out the patent at his own expense and divide.

The blackened front of the City Hall, over which the cupola stood Tuesday, looked yesterday morning like the sweated forehead of a man who has just removed from his head a dirty hat that was too tight for him, and the dark-browed windows of the upper stories, with the gutted rooms behind, are like the hollow eyes of one who has seen too much of the celebration.

LINCOLN and TRUMBULL on the other. In a recent speech, at Beardstown, DOUGLAS referred-to a charge made against him by LINCOLN as "an infamous lie."

THE FIREMEN AND THE ATLANTIC CABLE.--Owing to the uncertainty of the time of the arrival of the Niaraga the Fire Companies of the City were enable to have a grand torchlight procession last evening as intended, commemorative of the completion of the Atlantic Cable. A meeting of the companies is called for Monday evening, and on Tuesday or Wednesday evening of next week, the promised turnout will take place.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The undersigned acknowledges himself to have been one of a party of young men assembled last Sunday evening, in one of the Club-houses in Broadway, between Ninth and Tenth streets, to enjoy each others' society in harmless mirth, fun and frolic.

NEW USURY LAW IN CANADA.-The Canadian Parliament have passed an act changing the law of interest. Hitherto the legal rate has been six per cent. but by the new act individuals may allow and exact on any contract or agreement any rate of intererst or discount which may be agreed upon.

I send you the following journal of the last voyage of the Niagara, kept on board from day to day, and comprising a complete history of the successful laying of the Telegraphic Cable: Saturday, July 17.--Civil Reckoning.--At 7 P.M. got under way from Queenstown Roads; at 8 discharged the pilot one mile outside the head of the entrance of the harbor.

The screw steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 4th of August, arrived at this port last evening. Her advices have been anticipated by the Sexenia, which arrived on Tuesday. From our European files by the City of Washington we obtain a few items of news not before published.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : DEAR SIR: As an old reader and subscriber to your reliable (non-Plum.Gut) journal, I would ask, why will not steam answer as well on our canals as on those in Canada? In 1845 and '6, I traveled through a grent portion of both the Canadas, and I found there that a large portion of their freight was carried both by side-wheel and screwsteamers.

NAVAL STORES--The market for Spirits of Turpentine during the week has considerably advanced, and closes to day firm, at 48c. for lots in shipping order. Common Resin has also advanced, and, with a good export demand, it freely brings $1 60, afloat. OILS--There has been more animation in the market.

The United States steam frigate Niagara, Capt. HUDSON, anchored outside the bar early yesterday morning. and arrived off the Battery at 4:50 P. M. The Niagara, on her way up, was saluted from Fort Hamilton, by vessels in the bay, and, lastly, by 100 guns from the Battery.

TERRIFIC BOILER EXPLOSION AT PAWTUCKET--COTTON FACTORY BURNED.--At about 4 o'clock this morning the boiler connected with DEXTER Brother's cotton mill, on the corner of Pleasant and Main streets, in Pawtucket, exploded, tearing the building in which it was located into fragments, and sending the timbers and materials in all directions.

PERILS OF PRIVATE CORRESPONDENCE.--One of our Washington correspondents refers to the embarrassment in which Senator BIGLER finds himself by the publication of a letter which he wrote to Mr. STANTON, when that gentleman was Gov. WALKER'S Kansas Secretary.

The Postmaster-General has been assured that Messrs. BUTTERFIELD Co. will commence on the 15.h of September to carry the overland Pacific mails, and no doubt remains of their prompt and successful execution of the contract. By that time all the necessary means of transportation will be on the route. The stations are already fixed and supplies of water conveniently arranged.

To the President of the United States, Washington: Your Message in reply to that of the Queen was transmitted to Valentia at 7 o'clock this morning. Its transmission was delayed until then for some cause occurring at Valentia, with which I am yet unacquainted. DE SANTY, Chief Electrician at Trinity Bay.

The Cunard steamship Arabia, whose arrival off Cape Race and collision with the Europa we chronicled on Tuesday morning, is now fully due at this port. The President's reply to the message of Queen VICTORIA was not transmitted through the Atlantic Cable from Trinity Bay to Valentia until 7 o'clock yesterday morning. it having been delayed from some cause occurring at Valentia, and at present unknown to the electricians on this side.

No positive action has yet been had by the Common Council in respect to the matter of rebuilding the City Hall. But as it is not one of those things that can be trifled with and delayed, and as the exigencies of the case demand immediate action, we take it for granted that the work of restoring the Hall to its former condition will be commenced at once.

ANNUAL DIOCESAN CONVENTION OF WESTERN NEW-YORK. The annual Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church In the Diocese of Western NewYork, will be held in St. Paul's, in this city, during the present week. The order of proceedings will be as follows :-Wednesday, the 18th, the opening services will be solemnized with morning prayer, a sermon, and the holy communion. The Convention will then be organized and proceed to business.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am infinitely amused at the controversy now going on between Professor MORSE and his rivals, as to which of them all invented the Magnetic Telegraph, when it is patent to the world that it was a discovery of the eighteenth, not the nineteenth century; and that the wires were virating with electric messages between Madrid and Aranjuez, before any of the present claimants were born !

The Secretary of War has ordered a series of experiments with the new rifle-cannon of SYLVANUS SAWYER, of Fitchburg, Mass., to be made under the direction of the Ordnance Department, and the results, so far as reported, are entirely successful. It is the unanimous opinion of the Ordnance officers that this new gun stands without a rival.

BOY RUN OVER AND KILLED BY A CITY CAR.JOHN MULLIGAN, a boy three years old, was run over, at 6 1/d P.M., on Thursday, at the corner of Eighth-avenue and Fifty-sixth-street, by an Eighth.avenue car, and instantly killed. The body was taken to the residence of his parents, No. 247 West Forty.sixth street, where the Coroner held the inquest yesterday.

CONSULAR ESTABLISHMENTS.--A Select Committee of the British House of Commons was appointed during the recent session "to obtain the best information upon the present condition of the Consular service of Great Britain, to investigate any grievances or deficiencies which the system might seem to create or to foster, and to consider any remedies or improvements which competent persons might suggest."

English papers, received by the Arabia, announce the death of M. ALEXIS SOYER, the renowned professor of the culinary art. He was a Frenchinan by birth, but had resided in England for some tire. M. SOTER had become celebrated for his trip to the Crimea during the Russian War. The British army owed their enjoyments to the skill of this indefatigable gentleman, of which, without his aid, they would have continued destitute.

The following dispatches from Trinity Bay and Carbenear were received yesterday morning by CyBUS W. FIELD, Esq: CARBONEAE, Thursday, Aug. 19. The cable is working beautifully to day. I reached Cyrus station this evening. A. MACKAY. TRINITY BAY, Friday, Aug. 19.

JENKINS.--In this City, on Friday. Aug 20. After a short and severe illness. REVERE M. son of Wm. J. and Harriet A. Jenkins, aged 8 years, 4 months and 4 days. The relatives and friends of the monthly are respectfully is invite to attend his funeral. on Sunday afternoon. at 2. o'clock, from the residence of his parents, No. 162 Barrow-st. without further invitation.

ARREST OF RIVER THIEVES.-The Police of the Third Precinct, yesterday, arrested a gang of five river thieves, some of them old offenders, for stealing nine bags of wheat. JOHN MINCH alias Buffalo Jack," and JAMES CAIN, formerly one of the Municipal Police, are of the party arrested. ITALIAN OPERA.--Mr. MARETZEK'S season at the Academy of Music Commences on Monday week, the 30th instant. All the artists, with the exception of Signor GASSIER, are new. The prima donna is the lady of this popular favorite. For the past three years Mme. GASSIER has led the British public captive. She is beautiful, cultivated and gifted.

Mr. FIELD'S RESIGNATION -We understand that since Mr. FIELD has sent in his resignation as active Manager of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, a feeling of strong regret has been very generally expressed among the stockholders in this country, and many letters have been addressed to him, begging of him to withdraw his letter.

Our city was literally turned upside down, inside out, on the shortest possible notice, last evening. It was about 10 o'clock, or a little later, when the dispatch of tile Queen to President BUCHANAN Was announced. It was then that the reality of telegraphic communication with the other Continent broke upon the mind.

AMERICAN PARTY MOVEMENTS.--The American General Committee of Albany have put forth a manifesto of their intentions and views. In the first place they record a tribute to the memory of two leaders of their party recently deceased, Mr. S. S. WHALLON and Mr. JOHN N. WILDER.

By the Arabia we have advices from South America, brought to Southampton by the steamer Aton on the 4th inst. The dates are Buenos Ayres, June 28, Monte Video, June 29, Rio Janeiro, July 10. When the Avon left Rlo the Chambers were still sitting. Much satisfaction was felt at the terms of the new loan, The coffee crop was an average one, and of good quality.

THE COLLISION OF THE ARABIA AND EUROPA. A passenger on board the Arabia on her late passage from Liverpool, has furnished us with the particulars of the fearful collision which occurred between the steamer and the Europa. The accident occurred a little past 11 o'clock P. M., at which time the officer of the deck on the Arabia discovered a light off the starboard bow.

By the arrival of bark Venus, Captain ATKINSON, we have received advices from Curacoa to 4th inst. The English steamer Buzzard arrived on the 20th July, and sailed 23d for Laguayra. She was last from Jamaica. Salt at Bonaire was selling at 30 cents per barrel. Stock on hand 100,000 barrels, and weather favorable for making salt in abundance at Curacoa.

WHAT IT IS TO RUN FOR GOVERNOR.-- Mr. GERRIT SMITH finds his candidacy a troublesome business. He has already had occasion to issue a pronunciamento rebuking the Abolitionists and Prohibitionists of his own county for their lack of zeal in his support, and this in the face of the fact that he was first proposed for nomination by these very men.

DEATH OF OFFICER SANGER OF THE NINTH WARD-CORONER'S INQUEST TOBE HELD.--Officer HERATIO SANGER, of the Ninth Precinct, died on Friday at Hollister, Mass., from the effects of the assault committed upon him on the morning of the 22d of November last, by MARTIN KEARNEY, while the officer was attempting to arrest the latter during a row in an oyster saloon in Bleecker-street near Downing.

From the Philadelphia Inquirer, 20th. We learn, by Police telegraph, that between 9 and 10 o'clock last evening, a young man named JOSEPH FHEAS was fatally stabbed by CHARLES STILES. in West Philadelphia. We learn that the victim was named JOSEPH FREAS, and aged about 30 years.

KNICKFROCKER AND EXCELSIOR CLUBS--SPLEEDID GAME: DINNER, SPEECHES, return game of the home and home match between these clubs took place at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, on Friday afternoon, in presence of the largest number of spectators that have been present at any match in that locality for some time.

DEATH OF SOYER.--Among the lesser items of news brought by the Arabia was the melancholy intelligence of the death of SOYER, the famous "Gastronomic Regenerator." England could have much better spared a good many much greater men. SOYER was a good genius sent to reform the English kitchen.

FIRE.--Eight unfinished houses on Lafayette avenue, between Bedford and Nostrand-avenues, belonging to Mr. ONDERDONK, of Jamaica were destroyed by fire on Saturday about noon. The scarcity of water in the vicinity rendered the efforts of the firemen ineffectual. The loss is estimated at $5,000, partially insured.

GENERAL MUSTER OF THE MILITARY OF VERMONT--The Governor of the State of Vermont has incited the Volunteer Militia companies of the State to meat at Brandon for a general muster. They will there be reviewed by him and the Adjutant and Inspector. General of the State. Adjutant-General STORE of Massachusetts, is expected to he present.

The American Institute of Instruction convened in this city, to day, at 2 o'clock P. M, in the large hall of the Free Academy, for its twenty-ninth Anniversary. The number present was larger than ever before on the first day, and included a large number of prominent educators from all parts of the country. The hall, which will seat a thousand persons, was well filled at 3 o'clock.

NOMINATION IN TORONTO.-Our Canadian neighbors dutifully follow the English usage in nominating candidates for Parliament. In Toronto this formality took place on Friday last. Mr. JOHN HILLYARD CAMERON and Mr. GEORGE BROWN had been for some two weeks addressing the electors as the opposing candidates, but it was not till the day above mentioned the nomination took place.

EAST RIVER PIRATES.--Two East River Pirates, early yesterday morning, boarded a sail-boat off the foot of Bridge-street, and robbed a man on board, named JAMES FARLEY, of all the money and valuables he had about him. FARLEY finally reached the shore and gave information of what had occurred to the Second Precinct Police.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. SIR: I like the views of the TIMES in regard to Mexico. Mr. Weller, Sr., enjoined upon his hopeful son Samuel never to have a "mission ;" but Mr. Weller to the contrary notwithstanding, I think it the mission of the United States to rescue a whole nation from anarchy, by assuming the control of its government.

EARLE--In this City, on Saturday, Aug. 22, after a long and severe illness, FRANCIS B. EARLE. late of No. 54 East Broadway, in the 51th year of his age. The funeral will lake place from the residence of the wife's uncle, No. 130 West 37th st., this day, Tuesday, at 10 o'clock: The friends of the family and the members of the Bar are invited to attend.

Time, the metaphysicians tell us, is nothing but a succession of ideas. And a very odd succession of them it must sometimes bring, if one can only have had enough of it. Everybody feels an interest in a case of extraordinary longevity, even if it be of a slave on a plantation or of a day-laborer who has never been out of sight of the old church spire, under whose shadow he was born.

The steamship Hermann, Capt. CAVENDY, left her pier foot of North Moore-street, yesterday at 6 o'clock, P M, amidst the firing of cannon and the cheers of the multitude who had assembled to see her off Her decks were crowded with California and Fraser River bound passengers. She anchored opposite Bedloe's Island and will go to sea by this morning's tide.

A malicious report has been circulated that Lords GROSVENOR and CAVENDISH presented them selves recently, ata fancy ball at Saratoga, in an absurd and unbecoming costume. The story is wholly without foundation. We are requested to state that the gentlemen alluded to were never at Saratoga at all.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your candor, in admitting to your columns remarks from those that differ from you, has induced this communication. In general I agree with you and relish your comments, on public and social matters.

ACCIDENT AT THE DEPOT.-A man named NEBS, residing in New-York, bad one of his thighs fractured and was otherwise injured at the new depot, on Sunday night, by jumping from the cars while in motion. He left the cars, being apprehensive of a disturbance by some rowdy passengers, who were returning from Newark. The injured man was removed to the residence of Dr. HOLT.

The Chambers will continue to sit until the middle of next month to dispatch subjects which they were unable to get through during the usual session. Among these are the new Customs' tarif, the particulars of which are unknown to the public, and the Brazilan treaty of commerce.

BRITISH VIEWS OF MEXICAN ANARCHY--We prim, this morning, among our foreign extracts, several articles on Mexican affairs which will not fall to attract attention. The first article to which we allude is a letter from hom an English resident of Mexico, who bitiery complains of the outrageous treatment to which foreigners have been subjected by the Zuloaga Government.

The Secretary of the Navy is on his tour westward, to visit the different Navy-Yards. His arrival in this City, yesterday, becoming known at the Brooklyn Navy-Yard, a movement was at once set on foot by the boss workmen to visit Mr. TOUCEY at his hotel, and pay him the compliment of a sorenade.

Information from Caraccas indicates an unsatisfactory state of relations between Great Britain and France on the one side, and Venezuela on the other. The two European Powers, it will be remembered, interfered for the protection of Ex-President MONAGAS, in the recent popular revolution.

The treaty between the United States and Venezuela, negotiated in 1856, by Mr. EAMES, the American Minister, with the late Administration of this country, and which was approved by the late Venezuelian Congress without amendment, and by the Senate of the United States with a slight modification in one article, has now, it is said, been accepted by the new Venezuelian Administration with that modification.

Since my last there has been little or nothing doing in this market, especially for want of produce to operate in, and there does not remain 180 hhds, sugar to conclude the crop. The prices paid for parcels have been at an advance on last quotations, and as high as $5 has been reached for sugars of only second quality, which, however, are now the best in market.

I have been pleased with your frankness in dealing with defaulters and other delinquents in both our municipal and monied institutions,

The Democrats of Boston have taken the initiative, by making the first movement in the Congressional campaign-the only campaign that we have. They have called their District Convention in No. 5, now represented by Mr. BURLINGAME, who was chosen by only 69 majority in the Fremont contest.

A BELL-TOWER IN THE PARK--The Special Committee of the Board of Aldermen on Repairing the City Hall, have made, upon the whole, a very sensible and commendable report. We trust it may be adopted, lest, if any attempt should be made to amend it, a much worse plan might be adopted in its place.

VESSELS AT ASPINWALL AND PANAMA.--A report officially made to the President of the Panama Railroad Company gives the following: "The number of vessels that arrived at Aspinwall from January 1, 1857, to April 1, 1858, was as follows: Whole number of arrivals, 398; of which there were from the United States l91; all others, 207.

There is no sickness at this place, or in this harbor, of a dangerous type, save that which has been imported from Havana.
