BRANCH'S CONDITION--A gentleman upon whose statements we can place the utmost reliance, tells us that a day or two ago he visited BRANON, at Black well, Island, After crossing the river and reaching the Island, the gentleman was shown into a small office attached to the Penitentiary. At this place he saw one of the clerks present an order from one of the "Governors." to be permitted to see BRANCH.

THIEVES CAUGHT.--Peter McGinniss, Joseph McCusker and Joseph Clifford, all boys, were detected on Tuesday morning, in Baxter-street, by Officer Riker, of the Sixth Precinct, trying to sell a watch, which they had stolen in King-street, Monday, from a drunken man. The officer took them before Justice O-born and committed them for trial.

COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH, WEDNESDAY-At the meeting of the Board this day, the Health officer reported the arrival of the steamers Alabama and Huntsville from Savannah. He said that it had been indirectly reported to him, within the past two days that yellow fever was prevailing to a slight extent at savannah; that he had taken pains to ascertain the truth of these reports,

The secession of Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD from the management of the new suboceanic telegraph was an event of ill-omen. The whole business appears to be miserably bungled. There has been delay at every step since the cable was landed. There have been blunders and stupidity inexcusable ;

During a recent visit to New-York I obtained some political information, the importance of which I had no means of judging at the time, but which I have since my return here learned to value as throwing light on the much-rumored "Binghamton Programme" for the ensuing Fall. It shall therefore be laid before your readers. in so far as prudence will allow the same at present to be unfolded.

A destructive fire broke out at about 71/2 o'clock last evening, in the carpet manufactory in the State Prison at this place, and in less than four hours the building was a complete rain. Mr. AUGUSTUS H. SMITH was the contractor. The total loss of the stock, machinery, , will fall heavily on him.

Mr. TURPIN, the new Minister to Venezuela, received his complete instructions yesterday, and left for New-York. He will sail immediately for Laguayra. The Avis Island claim is not settled, as has been reported, and there is no approach to it.

IN EIGHTEENTH-STREET.-At 6 o'clock Tuesday morning a fire was discovered in the building corner of Eighteenth-street and Tenth-avenue, occupied by the Manhattan Gas Company. The fire broke out in a room used for storing matches, and was extinguished before it had extended beyond the place where it originated. Loss $150. No insurance.

At 2 this morning, the splendia 1.200 ton ship Orseanthe, in part loaded with the cargo of the ship Sultan, was discovered to be on firs in the main hold. The crew of the U. S. brig Daiphia. Captain MAFFITT, were promptly on board, and rendered efficient service. The hatches were battened down, and all the air-port covered with canvas.

The Cricket Match between the Western and City Cricketers was resumed at Hoboken on Tues day between 10 and 11 o'clock, four wickets having fallen on Monday evening, for duly 15 runs on the second innings of the Western Cricketers, and when the last wicket fell, only 54 more runs had been added to their score, which footed up for a total 69, 60 of these only being from a bat.

Our London namesake has for some time been seriously exercised as to the government of the New-Caledonian Gold Regions. It is amusing to see how painfully it is impressed with the necessity of immediately transporting thither the entire bristling battery of governmental forms, police and redtapeism, anticipating all kinds of chaos-comeagain, unless the same be forthwith effectuated.

A SON MURDERED BY HIS FATHER.-A most revolting murder was committed at St. Mary's Landing, in St. Genevieve County, about 9 o'clockyesterday morning, the 18th inst. JOHN SCHEEF, an old man.. a German, apparently about sixty years of age, deliberately shot and killed his own son, HENRY SCHEF.. aged about thirty-three years.

ITALIAN OPERA.-Mr. MARETZEK is pushing the preparations for his new Opera campaign with all of his accustomed energy. THRILLING SCENE AT ATLANTIC CITY.-A correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer describes a thrilling scene at Atlantic City, a few days since, owIng to the perilous position of Miss T--, of Senator SLIDELL'S family, who, with Mr. BONNEVILLE, from New Orleans, got beyond the surf. The Austin State Gazette of the 14th furnishes the annexed intelligence : We are glad to find that the United States Government has at last yielded to the repeated applications of the Executive, as well as the suggestions of the galiant head of the Department of Texas, and that the latter has already issued orders for an expedition against our frontier Indians.

The Consulate at Havana has been filled by The appointment of Mr. CHARLES J. HELMS, of Kentucky. The selection is fortunate. Mr HELMS has acted very efficiently as Consul at St. Thomas, a point of much importance to our West India trade, winning the respect of tile entire shipping interest plying thither.

We have at last some practical results of the Atlantic Cable. The first news dispatch reached us yesterday . But for the primitive habits of the Nova Scotian telegraphers, who retire to bed at 9 o'clock, we should have been able to present the telegram to the readers of the TIMES yesterday morning, so that the period of communication would have been brought within barely four hours.

ESCAPE OF A WHITE WOMAN FROM SLAVERY. We copy the following interesting case from the Maysville (Ky.) Eagle of Thursday afternoon: One of the most remarkable and intensely interesting cases ever brought before a court of justice, was tried and disposed of in our Circuit Court last week.

The following news has just been received from valentia, and, from its general Interest. I have forwarded it to the Press for publication: De SANTY. VALENTIA, Wednesday, Aug. 25. Later and highly important intelligence has been received from china.

MY DEAR JUDGE: No one of your friends has witnessed with more pleasure than I have the general approbation you seem to be receiving at the hands of the Democracy of Illinois. The impulse, to say this to you, is, under the circumstances, so strong that I hope to be excused for yielding it.

This has been a great day here. The occasion was the reception of welcome of CYRUS W. FIELD Esq., the world-renowned parent of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable scheme, which has been so successfully completed. Little time had been given for preparation, and there was more heart in the demonstration than sought to show itself in display.

The friends of the family are respectfully invited be attend the funeral, this (Friday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from the residence of his parents. No. 84 West 22d st. MISS Isabella Cass, daughter of Gen. Cass, Secretary of State, was married at Stonington on the afternoon of the 23d inst., to Mr. Van Limburg, Minister of the King of the Netherlands. The ceremony took place in Calvary (Episcopal) Church, the Rector, the Rev. Daniel C. Merton, officiating.

THE NATIONAL INTELLIGENCER.-It is with sincere pleasure we make room in another column for satisfactory information as to the condition of our venerable Washington cotemporary. The statement of a correspondent of this paper, we are happy to learn, is not correct. The Intelligencer is not in embarrassed circumstances, is not declining in pay and

The steamship Ariel, of the Vanderbilt line, C. D. LUDLOW, Esq., Commanding, arrived at this port, from Havre and Southampton, yesterday morning. We are thus placed in possession of London papers to the 11th inst, one day later than those received by the Anglo-Saxon, and of our European correspondence.

The clipper ship Great Republic, the largest and finest.modeled merchant vessel afloat, now lies at Pier No. 25 East River, where she is receiving baia, ce of cargo for California. She will sail for San Francisco in a few days. She is very deep, but her noble proportions anti towering spars are an object of attraction to multitudes who daily cross the ferries.

HUDNALL, at Enterprise, on Wednesday evening, by J. M. STEELE. From all accounts, it was a cold-blooded affair.

AN AGED MAN MURDERING HIS SON. The St. Louis Bemocral has the following: We have to record another deed of blood, the circumstances of which, even in the incomplete manner we have learned them, are of a nature to appal the thinking portion of our people.

The cams on Paraguay are large, just, and most reasonable. The selfish and unjust course taken by the rather dynastic Government of LePBZ, while it offers indignity to out country, violates its plighted faith and patcuted concussions to out people; despolling their rights, confiscating their property, and despotically driving them like criminals from the country.

Among the American artists in Rome, is a good deal of activity--the painters most of them are giving proofs of a diligent Summer--ROTHERMEL is engaged upon his grand picture of King Lear, which has been greatly admired, and is destined for your city.

ACCIDENT IN ULSTER COUNTY-THREE PERSONS INJURED--ONE FATALLY.--A serious stage accident occurred a few days since, near Ulsterville, Ulster County. JOHN HORNDRCK, the driver of the stage, in passing a wagon, attempted to put his foot on the brake to check the speed of his team. Missing the brake, and pulling tightly on the reins, he was thrown forward, and precipitated under one of the wheels, which passed over his head,

PREPARATION FOR THE EXECUTION OF THE ALMON COOPER MURDERERS--The Lewiston Falls Journal last week says the preparations for the execution at COX and WILLIAMS are bring made, as on Friday next the melancholy scene is to be enacted. The scaffold is eleven feet in height and twelve feet square, and is supported by a framework of strong timbers.

The grain crops, it was feared, would harvestlight. Numbers of parties were leaving Oregon by the overland, route for the Frasel's River mines.

STEVENS.--In this City, on Friday, Aug. 27, Mrs. RACHEL STEVENS, widow of Isaac Stevens, in the 69th year of her age Her friends are invited to attend the funeral, on Sunday, 29th inst. at 21/2 o'clock P M., from her late residence. No. 291 Henry-st., without further notice HUNT.--In this City, on Friday, Aug, 27. Mr. CHARLES Hunt, aged 24 years.

I arrived here last evening from Great Salt Lake, having made the trip thence to Placerville, in CHOR. PRNNINO'S overland mail line, in a little over fourteen days. The contractor has not yet had time to get that read stocked, but his agents are busily engaged in that duty, and, by the time this reaches you, I have little doubt that he wil be, prepared to carry the mail through in ten or twelve days.

WALLACK'S THEATRE--A new protean piece called "How to Get Out of it; or, the Irish Free Lover," was produced here last night with very decided success. The machinery of pieces of this kind is necessarily defective. Whatever the versatility of artists, there is a limit to successful impersonation, simply because it is impossible to assume a variety of costumes without fearful yawning intervals, which, somehow or other, cannot be filled up in an interesting manner.

French are a wonderful people. They are the most volatile and easily excited of any nation in Europe, they can improvise a great show in less time and in better taste than any other people; but what excites the rest of the world appears to have no effect whatever upon French sympathies; they only grow enthusiastic over their achievements.

During a considerable portion of the late session of the British Parliament, a Select Committee of the House of Commons was engaged in hearing evidence on the progress and prospects and the best means to be adopted for the promotion of European colonization in India,-especially in the hilly districts and healthier regions of that country,-as also for the extension of British commerce with Central Asia.

THE HON. JOSHUA R. GIDDINGS.--The fact is communicated by telegraph that JOHN HUTCHINGS has been nominated for Congress by the Republicans of GIDDINGS' district. This would seem to imply that Mr. G. is to retire from public life. Whether his failure to be renominated is according to his wish, is not stated. Probably it is ; for his influence in his district is understood to be unbounded.

The following dispatch has been received from Mr. SAWARD, Secretary of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, for the American Press: LONDON, Friday, Aug. 27. The Emperor of France returned to Paris on Saturday.

SPECIAL MEETING OF THE BOARD OF ALDERMEN--THE INVITATION TO JOIN IN THE NEW YORK CABLE CELEBRATION ACCEPTED.--A special meeting of the Brooklyn Common Council was held last evening, President KALEFLEISCH in the Chair.

To the Editions of the Union: In inclose a copy of a letter upon the new Hall of Representatives, just received from the Hon. JAS. L. ORR, Speaker of the House, Entertaining no deubt of success from the moment I undertook its construction, I have yet not been indiffcrent to the expression of public opinion in regard to it.

Chamber of Commerce--Testimonial to the Men who Latd the Cable. The Committee of Merchants and citizens appointed by the Chamber of Commerce to carry into effect the resolutions for bestowing testimonials upon the officers of the Niagara, met at 12 o'clock yesterday. There was a respectable attendance, Mr. PERIT presiding.

JORNALISM.--The press of New-York is one of its institutions. It is recognized as an element of great power in the social economy of that metropolis. It has done as much, if not more, than any other means to build that City up, and make it the central seat of commercial and financial influence on this continent. The New-Yorkers understand very well why their journalism is so potential.

SUPREME COURT--CHAMBERS--Aug. 27. THE WAY OF LIFE AGAIN. This morning counsel for George P. Edgar moved to vacate the second order of arrest against him. The hearing was postponed to Monday next. In the matter of the discharge from arrest on the first complaint, counsel for Hall have notice that he would appeal to the General Terse.

A WHALE 'IN THE', CHESAPEKE--Messrs. EDITORS; Though familiar with the Chesapeake and its rivers for forty years, I have never seen or heard of a whale in its waters. The following extract from a letter received yesterday from my sisters, residing in Gloucester County, Va.;, near the bay shore, may be of interest to your readers:

I am authorized to inform the applicants for the Consulship to London-more numerous than a small swarm of locusts-that they may withdraw their papers. The Hon. ROBERT B. CAMPBELL is not to be rotated. How could he be ? Primarily, he belongs to South Carolina, who does not acknowledge rotation in office as a Democratic principle, or any sort of a principle.

The United States Mail steamship Moses Taylor, JOHN McGOWAN, Esq., Commanding, from Aspinwall on the 19th inst., vid Key West, with mails, passengers and treasure brought down by the Pacitic Mail steamship Sonora, from San Francisco on the 5th inst., arrived at this post yesterday afternoon. The Moses Taylor found U. S. brig Dolphin, Lieuterant Commanding MAFFITT, at Key West on 231 inst. She was to sail next morning for the north.

The Navy Department has detached Lieutenant SPOTTS from the Michigan, now on the Southern Lakes, and ordered him to the Cyane. Lieut. TERRITT has been detached from the Receiving ship Pennsylvania, and also ordered to the Cyane. Lieutenant STILL WELL has been detached from the Receiving ship Princeton and also ordered to the Cyane.

Another evidence of the practical working value of the Atlantic Telegraph is furnished in our telegraphic column. A dispatch, communicating the terms of the Treaty consummated by the French and English Plenipotentiaries at Tiensin, reached us yesterday at noon, derived from the London papers of yesterday morning. It is also stated that the information it contains was only received at St. Petersburg on the 21st inst.

The action of the American State Council, in deciding to call a Nominating Convention at Syracuse on the day fixed by the Republicans, leaves little room to doubt a speedy and practical union of the two organizations. It now rests with the Republicans to receive or reject the manifest overtures which the Americans have made for a cooperation of those who entertain opinions adverse to the Democratic Administration.

THE SECOND TELEGRAPHIC DISPATCH FROM LONDON.--The Atlantic Telegraph has already become an old story. In our evening edition of yesterday we published the morning's news from London. The dispatch was headed "London, 27th August," and it was on the 27th it was published.

The sloop-of-war St. Louis went into the dry dock at the Navy-Yard to be coppered, yesterday. The St. Louis is now thirty years of age, having been built in Washington in 1828. She is a second-class sloop-of-war, and has been on the stocks getting re. paired for some months. The Niagara's crew was paid off on Friday.

The cherbourg Teles are over, and even in this dull season they would already have been well nigh forgotten, had not two well-known members of the House of Commons, who were present thereat, volunteered to give the world their impressions on the subject.

That mysterious and awful section of the year known as " the season," may be said to commence with the opening of the shooting season and the Academy of Music. Its precise importance in our social economy has yet to be determined, but that it is fraught with dire interests to blushing girls, and solemn swells, and opera managers and manufacturers of icecream, and many luxurious institutions of a like kind, is beyond a doubt.

Professor MOTT has lately published a catalague of his Museum. The collection is composed chiefly of parts removed from the living body during his numerous operations, and comprises more than a thousand specimens. It may be found at the Fourteenth-street Medical College and is free to the public.

NORTH--MULPORD.--In this City, on Wednesday, Aug. 25, at the residence of the bridge's mother, No. 83 Sullivan st., by the Rev. Saml. Benedict, JOHN D. NORTH, of Hastings, Minnesota, to Miss ELIZABETH V. MULFORD, of New-York City. FISKE--GREENWOOD.--In this city, on Tuesday, Aug. 24, at Calvary Church, by the Rev. Dr. Hawks, CORNBLIUS FISKE and MARY AMANDA GREENWOOD, both of New-York City.

BOSTWICK.--In this City, on Sunday afternoon, Aug. 29. CHARLES C. infant son of Charles Coffia and Mary F. Bostwick, aged 2 months. The funeral will take place from the residence of his grandfather, Courter Goodwin, Esq. No. 48 Amity-st., this day, (Monday,) at 4 o'clock P. M.

At a meeting of the Canal Board, held on the 25th, the following resolutions in reference to the use of steam on the Canals, were offered by Canal Commissioner RUGGLES and adopted: Resolved, That boats propelled by steam or other mechanical power on the canals of this State, shall be exempt from toll on their machinery.

On Monday next there will be held a general election throughout the Territory for members of the Legislature and for County officers. The " Gentiles" are making preparations to vote on an Independent ticket, and to elect, if possible, good and true men to all the offices, which are now occupied by mere tools of the Mormon priesthood.

THE TORONTO ELECTION -Mr. GEORGE BROWN has been reelected to Parliament from Toronto, by one hundred and fifty majority over JOHN HILLYARD CAMERON, Esq. The contest was severe, and Mr. BROWN'S opponents entertained strong hopes of defeating him. As it was, his majority was brought down to a tolerably low figure.

THE INTERNATIONAL TELEGRAPHIC CELEBRATION.-The Common Council determined not to celebrate the Telegraph success on the 1st September, but accepted tile invitation of the authorities of NewYork to unite in tile ovation in that City. Many citizens how ever have determined to make a demonstation on their own account.

ST. GEORGE VS. NEW-WINDSOR.-The first of a Home and Home Match took place, yesterday, at Hoboken, between the second eleven of St. George and an eleven of the New-Windsor Club. It terminated in favor of New-Windsor, with the loss of only one wicket in their second innings.

DEFEAT OF GIDDINGS.-We referred on Saturday to the fact, as announced by telegraph, that the Republican Cnvention in Mr. G??nDINGS' district had selected another candidate, and assumed the failure to renominate Mr. G. as probably in accordance with his own desire. But Cleveland papers, since received,

Honorable Ralph Metcalf, Ex Governor of New-Hampshire, died at his residence in Claremont, on the 26th list, aged sixty. Governor Metcalf was a native of Charlestown, N. H. He entered Dartmouth College in 1819, and graduated in the class of 1823. In 1825 he began the practice of law at Newport, and five years after was elected Secretary of State, an office which he held for several years.

Information was yesterday sent to the Police Head-quarters that a person sick of yellow fever ha?? been moved from on board the ship Rattler, lying a Pier No. 8 North River. This information was tele graphed to Mayor TIEMANN, at Manhattanville, who immediately came to the City to inquire into the case, and to take such steps as would protect the health of the City.

By the Cahawha, at New-Orleans, we have advices from Havana to the 18th inst. The news of the successful laying of the Atlantic cable was received with much enthusiasm in Havana, and in all probability and attempt will soon he made to communicate with the United States in the same manner.

" The principal feature in the London Foreign Market is the rise in Mexican Stock. for several days past there has been increased firmness, owing to steady purchasers. The impression seems to be that the present state of things in the Republic cannot long continue. and the remote probability of an annexation to the United States is sufficient to improve the Stock. when it can be had a trille above 20 per cent.

ACADEMY OF MYSIC.-Mr. MARETZEK's season of Italian Opera commences here to-night, when BELLINI'S ever-acceptable opera of "Somnambula" will be performed with the following cast: Anima, Signora PEPITA GABSIER, (her first appearance in America;) Elvino, Mr. PERRING, (her first appearance in Italian Opera;) Count, Signor GASSIER.

The departure of the steamer Moses Taylor enables me to send you an important item of news, which is no less an event than the capture of a slaver by the United States brig Dolphin. The Dolphin, Lieutenant JOHN N. MAFFIT, Commanding, which has been cruising on the northern coast of Cuba, called at Sagua la Grande on the 20th and left again on the 21st.

The Committee met again on Saturday. A number of Societies applied for position in the line of procession. Referred to the Grand Marshal. It was resolved and adopted that the Secretary write to Collector SCHELL to close the public stores on Wednesday next. The programme of the Firemen's Torchlight Procession was received, accepted and ordered on file.
IMPORTANT ACTION OF THE CANAL BOARD.Improvements and changes of much importance have been ordered by the Canal Board, a report of which we publish in another part of this morning's TIMES.

DEMOCRATIC TESTIMONY IN FAVOR OF A REGISTRY.-There is a class, not famous for good morals, as regard the public generally, who are nevertheless proverbially strenuous for the observance of fairness among themselves. They are thieves in respect to outsiders, but when it comes to dealings with each other, quite another rule is recommended.

From the Springfield Republican, 28th. The Springfield regatta of Aug. 27 grew out of a desire to meet the popular interest, excited by the arrangements for the series of regettas in July, but disappointed by the sad death of young DUNHAM, a leading member of the Yale College Club, that was expected to occupy the prominent position in the race of the college boats.

The United States mail steamship North Star, from Havre and Southampton 18th inst., passed Cape Race at 3 P. M. yesterday, 27th inst. The Hamburg steamer Austria, from New-York, arrived at Southampton on the 15th inst.

The expediency of a federal union of the five British Provinces in the Northeast, is again under discussion, and the late ministerial crisis in Canada is the text from which British journals are arguing in favor of the project. This remedy for removing the causes

The Vanderbilt steamer North Star from Havre and Southampton on the 18th inst., arrived off Cape Race on Friday afternoon, and we publish this morning a brief summary of her new received by telegraph. The advices from India are interesting, and indicate the continued success of the British arms.

THE COMPLIMENTARY DINNER TO CAPTAIN HUDSON.--Captain HUDSON and the officers of the Niagara, having accepted the invitation of the Jersey City Common Council to a public dinner on Friday next, active preparations are in progress for the event.

The following proclamation has been issued by the Board of Commissioners appointed by Congress, showing the returns, in full up to the time they were counted, on the 18th inst, at Lecompton: PROCLAMATION.

One of our cruisers off Cuba has captured and brought into port an American slaver, with a cargo of three hundred and eighteen negroes. A correspondent, whose letter we give elsewhere, furnishes a description of' the chase and capture, which added to the statement furnished on Saturday, completes the history of the transaction.

YELLOW FEVER ON STATEN ISLAND.-Dr. EDWARD C. MUNDY, the Health Commissioner of the town of Stapleton, in a report which we print this morning, states that yellow fever exists as an epidemic in Tompkinsville, where seventeen cases have occurred, six of which proved fatal.

M. de Lomonosoff, late Russian Minister at the Hague, has recently died. When a young man, M. ??e Lomorosoff was Secretry of the Russian Legation at Washington. General Tarrant, a pioneer of Texas, died recently. He was one of the members of the Annexa.

To the Editor of the Manchester Guardian : SIR: I am sorry to see that that mischievous paper, the New-York Herald, is again quoted in England as an exponent of prevalent feelings and opinion in the United States. Its present object is to stir up whatever anti English feelings exist among its readers, on the subject of the new gold colony of " British Columbia."

The steamship Empire City, Captain Jos. GRIFFIN, having left New-Orleans Aug. 20, arrived at Key West on the evening of the 23?? and left the same night for Havana, arriving off the Moro Castle at an early hour next morning, and communicating with the harbor by a steam-tug, after which left the same afternoon for Key West.

TERRIBLE TORNADO IN ULSTER COUNTYTWO LADIES KILLED.--A destructive tornado visited a few towns in Ulster County, last Wednesday, tearing up and destroying everything in its course, blow ing down trees, Hences and even dwellings, and in one of these dwellings were a number of persons, who were crushed by the falling building, killing three and seriously wounding three others.

The Postmaster at Pulaski, Ky., whose name is Carter, has been detected in playing a sharp game on the Post Office. The plan of operations was to address letters to tile Department requiring a supply of stamps, purporting to come from other offices than his own, and forging the names of the respective Postmasters to them, He only selected such office

The news from India by the last mail is more favorable than three months ago any one would have looked for. The Gwalior army has at last been finally disposed of, and the troops employed against it have gone into quarters for the remainder of the hot season.

ARREST OF A COACHMAN FOR STEALING HARNESS -- Officer Berry, of the Fourteenth Precinct, yesterday arrested a man named Edward Jackson, charged with stealing two sets of double harness, two sets of single harness, some horse blankets, netting, and other apparelings, valued at $175, from the stable of Mr. Rufus Story, at Bergen Point. Mr. Story is a merchant, and does business at No. 7 Front-street in this City.

ACADEMY OF Music.-The indomitable MAX MARTZEK resumed his chair at this house last evening, and attracted, as a matter of course, an immense gathering. A few of the subscribers who were not in town exhibited a vacant stare in their seats, but otherwise the capacity of the house was fairly represented with eager and intelligent faces. Every con. venient part was crowded.

ALTERNATIVE MANDAMUS GRANTED.--Some months, ago, Col. C. J. JACK, the indefatigable independent People's Candidate for Congress, appeared as counsel in several liquor cases arising under section of the Police Law, and beat the State. He applied to the State for his fees, as provided by Statute where the State is beaten, when the Comp?? troller refused to certify his account.

WHITE.-In this City, on Sunday morning, Aug. 29, WILLIAM A., infant son of Samuel P. and Caroline D. White, aged 10 months and 19 days. The funeral will take place from the residence of his parents, No. 132 West 18th-st., this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock. HITCHCOCK -In this City. on Monday morning. Aug. 30, ELECTA, widow of the late John Hitchcock, in the 73d Sear of her age.

A correspondent, writing from Lawrence, whose letter was published in yesterday's TIMES, contradicts the assumption of the Washington Union, that, by rejecting the English bill, Kansas virtually voted to remain a Territory, and states that an energetic application will be made at the approaching session of Congress for her admission into the Union.

John S. Dickey, Inspector of Hulls, and Andrew Watson, Inspector of boilers for the port of Pittsburgh, have been dismissed from office by the Secretary of the Treasury, for non-performance of their duty in the examination of one of the engineers of the Ill-fated steamer Fanny Fern.

TESTIMONIAL TO CAPTAIN ANDERSON, OF THE ARABIA. - All elegant silver pitcher and salver, manufactured by Messrs. BALL, BLACK Co., was yesterday presented to Captain JAMES P. ANDERSON, of the Arabia, by the cabin passengers who were on board of the vessel when the collision with the Europa occurred.

In accordance with the orders of the Central Committee, the Republican Assembly Conventions met last evening for the purpose of electing two delegates and two alternates to their State Convention, which meets at Syracuse on the 8th of the next month. Much interest was manifested in the proceedings. All, so far as learned, passed off quietly. We annex the result from the different Districts so far as ascertained.

The first of these great celebrations occurred thirty-three years ago, on the completion of the Erie Canal, when the waters of the great lakes were united with the waves of the Atlantic.

All political and scientific England wore brought to look upon a work such as they had not, and this of itself was a conquest for Frenchmen.

By a private letter lately received by a gentleman of this city. from GERARD RALSTON, Esq., London, the Minister Plenipotentiary of Liberia, we learn that Portugal is ready to acknowledge the Republic, and to make a treaty of amity and commerce with her. Mr. RALSTON was at once about to enter upon the formation of a treaty with Count LEVRADIO, the Portuguese ambassador.

JOHN MACGREGOR, Esq., the Secretary of the "Protestant Alliance," Secretary of the " Open Air Mission." and a devoted worker in the "Ragged School," and other religious and philanthropic enter prises of Great Britain, having arrived in this country, some friends welcomed him at the parlors of the Young Men's Christian Association, No, 32 Waverley Place, last evening. They had an exceedingly pleasant time.

BOY DESERTED.--A boy, named JAMES HAMMOND, nine years old, was found wandering about the Ninth Precinct, yesterday, by the Police. He said that his father had deserted him and he had no home. He was taken to the Truant Institution.

To-day the City surrenders everything to the Ocean Telegraph Celebration. Business halts, pleasure hairs, unless in the display. Everything waits till to-morrow. Full pariiculars of what the day is expected to bring forth may be found in another part of the TIMES this morning.

A man, giving his name as Chamberlain, has been passing a number of counterfeit bank bills on the Syracuse City Bank, new and well-executed, in Dutchess County. He first visited Rhinebeck,where he passed a large number, receiving good money in return. He then went to Poughkeepsie, where he also passed a large quantity of the spurious bills.

Yesterday New-York celebrated-and in a manner that will long be remembered-the wondrous event of a wondrous age. We were all prepared for an enthusiastic jubilee in honor of the Ocean Telegraph. We anticipated an unrivaled display; but the enthusiasm far surpassed our expectations, and the display was such as even New-York has never witnessed within its broad limits.

A letter from Ex-President Pierce, dated at Villeneuve, in Switzerland, says: "We may remain here during the remainder of August, and then perhaps proceed to Intertaken, by the way of Berne. If the weather is favorable we may cross the Simplon or Spingen, and pass into Italy in September."

The General has been exceedingly cautious in his communications, yet some strange things have leaked cut. It is evident the General has not the confidence of his Government.

THE HON. MR. HASKIN AND THE TARRYTOWN MEETING.--Mr. JOHN B. HASKIN, representative from the ninth Congressional District, proposes to define his position at Tarrytown, this afternoon. He has done what always requires more than an average amount of courage, by repudiating the programme of the party which elected him.

New-York celebrated yesterday, with unwonted enthusiasm, the success of the great Ocean Telegraph. All the City was astir, and throughout the day, from the Battery to the Crystal Palace, the route was densely, impenetrably thronged with eager spectators.

Early this morning the people of the country surrounding this locality began to flock into Lewiston Falls and Auburn to witness the terrible spectacle of the judicial homicide of tow criminals. From the Lewiston side the people thronged in crowds across the toll bridge to Auburn, and on the court house side of the town, the gathering was as rapid towards the fatal spot.

Another week's fine weather (though with occasional thunder-showers) has enabled farmers to secure most of their Wheat in excellent condition. The diversity, however, of the yield and quality is as remarkable as the season. It appears the weight of while Wheat, where it was blighted, does not exceed 47 lbs. bushel, and is only fit for chicken-food; while the strong lands, in favored localities, produce samples weighing 65 lbs. bushel.

Mrs. H. Marion Stephens, the well-know authoress. died in East Hampden, Ma, on Friday last of consumption. She was the daughter of the Rev John Atwell, and was born at Sidney, Me., July 2. 1823. In early life, she acted on the stage as "Miss Rosaile Somers." In 1848, she married Richard Stephens, comedian, and soon after commenced her literary career, under the signature of "Marion Ward."

To the Editor of the New-York Times Some years past the writer of this suggested to a then Member of Congress the propriety of equalizing the value of coin used in this country and Europe. The response was that it could not be done. Since then a commission has been appointed, and I understand are now in Europe for the purpose named.

A singular phenomenon of the Sulphur water found about Carlisle. Pa., was discovered last week by Professor Win. Corpenieus Wilson, of Dickinson College. The Professor having procured some sulphur water very highly impregnaled, subjected it to an immense pressure in the Brass Magdenbury hemispheres until to-thirds of the water contained had exuded from between the pores of the metal and where the cups are joined together.

The new steamship Pacfic, of the Galway and New York line, arrived at this port at 8 o'clock this morning. The Pacific left Galway at 1 A.M., Aug. 25. The United States Mail steamship Cahawha, J. D. BULLOCK, Commander, from New-Orleans via Havana. arrived early this afternoon at Quarantine. She arrived at Havana on the evening of the 29th, but did not sail until the afternoon of the 30th. The brig Nancy still furnishes a topic for conversation--and it is not fairly known what will be done with her--the general impression is that she will be liberated.

BURDGE.--In this City, on Thursday , Sept. 2, Mr. RICHARD BURDGE, aged 71 years, 11 months and 10 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from No. 207 Varick St., on Sunday, the 8th inst., at 1 o'clock. PAXSON--In this City, on Friday, Sept. 3, WILLIAM PAXSON late of Philadelphia, in the 80th year of his age.

I recently made a trip to the City of Mexico, stopping a day in Orizaba, and another in Puebla. In wandering around these cities I noticed the shops and stores particularly, and I found them all supplied with foreign goods, One would never imagine, from their appearance, that communication with the coast cities has been out off for nearly six months.

Condition of our Relations with Central America-Condition of the Treasury. WASHINGTON, Friday, Sept. 3. Senor YRISSARI, at the request of President MARTINEZ, has, It is understood, withdrawn his resignation as Minister from Nicaragua.

The Rev. ELEAZER WILLIAMS, for whom the claim was some years since set up that he was the veritable lost Dauphin of France, died on the 28th ult., at Hogansburg, a part of the St. Regis Reservation in this State, Mr. WILLIAMS died after a protracted illness, the dropsy intervening.

The entire destruction of the Quarantine buildings, at Tompkinsville, Staten Island, was announced in the TIMES yesterday, the conflagration swept away not only the Hospitals but all the residences of the physicians and of the laborers employed at Quarantine. It was rumored, yesterday, that the mob intended to set fire to the private dwelling in the infected district.

Mr. CAREY JONES returns to the Blair quarrel once more, in the St. Louis Republican: C STREET, WASHINGTON, Aug. 24, 1858. A friend has sent to me a slip of the New-York Evening Post, contaning "A Card from F. P. BLAIR, Jr.," dated St. Louis, Aug. 13. To make reply to the piece would be only to bandy words, and I have something more important to do.

JAMES H. WELSH and AZARIAH D. BARBOUR were last night elected Delegates to the Republican State Convention from the First Assembly District, composed of the First, Second, Third, and a portion of the Fourth and Sixth Wards.

The people of Washington are not inclined to celebrate the success of the Atlantic Telegraph by bonfires, illuminations and the firing of guapowder. Indeed, they do not rejoice over the event at all, so far as I can discover. Possibly they agree with the one idead H. C. CAREY, in thinking that the submarine cable will strengthen the Free-traders and strike deadly blow at the Protectionists.

An accident of a most disastrous and fatal character occurred on Wednesday evening, shortly before 7 o'clock, at Black's Run, two miles above Halton station, on the Allegneny Valley Railroad, and fourteen miles above this City. The passenger train, in charge of conductor G. M. ALEXANDER. was proceed.

THE FERRIES TUESDAY NIGHT.-We referretion Thursday to the crowded state of the ferries during the day, Tuesday. At the office of the Union Ferry Company they say that seventy thousand people crossed during the day and night. The rush at the Fulton Ferry was much greater after I o'clock yesterday morning than at any time previous.

There has been a good deal of excitement lately in Boston, and further Down East, arising from disputed ease of champagne. That volatile liquid seems to have gone to the heads of the disputants, and produced effects rather lamentable than unusual with those that meddle with it.

DEATH FROM ALLEGED VIOLENCE.--Coroner CONNERY Thursday held an inquest at No. 70 Willett street, upon the body of JOHN CONNER, an Irish laborer, 45 years of age. The deceased has a larger family and for a long time has been in the habit of drinking to excess, and when intoxicated was quarrelsome and difficult to manage.

At a few minutes to 6, yesterday morning, as the porter in the employ of C. J. HINE, tin-ware manufacturer, on the upper floors of No. 13 Bowery, opened the store, he discovered that the rear room on the second floor was densely filled with smoke. He immediately notified Mr. HORATIO REED, who keeps the eating and lodging house adjoining.

The steamship Fulton, from Havre via Southampton, at 3:10 P. M. of the 25th ult., was intercepted off Cape Race on Friday at 3:50 P. M. by the news. yacht of the New-York Associated Press; but owing to unfavorable weather, our dispatches did not reach here till a late hour this evening.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An important error was made by year printer in may article of the 16th inst., in the substitution of "a hundred" for a thousand millions of dollars as the cost of the Railroads in the United States, and of "seven millions" for seventy millions, as the annual interest on that cost.

The American and Pacific Ship Canal Company inaugura ed their first movement towards opening the route by an excursion down the Bay on Saturday last, on board of the steamboat Cass-Yeissari, formerly the American Eagle. About one hundred persons were on board, among whom were Senior YEISSARI, the Central American Minister.

Mr. SOULE is again here, and will have an interview with the President to-morrow. YRISSARI should look to his laurels, or he may find his treaty obsolete. Kind relations, I understand, have been restored between HENNINGSEN and WALKES, and the Transit arrangements are in a fair way of being concluded.

Several of the leading Quarantine incendiaries were arrested at Tompkinsville early on Saturday morning, before they had got out of their beds, upon a warrant issued by Justice WELSH. Sergeant WATERBURT and cetectives WILDEY and STEPHANSON, with a rife corps. went out and arrested CHARLES S DE FOREST, Justice of the Peace.

The election for Territorial and County officers, which was held throughout the Territory on Monday last, passed off, as far as we are able to learn, very quietly and peaceably. In this City, although there was, for the first time since its foundation, votes cast in opposition to the nominees of the Church. yet it created no disturbance, and but little excitement.

The first general master of the Uniform Militia of Vermont, under the recent re-organization of the system, and one of the most gratifying and successful military exhibitions ever witnessed in the State, was held at Brandon on Wednesday and Thursday, Sept. 1 and 2. Nine companies responded by their presence to the invitation of Gov. Fletcher.

The President's telegram to the Queen, it will be remembered, contained diplomatic as well as congratulatory matter. It suggested that steps should be forthwith taken to establish the inviolability of the Ocean Telegraph in periods of war.

The telegraph from St. Johns, N. F., brings intelligence from Europe, received by the steamer Fulton, off Cape Race. The Fulton sailed from Southampton on the 25th ult., and was boarded by the news-yacht on Friday afternoon. Commercial matters wore a more favorable face. The Agamemnn very nearly escaped destruction by fire.

A SUNDAY PRIZE FIGHT.--A prize fight occurred yesterday afternoon, in a field back of Hudson City, some two or three miles from the Hoboken Ferry, between a couple of bruisers named TOMHURBARD, a New-York boatman, and SITTERLY alias "Schenectady Boy," a gentleman residing in Williamsburg that "does nothing" for a living.

EX. MAYOR MILLER, OF NEWARK, N. J., FOUND DROWNED IN THE EAST RIVER.--The body of Mr. JAS. MILLER, formerly Mayor of Newark, N. J., and Adjutant-General of the State, was discovered on Saturday evening in the dock at the foot of Beekmanstreet. Some letters and papers found on his person led to his identification.

The workmen are now engaged in laying ways under her preparatory to a launch, which will take place the last of this month. The Democratic State Convention met at Worcester yesterday, the 2d, and there was a very lively time in that old Anti-Slavery town. The Beach-and-Butler controversy had suddenly lighted up the Democratic stubble, which burned away most brilliantly. much to the astonishment of the public, who had believed Democracy dead, whereas it was only roasting.

STEUBEN FESTIVAL OF BALTIMORE.--This great festival came off Thursday, and was an imposing spectacle. The procession was estimated to contain from 7,000 to 8,000 persons, comprising the several German Associations of that city and various military companies, who marched with banners, music, , to the festival grounds, where a tent had been created, 160 feet long and 80 feet wide, and dinner was served to 2,000 persons.

To the Editor of the Courrier des Etats Unis: Finding myself at last delivered from the judicial prosecutions to which I have been so unjustly subjected, I come to ask of you a rectification of the facts which have been communicated to you, and which have been so calumniously applied to my person.

We copy from the Charleston Mercury of, Wednesday last, the opinion of the Attorney-General of South Carolina on the case of the Echo's cargo of Africans. A law of that State, passed in 1835, forbids any free negro or person of color to be brought into the limits.

HOBOKEN WATER WORKS--The laying of pipe for these works will be completed in about two weeks. It was intended to have a public celebration on the occasion of the introduction of water into the city, but there seems to be a conflict between the Water commissioners and the Councilmen of Hoboken, which may result in there being no celebration at all.

Alderman JOHN CLANCY, President, in the Chair. Sundry petitions were referred. A series of resolutions in relation to public urinals on the piers, directing the Street Commissioner to advertise for designs, , offered and laid over under the rule.

In the TIMES of this morning will be found a communication from Mr. GEOEGE D. PHELPS, of this City, addressed to the stockholders of a railroad of which that gentleman was recently the president, but not confined in its interest to any one work. On the contrary, if we mistake not, it embraces views and suggestions which should be widely diffused through the community.

LA COSTE.-In this City on Sunday. Sept, 5, the Rev. MICHAEL LA COSTE, aged 71 years The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral. from the Congregational Church in 50th-st., between Broadway and 8th av., this (Tuesday) afternoon. at 1 o'clock. His remains will be taken to greenwood Cemetery for interment.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--ROSSINI'S "Barbiere"--for which we are always thankful--was played here last night, with a cast excellent in every respect, and an ensemble worthy of the management. Mme. GASSIER was the Rosina of the occasion. In the role we have had all the florid singers who have eve visited this City.

THE BASE BALL MATCH ON FASHION RACE COURSE.--On Friday the great event which is to decide who shall be the victors in the game of Base Ball, between the selected nines from the New York and Brooklyn Clubs, takes place on the Fasion Race Course Long Island.

ARREST OF SUSPECTED BURGLARS,-JOSEPH MARSH, of No. 163 Bay-street, and WM. JONES, residing with MARSH, were arrested by Chief of Police HAINES last week, on suspicion of having burglariously entered the premises of JAMES GILKINSON. No, 23 Montgomery-street, on the night of the 31st of August.

ARRIVAL OF THE DOLPHIN. -- The United States brig Dolphin, Commander J. A. MAFFITS, from Key West, arrived at Quarantine yes terday morning. She sailed in the afternoon for Boston. She put into this port to forward Capt. Tows SEND, of the slaver Putnam,captured by the Dolphin, to Charleston.

The Washington Union of Wednesday devotes two columns to the Douglas split in Illinois. The organ is against all concession or compromise while DOUGLAS refuses to confess his error of last Winter-his sin against a cardinal measure of the Administration.

DANGEROUS ASSAULT WITH FIRE ARMS.-Last evening, a stranger in this City, named STEVENSON, went to the Prescott House, corner of Broadway and Spring street, and after having procured his supper, he was about leaving without paying for. it, when he was accosted by the bookkeeper, Mr. CURISTIAN SAPP, who demanded pay for the meal.

FLOUR in moderate demand and good supply; market a shade easier; sales 1,400 bbls. at $5 25@ $5 50 for good to choice brands extra Indiana, Ohio, Michigan and Canadian ; $5 42@$5 75 for double extras. WHEAT in good demand and market hardly so firm; sales 45.000 bushels, at 70c for Chicago Spring; $1 23@$1 30 far white Michigan and choice white Canadian ; $1 05 for prime Milwaukee Club;

THE TEHUANTEPEC ROUTE.--In another column we give place to a letter of Dr. SONNTAG, stating the present condition of this line. According to this official report, it appears that the undertaking of the Louisiana Company, to carry the California mail that way, by the 1st of October, is a physical impossibility, the route having no road across it, and there being no means or facilities of transportation.

To-morrow two State Conventions meet in Syracuse to make nominations for the November elections--the Republican and the American. The First question to be decided by each is--not whom shall they nominate, but whether they shall nominate the same men. How this preliminary problem will be solved, it were useless to conjecture.

The scramble has already fairly begun for the credit of the Submarine Telegraph, which almost always follows a successful invention, or a successful application of one. Modest discoverers, who had shrunk from public notice while the issue of the experiment was doubtful, emerge from their lurking-places as soon as its prosperity is beyond a peradventure, and is making somebody famous.

I had yesterday the pleasure and privilege of dining in company with Captain DE RIVEIRE and his friend Mons. BOSQUET. (son of the Frech General of Crimean renown,) at the table of distinguished lady up town; and, from the knowledge the Captain posesses of many British officers who seved in the Crimea, and with whom I am personally acquainted.

Some new elements of excitement were yesterday developed at Quarantine The reception of a case of yellow-fever, on Sunday, into the hospital from the town of Ca?tleton, created considerable excitement both outside of the wall, among the villagers, and also inside among the policemen and employes.

The Board of Councillmen met last evening. Councilman CORNELL in the Chair. A number of petitions were presented of the usual character. A variety of resolutions were adopted having refer. ence to flagging sidewalks and paving streets in vari. ous localities.

Attorney-General BLACK reached Washington this morning, and had an interview with Secretary TOUOBY on the subject of returning the captured Africans. He had previously given no official opinion on the subject. The following officers have been ordered to the Niagara:

FATAL RAILROAD CASUALTY.-An inquest was held yesterday at the City Hospital upon the body of WM. ROONEY, an Irish laborer, who was run over a few lays ago at Yonkers by a Hudson River Railroad train. The evidence showed the occurrence to be purely accidental, and a verdict to that effect was rendered.

THE LAWRENCE-STREET TRAGEDY.-Mr. THEODOBE AUSTIN, who was found fatally injured on the area-way at No. 35 Lawrence street, Sunday morn ing, was still alive last evening, and talked rationally of all that transpired on Saturday, so far as he can remember. He was left on the stoop of the house where found at his own request.

THE CoURTS.-The September term of the Cour of General Sessions was opened yesterday morning, by Judge RUSSELL. There was, as is very usual on the first day of term, no quorum of Grand Jurors in attendance, and those present were discharged until this morning. Of the Petit Jurors called, sixty were absent, and they were fined $25 each. The Court then adjourned until to-day.

Before Judge Betts. One parcel marked "Kolpecke," containing 17 gold watches, 67 silver watches and 84 gold chains, vs. The United Status.--On filing bond and surety approved by the District Judge in pursuance of the Act of Congress. and on a motion of Mr. J. A. Godfrey, proctor for claimant, it was ordered that the property in custody be delivered by the Marshal to the claimant's proctor.

THE OFFICERS OF OUR NAVY ON THIS STATION AND THE MUNICIPAL DINNER TO THE OFFICERS OF H. B. M. SHIP GORDON.-Considerable surprise has been manifested that there should have been no response on the part of our Navy to the toast in which it was mentioned at the late Cable dinner at the Metropolitan Hotel.

A public meeting was held last night in the Cooper Institute, Eighth street, at which about six hundred persons (many of them recognized as preminent members of the Republican and American Parties)- were in attendance.

WHERE IS GOVERNOR KING?--Great anxiety is felt by the public to know what has become of Governor KING. A proclamation of some kind has been expected from him ever since the State Island rioters consummated their villainous designs in the destruction of the Quarantine Hospitals.

MR. YANCEY--THE SOUTHERN LEAGUE--THE RICHMOND SOUTH.--It was announced, some days ago, by telegraph, that the Hon. Mr. YANCEY, of Alabama, had written an angry letter to Mr. PRYOR, editor of the Richmond South, in respect to the so called Southern League. Mr. Y. is a Slave-trade advocate and a disunionist.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the 28th of August, with three days' later news, is now fully due at Halifax. There were no signs of her at 9 o'clock last night. The Pacific, of the Galway line, arrived off Halifax harbor on Saturday night, when she was detained by the fog, and did not reach her dock until Sunday. She left for New York at 6 o'clock last evening.

THE FLORIDA INDIANS.--We learn that the Secretary of the Interior has prepared instructions for Colonel ELIAS RECTOR, Superintendent of Indian Affairs in the Southwest, directing him to take measures for the removal of the Seminoles remaining in Florida. It was under the management of Colonel RECTOR that BILLY BOWLEGS and his party were removed to the West,

CITY DELIGATIONS TO THE REPUBLICAN STATE CONVENTION.--The Seventeen Assembly Districts of the City of New-York have chosen the following persons to represent them respectively in the Republican Convention which meets at Syracuse to-day:

The Columbus (Ohio) Statesman says: The crowd assembled about the jail at Columbus on Friday to be near the hangiug of MYERS, was large, an men, women and children stood around for three hours in a drizzling rain, waiting for the execution to come off. The prisoner was to have been brought from his scaffold, and the arrangements were complete.

Edward C. Delavan, Esq., late President of the NewYork State Temperance Society: DEAR SIR: In your recent letter to the TemperaLce Convention at Utica, you justify your strong preference of the Hon. GERRIT SMITH for Governor, by referring to what he has done for Temperance the last thirty years. You are not alone in your estimate of the value of the Temperance labors of that distinguished philanthropist.

The U. S. Mail steamer Fulton, from Havre and Cowes on the 25th, arrived at this port yesterday morning, Her news had been anticipated by telegram from Cape Race. We have added, however, various items of interest, and extracts, which will attract the reader. Nothing had been heard of the steamship Asia at Halifax up to the time of going to press this morning.

The magnificent steam-frigate Niagara, so justly the pride of our Navy, is to be allowed no extended period of repose after the achievement of her great telegraphic enterprise. Orders have already been received from Secretary TOUCEY, directing her to proceed to Charleston for the purpose of conveying the negroes of the slaver Echo back to Africa.

RAILROAD CASUALTY AT FISHKILL.--The collision at Fishkill Landing on Monday night, described in another part of this morning's TIMES, by which two men were killed outright and two others severely injured, appears to be due to the running of two cattle trains quite year each other. Both started, as would seem, almost together from Albany.

Matters at Quarantine during yesterday remained very much in state quo. Up to 12 o'clock the fifty persons appointed by the Board of Health of the town to guard the gates of Quarantine had not made their appearance.

On Sunday morning, two prisoners confined in the Western Penitentiary, were taken from their cells, at 4 3/4 o'clock, and placed in the engine-house, for the purpose of letting off steam into the cook-house for cooking breakfast. These prisoners, DANIEL KINGSBURY and THOMAS BURNS, had been employed in the engine-house for several months, making repairs to the engine.

REBUILDING QUARANTINE.--Mayor TIEMANN has lost no opportunity for speaking his mind plainly in relation to the Quarantine, since the destruction. Mr. Wm. H. Imlay, an old resident of Hartford, died in that city on Saturday, aged 78. He was one of the largest and most active proprietors of the Atlantic Dock enterprise at Brooklyn, and furnished considerable sums of money to push forward that work, at a time when his aid was essential to its success. He also made one of the largest original railway sub scriptions ever made in this country.

The Republican and American State Conventions assembled at Syracuse yesterday, and though they both worked with commendable diligence the business effected was scarcely more than preliminary. The Republican Convention of Massachusetts met at Worcester on the 7th of September, and nominated the Hon. N. P. BANKS for Governor, by acclamation. JOHN A. ANDREW, of Boston, presided. THE EQUESTRIAN CONVENTION.-The disgraceful failure of the "Ladies' National Equestrian Convention " yesterday, calls for some explanation from the Stewards. Not a single item of the programme was carried out, and the scene, as described by our reporter, was of the worst possible kind.

No NOMINATIONS YESTERDAY.-It will be seen that no nominations were made at Syracuse yesterday. Both Conventions--the Republican and the American-have appointed Committees of Conference, being apparently determined to make an effort for union.

THE SILENCE OF THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH.The long continued silence of the Atlantic Telegraph very naturally gives rise to uncomfortable suspicions that, after all, the Cable has proved a failure; that either some accident has happened to it, or that it cannot be made to work.

FATAL HAIL-STORM IN ILLINOIS--We learn by passengers from Memphis, that a violent hall-storm took place in the lawer Ohio, on Thursday night last. The Waiton was overtaken by the storm at Slim island, and war compelled to lay to all night. Trees and fences were blown down and immense damage done to the corn crop.

There is reason to suspect that of the Chinese plunder the Russians take the lion's share. The frontier of China, instead of curving some hundreds of miles to the northward, including the entire course of the Amoor, and the larger portion of its water-shed, is now curved as decidedly southward, ceding vast regions, embracing near two thousand miles of the Amoor and its navigation, to the Czar.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, Captain LOTT, arrived here at 5 1/2 o'clock this morning. She left Liverpool at 11:30 A. M. on the 28th ult. Her dates are three days later than those already received. The Asia reports strong westerly winds during tile first part of the passage, and much fog between the Banks of Newfoundland and Halitax.

From the Detroit Free Press, 5th. We gave an account several months since of the discovery of the remains of a human being in the woods some fifteen miles from this city, in the township of Taylor. The remains consisted of belles which had been exposed to the weather for such a length of time that they were entirely devoid of flesh.

A statement which appeared in the TIMES of Tuesday, in regard to the condition of the Tehuantepec transit, meets with a wholesale denial at the hands of a well-informed correspondent. The denial appears in another column of this paper.

We are indebted to Mr. ANTONY PIRZ, of this City, who has business connections in Austria, for the following statement showing the character and value of the new currency just adopted in Austria, On the 1st of November all the old coin will go out of lawful circulation, and pass only at its value by weight.

The American and Republican Conventions failed to effect a union yesterday, and separate tickets have been nominated, Immediately on the assembling of the Republican Convention, a motion was made to proceed to nominate, viva voce, candidates for Governor and all other State Officers to be supported by the Republican Party.

NEW STEAMER FOR THE NICARAGUA TRANSIT. The steamboat Catharine Maria left this port yesterday afternoon for San Juan del Norte. The Cass Yrissari left on Monday last, and the Laura Frances will go to day.

THE LADIES NATIONAL EQUESTRIAN CONVENTION-DELIVERING THE PRIZES.-The office of Supervisor TWEED, at No. 289 Broadway, was crowded yesterday afternoon by gentlemen, mostly all public officials, to witness the delivery of the prizes to the fair ladies who won them the previous day at the " National Equestrian Convention."

THE AUSTIN ROBBERY.--JAMES GILLEN, accused of having rabbed Mr. THEODORE AUSTIN of a considerable sum of money on Sunday morning last, was yesterday, brought before Justice CORNWELL for examination. HENRY A. MOOBE, Esq., appeared as counsel for the accused, and District-Attorney SCHOONMAKER for the prosecution.

The Republican State Convention, which met yesterday, at Worcester, was a decidedly effective body, and was very numerously attended, about 1,250 being the number of members. Mr. ANDREW, who presided, is the same gentleman who took the lead in the legislative war that was carried on against Judge LOEING, last Winter, and who more than conquered Gen. CUSHING, in that memorable contest.

The Republican Convention reassembled at 9 1/2 o'clock A. M. Mr. P. H. THOMAS, of Rensselaer, moved immediately after the calling of the roll that the Convention proceed to nominate by by viva voce vote a candidate for Governor and all other State officers, to be supported by the Republican Party.

In the absence of anything more definite, we are gratified to be able to announce, on the authority of Mr. DE SAUTY, the Chief Electrician at Trinity Bay, that the Atlantic Cable is positively not broken. He declines to make any statement for publication other than this, and that there are only temporary difficulties of an electrical nature.

CITY COURT.-The City Court, Judge CULVER, will be opened for business on Monday next, when the Calendar, embracing 95 causes,(some of them important,) will be taken up and as speedily disposed of as possible, ACCIDENT.-- Miss ELLIOTT, of Middle Village, while riding in a carriage with her brother on Broad.

It is interesting to watch the rapidity with which this City is now improving in every respect. One can hardly realise that six weeks ago it was entirely deserted; that all that stores, now thronged with customers, were closed, and that all these dwellings now surrounded with noisy little urchins, were fastened up, with doors nailed and windows boarded. Never before was this City the scene of such activity in every branch of business,

The monotony at Quarantine was suddenly disturbed on Thursday night about 9 o'clock, by tile appearance of a large mob in the streets of Tomp. kinsvillie, headed by a fife and drum. They marched down the main street, and halted opposite Burns' Hotel. The crowd carried with them the effigies of several obnoxious persons, which were labeled to represent Dr. JACOB LAFARGE, Ex-Assemblyman JOHN F. RAYMOND, Mrs. UHL,

The great Base Ball Match between the selected nines front the New-York and Brooklyn clubs took place yesterday on the Fashion Race Course, Long Island, and resulted In a glorious victory for NewYork, it being the conquering game of a home and home match. COWHIDING A FRENCH MUSIC TEACHER.- A French music teacher, about 50 years of age, who has a wife and several children, has, for some time past, been giving music lessons to two young ladies, daughters of a down-town merchant who resides in the Fifteenth Ward. The teacher fell violently in love with one of the girls-or, at least, so he pro fessed-and importuned her to elope with him.

In the course of that voluminous defence of the Trustees of the Dudley Observatory, to which, the other day, we devoted some attention, the Press came in for appreciative criticism at the hands of the Superintendent of the Coast Survey. The Household Book of Poetry, collected and edited by CHAS. A. DANA, is the title of a large and unique-looking volume of 767 doubled-columned pages, just published by D. APPLETON Co. The design of the volume, as indicated by its title, is a most felicitous one, and the editor has oxhibited rare qualifications for the execution of his task.

The steamer Asia, of the Cunard line, arrived at Boston on Thursday night. Her newspaper bag, owing to the habitual mismanagement of the agents of the Associated Press, reached this City only a short time before our paper was obliged to go to press.

FLOUR, market for Flour during the week has been without animation, and prices, generally, have favored purchasers. The receipts have been moderate, and the demand chiefly confined to pressing wants of the home trade, with a very limited export inquiry. Standard State brands continue searce and wanted, while rejected parcels are less inquired for, and prices, in a measure, nominal.

The great La Crosse and Milwaukee Railroad Swindle has received a touch from the hands of the directors within the last few days, which was all that it wanted to convert It into a masterpiece of the art of impudent fraud. They commenced by doing what has never been attempted even since the days of Jugurtha--buying up the whole government

SUICIDE OF THE ENGINEER WHO RAN THE NEWHAVEN TRAIN OFF THE NORWALK BRIDGE,-EDWARD TUCKER, the Engineer of the train which ran off the bridge at Norwalk, Conn., some five years ago, and resulted so disastrously in the destruction of human life, committed suicide on Thursday afternoon. About 1 o'clock he called at the house of Mrs. BODINE, No. 329 Tenth-avenue, with whom he formerly boarded.

One of the finest performances of the " Trovatore" ever heard in this City was given last night at this house to an overflowing audience. It was in every way a triumphant occasion-the artists being encored and recalled as a matter of course. Mme, GASSIRR displayed more dramatic force than in her previous essay of VERDI's works,

FELLOW-CITIZENS: The choice of a Governor and other executive and legislative officers of the State, and the selection of representatives in the next Congress of the United States. impart to the approaching election unusual interest and importance. The policy which is to mark the administration of our domestic affairs, and the varied interests which cluster around our national legislation,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You have given a some what prominent place in your issue of Saturday last to an anonymous reply to an article published by you on the 9th inst., under my name, suggesting a plan for a wire suspension bridge across the Harlem River, over the High Bridge.

Before Judge Hoffman. Frank Leslie vs. Thomas McSpedon.-- Mr Leslie is the publisher of an illustrated paper. The defendant is an Alderman, and was Chairman of the Committee on the "Atlantic Cable Demonstration," and through his agency Mr. Leslie was expelled from the dining-room of the Metropolitan hotel on the occasion of the dinner to Cyrus W. Field.

After Wednesday next there will be, as there were last year, three State tickets in the field, and the Democrats enjoy a jubilant confidence that the result will be entirely similar. They find themselves delighted with the failure of the Republicans and Americans to unite. It is a piece of good fortune which they eagerly hoped for,

The announcement, a few days since, of a reconciliation between Generals HENNINGSEN and WALKER was, in a measure, premature. HENNINGSEN and WALKER met accidentally at one of the New-York hotels when the latter announced the pleasure he belt at an opportunity to explain matters between them. Before any explanation, however, company interrupted them, and the fillibusters separated.

We make room in this morning's issue of the TIMES for the Address of the Republican State Convention. It discusses the subjects of Canal Enlargement, Executive Power, Kansas, and the Extravagance of the National Administration, at much length. While the doctrines it advances will doubtless meet the approval of the Republican Party,

To the Editor of the new-York Times: Permit us through your columns, to present a request for aid in behalf of the Young Men's Christian Association of New-Orleans. This organization is attending constantly to the relief of yellow fever patients among the poor.

The Critic speaks as follows of the Thackeray and Yates difficulty: " Whether, as a contemporary asserts, Mr. Justice Willes has or has not given an opinion as to Mr. Edmund Yates' cause of action against the Garrick Club, for having expelled him. we cannot say. It is very unlikely that a Judge would commit himself to an opinion upon a case which might possibly come before him in a judicial capacity.

RUTON.--In this City, on Friday, Sept. 10, CAROLINE E., only daughter of A. B. and Sarah Ruton, in the 17th year of her age. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, this (Saturday) afternoon. at 4 o'clock, from the residence of her father, No. 108 Wcoster-st, without further invitation. SCOTT.--In this City, on Thursday, Sept. 9, SARAH M., wife of the late Judge John B. Scott.

GENTLEMEN: I find in the Atlas and Argus of this morning, an article under the following caption, "The Burning of Quarantine--Crime and Speculation," in which I am thus referred to-- "What, however, is notoriously rumored, is that Dr. THOMPSON has been interested in a speculation for a new Quarantine, in which the Governor's Private Secretary, Mr. SEAMAN, is also a prominent participator."

A remark concerning the Illinois canvass, recently made by Mr. Speaker ORR in a stump address to his constituents, has given the Washington Union no little concern. He said that he was in favor of DOUGLAS as " a better Democrat than LINCOLN"-- one of the two being certain, in his opinion, to be elected to the Senate.

J. P. HARLEY, a favorite English actor, died suddenly at London, on the 27th ult. He was seized with violent illness while performing his character of Launcelot Gobbo, in "The Merchant of Venice, " at the Princess's, on Friday evening, On leaving the stage, at the conclusion of his scene in the second set, he was observed to stagger, and, being about to fall, was supported by Mr. G. ELLIS, the stage-director.

Although the official announcement of the results of the Parisian Conference has not yet been made, we find them authoritatively stated in the Constitutionnel. From the New-York Tribune. The attempt to combine the two parties represented at Syracuse in a united effort against the abhorred measures and the corrupt and faithless men of the Buchanan Democracy, appears to have failed. We regret this result, but are not surprised at it. A little more experience seems to be necessary to the masses or to the leaders of the two parties.

An adjourned meeting was held yesterday, (Sept. 10,) of the committee of merchants and citizens "to take measures for extending some proper act of respect to C. W. FIELD, Capt. HUDSON, and the officers of the United States steamship Niagara, and others." P. PERIT, Esq., in the Chair. The Treasurer reported that nearly five thousand dollars had been collected up to this date.

The Academy of Medicine had their monthly meeting on Thursday evening, instead of on Wednesday evening, of last week, the session having been postponed, on account of the Cable Festival. Dr. BATOHELD??R, the President, was in the Chair. Dr. Morr, in consonance with the invitation of the Academy, at the last meeting, continued his remarks on the prostate gland, or body, as it is often called,

ENCOUNTER OF POLICE AND BURGLARS--The Police of the Ninth Ward had a determined fight with burglars early Saturday morning. About 1 o'clock Officers BEASELEY, KELLY and LEACH, who were on duty at the time, noticed three men near the corner of Gates and Bedford avenues, whose suspicious movements gave cause for the belief that they were burglars.

It has been the policy of this paper to dissent from some of the leading measures of the Buchanan Administration, and to reprobate the inefficient execution of others. To find one which, in all its parts, and in its carrying out, responds to the dictates of a sound judgment and obtains our unreserved sanction, realty affords the luxury of a fresh sensation, and we pay homage to it accordingly.

The zeal with which our worthy Mayor addicts himself to the Quarantine question, and chiefly to the specialty of rebuilding the Hospitals, is deserving of admiration. Nothing less than the reeditication of the whole suite of buildings, fire-proof, will satisfy Mayor TIFMANN: and this must be done forthwith, and regardless of cost,

THE DEMOCRATIC STATE CONVENTION-This body will meet at Syracuse on Wednesday next, and, as it is to consist of no more than 128 delegates, it will be manageable, and, probably, harmonious. Outside of this City there is no special appearance of trouble among the Democracy,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The extraordinary farote occasioned by the performance of the "Trovatore" on Friday evening justifies the management in playing it again to night. The cast is the most perfect ever heard in this City. BURTON'S THEATRE.--Mr. STRAKOSCH'S Italian Opera, with Mine. COLSON, commences operations here tomorrow night.

The steamship General Rusk arrived at NewOrleans, on the 6th inst., from Brazos Santiago, with fourteen days later news from Northern Mexico. The news from Mexico is interesting and import. ant. It appears that Tampico is now in possession of the Liberals. Gen, VIDAURRI, with 16,000 men and 54 pieces of artillery, was left at San Luis early this month, to march against Guanajuato and the City of Mexico.

SUPREME COURT--SPECIAL TERM--SEPT, 11. Before Judge Ingraham. Amelia G. Clerk VS. John P. Clerk.--In this case the plaintiff applied for a divorce from her husband, and also for an allowance in the shape of alimony, which the Court had ordered him to pay. The order was not obeyed, and the unlucky husband was arrested for contempt.

By the arrival of the steamship Vanderbilt, last night, from Southampton which port she left on the 1st inst, we have four days' later advices from Europe, and also late intelligence from India and China. The Liverpool Cotton Market is an-changed, and consols are quoted at 96 3/4@96 7/8 for account. There is a variety of interesting general news by the arrival, but the most important intelligence is from China.

The discussion between Mr. PAYNE and Parson BROWNLOW which has been raging at Phitadelphia is not, in our estimation, very likely either to influence public opinion upon the Slavery question very largely, or to add much lustre to the name of PRYNE.

A "DEAR LITTLE QUEEN."-Our loyal weekly contemporary, the Allion, being the accepted representative among the American Press of H. B. M., is bound to vindicate the honor of his royal mistress whenever it is impeached, or her character assailed; and as he has done it most gallantly and directly, for many years, we have wondered that no official recognition of such services has been hitherto made.

The United States steam-trigate ?? look her departure yesterday for Charleston, S.C. where she is to receive on board the captured Africans of the slaver Echo, to convey them to the Coast of Africa. She will not, of course, enter the harbor, but will lay off and on outside the bar, and the slaves will be conveyed on board in a steam-jug provided for the purpose.

It is rumored that General JEREZ will return here in a few days, to renew his proposition to our Government touching the Cass Vrissari treaty. This will be time wasted by the General. The President will not further consider his fareical proposition, and his authority does not empower him to change. So he says, and so it appears from the papers he exhibited to the State Department.

A DRUNKEN FATHER KILLED HIS SON.--All inquest was held on Saturday at the Twenty-second Ward Station-house, by Coroner GAMBLE, on the body of JACOR CLUTE, an Irishman, 65 years of age, who died from the effects of a blow received at the hands of DAVED CLUTS, his son. Several witnesses were examined, who all told the same story.

From the correspondence of the Panama Star, we obtain some particulars of affairs in Nicaragua. About the middle of the month the Costa Rica government sent a force to Greytown to take possession of SCOTT'S property there and to claim the right to Punta Castilla or Punta Arenas; but the Commander of the British ship of war Leopard refused to allow Col.CAUTY, the Costa Rica representative.

It would be difficult to over estimate the importance of the Democratic State Convention, to the held next Wednesday at Syracuse. Entirely apart from the administration for State offices; to be then and there >> and which may or may not be successful, the struggle for State ascendancy and its result must exercise a powerful influence over the proceedings of the next Presidential Convention to assemble in Charleston.

The steamship Vanderbilt, from Southampton on the 1st inst., arrived at this port last night, with four days later news front Europe. The steamship Persia arrived at Liverpool on Saturday morning Aug. 28. We have by this arrival fresh confirmation of the news of the ??eaty of peace with China, and also some interesting intelligence from India.

THE MAILS--The Postmaster-General has taken measures for contracting with the North Missouri Railroad Company for the transportation of the though and way mail from St. Louis to Mexico, over their road. Arrangements are also to be made with J. C. Bernan, of Palmyra, for a continuance of the same mail, by four horse post coaches, via Huntsville on to St. Joseph.

On Friday afternoon, at about 6 o'clock, an unknown man was discovered on the premises of SILPHEN HARREY, Esq., in a dying condition. he having severed with a razor the blood-vessels of his arm, producing a frightful wound. Dr. SCOTT was promptly sent for, and applied one usual remedies, but without success, us life was nearly extinct before the individual was discovered.

With the exception of the arrival of the military at Quarantine, we have little news to report from the rebellious district. Four additional cases of yellow fever have occurred at Quarantine since our last report. Two of them are of Lightermen belonging to a Newark Lighter, called the Wm. H. Newell. The men are very ill, and have been admitted to the hospitals for treatment.
