ARREST OF YOUNG BURGLARS.--On Saturday forenoon, Officer Stone, of the Seventeenth Ward, discovered two young fellows hurrying away from the residence of Mr. Wm. H. Sackett, No. 45 St. Mark's-place, having two bundies in their possession, Knowing that the family of Mr. Sackett was absent in Europe, the officer suspected something wrong, and pursued the youths, who immediately took to their heals.

By the arrival of the bring Bohio, Capt. BARTLETT, at this port, we have received advices from Caracas to the 20th of August, and from Puerto Cabello to the 27th of the same month, inclusive. The only Item of importance is the statement contained in the Diaria Mercantil, of Puerto Canello, that the Venenzoclan Government has agreed to grant Dassnor is to General MONAGAS and his family.

DEATH OF JUDGE MULLETT.--The Hon. JAMES MULLETT, one of the Justices of the Supreme Court for the Eighth Judicial District of this State, died at Fredonia, Chatauque County, on Friday afternoon, the 10th instant. The deceased had long occupied a preminent position in the Bar of Western New-York. He was respected by his professional brethren for his acquirements, and esteemed for his genial disposition.

STEUBEN FESTIVAL AT PHILADELPHIA,--The celebration in honor of General STEUBEN, commenced yesterday morning, at Lernon Hill. The procession, formed of the military, singing societies, , the names of which were given in the Ledger yesterday morning, passed over the route indicated, and was viewed by a large number o four citizens assembled on the sidewalks.

CITY MORTALITY.--According to the City Inspector's report, the number of deaths in the City during the past week was 588--a decrease of 4, as compared with the mortality of the week previous, and 83 less than occurred during the corresponding week last year. Of the total number, 415 were of ten years of age and under, and 63 inmates of the various public institutions.

More than one hundred private schools and seminaries are advertised, under the head of "instruction," in the columns of the TIMES, to open during the present week. Among this large number are some of the most fashionable and celebrated schools in the country, where every variety of taste and requirement for the instruction of the young, on the part of parents and guardians, can be secured.

The principal event of yesterday in the Quaran. line excitement was the visit of a Special Committee of the Emigration Commissioners to the scene of the late arson. We give below a full account of this visit, and of its results, which are not unimportant. The Mayor, who accompanied the Committee, reviewed the troops now encamped on the island, and was highly gratified with their appearance.

The extended correspondence from the City of Mexico, which we give this morning, represents in a perspicuous light the condition of affairs in the neighboring Republic. VIDAURRI was advancing upon the Capital from San Lais Potosi, while MIRAMON was endeavoring to bar his way with the main body of the Conservative Forces.

The Paris Conferences at length are over, and the fate of the Danubian Principalities is no longer unknown. The incorporate union they desiredd has not been vouchsafed to them. A rosette in common at the top of their respective standards, and a uniform tariff of customs duties are about the only items of political identity which the diplomatic Areopagus has judged it meet to recognise.

The United States mail steamship Daniel Webster, Captain MINER, left New-Orleans the 5th, Key West 7th, Havana the 8th inst., at 3 P. M., and arrived here early yesterday morning, consigned to M. O. ROBERTS. She brings 77 passengers, $102,000 in specie on freight, with merchandise,

THE ANGLO-FRENCH REGENCY IN VENEZUELA. -The attempt of the French and British ministers at Caracas to nullify the constitution and laws of Venezuela has been successful. MONOGAS, with his two jackals, has been released and carried to Trinidad, where the vast sums, in the accumulation of which he impoverished the country, were awaiting his arrival.

CANGEMI'S counset made an application to Judge DAVIES, a few days ago, for an order directing the expenses of printing the case on appeal to be charged to the County. Judge DAVIES has denied the motion for want of power in the Court to make any such order, but has, on the other hand, stated that he thinks the County ought to pay for the printing,

IN EIGHTH-AVENUE.-A fire occurred, at 4 o'clock this morning, in the dwelling house corner of Eighth avenue and Fifty first-street, occupied by Mr. CHARLES STYLES, cause by tile upsetting of a fluid lamp. The fire was soon extinguished, the damage being about 100, which is covered by insuranced.

IMPORTANT SUGGESTIONS FROM A PROPER QUARTER.--We have received and perused with Interest a semi-annual report, recently published, of the " Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad Company." It embodies suggestions and rules which, if realized, will be of essential advantage, and which deserve the attention of the railroad public.

The city is tolerably well filled with the Democracy to night. The outsiders particularly are in full force. Voorhees House is the headquarters of both sections of the party, GIDSON TUCKER, Secretary of State, FERNANDO WOOD, PETER GAGGER and Gov. at the Syracuse House.

By the arrival, at this port, of the schooner Coast Pilot, we have papers from Bahia to Aug. 6, and Rio de Janeiro to Aug. 1. There is no general news of interest from Bahia. At Rio de Janeiro, on the 18th of July, there was an insurrection of slaves on a small scale, which at one time threatened to become serious.

Our dates from the Dominican Republic are to the 2d September. The political scenery of this Republic has again changed. After the party of Cibao had forced Ex-President BAEZ to capitulate, we thought then every thing would be right. President VALVERDE was doing all in his power for the good of the country.

NEW STEAMBOAT FOR THE TEHUANTEPEC ROUTE.--A new non steamboat, to be called the Suchul, was yesterday launched from the ship-yard fool of Houston street, East River, for the Louisania Tehuantepee Company. She has been constructed by BOARDMAN, HILBROOK CO, of the Neptune Iron Works, in an incredibly short time, forty two working days only having been employed in doing the work.

Our readers will he glad to learn that the Church has at last begun to take into earnest consideration the excesses of its female members in the enlargement of their phylacteries to a degree never dreamed of by Scribe or Pharisee of old. The movement has not, indeed, begun in any of the high places of any of the great sects; but what reformation ever did spring from the spiritual or social eminences of society?

The Advertising Agencies in this City have become so numerous, that it is a matter of no inconsiderable difficulty to decide upon the degree of their reliability. From the complaints of the Country Press, it is clearly evident that many of the establishments which pretend to do a legitimate advertising business in the City are simply bogus concerns in which it is unsafe to trust. The venerable M Von Humboldt lately wrote to a Parisian publisher, declining to prepare a revised edition of one of his works, and prophesying his own death as an event which would occur in the year 1859. This letter was produced in Court recently, during the course of a trial in Paris. M. Von Humboldt added that he preferred that his works should not be altered until after his death.

Now we are collecting our troops for what is likely to be the most desperate Indian contest we have ever had. The programme is all settled at last, and two columns are to be formed to enter the Indian country. One, under Major GARNETT, from Simcoe; the other, from this place, to enter the Spekan country, and meet the tribes which defeated Col. STEPTOE.

The failure to form a common opposition ticket at Syracuse is not easily comprehended by the great mass of the voters. They cannot preceive any adequate reason for their disappointment and the hazard it involves. That it was an affair not of principles but of men, they clearly see ; but what men were at the bottom of the difficulty, do?? not so plainly appear.
The R. M. steamship Persia, from Liverpool on the 4th inst., with three days' later news from Europe, is now fully due at this port. There were no signs of her at Sandy Hook at 12 o'clock last night.

Boston is "pretty considerably agitated" at this time by School Committeemen about school-books. The majority of the Committee have recommended some books that others do not approve. and, from what I have heard, I should say the minority have the best of the argument, if the worst of the vote. It is bitterly complained of by parents that there should be so frequent changes of books made.

The result of the meeting of the two Conventions at Syracuse, on the 8th is before the public. A faithful history of the proceeding remains to be written. No one doubts that a majority of the people, on the principal issues of the day, think alike. The reasons why they were not permitted to act to go here remain to be stated.

FERRY BOAT RUN INTO BY A SCHOONER--As the Fulton ferry boat Union left the Brooklyn side about 9 1/2 o'clock A. M., yesterday, she was suddenly placed in a position towards several other boats and vessels from which there was no escaping a collision. The wind was fresh from the northward, the tide was setting strong flood, and the East River was litrally full of selling craft and ferry boats.

The cool east wind of yesterday took away much of the romance that has hitherto surrounded affairs at Status Island. Thick overcoats were in demand among the Police, and the Military were self comp?? at the foresight which led them to adopt a thick uniform The prospect of an easterly storm caused many an anxious glance towards the wooden ?? which are happily now nearly completed and in which the meals are to be served.

SR: I have been much pleaded with your editorial of to-day, on "Paragua," and am glad to see that the appointment of the Hon, JAMES B. BOWLIN as United States Minister, to accompany the expedition now fitting out, meets your approbation.

PERRY'S victory on Lake Erie is a glorious event in our country's history, and deserving a glorious commemoration. The States of the Northwest, and the Lake Cities in particular, regard its anniversary as peculiarly interesting to themselves. Its celebration has not been regularly kept up, but the enthusiasm which characterizes its commemoration when the people do get in the humor for it, amply atones for the irregularity of its occurrence.

Opposition Ratification Meeting In Philadelphia. A grand Ratification Meeting of opponents of the Administration was held in Philadelphia on Tuesday evening. GEORGE BALDIN presided, and speeches were delivered by the Hon. E. JOY MORRIS, the Hon. CHAS. D. GILPIN, and the Hon. HENRY D. MOORE.

There are some thirty-eight journals in this country (including two in California and one in Oregon) which are mainly devoted to agricultural and horticultural subjects. An invitation was sent out during the past Summer to the editors of these papers to visit this City during the present week to attend the Pomological gathering, and also to meet for becoming better acquainted with each other and are ranging for a future general Convention if thought advisable.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The New-York TIMES of the 4th instant issue was handed me this morning and my attention directed to an article on the first column and first page headed " Death of the Rev. EELAZER WILLIAMS, the Pretended Dauphin of France." The article has created quite a sensation here, but not very agreeable, and the end is not yet."

IMPORTANT TO JURORS.--Judge CULVER, in the City Court, under the new law, fines all absentees $25 per day for non-attendance. The Judge not only imposes the fine, but intends that delinquents shall pay it. MEDICAL.-Mr. DANIEL BROOKS, a carman, sued Mr. WM. H. HANFORD, a doctor, for assault and bat tery, claiming $500 damages.

The third departure of the Galway steamers from this port occurs to-day. The Pacific, escorted by an enthusiastic company of Irish gentlemen in their excursion boat, will leave the harbor, with a lull complement of passengers and ample freight.

A letter to the St. Louis Democrat from the Kansas gold region, says: "The character of the gold from this region partakes of the quality of both dry and river diggings, some being seatly gold. whilst a part is the round, heavy gold found in dry diggings, and containing impurites. such as quartz rock,

Yesterday, at noon, the State Convention of the Democratic Party met at Syracuse. Mr. PETER CAGGER called the body to order, and, on his nomination, Ex-Governor HORATIO SEYMOUR was chosen President--a preliminary Chairman being dispensed with.

Pursuant to public notice, a meeting composed of a large number of citizens of all classes, laborers, mechanics, merchants, , between two and three hundred persons, was held at DUNELL'S Hotel for the purpose of devising the best means of procuring a proper and permanent steam terminus for the New-York and Harlem and New-Haven Railroads.

The Castleton Board of Health, at a late meeting, adopted an ordinance, prohibiting the Quarantine authorities from burying those who had died of infectious diseases in the Hospital burying ground which is located some two miles from the Quarantine, and to reach which the hearse has to pass through a portion of two streets of the village of Tompkinsville.

The great National Show commenced this morning at Hampden Park, in a most brilliant manner, by a grand cavalcade of all the horses that have arrived, numbering between five and six hundred of all classes, and not an inferior animal among them all. It Is said to be altogether the finest show that has been made since the exhibition was instituted five years since.

A curious Hebrew publication has just issued from the Berlin press-a biography of Alexander Von Humbolet, written in the ancient tongue, and destined to extend the knowledge of the life and scientific labors of this celebrated man in the wile circle of the Russe-Polish and Asiatic Jews. The full title is, " Alexander Von Humboldt. A Biographical Sketch. Dedicated to the Nestor of Wisoom on his 88th Birthday. By S. Slominski."

The Democratic State Convention for the nomination of candidates for State officers assembled at Syracuse yesterday, and after some skirmishing, and setting aside the contested seat disputes, succeeded in effecting a permanent organization, with HORATIO SEYMOUR as President.

The morning was occupied in issuing ticket to delegates and reporters, and in private caucusing, principally respecting organization. The Tammany delegation met and found the representation full. Their caucus was private. Some excitement was caused by the appearance, this morning, of a contestant for the seat of Mr. FAIRCHILD, of Madison, who was agreed on by the Softs as temporary Chairman.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The "Trovatore" was substituted last evening for "Lucia," in consequence of the indisposition of Signor GASSIER, whose presence was, of course, necessary in the latter opera. VERDI'S work seemed to satisfy the audience, and Signor STEFFANI'S singing, as usual, created a furore. After the third act he was called out three times.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In a leading editorial in your issue of Saturday last, under the rather famous caption of" Jonathan Wild in Wisconsin," you committed an act of singular injus ice, which, I doubt not, on a proper explanation, you will hasten to correct.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: This body, which is the only one, we believe, which acts in a combined form among the colored people, has recently finished its sittings at Chatham, C. W. The address of the Chairman. Dr. DELANY, is an able document, giving a concise view of the present state of the colored race in all parts of the world, and is well worth perusal.

OBITUARY.--Dr. WILLIAM POWER, an eminent physician of this City, died yesterday. The following notice is from the pen of Dr. VALINTINE MOTT: Dr. WM. POWER was a native of Ireland, and received his professional education in the great school of Dublin, and to comply with the then law 'of this State, received the diploma of M. D. in this City.

JUDGE BREESE.---Among the prominent old democrats of illinois is the Hon. SIDNEY BREESE, formerly United State Senator. For some years he has been quieseent, but during the Summer he was named as the Administration candidate for the Senate against DOUGLAS. Yet as he did not show himself, or mount the stump, a DOUGLAS editor took heart to say he was not a candidate.

Thompson, of No. 88 Prince street. The warrant was issued by Recorder BARNARD, and the papers sent to Justice CONNOLLY, but the papers could not be found yesterday at the Police Court.

A company of fifty Metropolitan Policemen were dispatched to Quarantine yesterday about 1 o' clock, under the supposition that their services would be needed, as it was rumored in the City that the rebels intended to celebrate the burning of the Hospitals, and possibly an attempt would be made to destroy the lately erected shahties.

CASTIGATED BY HIS WIFE.-A well-known men vidual in Brooklyn was at an early hour on Sunday morning last, discovered by his loving wife emerging from a saloon on Myrtle-avenue, near Fulton street. The injured wife had been looking for her liege lord several hours, had had visited several popular places of resort to find him, that she might secure enough money to buy a diner for Sunday, and stock tile larder for the week.

The General Muster of the Vermont Volunteer Militia, called by Governor FLETCHER, assembled at Brandon on Wednesday, the 1st of September, Early in the morning special trains arrived on the Rufland and Burlington Railroad, bringing his Excellency and Staff, the various Companies, and crowds of people.

THE FAIR AT THE "PALACE.-The Annual Faur of the American Institute is in a state of postponement, but positive announcement is made that it will open to the public on Tuesday. The reason of delay is the dilatoriness of exhibitors. The promise of a good Fair is flattering. More applications have been made by exhibitors than have been received in any one year before.

THE DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATE FOR STATE PRISON INSPECTOR.--EDWARD LEO DONNELLY, the Democratic nominee for State Prison Inspector, is but little known. He is a native of this City, but, as his name indicates, of Irish extraction. He is about 30 years of age.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Winter is approaching, and with it suffering among the poor of the cities. In all large towns there are many small boys, not only homeless, but friendless, who, to avoid the cold, go into haunts of vice, and there soon become adepts in crime. In New-York, the Children's Aid Society seeks to prevent these evils.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Will you allow an old inhabitant of the City to say a few words to the Aldermen of this great centre of trade and commerce in relation to the petition now before them asking a repeal of the law corn selling the Railroads to stop their steam-engines at Fortvsecond-street ? The ordinance was passed in 1854, but has not been enforced until the present time.

A SPELL OF WEATHER.-Yesterday everybody thought the Equinoctial storm had come, and the degree of preparation for that event, in the way of bad clothes and seedy hats, and umbrellas, was something startling. But by 3 o'clock the weather repented, the sun came out cheerily, the umbrellas and galoshes were stuck away in dusty corners, and Broadway was full and glad.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-DONIZETTI 'S opera of "Lucia di Lammermoor" was produced here last night, with a new distribution in two of the Principal parts Mme. GASSIER being the Lucia, and Signor STEFANI the Edgarde. The performance was a very even and excellent one, and gave abundant satisfaction to a full house.

The Queen returned on the 31st ultimo from her visit to her daughter, the Princess FREDERICK WILLIAM, of Prussia. Throughout her Majesty's tour in Germany she was everywhere greeted with hearty expressions of respect and good will. The Prussians are weary and ashamed of the pitiful position to which their country has been politically reduced of recent years,

DISABILITIES OF ALIENS IN RESPECT TO REAL ESTATE.--A correspondent calls attention to the statutes which disqualify aliens from holding or conveying real estate, as being useless, troublesome and mischievous, and suggests their repeal. We concur in his opinion of this matter.

We copy from the London Times of the 28th ult. a most extraordinary article in relation to the rejoicings in this country over the success of the Atlantic Telegraph. We call it an extraordinary article, for the tone of it is not only indecent and malignant towards this country, but wholly at variance with the usual tone of the paper in which it appears.

With the present number, the Nr.w-Yonr TIMES enters upon the eighth year of its existonce. Precisely seven years ago to-day the first sheet of the paper was put forth from the narrow quarters at No. 113 Nassau-street. It was issued without any untranquilizing apprehensions of the future.

THE RAG-PICKERS AGAIN.--During Thursday night a large quantity of bedding, supposed to have been thrown from vessels lying at Quarantine, was washed ashore at Bay Ridge and vicinity, By daybreak yesterday morning the beach was lined with rag pickers, who, when discovered by the Police, were busily engaged in removing the property.

The Ring. THE FIGHT FOR THE CHAMPIONSHIP. The approaching fight, to take place between MORRISSET and HEENAN for $2,500 a side on the 20th prox., is the first real bettle for the Championship since the meeting between liver and SULLIVAN in 1849. It of course, creates an unusual amount of excitement in the "sporting" world.

The fourth annual regatta of the Empire City Regatta Club, which was postponed from Thursday on account of the rain, came off at Conrad's Garden, Yorkville, yesterday afternoon. With the exception of a little too much wind, the weather was favorable for the occasion, and the attendance was respectable, though not as numerous as on previous annual races of the Club.

IN FORTY-SIXTH-STREET--At 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in a small wooden stall in Forty-Sixth-street, between Tenth and Elcyenth avenues, owned by JOHN DIXON, The entire stall was consumed, and a horse valued at $100, belonging to a Mr. BARTLETT. The total loss was $150, and insured.

The sudden and hasty flight made by FERNANDO WOOD from the Convention has brought down on that unhappy gentleman the maledictions and invectives of the only class of Democratic politicians in the State not already engaged, either directly or indirectly, in the vivacious and exhilarating business.

Last night, about 10 o'clock, a murder was committed at No. 25 Baxter st,, in the grocery and liquor store ot Jouxi LEwls, a German, the farorite resort of a number of thieves, loafers and vagabonds, of all sizes, shapes and colors, the blacks, however largely predominating.

The introductory lecture, by Dr. BOYNTON, was given last evening, at the Cooper Institute, to an audience which completely filled the spacious hall. The lecture was of an elementary character, and mostly devoted to Mechanical Astronomy. The law, said the Doctor, which governs the atom, governed the mass. All matter is governed by law.

BEDFORD--BOSTON.--In this City, on Tuesday, Sept. 11, by the Rev. Robt. G. Dickson, Mr. HENRY A. BEDFORD to Miss CARDLINE T. HORTON all of this City. PAYS-FORDHAM.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday evening, Sept. 26, at the residence of the bride's parents, by the Rev. Dr. Lexis. WALTER K. PAYL to JOS?? laughter of A. S. Ferdasm, Esq. all of Brooklyn. n.

Commander BBLL has been appointed Lighthouse Inspector of the Third District, New-Yotk, vice MCI(iNSTBY, detached. Commander STELLWAGEn has been appointed Lighthouse Inspector of the Fourth District, Philadelphia, vice STrADMAY. who has been ordered to the command of the brig Dolphin, in place of Lieutenant MAmPIT who is a witness in the case of the recaptured Arlcans.

New-Jersey is on the eve of indulging in that autumnal luxury, an election, bringing thereunto a more than ordinary zest and appetite. There is a Legislature to be chosen, which will either return the IIon. WILI.IAM WRIICIT to the United States Senate, or name his successor.

WHY THE TELEGRAPH IS IDLE.--We are at last furnished with a reason why the Atlantic Cable is not working. The Company appears tolhave been taken by surprise in the successful laying of the long wire, and to have omitted provision for a stouter and stronger strand required at either terminus, to save the line from the dangers of shallow water.

Our advices from Brazil are to the 9th ultimo. The operations of the American Engineers upon the second section of the Pedro II. Railroad still occupied public attention. MIr. MIP.AD, the American Minister, had accompanied the President of the Company to the theatre of work.

THIRD DAY. Before Judge Metcalf. Pursuant to adjournment, the Court met punctually at 9 3/4 o'clock. The prisoners were both present, and a large number of their friends and sympathizers speedily filled the Courtroom. The first witness was Dr. Daniel H. Bissell, who was recalled, and examined by Ex-Judge Dean. RE-EXAMINATION OF DR. RUSSELL.

ROBBERY AT THE MERCHANIS' HOTEL-$15,000 OF NOTES AND STOCK CERTIFICATES DESTROYED.-A Car pet-bag belonging to Mr. J. W. Lacy, a number dealer from Pennsylvania, stopping at the Merchants, Hotel in Cortlandt street, was stolen on Wednesday form the office of the hotel. The carpet-bag contained a number of certificates of railroad stocks, bonds, checks and notes, representing $15,000 in value,

The probable results of the late Demo ratic State Convention, held at Syracuse, are manifold and important; but in no aspect of more value to politicians of every stripe, than in the lessons there furnished of obedience to party necessities, and the example of great concessions cheerfully made for the sake of securing united action.

THE THIRD CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT.-The forthcoming campaign for members of Congress from the Third District, composed of the First, Second, Third, Fifth and Eighth Wards of this City, bids fair to be an exciting one. DANIEL E. SICKLES, the present member, Is in the field for reflection, and Gen. HIRAM WALBRIDGE yearns to serve another term, and expresses his determination to run again,

The Lord Mayor, after some highly complimentary remarks, having proposed the health of Mr. BRIGHT, that gentleman said: MY LORD MAYOR, MY LORD CARDINAL, AND GENTLEMEN: I beg to return to your lordship and to all present my most sincere thanks for the great honor which you have conferred upon me this evening in drinking my health,

NORRIS.-In this City, on Saturday, Sept. 18, SAMUEL, only son of Alexander and Margaret I. Norris, aged 4 months and 16 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from No. 311 West 19th-st., this (Monday) morning, at 10 o'clock, without further invitation.

The Philadelphia Press has this story: Several Years ago, James Young, a wealthy citizen of Milford township, Butler County, deceased, leaving property valued at $105,000, to be equally divided between his five children. Subsequently the homestead was sold to a Mr. Williamson, who has resides upon it since the sale. A few days ago Mrs. W. found an old Spanish half-dollar while sweeping in a closet near a chimney in the main sitting-room.

The steamers Fulton and Water With, forming part of the expedition to Paraguay, are now ready for sea and will probably leave to-morrow for Norfolk. uns of very heavy calibre have been selected for both vessels-the armament of the Fullon consisting of one eleven-inch shell gun on a pivot, and four of nine-inch in broadside, and that of the Water Witch of one nine-inch shell gun on a pivot.

It apears that the great master-minds of the Mormon Church have been compelled, by experience, to acknowledge the truth of the old maxim, that familiarity breeds contempt. They have discovered that even their own people, instead of entertaining increased respect, veneration and affection for the elders, apostles and prophets, after constant intercourse and intimate acquaintance with them,

To the Editor of the New - York Times: A poor man or family may be immediately and permanently relieved by sending him West, Ta?? benevolent there are willing to cooperate with the friends of the Poor in the East by giving employment and homes, together with fair wages, to all persons sent to them who are willing to engage in honest labor, Applications are on hand at the office of the American Industrial Association.

I have first two errors to correct in regard to the Morse recompense. The protocol allowing the 400,000 francs is not yet a law, since the Minister of Holland, one of the members of the Convention, refuses to sign the act. His Government only agreed to the arrangement on the ground of its being an honorary tribute to Professor MORSE, and not a debt, and as such they consider the sum mentioned as too great,

From the Gazette of Saturday. About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the row of brick buildings on Front-street, known as Cassilly's Row, situated on the South Side, between Broadway and Ludlow. The rear of these buildings, i.e. the portion which fronted on the landing, was occupied by low doggeries, boarding-house keeners. and constituted a portion of Rat Row.

In relation to the robbery of the Union Bank of kinderhook, we learn some additional facts. On the evening of the robbery, three suspicious individuals were observed in Kinderhook. The next morning these same characters bought three tickets at Coxeackle, two for Newbrug, and one for this City. The sherill, hearing of this, immediately started for Newburg but up to this time no arrests have been made.

THE GRAVE OF FRANKLIN.-We are glad to learn that the vestry of Christ Church are taking measures towards opening to the public a view of the tomb of FRANKLIN. They have resolved to remove that portion of the brick wall which bounds the graveyard of Christ Church northward and to substitute an iron railing.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. Over a hundred and twenty " Institutes," "Academies," " Schools," "Collegiate Institutes," "Collegiate Academies," "Collegiate Schools," "Seminaries,"

STATE, ELECTIONS.-Whoever imagines that no other object is involved in the State elections to be held this Fall, than the filling of certain offices about to become vacant, is grievously deficient in his comprehension of the case. They have an ulterior object, far more interesting. To choose Governors, Legislators, Sheriffs, , is all very well.

At last, we are also Constitutionals! This place is in Possession of the State troops, commanded by General CARVAJAL. A part of the garrison pronounced on the 25th inst., at 6 o'clock P. M., and look possession of the Casa Mata, which is the principal fortification, situated near the burying ground. General MARIN, with the rest of the garrison, and all officers, kept on the defensive.

Regatta of the Brooklyn Model Yacht Club. The Fall Regatta of the above Club took place on Saturday, the yachts starting about 2 1/2 o'clock from a boat moored off the Club-house, at the foot of Court-street, South Brooklyn. Thirteen yachts were entered, but only eight started for the prizes, which were a silver tankard, a silver pitcher, and a goblet, all elegantly chased.

The testimonial of honor, ordered by the Legislature of Virginia, as a tribute to the memory of the late Capt. WM. L. HERNDON, United States Navy, who was lost in the steamer Central America, when she foundered at sea, has been prepared for presentation to his widow. The Richmond Enquirer describes it:

How Bonus COIN IS MADE--The art of making bogus coin has nearly reached perfection, and some of the specimens of American halves and quarters exhibited of late are so good an imitation of the genuine that It requires more than a casual glance to detect the fraud.

INGENIOUS DODGE FOR COMPANIES SEEKING ON-CORPORATION - - SERIOUS CHARGES AGAINST MEN OF NOTE. Last Saturday afternoon, Mr. EDWARD S. LATHAM, of Seneca Falls, appeared before Justice WELSH at the City Hall Police Court, and made a singular affidavit, developing a somewhat curious, but not, perhaps, very novel way, in which a Company seeking incorporation may make its required advance deposit of cash capital without greatly straining the stock-holders.

ACCIDENT.--The North Atlantic Steamship Company's Screw-steamer Pacific, of the New-York and Galway line, which has recently been inaugurated, it is said, under most favorable auspices, left this port on Saturday, carrying a full cargo and a full complement of passengers.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: As you must be inured to groans from afflicted individuals, on any and every pretence, perhaps you will open your columns to an actually classical com. plaint. I am a pedagogue ; expected to prepare bays for college. In this country the preparation required is, not for one, or two, or three universities, as In England, but for one of Legion.

From the St. LOHiS Democrat, We had, yesterday, an interview with Mr. J. C. HEMINORAY, of the firm of J. C. HEMINORAY Co., bankers, of Leavenworth City, Kansas Territory. He puts us in possession of some deeply interesting information relative to the rumored gold region of Kansas.

To that excellently got up and leismely man of business who now strolls down Broadway to his counting-room, just before noon, the Ocean Telegraph, we are sorry to say, brings disagreeable tidings. It requires him to enter upon an instant and radical change of habits. His day must begin sooner, and end later.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- DONIZETTI'S opera of "Lucia di Lammermoor" will be played here to night, for the second and last time. The distribution is admirable. BURTON'S THEATRE. -- Mme COLSON made her third appearance on Saturday evening, and essayed a role which, in the minds of many of the critical, was considered to be beyond her powers. The opera was the "Traviata"--Mme. COLSON being the horoine.

Commodore Paulding, U. S. N., was honored with a public reception on the occasion of his visit to Burlington, Vt., on the 15th inst. After listening to the address welcoming him among the Green Monument, made a reply, in which he said: "During my long naval life, I have acted with the single purpose of securing to myself a character for honor and professional zeal,

THE REV. WILLIAM HENRY CHANGING, of Liverpool, preached in All Souls' (the Rev. Dr. BELLOWS') Church, yesterday morning, and in the evening a large audience assembled at the Church of the Messiah, in Broadway, where it had been announced that Mr. CHANNING, and other distinguished divines, would take part in the exercises.

LARGE FIRE IN COLUMBIA COUNTY.--The papermill, dwelling and barn, belonging to Mr. ISAAO SON, near Chatham Four Corners, Columbia County, were entirely destroyed by fire about 2 o'clock, on Thursday morning. The fire originated in the dry left, where no fire is ever used.

THE POST-OFFICE.-The Journal of Commerce professes to have seen some time ago the ground plan of the Broadway Theatre, and on the strength of the vision amends our estimate of the superficial contents. Our estimate was, however, based on the representations of the Journal itself in its remarks on Thursday.

TROUBLE AT THE CUSTOM-HOUSE--THE COLLECTOR IN A TIGHT PLACE.--There have been a variety of scandalous stories in circulation during the past fortnight in relation to Collector SCHELL, and the efforts made by his enemies to oust him from his uncomfortable office; but, as it was only a Democratic family quarrel,

THE INDEPENDENT CANDIDATE,-- Mr. GERRIT SMITH was last heard from at Buffalo, where he delivered two addresses, the first to about three hundred persons, at one o'clock in the afternoon, and the second to a crowd, in the evening. Wherever he goes he collects large audiences.

The Pacific mail steamship Star of the West and the U. S. mail steamer Philadelphia will both leave to-day, at 2 o'clock, with the United States mails and passengers for California. The Philade phia transfers her passengers at Key West, on board the fine steamer Granada, without landing, and they arrive at Aspinwall at the same time and cross the Lathmus with the passengers per Star of the West.

YELLOW FEVER IN GALVESTON.-Yesterday (Sunday) morning quite a panic was produced, among the unacclimated portion of the population of Galveston, on account of the announcement of the appearance of yellow fever. A number of cases of sickness had occurred towards the close of the, week, but having the appearance of light bilious fever, they attracted no attention until Saturday night,

Ira Young, Appleton Professor of Natural Philosophy in Dartmouth College, died at his reeidence in Hanover, N. H., on the evening of Monday last aged 67 years. He last met his classes on Saturday, Aug. 28. His disease was internal, he having bean subject to its attacks for several years. A very aritical surgical operation was performed on Monday ofternoon, as the only means of preserving his life.

The owners of slave-property in the neighboring counties of Maryland, and also in the District ?ere, have become very much alarmed at the facility with which said articles of property walk off and vanish. It beats the spiritual manifestations entirely out of sight. Household chattels not only dance like tables and chairs under the manipulation of Mr. HOME, but they actually "cut stick"--"clear the kitchen"--fly to Northern latitudes.

PUBLIC MEETING OF THE STATEN ISLANDS.We have never believed that the respectable residents and citizens of Richmond County, either abetted the incendiaries who destroyed the Quarantine Hospitals, or approved of the means taken to rid that lovely Island of what the inhabitants regarded as a nuisance But no expression of their opinions having been made by the respectable and law-abiding part of the Staten Islanders,

From the Washington Union. Mr. DOUGLAS is a self-nominated candidate for reelection to the Senate by the Legislature of Illinois. He asks the Democracy of that State to Sustain him and to indorse his opposition last Winter to the President and the Detaocratic members of the Senate and House of Representatives, He has made that issue. It is not a Party contest: it is whether he shall he sustained in his apostasy.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: When you again advert to laws obsolete, and those that ought to become so, as you have done in the article headed "Equitable Justice," in your Columns to day, might not the provisions of our statutes relating to the acquisition, or rather the non acquistion, of real estate by allens, be brought under review?

THE DUDLEY OBSERVATORY.---The Trustees of Dudley Observatory publish in the Albany Statesman a reply to Dr. GOULD'S charges that they garbled certainly four letters written by him, They positively deny that Dr. GOULD'S mealling was in any Instance perverted, although large portions of letters of very great length were omitted, mainly for the sake of brevity. The card of the Trustees concludes:

GENTLEMEN: In regard to the questions mooted in reference to the election of representatives to the next Legislative Assembly, it seems to me clear that the election must be held under the provisions of the Act of 1857, or else that there is no authority for holding it at all. To remedy the evil complained of, I have received numerous petitions requesting me to call an extra session of the Legislature.

FIRST OVERLAND MAIL TO CALIFORNIA---The St. Louis Republican. of the 16th says: "The first overland mail for san Francisco. Cal., by the way of Jefferson City and Springfield, Mo., Fort Smith, Ark., and Preston. Texas. makes its departure this morning from the St. Louis Post-Office. at 7 o'clock. It goes by the way of the Pacific railroad to Tipton, from whence it will be conveyed in coaches and spring wagons the whole of the distance.

In compliance with the announcement, and in conformity with a custom heretofore observed on similar occasions, the good people of Springfield entertained themselves and their visitors this evening by a supper at the City Hall. Provision was made for eight hundred guests, through probably not more than two-thirds of that number were present. Scattered here and there at the tables a number of lady participants appeared.

There is a pretty good demand for FLOUR today, in part for New--York market, quotations unchanged, and market steady; sales 22,000 bbls, at $4 75@$5 for medium to good brands superfine Indiana Michigan and Ohio; $5 121/2 for choice do.; $5 25@$5 50 for good to choice extras; $5 75 for double extra.

Yesterday, at the village of Richmond, in Staten Island, a meeting of residents interested in the matter of the removal of the Quarantine was held, pursuant to a public notice which had been extensively circulated for the week previous. The purpose of the assemblage, as set forth in the advertisement, was "to interchange views in relation to the recent events connected with the Quarantine in this county,

It is not well to let the great pass away without note and worthy honor. DRED SCOTT is dead. Yesterday, from St. Louis, that illustrious personage carried his case to the Supreme Court above, not doubting, we may believe, that the adverse decision he encountered here will there meet with reversal, and that he will be at once admitted to a better freedom and more equal citizenship.

THE POOR--THE SABBATH--THE PHILANTHROPISTS. Sundry Conventions have been held in this State during the week, besides the political gatherings. The State Convention of Superintendents of the Poor has been held at Utica.

It is hard to give a name to the State Convention which met here yesterday. It represented the ultra Know-Nothings or old Native Americans, and the Fillmoreans of 1850, and I suppose the Know-Nothings name is that to which it is best entitled. It has now in its organization some gentlemen who were Fremonters in '58, the chief of whom is Ex-Governer GARDNER:

The steamship North Briton, with four days' later news from Europe, passed Riviere du Loup yesterdayy afternoon. The boatmen went out for her news, and it was thrown overboard for them, but the can containing it sunk, from (probably) not being water tight. The steamer passed Montreal, and was anchored off St. Roch's last night.

THE LITTLES MURDER CASE AT ROCHESTER--NEW TRIAL REFUSED TO IRA STOUT.--The Rochester Union of Saturday says. "This afternoon the General Term of the Supreme Court announced its decision in the case of the People vs. Ira Stout, by denying the application for a new trial. The Court was unanimous--the Judges, Messrs. WELLES, JOHNSON and SMITH concurring, and each has written an opinion.

MILITARY DUTY AT QUARANTINE.--We find amongst the items of intelligence from Staten Island, that Private WILLIAM WILSON, (the somewhat notorious Ex-Alderman,) of Company G. of the Eighth Regiment, was recently seized with a fit, and obliged to go home to recover himself, in consequence of over-exertion.

Advices from St. Louis, both public and private, imply that the evidence by which FRANK P. BLAIR expects to unseat J. R. BARRETT is of a very formidable character. In ordinary contested cases tile public incline to favor the pretensions of the successful candidate, and naturally attribute the effort of his opponent as much to disappointed feeling as to any other cause.

The Toronto Globe notices the arrival of the steamer Rescue, at Collingwood, from Fort William, bringing Mr. WILLIAM GIBBARD, of Collingwood, who conveyed the second mail to and from Red River. Mr. GIBBARD was detained three days and a half out of sixteen days and three-quarters,--making the actual traveling time between Red River and Lake Superior, twelve days and quarter.

I presume that ere this reaches ou the news of the Pink Tone, which Capt. LOCKWOOD was bringing on here for the navigation of the tipper part of the Guasacualcos River, will have been received Capt. LOOKWOOD and the crew were obliged to abandon her the 29th ult., some sixty miles from the Alacranes. They all arrived here in safety.

SUPPOSED LOSS OF THE AUSTRALIAN PASSENGER SHIP ULTONIO, WITH 180 SOULS. For several weeks the most painful anxiety has prevailed respecting the fate of the Australian passenger ship Ultonia, Captain Wm. S. Baker, which left the Thames for Melbourne, with 180 souls on board, in the early part of last November.

Col. FORNEY has stirred up a prodigious commotion. The Washington Union attacks him fiercely, ??propos of a letter from Judge BREESE of Illinois. After referring to the Judge's letter, the Union says of Col. FORNEY:

The United States mail steamer Black Warrior, J. W. SMITH, Commander, from New-Orleans 12th and Havana 15th inst., has arrived. The Spanish marine authorities had taken off Colorado Reef a Spanish vessel abandoned, supposed to have landed 900 Negroes. She Was commanded on her late voyage by EUGENIO VINAS, celebrated as a fearless and successful slaver.

We have advices from Belize to the 15th ult, with later from Guatemala and Honduras. The People of the latter State were represented as begin perfectly healthy, with the exception of a cough, predisposing the small pox paticuts of last year to consumption, a disease which was never before known in that part of the world.

Before Joseph Bridgham, Esq. The case of the nine mutineers of the American ship Orient was called on for examination. The examination was commenced in the Grand Jury stairways, lobbies and halls being thronged with witnesses, seamen and women, friends of the prisoners, Leopard C. Newmann, Esq., for the United States District-Attorney, opened the examination for the prosecution.

Captain PARK, of Br. brig John Butler, arrived this morning from Port an Platt, (5th inst.,) informs as that SANTANA marched into Santiago on the 1st day of September, with 2,000 men and 7,000 horses, and took possession of the Fort. Santiago had previously capitulated; the President, VALVERDE, fled to Monte Cristo, there to embark for Turks island.

The city of New-Orleans is stricken in a sorrowful way. The mail of yesterday brought us full particulars of the ravages of the yellow fever. Telegrams, announcing from day to day tile progress of the scourge, have hardly sufficed to give an idea of the reality, The Delta publishes a statement of the number of deaths per week, since the fever assumed an epidemic form.

A WHITE SLAVE.--A boy, 14 years of age, who claims to be white and free, was offered for sale at St. Augustine, Florida, on the 4th inst. He was released on a writ of habeas corpus, and the case is pending. The Charleston Courier tolls the story as follows:

LEAYCRAFT--WHITE.--In this City, on Monday, Sept. 20, at the bride's residence, No. 188 Stanton-st., by the Rev. Gardner Dean, Mr. ROBERT J. LEAYCRAFT and Miss ANN ELIZA WHITE, all of New-York. MILLS--DARROW.--In New-London, on Wednesday, Sept. 15, at the residence of the bride's father, by the Rev. O. T. Walker, CHAS, F. MILLS, of Brooklyn, to LUCY HUNTER, only daughter of John Darrow, Esq., of the former place.

During a recent visit to Frankfort-on-the Main, Prince Metternich, calling aside the host of the "Roman Emperor" Hotel, at which he was stopping, stated that on that day (the 23d of August) it was just eighty years since he, then a lad of five years, had first set foot in that house, in the retinue of the Emperor .Joseph II. of Austria.

To the Editor of the New-York Times; There has been quite a flurry of excitement in our neighborhood for several days past, originating in some very mysterious arrivals of sundry very mysterious men from oceanward, on an errand which nobody succeeds in comprehending.

WM. DUMONT sold, by order of Court, house and lot on the north side of Twenty-ninth-street, 201 feet west of Seventh-avenue, 24 feet 10 1/2 inches front and rear, by 98 feet inches in depth. Bought by WM. LEGGETT, for $5,900.

EXTRAORDINARY MURDER BY A PHYSICIAN NEAR LOCKPORT.--A man by the name of PHILIP HAWKINS, an old Peninsular soldier under WELLINGTON, was murdered in Wilson, Niagara Co., on Tuesday, under extraordinary and peculiar circumstances. The Lockport Courier of Thursday morning says that HAWKINS had been complaining for several days, when Dr. JOHN CRESWELL was called to visit him.

RICHARD.--In this City, on Sunday, Sept. 29 the Rev. Wm. RICHMOND, Rector of St. Michael's Church, New-York, in the 61st year of his age. The clergy generally, the relatives and friends of the family, and the parishioners of St. Michael's Church, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral at the Church i Bloomingdale, on Tuesday, the 21st, at 4 o'clock P.M.

THE STATES ISLAND MEETING--The meeting of Staten Islanders, at Richmond, yesterday, was a highly respectable gathering in point of numbers and also in the personal character of the gentlemen who took part in the proceedings. The report presented by the Committee, and a sketch of the speeches made occupy a considerable part of our columns this morning.

Whether the Statement of the nine Trustees does mot contain extracts from letters essentially private and unofficial ?

The steamship North Briton, from Liverpool on the 8th inst., is at anchor some fifteen miles below St. Roch's. and near L'Islet. A heavy storm is prevailing, and it is impossible to obtain her news tonight.

The Succession in the Third Congressional District. THE CAMPAIGN OPENED--LARGE DEMOCRATIC MASS MEETING--SPEECH OF THE HON. HIRAM WALBRIDGE. A large meeting of Democrats of the Third Congressional District was held in the open space in Franklin-street, adjoining the Fifth Ward Museum Hotel, last evening.

The Committee who presented a " statement of facts" to the meeting at Richmond on Monday afternoon, say in their address that " It was deemed advisable that such statement should be withheld until the passions and prejudices, excited by the exaggerated reports in circulation, had subsided, and they could obtain a dispassionate hearing.

THE CITY PASSENGER-RAILWAYS IN CITIES.--The great success of the five lines of City Railways in New-York has raised up the Philadelphians to a proper degree of enthusiasm. The fifth line was opened in Philadelphia yesterday, so that the two cities have now the same number. The North American has some interesting items concerning these enterprises:

Launch of the Russian Frigate, Yesterday. The early hour fixed for the launch of this immense ship of war did not catch many people napping, for?? the wide-spread interest which was felt in the event, and the anxiety to witness it, drew one of the largest crowds together that probably ever assembled upon any similar occasion.

SHRIEKS OF LOCALITY.--There is trouble among the Republicans in the Thirtieth Congressional District (Wyoming, Genesee and Allegany Counties) respecting candidates. The nominating Convention met at Warsaw on Friday last, when the Allegany delegates insisted upon renominating the lion. JUDSON W. SHERMAN, who resides in that county.

The Board of Councilmen met on Tuesday, the President, C. H. HASWELL, Esq., in the Chair. WILLIAMSBURG FERRY. Councilman FRAZER moved that counsel report for what reason the injunction obtained by the williamsburg Ferry Company, restraining the Common Council from ordering the advertising of the lease of Peckslip for a ferry, was permitted to go by default Adopted. The following resolution was moved by Councilman DUNN:

DR. BOYNTON'S LECTURES -Dr. BOYNTON delivered the second lecture of his course last night, at the Cooper Institute, to a large and interested audience. The subject was one of uncommon interest, and engaged the profound attention of all present. Our planet was once a melted mass of rock, and melted because of the heat generated by the chemical union and action of the particles of which it is composed.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have not seen your paper of this morning, some more early-rising admirer of your broad sheet having surreptitiously transferred it from the stoop into his own possession, I understand that it contains some reasonable and appropriate remarks upon the ungracious commentaries of the London Times upon the late great celebration in this City, for which, as an abhorer of calumny, you have my thanks.

AN INDEPENDENT CANDIDATE FOR CONGRESS.--The Hon. HENRY W. TAYLOR, of Canandaigua, announces himself a candidate for Congress in the Twenty-sixth District, composed of Ontario, Yates and Seneca Counties. In his address to the electors he declares himself a Republican of the straitest sect in all that regards Slavery.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--BELLINI'S opera of "Somnambala" will be played here to-night for the last time. Mme. GASSIER is seen to great advantagein this opera. BURTON'S THEATRE.--VERDI'S opera of the "Trovatore" was produced here last night to a very good house.

SIMMONS.--In this City, on Monday, Sept. 20, WILLIAM HENRY SIMMONS, in the 29th year of his age. Funeral from Trinity Church, at 1 o'clock, this day, (Wednesday.) Friends and acquaintances are requested to attend, without further invitation. PITCHER.--In this City, at the Astor House,on Friday night, Sept. 17, Major PITCHER, who served in the Mexican war, under Col. Temple. He was a son of the late Lieut. Governor Pitcher.

The Postmaster-General, Attorney-General and Secretary of Treasury have come to an agreement, as yet private, concerning the Post-Office, Court and Custom-House accommodations in Philadelphia. The steamer Waterwitch left for Norfolk to-day, and the Fulton will follow to-morrow morning.

The Royal Mail steamship North Briton, from Liverpool on the 8th inst., at 10 1/2 A. M., arrived at Quebec yesterday morning. The steamship Northern Light, of the Vanderbilt Line, E. L. TINKLEPAUGH, Commander, from Southampton on the 8th, arrived at this port last evening. Through the entire passage she experienced westerly gales.

Staten Island Matters. The Castleton Board of Health, which continues to hold its meetings at the Burns Hotel, met yesterday morning at an early hour. The four gentlemen who look after the health of the town, were present, with their Health-Officer.

THE RIVAL COMMITTEES.-The decision of the Democratic State Convention in favor of the Soft, or Bradley delegates, has been received with great disgust by the partisans of the Hard-Shell Committee, presided over by Judge VANDERBILT. The latter anticipated their opponents by calling their Conventions at an earlier hour, though on the same days.

In another column will be found a letter from Dr. COGSWELL, on the condition and resources of the Astor Library. The amount of positive information in this communication is scarcely commensurate with its extent; but it has many points of interest, notwithstanding, and will be eagerly read by a very large class of people.

The bad news comes to us from beyond the Atlantic, that the Directors at London have announced the cessation of signals through the Telegraphic Cable. No particulars are given. A rumor, however, had obtained currency that the source of interruption was near the shore end; a statement countenanced by

OPENING OF THE FAIR OF THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE.-The Thirtieth Annual Fair of the American Institute had a jolly day for its opening yesterday. The postponement of the opening for a week ought to have afforded time to exhibitors to (occupy their allotted number of inches, but they were dilatory still, and hence the Fair is not what it will be.

CAPT. DE RIVIERE DISCHARGED.--The Court of Special Sessions was crowded, yesterday, by an assemblage brought together by the announcement that the celebrated Capt. DE RIVIERE would be tried on the charge of assault and battery preferred against him by Col. LOUIS GRANT. The Captain was in Court accompanied by his counsel, RICHARD BUSTEED, Esq., all the morning.

My brief letter of the 5th inst. announced my arrival at this point by the Overland Mail route from Great Salt Lake City, but did not give any detailed account of the trip such as may be of interest at least to those who contemplate a journey over land. I propose now to supply the omission. We left the Mormon Zion on Monday morning,

Warren Hose Company, No. 33, numbering 42, men, accompanied by Shelton's Band, left this City on a visit to Philadelphia, in the 11 o'clock train, yesterday morning. Several City Fire companies escorted them to the boat, and the parade was well worth seeing. A cordial welcome, it is said, will be extended to the New-York Company by the Fire Department of the city of "Brotherly Love."

The Washington Union has a story about the Comet (now visible, morning and evening) that tells all that need be known: "Notwithstanding the presence of the moon, which materially diminishes the brilliancy of this celestial visitor, it is quite a conspicuous object, and multitudes of star-gazers are nightly turning their gaze in that direction.

The steamship Niagara, of the Cunard line, from Liverpool on the 11th inst. for Boston, called at Halifax early yesterday morning. Her news is not important. Nothing further in regard to the Atlantic Cable has transpired, though from the fact that the shipment of the heavy shore ends from Plymouth has been countermanded, it is to be presumed the directors regard the accident as serious.

The Detroit Tribune says: "We have learned full particulars of the balloon ascension at Adrian, on Thursday, its subsequent descent, and its second ascension and runaway with the aeronaut while beyond his control. It is a brief narrative, but of thrilling interest: The first ascension took place about 9 o'clock in the morning. It was on the occasion of a large Sunday School celebration at Adrian. The ballon was a very large and well-constructed one,

CONGRESSIONAL INDEPENDENCE.--Curious notions of personal independence prevail at Washington, if the Star is to be taken as authority. That paper of Monday, in the course of an article eulogistic of Mr. LETCHER, of Virginia, says " As JOHN LETCHER goes, so invariably go twenty or thirty gentlemen of different parties, who are sufficiently independent to do what they believe to be right."

The principal Market Places are WASHINGTON DROVE-YARDS, 4TH- STREET; BROWNING'S, on Sixth-Street; CHAMBERLIN'S, on Robinson-street; and O'BRIEN'S, on Sixth-street. Our reports refer to these regular markets. Irregular sales are sometimes made at Bergen Hill, N. J., and from the Hudson River Boats. The great sales day at the Washington Yards is on WEDNESDAY of each week. The reports from all the yards are made up for the providing week to the evening of that day.

LATHAM, of Seneca Falls, in respect to the organization of the above-named Company, if true, discloses a remarkable case of fraud and perjury. It will be recollected that he charged CALEB S. WOODHULL, WALTER BRYANT, STEPHEN M. ALLEN and DANIEL D. BADGER with falsely

MURDEROUS ASSAULT-THREE PERSONS WOUNDED--ESCAPE OF THE ASSAILANT.-- Mrs. Mary Hays, one of the occupants of the large tenemen' house rear of No. 199 Second-street, was assaulted yesterday morning by Geo. Simon and stab: bed several times, receiving such serious injury that her recovery is deemed highly improbable, She was in the yard drawing some water at the hydrant when Simon commenced talking in an abusive manner to her.

There is a want of explanation as the failure of the Atlantic Cable to transmit signals that is anything at all but satisfactory to the public. First, we are informed by telegraph that the Station at Valentia. Bay announced in London on the 6th that communications had ceased. Secondly, the Superintendent at Newfoundland telegraphs to the New-York Directors to-day,

OPENING OF THE NEW JERSEY STATE NORMAL SCHOOL. -- This admirable School opened with over 100 pupils, and this number promises to be considerably increased during the present month. The class of pupils is superior to any former class. More than two-thirds are young women. This School has a most thorough practical and scholastic course of instruction,

The summaries hitherto given of the several treaties just made by the Christian powers with the Emperor of China, have not been full or correct. The secrecy of Russian diplomacy, and the small progress made by the French and British plenipotentiaries, have been sufficient to account for our inaccurate knowledge of their transactions;

At the meeting of the American Pharmaceutical Association in Washington on Thursday, Mr. J. D. BROWNE, of the Patent Office, was announced, and , in conformity with the request to hear him in reference to what the Agricultural Department of the Patent Office is doing for the introduction and naturalization of medicinal and other herbs and plants, proceeded to address the Association.

The business news is as satisfactory as could be expected, after the double crisis, political and commercial, to which they were simultaneously subjected about the beginning of this year. In politics, party spirit runs high, and it is not to be wondered at that some should apprehend a new collision ; a fear that may precipitate the danger, whilst in the meantime it chills the ardor of enterprise.

THE POLICE WITHDRAWN-THE EIGHTH REGIMENT TO BE RELIEVED. The Staten Islanders took a long b?? death yesterday. Their characters having Improved so rapidly under the watch and guard of the Metropolitan Police, that the presence of this formidable body of men within the Qnarantine inclosure was no longer necessary, they were withdrawn.
The Board met at noon yesterday. Applications for permission to being up to the City some cotton from the Kate Stewart and P. D. Wagner were granted. It was resolved that the steamer Black Warrier,

VANITAS VANITATUM.--The Boston papers are chronicling the death of an old man in that city, named FRANCIS, who, after a long life of penuriousness and note-shaving, left a fortune of four millions of dollars. Tile sum is not altogether contemptible, but in these days of millionaires it is not startling, and as the result of nearly eighty-three years devoted to

GARAY.--In this City, on Tuesday, Sept. 21, JOSEPH DE GARAY, a native of Mexico. His funeral will take place this day. (Thursday,) at 2 o'clock, from No. 57 Bleecker-st. The friends and acquaintances of the deceased are respectfully invited to attend, without further notice. LOWERRE.--In this City, on Wednesday morning, Sept. 22, SARAH B., relict of the late William R. Lowerre, in the 83d year of her age.

NEW-YORK POLITICS.--Not long since, President BUCHANAN confessed to a deputation of the Democracy of this City--who waited upon him to solicit his interference--that he was wholly unable to understand New-York polities, and was sorely puzzled what to do in relation to the opposing factions which constitute the Democratic Party of this State.

The Republican Primaries. The Republicans of the City met last evening, between the hours of 6 1/2 and 8 o'clock, in their respective Wards, to elect delegates to the County and Congressional and Assembly Nominating Conventions. Much interest was manifested in the result, and in many of the Wards, two tickets were voted. In the First Ward there was considerable excitement. There was a " Regular" and an " Opposition"

This establishment, which interposes such a perfect barrier between the poor emigrants and the runners and thieves who heretofore enriched themselves by plundering these helpless

JARMAN--BARMORE.--In this City. on Wednesday, Sept. 22, by the Rev. J. Quincy Adams, Mr. Z. H. JARMAN, of Berlin, Maryland, to Miss AMANDA M. BARMORE, eldest daughter of Garret Barmore, Esq., of this City.

A FAMILY CELEBRATION IN MASSACHUSETTS. The Cushman monument, at the Plymouth, was dedicated on Thursday. The bad weather rendered the attendance small, but the exercises were interesting, all those taking part in them being descendants of ROBERT CUSHMAN, the Puritan; prayer by the Rev. RUEL L. CUSHMAN, of Orleans; reading of the Scriptures by the Rev. J. F. CUSHMAN, of Cahaba, Ala.; prayer by Rev. A. S. CUSHMAN, of Orwell, Vt.;

THE PARAGUAY EXPEDITION AND THE CROMWELL STEAMERS.-The steamers of the Cromwell line, which have been chartered by the United States Government for service on the Paraguay expedition, are the Memphis, Atlanta, Caledonia and Westernport. They are each about 500 tons burden, with a sufficient capacity for coal, after the men, provisions and armament are on board, to carry them to Buenos Ayres.

FATAL ACCIDENT.--JOHN LUNNIGAN, a boy 17 years old, was almost instantly killed, yesterday morning, by being run over on tile Long Island Railroad, near the Depot, in Atlantic-street. The deceased was on his way to New-York, and was about to cross the track as a train of cars which had been detached from the locomotive was passing from the funnel into the depot.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. It may be inferred from the statements of E. S. LATHAM, in relation to the Niagara Falls Hydraulic Company, that I had been associated in an attempt to establish a Corporation representing a large capital, when in fact it had none. The following facts will clearly dispel any such idea:

The royal mail steamship Niagara, Capt. MILLER, left Liverpool at 10 1/2 A. M. of the 11th, and arrived at Halifax on the morning of Wednesday, 22d. She reports having had good weather. Sept 11, at 21/2 P.M., passed the Arabia, from New-York, bound in. The steamers City of Washington and Nova Scotian arrived at Liverpool on the evening of the 9th.
