The latter saying has been verified quite recently by the action of the parties belonging to the soi-disant "General Committee" now in possession of Tammany Hall, through the grace of seven Sachems,

The Journal d'Odessa gives some particulars of the reception in that city of M. FERDINAND DE LESSEPS, the projector of the Suez Canal, which, in view of the wide-spread notoriety of the subject, and the stand which several nations have taken with regard to the plan, are not without importance and significance. In describing the ovation to M. DE LESSEPS, the Journal remarks:

Yesterday, at 11 A. M., the investigation into the charge preferred by Gen. NYE against Mr. F. A. TALLMADGE, General Superintendent of Police, for neglect of duty in failing to send a posse of Police to repress the incendiarism at Staten Island, was resumed before the Police Commissioners, all of whom, with the exception of Mayor POWELL and Mayor TIEMANN, were promptly in attendance.

A Paterson paper tells a funny story of a matrimonial adventure that occurred in New-Jersey: We learn that there is a report that a girl by the name of Catharine Maria May was to have been married to Andrew E. Bush, at Yawpough, Bergen Co., on Saturday night, the 4th inst. The company was all assembled and the ceremony about to take place.

From the Daily Advertiser, of yesterday. The examination into the cause of the death of Mrs. ANN M'MAHON, who was murdered on Sunday, was resumed yesterday afternoon, and concluded last evening, by a verdict against JAMES M'MAHOS, as, follows: "We find that the said ANN M'MAHON came to her death on the 19th of September, 1858,

The Paraguay squadron is now on the eve of departure, and the work of preparing for service the fifteen vessels of which it is composed has been done quickly, quietly and well. Though the object of the menacing attitude we are about to assume is to obtain satisfaction for past grievances, there are other considerations which make the expedition one of the most important in character that has ever left these shores.

A telegram from Halifax announces the alarming intelligence of a burning steamship having been seen at sea, some four hundred miles East of Newfoundland. The observers approached near enough to discover that the passengers had abandoned the fated vessel; but beyond a statement that she was large, apparently of American build, with a short bowsprit, and that the engines worked through the upper deck, furnish no clue to her identity.

A SCREW STILL LOOSE.-Notwithstanding the Democratic State Convention resolved the other day, at Syracuse, that the recent vote on the English-Lecompton bill " has removed tile Kansas question from Congress," there still seems to be a little misconception between the Northern and Southern branches of that party on the subject.

DOUGLASS--In this City, on Thursday morning, Sept. 23 JAMES B, DOUGLASS, formerly of Albany, in the 71st year of his age. The friends of the family are requested attend the funeral, from No. 31 West 30th-st., on Saturday next, at 2 P. M., without further invitation.

We learn that the Board of Inquity, which met at Fort Leavenworth to investigate the complaints made by the contractors against Capt. VAN VLIET, A. Q. M., in relation to his inspection and appraisement of the mules, have presented a report signed by Col. ROBERTS and Major GAINES, condemning the conduct of VAN VLIET, and justifying the complaints of the contractors.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: The free use which has been made of my name by a number of the daily and weekly journals, authorizes me in demanding a little of your space for the purpose of making an explanation. I am a Domocrat, and always have been. I am also a member of the General Committee of the Society of Regulars,

I.-- IMPORTANT FROM CHINA--Our Special Correspondence--History of the Negotiation of the American Treaty--Striking picture of Celestial Diplomacy--Interesting Scenes and Incidents. II.--OUR FOREIGN CORRESPONDENCE--London--Paris--St. Petersburg--Havana,
ANOTHER FLICKER FROM THE CABLE.--At the very moment our hopes of the Atlantic Telegraph were flickering in the socket, the enterprise flares up again, and promises to renew its early splendor.

From the Boston Traveller. The case of Capt. TOWNSEND, of the slave brig Echo, (captured on the coast of Cuba by the United States brig Dolphin, with three hundred and eighteen negroes on board,) will come up according to assignment before United States Commissioner LORING tomorrow. The only witnesses in the case, in addition to Lieut. MAFFIT, are the officers and crew of the Dolphin.

ANOTHER FEMALE EQUESTRAIN PERFORMANCE--MORE SUCCESSFUL THAN THE UNION COURSE AFFAIR.--The ninth Fair of the Ohio State Board of Agriculture, now open at Cincinnati, has added to its attractions by getting up a Female Equestrian Convention, which appears to have been managed, unlike the affair at the Union Course, in a respectable fashion. The race was the finale of the show.

A POCKET-BOOK DROPPER IN LIMBO.-GEORGE BOWER, of No. 88 White-street, while walking through Greenwich-strect, about 7 o'clock this (Thursday) morning, was accosted by one HIBAM LEWIS, who dropped at his (BOWER'S) feet a pocket-book, stuffed with $100 bills on the City Trust and Banking Company, and some pieces of metal representing gold coin.

The Grand Lodge of the United States, I. O. O. F., representing the great Brotherhood of Odd Fellows of the United States, yesterday commenced the holding of their annual sessions at the Odd Fellows' Hall, Baltimore. The body received the report of the Committee on Credentials; and, after this, heard the report of the Grand Secretary, which, after some preliminary matters, gives the condition of the Order throughout the jurisdiction of the Grand Lodge.

The Springfield Republican makes the following report of an interesting case under the usury laws, just tried in that city before Judge Bigelow of the Supreme Court: "Mr. Charles Ely, of New-York and West Springfield, resisted the payment of notes to the amount of $5,000, discounted by the Hadley Falls Bank of Holyoke, on the ground that the Bank took usurious interest to the amount in gross of $12 50.

The Educational Convention which assembled here during the present week, net in Ely's Hall, on Tuesday, Sept. 14, at 2 o'clock, P.M., and was called to order by the President, the Hon. H. H. VAN DYCK, Superintendent of Public Instruction. At the first roll-call thirty-eight District Commissioners and City Superintendents answered to their names.

TERRIBLE ACCIDENT AT THE OHIO STATE FAIR.--The enjoyment of those visiting the Ohio State Fair, now being held at Sandusky City, was sadly marred by an accident last week. A large number of persons had collected outside of a ring, formed by posts with a single board nailed across, in which a class of horses were being shown through their paces.

TWO SUICIDES IN CINCINNATI.--The Cincinnati Enquirer has the following: "A German, named CONRAD HIRSCH OF EACH, living on the Harrison Turnpike, who had been drinking during the morning, suddenly left his companions about 10 o'clock yesterday, and crossing into an adjacent field, draw a pistol from his pocket, and placing it against his left temple, pulled the trigger.

NEW-YORK PRISON ASSOCIATION.--The regular monthly meeting of the above Association was held last evening at 71/2 o'clock, at the residence of JOHN H. GRISCOM, M, D., No. 42 East Twenty-ninth-street, Madison-avenue.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. You have done me great injury by the statement contained in your paper of the 20th inst., connecting any name with the charge against Mr. ALLEN. The following is a correct statement of my connection with the matter:

THE EMPIRE STEAM STONE-DRESSING WORKS DESTROYED LOSS $80,000--FORTY WORKMEN THROWN OUT OF EMPLOYMENT. A fire broke out shortly after 6 o'clock last evening in the planing-mill adjoining the large building occupied by the Stone-Dressing Company, (MASTERSON SMITH,) foot of East Thirtieth-street, near the First-avenue.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. As we believe you prefer to give the ?? truth, rather than fiction, though less romantic, you will please correct some essential errors in year statement of the "Late shooting case in Twenty-seventh-street."

The trial of HENRY W. BOWYER for shooting JAMES McDOWELL, Sr., which has been in progress at Fincastle, Va., was terminated on Thursday last, the eight day of the examination, by the acquittal of the prisoner. The provocation to the shooting, it will be remembered, was the alleged seduction by McDOWELL who was a man advanced in years, of BOWYER'S insane daughter.

From the Richmond South, Saturday. About sunrise yesterday morning a duel was fought in a retired spot, just beyond Fairfield Race Course, between Mr. O. JENNINGS WISE, one of the editors of the Richmond Enquirer, and the Hon, SHERRARD CLEMENS, Representative in Congress from the Wheeling district in this State.

From the St. Louis Democrat. Our correspondent at the Illinois Fair, at Centralia, acquaints us with the following most thrilling occurrence: Mr. G. W. BROOKS, of this city, an aeronant of considerable distinction, was advertised to make an ascension from a spot contingent to the Fair grounds, on Friday evening, after the closing exercises of the Fair.

From the Albany Statesman. The mounting of a Meridian Circle and Transit instrument at the Observatory in this city, under the superintendence of Dr. B. A. GOULD, Jr., has, as the public are a ware, occupied many months, and is not yet finished.

Surveyor HART and JAMES B. CRAIG, Clerk to Collector SCHELL, arrived here last evening, and had a long interview to-day with the President and Secretary COBB touching the Custom-House difficulties. They came, I understand, to effect a compromise. It is proposed to examine closely the work of all the Custom-House officers, and remove such us may be detected in errors.

As the firemen's procession (on the occasion of the reception of the New-York visitors) was passing Twelfth and Fitzwater streets, yesterday afternoon, the Washington Engine Company was attacked by a party who threw bricks and stones. Three shots were fred from a pistol in the hands of a man, who is alleged to have taken deliberate aim from behind a tree.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am uncomfortably situated, and want your advice as to the best mode of setting myself right. I bought two lots of ground up-town and built myself a house thereon to my own taste, wishing to have a little bit of a garden.

The members of the New-York Caledonian Club, composed of natives of Scotland, resident in this City, could not have selected a more delightful day for their annual out-door recreations than they had yesterday. In the morning, when the Club, which had assembled at 7 A.M. at the Mercer House, arrived within the inclosure on your right-hand side as you enter Jones'

In New-York, during the past week, Wool has been more sought after, chiefly by manufacturers; and with light supplies of attractive lots, available prices have been sustained. Dealers halve filled most of the orders-and on this account, the business with receivers has not been heavy.

Two Sing Sing convicts, named ANDERSON Thorp, an Wednesday, while at work with other in a potato field near half a mile from the prison, fled form their keeper, a Mr. LOWE, and succeeded, by leaping fences and secreting themselves in corn-fields and the covert of the woods, in eluding their pursuers.

A TAX-PAYERS' PARTY.- One of the latest absurdities is the talk of organizing a "Tax-payers' Party" in this City, to counteract the corruptions and rasealities which have been so long practiced by all sorts of municipal officials. Every man who is not a pauper is a tax-payer ; he pays taxes on every article he consumers.

THE ELECTIVE FRANCHISE.-It is an unquestionable fact that one-third of our legal voters care too little about their right of suffrage to exercise it. They stay at home on election day, and thus allow others to rule them. Yet the same me men would fight to the death in defence of what they thus neglect.

We learn that Father DE SMET has received a dispatch from Washington. requesting him to join General HARNEY at New-York, as chaplain to the army in Oregon. Apart from all considerations of a religious or spiritual character, there is eminent propriety in the selection of Father DE SMET for this position.

MAN KILLED IN SELF-DEFENCE.--The Cincinnati Enquirer says: "Near Ironton, Ohio, on Monday of last week, two men named NASH and GUTHRIE, who had had a previous difficulty, growing out of a lawsuit, met at the house of a justice to have a new trial. NASH went there armed with a rifle and revolver, persistently threatening to shoot GUTHRIE if he made his appearance.

The investigation of the charge of arson, preferred against Messrs. JOHN C. THOMPSON and ??AY TOMPKINS, growing out of the burning of the Quara??tine Hospitals, was not resumed yesterday according to adjournment.

Summer departs from us most pleasantly. The God of Gladness sheds his parting smile on us with a benevolence that really does him credit. Yet a few hours, and the Summer of 1858 will be with all the other Summers that have been. On the 23d, at 3h. 40m. A.M., the Sun will enter Libra, getting into the Seales, as it were, and then Autumn begins with us.

THE ENGINES AND MACHINERY FOR THE NEW NAVAL STEAMERS.--The Board of Engineers appointed by the Secretary of the Navy, a few days ago, to examine the proposals for building and putting on board the engines and machinery for the new propeller sloops of the act of Congress, passed at its recent session, are rapidly drawing their labors to a close. It is probable they will make their report in a few days.

On this day, twelve years ago, the Mexican Army, at Monterey, under General AMPUDIA, surrendered to General TAYLOR. The battle of Monterey was one of the most brilliant and severely-fought battles of the war with Mexico.

The steamship Austria, from Hamburg ??id Southampton, 4th inst., has not yet been heard from. Her consignees (Messrs. KUNHARDT Co., of No. 62 Beavcr-street) have received information of her leaving Southampton on the above date. We find the following list of the Austria's passengers in the Handel Zeitung, of this city.

A FUSION MOVEMENT.--A movement is on foot in Brooklyn, having for its object a union of the distracted elements of the Democratic Party. Prominent and influential Democrats have the matter in charge and it is now determined that a mass meeting of the people shall be called some time next week which will do away with both Vanderbilt and Bradley Committees, and wipe out all of the nominations made under them.

SICKNESS AT FORT McHENRY.--Our information from the Fort is that there are several persons on the sick list,. with various complaints ; that the police of the Fort is perfect and the hygienic supervision complete. Not an unpleasant odor can be dedetected ; lime and chloride of lime have been freely used during the Summer, and the eye can discover nothing which could offered or be thought to engender disease.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--ROSSINI'S great opera of "William Tell" will be produced here to-night, with a splendid caste. It has gone through a series of very careful reliearsals, and will be presented with great completeness. In the ballet Mile, LAMOUREUX, Signora GALLETTE, Signor PRATESI, and other leading members of the Ronzial ballot troupe will appear.

Now that we are embarked upon another canvass, it may be interesting to look back to the origin of our State Government for the purpose of seeing who have filled the office of Governor. Our first Chief Magistrate, GEORGE CLINTON, was chosen in 1777, and until 1822 the term was three years instead of two, as it has since been.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is astonishing to observe the general apathy that pervades the community in respect to the manner in which this great work is being constructed. I have watched it closely from the beginning, and have hoped that some one abler than myself would step forward and give an expose of the whole matter.

To the Chief Engineer of the Orange Fire Department: HONORED CHIEF: We have successfully tested the "Jersey lightning" which you did us the honor to send. The first message sent over the wires was met by the quick response "give us more of the same sort, but send us no more reports."

Col. Samuel Williams, President of the Commercial and Agricultural Bank of Galveston, and one of the oldest citizens of Texas, died at his residence near Galveston, on the evening of the 13th. He was one of the leading spirits of the Texas revolution, and, in conjunction with Thos. F. McKinney, did more to furnish means to carry on the war than any other party.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : Now that the Aldermen have repealed the law forbidding the use of steam in the Fourth-avenue tunnel, I think it is a proper time to urge the adoption of a plan which I am confident will meet the reasonable requirements of all parties, including the travelers on the railroads, who are entitled to more consideration than has been given them.

A telegram, dated yesterday, at Trinity Bay, announces that signals had been resumed at that end of the cable, three days before, in all their pristine energy. It was thought the line would be ready for public service in a few weeks at farthest. By an arrival at Philadelphia we have dates from Rio Janeiro to the 14th of August.

FREEMAN--CONKLIN.--In this City, on Thursday, Sept. 23, at the 18th-st. M. E. Church, by the Bev. J, Poisal, Mr. LEWIS C. FREEMAN, of Vicksburg, Miss., To miss M. ANTOINETTE CONKLIN, daughter of J. W. Conklin, of this City.

He says: "As soon as the cross had been dedicated and was about being raised, there appeared on the blue sky,

The Co?? Council referred the papers to the Committee of Wharves, Piers, and Slips, viz: Aldermen HOPPMIRE, MURRAY and STARR; and Councilmen BICKFORD, ??MIN T. RODER and JOHN BRADY.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. An article in the Tribune of Yesterday, so totally misrepresents my position with reference to Mr., JOHN KELLY, that I consider myself called upon to notice it, and will correct its misstatements in as few words as possible.

Next to the positive novelty of an opera entirely new, the freshest work at the command of a management is undoubtedly "William Tell," The peculiarity of its construction and the vast resources it calls into play, place it beyond the reach of a mean company, and even with the best of aids it demands a wearisome amount of rehersal, which can seldom be bestowed on it.

The Rev. WILLIAM CATHCART, of Second Baptist Church in Philadelphia, has Issued a sermo?? against Union Prayer Meetings, now so popular. He warns the members of his own sect against them. He deprecates the idea that his flock should ever sit down to the table of the Lord with " unbaptized Christians, "as he calls the Episcopalians, Dutch Reformed and others.

A story about the "Dauphin". WILLIAMS appears in the Buffalo Commercial, to the effect that, many years ago, the reverend gentleman applied to an Oneida Soothsayer, to know whether his claims would be acknowledged, and when. The prophet told him that the time would come when they would be admitted, should WILLIAMS live long enough.

From the Charleston Mercury. DANIEL S. DICKINSON, when the contest arose in Congress in 1850-52, on the Wilmot Proviso, and the exclusion of the South from California, stood firm for the rights of the South.

From the Sun of Friday. The western quarter of the city on Wednesday night was the scene of an affray, the result of which was the instant killing of police officer BENJAMIN BENTON, of the Western District, by a shot from a pistol in the hands of a man named HENRY GAMBRILL, the keeper of a public house on Franklin-street, near Howard-street.

GEORGE HALL, of Brooklyn, EGBERT BENSON, New-York, and ORADIAH BROWN, of Staten Island, Commissioners for the removal of quarantine, convened here today for the purpose of presenting a plan for the removal of Quarantine to Governor KING, the Lieutenant-Governor and the Comptroller, who have supervision over the selection of a site.

Fair of Queens County Agricultural Society. This annual festival, which occurred at Flushing the present week, was the most largely attended and most successful one ever held in the county, or on Long Island. Several persons who have attended exhibitions in different counties throughout the State, expressed the opinion that they had never seen so large a gathering at any county show.

THE FOURTH WARD WIFE-MURDER.--The inquisition in the case of Mrs. Mary McIntyre, who was murdered by her husband, Michael McIntyre, on Thursday morning, at No. 62 James-street, came of yesterday at the New-York Hospital, before Coroner HILLS.

The death of JOSE DE GARAY, as already announced, took place suddenly, in this City, on the 21st inst. Senor GARAY was a native of Mexico, and was born on the 21st day of September, 1801, and died, having attained the age of 57 years, upon the anniversary of his birthday. He was descended from one of the most distinguished families of Spain, and has occupied many important post in his country.

QUARANTINE AT BOSTON.-It is getting too late in the season for Boston to run an opposition to New-York on the score of Quarantine. Judging from the frequent mention of yellow fever vessels at anchor near Deer Island during the last two months, our Boston neighbors have been fully as careful of their health as we leave.

Rich, senior officer of the Marine Corps on the Sabine. He testified that on the 2d of September, about four o'clock in the afternoon, when on board the vessel,

From the National Intelligencer. Among the different routes and means of communication by which it is proposed to shorten the distance between the Atlantic and Pacific portions of the Union, a wagon road across the Isthmus of Tehnantepec, as preparatory, we believe, to the completion of a railway, has long attracted the speculative enterprise of individual capitalists,

Although the Hon. D. S. DICKINSON was remorselessly slaughtered by the Softs at Syracuse, he finds some sympathy in South Carolina. An article which we copy from the Charleston Mercury not only does him justice as a supporter of "The Constitutional rights of the South on the subject of Slavery," but touchingly bewails the fate to which his course has consigned him.

The Third Division of the Massachusetts Militia has been encamped, for military drill and exercise, at Camp Wool, in Springfield, whither Gov. BANKS went on Thursday to make a speech. The following passage from his address puts the militia-man in a strong light, making guns and sabres rather attractive than otherwise: "The school of the soldier has still stronger claims upon the public as a means of rational amusement and manly exercise.

THE MYSTERY OF THE ATLANTIC CABLE.-- Ever since the first announcement of the landing of the Telegraph Cable at Trinity Bay was made, the whole subject has been involved in mystery, and the public have never been fairly and candidly informed of the actual condition of things at the two telegraphic stations.

To the Associated Press: Accompanying this I beg to hand you copies of recent communications from tile honorary directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Company and myself to Mr. DE SAUTY, tile chief electrician at the Trinity Bay Office. Mr. DE SAUTY's answers swill be furnished for publication without unnecessary delay.

ELECTION FOR ALDERMEN.--Messrs. NATHANIEL BOYD and SAMUEL SMITH, Democrats, were elected Aldermen to fill vacancies in the Council of Hudson City at the recent special election. The Democratic vote was 138? Opposition, 37. ATTEMPTED SELF-DESTRUCTION--A German, named JOHN SWANCE, residing in South First-street, attempted to shuttle off his mortal coil on Thursday.

ADVICE FROM OHIO.--The Cincinnati Gazette makes the following suggestion in relation to the failure of the Republican and American State Conventions to unite: "If we mistake not, the hand of certain prominent politicians is quite too clearly seen in this intrigue for their own good. The people will remember those who have so zealously labored to thwart their will.

The fresh exposure of frauds in the financial department of the City Government is exciting, as usual, great indignation, and the thieves and peculators of the City Hall are receiving their quarterly castigation on all sides. Highminded and honorable men, as usual, are solemnly invoked to take office and save us, and decent voters are being solemnly exhorted to go to the polls.

Some of the Republican and American journals still think it worth while to inquire who was to blame for the failure to unite those parties at Syracuse. The failure of the Atlantic Cable is the prominent topic of the Press. The Times' City Article of Wednesday, the 8th inst., says: "Nothing fresh has transpired with regard to the Atlantic Telegraph. There is still communication through the whole length of the cable, but only of the faintest and most uncertain kind.

EAST THIRTEENTH-STREET--At 6 1/4 o'clock, on Friday evening, a fire broke out in the stable in the rear of No. 213 East Thirteenth-street, owned by PATRICK BEGAN, and occupied by THOMAS RILEY, who had four horses in it at the discovery of the fire; but, fortunately, they were rescued before the flames made much progress. The total damage will amount to $100, on which there is no insurance.

At the very moment we learn from the China Seas of the spread of Russian authority to the very foot of the Great Wall, come the tidings of a corresponding movement toward the west. The port of Villafranca, upon the shore of shore of Piedmont, within a dozen miles of the French frontier, has been leased for a term of twenty-two years, from the Sardinian Government, as a Russian naval depot.

Before Judge Davies. Jonathan Peel vs. James Sutton Elliott.--This case came up again this morning, when the counter affidavits from the plaintiff's side were read. At the suggestion of the Judge the controversy was reduced to one point, and a day was fixed for the argument thereon, namely, whether an agent being employed by a principal to receive and disburse moneys for a particular and specified purpose,

Republican Congressional Conventions. THIRD DISTRICT - The Republican Congressional Convention for the Third District,-embracing the First, Second, Third, Fifth and Eighth Wards,-met last evening at the Fifth Ward Hotel, corner of Franklin-street and West Bradway.

The Rev. Dr. BELLOWS last evening delivered,very impressively and with the close attention of his audience throughout,-the following sermon, at All Soul's Church, in Fourth-avenue: I propose, this evening, to repeat the substance of an Address, given on Friday last, at the laying of the corner-stone of the New-York Inebriate Asylum.

On Friday last the corner-stone of the abovenamed institution was laid at Binghamton. It is intended, as its name imports, for the cure of drunkards. There are thousands in the State in every walk of life who, having become slaves to their appetite for strong drink, would gladly break their chains if they could.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: Please acknowledge receipt of the following additional contributions for the relief of the Yellow-Fever patients under the care of the Young Men's Christian Association, New-Orleans. The funds have been paid over by telegraph, as received, that the Association might have the use of them at the earliest moment;

Official advices were received yesterday from Governor DENVER of Kansas, giving a detailed account of the condition of Indian matters in that Territory. He makes no mention of an intention to resign his present office, nor has he expressed a wish to resume the duties of Commissioner of Indian Affairs here.

RETURN OF WARREN HOSE Co. No. 33.-Warren Hose Co. No. 33 returned on Saturday night, from Philadelphia, where they have been enjoying large hospitalities. As it was understood the expected Company would arrive in the 9 1/2 O'clock train from Philadelphia, the various companies which intended to join in the procession, assembled at or in the vicinity of the Jersey City Ferry, where the line was to be formed.

Should the views therein set forth meet with your approval,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-ROSSIN'S grand opera of " William Tell" will be played here to-night for the second time. It is not often that works of this importance are given, even In the principal cities of Europe. They require a vast amount of preparation, and involves much additional expense, for extra artists, musicians, ballet dancers, ,

NEW-YORK RACES-FASHION COURSE, L. I.The running which commences to-day is the principal topic of conversation in the sporting circles of the Union. At the present moment the prospect is line. As the merits of the various horses which are booked on as likely to represent the different States interested are freely canvassed opinions differ widely in these matters, and lead to high betting on the various points presented.

The dispatch from Halifax touching the burning steamer seen on the 15th instant, is regarded as strongly confirmatory of the impression already so generally felt, tha the lost steamer is none other than the Hamburg steamer Austria, which left Hamburg on the lost instant, with 420 passengers, and Southampton on the 4th, where she received 40 more in the steerage.

From the St. Louis Democrat. The Wyandotte (Kansas) Gazette, of the 18th. says: "Yesterday $10,000 in gold dust arrived from Pike's Peak. One man brought in $6,000 as the result of a few week's work. A small boy had $1,000, which he says 'he dug down and found,' and the little fellow says 'he can get all he wants.'

According to public announcement, the Church recently occupied by a Society of Baptists in the Fifth-avenue, corner of Thirty-fifth-street, was opened for divine service yesterday morning, according to the rites of the Reformed Church of England.

FATAL ACCIDENT.-An Inquest was held, yesterday, at the City Hospital, upon the body of HUGH N. MANNERS, who was killed by being run over by a Hudson River Railroad car, at the corner of West and Canal streets, and instantly killed as already reported. The evidence showed the occurrence to be accidental, and a verdict to that effect was rendered.
The steamship General Rusk, Capt. DENISON, from Brazos Santiago, via Indianoia, arrived this morning, bringing $99,625.49 in specie.

A MOTHER MURDERING HER, FOUR CHILDREN AND COMMITTING SUICIDE. The Columbus (O.) Statesman gives the particulars of a horrible tragedy which was noted in our telegrams a day or two ago: "Our citizens were shocked 'yesterday morning by a rumor that a horrible tragedy had occurred near Grove City, a village about nine miles from this place,

From the London Saturday Review. The history of the last quarter of a century gives tile measure of the political importance which belongs to the Atlantic cable, Not a single difficulty has arisen with tile United States during all that time which might not have been readily obviated, or rapid ly removed, if such a mode of communication had existed.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. It is no longer a matter of doubt that Cotton can be largely cultivated in Central Africa. The Rev, T. J. BOWEN, the indefatigable missionary and explorer of that region, has set this question at rest. Not only is Cotton of a superior quality grown there, but it is so well adapted to that soil that it springs up spontaneously.

1. Action (or motion) depends upon the expansibility of electricity, which pervades all things. 2. This expansibility s due to heat, solar or artificial. (induced.) 3. Non-action (or immobility) is caused by the contractibility of electricity. 4. This contraction is due to the absence of heat--in other words, to cold.

A MYSTERY SOLVED.--On Thursday afternoon. considerable excitement was created in the vicinity of Pier No. 11, East River, by the discovery of the corpse of a woman, in a large packing-box, (marked "W." in a diamond.) which bad been placed in the hold of the bark Charles C. Fomler, bound hence for Mobile. The disagreeable stench from the box, ?? to an examination of its contents.

The intelligence received on Saturday evening, by telegraph from Halifax, leaves no room to doubt that the burning steamship, an account of which had been previously reported, was, as we have assumed must be the case, the Austria, which left Southampton on the 4th instant.

There is considerable excitement in the Barley market, with little offering on the spot; the samples shown on 'Change, to-day, were almost entirely of parcels to arrive. The Western and Canada markets have advanced their views on Barley; at Montreal, the quotations range from 80c. to 90c.; at Geneva, 90c. @c. @95c.;

We announced, some days ago, that the double-headed English mission at Washington would shortly end, with the departure of one of its chiefs for CentralAmerica. We are now enabled to disclose the object of Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELEY'S prolonged residence in the National Capital-a residence that has given rise to so many and such varied speculations among our statesmen and politicians.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The benches on Boston Common are covered with sheet-iron. Not because the loungers who frequent that spacious park are more addicted to whittling than the loungers who frequent our Washington square and Union -place, but because the "sold men of Boston" have more consideration and tact than our City Fathers, who leave the benches in these beautiful retreats totally unprotected.

First District.-The First District Republican Convention met Saturday evening at No. 19 Beekmanstreet, but adjourned without making any nomination. Second District.-This Convention met at the Republican head- quarters in William-street, but adourned over without making a nomination.

To the Editors of the Washington Union: As the Capitol extension approaches completion, the attention of those interested in art is turning towards its walls in the hope of seeing the prominent incidents of our national history, and the deeds of the fathers and sustainers of the country, worthily recorded in its many panels and niches.

THE BOUNDARY SURVEY BETWEEN MEXICO AND THE UNITED STATES--The Department of the Interior is now engaged in dispatching the party to make this survey. It is expected that they will reach Indianola, Texas, about the 15th of October, and leave San Antonio about the first week in November for the Rio Grande, near El Paso.

The bark Arabian, which fell in with the burning steamer on the 15th inst., and whose arrival has been so anxiously looked for with the expectation that she would bring more definite news of the lost steamer, reached Halifax on Saturday morning.

To the editor of the New-York Times: You are correct in your remarks on the " Staten Island Rioters," but is it not a sad commentary on our institutions and the moral instinct of our people, to say that twelve man cannot be found amongst us who will agree that crime shall be punished?

MAIL COMMUNICATION WITH EUROPE.--From the finance branch of the General Post-Office many important facts on the subject of emigration to and through the vast extent of our American States and Territories may annually be gathered. The extent and importance of until communication between the old and the new worlds is in every quarter abundantly evidenced.

PLYMOUTH CHURCH.-The number of people who desire to attend public worship in this Church is so large that it is found impossible to accommodate them. Hundreds go away every Sabbath unable to enter, and hundreds more would be glad to worship there if they could procure seats.

Among the legacies bequeathed by Mayor WOOD to the City, as tokens of his four years' reign, is this great suit against the Metropolitan Police Commissioners, brought by the members of the old force, who were induced by his advice and promises to resist the authority of the new Commissioners.

CHARGE OF BIGAMY.--Saml. Morris, A Hebrew. about 30 years of age, was arrested a few days since, charged with stealing wearing apparel, , from the house of Mrs. Schrimer, No. 93 St. Mark's place, and from that of Mrs. Wardell, No. 19 Stuyvesant-street, to both of which places he formerly boarded. A silk visite, which was part of the stolen property, was found on the person of his wife.
From the Rochester Union, 24th. The investigation of ALBRO'S stupendous scheme of bounty land-warrant forgeries continues to-day at the Supreme Court-room, before the United States Commissioner.

The Bremen screw-steamship Hudson, G. WENKE, commander, having left Bremen at 6 1/2 P. M. on the 11th September, arrived at this port on Sunday morning, making the passage in fourteen days and four and a half hours. She brings 164 passengers and 400 tons of cargo.

The Light Guard, Captain GARLAND, are an independent corps no longer, but Company A, Seventy-first Regiment, as will be noticed from the annexed Special Order from General Head-quarters: SPECIAL ORDERS--NO. 168. GENERAL HEAD-QUARTERS, STATE OF NEW-YORK, ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE, ALBANY, Sept. 16, 1858.

Some curious changes in trade are noted by the Boston Transcript: Last Spring we received from the ports of Baltimore and Philadelphia large quantities of apples. Now we are sending to these places thousands of bushels. It is fortunate that the apple-crop in the New-England State promises a larger return than for three or four years.

LIGHTNING AT SEA.-The Salem Register states that the schooner Sarah Burton, of Plymouth, Capt. HASKINS, which arrived at Salem on Tuesday from Para, reports that on the 8th of September, at 3 A.M., lat. 26?? 49', lon. 60??, she experienced a severe tempest and was struck by lightning four times-twice on the foremast, once on the mainmast and once on the jibboom-all in the space of half an hour.

NEVINS.--In this City, on Saturday, Sept. 25, Mr. CHRISTOPHER NEVINS, of consumption, aged 32 years and 1 months. His friends and relatives are invited to, attend his funeral, at the residence of his brother, No. 266 7th st., this day, (Monday,) at 1 1/2 o' clock P. M. Newburg papers please copy. JUST.--In this City, on Saturday, Sept. 25, JEMIMA, Wife of John Just, aged 42 years.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The public buildings of New-York ought to be imposing anti beautiful. The City of New-York owes something to her own rank and dignity, and something to the arts. If the public buildings of a city are of a high order, the growing city will spring up in better taste.

A very general feeling of disappointment was occasioned here some days ago by the announcement that regular communications through the Oceanic Cable had been interrupted.; and it is not too much to say that the eye of every reader of the daily press throughout the Kingdom, has every morning since looked first in quest for further tidings on the subject.

An inquisition was commenced Saturday morning, at Bellevue Hospital, by Coroner CONNERY, in the case of Mrs. SOPHIA STEPHENS, alleged to have been poisoned by her husband, JAMES STEPHENS, about a year ago. But few persons were present. After the impanneling of a jury, the two sisters, SOPHIA and FANNY BELL, neices of the deceased, upon whose affidavit, before Justice WELSH, STEPHENS was arrested were examined.

We are enabled at last to understand the cause of Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELEY's prolonged residence in Washington, while holding the title of "Her Britannic Majesty's Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary on a special mission to the Republic of Central America."

The alarm of the Staten Islanders on account of sporadic cases of yellow fever outside the Quarantine walls, which had almost been lost sight of in the excitement attending the destruction of the Hospitals has broken out anew within a day or two by the report of three other cases at Vanderbilt's Landing. A blacksmith named QUINN, with his two children, are said to be the victims.

Mrs. HARBIET BEECHER STOWE is not in Europe, but has been residing quietly at her home in Andover for a year and a half past. We are authorized to say that the lady has not been ??ted in Paris, for the reason that she was not in Paris when somebody who took her name was ??ted ; nor is she preparing a book on Normandy, as the English papers insist upon reporting.

The painful suspense concerning the fate of the steamship Austria is at length relieved, but with the positive intelligence which comes to us, the community are thrilled with horror at the details of one of the most dreadful disasters upon record. The following dispatch was among the first that came over the line from Halifax yesterday morning:

Since the defeat of the Binghamton programme at Syracuse, Mr. FERNANDO WOOD seems at last to have become convinced that your City is unworthy any further attention--too obtuse, in fact, even to "prize and appreciate him" as his sensitive nature requires. He, therefore, came on here as an applicant for some foreign post ; but hearing of the resignation of Governor RICHARDSON, has set himself up as candidate for the Governorship of Nebraska.

The inquest in the case of Mrs. SOPHIA STEVENS, alleged to have been poisoned by her husband, JAMES STEVENS, was resumed yesterday by Coroner CONNERY, at 10 1/2 A.M., at the Bellevue Hospital. The two sisters, SOPHIA and FANNY BELL, were present during the fore part of the day, but left about noon, to attend the examination in the case of the husband of the deceased, pending before Justice WELSH,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- In consequence of the indisposition o Signor STEFANI, ROSSINI'S opera of "William Tell" had to be postponed last evening. "Lucia" was substituted, with Signor MACCAFERRI as the Edgardo. "William Tell" is announced for Wednesday. NIBLO'S SALOON. -- Mr. STEPHEN MASSETT will give his second entertainment at this place to-night.

The races over the Fashion Course, Long Island, commenced yesterday, with the entries advertise for Friday last, but postponed on account of the unfavorable weather of that day. The published programme gave promise of an entertainment of usual interest. and, as the weather was all that could be desired, the attendance was very large.

It being now judicially settled that a returned Californian may assault and battery--pugnis et calcibus--any member of a San Francisco Vigilance Committee for the sum of $250, we shall expect to witness frequent demonstrations in hotels and public places similar to the attack of Mr. MULLIGAN on Capt. WEBB.

CYRES W. FIELD, New-York: I have arrived here on my way to Bay of Bulps Arm, with instruments and regulations to test the cable in concert with Valentia. Good and regular currents from Newfoundland were received up to the day I left Valentia, (the 12th inst.) but no words had been received since the 2d inst. The testing shows a loss of insulation three miles from Valentia,

The steamship Prince Albert, Capt. WATERS, from Galway at midnight of the 14th instant, arrived off Halifax harbor at 10 o'clock on Saturday night, and reached her dock at 9 o'clock Sunday morning. She reports having met with a succession of heavy gales for the first few days of her passage.

GOLD IN KANSAS.--That gold is found in Western Kansas can no longer be doubted ; and there is good reason to believe in quantities sufficiently great to render mining remunerative. Pike's Peak--which is the centre and landmark of the diggings--is about five hundred miles almost due West from Leavenworth City.

COMMON COUNCIL--THE WATER WORKS.--The Board of Aldermen, after a recess of nearly two months, reassembled for business last evening. After the usual introductory business had been disposed of Alderman DOUGLASS called for the report of the Water Committee, on the subject of altering the contract for constructing an open canal east of Baisley's Pond, so as to have a covered conduit instead thereof.

LONDON MONEY MARKET. The English Funds had been firm, and Consols had advanced to 97 1/4@97 3/8 for Money, and 97 3/8@97 1/2 for Account--closing firmly. The prospect is, that in the course of a fortnight or three weeks the Bullion in the Bank of England will have again have attained the point reached in March, which was the highest attained for a period of five years.

Our worst fears with regard to the fate of the passengers and crew of the steamship Austria are more than realized. Out of five hundred and sixty persons on board, only sixty-seven are believed to have been saved! The ship caught tire in the steerage, while being fumigated with burning tar on the 13th instant, in latitude 45[degrees] 01, longitude 41[degrees] 30',

In compliance with orders from the commanding officer of the First Division New-York State Militia, the Sixth Regiment, (Governor's Guards,) Col. Jos. C. PINCKNEY, went to Staten Island, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of relieving the Eighth Regiment, which has been on duty there for a couple of weeks past.

The news received yesterday of the destruction of the steamer Austria by fire proved more terrible than had been anticipated, fearful as the apprehensions were which the first intelligence of the disaster awakened.

COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH.--The Board met at noon yesterday. Present Drs. THOMPSON, ROCKWELL and MILLER. The Mayor was too ill to attend, owing to an attack of neuralgia. The schooner A. P. Howe, from Havana, was allowed a permit to come up eight days after discharging.

JUST.--In this City, on Saturday, Sept. 25, JEMIMA, wife of John Just, aged 42 years. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, from her late residence, No. 31 West 37th-st., on Wednesday, the 29th inst., at 2 P. M CROCHERON.--In this City, on Monday evening, Sept. 27, of chronic dysentery. NICHOLAS CROCHERON, aged 51 years, 5 months and 9 days. 9 days.

A QUESTION TO BE ANSWERED.--Do the people of this State intend to have a new Constitution next year? This question will be asked at the polls on the 2d of November. How many of the voters are prepared to deposit in the ballot-box an intelligent well-considered answer? We venture to say not one in five hundred.

Last night, in the Cooper Institute, the Republicans of the City and County of New-York met, pursuant to advertisement, to express their approval of the candidates recently nominated for State Officers by the Republican Convention at Syracuse. The platform was occupied by the appointed officers of the meeting, the Hon. JOHN W. EDMONDS presiding.

The English Founds continue steadily to improve. The Railway-Share Market has shown increased activity, mainly from numberous speculative purchases, and a further general advance has taken place. The final prices on the Paris Bourse this evening show a further rise of nearly 1/2 per cent. Gold is at about the same Price in Paris and London.

Governor DENVER, writing to the Secretary of Interior, Sept. 17, says that late news from Pike's Peak leaves no room to doubt the correctness of the reported discoveries of gold in that vicinity. The explorers have found gold on the Arkansas, on the beads of the Kansas, and on the South Fork of the Platte River, embracing an extent of country of more than three hundred miles.

The Republican County Convention, composed of five delegates from each Ward association, met, last evening, at the Republican head-quarters, No. 618 Broadway. Mr. EDGAR KETCHUM, of the Twelfth Ward, called the Convention to order, and moved the appointment of JOSEPH HOXIE, of the Seventh Ward, as temporary Chairman. This motion was carried by acclamation.

The Board met at 12 o'clock M., yesterday, al the members present except the City Inspector. The Health Officer reported the steamer Star of the South, from Savannah. She had no passengers. It was ordered that she lie at quarantine at present for observation.

As the time for the departure of the Paraguay expedition approaches, all question affecting the inland waters it proposes to visit rise in importance. The most conspienous of these questions is the controversy pending between Buenos Ayres and the Argentine Confederation. It is of old standing.
THE OUSELEY CONVENTION.-Some City journals fear that tile draft of a treaty between Great Britain and Nicaragua, published exclusively in the TIMIES of Monday, was not authentie.

REPUBLICAN COMMITTEE.-The Committee of the Republican County Convention on Contested Seats met Yesterday, and decided to admit the following gentlemen as delegates froth Fifth Ward JOHN E. CAMMEYER, JOHN SIMS, JOHN LEE. EE.

The investigation in the case of General Super-intendent Tallmadge, for neglecting to send a Police force to protect the remaining buildings at Quarantine on the 2d instant, was resumed yesterday at the office of the Police Commissioners. The Mayor was not present; the other Commissioners. The Mayor was not present; the other Commissioners, Messrs. Nye, Bowen, Stillman and Stranahan were in attendance.

SALES OF STOCKS AT PHILADELPHIA.--Tuesday.--First Board.--$600 Pennsylvania 5s, 90; $2,000 City 6s, 98; $5,000 Camden and Amboy Railroad 6s, '89. 84 3/4; $1,600 Harrisburg Railroad 6s, 94 3/4; $2,000 Pennsylvania Railroad 6s, 92 3/4; $1,000 North Pennsylvania Railroad 6s; 58; $3,000 Elmira Railroad is, 24 mort., Coupon off, 49, 6 Camden and Amboy Railroad, 110 1/4; 40 do., 110 1/2; 4 Pennsylvania Railroad, 44 ; 800 Reading Railroad, 24;

We observe in the Special Washington Dispatch of a morning contemporary, that General CUSHING is about to appear with a statement in respect to "his action upon what are called town-sites upon the public lands" As General CUSHING was never in a position to take any "action" upon the subject, the allusion, we presume, is to his opinions officially given while he occupied the place of Attorney-General.

The mail steamship Moses Taylor, with advices from California to the 6th inst., arrived at this port last evening. Her news is a fortnight later. The principal subject of interest at San Francisco continued to be the election, which took place on the 1st.

Those who are watching the signs of the times will read with interest our report to-day of a sale of 29 lots on the west side of Eighth-avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-eighth and One Hundred and Thirty-third streets, by Mr. ADRIAN H. MULLER. It was foreclosure sale in the case of CHAS. S. ROE, plaintiff, us. BRYAN LAWRENCE at al. All the lots were full sized unless otherwise stated.

Capt TOWNSEND, of the slave brig Echo, after a further examination this morning, was remanded for a further hearing before the U. S. Circuit Court, which meets Oct. 15, when the question of jurisdie tion will be argued. He was also admitted to bail in $5,000, on a complaint of misdemeanor under act o 1818 preferred by the District-Attorney.

The Court of Appeals commenced hearing causes to day. Mr. BLANKMAN, counsel in the Cancemi case, moved that the cause be placed on calendar for the present term, and argued on the 13th of October. This motion was granted. He also moved that two counsel be heard on the part of CANCEMI, but the Court decided they could only hear one on each side.

CHARTRES BREW left for Boston in the steamer Eastern State to-day. JOHN F. FOX, of Boston, the other survivor of the ill-fated Austria, who declined passage in the Prince Albert, is also on board the Eastern State.

Affairs at the Dudley Observatory seem to be approaching a crisis. The Albany Atlas and Argus publishes a correspondence, submitted by Mr. RUTGER B. MILLER, a nephew of Mrs. DUDLEY, which embodies a letter from that lady, and conveys divers threatening intimations.

The U. S. Mail steamship Moses Taylor, JOHN McGOWAN, Esq., commanding, which left Aspinwall on the 20th inst. with the mails, passengers and treasure from San Francisco, per pacific Mail Steamship Company's steamer John L. Stephens, which reached panama evening of the 79th, arrived at this port yesterday in the afternoon.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--ITALIAN OPERA--WILLIAM TELL--RONZANI'S BALLET TROUPE. BURTON'S THEATER--LA FIOLIA DLL REGGIMENTO. NIBLO'S GARDEN--THE LIFE OF AN ACTRESS. LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE--THE ROAD TO RUIN--JENNY LIND.

SAVAGE.--Is this City, on Tuesday morning, Sept. 28, MARIA CRANE, Wife of Charles C. Savage, aged 36 years and 6 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 2 1/2 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 56 East 28th-st.

Hitherto no manifest efforts have been made by any one of the three political parties in the field, if we except some ratification meetings on the part of the Republicans. These demonstrations have been respectable in point of numbers, and ably addressed by prominent members of that party.

RED-TAPEISM.--To transact any public business, except through the one legitimate channel, is regarded by the whole British Nation as a crime only second to a breach of court etiquette. The horror with which an Englishman views any deviation from rule has been illustrated recently in a manner too amusing to be passel over.

Judge BOWLIN will receive his instructions tomorrow, the same having been arranged in Cabinet meeting to-day, and he will leave on Friday for New-York. It is expected that the Sabine will sail on Monday.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-ROSSINI'S opera Of " William Tell" will be given to-night for the second time. None of our country friends should neglect the opportunity of seeing this work as presented at the leading opera house of America.

That long-expected and much-talked about event, the revolution, that was to have come off on the 15th September, on the occasion of the scrutiny of the ballots for Governor of the State of Panama, was postponed indefinitely, the Government Party, after all their preparations, threats, and gas, not having the courage to "come to the scratch."

GOV. BROWN still continues in the City, engaged in canvassing the claims of the rival sites for our City Post-Office. He is beseiged by a host of property-owners in various localities, each one of whom has a site exactly adapted to a Post-office; which, for the good of the City, he is willing to sell below the market price.

THE CANVASS IN CALIFORNIA.-The Administration has secured a victory, such as it is, in California. The election, after a hasty canvass, took place on the 1st inst., the offices involved being local, and the vote, so far as reported, a light one.

Mayors TIEMANN and POWELL, with severe gentlemen of the City Government of Brooklyn, together with Messrs. CARRISAN, CUMMINGS and ?? TREE. of the Commissioners of Emigration, and ?? CORLIES, yesterday made an official visit to Quaratine, for the purpose of comparing views and adopting plans for the future.

Odd Fellows Hall, in this city, was dedicated to-day with appropriate and imposing cere?? Several prominent members of the Order from a were present, among others, General SIMON CAM?? and the venerable P. G. WILDEY, officers of the Lodge of Pennsylvania.

The steamship Prince Albert arrived at this port yesterday, bringing ten of the survivors of the burnt steamship Austria, who were rescued by the French bark Maurice, and were afterwards transferred to the British bark Lotus, the day following the disaster. After being twelve days on board the bark they reached Halifax, and the Prince Albert calling there about the same time, they were all offered a free passage to New-York.

We learn from Major NICHOLS, Adjutant-General of the Department, that the latest dates received at his office from Fort Defiance are up to the 18th inst. No hostile movement has yet been made by the troops against the Navajos. At the earnest solicitation of ARMIJO, an influential chief, the commanding officer had given him ten days to raise his people and go in search of the murderer of Major BROOKS' negro.

The Board met at 12 M. yesterday TIEMANN and Mayor POWELL were absent. The investigation of the charge against General TALLMADGE was proceeded with. Emanuel B. HOW A DEFAULTING CASHIER CARRIED ON HIS RASCALITY FOR FOUR YEARS.--The Boston Atlas gives some interesting particulars of the way in which the defaulting cashier of the Brighton Bank managed his rascality: "The reason for the recent resignation of Mr. ROBERT N. WOODWORTH, cashier of the Brighton Bank, has become apparent.

ANOTHER LARGE SWINDLE -- BAD EFFECT OF A FAILURE. -- The Springfield Republican states that the failure of WHITE, SMITH CO., of Northampton, Mass. manufacturers of enameled cloth, was brought about by the embezzlements of their selling agent in new-York, Mr. DAVID S. DAMON, whose depredations upon the company are estimated all the way from $30,000 to $75,000. The firm possessed the confidence of the community, and many citizens had invested in its notes;

Patents have been issued to OWEN G. WARREN and SAMUEL SAMUELS, both of New-York, each for an improvement in the method of laying submarine telegraph cables. The patent has been reissued for HOUSE'S Improvement of a Magnetic Printing Telegraph.

Parson BROWNLOW is much more spicy through the columns of his Knoxville Whig than he is on the rostrum. A letter, written home during the progress of the debate in Philadelphia, gives his views of his antagonist, Mr. PRYNE. Hear the Parson:

From the Detroit Tribune, 25th. We learn from Mr. HIRAM WILER, who lives about two miles from this city, at whose house the following transactions took place, the particulars of a death-bed confession which, if true, brings to light the hidden mysteries of the awful murder of a mother and son at Fentonville nearly or quite a year since.

THE CORONER'S INVESTIGATION CONTINUED--FOURTH DAY'S PROCEEDINGS. The inquest regarding the death of Mrs. SOPHIA STEVENS was resumed yesterday. The husband of the deceased was present for the first time. Before the examination of witnesses was entered upon STEVENS said he desired to converse with the Coroner, but the latter refused to have any conversation with him except through his counsel.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, JAMES STONE, Esq., Commander, from Liverpool at 3 o'clock P. M., Sept. 18, arrived at this port last evening. The screw-steamship Alps, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the morning of Friday, Sept. 17. The screw-steamship Hammonia, which sailed from Hamburg on the 15th, for Southampton,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.- ROSSINI'S "William Tell" was played here last evening for the second time. It was an excellent performance, and fully satisfied a large audience. Signor STEFFANI has recovered from his recent indisposition, and sang with his usual fire. The Fisherman's song in the first act was very nearly and artistically rendered by Signor GUIDI--a magnificent improvement on the gentleman who essayed it on Friday last.

POLITICAL.--In a card, which we publish this morning, Mr. ABRAM WAKEMAN declines the nomination for Congress, tendered him by the Republican Convention for the Eighth District, held on Friday last. He states that his reason is the nature of his professional engagements, which precludes his undertaking the duties of a member of Congress.

The Fashion Handicap. Prominent in the programme of races over the Fashion Course yesterday , was a Handicap sweepstakes, 2 1/2 miles heat; $100 subscription, $75 forfeit, $25 declaration, with a plate valued at $1,000, added by the proprietor. As it was tile first announcement of a general handicap to be run in this country, the regular patrons of the turf attached great importance
The Prince Albert rounded the fort at the Narrows yesterday morning, at 10 1/2 o'clock, and was immediately boarded by the Health-Officer and the reporters of the Press.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Will you tell me why it is a mechanic can never have a hearing communications which prevents their voice being heard among the multitude of other complains which reach the public ear? I am led to these remarks by the fact, that at this time there never was known such oppression on the part of capitalists and employers against them.

The new iron steamer just completed by BOARDMAN, HOLBROOK Co., for the Louisiana Tehuantepee Company, to ply in the Coatzacoales River, above Minatitlan, made a short trial trip Tuesday, in which she gave great satisfaction to the gentlemen who were on board. Her engines worked well, and the boat traveled at the rate of eleven miles an hour.

From the Rochester Union, 25th. The examination of the parties concerned in the Bounty Land-Warrant frauds, before Commissioner CONKLING, was concluded yesterday. ALBRO was, of course, held and fully committed to answer charges that will consign him to prison for life. The Commissioner decided to hold Justices WILCOX and VAIL to answer at the next United States Court, in the sum of $2,000 each, which bail they promptly entered and went their way.

THE LOSS OF THE AUSTRIA--STATEMENTS OF THE RESCUED PASSENGERS.--The terrible disaster to the Austria--the most fearful, so far as the loss of human life is concerned, that has ever happened to an Ocean steamer-- continues to engross the public sympathies. Ten of her rescued passengers arrived in this City yesterday, in the steamer Prince Albert, from Halifax,

THE NEW "BRICK CHURCH." --Dr. SPRING'S church, at the corner of Fifth-avenue and Thirty-seventh-street, is so nearly compledted as probably to be ready for occupancy by the 1st of November. The organ is being made by FERRIS. The steeple will be finished this week, when the cap-stone, weighing 2,500 pounds, will be put in its place. The whole will be surmounted by a gift vane and ball.

ARKANSAS FOR DOUGLAS.--Our special dispatch from Washington announces the arrival in that city of the Hon. ALBERT RUST, from Arkansas, with the intelligence that the Democracy of that intensely Democratic State side almost unanimously with DOUGLAS on his present war with BUCHANAN. Mr. RUST is a prominent Democratic politician, and was one of the two Representatives from Arkansas in the Thirty-fourth Congress.

ROWE--BARNES.--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 15, by the Rev. Edward Lathrop, Mr. JOHN ROWE to Miss ALMIRA A. BARNES, both of this City. BAILLIERE--SMITH.--At Newark, N. J., on Tuesday, Sept. 28, at Trinity Church, by the Right Rev. G. W. Doane, assisted by the Rev. Dr. E. Neville, HIPPOLYTE E. BAILLIERE, of New-York, and MARY D., only daughter of the late Hanford Smith, of Newark.

The following dispatch has been received by the honorary Directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Company in this City: CYRUS STATION (Trinity Bay,) Sept. 28. To Peter Cooper, Esq., (for the Directors,) New-York: Nothing was done yesterday with Valentia. The electrical indications continue without change since my dispatch of Saturday. DE SAUTY.

JAMES LEWIS HATCH, assistant editor of the Charleston (S. C.) Courier, died on the evening ?? Saturday, the 25th inst., after five days' illness, of ?llow fever. Mr. HATCH was a native of Oxford County, ??., and was only twenty-five years of age when he died. He was educated at Bowdoin College, in his native State, where he was graduated in 1854. His College rank was very high.

REPORT OF A DEMOCRATIC DELEGATE.--Yesterday's Washington Union contains a letter from the interior of this State, written by a delegate to the recent Democratic Convention at Syracuse, who claims to have taken "an active part in its proceedings." He sends to headquarters a rose-colored picture of political affairs generally.

KINGS COUNTY COURT OF SESSIONS--WEDNESDAY, Sept. 29. Before the Hon Samuel D. Morris, County Judge, and Justices Emmous and Schoonmaker. SENTENCES. David Hopkins, convicted of burglary in the third degree, was sentenced to three years imprison-at Sing Sing. Abraham Vermilia, indicted for burglary, was found guilty of petit larceny, and sentenced to six months imprisonment in the penitentiary, and to pay a fine of $100.

It was but a fortnight ago, when the public was all anxiety with regard to the Atlantic telegraph, that it was supplied day after day with telegrams and other information, apparently authoritative, in regard to the reasons of suspension. The Turkish Sultan is astonishing everybody by a coup detat in the interest of economy. It appears that he has found out that his expenditure enormously exceeds his revenue, that the civil list in the hands of tile harem, has swollen to an immense sum, that every one of his ministers has helped in tile work and is guilty of peculation on a gigantic scale,

The English steamer Buzzard arrived from Laguayra yesterday, with intelligence of the blockade of Laguayra by the English steamer Tartar and a French steamer. The French Minister had left for Martinique, for reinforcements. Mr. BINGHAM, the English Charge d' Affaires, is on board the Tarlar. All Venezueian ports are to be put under immediate blockade for national vessels,

MAKING THE CANAL ENLARGEMENT IMMEDIATELY AVAILABLE.--An important discussion took place in the Canal Board, at Albany, on Wednesday, upon a proposition, by Commissioner RUGGLES, to expend $16,000 in improving the channel of the Eric Canal, where it crosses the Cavuga marches.

A dispatch from Mr. LUNDY, the electrician recently arrived at Trinity Bay front Valentia, to CYRUS W. FIELD, Esq., is published this morning. He hopes, by establishing a system of unison between the two stations, to be able to get signals through, the conductor not being broken, and the defect being a loss of insulation 280 miles from Valentia.

The examination of JOHN C. THOMPSON and RAY TOMPKINS on a charge of arson, proceeding from the burning of the Quarantine buildings, was resumed yesterday at 10 3/4 A.M., at the Lyceum, Stapleton. Mr. RUFUS W. PECKHAM appeared in behalf o f the State, and Mr. DE GROOT represented the County of Richmond. The prisoners promptly attended, accompanied by Mr. ANTHON, their counsel.

From the Journal of last evening. The Fireman have had another beautiful day for their exercises. Notwithstanding their fatigue of yesterday, and the late of yesterday, and the late hour into which many of them pushed their festivities, they appeared fresh and muscular this morning. Soon after 8 o'clock, they began to move, in isolated detachments, to the Fair Grounds, where was to be the "tug of war."

The last regatta of the season of the New-York Yacht Club took place yesterday. The day was beautiful, with a light wind from about S. S. E., which, during the afternoon, increase to a good sailing breeze. There were 16 entries made, of which but 12 started, as follows: First Class--Rebecca, Zinga, Una, Favorita, Restless and Madgie. Second Class--Mannering, Irene and Scud. Third Class--Fanny, Margaret and Narragansett.

No one in our Metropolitan City but knows that the Parisian Patissiers comprise that creative corps who devote their genius to the embodiments of the principles of high art in tarts,

A WILD ANIMAL IN ULSTER COUNTY.-A dangerous visitor has made his appearance in the mountain, near Ellenville, Ulster County, creating no little alarm and excitement in that quiet neighborhood by his ferocity. It is said to be about the size and bears some resemblance to a panther. A few days ago he descended from a tree after a man, and chased him some distance.

We, in this region, have been greatly amused at the reports of the celebration in America of tile successful completion of the Atlantic Telegraph, of which recent numbers of the American journals have been full. By the time this reaches you, the excitement will have died away, and very likely the whole affair will be well nigh forgotten.

ATTEMPTED WIFE-MURDER AND SUICIDE.--FRANCIS GORMAN, a German nearly forty years of age, who resided in Forty-street, has for some time past been so intemperate in his habits, and so abusive to his wife and children while intoxicated, that his wife a few weeks since left him and went to live with some relatives. She took the children with her, and GQRMAN has since been endeavoring to get the children in his own keeping.

THE PUBLISHERS OF OBSCENE PRINTS.-The two Frenchmen, de Bram and Moriale, arrested a few days since for publishing and selling obscene prints, were yesterday arraigned for trial at the Court of Special Sessions. Justice BRENNAN, STEERS and CONNOLLY presiding. The prisoners were brought in with some two score of other criminals, charged with all kinds of miscellaneous offences, from kicking a wife into the street to kicking up a shindy in a groggery.

Three days ago we arrived at this place on route for the Guano Islands of tile Gulf of California. The northwest wind, which, without shift or change, blows steadily throughout six months of the year, had delayed our passage, and almost worn out our patience, so that it was with great pleasure that we once more landed, after fifteen wearisome days of continual tacking and efforts to beat up the Gulf from Mazatlan.

JONES.--In this City, on Thursday, Sept. 30th, after a short illness, ?? ADELIA, only daughter of John W. and Charlotte Jones, aged 19 months and 27 days. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Saturday, Oct. 2, at 2 o'clock P. M., at the residence. No. 436 8th-av.

FOUNDLING.-On Wednesday night an infant, apparently about three weeks old, was deposited under the stoop of house No. 15 Monroe-place. It was discovered by the " head of the family," who turned it over to the care of the Police. The child was sent to the Almshouse yesterday.

At 2 o'clock yesterday, in the Metropolitan Police Office, in Broome-street, Mr. WM. CURTIS NOYES addressed the Commissioners in behalf of his client, Hon. FRED. A. TALLMADGE, who had been suspended from his office on the strength of certain charges (already familiar to the public) which were preferred against him by Gen NYE, the President of the Board.

Judge BOWLIN had another long interview with the Secretary of State to-day touching his instructions, which will be read over and considered in the presence of both parties at 10 o'clock to-morrow. Commodore SHUBRICK now gives it as his opinion that the Sabine cannot sail before the latter part of the week.

SALE OF THE CANALS.-It is deemed a matter of the highest prudence, in view of the approaching election, for all parties to profess the almost devotion to the canal interests of the State. The Republican candidate for Governor made a canal speech when he called his Convention to order, and another when he was nominated, to say nothing of several canal letters he has since written.

IMPORTANT FROM THE SOCIETY ISLANDS.--ANNEXATION TO THE UNITED STATES.--We have important news from the Society Islands, dated at Raiatea and Tahaa, on the 9th of June, and at Tahiti on the 12th of July. The governors of the first-named islands, who have the power of appointing or dethroning the kind, had, it appears, taken the supreme power from TAMATOA V., son of Queen POMARE, of Tahiti, who was elected chief magistrate about a year ago.

PRESENTATION OF A SILVER TRUMPET TO LIEUT. MAXWELL WOODHULL.--A most interesting ceremony, to which a very select party were invited, took place yesterday, at the Astor House. Lieut. MAXWELL WOODHULL, the first Lieutenant of the U. S. frigate Sabine, which was lying off the Battery, was presented with a silver trumpet--a testimonial, from a few friends, of the important services rendered by Lieut.

SIXTH DISTRICT REPUBLICAN CONGRESSIONAL CONVENTION--No NOMINATION YET.--The Republican Congressional Convention of the Sixth District convened at No. 618 Broadway, at 8 o'clock last evening, Mr. JAMES CUSHING, Jr., the Chairman, presiding. The Chairman stated that they had been in some error when the present night was designated for the meeting: it was supposed that the American Convention would meet before this;

To the Editor of the New-York Times. Mr. RICHARD A. LOCKE testified before th Police Commissioners to having seenthe Rev. Dr. WINSLOW, of St. Panfs Church, at the burning of the Marine Hospital,--looking on with complaceney, and apparently with some degree of satisfaction.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. The Sheriff has advertised the pictures in the Governor's room,-the benches, carpets and furniture of the several Court-rooms in this City for sale to satisfy the execution of Mr. LOWDER, upon his judgment.

PLUCK.--The Signal, GERRIT SMITH'S Buffalo organ, cries out valiantly to "call out your candidates!" This challenge is addressed to the Republican, Democratic and American parties. Mr. SMITH has voluntarily taken the stump. He is a fine speaker and personable gentleman. His friends are proud of his oratorical powers and his good looks. They have reason to be.

The examination of Messrs. RAY TOMPKINS and J. C. THOMPSON, for arson, in connection with the conflagration of the Quarantine establishment, was resumed yesterday at the Lyceum, Stapleton, Staten Island, before Judge METCALF. The room, during a great portion of the proceedings, was well filled with spectators.

The figures of the recent election (says the Portland, (Me..) Advetiser) demonstrate conclusively that the Republican Party of Maine has as great popular strength to-day as it exhibited two years ago, when Hannibal Hamlin was elected by a vote so unprecedentedly large. Governor Morrill received at the late election sixty-one thousand votes, and Mr. Hamlin received sixty-nine thousand in 1856.

THE CEMETERY OF THE EVERGREENS CONTROVERSY.--An adjourned meeting of the lot-owners in the Cemetery of the Evergreens was held in Washington Hall, E. D. There was a very large attendance of lot-owners and others, who take an interest inthe controversy going on between the schareholders and managers.

The Club Races for September, over the Fashion Couse, closed yesterday, and , notwithstanding the rain, the attendance was large and the races very interesting - they were as good as those of the first day, and much better than those of the second.

Professor GLAUBENSKLEE gives the following names of persons who, he personally knows, were passengers on board the Austria: 1. MELCHER, mosic teacher from New-York, widley known here. 2. BOCKENTHAL, from Mobile. 3. STOPEL, or STOPLER, a young man in company of the latter.

The work of nominating candidates for Congress has been fully commenced, and with no very ??attering results to either old members or new aspirants. In the Tenth District, Mr. DELANO, of Northampton, who had hardly been named, beat Dr. CHAFFEE and Purser GREENE, who wished for his place.

COMMITMENTS TO THE CITY PRISON.--The number of persons committed to the City Prison for the month of September was 114, on the following charges: Drunkeness, 71, assault, 11: suspicion of robbery, I; passing counterfeit money, 3; fighting, 5; robbery, 4; disorderly, 7; suspicion o stealing, 4; suspicion of burglary, 2; ubrglary, 3; stealing, 3; attempt to pass conterfeit money, 2; witness, 1. Nationly.--Ireland, 72; England, 13; Scotland, 6;

Before Chief Justice Nelson. BOTTOMRY-C. A. Robert, Appellant, vs. Bark Yuba, Appellee.-This was an appeal from a decision on a Bottomry Bond, and involved the question of the master's power to bottomry iris vessel and cargo. The bond is for $9,240. The District Judge allowed $4,000 in the bond, and from this decree the appellant appeals.

I.-THE APPALLING CALAMITY OF THE STEAMSHIP AUSTRIA-Fearful Destruction of Life-Full List of the Survivors-Names of the Lost-Particulars of the Disaster-Statements of Prof. GLAUBENSKLEE, Mr, VEZIN, and others. II.-THE CENTRAL AMERICAN TREATY-Object of Sir WM. GORE OUSELEY'S Mission-Draft of a Treaty between Great Britain and Nicaragua, now first published.

MURDER IN ERIE COUNTY.-The Buffalo Republic, of Wednesday, says: " On Friday night last several German residents of Clarence, Erie County, went into tile house of a German two or three miles from the village, the understanding being that there was to be a dance there during the evening. Among those who went was a man named JAMES GRAHAM, also a German.

Secretary Toucey awards contracts for constructing the engineers and machinery for the vessels of war, as follows. Fulton Irom works, for the vessel at Pensaco'a. Morgan Iron Works for the vessel at Pansaco'a Woodruff Beach for the vessel at Portsminth. N.H.

Professor MITCHEL communicates to the Cincinnati Gazette the result of his observations of DONATI'S,Comet; from the Cincinnati Observatory. He says the Comet will soon commence to change direction, at first slowly, afterward more rapidly, as seen from the earth. when sweeping swiftly round the sun it will regain those distant regions of space wherein a vast proportion of its orbit lies far beyond the reach of telescopic vision.

Considering the Claims which Mr. BUCHANAN's friends say he has on the public esteem, the treatment he is receiving at the hands of a large part of his own party is something unaccountable. At a "Democratic ratification meeting," held at Albany,

NEW-YORK. The Hon. JAMES WADSWORTH, ex-Senator, is the Democratic candidate for Sheriff in Erie County, in this State. He recently resigned the Senatorship in consequence of personal engagements, which required his presence at home. Mr. JOSEPH C. Y. PAIGE has been elected Chamberlain of the city of Albany.

GRKAT FIRE AT JACMEL, HAYTI--LOSS OVER A MILLION AND A QU??FER.--The Fenille da Commence, of the 21st ult., states that on the 15th of August, a destructive fire accurred at Jacmel. "The most beautiful part of the City," says the account, "the principal seat of commerce, is a heap of rains.

ADMINISTRATION WAR ON DOUGLAS.-The conflict between President BUCHANAN and Senator DOUGLAS is daily assuming more and more the character of embittered personal hate. Especially is this the case on the side of the Administration.

How TO SAVE LIVES AT SEA.-The terrible catastrophe of the Austria, has very naturally elicited a great number of propositions for the avoidance of similar calamities,-some of which have good sense to recommend them. The communication of a " Passenger," which we publish in another column,

A UNION OPPOSITION TICKET. - The Buffalo commerical Advertiser publishes the following extrct from a Chautauque county letter: "The people of all parties, especially those of the Republican and American organizations, are panting for a Union State Ticket, to be make up by a People's State Convention,and constituted of BURROWS and BENTON, and two good and ture Republicans.

The weather yesterday was uncomfortabley warm for the season. October came in like a lamb. The sun shone, the ladies went shopping numerously, and the streets were full of people. Suddenly, and without much warning, at 12 o'clock, large drops of rain began to fall, and so rapidly and so close together they came down that many were wet through before they could get under cover.

PREIST-In this City, on Friday Morning, Oct. 1. HENRY L.PREIST, aged 37 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to atend his funeral. this (saturday) afternoon, at 3.o clock precisely from his late residence.
