To the Editor of the New-York Times: A few weeks since, I saw certain letters which had lately been written by a minister of one of the denominations, who is not undistinguished in the world of letters. These documents were not on political subjects.

Of the three steamers which have been dispatched by the Ship Canal Company for Nicaragua, two halve been reported-the Catherine Maria at Savanah, on the 15th, and the Laura Frances, on the same day, at Norfolk, which place she left on the 17th.

Southern editors have a hard time. Dueling is a favorite way they have of settling their little differences. We have still another specimen. The Donaldsonville (La.) Vigilant notices an " affair of honor" which took place a few days ago, the parties being, Mr. D'ARTLYS, of the Ascension Flag, and Mr. EDRINGTON, of the Young America.

COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH.-The Health Coinmissioners met in the Mayor's office, on Friday, at noon. Mayor TIEMANN was present, together with the Health Officer, Dr. THOMPSON, and Drs. MULLER and ROCKWELL. The schooner Palmetto, from Orizaba, was permitted to come to the City on Monday to unload.

SIXTEENTH ANNIVERSARY OF THE SONS OF TEMPERANCE.-This anniversary was celebrated last Wednesday evening by Harmony Division No. 5, at its hall No. 281 Grand-street. The room was crowded. Mr. WM. H. ARMSTRONG presided, and " fifteen minutes' addresses" were made by the Rev. THEO. L. CUYLER, HENRY A. GUILD, and Messrs. BEALE, HEIGHWAY, BOOTH and SNOW.

Yesterday and to day the Monmouth County Agricultural Socicty held their first Fair as an incorporated society, with results exceeding their highest expectations. In every department of agriculture the exhibition was worthy of one of the richest counties in the State.

The following orders have just been issued by the Navy Department: Pursers W. W. J. KELLY, J. K. HARWOOD and C. C. JACKSON have been ordered to the Paraguay expedition. Purser JOHN HAMBLETON has been ordered to the Naval Academy at Annapolis.

The Rev. PRESTON S. TURLEY expiated to-day upon the scaffold the crime of murdering hid wife, in this county, in January last. The scene was one of unusual sadness, rendered so no less from the high standing which the unfortunate culprit once occupied in this community, than from the strange spectacle of the execution of a white man in this region.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article in the TIMES of Friday purports to give the meeting of the General Committee of Regulars on Tuesday night last. I was present and heard his remarks, and can assure you that your informant has been deceived or is deceiving you.

The following correspondence explains itself: NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Sept. 29, 1858. Rev. RALPH HOYT: The account which I have seen in the daily press of the great loss you sustained by the destruction of the Church of the Good Shepherd, and of the sacrificing devotion with which you are trying to rebuild it,

Cooper, of Hoboken.

AMMERICAN COUNT CONVENTION. The American Countty Convention met at 8 o'clock Thursday evening, at the Sinyvesant institite, Broadway. There was a full delegation-there froreach Ward. Two Chairmen-Mr. DENE and Mr. BARNET-were nominated for temporary Chairman by their respective partisans.

CAPT. DE RIVIERE ON "LOVE."--A notice placarded in front of Hope Chapel, yesterday, announced that Capt. DE RIVIERE would, the same evening, "clear of all warrants," deliver a lecture there, on "Love." Shortly after 7 1/4 P. M., the hour at which the lecture was to commence, Cap. DE RIVIERE placed himself behind the desk, and began to read his views of the tender passion.

There are contingencies in which desperadoes desire the presence of the Clergy, and to this rule the Quarantine burners offer no exception. At the trial of Gen. TALLMADGE, on Wednesday last, before the Board of Police Commissioners, RICHARD ADAMS LOCKE was examined as a witness.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Probably the best organization for the security of the lives of the passengers in case of fire or collision, existed on board the Pacific Mail Company's ship the John L. Stevens, Captain R. H. PEARSON running between Panama and San Francisco.

RAILROAD PACIFICATION--The two great railways of this State, after a most unprofitable season of hostilities, have entered into a treaty offensive and defensive, and peace again prevails. They have returned tothe former system of high prices, and agreed not to underbid each other. In some unimportant respects economy has been resolved upon.

Tile public have not yet heard from Mr. Assistant District Attorney SEDGWICK in reference to his part in the late extraordinary scene in the Court of General Sessions. The farce of punishing Mr. MULLIGAN was enacted with as much solemnity as an exhibition of the ancient Augurs, and in just about the same sincerity and good faith.

According to the official accounts of the Board of Trade at London, the computed real value of all the foreign and colonial merchandise imported into the United Kingdom during the six months ended June 30, 1858, was ??69,677,151, of which sum ??47,193,604 represents the imports of the three months ended the same day.

The London Daily News announces the death of Mr. WILLIAM WEIR, who succeeded the late FREDERICK KNIGHT HENT in the principal editorship of that journal. The News says: Intelligence, still lacking positive information, has been received in England, to the effect that ADOLPHE SCHLAGENTWEIT the adventurous explorer and naturalist, has been murdered by one of the Cash mere tribes.

THE GREAT BELL CREVASSE.--The Picayanc says: "A friend, who visited this scene of disaster day before yesterday, gives us some details of its present appearance. The crevasse is about 300 feet wide at its openin on the river, and extends back a quarter of a mile to the Opelousas railroad track, warying in depth from 5 to 40 feet.

The Washington corespondent of the Baltimore Sun writes as follows: "By private advices from Constantinople, of the 29th ult., we learn that MOHAMMED PACHA, who was sent on a mission to this country last Winter, to examine our public and private dock-yards with a view to the construction of a screw line of battle ship for the Sultan, had returned and made his report.

THE NEW CITY POST-OFFICE.-It Will be seen by the dispatch from our Special Correspondent at Washington that Postmaster-General BROWN has not decided, as has been stated, to purchase Appleton's Building for our City Post-Office. Mr. BROWN appears to have come to a positive determination in his own mind as to the proper site for a Post-Office,

The Postmaster-General denies that he has fixed upon a spot for the New-York Post-Office. He says that he could decide between the propositions before him in five minutes, but that it is by no means certain that he will accept of either. The proposition to build in conjunction with the City on the upper part of the Park would have been favorbly considered, had not the corporation contended for the disbursement of the money.

The movement having in view a change in the Republican and American programme, on the State Tickets, referred to in the TIMES a few days since, has a real foundation, but the prospects of its success are regarded as not over-flattering. If I am correctly informed, it originated with the American friends of WM. A. RUSSELL, (present Prison Inspector,)

HYDROPHOBIA,-About the middle of August last a boy named PATRICK MADDEN., residing on Hamilton-avenue, near Mill-street, while on Van Brunt-street was attacked by a dog, and severely bitten by him in the face. The injured boy was taken to the Long Island College Hospital, where the usual remedies were applied, and the wound soon healed.

THE SEVENTY-FIRST REGIMENT FOR QUARANTINE.--The following is the Regimental Order, just issued, in accordance with which the Seventy-First Regiment will proceed to Quarantine next Wednesday: AMERICAN GUARD. SEVENTY-FIRST REGIMENT, LIGHT INFANTRY, N. Y. S. M. Regimental Orders, No. 11. HEAD-QUARTERS, NEW-YORK, Oct. 2, 1858. In compliance with Division and Brigade Orders.

BLEECKER.-In this City, on Saturday morning, Oct 2, MARY, daughter of the late Anthony L. Bleecker, in the 82d year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, at Trinity Church, this (Monday) afternoon, at 3 1/2 o'clock, without any further notice.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I cannot agree with Professor MAURY that there is a plateau in the Northern Atlantic Ocean. Admitting, however, the fact, and that the bottom of the ocean is composed of "mites of little shells," as shown by the miscroscopic investigations " of that charming scientific man, Professor BAYLY," we shall find that the plateau has no firmness;

From the Toronto Grove. The new Provincial Crystal Palace is situated on the west of Toronto, and is distant about a mile and a half from the centre of the city. It occupies a high and commanding situation, having an excellent view of the harbor and lake; and being adjacent to the Grand Trunk and Northern Railways, it is easily accessible.

The Board of Directors of the German Benevolent Societies of New-York recently issued a call inviting all the German Societies in the United States to convene at New-York, to take measures for making public the ill-treatment received by German emigrants, on ship-board and after their arrival in this country, with a view to inducting Congress to pass a law immediately for their protection.

A letter from the Hon. CHARLES SUMMER, dated at Aix, Sept. 11, says: "My life is devoted to my health. I wish that I could say that I am not still an invalid; but, except when attacked by the pain in my chest, I am now comfortable, and enjoy my baths, my walks, and the repose and incognito which I find here.

THE PRESIDENT AND THE JEWS.--It may be recollected that President BUCHANAN made use of the phrase " all the nations of Christendom," in his answer to Queen VICTORIA'S message transmitted by the Atlantic Telegraph. This expression gave offence to Dr. ISIDOR KALISCH, rabbi of the Ben Jeshurun Congregation in the city of Milwaukee, who wrote to the President demanding an explanation.

FUSION IN THE CITY.-Since the Americans and Republicans committed the capital mistake of not fusing on their State tickets, they have been endeavoring to atone for their blunder, as far as they can, by uniting on the local county tickets. The two committees meet this evening to take some steps towards a union, and as Barkis is willing on both sides

DEDICATION OF THE MORTUARY CHAPEL IN CALVARY CEMETERY.--The recently-finished Mortuary Chapel, in Calvary Cemetery, was dedicated on Sunday. The Most Reverend Archbishop HUGHES having been otherwise engaged, the Very Reverend Father STARHS, Vicar-General of the Arch-diocese, officiated, aided by the Rev. PATHICK HENNESSY, chaplain of the cemetery

We find the following letter from J. McFETRIDGE, Collector of Customs at Pembina, in the St. Paul Pioneer and Democrat : " It is with regret that I have to announce the murder of three of our people by tile Sioux of the Plains. Thev were on their wav from St. Paul, and were within one day's march of Pembina, when the party (only four in number) was attacked by a party of nine Sioux.

From the Norwich (Conn.) Courier, 2d. We understand there was a sudden and stirring breeze of excitement in New-London yesterday. A coasting vessel, owned in New-London or Groton, arrived in port with a fugitive slave on board --said slave having smuggled himself with a jug of water and a ham on board the schooner, as she lay at the wharf of one of the North Carolina ports. lie continued to "lie low and keep dark"

If the Thirtieth Annual Fair of the American Instiute fails to attract that liberal share of public attention which in former years it was its good fortune to command, the fact must be attributed to a rare and unique embarrassment of riches which at the moment has overtaken our goodly citizens, and rendereed them insensible to the demands of monster pumpkins,

Tile case of RODGERS has at last been disposed of, and after eight months' litigation, he has finally been sentenced to be executed on the 12th of November. All the means which the law offers to people in his condition for effecting their escape have been exhausted. The Court of Appeals has held his conviction to he legal, and the Governor has been already in vain solicited to grant him a pardon.

Since my last letter, nothing save the arrival of recruits and supply trains has transpired to relieve the monotony of camp life, with little or nothing to do. Major EASTMAN arrived about a fortnight since, with several hundred recruits for the Fifth Infantry. The regiment, which was a mere skeleton hitherto, on account of the large number of discharges on expiration of enlistment, is now comparatively full, averaging more than sixty men per company.

CANADIAN TASTE OUTRAGED.--A Mr. G. G. NORRIS, of Toronto, has given immense umbrage to his fellow subjects of Canada West, by a display of officious loyalty. Feeling a deep interest in the success of an industrial Exhibition to be held this Fall in Toronto, he had the audacity to present a petition to the Queen, asking that tier Majesty would be

Two STABBING AFFRAYS--BOTH CAUSED BY RUM.-About 1 o'clock yesterday morning a number .f .Irishmen, who had been drinking whisky punches pretty freely, had a fight at No. 65 New Bowery, during which Patrick Fox was dangerously stabbed in the abdomen.The police were called, and Dennis McLane and J. H. Diehl were arrested, the rest of the party escaping through a rear door.

POSITION OF EX-GOVERNOR HUNT.-We publish this morning a letter written by the Hon. WASHINGTON HUNT, in which he defines his relation to the several parties now in the field. His position, he says, remains unchanged. He is still a National Whig, and continues to cherish the conservative principles of that party.

RESIGNATION OF P. B. SWEENEY.-We regret to learn that P. B. SWEENEY, Esq, has placed his resignation of the office of District-Attorney in the hands of the Governor. Mr. SWEENEY went to Europe some months since, his medical advisers hoping that change of air and treatment might restore his health.

Two steamers are now due with European advices to the 22d of September-the Arago, at this port, and the Nova Scotian, at Quebec. The latter had not passed the Riviere du Loup Station at 7 o'clock, last evening, and the former had not been heard from up to the time of going to press. Dr. BILLINGS arrived at New-Orleans on Monday, bringing dispatches from our Minister at Mexico. Mr. FORSYTH, to our Government.

UNKNOWN WOMAN RUN OVER AND KILLED.-- On Saturday afternoon an unknown woman was run over in Greenwich-street, near Vesey, by a horse and cart,--the latter loaded with iron bars--and instantly killed. The driver, SAMUEL COURTNEY, was immediately arrested to await the result of the Coroner's inquest which was held yesterday. The evidence showed that the deceased ran suddenly in front of the cart, and was run over before the driver could stop the horse.

Democratic Ratification Meeting--Captain Ryaders Missed. The Democratic State Nominations were ratified on Saturday night by the Metropolitan Club, at a public meeting held in Stuyvesant Institue. The lecture-room was crowded. Judge S.S.BOWNE was called to the chair, and a long list of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries was submitted and approved.

The Boston Traveller has seen a letter irons Beyrout, dated Aug. 11, in which it is stated that the American Consul for that place had arrived there about the middle of July, with his family, and that the raising of the flag of the Consulate, for the first time in sixteen months, was a pleasant sight for the American residents.

The bill, or project of a law, establishing a tariff of exports, discriminating to the disadvantage of Buenos Ayres and Montevideo, was pending, according to advices received a few days ago, in the Argentine Senate. Doubts were thrown upon its passage, as several leading conservations were known to be antagonistie.

We have letters from Mr. ROCKWOOD, and an extra from the Indianola Courier, announcing the arrest of the robber of the San Antonio mails, and the recovery of a large amount of drafts, The Courier says : "Through the indefatigable efforts of Col. JOHN T. ROCKWOOD, local agent at Galveston, JACOB DAMMERT, a boy about fifteen years of age,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Some years ago a promising Institution with the above title was formed in the metropolis. A number of gentlemen subscribed and became lifemembers, the funds were expended, a nucleus of paintings was purchased, and the hall of the Rotunda was adorned with the same, (for Uncle Samn's Post Office people had all " gone to church" in Nassaustreet.

Our dates from Rio Janeiro extend to Aug. 16. The Chambers were still in session, but engaged in questions of merely local importance. Two new projects of railroads, in the province of Bahia, had been brought forward. They will be built, it is thought, under a guarantee of a remunerative dividend, by the Provincial Legislature.

HICKSON--AUTEN.--In this City, on Saturday, Oct. 2, by the Rev. Charles Shelling, Pastor of the Sullivan-st. M. E. Church, Mr. W??. H. HICKSON to GERTRUDE V. S., eldest daughter of James W. Auten, Esq., all of this City. BREVOORT--TUTHILL.--At Brooklyn, on Monday, Aug. 2, by the Rev. Jacob West, Mr. JAMES RENWICK BRNVOORT. of Fordham, to Miss ANNA AUGUSTA TUTHILL, of Brooklyn.

The United States mail steamship Cahawba at Charleston, from Havana, brings our files and correspondence from the latter point to the 24th ult. The British West India Royal mail steamer Solent, LEWIS, Commander, arrived from St. Thomas on the evening of the 21st, with Southampton mails to the 2d inst. She left on the 24th for Vera Cruz and Tampico.

Among the Lost. The Chicago Press says:-- "CAEL NETTMAN, a German of wealth, intelligence, and great moral worth, of Ponoosac, Hancock Co., III., was among the passengers of the ill-faled Austria, and is undoubtedly among the lost. Mr. NETTMAN was a member of the prussian Parliament during the revolutionary period of 1818,

By the arrival of the schooner Star, Captain GAMMON, from Vera Cruz, we this morning received news from Vera Cruz and the capitol of Mexico. Our papers from Vera Cruz are four days later than had been previously received. We are obliged also to Dr. BILLINGS for prompt and acceptable courtesies on his arrival in this city, after a protracted and somewhat exciting, not to say perilous. trip from Mexico.

This is a wonderful country, and wonderful events are of daily occurrence: but as our wonders are of such a character of extravagance, I frequently feel delicate in relating them. In former letter I have impressed upon you the rapid decline of this country into settled anarchy. I think the point is nor reached. for daily we hear new cases of plunder and outrage.

REFUSAL TO IMPROVE CANAL NAVIGATION IN THE CAYUGA MARSHES.-A proposition by Commissioner RUGGLES to expand $16,500 in deepening the channel of the Eric Canal where it crosses the extensive marshes at the foot of the Cayuga Lake, was rejected on Friday last, in the Canal Board, by a party division-the Republican members all voting in favor there-of, and the Democrats against it.

Yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, the delegates to the National Convention of German Societies, which has been in session in this City for several days, met again in Pythagoras Hall, Canal-street, east of Broadway. Messrs. UNGEP. and HENNIG, delegates from St. Louis, appeared for the first time, and took their seats. Mr. SCHUMACHER occupied the Chair.

About 10 o'clock Sunday evening a serious fight occurred at the lager-bier garden corner of Third. avenue and Seventy-eighth-street, kept by LECONDO OCUES, an Italian. The garden has been a noted Sab. bath resort for Italiansall Summer. Between forty and fifty Italians were gathered there Sunday evening spending their time in drinking lager-bier, singing songs and talking Italian vehemently.

We are enabled to announce, from sources entirely authentic, the appointment of the Hon. WILLIAM PRESTON, of Kentucky, as the American Minister at Madrid. Mr. PRESTON has accepied the appointment, and will make his arrangements for an early departure to the seat of his mission.

The Honorable CALEB CUSHING wrote a letter the other day to the Committee engaged in getting up a dinner to Colonel ORR, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, at Craytonville, S. C., a portion of which we extracted in the TIMES of yesterday. The learned gentleman, we think, shines more in his letters than in his speeches,

The hopes entertained relative to the Norwegian vessel seen in the vicinity of the burning steamship Austria, have proved to be well founded.The ship (not bark, as reported) arrived at Quebec on Sunday, and proves to be the Catarina, from England, having been forty-three days on the passage.

A Cambridge correspondent of the Evening Post gives an interesting chapter of gossip about the Harvard corps of Professors. The HON. JOEL PARKER, Royal Professor in the Cambridge Law School, contemplates a resignation, to the grief of his numerous friends. He has filled the Chair for twelve years. The reported intention of President WALKER to re resign, is not confirmed,

IN ONE HUNDRED AND TWENTY-SECOND-STREET--At 12 1/2 A. M. yesterday, a two-story dwelling in One Hundred and Twenty-second-street, between Seventh and Eight avenues, caught fire, and was consumed together with its contents. The house and furniture was insured in the Park Insurance Company, for $1,250, which will nearly cover the loss. The origin of the fire is unknown.

The Norwegian Vessel seen in the vicinity of the burning Steamship Austria Proves to have been the ship Calarina, from England. She arrived at Quebec on Sunday, but the announcement of her arrival was not made by telegraph until yesterday. She succeeded in saving twenty-two persons from the wreck-sixteen passengers and six of the crew. All the particulars which have yet reached us are contained in the following dispatches:

As the late frequent comments of the Press on my salary as President of the New-York and Erie Railroad Company, and on my administration of its affairs, will be read by persons to whom I am entirely unknown, justice to myself renders it necessary that I should make some reply.

FOR EUROPE.--The steamer Vanderbilt, P. E. LEFEVRE, sailed on Saturday for Southampton, Havre and Bremen, carrying an unusually large mail, $477,467 70 in specie, 201 first cabin, and 228 second cabin passengers-in all, 429 passengers. This is believed to be the most numerous ship load with which any vessel has ever sailed hence for Europe. On board are the Hon.

At a meeting of the Land Reform Association, of the City of New-York, held last evening, JOHN COMMERFORD in the chair, and BEN PRICE, Secretary, the following preamble and resolutions were unanimously adopted:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The TIMES of the 3d inst., in an editorial, made reflection upon Assistant District Attorney SEDGWICK'S relations to the MULLIGAN conviction, which a large number of gentlemen, professional and lay, who are somewhat conversant with the subject of the editorial, believe to be exceedingly unjust and ungenerous.

OPPOSITION NOMINATIONS.--The delegates to the Opposition County Convention met yesterday afternoon at Newkirk's Hotel, on the five corners, and organized by choosing FRANKLIN B. CARPENTER. Chairman, and WM. B. DUNNING, Secretary. The following nomination were made :

THE REPUBLICAN AND AMERICAN COMMITTEES OF CONFERENCE-It has been arranged that the Republican and American Committees of twenty-two from each County Convention, appointed to agree upon an opposition county ticket at the approaching county election, are to meet to-morrow evening at No. 618 Broadway.

We gave place, yesterday, to a communication in defence of Mr. Assistant District-Attorney SEDGWICK'S " conduct" in the case of MULLIGAN. In a morning contemporary we are charged with having committed a "grave and important error" in blaming that gentleman for his "action" in that case.

Alterations are being made to-day in Judge BOWLIN'S instructions, which must delay the Paraguay Expedition several days. The instructions proper are short, but to them is attached a lengthy record of all the facts involved in our previous diplomacy with Paraguay. Judge BOWLIN will not demand a ratification of the Schenck and Pendleton Treaty, but goes with plenary powers to negotiate a new one.

Arrival of the Cahawba. The United States mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCK commander, from New-Orleans, via Havana, arrived yesterday morning. The Cahawba left New-Orleans on the 26th, and Havana on the evening of the 29th. From the latter place the only intelligence of interest she brings is that the city is very healthy.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, Presdent CLANCY in the Chair. A message was received from the Mayor. transmitting the proceedings of the Police Commissioners, providing for repairing a number of Station-houses and leasing some new ones.

To-day, at 10 o'clock, the Sabbath School teachers of this state meet in Convention, in the Pierrepont-street Baptist Church, Brooklyn. After organizing, the day will be given to reports from the several Country Secretaries, Wednesday morning will be given to discussions; the evening, as also that of Wednesday, to addresses. Thursday closes the Convention.

Quite a time occurred at the pier foot of Cortlandt-street last evening, which was participated in by Washington Engine Company No. 5, of Buffalo, and Amerians No. 6, of this City. Washington was one of the companies at the late firemen's tournament in Albany, and made a rather unexpected visit to this City on Friday last.

MISSIONARIES FOR CHINA.--The Rev. S. L. BALDWIN, Missionary for China, who was ordained in the Clinton-street M. E. Church last Friday evening, was to sail yesterday for China, in the clipper-ship Empress. He takes out with him his wife, also Mrs. BEULAH and Miss SARA WOOLSTON, sisters, both of Trenton, N. J., and Miss F. A. POTTER, of New-York, as teachers.

COX.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 4. at her residence, No. 200 9th-av., Mrs. HERCELIA U.. wife Edward Cox. and daughter of L. H. Haisey, of Seneca Fails, aged 29 years. Her remains were taken to Seneca Fails for interment. MICHLER.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 4. FANNIE K., wife of Lieut. N. Michler, of the Topographical Corps of Engineers, U. S. A., and daughter of the late Judge Kirtland, of this City.

MYSTERIOUS DEATH.--On Sunday, a woman named JULIA LYNCH was found dead in her room on an upper floor of the tenement-house No. 256 East Twelfth-street. It appears that on Friday night she visited her landlord for the purpose of paying her rent, and on her return locked herself within her own apartment.

There are doubtless many persons who have an Interest in the whereabouts and doings of their talented countryman, Lieut. GILLISS, sent out to take observations on the approaching Solar Eclipse. As I accompany him in his mission I may be able to give a few details of the Expedition thus far, which will be interesting.

Since our advices of the 28th ult., the Stock Markets has been a little more spirited, with an upward tendency on all classes with the exception of Railroad Shares. The latter have, in the greater number of cases, lost a part of the rise to which reference was made in our last circular; but New-York Central and Galena and Chicago have advanced in consequence of considerable purchases made by speculators and the public generally.

Our readers must remember the "Montauk mystery," of which we published the exclusive account some two weeks ago. It is at last all explained. We give the whole story from the beginning. On the morning of the 18th of September Mr. GOULD, who keeps the Lighthouse upon Montauk Point, on going up at sunrise to extinguish the light, observed in the southern offing a square-rigged vessel lying off and on, as if waiting for something.

FLOUR--Demand fair at last week's prices; sales 1,500 bbls. WHEAT dull; sales 1,000 bushels Red Winter at $1 20 ; 1,400 bushels prime White Canadian at $1 40. CORN dull and lower ; sales 10,000 bushels sound Western mixed at 70c. Very little demand for OATS; sales 1,000 bushels State at 45c.; 2,000 bushels State at 45 1/2c., both measure.

IS THE SOUTHERN PRESS FOR DOUGLAS?--The Washington Union, of Sunday, denounces the assertion "that the Democratic Press of the South are supporting Judge DOUGLAS" as an "allegation too monstrous for the credulity of the public," and one which "requires no serious refutation."

COPELAND--WORSTER.--In this City, on Thursday, Sept. 30, by the Rev. Dr. Hutton, Mr. P. H. COPELAND to Miss MARY J., eldest daughter of Joseph Worster, M. D., all of this City. BREVOORT--TUTHILL.--At BROOKLYN, On Saturday, Oct. 2, by the Rev. Jacob West. Mr. JAMES RENWICK BREVOORT, of Fordham, to Miss ANNA AUGUSTA TUTHILL, of Brooklyn.

THE LONG ISLAND MYSTERY. -Thanks to the perseverance of Marshal RYNDERS, the mysterious strangers who recently landed on the east end of Long Island, after scuttling their ship, and created so much suspicion by their mysterious conduct, have been found, and the whole mystery of their landing has been explained.

The Christian Denomination are to have a General Convention in this City, commencing this morning, at 10 o'clock, in the Lecture-room of the Mercantile Library, Astor-place. This evening an address will be delivered before the Convention by the Rev. JAMES MAPLE, of Ohio; and on Friday evening the Hon. HORACE MANN, President of Antioch College, founded by this Denomination, will deliver a lecture on " The Relation between Colleges and the People."

Our Havana files furnish information from Laguayra, to Sept. 8. The troaty for the surrender of MONAGAS and GUTIERREZ, negotiated on the part of the French and English by Mr. F. DOOXTON ORME, the new English Charge Affaires, was signed on the 28th of August. The following were its provisions: ART. ??. The dismissal of Gen. J. T. MONAGAS in Safety from the country.

A BURGLARY.-The silk warehouse of Mr. ISAACS, No. 104 Duane-street, was broken into at a late hour last night by burglars, who effected an entrance by prying open one of the iron shutters in the rear, which is an alley-way. The thieves succeeding in collecting and packing into bags several thousand dollars worth of silks, when they were prematurely disturbed by a private watchman, who fired a pistol at them as they fled.

Among the foreign intelligence in the TIMES of this morning, it will be read that the Czar has conferred the title of "Count Amoorski" upon General MOURAVIEFF. The rescript ascribes the honor to the General's share in the negotiation of the late Chinese Treaty ; and to his efforts for the "civil regeneration of Siberia."

The Cooper Institute was quite filled last evening by the members of the American Party, assembled there to ratify the State ticket of the party. Tar-barrels blazed outside, and Robertson's Band serenaded the passers-by previous to the organization of the meeting. At 8 o'clock HIRAM KETCHUM, Esq., was called to the Chair, and Mr. RIKER read a list of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries, which was ratified by acclamation. Mr. KETCHUM then made a speech.

AN OLD LADY ASSAULTED BY FOUR ROWDIES. HER PROBABLE DEATH.--Margaret Crossin, a woman over fifty years of age, residing at No. 637 Washington-street, now lies at the point of death from the effect of a murderous and wanton assault committed upon her by four young rowdies belonging to the gang of Eighth Ward " Short Boys." The anger of the assailants for some reason had been excited against a son of Mrs. Crossing.

The destruction of the crystal Palace, yesterday, was one of the most disastrous conflagrations that New-York has been visited with in a long time. The calamity has struck every one aghast, for the possibility of such an event has never been calculated upon.

THE NOMINEE OF THE SECOND CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT. - We notice that EDWIN C. LITCHFIELD, Esq., has been nominated for Congress in the Second Congressional District - which is composed of the first twelve and Nineteenth Wards of the city of Brooklyn - by what is termed the "Venderbilt" section of the Democratic Party. Mr. LITCHFIELD enjoys the confidence of his fellow-citizens, and will consequently poll a very large vote in his District independent of party.

At ten minutes after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the famous Crystal Palace, where the Fair of the American Institute was being held, took fire. The flames spread so rapidly that in twelve minutes the dome fell, and in twenty-one minutes almost the whole structure was burned to the ground. One of the minarets still stands, and small portions of the wall are yet erect.

UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE.--The population of this State is estimated to be 3,750,000. Of this number about 700,000 are legal voters-less than one-sixth . By what rule of language, then, do we speak of universal suffrage? Those who are not permitted to approach the ballot-box are subject to laws which they can have no voice in framing.

PATRICK TRACY and GEORGE BURNS, two of the unfortunate men stabbed in the fight on Sunday night at the Cosmopolitan Lager-Bier Gardens, corner of Third-avenue and Seventy-eighth-street, [were reported in the Nineteenth Ward returns,' yesterday morning, to have died during Monday night, but the report was not correct. ' Among the Irish population residing in the vicinity there is evidence of increasing and alarming excitement growing out of the death of the deceased.

The rel??ves and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further invitation, this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 1 1/2 o'clock, from his late residence No. 141 Broome ??. His remains will be taken to Gre?? wood Cemetery for interment.

BENEFITS OF TRAVELING.--Gen. JEFFERSON DAVIS, of Mississippi, has been lately sojourning in the State of Maine, with manifest advantage to his physical and political condition. On the 30th ult. he attended an Agricultural Fair at Augusta, where he made a very sensible speech.

A private letter receive from Arizona, states that the Fort Yuma wagon-road, under the superintendence of Col. LEACH, is nearly completed. The largest political Convention ever held on the Rio Grande, assembled at Messilla, on the 3d of September. The delegates represented about 10,000 people. Resolutions were passed calling on Congress to organize at an early day;

The Crystal Palace was totally destroyed by fire yesterday. At a few minutes after 5 P. M., a fire was discovered in the Forty-second-street entrance, which has been used as a lumber room since the opening of the Fair. The flames spread with fearful rapidity, and darting up through the steps of the staircase above communicated to a large gas chandelier with thirty-one burners,

The Screw-steamship Hammonia, of the Hamburg line, Captain SCHWENSON, from Hamburg on the 21st September, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The steamship Nova Scotian, of the Montreal fine, from Liverpool on the 22nd September, arrived simultaneously at Quebee. The R. M. steamship Canada, from Boston, arrived at Liverpool on the evening of the 18th.

There were at least 6,000 people-sound and reliable Democrats to appearance-gathered at the corner of Hudson and Charlton streets last night, to hear General WALBRIDGE on national questions and State politics. A series of resolutions were passed, approving the National Administration, indorsing the Democratic State ticket, and winding up with the following:

The Commissioners sent hither by the Govvernment of Venezuela to recall the veteran PAEZ, yesterday achieved its mission. The scene was one of exceeding interest. At the Metropolitan Hotel a large body of ladies and gentlemen had gathered to be its witnesses;

TESTIMONIAL BENEFIT TO MAX MARETZEK.--An agitation of a peculiar kind is now moving the depths of that somewhat shallow affair known as the artistic conscience. It is proposed that a grand testimonial performance be given for the benefit of Mr. MARETZEK, and a number of prominent admirers of the "indomitable" are working "with a will" to make it a perfect success. The occasion is well chosen.

The United States Mail steamship Arago, D. LINES, Esq., Commander, from Havre and Southampton at 6 o'clock P.M. on Sept. 22, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She encountered strong westerly gales throughout the passage. Amongst her passengers are Colonel RAASLOPP and family, Charge d' affaires from Denmark to Washington;

THE OPPOSITION CONFERENCE COMMITTEES.--The Committee of Twenty-two (composed of one from each Ward) appointed by the Republican County Convention, to confer "with all opposed to the Buchanan Democracy," has a meeting last evening at No. 618 Broadway. There was but one absentee.

HOW TO GET CUBA.--A NEW SCHEME.--The Albany Atlas and Argus undertakes to solve the problem of Cuba in an article which we copy this morning. Slaves, it assumes, on the joint authority of HUMBOLDT and experience, are constantly decreasing in Cuba. An Imperative demand for laborers is thus created.

Early as daylight, and thence onward to dusk, the Sixth-avenue, between Forty-first and Forty-second streets, was yesterday crowded with people of all classes, complexions and conditions, attracted to the spot by the news of the destruction of the Crys- THE PALACE STATUARY. The lovers of Art will regret the loss of one or two noble works which were in tile Palace, and shared its destruction.

By order of Court, in the case of HENRY W. SARGENT vs. PHOEBE WYCKOFF, Mr. BLEECKER sold the building and lot known as No. 38 Pine-street on the north side, between Nassau and William streets, 23.8 x 61.8 feet, for the sum of $18,000. The name of the buyer was not announced so as to be understood; it sounded something like JOHN K. BELL.

The New-York State Fair nominally opened this morning with the usual assemblage of all the agricultural enginery--the adipose sheep and swine, and the masculine, feminine and neuter of the bovine race. The usual mixed assembly of Hereford, Devon and Durham calves, COWS and bulls Is already very large, although the ordinary incompleteness and uproar of preparation, inseparable from a first exhibition day, governs the occasion here.

In your issue of to-day I notice a leading article in which the memory of the liberator of my country, General SIMON BOLIVAR, is treated with entire injustice. Your article has deeply grieved me, and is opposed to all that I have seen and that the world knows of that immortal hero, whose great achievements, both political and military, occupy a prominent place in history.

The Second Assembly District Convention American, organized last night by electing. AUGUSTAN P. GREENE, of the Fourth Ward, Chairman, and BENE E. HANCOCK, of the Sixth Ward, Secretary. After appointing a Committee of three to consult with the Republicans of the District the Convention adjourned. The Comet blazes brighter and brighter every night and morning. A week ago it flamed up, from under the Great Bear.

The Governor of the State, Mayor TIEMANN, Lieutenant-Governor SELDEN, the State Comptroller, and the Quarantine Commissioners, Messrs. HALL, BOWNE and BENSON, on Tuesday made an excursion to the Lower Bay, for the purpose of examining into the various plans proposed for the removal of Quarantine. Besides the gentlemen above mentioned, Commodore VANDERBILT, GEORGE LAW, Gzo. W. BLUNT, Mr. HALSTEAD, of New-Jersey:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Wanted--by the Comptroller of the City of New-York--two hundred gentlemen, tax-payers of the City of New-York, to become security in the sum of $1,000 each, on behalf of the Comptroller, to enable him to remove the late decision of Judge INEGRAHAM in the case of this judgement to General Term of the Supreme Court for review.

THE LADIES' EQUESTRIAN CONVENTION.--At Jones' Wood, yesterday, some eight or nine hundred people assembled to witness a Ladies' Equestrian Exhibition. It has been announced in the journals and on huge posters with a vast flourish of trumpets but it proved but a sorry, not to say, a disreputable affair.

DURING--HINSHELWOOD.--In this City, on Monday, Sept. 27, by the Rev. H. Mattison, Mr. C. A. A. DURING to Miss F. HINSHELWOOD, all of this City. FINCH--PATTERSON.--In this City, on Tuesday, Oct. 5, by the Rev. Duncan Dunbar, Pastor of the McDougal-st. Baptist Church, GEORGE W. FINCH to RACHEL, the only daughter of Robert Patterson, Esq., all of this City.

Recorder BARNARD's charge to tile Grand Jury on Tuesday morning is a singular specimen of Judicial logic. His official position in connection with our criminal Courts entitles his utterances to brief examination. Last Spring the Grand Jury made a presentment of Sunday disturbances as a prominent cause of crime.

It alleges that as member of Congress he achieved no other distinction than that of deserting his own party and joining one which had been the bitter and unscrupulous

We have news from Havana to the 2d inst., by the arrival of the Black Warrior at New-Orleans. A terrible explosion of a powder magazine occurred there on the night of the 29th ult. The magazine was filled with powder, shells and rockets, and the explosion was attended by the most disastrous effects.

CHANGED ASPECT OF THE CITY.--Such of our citizens as have been spending the Summer abroad will miss, on their return, three of the most noticeable objects which have heretofore arrested the eye on approaching the City.

MULLER.-In this City. on Tuesday, Oct. 5 MARY, whe of Charles Muller, only laughter of John and Elizabeth Matthews, aged 27 years. 10 months and 5 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further invitation, on Thursday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 43 1st- av.

The Boston Gurorier is authorized to state that Dr. GOULD is instructed by his legal counsel that, under the contract in writing which was referred to in the resolutions of the Trustees of Jan. 9, 1858, he is entitled to the charge of the Duchley. Observatory, which he now has, and that the contract will be ?? at the trial of the suit at law which he is awaiting from the Trustees.

A Public meeting was held last night in the Cooper Institute, in pursuance and of advertisement intimating that then and there the Hon. GERRIT SMITH would present himself as a candidate for Governor, answer such queries and questions of public policy as might be propounded to him, and state the views by which he would be guided in the event of his election.

The Administraion attributes the sudden change in the course of Gen. JEREZ to the timely exposure made of the Ouseley Treaty. JEREZ now comes forward, makes the required apology, promises all that has been demanded, and is received as Minister from Nicaragua. Secretary FLOYD left this morning to visit his coalfields on the Kenawha.

THE SCHEME OF THE QUARANTINE COMMISSIONERS FOR CREATING AN ISLAND IN THE LOWER BAY.--The Governor, Lieutenant-Governor and Comptroller have done a wise thing so far assenting to the proposal of the Quarantine Commissioner for constructing hospitals in the lower bay, as to consent to a survey of the shoals being made by competent engineers appointed by the Governor and his two associates.

SUFFOLK COUNTY.--The following are the nominations for Country Officers in Suffolk County, by the Republican and American Conventions, Jointly: Sheriff--Stephen J. Wilson. County Clerk--Charles R. Dayton. District-Attorney--George Miller. Superintendent of County Poor--Alanson Seaman. Justice of Sessions--Edwin Rose. Assembly--First District--Benjamin F. Wiggins. Assembly--Second District--Robert Rogers.

The decision of Mr. Justice NELSON in a recent revenue case, which published yesterday, requires a few words of comment that must not be regarded as disrespectful to the Bench. The law of tile land is supposed to be the aggregate common sense of the country; and as common sense is not confined to judges, lawyers, or legislators,

GERRIT SMITH IN BROOKLYN.--In the course of his political circuit, Mr. GERRIT SMITH bestowed himself last evening upon the County of Kings. But the colored men of Brooklyn forestalled him. They met on Wednesday night to ratify the doings of the Troy Colored Convention, which they did with a will.

A man named FRACTRELLEN, residing at No. 70 Waterloo-road, Liverpool, has been in the habit of issuing passage tickets to emigrants from Liverpool to various parts of the United States and Canada. His drafts and orders were directed to P. A. LOESCHER, No. 74 Greenwich-street, New York. It appears that LOESCHER refuses to honor many of these drafts, now in the hands of swindled emigrants.

Last night GERRIT SMITH, the independent candidate for Governor, met a large assemblage of the voters of Brooklyn in Montague Hall. Mr. S. A. BEERS was chosen Chairman. A large number of queries, written and oral, were put to Mr. SMITH, to all of which he replied with his customary promptitude and ability. Many were substantial repetitions of those proposed and answered at the meeting in New-York on the previous night. These we omit.

The agricultural discussions which were inaugurated last year, as a lending feature of the annual meetings, were well attended at the Voorhies House, and several topics were treated in a practical point of view, by practical men. Chancellor McCOUN, of Oyster Bay, presided. THE TREATMENT OF CATTLE, OF THE HAY AND ROOT CROPS DAIRY, VENTILATION, ,

The ruins of the Crystal Palace yesterday presented a very desolate appearance. The City authorities having taken possession of the grounds, no person was admitted within the inclosures, and the crowd of spectators that thronged the outskirts on the day previous, were kept away by the rain.

The R. M. steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 25th Sept., with three days later news from Europe, arrived at Halitax yesterday forenoon, and a telegraphic summary of her news will be found elsewhere. The commercial and monetary news by this arrival is of interest.

The Occidental (Independence) Messenger, of the 25th, says: "Several gentlemen arrived at this place on Thursday last, direct from the gold mines near Pike's Peak. The parties live in Ray County, Mo., and have spent several months prospecting for gold in these mines.

The approaching marriage of the Duke of MALAKOFF is just now exciting a great deal of rejoicing amongst the court circles in France and England. The Duke has reached the ripe age of fifty-five; he is robust in form, short in stature, has the temper of a fire-eater, and the manners of a trooper, while his intended bride is a lovely girl of eighteen.

M. VON HUMBOLDT has celebrated his ninetieth birthday. An English correspondent. writing from Berlin, says that "never did a conqueror receive congratulations from so many persons and such great distances, as the post-boy had to carry on Tuesday morning to the well-known house in the Oransien-burger-scrasse.

A correspondent writes us from Chicago, to say that the politics of this State are to the simple-minded people of the West an impenetrable mystery. We can easily believe it. Nor are the denizens of Illinois alone in this bewilderment.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Capt. LANG, left Liverpool at 10 o'clock A. M. on the 25th ult., 2nd arrived at Halifax at 7 A. M. of the 7th inst. She reports, 25th ult., passed the American ship Resolute, bound west; 4th inst., passed the British bank Catharine, bound east.

BIBLE PRESENTATION TO FIRE COMPANIES. The various fire companies of Jersey City assembled, last evening, at the Baptist Church, in Grove-street, where each company was presented with a large elegantly-bound bible by the Jersey City Bible Society. There were about 150 members of the Department present. Captain W. T. RODGERS presided.

Professor E. FELIX FORESH, for several years a well-known resident of this City, and recently appointed United States Consul at Geno a, has just died at the latter city. Professor FORESH'S history was remarkable. He was a fellow-prisoner with SILVIO PELLICO, and suffered severe hardships for his devotion to the liberal cause in Italy.

SUPPOSED SUICIDE OR A YOUNG GIRL--?? BILLING ?? a young girl, ?? years of ago, ?? lived with per parents ?? James-slip, and who, had been missing for a week, was found drowned yesterday morning at the foot ?? Catherine-street. Coroner HILLS held an inquest on the body.

New York politics, to us simple-minded Illinoisans, is like the ways of Providence, mysterious and past finding out. The failure of the Americans and Republicans to unite on one State ticket when both sides professed such good intentions, is an enigma that we, out here, cannot solve or understand. In this State we had no difficulty in uniting.

The Board of Alderman met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. A message was received from the Mayor, transmitting a communication from P.T. Rojas, in behalf of the National Convention of Venezuela, as follows: NEW-YORK, Oct, 6, 1858.

In New-York, during the past week, the leading kinds of WOOL have been in lively request, and desirable lots of Domestic,which have been less abundant, have commanded somewhat firmer prices. The market for Foreign has also exhibited increased vigor, especially for coarse, low-priced qualities, which have been most sought after by manufacturers,--who have purchased freely,-though the particulars of their movements have not been disclosed.

THE DUDLEY OBSERVATORY CONTROVERSY AGAIN.--The Albany Atlas and Argus publishes a long letter from the Hon. JOHN V. L. PRUYN, occasioned by personal allusions in the recent statement of the Trustees of the Dudley Observatory. Mr. PRUYN denounces that statement as disingenuous and dishonorable in that it contained extracts from private correspondence and attacked personal character.

Judge BOWLIN received his instructions at a late hour last night, and he will leave this afternoon for New-York. SAMUEL WARD, of California, has received the appointment of Secretary of Legation to Paraguay. The Sabine will sail on Wednesday next by order of Secretary TOUCEY. The steamers Atlanta and Memphis have been pronounced unseaworthy.

A resolution directing the Counsel to the Corporation to institute legal proceedings against Mr. TERENCE FARLEY for alleged defalcations, to the amount of $4,308 45, was lost, in the Board of Councilmen, on Monday evening last, by a vote of 11 to 6.

BRITISH FEELING TOWARDS AMERICA.--The solemn exhortations of the London Times which we copied yesterday, calling upon America to live on good terms with the British people, forms as close an approach to the embarrassing position of Satan reproving sin, as that highly respectable journal can be expected to make.

SCUDDER, BENJAMIN VAN RIPER, JAMES A. BRIGGS and others. The Democratic (Sweeney) Rebublican General Committee met last evening at Tammany Hall for the purpose of making arrangements for the primary election for delegates to the various nominating Conventions.

DECLINING THE STUMP.--The Republican candidate for Congress in the Oneida District is ROSCAL CONKLING, and P. SHELDON ROOT is his Democratic competitor. On the 28th ult. the former addressed the latter, proposing a joint canvass of the District for the purpose of discussing in the presence of the electors the political issues which now occupy the country.

AN IMPORTANT VERDICT.---In the Philadelphia Court of Quarter Sessions, oil Monday last, a man named WILLIAM NIXON was pronounced guilty of manslaughter, for having left his horse and cart standing, unattended in a public street. by which negligence a child was killed. The verdict in this case, the Inquirer says, will be a warning to those, and they are numberless.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: On Tuesday, the 5th inst., it was my great affliction and sad misfortune to witness the death of my beloved wife. Sho died from confirmed consumption, and had been sick and confined to her house for many months. At the time of the lire at Quarantine, on the night of the 2d September ult., my dwelling was burned by tile mob,

A man was most miraculously saved from drowning at the foot of Beach-street, North River, at 10 o'clock last evening, through the most humane efforts of Captain P. W. KING, of the steamship Washington, at the risk of his own life. He was on board at the time, and hearing a noise on the dock, rushing to the side of the ship he heard the ery of a man overboard.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: A new and very dangerous counterfeit $20 bill purporting to be on the Bank of the State of NewYork of this City, has just been put in circulation. The following is a description: The vignette represents an Indian girl seated, leaning her arm on a rock and looking at rail-cars, steamboat and city in the distance.

Whatever may be thought of GERRIT SMITH'S political principles, or of his chances of becoming Governor of the State, there can be but little question that in his manner of conducting his canvass, as at present,he is doing the right thing.

At the quarterly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, Thursday evening, at Clinton Hall,Astorplace, a communication was received from the Mayor, requesting their opinion upon his proposition to con:struct a wharf and pier on the west bank, to allow vessels undergoing Quarantine to unload their cargoes. Capt. C. H. MARSHALL had some objections to the ?? recommended.

We publish, this morning, all the testimony that has yet been taken by the Committee of Managers of the American Institute Fair, with reference to the origin of the conflagration of the Crystal Palace. This testimony consists of the affidavits of managers, superintendents, floor clerks, exhibitors, and visitors, and it all tends to the same point-that the lire must have been the work of an incendiary.

Mrs. ANN BURGES, a woman neither very young nor remarkably handsome, assaulted with a cowhide, in his store No. 41 Warren-street, her brother-in-law, Mr. JOSEPH BURGES. She laid on the blows both fast and thick, which caused a disturbance so great that a Policeman interfered and made a prisoner of Mrs. BURGES and took her before Justice WELSH at the City Hall Police Court.

The workmen engaged by the City authorities to complete the demolition of the crystal Palace, and put the grounds in a safe condition for the reception of the exhibitors at the late Fair, were employed all day yesterday at their task, and at dark only tow of the eight large iron towers that supported the structure, were left standing. A large crowd of spectators were on hand to witness the final destruction.

ARREST OF THE MURDERER MCMAHON.--We are gratified to learn that a dispatch was received yesterday by Major BIGELOW from Chief of Police WHITNEY, dated St. Louis, stating that JAMES McMAHON, who murdered Mrs. ANN McMAHON in this city on the 19th of September, had been arrested in that city. We are without any details as to the arrest, but the simple fact is in the highest degree gratifying.

Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELEY leaves for Central America in the British war-steamer Valorous, which attended tile Agamemnon while paying out the Atlantic cable. The Valorous has been attached to the Halifax station, and may be expected hourly at New-York. Sir WILLIAM will cross the Isthmus at Panama, and proceed thence in a British vessel up the coast to Realejo-thence by Leon to Granada.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In an article published in your paper of this morning, animadverting upon the decision of Judge NELSON, in the case of EDWARD MARSHALL and THOMAS TILLOTSON against HEMAN J. REDFIELD, great injustice is done the present Secretary of the Treasury. You say, referring to the money paid as duty which had been the subject of litigation.

IS THERE AN ABSCONDING DEBTOR AMONG US?--A man named JOHN METCALFE was arrested yesterday on board the steamship Washington, which sails to-day for Europe, charged with attempting to abscond with moneys which he owed Mr. JOHN LAIDLAW, dry goods merchant of Toronto, Canada. Mr. LAIDLAW said that he had sold goods, worth $120, to METCALFE, at Toronto, some two weeks since;

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-DONIZETTI'S delightful opera of "Linda di Chamounix" was played here last night, and, although for the first time this season, failed to attract a crowded audience. It was well given, especially tile Linda of Madame GASSIER, one of her best and most complete efforts. The opera afforded the new basso, Signor GARIBOLDI, an opportunity to make his mark / and he succeeded in doing so to the entire satisfaction of the audience.

This was to have been the great day of the feast, but I fear it will prove a Barmecide repast, for the murky sky anti occasional showers must dampen the enthusiasm as well as lessen the attendance. The Fair has been considered a great success-the receipts being considerably in advance of last year, and the promise of attendance during the remaining days of the Fair large.

The whole world, just now, are more or less excited about comets, and comets are, therefore, proper subject for journalistic reflections, at a time when DONATI'S comet is in full view, and is attracting the attention of savants, professional and amateur, in both hemispheres. It may not be uninteresting to chronicle the appearance of the most remarkable of these erratic bodies.

We have received our Utah correspondence to the 11th September. There is no news of importance. A search for the Territorial Library has been made, but unsuccessfully. Snow had begun to fall in the Territory, and several cattle in the mountains had perished from cold. The army had moved into Winter quarters. Gen. JOHNSTON had assigned the command to Lieut.-Colonel SMITH, and himself entered upon the duties of Commandant of the Department of Utah.

A NEW SWINDLING DODGE.--Two respectable looking men did a very successful swindling business yesterday, in the eastern side of the City, with a $20 gold piece. Their mode of operation was to go into a store and ask change for their gold piece. Bills would be passed to them and they would adroitly extract a bill, then throw back the remaining bills, stating that they wanted smaller gold.

YELLOW FEVER REPORT.--At the meeting of the Commissioners of Health yesterday, the Health Officer submitted a statistical report showing that a much greater number of infected vessels and imported cases of yellow fever have arrived at Quarantine during the past two months than at any previous and similar period since the establishment of the institution.

ASSEMBLY NOMINATION IN THE THIRD DISTRICT. -The Republicans of the Third Assembly District met at Riley's Hotel, last evening, and unanimously nominated HENRY A. MORGAN as the candidate for that District. The Americans met at the same time at the St. Johns Hotel, and made the same nomination.

THE PRINCE ALBERT--PROPOSED FLAG PRESENTATION.--A large and respectable meeting took place last evening at Tammany Hall to make arrangements for presenting a flag to Captain WATERS upon the next sailing of the Prince Albert on the 18th inst. Mr. McMAHON presided. A Committee was appointed to carry out the objects of the meeting, and subscriptions were received.

The Managers of the Fair, at their meeting yesterday, determined after long discussions that it was inexpedient to reopen the Fair this Fall. One party urged it at any cost,-deeming it due to exhibitors, who had lost so much, that they should have the opportunity at least to compete for the premiums of the Institute.

The Revolution, or civil war in Sonora, commenced in June, 1856, with an attack on the capital, Ures, which was in possession of the party of GANDARA, a former Governor, and the Commandant General. GANADARA was man of large estates very hospitable, and of liberal views, much loved and respected by all the liberalists in the State.

FROM SAN FRENCISCO OVERLAND.-The Overland Mail Company has demonstrated the practicability and utility of its contract. We print in another column news which left San Francisco on September 16, reaching St. Louis on the 9th instant, thus effecting the transit in twenty-three days, rivalling the fastest time by the sea route. This is well.

A NEW LINE OF STEAMERS FOR HAVANA.--Capitalists who are largely interested in the Cuban made both here and in Havana, have organized a Joint Stock Company. with a large capital, for the purpose of placing a new line of two fast steamers upon the route between New-York and Havana.

ROBERY IN AN WHOLESALE HOUSE. - About 10 1/2 o'clock on Saturday night, JOSEPH REDING, residing at the corner of Washington and Montgomery streets, was arrested at the Jersey City Ferry Depot by Officer FARLEY, on a charge of feloniously entering the saddlery store of BETTS, NICHOLS Co., No. 99 Liberty-street, New-York, and stealing $200 from the safe.

It was then distant from the noses of the free and enlightened population of this favored town only the trifling stretch of fifty-four millions of miles.

The first Overland Mail from California arrived at St. Louis at 9 o'clock on Saturday night, having left San Francisco on the 16th of September. The news is, consequently, ten days later than was received by way of Panama. The trip occupied but a little over twenty-three days, and six passengers came through by the stages.

It calls upon the Democracy to stand by the Dred Scott decision as a finality:

Notwithstanding all the adverse measures of some of the extreme members of both the Republican and American parties, there is so strong a desire for fusion among the masses on both sides that it will be difficult to prevent a union in the City and County tickets.

Horrible Murder at Pawling, Dutchess County-Escape of the Murderer. A brutal murder was committed in the town of Pawling, Dutchess County, on Sunday night, 3d inst. A gentleman named BANCROFT has a county residence at Pawling, where he resides through the Summer months.

The U. S. steamer Harriet Lane left her anchorage at Quarantine on Saturday morning at 8 o'clock A. M., and proceeded to sea. She touches at St. Thomas for supplies on her way to Paraguay. OUR SQUADRON IN THE EAST INDIRES.--The Secretary of the Navy has received dispatches to the 5th of July from Commodere TATTNALL, in command of the squadron in the East Indies and Chinese seas.

AN ORGAN READ OUT OF ITS OWN PARTY.--The Democratic Party has but one professed daily organ in this City, and that one, we regret to see, has been read out of the party by bell, book and candle. The Administration organ in Washington performed this ungracious act on Friday last.

THE CASE OF IRA STOUT.--All efforts to save IRA STOUT from execution, for the murder of CIIARLES W. LITTLES at Rochester, seem to be unavailing. The individual Judges of the Supreme Court have in turn been applied to by STOUT'S counsel, and in turn have refused to grant a writ of error.

The Hon AMASA J. PARKER, Democratic candidate for Governor, addressed a large meeting at Mechanics' Hall, in this city, last evening. In the course of his speech, Judge PARKER denied that he had voted against the right of petition in Congress.

Yesterday morning, DODWORTH'S Dancingroom, adjoining Grace Church, was to filled to overflowing (as the phrase goes) with a congregation of Spiritualists. There was not sitting-room enough for those who came early; there was not standing-room for those who caine late.

Mr. BERRY AT THE PRAYER-MEETING IN JOHN STREET CHURCH.--On Saturday last a large prayer meeting was held in the john-street Church, at which Mr. BERRY, one of the passengers saved from the Austria, conducted the services and related his personal experiences whilst awaiting instant death at the time of the destruction of that fated vessel.

From the Philadelphia Press. On Monday the Norwegian bark Calarina arrived at Quebec with fifteen of the passengers and seven of the crew of the burned steamer Austria. These are additional to the sixty-seven already rescued, and make a total of eighty-nine.

Gov. BANES and lady attended the parade and ball of that ancient Boston institution, the "Honorable Artillery," at Barnstable, last week. THE YELLOW FEVER IN NEW-ORLEANS NO BETTER.--The New-Orleans Picayune of the 3d says: "There is ever indication of a very heavy Fall business, and it is as much as the epidemic can do to keep back to some degree the tide of commerce swelling to our port. The daily and weekly reports sufficiently tell the tale of the sickness.

State Elections to be Held To-day. Elections take place to-day in five States--Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Iowa and Minnesota. Sixty-one members of the House of Representatives--or nearly one-fourth of the whole number--are to be elected in these States.

NO ADMITTANCE FOR YOUNG LADIES.--Progress has received a check in Michigan. Young Ladies are denied admission to the classes of the University at Aun Arbor. That institution has been founded and indorsed by the State, and it is contended that the Act of its incorporation includes women as among the "persons" entitled to its benefits.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. Presuming you are familiar with the cause or origin of the difficulty between the United States and Paraguay, will you state briefly in the TIMES what it is? We are, here in the country, entirely unacquainted with the matter, nor can we imaging how we could have any cause of controversy with the isolated State.

Another year of abundant harvests, of general health, contentment and tranquillity, admonish us of our first and constant duty, to render thanks and praise to Him who is the gracious Author and Giver of those: needful benefits, and the manifold blessings we have been permitted to enjoy; and especially are we called upon to acknowledge the power and goodness of our almighty Father.

We have European advices by the Indian Empire at Halifax, and the City of Baltimore off Cape Race. The Indian Empire, of the Galway Line, ar rived at Halifax on Sunday. Her dates are to the 28th September. A synopsis of the Chinese Treaty has appeared in the English papers, supplied from the Foreign Office.

JUDGE PARKER'S UTICA SPEECH.--We pub lihed in yesterday's TIMES a report of the speech made at Utica on Friday evening by the Hon. AMASA J. PARKER, the Democratic candidate for Governor. It will, we apprehend, disappoint the public expectation. From that gentleman's professional and judicial

THE MUTINEERS OF SHIP JUNIOR.--The eighth persons charged with mutiny and murder on board the whale ship Junior, of New-Bedford, have been arraigned at Boston. After two days' examination into the case, Commissioner CUSHMAN gave his decision.

The Cumberland and the Commodore, with the corvettes Dale and vincennes, and the Storeship Release, of Arctic fame. have all been filing up with provisions at Porto Praya, for immediate cruising down the coast. The Date goes, in a few days, to the Gulf of Guinea, the mouths of the Niger, Fernando Po, and to the country of Dahomey, with its Amazonian army.

The name of Mrs. WACHMANN and child, of Cincinnati, which has been set down in the list of those lost by the Austria, should not have been placed there. She arrived at Hamburg too late to take passage in the unfortunate vessel. She arrived in this City by the Hammonia, safe and sound.

The American Institute yesterday resumed possession of the grounds where formerly the Crystal Palace stood, and exhibitors were permitted to search among the ruins. From three to four hundred availed themselves of the privilege, but such is the condition of the ruins that it is next to impossible to recover the relics of the Exhibition, even in cases--rare indeed--where they are worth recovering.

LOTTERY SWINDLERS.--His Honor, the Mayor, received on Monday morning, from a Mrs. DERBY, of Belvidere, Boone County, Illinois, the following communication, upon which she wishes the Mayor to compel the agent to return the money; sating that herself and her husband are emigrants, and very poor. The Mayor was of opinion that he had no authority to interfere in the matter;

GOV. WISE ON DIRECT TRADE--GOV. WISE, of Virginia, has recently addressed a long letter to the people of Norfolk on that chimerical hobby of the South, direct trade with Europe; and that eccentric but brilliant statesman has given his follow-cilizens on this occasion, as he has often before, some sound practical advice, which is too direct and sensible to be altogether acceptable to them.

Senator BROWN, of Mississippi, left here this afternoon for New-York. He declares his entire confidence in the success of Judge DOUGLAS. Capt. REYNOLDS, of the U. S. Army, arrived here to-day from Mianesota, where he had been to turn over the Fort Shelling property to the purchasers. Capt. R. thinks the Government got at least twice the value of the property.

DIED IN THE STATION-HOUSE.--MARGARET HALPIN, an Irish woman, on Sunday night applied for lodgings at the Fourteenth Ward Station-house, and was shortly afterwards found dead in her cell. An inquest was held yesterday on the body. Death was supposed to have been caused by disease of the lungs and liver, combined with want and exposure.

The Brownsville Flag, of the 29th ult., which furnishes the following Mexican news. It appears that the expected battle between the forces of VIDAURRI and those of MIRAMON had not taken place at last accounts. Private letters have been received in this city from San Luis Potosi to the 13th instant, from which it appears that there has been no fighting there as yet.

FASHIN COURSE, L. I.--TROTTING. The trotting match for $2,000, mile heats, best three in five, to wagons, between bl. g. Lancet and b. g. Lantern, came off Saturday afternoon, according to announcement, and was won by Lancet after four severely contested heats. Three-fourths of the track was as heavy as if it had recently been ploughed up.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The following resolution was offered by Alderman REED, and laid over: Resolved, That the Street Commissioner be authorized and directed to remove all obstructions on the Eleventh-avenue, from Twenty-third-street to its south erly terminus, the same to be done forthwith.

Brooklyn Common Council. A regular meeting of this Board, was held last evening, President KALBELEISCH in the chair. The Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies was directed to advertise for proposals to repair the dock at the foot of Main-Street. The City Clerk was directed to give the necessary notice for the November election, and was authorized to obtain the necessary blanks.
MULLIGAN TRIUMPHANT. - It was no fault of Recorder BARNARD, nor of the District-Attorney, that the Mulligan was not tried yesterday in the Court of Sessions.

Our files of Nassau papers extend to the 29th September. The intelligence is without interest. The General Assembly has been further prorogned to Tuesday, the 23d of November. The case of the American ship Inca, bound from New-Orleans to Boston. Laden with cotton, but wrecked on the Riding Rocks, has been decided by the local court of Appeals.

The Daily News City Article of this morning says. "Throughout the Stock Exchange the Extraordinary case of the Money market, and the rapid accumulation of bullion, are exercising a stimulation influence on every side; buyers predominate. and nearly all classes of securities are rising. Business is at the same time becoming more active, and in source departments considerable animation prevailed to-day.

PARKS.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 11, at the residence of Capt. E. U. Walford, MARGARET A. PARKS, aged 33 years. Her funeral will take place from the dwelling of her sister-in-law, Mrs. Starkweather, No. 51 Pike-st., this day. (Wednesday,) at 10 A. M. All the friends of the family are invited to attend, without further notice. Danville, Va., papers please copy.

THEu POLILCY DEALERS.-Nelson Holmes, of No. 140 Forsyth-street, appeared before the Mayor, yesterday, complaining of two alleged policy dealers, one, named Martin Doyle, corner of Fourth and Thirteenth streets, the other, Michael Fitzgerald, of Avenue D, between Ninth and Tenth streets. They were arrested by one of the Mayor's Police, and each was held to bail to answer in $500.

There has been great buoyancy in the English lands to-day, and Console have closed at a further improvement of a 1/2 cent. The first price was 97 ?? at which they remained until noon, when the Government broker, whose purchases on account of the Savings Banks had been discontinued for the past two or three weeks, resumed his operations, and took [pound]20,000 stock.

United States frigate Macedonian, Commander H. P. LEVY, was at Spezzia on the 14th alt., all well. On the passage out the Macedonian fell in with an English merchantman, the ship Chanticleer, of London, short of provisions. A handsome supply of everything necessary was sent on board by Captain LEVY, and the Chanticleer went on her way rejoicing.

The screw steamship City of Baltimore, R. LEITCH, Esq., Commander, from Liverpool at 11 A. M. of Sept. 20, arrived at this port last evening. To the meagre outline of her news forwarded from Cape Race, we add important details and extracts. The Borussia steamer arrived at Southampton on the 28th ult. from New-York. The conditions of the Treaty were generally regarded with satisfaction.

Congressional Nominations. The Tammanny Democracy met last evening, in their respective districts, to nominate candidates for Congress. But little interest was manifested in the result, and, as a general thing, the occasion was not marked by any unusual disturbance.

THE BRITISH-CHINES TREATY.--Thanks to the judicious grumbling of the London Press, an exhaustive abstract of Lord ELGIN'S Chinese Treaty has been issued by the Foreign Office. It corresponds with the synopsis previously given by the North China Herald. The compensation afforded to England falls, however, far short of the sum first represented.

Our Jenkins has begun to extend his operations to the Presidential court, and we should not wonder if we shortly had a daily circular announcing that Mr. BUCHANAN took a walk in the grounds of the White House for five minutes before breakfast on the previous day, in company with Colonel TITUS or Dr. ATCHISON ;

The Rev. HENRY GILES is announced for three new lectures in New-England, on "Irish Mental and Moral Character," "Irish Social Character and Humor" and on" DANIEL O'CONNELL." The lion. JEFFERSON DAVlS and a party of Aldermen and scientific men went down Boston harbor on Monday in a steamboat excursion, at the invitation of the Mayor.

Last night a meeting was held in the Cooper Institute of the Crystal Palace Exhibitors. The attendance was not remarkably large, though probably it constituted a fair representation of all the parties interested. Among the more influential persons present were Mayor TIEMANN, PETER COOPER and Rev. Dr, CHAPIN. Mayor TIEMANN was moved to the Chair, and elected without dissent.

FATAL ACCIDENT ON BOARD THE STEAMER CITY OF BILTIMORE.-A serious accident occurred on board the steamer City of Baltimore yesterday, upon the arrival of that vessel, which caused the instant death of one of the crew and the maiming of another. It is always customary for these steamers to fire one or two guns as theo pass through the Narrows, partly to attract the attention of the Health Officer, and also as a salute.

The victim of the late murder at Pawling, Dutchess County, an account of which was published in Monday's TIMES, died on Saturday evening last and was buried on Monday. A coroner's inquest was held upon the body at Pawling on Sunday last, when the following testimony was elicited:

PICCOLOMINI.-The "cara bambina" of Her Majesty's theatre has not yet arrived. We make the announcement briefly and explicitly, because every one will be looking into the paper this morning to see if she has arrived, and it will be a comfort to them to find out at once that she has not. Let us be patient.

From the London Daily Notes. It is a serious matter at any time to deal with a disturbed, much more with an insurgent New-York. There is nowhere a more heterogeneous Population, and the great heterogeneous populations of the world's chief ports are elsewhere kept in order by the ancient customs of long-established power.

The Union Movement In Kings county. The Conference Committees appointed by the Republican and American County and Congressional Conventions, respectively, met, last night, at the Shakespeare Hotel, Montague-street, Brooklyn, and proceeded with the business for which they had assembled.

The steamship Isabel has arrived at this port from Havana. The steamer Solent had arrived at that port from Vera Cruz on the 3d inst.. at noon. A courier arrived there at 7 o'clock that morning, from the City of Mexico, stating that General VIDAURRI had been beaten by General MIRAMON, near San Luis, and that the latter capturd (a thousand prisoners and several pieces of artillery.

We have highly important news from Mexico, a summary of which we publish under our telegraphic head. A battle seems to have taken place between VIDAURRI and MIRAMON,but the reports relative to the result are contradictory. The condition of the country is growing more and more desperate.

The sale of the City Hall and furniture at auction, under the judgment obtained against the City by Mr. LOWBER was advertised to take place at 10 A. M. yesterday, but was again postponed to this morning at the same hour. Mr. LOWBER says he has requested the Sheriff to be as lenient as possible,in the hope that the Corporation will settle.

The Nicaraguan cauldron will explode before to-morrow evening. YRISSARI, WHITE Co. are all there, and down on JEREZ, who, it appears, is acting without authority. YRISSARI exposed to Secretary CASS, to-day, the fact that JEREZ had no authority to exchange ratifications of the Treaty, except in its modified form.

ADMINISTRATION AND OPPOSITION PARTIES.We are experiencing, in a large measure, the disadvantages of having too many political parties. There should be but two. In the nature of the case there is rational ground for no more. Those two should comprise the supporters of the National Administration on the one hand, and its opponents on the other.
