DESTRUCTIVE CONFLAGRATION IN CLARKSON-STREET--SEVERAL STABLES AND STORES BURNED.--A fire was discovered at a few minutes to 1, yesterday morning, in a row of wooden buildings in Clarkson-street, between Greenwich and Washington-streets. The stables were entirely consumed. Several horses which were in the stalls were removed without injury. Loss on the stables, $300--no insurance.

IMPORTANT INTERROGATORIES.--The Washington Union, of yesterday, in view of the pending State Elections, asks the Democracy to answer two very significant questions, as follows: "Are we to have a Northern and Southern Democracy? Are we to oppose the Republicans, and support their policy?" Now, whatever response may be given in words to these pointed interrogatories, the practical answer will be in the affirmative.

THE NINTH CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT.--The interesting triangular fight in the Ninth Congressional District between the Republican and Democratic friends of Mr. HASKIN and his Republican opponents is becoming intensely exciting, and the nomination of Mr. KEMBLE by the unadulterated supporters of the National Administration, has added to the interest of the contest.

Democratic County Nominations. The Regular Democratic County Nominating Convention met, at Tammany Hall, last evening, and transacted their business with dispatch. ISAIAH RYNDERS, United States Marshal, presided. The'" slate" arrangements appeared to be pretty well understood, and were carried out to the letter, the opposition being very tripling.

MONSON BANCROFT, the person implicated in the late murder, or homicide, at , Dutch's Co., a full account of which was given exclusively in yesterday's TIMES, had not been arrested at the last accounts. Warrants for his arrest have been issued by the authorities of Dutchess County. His whereabouts have not yet been ascertained. ed.

The returns from Pennsylvania have come in sufficiently to indicate the overwhelming defeat of the Administration and the repudiation of Lecomptonism. A few counties in the interior of the State are not yet heard from, but the result will not be materially altered by the returns from them. Out of twenty-five Members of Congress, the Lecomptonites elect only two, or at most three.

A Convention of believers in the rapping and table-moving dispensation was recently held at Kiantone, a town in Chautauque County, adjacent to the Pennsylvania line, for the alleged purpose of discussing seven distinct topics, suggested by a number of departed spirits, including that of Dr. BENJAMIN RUSH.

The election returns from Pennsylvania startle Mr. BUCHANAN, who to-day expressed his astonishment at the result and admitted that he had been misled as to the popularity of his Administration in the Keystone State. Where's FORNEY? Q. [FROM THE REPORTER FOR THE ASSOCIATED PRESS,] WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 13.

KINGS COUNTY POLITICS.--NO UNION--The American County Convention met last evening, at the Military Gardens. Joralemon-street. The Conference Committee made a report of the result of the meeting at Shakespeare Hotel, the same as appeared in the TIMES of yesterday morning.

The long-threatened sale of the City Hall paintings, on execution, to satisfy the Lowber judgment, actually took place yesterday, and the entire lot of portraits, including all the Governors of the State and the Mayors of the City, together with the bronze statue of JEFFERSON,

I lately met an American who was furious because of tile treatment he had received from a distinuished French Professor to whom he had brought a letter of introduction from a brother Professor in the United States; so I seize this occasion as the text of a sermon I have long wished to preach. Let us see first how the incident in question passed, for this will serve as the type of all the rest.

In the NEw-YORK TIMES, of Monday, we had the pleasure of announcing the arrival at St. Louis of the first Overland Mail from the Pacific, through in twenty-three days from San Francisco, bringing advices ten days later. To the telegraphic outline then furnished, we now add details of the highest interest, with such items of intelligence as may be important.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The Annual Festival of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum takes place today under the direction of Mr. JOHN BROUGHAM. There will be two entertainments, one in the afternoon, the other in the evening. The programme cannot be easily condensed, so we refer the reader to our advertising columns, with the simple remark that every possible variety is provided. The Charity itself will, we trust, be the principal attraction.

The people of this Congressional District are becoming very much interested in the coming election, and are preparing for an active contest. This is the district which is at present represented by the Hon. G. B. ADRAIN, one of the few members of the North who sustained the rights of the people against the power of the Administration. His action is the subject of much discussion among all parties,

OUR ROTTEN BOROUOHS.--The Third Congressional District of this State, consisting of the lower Wards of the City on the north side of Broadway, appears to be a kind of Old Sarum, and to be the private property of its present Representative, who offers to dispose of it on the most accommodating terms.

PINSENT--FISHER.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 13, by the Rev. C. Fletcher, Mr. JOHN PINSENT, Jr., to SOPHIA JANE FISHER, both of this City. SCOTT--COOPER.--In this City, on Tuesday evening, Oct. 12, at the residence of Wm. Cooper, No. 88 Hammond-st., by the Rev. W. S. Mickels, ALEX, SCOTT, Jr., to ADELINE B. COOPER, both of this City.

The St. Johns papers publish a card from Mr. FREDERICK N. GISBORNE, in reply to the recent statement of Messrs. FIELD, COOPER and others, concerning the origin of the Atlantic Telegraph enterprise. He accepts the challenge of those gentlemen, and proceeds to state his case. After narrating his adventures in the Provincial Telegraphic Survey of 1851, he says:

On the day after my last letter was written, a transaction took place, which, in the present dearth of striking events, has been a perfect godsend to political gossips here, and which has had the singular merit of absorbing at the same time no little attention in the sporting world. I allude to the sale of Lord DERBY'S horses at Doncaster, which turned out o be nothing more than a weeding of his Stud.

DEAD LETTERS.--The dead-letter branch of the General Post-Office has just closed another quarter's work. POLITICS OF ALBANY COUNTY.--We have al ready noticed the nomination of an irregular or bolting Democratic ticket in the County of Albany, embracing the presentation of JoHN H. REYNOLDS for Congress in opposition to ERASTUS CORNING, who will receive the Regular or Soft nomination on Saturday next.

INDIANA.-Our reports from this State are as yet meagre, but they tend the same way with those from Ohio and Pennsylvania. Where any Democratic members of Congress are reelected, a rare occurrence by the way, it is by renouncing the distinctive profession of the English Lecompton Bill, which discriminates in favor of Slavery in Kansas. STEAMBOAT COLLISION--LOSS OF LIFE.--On Tuesday evening, while the steamer Empire State was on her way from Fall River to New-York, and only a short distance from Newport, she came in collision with a sloop called the Exchange, or Dartmouth, of some twenty tons, and sunk her almost instantly.

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT--FOUR MEN ALMOST INSTANTLY KILLED.--About, 4 o'clock Saturday morning, an accident occurred on the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad, near Shoal's Station, about 150 miles from this city, which resulted in the almost instant death of four men, all employes on the road. A freight train from the East and another from the West came into collision at the point named,

M. THEOPHILE GAUTIER has just published in Paris a cleverly written treatise. called Lu Mode, forming a little book about five or six inches square, containing only just thirty-three pages, each page being of only a dozen lines coquettishly framed in wide white e margins, and bordered by one small streak of red. In this little volume M. GAUTIER raises his voice in favor of paint!

Mr. HENRY C. SCHOONMAKER, of the Second Ward, says he neither sympathizes with nor participated in the meeting at the Girard House, Tuesday night, at which the name of EDMUND GRIFFIN was brought forward as a candidate for Congress from the Third District, and that his name was used as that of one of the Secretaries of that meeting without his knowledge or consent.

SHE CASTIGATES THE EPISCOPALIAN CLERGY OF NEW-YORK. Last night, in Hope Chapel, Madame LOLA MONTEZ Lectured on "Rome," for the benefit of the Rev. RALPH HOTT'S new Church. the audience was quire large, considering the weather. The Rev. Dr. HIGBEE and Ex-Judge EDMONDS were among the most interested of her listeners.

Mr. ULLMAN'S programme for the Winter season will be found in another column. It is emphatically a discourse. We can imagine the enterprising manager standing in the portico of the Academy, with his cloak gathered around him, after the fashion of the Athenian orators, an average amount of managerial inspiration in his eye, and this effort dropping from his lips.

As indicated by the returns received on Tuesday night, the State and Congressional elections in Pennsylvania have resulted in an overwhelming defeat of the Administration, and the consequent repudiation of Lecomptonism.

Some uncertainty still hangs about the results of Tuesday's Elections. Enough, however, is ascertained to make it sure that Government has been signally beaten; and that tile Opposition in the Northern States largely outnumbers the friends of the Administration.

At noon, yesterday, there was a mysterious movement about the City Hall. Everybody said that "He was going to do it," but who he was that was going to do it, and what he was going to do, seemed for at least ten minutes involved in the profoundest mystery. Parties, apparently big with something, were running wildly about. They would speak to nobody, though strongly entreated.

OHIO.--The Administration, which loses so much in Pennsylvania, gains nothing in Ohio. As a general rule, the Republicans carry the Congressional Districts by large majorities, showing plainly the drift of popular opinion. So far as returns have been received they will be found under our telegraphic head. TOM CORWIN is elected in the Seventh District. S.

CAMPBELL.-- In this City, on Tuesday, oct. 12, after a protracted illness. Mrs. MARGARET E. CAMPBELL, widow of the late Capt. Denald Campbell, in the 60th year of her age. All the friends of the family are requested to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 71 Hester-st., on Friday, the 15th inst., at 1 o'clock P. M. Her remains will be taken to Cypress Hills Cemetery for Interment.

The Board assembled at the rotunda, Tuesday, The President, WASHINGTON SMITH, Esq., in the chair. This being requisition day, the usual demands were submitted, anti with some modifications, passed. Governor ANDERSON moved that the item " one dozen champagne glasses," be stricken out. In his opinion, Bellevue Hospital was nothing better than an " immense grog shop."

THE STEVENS WIFE MURDER.--Yesterday, according to adjustment, the investigation as to the alleged murder of Mrs. STEVENS by her husband, was to have been resumed at Bellevue Hospital. The adjournment had taken place to give time for Dr. DOREMUS to complete the chemical analysts of the contents of the stomach of the deceased. The Doctor stated that the analysis had not yet been perfected, and asked an adjournment for another week, which was granted.

NIL DESPERANDUM.--GERRIT SMITH issues a farewell circular "to the friends of Temperance and Freedom in the State of New-York." He reports that he has been in all quarters of the State, and held meetings in most of the counties. His discoveries are not at all pleasant. Temperance and Freedom are little better than dead.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE AT POUGHKEEPSIE.--On Monday night last, about 8 o'clock, a frame building in the rear of the Forbus House, in Market-street, Poughkeepsie, was burned. So rapid was the progress of the flames that in a little time they spread to the extensive livery stables of Mr. ISAAC McKIRBIN, and in a short time the above buildings, together with another in the rear of Mayor SWIFT'S residence, were entirely consumed.

THE BOARD OF MANAGERS of the American Institute held a meeting Wednesday evening when a committee was appointed, consisting of john Johnson, Col. De Voe, W. H. Butler, Bailey L. Hathaway and Chas. Turner to take into consideration the propriety of the Institute awarding premiums on articles exhibited at the late Fair.

From the Evening Post. To the Editor of the Evening Post: SIR--On my return to this City, after an absence of near five months, my attention has been called to a publication entitled the " Story of the Telegraph," in which the authors have attributed to me the entire credit of the improved plan of the paying-out machines by which the Atlantic cable was laid.
Her British Majesty's steam-frigate Valorous, Capt. ALDHAM, 16 guns, which has been expected at this port for several days, arrived last evening in 28 days from Plymouth, England, via Fayal, 16 days.

AN AWFUL RESPONSIBILITY.--It happens in matrimony, sometimes, that an aspiring bridegroom discovers, when too late, that he has not only married a wife, but espoused a family with all its infinite ramifications of mother-in-law, maiden aunts, and cousins of remote degree.

CONCERT.--Mile. EMMA WELLIS, a very talented lady organist, gave an interesting Concert last evening, at Niblo's Saloon. The lady is a professor of the celebrated Alexandre Harmonium, an instrument which, in capable hands, is capable of introducing many novel effects into the concert-room and of imparting an air of agreeable variety to the Programme.

CONGRESSIONAL NOMINATIONS.--Whether it be owning to the unfavourable influence of separate State tickets, or to other causes personal and legal, the fact is evident that the Opposition are trying to throw away a number of congressmen. This is, of course, quite agreeable to the Democrats who fund an offset to their own splits in the divisions of their opponents.

ANNUAL FESTIVAL IN AID OF THE R. O. ORPHAN ASYLUMS.--Yesterday afternoon and evening the annual entertainments in aid of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylums, took place at the Academy of Music. The fete was intrusted to the management of JOHN BROUGHAM, and owed its success in the first place, of course, to the charitable object for which it was designed, and next, to the talented artists who volunteered their services for the nonce.

The late frauds on the Post-Office in Texas have been pretty well equaled in New-Orleans within a few months, if not in ingenuity certainly in audacity ; and with almost as incomprehensible hick in escaping detection.

The statutes of Virginia contain a law, the existence of which is known to but, if any, without the limits of the State, and to a very small number within. It is entitled "An act providing for the voluntary enslavement of the free Negroes of the Commonwealth," passed Feb. 18, 1856.

The election in this State is to be held on the same day as it is in New-York, and as the day approaches the interest heightens, although not to the extent it does in New-York, for the result of the election here is not as doubtful as it is there.

LETTER OF THE HON HORACE F. CLARK-The manly and honorable tone of Mr. HORACE F. CLARK'S letter to the Democrats of the English Congressional District, who have tendered him a nomination for reelection,

Political. UNION OF AMERICANS AND REPUBLICATIONS.--The Conference Committees of the American and Republican Parties met last evening, when the Committee of the former proposed to give the latter the Congressmen and County Clerk, and the Americans to have the balance of the office. This was accepted by the Committee, was subsequently ratified by the Congressional Conventions.

Kansas is played out. No political movements outside of her own borders can materially affect her future condition. She will be admitted upon her first asking. The Administration dare not risk an attempt to keep her out, or if it should, its defeat will be overwhelming. As a political issue, therefore, the Kansas question belongs to the past.

AN UNFORTUNATE MANAGER.--Mr. MAX MARETZEK is the most unfortunate of men. Fate seems to have singled him out for all the blows, disappointments and losses that can be dealt to musical art in this country. After ten years of hard labor in this City, he has still to look to Havana for the wherewithal to make both ends meet.

That the Administration has met with, a signal defeat in the President's own State is conceded. It will no longer be pretended that tile Lecompton policy of Mr. BUCHANAN is popular, or that tile manufacture of party tests by the Administration has been a successful operation in Pennsylvania.

GOODHEART.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 13, suddenly. ANNA GOODHEART, wife of William Goodheart, aged 26 years and 7 days. The relatives and friends of the family, those of her brothers, James and John Leonard, also those of her brothers-in-law, James Irving and George Goodheart, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, in 80th-St., between 2d and 3d as, this (Friday)afternoon, at 1 o'clock.

A sudden change in the weather, with Jack Frost and the cool Northwest, have precipitated not only the late autumn but the President upon us. The trees in the Capitol Park are crimson and yellow and brown, and the White House has resumed its old inhabitants.

All the rumors afloat, including those in the eventing papers here, concerning Gen. JEREX and his Mission, are entirely erroneous. The General had a protracted interview of the kindest character witm Secrclary CASS, to-day, which was adjourned over until to-morrow, and I am authorized to say that both parties entertain strong hopes that all our Nicaraguan difficulties will be speedily settled.

All cases involving a lady are interesting. Especially is this a when a young and handsome window is arraigned in a court of Justice for a Capital offence. A case of this nature has just been tired in this city, On yesterday morning the case of the common wealth Martha Morgan was called.

The Board of Aldermen met last evening, Presient CLANCY in the chair. A communication was received from the Mayor in relation to certain water grants on the North River, between Hammond and Thirtieth streets.

The U. S. Mail steamship Philadelphia, Capt. HARRISON, left New-Orleans the 5th,Havana the 8th and Key West the 9th inst., and arrived here early yesterday morning. She brings 16 passengers, and a cargo of flour, oil, cochnial, tobacco, segars and fruit. She comes consigned to M. O. ROBERTS.

The following named Americans are touring in Europe: At Interlachen-Lieutenant and Mrs. Aulick, U. S. N., Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bergh, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond, Mr. and Mrs. Hutchinson, Mr. Van Buren, New-York ; Madame Bodisco and family, Mr. Whitwell, Massachusetts.

Incendiaries are very active in this part of the world, not withstanding the terrible example that has been made of one of the Quincy fire-raisers, who has been sent to the State Prison for life. There are now under arrest several youths who caused the fire in Charlestown, last week. who admit their guilt, and who implicate others.

The steamship North Star, of the Vanderbilt line, A. G. JONES, ESQ., Commander, from Southampton on the 29th, and the Indian Empire, E. COURTENAY. ESQ., Commander, from Galway on the 28th, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The unfortunate, if deserving, have never appealed in vain through the columns of the TIMES, and to the credit of the readers of that paper be it said. Emboldened by the success of others, I ask you to be the means of bringing to the notice of the benevolent the case of an English family that is really in need.

The Canard steamship Africa, from Liverpool on 2nd inst., with three days' later news from Europe, arrived at this port at a late hour last night. She brings a variety of interesting intelligence. The anticipated reduction in the rate of discount had not been made by the Bank of England. The advance in Consols during September was about 2 per cent.

From the St. Louis Republican, 5th. Our reference, a few days since, to the gold diggings reported to exist in the region of Pike's Peak was in fill view of the several accounts, that have reached as through a variety of channels. The general tenor of these accounts justifies tile opinion then expressed by us that there was good reason for believing these mines to be highly productive.

NEW UNIVERSITY AT FORONTO.--The corner-stone of the new University buildings at Toronto was laid on the 4th inst, by the Governor-General. The edifice is to be 300 by 200 feet, erected in University park, comprising 168 acres.
ARRANGEMENTS FOR ELECTION DAY--THE GLASS BALLOT-BOXES AGAIN.--The Police Commissioners met yesterday at 2 P. M., all the Commissioners present except General NYE.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of this morning we find an article headed "Prize Money and the Echo," embodying an extract from the National Intelligencer, in which the following passage occurs: "It is doubted whether the Flag-officer. Commodore McINTOSH, is entitled to one-twentieth, as he was absent on leave from his station at the time of the capture."

Certainly nothing new has occurred here in the world political or polite, since I dispatched my letter of last Saturday, to provoke from me a new batch of sentences. The Atlantic Telegraph remains as mute as ever, in that respect reading a lesson to its human friends and Directors, by which it is much to be desired that they should profit.

RODGERS--BOWKER.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 14, at the chapel of the Broadway Tabernacle, by the Rev. Joseph P. Thompson, D. D., Mr. CHARLES T. P. RODGERS to Miss SARAH M. BOWKER, all of their City. SEARS--DATER.--In this City, by the Rev. G. A. Peltz, Mr. MILTON SEARS, of Paterson, N. J., to Miss CAROLINE DATER, of this City.

In steamship Africa from Licerpool-Mr. and Mrs. MC Allister, 2 children and nurse the Hon. John and Mrs. Boyee. Miss M. Barras and lady, Robert Mure and Lady, 2 children and nurse, Miss Elixabeth Mure, Mr. and Mrs. D. Paul, Miss Paul, Mr. and Mrs. J. Robb, Mr. and Mrs. E. Hill. 2 children and nurse, Mr. Marande.

Our advices from Kingston, Jamaica, extend to the 6th inst. There was much satisfaction felt at the announcement that the steamers running from Aspin wall to New-York would stop at Kingston once a month. This, it was expected, would give an impetus to trade now so deplorably stagnant.
A special meeting of the American Institute was held last evening at their rooms ill Broadway, Vice-President HALL in the Chair. The Board of Trustees reported the following preamble and resolutions:

THE ADMINISTRATION MOVE IN THE EIGHTH DISTRICT--Mr. BUCHANAN'S friends in the Eight District have a very peculiar manner of manifesting their respect for him. They cast the largest number of votes in the Congressional Convention for a man who was an advocate of FREMONT, and whose candidate for the succession is not Mr. BUCHANAN, but Gen. SCOTT.

In stamship Hammonin. for Hambur--John Orbrey, Mrs. Nesnitla. two children and nurse: H. B. Rosin, Ch. Silsfeld, Mr. Henry Jaquin, lady and sister; Ch. Salm. W. Langer, capt. Behn, Enos barberich, W. B. Berger, Louis Mr. H. C. Carl Vorwerk, J. Broome and lady, Henry Kreishel. W. v. d. Roest, W. H. Barow, Fr. Westphal, max Wittkofasky, G, Mexander, Jacob Reisser, Ch. Zimmermann. Ch.

A Texas paper says that " Dr. Shumard, State Geologist, is making preparations to forward his library and geological collections to Texas. He will go in person to New-York to superintend the purchase of instruments, chemicals and other necessary articles for the prosecution of the work.

NICARAGUA TRANSIT STEAMERS.-The Nicaraguan steamer Cass- Vrissari, Captain SLOCUM, arrived at San Juan del Norte on the 2d inst. A letter from Aspinwall states that she was a miserable wreck, and totally unfit for the service intended. Per contra, our own correspondent at San Juan, under date of Oct. 2, says she was in good condition.

We have the Diaro de Rio de Janesro, of Sept. 11. There is no local news of importance. The city had for a week been given up to the great national festivities in honor of Brazilian independence. The festivals were still in progress in the suburbs.

The annual inspection and review of the Seventy-first Regiment, (American Guard,) Col. VOSBURGH commanding, took place yesterday on the camp ground, near Quarantine, Staten Island. The day was fine, and the boats from the City were crowded during the day with people going to the review.

The United States Mail Steamship Star of the West, A. G. GRAY, Esq., Commander, from Aspinwall on the 5th inst., with passengers, mails and treasure, which left San Francisco on the 21st ult., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Star of the West touched at Kingston, Jamaica, on the 8th inst.

By the arrival of the Star of the West, we have intelligence from San Francisco to Sept. 21-five days later than by the Overland Mail. The news is interesting. The death of Senator FERGUSON on the 15th ult., from wounds received in his duel with Mr. G. P. JOHNSON a month before, is announced.

SHILTON.-In this City, on Thursday afternoon,Oct. 14, after a short and severe illness. Mrs. FRANCES SHILTON, wife of Joseph Shilton, aged 44 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from her late residence, No. 81 East 39th-st., on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

Blakesby, E. B. Pond, H. B. lathrop, Jr., Mrs. Overtonand infant, G. L. Bradley, Miss C. Thomas, the Rev. F. Carro, F. B. Hight, Mrs. Morgan and child, Mrs. Daniels and child, Mrs. I. M. Pindall, Capt. Sherman, S. Keyes,

The information furnished by the correspondent of this paper at the City of Mexico presents a desperate picture of the condition of the Republic. Among the least significant of the facts, are those of doubtful authenticity giving the result of a battle between the Conservatives under MIRAMON,

The mail of Sept. 12, from Bogota, having again failed, we have nothing later than Aug. 28. There is little of interest from that capital. The country was tranquil in all its parts. The papers have ceased their speculations on the fate of the Cass-Herran Covention.

UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT. The regular October term of the United States Circuit Court will be opened on Monday next, by Judge INGERSOLL. SUPREME COURT--CIRCUIT--Oct. 15. Before Judge Noah Davies, Jr. MALICIOUS PROSECUTION.

The English Mail Company's steamer Clyde will leave here early to-morrow morning, and I embrace the opportunity of writing, although there is really nothing of importance to communicate since your last dates from this place.

CONE-WESTON.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 13, by the Rev. Tyng, Mr. Ed. WINFIELD CONE to MARY E., daughter of John L. WESTON, both of this City. WETMORE--LOVEJOY.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 14, at St. Bartholomew's Church, by the Rev. Saml. Cooke, D. D., JACOB S. WETMORE to MARY L. LOVEJOY, adopted daughter of Wm. C. Wetmore, Esq., all of this City.

An adjourned meeting of the exhibitors at the recent Fair of the American Institute, which was so unhappily and so prematurely terminated by the burning of the Crystal Palace, was held last night in the Cooper Institute.

The shares of the Atlantic Telegraph Company continue in demand, and closed on the afternoon of 1st at ?? 400 to ?? 430. The following letter has been addressed by Mr. VARLEY to the editor of the Times:

The negotiations now in progress between Gen. HERRAN and our Government are touching to a speedy settlement of all outstanding difficulties with New-Granada. What these difficulties are seem not to be understood by the American public.

The British journals are indulging in congratulations over the fact that the revenue returns for the last year show an actual increase, allowing for the reduction of the income tax, of ??1,883,000, and the Times hopes that a year or two more of tranquillity will enable the Government to abolish more of the obnoxious taxes, without diminishing the yearly supplies.

At a special meeting of the Medical Society of Richmond County, held at the Lyceum, on Friday, Sept. 24, 1858, the subjoined resolution was offered and adopted: Resolved, That, whereas Dr. THEODORE WALSER has published an article reflecting upon the Committee appointed by this Society,

This Convention reassembled in Musical Hall yesterday afternoon. Long before the hour for meeting had arrived, a crowd of persons interested in the proposed union with the Americans, blocked up the sidewalk in front of the building, the stairway leading to the hall, and even the hall itself was well filled with outsiders.

DEATH OF THE HON. WILLIAM JAY.--The Hon. WILLIAM JAY, second son of JOHN JAY, died, on Thursday, at his residence in Bedford, Westchester County, aged 70. Mr. JAY was a native of this City, was a fellow-pupil with FENIMORE COOPER under the tuition of the Rev. Mr. ELLISON,at Albany,entered at Yale College in 1804, and graduated in 1807.

It is reported, on the authority of what purports to be a letter from Capt. Pope's camp, on the Pecos, dated Aug. 21, that the attempt to sink an Artesian well in that plain has proved a failure. The bore was made to the depth of 1,000 feet, and the formation at that depth is said to be just as soft and rotten as at the surface.

The British steamship New-Granada arrived at Panama Sept. 21, having dates from valparaiso to Sept. 1. Callao and Lima the 13th, and Guayaquil the 16th, She brought $414,000, principally in silver for England. From Ecuador there is nothing of interest, except that the Government was trying to make a show of defence against a possible attack from Person the Amazon business.
Nothing tends more to wake up the people and to fetch out a full vote on election day than a long and hearty struggle over the nominations. This great fact remained for years a secret with Tammany.

The result of the Pennsylvania election will hardly fail to operate unfavorably upon the Democratic Party in this State. It is, in fact, a remarkably wet blanket. The Syracuse Convention of that party, to be sure, cast an anchor to windward by the adoption of equivocal endorsement resolutions;

From the Washington States. Col. JJAMES R. BELLVILLE, a clerk in the Chicago Post-Office, (one of COOK"S appointments,) was arrested at Chicago a few days ago upon the charge of stealing from the mail. Colonel BELLIVILLE was employed in the office about three months ago, upon tile recommendation of some of the famous Colonels of COOK.

SALT FISHING FOR HAVANA.-Some of the bank fishermen are getting ready for a trip to milder latiudes to spend the Winter in fishing. The schooner Ocilla, Captain BURROWS, has left; and the schooner R. Fowler, Captain ELDEIDGE, is about sailing for Key West to engage in salt fishing for the Havana market.

ENCOUNTER WITH A BURGLAR.-Mr. CARPENTER, living in the rear of the County Jail at Hudson City, was awakened Thursday morning about 3 o'clock by the noise of some person in his room. Mr. C. sprang from the bed and seized a man, who, after a short confliet escaped by means of the front piazza.

By the arrival at this port of the schooner C. N. Casey from Port-au-Platte, we have received a copy of the Gaceta Official of the Dominican Republic, dated Santo Domingo, Sept. 14. Its leading article congratulates todos los Dominicanos-all the Dominicans-on the restoration of peace, and the final triumph of the great work of reform commenced in that capital on the 27th of July last.

DUBEROW.--In this City, on Sunday afternoon, Oct. 17, after a brief illness, WILLIAM DURDROW in the 68th year if his age, His relatives and friends, members of the First, members of the First Baptist Church, and of his sons William S. and John B., are invited to attend his funeral, on Tuesday, Oct. 19, at 2 P. M., from NO. 7 East 33d-st., without further invitation.

The Washington Union professes "a little surprise that a public journal in the great commercial emporium of the Union should counsel the organization of Parties upon purely sectional grounds." The Union refers to the TIMES. But it labors under an error. We have offered no "counsel" in respect to organizing Parties.

The Commercial Advertiser describes a method of constructing domestic telescopes whereby to see the Comet: " Procure from an optician a 30-inch object glass (that is, a convex glass, which produces a focus of the sun's rays at the distance of 36 inches,) and a oneinch eye-glass, (that is, a convex glass producing a focus at one inch,)

THE ALLEGED VIOLATION OF AUCTION LAWS.--It will be remembered that sometime ago, an auc tioneer, named THEODORE GOIDSMITH, Was charged with stuffing houses up town with goods,, and then selling them off, and that he had three such establishments. On Saturday some further evidence was taken before the Mayor in support of this allegation, the object of which, if supported, would have been a deprivation of his license.

In cordial response to an invitation tendered them by the firemen of this City, the Hope Hose Company of Philadelphia arrived on a visit to this City, at Pier No. 1, shortly after 7 o'clock on Saturday evening, where they were met by eighteen full companies of firemen, each preceded by a band, and first escorted to the Washington Hotel, for the purpose of initiatory refreshment.

The Construction Committee of the Commissloners of Emigration, Mayor TIEMANN, Chairman, visited the Quarantine grounds, Saturday, to inspect the work of the contractors, who are busily engaged in rebuilding tile Hospitals. They find the work going on rapidly, and in accordance with the plans and specifications. The Hospital buildings, which will first be needed by the sick.

Political. The Republican and American County Conventions meet in Brooklyn at 2 o'clock this afternoon, when one more effort will be made to unite the two parties upon the ticket. The Vanderbilt Democracy hold a mass meeting in the City Hall Park this evening.

The State Department has received no communication from the Society Islands on the subject of annexation. The paper presented by Count SARTIGES asked the withdrawal from these Islands of two Americans who were intermeddling in their political affairs. The American Consul refused to forward the paper, and hence it was sent through French officials.

We observe that the library of tile late Dr. PERCIVAL has been offered by his executor and residuary legatee to the City of Chicago, in a letter written to " ascertain if it would suit Chicago for a City Library." As some City Libraries are managed it would matter very little of what hooks such an institution were composed;

GROANS FROM THE UNITERRIFIED.--In the present City and County democratic nominations the influence of the Executive is too palpable and undisguised to give satisfaction to the strait-laced and stricter members of the old Jeffersonian Church.

The returns from thirty-six counties of Pennsylvania (comprising the larger portion of the vote of the State) show a majority for READ (Opposition) of upwards of 35,000. This will probably be increased by the full returns. The State Senate stands 16 Opposition to 17 Democrats. The House has a large Opposition majority.

PATRIC--OSBORN--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 14, at the Mariner's Church, by the Rev. Chas. J. Jones, Mr. JOHN H. PATRICK To Miss CECELIA E., youngest daughter of Capt. Morris Osborn, all of this City. Albany and Norfolk papers please copy.

THE GREAT ILLINOIS SUIT.--We learn from Chicago that the suit of Mr. BATES against the Illinois Central Railroad Company for the possession of the valuable depot grounds of that company has been decided in favor of the company. The case was tried in the United States Circuit Court before the Hon. JOHN MCLEAN, and it is said the property involved, with the extensive and costly buildings thereon, was worth $2,000,000.

The Opposition are, unfortunately, divided. When the American and Republican Conventions recently assembled at Syracuse, there was a foregone conclusion among the honest masses of both parties, that they should sink all former differences, and unite heartily upon the common principles which both avowed.

Burr, C. W. Topham,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As it is supposed that Editors know everything, or should, please answer me the following questions : How is it the Common Council refuse to confirm the building of numerous sewers, much wanted, and not opposed. Is it to keep poor men out of employment, or for what is it?

INTRODUCTION OF WATER. - Last week the Water Commissioners let in the first flow of water from the Passaic Water-works, and since that time the applications for water from the inhabitants have been numerous. The pipes are being tapped daily, and the rates, though not at present fixed, will be about equal to those of Jersey City.

There is as much rivalry, you must be aware, among landscapes as among ladies, and one can never praise the beauty of any particularly lovely region, in the presence of a mixed company, without finding himself suddenly caught by some loyal worshiper of another and a superior scene.

The United States frigate Sabine. Captain ADAMS, the flag-ship of Commodore SHUBRICK, of the Paraguay Squadron, left her anchorage off the Battery at 11 1/2 o'clock on Saturday, in tow of the steam-tug Huntress, bound to Paraguay. She carries out as Special Minister Judge JAMES B. BOWLIN, and THOMAS J. PAGE, as Commander of the fleet.

Our dates from Havana are to Oct. 10, two days later. The correspondent of the Savannah Republican writes that the loss of life in much greater than was indicated by the first reports. He sets it down as 300, or over, and his estimates are sustained by the accounts in the Prenza.

CASE OF CANCEMI IN THE COURT OF APPEALS.--This case was argued in the Court of Appeals at Albany, on Thursday, by Attorney-General TREMAIN, on the part of the People, and Mr. ASHMEAD for the prisoner. The Court reserved its decision.

The bark Eliza Barrs, which left Bermuda on the 5th instant, brought papers only to the 29th ult. These papers contain but very little news of interest. The equinoctial storm had been very violent at the island, lusting for several days, the wind at times blowing with the force of a hurricane.

In another column of this paper may be read the testimony of three colored gentlemen bearing more or less distinctly upon the subject of African emigration. They utter their discourse with far greater intelligence than we are apt to ascribe to the negro;

At 2 o'clock on Saturday morning the Detective Police of this City, headed by Captain Walling, made a descent on a counterfeiting den at Mott Haven, arrested two counterfeiters, obtained possession of $12,000 in bogus bank bills, and seized a quantity of dies, presses, chemicals, plates, and all the apparatus for extensive counterfeiting.

In the First District the Opposition have very great hopes of electing LUTHER C. CARTER, of Flushing, whom the two Conventions so readily agreed upon, SEARING, who is renominated by the Democrats, stands badly with his party, especially in Suffolk, where Ex-Speaker LUDLOW was the favorite candidate.

In bark Eliza Barrs, from Bermuda--Dr. T. Godet, R. Dunscomb, Miss Preston. In brig Hannah, from Rio Grande--Capt. Isaac Beauchamp, of brig Foaming Sea, of Baltimore, recently sold. In ship American Eagle, from London and Portsmouth--Capt. W. B. Stoddard lady, Cleaveland, Miss M. Ross, Scotland, Wm. Morrison, Boston, Master Barnett, England, Franklin Burdage, New-York, Richard Benouggh, New York.

To men in capital cities bred, country towns, however smiling they seem in poetry, are rather dull and dreary, even in their brightest hours. How much more so when rain exhibits such devoted attention as that it has poured for the last twenty-four hours on his town, or to use the more gorgeous designation of its residents, this city of Buffalo, famous for FILLMORE, flour, and THE COMING FIGHT.

BURTON'S THEATRE--Mr. STRAKOSCH commenced one of his erratic seasons at this house on Saturday evening, playing the "Traviata," with Mme COLSON as the heroine. There was a large and fashionable attendance, and every one seemed pleased with the lady's performance. To-night Mine. DE WILHORST makes her first appearance, (since her visit to Europe.) in the "Puritani."

WM. SANDER, who, on the night of the 13th of August last, murdered PETER SHORK, at the house of Mr. REEVES, near Goshen, Orange County, N. Y., by shooting him with a pistol, and shot MARGARET SHEALING in the breast, inflicting a wound which had well nigh proved fatal, was tried last week at Newburgh.

WHAT THE PENNSYLVANIA REPUBLICANS THINK OF THEIR BRETHERN IS NEW-YORK.--An article which we copy front the philadelphia North American shows how the attitude of the New--York Republicans appears to their brethern in the Keystone State.

Our advices from Buenos Ayres are to Aug. 28. A project, presented to the Legislative Assembly by M. SARMIENTO, providing for the erection and support of Schools, has excited warm controversy, wherein the Government has opposed tne scheme. It has finally been determined to appropriate a sum not exceeding $5,000,000 as a fund for this object.

Last evening a well-dressed Frenchman, named LEWIS BEERIERS, entered Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, in Thirty-fourth-street, and took a sent in a front pew facing the pastor, the Rev. M. D. C. CRAWFORD. The reverend gentleman had about concluded his exordium, when BEERIERS coolly arose, pulled out a heavily-loaded pistol, and discharged its contents at Mr. CRAWFORD.

NEW-YORK REPUBLICANISM -LETTER FROM SIMEON DRAPER.--We copy from the Albany Statesman, a letter written by Mr. SIMEON DRAPER of this City, which appears to have been addressed to a friend and fellow-Republican soon after the Syracuse Convention, although only now published.

Two weeks from to-morrow our annual State election will occur; and, although the event is so near in point of time, there is surprisingly little excitement in the public mind in regard to it. As to enthusiasm, it is lacking altogether.

A few months ago some twenty colored families of this place formed an Association for the purpose of emigrating to Liberia. They invited Judge James, one of the leading citizens of that Republic, now in this country, on business, to give them some account of its condition and prospects.

Chief Justice ECKELS, who has, by the determined and independent position which he has taken and maintained in regard to the affairs of this Territory, earned the regard and respect of every good citizen of the Territory, left this city on Wednesday last for the States, on a leave of absence, for three months.

THE GREAT BALLOON RACE TO COME OFF.-"Sporting" circles in Cincinnati are clated at the prospect of rare fun in the clouds. The great balloon race, so long talked of, is to come off on Monday, the 18th inst. The Cincinnati GAZETTE says:

THE ATLANTIC MONTHLY FOR NOVEMBER.-The October number of the Atlantic Monthly, which brought the Magazine to the end of its first year, was the most brilliant and popular one of the whole issue, and yet it caused a universal outburst of lamentations among the reading public because the "Autocrat of the Breakfast table" went off with the school-mistress, in that number. and wrote finis at the end of his article.

FATAL RESULT OF A STATE DRIVER'S CARELESSNESS.--HARRIET FRAGAN, a lady, 67 years of age, who resided at No. 555 Greenwich-street, died, yesterday, from injuries received through the gross culpability of an omnibus driver. She was getting out of a Greenwich-street stage when the driver started his horses too soon.

CORPORATION CULPABILITY.--Two men were standing, on Saturday, at the corner of Grand-street and the Bowery, waiting for the approach of a Fourthavenue car. Suddenly, the ground on which they were standing gave way, and one of the men was carried with precipital velocity into the bowels of the earth, some 20 feet.

The steamship Saxonia, from Southampton on the 4th, with two days later news from Europe, is now about due at this port. The Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 6th, with four days later news, is also about due at Quebec.

There were admitted on Sabbath afternoon last into full membership 140 that have stood out their probation of six months, in the Methodist Episcopal Church, Second-street, between Avenues C and D. The house was well filed with spectators, who seemed to be much interested with the exercise.

Another trial for murder is in progress at Rochester. The prisoner, MANLEY LOCKE, 22 years of age, is indicted for killing a constable, BENJ. STARR, who attempted to arrest him at Honeoye Falls, N. y., on the night of the 30th October, 1857. The defence set up is hereditary insanity.

Mr. Stevens Deflues His Position--Speeches, Resolutions, There was a very large meeting of the Democracy near Chatham-square, last evening, called for the purpose of indorsing Alderman THOMAS STEVENS as a candidate for Congress in the Fourth Congressional District, comprising the Fourth, Sixth, Tenth, and Fourteenth Wards.

RETURN OF THE SEVENTY-FIRST REGIMENT--THE SIXTY-NINTH GONE TO QUARANTINE.--Yesterday being the day for relieving the Staten Island military, the Sixty-ninth. Regf??nt, under orders from General SANFORD; went down to the encampment. They mustered about two hundred muskets, and with a few exceptions they were dressed in the new overcoat.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : Your highly interesting notice of the death of tile late Judge JAY emboldens me to send you an account of what many of your readers were doubtless anxious to unite in, though in consequence of the day and distance few were able to do it-I mean the last sad services paid to the memory of a good man's life.

RAILROAD ACCIDENT -- HEAVY DAMAGES AGAINST THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD.--On the 20th of May, 1854, a young lady named CATHERINE PITCHER took the cars at Poughkeepsie for Tivoli, and, on arriving at the depot at Tivoli, attempted to leave the cars, when they started, and she was thrown down, the cars passing over one of her feet, crushing it so that amputation became necessary.

The President's Washington organ regards the result of the Pennsylvania election entirely from a party point of view. It makes no attempt to show that the heavy majority which voted for the Opposition tickets, misjudged the measures of the Administration. Nor does it think proper to vindicate, in any degree, the policy of the President.

MARTIN.--In this City on Sunday, Oct. 17, after a short illness, CATHERINE M. MARTIN, aged 23 years 6 months and 17 days. Her friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from No. 137 West 17th-st., on (this) Tuesday, Oct. 13, at 12 M. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The sale of tickets for the first performance of Mlle. PICCOLOMINI commenced yesterday morning at the Academy of Music. There was a great deal of excitement, and from an early hour people were in waiting to secure their seats. Between two and three thousand places were sold. BURTON'S THEATRE.-- BELLINI'S opera of the " Puritani" was produced here last evening, and attracted a very fine audience.

ROBERTS--TELLER.--In this City, on Sunday evening, Oct. 17. by the Rev. Dr. Thomas De Witt, at Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church, corner of 29th-st. and 5th-av., Mr. RICHARD WARD ROBERTS to Miss ELIZA JANE TELLER youngest daughter of Mr. Abraham Teller, all of this City. California papers please copy.

The manly and independent letter of the representative of the Eighth Congressional District has excited a feeling of admiration among all classes, which cannot fail, we think, to secure his reflection. The spectacle exhibited by the brief Congressional career of Mr. CLARK is, unhappily, so uncommon a one that tile admiration it has excited is the severest condemnation that could be pronounced on the degraded tone of the political morals of the people.

SPECULATING IN OPERA TICKETS.--We publish a letter this morning from an unhappy gentleman who complains indignantly of the tricks at the Academy of Music, whereby the public are made to pay prices for the privilege of hearing PICCOLOMINI which the rapacity of Israelitish speculators may see fit to impose upon them.

A meeting of the Police Commissioners was held at 2 P. M. yesterday. A resolution was passed directing the Deputy-Superintendents of New-York and Brooklyn to issue orders to Captains of the various Wards in their respective Precinets, requiring eight glass ballot-boxes to be placed, by daylight on the morning of the ensuing general elections at the polls in each election district.

It is a pity to meddle with any young and promising speculation, so long as it affords innocent gratification to the parties engaged in it. Gentlemen of a visionary turn are really entitled to some indulgence in a world of hard facts ; and he is sadly lacking in charity who ruthlessly tears down their unfinished castles in the air, or scuttles their imaginary steamships of a million or so tons burden.

ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS AT HYDE PARK.--Two persons who stand charged with passing counterfeit bills in this City, were arrested at Hyde Park on Wednesday last. The counterfeits are "fives," "tens" and "twenties" on the Onondaga Bank, Lee Bank, Market Bank of Troy, and the Windham County Bank.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.-An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening--President KALBFLEISCH in the Chair. The Comptroller was authorized to issue bonds for street repairs, amounting to $2,000. The subject of magistrates retaining fees in bastardy and lunacy cases, was referred to the Law Committee.

An extra of the Fort Smith (Ark) Times of the 8th, gives the particulars of the conflict between the United States troops and the Camanches, which occurred near the Wichita Village on the 1st inst. A correspondent writes:

The Vanderbilt United States Mail steamer Ariel, Captain LUDLOW, from Bremen and Havre via Southampton Oct. 6, passed Cape Race on Sunday, the 17th inst., at 5 o'clock, P. M. The Ariel has 250 passengers for New-York. Her news reached here to-day. There is no improvement in the working of the Atlantic Cable at Valentia.

THE NICARAGUA ROUTE TO CALIFORNIA.-A great amount of mystery and uncertainty continues to invest the operations upon the proposed new route to California. The Company which sent away the Hermann, and afterwards advertised, first, the steamer Washington to positively sail on the 16th of October, then to positively sail on the 20th, and finally put up the Collins steamer Atlantic to positively sail for California and Fraser's River on the 25th inst.,

From the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin. A dispatch from Reading assures us that Mr. J. GLANCY JONES, who was not elected to Congress, from Berks County, on Tuesday last, has received a letter from the President, offering him the mission to Vienna. The salary is nine thousand dollars ; the Stonors are considerable ; but, after all, it can afford but little consolation for the loss of the confidence of the Berks County Democracy.

The Vanderbilt steamship Ariel arrived off Cape Race on Sunday evening, arid we received a brief summary of her news, telegraphed from St. Johns, N. F., last evening. Her advices, which are to the 6th inst., are not very important. There had been no improvement in the working of the Atlantic Cable at Valentia.

The U.S. sloop-of-war Saratoga was at Aspinwall on the 5th inst., all well. H. B. M. sloop-of-war Cockatrice had been condemned at Caliao, and sold for [pound]1,140; she was bought by Mr. ROBINETT, and is intended to take passengers to Fraser's River. The officers and crew had been transferred to the frigate Ganges, for Vancouver's Island, with the exception of her Commander, Capt. PALKINGHORN, who took passage for Panama on his way to England.

From private letters of the most reliable character we have received information of the complete success of Lieut. GILLIS' expedition to South America, to observe the late solar eclipse. In a letter dated Payta, 15th of September, from Lieut. GILLIS himself, he complains of much suffering that he was obliged to undergo in crossing the desert and returning to Payta.

A PUBLIC SCANDAL AVOIDED.--We are very glad, on the whole, to be spared the scandal of witnessing the trial of our City Judge for assault and riot and think, therefore, the country ought to feel under an obligation to Ex-Recorder SMITH for entering a nolle prosequi in Judge RUSSELL'S case.

The holy day of St. Luke was celebrated yesterday by a special service at St. Luke's Hospital. situated on Fifty-fourth-street, corner of Sixth-avenue, and connected with the Protestant Episcopal Church. The little chapel of the institution, which is a plain but elegant structure, was well filled on the occasion, the bulk of the congregation consisting of crinoline.

The Chamber of the Board of Councilmen, in the City Hall, was full of people at 3 P. M., yesterday, the hour at which it had been announced that the public reception, by the City authorities, of the Commissioners appointed to escort Gen. PAEZ home to Venezuela, would take place. Within the semicircle of desks were sealed the members of the Board of Aldermen, Recorder BARNARD, and others of the Municipal powers that be.

From the Washington Evening Star. We have every reason to believe that the party receiving something in the neighborhood of half a million of dollars per annum bonus, for keeping the American public out of the use of the Nicaraguan Isthmus route, is at the bottom of the efforts of Dr. JEREZ, the supplemental Nicaraguan Minister, to avoid the return of the CASS-YRISSARI treaty, unmutilated by MARTINEZ.

The Rev. ADAMS AYER, of Charlestown, N. H., has been appointed a member of the New-Hampshire Board of Education for Sullivan County, in place of the Rev. GILES BAILEY, resigned. The Washington Light Guard of Bridgeport have had a superb sword manufactured in this City, for presentation to their commanding officer, Captain FITZGIBBON.

TRIAL OF THE STEAM ENGINE IN WALL-STREET-BANQUET AT THE APOLLO ROOMS. Wall-street was completely blocked at 2 o'clock, yesterday, with a crowd of persons whom curiosity had attracted to witness the capabilities of a fire engine belonging to Hope Hose Company No. 7, of Philadelphia. A party of police from the First Precinct were present to maintain order.

The Hon. ABRAM B. OLIN, Fusion candidate for Congress?? the Thirteenth District opponent, D. L. SEVMOUR, to a series of public discussions on political topics--but SEVMOUR declines the contest. Lieutenent-Governor SELDEN writes to the Chairman of the Monroe County Republican Central Committee:

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 9th inst., is now in her eleventh day and due at Halifax. She had not been heard from at 11 o'clock last night. The Galway steamship Pacific, which left on the 12th-three days later--is also due at St. Johns, N. F.

Political. The Union Ticket in Kings County is received with great favor by the masses of both the Republican and American Parties. So much is this the case that the Democracy have become alarmed, and a desperate effort is being made to bring about union in their ranks.

RIVER THIEVES AT WORK.--Two of the Harbor Policemen discovered two suspicious-looking customers helping themselves to sugar from on board the brig Billow, at Ford's Dock, Brooklyn. The two men, seeing that the officers had spotted them, pulled their oars vigorously--they were loading the sugar into a small boat when discovered--and endeavored to get out of the way.

The accompanying table of the length of routes on the globe over which lines of steamers are already established, 'or towards which, to that end, mercantile enterprise, both in this country and Europe, is now directing its energies, is regarded as of importance in estimating the relative value of the routes.

THE WELL THAT CAVRD IN.--An inquest was held yesterday at the City Hospital upon the body of LEVY SPIRES, the man who died from injuries received by falling on Saturday morning, down a well, corner of Bowery and Grand-street. No evidence was elicited showing what contractor took the job of filling the well.

A man, about 30 years of age, apparently a Frenchman, and rather prepossessing in his appearance, called at a house in Twenty-ninth-street, on Monday, and inquired for the lady of the house by name, saying that Mr. SAMSON wished to see her. The servant showed him to the parlor, and while absent he appropriated to himself all the visiting cards on the centre-table.

In the United States Circuit Court at Boston Judge SPRAGUE presiding, in the case of Captain ToWNSEND, of the slaver Echo, the Court laid down the law as follows in relation to the question of jurisdiction in slaver cases: "By the Constitution of the United States, all offences against her laws. committed within the limits of the country, are to be tried within the State and district where such offences were committed.

Last night the Democrats of the City and County of New-York met, pursuant to the call of the above organization, to indorse the City and Congressional nominations of the Party, in the Palace Gardens, corner of Sixth-avenue and Fourteenth-street. The Garden was hung with colored lamps, was crowded with hearers, and resounded with the music of Dodworth's band. About five thousand persons were present.

PERSEVERING BURGLAR.--Patrick Branner, alias James Corkan, attempted, yesterday morning, to break into the dwelling-house No. 37 1/2 Chrystie-street, but became alarmed and fled. Determined not to "give it up so," he boldly mounted the steps of No. 111 Canal-street, introduced a skeleton-key into the keyhole of the door, and passed inside.

In another column may be found estimates, carefully prepared, illustrating the relative advantages of the three transit routes to the great South Sea. The figures, it will be observed, represent nautical, not statute miles; and the calculations assume the sailing to be done upon a great circle.

The steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool 6th inst., arrived this morning. Her news has been anticipated by the dispatch from the Ariel off Cape Race. A careful examination of our files, however, gives us some little additional news of interest. Later advices from Lady FRANKLIN's Arctic yacht Fox, mention that the expedition had safely crossed the middle ice of Baffin's Sea, and was in a fair way of accomplishing the object of the enterprise.

A GEORGIA DOUGLAS MAN.--A letter appears in the Atlanta Intelligencer of the 13th inst. from the Hon. AUGUSTUS R. WRIGHT, the Democratic representative in Congress from the Fifth District in Georgia, in which the course of Senator DOUGLAS is fully sustained.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. In your journal of to-day I noticed an article under the heading of " Steamships in the Air," which you solicit a reply to. From the numerous erroneous statements contained therein, I feel compelled to comply with your request, as a simple act of justice to myself and those associated with me.

BOGUS MEDICAL PUBLICATIONS.--A man in New-York, styling himself Dr. Hankinson, has for some time past published and circulated a sheet, which he sells for a cent, purporting to be "the New-York Journal." To such postmasters as would consent to act as agents, he allowed a commission of 25 per cent., and upon some medical nostrums a larger gratuity.

THE UNION OF THE REPUBLICANS AND AMERICANS.--Since the Pennsylvania election the Washington Union has become extremely amiable and sprightly. It runs altogether to fun. In fact it is so witty that there is no living with it. What principally excites its satire

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of to-day I notice a letter from your Panama correspondent, F.W.R., which is full of errors, and betrays great ignorance of the events he wishes to record, besides making several sweeping assertions that have not a semblance of truth in them, which, if left without a word of remonstrance, would he received by the public as facts,

GUNTHER.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, Oct. 19, after a lingering illness, MARY MAGDALEN, wife of Christian G. Gunther. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral of the deceased, from her late residence, northwest corner of 2d av. and 14th st., on Friday, Oct. 22, at 1 P.M., without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

DORE--UPDIKE. - In this City, on Tuesday, Oct. 19. by the Rev. Dr. Winter, JOSEPH DORE to Miss MARY A. Up-DIKE, all of this City. HOLLINSWORTH-TURNER. - On Monday, Oct. 18, by the Rev. J. Poisal, JOHN H. HOLLINGSWORTH, Jr., of this City, to Miss SUE S. TURNER, of Paterson, N. J.

INNOCENT AMUSEMENTS OF THE BALTIMORE YOUTH.--Yesterday afternoon, while a youth named WILLIAM CORD, about IS years of age, was returning from Mr. VINIGAR'S, he was stopped near the eastern fence of Patterson's Park by a party of five lads, the oldest about 16 years of age, who asked him to let them shoot at him with a double-barreled gun.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mlle. PICCOLOMINI, the renowned prima-donna of Her Majesty's Theatre, makes her first appearance here to-night in VERDI'S opera of the "Traviata." It is the opening event of the season, and has already created a genuine excitement. Concerning the difficulties which surround the purchaser of tickets in consequence of the envitable spectators in the same, Mr. ULLMAN has addressed the following letter to the Times, in reply to a communication published yesterday.

Considerable testimony must be taken before we shall be in a position to apportion the honors of American diplomacy in China, such as they are, among such as deserve them. The Washington Union, dissatisfied with the share of credit currently assigned to Commissioner READ, begs us to understand that all he did of a meritorious description was accurately set down in his instructions.

While some workmen were digging in the marsh on the land of Mr. John McElthone, in Ellenville, Ulster County, a few days since, they discovered several huge bones. One is a portion of a jaw-boen; the others are, evidently, portions of leg or thigh bones. They are all much decayed, having, apparently, been under the soft mud for ages.
Bellevue Hospital School.l.

SIXTH CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT.-Affairs in the Sixth Congressional District wear a promising aspect. The Republicans and Americans have effected a harmonious fusion, adopting as their candidate one of our oldest and most respectable citizens, Mr. R. H. McCURDY, a retired merchant, who has never sought nor held office, and who consents to run only that the fusion in his District may be rendered perfect.

THE DIFFICULTY AT BROWN UNIVERSITY.--The Providence Journal explains the difficulty which has occurred between the faculty and students of Brown University. A custom has long prevailed in the College, and has latterly increased, of "hazing" the Freshmen. At first the ceremony was little more than a harmless pleasantry, and though always discountenanced and forbidden, was not severely rebuked.

THE RIVAL EDITORS.--Two gentlemen of the editorial fraternity were before the Democratic Nominating Convention of the Eighth District for Congress--Mr. HERRICK, of the Sunday Atlas, and. Mr. BENNETT, of the Herald.

Mr. REED has signed his treaty, a better compact than the former one of Mr. CUSHING in many of its particulars and provisions. but obtained under the power of the guns of the English and French, and while they were negotiating their treaties.

From the Washington Union. We respectfully suggest that since there seems to be growing up so much business between these two miserable factions they should establish regular diplomatic intereourse--that there should be accredited to each concern diplomatic representatives.

The tone of preparations here and elsewhere, as gathered from the several papers in every section of the State, foreshadow great success for the approach ing United States Agricultural Fair, to open in Richmond on the 25th inst. The success of the past State exhibitions has given an impetus to agricultural pursuits, and produced a rivalry in arts and manufactures which will materially enhance the value and interest of the forthcoming exhibition.

We presume that there is no reason to doubt tile telegraphic report that tile lion. J. GLANCY JONES has been appointed Minister to Austria. The lesson which Mr. BUCHANAN intends to convey by this appointment is the advantage to the representative of serving the President rather than serving the People.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool at 10 1/2 o'clock on the morning of the 9th inst., arrived at this port at 12 o'clock last night. Her dates are three days later than those already received. Among her passengers are the Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND, of the NEW-YORK TIMES, and Judge PUTNAM, of Boston.

The spectacle of a brilliant operatic gathering, with its attendant flutter of graceful forms and bright faces, is assuredly one of tile most pleasing that the hampered fastidiousness of City life can afford. It takes us for a moment beyond the chilling limits of aristocratic hauteur, without depriving us of the agreeable influences of fashion and good-breeding. In no city of the world is an Opera crowd so intoxicating as here.

The friends of the Hon DANIEL E. SICKLES, the Administration candidate for Congress in the 'Third Congressional District, met last evening in the Chinese Assembly Rooms, Broadway, to ratify his nomination. The meeting was called for 7 1/2 o'clock, but at that hour the attendance was exceedingly scanty, and after a time became extremely impatient.

The City--especially that part of it in which the newspaper offices are located--was as full last night of noise, ce??rion, blasphemy and drunkenness, as any 4th of July night. The only cause of excitment was the anticipated news from the prize fighters. The newspaper offices were throunged as curly as 7 o'clock, and false rumors of news brought the crowds back again in the haste many time after they seemed to have dispersed.

The march between Mr. MORPHY and Mr. HARRWITZ has proceeded another stage, the former having the advantage. It will be remembered that the first two games of this Combat inured to Mr. HARRWITZ, after which four were played. Mr. MORPHY being the victor. Mr. HARRWITZ, on a plea of ill-health, postponed the further prosecution of the fight for sometime, until on the 29th alt. it was resumed.

IS THERE TO BE ANY ATTEMPT MADE TO COMPEL RICHMOND COUNTY TO PAY FOR THE QUARANTINE HOSPITALS?-By the Act of 1853 (Chapter 428 of Session Laws) counties are made responsible for damages to real or personal properly occasioned by any mob or riot. This is the law under which it is proposed to hold Richmond County liable for the destruction of the Quarantine property.

YOUNG.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 20, PIERRE E., infant son of Jefferson and late Catherine C. Young. The funeral will take place on Friday morning, Oct. 22, at 10 o'clock, from No. 206 Monroe-st. GUNTHER.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, Oct. 19, after a lingering illness, MARY MAGDALEN, wife of Christian G. Gunther.

STEAMSHIP VANDERBILT.--The Saxonia arrived to day, reports having met the steamship Vanderbilt, Saturday, Oct. 9, at 6 o'clock, P. M., in lat. 50?? 12', long. 23??. The Vanderbilt was then seven days from New-York, and had made 2,310 miles distance, an average of 330 per day.

On Tuesday afternoon, just before the closing of Court at the Tombs, a very respectable and intelligent looking Irish girl appeared before Justice CONNOLLY and made a complaint of murder against Robert L. Willis, proprietor of the noted gambling-house at No. 581 Broadway.

NEW-YORK IN AN UPROAR.--October is always a noisy month in this metropolis, for it is not only the favorite season for target excursions and all manner of street shows, but the City is then crowded with strangers from all parts of the Union, families are returning from the country, the streets overflow with excited

BOUNDARY BETWEEN NEW HAMPSHIRE AND MAINE.--General J. C. ABBOTT, of this city, returned yesterday from a month's exploration with the Commissioners of the above-named States, who have run the line from the northern United States boundary to the lower end of Lake Umbagog.

We have already more than once commented upon the important status in society which professed pugilists have come to occupy among us. They to all intents and purposes, form at the present moment a "privileged class," and are in possession of vastly more immunities than a nobleman in most European countries.

It is for the sake of the lovers of art and to encourage its growth among us that we call attention to a remarkably fine collection of pictures,

HUDSON COUNTY CIRCUIT--BEFORE JUDGE OGDEN.--Abbey Hanson vs. John Shotwell.--This was an action to recover damages for an alleged error in the survey of the property of plaintiff, by which this property was encroached upon by a building belonging to the defendant. The property is situated in Third-street, between Washington and Hudson streets, Hoboken.

Soon after the death of LORENZO B. SHEPARD, Esq., in September, 1856, an organization was formed by his acquaintances and political associates for the purpose of obtaining by voluntary contribution a sum sufficient to erect a suitable monument as a tribute to his memory. A long time did not elapse before the necessary amount was all subscribed and paid in, although no one person was permitted to contribute more than $50.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A misprint in your advertising columns announced the opening of the Rockland Female Institute on the 18th of November, which has misled many of our patrons. Will you allow me space to say, definitely, that our School opens on the first day of November.

Advices from Venezuela, which extend to the 27th ult., announce the settlement of the international difficulties which at one time looked so threatening, General MONEGAS has left the country in safety, and the English and French Representatives, who were on board their men-of-war, have returned to their duties at Laguayra.

THE FOREIGN VOTE.--Although the Washington Union is in the main facetious and jolly over the late disasters of its party, there are some things of which it feels inclined to complain. One of these is the fact "that a large class of naturalized citizens have gone over with the Americans to the Republicans."

By the arrival of the Saxonia and Edinburgh at this port, and of the Europa at Halifax, our European advices are carried to Oct. 9. they are unusually destitute of importance. Two French ships of war have been dispatched to Lisbon to obtain the restoration of the ship Charles Georges, seized by a Portuguese frigate in the Mozambique Channel as a slaver. From India the intelligence is of interest.

AMENDING THE CONSTITUTION.--Besides the ballots for State and local candidates, the voters will find at the polls on the 2d of November two other kinds of tickets, in reference to a new Constitution. One of these reads thus Shall there be a Convention to revise the Constitution 2nd amend the same ? Yes."

Mr. JOHN B. HASKIN.--The opposition in the Ninth Congressional District (Westchester, Putnam and Rockland,) have definitively arranged for the campaign by conceding a clear field to their present representative, Mr. Haskin. He received an independent nomination from the Anti-Lecompton Democrats, on the ground of opposition to the President's Kanasas

Captain JENKINS left this afternoon to take command of the Preble, which sails from Norfolk for Paraguay. Governor McMULLEN has been notified that he will be superseded as Governor of Washington Territory.

From the National Intelligencer. We have been favored with the following letter from Lieutenant GILLS to Professor HENRY, of the Smithsonian Institution, in which the former briefly relates the success of his visit to South America, to take observations of the late Solar eclipse: PAYTA, Wednesday, Sept. 15, 1858.

THE GREAT HORSE FAIR.--To-day is the last day of entering horses for the first annual meeting o the Association for the Improvement of the Breed of Horses. This meeting is to take place on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of next week, on the Eclipse ([ate Centreville) Course, Long Island. Over two hundred horses have been entered for the prizes,

A MAIL AGENT ARRESTED FOR ROBBERY.--The St. Louis Democrat notices the arrest of a United States Mail agent named MORRIS, for a robbery committed on board the Missouri steamer Emma. Tile amount stolen was $2,000, belonging to the boat. The robbery was ingeniously effected. The room occupied by the clerks as the money depository and that used by the mail agent had formerly been divided by a partition,

We learn from our correspondence in Berlin that Ex-Governor JOSEPH A. WRIGHT, United States Minister to Prussia, is now corresponding with the Administration upon a highly important subject--nothing less than the violation of our passports by the Government to which he is accredited. It seems an American citizen has been seized by the Prussian Government and made to serve in the army.

The steamship Pacific, of the North Atlantic Steamship Company's Line, from Galway, on the morning of Oct. 13, arrived at St. Johns, Newfoundland, yesterday morning. Her advices are three days later than those by the Europa. She reports that the equinoctial gales had (lone serious damage, attended with loss of life, to the shipping in the North Sea.

The steamship Pacific, Capt. W. C. THOMPSON, has arrived at this port, from Galway at 6 o'clock on the morning of the 13th. The Pacific arrived at 1 o'clock this morning. She has 280 passengers, among whom are Lord and Lady BURY and suite. She encountered heavy westerly gales during five days.

FIRST ASSEMBLY DISTRICT.-The Republican Convention for this District, which embraces the Eighth, Seventeenth and Eighteenth Wards of Brooklyn, and the County towns in Kings County, met last night at Boerum's Hotel, Joralemon-street, and nom inated Mr. GEORGE W. STILWELL. There are now four candidates before the people in this District for Assembly. A union of Republicans and Americans was at first confidently anticipated.

In view of the recent Congressional elections and of those which are to oceur before the assembling of the Thirty-sixth Congress, the following information in relation to tile franking privilege will be of general interest. The franking privilege of members of CongressSenators and Representatives-commences with the term for which they were respectively elected,

Politics at the Capital are decidedly "high-mixed." It would be difficult for one at a distance to have a just understanding of the precise state of affairs here locally. indeed it is difficult for one on the spot, with the best of advantages, to have a clear notion of how things are, with the whys and wherefores. For some things it would be exceedingly difficult to give any reason, good or bad.

From the Washington Star. The Secretaries are also getting up the annual statements of their respective Departments. These will generally be far more interesting than usual, illasmuch as the current year has been peculiarly prolific of important subjects connected with Governmental affairs.

The examination in the case of the parties arrested on Tuesday evening, at the alleged gambling-house No. 581 Broadway, upon the charge of gambling, was resumed at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, at the Tombs, before Justice CONNOLLY, Robert Willis, the proprietor of the gambling-house, was present, wearing his kid gloves and complacent smile of the previous day.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In this morning's issue of your paper I noticed a remark in allusion to the mortality in Charleston from Aug. 7 to October, which tends to convey a false idea of the prevailing pestilence. It was stated that the whole number of deaths during the interval of two months was but--573 less than last year.

BARR.-In this City, on Wednesday evening, Oct. 20, after a short illness, Mrs. CATHARINE BARR. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the Dutch Reformed Church, corner of Avenue B and 5th-st., this day, (Friday,) at 2 o'clock. CEISTY.--In this City. on Thursday, Oct. 21, ELIA FRANCES, only chill of Henry F. and RACHEL A. Cristy, aged I year, 7 months and 16 days.

The introductory to the regular Winter Course of lectures in this institution, which, from the year of its inauguration, has never failed to graduate more students annually than any of its City rival, s was delivered by Dr. ALFRED C. POST, on Monday evening, at the College, in Fourteenth-street. There was a large attendance of professional gentlemen, students and ladies, and the Doctor's appearance was greeted with warm applause.
