The intelligence of the illness of Mr. PAEKER, says the writer, "will be received with sorrow throughout the country. He has occupied so large a space in the public eye for so many years, and maintained it with such vigor,

An interesting case, involving the ownership of slave property, has been pending in Lowell for several days, and the Vor Populi states the following facts in relation thereto, as it learns them: "JESSE CORNWELL, a rich planter in Mississippi, had a favorite slave named BETSEY, who was employed in the confidential relation of housekeeper, and with whom he cohabited.

A meeting of influential citizens was held on Wednesday night at the rooms of the Academy of Design, in Tenth-street, to take into consideration "the recent exposure of the astounding errors and frauds committed in many of the Departments of the City Government, with a view of digesting some plan or system of accountability in the public offices, by which plundering and peculation may be checked and prevented in the future."

MORTALITY AT SEA--BRIG ESPERANZA (BR.) PICKED UP DERELICT.--Captain NELSON, of the steamship Orizaba, arrived at New-Orleans from Key West, via Florida, reports that on the 28th ult., at 5 P. M., when 15 miles off St. Martin's Reef, he saw a brig at anchor, showing signs of distress, and made for her. She proved to be the british brig Esperanza, Captain RUSE, from Vera Cruz, loaded with mahogany, and bound for Liverpool.

The fair ground was yesterday, about 12 o'clock, the scene of a terrible affray, which resulted in the death of one man, and the mortal wounding of two or three others. It occurred on the promenade back of the upper tier of seats, and created the greatest excitement imaginable.

POLITICS AND FINE ARTS.--The City is not so entirely convulsed by politics but that the sale of American paintings at LEEDS', yesterday, attracted a very large number of the lovers of art, and the pictures sold, particularly those of KENSETT, LEUTZE, GEORGE BAKER, HART, BOUTELLE and JENKINS, brought very good prices.

The third Overland Mail from California arrived at St. Louis on the 18th inst., in twenty-five days from *San Francisco. The dates from California are to Sept. 24, three days later than the news by the last steamship arrival at this port. The papers, however, contain no news, nor do the mail agents report any intelligence later than former dates. The St. Louis Republican says:

Mrs. LAMBERT, alias Flora Temple, of Boston, and Mrs. MARTHA BUCKLEY, alias Prioress, of Lynn, Mass., commenced a walking match at Montgomery Hall, No. 76 Prince-street, on Tuesday. Both parties have been in training for the match for the last six weeks, and both appeared to be "in good condition" at starting.

WOLFE--LAFORGE.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 21, by the Rev. Edwin F. Hatfield, D. D., Mr. STEWARD WOLFE to Miss MARY L. daughter of Bornt S. Laforge, Esq., all of this City. BARLOW--LOCKWOOD.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 20, by the Rev. Mathew Hale Smith, GEORGE BARLOW to MARTHA A., youngest daughter of John H. Lockwood, Esq., all of this City.

The centre and focus of Southern Democracy is at Charleston. There is published the Mercury, that chief organ of Southern opinion, and there the next Democratic Presidential Convention is to be held. The influence of CALHOUN'S name and the authority of his opinions still linger in that political metropolis;

The Hon. JOSHUA R. GIDDINGS has written a letter to TOM CORWIN, in which he criticizes some remarks made by the latter in a recent speech at Xenia. It appears that Mr. CORWIN expressed himself in favor of admitting Cuba as a Slave State in case that island shall be acquired by our Government.

NEW TRIAL FOR CANGEMI.--We learn by telegraph from Albany that the Court of Appeals has reversed the judgment of the Supreme Court in the case of MICHAEL CANGEMI, and granted a new trial. He has already been tried three times. Twice he was convicted, and once there was a disagreement of the Jury.

Last evening a meeting of the American and Republican electors of this City, favorable to a union against the Administration, on Anti-Lecompton principles, was held in the Park. The immediate origin of the demonstration was a call, addressed to those whose sympathies were with the united Opposition in their recent triumphs in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana and Iowa.

TWENTY FOR ONE.-In the recent elections the Opposition took a sweeping revenge for the loss of FRANCIS P. BLAIR, Jr. On his political grave twenty Denocratic victims have bled. Thirteen Lecompton ghosts crossed the Styx from Pennsylvania, four from Ohio and three from Indiana. Well may the wrathful shade of BLAIR be appeased.

The stockholders of the New-haven County Bank met at New-Haven, yesterday, to hear the report of the Committee appointed to investigate its affairs. The report is very severe upon the management, and particularly upon its President. The capital of the bank is $500,000, and though its trial balance shows liabilities amounting to $978,000, and resources to the same amount,

In a fortnight the campaign will be at an end. There is a pretty fair amount of steam on now, meetings being held every evening, and many of them. The Democrats and Americans have had Faneuil Hall assemblies, which are just as much parts of an election here as is voting itself. The Democratic meeting I have already written of.

The most difficult task in literature at tile present day, we should imagine, would be to achieve distinction by bringing out a new edition of SHAKESPEARE. That field of literary labor has been so completely overworked by ingenious editors of every grade of qualifications that it must require a rare combination of talent, opportunities and devotional industry,

THE NEW MINISTER TO AUSTRIA.--The Washington Union of yesterday announces with " great pleasure" the appointment of the Hon. J. GLANCY JONES as Minister to Austria, which post, it says, " was voluntarily tendered him by the President." Mr. JONES has, no doubt, all requisite qualifications for the place;

The U. S. Mail steamship Black Warrior, J. W. SMITH Commander, from New-Orleans 12th and Havana 15th, at 10 o'clock A. M., arrived at this port yesterday. The Black Warrior has experienced very heavy weather from the northward and eastward since leaving Havana.

THE HON. J. GLANCY JONES.--It affords us great pleasure to announce that the appointment of the Hon. J. GLANCY JONES, of Pennsylvania, as Minister to Austria, which was voluntarily tendered to him by the President. has been accepted by that gentleman. The faithfulness and ability of his whole course in Congress as a national Democrat have been recognized and indorsed by the country.

PRACTICAL EDUCATION.-All good thorough education is practical; but there are particular institutions in which industrial efficiency is made more than usually prominent. One of these is the new " People's College," at Havana, near the head of Seneca Lake, in this State, the corner-stone of which was laid with appropriate observances in the presence of ten or fifteen thousand people last month.

The U. S. sloop-of-war Decatur was at Callao. The Merrimac had sailed from Callao for the Sandwich Islands, and from thence was to visit the western coast of Mexico. The U. S. ship Roanoke touched at Aspinwall on the 20th of September, and left immediately for San Juan del Norte. The U. S. sloop-of-war St. Mary's was at Acapulco on the 28th ult., bound for Panama.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--Mr. STEAKOSCH'S season of Italian Opera (a prosperous one we think) came to an end last evening. The Company proceeds to Baltimore and Washington, returning by way of Philadelphia. ACADEMY OF MUDIV.--The " Traviata" will be repeated to-night for the second time, with PICCOLOMINI, STEFANI and FLORENZA in the leading roles.

The provincee of New-Brunswick and Nova Scotia are occupied with the discussion of Railway matters. Delegates from the Governments of Canada, New-Brunswick and Nova Scotia have gone to England recently with a view to the Inter-colonial Railway. The Hon. C. Fisher, Attorney-General; and the Hon. A. J. Smith, of the Ministry, sailed two weeks since to join the delegations from the other weeks since to join the delegations from the other provinces.

PORTUGAL INTERFERING WITH THE FRENCH SLAVE-TRADE.--Under a properly-conducted system the French negro colonization scheme might have been so worked as to have been a blessing both to the negro and to the country where his services were in urgent demand.

Many hard things may he imagined. The ancient poets invented all manner of penal woes to be undergone in the spirit for sins committed in the flesh. There was one poor fellow condemned to fill a sieve with liquid, and another to roll a wheel up hill that never reached the top.

COLUMBIA COLLEGE.--The Post-Graduate instruction, which, according to the advertisement in another column, Columbia College is about to undertake, promises well for the cause of thorough education. It is known that many of the cleverest and most earnest of our College graduates are now coinpelled to go to Europe, and then at Edinburg,

THIRD CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT. It will be remembered that the Conference Committee of the American and Republican Conventions of the Third Congressional District advised a union, and the nomination of AMOR J. WILLIAMSON as candidate for Congress.

McLEOD--WILSON,--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 21, by the Rev. John Thomson. Mr. NOEMAN McLEOD, of this City, to JESSIE WILSON, daughter of the late Alex. Wilson, Esq., merchant, of Busby, near Glasgow, Scotland. LIVINGSTON--HYSLOP.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 2??, by the Most Rev. Archibishop Hughes, Lieut DR GRASSE LIVINGSTON, U. S. N., to GEORGLANNA MESTER. daughter of Robert Hyslop, Esq., all of this City.

Two Philadelphia detectives are now in this City on the look-out for a French woman, aided by a male companion, who has lately been perpetrating magnificent swindles upon some of the credulous inhabitants of Philadelphia. She came to Philadelphia from the South, after having performed very "successful engagements" in all the leading Southern cities, including California and Texas.

McNAMEE.--In Brooklyn. on Thursday, Oct. 21, Mrs. CATHARINE McNAMEE, aged 60 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, this (Saturday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 363 Cumberland-st. Her remains will be taken to Calvary Cemetery.

THE REPORTED CHILD-MURDER CASE--An inquest was held yesterday at No. 355 West Twenty-sixty-street upon the body of CATHARINE STACKPOLE, a child three months old, who was reported to have been killed by her father.

A recent stretch of Papal power in Italy is making a noise in Europe, which will not be hushed up we believe. without serious detriment to somebody. It appears that, five years ago, a respectable Jew, named MONTARD, residing in Bologna, had a child suffering from worms, or some other infantile disorder.

By the arrival of the Europa's mails a full list of the passengers who were on board the Austria when she was burnt at sea, on the 13th day of September, has been received by the agents in this City. We have so classified it as to exhibit the number lost and saved ; the later are distinguished by an asterisk;

A statement, prepared by a thoroughly competent person at Shanghae, setting forth the scope and probable operation of the recent Chinese treaties, so far as they affect American commercial interests, may be found in an-other column. The writer, with apparent reluctance, admits the liberality of the concessions, and the large extent to which they exceed the general anticipation;

NICARAGUAN AFFAIRS IN EUROPE--The Count ANTOINE DE MELANO, Consul-General of Nicaragua in London, has published, in the Paris Presse, a communication which does no great credit to his discretion or his common sense. The communication will be found in the letter of our Paris correspondent, who, at the same time, gives an interesting historical resume of the origin and progress of the famous Belly contract.

At the Mayor's Office yesterday there was a compulsory gathering of female astrologers, clairvoyants, spiritualists and fortune-tellers. Armed with warrants, officers BIRNEY made a general tour of inspection which resulted in a grand gathering of female notabilities in the presence of the Chief Magistrate and Justice WELSH--young and old, the coarsely vulgar, and the semi-genteel.

THE NEW STEAM-PROPELLER LANCASTER.-The dimensions of tile new United States Steam-Propeller Lancaster, just launched from the Philadelphia Navyyard, are as follows: Length of spar-deck, 251 feet 10 inches; extreme breadth of beam, 45 feet 6 inches; depth of hold from top of kelson to berth-deck, 11 feet 7 inches; length of keel, 236 feet 8 inches;

A good deal of curiosity was felt by expectant politicians at the commencement of the present week, regarding the speech Mr. DISRAELI was announced to make at Aylesbury. It has been his custom for several years to avail himself of the annual dinner of the Agricultural Society of Buckinghamshire, to give utterance to the pungent criticisms on the public affairs in which he is so great a master.

As November approaches, the interest attaching to the Illinois contest deepens. Yesterday a letter was received at Springful, from Vice-President BRECKINRIDGE, urging the election of DOUGLAS. Thus the split in the Democratic Party developed by the Illinois war, has reached the Administration itself.

Today Buffalo has shaken off a large load of rowdyism, and breathes more freely, although it is estimated, by a keen statistical authority, that $75,000 has been spent here. No city ever rejoiced more at the departure of an invading army than does this at the receding roll of every train which carries off a detachment of "Dead Rabbits."

The official list of the passengers who were on board the burnt steamer Austria, which was destroyed on the 13th of September, has been received by the agents of the Hamburg Packet Company in this City, by the Europa. The first intelligence of the disaster was received in Bristol, Eng., by the screw steamer Pemberton on the 2d inst., which had spoken the bark Lotus with 18 passengers on board.

In ship Palestine, from London--Jas. Mitchell and lady, Horace Hunt. W. C. Hall, G. D. Cooper, J. H. Raymond and lady, J. W. Harper and family, Mrs. E. Walker. Miss Walker. J. A. Uhsdell, J. D. Hague, C. Meyer, of New-York , Mrs. Sheddell, H. M. Adley, of London Chas. H. Haile, of Tennessee; J. P. Kimball, of Massachusetts and 75 in the steerage.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: The four Treaties, recently completed at Tien-tsin, have all gone home for ratification, and until this is notified to the Chinese Government none of them can take effect. Meanwhile, synopses of the American and English Treaties have been published here, setting forth very clearly those acquisitions which are of most importance to commercial interests.

THE CASE OF THE HAIDEE SLAVERS. -- This case was to have been concluded before Commissioner WHITE to-day, but owing to engagements of Mr. Jeachimssen it was postponed without day. SUPREME COURT -- Oct. 22. Before Judge Clerke. Joseph Felds vs. Felverti Vestvalli and Henry Vestvali.-- Verdict for plaintiff $990.

It is understood here that Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELEY will leave for Central America to-morrow. The treaties he is instructed to negotiate, drafts of which have already been prepared, will be entirely satisfactory to our Government.

From the Buffalo Express, 20th. We learn from Mr. S. R. THURSTON, of Livingston County, a brother of the unfortunate aeronaut who recently ascended from Adrian, Mich., and has not since been heard from, that, while on his way to this city, via the Lake Shore Railroad, when near Fremont, Monday evening, about 8 o'clock, he saw the rival balloons of Messrs. GODARD and STEINER.

On Saturday afternoon Justice CONNOLLY resumed the examination of Robert L. Willis, of No. 581 Broadway, suspected of murder on the testimony of his late servant girl, Catharine Mulhearn, Mr. Basteed. the Corporation Counsel, appeared for Mr. Willis, and very sharply cross-examined the girl Mulhearn.

GEN. WALKER'S CIRCULAR--"The Gray-eyed Man of Destiny," as his admiring friends-- the survivors of them, we mean--are fond of styling him, proposes to go into the passenger and transportation business.

The Brownsville (Texas) Flag, of the 13th inst., has dates from Victoria to the 30th ult., from Tampico to the 2nd inst., and from Monterey to the 10th inst. The news confirms the accounts of a battle between the Conservatives, under MIRAMON, and the Liberals, under VIDAURRI, in which the latter were partially defeated.

Mr. DOUGLAS is waging a very unequai contest. Illinois, in the last Presidential eanvass was earried for BUCHANAN, by only about 10,000 majority. Mr. DOUGLAS now proposes to carry it, not only against the Republicans, but against Mr. BUCHANAN also.

In steamship Montgomery, for Savannah--Lewis Lehse, Fred. Young., Miss M. E. James, H. Finch, Ira W. Porter, Harvey Swain. W. H. Manning. J. P. Penn. H. E. Bostwick, Miss C. E. Holt, Jacob Kahn, Kate Kelley, M. Cullinan, R. J. Caughey., Jas. Stewart., S. H. Fisk, Thos.

CAHOONE--MARSCHALK.--At the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn Heights, on Thursday evening, Oct. 21, by the Rev. Dr. Lewis, STEPHEN H. CAHOONE to SOPHIA A., daugher of Capt. John Marschalk, all of that city.

Yesterday, and for several days previous, all things mere very quiet at Quarantine. The present regiment of "citizen soldiers" stationed there seems not to have attracted so much attention as its predecessors.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mile. PICCOLOMINI'S engagement has been eminently successful so far. The houses have been large and remunerative. Mr. ULLMAN announces that the "Traviata" will be given to-night for the last time.

The Captain of the bark Contest. which arrived at this port on Monday last, from Altala. Gulf of California, delivered to the United States Marshal a colored man named ALEXANDER COOK, upon a charge of mutiny and revolt.

The Overland Mail which left San Francisco Sept. 23 arrived at New-York on the 22d inst. The news we receive comes to us from private sources, as under the present arrangements of the road newspapers are not carried in the mails.

The Commissioners deputed by the Republic of Venezuala to wait on Gen. PAEZ in this City, and invite his native land, gave a banquet on Saturday night in the Metropolitan Hotel as the Municipal authorities, in recogination of the hospitality displayed towards the eminent exile during his southern among us.

GERMAN CONVENTION--The German Republicans of the City having elected two delegated from each Ward for the purpose of considering the interest of the German population in reference to the celebrated "Twelfth Section" of the Syracuse

The August accounts of the British Board of Trade, delivered a day or two before the departure of the mail, show a marked improvement in the trade between the United States and Great Britain, as compared with the earlier months of the present year.

QUICK MOVEMENT OF TROOFS--Private advices have been received at the War Department of the arrival at Fort Vanconver, Washington Territory, of the detachment of troops sent out in July last. This detachment, consisting of four hundred and fifty recruits, left New-York City on the 21st of July, and arrived at Fort Vancouver on the 26th of August, without any casualty except the loss of one man.

A WOMAN FATALLY BURNED.--Mrs. JEANETTE WHITE, a French woman, residing at No. 310 West Forty-fourth-street, was fatally burned at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, her clothes having caught fire from a lamp.
SMITH--In this City, on Saturday. Sept. 23, Mrs. CLOTILDA SMITH. widow of the late John J. Smith, in the 65th year of her age. Due Notice of her funeral will be given in Tuesday's morning papers.

THE NATIONAL MONUMENT AT WASHINGTON.--We learn that the old managers who for so many years conducted the offices of the National Monument at Washington, and who were removed to give place to an "American" Board of Directors,
The provisions in unusually depressed, owing to heavy importation and a very reduced consumption, arising from the great abundance and cheapness of sweet potatoes.

The Weathersfield (Texas) News Says: "We learn from some families that came in on Tuesday from Jack County, that the Indians are about making a descent upon the whites in this region. From all we can learn, it seems that the Kickapoo and Camanche tribes have united, and are now preparing to wage a war of extermination upon the whites.

The New-Oregon (Iowa) Sentinel, of the 17th ult., states that on the 9th of this month two strangers came to that village from the southwest on foot. On inquiry subsequently of Mr. HOCKINGS, a man with whom they stopped several days,

" How cool this Summer has been." This remark has been often made in our hearing within the past week, and has mduced us to examine the record of the weather kept in this City for the four preceding years, and the result, like many other Popular errors, is that such is not the fact.

The Committees appointed at the Mayor's meeting held on Friday night last, in Brooklyn, to endeavor to effect a union of the Democracy, will report this evening. It is understood that their efforts have thus far proved fruitless.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I respectfully ask a little space in your columns for the defence of right against wrong-to vindicate political principle against political incendiarism; and I pay no fulsome compliment to the TIMES when I say that its columns are never closed against any man,

The Saturday Press is the name of a new and neatly-printed weekly sheet published in this City. The first number appeared on the 23d inst. Its aim is to "furnish its readers with as great a variety as possible of interesting facts,

The 26th Ultimo. (Old style,) the anniversary of the coronation of His Imperial Majesty, ALEXANDER II, was kept as a fete day throughout the Empire. The Emperor was absent from St. Petersburg, which necessarily diminished the interest of the ceremonies here.

From files of the Asuncion Seminario to Aug. 21, we derive additional details of Paraguayan intelligence. Don JOSE RUFOS CAMINOS has been appointed Consul-General for Paraguay, at the capital of the Argentine Republic.

THE CUNARD STEAMERS--WITHDRAWAL OF THE PERSIA.--The British Mail steamer Persia, which was to leave Liverpool on Saturday, the 16th instant, will be due at this port on Wednesday or Thursday of the present week.

THE SLAVE-TRADE.--Southern men are beginning to discuss the trade in salves as a moral question. A correspondent of the Richmond South ask, "Ought negro-traders to be hung," His own convictions are decidedly that they ought not.

From Mexico we have at last what is probably an authentic account of the engagement between VIDAURRI and MIRAMON. The former was not on the field when the engagement commenced, and his army appears to have been attacked when least prepared for it.

By the arrival of the bark Virginia, Capt. HILL we have dates from Democratic to the 29th September from Berbice to the 23d. from St. Kitts and St. Eustasius to Oct. 2, and from Turk's Island to the 9th inst. At Demerara the sugar crop was nearly all gathered in, and was one of the most abundant in British Guiana for twenty years past that is,

SANITARY INVESTIGATION.--The sanitary investigation as to the condition of the City, before the Committee of the Senate, is still progressing. Dr. GRISCOM, Dr. McNULTY and Dr. SAMUEL ROTTON were examined on Saturday.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your able journal of Sept. 21, in an article headed, "A Stricken City," appeared the following: "I regard the application of the Young Men's Christian Association for foreign aid as wholly unwarranted, and an unjust reflection upon the proverbially liberal benevolence of our people."

I learn to day, from a reliable source, that Mr, BUCHANAN will take strong ground in ?? Message in favor of the Passage, this Winter, of a Pacifs Railroad bill. He will sketch the plan of construction to be favored by his administration.

Sir WILLIAM DON, the amateur actor who figured in this City not long ago, has been convicted at the Sunderl and (Eng.) Police Court, of an assault upon an actor, and sentenced to a fine. The suit was brought by one EDWARD BURCHELL, who prayed relief

A SLAVER GAMBLED AWAY BY THE CAPTAIN--It was announced in the ?? of the 23d inst., that the Lark John Gripin, while arrived at this port the day before from Loando, Africa, reported that the bark E. A. Rawlins, from New-Orleans, was "run away with" from Loando about July 26th, by the male and crew, while the Captain, GILLEY, was on Shore.

The question issue between Buenos Ayres and the Argentine have already, if we may trust information received from the former city, elicited British intervention. Mr. WILLIAM D. CHRYSTIE, the English resident at Parana,

The question in dispute between the French and Portuguese Governments, as to the seizure of the French bark and Charles and Georges, is a very unpleasant one ; but I have reason to hope that it will be settled without serious consequences.

FEDERAL UNION OF THE BRITISH-AMERICAN PROVINCES--The recent arrival of Lord BURY in Canada lends probability to the rumor that he is specially commissioned to take initiatory steps for erecting the five British-American Provinces into one federation.

Rev. H. A. GUILD, Poughkeepsie--Dear Sir: I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th inst., making certain inquiries of me relative to the views and position of the Hon. E. D. MORGAN, the Republican candidate for Governor, on the question of Temperance or Prohibition.

DEATH OF MR. C. F. DANIELS.-- Mr. C. F. DANIELS, recently editor of the New-London Chronicle, died at New-London, Conn., on the 20th instant, aged 69. Mr. DANIELS was a native of Waterford, Conn., was educated for the law, but forsook the profession and assumed editorial labor in Cheraw, S. C., in 1825.

THE POLITICAL PRIZE RING.--Talk of the terrible blows that MORRISSEY and the Benicia Boy bestowed upon each others heads! They were mere love-taps and gentle endearments compared with the terrific epithets which some of our political cotemporaries hurl at each other.

A RESIDENT OF NEWARK LOST IN THE AUSTRIA--The Newark Mercury of yesterday says: "The suspence concerning the fate of our fellow-citizen, Mr. JOHN MENTZ, is at last ended. His loss in the Austria is a matter of certainty.

From the Rochester Union and Advertiser, 22d. The tragedy of Fails Field--the first set of which was performed on the night of the 19th of November--has this day been concluded by the execution upon the gallows, of MARION IRA STOUT, the chief actor.

THE COLLINS STEAMERS.--It has been currently ??mored, for some time, that the Panama Railroad company was negotiating for the purchase of the Collins steamships Adriatic, Baltic and Atlantic, with a view of establishing a weekly line to California via Aspinwall and Panama.
NO MORE MARYS FOR THE CATHOLICS.--The doctrine of the Immaculate Coneption, brings comfort to the Protestant heart. That antecedent of the Virgin Mary's birth having been adjusted, and sanctified,
To the Editor of the New-York Times: Having ocasion to pass down the Sixth-avenue this morning, about 7 o'clock, I was foreibly struck with the growing rowdysim of a certain class of our young men.

A question having been recently started respecting the circumstances which attended the capture of the Seminole warrior, OSCEOLA, Major--General JESUP, of the United States Army, with the view of placing in their true light the incidents connected with a transaction in which he was personally and prominently an actor,

CHAPTER OF BURGLARIES--The gentlemen of the false key and jimmy were around in great numbers saturday night and yesterday morning. The drug store of Mr. George Lee, corner of Grand and Allen streets,

From the Albany Argus. Several cases were decided by the Court of Appeals at the term which has just closed involving important questions of law, or of Constitutional construction, some notice of which may be acceptable, at least to our legal readers.

A Moldavian Jew, ISRAEL BENJAMIN, is preparing for a journey through Affghanistan and China. Since 1845, he has gone over the Eastern countries of Europe, as well as Egypt, Palestine, Persia, the Regencies of Tripoli and Tunis, Algeria, and Morocco. The Geographical Society of Berlin have charged him to solve several geographical and ethnographical questions.

The Tammany Hall Democracy have at length taken the field. Last night, in pursuance of a public call headed "Buchanan, Parker and Victory," the Democratic electors of this City, " friendly to regular nominations and the usages of the party;" as tile phrase goes, met en masse in Tammany Hall to express their approval of the State and County nominations.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Can you inform the many anxious inquirers in the vicinity of Tompkins Market why it is that the work upon that building has ceased? There has been nothing done upon it for some time. There is certainly a pack of good management somewhere, the work lying the ?? beautiful weather as we have had, with Winter fast, approaching,

The original of the following letter is published in the Echo d' Italia of this City. It derives additional interest from the recent decease of its gifted and distinguished author: "GENOA, Thursday, July 22, 1858.

The New-York State Arsenal, corner of Thirtyfifth-street and Seventh-avenue, is rapidly approaching completion. It is the intention to inaugurate it on the 25th of November. During the present week there will be an opportunity for architects, engineers, builders, and others interested, to examine the construction of the roof which spans the drill-room, 183 feet long and 83 feet wide, without support between the walls.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--Mile. PICCOLOMINI'S third appearance last evening was attended by an audience scarcely, if at all, inferior to that of the first right. The fascinating little lady grows on the public, and will evidently maintain her position. The opera was admirably given every respect--as well as any work of art need be given.

GENTLEMEN: I have just received your favor of the 12th instant, informing me that at a Convention of the Order of United Americans in this State, held on the 11th instant, I was unanimously adopted as the candidate of the Order for the office of Governor. Although I can, with sincerity, say that I do not covet political office, I am by no means insensible or indifferent to the good opinion of my fellow-citizens,

Observing in your issue of to-day an account of a College row in Amherst, doubtless appreciated by your readers, I thought that they might be also interested in some of the doings of our Sophomore Class of '61 in "Old Yale," the arena of so many miniature political contests. Be it known then, that during the customary persecution of last year, we meditated a terrible revenge upon our innocent successors,

FELLOW CITIZENS: The announcement of my resignation of the office of Governor having induced many of the good people of the Territory to express their regrets that I should do so, and some having gone so far as to express misgivings as to the future, it may be proper for me, when about to sever my official connections with you forever, to address to you a few words at parting.

THE INDICATED CITY OFFICIALS.--Who are the illustrious defalcators indicated by the late Grand jury of the Court of General Sessions. As we remarked yesterday, although only seven were indicted, there were three or four times seven quaking in their boots, anticipating that their turn is come at last. Then who are the seven, that the other may be relieved of their apprehension for another term of so?

From the Cincinnati Enquirer, 22d. Another unprovoked, brutal and bloody murder has been committed in our city, and by one of the most notorious rowdies in our midst, who was once an inmate of the Penitentiary, and has time and again been confined, for violation of the laws, in the City Prison and the County Jail. The victim of the Sanguinary assassin was a very quiet and amiable citizen.

POLITICAL. In the Sixth Assembly District, Brooklyn, the Association of Tax-payers have nominated for Assembly Mr. CHAUNCEY A. LAY, who, if he stands, will doubtless receive a respectable Democratic vote. In the Second Assembly District, Brooklyn, "the Workingmen's Protective Democratic Club" have nominated WM. SILKE McNAMARA for Assembly, as an independent Democrat.

A political canvass in Mexico is attended with several peculiarities that seem to distinguish it from the conduct of tile same business here. Tile candidates take the field in no metaphorical sense. Their devices are not merely abstract sentiments, or threadbare and thrown-away principles. Their assertions are eminently practical, so much so indeed,

GENTLEMEN: I have this moment received from the Committee, selected by you, information of my unanimous nomination as the candidate for Congressional District. It comes from the American Party, with which I have acted from the start, and to whose principles upon all questions of National and State policy, as they have been put forth by our authorized Conventions, I feel an abiding attachment.

Hope Chapel was crowded, last night, with quite ? select audience, attracted thither by a curious ananouncement that STEPHEN H. BRANCH would give a delineation of his recent convict-life on Blackwell's Island, where, in pursuance of the verdict of the Jury, he expiated his libel on Mayor TIEMANN and Governor SIMEON DRAPER.

BARCLAY-STREET.--The alarm of fire for the Eighth District, at 7:25 o'clock on Monday evening, was caused by a fire occurring in the store No. 96 Barclay-street, occupied by RENAUD ZEMEGNIO dealers in foreign and domestic fruits. The basement was occupied by STOCKFLETH ESPRIS, produce brokers. The loss of the former will amount to $1,000, said to be insured. The stock of the latter firm sustained damage to the amount of $300; insured.

The Vigo, which left Liverpool on the 13th inst., and the Persia, which left the same port on the 16th, are now about due. The former brings four days', and the latter a week's later European advices. Two lake steamers--the America and the Ontario--owned by HUGH TYLER, were chartered yesterday for the Paraguay Expedition, at $4,000 per month.

DUNCAN--YOUNG.--In this City, on Tuesday, Oct. 5, by the Rev. T. De Witt Talmadge, of Belleville, LIVINGSTON W. DUNCAN to JULIA MILLER YOUNG, daughter of Silas YOUNG, Esq., all of New-Jersey. BARTON--BARTON.--At Buffalo, on Thursday, Oct. 14, by the Rev. J. Hyatt Smith, JOHN BARTON, Esq., of San Francisco, Cal., to ISABELLA, youngest daughter of Phineas Barton, Esq., of New-York.

TINGLE.--In this City, on Sunday, Oct. 24, of consumption, MARY CHARLOTTE TINGLE, aged 24 years, 3 months and 24 days. Will be buried from her mother's house No. 125 East 13th-st., at 3 o'clock, this day. (Tuesday.) Friends are invited, without further notice. ANDERSON.--In this City, suddenly, WILLIAM ANDERSON, aged 35 years.

A legal correspondent, to whose communication we give place this morning, expresses himself strongly opposed to any radical change in the framework and machinery of our present judicial system. He thinks that the Court of Appeals and the Supreme Court have done as much work as could have been reasonably demanded of them, and done it as well;

The Westchester District absorbs a large share of political attention just at present. The point at issue secins to be whether Mr. HASKIN shall go back to Congress or not. The party which elected him two years ago is now the only one from which he has anything to fear. Its leaders have decreed his political extinction. Ile has been guilty of that deadliest of all political sins--independence.

PARTING ADVICE.--Governor J. W. DENVER, of Kansas, upon resigning his office, improves the occasion by offering some suggestions to the people of that Territory. Among other things he advises them not to be in haste about establishing a State Government. The Territory, he says, has no money, not a dollar--but, on the contrary, labors under a heavy debt, and is, therefore, in no condition to incur the expense of a State organization.

M. EUGENE RUOLLE, Professor of Natural History and Chemistry, at Laval, was found a few days back lying dead on the beach of Cesson. He had gone out with the intention of bathing in the open sea, but had not afterwards been heard of. Mr. KIMBALL CLEAVER, a prominent politician of the American Party in Permsylvania, died at Pottsville a few days since, aged 44.

The Coroner's Jury, impanneled to inquire into the charge preferred against JAMES STEVENS. of having poisoned SOPHIA STEVENS, his wife-after an adjournment of nearly a month to await the report of the chemical analysis of the body-reassembled at 10 A. M., yesterday, at Bellevue Hospital. About a dozen persons were present.

The Detective Police are still engaged in the investigation regarding the alleged murder at the gambling-house of Robert L. Willis, No. 581 Broadway. In the case of parties reported to be missing, the time of their disappearance and the circumstances connected therewith, have been carefully inquired into with a view to ascertain if any ground existed for connecting their disappearance with the alleged murder at Willis' establishment.

There has been very little of interest transpiring during the past week. The absorbing topic with us has been sudden increase of the police force of the city--one hundred and twenty special policemen having been sworn in. This sudden transition from one extreme to the other, from the apparent non-existence of a single policeman to the crowding of every store and thoroughtare with these gentlemanly

The "North American Telegraph Association," composed of the leading Companies now owning or working the main telegraph lines from Newfoundland to New-Orleans, and from Quebec to the western border of Missouri, closed a three-days' session in this city on Saturday. The Association was organized by the appointment of PETER COOPER, Esq., of this city, President; CHARLES A. MANN, Esq., of Utica, Vice President, and A. A. LOVETT, Esq., of this city, Secretary.

THE LOCKE TRIAL AT ROCHESTER.--In the Locke case at Rochester, a summary of which we gave a day or two ago, tile Jury have returned a verdict of manslaughter in the first degree. The Court charged explicitly that the crime of LOCKE did not come within tile first or second degrees of manslaughter: so that the case assumes a peculiar phase. Counsel for prisoner argued,

FLOUR continues dull and heavy. There was a disposition on the part of some holders to meet buyers at lower prices; sales 800 bbls., at $4 37 1/2 @ $4 62 1/2 for medium to choice Superfine Wisconsin, Michigan and Indiana; $5@$5 12 1/2 for good to choice extras $5 50 for double extras. WHEAT in fair demand, and market for Red Winter firm, for Spring dull and heavy; sales 60,000 bushels, at 67c.

When Mr. RICHARD BARRY, one of tile Commissioners of the Board of Education, committed the offence for which he was sentenced on Saturday in the Court of Sessions, the account of it published in our columns was extracted into the London papers, and appended thereto were editorial exclamations of surprise that we should have given such a story to the world without note or comment.

There is a perfect panic among the Anti-Doug lasites in the Administration. The president have out, but stands alone. The entire Cabinet is eith favorable to DOUGLAS or neutral. HUGH TYLER'S lake steamers America and Ontario chartered to-day for Paraguay at $4,000 a month, ar 300 feet long, 58 feet beam, and 1,200 tons burden. They cost $300,000 each.

The blue-book of the Select Committee of the House of Commons for considering the questions of European settlement in India has been published, but the inquiry not having been completed, the report contains no expression of opinion upon the subject. The evidence, however, of which an enormous amount has been taken,

The Commission dispatched by the Brazilian Government to observe the solar ecllpse, have returned to Rio. Their point of observation was paranagua, where they report they met with a cordial reception and unbounded hospitality. The following notes of the Expedition were furnished by scffor CANDIDO DK OLIVIDERA, the head of the corp, to the Rio Press:

Dehon and lady, John Tweddle, lady and 3 daughters, Mr. Izard and lady. Elliott, Mrs. Ellis, Chus, Green H. Ball, D. Harris, O. R. Gordon, John P. Porcher, Geo. Porcher, P. J. Joly,

By the arrival of the Cunard steamship Persia, we receive four days' later advices from Europe. Politically, the news is not important; and, in he absence of more interesting topics, the Paris and London journals are discussing the interminable Central American question. Both are unfavorable to the predominant position taken by the Unites States in Nicaragua.

Yesterday, the parties indicated by the late Grand Jury for defalcations committed in their official capacity. having been arrested by Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Ward, on bench-warrants issued by Recorder BARNARD, appeared at the Recorder's office with their counsel, Mr. JOHN GRAHAM. They waived an examination and proceeded to give bail.

A PLEASANT SPECTACLE.--A goodly number of the ex-officials of our City have been indicted by the Grand Jury. Their names will be found in the criminal record of this morning's TIMES. This is an edifying spectacle--one calculated to stimulate our municipal pride and make as deeply proud of our institutions.

Mr. Nathaniel Willis published in the Boston Recorder his experience of half a century in newspaper life. In 1796, he commenced an appreaticeship in the Boston Chronicle, in the same room in which his father had worked, and where Benjamin Franklin worked before him. In 1803 Mr. Willis started the Eastern Argus, in Maine, and in 1816 started the Recorder, a religious newspaper, in Boston,

THE MISSING MR. SULLIVAN.--ROBERT SULLIVAN, Esq., of Brooklyn, writes us concerning the rumor which was published yesterday on the authority of officer McDOUGAL, of the Detective Police, coupling his brother's name with the victim of the suspected murder in a Broadway gambling-house, that his brother left his residence (cornor of fayette and Cumberland avenues)

To Editors, Reporters, Telegraphers and Politicians: The Superintendents of the several lines of Telegraph in this State have, in the kindest manner, signified their willingness to hold all of their offices open on the night of the election, for the reception and transmission of returns for the Press, free of all expense except for the services of operators, which will be defrayed by the several editors served;

It would seem as though the excitement in regard to the Nicaragua transit had been transferred from the American to the European continent. London and Paris journals, lacking a more interesting question to discuss, are just now occupied with the Central American imbroglio, including the famous Belly contract and the special mission of Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELEY.

The Board of Aldermen met on Wednesday evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. The following communication was received from the Hudson River Railroad Company: PRESIDENT'S OFFICE, HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD. No. 68 WARREN-ST., NEW-YORK, Oct. 5, 1858.

SMITH.--In this City, on Saturday, Oct. 23, Mrs. CLOTILDA SMITH, widow of the late John J. Smith, in the 65h year of her age. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on Wednesday, Oct. 27, at 12 1/2 o'clock P.M., from her late residence, No. 12?? West 23d st. BUCEBEE.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, Oct, 25, after a lingering illness, ALANSON K. BUCEBEE.

A meeting, having for its object the establishment of a library and reading-room for the working girls and women of this City, was called, by advertisement and circular, at Dr. CHAPIN'S Church, last night, which it duly took plat. Nearly an hour before its commencement. the spacious edifice was so crowed that the aisles could afford no more standing room,

THIRD CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT.--Yesterday the Fifth Ward was in a ferment. A political row was deemed inevitable. The irreconcilable division among the Democrats of the District of which this Ward Forms a part, was thought to approach a bloody collision. The friends of SICKLES, the Tammany nominee, had called a Ward ratification meeting for last evening, at the Fifth Ward Hotel,

THE KANSAS GOLD REGION--THE TRUE STORY--A correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat, who has visited the Kansas gold region at Pike's Peak, for the purpose of investigating the actual condition of the locality, sends home a long and interesting account of his examination. The writer says positively that there is no gold at Pike's Peak. He remained at the diggings for five days, and did not find a trace of gold.

PEARL-STREET.--The alarm of fire for the Seventh District, at 6 1/2 o'clock last evening, was caused by the burning of a straw bed on the premises No. 293 Pearl-street, near Fulton-street, in the room occupied by Officer BENNETT, of the Second Precinct. THIRTEENTH-STREET AND EIGHT-AVENUE--At 8 1/4 o'clock last night, a fire was discovered in the stable at the corner of Eighth-avenue and Thirteenth-street. owned by Mr. WALLACE.

ONCE MORE.--We have repeatedly endeavored to call attention to the fact that the question, whether we shall have a Convention to revise the State Constitution, is to be decided one way or the other next Tuesday.

HUDSON COUNTY COURTS--CONVICTION OF PRIZE-FIGHTERS.--The criminal business before this Court-Judge OGDEN and Associate Judges FINE and CHARLES presiding--is progressing rapidly. The only trial of interest so far is that of HENRY HAZZARD and JOHN CLIFFORD, as principals, and JOHN HALL as second, in a prize-fight. The affair occurred some time since, in a field near Hudson City.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--DONIZETTI'S popular and pleasing Opera. "The Child of the Regiment," will be given to-night for the first time this season. PICCOLOMINI, FORMES and TAMARO (tenor, his first appearance) are in the cast. NIBLO'S SALOON.--An agreeable Concert was given here last evening, by Miss KATE DEAN, a debutante fresh from the academy of Signor BAGIOLI.

The investigation in this case was resumed before Justice CONNOLLY, at 3 P. M., yesterday, at the Tombs. Willis, the accused, was present with his counsel, Mr. Busteed, exhiorting no consciousness either of guilt or innocence. He seemed interested in the proceedings, but manifested no excitement.

JOHN VAN BUREN made a good speech at Tammany Hall on Monday night. He seldom makes a poor one. He is always witty and sometimes sensible. He has a capital faculty of making points that tell, not only with his immediate audience, but with everybody who reads his speeches.

THE HOME SQUADRON.--It is stated that in compliance with the urgent representations of Secretary CASS, a number of the national ships will be recalled from distant foreign service to strengthen the Home Squadron with special reference to our Mexican relations. This is a sensible measure. Our Government cannot devote too much attention to Mexico and Central America.

The Board of Governors of the Almshouse met on Tuesday, the President WASHINGTON SMITH, Esq., in the Chair. This being "requisition day" the usual demands were recited, and with some modification, allowed. Mr. Rufus Riply forwarded a communication, through the Warden, offering his resignation, unless continued at an increased salary, his demand being $800 per annum.

ARSENIC AND CANDY.--PATRICK McCormick, who has been stopping for several days past at the Bowery Hotel, Corner of Bowery and Sixth-street, died. Yesterday morning, quite suddenly. He told a physician before his death that he believed he had poisoned himself. He had purchased some arsenic to kill rats, and the paper getting loose in his pocket. It was mixed with some candies in the same pocket,

USE OF CAMELS FOR ARMY SERVICE.--Within the last three years, the Government has imported seventy-five camels for service on the Plains. The Washington Star says. "The Secretary of War is thoroughly satisfied of the great usefulness of these animals, and their superiority for army service in the wilds of the interior over both the horse and mule.

THE PUGILISTS.--MORRISSEY, the pugilist, and his companions, it appears, on their return from Buffalo, Saturday evening, according to Buffalo and Rochester papers, literally "traveled on their muscle." They absolutely took possession of the cars in which they were riding, refused to pay any fare and intimidated the conductors. One, when his fare was demanded, presented a pistol at the conductor.

DEPARTURE OF THE BRITISH STEAM-FRIGATE VALOROUS.--The British Steam-frigate Valorous, Capt. ALDHAM, is announced to leave this port to-day about noon, with the British Minister to Central America on board. She goes direct to San Juan del Norte de Nicaragua.

The Royal Mail steamship Persia. C. H. E. JUNKING, Esq., Commander, from Liverpool on the afternoon of Oct. 16, arrived at this port early yesterday morning. She brought 221 passengers. The Royal Mail screw-steamsain Vigo. P. McGUIGAN, Esq., Commander, from Liverpool Oct. 13 with 250 passengers, arrived two hours later.

The National Horse Fair. The proceedings of the Second Day on the Eclipse Course, Long Island, attracted an unusually large attendance. The cavalcade of houses of all classes entered for exhibition commenced at an early hour, and was an interesting feature in the day's proceedings. The an interesting feature in the day's proceedings. Th show of thoroughbred and trotting stock, stallions mares and foals, was remarkably time.

OUR CITY POST-OFFICE.--A telegram from Washington states that the choice of a Post-Office site for this City, has nearly "settled down between the buildings of APPLETON Co. and those of Messrs. BOWEN MCNAMEE." It is not impossible, but it is very unlikely, that this should be.

THE HON. JEFFERSON DAVIS.--What the South needs is a political quarantine. Her soundest men cannot visit the North with impunity. Even JEFFERSON DAVIS returns from his Summer rambles in Maine very badly infected. Ever since he made that Fourth of July speech on shipboard, his fire-coating associates have been concerned about him, and their alarm increased with his every public appearance in the Free States.

Baron Benjamin de Tascher de la Pagerie has just died, at the age of 61, near Orleans. The Baron served as a Royalist volunteer in 1815, and married the daughter of Count de Montalivet, Senator and Minister of the first Empire. The Tascher family was divided, in the middle of the fifteenth century, into two branches, that of Tascher de Pouvray, from which descended Baron de Tascher, and that of Tascher de la Pagerie.

The politicall cauldron continues to boil here with its accustomed fury, and the country continues settling lower and lower. Ii is a great mistake to think that we have yet come to the worst. Mail after mail has carried you bad news from his country, and you have repeatedly said that our condition was then the worst possible.

NICARAGUAN EMIGRANTS.--The Government of Nicaragua has taken active measures to meet the renewed invasion of fillibusters with which they are threatened by WALKER. Its Minister, M. YRISSARY, has published a notification to all who intend to emigrate thither, that passports will be required duly signed and countersigned by the representatives of Nicaragua here,-and that without such documents they will not be allowed to land.

THE SHOOTING CASE.--The name of the man shot at Brushville Monday night, was DAVID KING. The shot entered his side and back, but he is not thought to be in any immediate danger. The shooting was by a relative, and the cause, a long-standing family quarrel about property.

The fact that in the first attempt yet made to punish the frauds on the City Treasury the Grand Jury has been compelled to indict almost every official who at the time the offences were committed had anything whatever to do with the execution of the municipal works, speaks volumes for the depth and extent of the corruption.

The undersigned, members of the Finance Committee of the "American Industrial Association, convinced, after a through acquaintance with the practical working of the institution, that its objects and plans have everything to recommend them to the practical philanthropist, now desire to bring before the public the project of sending the unemployed poor to the West.

THE QUARANTINE TROUBLES.--APPLICATION FOR AN INJUNCTION AGAINST REBUILDING THE HOSPITALS.--The Castleton Board of Health has applied to the Supreme Court of Richmond County for an injunction to restrain the Commissioners of Emigration from rebuilding the hospitals and other Quarantine buildings on Staten Island.

We publish in full Gov. SEWARD'S speech recently delivered at Rochester. Though professedly discussing the pending State election, it is devoted exclusively to federal polities, and to the single topic of Slavery. It is evident, therefore, that the only importance of the coming election, in his view, grows out of its bearing upon national politics, and the contest between the Democratic and-Republican parties for control of the Federal Government.

The Hon. LEVI S. CHATFIELD will deliver the first of his series of lectures on Criminal Law, at the New-York University, this evening, at 7 1/2 o'clock. M. Rene de Genoude, youngest son of the former editor of the Gazette de France, has been appointed French Vice-Consul in China.

ELLIOT.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 25. MARY, wife of Dr. James W. Elliot, aged 40 years, 5 months and 1?? days. Her funeral will take place on Thursday, Oct. 23, at 1 o'clock, from St. Lake's Church, Hudson-st. JESSUP.--In this City, on Tuesday, Oct. 26, of apoplexy, Mrs. ABIGAL JESSUP, aged 52 years, 1 month and 24 days.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: At the ensuing election the places of half of the School Officers of the several Wards are to be supplied by new men. Six in each Ward, making 132 altogether. The position of a School Officer should be kept separate and aloof from party politics.

FELLOW CIT1ZENS: The unmistakeable outbreaks of zeal which occur all around me show that you are earnest men-and such a man am I. Let us, therefore, at least for a time, pass by all secondary and collateral questions, whether of a personal or of a general nature, and consider the main subject of the present canvass.

The Rev. HENRY BLERY delivered a lecture las evening in the Church of the Puritans, on the "Results of Emancipation in the West Indies," where he has been performing missionary labor for the last 27 years. After reading of the Scriptnces, and prayer by the Rev. Dr. CHEEVER, Mr. BLERY was introduced.

The principal has been settled in CANCEMI'S case that in a criminal trial no lawful conviction can take place by a jury consisting of less than twelve persons. This particular number has come down to us with the sanction of the common law, as has also the rule that unanimity among the jurors is essential to a verdict.

THE THIRD DISTRICT.--THE CASE OF MR. SICKLES.--The contest in tile Third Congressional District waxes warm. There seems to be a great multiplicity of candidates, without a corresponding variety of issues. Both political parties seem to have " split" upon some of the many hidden rocks which impede political navigation during the present low tide of principle. Mr. A. J. WILLIAMSON iS presented--by

There is no doubt but that Admiral KELLETT has instructions from the British Government to prevent ??illibustering expeditions into Central America. The indications are that the president will shortly issue a proclamation with a view to prevent the violation of the Neutrality Laws.

BOARD OF EDUCATION. - The Board of Education was in session from 5 o'clock to 10% last evening. The award of contract for mason-work, ($15,400,) and carpenter-work ($1,700) for a new school-house in Oliver-Street, by the Fourth Ward School Officers, with a request for an appropriation of $800 more for painting, occasioned considerable debate.

The following letter was written by Mr. WILLIAMSON in reply to the Committee who informed him of his nomination for Congress. It is a clear and explicit statement of his opinions, and leaves no doubt as to the political course which he will pursue if elected:

PENNSYLVANIA AND THE FOREIGN MISSIONS.-- Of our foreign missions the Keystone State has received the Hon's share. There are twenty-six in all, and Pennsylvania has six. She has Mr. DALLAS in England, Mr. CHANDLER in Naples, Mr. REED in China, Mr. BUCKALEW in Ecuador, Mr. CLAY at Lima, AND Mr J. GLANCY JONES about to go to Austria.

AN IMPORTANT CHANGE IN THE NAVY.--Ever since we had a Navy the midshipman has been regarded as an indispensable Institution on board our ships-of-war, and our old Commodores would as soon have thought of going to to sea without a binnacle, or a bobstay, as without the usual number of "young gentlemen."

At a late hour on Tuesday night a more horrible tragedy was enacted in this City than we have ever before had occasion to record. Francis A. Gouldy, aged 19 years, attempted, at his father's house, No. 217 West Thirtieth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, to murder his father, mother, two brothers and two servant girls, and terminated the terrific scene by effectually blowing out his own brains.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--DONIZETTI'S operate of the "Daughter of the Regimont" was produced here last evening with an entirely new cast. Mlle, PIOOSLOMINI was the Marte. HEER FORMES the Sulpitio, and Signor TAMARO the Tonio. The "house" attracted by this fine bill presented an extremely animated appearance, and was, in a pecuniary point of view, quite equal to the opening night of the season.

The St. Louis Democrat says of the overland route to California, that some of the stations are sixty-five miles apart; but most of them are from eight to ten miles. On the plains the corrals are either of logs or stone, and occupied, some by a dozen men and some by no more than four or five.

Isaac H. Sturgeon, Esq: DEAR SIR: I have received your note putting certain interrogatories to me in reference to the conversation held by Judge DOUGLAS and myself at his house last Winter. It has always been a principle with me to hold sacred every private conversation between any gentleman and myself and this will forbid my saying anything in answer to the questions you have asked.

We have been favored with the perusal of a letter just received from this gentleman, concerning whom so much anxiety is felt. Mr. EISFELD is still in Fayal, and the state of his health prohibits the possibility of hisreturn this Winter. The terrible shock occasioned by the catastrophe to the Austria terminated in an inflammation of the lungs, under which Mr. EISFELD is still suffering.

LAST DAY--THURSDAY. The proceedings, yesterday, commenced with a final examination of the stock entered for premiums, which occupied some time, and excited much interest, as all the candidates were paraded in front of the stand, and their names and pedigrees announced.

It is currently reported in political circles, that Mr. BUCHANAN, in his forthcoming message, will favor the passage, this Winter, of the Pacific Railroad bill. We are not yet enlightened as to the plan of construction to be favored by the Administration, but we can safely say that any plan which advocates the immediate and energetic commencement of this great national undertaking will be appreved and warmly acconded by all classes of the people.

THE INDIANA KIDNAPPING CASE.--The unlawful arrest of Captain HORACE BELL, a citizen of Indiana, at Albany in that State, by some five or six ruffians from Louisville, is one of those occurrences which excite to the highest pitch a spirit of animosity between Free and Slave States.

The United States Mail steamship St. Louis, JOHN MCGOWAN, Esq., Commanding, from Aspinwall, Oct. 19, with mails, treasure, and passengers, brought down from San Francisco, Oct 5, by the Golden Gate, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

We regret to hear of the decease of the Hon ALVAH HUN" whose connection with public affairs has amde him well known to the people of this State. He made him well known to the people of this State. He died, yesterday morning, at the residence of SOUTH C HAWLEY, Esq., after an illness of but few days. He was a native of Secknok,.

An important modification of WHEATSTONE'S storescope has just been communicated to the French Academy of Sciences by M. D'ALMEIDA. With the common instrument only one observer at a time can view the relief; M. D'ALMEIDA renders it visible to several at a time, and at a distance of several metres.

THE PARAGUAY EXPEDITION.--The Naval Department have chartered the steamers America and Counda for the Paraguay expedition. These steamers arrived here about a month ago from Qucbee. Er route for the Pacific, to take their place on the line to Fraser's River. and have been undergoing repairs at Green Point.

The State Election is close at hand. The preliminary canvass has been unusually animated, less, however, from any intrinsic importance in the issues of the contest than from their bearing upon the approaching Presidential contest of 1860.

PLEASURES OF MISERY.--The Charleston Mercury finds its chief enjoyment in being miserable. It talks of disunion with melancholy satisfaction. The late elections have by no means gone as it could have wished. Like the distressed Hibernian damsel, the South has been ruined times without number.

About 12 o'clock last night HEENAN, one of the the principals in the late prize-fight, entered the barroom of the Lafayette Hall in Broadway, which was crowded at the time. He had been there several times during the evening, apparently in quest of someone. He made his way towards the billiard-room,

The Panama Railroad Company's U. S. Mail steamship Columbus, Captain J. M. Dow, arrived at this port on the evening of the 6th inst. She brings dates from Guatemaia to Sept. 27, from Salvador to the 20th, from Realejo, Nicaragua, to Oct. 1, and from Costa Rica to the 3d. I am, as usual, indebted to Captain Dow for matters of interest that cannot be found in the newspapers of the different States.

General WALKER'S ambition appears to be to constitute himself the Sysiphus of our age, with the State of Nicaragua for his own private and particular boulder.

We have dates from Bogota only up to Sept. 12. There is not a word of interest from that quarter, save that tile Attorney-General has made an adverse plea to the last Court of Appeals against the claims of the Panama Railroad Company that their road was only finished this month, and that consequently their fortynine years' charter only commences now, instead of in March, 1855, when it was first open to traffic and travel.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. We have received a file of the Vera Cruz Progreso, to Oct. 3 We find in it a decree of the Constitutional Government, proroguing to the end of the year the permission to introduce foreign soap, rice, lard and corn, under the decree of the 5th of April last.

We are glad to see by the following letter that GOU?? KAMGLE, who has been ?? as the especial Administration candidate for congress in the Westchester District, repudiates what has been represented to be the settled policy of the President in regard to the admission of kansas.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your journal of this date, in commenting upon the speech of Senator SEWARD, lately delivered at Rochester, you say: "No party except the Abolitionist has ever asserted the right of the Federal Government to interfere with Slavery wherever it exists under the guaranty of State laws."

The Thirtieth-street Tragedy. The body of FRANCIS A. GOULDY was removed on Wednesday night at 8 o'clock to the premises of Mr. MERRITT, the undertaker, No. 149 Eighth-avenue. Yesterday morning it was taken to Greenwood Cemetery, only one carriage, containing an uncle of the deceased, the undertaker, and sexton of the Thirty fourth-street Methodist Church, being in attendance.

NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY.--The sixth annual Fair of the above-named organization, which has just been held at Richmond, in Virginia, turns out to be a failure. We believe this is the first of its anniversaries celebrated out of Washington City. Large preparations were made for visitors visitors did not come, and for a Show which proved discreditably meagre.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--The "Daughter of the Regiment" will be given to-night for the second time. The cast includes the names of PICCOLOMINT, F ORMES and TAMARO. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Mr. BOURCICAULT'S drama of ? Sixths the Fifth" was revived here last night under the title of the "Pope of Rome."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Mr. SEWARD was mistaken when he said that free labor had supplanted slave labor every where but Russia and Turkey. Russia is the only exception. The only slaves in turkey, are the female in males of the harems of some of the great men, and a few male domestic servants.

The United States Mail steamship St. Louis, from Aspinwall on the 19th, arrived yesterday, with two weeks' later intelligence from the Pacific coast. Her dates from San Francisco are to Oct. 5. The California news is unimportant. On the 27th ult., the laying of the Atlantic cable was celebrated with uncxampled pomp at San Francisco, and with duc honor at other points of the State.
The British Mail steamer Bogota arrived at this port on the 7th inst.

The interests of the two Governments--the Russian and American--are becoming daily more intimate. Our increasing settlements and trade in California and on the Pacific are bringing us into intercourse with Russian possessions on the Amoor River and the Asiatic coast, as well as with their possessions in America.

The Emperor Napoleon has presented to the Empress' mother, Mine. de Montijo, the splendid mansion in the Champs-Elysees, lately purchased of he Marquis de Lauristan. The property is valued at 4,000,000 frames. The Emperor also gives it million of francs as his contribution to the dowry of Mile. Paniega, the future Duchess of Malakoff; while her Majesty superintends the preparation of the bride's ??.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I observe, in your paper of Tuesday, an account from a correspondent at New-Haven, of an "Uproar at Yale," with a threat of certain other proceedings, which are to be "soon forthcoming." Every graduate of our American Colleges knows that many customs have existed in them from time immemorial, assuming the form of "practical jokes."

NEWELL--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 25, ?? MARY, wife of Wm. E. Newell. Relatives and friends are invited to attend her funeral this (Friday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock, at No. 71 West 47th st. Her remains will be taken to Boston for interment. McCOWAN.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct, 27, at the residence of Mrs. Lovell, 7th av., near ?? after a lingering illness, ISABELLA McCOWAN, in the 31st, year of her age.

The banquet and ball in aid of the Jews' Hospital in New-York at ?? Saloon last evening, was attended by at least 1,000 persons, who sat down at 7 o'clock to tables bountifully spread. BENJAMIN NATHAN, Esq., President of the Hospital presided at a table at one end of the room, at which also were seated Mayor THEMANN and other distinguished guests.

The sloop-of-war Vandalia, Captain SINCLAIR, arrived at Tahiti on the 10th ult., having on board Capt. J.N. KNOWLES, late master of the ship Wild Wave, which left San Francisco on the 9th of February last for Valparaiso. She was lost on the island of Jeno about 75 miles northwest of Pitcairn's, on the 5th of March, at 11 1/2 o'clock A.M.

The alarm for the Fifth District at 8:17 last night was caused by the discovery of a fire in the cooper-shop attached to JONES' brewery in Sixth-street, between Avenues B and C. The flames soon communicated to the stable in the basement of the brewery, in which there were twelve valuable cart horses. All effort to save the horses proved unavailing.

PREPAYMENT OF POSTAGE TO SPAIN OPTIONAL.--We are requested to state that notice has been given by the British Post-Office that the reduced rates of postage in the British mail between the United States and Spain, including Majorea, Minorea, and the Canary Islands, may now be paid in advance, or left to be paid on delivery, at the option of the sender.

DEDICATION OF A CHURCH AT BERGEN, N. J. The First Presbyterian Church of Bergen, N. J., was dedicated last evening. Dedicatory prayer by the Rev. S. D. BURCHARD, D. D., of this City: sermon by the Rev E. W. FRENCH, Pastor of the church; address by the Rev. Mr. PARKER, of Bergen Point.

General JEFFERSON DAVIS left here for Mississippi this morning. He returns charmed with his Northern tour, and with many of his ideas of Northern people changed. The Hon. JAMES CRAIG, of Mississippi, is here, and reports the Misouri Democracy in favor of the suscess of Senator DOUGLAS.

The names of the vessels which have been chartered by the Navy Department for service in the Paraguay expedition, after sifting out all unseaworthy crafts, are the Caledonia, Westernport and Atlanta, of the Cromwell line of steamers; the Southern Star, of Richmond, Va.; Metacomet, of New-Orleans ; the M. W. Chapin, of Philadelphia, and the Canada and America, owned by NELSON P. STEWART, of Michigan,
