WENMAN.--In this City, on Friday, Oct. 29, CATHARINE A. WENMAN, wife of the late Samuel P. Wenman, and daughter of John Conrey, deceased. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from St. George's Church, Stuyvesant-square, on Monday, Nov. I. at 2 o'clcok P. 31. without farther invitation. RICHARDS.--In this City on Friday morning, 0ct. 29,

Mr. THOMAS WINANS publishes in the Baltimore Sun the following letter in regard to the alleged discovery that the American contractors for the St. Petersburg and Moscow Railroad had cheated the Government by misrepresenting the length of the road. The whole story strikes us as preposterous. Mr. WINANS, after copying the paragraph, says:

Until the gold discoveries were made in New-Caledonia, a few months ago, there were few probably, ever among the best students of geography, who could tell you in what part of the world the point from which I date this letter was located. But already the gold-hunters have made it familiar as a household-word all along the Pacific coast of North America,
NEW-YORK-STATE.

We have a letter from Lieutenant TYlER, of tile United States Oregon Army, dated at Coeur Alue Mission, Washington Territory, Sept. 15, with fifteen days later news than any other account from there, The Spokan and Pelouse Indians had been defeated after two days fighting. The Spokan Chief was he1d by the United States forces, and 900 horses had been taken from the Pelouse tribe.

Thursday was de facto the last day of the Fair, yesterday being devoted to the preparation of the Judges' reports on the exhibitions of stock, for the several premiums to be awarded, and the sales by auction of racing and trotting stock. First, however, the adjourned double-team trot of the previous day had to be completed, which we now give in full.

THE POL?TICAL SORROWS OF MR. CARR.-Mr. THOMAS N. CARR, who was once more prominent as a Democratic politician than he is now, has published a letter addressed to our excellent Postmaster, Mr. FOWLER, assuring that gentleman that he is not a good Democrat, and does not deserve half the favors he receives at the hands of the Democratic Administration.

YELLOW FEVER IN NEW-ORLEANS--It seems to be an ascertained fact that the fever in New-Orleans would gradually disappear but for the constant arrivals of unacclimated persons, who will not been the official remonstrances of the authorities. The reports from the health Department show a decided diminution in the number of deaths of acclimated residents.

Among the passengers who leave for New-York in the steamer for Panama, to-day, is Captain J. M. KNOWLES, of the clipper-ship Wild Ware, which has been missing for several months, and long since given up as lost, with all on board. As the Captain's story is a very interesting one, I have obtained the particulars from him for your readers.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Previous to my recent engagement with Mr. HENNAN, I publicly announced that it would be my last fight. At its conclusion I proclaimed the same determination. Circumstances, seeming to me imperative, forced me into that contest. I considered myself, in my position, obliged to make the match, and fight it,

A NEW CITY HALL.--The Board of Supervisors is acting the part of the dog in the manger, with distinguished success. The Mayor last evening, for the fourth time, sent in the names of a Commission to proceed with the work, and for the fourth time the Board rejected it.

BURNING OF THE AUSTRIA-AN IMPORTANT DISCREPANCY.-Upon the arrival on this side the Atlantic of the survivors of the terrible catastrophe on board the Austria, it was represented that the officers did nothing whatever towards extinguishing the flames, or providing for the safety of the passengers.

THE LOCKE MURDER CASE AT ROCHESTER.--The verdiet in the case of MANLEY LOCKE, at Rochester, has already been announced as that of manslaughter in the first degree. The Court charged that the proof did not show the case as coming properly under that designation; but the Jury thought otherwise and returned the verdict, which is now made the plea for suing out a writ of error.

Motions and decisions. SUPREME COURT--SPECIAL TERM--Oct. 23. Before Judge Sutherland. The Harlem Railroad Steam Injunction Cast.--In the matter of the application of Daniel M. Whitney and wife for an injunction restraining the Mayor and Commonalty of New-York from repealing the ordinance prohibiting the use of steam on the Fourth-avenue, below Forty-second-street.

While the Cass-Yrissari treaty figures in a state of suspended animation upon the files of the State Department. Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELEY has steamed away to San Juan to conclude a convention of amity and mutual guarantees between Nicaragua and Great Britain. The treaty is almost identical in terms with the American.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The second performance of the "Daughter of the Regiment" was a decided improvement on the first. Mile. PICCOLOMINI was even more lively than usual, and excited the audience to frequent bursts of applause. Signor TAMARO was in better voice, and sang with artistic finish and neatness. FORMES, in his own peculiar way, was all that could be desired. Chorus and orchestra admirable.

THE KANSAS GOLD.--Accounts from the new gold region in Kansas differ widely. According to some correspondents, there is none of the precious metal except the few grains that may be washed out after hard labor, while the Kansas papers publish glowing accounts from the mines. The Lawrence Reprolican announces the arrival of members of a company,

The Committee on Life-Boats, consisting of ISAAC H. UPTON, of New-York ; WM. S. SMITH, of Philadelphia, and Captain JOHN WHITCOM, of the Revenue Service, who have been appointed by the Hon. HOWELL COBB, Secretary of the Treasury, to test the comparative advantages of Life and Surf Boats, give notice that they will be at Fire Island, on Long Island, on the 17th of November next, for the above-named purpose.

The scholarship and statesmanship of England have their National Association, as well as the resolvers of impossible equations and the finders of squandered asteroids. Tile Association for the Advancement of Social Science has just had its yearly session at Liverpool,

FOR CALIFORNIA.--Since the departure of the steamer Hermann for California, via Cape Horn, with a full load of passengers, the bark Vickery has sailed for the same destination with about one hundred passengers, male and female, and the elipper -ship Gray Feather?? now on the berth at No. 6, North River, to sail in a few days for the same destination.

TOWNSEND--SHEPARD.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct, 28, by the Rev. E. H. Chapin, Mr. WILLIAM E. TOWNSEND to Miss JENNIE SHEPARD, adopted daughter of S. W. Britton, all of New-York. TUBBS--TUTHILL.--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, Oct, 27, by the Rev. H. W. Beecher, assisted by the Rev. J. B. Hagany, Mr. SAM W. TUBIS to Miss R. EMMA TUTHILL, daughter of Saml. B. Tuthill, Esq., all of Brooklyn.

The Rev. Mr. Chiniquy, the celebrated Canadian priest, has become converted to Protestantism. On Sunday, the 22nd ult., he declared, in a public meeting in the Court--House at Kankakee, III., "that he separates himself from the Romish Church to follow the religion of the Bible." Lucille and Helen Weston, two actresses, have sued the Cincinnati Gazette for $10,000 damages, for saying that they were "the sisters of Charles Matthews' little arrangement, ridelicit Lizzie Weston Davenport."

The meeting of HORACE F. CLARK'S political friends on Thursday night was, what the Daily News very justly styled it, " a piebald affair." It was made up of men from all parties,-men who have never before been found acting together and who will probably never act together again. There were Republicans,

The screw-steamship Borussia, Captain TRAUTMANN, of the Hamburgh Line, from Southampton on Monday, the 18th ult., arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her intelligence is two days later. The steamship Niagara arrived at Liverpool on the morning of the 17th. The Queen of England was still at Balmoral.

TEHUANTEPEC ROUTE.--The opening of this route to travel and the mails, on Wednesday next, will be very quietly done; but the importance of the event cannot be sufficiently estimated. However, it is the part of prudent men not to perform an anticipatory arithmetical operation, which is vulgarly called counting one's chickens before they are hatched, and our people here are not apt to celebrate an eventere it shall have proved itself worthy of that honor.

WENMAN.--In this City, on Friday, Oct. 29, CATHARINE A. WENMAN, wife of the late Samuel P. Wenman, and daughter of John Conrey, deceased. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from St. George's Church. Stuyvvesant-square, on Monday, Nov. 1, at 2 o'clock P. M.. without further invitation.

The United States mail steamship Empire City, S. P. CRIFFIN, Esq., commanding, which left NewOrleans at noon of the 20th October, arrived at NewYork yesterday morning. The Empire City arrived at Havana at sunrise of the 26th, having been detained three days on the bar at the Southwest Pass. She left at 5 P. M. of the 26th, and has experienced strong southeasterly winds during the whole passage.

MYSTERIOUS DISCOVERY AT SEA--A most horrible and mysterious discovery of a wreck at sea in reported by Captain FARLEY of the ship William Singer, arrived yesterday from London. He says that on the 26th of September lat. 38 degree 44', lon. 45 degree 57' W., he discovered a wreck to the northward, which proved to be the bark May, flower of New-York with her bulwarks gone and nothing standing but the mizzen-mast.

THE THIRTIETH-STREET TRAGEDY.--The accounts as to the condition of the Gouldy family continue more favorable. Mr. GOULDY was conscious all day yesterday. He knows that he has been the victim of some violent assault, but has manifested no inquisitiveness in the matter. He occasionally asks for FRANK, but the conversation is directly turned by his friends to something else.

It will be remembered that representations were made by the captain of the French vessel Regina Cali, recently concerned in transporting negro emigrants from Africa to the French Colonies, implicating the authorities of the Colony of Liberia in the business. The President of the Colony, Mr. BENSON, has written the following letter to the Rev. Dr. PINNEY, Secretary of the Colonization Society, which denies in the most explicit manner every one of these allegations:

Messrs. WHITE CO. are defeated, and Gen. JEREZ has triumphed. A transit contract with Messrs. VANDYCKES WALLACF, Of Philadelphia, under the tithe of the Central American Transit Company, was executed to-day by Gen. JEREZ. It was signed, sealed and delivered in the presence of Secretairy CASS, who cordially approves of the same. It is understood that Commodore VANDERUILT is the secret cash partner.

Captain CLARKE and several other officers of the burnt boat Ben. Franklin, reached this city last evening. To the courtesy of the captain we are indebted for tile following particulars of the disaster: At 3 o'clock on Thursday morning, when the boat was approaching Ashton, about ninety miles below Vicksburg, smoke was discovered issuing from the hold, through the pump-holes, aft the boilers.

The Boston Traveller has a letter from its correspondent at Beirnt, dated Sept. 28, detailing the particulars of another outrage upon Christians in Asiatic Turkey. Miss CREA??Y, an English lady ofextreme benevolence had addicted herself to the instruction of native children at Jerusalem, where for several years her charities had made her generally esteemed.

The following is the letter of Lieut. TYLER. Published in the Hartford Times, the substance of which was telegraphed on Saturday. The Times says: "The following letter from Lieutenant ROBERT O. TYLER, of the Untied States Army, which was received in this city last evening, Oct .l 28, gives intelligence from the Oregon army, fifteen days later than heretofore received.

Advices from Porto Rico to the 9th ult., reach us by way of Havana. The prospect of the crops which had previously been gloomy, had improved under the beneficial effects of recent rains, Coffee promised finely. From Ponce we learn that the brig Consuele, which had left Santander with a cargo of flour, was wrecked three days out, at the Caja de Muerto.

Utah Correspondence of the St. Louis Republican. Since the year 1855 several efforts have been made to introduce the cultire of cotton in this Territory, the first at Fort Clara, on the Santa Clara River, upwards of 300 miles south of the Great Salt Lake City, but the result was not satisfactory. The present year, at the same place, more than twenty acres have been planted, one- half or two-thirds of which is a failure.

DONATI'S COMET SEEN THROUGH DONATI'S TELESCOPE.--The Florence correspondent of the Newark Daily says: "I saw the Comet a few evenings ago through the telescope of DONATI, its discoverer; but the effect was notgood. Signor DONATI estimates its period around the sun at about 30 years. 'Why, then,' I asked 'has it not been known and registered ?' 'Because,' he replied,

The number at the Fair ground to day was, if anything, greater than on yesterday. Tile fact that the lion. CALEB CUSHING was to speak, as announced on the first day, brought thousands to the scene who took no interest in the Fair. I have no doubt that many had deferred their departure from here until after the delivery of this address, so great seemed to be the fame of Gen. CUSHING among the Virginians,

Gen. CUSHING enjoys, and deserves, the reputation of great ability, learning, industry, and restless and rather unscrupulous political ambition. He has acted a conspicuous and influential part upon several scenes already, and will unquestionably play a still more prominent role in the political future of the country.

The canvass for members of Congress in our City Districts has been unusually animated. The intrinsic importance of the office combines with its party aspects to give the contest this character. It is perfectly well understood among professional politicians, -by which we mean those who seek office as a means of making money,-that tile office of Congressman affords abundant opportunities for accomplishing this object.

A correspondent writes to the Boston Herald from Hakodadi, Japan, under date of Aug. 18, giving interesting notices of the new treaty effected by Col. HARRIS with the Emporor. By this treaty, he says: "The port of Simoda, of no account to us, will be closed, and the beautiful harbor of Lanagua, only twelve miles from the city of Jedde, is to be opened to us for commerce,

THE CITY MORTALITY.--The health of the City is remarkably good. The deaths reported to the City Inspector last week numbered 348, which is less by 12 than the week preceding, and 53 less than for the corresponding week of last year. There is no epidemic in the City, and of contagious or infectious diseases less than usual.

We have files of Buenos Ayres journals extending to September 5. The Chambers were still in session. The House of Representatives had passed an act modifying the tariff in certain particulars, among others, reducing the duty upon wines and liquors 20 to 25 per cent. The estimates of the Treasury for the ensuing year were also approved.

To-morrow our citizens plunge into the excitements and responsibilities of a new election. No election is unimportant--though some may be less important than others. But at every election men are to be entrusted with power and authority,-with the power to make laws for the control of our persons and property, and the power to put them in execution.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Verdi's popular opera of the "Trovator" will be played here to-night, with PICCOLOMINI, D'ANGRI, STEFANI, FLORENZA and GASPARONI in the principal roles WALLACK'S THEATRE.--There is a prevalent impression that nothing in the world is easier than editing a paper, unless, indeed, it be writing a comedy.

SIR: On my arrival in England, three months since. I renewed the challenge to you personally which the New-Oleans Chess Club had given you some months previously. You immediately accepted, but demanded a month's delay in order to prepare yourself for the contest. Subsequently you proposed that the time should be postponed until after the Birmingham meeting, to which I assented.

THIRD CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT--MEETING OF THE FRIENDS OF GENERAL WALBRIDGE--SPEECH OF HON. FERNANDO WOOD--ATTACK UPON THE POLITICAL CAREER OF HON. D. E. SICKLES. A mass-meeting of the Democratic electors of the First Ward, for the purpose of responding to the nomination of General HIRAM WALBRIDGE for member of Congress from the Third Congressional District, was held, on Saturday evening, in Greenwich-street,

For the last twelve years improvements of a marked character have been in progress in the buildings ground and machinery of the United States Armory in Springfield. Within that time, the huge arsenal standing upon the brow of the hill has been built --a repository for more than 90,000 muskets in each of its three rooms; and a brick store-house, 400 feet lomn, has been constructed on the hill northward.

Our correspondence from Washington announces the final settlement of the controversy concerning the Isthmus route, by the grant of a charter to a new Company and the assured ratification of the Cass-Yrissari treaty. So many reports to the same effect have proved to be unfounded, that the public will regard this with something of suspicion.

We learn from Washington that a new transit contract has been executed between General JEREZ, the Nicaraguan Representative, and Messrs. VANDYCKES and WALLACE, of Philadelphia, under the title of the Central American Transit Company. The main points of the contract, which meets the approbation of our Government, are that the transit shall be opened within four months, and that there shall be a mail at least twice a month.

It is very well for the American whalers to vex every sea with their fisheries, but when they vex those who claim the ownership of the seas, a little wholesome hesitation may not be ill-placed. Of late years the whaling fleet has pushed its search into the Sea of Ochotsk, among the Aleutian Islands, through Behring's Strait, and along the Arctic shore of Siberia.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In yours of this date you speak of the Sabine going to sea without any midshipmen as an extraordinary circumstance. By reference to your files for tile last four years, you will find that at least threefourths of our "men-o'-war" during that period have carried no midshipmen, and at one time there were none afloat except in the practice-ship Preble.

WATER FOR BROOKLYN.--One half of the Ridgewood Reservoir, from which tile people of Brooklyn are to obtain their water, Is now ready for use. The aqueduct connecting tile pump-well with the sources of supply is also complete, and tile iron pipes through which the water is to be forced into the ReservoirThe pump-well and the lifting machinery will not be in order under several weeks yet.

A "few last words" will sum up the state of the political field here, just previous to the little of voting. This is virtually tile last day of the contest, Monday amounting to nothing, and on Tuesday we vote--such of us as shall not stay at home. The whole vote is variously estimated. Tile highest figures are 150,000, and the lowest 135,000;
PEASANT LIFE IN GERMANY, BY ANNA C. JOHNSON. New-York: CHARLES SCRIBNER Co., Broadway. We have already alluded, in a brief paragraph, to bliss JOHNSON'S capital book on German life;

EIGHTEEN PERSONS POISONED AT DINNER.--Mr, MUCHLIMANN, his wife, two children, two servant girls and twelve boarders, were poisoned, Wednesday while at dinner, by taking arsenic, which had been mixed with their food. Mr. MUCHLIMANN keeps a Public house on Second-street, between Almond and Poplar.

President BUCHANAN'S proclamation against WALKER and his new crusade upon Nicaragua will be read with general satisfaction,-and this feeling will be greatly increased by the indication of a purpose to enforce the principles and prohibitions which it embodies.

The prospects of a new English Dictionary has been put forth by the British Philological Society. About a year ago the Association proposed to complete the deficiencies of JOHNSON and RICHARDSON ; and, with that view, issued an invitation to scholars at large to furnish such omitted words as they might encounter in their reading.

AUSTIN.--In this City, on Sunday, Oct. 31, BENN, AUSTIN, aged 73 years. His Friends, and relatives of the family, also the members of the E. L. Snow Social Union No. 1, and the members of the Exempt Engine Company, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from the residence of his son John, No. 152d-st.. without further invitation.

WALKER'S NEW FILLIBUSTER SCHEME.--The New-Orleans Crescent has the following: "A vessel is to leave Mobile on the 10th of November, for the Central American paradise, and with the emigrants there collecting, the company in this city is forming and preparing to leave. Major ELLIS is forming the company here, and his office is at the Merchant's Hotel, where he will be pleased to receive the applications of all who desire to go along.

The following letter to the Galveston Civilian give's some interesting details of the long anticipated conflict between VIDAURRI and the Government forces under Gen. MIRAMON. It is written by a warm sympathizer with the Church Party: Some weeks ago I wrote you that it was impossible for the Northern faction in Mexico long to sustain themselves in opposition to a Government having its headquarters about the City of Mexico, and sustained by the Catholic clergy.

FERNANDO WOOD--THE NOBLE ARMY OF BOLTERS.--The Albany Atlas and Argus publishes, as a matter of interest, the following extract from a private letter written by ExMayor WOOD, on Thursday last: "Myself and friends have supported the Democratic State ticket from the start, and shall continue to do so to the end. It will receive the whole Democratic vote of the County, so far as my friends are concerned."

THE FEVER AT NEW-ORLEANS.--The appeal of the Howard Association of New-Orleans meets a ready response. Voluntary contributions are passing rapidly into its coffers. Two days after the publication of their appeal the sum of $970 was received. On the following day $1,487 were contributed. All classes lent their aid, and among the names of the contributors appeared merchants, planters, ladies at wateringplaces, grocers, confectioners and billiard saloon keepers.

Mr. JOHN McCLAVE reports the sale of one piece of ground on the south side of Fifty-first-street, about 150 feet cast of Ninth-avenue,--41 feet wide on front, 48 feet wide on rear, and 100 feel deep, with two-story frame building thereon, for $5,500. Also, the lease of a lot on tile north side of Twentyninth-street, about 270 feet west of Ninth-avenue, with three-story frame building, having 12 years to run, price $1,250.

SINGULAR CIRCUMSTANCE.--A very singular circumstance happened to a young lady a few nights since. The evening, or rather all the day previous, she had been complaining of a severe pain in the head and eyes, more particularly the latter. Judge of her astonishment and that of her friends to find, the morning following, that during the night she had become completely cross-eyed.

It has been frequently reported, of late, that Gen. HERRAN, the New-Granadian Minister at Washington, was disposed to take a reasonable view of our long-standing difficulties with his Government, and that they were on the eve of a final and satisfactory settlement.

No.49 EXCHANGE-PLACE, New-York, Oct. 28, 1858. STOCK EXCHANGE NOTICE--I have this day associated with me, as partner in my business, Mr. H.A. BOSTWICK, member of the Stock Exchange, and Mr. H. TRACY ARNOLD. The business will hereafter be conducted under the name and firm of SATTERLEE CO. GEORGE B.SATTERLEE.

The following is the decision of the Attorney General of the United States, in reference to titles to land warrants: "It is held that the heirs of a man are those persons who are entitled by the lex reisitus to take his inheritable real estate at the time of his death. His legatees are those to whom he has bequeathed his personal property by will.

THE HORACE BELL KIDNAPPING CASE--The Louisville Democrat of the 28th ul. says;--"The excitement still continues intense in this city in relation to the kidnapping of HORACE BELL. Every group of men have different rumors; now one thing, now another, but still all of them equally absurd. We mention a few: one was that the party who left Albany for Brandenburg had rescued BELL, and taken him back to New-Albany;

Presentation of a Banner to the Italian Domocratic Club. The Italian Democratic Club, a political organWallon, most of whose members reside in the Third Congressional District, were the recipients last night of a magnificent banner, at Gardner's Hotel, corner of Park-place and Broadway.

SPECIAL MEETING IN RELATION TO THE RUMORED INDICTMENTS. The Board of Aldermen held a special meeting at 1 o'clock yesterday, for the purpose of considering upon the course most proper to pursue in relation to the rumored indictments against the members of the Common Council.

The steamship Indian from Liverpool at 9 o'clock on the morning of the 20th ult., has passed this point on her way to Quebec. The R. M. steamship Niagara from Boston vid Halifax, arrived at Liverpool at 8 o'clock on the morning of the 17th. A poor English woman, Mrs. Houghton, attempted to commit suicide in New-Orleans a few days ago. Her late husband was a Free Mason, and since his death the fraternity in New-Orleans have allowed her $6 a week. Becoming discouraged, site tried to drown herself, but was rescued. The political contest, today, is likely to be unusually earnest and animated. Both parties strive for prestige rather than immediate power. Both look rather to the effect of the result upon the Presidential election of 1860, than to the offices which it will immediately place at their disposal.

" An English officer direct from Paraguay reports that LOPEZ is preparing effective modes of resistance and defence by building fortifications and obstructing the navigation of the river. He has placed chains and booms axis, and proposes sinking light vessels in the channel, in which event our expedition could not ascend. Several Heigian and Hungarlan officers are engaged in directing operations."

The position of Principal of the Philadelphia Central High School has been resigned by Professor John S. Hart. after an occupancy extending over 16 years. Dr. Hart was chosen upon the resignation of Dr. A. D. Bache, when the latter accepted the charge of the Coast Survey. His administration has been eminently successful.

From the Washington Star. General PAEZ arrived in town on Thursday evening, with Messrs. ROJAS, MUJICI and MANUEL PAEZ, the last the General's son. The President had signified his desire to shake hands with the renowned companion of the immortal BOLIVAR, before his departure for Venezuela. This leave-taking occurred yesterday, at noon, in a private and friendly manner.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The "Trovatore"--most popular of operas--was played here last evening with an important cast. The house was crowded in every part. Mlle. PICCOLONINI as Lconora is heard to very decided advantage. She sings better, more dramatically, and with greater accuracy of intonation, than in any other work that we have heard.

A PROFITABLE TRANSACTION--The Batavia Courier says: "We learn that during last year's financial crisis, Messrs, BROWN, BROTHERS Co., of London, shipped some twenty thousand bags of linseed, per order, to several mercantile firms of this city, but the consignees, in consequence of the state of business affairs and the low price of linseed at that time, were unable to respond to the drafts of the English firm in payment for the merchandise.

VALUE OF THE NEW FIRE-ARMS IN INDIAN WARFARE. - The value for Sharpe's rifle and the Minie ball in Indian warfare has been thoroughly demonstrated in the operations in Washington Territory . Col. WRIGHT's command is the first one that has encountered the Indians with these modern weapons.

THE RIOT AT PEORIA.--THE BANKING-HOUSE TROUBLE.--A telegram from Peoria gave some particulars of a recent riot in that place, more fully explained by the following from the Transcript: " The failure of the banking-house of N. B. CURTIS CO. created great excitement throughout the city.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT--Nov. 1. Before Judge Betts. SMNTENONS. Oliver Brown, convicted of stealing wearing apparel, sentenced to imprisonment 60 days. Fred. Francis, John Stevenson and Henry Girard, convicted of riot on board the ship Gem, were sentenced to pay a fine of $15, and the others $2 each.

We have two days' later news from Europe, by the arrival of the steamship Indian, at Quebec, from Liverpool, which port she left on tile 20th ult. There is nothing of special importance. The Confessional question was still agitating the public mind in England, and another demonstration against the innovation in the Church of England had taken place In London.

ALLEGED DISCOURTESY OF NEW-YORKERS TOWARDS ENGLISH OFFICERS.--The Albion Complains, with a good deal of feeling, of the lack of hospitality on the part of citizens of New-York towards the officers of the British steam frigate Valorous, which aided the Agamemnon in laying down the Atlantic Cable, and has now gone to take Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELEY to San Juan.

GENTLEMAN: I thank you for your polite invitation to preside at the proposed meeting of the National Men, on Monday evening next. It will not be in my power to attend it, and I must beg you to excuse me. Belonging to neither of the three parties which have candidates in the field. I have had no disposition to render myself responsible for any vote but my own at the coming election.

SUICIDE AT THE SMITHSONIAN HOUSE--JOHN STILLWELL JONES, who has been boarding for severa weeks past at the Smithsonian House, corner of Broadway and Houston-street, was found, yesterday, dead in his bed. An empty vial, which had contained landanum, was on a table in the room.

BUTTERFIELD'S OYNRLAND MAIL.--The enterprising gentleman who presides over the California Mail Route Company is reported to be making application at Washington for military protection against Indiana. Hitherto, during the few weeks the line has been in operation, the savages have caused little or no trouble;

This is an immense department of our country of primary significance and interest. Vaguely de nominated as the "Story or Rocky Mo??tains," occupying an inhospitable waste beyond the energies of social adventure, mankind has ??tofore heard the name with indifference, and all minute details with dogmatic aversion. To establish its title to esteem in the popular opinion of the world, the complete reverse of this, is my object.

THE NIAGARA RIVER--TELEGRAPHIC CABLE.--A submarine cable was laid across the Niagara River, near the foot of Albany-street, below the ice-breaker erected by the Buffalo Lake Huron Railway Company, on Saturday afternoon. The cable is about an inch and a half in diameter, and contains three conducting wires. It was wound on a large reel, which was placed in the stern of the tug Henry N. Martin, Captain COOK.

The New-York election, yesterday, gave the Democratic ticket In the City about nineteen thousand plurality over tile Republican, and twelve thousand majority over all. This on the Governor. The County ticket, not yet canvassed, has probably gone the sane way. For Congress, Mr. BRIGGS, Fusion, supersedes Mr. WARD in the seventh District, and Mr. CLARK, Anti-Lecomplon, is reflected in the Eighth District.

A COURTESAN MURDERED IN CINCINNATI--The Cincinnati papers have full particulars of another horrible murder, committed in that city on the evening of the 30th. The place of the murder was a house of ill-fame, on Lodge-street, kept by a woman named DAVIS; the victim, a courtesan, who went by the name of KATE BEAREAU; the murderer, CHARLES COOK; and the accessory. LIAM SEITER.

The partial returns from the interior, coupled with a diminished Democratic majority in the City, received to the hour of sending the first edition of THE TIMES to press, this morning, render it pretty certain that EDWIN D. MORGAN, the Republican candidate, is made Governor of New-York.

A Scotch journal says: "Another of the contemporaries of Burns has been gathered to his fathers. James Nell died recently at Hurlford, aged 90 years. The United States Mail steamship Fulton, J .A. WOTTON, Esq., Commander, from Southampton on the 20th ult., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The general traits of her news have been anticipated by the arrival of the Indian at Quebec. The Queen, Prince Consort, Princes and Princesses and Royal suite were to leave Edinburg on Wednesday morning . Oct. 20.

The advices from Europe by the Fulton furnish us with a piece of intelligence, which is, to say the least, extremely painful, and which will require a very lucid explanation before we shall be able to contemplate its disclosures without a feeling of national horror.

FROM THE NORTHWESTERN BOUNDARY.--A private letter has been received by a gentleman of this city from a member of the Boundary Commission, appointed to run and mark the boundary line between the United States Territory and the British Possessions, from the Pacific Coast to where the line is already established. It is dated at Camp, on the Bay of Simiahano, Sept. 15.

A desperate encounter with a burglar is noticed in the Rochester papers. The residence of Wm. C. Ely, at Clyde; N. Y., was entered on Sunday night by a burglar who was detected by Mr. Ely. A scuffle enused, in he course of which Mr. Ely received eleven wounds, some of which are dangerous. The robber escaped.

Divers circumstances, anti, among others, be bearing upon the Presidential contest of 1860, rendered the election of yesterday one of special interest. Our returns of the result, at the time of going to press with our first edition, are not as full as we could desire, hut enough is known to make it pretty certain that, in this State, the Republican ticket is elected.

We have files of the Vera Cruz Progreso to the 22d October, inclusive. On the subject of the rout of VIDA??, already reported, we find nothing later in them. The accounts of the Zuloaga Government are discredited. The report of the triumph of DEGOLLADO over CASANOVA, at Guadalajara, is fully confirmed; and he is stated to have a well-armed and equipped force of 5,000 men, and to be threatening Tulancingo.
By the arrival at this port, yesterday, of the London packet -ship Isaac Bell, Capt. EDWARD JOHNSON, we have received the particulars of a most fearful ship-wreck and loss of life.

By the Isabel, intelligence has been received of the circumstances attending the capture of the schooner Lydia Gibbs, formerly of this port, upon the west coast of Africa, for alleged Slave-trading. The schooner Lydia Gibbs, Captain THOMAS WATSON, sailed from Cuba on a trading voyage to the west coast of Africa, arriving at Wydah on the 22d of May last, where the British war-steamer Trident was lying.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The "Trovatore" was played here last night, for the second time and despite the weather, attracted a magnificent house. It was a good performance in every respect, Signor STEFANI distinguishing himself particularly, and we may add unexpectedly, after his recent indisposition.

Under the new Charter, the newly-elected District-Attorney, N. J. WATERBURY, Esq., enters immediately, we believe, upon the duties of his office, without waiting, as hitherto, for the 1st of January.
Mr. JOSEPH HARRISON, one of the American contractors for the Moscow and St. Petersburg Railroad, publishes in the Philadelphia News a response to the charge of fraud, circulated by the English Press.

POPULAR LECTURES.--The lecture season this year opens with even more than the usual amount and diversity of promise. We find lectures announced to take place at all possible points around us, and the names of the Professors, Reverends, and others who are to hold forth, stare us in the face from the walls in every corner of the City.

With a view to complete the theory of anaesthetics, M. OZANAM, some time ago, instituted a series of experiments on prussic or hydrocyanic acid in a gaseous state, the results of which he has now laid before the Academy of Sciences.

The rumor that President BUCHANAN refused to see Gen. JEREE when he called, prior to leaving this city, is untrue. The President and Cabinet treated him with the greatest courtesy at all times. My announcement of the new Transit contract has brought Mr. WHITE post haste to Washington.

From the Lawrence Republican. We are at last enablied to lay before our readers, direet and reliable news from the newly discovered gold fields of Western Kanas. Mr. H. F. BRITTAN arrived in this city last Sunday evening, direct from the mines, having just been twenty-eight days on the route.

FROM AUSTRALIA.--Advices from Melbourne, Australia, are to Aug. 16, vid London. There were 39 arrivals between the 15th of July and the 14th of August, including six American vessels; the clearances for the same time were 27, including eight American vessels. The leading articles of import had fallen off during July as compared with me same month last year from 33 to 50 per cent.

Further returns from the interior of the State confirm the view taken In the TIMES of yesterday, that Mr. MORGAN is elected Governor of this State by a majority of 20,000 over the Democratic candidate. In the Congressional delegation, LUTHER C. CARTER, Republican, is most probably elected from the First District.

The police of Philadelphia made a descent, on Monday night, upon a gambling den, at No. 927 Chesnut-street. A drover, who had been fleeced, made complaint to the Mayor. When the police entered, they found thirty persons around the bank, but nobody was arrested except the alleged proprietors, named Rose, Robbins and Fricker.

Diplomacy has its own little eccentricities. One of them is illustrated in another column of the TIMES, where is given the substance of dispatches from Commander DAHLGREN, in reference to the forced loans extorted from American traders at Tampico. That officer, in charge of the Plymouth, was sent to Vera Cruz, it will be remembered, to bring away Mr. FORSYTH.

THE INDICTED CITY OFFICIALS.--Our District-Attorney, Mr. BLUNT, who, we are happy to know, holds his office until the 1st of January next, declares his readiness to proceed immediately with the trial of the army of City officials whom the Grand Jury has just indicted.

The United States Mail Steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCK, commander, from New-Orleans via Havana, arrived yesterday afternoon, having left the latter port on the evening of the 30th ultimo. We have very little to chronicle from Havana. The Villanueva Theatre is in course of preparation for the Opera Troupe of MAX MARETZER, and will be ready for him on his arrival.

The Navy Department has received dispatches form Commander JOHN A. DAHLGREN, commander of the United States sloop Plymouth, giving the particulars of the visit of that vessel to Tampico, and of an interview with President JUAREZ at Vera Cruz. The date of the last letter is at Vera Cruz, Oct. 17.

A correspondent suggests that free competition, without restriction or legal regulations of any kind, is all that is needed to give us a good Public Cab system. If the whole business were left open, he says, the best and cheapest cabs only would be patronized, and the second-rate would be compelled to improve or fall into the rear.

A BLOW AT THE OLOGIES.--The Brooklyn Board of Education met last night, and did nothing worthy of note. Mr. ROBERT M. WHITING, Jr., a member, attempted to do something that would have made him famous if he had succeeded in carrying his resolution, which was a proposition to strike off from the list of text books authorized by the Board all books on astronomy, algebra, geometry, zoology and physiology.

According to telegraphic reports Senator DOUGLAS has achieved a signal victory in Illinois. He has a clear majority of three in the Senate, and of four certainly, and probably eight, in the House--so that his reelection to the United States Senate is considered certain. The Democratic State ticket is also said to have been elected.

He had been a resident of Washington some fifteen or twenty years,

The additional returns of the Election in this State received since our last issue do not materially change the character of tile result as then Indicated. It is believed, however, that HASKIN is defeated for Congress, though the result is still somewhat in doubt. We repeat our table of majorities for Governor throughout the State, with such additions and corrections as we have received from various sources, together with the latest telegraphic dispatches.

MEETING OF THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE.--The monthly meeting of the American Institute was held last evening at the rooms in Broadway. General WM. HALL presided. There were about forty persons present. Whatever may be the decision of the public in regard to the fiscal policy of the United States, there is one point, at least, on which we believe there will be found but little difference of opinion among commercial men. To the Editor of the New-York Times: The triumph of the Anti-Lecompton wing of the Democracy, under the able leadership of STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS, is complete; and this triumph should serve as a stepping-stone to the universal and efficient organization of the Douglas Democracy, upon a national basis, with a platform strong enough and broad enough to control the approaching Presidential election.

CRLEBRATION OF AN HISTORICAL EVENT.--The citizens of Western Pennsylvania area making arrangements to celebrate the centennial anniversary of the capture of Fort Duquesne, which will occur on the 25th Inst. Fort Duquesne stood upon the site of the present Pennsylvania Railroad depot at Pittsburg.

The routes to the upper Fraser River country already in use are several. Those heretofore most frequented are by river to Fort's Hope or Yale, and thence by long and tedious trails over mountains and through woods. These trails were opened years ago by the Hudson Bay Company for their own use in trading with the Indians of the Interior.

OUR MERCHANT GOVERNOR.--The election of Tuesday proved very conclusively that there is no such thing as a feeling of class-interest among our merchants as a body. It was the first time they ever had the opportunity of voting for one of their own members for so important an office as that of Governor of the State.

It is the geniality more than the genius which attracts in the works of DICKENS. They warm and widen our bosom, even if we have discovvered it thousand faults; for faults abound. DICKENS is neither a faithful, forcible painter, nor a consummate artist. He is a caricaturist: he is a mannerist. In general the incidents are impossible, the plot clumsily constructed, and the characters wooden.

The Thanksgiving proclamation of Gov. Morre of Alabama, is a remarkable production. It suggests the propriety, first, of keeping Thursday, Nov. 25 and secondly, of making the day a time of prayer for the preservation of the Union. The Mobile Register thinks the idea good, and comments upon thus: I'll will be observed that our worthy Governor here develops a new department for preserving the Union.

A LUCID THEORY OF THE COMET.--Professor BENJAMIN PEIRCE, of Harvard, explains the cosmetic phenomena as follows: "While planets and comets describe their orbits about the sun, and are attracted to the centre by a law of force, which varies inversely as the square of the distance from this centre--the particles of the tail move under the influence of a repulsion which follows the very same law as gravitation, of a decrease with distance.

UNITED STATES ARMY.--The present military force of the United States consists of nineteen regiments of the line, composed of the following corps: Five regiments of cavalry, four regiments of artillery, ten of infantry, making a grand aggregate of 13,000 rank and file of all arms. This little army covers an area of all Europe.

HUMAN DEGENERACY, AS EXPLAINED IN BOSTON.--A paper was read by the Rev. Mr. RICHARDSON, at the last meeting of the New-England Historic Genealogical Society in Boston, on the degeneracy of the age. The reverend gentleman assigned the following causes: There were two causes, he said, for the degeneracy of the human family. First, the institutions of government and religion, based on erroneous principles and managed by selfish ambition for power and fame.

It is perhaps unfortunate for the progress of virtue that the world has always measured the greatness of men less by the good than the harm that they have done. A great warrior appears once in a thousand years upon the earth, deluges its fields with the blood of millions of victims to his ambition, and the world calls him " Great."

The London Sunday Times announces the death of two famous chess-players. The first, Dr. ??, was one of the editors of the Berlin Sehachzeitung, which will deeply feel the void left by his early demise. The second is Herr MATSCHECKO, from Vicnna, known, years since as one of the best players and most esteemed members of the Vienna Chess Club. His strength in, and predilections for, the gambits were proverbial in that capital.

At a Convention of the Tobacco-Growers of the Connecticut Valley. held at Hartford. on Tuesday, Nov. 2, the following resolutions were adopted, and the growers in each town invited to choose a director to represent them at the Warehouse, on Tuesday, Nov. 17: 1. Resolved, That we consider the Tobacco Warehouse indispensable to the tobacco-growers, and feel it unwise to give it up.

The last Legislature of Minnesota, which was Democratic, passed an act that its successor should not assemble in two years, unless called together by Governor Sibley. The returns make it very evident that the Legislature is clearly Republican, which renders it exceedingly probable that Gov. Sibley will never call it together at all;

SHOT WITH WATER--A young German of Chicago, named SIMON--says the Press of that city--committed suicide on Saturday last in the following strange manner: He went into a shed, took a gun, and loading it with water, placed the muzzle in his mouth and fired, completely shattering his head. When found he was standing in the corner leaning on his gun.

Returns are in from all the counties in this State. The total Republican majorities foot up 125, 129 against Democratic majorities of 105, 539. Republican majority in the State, 18,640. The Boards of County Canvassers will meet to-morrow, and it is probable that the declaration of the official vote will increase the Republican majority.

A difficulty occurred on board the ship Golden State, of New-York, lying in the harbor of Penang, on the 10th of July last, which resulted in the homicide of Mr. WILLIAMS, the first officer, and the hanging of CARTER, one of the seamen, for his alleged murder. Two men, MAXWELL and BRUET, who were also convicted and sentenced to be hung, had their punishment commuted to transportation for life.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As I was coming down this morning in Madison avenue omnibus No. 947, a little girl (having some bundles, but not such as would incommode other passengers) hailed the omnibus. The driver not stopping, one of the passengers pulled the strap; the driver, however, did not stop till the strap was pulled a second time, the little girl then being out of distance.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Now that the election is over. I should like to officer a few suggestions. One of them perhaps is in a measure prophetical, and with that one I begin. The Republican Party has succeeded, but what will it gain? Nothing ! That is, nothing of its professed object The object of that Party, eve is Reform ! Please mark my words--There wil be no Reform!

THE CONGRESSIONAL GLOBE.--Mr. RIVES has issued the Prospects of his congressional globe for the coming session of Congress. To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is very hard to head off a slanderous report, no matter how originated. The mutiny on board the Regina Cali last April, reached America through the very unfair channel of French statements, and relying upon these as true, the Press in this country were very severe in their censure of Liberia, and vehemently called upon the friends of Colonization to examine into the matter.

GEORGIA. The annual Message of Governor BROWN, of Georgia, treats in voluminous detail, of all the affairs of the State. It opens with a general view of the Banking system. In December, 1857, the Legislature passed, without Executive Sanction, a bill providing against the forfeiture of Bank charters, in consequence of the suspension of specie payments.

WHITTEMORE.--In this City, on Monday evening, Nov. 8, ANN HARVEY, elded daughter of Timothy Whittemore. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her father, No. 14 West Washington-place, on Wednesday, at 3 P. M., without further notice.

PRIMARY ELECTION FIGHT IN THE FOURTEENTH WARD.--BLOODSHED.--The primary election for the choice of delegates to the Convention to nominate Ward and City officers, resulted, last night, in a serious fight in the Fourteenth Ward between the friends of the rival candidates for Councilman of the Fourth District.

A MUCH LAMENTED DEATH.--In all that makes admirable womanly preeminence, Mrs. MARY E. MONELL (Wife of JOHN J. MONELL, of Newburg, and daughter of the Hon. N. B. SMITH, of Woodbury, Conn.) was singularly distinguished. From her many natural gifts and her admirable use of them, her recent death (Oct. 22) has left a very unusual void in the community where she resided.

A BOLD FRAUD.--We stated a day or two since, that the State Department at Washington had reason to apprehend the existence of an attempted fraud originating in England and practical upon our citizens. We have been put in possession of a bit of evidence in relation to it by SAMUEL LAWRENCE, Esq., of our city.

MURDER IN PHILADELPHIA.--The Philadelphia Press of yesterday says: "In the Fifteenth Ward, yesterday morning, a fracas occurred between several Irishmen, at a small drinking house, which resulted in the death of a laborer named WM. McNEELIS. The locality of the occurrence was No. 1,708 Carlton-street, near Vine, between Seventeenth and Eighteenth.

General WALKER and J. L. WHITE are constant companions, and understand each other well. It is hinted that the passengers on the steamship Washington are fillibusters. WHITE says that as the Government here would not protect him, he found it necessary to protect himself. JEREZ offered him the Vandyke contract, but he refused it believing his present contract valid.

NIAGARA FALLS--THE ROAD TO TERMINATION POINT FALLEN AWAY.--We learn from the Hamilton Spectator that constant change, the law of nature, reigns, too, at Niagara. Every year, the outline of the wonderful cataract changes, as the mighty waters slowly but surely wear away their channel, carrying in their embrace now a small fragment, then a huge mass of rock, into the chasm below.

IMPORTANT TELEGRAPHIC MOVEMENT.--Mr. FREDERICK N. GISBORNE his brought to the notice of the merchants of Boston, a project for laying a Submarine Telegraph from Boston to Nova Scotia. He proposes to threw a wire across from Yarmouth, N. S., to Cape Aan, Mass.

THE CONGRESSMAN ELECT.--A paragraph in the Evening Post of yesterday, to the effect that Mr. HUMPHREY, Congressman elect from the Second District, was seriously ill, "in consequence of the excitement of the election," caused considerable apprehension among the friends of that gentleman. His house was besieged with anxious inquires, We are glad to state that the report is wholly unfounded.

DISTRUSSING OCCURRENCE AT APALACHICOLA.--We learn of a distressing occurrence at Apalachicola, on Saturday the 30th ult., during the brief stay of the steamship Calboun at that port, on her trip from Key West to this port. It appears that among the passengers in the Calboun were a Mrs. HAZARD, of Mobile, and three children.

Spurseon's admirers, says the Bury (England) Times, will be sorry to learn that the reverend gentleman has been attacked with a very painful disease-Inflammation of the kidneys--and that a few days ago his life was all but dispaired of. Ills medical advisers have given it as their opinion thai no danger now exists, but he is prohibited from preaching just yet.

ARREST FOR A MURDER COMMITTED IS 1856 -- The New-Haven Register, of Tuesday, says: "In August 1856, a man named TIMOTHY EGAN, was found on the railway track, near the New-Haven and New-London Freight Depot, in a dying condition, in consequence of severe cuts on the head. He remained senseless until his death, which took place within twenty-four hours.

AMERICAN ORIENTAL SOCIETY.--This Society, which has on its roll of members the first scholars in the country, held its semi-annual session in this City last week. Heretofore it has preferred the more literary atmosphere of Boston, but its energies were becoming so paralyzed that its managers found it necessary to make vigorous attempts for its resuscitation; and as one of the first steps toward that end, ?? the experiment of changing the place of meeting.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Who has not often wondered at the facility with which dram-shops are multiplied in our City? Patrick or Hans, known to be without a shilling of capital on Monday, is found on Tuesday behind the counter of a well-stocked bar, and with hundreds of dollars worth of "the stuff." How is the thing done?

THE BANK-NOTE ENGRAVERS.--Some few months ago a combination of all the bank-note engravers in the country was effected, ostensibly for the protection of the community against the fraudulent issue of spurious money. This coalition has, no doubt, effected a great deal of protection-for its members-since it has sesured the monopoly of all work at fixed rates.

STATISTICS OF FOREIGN COUNTRIES.--A blue book has just been published, being part five of a series of papers containing from official sources. The population of Portugal in 1851 is state 1 to have been [3.499.121, and the area 35,400 English square miles. The total population of Spain in 1857 (including the Balcarie Islands and the Canary Island) is calculated to have been 16,301 851.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Pacific, Atlantic, Middle and Western States of our Union must be united by a railway very soon. It is called for by commercial, military, financial, agricultural and high political considerations. We now possess 1,600 miles of pacific seacoast, with several harbors where all the ships of the world might ride at anchor in safety.

From the Chicago Tribune. A most singular case of dishonesty on a large scale, by an humble employe in a mercantile house, has just been brought to light in this city. We wish we could pronounce it singular in other respects than of more magnitude, but it is too true that no small list enrolls the number of employes who are suffered almost notoriously to carry on expensive living by robbing their employers.

Notwithstanding the repeated denials in certain quarters, it has now transpired officially that the Onseley Treaty with Nicaragua, as originally published in the TIMES, was correct to the very letter in all the provision given. It seems, however, that the mission of Sir WILLIAM is not confined exclusively to the matter of the Nicaragua Transit, but has reference also to the relinquishment of the sovereignty of Greytown and the Mosquito Coast to Nicaragua.

SOUTHERN RAILROAD CONVENTION--A Convention of Southern Railroad managers will be held at Chattanooga. Tennessee, on the 2nd instant. The principal business of the meeting will be the establishment of a thorough schedule of passenger and freight rates.

The fall term of the United States District Court in this, the Third, Judicial District of the Territory commenced on Monday last. The Grand and Petit Juries were, however, both adjourned until the first Monday in November next, as is understood in consequence of the absence of the United States District-Attorney for the Territory.

As is usually the case about election time, we hear a great deal on all sides about the necessity of reducing the taxes. The feeling which an English statesman once rather flippantly described as "an ignorant impatience of taxation," is strong upon our citizens at all times, but never more so than on the eye of a municipal election.

Prof. BACHE, Superintendent of the United States Coast Survey, by the authority of the Treasury Department, publishes in the November number of the American Journal of Science and Arts the results of his investigations into the change of the tidal currents in New-York Bay, near Sandy Hook. The subject is discussed under three divisions: First-- The normal currents in the main ship channel and its approaches.

The Evangelical Alliance commenced its session at Liverpool, on the evening of the 26th ult. The Rev. Dr. RAPPLES presided, and made the opening address, after which several other speeches were made, and finally the Rev. Dr. PATTEN, of this City, responded to the call of the Chairman. He said he was happy to receive from the lips of the Chairman such a very cordial invitation.

The saddest case of the kind that has conic to our knowledge this season says the Crescent of Oct. 23, is that of the Paulsackel family.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--Mr. HACKETT--an un-approachable comedian in a special and enjoyable line of business, commenced an engagement at this establishment on Monday evening. Last night SHAEESPEARE's comedy of the "Merry Wives of Windsor" was played, and Mr. HACKETT gave his celebrated impersonation of Falstaff.

From the London Saturday Review. Public decency is in a difficulty, and it seems than the remedy is worse than the disease. We appear to be in that condition which the Roman historian has described as the vice of a falling State---we can neither endure our vices not their cures.

We are in receipt of the Alta California made up to a late hour of the night of October 10, for the Butterfield Overland Mail. A portion of its news has already been anticipated by telegraph. We add other particulars of interest.

In New York, during the past week, domestic Wool has been in less request. With reduced stocks, however, prices have been well maintained. Foreign Wool has been actively sought after at strengthening rates. Sales have been reported of about 75,000 lbs, domestic ?? at from 35c. @50c.; 30,000 lbs. domestic pulled at 32c. @40c.; 450 bales unwashed Morocco and 175 bales Cordova on terms not disclosed.

The tax-payers of our City have been in council. They have held meetings and formed an association, upon the name of which they have not yet been able to decide, but whose object is "to oppose and prevent, if possible, all increase of taxation, to diminish its existing rate, and to check the prevailing corruptions of our Municipal Government."

BOARD OF COUNTY CANVASSERS.--The Board met at noon again yesterday, and was in session all the afternoon. Supervisor STEWART moved that the names of District Canvassers not making returns according to law, be sent to the District-Attorney for prosecution; he made the motion in view of the informalities in the returns from the Fourth Ward.

SIR: I have the honor to send you by this mail a parcel containing three packets of seeds, which may prove worth cultivation in the United States. The largest packet is probably of most importance. It is a species of Brassica, which is cultivated largely in the province of Chekiang for its oil, which is expressed from the seeds.

One of the First Ward Police, yesterday afternoon, shot a prisoner who has escaped from him. Three shots were fired, and the third was fatal. Great Public excitement followed the shooting---an excitement that seriously threatened for a time to culminate in the lynching of the officer.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In replying to C. E H. allow me first to ask you to relieve me from the soft impeachment--contained in your leading editorial of the 9th inst.--of being the "warm partisan of Mr. SEWARD" or of any other man. Knowing that patriotic motives will govern his vote, Vindex awaits the developments of the future, to determine in whose favor it shall be cast.

DIFFICULT TO PLEASE--The Board of Supervisors have rejected another nomination made by the Mayor for a City Hall Commissioner, and as his Honor has found it altogether impossible to find a man whom they will approve, we would suggest that, for the sake at completing the commission, so that the much-needed Hall may be built, the Mayor shall allow the fastidious Supervisors to nominate their own man.

The Board of Supervisors of Westchester resumed its sessions at White Plains yesterday morning, and sat until 4 o'clock, canvassed all the towns but seven, and adjourned to this morning at 10 o'clock. The result in seventeen towns is officially announced, and seven remain to be counted.

An impromptu festival, designed to give public expression to the good will with which the people of Essex County, N. J., have regarded the victories recently achieved by the opposition to the Administration throughout their State, was held last night in the City Hotel, Newark.

THE COLUMBIA COLLEGE LECTURES.--Columbia College has taken a step in advance of our collegiate institutions generally, in the establishment of a Post-Graduate University Course, in which lectures are given for students who desire to push their studies beyond the limits of the College course.

A vast deal of official jealousy and undignified squabbling would appear to be inseparable from the executive management of all great enterprises. Now, there are two railway companies at swords' points with each other. Again, a " split" in a board of directors is insinuated rather than announced in the newspapers.

A NEW EMPIRE--THE EMPIRE OF ANAM.--The Paris Monitor de d Armee publishes some interesting details relative to the Empire of Anam against n division of which a joint French and Spanish expedition is by this time in full operation. The Empire of Anam comprises three great and separate divisions--Cochin China, properly so paled, with Tsiampa, Campbocia and Tonkin. Cambodia and Tonkin are each governed by a vicerby.

STARVING JURIFS--However opinions may differ as to the expediency of the rule which requires unanimity in the Jury, either in civil or criminal trials, there surely can be none as to the absurdity of that which prohibits them from receiving any kind of refreshment while they are considering their verdict. They must agree or starve, not exactly to death, but up to a considerable amount of endurance of physical exhaustion.

Judge METCALF yesterday rendered his decision in the famous Staten Island arson case, and that opinion, as every one anticipated, is in favor of the defendants--RAY TOMPKINS and JOHN C. THOMPSON. The Judge enters at great length into the history of the destruction of the Quarantine buildings on the nights of the 1st and 2d of September last.

CHESS MOVEMENTS--MR. MORPHY.--From a letter dated Paris, Oct. 20, recently received by a gentleman in this City, from PAUL MORPHY, the young champion of American chess, we learn that it is the intention of Mr. MORPHY to meet ANDERSSEN and LANGE, who propose to play with him in Paris during the holidays, If he can possibly remain there so long.

MR. BILLINGS FOUND--Mr. J. B BILLINGS, of the Irving House, whose mysterious disappearance from his home on Tuesday last excited serious fears for his safety has been found. His friends in this City yesterday received notice from Mr. HENDRICKSON, Sheriff of Hempstead, L. L, that Mr. BILLINGS was in his custody.

The Board of Canvassers of Westchester County finished then their labors yesterday. The remaining seven towns were canvassed, and the defective returns from North castle Township were corrected. The full official vote elects JOHN B. HASKIN by a majority of thirteen. The following are the complete official returns: WESTCHESTER COUNTY.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a communication was received from the Mayor, stalling that he had received the resignation of Edward Cooper, of the office of Street Commissioner, and nominating Gusiavus W. Smith to fill the vacancy. The appointment was confirmed by the vote of all present.

The steamer Delta, from St. Thomas on the 24 and Bermuda on the 7th inst., arrived here to-day. Bermuda was visited with a terrific hurricane the 23d, 24th, 25th and 26th of October, and immense damage was done to property. The United States frigate Sabine put into Bermuda on the 31st ult., having been disabled in the hurricane on the 24th.

THE MORTARA CASE AGAIN.--The intelligence received by the Asia puts a new and even more revolving face on the Mortara affair. It is now stated, on the authority of the Paris Siecle, that the Jewish child was never really baptized according to the ritual of the Roman Catholic Church, but only "had Christian ['holy'] water thrown, by the nurse, upon its face when ill of a fever, at one year of age."

An interesting ceremony took place lately at the Church at Versailles, where Madame Goujon celebrated by a mass the 100th anniversary of her birthday. She was led to the church by her son, who is librarian and treasurer of the Mazarine Library, a post which he has filled since 1813, being now in his 75th year. A great number of the inhabitants of the town, headed by the Mayor, were present.

Yesterday was quite a gala day for the ?? circles of New-York society. The ladies and other respectabilities of the City gathered in great numbers in the afternoon to listen to Mr. EVERETT'S oration on WASHINGTON, and the more fashionable classes very nearly filled the opera house in the evening to hear the music of the distinguished prima donna who is carrying everything by storm.

A terrible tornado occurred in East Mississippi on the night of the 20th and 30th ult. It occurred about 4 o'clock, P.M., and passed through the western portion of Jasper County. In its course it struck the plantation of Josiah Moody, and the report that reaches us is that every house was swept completely away, and their fragments scattered far along the whirlwind's path, and with them almost the entire family swept into eternity.

MEMORIAL TO JUDGE JAY. -- A meeting of the Bench and Bar of Westchester County was held at Bedford on the 8th inst., Judge ROBERTSON presiding, to adopt suitable measures of respect to the memory of the late judge JAY. A series of resolutions was presented by Mr. WM. NELSON. and adopted.

The undersigned would respectfully inform the merchants and other residents on Broadway that they despair of ever receiving any further assistance from the City authorities beyond tile sum sufficient to clean our principal streets two days out of seven, and would therefore suggest to them a renewal of our united effort to obtain the means, by Increased subscriptions, to have It cleaned every nigt during the Winter.

French papers announce the death of M. Demand, the celebrated engraver of medals, at the age of 66. He was Chevalier of the Legion of Honor. He studied the art of engraving on precious stones under MM. Jouffroy and Coutillier, and at the age of 18 won the second prize from the French Institute for a paper, and afterwards was commissioned to execute a bronze figure of Jupiter.

LONG ISLAND BIBLE SOCIETY.--this vencrable Society held its forty-third anniversary at Newtown, on Thursday last. The exercises were of decided interest. It was stated that the work, undertaken some two years since, of supplying the entire Island with the Bible had been bearly completed, at the cost to the Society of about $3,700, of which $3,000 was furnished by GEORGE DOROLAS, Esq.

Washington Correspondence of the Charleston Mercury. A regretted chasm has been made in our social world by the departure (to Central America) of Sir GORE OUSELEY and his amiable and accomplished wife. A heavy family affliction--the sudden death of their eldest and only remaining son, which occurred a few months since--excited much sympathy in our community.

The President has not offered the Governorship of Kansas to Colonel MEDARY, nor has the latter applied for the appointment. The statements on this subject published in the papers are entirely without foundation. The statement that Secretary Conn had not yet written one line of his Annual Report is quite as ridiculous as many of the statements which daily appear, professing to give the Secretary's views on the tariff and other financial questions.

GERRIT SMITH has issued an address to the men who put him in nomination for Governor upon the results of their action. He says he made fifty three speeches in the campaign, averaging two hours and a half each, traveled four thousand miles, and spent two months' time. The meetings reduced rather than increased his vote, because they drew out a great many unpopular answers to question that were asked.

Tile official returns of the vote on the question of a Constitutional Convention in this State, are all in except three counties-New-York, Ulster, and Westchester. Fifty-seven counties give a vote of 102,418 for, and 136,516 against the Convention. Majority against, 34,098.

An extraordinary suit has been tried in Canada. At the recent woodstock assizes, Mr. Horseman, Reeve, and Messrs. Carr and Johns, Councillors far the Township of East Nisscuri, were each muleted in the sum of $1,000 damages for mismanaging the township affairs, and afterward refusing to give their attendance and yield up the books to a commission appointed by the Governor-General to investigate the matter.

Some eighteen months since a wealthy farmer of: Kentucky, living near Campbellsville, was murdered and robbed of between $5,000 and $6,000 by parties who entered his house at midnight, and accomplished the double deed while he was soundly sleeping in his bed.

The shooting of an escaping prisoner by Policeman CAIRNES is exciting a good deal of public attention. One portion of the community cry out that it was a deliberate murder--which is simply absurd, because there is no pretence or suspicion of malice. The Journal of Commerce, on the other hand, cries out "Sustain the Police" --advice which depends for its soundness very much on what the police may do.

Not being fanatics ourselves, we can speak flatteringly of the family without suspicion of self-glorification. We believe in fanatics. Without them our slow old would grow sleepy and come in at Christmas a week behind time. We pity their next neighbors, and would willingly pass the hat for the relief of the poor wives and hungry children,--for certainly the state of the world could not be maintained without them.

Count MONTALEMBERT always fills a place in the foreground of French politics, though what precise business he has there, has been these many years a vexatious enigma In 1848 he was understood to be so far a Bonapartist as to be admitted to the Corps Legislative.

There are thousands who, having every comfort of home, are utterly ignorant that hundreds are nightly obliged to sleep in the streets, in open stairways, old wagons, coal-boxes, market stalls, , in fact, anywhere out of public sight. They feel favored when sheltered only from wind and rain. They have no covering other than their day clothing, which is commonly scanty.

A BIT OF ADVICE.--The Tribune and the Herald ignore the existence of the Chinese treaty, in cause it was published in the columns of the TIMES. This is very had policy. The result of it that their readers consider them hopelessly beyond the times, and cease to look in their columns for the news of the day.

Arrival of the Philadelphia. The United States Mail Steamship Philadelphia McARANN, Commanding, left New-Orleans the 5th, and arrived at Havana the 8th inst., which port she left again on the same day, and arrived here early yesterday morning.

In the fall of 1831, a slender, well-featured and unobtrusive little woman, who had roamed alone over nearly all the earth, took New-York in her course on her fourth grand tour of observation. She was received with a cordial welcome, held levees after the manner of distinguised personages, and for the space of a month was the object of marked attentons and unbounded civilities.

MCCREADY.--In this City, on Friday, Nov. 13. GEO W. MCCREADY, an old inhabitant of this City, in the 81st year of his age. Also, on Sunday, Nov. 14. his son, GEO. W. MCCREADY, Jr., in the 43d year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend their funeral, from, their former residence. No. 73 Spring-st., on Wednesday morning, at 10 o'clock.

DESTRUCTION OF THE BREMEN STEAMSHIP HUDSON AT BREMERHAVEN--NO LIVES LOST. Information was received at LLOYDS, by telegraph from Bremehaven on the 4th inst., of the burning of the North German Lloyds Steamship company's steamer Hudson on the 2d inst., and stating the loss to be 70,000. The agents in this City have received no notice of the disaster.

Congress meets three weeks from yesterday. Its session will end on the 4th of March. If the whole interval is not spent in debating the Slavery question, adjusting platforms and preparing for the Presidential contest of 1860, it will not be the fault of politicians and party leaders.

TWO MURDERS IN MISSOURI.--The St. Louis Republican has the particulars of two murders lately committed in Missouri. One occurred in Fulton, Calloway County. A white man, name not given, and a negro, were imprisoned on a charge of enticing slaves away. They were kept in jail at Fulton--the negro to be detained until he could be sold, and his white confederate to await trial.

In some of the most salient points of the policy of Mr. BRIGHT, as contained in his last speech, he is not unlike a certain class of philosophers in this country. All his efforts tend to inculcate the doctrine that an extreme policy is always dangerous.

ARREST OF A BANK ROBBER.--The Buffalo on Friday, says: "It will be remembered that BROWN KEEP'S Bank will robbed about two months ago of some $12,000 in bills on various banks of this country and Canada. The robbery was effected, evidently, by some person or persons acquainted with the Bank, but so adroitly was it performed that the police were completely baffled. ed.

CLOSE OF THE INDIAN WAR IN WASHINGTON TERRITORY.--The War Department received on Saturday important dispatches from the Pacific, announcing the conclusion of the campaign against the Indians in Washington Territory. General CLARKE sums up by saying all the Indians engaged in hostilities have been beaten, and all have been driven to terms.

ANOTHER GANG OF COUNTFRFEITERS BROKEN UP.--The Cincinau papers of Wednesday state that an extensive organization of Coin counterfeiters has been broken up in Lawrence County, Ohio. The police officers found at the houses of JOSEPH KELLY and Wm. H. SHERPHSHIP, near Ironton, a large lot of counterfeiters' machinery, tools and acids--a full and complete set, and all that was necessary to manufacture bogus coin--concelaed in different parts of the dwellings.

A decision, important to Railroad travelers, has just been given in Canada by Chief Justice Robertson, several of the victims of the Desjardins bridge accident were traveling at the time with free passes. It has been held in the United States Courts that the acceptance o a free pass by a traveler did not exonerate the Railway Company from their obligation to carry him safe to his destination.

THE TEHUANTEPEC ROUTE.--The bark Rapid, Capt. MAROHANT, arrived to-day from Vera Cruz. She is the vessel that took from this port in July last, the 200 workmen for the Tehuantepec Road. Capt. M. reports that they all arrived in good health, and that in his opinion Mr. MURPHY, the overseer, understands and is well calculated for that business. He embarked all his men up the river.

GENERAL WALKER'S NEW PROJECT.--The Houston (Texas) Telegraph of the 3d says: " We have before us a letter from WM. WALKER, to a friend in this neighborhood in which he announces that a vessel will leave Mobile on the 10th of November for Nicaragua. This vessel is capable of taking 500 passengers. She is comfortably fitted up, and persons desiring to emigrate to the land of promise and adventure will find things 'all right' now.

Our clipper-ships, marine engines, machine reapers and various other of the more massive productions of inventive and mechanical genius, long since won enduring fame for American inventors and artisans;--and the sewing-machine,--already equally familiar and indispensable to every family--presents marvellous evidence of the triumph of American genius in the more delicate departments of labor-saving apparatus.

From the Sacramento Ber. The mountains of California have become proverbial for the salubrity of their climate. Even in the Winters of '49, '50 and '51, when the comforts of life were seldom met with and the necessaries were no easily obtained, the destruction of human life by discases, engendered, was astonishingly small, and sickness was comparatively unknown in those regions.

THE LABORS OF SENATOR DOUGLAS.--A Western correspondent sends us a detailed statistical account of the labors of Senator DOUGLAS in the recent canvass of Illinois, from which it appears that they were almost equal to the labors of Hercules. It seems that he has addressed his constituents in 57 counties.

HOW OUR BALLOT-BOXES ARE MANAGED.---In the report which we published yesterday of the proceedings of the Board of Canvassers, one of the Inspectors stated that he signed the returns of the votes given in the First Ward, although he knew those returns to be crroncons;---and that he did so under the direct intimidation and threats of rough, noisy crowd, who filled the poll-room.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES AND THE HERALD.--The New-York Herald is far behind the NEW-YORK TIMES in giving its readers the latest domestic and foreign intelligence. Besides, the news furnished by the TIMES is generally much more reliable.

FATAL OYSTER WAR.--A few days ago a young man named WASHINGTON MISTER, from Deal's Island, on the Eastern Shore, with a colored man, went into Fishing Bay, lying at the southwest end of Dorchester County, to dredge for oysters. The people on shore warned them off, under the threat of enforcing the law against them. They refused to obey the warning, and at once boats were prepared and a strong party started in pursuit.

RELICS FROM THE FRANKLIN HOMESTEAD.--The Franklin homestead in Hanover, corner of Union-street, is in process of demolition. As the residence of BENJAMIN FRANKLIN and his ancestors, it has at ways been a place of interest to our citizens, and a general desire has been expressed to preserve as ?? appropriate portions of the old building.
