BOARD OF COUNCILMEN.--The Board of Councilmen met last evening, C. H. HASWELL in the chair. Several papers were received from the Aldermen and laid over under the rule. The President submitted an act, which was laid over, to prevent the discharge of ordinance south of One-Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, except on the Battery and in the Central Park, under a penalty of $10 for each offense.

From the Cincinnati Gazette, 15th. On Thursday morning, the stern-whell steamer Fulton City, Capt. DAVID BRICKELL, from Pittsburg for St. Louis, sank in coming through Buffinton's. The morning was very foggy and hazy, and the boat got too close to the island, when the pilot, THOMAS VARNEY, gave the wheel out, when the stern swung around and struck a stump, which cut her down so that she sank in a few minutes.

That England is dissatisfied with the net result of its negotiations on the Pei-ho is no matter of surprise. Whatever lord ELGIN gained there he gained for mankind, while the losses and costs, which thrice the nominal indemnity exacted would indifferently repay, have to be drawn from the private treasury of England alone.

From the Daily Advertiser of yesterday. JAMES McMAHON, who was convicted last week of murder, was sentenced at 9 o'clock this morning, by Judge HAINES, to be executed in the County Prison yard on Wednesday, Jan. 12. McMAHON was brought into Court and stationed within the bar, just back of the lawyers' tables, and immediately facing the Bench.

I have just returned from the bedside of the Hon. JAMES L. HARRIS ; probably the next letter you will receive must announce his death. You remember that during the last session of Congress he was scarcely able to perform the duties of his position on account of ill-health. He returned home and partially recovered, but was again prostrated by the accidental use of a poisonous drug.

HONIWELL--In this City, on Monday, Nov. 15, at 5 o'clock A.M., CAROLINE VALENTINE, aged 10 months and 10 days, and at 9 o'clock P.M., same day, ELIZA MARSHALL, aged 4 years and 5 months, youngest daughters of William and Deborah A. Honiwell. Funeral service this day. (Wednesday,) at 1 o'clock, at their parents residence, No. 189 West 22d-st. Friends and relatives are invited to attend, without further notice.

The Altoona, Penn., Tribune notices a remarkable cure of deafness, by electricity. A citizen of that place suddenly lost his hearing, and after every means known to the medical fraternity had been exhausted, electricity was resorted to. An instrument was produced, and placing the end of piece of wire in each ear, the electric current was let on lightly at first, and gradually increased.

THE HON. JOSIAH QUINCY, JR., AT THE MERCANTILE LIBRARY--The annual course of lecturers before the Brooklyn Mercantile Library was opened last evening by the Hon. JOSIAH QUINCY, Jr., of Boston, under most favorable auspices. Every seat was filled long before the lecturer appeared, though he was characteristically prompt; and when he entered the hall, he was warmly received by the audience.

Winter has come upon as more than a fortnight earlier than it did in 1857. Then we had no really severe weather until the last days of November, and that did not continue, and was the only cold spell we had. For a week past we have had bitter days, with strenuous attempts at snow-storms on the 12th and 13th.

We left Simoda ou the 5th inst., bound to this place, via Nagasaki, with the Treaty. The second day out we encountered quite a severe gale, which handled even us quite roughly, and caused us to wish all smaller vessels safety under shelter. Messrs. EDITORS: Mr. TOWNSEND HARRIS, U.S. Consul General to Japan, has just concluded a most important treaty. Instead of continuing our summer's cruise, therefore, direct to Hakodadi, we return first to Shanghae for the purpose of putting a bearer of dispatches on board of the Overland Mail steamer. I suppose the treaty will reach Washington about the time this letter does Philadelphia.

THE POLICE ARRESTS FOR THE YEAR.--The statistical table which we published yesterday, headed "A Year's Crime," was, more properly, an account of "a year's arrests by the Police." That report shows a total number of 60,865 individuals who passed through the custody of the Police during the twelve months.

I mentioned to you last week that the Mormons are nowhere plowing with a view to sow Fall wheat. We print in another place this morning an ample and highly interesting extract from the recent opinion of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania against the county of Alleghany. This decision concludes with a peremptory mandamus directing the County Commissioners to levy and collect a special tax upon the people to pay the interest upon certain County Bonds issued to a Railway, which Bonds these Commissioners had attempted to repudiate.

Among the many striking proofs of the progress of the Greek race in all that contributes to make a nation truly happy, none appears to us more encouraging than the increased attention paid to literature and education, Already the city of Athens boasts of some fifteen or more political journals, besides three or four literary periodicals.

The practice-ship Plymouth, arrived at Mobile on Saturday last, from Vera Cruz, having on board Mr. FORSITH, the United States Minister to Mexico, She has been ordered to this City, and the sleep-of-war St Louis will be dispatched to supply her place in the Gulf squadron. Commissioner OGDEN will be ordered to the St. Louis.

THE EXULTATION OF MR. SICKLES.--The Hon. DAN. E. SICKLES is evidently clated with his recent victory. He lavishes compliments on every side, with a reckless disregard of consequences and a hilarious freedom of movement, which indicate the most sublime contentment with his own position.

In Philadelphia a girl, only 13 years old, employed on the place of Mr. John Scott, of Northampton township, backs County, has confessed to Chief Detective Blackburn that she set fire to the barn of Mr. Scott, on the 18th of October, by which it was destroyed, together with a large crop of hay and grain.

A GHASTLY POLICY.--The Hon. R. B. RHETT, two years ago, wrote a very long letter to Governor ADAMS, of South Carolina, filled with a rehearsal of the wrongs of the Federal Government towards the South, and saying that, in his humble judgment, "all ture statesmanship in the South consists in forming combinations and shaping events so as to bring about, as speedily as possible, a dissolution of the present Union, and a Southern Confederacy."

From the Philadelphia Public Ledger. We arrived from Nagasaki on the 25th alt., after a passage of 67 hours. The distance is over 000 miles. We found the Mississippi at anchor in the inner harbor and came to near her. hoping for a few days of quiet and long walks back into the country.

On reaching an eminence, we had a sight of the residence of Lady HESTER STANHOPE, standing on a conical hill near the village of Djouni. The place is called Marilius, having formerly been a convent, and was presented to Lady H. by the Pacha of Sidon.

The message of Governor BRAGG, of North Carolina, shows that the debt of the State is $6,879,505. A large portion of this debt has been incurred by loans and subscriptions to State works. A considerable portion falls due next year. The Governor suggests the expediency of making permanent provision for relief.

THE LATE POST-OFFICE ROBBERY--AN IMPORTANT ARREST.--In the TIMES of the 19th inst. we published particulars of a Post-Office robbery, committed by HENRY REED, one of the clarks in the establishment. From confessions made by the prisoner it appeared that his depredations had been carried on for some considerable time, and on a very extensive scale.

GAZZANIGA, a fine delicately-tinted picture of the heroine. In the best scenes of the opera Mine.

THE LATE CRUEL HOAX. The writer of the note published in the Sun of the 15th, and the Herald of the 16th, announcing that bread and meat would be distributed to the poor on Thanksgiving Day, at Union-square, was a young lad, who committed the act in boyish thoughtiessness, not realizing, until he witnessed its consequences, its cruel impropriety.

THE GENERAL ADMIRAL-This large Russian frigate has attracted many persons to inspect he mammoth yet graceful proportions since she has been on the Balance Bock receiving her copper, and great admiration was expressed not alone for the frigate and her American architects, but also for the massive floating dock which hits her with such slight apparent effort out of the water-.

The Pork trade was decidedly buoyant again yesterday, and sellers succeeded in realizing a further advance, with sales of 6,000 head at $6 40@$6 571/2, closing firm at $6 50@$6 go for good lots, averaging from 200 to 215 lbs. The President of the United States is virtually an unarmed Autocrat. For the four years of his power he sways the destinies of the country to a very great extent by the exercise of his individual will. Restrained by the barriers of the Constitution from infringement upon the rights of individuals, he controls their duties with an almost irresponsible authority.

GOV. KING has just pardoned a man named JACKSON, who was sentenced, in March, 1857, to the State Prison for ten years, for a brutal outrage upon an emigrant girl. This pardon comes just in time to assure the four hell hounds who were guilty of a similar outrage last week, of the clemency that probably awaits them, if by some unaccountable accident they should happen to be convicted.

THE OPERA WAR. The great opera campaign to be drawing to a close. Each party as shot in our columns this morning, but the diminished noise of the discharge indicates a retreat. Neither party has probably inflicted any serious damage upon the other.

On the evening of the 14th inst., a force of 7,500 federalists, under General BLANCO, suddenly and unexpectedly made their appearance in Taczoaya, a village in this valley, five miles distant from this capital. So suddenly did they come upon us that for an hour after their arrival in that village the populace of this capital were ignorant of the fact. But when the last became known, the wildest confusion prevailed.

It is not easy to decide whether our Clemency in the type presented by Governor KING, or our Justice in the form of Judge RUSSELL'S decisions, does most of make those sin who never sinned before, and those who once have sinned still sin the more.

DEATR OF SIR WILLIAM REID, THE METEOROLOSIST--English papers announce the death of Major-Gen. Sir WILLIAM REID, author of valuable works on the Law of Storms.

BRODHEAD--CASSEY.--In this City, on Thursday, Nov. 11. by the Rev. A. P. Van Neat, FRANKLIN R. BRODHEAD, Port Jervis, N. Y., to ELIZA A. CARKEY, of this City. CARMEN--DAVENPORT.--In Brooklyn, on Monday, Nov. 22, in the Third Presbyterian Church, by their pastor, the Rev. Mr. Kerr, Mr. J. BLOOMFIELD CARMAN to Miss ANN ELIZABETH, daughter of Mr. J. T. Davenport.
Sale of Real Estate Nov. 19, by WILLIAM H. FRANKLIN, one lot on the east side of Second-avenue street south of Eighty-fourth-street, 25 feet 6 inches by 100 feet; purchaser, HENRY BRUNER--$1,200.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me respectfully to ask, through your columns, the advocates of Congregational Singing, If it would not aid their cause if the conductors should favor the movement of the audiences, they sing for, a little more.

A MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE.--Our Kansas correspondent informs us that the Free-State party in that Territory has suddenly disappeared. A Convention recently held to take steps for admission as a Free State, and to arrange for future political movements, was very thinly attended and finally adjourned without doing anything at all.

The city of Mobile must be at this moment a particularly agreeable residence. It is in a manner occupied by the advanced guard of the grand army of liberation intended to throw open the fertilo dominions of Nicaragua to the expanding energies of the Anglo--Saxon race, and to carry those great institutions, the bowie-knife, the quid, the julep and the game of brag into the hitherto lifeless plains of the American Isthmus.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : DEAR SIR : Insured you there is one class of men that offer from the general description you give in your article of yesterday, "Our City Affairs," of the disposition of our citizens to submit to the present manner in which our City is governed. That class of men are not "comment with things as they are," they do more than "talk in ommbuscs;"

The Territorially Delegate Convention called by the Central Committee to assemble at this place on the 10th inst., for the purpose of considering the subjects of our admission into the Union, and of the future organization of parties in the Territory, was, from unavoidable causes, very thinly attended, and resulted in nothing.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In your paper of 17th inst. I find a "Retrospect of a Year's Crime," taken from the "First Metropolitan Police Report," in which the "total number of arrests" is stated to have been "60,885:" and after a statement of "the nativity of those arrested," it is added," among these were 566 colored persons."

But little of interest has transpired here during the past week. On Monday morning Senator BRODERICK arrived in the Mail from California. He was received by the Mormons as a guest and has been entertained by them at the residence of WM. STAINES, an adopted son of BRIGHAM YOUNG.
OUR UTAH BRETHREN.--Our Utah Correspondent brings to light a very edifying piece of testimony concerning the boasted devotion of the Mormons to the institutions of their beloved country.

Our readers will remember that some few weeks age, Dr. GAILLARDET was convicted, in the Court of Sessions, before Recorder BARNAER, of a felonious and very aggravated assault upon Mr. HIRAM CRANSTON, of INGRAHAM for a stay of proceedings, in order to obtain a new trial, but this was refused, and Dr. G. was ?? to the City Prison under charge of officer ENWAED O. BAKER, to a wall his sentence.

Attorney-General Black, at the request of the Secretary of the Interior, has decided that the swampland grant made to Arkansas by the act of Sept. 25. 1850. establishes the right of the State to all swamplands within its limits; and that the vesting of the title was completed by the act, though patents had not been issued, did that the subsequent grant by act of Feb. 9, 1853.
The instructions with which Lord ELGIN left England, were founded upon a draft furnished to the Earl of CLARENDON by a Committee of merchants engaged in the trade of China.

THE GIFT OF HOLIVAR'S PORTBAIR FROM VENEZCELA TO NEW-YORK--THE DEPARTURE OF GENERAL PAEZ--SMALL GARS ON THE HUDSON RIVER ROAD. The Board met at 5 P.M., yesterday, President CLAVEY in the chair. The following communication, with document annexed, was received from the Mayor:

ACADEMY ?? MUSIC.--MOZAUR'S celebrated opera of the "Nozze di Figare" will be produced here to-night for the first time in this country. Great care has been be stowed on the rohearesals. Mile. PICCOLOMINI and Herr FORMES sustain the principal parts.
PERFECTLY SATISFACTORY.--We expressed some curiosity a few days since to know why our Government was to incur the expense of sending Gen. PAEZ back to Venczucla in a national vessel.

THE FORGED BILLS UPON THE AUSTRIAN BANK.-The Detective Police, having this case in hand, are still unremitting in their efforts to discover and arrest all the culpable parties. Yesterday they succeeded in ascertaining the fact that the plates and bills were manufactured in this country-the supposition heretofore being that they were produced in Austria.

You will learn of our mishap by the telegraph long before you receive this letter. We were six nights and five days in a cyclone, or circular hurricane, corresponding to the typhoon of the Indian Ocean--save that they only blow with violence for from 3 to 6 hours, and ours only abate 15 hours at one time, and 3 at another during 140 hours !

REPUBLICAN CITY CONVENTION. A special meeting of the Republican City Convention was held last evening, at no. 618 Broadway, A?? F. Dow presided, and Messrs. BOYD and McFARLAND officiated as Secretaries. After the meeting had been called to order, the Chairman desired all present who were not members of the convention to retire.

DISCUSSION ON STREET CLEANING AND STREET SWEEPING MACHINES. Mayors TIEMANN and WOOD did not appear before the Committee yesterday afternoon. Some rather spicy proceedings, not put down in the programme, was substituted for the interesting statements these gentlemen were expected to make.

It is not necessary for me to say to those who know anything of Mexico, that the news of the reported determination of the American Government to bring all the Spanish-American Republics "to an account" has been received here with joy by many Americans who have long been praying for the even, and by all foreigners who are not directly interested in preserving the present state of anarchy which prevails in this country.

The Overland Mail brought the passengers. During a severe storm at Tejon, on the 2d of October, a stampede occurred among the camels used by Lieut. DEALE, Nine of them had been recovered, but six were still missing. The Los Angels Star,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I shall enter into no controversy with anonymous letter writers, but I would ask space in your columns to state the facts regarding the removal of Miss GILDEERSLEEVE from the principalship of the Primary Department of Ward School No. 37. The stated meetings of our School Board are held on the first and third Fridays in each month.

Two steamers are now about due with later European news--the City of Baltimore at this port, from Liverpool on the 10th , and Prince Albert at St. Johns, N. F., from Galway on the 11th. By the Overland Mail, at St. Louis, we receive later news from all points on the Pacific. The dates from Victoria, to Oct. 18. bring more favorable accounts from the Fraser's River gold mines.

When we left the United States, seven months since, we scarcely hoped to visit Japan during, our cruise. Here we are now, novertheless, quietly anchorsed in the beautiful harbor of Nagasaki. Three years since, while surveying around the world. I saw much of this country. but never happened to visit this particular port.

The mail screw steamship City of Baltimore, R. LEITCH, Esq. Commander, from Liverpool at noon of Nov. 10, arrived at this port yesterday morning. A brief summary of her news appeared in a portion of our morning edltion of yesterday. The City of Baltimore arrived out on the evening of the 6th, and the Cunard sleamship Africa reached Liverpool at 9:30 on the morning of the 7th Inst.

The excessive depression which has so long affected the general shipping interest, as well in Europe as in this country, finds its origin beyond the period of the panic of 1857. Much as that revulsion undoubtedly had to do with keeping vessels out of employment, it was not the primary cause of the prostration of the shipping business.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Editor of the TIMES seems to question the desire of the people to relieve themselves from the load of accumulated evils under which this City greans. The Evils they have pointed out, all alike admit, alike condemn, and alike express an equal releiness to remove.
The Emperor NAPOLKON III, has lost his hold, we fear forever, upon the esteem and respect of our enlightened fellow-citizens, the Border Ruffians and Mr. JOHN MITCHEL.

PACIFIC RAILROAD.--A petition has been prepared, and is circulated for signatures, praying Congress to provide for the construction of a double-track Railroad from the Atlantic to the Pacific, with a collateral telegraph,--the work to be done by ten distinct companies, in as many sections, each beng paid its share of one hundred millions of dollars as its work may be done. No lands are to be given;

DEATH OF THE HON. BENJAMIN F. BUTLER.--Letter from Paris announce the death, in that city, Nov. 8, of the Hon. BENJAMIN F. BUTLER, of this City. His disease was diabetes. Mr. BUTLER was born at Kinderhook, in this State, in December, 1795 He studied law with Ex-President VAN BUREN, and when admitted to practice, became his partner.

Col. JEFFERSON DAVIS has been making a very ferocious speech in Mississippi, of which we give a report in another column. He seems to have been charged, on returning home from his Northern tour, with having betrayed the State Rights party, and the principal object of this speech was to acquit himself of this horrible allegation.

Though the Legislature will not meet for seven weeks to come, the settlement of its organization is attracting some attention. It is taken for granted that Mr. HALE is to be Speaker of the House of Representatives, and that Mr. STOWE is to be reelected Clerk of that body.

THE WATER WORKS--WATER IN THE RESERVOIR.--At last we have the gratifying intelligence to announce that there is water in the Easterly Section of the Reservoir at Ridgewood--water direct from Baisley's Pond, in Jamaica--the source from which Brooklyn is promised an abundant supply as soon as the machinery is in position, which, we are positively assured, will be the case by the 1st of January next.

From the Vicksburg Whig of the 10th. Colonel Davis spoke in the hall of the House of Representatives, by invitation of the Legislature, on last Thursday night, and as, both from his position and reputation, his views and opinions are looked to with great interest by all parties, we give a brief synopsis of his speech.

IMPROVEMENT IN THE BAROMETER.--A very marked improvement has recently been made in the mercurial barometer, which can scarcely full to bring it into much more general use than it has enjoyed hitherto.

I telegraphed you last night that General WALKER'S friends suppose that he has left the United States with five hundred men for Nicaragua. It seems that anticipating difficulty at Mobile from interference by the Collector, he selected about five hundred men who rendezvoused at another and smaller port on the Gulf, where the Revenue Officers sympathise sufficiently in his plans, to be readily convinced of the legality of the enterprise.

The following letter, from an intelligent officer of the English Navy, gives a clear, and, we believe, not inaccurate statement of the proceedings which have led to the Paraguay Expedition. Its opinions are worthy of consideration.

TWO MURDERS IN DETROIT-- A BRUNEEN FRACAS--PRACTICIDE. At Detroit, Nos. 17, a disturbance occurred on the dock at the foot of Woodward avenue, ending in the murder of one of the participants, an Irishman named DANIEL FLYNN, who lived on Sixth-street, above Michigan-avenue.

The Philadelphia Bulletin says a desperate attempt to commit suicide was made on Saturday by a young woman, who threw herself before a locomotive on the Reading Railroad, at Frankford-avenue. The woman was dragged away by the gatekeeper at that point, just in time to save her from a frightful death.

THE TRIAL OF THE HIBERNIA STEAM FIRE-ENGINE, OF PHILADELPHIA--Our Philadelphia visitors, the members of the Hibernia Company, made trial of their steam fire-engine in the Park, yesterday afternoon. The Company looked well, and marched heavely, in spite of the cold northeaster, and falling rain.

On Saturday, Mr. R. LINDSET WALKER, of Atbemarle County, Va., while on his way to Bludensburg battle-ground, near Washington, to fight a duel with Mr. WM. F. GORDON, of the same County, was arrested and brought before Mayor MAYO.

The screw-steamship City of Ball?? from Liverpool on the 10th of November, arrived at this port on Tuesday morning. Her news is of interest. The Atlantic Telegraph Company, after rejecting the offer of Mr. E. O. W. WHITEHOUSE to resume the management, has shut up the telegraph house at valentia and dismissed the operators.

COLEMAN.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 23, CHARLES S. COLEMAN, aged 44 years, formerly of Troy, N. Y., and late of Hamilton, C. W. The funeral will take place from the house of his brother, Robert B. Coleman, No. 423 4th St., on Thursday, the 25th inst. at 1 o'clock P. M. The relatives and friends of the family are requested to attend, without further invitation.

The escape of Dr. GAILLARDET was the prominent topic of conversation yesterday in the City. It interested all classes of persons. The deliberation with which the affair, with its antecedents and concomitants, was attended, was a subject of general comment, and Officer BAKER, to whose charge the doctor was intrusted, was everywhere accused, not only with conniving at, but with directly prompting and aiding the escape.

Two famous old London Coffee--Houses have recently come under the hammer. The first of these was the Rainbow Tavern, Fleet-street, mentioned by Aubrey, in his Lives, as a Coffee-house, in the days when Coffee-houses first came it.

The Governor's team was thrown open yesterday afternoon to General PADZ, that he might bid farewell to his may friends. Prior to the leave-taking there, Mayor TIEMANS, and his Secretaries, Messrs. AULD and SCOTT, and several members of the Common Connell, met the General in the Chamber of the Board of Councilmen, where an interesting ceremony occurred.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of the 15th is exists from the Christen Mercury of the 11th inst., in regard to the Ketch Brothers, recently captured on the court of Africa by the United States ship Marion on suspension of being engaged in the Slave-trade.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you oblige me by correcting an error in your paper of this date, wherein you state that the adjourment of the Telegraphic Chess Match between this place and Philadelphia was until to-morrow. The next meeting is fixed for Thursday.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--If there is anything more disheartening than the effort to unravel an ordinary dramatic plot, it is sured ?? the lobor of dissecting an operatic one. We shall spare our readers the infliction ; accomplishing, at the same time, a great personal relief. MOZART'S comic opera describes itself in the title.

KIERSTED--PISCKNEY.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 17. by the Rev. E. F. Hatfield, D. D., Mr. JAMES I. J. KIERSTED, son of Gen. H. T. Kierstel, to Miss MARY C. PISCKNEY, daughter of Col. Joseph C. Pinckney, all of this City.

All signs indicate the hulling of the Slavery storm which has so rocked the country for the last few years. Here and there faint murmurings betray the lingering of the lightnings, --but they do not break with any force, and the noise awakened is rather the mimic thunder of the stage than the deep and dangerous explosion of warring elements.

It may be remembered that Mr. TAYLOR, the late Collector of Assessments, with Messrs. LIBBY, SHERWOOD and OAKLEY, his Deputies, were not long since reported as defaulters in the City in the sum of $227,102.

The telegraph has reported the fall of a building and consequent loss of life at Waterbury, Ct. The Waterbury journal gives fuller particulars. The accident occurred about 5 o' clock in the afternoon. The roof fell to the ground with a tremendous crash buying several men in the ruins, .

To the Editor of the New-York Times: This is either a department of Public Health, or it is simply a branch of the Police Department, If its functions are of the forme. character, then It is imperative that its officers shall possess peculiar qualifications to enable then to perform the duties pertainingto the officer, such qualifications can only be found in the thoroughly-educated scientific physician.

1. In pursuance of general order No.21, from the headquarters of the Army the portion of the 1st cavalry at Fort Leavenworth is assigned to posts as follows: Captain DE SAUSSURE'S company F, and Captain STEWART'S company K, to Fort Riley, under command of Major SEDGWICK; Captain A, to Fort Smith; Captain WOOD'S company C, and Captain CARR'S company 1, to Fort Washita.

Professor THOMSON, writing to the Glasgow Herald, says: "I have read with considerable interest your remarks in yesterday's piper on the recent revival in the Atlantic cable. Although it is best to be hopeful under all circumstances, there are still certain occasions when we may delude ourselves and be buoyed up with false expectutions.

To the Editer of the New-York Times : The iron railings around the City-Hall Park are converted Into ballad stands, kept by dirty, barefooted boys andgirls, A penny will buy a dirty song. "Free and Easy Still," "The Fate of a False Lover." "John Dean and Ills Own Mary Ann," or "My Love he is a Sailieur Boy nineteen years old." It is the literature of the Five Points transferred to the Park.

We have received the Bermuda Gazette of Nov. 9, and the Nassau, N. P., Guardian of the 6th, a few days later than our previous advices. We find nothing more of interest in them to the American reader, than what has already been published.

The Atlantic Royal Mail Steam Navigation Company's steamer Prince Albert arrived at this port at 10 o'clock this morning, but, owing to the wires being down on the route between this place and Sackvihe, we were unable to transmit her news until this evening. The Prince Albert brings Liverpool and London advice to Thursday noon, the 11st Inst., which were telegraphed to Galway for the New-York Associated Press.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The articles in the TIMES, of Oct. 17 and 18, on the Coast Survey, signed B. B., have probably taken no one by surprise who has followed, with any interest, events in scientific circles within the last few months.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have spent a good part to the last ten days on Western Railroads, and will give those of your readers who have invested in them a few facts of interest from which they can make their calculations about fature dividends.

ANTI-TAMMANY RATIFICATION. INDORSEMENT OF STEPHEN P. RUSSELL FOR COMPTROLLER, AND JAMES LYNCH FOR GOVERNOR OF THE ALMSHOUSE. A meeting of that section of the Democracy which, under the leadership of Mr. FERNANDO WOOD, professes to have for its aims the demolition of the Tammany "misrule," the abatement of taxes, and general reform, was held last night in Mozart Hall.

THE DISAPPEARANCE OF DR. GAILLARDET.--From Dr. GAILLARDET no idings have been received, Wherever he may be, he has failed to report himself. The latest rumor suggests some part of Canada as his temporary place of sojourn. This morning Recorder BARNARD will inquire into the conduct of Officer BAKER, and investigate, as far as possible, the modus opearandi of the Doctor's exodus from prison.

There are two sides to all things in nature, if we except the moon and Mr. WOOD'S Mayoralty; and the Paraguay Expedition demands a moment's criticism. Our Government has been, for some time past, making preparations the most tremendous to avenge an insult offered to our flag by that South American mandarin, LOPEZ;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR : You may regard the writer as being influenced by an over-captious spirit in so persistently persuing the editor of the Christian Intelligencer. But that gentleman, in spite of the very plain facts which have been laid before him, is determined to make it appear to the readers of his journal that there is no possible need of a woman's library.

The steamship Prince Albert, from Galway on the afternoon of the 11th Inst., arrived at St. Johns, N. F.. yesterday morning-having, as we understand, been detained on her passage by an accident to her machinery, Her advices are to noon of the day of sailing-one day later than received by tile City of Baltimore. Cotton is reported steady, and Breadstuffs and Provisions very dull. Consuls had declined.

We are heartily rejoiced to learn from the Tribune, of yesterday, that a bill has been introduced into the State Senate of Vermont, which will, if passed, "effectually put a stop, so far as Vermont is concerned, to the attempts of Northern visitors to play the slaveholder within the limits of that State."

If Mr. BUCHANAN could be supposed capable of so far forgetting the traditions of his long life as ever to do the right thing at the right time, we might confidently anticipate a definite solution of the Mexican question from his forthcoming Presidential message.

The U. S. frigate Sabine, Commander SHUBRICK, sailed from Bermuda, after repairing, Nov. 9. MOVEMENTS AT THE NAVY-YARD.--At the Brooklyn Navy-yard the work of fitting a way the Paraguay steamers progresses. The Atlanta went into commission yesterday at 1 P. M., and the sailors ad marines were sent on board.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In Your issue of this morning you have an article headed "City Defaulters and their Sureties," in which I know you have dealt unjustly by the parties concerned. You state that the Collector of Assessments and Deputies have been reported defaulters to a large amount, and that " a forfeiture of their hands has in every case been incurred."

We have received San Francisco papers to Oct. 25. by the Overland Mail, and St. Louis, bringing further details of new from all points on the Pacific. The dates, however, are not so late by eleven days as the arrival at New-Orleans and Tehuantepec. Our files contain some interesting items of intelligence.

A POLICEMAN SHOT AT BY BURGLARS--NARROW ESCAPE.--At about 8 o'clock on Tuesday evening, last, as officer LYONS of the 9th President, was passing through Throop Avenue from Myrstle to Flushing, he suddenly came upon three burglar engaged in quarreling over the spells of a burglary, doublless just committed by their. One of the three had a stocking filled with something which the officer supposed to be silver.

A RULE THAT WORKS BOTH WAYS.--In the speech which Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS recently addressed to the Legislature of Mississippi, he is reported to have said that the sentiments of the people of the North "could not be fairly judged by the votes and speeches of their representatives ; men of extreme opinions got into Congress and went further than their constinents would follow them."

The escape of Dr. GALILLARDET: from Officer BAKER is treated by Judge RUSSELL'S special organ as affording a species of miraculous revelation concerning the management of our criminal Courts. In commenting on the subiect the Herald says:

The veritable Colonel TITUS, of Kansas notoriety, passed through this place yesterday. As he has figured in many Eastern papers, as being at the head of several hundred men, it may be of interest for your readers to know that the exact number that accompanied him was nine, six mounted and three in a baggage wagon.

JOHN MORRISSEY ON EXHIBITION IN PHILADELPHIA, - JOHN MORRISSEY, the bruiser, who had the Prize fight with HENAN which made so great a stir, arrived in this city yesterday, and in the evening gave a sparring exhibition at Franklin Hall. About one hundred persons were present; most of them being of the regular rowdy and blackguard stamp, while there were various velvet-fingered and fancifully-dressed gamblers and prominent politicians among the crowd.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The second performance of tile "Nozze di Figaro" attracted an overflowing house last night. It was a more complete performance in every respect, and passed off with more of the spirit and quickness of comic opera than were perceptible on the first night.

A GREAT RASCAL FINALLY CAUGHT.--The Cincinnati Gazette has the following: An officer of the Baltimore Police reached this city yesterday with a requisition for a fugitive, who is under indictment for bigamy, and who has passed hereabouts as "Dr. W. H. Emmett" buy whose real name is ISRAEL A. LEON.

A MARRIED MAN ELOPING WITH A YOUNG LADY.--The Hartford Courant, Nov. 22, says: "The facts of the recent elopement in this city have been in our possession for several days past, but have been previously withheld at the request of parties interested.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: In the TIMES of Oct. 28 was published an article mentioning certain changes in the Navy, which, it was said, would prevent the necessity of appointing a new Retiring Board to "weed the Navy of the incompetent drones who had fastened themselves upon it."

From the Balletin of last Evening. Abort 11 o'clock this morning, a pair of shears (or a derrick) fell the Chesnuat-street front of the new hotet building , at Ninth and Chestnat Streets, instantly killing a stone mason. named JOHN TWIGGS and injuring another so severely that he died in a few hours.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : LOUIS NAPOLEON'S repudiation of the free emigration system, addressed to "his dear cousin," though tardy, is better than nothing. It declares that his action in the case of the Charles at Georges, though sufficiently energetic, was intended rather to evince a solictate for the honor of the flag, than a sympathy with the Slave-trade.

Five-and-twenty States and Territories celebrated a Thanksgiving Anniversary yesterday, but New-York was left out of the catalogue by degree of His Excellency the Governor, who ordained that our particular feast should happen, as it did, last week on a Thursday.

THE PEOPLE'S CONVENTION. An adjourned meeting of the People's Convention was held last evening at THORF'S, corner of Broadway and Ninth-street, A. M. BININGER presiding. The Committee appointed to wait upon Mr. JOHN B. LEVERIDGE and inform him of his nomination, reported that they had an interview with that gentleman, who stated that he was not then able to give a decided reply, but intimated that he would do so on Friday..

A sad story is told by the Huntsville (Texas) Item: A Frenchman and his wife were recently found dead, near their residence at White Rock Shoals, on Trinity River. Some time this year the parties eloped from Louisiana, unwedded. They took a place on the river, and turned their attention to stock-raising. But rumor followed; it was whispered they were living in adultery, and a true bill was found at Sumpter Court, Trinity County.

A private letter has been received at Washington from the United States ship-of-way Dale, dated at Acra, on the southwest coast of Africa, Oct. 14. All on board were well. The Date left Porto Praya oil the 30th of August and landed at Cape Palmas on the 14th of September.

This being thanks giving with us, none been more truly thankful than the President and his cabinet, who have been steadily at work all day without the usual annoyances. Mr. BUCILANAN has been locked in at the state Department with Secretary CASS.

TERRIBLE AFFRAY BETWEEN TWO BROTHERS-IN-LAW.--We have the particulars of a most terrible tragedy in Grand Cote Prairie, in this County. As we understand it, two brothers-in-law by the names of HUNTER and REID, in a room by themselves,

We hope something will be done at the next session of the Legislature to regulate the exercise of the pardoning power by the Governor. It is grossly abused, is exerted by fits and starts, without reason or method, and every year practically nullifies the law by turning loose on society criminals who have been justly convicted at great expense and alter great trouble.

To-day is the two hundred and fifty-third anniversary of Guy Fawkes ineffectual treason; and since break of day the air has been filled by the shouts of the urchin rabble, to whom is left the duties of historical commemoration.

PERSONAL. The Executors of the will of the Hon. John M. Niles have paid over to the City Treasurer of NewHaven, Conn., the sum of $20,000, devised by Mr. Niles as a fund, tile interest of which is to be annually expended in assisting the heads of families, especially poor widows, in the payment of rents and the purchase of fuel--under a Committee to be appointed for the purpose.

FUNERAL OF CORNELIUS V. ANDERSON.--The funeral of the late C. V. ANDERSON took place yesterday, at noon, at the Central Methodist Church, in Seventh-avenue. The immediate friends of the deceased, with the pall-bearers, assembled at his late residence. No. 57 Bank-street, where the remains were placed in the hall, enclosed in a rosewood coffin, ornamented with silver mounting.

The Mobile Register has discovered a fresh grief. It is in the depths of despair, because Judge CAMFBELL, of tile United States Court, has ordered a special circuit. The Register smells mischief in this proceeding. It is quite sure the Judge intends to put upon their trial the men who have been endeavoring to get up another crusade against Nicaragua.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As one of that great army of martyrs, the property-holders of this City, I have paid strict attention to the various revelations of fraud and defalcation made by Street-Commisioner COOPER to the Common Council; and I confess myself largely indebted to that officer for knowing "how the money goes," and halving pretty correct suspicions as to the "weasels" who have popped or pocketed it.

MACKIE - In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 24, Mrs. GEACE MACKIE, widow of the late John Mackie, aged 53 years. The friends and relataives of the family are invited to attend her funeral, From Dr. Muhlenburg's Church, corner 20th - St. and 6th - av., this (Friday) morning, Nov. 26. At 11 o'clock.

The Rev. Dr. Storrs on the Influence of Climate on Civilization. The Rev. Dr. STORES, of Brooklyn, delivered an interesting lecture on this topic last evening, in the Cooper Institute, before the Young Men's Christian Association. Between two and three hundred persons were present.

Among the many new questions now being agitated in Russia, one of the most important is that relative to the judiciary system, and the reorganization of tile tribunals. Red-tapeism has hitherto existed in the administration of justice to an incredible extent-and, indeed. still exists.

Indiana has a very pretty light on hand, the end whereof no on can foresee. Each side continues the game of reading out of the Democratic Party, until now much doubt exists not only as to which is within the organization but as to whether a Democratic Party exists within the State at all.

It is confidently asserted that the new move against Mr. SCHELL will be successful, and that he will retire from the Collectorship as soon as a successor shall have been agreed upon. How long this resolution will last remains to be seen. The place has been offered to and declined by Judge PARKER.

The steamship Africa, of the Cunard line, arrived here yesterday with European advices to Nov. 13. They are of interest. The arrival of the steamship Indian Empire, which left New-York for Galway five weeks since, had not been reported at Liverpool when the Africa sailed.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN. The Board met at 5 P. M., yesterday, President CLANCY in the chair. The Committee on Finance reported in favor of making donations of $1,000 to the Northwestern Dispensary, $250 to the Ladies' Depository, and $500 to the Women's Prison Association and Home. The report was laid over.

The Democrats who have proved faithful to the Tammany regime, through all its varying fortunees, met last night, in the old wigwam, to show by their presence their devotion to the principle of " regular nominations and the usages of the Party," and, more specifically, to ratify the nominations of GEO. H. PURSER for Comptroller, and ISAAC H. TOWNSEND for Almshouse Governor.

We published yesterday morning a statement from the Governor's Private Secretary of the reasons for the pardon of JACKSON, who had been convicted and sentenced for a brutal outrage upon an emigrant girl.

At its meeting on Wednesday, at Albany, the President of the State Temperance Society delivered an address stating that the cause might be in a healthy and advancing condition, in spite of retrograde appearances in some of the large cities.

The Royal mail steamship Africa, NEIL SHANNON, Esq., Commander, which sailed from Liverpool at noon on the 13th inst., arrived here early yesterday morning. The Indian Empire--three weeks out--from New-York to Calway, had not been heard of at Liverpool when our dispatch was closed.

THE NEW-YORK STATE ARSENAL.--So far as we are aware, there has been no inquiry into the causes of the recent falling of the roof of the new Arsenal in Seventh-avenue. Yet such an inquiry should be had, not only to fix the responsibility of that disaster where it belongs, but as a precaution for the future.

It may startle some of our readers to know that the Union of these States no longer exists. The catastrophe y which this long threatened dissolution of the great confederacy, so fondly founded by our honest though mistaken fathers, has been brought about, was equally unexpected and tremendous.

The letter of our correspondent at St. Petersburg, published in yesterday's TIMES, foreshadows the important changes which mark the new era of Russian civilization. Among other reforms, the Judiciary is proposed to be reorganized, and trial by Jury inaugurated-it having been found that, "without a clear, concise, equitable administration of justice, all other reforms of a national bearing are out of the question."

The members of this old Society dined together at the Everett House on Evacuation Day. Formed as long ago as May, 1783, this Society, which once boasted WASHINGTON as a member, was created, First--"With an unalterable determination to promote and cherish indissoluble UNION between the States."

Mr. MORPHY fairly deserves from his countrymen the reward once offered by a Roman tyrant to the inventor of a new pleasure. He has inspired the dullest Clubs of his native land with sudden life, and kindled anew on many a domestic hearth the dying fire of home attractions.

On Wednesday morning, the dead body of a young man was found in his room at the American Hotel, in Jersey City, where he had taken lodgings for the night. The next day an inquest was held upon him by Coroner MORRIS, but nothing was ascertained to establish his identity.

KENT-MUMFORD.--In this city, on Thursday, Nov. 25, at the Church of the Annunetation, by the Rev. Dr. Seabury, HENRY F. KENT and CHAELOTTE S., daughter of Benjamin A. Mumford, Esq. HOFFMAN--POWERS,--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 24, by the Rev. Dr. Morgan, JOSEPH G. HOFFMAN to CAROLINE A., youngest daughter of the late Wm. M. Powers.

A grand reception was yesterday extended to Mr. PETER COOPER by the children and teachers of the public schools of the City at the Lecture-room of the Institute. The first three grammar classes of nearly all the schools were present, numbering about 3.000 scholars and teachers.

A SFA CAPTAIN IN TROUBLE-ALLEGED BIGAMY.-A few days ago, Captain WILLIAM McGILL, In the employ of the Block Ball line-of-packet ships, was arrested and having one more wife than the law allows. The complainant in this case was an Irish girl, about 17 years of age.

ACCIDENT ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD. On Thursday evening the 5 o'clock Express train ran over and killed a Mr. GEORGE BLACK and his wife, a short distance from Tarrytown, near Ex-Mayor KINGSLAND'S residence. It seems they were walking up the track for the purpose of calling upon some friends living on Mr. KINGSLAND'S place.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The repetition of "Robert le Diable" last night attracted a fine house, an extra attraction existing in the fact that it was the first part of Mme. GAZZANIOA'S farewell appearance. The performance was a very fine one in every respect.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I much regret being compelled once more to trespass upon your kindness, in the use of your columns, but the manifest errors contained in an article published in your paper of this date make it necessary for me so to do.

We willingly publish, in another column, a letter signed "H.," complaining of the abuse of power by the Police in the seizure of lottery tickets at tile house of a German Jewish clergyman. Without indorsing all that our correspondent has to say in regard to the venial character of the offence of dealing in these gambling conCerns, we must say that there can be no excuse for the conduct of tile officers.

On Thursday morning an investigation into the circumstances connected with the escape of Dr. Gaillardet was commenced before Recorder BARNARD at his office. The proceedings were strictly private, no winners being permitted to be present during the examination of another. Mr. Blunt, the District-Attorney, conducted the investigation, assisted by Ex-Judge Whiting.

Judging from the comments upon the subject of reading the Bible in our Public Schools, which recent events have elicited, a clear statement of the facts of the case may not be without interest and value.

The United States Mail Steamship Illinois, Captain F. McGOWN, from Aspinwall, at 10 1/2 o'clock, A. M., of Nov, 20, arrived last night, bringing the treasure and passengers from San Francisco by the Sonora.

Mr. THOMAS O. LARKIN, a California pione died in San Francisco, Oct. 27. He was a native of Charlestown, Mass., born in 1802; went to California in 1532, was appointed U. S. Consul at Monterey in 1844, and since the admission of the State into the Union had lived in retirement.

Within the last week or ten days WILLIAM LEMON OLIVER, described as a stockbroker, of 4, Austinfriars, has from time to time been brought up to Guildhall under remand. He was not, however, a member of the Stock-Exchange.

The Albany Evening Journal charges the TIMES with having assumed that "the exercise of Executive clemency in the case of JACKSON was itself a crime." The charge is unfounded, and is not sustained by the extract quoted to sustain it. We did assume that this pardon was most untimely, and that, prima facie, it needed explanation.

LAUNCH OF THE CHINESE STEAMER FIRE-WITCH A fine light-draft steamer of 1,250 tons burthe?? intended for the navigation of the Chinese rivers, was launched on Saturday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from the ship-yard of THOMAS COLLEGE, Forty-third-street F. R.

FIRE IN BEEKMAN-STREET, CORNER OR GOLD.--The alarm of fire for the Seventh District, at twenty minutes before 30 o'clock last night, was caused by a fire in the basement of the building No. 56. Beakman street, corner of Gold, occupied by JOHN C. SPATZ as a lager bier saloon and restaurant. The fire originated in a sub-cellar used as a kitchen.

The Panama Railroad Company's steamship Columbus arrived here on the 4th. Her dates are from Guatemala to the 25th, from Salvador to the 27th, Nicaragua to the 29th, and Costa Rica to the 31st October.

To the Editor of the London Times: SIR: My attention having been drawn to a letter under the above heading in the Times of to-day, signed "Voyageur," from the Reform Club, I trust that you will do me the justice to allow me to state that I am unacquainted with "Voyageur," and that I feel myself called upon to correct him as far as regards certain statements made in his letter.

Governor ALLSTON, of South Carolina, in his Message to the Legislature, counsels the people of the State concerning the expenditure of their money at the North. He says: "There are Southern men of wealth, doubtless, who expend most of their surplus profits in Northern investments and objects of pleasure. It has been estimated that some forty millions of dollars of Southern income have been disbursed in a single year north of the Potomac.

A golden wedding anniversary was celebrated at Pawtucket. R. I., a few days since. The host and hostess were Mr. and Mrs. Dexter. An interesting incident of the occasion was the presence of an old printer, Capt. Jones, who "set up" the marriage notice for the couple, years ago, and read it to the guests from the original paper.

The Paris Constitutional returns to the subject of a Corn Reserve, which it asserts to be decidedly contemplated by the Imperial Government. "Our readers," the article commences, "will not be astonished if we treat the great question of the organization of a Grain Reserve at some length.

Orange Co., N.Y., on Wednesday, Nov. 24. by the Rev. John Forsyth, D. D., the Rev. ALEXANDER McWILLIAM to Miss MARGARET, daughter of Andrew Kernochan, Esq.

GEN. PAEZ AND THE PARAGUAY FLEET.--Not only does the Administration adhere to its resolution to place Government steamers at the disposal of Gen. PAEZ, but we see it announced that Commodore BREEZE, who called on the illustrious Venezuelan on Saturday, intimated to him that, in consequence of the accident which has recently befallen the General, "the steamer Calcdonia would be detained here till he should be sufficiently recovered to embark for Venezuela."

The second election under the new Charter of New-York will take place on the first Tuesday in December, (one week from tomorrow,) and we have compiled from authentic sources a list of the various candidates already in the field. A few more nominations for minor offices have yet to be made, but the Municipal candidates are now before the people, and our list, as far as it goes, will be found complete and accurate.

Hutchinson, E. B. Francis, Miss M. C. Smith, Miss Cushing.

We are within a week of our Charter Election. The result of it will determine the character of our City Government for another year. The Mayor holds over, but theComptroller is to be changed, half the Aldermen and all the Councilmen are to be elected, and the Board of Education and all the local Boards which have control of our system of education are to receive their character from the issue of this canvass.

A YOUTHFUL KENTUCKIAN IN THE JAWS OF THE TIGER--A SEVERE MASTICATING PROCESS.--Every one knows that villainous masculine decoys, professionally known as ropers-in, swarm about the City hotels ready to pounce upon tile newly-arrived stranger and lure him into the destruction den of the tough "tiger.'

ESTY.--In this City, on Sunday morning, Nov. 28. FRANK, only son of Francis A. and Sarah A. Esty, aged 2 years and 8 months. Funeral this day, (Monday,) at 3 o'clock, from No. 7 Hammond-st. Relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend, He will be taken to Hudson, N. Y., for interment.

Judge EDMONDS made an address yesterday morning at Dod worth's Saloon, in Broadway, to a congregation mainly of Spiritualists, upon the general subject of their faith. It was in the .usual course of the Sunday services which are regularly maintained in that place by this newest of the religious sects. The Judge spoke from copious notes of the heads of his discourse, and with easy fluency and marked candor of manner.

The President's message will take such bold and vigorous ground with reference to our Mexican relations as to throw upon Congress the responsibility of further continuance of their present condition. It is to be hoped that Mr. BUCHANAN will not fail to express the sympathy which himself and the country feel for the Liberals, in emphatic terms.

The "People's City Convention," called for the purpose of nominating People's candidates for Comptreller and Governor of the Almshouse, held its final meeting at THORP'S, corner of Broadway and Ninth-street, on Saturday evening. The attendance was not large.

We learn that there is reason to believe that, instead of having committed suicide as was at first reported, Mr. E. J. DICKENS; whose sudden death at Jersey City has been already noticed, was accidentally poisoned.

Gentile energy and enterprise, assisted by Mormon industry, and backed by the capital afforded by the expenditures which the Government is now making in this Territory, is rapidly developing its resources and gradually working a reform, both in its social and political characteristics.

The Canadian Steamship Company's screw steamer North Briton, Captain THOMAS JONES, from Liverpool at 4:15 P. M., on Wednesday, the 17th inst., arrived here at 3 o'clock this morning. The North Briton has made the passage in ten days and a half. Her advices are four days later than those by the Africa at New-York.

THE COLUMBIA-STREET MURDER--ARREST OF THE OFFENDER.--At an early hour, Saturday morning last, Captain SHAMMAN and Sergeant FURY, of the Third Precinct, succeeded in arresting WILLIAM CULLEN, accused of killing JOHN HART, in Columbia-street near Kelsey's Alley, South Brooklyn, on the night of the 17th instant.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC-Like a skillful pos??illion. Mr. ULLMAN has reserved a gallop for the last stage of his journey. To-night he gives us Mile. PICCOLOMIN in "Lucrezia Borgia"--the lady impersonating the matronly heroine. The cast in other respects is very attractive; Herr FORMES is the Duke, and Mile. GHIONI the Orsini.

ONE MORE UNFORTUNATE.--The body of a young lady was found at an early hour on Saturday morning. floating in the East River, near the foot of Twenty-sixth-street. Two men with a small boat brought the body to the shore.

The screw steamer North Briton, of the Canadian Steamship Company's line, from Liverpool on the 17th inst., arrived at Portland yesterday morning, having made the passage in ten days and a half. Her advices are four days later. Cotton at Liverpool on the day of sailing was reported steady and firm, while Breadstuffs and Provisions were very dull. Consols were at 98 1/2 for account.

When Frenchmen and Spaniards went to war with the imbecile monarchy of Annam, there were those who saw in the business another realization of the lion and ass who went hunting, in the fable. France embarked in the venture upon a shrewd calculation of securing enough territory to pay the outlay.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. We have received copies of the Vera Cruz Progreso to the 11th inst. inclusive. and of the Oaxaca Democracy of the 28th ult. The notable thing that we perceive in the latter is an advertisement of the Quaker City and the Tehuantepec route, giving notice that she will leave Minatitian twice a month, the 2d and the 17th, for New-Orleans.

The mail steamship Europa, Captain LEITCH, from Liverpool at 9 A.M. on the 20th November, arrived at Halifax yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock. The Arago, from Southampton on the 17th November, arrived at this port last evening. Her advices were anticipated in brief by the North Briton at Portland.

Our files of Buenos Ayrean journals extend to Oct. 6. The intelligence is without interest. The Legislative Chambers continued their sessions, but had transacted no business of moment. The Commission to transfer the remains of the revolutionary General, JUAN LAVALLR, from Chill to Buenos Ayres, had been appointed by Government. Senors GEORGIA LAS HERAS, OCAMPO and LARRATBA were nominated.

EXHIBITION OF THE PUBLIC SCHOOLS AT COOPER INSTITUTE,--From the opening of the School Exhibition, on the 22d Inst., until its close on Saturday, the rooms of the Cooper Institute have been daily visited by large numbers of persons who take an interest in education, and the efforts of the teachers of the Public Schools to respond to this first attempt to set forth the evidences of progress among their pupils, have met with many encomiums.

We learn by a private letter received from a gentleman in Sonora, that another revolution is about breaking out, that the Gandora Party, once the powerful party of the State, are about to take the field against PESQUERI, the present Governor. GANDORA'S army, 700 strong, is now on its march north, having entered the State from the south, and are being joined by many of the citizens.

The statements is erroneous that Senor MAGUAN came here from Mexico to get a loan from our Government for the JUAREZ party. He sought no interview with the President, but proceeded immediately to New-York. Secretary Conn will leave the Cabinet within ten days, probably taking the Mission to London.

The Empire City, Capt. S. P. GRIFFIN, left New-Orleans at 8 A.M. on the 20th inst., arrived at Havana at sunrise on the 23d, and left at 4 1/2 P.M. same day for this port, where she arrived yesterday morning. Her passage has been prolonged by constant heavy weather and head winds. She brings 25 passengers and a large freight of produce from both mentioned ports.

Mr. COLOHAN, who has recently, by a decision of the Supreme Court, been awarded the office of Alderman of the Fourteenth Ward, in place of Mr. SMITH, was present and took his seat.

MARCY from Fort Bridger to New-Mexico, last Winter, on which he was dis patched, by General JOHNSTON, for the procurement of horses, mules and cattle for the army at Camp Scott, was one of the most remarkable on record.

It is well known that our great object is to aid the poor or vagabond children of the city.

DEATH OF ROBERT OWES,--The Europa brings intelligence of the death of the celebrated ROBERT OWEN, in his 88th year. Mr. OWEN'S name was identified with sundry reformatory movements. He proposed to reconstruct society, projected a variety of measures for the elevation of mankind, and labored diligently in his vocation of philanthropist.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I inclose $3 for the relief of "Poor Book-keeper," and heartily respond to the suggestion of "F", in your issue of to-day, that an association be organized for the benefit of those who may be placed in the unfortunate position of "Poor Book-keeper."

THE NEW-ORLEANS EPIDEMIC.--The Howard Association of New-Orleans publishes the results of its operations during the prevalence of the epidemic this year. On the 14th of August last it assumed the responsibility of declaring the yellow fever epidemic, and on the 1st November announced the cessation of the epidemic.

GENTLEMEN: I have had the honor to receive your invitation to be present, on the 25th inst., at the centennial anniversary of the capture of Fort Duquesne ; and I regret that the pressure of public affairs, at a period near the meeting of Congress, renders it Impossible that I should enjoy this privilege.

A meeting to further the interests of this institution was held, last evening, at the Cooper Institute. The audience in attendance was not such as might have been expected from the names of the speakers announced, not more than three or four hundred being present at any one time.

The St. Louis Republican has the following: Messrs. A. FRENCH. JOSEPH BHADT, WM. HARTLEY, T. C. DICKERSON and WM. SMITH, arrived in this city on yesterday, direct from Pike's Peak gold diggings. They left the mines Oct. 1, in company of fourteen persons, nine of whom remained at Lawrence, K. T.

DURELI.--In this City, on Monday, Nov. 29, or erysipelas, DERORAH DURELL, aged 65 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend to funeral, this day, (Wednesday,) from her late residence, No. 41 7th-st., at 3 P. M.

We are having our municipal affairs getting themselves into some sort of shape, and hope to have everything straight by election day, a fortnight hence. Some people will be straightened out by that time, at all events, whose minds are in a desperately crooked condition at this present writing.

From the Philadelphia Bulletin, last evening. QUARTER SESSIONS--Judge THOMPSON.--This morning the case of THOMAS ALLINONE and THOMAS A. NEWHALL was called as. The defendants are charged with conspiracy and cheating and defrauding the Bank of Pennsylvania out of large suns of money.

The throne-room is magnificently fitted up, and is decorated with paintings by Jerome representing the Church seated between St. Peter and St. Paul, the four Evangelists, the pope blessing a railway. c.;

A CARD. TO MY FRIENDS AND THE PUBLIC. DANIEL E. SICKLES, Member of Congress from the Third Congress District of this State, has recently delivered in New-York City three speeches, namely, on the 30th October, and the 3d and 19th November, in each of which he has assailed me in an Opprobrious and abusive manner.

The President has finally decided to favor a temporary revival of the Tariff of 1816. Whatever differences of ??m upon this subject existed between the President and Secretary of the Treasury, have been adjusted, and it is now supposed that the Cabinet will remain intact.

The personal and political friends of the Hon GEORGE TAYLOR gave him a public dinner on Monday evening last, at which, in response to a complimentary toast, be made the following address: MR. CHAIRMAN AND GENTLEMEN: I feel quite unworthy of your generous hospitality, but I know that this manifestation of public feeling rises above all personal considerations.

Before Judge Betts. PRACTICE--COSTS-DOCKET FEE. Chapman vs. The bark Lucerne.--The libel in this case dismissed, and the claimants proposed to tax a docket fee of $20, to which the libetant's proctor objected, on the ground that the libel was filed to recover less than $50, and the docket fee should therefore be but $10.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I see by the papers that the Sabine not only damaged her steering gear but her rudder in the late gale. I should like, very much, to know all the circumstances of the accident. As they come to us through the papers, it would appear that the Sabinc was lying-to in a heavy gale of wind, under closereefed maintopsail, close-reefed foresail, fore stormstaysail and main trysail.

AN IMMENSE WINDFALL.--According to the Cumberland (Md.) Allehanian, an old man, named JOHN BROST, living in the Glades, in that county, recently discovered he was the rightful owner of a large tract of land in the richest mineral region of Pennsylvania, underlaid with inunense seams of coal and iron, and valued at $8,000,000.

Electors will scarcely have a more imports ant duty to perform at the coming Charter Election than that of selecting the men to fill the twenty-two vacancies in the Board of Education. In the Board which consists of two Commissioners from each Ward is vested the entire control of the public School interests of the City.

(probably ORTON'S, as that is the only one we know of in this section at present,) a day or two since, murdered a man named key, who kept a "groggery" in Not-asulga, Macon County.

Mr. Thomas B. Carroll and wife, and Messrs. John Knower and George W. Newell, executors of the estate of William L. Marcy, deceased, have united in conveying to the Rev. Peter Havermans, as a donation in aid of St. Peter's College, Trov, four lots on the southwest corner of Adams and Fifth streets in that city.

The meeting of the New-York Bar met yesterday afternoon in the new U.S. District Court Room, on Chambers-street, to pay their tribute of respect to the memory of late Hon. B.F. BUTLER. Soon after 3 o'clock, Mr. B.F. MARBURY called the meeting to order, and nominated as Chairman the Hon. SAMUEL NELSON, Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.

" Venerable," says the poet, " is the voice of the past." Words that fall upon hearts heated with present excitements and disturbed by momentary passions, from the still, sad treasury of half-forgotten ages, have a wisdom of their own that is full of healing.

KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--A. regular meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held in the County Jail yesterday. The special object of the meeting was to consider the matter of purchasing forty-five acres of land, at about $500 per acre, for Hospital purposes at Flatbush. This land is adjoining the present county buildings, and has been leased by the county for the last ten or twelve years.

The movements in Wool, during the month of November, Messrs. TELLKAMPF KITOHING notice thus: "Our market has for the last month been active for all descriptions of domestic Fleece and Pulled Wools, with prices tending upwards, and we now quote a decided advance, while the stock of Fleece has been considerably reduced; desirab'e kinds of pulled Wools remain searce and are much wanted.

The Board of Ten Governors voted some time since a donation of $1,500 to Dr. MORTON for the invention of Anaesthesia. The President of the Board, Mr. SMITH, refuses to sign the check, on the ground that the Board has no right thus to give away money of which they are only the Trustee, and which they are bound by law to devote to a special object.

YOUNG LADY MISSING,--In our advertising columns will be found a notice of the disappearance from her home in Rye of a young lady, named Miss EMILY THOMPSON. She is supposed to have come to New-York on Saturday, while laboring under a temporary aberration of mind. Her family are naturally in the greatest distress, and will be under the greatest obligations to any persons who can give them information concerning her.

The Board of Education did not hold its usual regular meeting last night, owing to the absence of a quorum. On account, however, of the general interest felt in the subject, we publish the following report, which was to have been made by the Committee on the By-Laws, in regard to the power of the Board to enforce the use of the Bible in the schools;

Hon. HENRY BEDINGER, Ex-Minister to Denmark, died suddenly at his residence in Shepherdstown, Va., on the 26th of November. He returned home from Europe a few weeks ago, in good health and partook of a complimentary dinner tendered him by his fellow-citizens. Mr. BEDINGER was formerly a member of Congress, and distinguished for the ability and energy he brought to the discharge of public duties.

DEPARTURE OF THE WESTERNPORT FOR PARAGUAY.--The United States steamer Westernport, for Paraguay, steamed from the Navy-yard this morning at 5 o'clock, and discharged her pilot off the Highlande at 8 o'clock. She was going off then, under steam and canvas, about nine knots, with the wind from the northwest.

HAYTI.--The brig Santiago of Plymouth, Capt. Hadley, at Boston from Aux Cayes, reports having touched at Inagua for men, the crew being all sick, Mr. JAMES NICKERSON, mate, of Provincetown, died at Aux Cayes, Oct. 28, aged 26 years. The Santiago has been under short sail most of the time for the last fifteen days.

The steamship Europa arrived at Boston early yesterday morning. Her mails were forwarded by the train which reached this City late last evening. We add to the summary already received by telegraph. The Schastopol, Captain DAWSON, arrived at Queenstown, from Callao, reports on the 7th September, in lat. 29?? S., long. 29?? W., she picked up a ship's longboat, not bearing any name.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MOZART'S "NOZEE di Figaro" was given here last night for the third and last time. The performance was an excellent one in every respect. Mile, POINSOT, who was announced to appear on Friday in MEYERBEER'S "Huguenots," strongly supported by the best members of the company, will not make her debut until Saturday, owing to the continued indisposition of Signor TAMARO. The "Traviata" is announced for Friday.

In Detroit, Mich., on Nov. 25, an Irishman named MICHAEL McNAMARA, a sailor, living on the south side of Franklin-street, between St, Autoine and Hastings streets, made a deliberate attempt to cut the throats of his wife and step-daughter, the latter a girl about 16 years old, with a razor, and succeeded in infecting several very serious wounds on the neck, head and hands of each, the girl suffering much the most severely.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Fatigued, exhausted and almost discouraged, we make this last appeal for public and through your columns to the sympathics of your readers. Our desires are in behalf of a poor family who have seen better days, but are now oppressed by extreme poverty. They have neither food or fuel, their rent is in arrears, although only for one month;

WRANGLINGS IN THE DEMOCRATIC RANKS.The dissensions of our City Democracy are notorious. There seems to be very little harmony among the illustrious leaders of the Administration forces, and their remarks about each other are the reverse of complimentary.

The Paris Presse of November 13 devotes its feuilleton to the subject of a Ship Canal through Nicaragua. The Presse, it will be remembered, is the property of that M. MELLAUD who is the leading grantee of the recent French contract, and the present article is a review of a brochure of M. BELLY, just issued, with the title "The Opening of the Isthmus of Panama by the Canal of Nicaragua.

The talk of the Clubs and of Westminster Hall this week has been more about Sir JOHN YOUNG'S confidential dispatches, and how they came to be published, than about any other topic which floats upon the surface of attention.

COMPLIMENTARY DINNER TO MR. GIDDINGS-The Boston friends of the Hon. JOSHUA R. GIDDINGS gave him a complimentary diner on the 1st December, at the Parker House. Senator WILSON presided, Mr. GIDDINGS made a speech reviewing his early career, his associations with JOHN QUINCY ADAMS and his Congressional experience generally.

Some citizens of the Fifteenth Ward have appised Mr. E. C. Mr. B. has written the following reply: NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Dec. 1, 1858.

THE WATER CELEBRATION.--The special Committee, having the matter in charge of recommending to the Common Council some plan to appropriately celebrate the introduction of water into the city, have had several meetings, but, thus far, they have not decided upon what they shall recommend. It is understood, however, that one of the features will be a fountain in the City Hall Park.

Before Judge Nelson. THE SLAVER HAIDEE--MOTION TO DISCHARGE. A motion was made this morning by Mr. Joachimsen, counsel for the crew of the slaver Hundec, that the men be discharged from custody, on the ground that, as all the facts which the Government must prove to convict the prisoners under the other indictments against them had been proved on their previous trial, they could not be tried under the other indictments.

THE HON. ISAAC I. STEVENS ON THE GEOGRAPHY OF THE NORTHWEST.-At the regular meeting of the Geographical Society at the Historical Society's building, in Second-avenue, corner of Eleventh-street, the lion. ISAAC I. STEVENS, Ex-Governor of Washington Territory, delivered an interesting address on "The Geographical Features of the Northwestern Territories."

The Tribune devotes a column to the demonstration of a point which no man has ever thought of doubting. It proves conclusively that the Republican Party was organized to prevent the extension of Slavery into free Territories of the United States. It quotes from its resolutions and addresses, and gives copious references to its history, to establish that fact.

The youthful Grand Dukes, NICHOLAS and MICHAEL--brothers of the Emperor--continue their travels in the southeastern part of the Empire. They were, at last accounts, at Poti, a city on the borders of the Caucasus, every day increasing in population and importance. The young Princes arrived on board the steamer Taman, and were received at the landing by Prince BARIATINSKY, Lieutenant of the Emperor in the Caucasus, and by repeated salutes of artillery.

Tile French have always excelled in imaginative literature. Of one of the latest efforts we reproduce some notice in another column, wherein the scheme of a Nicaragua Shipcanal, of which Mr. FELIX BELLY is the allthor, is congenially appreciated.

A grand gathering of Italian refugees have followed to the grave the funeral at Montinartre of Col. Gallieno. late commandant of the National Guard at Rome. He led 2,000 of that militia into Lombardy against Nugent, whom he encountered under the walls of Vicenza. He subsequently took part in the city's defence against oudinot.

A brilliant fele, designed by Mr. SICKLES' friends to testify their gratification at his recent triumph as a candidate for Congress in the Third Congressional District, occurred last night in Niblo's Saloon. There was a large concouse of ladles and gentlemen-many of the latter well known by their public station or professional ability.

The ease of a young lady in a trance is narrated In the Boston Journal. The name of the girl is unknown. She took passage on the Fall River Railroad cars a day or two ago, complained of illness and was left at Bridgewater, where she took lodgings at a hotel. As she did not appear the next morning the landlord went to her room and knocked, but received no answer.

MOTT--??EN,--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 30, by the Rev. Stephen II. Tyng, D. D., JAMES S. MOTT to EMMA A., daughter of Joseph G. Allen, Esq., of Fairfield, Conn. EVERDELL-EWBANK.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 30, at St. ?? Church, by the Rev. Stephen H. Tyng, D. D., HENRY BYERDELL to MARY H., daughter of Thomas Ewbonk, Esq., all of this City.

WOODWARD.--In this City, on Wednesday, Dec. 1, SARAH N. ZABRISKIE, wife of James L. Woodward, aged 30 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the Reformed Dutch Church, (the Rev. Dr. Van Zandt's,) 9th-st., on Saturday, 4th inst., at 9 1/2 o'clock A. M., precisely, without further invitation. The remains will be taken to Hackensack N. J., for interment.

The funeral of the late BENJAMIN F. BUTLER took place yesterday afternoon at the Mercer-street Presbyterian Church, of which he was formerly a member. Soon after 3 o'clock the funeral cortege, headed by the officiating clergy, Drs. SPRAGUE, ADAMS, BETHUNE and SKINNER, entered the Church. Among the more distinguished members of the bar following, were Judges BETTE, VANDERPOOL and MASON, and the From, JOHN VAN BUREN.

The Board of Councilmen met last evening. A petition was presented from the property-owners on Hammersley-street, to have Houston street continued on to the North River, and to have the same renumbered. Referred to the Committee on Roads. Mr. ARCULARIUS offered the following resolution on Street-cleaning, which was adopted:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I observe under the above head a notice that the estimates of the expenditures of the Board for the year 1859, amount to $827,670--being an average of upwards of $100 for each pauper in the Almshouse.

The trial of the sixty-two indicted Ex-City officials, including Ex-Mayor WOOD, which was to have commenced yesterday, was put off till the next term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, in consequence of an insufficiency of Jurors. Only seventeen Jurors answered to their names, while not less than three hundred would have been necessary, as each of the defendants has the right of five peremptory challenges.

The apathy with which the Charter Election, to take place on Tuesday, is anticipated by the mass of our citizens, scarcely accords with the complaints which are so liberally made at other seasons touching the misgovernment of the City, the extravagant squandering of the public money, and the gross corruption which pervades the Corporation.

In another part of this paper a correspondent sets forth a highly intelligent appreciation of the state of affairs in Mexico. In ascribing the entire situation to the influence of a Church, defending itself against the encroachments of enlightened liberalism, he advances no novel position, but he verifies it by various historical facts and data, which give the point the prominence it deserves.

To people of imperfect sympathies, going to hear the Rev. Mr. KALLOCH preach on Thanks-giving Day may not appear the jolliest possible way of keeping the great New-England festival. But tastes differ; and for myself I could not conscientiously have said that my name was McGregor, not withstanding my feet were on my native heather, if I had neglected the custom of my Puritan progenitors and not gone to meeting before eating my roast turkey.

The resolutions touching the Slave-trade which have been introduced into the South Carolinian Legislature, and which that body has thought worthy of reference to the Committee on Federal Relations, furnish a fresh instance of that disposition to play the fool which we have often remarked as one of the prominent characteristics in these latter days of too many deliberative bodies in the South.
