In obedience to the order of the Editor-in-Chief, I undertook to "to go about" among the amusements, and describe such of them as were not habitually "done up" under the regular head, In order that the renders of the TIMES might learn how the great mass of our People,--the mechanics, laborers, and others who earn their living by work,--secure that relaxation and amusement which, in some form or other, seems a necessity for every class.

From the London Times, 17th. The details of a grievance said to have been sustained lately by the Haytian Government at the hands of the Washington Cabinet have just transpired, and seem not without importance, although the case will probably be found to have arisen from the absence of sufficient explanations.

The Moniteur publishes the following report received by the Minister of Marine from Vice - Admiral RIGAULT DE GENOUILLY, the Commander - in - Chief of the expedition in China : BAY OF TOURANE, Sept, 17, 1858. MONSIEUR LE MINISTRE : I have the honor to inform you that the orders of the Emperor have been executed as regards the capture and occupation of the forts of Taron.

Superintendent F. W. LANDER, of the United States Overland Wagon Road Expedition arrived here yesterday from the Rocky Mountains, and we are enabled to lay before our readers valuable information of this important route, the more difficult mountain sections of which have been explored, surveyed and carried to completion during the contingencies of the Mormon war.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : In the TIMES of this morning, in an article headed "Interesting to Policemen," it is stated that the "Importers' and Traders' Bank refuse peremptorily to make an advances under the existing state of affairs." This statement does us some injustice. We received from the Police Department the following letter the day of its date:

Mr. A. R. CORBIN will leave here in the afternoon train to-morrow, for St. Louis, in charge of the Message and Cabinet reports, to be forwarded by overland express to California. The message will fill eighteen columns of the Union, while most of the reports are unusually short. The President will recommend the ratification of the Cass-Herran Treaty, as now modified.

SCHOOL COMMISSIONER FOR THE NINETEENTH WARD.--Mr. M. A. REED, the Republican candidate for School Commissioner in the Nineteenth Ward, has written a letter to one of the Committee accepting the nomination, declaring his earnest desire for the welfare of the schools, and his conviction that the daily leading of the Bible in them is essential to their usefulness.

Yesterday afternoon the pupils of the Public Schools met at the Cooper Institute, in considerable numbers, to receive the medals awarded them for excellence displayed at the late Fair in Drawing and Penmanship. PETER COOPER, Esq., presided. After the reading of a portion of Scripture by W. J. HASKETT, Esq., Mr. NELSON, the President of the Board of Education, made a few remarks.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: It may be safely assumed that the time for the discussion of the "Mexican question" has filly arrived. Its solution seems likely to be speedily forced upon us. But are we at all prepared to decide wisely under the delicate and important interests involved?
At Mobile, Nov. 26, Judge CAMPBELL delivered his charge to the Grand Jury of the United States Circuit Court of the Mobile Judicial Circuit, in relation to the fillibustering movements.

The past fortnight has boon eventful for the present eventful times in Mexico. Events have crowded one another with such astounding rapidity that the population of this capital are prepared to hear any new atrocity without expressing surprise. The consoling exclamation, which has so long soothed us, that " things cannot get worse," is now being dropped.

Before Judge Nelson In the case of Smith vs. Higgins, which has been on trial for several days, Judge NELSON this morning delivered his charge to the Jury; the case having been summed up yesterday. The Jury retired, but had not agreed upon a verdict up to the adjournment of the Court.
The mail steamship Tennessee, from Vera Cruz on the 22d November, furnishes us with files from that city to that day, and correspondence from the capital to Nov. 18. The news is of unusual interest.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The people of this misgoverned and overtaxed City are called upon to select on Tuesday next one of three gentlemen now in nomination for the office of Comptroller of the City of New-York-an office more important to the various interests of this City than the heads of all the Departments put together.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Permit me to return to you and others the sincere and hearty thanks of the poor family for whom the "Appeal to the Benevolent for Aid" was made in your paper of yesterday. Several kindhearted gentlemen and ladies came foward promptly to their relief. The heart of the father, mother and four little children were made glad by the provision so soon and cheerfully made for them.

At Mozart Hall, this evening, our Jewish fellow-citizens will hold a mass meeting, to which they have invited members of all other denominations who concur with them in denouncing the abduction of MORTARA'S child by the Inquisition.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The "Traviata" was performed here last night to a full house. It was a fine performance, and elicited much applause. To-night Mlle. POINSOT, a distinguished European artiste who has won not only the approbation of a variety of publics, but of MEYERDEER, an exigeant composer, makes her debut in the " Huguenots."
Among the contents of THE WEEKLY TIMES for the current week are the following: LITERARY.--A Paradoxical Experiment-A Story of the London Market-Miscellaneous Extracts-Literary Reviews.

THE MORTARA CASE IN CHARLESTON--A meeting of the Israelites of Charleston, S. C., convened at the Masonic Hall, on Tuesday evening, Nov. 30, in pursuance of a call through the public papers. The meeting was organized by the appointment of SAMUEL HART, Sr., Esq., President; JOSHUA LAZARUS and ISAAG S. COHEN, Esq., Vice-Presidents; and NATHANIEL LEIN, Esq., Secretary. ary.

MANSON.--In this City, on Friday, Dec. 3. RACHEL GRAY. youngest child of William and Rachel Manson, aged 10 months and 28 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, at the residence of his parents, corner of Spring and Varick sts., this day, (Saturday,) at 2 o'clock I'. M. His remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

At the time of the Emperor ALEXANDER'S visit to Moscow, two months ago, I mentioned the fact the fact His Majesty had received the principal nobles of that important Department of the Empire, and had addressed them on the subject of the great reform he has undertaken.

From the " List of Books that are Books," CHARLES LAMN - the most whimsical, but not for that the least reasonable of critics - remorselessly excluders all gift - books, annuals, and editions deluxe, relegating them to the same limbo with dictionaries and gazetteers, almanacs and guide - books.

THE STATE ARSENAL AND THE CITY ARMORY.-In the year 1854 Mr. SAMUEL GRAHAM, Colonel of the Seventieth Regiment. New-York State Militia, then an Alderman representing a part of the Seventh Ward, urged upon the attention of the city authorities the necessity of building a suitable place for keeping the State arms, for which they are responsible.

The City of New York is always in some kind of difficulty :--social, as at the garroting period,--political, as during the squabbles of various contestants for the office of Street Commissioner,-or financial, as now when there is no money with which to pay the Police.

Attentive readers of our real estate reports cannot fail to have noticed a remarkable advance in prices during the last three or four months. The rise is chiefly noticeable in the vicinity of the new Central Park. But it is not confined to that vicinity.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am informed that there is every prospect of the Skating Pond on the Central Park being in condition this month for flooding and freezing, weather permitting. Will you allow me to ask through your columns where this pond is situated, and how it is best got at?

Mr. Clark Mills has nearly finished the plaster cast of the equestrian statue of Washington, for which he received the commission from Congress. The casting will be speedily commenced, and, when finished, the statue will be placed at the corner of Massachusetts and New-York avenues, Washington.

Mr. STAUNTON, who has hitherto enjoyed the Championship of Chess in England, has published the following letter, in response to Lord LYTTLETON'S letter to Mr. MORPHY, which we published a few days since. It speaks for itself. Our English friends were quite reconciled to the notion of Mr. STAUNTON'S being beaten at chess by an American, but they have evinced some natural and very creditable surprise at his lamentable lack of courtesy and manliness.

The conflicting accounts received respecting the movements of the two steamers recently dispatched from this port with passengers for California-the Hermann via Cape Horn, and the Washington to San Juan del Norte, to connect with the Hermann at San Juan del Sur, has excited some public curiosity, and no little anxiety among those who have friends among their passengers.

INGRAHAM--CHAMBERS.--In this City, on Friday, Dec. 3, at the parsonage of the Green-st. M. E. Church, by the Rev. Wm. P. Corbit, Dr. DUNCAN INGRAHAM, of Charleston, S. C, to Miss ELIZA CHAMBERS, of Cornwell, Eng. THOMSON--ROGERS.--In this City, on Wednesday, Dec. 1, at the prebyterian Church, Lennox-place, by the Rev, Dr. Smith, CHARLES THOMSON to JOSEPHINE, daughter of James E. Rogers, all of this City.

In spite of the apparent indifference, there is really a good deal of interest felt in the result of our City Election. A very large proportion of our citizens begin to feel the necessity of electing men of decent intelligence and of common honesty to the various offices of responsibility and trust in our City Government.

Mr. EDWARDS, brother-in-law of Lieut, BEALE, passed through here to day, having left BEALE'S party on the 16th November, beyond the Choctaws' trading post, 250 miles west of Fort Smith. They had no difficulty with the Indians, as stated, nor had they gone into Winter quarters, but were pursuing the labors of the Expedition.

The Autocrat of the Breakfast-table never uttered a truer or a wittier sentence than when he said that if you took the tire of all creation for a crowbar you could not pry out of the mind of a Bostonian the belief that the State-house on Beacon Hill was the hub of the Universe.
The telegraph reports that the President's fourthcoming Message will make eighteen columns of the TIMES! If this be true, Mr. BUCHANAN really abuses his privilege.

THE REV. DR. HALL'S LECTURE AT THE BUTGER'S INSTITUTE.--On Wednesday evening the Rev. Dr. BAYNARD R. HALL, of Brooklyn, delivered a lecture at the Chapel of the Rutgers' Female Institute, on the them, "Words are Things." This theme was philosophically discussed, with just discrimination and great beauty of thought and expression.

There was quite a large gathering of " the people" at Hildebrand's Hall, in Hester-street, near the Bowery, last evening, called together by the following characteristic advertisement: Fourteenth Ward.--Gibraltar on deck! Democrats of the old Fourteenth don't fail to attend the Grand Mass Ratification Meeting at Hildebrand's in Hesterstreet to-night.

Virginia Democratic State Convention. NOMINATION OF MR. JOHN LETCHER FOR GOVERNOR. PETERSBURG, Va., Friday, Dec. 3-12 P. M. Mr. PRYOR has made a speech amid tremendous applause. He was followed b Mr. WM. M. TREDWAY for LETCHER, and Mr. O. JENNINGS WISE, also for LETCHER. The latter was speaking at 10 o'clock.

The general indignation which the Mortara affair has excited in the minds of all classes and creeds in this community, found enthusiastic expression in the meeting of our Hebrew fellow-citizens held on Saturday evening.

The United States Mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCH, Esq., Commander, from New-Orleans by the way of Havana, arrived yesterday at this port. The Cahawba left Havana on Nov. 30, to which date we have received our files.

BLIFFENS--MUNSON.--COOLEY--BURSLEY.--In this City, on Wednesday, Dec. 1, at the residence of Capt. Isaac Bursley, No. 32 East 28th-st., by the Rev. Gen. Lucas, Capt. THOS. V. BLIFFENS to ELIZABETH S. MUNSON. Also, by the same, and at the same time and place, EARL K. COOLEY to LOUISA G., daughter of Capt. Isaac Bursley, all of this City.

PROVIDENTIAL ESCAPE.--The Washington Union is exceedingly gratified that the TIMES displeases the Tribune, and feels quite inclined to be particularly civil and patronizing towards us. It does not see, however, that the TIMES has " delighted the Democrats very much," although it has offended the Republicans: and it, accordingly, prefers to "wait a little before inviting us to Democratic retreats."

IN WATER-STREET.--Last evening, at 8 1/4 o'clock, a fire broke out in the building No. 245 Water-street, occupied by VANDERPOOL, DICKERSON Co., Importers of tin plates, sheet iron, wire, but having been discovered at an early moment, was soon extinguished, though not, however, before considerable damage was done by water.

There are various types of human perfection, as various as the definitions of human character. The model man of Wall-street. for instance, would be that hero--as yet unborn--who, though a long life of barberism, should never once himself be shaved, and the shortand long of whose life should balance themselves exactly with all the changes of the cotemporaneous stock market.

Public attention is mainly turned towards Washington. Congress meetsto-day, and our readers are tolerably certain of being able to read the Message to-morrow morning. We are happy to say, moreover, that its length is likely to be somewhat less formidable than was apprehended. Its eighteen columns have dwindled down to ten.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MEYERBEER'S opera of the " Huguenots" was revived hero on Saturday for the purpose of introducing Mile. POINSOT to an American audience. The lady debuted in the role of Valentine, and achieved a thoroughly complete success, merited alike as a vocalist and as an actress. With a pure soprano organ, and an education rarely finished, Mile.

A FAST YOUTH SAILING UNDER FALSE COLOR.--A decidedly dressy and engaging young man bad a very fine and dashing time for several days last week at the Metropolitan Hotel, representing himself to be the son of the Hon. Erastus Corning, of Albany.

AN ALARMING PIECE OF INFORMATION--At a meeting of the friends of Mr. RUSSELL, the candidate for the Comptrollership, on Saturday night, Ex-Mayor WOOD made the very startling declaration that from what he knew of the office during his term of service as Mayor, the Comptroller of the City could easily pocket a hundred thousand dollars of the public money annually without being detected.

CIVIL SIDE. December Term commences to-day at the City Hall, in the Supreme Court, for the First Judicial District of the State of New-York, (composed of New-York City,) in the Superior Court of the City of New-York, and in the Court of Common Pleas for the City and County of New-York. Besides these there are the Marine Court, open every day except Sunday, and the Surrogate's Court, which have no specific Terms.

DEATH OF A COLORED WOMAN--SUSPICIONS OF FOUL PLAY.--MARY A. CROSBY, an aged colored woman, who lived at No. 535 Broome-street, died suddenly on Saturday. An inquest was held and a verdict rendered, ascribing death to natural causes.

An independent political Press is of some service, after all. That it may be useful in checking the extravagancies of ultra partisans themselves, we have striking proof in the effect of our strictures upon the Tribune. That energetic and impulsive Republican organ was riding the high horse of Abolition at a fearful pace, only a week ago.

There was quite a large gathering, in Milman's Hall corner of Twenty-sixth-street and Seventh-avenue, on Saturday evening, called together for the purpose of ratifying the "People's and Regulars'" nominations, and to listen to a speech from FERNANDO WOOD.

VARICK,--In this City, on Saturday, Dec. 4, RICHARD VARICK, son of the late Abraham Varick, in the 42d year of his age. His friends, and those of his family, are invited to attend the funeral. from his late residence, No. 116 West 11th-st., this day, (Monday,) at 91/2 o'clock A.M., without further notice.

DARING HIGHWAY ROBBERY.--On Friday afternoon last Mr. WILLIAM BENNET, of Brooklyn, while riding over the Myrtle-avenue Plank Road with his wife, was stopped by three Irishmen near the turnpike gate, and his money demanded. A pistol was held to the head of Mr. BENNET to enforce a compliance with the demand.

MEETING OF THE FRIENDS OF THE LATE ROBERT OWEN.--On Sunday afternoon, in pursuance of a call in the newspapers, a number of persons assembled at No. 72 White-street, for the purpose of taking measures to perpetuate the memory of the late ROBERT OWEN. O. C. HALL occupied the Chair. B. WARDEN,

Senator DOUGLAS is making speeches on his Southern journey. It is a hazardous business for a Presidential candidate, but he enters upon it with his characteristic pluck and frankness. We publish one that he made in Memphis, Tennessee. It contains nothing specially new, and is chiefly noticeable for the fidelity with which he adheres to the same views there which he had put forth in Illinois.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of yesterday, two Evening School scholars complain that one of their mates, who is a very meritorious artist, did not receive a medal. The answer to this is, that the Evening School Scholars were not entitled by the By-Law in relation to the exhibition to compete with the Grammar Schools. This is wrong, but it is the law.

SENATE SANITARY COMMITTEE.--The Sanitary Committee met at 3 P. M. yesterday in the City Li brary, and listened to a statement from Lieut. EGBERT L. VIELE with regard to the existing evils in the management of the sanitary affairs of the City and their remedy. He said the health of a particular locality depended on its topography and not on its latitude.

THE JUVENILE HOUSE OF INDUSTRY.--The first anniversary of this institution was celebrated at the building, in Flatbush, yesterday afternoon, by a variety of exercises on the part of the children, to show their progress under the system of training here adopted.

It is nearly two years since we heard a gentleman, then and now holding one of the most honorable and lucrative appointments under President BUCHANAN, remark of that distinguished man, that he was a very moral and a very pious person,-and that his principal failing was a constitutional inability to tell the truth.

The steamship General Rusk, from Brazos 30th ult., brings news from Mexico favorable to the Liberals. ZULOAGA was about to decamp. The Liberals were in favor of a treaty with the United States for the extradition of slaves and criminals. WASHINGTON, Monday, Dec. 6. New-Orleans papers of Thursday last are received, containing Mexican news.

Fellow-Citizens of the Senate and House of Representatives: When we compare the condition of the country at the present day with what it was one year ago, at the meeting of Congress, we have much reason for gratitude to that Almighty Providence, which has never failed to interpose for our relief, at the most critical period of our history.

The Secretary of State has issued a call for the Board of State Canvassers to meet in this city on the 15th inst., to determine the official canvass and award the certificates of election. The Board consists of the Secretary of State, the Comptroller, the Attorney-General, the Treasurer and State Engineer.

The schooner Wm. C. Eliason, of Philadelphia BUCKALOO, from Wilmington, N. C., for Boston, with a cargo of 1,300 bbls, resin, 215 bbls. spirits of turpentine and 237 bales cotton, went ashore at 8 P. M. on the 5th, on Charlestown (R. I.) beach, between Point Judith and Watchill, and, it is feared, will prove a total loss.

The Second Session of the Thirty-fifth Congress commenced yesterday. On assembling, at 12 o'clock, fifty Senators answered to their names, and about two hundred members of the House. After the usual preliminaries, the President's Message was delivered, in the Senate at 1:40 P. M., and in the House at 2 o'clock P. M.

It is purely a matter of domestic concern, and the vote of every man should be given for domestic reasons.

The Overland Mail, with San Francisco dates to the 9th ultimo, arrived at St. Louis last night. It was twenty-five days out. Three through passengers came with it. The road from San Francisco to the boundary of Texas was in good condition. The mail party saw no indications of hostile Indians.

WARD, of Texas, and CLingman, of North Carolina, were presented. On motion of Mr. Gwin, of California, the House was notified that the Senate is ready to proceed to business.

No public sales to-day. There has been, for a few days past, a current street report of the sale of 106 lots above Yorkville. As we understand it, on or about the year 1850 Mr. GALE bought the lots hereinafter-mentioned for $60 per lot--total, say $6,360. He sold them last week to FRANCIS P. FURNALD for $51,000. Mr. FURNALD immediately turned round and resold them for $67,000, being an advance of $16,000.

A NEGRO WHIPPED TO DEATH -- An atrocious murder was recently perpetrated in Northumberland County, Va., under the following circumstances, as narrated by the Alexandria Sentinel: "There had been a party of persons engaged in trafficing with servants for stolen goods, and they carried it to such an extent that the community, in self-defence, determined to put a stop to it.

CANADA INDIGNANT.--Great excitement exists at Port Huron, Mich., in consequence of the shooting of Capt. JONES, of the brig Concord, by Deputy U. S. Marshal TYLER, of Detroit. The evidence taken at the Coroner's Inquest goes to show that the vessel was in British waters at the time the homicide was committed.

Our Administration seems to be anything, but a unit on the Tariff. The curious anomaly is presented of a direct hostility of sentiment between the President and one of his Cabinet, upon a vital question of legislation. While Mr. BUCHANAN urges specific duties, Mr. COBB devotes his energies, such as they are, to refuting his argument.

The Standing Committees of the House will be announced on Thursday, to which time an adjournment took place, to enable the Speaker meanwhile to arrange them. According to usage, the Committees of the First Session are continued to the Second, with such alterations as may be necessary to fill vacancies. The Democrats generally in the House to-day voted against laying the resolution to repeal the ClaytonBulwer treaty on the table.

This is the season of Apache incursions into our country. They commenced their work of murdering and stealing about two weeks ago by murdering a Mexican within half a mile of Tueson. He was an oldish man, and was watching a pile of wheat. The Indians attacked him about daylight, shooting thirteen arrows into him, stealing only an old musket.

ACCIDENT AT SOUTH FFRRY.--The steamboat Atlantic, when arriving at her dock on the NewYork side, yesterday, about 2 1/2 P. M., in consequence of the engine stopping on the centre, came with great force against the bridge, tearing the planking up from the platform and severely injuring several persons standing on It, who were waiting to cross to Brooklyn.

In the City yesterday the election passed off very quietly. The vote is small, owing, in part, to the state of the weather, which was very bad, the rain falling nearly all day, and the streets being in a shocking condition. Under these unfavorable circumstances it was anticipated that PURSER would be the fortunate candidate;

Gen. CASS' letter to our Minister in Nicaragua, though written in July last, will still be read with interest. It is a clear and strong statement of our attitude towards the Isthmus, and of the rights and duties which that attitude involves. A considerable portion of it is devoted to the extraordinary manifesto signed by the Presidents of Nicaragua and Costa Rica, and published in connection with the Belly contract.

SIR: The serious causes of complaint existing on the part of the United States against the Governmentsof Nicaragua and Costa Rica, have already been made known to you, and you have received the necessary instruction to demand of those Governments prompt and ample reparation for the injuries for which they are responsible.

The commercial says: "Fourteen years ago HARLOW CASE was a respectable and esteemed citizen of Buffalo. He held the place of Assistant Postmaster under Mr. DORSHEIMER, and was for many years intrusted with the more important duties of the office.

The Charter Election, which was held in this City yesterday, passed off very quietly. There was little or no disturbance in any of the Wards-a fact which may be partly attributed to the rainy weather, and pertly to the fact that the rowdy portion of the population were outnumbered at the polls. A very small number of persons, as compared with former elections, were arrested for illegal voting.

Prof. Neumann, the orientalist, of Munich, writes to the Illinois Steats Zeitung that he is disgusted with European Governments, under which an independent man can neither speak, write nor act as he pleases and that but for his advanced years (60) he should emigrate to the United States. He adds: "Even arts and science form only a part of our slavery.

CONFESSION AND EXECUTION OF WM. SCHWITZER AT GOSHEN. At Goshen, New-York, Dec. 3, WM. SCHWITZER alias SANDERS, was hung for the murder of a fellowservantn amed SHORK. The murder was committed at a farm-house near Goshen, and the murderer wounded a female servant: jealousy being the cause of the assault.

From the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury it appears that on the Ist of July, 1857, being the commencement of the fiscal year 1858, the balance in tile Treasury was $17,710,114 27. Tile receipts into the Treasury during the fiscal year 1858 were $70,273,860 59; and the aggregate means, therefore, for the service of the fiscal year ending June 30, 1858. were $87,983,983 86.

Mr. WILSON gave notice of his intention to introdue a bill to appropriate one million acres of the public lands for the support of the free public Schools of the District of Columbia. Mr. GWIN moved to take up the Pacific Railroad bill, but Mr. PEARCE objecting that the motion was not in order, Mr. GWIN notified the Senate that he would call it up at an early day.

Mrs. Mary A. Bennett, recalled.--Direct examination--While living at New-Rochelle, in 1850, one washing-day, I prepared the dinner. When we sat down Doctor was not pleased with it. We had mashed potatoes. Doctor took them on his fork and threw them at me across the table: also swore at me. In the Spring of '56, at the George-street House, my children had scarlet fever. I wanted a physician.

GENERA, ORDERS NO. 21-1.--In pursuance of General Orders No. 21, from the Headquarters of the Army, the portion of tile First Cavalry at Fort Leavenworth is assigned to posts as follows: Captain Desaussure's Company F, and Captain Steu art's Company K to Fort Riley, under tile command of Major Sedgwick: Captain Sackett's Company B. and Captain Beall's Company A to Fort Smith; Captain Wood's Company C and Captain Carr's Company I to Fort Washita.

Before Judge Betts. The December term of this Court was opened this morning in the new court-room. The room had not been entirely fitted up, there being no carpet on the floor, and Judge BETTS stated to the liar that there would be no contested cases taken up until Thursday, to give time to the Marshal to complete the furnishing of the room.

?? statesmen find no so calm retreat as the Historical Socioty Rooms. We have seen before now the defeated candidate for the People's Suffrages turn in to its cool alcoves and quiet lecture room, and in listening to the papers, out of whose folds and wrinkles came a very ancient sternutatory dust as read by some zealous antiquarian, find healing balm for his wounds political.

There is hope of our City Government after all. The election yesterday resulted in the election of ROBERT T. HAWS to be Comptroller, by a very decisive and satisfactory majority. Something of this result is due to the split in the ranks of the Democratic Party. For once FERNANDO WOOD has rendered a substantial service to the City.

The abstract of the Report of the Secretary of the Navy, which we published yesterday, shows a patriotic, even if extravagant, reliance upon the ability of our Navy to meet that of any other Power. .The English abandonment of the right of search is attributed to our demonstration of naval force in the Gulf of Mexico.

The Overland Mail has arrived, with San Francisco dates of the 7th ultimo. Five passengers came through. The United States Coast Surveying brig Fauntleroy arrived at San Francisco, from the Gulf of Georgia, on the 5th. The bark Marina, the pioneer vesse of the Tekuantepec line, left San Francisco for Ventosa on the 6th with a number of passengers.

The Grand Jury was in session several days last week. The following witnesses were examined: Mr. SANDFORD, Collector of the Port; Mr. SMITH, Deputy Collector; General WALKER, JULIUS HESSE and WILLIAM A. SMITH. General WALKER was before the Jury about six hours, and was Interrogated as to his course of life In California, Sonora and Nicaragua. No bill was found on Friday.

BOARD OF EDUCATION--THE EVENING SCHOOLS. -A regular meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Education was held last evening, President SMITH in the Chair. The School. book Committee, to whom was referred the subject of text-books necessary for the use of the Public Schools, made a report recommending the adoption of the list of text-books: Cards, Primmers, Spellers, Readers, Arithmetics, Geography,

REDUCTION OF BRAZILIAN TARIFF ON FLOUR.--Through the efforts of the State Department for amelioration of the duty of Flour in Brazil, an imperial decree has been issued, reducing it 30 per centum below the former tariff. This is considered an important concession, form the fact that there has been here to fore a large balance against the United States ?? of the extensive importations of Coffee.

Three inquests were held yesterday. JOHN B. WILLIAMSON, who resided in Fourth-street near First-avenue, suddenly dropped while in a slaughter-house, dead from disease of the heart. ANN DONOVAN, a child four years old, whose parents reside at No. II Vandewater-street,died from her clothes accidentally taking fire from the stove.

BLANCHARD, of Poughkeepsie, to NATHANIEL FLEMING, of this City. KNAPP--WAINWRIGHT.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 30, at the residence of the bride's father's. JACOB F. THE DELAWAR RESERVE.--A rumor is afloat, says the Leavenworth Herald, that the Delawares are about to form another treaty, and cede a large portion of their valuable lands to the Government. How it originated we do not know.

We copy the following from the Montrcal Daily Transcript of Tuesday. Accounts which have reached us through another source of the conflict between the Crow and Sioux Indians, create some doubt as to the melancholy result said to have attended that conflict.:

The steamship City of Washington left Liverpool for New-York on the 24th of November, and was considered as due here on the 6th inst. The Persia left Liverpool on the 26th of November, and is now twelve days out; she is consequently fully due, making all necessary allowance for stormy weather on the Atlantic.

The President has declared his intention of keeping the peace in Central America, by protesting the transit routes over the Isthmus, as well from the bad faith of the Central Amerlcan Governments, as from the violence of filibustering adventurers.

We are enabled this morning to publish a correct list of the principal Municipal officers elected on Tuesday. ROBERT T. HAWS, the Opposition nominee for Comptroller, has a majority, as we stated yesterday, of 13,751 over PURSER, and of 1,835 over both the Democratic candidates.

The Herald is exceedingly boastful over its superior " enterprise" in publishing the President's Message in advance of its neighbors. It has a perfect right to exult. Its peculiar style of enterprise was never better illustrated or more successful. If there is any news to be obtained in the duo course of fair competition, tile Herald is always behind hand.

KING--REMSEN.--In this City, on Tuesday, Dec. 7, by the Rev. M. S. Hatton, D. D., JAMES S. KING to CORNELIA, daughter of Henry R. Remsen, Esq., of this City. SCHMIDT--POLLEN.--On Wednesday, Dec. 8, by the Rev. Robt, Travis, Jr., D. D., F. LEOPOLD SCHMIDT to MELENDA, daughter of Geo, P. Pollen, Esq.

THE CONVICT SNOWERED TO DEATH IN AUBURN STATE PRISON.--The Auburn Advertiser publishes the testimony taken at the Coroner's Inquest on the body of SAMUEL MOORS, the convict who died recently in Auburn State Prison, while undergoing the punishment of the shower-bath. JOHN T. BAKER, a keeper in the Prison, testified that MOORE was kept in the shower-bath from half to three quarters of an hour.

The telegraph of last night announced a disaster to the bark Parthian, which sailed from Richmond, Va., on the 1st November, for Rio de Janeiro, with a large number of workmen engaged by Messrs. HAWEY, HARRAH Co., contractors on the Don Pedro Railroad, in Brazil.

The steamer Quaker City has arrived here with California dates of the 20th ult., received via the Tehuantepec route. She brings 80 passengers. Business continued to improve at San Francisco. Eight ships had arrived there during the fortnight from Atlantic ports. [Mem.--Our New-Orleans Correspondent does not give us the name of any of these vessels.--New-York Rep.]

A letter from Senator Sumner, received by a gentleman in Washington, says: " My Summer, down to the close of August, was most painful and harrass ing. My sufferings were complicated. There seemed to be hardly an ache or smart in nature which did not visit me, and at times with an intensity which was overpowering. But now I am comfortable.

We have been so accustomed to friendly visits from Philadelphia firemen, that the arrival of a new company with their glazed hats and gorgeously gilded capes has ceased to cause any undue excitement in our streets; but a visit by a deputation of Philadelphia Aldermen is so unusual an event that it will naturally create some stir among our municipal authorities.

Mr. BUCHANAN insists upon the removal of Judge DOUGLAS from the Chairmanship of the Territorial Committee, and the impression to-day, is, that it will be done, and GREEN, of Missouri, promoted to the position. The friends of Mr. DOUGLAS do not object to his removal. It will benefit him, in their impression. It is understood that if the attempt thus to overslaugh DOUGLAS should be persevered in, to-morrow there will be a grand row.

ILLEGAL VOTING.--Six persons were arrested for attempting to vote illegally on election day, in addition to those reported in yesterday's TIMES. Four of the six were arrested in the Sixth Ward. The latter Precinct, therefore, still maintains its ascendancy in the illegal voting line.

It is nearly forty years since HALL OK, in one of his "Croakers," said or sung: "There's a barrel of porter in Tammany Hall, And the Bucktails are swigging it all the night long; In the days of my boyhood 'twas pleasant to call, For a seat and cigar 'mid the jovial throng."

The trial of THOMAS ALLIBONE and THOMAS A. NEWHALL, charged with conspiring to defraud the stockholders of the Bank of Pennsylvania, was commenced in Philadelphia, Nov. 30, in the Court of Quarter Sessions, before Judge THOMPSON. The defendants demanded separate trials, but the Court refused.

THE FILLIBUSTERS AGAIN.--Under the usual telegraphic head is an announcement that the schooner Susan, having on board 140 fillibusters bound for Nicaragua, had been stopped while attempting to leave the port of Mobile. Under the pretence of sailing on a coasting voyage, she had taken no clearance. d taken no clearance.

The United States District Court for this district, Judge SINCLAIR presiding, met on Monday last, but, in consequence of the absence of the United States District-Attorney, was again adjourned until the 15th inst. Mr. D. A. BURR was appointed Clerk of the Court, in the place of Mr. SAMUEL GILBERT, Who has resigned.

The Court met at 10 o'clock precisely. The prisoners in the slaver Echo case, sixteen in number, were brought into Court in custody of the Marshal and his assistants. The Court--Have you any return to make, Mr. Marshal ?

The steamship City of Washington, which has been considered duo at this port for a day or two past, arrived off Cape Race at 3 o'clock on Tuesday afternoon, and will not probably arrive here until Saturday. She brings advices four days' later-to the 24th ult. She had encountered a succession of westerly gales for ten days. The news by her is interesting.

Intense excitement has been occasioned at Fulton City, Ill., by an outrageous assault committed by two unknown men upon Mrs. Forest, the wife of a respectable mechanic. At the time of the assault, her cries were stifled by a cloth, thickly coated with mud, which was laid over her face. The worst of the case remains to be told.

TOOKER.--In this City, on Tuesday, Dec. 7, after a long and painful illness, ELIZA, wife of Edward B. Tooker, in the 46th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her brother, William H. Burger, No. 260 Houston St., to-morrow (Thursday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock.
I am booked here for another Winter, but fortunately with no fear of starvation this time. We have been most successful the last Summer in our Agricultural labors.

The Bible in Public Schools. A special meeting of the Board of Education, was held last evening, Commissioner NIELSON in the Chair. The School officers of the Twenty-second ward reported bids for furniture for a school-house in 44th street, which, together with an appropriation asked for the purchase of a piano, amounted to over $4,475 75.

The lion. S. A. DOUGLAS arrived at the levee about 7 1/2 o'clock last night, on the steamboat City of Memphis, which had been delayed several hours beyond the time at which he had been expected by fog on the river. Ills arrival was heralded with a grand salute, and a large crowd were on the levee to welcome him.

A MASTODON IN OHIO.--The Oleveland Leader, on the authority of a party of hunters, states that the remains of a mastodon were recently found near Clarksville, Defiance County, Ohio, in the bed of a pond that had recently been drained off. They are of enormous proportions.

The proceedings instituted in South Carolina against the crew of the brig Echo, captured by the Dolphin, have resulted in the ignoring of the bills against them by they Grand Jury. They are, however, still in custody, and it appears the District Attorney intends to try his luck in some other way.

Mr. CRITTENDEN appeared in his sent. Messrs. TOOMBS and JOHNSON, of Tennessee, were also in their places. Various petitions were presented. Mr. BRIGHT, of Indiana, offered a resolution that the Committee on Public Buildings inquire and report when the new Senate Chamber will be ready for occupancy.

Case, were arrested, at a late hour Wednesday evening, by the Eighth-Ward Police, on suspicion of being implicated in the murder of an unknown man, at the foot of Desbrosses-street, about a month ago. The Divorce case of BENNETT vs. DENNETT grows more spicy. The best part of it is to come. Dr. BENNETT, respondent, was put on the stand at noon-to-day , and his direct examination occupied all the time after o' clock . He will be subjected to a very ridge cross-examination, Mrs. BENNETT being represented by ex-Judge BLACKMAN, one of the most skillful lawyers in the State. He scores the witnesses in a dreadful way.

AN IMPORTANT IMPROVEMENT.--The contract for grading and regulating Fifth-avenue, from Twenty-seventh-street to the city-line at New Utrecht, a distance of about 9,000 feet, was signed yesterday. Mr. THOMAS HUNT, a large property holder, and personally interested in seeing that the work is well done, is the contractor. Messrs. O'DONNEL BANNEN, it is understood, are the sub-contractors.

The result of our late City Election is due to a variety of causes,--aside from politics. The election of Mr. HAWS is claimed in some quarters as Republican victory, and in others as demonstrating that the united Opposition is stronger in the City than Democratic Party. Neither conclusion sustained by facts.

NEWS FROM HEAD-QUARTERS.--The Sandnsky (O.) Register winds up a paragraph about the TIMES with the remark that it is--"intimated by those who have a right to know, that a prominent railroad manager, and withal a furious Lecompton Democrat, who did not get returned to Congress in November, is too heavy a stockholder in the TIMES establishment to permit the advocacy of Republicanism by that paper."

THE MEXICAN LOAN.--The efforts of Mr. MAGNAN, the agent of the Juarez party, who is now here from Mexico, are not to negotiate a loan from this Government, but from individual capitalists. His object in calling upon Mr. BUCHANAN was to influence, if possible, the recognition of the Juarez party as the Government of Mexico in order to render the task of effecting a loan easier.

To the Editor qf the New-York Times: I observed in the editorial department of your paper, a few weeks since, an exceedingly well written article, headed "Who Invented Anaesthesia," which I rend with satisfaction, not because it did full justice (as I thought) to tile claims of the late HORACE WELLS, of Hartford, Conn., but because it secmed to me to be characterized with moderation and impartiality, and exhibited much knowledge of the subject.

When ROBERT and L.STEVENS' and lSAAC NEWTON's steamboats had regularly traveled over 20 miles an hour, the astonished people said " We will believe anything now." For several months past, a Hungarian peddler, by the name of Moses Loeb, has been driving a sharp and paying business among the farmers of Ohio, by selling them worthless and rotten auction goods at the rate of $ 6 a yard, but was caught a few days ago, and is in prison at Columbus.

THE MOUNT VERNON ASSOCIATION.-The Grand Gala Festival, which takes place next week in aid of the finds of the Mount Vernon Association, commends itself to universal attention. Very extensive preparations have been made to render it one of the most brilliant and attractive festivities of the kind ever witnessed in this country.

It is rumored from England, and believed in Washington, where men are by no means incredulous, that Lord NAPIER has been, or will soon be, recalled by his own Government. Of course, this report has given birth to many fledgling stories of the reasons which have operated to determine the actual Administration of Great Britain upon taking such a step. Lord NAPIER has made himself singularly popular since he came to this country.

When RANNEY, the Artist, died in West Hoboken, about a twelvemonth ago, he left his family, if not in indigent, at least in narrow circumstances. This was his last regret. Since then their worldly means have not, of course, increased, and the friends to whom this has been made known have taken measures to secure the necessary aid.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In my remarks, the other day, concerning the accident to the Sabine, I stated on the authority of letter-writers that the ship was lying to under a close, reefed maintopsail, close-reefed foresail, fore stormstaysail and main trysail, and that, I supposed, she "forced in" her bow ports while under this sail.

Robert T. Haws, Comptroller elect, left tile City last evening, expecting to be absent some days. As executor of an estate, he has business in the northern part of the State, and wishing to devote all of his time to th office to which the people have just elected him, he is anxious to close up all outside business before the first of January.

THE WAR BEGUN, --The President and his party in the Senate have opened the campaign early against DOUGLAS. It was determined in caucus of the Senate last night that he must be ejected from his position as Chairman of the Committee on Territories. The object of this is merely to brand him as an unsound Democrat,--to notify the party at large that he is no longer to be regarded as in good and regular standing.

HITCHCOCK.--In this City, on Friday, Dec. 10 CHARLES HITCHCOCK, Artist, son of the late Judge Hitchcock, of New-Haven. His friends and relatives are invited to attend the funeral services, at No. 470 Greenwich st., this day, (Saturday.) at 111/2 o'clock A. M. His remains will be taken to New-Haven for interment.

SECOND LECTURE OF THE HON. CALEB LYON. The second lecture of the Hon. CALEB LYON an the Holy Land, was delivered under the auspices of the Mercantile Library Association at Clinton Hall last evening. The audience quite filled the hall. The lecture,-which was much of it of a descriptive character,-was much more interesting thao it can be made to appear in a report of limited length, and its delivery was earnest and effective.

A report was received from the Secretary of the Interior, concerning the amount of expenditures for the District of Columbia. Also, a report from the Secretary of the Treasury, inclosing his accounts. Both were laid on the table.

The sharp Winter creeps on apace. It takes no note of the houseless, the unclothed or the starving, but sharpens their sufferings with remorseless and unpitying tooth. But for the Charity which pours its abundant flood through the streets and into the by-ways of our City every year, hundreds would starve and thousands would pass weeks of anguish to which death were a welcome relief.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The last report of the Ten Governors (for 1857) shows the remarkable fact that, beside tenants of our prisons and nurseries, the City of New-York administered, in a greater or less degree, to the support of 44,085 persons; that of these 44,085 persons, 36,407 were of foreign birth, and 7,688 were natives of the United States;

But there are occasional examples of quackery and insanity--there are cases of insolent effrontery and brazen impertinence which are disgust the to startle the most experienced, and disgust the least sensitive of observers.

THE MECHANISM OF THE UNIVERSE.--A lecture was delivered in the Cooper Institute last evening, by Prof. JAMES C. LANE, the gentleman who has undertaken to demolish NEWTON's theory of gravitation, and tell why the comets come and go, and why they now and then spread their tails so widely over the heavens. Three hundred persons, perhaps, were in attendance.

The election is now over,-and, as one prominent result of it, the Board of Education is under the control of men who are resolute in insisting upon the policy of having the Bible read in our Public Schools.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The recent decision of the Supreme Court of Minnesota, refusing to the State a priority of lien over other bondholders of the Minnesota and Pacific Rail road Company, is greatly misunderstood by the Press of other localities.

RHETT, CHESNUT, MCQUEEN and KEITT.

Stern Winter is upon us this year earlier than is usual even in this 'elevated region. Already are the tops of the surrounding mountains powdered with snow, and the w nds that descend from their summits, make the denizens of the valleys appreciate the comfort of warm clothing and good fires.

BUILDING OPERATIONS. is estimated by those who ought to know something about it that not less than eight hundred buildings are in process of construction n Brooklyn at the present time-a greater number by far than were ever before under contract at this season of the year. The indications are that as soon as Spring opens there will be a larger number ot buildings in process of erection than were ever commerced in one season.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It rarely happens that so many errors get into a short article as are contained under your Obituary head on the 8th inst., in a statement respecting Bishop ONDEEDONX, of Pennsylvania.

To the editor of the New-York Times. In a former number we spoke of some of the great leading considerations in favor of a railway connecting the pacific at San Francisco-Puget's Sound with lake Superior, the river Mississippi, and the network of railways of Missouri, Iowa, Wisconsin and Minnesota, and thereby with all our Atlantic and Gulf ports and with our great inland cities.

Nothing of special importance transpired at Washington yesterday. The Senate was in session but half an hour when it adjourned till Monday. There has been nothing further done in relation to the removal of DOUGLAS from the Chair. manship of the Territorial Committee.

At a few minutes after 4, yesterday morning one of the private night watchmen employed at the New-Haven and Harlem Railroad Depot, in Centre-street, between Franklin and White streets, discovered a fire in the second story of the building, on the White-street side.

BROOKLYN.--The second concert of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society takes place to night at the Athenaeum, under the direction of M. CARL BERGMANN. CITY ASSEMBLY ROOMS.--Two years ago we had a most delightful series of Sunday-evening concerts at this establishment, under the direction of M. CARL BERGMANN.

COURT OF COMMON PLEAS. Before Judge Hilton and a Jury. Petersen vs. The Mayor of New York.This was a action brought by plaintiff to recover the value of certain plans and specifications, made in 1851, in reference 10 the then contemplated rebuilding of Washington Market.
There will be no further fighting over the exclusion of Senator DOUGLAS from the Chairmanship of the Territorial Committee. In open session, the caucus decision will be binding. S.
At 9 o'clock this morning the court opened, and the direct examination of respondent was continued. Gov. DUTTON again took his station close to the ear of the witness.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The practice of drumming has been, and yet is carried on to such an extent by jobbing merchants, that it has brought about a state of things in the trade which is degrading to all concerned. It has been said that competition is the life of trade, and when it is a competition based on honorable principles, its results are most happy, in both buyer and seller.

No. 109.--December Term, 1858.--Edmund Rice, plaintiff, vs. The Minnesota and Northwestern Railroad Company. On the motion of the defendants this cause was set down for argument on Friday, the 17th inst.

SONORA AND CHIHUAHUA.-It seems to be taken for granted by a very considerable portion of the Northern Press that the object of" protecting " Sonora and Chihuahua is to annex those provinces, and convert them into Slave States.

The Senate is not in session to-day. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. WASHINGTON, Saturday, Dec. 11. Twenty thousand extra copies of the President's Message, and accompanying documents, and 16,00O extra copies of the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury were ordered to be printed.

COOPER.--In this City, on Sunday morning, Dec, 12, Mrs. LOUISA COOPER, widow of the late John Cooper, aged 72 years. Her relatives and friends, and those of her son, Charles P. Cooper, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from his residence. No. 323 West 23d-st., this day, (Monday,) at 2 o'clock P. M. Her remains will be taken to Duchess County for interment.

Return of the Washington-Full Particulars of the Manner in which She was Visited by British Officers at Sun Juan -Correspondence Between Flag-officer McIntosh and the Captain of the Valorons-Closing of the Nicaragaan Route-The Washington at San Juan and at Aspinwall-Scene

It is time that the position of affairs on the Isthmus should be cleared of the mist and fog which surround it. The United States must not be suffered to drift into a great war at the pleasure of half a dozen contending petty interests and private speculations. Whatever risks the nation is to run in the assertion of great principles must be assumed deliberately and in the face of day.

IMPORTANT DECISION.--The law creating the Brooklyn City Court, makes it one of the duties of its Judge to tax all Constables' bills against the City, without which they cannot be paid, These fees during the last year have amounted to $20,000, a sum which has created some stir among the city authorities, and the attention of the City Judge was called to it.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The grand gala festival in aid of the funds of the Mount Vernon Association occupier so much of the public thought, that it is unnecessary to call attention to it in the usual way. The patriotic object for which this Association labors is appreciated, we believe, by the whole community.

The recent escape of filibusters from Mobile excites intense interesting official quarters, as it is considered that if they shall be arrested by the lritish and other foreign forces, tile volunteer feeling of this country would be aroused to the highest degree of excitement, and immense reinforcements rush to their rescue;
Important Arrest of Lottery Managers and Agents-Seizure of $25,000 in Money and Tickets-Warrants Against Newspaper Proprietors for Advertising Lotteries-Names of the Parties,

Our columns, this morning, contain an extraordinary amount of important and interesting news, both foreign and domestic. The steamship Persia, after an unusually protracted passage, arrived, yesterday afternoon, from Liverpool, Whence she sailed on the 27th November. her advices are of interest.

THE KINDERHOOK BANK ROBBERY. - GEORGE FISH, ALBERT WALLACE, alias Moray, and MICHAEL O'BRIEN, who were arrested in this City few days since on suspicion of being implicated in robbing the Kinderhook Bank of $9,000, on the 15th of September last, were, on Saturday, taken before a magistrate at Kinderhook.

Dr. George Bennett has been on the witnessstand for two days, undergoing direct examination. At least one more day will be occupied in the same way, and then the cross-examination. Rare sport is looked for when Judge Blackman and the witness have to deal with each other. At times the counsel get terribly befogged in the attempt to get at the meaning of Bennett's testimony.

The United States man steamship moses Taylor, A. G. GRAY, Esp., commanding, from Aspinwall Dec. 4, with the passengers, mails, and treasure, brought from San Francisco by the Golden Age, Nov. 20, arrived at this port yesterday. The Moses Taylor left the United States steam-frigate Roanoke in the harbor of Aspinwall. All hands well.

' New-Orleans papers of Sunday last are received. 'They contain a letter from Monterey, dated Nov. 15, -which says: " During tile ensuing week 500 riflemen will leave for San Luis, and thus in a short time the number of men will amount to 3,000. Zacatecas came back to the Constitutional order as soon as the 'Mochos' left the city.

The Royal Mail steamship Persia, C. H. E. JUDKINS, Esq., Commander, from Liverpool, on the 27th November., at noon, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. The screw-steamship City of Washington, whose news was telegraphed from Newfoundland, also arrived last evening, having experienced on her passage a succession of violent westerly gales. She left Liverpool on the 26th of November.

The United States steam - frigate Niagara, capt. JOHN S. CHAUNCEY, arrived on Saturday morning, from Monrovia, (Africa,) and anchored in the North River.

Madame MARIO, the " Miss WHITE" of the latest troubles in Italy, a lady who has done much and suffered much in the cause of Italian freedom, and has been one of the most active and ablest agents MAZZINI has ever had, is now delivering a course of lectures in this City, upon the subject she has most at heart.

Nothing has transpired to thrown any light upon the mysterious conduct of the steamship Hermann, in refusing to stop at San Juan del Sur for the Washington's passengers. Capt. CAVENDY has thus far shown no disposition to fulfil the pledge given in his published card, to lay all the facts and reasons for his conducts before the public.

To the Editor of the New-York rimes: The following paragraphs appears in a recent number of the Chicago Democrat: "Eastern papers will please notify the creditors of the State of Illinois that upon the 1st day of January next $900,000 will be divided upon such bonds as may be presented at the Comptroller's Office in our State.

F. W. LINCOLN JR., was reelected Mayor of Boston, to-day, by over 2,000 plurality. He was the citizen's candidate. MOSES KIMBALL, Republican, has 4,372 votes, and JULIUS A. PALMER, Temperance, 1,130. A majority of the Aldermen elect were on the Citizens' ticket. In Worcester the citizen's ticket is elected entire, Colonel BULLOCK, for Mayor, has 1,655 to 1,599 for RICE, Republican.

The all-engrossing topic of the day is the trial and sentence of M. MONTALEMBERT. Although no account of the proceedings has been permitted to transpire through, the columns of the Paris press, and although threatening orders were issued to all who obtained tickets of admission that they should not dare to make a note of what took place in Court,

" THE MOUNT VERNON PAPERS," by the Hon. EDWARD EVERETT, will be commenced in the first lumber of the New York Ledger for the new year, which will be for sale at all the book-stores and periodical depots throughout the country next week. A week or two ago, Mr. BONNER occupied one page of the TIMES with " opinions of the Press,"--he now monopolizes another in a similar manner.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In that intelligent newspaper, the NewYork Herald of Saturday, there is an article on the subject of our relations with Mexico and Central America, our naval strength in the Gulf, and the strength of the British, French and Spanish squadrons.

To the Editor of New-York Times: SIR: I would wish to state, through your valuable columns, that there are many clerks out of employment in this City, and that they are continually swindled by pretended employment officers, and who have families depending upon them for support.

Editors Albany Evening Journal: DEAR SIRS: I beg to inform you that I have made the following appointments to compose my Staff: FREDERICK TOWNSEND, Adjutant-General. GEORGE F. SHERMAN, Inspector-General. CLARENCE A. SWEARD, Judge Advocate General. JAMES L. MITCHELL, Quarter-Master General. GEORGE F. NESBITT, Engineer-in-Chief.

The Liverpool correspondent of the London Times writes on the 26th November: "It was stated in the Times of the 19th inst. that the steamship Indian Empire, of the Galway line, sailed from New-York on the 23rd ult., (after being foul of a brig.) reached Halifax on the 28th, and departed for her destination on fax the 31st.

CASES OF STABBING--CONDITION OF POLICEMAN DAVIDSON.--Officer DAVIDSON, of the Eighth Precinct, who was stabbed by JOE COBURN on Sunday night, as reported in yesterday's TIMES, proves to have been much more seriously injured than was supposed.

THE WATER-WORKS--REPORT OF A SPECIAL BOARD OF ENGINEERS,--It is well known that the Water Commissioners have had a strong opposition to contend against since the first commencement of the Water-Works. Every step taken and every change from the original plan has been represented by this opposition in anything but a favorable light.

The novel suit instituted by Senor YRISSARI against the editor of the TIMES in being freely commented on by the diplomatic corps here. They feel outraged by the action of Mr. Y., who invades the special privileges of foreign ministers, by bringing himself within the jurisdiction of the courts.

Senator DOUGLAS, after a triumphant reception at New-Orleans, is on his way to Washington, via New-York per Black Warrior steamer. His speech at New-Orleans was " two hours in length," says the Picayune,but neither that nor any other of the enterprising journals of the Crescent City give more than the most meagre outline of it.

The news by the Persia announces the death of Lord LYONS, at Arundel Castle, on the 24th of November. The Admiral was 68 years of age. He was born at Burton, near Christchurch, from which place he took his title: Baron LYONS, of Christchurch.

The Republican of this morning says that the yacht Wanderer positively landed Africans near Brunswick, Mr. JOSEPH GANAHL, the District Attorney, arrived on Saturday with three men believed to be implicated. Their names are JUAN BT. RAJESTA, N. A. BROWN and MIGUEL AGINOI or RAQUET, hailing from New-Orleans.

The non-interference doctrine of the United States, as set forth by Mr. MONROE, seems of late to have become more than usually obnoxious to various organs of the Paris Press. The Patrie, in reference to the canal which it is intended to cut at Nicaragua across the isthmus connecting the two American continents, calls attention to the manner in which the above doctrine, if permitted to prevail, would interfere with that useful work.

HOWELL.--In this City, on Monday, Dec. 13. EMILY J., daughter of John S. and Mary E. Howell, aged 12 months and 28 days. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her parents, No. 78 Jane-st. on Wednesday, Dec. 15, at 1 o'clock P. M. Her remains will be interred in Greenwood.

END OF THE CANGEMI TRIAL.--The case of the Italian CANGEMI is one of the most remarkable criminal trials on record. He was yesterday found guilty of manslaughter in the first degree, it being his fourth trial for the murder of ANDERSON, the Policeman.

By this mail you will receive more cheering accounts of matters and things in California than at any time for the last two or three years. There is a decided improvement and a better feeling among all classes. We have been living on hope so long, that even a slight improvement is hailed with joy.

The State law makes it the duty of the County Clerk to furnish stationery, blanks, lights, , to the several election polls of the City. RICHARD B. CONNOLLY, County Clerk, under this law bought of McSPEDON BAKER stationery, for which two bills were rendered, one for $1,494 58, and the other for $2,298 50, making $3,793 08 in all.

In the United State Senate, yesterday, the principal business transacted was that of appointing the standing commitees, which was done by voting for the entire list. Yeas, 31. Nays, 20, Absent, 11. By this vote the name of GREEN, of Missouri, is substituted for that of DOUGLAS as Chairman of the Territorial Committee.

The passengers by the Overland Mail state that so great was tile rush for seats that the applicants adopted the course of deciding by lot who should take passage. Upward of 100 applications were made this trip, and as high as $100 premium was offered for seats. The Gila River Mines are yielding largely. Emigrants are flocking in from all quarters, and the excitement along the route is intense.

MCKENZIE--DICKSON.--In this City, on Wednesday. Dec. 1, at the house of the bride's father, No. 593 Hudson St., by the Rev. H. Blair, Mr. ALEXANDER MCKENZIE to Miss ANNIA DICKSON, eldest daughter of Mr. Geo Dickson, both of this City. BURTON--NOBLE.--In Brooklyn. on Thursday, Dec. 9. by the Rev. Samuel Longfellow, Mr. WALTER BURTON to Miss CORNELIA J. NOBLE.

A CARD.--My attention has been called to a paragraph in a letter to the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 9th inst., in vague and general terms, that the President had caused certain money, justly due to some individual, to be used for electioneering purposes ; with this accusation my own name has been so generally connected in conversation that I feel constrained. public.

The present aspect of political affairs in both hemispheres gives an immediate interest to all statistics bearing upon the question of the relative strength of nations, and especially upon the distribution of maritime force.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Confident of your opposition to anything that smacks of injustice, I send you this communication in the hope that by its publication, and exposition of the facts, they who contemplate the act which is the subject of my letter, may be turned from their purpose and a case of petty tyranny averted.

From the Detroit Advertiser. The President has been as mean and dishonorable in the favoritism he has shown in distributing his messages to the Press as he is false and unprincipled in his official acts. But as the message is conceived in iniquity, it is but natural that the President should carry cut the instincts of his nature in the distribution of it.

From the Boston Transcript. Mr. EVERETT commenced his address by observing that the statement of the Chairman of the Trustees of "the Dowse Institute" made it unnecessary for him to enlarge upon that topic. Its inauguration had furnished an appropriate occasion to commemmorate the munificient founder, and it was for that object they were assembled.

A serious misunderstanding has occurred among the Printing sportsmen here. WENDELL has refused to comply with the demands of STEADMAN, who is nominal Printer to the House. Under the law talionis the latter has placed his resignation in the hands of Mr. COX, of Ohio, to be tendered Congress on the first opportunity.

THE MOUNT VERNON FUND.--Nothing can exceed the energy with which the Managers of the Mount Vernon Association are pushing forward their preparations for the magnificent three days fete soon to commence at the Academy of Music.

On Monday night there were indications, as Mr. MERRIAM would say, of the near approach of a foggy term. It was not dense enough, however, to cause any interruption to the passage of the river steamers and of the ferry boats; but it continued steadily to increase in density, through the night, until yesterday morning, when it became so thick as to almost put a stop to navigation on the Bay and rivers.

In preparing the following comparative view of the naval armaments of the world, we have been anxious to ascertain as accurately as possible the present available efficiency of those armaments; and to illustrate the extraordinary development, to which the Russian war gave so vigorous an Impulse, of the steam marine of war.

A PERSONAL ACKNOWLDGEMENT.--Mr. BUCHANAN has at last placed us under substantial obligations. He has given orders that the TIMES is to receive no " facilities" at the Executive Departments. This is equivalent to a pledge that he will make no more promises of fair-dealing, and will, therefore, break none.

THE BERGEN TUNNEL--IMPORTANT DECISION.--When the contractor for the new tunnel through Bergen Hill, Mr. MALLORY, suspended operations last year, an action was brought against him by the Long Dock Company (Erie Railroad Company under another name) for breach of contract.

The city is full of exciting rumors--that dispatches were received to the effect that the joint protectorate flag of Great Britain and France had been hoisted over Nicaragua. The result of my inquiries satisfies me that there is not the slightest foundation for the story.

The President sent to the Senate the treaty with Siam, which was concluded May 29, 1856, and proclaimed in Slam in August last. The President suggests an extension to the Consul at Bangkok of the judicial powers conferred on Consuls in China and Turkey.

LIGHTS AND SHADOWS FROM COURTS AND JURY ROOMS.--Mr. A. OAKEY HALL lectured upon this subject in the Cooper Institute on Monday evening. The topic was one upon which, of all others, Mr. HALL is most qualified to speak. His professional reputation, and the general interest felt in the subject, drew together quite a numerous audience in spite of the unfavorable weather.

THE COLUMBIA-STREET HOMICIDE.--WILLIAM CULLEN, indicted for killing a boy named JAMES HART, a few peeks ago, on Columbia-street near Kelsey'salley, was tiled in the Court of Sessions yesterday, before Judge MORRIS, and Justices SCHOONMAKER and EMMONS. when the Jury rendered a verdict of guilty of assault and battery.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me to ask the courtesy of space in your columns to exonerate myself from the unjust charges and insinuations in your issue of yesterday and today concerning my withdrawal from the command of the steamship Hermann.

The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of her parents, No. 78 Jane-st., on Wednesday, Dec. 15, at 1 o'clock P. M.
