This case was resumed, Dec. 13, at Philadelphia. Mr. MEREDITH, one of the counsel for Mr. NEWHALL, was absent on account of illness. All the Jurymen answered to their names and the trial proceeded.

We have had quite a "Fourth of July" during the past week in Camp Floyd. It was on the occasion of the display, for the first time since the arrival of the army in this Territory, of the National Ensign.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Your article on the Italian question has just been pointed out to me, and, anticipating several of the topics of my future lectures, in order to reach such of your readers as may not hear them, I will, with your permission, reply to it in your own columns.

The speeches delivered in Westminster Hall by prosecutors and counsel for the defence, on the occasion of the impeachment of WARREN HASTINGS for high crimes and misdemeanors in the government of India, had a world-wide fame, from the impression they made at the time. No full report, however, has ever been printed of the elaborate harangues of BURKE, FOX, and SHERIDAN, anti of their antagonists--LAW, PLUMBER and DALLAS.

We have received the following interesting, but rather mysterious, note from Chevalier WIKOFF, which we hasten to lay before the public: To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: An editorial article appeared in your columns of yesterday, commenting on the forthcoming Mount Vernon Festival at the Academy of Music, in which you thought fit to introduce my name.

ADDRESS ON THE LIFE AND GENIUS OF THOMAS CRAWFORD. The Historical Society celebrated its Fifty-fourth Anniversary last evening. The Hon. LUTHER BRADISH presided. With the exception of nominations of new members, all routine business was dispensed with.

Nothing of importance was done in Congress yesterday. The House was occupied with the impeachment of Judge WATROUS, and there was some sharp personal rencontres between the two representatives from Texas, Messrs. BRYAN and REGAN. The question will probably be taken today in reference to this case.

To Mr. A, Hart, President of the Congregation "Mickve Israel," Cherry street, Philadelphia: SIR: I have received your letter of the 1st inst., but, after, carefully considering it, I find no reason to change the views which I communicated to you on the 21st ultimo. The Government was asked to express its condemnation of an inexcusable act of cruelty committed by tile public authorities at Bologna, in the Papal dominions.

The Senate's Sanitary Committee has ceased to take testimony, and now has nothing to do but to bundle its voluminous documents into a report to the body that spoke it into existence and be forgotten. The Committee commenced its sessions towards the last of October, and has averaged more than two sittings a week ever since.

The Persia's advices had an unfavorable effect, on our COTTON market, causing less firmness, with light sales. Sales to-day 1,300 bales; middling l1 1/8 c. NEW ORLEANS, Monday, Dec. 13. The Persia's advices had no effect upon our COTTON market, and prices remain unchanged Sales. to-day 5,000 bales. SUGAR dull, and declined 1/2 C.

AUSTRALIAN SOIL-HOW TO MAKE THE MOST OF THE MANURE HEAP--CURE OF BLOWY LANDS. The American Institute's Farmers' Club assembled again yesterday in weekly meeting, Mr. LAWTON in the chair. The Secretary read a letter from Mr. D. K. MINOR, of Melbourne, to the Club concerning the agricultural resources of Australia.

DODWORTH'S SALOON.--ARTHUR NAPOLEON'S fourth and last soiree attracted a fine house last evening, notwithstanding the unpleasant condition of the atmosphere and sidewalks. The young virtuoso played admirably, and was warmly applauded. He starts on his travels with the best possible reputation. Signora CAIROLI, Mr. GEORGE SIMPSON and Signor BERNARDI assisted.

SENATOR SUMNER AGAIN.--A letter from Dr. HEYWOOD, in Paris, to Senator WILSON, states that Mr. SUMNER will spend the coming Winter in France. His seat in the Senate will remain vacant, therefore, during the coming session, unless he resigns, and thus allows Massachusetts the benefit of a full representation in that body. We hope he will conclude to do so.

The House of Representatives, to-day by a vote of 91 to 111, refused to institute an impeachment against Judge WATROUS, of Texas. Many members who entertained strong suspicion of corruption yet voted against impeachment, as they regarded the evidence as insufficient to justify any hope of conviction by the Senate. Judge WATROUS, it is rumored, will immediately resign.

In steamship Marion, for Charleston--Gen. Winfield Scott and servant, Col. lay. G. K. Wood, P. L. Cunning ham, S. A. strang, Jno. Thompson, G. H. Brown, E. Currant, Mr. Hammond, A. Salisbury, H. H. Fonda, the Rev. Gen. C. Robinson and lady, Mrs. Win. B. Barher, S. Chester, B. Weim. S. F. Leopold, F. Nichols, G. B. Griffin, M. Mesa and lady, 3 children and servant,

Gen. CASS is by no means happy in his epistolary efforts. We published yesterday a further letter from the Secretary of State to Mr. HART, acknowledging the " justice" of the terms of reprehension with which the President of the United States referred, in his dispatch to the American Consul at Cairo, to the persecutions of the Jews of Damascus in 1840;

The Hon. PIERRE SOULE introduced Judge DOUGLAS to the audience in the following speech: FELLOW-CITIZENS: On no occasion could I have been called upon to perform a more grateful task than that which is assigned to me as presiding officer of this meeting. I shall discharge it briefly.

The California advices by the Overland Mail, which, on the 9th inst., reached St. Louis, have been anticipated by the Moses Taylor. One of the passengers, Mr. G. J. WHITNEY, states that a considerable emigration is setting in for the Arizona gold diggings. A large portion of the emigrants are from Texas and Arkansas.

SIR: The effect of that portion of the President's Message, in which he suggests the propriety of assuming a temporary protectorate over a portion of the Northern provinces of Mexico, is full of consequences that may not have been followed to their practical results. The late exodus to Fraser River will sufficiently inform you of the migratory character of the people of the Pacific.

A NEW RELIGIOUS SECT IN NEW-HAMPSHIRS.--A new sect of Perfectionist has ariser in New-Hampshire, where they have held meetings at Concord and Dover, They think of calling themselves "The Orthodox Catholic Church." Altogether, they number about one hundred. They believe in community of goods. Civil law they do not regard. Their laws are Bible laws.

THE TRANSATLANTIC TELEGRAP.--The Atlantic Cable seems fairly to have given up the ghost. We have no news whatever about it now either from DE SANTY or SAWARD. The offices at Valentia Bay, which appear to have been the head-quarters, are closed for the present ; and all attempts at carrying on the working seem to be suspended.

Various memorials of little importance were presented, with the exception of one from the Convention of Iron Masters who met in Philadelphia on Dec. 20, 1849. On this memorial Mr. CAMERON addressed the Senate, showing from the tables of the Secretary of the Treasury that an ad valorem duty on Iron is alike opposed to the interests of the Government and the consumers of foreign iron and steel.

A NOBLE PERFORMANCE OF DUTY.--The Washington Union publishes, with an air of prodigious triumph, the fact that Lieut. WHITE, who was put on board the Susan by a revenue cutter, found his orders disobeyed,-and that the vessel proceeded to sea. Lieut. WHITE is to report in person to the Governmnent.
THE MOUNT VERNON FESTIVAL.-We are delighted to hear that Chevalier WIKOFF is perfectly satisfied with our explanation of his little matter, in yesterday's TIMES.

Madame MARIO has taken the trouble to endeavor to set us right on some of the points relative to which we suggested difficulties in our recent article on the Italian question. Her letter was published in the TIMES of yesterday.

The schooner H. E. Spearing, at New-Orleans from Vera Cruz, brings dates from the latter port to Dec. 2. The Progreso of that day says: "The diligence which arrived in this city yesterday brings us more reliable and trustworthy news. The defeat of Marquez (ZULOAGA) by Gen. DEGALLADO, at the bridge of Tololation, is confirmed."

A DEMOCRATIC ARROWSMITH.--We have hitherto abstained from any comment upon the alleged arrival of a cargo of slaves in a port of the State of Georgia, of which several rumors have already been made public-because we were unwilling easily to give our belief to a story so full of shame for the authorities of the nation and for the people of a sister State.

THE SOUTH ON THE PROTECTORATE.--The Charleston Mercury, as will be seen by an extract which we publish in another column, pauses over the suggestions of Mr. BUCHANAN'S Message. It fears the consequences of annexing to the union the Northern Provinces of Mexico.

The report of the Committee on Finance, presented to the Board last evening, in favor of donating $1,000 to the New-York Eye and Ear Infirmary, was adopted. The Committee on Roads reported in favor of opening and grading Eleventh-avenue, from Twenty-fifth-street to its southern extremity, and the report was adopted.

CRAIG.-In this City, on Wednesday morning, Dec. 15, Mrs. ELIZBETH CRAIG, in the 80th year of her age. Her relative and friends and those of her grand-sons James M. and Benj. E. Hanceck, and those of her nephew. George Sibell, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the first Baptist Church, Corner of Broome and Elizabeth St. Friday, the 17th at 1 o'clock P.M.

NEWSPAPER ENTERPRISE.--The newspaper Press seems to be in a thriving condition in the cities. Our principal exchanges appear in new type, with improvements in the style of typography, showing signs of prosperity. The Delta in New-Orleans, Atlas ant Argus at Albany, the Gazette at Cincinnati, the State journal at Columbus, Ohio, the Enquirer at Richmond, Va.,, are especially noticeable.

The Board of State Canvassers met at noon to-day. The Secretary of the State acted as Chairman. JOHN H. REYNOLDS appeared as counsel on behalf of Mr. HASKINS in the case of the Ninth Congressional District. A letter was received from AMASA J. PARKER, counsel for GOUVENEUR KEMBLE, asking a postponement till Monday.

An Indianapolis correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette Writes: " The United States Senatorial bill having gone over, after its second reading, to Tuesday next, at 2 P. M., there cannot by any possibility be an election to supply the vacancies in the United States Senate, until Monday week, when, in as probability, it will come off.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: I am but "a looker-on in Venice," and having no pecuniary interest to serve, (nor indeed any other interest,) can view the whole subject of the non-connection of the Hermann with the Washington dispassionately.

The Siberian mail is conveyed from St. Petersburg to Moscow by rail, and from thence to Irkutsk, the capital of Eastern Siberia, in carriages drawn by horses. The distance from Muscow to Irkutsk is 3,426 miles, and there are 210 mail stations on the road for changing horses. The mail communication is semi-weekly, and the expense of it to the Russian Government is about ??57,000 a year.

THE EXHIBITION OF FAT GAITLE, , AT TATTERSALLS.--The annual exhibition of fat cattle and other stock was opened yesterday at TATTERSALLS, corner of Sixth-avenue and Thirty-ninth-street. The collection was not very large, but in other respects compares very favorably with previous shows.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The East is interested in almost every subject of Western legislation. Whether this legislation relates to collection laws, railroads, banks, or internal improvements, we cannot escape its influences. Our merchants supply the West with goods, and are deeply in the laws for the collection of their debts. Our capitalists supply the means for public improvements, railroads, banks, and other institutions.

The New-Mexican mail, with dates of the 22d ultimo, reached Independence on the 12th inst. There is no news from Fort Defiance. Mr. YOST, the editorial correspondent of the Santa Fe Gazette, says that the Navajo war will not be closed this Winter, and probably not for years, and that if the work of desolation continues, the Indians cannot fail to be thrown back ten years in the march of civilization.

NON-ARRIVAL OF THE ARABIA. SACKVILLE, N. B., Wednesday, Dec. 15. Owing to a break in the line between Truro and Halifax, we are unable to communicate with the latter place this evening. At our latest advices from Halifax this afternoon, there were no signs of the Royal Mail steamship Arabia, now in her twelfth day from Liverpool.

HON. HENRY WILSON--Sir: As the colleague of the Hon. CHARLES SUMNER, I thought you would be glad to learn the result of the medical consultation held to-day in his case. There were present Prot. TRAUSSAU, one of the most eminent practitioners in Europe; Dr. BROWN-SEGUARD, the attending physician, and myself.

THE BERGEN TUNNEL--CORRECTION.--The Jersey City Courner corrects the report that Mr. MALLRY, contractor for the Bergen Tunnel, has received $100,000 from tile Erie Railroad Company. The Courier states the facts as follows: " It appears that MALLERY has sued the company for $200,000 for work done on the tunnel, and for damages for preventing him from finishing it.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I see by the proceedings in the Board of Comcilmen, on Monday, that SILAS M. STILLWELL, GEORGE LAW, THOMAS E. DAVIS, SHEPARD KNAPP, WILLIAM B. ASTOR, ISAAC C. KENDALL, and COURTLAND PALMER, have presented a petition to have an investigation of the manner of the construction of the Central Park new reservoir, and that the petition was referred to a committee.

The remaining portion of Dr. BENNETT'S cross-examination, of which I have already given you so much, is scarcely of sufficient interest for publication it grew painfully tedious ; no new facts were elicited, and at its close the feeling of the audience was one of relief.

No. 262- Andrew Laurence vs. Hiram A. Tucker. Appeal from tile Circuit Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Cause docketed and dismissed with costs. No. 10-The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania vs. Eliza Kohns, executor. Argument concluded for the plaintiffs.

From the Charleston Mercury, * * It is true the President proposes such an occupation to be only temporary, until Mexico is capable of governing herself, and of paying the ten millions of dollars said to be due by her to our citizens. But we presume that no one, in or out of the United States, will doubt that our possession of these Territories will be permanent.

SENATOR DOUGLAS AT NEW-ORLEANS.-- We have at last a full report of the speech of Senator DOUGLAS at New-Orleans. We publish it in another column. It is not very long, --but it is clear, compact and explicit in its declaration of principles.

CONVICTION OF PETER DAWSON OF ASSAULT They AND BATTERY WITH INTENT TO KILL.-PETER DAWSON, -well-known in the Fourth Ward of New-York, was yesterday, in the King's County Court of Sessions, convicted of an assault and battery, with intent to kill a respectable resident of Brooklyn named WH. J. POTTS. From the testimony it appears that the offence was committed in September, 1857. DAWSON, Ladies with some friends, had been to the races.

By the way of New-Orleans we have Jamaica dates to Nov. 15. We learn from the Advertiser that the Island had been deinged with rain and much damage had been done. In St. Davids, six lives were lost by a food, and several cottages were swept away. There had been violent storm at Falmonth and in the vicinity, which caused great destruction.

The United States Mail steamship Philadelphia, Lieut. MCARANN, U. S. N., commanding, left New-Orleans morning of the 5th inst., for IIavana, at which port she arrived morning of the 9th, having been detained 15 hours by fog at the Pass a I'Outra,-left Havana night of the 9th and arrived here yesterday morning.

Ever since the arrival of the steamer Washington from San Juan de Nicaragua, on Saturday last, our columns have been filled with letters, replies, charges, rumors and comnunications, referring more or less rationally to the state of our diplomatic relations with England, France, Spain and Central America

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In a recent issue of your valuable journal my attention, in common with others, was arrested by a paragraph referring in brief terms to a late inprovement in the barometer and its adaptability in its new form to popular usage.

SUYDAM-McELROY.--In this City, on Monday afternoon, Dec. 13, by the Rev. John Thomson, Mr. EDGAR C. SUYDAM to Miss KATE A. McELROY, all of this City. COLLIN-KELLINGER.--In this City, on Wednesday, Dec. 15, at Calvary Church. West 23d-st., by the Rev. A. D. Gillette, ORIENT H. COLLIN to CARRY D. KELLINGER, daughter of SAMUEL KELLINGER, Esq.

Mr.MORRIS, of Illinois, is evidently one of your slap-dash legislators. Finding, on the one hand, a popular clamor for a low Tariff, and on the other a bankrupt Treasury at Washington, Mr. MORRIS steps in to satisfy the one without paying much attention to the other, and gives notice of his intention to abolish the duties on Sugar.

The schooner Susan, with her passengers aboard, went to sea early Wednesday morning. After leaving the wharf Saturday night she proceeded to the lower fleet, and on Sunday look aboard her water. The revenue cutter chased the schooner, but the Susan gained on her, and the cutter returned to the Bay. At last accounts the McClelland was fast aground.

There was not the least occasion for public mystification in regard to recent events on the Coast of Central America, and especially in regard to the supineness with which the Administration has received intelligence of the high-handed measures of the British force upon that coast.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the morning of the 4th inst., with one week's later advice, arrived at Halifax at 10 o'clock last night, and a summary of her news will be found elsewhere in this morning's TIMES. The most important intelligence by this arrival is the assurance of the safety of the steamship Indian Empire, which had been given up as lost.

ADMISSION TO THE BAR.--At the opening of he General Term of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the present week, the following-named gentlemen were appointed a Committee to examine the candidates for admission to theo Bar: John Greenwood, Jesse C. Smith, Edward Wells.

NEW-JERSEY STATE TEACHERS' ASSOCIATION--The Sixth Annual Meeting of this Association will be held in Jersey city, on the 28th , 29th and 30th inst. On the first day;, after business has been transacted, Dr. FRANK TUTHILL will deliver an address. On the Subsequent days addresses will be delivered by Prof. HART, OF Philadelphia; :

TWELFTH DAY--(CONCLUDED.) [FROM OUR OWN REPORTER] NEW-HAVEN, Wednesday, Dec. 15. Mrs. Ward's cross-examination was continued. Q.--What hour in the day was it that you got to the house in Dixwell-street? A.--Between 10 and 11 o'clock; I found Mrs. Bennett alone in her room; I don't know whether anybody else was on the second story; Mrs. Bennett was holding on to the front of the bedstead in great agony.

Question No. 120.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I was a little surprised to read in the address of the Recorder to the Grand Jury, on Wednesday last, these words: "In reference to the Liquor Law, its constitutionality had been settled by the Court of Appeals."

WILSON-In this City, on Thursday, Dec. 16. EMMA C., daughter of William and Deborah A. Wilson, aged 25 years. The friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend her funeral, on Saturday, Dec. 18, at 1 o'clock P. M., at the Allen-st. Presbyterian Church.

Ce que femme veut, Dieu le veut, "whatever a woman wills, that Heaven also wills," says the old French proverb. We have much faith in proverbs, more in women; and we therefore make no manner of doubt that Mr. JOHN WASHINGTON will one day find himself free of that home and tomb of his great ancestor which have so oppressed and tormented him for many years.

From the Albany Statesman. No little excitement prevails at the South, as well as in the Northern States at the present time, on the subject of the reported practical reopening of the Slave-trade, by the supposed successful landing of a cargo of Africans, fresh from their native coast, by the yacht Wanderer.

AMERICAN INSTITUTE--MECHANICS' CLUB.--At the regular meeting of the Club, held on Thursday evening, the subject of warning and ventilating buildings was again disscussed. The opinions of experienced men seemed to point to the conclusion that the same method is not applicable in all cases.

Various petitions were presented and referred. Mr. WILSON, of Massachasetts, moved to amend the Arizona bill so as to provide for the election of a Governor, Seeretary, Judges, and other officers, by the people, for the term of two years. Referred to the Committee on Territorles.

The case of the Amistad has not been brought forward in the Senate with exclusive reference to its merits. There has always been, it is true, a strong desire on the part of Southern statesmen that this claim should be formally acknowledged and paid,-and the pertinacity with which it has been pressed upon Congress and the country indicates the very strong motive which has prompted their action on the subject.

The proposed meeting of gentlemen friendly to the election of Mr. CRITTENDEN to the Presidency, which was held here last evening, brought quite a number of politicians to the city. It was designed originally to be an exclusive meeting of gentlemen in opposition to the Democracy, who do not cooperate with the Republicans, but several gentlemen were invited, and piesent, whose position in the Republican Party is dcfinte.

BENJAMIN LETT, the man who was convicted about twenty years since of blowing up the Brock monument at Queenstown Heights, but escaped as he was being taken to prison, died in Milwaukee, a few days since, from the effects of poison, as is supposed.

Mr. BOYLE, a passenger by the Overland Mail, reports the roads in good condition from San Francisco to Fort Smith. Accounts from the Gila River mines are very favorable. Mr. PARDEE, the expressman, was met one day out from Fort Smith, fifteen hours ahead of time. He had not abandoned the coach, no hostile Indians were seen.

TOO FAST AND TOO FAR.--The New-York Tribune is a paper many of the suggestions of which are of the most valuable kind; but when-it undertakes to commit the Republican Party to Anti-Slavery views of extreme character, it can do no good, and may make much mischief.

SETTLEMENT OF POLITICAL, ACCIDENTS.--There is considerable commotion in New-Rochelle, growing out of the removal of Mr. KISSAN, the popular postmaster of that town, on suspicion of not having been sufficiently active and efficient in the crusade against Mr. HASHIN. as we understand the matter.

Dr. L. R. HERRICK, who was designated by the governor elect as Surgeon-General upon his Staff, publishes in the Albany Atlas Argus a declination of that office. He makes the following statement: "Having been wantonly assailed in a leading Press in this city, and learning from a mutual friend that representations have been made to you, designed and calculated to excite professional prejudices.

THE HERALD AND THE TIMES.--Last week we transferred to our columns the just complaint of the TIMES on account of the deception practiced in the manner of supplying copies of the President's message to all the paper at the same time professedly, while the Herald was allowed to have a copy in advance.

The financial crisis of last year bore with great severityy upon the manufacturing interest, and many large fortunes in New-England were nearly swept away by the depression of the stock ot incorporated companies, and the revelations made by the failure of agents. For months the prospects of this important element in the material prosperity of the State were gloomy in the extreme.

The ship-owners of Great Britain have been holding a series of protracted meetings during the past month, at the principal seaports of the kingdom, the object of which was to agitate the subject of the Navigation Laws, and to influence the Government to do something towards compelling foreign States to reciprocate the Free-trade system which was adopted by the passage of the " Customs. Consolidated Act."

Vice-Regents of the Mount Vernon Association have been appointed for twenty-one States, and all of them are zealously at work collecting funds. Each Vice-Regard, on entering upon her duties, puts forth an appeal to the State over which she presides.

A Board consisting of Col. Johnson, Lieut. Col. Buchanan, Lieut. Col. Steptoe, Capt. Dyer and Lieut. Wilcox, is ordered to convene at Fort Monroe, for the purpose of making experiments with small arms. A Convention of forwarders, shippers and others, interested in the completion of Canals, and in favor of protecting the public works, is called to meet in Syracuse on Tuesday, the 28th of December.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Capt. STONE from Liverpool at 9 o'clock on the morning of the 4th inst., arrived here at 10 o'clock this evening, Her dates are one week later than those already received. The steamship Indian Empire reached Broadhaven, County Mayo, on the 26th ult. All well on board, but her fuel exhausted, and a portion of her cargo and wood-work consumed, and short of provisions.

To the Editor of the New-York Times:. Tile extent to which rowdyism is carried in this City is becoming truly fearful. Villains no longer wait for thi cover of night to perpetrate their evil deeds-they can commit them with impunity in the open day.

Died, on Wednesday, Dec. 15, at Chester, Orange County, N. Y., Mrs. ELIZABETH BEADFORD ABBOTT, formerly of the Park and Broadway Theatres, this City. Though no one could be more highly respected by all who knew her, yet such was the extraordinary character of this lady that but few, we suspect, comprehended it in its massiveness, its strength, and its beauty.

THE NEW-ORLEANS EPIDEMIC.--The report of the Howard Association of New-Orleans states that they attended to 3,414 cases of yellow fever during the recent season, 1,000 of whom were Germans, 1,485 Irish, and 409 natives of the United States; 771 died, and the remaining 2,643 were discharged cured. The amount of money expended was $45,000.

A very intelligent audience crowded the ?? room of the Historical Society on Thursday evening, to listen to an address by Dr. HAYES, (late Surgeon of the second Grinnell Arctic Expedition,) on the Polar Discoveries of Dr. KANE, and the plans he himself had partially matured for further research. The Rev. Dr. HAWKS, President of the Society, introduced Dr. HAYES to the audience, the ordinary routine of business being dispenses with.

WHAT SHALL BE DONE WITH THE PARK.--The lovers of rural simplicity must have been gratified with tile appearance of the Park yesterday. It was converted. into a sheep pasture, and presented a striking picture of rustic life,--the ragged girls who sweep the crossings answering in place of woodland nymphs, and a few stalwart Irishmen with brooms filling the parts of shepherds will their crooks.

OFFICIAL DUTY.--The Journal of Commerce, noticing the statement that Mr. BUCHANAN has determined to enforce an adjustment of the party differences in this City, says: "We can only say that if he has undertaken such a job, it is one which will be likely to tax his powers more fully than any other official duty on his hands."

THE MEMORY OF THE COURT.--A woman named MARGARET BURNS was convicted yesterday, in the United States Circuit Court, of the crime of passing counterfeit coin. Her husband was tried at the same time in an indictment for making the counterfeit coin which his wife had attempted to pass.

Congressional proceedings, yesterday, were devoid of general interest. The Senate was not in session, having adjourned over from Thursday to Monday. The House was engaged all day in the consideration of the private calendar-the bill providing for the examination and payment of the claims of citizens of Georgia and Alabama, for losses sustained by the depredations of the Creek Indians, occupying a considerable share of attention. The matter was not disposed of,

POSTAGE TO SPAIN.--The United States postage only is required to be prepaid in this country on letters to Spain, including Majorca, Minorca, and the Canary Islands, forwarded in the British mail via England. Postmaster will require prepayment in all cases of the United States postage, viz., 21 cents the single rate of half an ounce or under, when the Atlantic conveyance is by United States steamers,

THE UNITED STATES FRIGATE NIAGARA.--Capt. CHAUNCEY, yesterday, handed over the Niagara to the Commandant of the Navy-years; her colors were hauled down, and she went out of commission. Previously, however, the customary inspection was face, and a certificate given to the effect that the ship was in condition which reflected great credit upon the commander, as well as on the officers of the ship.

FIRES--Mr. N. REEVES' carpenter-shop, on the corner of Fifth and North Second-street, Eastern District, was destroyed by fire on Saturday evening; loss $500; insured for $100....Between 4 and 5 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the basement of store No. 11 Fulton-avenue, The fire soon communicated with the first story, occupied as a furniture store by A. NEWMAN, who lost nearly all his stock valued at $1,200, upon which there was no insurance.

BROWN,--In this City, on Saturday, Dec. 18, suddenly, HENRY BRON, aged 44 years. His friends, and the friends of his brother, John H. Brown, and friends of his brother-in-law, Henry Striker, also George, William, and Samuel Hawley, likewise his uncle, Enoch Dean, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, corner of 10th-st and 1stav., this day, (Monday,) at 1 o'clock precisely.

That particular region of the State of Michigan which is known as the "Muskegon Valley," most be a very vicked place. A writer in the Newaygo Republican, in a series of articles, has undertakes to shown up hte morals of the community. It is states that the common practices are Sabbath-breaking, profane and filthy language, drunkenness and garabling, and a general recklessness in regard to all that is good.

Neither House of Congress was in session on Saturday, and the only occurrence of interest at the National Capital was the first light of the season, which occurred in the morning, on Pennsylvania-avenue, between Mr. ENGLISH, of Indiana, and Mr. MONTGOMERY, of Pennsylvania. The latter gentleman, who got the worst of the fight, appears, from the reports of the affair, to have been decidedly in the wrong.

The shelves of our Book-sellers are in full blossom for the holiday season. Perhaps the number of what are prepared for the market as gift-books proper is somewhat loss than usual; but several of those which are now offered to the public are certainly among the richest and most elegant ever presented for such occasion.

In New York, during the present week, the inquiry has been animated at strenghening prices. Desirable lots, which manufacturers really want, have been sparingly offered,--and business has been some what restricted by the increasing difficulty of filing orders for the better qualities. The reported sales include 175,000 lbs, domestic hence within a range of from 38c.@56c, for common to full blood Merino and Saxony' 45,000 lbs, domestic Pulled at from 32c,@45c.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is not true, as stated, that I or any person authorized to represent the Anti-Tammany Democracy have recently been to Washington for an adjustment of difficulties in the party here, Nor do I believe that the President could have undertaken such a task.

WHITTELSEY--REEDER.--In this City, on Thursday, Decf 16, by the Rev. J. P. Thompson, D. D., at the Church o the paritans, JOHN C. WITTELSEY to CORNELIA LIVINGSTON, daughter of the later Alfred S. Reeder, of Cincianati. REED--POST.--In this City, on Thursday, Dec. 16, by the Rev. Samuel Osgood, D. D., JOHN H. REED, of Boston, to Miss SARAH BYERS, daughter of the late Jotham W. Post, of this City.

A most destructive fire occurred on Saturday afternoon. Three buildings were entirely consumed, including the Odeon Theatre, and six buildings were partly burned. The total estimated loss is $25,000, and there were several narrow personal escapes. The fire originated in the Odeon, a lager-bier, concert and theatrical saloon, at No. 49 Bowery.

SENATOR DOUGLAS AND THE CITY GOVERNMENT. -Both branches of our Common Council have voted to give Senator DOUGLAS a public reception on his arrival here from Havana. How much or how little this means we are not aware ;--but the flags are to be displayed upon all the public buildings, and a Committee of the two Boards has been appointed to wait

Notwithstanding the vein of ridicule which runs through tile whole article, I should not complain were it not for the last remarks, which are decidedly unjust both to myself and to the subject. I quote:

You will oblige me by nominating a day on which it will be convenient for you, or any friend you may authorize, to confer with the Doctor either at Philadelphia or Baltimore.

E. SICKLES, Member of Congress from this City. Mr. SICKLES, it will be remembered, during the Congressional canvass.

THE TELEGRAPHIC CHESS-MATCH.--The second game of the Telegraphic Chess-match between New-York and Philadelphia was commenced on Saturday evening. The New-Yorkers occupied their old quarters at the Rotunda in the Merchants' Exchange. There was not a large attendance of amatours. In the first game, which it will be recollected was draw, New-York bad the move.

The trial of ALLIBONE and NEWHALL, at Philadelphia, on a charge of conspiracy, terminated on Saturday, in a verdict of Not Guilty. The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin gives tile concluding testimony: John S. Newbold testified: We exchanged the Reading Railroad notes of $50,000 for the Southwark and Tradesman's Bank; these are the Bank's due bills; the bills were taken at their face.

To the Editor of the New - York Times : SIR ; The interest you take in naval maters, and your correct views on the subject, ;induce me to solicity the favor of incumbering your columns with a few remarks relative to our policy. A yearsine, Commodore PAULDING was indirectly censured for his efficiency in removing WALKER'S piratical gang from the Shores of Nicaragua.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: My attention having been called to certain communications, which have recently appeared n the columns of the New-York newspapers, over the respective signatures of HENEY HANDALL and EDWARD CAVENDY, in which my name has been used as one cognizant of all the facts which the said communicalions desire to establish, I am reluctantly obligated to make the following statement:

we are glad to be able to announce, this morn ing, the safety of the Ariel, which left Southampton o the 1st instant for this port, though the announcement is coupled with intelligence which will be received with heartfelt sorrow by many. She put into Halifax yesterday afternoon short of coal, and will sail again for this port to-day.

No. 263-Rock Island Factory vs. John Godwin et al.-Error to Circuit Court for the Middle District of Alabama. The cause was docketed and dismissed. with costs. No. 264.-Samuel H. Clark et al. vs. Wm. Hart, Jr. -Error to the Circuit Court for the Northern District of California. Cause docketed arid dismissed, with costs.

The proposed execution of the persons implicated in the assassination plot of the 16th September last, is the first event noticeable since tile date of my last letter to you. The criminals (7) were thrown in capilla on the day previous to the departure of the last mail, but the circumstance was not openly proclaimed until too late to notify you of the fact.

The Senate met at noon. The reading of the ournal occupied upwards of half an hour. Various memorials were presented, mostly asking for pensions. On the joint resolution to adjourn from the 23d of December to the 4th of January, Mr. FOOT called for the yeas and nays. The resolution was adopted. The following Senators voted against it:

Yesterday, we announced the acquittal of ALLIBONE and NEWWHALL at Philadelphia. The Phladelphia papers give full reports of the arguments of the counsel in the case, with the reason a assigned by the Distrlct-Attorney for abandoning the prosecution.

ENTERPRISING.--Chevalier WIKOFF, who manages the diplomatic department of our dilapidated neighbor, the Herald, professes to have just discovered that the Ouseley Treaty, which was publisted in the TIMES of Sept, 27, was never concluded ! He professes to derive his information from the State Department.

THE BROOKLYN MUSICAL ACADEMY.--A sufficient sum has already been subscribed towards the election of an Academy of Music to warrant the Committee having the matter in charge to purchase the ground for the building. The site has not definitely been fixed upon as yet, but it is expected that the work will be commenced next Spring, as soon as the weather will permit.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The grand ball of the Mount Vernon Association takes place to-night. A well ordered entertainment may safely be anticipated. The Floor Committee embraces the names of some of our most reputable citizens,-- guaranteeing an attendance of the best sort.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. It being almost impossible to address all the Shareholders of the Illinois Central Railroad in any other way than through a public paper, I hope you will do me the favor to insert this short statement in your columns, that it may obtain the attention of the commercial classes who are interested in this enterprise, here and abroad.

SHERIFF-STREET.--The alarm at 8 o'clock last evening, in the Sixth District, was occasioned by a fire in the tenement house No. 83 Sheriff-street, (rear.) The fire was caused by the explosion of a camphene lamp in the apartment of JOHN BUCK, on the second floor, and his furniture was damaged about $1,000, on which there was no insurance.

We have already alluded to the fact that the old Postmaster at New-Rochelle, Mr. KISSAM, had been removed from office because he did not make himself sufficiently active in securing the defeat of Mr. HASKIN.

The Chicago Press and Tribune recently stated that Mr. SLIDFEA had asserted that tile slaves of Senator DOUGLAS, held in Louisiana, were "over-worked, All-fed,) badly clothed, and otherwise neglectfully treated." The statement being denied, the Press and Tribune gave as its authority a personal friend of Mr. SLIDELL, who said he had it from Mr. S. himself.

The Board of Councilmen met last evening, with President HASWELL in the chair. A resolution was offered and laid over, directing the Clerk of the Board to have a full report of the celebration of the laying of the Atlantic Cable published. A report on the fame subject was also laid over, appropriating $25,000 to defray the expenses of the celebration.

The National Intelligencer publishes the following "authentic" account of the informal political meeting which was lately held in that city by a number of gentlemen from different parts of the country: "A number of gentlemen from all sections of the country, and heretofore cooperating with the different political organizations, held a few days ago in informal meeting in this City to compare opinions and interchange information in regard to the present condition of public affairs.

THE LIBERIAN GOVERNMENT AND THE REGINA A CELI AFFAIE.--The Baltimore American publishes a long correspondence between Mr. JOHN H. B. LATHOBE, President of the American Colonization Society and Senator HAMMOND of South Carolina, in reference to the affair of the Regina Coeli.

There was a heavy fall of snow on Sunday night at Poughkeepsie, and yesterday morning the ground was covered to the depth of three inches. The weather on Saturday night and Sunday morning was cold, the thermometer standing at 8 degrees above zero. The river is frozen over from Albany to Poughkeepsie. On Sunday, the steamboats Robert L. Stevens, Manhattan, and the Norwich passed Poughkeepsie on their way up.

In steamship Star of the South, from Savannah.--W. G. Lineburgh and lady, Geo. Hilbratz and lady, Geo. Blackburn an lady, Mrs. C. E. Macleod, Wm. Scott, A. Ancher. Cyrus Blackburn, S. W. Mason. H. J. Long, and 30 in the steerage.

There has ceaseu to be a newspaper ?? the City of Mexico. What information we derive from that quarter comes from our own correspondent and those of other papers, whose opportunities for following and noting the current of affairs are far less complete than is desirable.

CHURCH-VAN BOSKERCK.--In this City, on Thursday, Dec. 9. at the Scotch Presterian Church, 14th-st., by the Rev. Dr. McElroy, Mr. JAMES H. CHURCH to Miss LIZZIE VAN BOSKERCK all of this City. MOSELEY-JOHNSON.--In Williamsburg, on Thursday, Dec. 9, CHARLES H. MOSELEY, of New-York, to Miss MARY E. JOHNSON, of Williamsburg.

YOUNG.--In this City, on Monday, Dec. 20, JULIA MARIA, youngest daughter of Henry C. and Sarah E. Young, aged 16 months. The friends and relatives of the family are requested to attend the funeral, at their residence, No. 10 Cannon-st., this day. (Tuesday,) at 1 o'clock. FINCH.--In this City, on Sunday, Dec. 19, MARY FINCH, relict of the late Ferris Finch, aged 64 years, 6 months aged 15 days.

FAIRS IN THE METROPOLIS.--The few weeks preceding the holidays are usually selected for holding the Fairs of various benevolent institutions, and in the City, at the present time. Each of these is intended for the support of some commendable charity, and all have their particular friends and promoters.

A GLANCE AT THE NEW HOSPITALS--THE MILITARY, THEIR DUTY AND EXPENSES--RUMORS OF FURTHER INCENDLARISM--CONTEMPLATED PROCEEDINGS AT ALBANY, Since the erection of the new hospitals, offices, stores and dwellings at cleared away, the grounds begin again to wear the appearance of comfort.

The Secretary of War has not furnished to the Military Committee his reply to the call for estimates for holding military possession of Sonora and Chihuahua. The Committee on Foreign Relations of the House will report a resolution authorizing Consuls to receive presents from foreign Governments.

A PROSPEROUS STATE.-The witty and genial Canon of St. Paul's died a few years too soon. As there has never been more than one Canon of St. Paul's to whom these epithets could be applied, of course every one knows that we mean SYDNEY SMITH, whose loving daughter, Lady HOLLAND, attributes to her father's satirical pen the great feat of compelling the State of Pennsylvania to pay its honest debts.

The Republican of this morning reports the proceedings in the yacht Wanderer affair on Saturday. The prosecution was vigorous, District-Attorney GANAHL being assisted by HENRY R. JACKSON. Esq. The prisoners were defended by Messrs. LLOYD and OWENS Two witnesses, Dr. HAZLEHURST, of Brunswick, and Collector MABOY, of Darien, were examined.

DEAR SIR : Your letter of the 29th ultimo has been received, and I take pleasure in responding to your inquiry whether the speech make by me on a recent occasion here, when I was serenaded by the citizens, of Washington, was correctly reported. The speech was extemporaneous ; it was delivered in the midst of a snow - storm , and was not fully reported.
Were a catastrophe proportioned to the plot indispensably requisite to a cause celebre, the case of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania against ALLIBONE and NEWHALL, could hardly support that character.

The City Hall was burned to a ruin on the 18th of last August. The universal grief was tempered by the general assurance that the accident would hasten the erection of a now and more com. modious building, for which the Courts, the City Government and the public had long been clamor. ing.

Tile Fair of the American Union opened last night at the large fire-proof building No. 620 Broadway, adjoining Laura Keene's Theatre. The American Union, as most of our readers are a ware, is a new Association, which has arisen from the ruins of the Crystal Palace, and therefore is entitled to be considered a sort of Phoenix, to which ornithological marvel it was indeed repeatedly compared by the orators of the occasion.

HEALTH OF THE CITY--ORGANIZATION OF A SANITARY ASSOCIATION.--A movement has been on foot for some time to improve the sanitary condition of the metropolis, and, according to present appearances, practical results may be expected. The movement originated in the Academy of Medicine, and several medical gentlemen have already had five informal meetings on the subject.

The stockholders of the Southern Pacific Railroad met here in Convention to-day. General RICHARDSON offered a resolution requiring the stockholders present to register the amount of stock they represented, so that a majority of shares might decide the questions that came up.

Out of fifty-eight cases of officers retired by the Naval Board, and subsequently referred to tile President for his decision, he to-day nominated thirty-five for restoration. Among the number are the following: Captain--Voorhes. ComManders--Armstrong and Long.

From the Cincinnati Gazette. One of the most painful scenes which has ever come within our experience was witnessed at the execution of ALBERT MYERS, for the murder of BARTLETT NEVILLE, (both formerly convicts in the Penitentiary) at Columbus, yesterday, Dec. 17.

We are glad to hear that the Post-Office Committee in Congress proposes to take some measures to put our ocean mail service on a better footing. Thus far its mismanagement has been most conspicuous and disastrous.

Not with standing the hard rain of last evening, the Rutgers-street Church was well filled by an eager audience, to hear Doctor HOEMES poem of "The Heart's Own Secret." The poem is not a continuous narration, but a series of four poems, each one, though different in subject, illustrating the theme, and narrated as the youthful Feramorz, recited his romances to Lallah Rookh.

From the Union of Tuesday. It is highly probable that a cargo of slaves have been landed in one of the States of the Union. We are in possession of no specific information on the subject ; there are, nevertheless, many reasons to believe that the question has assumed a practical shape, and perhaps it should be so treated by the public.

The Pacific Railroad is in peril from its friends. Some of them have shown a disposition to kill the enterprise with kindness, and to protect it into paralysis which the country can ill afford to allow them to indulge. For the Pacific Railroad is one of the urgent necessities of our present national position.

A remarkably sudden death occurred recentlv, at the Parisian Italian Opera House Mercadante's " I Giuramento" was given. Towards the closet of the opera the tenors Viscardo, stabs the prima donna, Elaisa. At the moment when this event took place, on Saturday night, a slight scream was heard from a lady in one of the grand tier boxes.

The following memorial, addressed to Senator MASON, is on the Senate files at Washington, and is of interest in connection with the narrative of the AINSA case, which we have already published: Hon. James M. Mason, Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs:

FINCH.--In this City, on Sunday, Dec. 19, MARY FINCH, relict of the late Ferris Finch, aged 64 years, 6 months and 15 days. The friends and relatives are invited to attend her funeral, on Wednesday, at 10 1/2 o'clock, from No. 22 Lewis-st., without further invitation.

The ball last evening was a comfortable success A brilliant, and, considering the publicity of the entertainment, select audience enjoyed all the fascinating pleasures of music anti the dance up to a late hour of last night and an early hour of this morning.

THE SPPOSED MURDER IN WEST HOBOKEN-ELUCIDATION OF THE MYSTERY.--The inquest upon the body of the unknown German found shot early on Monday morning, on the Paterson Plank-road, was held on Tuesday morning, by Coroner BOHNSTEAD. As the investigation was in progress, inquiry was made of a stage-driver who was coming from West Hoboken, as to whether anything farther had been learned.

To the Citizens of New-York: We ask your attention for a few moments to a subject that concerns each one and all of us. In a little more than two months--on the 22d of February next--Mount Vernon, the home that WASHINGTON cherished in life and now hallows in death, can be placed in the care of the people of the United States, as the property of the themselves and their descendants in perpetualty.

Le Nord reprints from the Paris Moniteur of the 22d July, 1849, the speech delivered in the Legislative Assembly by M. Montalemaert, in defencs of the law upon the Press under which he has just been convicted. The speech, from its conservative tendencies, appears to have provoked numerous interruptions from the members of the Left.
The unquiet genius, whose schemes have already created so much unnecessary excitement on this side of the Atlantic, has materially narrowed the field of his mischievous proclivities.

Tuesday afternoon, Messrs. HENRY BAYSE, of Weston, CHAS. LEMMON, of St. Louis, and BENJ. DUNCAN, of this city, arrived direct from the Great Salt Lake City. These gentlemen left with the mail on the morning of the 20th of November. Mr. MAJORS, of the firm of RUSSELL, MAJORS WADDLE, in company with Dr. HOBES, was also to leave Salt Lake City for the States, by private conveyance, on the following Monday.

Reliable intelligence is said to have been received in Washington relative to the designs of Spain upon Mexico, which is in direct conflict with the positive assertions of Seiior TASSARA, the Spanish Minister to our Government.

SIR: Though several months have elapsed since the date of your kind communication to my niece, Miss FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE, it is not very many days since it reached her hands.

Various memorials of no public interest were presented. The Senate passed the bill making appropriations for the improvement of the; St. Clair Flats, by Ayes 29; Nays 22. The Pacific Railroad bill came up. Mr. SEWARD, of New York, addressed the Senate.

This morning, every thing seems to be under a cloud. The Court itself, that impersonation of justice, complains of feeling unwell, and the ladies are kept away by the rain, excepting an indefatigable half dozen. Yesterday, the trial dragged tediously enough until afternoon. Then public curiosity received a new and unexpected impetus.

JUDGE EDMONDS AND SPIRITUALISM.--Judge EDMONDS denies a statement published in a morning paper, that his faith in Spiritualism is beginning to waver. On the contrary, he declares that his belief is founded upon over eight years' careful investigation, and cannot be shaken by the "pretended exposures of knaves or fools," or by the "denunciations of those who have never investigated " the subject.

A CURIOUS CASE FOR THE MEDICAL FACULTY. -On Sunday evening last Coroner REDDING was notilied to hold an inquest on the body of JOHN FARRAN, who had - died suddenly at the corner of Joralemon and Furman streets. A jury was impanneled, and the body viewed on Monday.

From the N. O. Commercial Bulletin. We briefly mentioned, a few days ago, the fact that the duly on flour imported into Brazil had been reduced by an Imperial decree thirty per centum below the former Tariff; and expressed the opinion that this reduction of duties on the chief articles of export from this country to Brazil would undoubtedly have the effect, in a few )ears, of making the balance of trade in our favor.

By the way of Havana we receive advices from Merida to Dec. 1. On the 3d of October the authority of the Constitutionalists had been definitely established in that city, Don LIBORIO IRIGOYEN, being inaugurated as Governor. A large number of resignations of civil officials and desertions from the army had followed.

A CARD FROM ML L. W. OGDEN. In yesterday's number of your paper my notice was called to the publication, furnished by "a friend of the Hon. D. E. SICKLES," of certain correspondence carried on by the lion. S. F. BUTTERWORTH in behalf of Mr. S., and myself in behalf of Dr. TUCKER.

ARRIVAL OF THE OVERLAND MAIL AT ST. LOUIS. The Overland Mail at St. Louis brings dates from San Francisco to Nov. 22, two days later than steamer advices. Our telegrams from St. Louis have indicated the leading items of intelligence. The California papers contain some additional news:

Inasmuch as JUAREZ is not the President of Mexico, and as the Government de facto of that country is hostile to him, and seems likely to subjugate him and his followers, Senor MATA'S power to negotiate the. bale of a portion of Mexico in the name and on behalf of JUAREZ is not likely to be acknowledged by the Government at Washington.--Commercial.

From the Albany Statesman of Tuesday Evening. The Board mot Monday for the purpose of completing the canvass of votes cast in November last. The return of the votes for Governor and Canal Commissioner were carefully examined, found to be correct, and the estimates were signed.

The U. S. Man Steamship Black Warrior, J. W. SMITH, commander, from Now Orleans and Havana, arrived here yesterday afternoon. She was detained all the morning outside tile bar by a dense fog. Owing to a very heavy fog, the Black Warrior was unable to leave the Mississippi until tile morning of the 13th; arrived at Havana on the evening of the 15th, and left there the next day at 2 1/2 P. M.

MEEKER--GREENWOOD.--In this City, on Tuesday, Dec. 21, at the residence of the bride's mother, No. 123 Lexington-av., by the Rev. Henry E. Montgomery, CHARLES H. MEEKER to CLARA, daughter of the late Clark Greenwood, all of this City.

Y., from citizns of Berks and Lancaster Counties, Penn., asking for protection for American industry; and fifty or sixty more presented by Mr. CAMERON, of Penn., from all the counties of Pennsylvania, making the same requset.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: My attention has been called to the report on yesterday's Times of the dismissal of the complaint against CHARLES KNOX for perjury, by Justice OSBORN. That report is erroneous and calculated to mislead the public as to the facts. Upon the state of facts before the Magistrate various legal questions were presented and discussed.

If there be any sense of earthly things in souls set free, the late President MONROE must look with mingled scorn and surprise upon the scene of this mortal labors. With scorn, certainly, as finding that the lapse of thirty years has made men no wiser; that grave National questions are handled now, as in his time they were, in the spirit of sixpenny partisan passion;

The Senate confirmed all the nominations for restoration to the Navy, sent in yesterday, as follows: Captains--Paine, Ramsey and Inman to the Active list, and Voorhees to the Leave on Pay list. Commanders--Armstrong, Long, Johnson and Shaw to the active list, and Lecompte to the leave list. Promotions to Commandres on the Active List--Lientenants Porter, Williamson, Carter, Bissell, Gleason, Killy, Chandler, Meade and Gibson.

The Overland Mail, with San Francisco dates of the 25th ultimo, four days later, has arrived here. The news is unimportant. Three passengers by the Overland Mail from Kansas City reached Stockton Nov. 24. They were fifty-one days out. The Mohave and Navajoe Indians were hostile and troublesome.

The December Term of the Superior Court began yesterday afternoon. As that Court has a prior claim to the room in which this trial has thus far been held, the Judge adjourned the afternoon session to the Senate Chamber. The Superior Court, however, adjourned until next Monday, so that this case might proceed as before.

From private sources we are enabled to add the following interesting particulars to those furnished by our own correspondent. President JUAREZ, at Vera Cruz, is awaiting the receipt of duties from vessels lately arrived, for the funds with which to move his forces against the City of Mexico; and is not at all intimidated by the rumors of ECHEAGARY'S march upon Vera Cruz,

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The last entertainment of the Mount Vernon Festival took place last night, and was a success. For the first time in New York, Mr. MUSARD had the satisfaction of beholding and audience really disposed to promenade, and a house crowded in every part. If two or three such results could be obtained, there would be no difficulty in making the promenade concert a permanent institution, even as it is in London.

Various rumors touching the attitude of Spain towards Mexico were afloat in Washington to Tuesday, and were given yesterday in our telegraphic dispathces from the Capital. It was stated that the Spanish fleet, under TOPETE, had taken possession of the Bar of Tampico, or of the forts at the entrance of that harbor, and that a Spanish force was to be landed at Tampico, to enforce by landoperations the claims of Spani upon Mexico.

A variety of topics occupied the attention of Congress yesterday, which will be found set forth in our telegraphic summary. The Pacific Railroad discussion was not continued in the Senate, several messages being received from the President, which were considered in Executive Session. Their contents have not transpired. In the House, the bill pensioning the soldiers of the War of 1812, was passed by a decisive vote.
The following note, we are informed, was placed in the hands of Mr. SICKLES before 3 P. M. of yesterday:

The steamship Edinburgh, of the Glasgow line, from Glasgow on the 2d December, reached this port yesterday, at noon. The Edinburgh experienced for fifteen days after sailing a continuous succession of very heavy westerly gales, accompanied by high dangerous seas. For the rest of the passage, winds still westerly, but more moderate.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The second promenade concert, at the remarkably low price of twenty-five cents, takes place to-night. A magnificent orchestra of a bundred players, two conductors, Messrs, BERGMANN and MUSARD, and a fine programme, are provided for the occasion. The very tasteful decorations of the Mount Vernont Ball are retained.

Valor is a very excellent commodity, and is all the better for being mingled with a little common sense. Dr. J. C, TUCKER is probably a valiant man:-we wish we could add with truth that he is also sensible. It is possible he may be, but he certainly has a very odd way of showing it.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Mr. JAS. M. SMITH is under a mistake in saying that your report of the dismissal of the charge against me was erroneous, The facts are that when the prosecution rested, my counsel moved, without going into any evidence on my behalf, to dismiss the complaint on the prosecutor's on showing.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I observe in the journals of this morning a communication from Dr. J.C. TUCKER addressed to me. I have no acquaintance with this person, and he has no right to claim any notice from me; first, because he has never received an injury at my hands, and secondly, because he has chosen a mode of communicating a challenge--through a newspaper--never employed by gentlemen.

There is naturally a strong desire to know something of Dr. Brnnets's antecedents and history. For. tunately I have succeeded In getting hold of docu. ments,-the source of which vouches for their authentlcity,-which give as full information on this sub. ject as could be desired, as they bear marks as having emanated from the Doctor's:own mind and pen.

MAN MURDERED BY HIS SON.--A murder was committed Dec. 16. at Northfield, Ct. A man named HIRAM TRIPPE was killed by his son, 30 years of age and insane, No cause assigned. About dark, high words having passed between father and son, the latter drew a dirk-knife and pursued the old gentleman, who took refuge in his bed-room, closing the door after him, and holding it fast.

Great pressure has been brought to bear on the President yesterday and to-day to induce him to send in the nominations of Lieut. BOYLE and various other Naval officers, but without avail. One additional nomination--that of Lieut. CHARLES HUNTER, for transfer from the Furlough to the Deave Pay list--was transmitted to the Senate to-day, and confirmed.

MINIE RIFLES IN INDIAN WARFARE.--Mr. KENDELL writes from Texas to the New-Orleans picayune: "In one of LINDSAY'S recent scouts against the Navajos, one of the latter was killed at the distance of four hundred yards, and another wounded. If we can outreach them in this way, it is a great point gained ; for the Indian is notoriously too prudent of his blood to fight long at a disadvantage.

A Pacific Railroad bill is likely to run the gauntlet between opposing political interests, parjobberse 'and double-faced friends, till it is cheatedd of its fair proportions, and distorted with excrescences that will leave their scar forever. All those kicks and bruises and stabs 'in the back will dehray the completion of a Pacific Railway, and modify itt' usefulness, but they will not kill it,

The steamship Pacific, with European advices five days later, arrived at St. Johns, N. F., yesterday, from Galway on the evening of the 9th inst., en route for New-York. Her news is quite interesting. A general meeting of the shareholders of the Atlantic Telegraph was called for the 15th inst., to consider the condition of affairs, and Lord DERBY acknowledges the receipt of a memorial praying for further Government aid for the enterprise.

The steamship Quaker City is below, She has 123 passengers, and San Francisc dates of the 6th inst. The steamship Hermann arrived at San Francisco on the 27th ult. The bark Columbus, of New.London, was totally wrecked in Shasta Bay on the 10th of August.

The Southern Pacific Railroad Convention me again last evening, and the prominent stockholders gave details of their connection with the Road, show ing that no fraudhilent stock had been issued. General RICHARDSON, Chairman of the Business Committee showed that enough money was already provided to pay for immediate liabil-ties.

AN AMERICAN VDMIRAL AT last.-ThE result of that hasty and ill considered act authorizing the creation of the Naval Retiring Board, is just what might have been anticipated as the natural reaction of a piece of gross injustice. Half a million of dollars is a very moderate cstimate of the cost to the country of the action of the famous bill for improving the condition of the Navy, while the good accomplished is naught.

The Senate was opened with prayer by a Catholic priest, in a white surplice. Various memorials were presented, and a message was received from the President of the United States. Mr. CRITTENDEN, of Kentucky, introduced a bill to regulate the manner of election of United States Senators. Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

AN ELEGANT ENGRAVING.--A very fine steel engraving, which appeals at once to our national pride and to our love of art, has just been published. It is a picture of WASHINGTON and his Gencrals, representing the great Commander standing in the centre, with over thirty of the most prominent general officers of the Revolution grouped around him.

The Belfast ship United Kingdom, Capt. ADAIR sailed from Quebec Oct. 6, with a cargo of lumber bound to Belfast. She had continual gales from the Banks. On the 7th of November, during a heavy gale she sprung the rudder, and was kept off to ease it. After wards. in a severe gale from the northwest, she lost the rudder entirely. The ship, for a few days, was steered with chains.

The Washington Union seems to be suffering very acutely under the conviction that there is not much probability of Mr. BUCHANAN's being able to enforce the laws against the Slavetrade by the aid of Southern juries.

Our readers do not need to be informed that we have been slow to put faith in the alleged revival of the Slave-trade on the shores of this country, and within the limits of one of the thirteen States which formed the original Union of the American colonies.

CHINESE INTELLIGENCK.-The opening of commercial relations with China has led to the establishment of a bi-monhly newspaper in London called the China Ttlegraph Its object is to present a more complete and accurate summary of intelligence from China and the East than is given in the other journals of the day.

As a mere question of philanthropy to the negro, the persons who have recently brought a cargo of Africans from the coast of Guinea and landed them in Georgia, may have done a beneticial work. But, aside from that isolated feature of the transaction, we cannot perceive a single circumstance to relieve moral ?? of the crime.

The Scrow-steamship Guatemala, now nearly completed at Greenpoint for the Panama Railroad Company, is worth a passing notice. She is 214 feet long on deck and 32 feet 0 inches wide; her hold Is 10 feet 6 inches deep, between decks there are seven feet, and from main dock to passenger deck there are 7 feet 4 inches, making a total depth of 25 feet 6 inches.

The steamship Pacific has arrived at this port from Galway on the evening of the 19:h Inst. She brings Livervool mail advices of the evening of the 8th, and teiegralphic accounts from Liverpool ald London to the 9th. The Royal Mail steamship Asia from Ne w-York on the 24th ult., arrived at Liverpool on the 5th inst.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is understood that the prisoner CANGEMI will be brought before the Judges of the General Term for sentence, at an adjourned Court to be held next week. Some censures have been pronounced upon the Jury in some of the City papers, which seemed to me entirely undeserved, and unwarranted by the facts.

The following is the bill relative to the Territories, introduced in the House by Mr. MORRIS of Illinois: A Bill for an act granting to the people of the several organized Territories of the United States the right to provide, through their respective Legislatures, for the appointment or election of their Governors, Judges and all other Territorial officers in such mode or manner as said Legislature may by law determine.

A WORD OF CAUTION.--A person, calling himself L. M. RAYMOND, and referring to the TIMES Editor for evidence of character, is engaged in collecting advertisements for various newspapers and other periodicals. We desire to say that we know nothing whatever of hire, but have reason to infer, from some of his operations, that he is a swindler;

WELCHER.--In this City. on Thursday, De. 23, MARIA ESTRELLE, only daughter of Henry B. and Sarah F'. Welcher, aged 14 months and 8 days. The funeral' service will take place this evening, at No. 224 West 16th at, at 17 o'clock. I The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend.

The California papers by the Overland Mail furnish a few additional items of news, The Pitt River Indians have massacred several whites. The mines in Southern Oregon are yielding largely, and new discoveries were being made. Tidings of the overdue steamer Columbia had been received. She Put into Umpqua Straits in coasequenee of stress of weather.

Compromises are charming devices, the design of which usually is to conciliate two opposite interests by destroying the value of each. Nothing more delights your average statesman than to achieve such a triumph; and compromise-making has accordingly made the political fortune of several illustrious men in modern times and in various countries.

The case of Bennett vs. Bennett strongly resembles a case of Intermittent fever. About every other day the excitement reaches a high mark. Then witnesses are spicy and keen, lawyers witty, and the spectators are all on the qui vive. At the intervening periods a state of affairs exactly opposite prevails.

TAYLOR--MERIAM.--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 22, 1858. by the Rev. Dr. S.D. Burchard, W. RALPH TAYLOR to RACHEL B., daughter of J. H. Meriam , Esq. , all of this City. TIMPSON--FLAGLER.--At Peekskill, on Wednesday. Dec. 22. by the Rev. Mr. Roberts. EDWIN W. TIMPSON, of this City, to FANNY, daughter of Philip Flagler, Esq ., of Peekskill.

Last evening, Signor ALBERTO MARIO delivered a lecture on Italy, in Italian, at Professor MACMULLEN'S lecture-room, No. 21 East Twentieth-street, for the benefit of the Italian Society of Mutual Aid. We understand that Signor MARIO'S object in coming to here, and to induce them to form part of the National Italian Association, whose members, spread through-out the Italian Peninsula, are preparing for the next struggle after Liberty and Independence.

MOUN? VERNONISM.--We have a budget of communications urging ladies who receive New-Year's calls to open a box for contributions from their visitors to the Mount Vernon fund. We decline to publish them, and hope-nothing of the kind will be done.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is of no consequence how long ago it was since I moved into the neighborhood of an extremely progressive church, whose minister is the equivalent of all that is ardent and enlightened in the humanities of religion. Whenever it was, it is sufficient to know that I hailed the new neighborhood as the crown of sundry long cherished desires. I have a family.

McBLAIR, now commanding the sloop Dale on the coast of Africa, which are founded upon a statement quoted from the Tribune, purporting to be contained in a letter written on board the Dale.

The rumors of further fillibuster expeditions from our Southern ports to Nicaragua are daily becoming more numerous and significant ; and, for our own part, we do not doubt that they are well founded.

The screw-steamship Saxonia, of the Hamburg line, from Southampton, on Sunday, Dec. 5, at 101/2 A. M., arrived at this port early yesterday morning. She brings 92 passengers. Capt. ERLERS has experienced very severe weather. The gales have been almost continual from the northward and westward during the entire passage. From the 10th to the 15th was obliged to lie to most of the time.

THE LIQUOR CASES.--Of the fifty liquor dealers indicted by the last Grand Jury for selling liquor without license, twenty-four were, yesterday, sentenced in the Court of Sessions. Eleven of these pleaded guilty to the indictments found against them, and the others were tried and found guilty. In only two cases was sentence suspended, and this was where the parties had given up the liquor traffic and gone into some respectable business.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Please allow me to suggest to the managers of the Philharmonic Society, in behalf of many subscribers, the propriety of an earlier hour for their afternoon relcarsals. These now commence at 31/2, and many ladies from the suburbs are compelled either to return home in the dark, or to leave the room before the entertainment is concluded.

We received, yesterday, by mail, the following interesting documents from the Superintendent of the Bank Department: BANK DEPARTMENT, ALBANY, Dec. 23, 1858. To Messrs. Raymond, Wesley Co., Times Office, New-York:

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The annual performance of HANDEL'S sublime Oratorio, the "Messiah," takes place to-night at the Academy of Music. The Harmonic Society will appear in its greatest force assisted by several eminent artists in the solo parts. No better entertainment can be found for the Christmas night.

From the Washington Union. Mr. DAVIS, of Mississippi, proposes to proceed by attachment against Spain as an absent, absconding or fraudulent debtor. We have a long account against Spain, contracted under aggravated circumstances, and sufficient time has elapsed to show that she is utterly indifferent alike to the obligations she has incurred, and to the very offensive events of their origin.

LOSS OF THE SIIIP UNITED KINGDOM. ARRIVAL OF THE CREW AT THIS PORT. The particulars of the loss of this ship, which was briefly alluded to yesterday, in our marine report, have been furnished by Captain ADAIR, who, with his crew, arrived at this port yesterday, on board the ship Daniel Webster.

Mrs. Lydia Sayer Hasbrouck, who publishes the Sybil, a "Dress-Reform" periodical, at Middletown, N. V., is discussing the question whether a married woman should relinquish maiden name. She says that she and her husband agreed to give her name the preference--but she doesn't "care so much as the wave of straw" whether she is called Sayer or Sayer Hasbrouck.

The pale moon shimmered through the blind, Heal broken moaned the horneless wind, As if the whole world was unkind. The chimes, with wild, harmonic din, From turrets, rang the New-Year in-- The infant born without a sin. Amid a heap of ashes boar, Like heart that ruin bravely bore, Still glowed the pine-log's dull-red core.

Under the City Charter, tile enterprise of cleaning our streets must be undertaken by contract, provided the job costs over $250. So much of street-cleaning as we have enjoyed during the year is likely to cost $300,000, yet no contraets have ever been entered upon, and it is only by an evasion of the plain language of the law that a cent of this amount has been paid.

The steamship Saxonia, from Southampton, Dec. 5, arrived yesterday morning. The only addition by her to the news by the Arabia is continued in London files of the 4th--one day later than were brought by that vessel.

CHRISTMAS DAY,--How many old and tender associations are connected with the word! It is not for us, as for the natives of the Old World, brimful of the pleasantest thoughts and most delightful home records. Our pulses do not throb as we imagine the Yule Leg burning on the earth; the holly, with its scarlet berries, is unappreciated, and mistletoe, unfortunately for one sex, is unknown.

DOUGLAS AND THE DEMOCRACY.--Business--especially political business--at Washington, seems to await the arrival of Senator DOUGLAS. A profound mystery as to his course seems to brood over the public mind.

DOMESTIC MARKETS. In New-York, the week opened quite briskly, especially for domestic Wool, at very full and buoy. ant prices. Toward the close, owing, in part, to the influence of unfavorable weather, less activity was discernable, yet holders steadily adheared to their asking prices, and appealed to be reluctant to make any concussions, oven to buyers of large quantities.

DEAR SIR: We have the honor to present you a specimen of gold obtained from the nowly-discovered "El Dorado," In Western Kansas. This specimen is a part of several ounces purchased by us from two miners by the name of RUSSELL, untives of Georgin, by whose adventures in search of gold the gold mines of Kansas have been developed.

There can be no stronger indication of the speedy disappearance of dueling from amongst even the possibilities of social intercourse, than the practice now prevailing amongst politicians of giving challenges, which it is well known on both sides will not result in a fight.

The stampede of members of Congress has left the city extremely dull. To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you allow a plain man to offer a few remarks in answer to your strictures upon Mr, FOSTER'S amendment to the Pacific Railroad bill now pending before Congress.

CHRISTMAS DAY.--The festival of Christmas was very generally observed in the Metropolis. There was a suspension of business; the public offices and Courts were all closed, and in most of the City churches Divine Service was celebrated.

DISCONTINUANCE OF LAND DISTRICTS.--The Secretary of the Interior has found it necessary, in compliance with law, to order the discontinuance of the "Platte" and "Chariton" land districts in the State of Missouri.

New from Australia-Cannibalism at the Fejee Islands-Nez-Perces Treaty. The Overland Mail, though with dates from San Francisco not so late as the news by the Quaker City, brings some intelligence not before published. The Sydney (Australia) papers had been received to 8th September.

WIGHT--RICH--At Yonkers, N. Y., on Thursday, Dec. 23, at the residence of the bride's father, by the Rev, Rollin A. Sawyer, Mr. BERBERT WIGHT, of Milwaukee,. Wis., to CAROLINE M., daughter of Josiah Rich, Esq., of the former place.

GENERAL SCOTT AT CHARLESTON.--The steamship Marion, Captain FOSTER, reached Charleston on Saturday morning at 3 o'clock, having on board Lieutenant-General WINFIELD SCOTT, U. S. A. In company with him were Lieutenant-Colonel Lay. U. S. A., and Dr. WOOD. U S. A. As Soon as the steamship reached the wharf he was waited upon by a Committee of six from the Washington Light Infantry, in full uniform.

The daylight really seems to be breaking in upon the darkness of tile Nicaraguan chaos. The political complications which have so long been permitted to hamper the freedom of commercial enterprise on the Isthmus are fast unraveling at Washington and San Juan.

CHRISTMAS DAY.-This festival was very generally observed in Brooklyn. All-places of business were closed at an early hour in the morning, always excepting the bar-rooms. There was one service in many of the churches, and in others the SabbathSchool children gave entertainments, and divided the contents of a Christmas-tree, furnished by their friends.

THE OHIO TRUST COMPANY DIFFICULTY TO BE COMPROMISED.--We understand that the attorneys for BELL GRANT and those for SPINING BROWN, have agreed upon a general basis for a compromise of the matters in dispute, and that the controversy will be settled without the further interference of the Courts.

In the recent treaty between Russia and China it is stipulated that there shall be a monthly mail communication between Kiachta, on the Russian frontier, and Pekin, the communication to be effected in fifteen days, for the convenience of the two Governments, as well as for the wants of the Russian Ecclesiastical Mission at Pekin.

No storm was ever succeeded by a calm more profound than that which has followed the political tempest that, not long since, swept over the emerald plains of Kansas. Peace is now as universal as was contest; harmony, as was discord; industry, as was idleness; and prosperity as was wastefulness and ruin.

The intelligence by these arrivals has been anticipated to Dec. 4 by tire arrival of the Arabia, at Bosten, and briefly to the 8th by the Pacific, at St. Johns.
