SENATOR DOUGLAS.--There are rumors on every side of a determination on the part of sundry partisans of the Administration to force Senator DOUGLAS into personal quarrels immediately on his return to Washington.

From the Boston Traveller. For the year 1858, now near its close; only one death has occurred in this city from small pox, while in New-York the mortality from this disorder has, at times, been as high as twenty par week, and, probably for the entire year, will reach 100 or more. The exemption of Boston, in this particular, has now continued through several years.

The popular notion that Yankees are quite as fond of the almighty dollar as of the "Self- Denying Ordinance," or the Blue Laws of Connecticut, has just received fresh support from two remarkable incidents in the life of New England.

A great City furnishes tableaux vivants sufficiently numerous and varied to occupy pen and pencil for a life-time. The contrasts of characters, classes and quarters are so great as to raise a doubt whether races as diverse as the Angelic and the Satanic have not gathered under the same municipality.

The Coos Republican narrates the successful termination of an enterprise several times attempted but never before accomplished, viz., the ascent of Mount Washington in Winter. Later than the early part of September, the ascent of any of the White Mountain range is attended with danger, and several who have made the attempt have lost their lives.

OUR CONGRESSIONAL DEBATES.--The House of Representatives on Thursday adopted, by a vote of 73 to 55, a resolution directing a special Committee "To consider and report on the expediency of removing the president desks from the Hall, and making such arrangements it the seats of members as will bring them together In a smaller space, for the purpose of further facility of hearing and more orderly debate."

Gen. HEIBAN returned to New-York yesterday, after short but satisfactory interview with Secretary CASS touching New-Granadian affairs. He submitted for the consideration of Government an important dispatch which he has lately received.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Will you allow me, through the columns of your widely circulated journal to Indulge In a few reflections concerning the propriety and expediency of selecting the next President of the United States from the South.

The news from Washington is small in amount and unimportant in character. All public business, nearly, has been suspended until after the holidays, and such of the members of Congress as live too far from the Capitol to go home to their families have taken the opportunity to pay a visit to New-York and Philadelphia, and see something of real Metropolitan life.

MOTLEY.-In this City, on Sunday evening, 20th inst., Mr. JOHN C. MOTLEY, in the 40th year of his age. The friends of the family and those of his brothers, James M. and Samuel S., and of his brother-in-law, JamesT. Barker, are requested to attend his funeral, from his late residence, Lexington-av., between 37th and 38th sts., on Tuesday, 28th inst., at 2 o'clock P. M.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I take this form, to ask your subscribers if there is any one of them interested in the prosperity of the young men of color in this metropolis. I am not a little interested in their welfare, and would solicit, if I am not too impetuous, the attention of the public.

ACADEMY OF Music.-The Annual Performance of the "Messiah" by the members of the New-York Harmonic Society, attracted a splendid audience on Saturday (Christmas) night. The performance has become so much a matter of routine, that it does not, we apprehend, excite a great amount of enthusiasm among the members.

The Vanderbilt steamer Ariel, from Havre and Southampton, whose arrival at Halifax was announced on the 20th inst. together with the death of Captain LUDLOW, arrived at this port yesterday noon in 26 days from Southampton.

Madame Barrot, the mother of M. Odillon Barrot, and MM. Ferdinand and Adolphie Barrot, died Nov, 28, at the age of 03 years. She was the widow of the M. Barrot who voted in the Convention banishing Louis XVI, instead of beheading him.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, Captain LOTT, from Liverpool Dec. 11, at 10 P. M., arrived at this port last evening. On the 12th December, at 8 A. M., the Asia exchanged signals with the steamship Canada. On the 13th December, at 7 1/2 P. M., she passed a large screw steamer, supposed to be the City of Baltimore.

The property, such as it is, belongs to the public;

One Henry Wright is under bail of $10,000, at Nashville, to stared his trial for forging land-warrant certificates. A plea of insanity having been set up, the prosecuting officer produced the testimony of the medical officers of the Lunatic Asylum, which failed to establish the lunacy. Hence, Wright is bound over to appear and answer.

DEATH OF GENERAL JAMES GADSDEN.--A telegram from Charleston announces the death of Gen. JAMES GADSDEN, in that City, on the 26th December. Gen. GADSDEN was a native of South Carolina, and was about CO years of age. lle was a brother of Bishop GADSDEN.

FIRST GUN FROM PARAGUAY.--It is something less than a year since the United States published its resolution to chastise the perversity of Paraguay. From that time formidable preparations have been made to carry the resolution into effect. A fleet of shallow shipping has been bought up; men-of-war have been placed in commission; marines mustered, and drilled, and shipped;

CALVERT--In this City, on Monday morning, Dec. 27, of remittent and typhoid fever, Mrs. MARTHA CALVERT, wife of John Calvert in the 54th year of her age. The statue of Handel is now ready for casting. The sculptor is named Heidel, and his work is inlended for Halle. The figure is attired in the costume of the period in which Handel lived; the left hand rests on the side; the right, in which is placed a roll of music, rests on a small desk before him, on which lies the score of the "Messiah."

MOBBING FREE LOVERS.--They have had an interesting time, recently, at Burr's Mills, on the Central Ohio Railroad. Some time since a woman, Mrs. PEPERS, and a man named ALMOND commenced living together near, Burr's Mills, dispensing with the preliminaries necessary to make them "man and wife." This excited the indignation of the populace, especially as ALMOND had a wife living.

It is not very long since we had occasion to allude to a pamphlet issued by Gen. COMONFORT, in defence of his administration in Mexico. It was, it may be remembered, a calm, dignified self-justification, without asperity in the treatment of adversaries, and, upon the whole, a highly creditable specimen of memoir writing, under the embarrassing condition of following immediately upon the facts, and while the actors in the drama still crowded the stage.

By the Chicago train, yesterday, the party of English tourists who have been on a hunting excursion to the west of us, arrived in St. Louis and took up quarters at the Planters' House. LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--There will be a per, formance of "Our American Cousin" at this house to-day in aid of the funds of the Mount Vernon Association. A comedy so celebrated and popular as Mr. TAYLOR'S is sure on Its own merits to attract a large audience, especially when it is known that the entire proceeds of the performance are generously donated by Miss KEENE to the Ladies' fund.

The New-Jersey State Teacher's Association asssembled at the Lyeum Hall, Jersey City, at 3 o'clock P. M. Yesterday, agreeably to announcement,--President PHELPS in the Chair, Prayer was offered by the Rev. Mr. LOCKWOOD, the delegate from Monmouth County. His HONOR Mayor GREGORY then welcomed the Association to the city and offered its members the hospitalities of its citizens.

KINGS COUNTY DEMOGRACY.--The delegates from the different Committees of the two factions into which the Democracy of Kings County has been divided for two years past, have agreed upon a basis for a union, provided that their action is ratified by the masSEs of both sections, which, in the minds of many, is a test that the bargain will not stand.

Sylvester Groat, a young man residing in Kinderhook, eloped, Dec. 24, with a young girl, Eineline Folmsdee, of Schodack. The twain proceeded to Albany, Whither they were tracked. The girl was taken back to her friends, but Groat included the police, and has since returned to Kinderhook. Miss Folmsdee states that she ran away, not because she ??touch of Groat, but because she thought less of certain other folks.

L., Nov. 30, 1858. SIR: We have delayed wiriting to the Department since our arrival at this post, until we could do so in a manner satisfactory to you. We are now encamped within sight of Major VAN DORN'S command, on Otter Creek.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The writer was quite amused upon reading your article, New-York in Danger," in this morning's paper, as it is a well-known fact that Boston merchants have for the past five years been making great efforts to induce their domestic commission houses to efforts to induce their domestic commission houses to withdraw from New-York; but they understand their interest too well to do so.

THE PARK GROUND.-One branch of the Common Council voted night before last to open a carriage-way across the Park. This is something, but not enough. It will relieve the pressure upon Broadway and Fulton-street somewhat. But it would have been much better if steps had been taken to convert the whole Park into an open, available plaza,

THE WANDERER'S AFRICANS.--The following Interesting communication appears in the Edgefield (S. C.) Advertiser: MR. EDITOR: Please insert this as an authorized announcement that the cargo of slaves. brought by the Wanderer from Africa, have been landed in Edgefield District, and that most of them are now within its confines. This act has been done bya combination of many of the first families in Georgia and South Carolina, from purely patriotic motives.

A delegation from Fort Scott, consisting of Mr. BULL, the present Sheriff of Bourbon County, JAMES JONES, Editor of the Fort Scott Democrat, and Mr. CAMPBELL, Deputy Marshal of the County, arrived in our City this morning, en route to visit Gov. MEDARY, at Lecompton, with important news of further outrages in Southern Kansas.

PRESENT TO BARON HUMBOLDT.--Mr. MORITZ LOTH, of this city, the proprietor of REUTHE'S somewhat celebrated "Animal Trap," (the barbed hook and pistol combination,) has fitted up an elegant rosewood case containing a set of these traps, which he designs to send and present to Baron HUMBOLDT, the eminent Prussian philosopher and savant.

KNIPE.-In this City, on Tuesday, Dec, 28, WILLIAM. son of James J and Elizabeth knipe, aged years, 1 month and 28 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, this (Thursday) morning, at 10 o'clock, from the residence of his parents, No. 364 Broome st. His remains will be taken to Yonkers for interment.

Mr. WHITNEY, of New-York, applied to a physician of that City for treatment of a bronchial affection. The Doctor undertook the application of nitrate of silver by the use of an instrument invented by himself, and, during the operation, he punctured the windpipe, causing the death of the patient in one week.--Boston Post.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN. REORGANIZATION OF THE STREET DEPARTMENT. The Board met last evening, Alderman MCSPEDON in the Chair. Alderman BOOLE offered a resolution playing the Chamber of the Board at the disposal of the Hon. J. L. Orr, to-day, between the hours of 12 and 1 o'clock, for the reception of his friends and others of the citizens.

The Illinois arrived yesterday from Aspinwall, bringing dates from California to Dec. 6, and $1,494,000 in treasure. The dates from California have been anticipated by the Tehuantepec arrival at New-Orleans. The Hermann arrived at San Francisco Nov. 27, with 600 passengers from NewYork, via the Straits of Magellan, having made the trip in ninety-five days.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--An adjourned meeting of this Board was held yesterday, in the Jail on Raymond-street. An act was presented, by Supervisor T. G. BERGEN, in favor of reducing the fees attached to the office of Sheriff to about $3,200, with the profits to be derived from boarding prisoners, out of which the Sheriff to be required to pay for all assistance required.

A NEW EDITOR.--JESSE CLEMENS, formerly UnitedStatesSenator from Alabama, has assumed Inthe editorship of the Memphis (Tean.) Eagle and quirer. In his introductory he announces that it will be a party paper; that it will wage war upon the miscalled Democracy of the day,-opposing all its factions as alike corrupt and dishonest, and holding the whole party responsible for the evils that hare grown out of the Cincinnati Platform.

THE LANDING OF FILLIBUSTERS.--It is not easy to discover any reliable source for the apparently premature report that the Susan has succeeded in landing her " cargo of filibusters', in Nicaragua. The rumor is given without any statement of the route by which it can have come, and there is therefore little room to believe it correct.

PRESENTATION OF MEDALS FOR SAVING LIFE.--An interesting ceremony took place yesterday afternoon, at the private rooms of the Ailantic MuTual Insurance Company in Wall-street, in the presentation of medals, by the Life-saving Benevolent Association, to various persons whose names have been honorably mentioned in connection with the saving of life upon the ocean.

We published, yesterday, a series of resolutions adopted by the Canal Convention at Syracuse,--a body composed of some 400 persons, connected, more or less directly, with Canal navigation. They urge the completion of the enlargement by a direct tax; but the main object of the meeting seems to have been to urge measures against the railroads.

Your readers will have learned of the battle fought in Sinaloa between PESQUEEA 'S troops, under JESUS GARCIA MORALES,and some four hundred of GANDARA'S troops, under Gen. BORUNDA. It is impossible for us here to get at the true of the result, as PESQUERA does not permit letters to be sent by any without an examination of them, destroying such as do not contain intelligence favoring his side.

Tile adventurous few who yesterday traversed that stony desert called tile Park, in the early afternoon, when the winds of heaven blew the wildest, and the small sweepers at the crossings shrank appalled from their " dreadful trade," were refreshed and delighted with the sight of our country's flag proudly floating over the half-charred ruins of the City Hall.

From the Washington Union. There may be wisdom in the policy which confers despotic authority upon the Captain - General of Cuba. It accords substantially with the principles of the home Government. Her Catholic Majesty is aware that where so much authority is to be exercised it is necessary that it should be concentrated. Cuba is in the condition of perpetual war : it is a grand camp, under the command of a General.

To the Editor of the New - York Times : If we cannot have an Iron Pavement in Broadway, and relay the same blocks an inch apart on every side, filling in the with granite rubble about the size of filberts, and then turn in cement to till the spaces to make it solid?

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Having recently enjoyed a refreshing sleep in one of the night cars running on the Central Railroad, I desire to inform that class of your readers who ride on the rails, of the great alleviation of the fatigue and suffering heretofore Inevitable in night travel, furnished by this now feature In the appointments of the Central.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I see that you agree with the independent, national and practical editor of the Louisville Democrat, that "it is more in accordance with the genius of our Government to surrender all legislation over persons or property, to the people concerned;" and that "no party in the Free States will legislate to protect Savery in the Territories, contrary to the will of the people concerned."

Pursuant to public notice, a meeting of the citizens of Columbus and Lowndes Counties convened on Saturday, the 18th, to take into consideration the state of affairs in Central American, Southern emigration to Nicaragua, and the recent outrages committed by a British cruiser upon an American vessel at Grey town.
We hope nobody will imagine that all he has to do during this bitterly cold weather is to make himself as comfortable as possible. Winter brings its peculiar duties as well as discomforts.

The Nicaraguan Legation received dispatches to-day announcing the receipt of the Cass-Yrissad Treaty. They assure Gen. JEREZ that the Deputies will be immediately assembled, and the views of this Government laid before them. President MARTINEZ heartily sanctions these views, and promises that the Treaty shall be back here by the first of February, fully retitled.

SPIRITUALISM EXPOSED.--At the Melodeon, in Boston, on the evening of Dec. 27, Mr. M. V. BLY, a young gentleman who calls himself an "unconverted detective medium," and whose especial mission it is do denounce and expose the Spiritualist manifestations, threw a large audience, composed party of Spiritualists, into a violent fever.

THE NEW GUTTA PERCHA LIFE-BOAT.--The gutta percha life-boat sent out to Liverpool on board the ship Dreadnought, has been subjected to a variety of tests in the Liverpool docks, in the presence of a number of scientific and practical men. The Liverpool Times of the 6th, the Post of the same date, and Several other papers, contain very full descriptions of the boat, and of the experimental tests to which it has been subjected. .

To the Editor of the New-York Times : Several articles, editorial and communicated, have recently appeared in your columns, discussing subjects directly or incidentally affecting the manufacture of Iron in our country. Most of these articles have borne strong evidence of a jealous sympathy with the commercial interest to the exclusion of all others.

SOUTH CAROLINA AND THE MONUMENT TO THE SIGNERS OF THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE.--The project to build monument to the singers of the Declaration of Independence in Independence-square, in Philadelphia, all the thirteen original States contributing to it, has not been received in South Carolina with the same favor extended to it in other States.

SETTLEMENT OF A LONG--VEXED QUESTION,-- That tronblesome subject, the Quarantine question, has been finally disposed of in a very ingenious, economical and effective manner. The State authorities have adopted the suggestions of Captain BENHAM, and determined to build an island of five acres extent on the old Orchard Shoal in the Lower Bay, whereon it is intended to construct the necessary offices and hospitals.
POST-MARKING LETTERS.--We hear many and well-founded complaints of the loose and ineffectual manner in which post-marks are stamped at Post-Offices throughout the country, upon letters.

The London "Law Amendment Society" has just received a report from one of their committees on the Jury System, which recommends the retention of the rule of unanimity in criminal cases, but advises that it be dispensed with in civil suits.

THE UTAH EXPEDITION.--The Philadelphia Press publishes a letter from Leavenworth, giving the leading items of the cost of transportation of supplies for the Utah Army. One hundred and forty-six trains of wagons were sent out,--total number of wagons, 4,796. Each train had 320 yoke of oxen; total oxen 46,720.

The Pennsylvania Legislature meets at Harrisburg on Tuesday next, the 4th proxium. It is stated that the Governor's forthcoming message will present a most gratifying financial exhibition. The Senate, which is Democratle by one majority, will probably elect the Hon. John Creswell Speaker, and General Wm. H. Miller Clerk.

SMALL PREMISES AND LARGE CONCLUSIONS.--Our provincial contemporaries from time to time exhibit a sort of spasmodic concern about the progress of the metropolis which is very pleasant to see, since it illustrates at once the reality of our own advance and the vitality of the country at large.

Dr. Tschudi arrived at Panama early in December from a trip across the Cordilleras, from Buenos Ayres to Coblja, a distance of upwards of some hundred leagues. He left for Europe in the British steamer, with the object of compiling another work on South America.

The Baton Rouge Comet and Gazette says: "On Tuesday, Dec. 21, a free colored man, known in this as well as the adjacent parish as "Morgan the Peddler," was basely and cowardly murdered on his own premises. Morgan has been engaged for many years trading with people in this city--carrying goods from town in this wagon, and returning with products from the country.

" Who is it in the Press that calls on" New Year's day? asked, or very nearly asked, WILLIAM SHAKESPEARK; and we believe we are not far wrong when we answer. "Nobody," since Editors have no time for such pleasures. Not the less, however, do we like the honest, hearty old custom of opening the New Year with u cheerful smile and a pleasant word to all one's friends, and especially to the ladies.

A dispatch was telegraphed from Augusta, Ga., yesterday, and appeared in the evening pipers. stating that forty persons had been killed and drowned in consequence of a train running off the track on the railroad between Columbus and Macon, the accident being caused by the washing of the track by the late heavy rains.

Forty persons are reported killed and drowned this morning, by the train from Columbus to Macon running off the track, in consequence of injury hereto by late heavy rains. AUGUSTA, Friday, Dec. 31--P. M. This morning the train from Macon ran off the track two miles from Columbus, and a fireman and woodpasser were killed, and G. W. SMITH, engineer, and his jaw broken. None of the passengers were injured.

Manley Locke, the murderer of Constable Stair, made an attempt to escape a second time from the jail at Rochester on Tuesday night. He had effected a breach in the stone wall of the prison, with an iron bar taken from his bedstead, and loosened his shackles with the blade of a penknife.

She reports strong westerly gales during the entire passage. ACCIDENTS ON NEW-YEAR'S DAAY.--A child, four years of age, named CATHAHINE LINGH, fell, on Saturday, from the fourth story of the house, No. 40 Willett-street, and was taken up dead. A woman, named HENRIETTA SMITH, was run over by a carriage, in Sixth-avenue, near Thirteenth-street, by which her leg was fractured. A camphene lamp exploded at No. 143 West Broadway, setting fire to a straw bed and bedding. Engine No. 16 put out the flames.

NEW-YEAR'S DAY IN BROOKLYN,--As usual, the New Year was duly welcomed by the denizens of Brooklyn. All regular business was suspended, and each and every one tried to commence the year satisfactorily to himself, at least. Nothing occurred to put a damper upon this good intention. A careful observer, who had nothing to do but stand on a coiner and look after the business of other people, furnishes the following statement, which he professes

It affords me no little pleasure to report the probable conclusion of the Navajo war. Col. MILES, the commander at Defiance, went out, as planned, with his available forces to the stronghold of the nation. Flags of truce were hoisted, and all the chiefs came in and implored respite from hostilities. Certain conditions, not now understood, were asked and granted, and a thirty days' armistice is passing.

The newly elected City officials took possession of their respective offices on New-Year's Day. Mr. JOHN CLANCY, County Clerk elect, received the oath from Mr. RICHARD B. CONNOLLY, the retiring incumbent. Mr. CLACY then administered the oath to his Deputy. Mr. DAVID A. FOWLER, who occupied the same position under Mr. CONNOLLY. Mr. JOHN KELLY, the Sheriff elect, and his Deputies, were then sworn in.

THIRD DAY. The Association met at the Lyceum, at 9 o'clock A.M., Thursday morning, President PHELPS in the Chair. Prayer by the Rev. Mr. BARTLETT. A resolution was offered by Mr. JOHNSON, in favor of reducing school sessions to five hours per day. The resolution was opposed, and finally lost.

THE NEGROES OF SENATOR DOUGLAs.-The issue in regard to Senator DOUGLAS' slaves has advanced another step toward adjustment. Dr. BRAINARD, who originally told the story, and who, it was said, gave Mr. SLIDYELL for his authority, has just issued a card denying the complicity of that gentleman, and assuming the entire responsibility.

A SPIRITUAL INFANT.--John Mr. Spear, the apostle of "Self-Development," has been living in a small shanty at Kiantone, N. Y., for some time, with his spiritual bride, Miss Hinkley. Recently, between the two, in some mysterious way, "a son of man has been made manifest in the flesh as Spear says, and they both declare that it is wholly a spiritual development, with nothing natural or material about it.

If, during the small hours of the morning, and before the great City was awake, the amiable companion of some errant Diable boiteux were to be set down in the "Park," the first view of the locality would probably give that amiable companion the impression that he was beholding the ruins of a decayed city.

Tile Court of General Sessions will open for the January term of the New Year, at 11 o'clock this morning, when Mr. Nelson J. waterbury the new District-Attorney, will make his first appearance as public prosecutor. Report speaks favorably of this gentleman's abilities to fill the distinguished post to which he has been elected.

The correspondent of the Associated Press sends the following, dated Belize, Honduras, Dec. 20: The schooner Susan was wrecked on the Glovers, a coral reef, sixty miles from Belize, on the morning of the 16th. The passengers were saved, but the vessel is a total loss. Captain MAURY endeavored to charter another vessel to carry his passengers on.

We have repeatedly published articles upon the remarkable movement of the Emperor ALEXANDER for the emancipation of serfs in Russia. The general interest felt in the subject, and its intrinsic importance as one of the greatest revolutions of the age, will justify us in recurring to it and presenting somewhat more fully the historical and other facts necessary to the formation of a just judgment in regard to it.

THE LEGISLATURE.--Several members of the Legislature are already in the city. The Legislative Caucuses will be held on Monday evening-the Republican in the Assembly, and the Democratic in the Senate Chamber. A meeting of the members elected on "Union Tickets " is called for Monday afternoon at Stanwix Hall.

BURNS A HIGHLANDER.--DONALD ROSS of Toronto, a correspondent of the Montreal Pilot, says: "Although it may be known to some of your readers, I think as we are on the eve of celebrating the centennial anniversary of the birth-day of the poet BURNS, that it should be made known to the public generally, that ROBERT BURNS was really and truly of Highland descent :

DODWORTH'S SALOON.--Messrs. MASON and THOMAS gave their second classical matinee yesterday to a fine audience, considering that it was the ladies visiting day. The programme opened with BEETHOVEN'S Quartette in B flat, (opus 18;) after which a delicious Ballade by Mr. MASON, admirably played, then a trantelle on the violin, performed by Mr. THOMAS; and finally a trio in F major, by BARGIEL.

MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL--THE COMPTROLLER'S ESTIMATES.--A regular meeting of the Brooklyn Common Council was held last evening, President KALBFLEISCH in the chair. A communication was received from the Mayor, inclosing one from the Brooklyn City Gas Light Company, refusing to enter into contract with the city to supply the city with gas for five years upon the terms proposed.

The fillibusters as filibusters, are, it -must be confessed, by no means fortunate men, but as common pirates anti outlaws, they are the luckiest dogs we ever heard of. Their fillibustering has never gone well. Hard knocks, bad fare, sickness, and repulses attended their first campaign in Nicaragua. The fortune of war was all against them.

New-Year's opens warm, damp and blue. The sleighing is good, but the sidewalks are wet and slippery. From early morning the military are putting themselves through their evolutions, and the life and drum are continually stirring in our chests those emotions which are uppermost on General Training days. As early as 11 o'clock the Capital is crowded with people, anxious to see by what process the Empire State surrenders one Governor and assumes another.

GOVERNOR MORGAN's FIRST ACT.-The first official act of Governor MORGAN indicates a prompt and very decided character for business. He had but just taken his oath of office when he issued his order for the withdrawal of the militia from Quarantine.

FLOUR opened dull, but closed with a letter demand. WHISKY advanced to 22 1/2. HOGS--Sales 1,000. at $5@$6--the latter price for heavy. MESS PORK--Sales 1,2000 bbls., before 'Change, at $17, but the market closed unsettled afterward under the America's advices. LARD is steady, at 11c. SAVANNAH, Monday, Jan. 3.

The Message of Mayor TIEMANN to the Common Council, which we publish in full, is a very long document, but let none of that long-suffering class known as Tax-payers neglect to give it an attentive reading on account of its length. Though long, it contains no extraneous inatter, nor a superfluous sentence.

A MOVEMENT IN THE RIGHT DIRECTION.-A large number of the citizens of the New-Haven (Conn.) District have invited Ex-Senator BALDWIN to permit his name to be presented as a candidate for Congress. An outcry is raised against the movement, in some quarters, on the ground that it interferes with the regular mode of making nominations by Conventions. So much the better.

MUIR.--In this City, on Sunday, Jan. 2, Mrs. JANE MUIR,, the wife of Mr. John Muir. originally of Scotland, after a short illness, in the 39th year of her age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of the family, No. 296 Hudson-st., on Wednesday, at 2 o'clock P. M., without further invitation.

Guadalajara has fallen at last, so say reports received from that quarter. According to these, the Government forces moved to the attack on the 14th, and on the 15th the place was occupied by the "loyal" troops of the Government. The news reached this on the 18th, and the usual Ceremony of bells, trumpets, drums, , was gone through with.

The Mount Vernon Association will have more work ready to their fair hands as soon as they shall have finally bought Mr. JOHN A. WASHINGTON out of the sight and hearing of his disgusted fellow-countrymen. Let them not, therefore, spare to add Roadway's Ready Relief of $25,000, just offered by that enterprising Aseulapius, to the ten thousand already pail by the prosperous publisher of the Ledger.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The festival in aid of the Mount Vernon Fund occurred here yesterday. The receipts were $356, which is a little more than ten cents for each inhabitant of the town. This is comparatively one of the best efforts yet made in this good cause, and fully indorses the patriotism of our enterprising ladies.

RECEPTION OF THE PHILADELPHIA COMMITTEE AT THE EVEREST HOUSE-THE SENATOR'S ESCORT TO THE STEAMER. The Committee appointed by the citizens of Philadelphia to visit New-York and escort Senator DOUGLAS to that city. met yesterday morning at 10 o'clock at the Everett House, New-York, where the Senator was introduced to the members of the Committee by Colonel FORNEX.

The R. M. steamship America arrived at Boston from Halifax last night. Her mails will reach this City about 5 o'clock this afternoon. Congress will reassemble to-day, after a recess often days, and we may look for a busy season at the National Capitol for some time to come.

HIS LETTER DECLINING THE HOSPITALITIES OF THE CITY. Gen. HOUSTON left New-York yesterday morning for Washington. In consequence of pressing business he was compelled to decline the hospitalities tendered him by the common Councl, which he did in the following letter:

Letters received at the British Legation, four days ago, announce that Lord LYONS will arrive here early in February. The report that Lord ABERCROMBIE is to be the successor of Lord NAPIER is a mistake. Lord A. is yet in his minority. NAPIER succeeds ABERCROMBIE, now Lord DUNFERMLINE, who retires on a pension. This fact may account for the error in names.

The canvas for the Presidency, early as it opens, is already brisk. In every party strenuous efforts are made to secure the nomination of special personal or sectional favorites. The Democratic Party is greatly divided,more so probably than it has been at any time since 1848.

No public sales to-day. Mr. SAMUEL EDDY reports the sale, Dec. 31, 1858, of seventeen lots--eight on Fifth-avenue, being the entire front on the avenue between Seventy fifth and Seventy-sixth streets, in connection with five lots adjoining on 75th street, and four adjoining lots on Seventy-sixth-street. for $80,000;

A MISERABLE CASE OF DESTITUTION.--On Sunday night Mr. BOGRET called at tile Station-house in the Twenty-second Ward, and informed the officer in charge, of a case of destitution which had just come to his knowledge. lie said that in Forty-sixthstreet, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues, there was a family, consisting of a man, his wife and four children, who were at the point of starvation.

IMPLIED TRUTHS.-Any man who enriches the language with a new phrase for an old fact deserves the commendations of the Press, at least, and of the Bar. It was only a Judge, we believe, who objected to Webster's Dictionary, with its thirty thousand new words, being put into the hands of a certain eloquent advocate.

Bourd of Aldermen. ORGANIZATION OF THE NEW BOARD-ALDERMAN MOSPEDON ELECTED PRESIDENT, AND D. T. VALENTINE CLERK--REGISTRATION OF ALDERMAN CLANCY. At 12 o'clock M. Yesterday the Alderman's chamber was densely thronged, and a few minutes after that hour the members of the new Board were in their seats.

Governor MORGAN, in the following letter, issues instructions for the withdrawal of the troops from Staten Island. The announcement that the " Staten Island war " is at an end will be received with satisfaction by the troops and by the public at large: EXECUTIVE CHAMBER, ALBANY, Jan. 1, 1859. Adjutant-General Frederick Townsend:

To the Editor of the New- York Times: SIR: Nowhere in the land do the people of the States unqualifiedly and perpetually protect any species of property which they don't want in their midst ; but, on the contrary, subject to the Federal Constitution and to the general commercial regulations of Congress, they legally shut it out and keep it out from their borders.

At 12:10, this afternoon, Mr. DOUGLAS went to Independence Hall, in compliance with the invitation extended to him by the City Councils. There was a great crowd assembled outside the State House, and the appearance of the Senator, as he descended from his carriage, was greeted with lond cheers.

The London Times considers President BUCHANAN'S Duquesne letter as affording conclusive evidence that this country is rapidly going to the dogs. We are quite prepared to make due allowance for the importance which foreigners very properly attach to the office of President of the United States;

QUARANTINE AFFAIRS--THE ORCHARD SHOALS PROJECT.--Reflection upon the plan of the Quarantine Commissioners, for removing Quarantine to an island to be created upon the Orchard Shoals, does not commend it to the confidence of the people of Staten Island.
The Legislature meets to-morrow. At the American-Republican caucus, this evening, Mr. CHARLES HALE was nominated for Speaker of the House, and Mr. WILLIAM STOWZ, of Springfield, for Clerk.

A few minutes before seven o'clock this morning, a fire broke out in the second story of the large and extensive hat manufactory, situated on the west side of Lawrence-street, above Brown, in the Twelfth Ward. The main structure was four stories in height,

ELECTION OF OFFICERS--PRESENTATION OF DR. KANE'S LIKENESS--ADDRESS BY H. C. VAN SCHAICK. The Historical Society met last evening in its room at the corner of Second-avenue and Eleventh-street. A large audience was present. After the reading of the minutes, the Hon. LUTHER BRADISH, President of the Society, read a correspondence between himself and Mr. LENNOX, who lately presented some Nin?? mareles to the Society. [Degree]

CANADIAN MISSIONARIES FOR BRITISH COLUMBIA--A meeting was held at the St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, in Fourth-avenue, last evening, for the purpose of bidding farewell to four Missionaries of the British Weslevan connection, who sail today for British Columbia.

MR. ELLSWORTH'S BEQUEST TO YALE COLLEGE.--The Hartford Courant, Jan. 3, says: "The Will of the Hon. HENRY L. ELLSWORTH was proved to-day. It is estimated that Mr. E. was worth eight hundred thousand dollars ($600,000) at the time of his death. His immense land speculations at the West, now in cultivated farms, proved immensely profitable to him.

One John Lansing, of Ballston, stole his wife the other day. Because of his dissipation, she had left him, and procured a situation in a milliner's. On Monday evening he called there and insisted upon her going with him, but she peremptorily refused.

The steamship Weser, of the North German Lloyd, left Bremerhaven on Dec. 4, at noon, and has not been since heard from. The following is a list of her passengers and of such of the officers as are known to the agents of the Company in this City, the ship never having been at this port.

The publication of the America's advices here caused an advance in the prices of COTTON of 1/2 c. The sales to-day add up 2,400 bales, at 11 1/4 C. for Middling, the market closing firm, and with a tendency to a further advance.

A special dispatch to the Press from Springfield says that the Illinois Legislature met, yesterday, but the Republicans of both Houses absented themselves, breaking up a quorum. Mr. MORRISON, Anti-Lecoinpton Democrat, had previously been elected Speaker of the House. The Democrats were to meet last night, to nominate Mr. DOUGLAS for reflection to the Senate.

What use is a snow-storm? we often hear asked. We need not go very far for an answer. Let us think for a moment of the thousands of poor people in this metropolis who daily and vainly seek employment, and who are glad to find it, and to earn their half-dollar, in clearing away the snow from sidewalks, areas and railroad tracks.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you be good enough to assure your correspondent, "M. M.," who writes to inquire what has become of the movement to establish a Free Library for Women, that it is by no means dead-nor even sleeping.

Senator HOUSTON and Gov. KING have respectively declined dinners proffered them by political and personal friends. It was a sensiblo step. A dinner, when paid for in money, is sometimes worth what it costs; but never when the quid pro quo is a speech.

Education, not only primary, but also professional, opears almost to absorb the energies of the Governent of King OTHO.

It is already known that His Excellency, Mr. PHILO WHITE, Minister Resident of the United States, has presented his letters of recall, having repeatedly solicited them, to enable him to return and breathe the air of his native land. The motive which attracts Mr. WHITE northward, and which is about to remove him from among us, is one of those prevailing impulses of the human breast.

In New-York, since Jan, 1, the movements have been restricted, yet prices have been well supported. The trade during December, Messrs. TELLKAMPP KITCHING notice thus : "The last month has been replete with activity in all kinds of Domestic Fleece and Pulled Wools in all our markets, large quantities having been sold.

C., came ?? this city on a visit and took board at a house in ??-street, near Eighth. She brought with her her daughter, a pretty young lady, about fifteen years of age.

The Overland Mail, with dates from San Francisco to the 10th of December, (four days later,) has arrived here. Three through passengers came with the mail. A rich quartz vein bad been discovered in the suburbs of San Francisco. The news from Fraser's River was more favorable. The last steamer from Victoria brought down $200,000 in gold.

The Senate met at noon in the old hall, from which the desks had been removed, but a supply of cane-bottomed chairs had been provided for their accommodation. The galleries and floor were crowded, notwithstanding the falling snow, it having been understood that the Vice-President, Mr. CHITTENDEN, and others, would speak.

The bill in relation to ocean mail transportation between the East and California, introduced in the Senate, to-day, by Mr. GWIN, authorizes the Postmaster-General to make contracts for five mail services, by the following routes, viz.: From New-York to San Francisco and Astoria, in Oregon, via Panama, once a month, at a compensation not to exceed $250,000 per annum; time 24 days.

The Convention held here to-day, was one of the largest ever held by the Republicans of New-Hampshire, notwithstanding a storm of unprecedented violence prevailed. The whole vote for Governor was 373, of which ICHABOD GOODWIN received 368; scattering, 5.

No small part of the legislation of mankind has been wasted upon efforts to protect men against the consequences of their own. blunders, or to indemnify them for losses invited by their own headlong selfishness.

BROOKLYN COURTS.--The Supreme Court Special Term was adjourned, yesterday, by Judge LOTT, to Friday, the 7th inst. Ex-parte business will then be taken up at 9 1/4 o'clock, and the calendar will be called at 10 o'clock A. M.

The, ice-bridge over the St. Lawrence connecting Montreal and Longueil, was firmly established on the 31st lt. As the mercury was 16[degree] below zero, it was believed the bridge could not be disturbed Deforo Spring. Mr. Wm. Torrey, a resident of Quincey, Mass., of Independent circumstances, hung himself Jan. 1. He was 60 years of age. Ill health is supposed to have been the cause of his act.

Mr. WOODS, a passenger by the California Overland Mail, which arrived here last night, says that the Camanche Indians have declared war against the whites, and are waiting for a favorable opportunity to attack the mail stages.

The tempest which has for some time past agitated the Irish teapot seems to be still prevailing, and with unabated force. In Belfast especially, the home and hot-bed of intolerance, Protestant and Catholic, the storm has raged with the utmost fierceness.

Senator Douglas at Philadelphia. Senator DOUGLAS received the compliment of a serenade at Philadelphia on Tuesday evening, and made another speech, which the Press reports. Speaking of the Slavery question, he said:

Our readers probably remember that at the close of CANGEMI'S trial, Mr. ASHMEAD, as one of his counsel, presented a protest against its legality, and desired that he might be permitted to read it before the prisoner was sentenced ; the request was denied both when urged as a legal right and asked as an act of courtesy.

The railroad and steamboat travel so greatly disarranged by the snow-storm, is again beginning to assume regularity. The steamboat train vid Stonington from New-York, yesterday, afternoon, arrived here shortly after noon to-day.

Lord LYONS, after all, is to come in the place of Lord NAPIER--a young Lord, a bachelor, and the brother-in-law of a Duke, uniting in his single person three important recommendations to the good will and the graces of "our best society."

Arrival of the Steamship Cahawba. The United States Mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOGH, commander, from New-Orleans via Havana, arrived yesterday afternoon, bringing dates from the latter place to the 31st ult. We glean very scanty intelligence from them, however.

HAMILTON, the leader of the party who committed the atrocious murders at Chontean's trading post last May, has taken the geld in Southern Kansas,

The steamship North American from Liverpool on the 22d of December, with four days' later advices from Europe, put into Halifax yesterday short of coal and leaking badly--she having struck upon a rock off Cape Race, and her forward compartment being filled with water. The news is very interesting.

A telegram from New-Haven, yesterday, announced the decision of the Court in the Bennett Divorce case, granting the petition of Mrs. BENNETT. We copy from the New-Haven Journal and Courier the decision of Judge WALDO in full:

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. ULLMAN'S supplemental season commences to-night and will continue for six nights. BALFE'S popular opera of the "Bohemian Girl" ("La Zingara") will be produced for the first time in Italian. Mile. PICCOLOMINI, Signor BRIGNOLI, Signor FLORENZA, and other prominent members of the company are in the east.

RECOGNITION OF HIS SERVICES--PRESENTATION TO MRS. PERRY FROM AMERICAN RESIDENTS IN CHINA. There is how on exhibition at TIFFANY'S a magnificent silver candelabrum, just received from China. It was to have been presented by the American residents of that Empire to the late Commodore PERRY, as a recognition of his services in the East, but death overtook the gallant officer before he received this well-meant tribute.

It is not in the nature of a Yankee to give up and cry "heat," or, at least, we fondly delude ourselves with such an idea. Our favorite figure, which is supposed to represent the true sprit that, animates us as a nation, is that of a sailor mailing the Stars and strips to the masthead, to indicate that we will never cry beat.

The screw steamship North American, Captain MCMASTER, from Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 22d ult., bound to Portland, put into Halifax on the afternoon of the 5th inst., short of coals. She experienced boisterous weather during the whole passage.
The steamer Cornelius Vanderbilt, of the Stonington line, which left New-York on Monday afternoon, was overtaken, probably, by the heavy snowstorm which commenced here about 7 o'clock P. M.

The Legislature organized about noon to-day Mr. CHARLES A. PHELPS, of Boston, was chosen President of the Senate by 26 votes against 5 seattering Mr. STEPHEN A. GIFFORD, Clerk of last year, has been reelected.

The Comptroller's Report will not propably be presented to the Legislators for some days. When it does come it will throw some light upon that four million debt contracted in behalf of the state in direct violation of the Destitution. It will if any thing can started the people to learn how systematically the state is plundered under corner of State Officers and by state officials.

A horrible instance of cruelty to a child has been developed in Baltimore. The Patriot, Jan. 3, says. "A little boy, named William Wallace, aged about eight years, died at the residence of his step father, William Russell, on Thompson-street, near Aisquith, on Saturday morning.

ITALIAN REVOLUTIONS--THE REVOLUTIONISTS AND THEIR PLANS--KOSSUTIH AND MAZZINI. Signora MARIO delivered another lecture last evening, at Clinton Hall, on the Italian Revolutions. Tile audience in attendance was quite select, but by no means numerous. The lecturer first reviewed hastily the prominent events in Italian history, which had been detailed at length in previous discourses.

The 12th inst. was the Feast Day of Guadalupe, and as the crowing effort of the clergy in these days, the day was the occasion of a more than common display of elegance at the shrine of the patron saint of Mexico.

From the Washington Union. There are many considerations connected with this great measure calculated to fix the attention of the public mind. All must perceive that the road is a work not only of great national utility in a commercial and business point of view, but of absolute necessity as connected with the immediate operations of the Government.

The Governor's Message states that the finances of the State are in a most satisfactory condition. The receipts at the Treasury for the fiscal year were over four millions; the expenditures were three millions and three-quarters; the balance on hand is over three-quarters of a million; and tile entire State debt nearly forty millions.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: My previous communication gave a brief outline of the Expedition of the Arizona company of poineers to the Arizona Mountains. To reach that point it was necessary to cross the desert country extending from the River Colorado in a southeast direction nearly to the Arizonas, a distance of about three Hundred and twenty-five miles.

From the Albany Atlas and Argus. We understand that Dr. GOULD and the accomplished young gentlemen who have acted under him a observes at the Dudley Observatory, were waited upon yesterday by "a surprise party."

NEW MODE OF DISTRIBUTING CHEAT LITERATURE.--We have seen a new style of envolope, got up by a philanthropic gentleman for the purpose of circulating sound literature among the people. The inside of the envelope is printed with instructive reading-matter, and, in this form, can be sold for less than one mill, more than the ordinary cost. But this is not its sole economy as an educator.

The Annual Message of Gov. CHASE, of Ohio, relates chiefly to the past social progress and present social condition of the State. In 1850 the population of Ohio was 1,980,000; it is now 2,420,000. In 1853 the Common Schools of the State were 5,984; they are now 12,500, and Gov. CHASE bears testimony to their efficiency.

The House Committee on Foreign Affairs have now under consideration a proposition for purchasing Cuba, but the prospect for a favorable report is not very flattering. The committee on Ways and Means will cut off the estimates for the Treasury building, and reduce the estimates for the Springfield and Harper's Ferry armories from $300,000 to $150,000.

A communication was received from the President covering a letter from our Minister to China, and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, as were also some unimportant communications from the Navy and Interior Departments.
Lord CLARENDON, the historian, has said that any two men might have taken opposite sides in the quarrel between the King and the Parliament, and yet both be perfectly honest and honorable.

Our cotemporaries--who, "though foreign are not strange"--in the New-York Press, the Courrier des Etats Unis and the Albion, hate wished themselves a happy New-Year after their accustomed sort, by appearing in new garments and with phylacteries made broader than before.

Colonel Amos Johnson died at his residence in Redfield, Oswego County, N. Y., Dec. 7, at the age of nearly 160 years. He was born at Middletown, Conn., Sept. l6, 1760; enlisted In the army at the age of 17, and bore an honorable part in the stirring scenes of the Revolution, upon the Hudson and its vicinity, and in later years was fond of detailing his reminiscences of Washington.

The butchery of a family, almost as deliberate and horrible in its details as the late Gouldy tragedy, was attempted yesterday morning at a house in tile rear of No. 154 Sullivan-street. FELIX SANCHEZ, a young Spaniard only twenty years of age, was the criminal, and the victims of his infuriated attack were his father-in-law, his wife and his wife's mother.

The Legislature assembled at Lansing yesterday. HENRY A. SHAW was elected Speaker of the House. The retiring and incoming Governors delivered their Messages, as required by law. The former states that the finances are in a satisfactory condition. The receipts at the Treasury for the fiscal year have been $1,024,000 and the expenditures $848,000. The balance on hand is $170,000.

There were no public sales of any importance to-day at the Exchange. Messrs. RANNOR BLACKWELL report the sale of 25 full lots, on the north side of One Hundred and Thirteenth street and south bide of One Hundred and Fourteenth-street, through lots, 100 feet east of Fifthavenue, at $450 per lot.

We have the Revue de Commerce to dec. 18. from Port-au-Prince, but find in it no political news whatever, The resume of the markets is as follows: DEC. 18-The weeks has been very animated, COFFEE having risen successively form 1141@117. The delivery was 6,423 bags, weighing 787, 208 lbs. LOG. WOOD IS quoted at 40lb. but has been sold at 60lbs, with delivery of 113,590 lbs. There are no advices from Can and Jacmel.

A night mail-train to New-York, over the new route from Boston, is recommended by business men in Providence. Upwards of 17,000 emigrants passed westwards ever the Pennsylvania Central Railroad last year. The number was nearly equal to that of 1857.

The ship John H. Jarvis, ashore on Beach Island, 12 miles below Castine. has bilged and is full of water to her lower deck. She will be stripped, as there is no prospect of getting her off. The Bark Cruise, from Boston for New York, reports off Cape Cod last night, she ran into Schooner Flacon, and sunk her in two minutes. The Bark lest bowsprit and foretop-gallant mast.
