Esq., all of this City. DE ZOUCHE-BUSBY.--In this City. on Saturday.

Governor BANKS' Message will be delivered to the Legislature to-morrow. The Rev. TROS. DEDGE, of Chatham, was to-day chosen Chaplain to the House. The Senate assigned Tuesday next for the choice of United States Senator.

I see in your issue of Monday last an article taken from the Pittsburg Post, in reference to the birthplace and relatives of Lieutenant I. G. STRAIN, late of the United States Navy. Allow me, as a relative of Lieutenant STRAIN, to correct that statement, and all others in circulation bearing on this subject.

We published yesterday the translation of a remarkable article on Mexico from the Paris Constitutionnel. It exhibits in a fair and truthful manner the evils which afflict the almost effe?? Republic of Mexico, but it also attributes the condition of that country to causes which have but indirectly led to it, and deduces therefrom inferences which are, to say the least, extremely questionable.

Mr. SEWARD, of New-York, presented the Constitution adopted by the late Constitutional Conven tion held at Leaven worth, Kansas, which was referred to the Committee on Territories. On motion of Mr. CRITTENDEN the French Spoliation bill was taken up, by a vote of 24 against 18. This bill was brought in January of last year, by Mr. FESSENDEN, and referred to a Special Committee, Mr. CRITTENDEN Chairman, and reported without amendment.

The steamer C. Vanderbilt, Captain FRAZEE, of the Stopington line, left New-York on Monday at 4 o'clock P. M., with 75 passengers, and a larger assorted freight than usual, consisting of dry goods, cotton, wool, flour, and leather. There were only 15 ladies among the passengers, and fortunately only four children; the remainder were gentlemen, many of them being well-known merchants belonging to Providence and Boston. The freight was mostly consigned to Providence.

FLOUR unchanged. WINSKY advanced to 23c. PROVISIONS unchanged. MESS PORK nominal. LARD firm at 11c. SAVANNAH, Thursday, Jan. 6. COTTON market unsettled; sales to-day 450 bales. The Sales of the week add up 4,800 bales, and the receipts 6,750 bales. Receipts at this port ahead of last year, 167,000 bales; dilto at all Southern ports, 790,000 bales.

The Bank Superintendent's Report, of which you published an abstract this morning, was laid on the Speaker's desk this afternoon. The Comptroller's of which you will probably publish an abstract tomorrow, is not yet forthcoming. Gentlemen of Kings County--attention; Senator SPINOLA in the Senate, and General DURYEA in the House, to-day presented petitions of exceeding interest to Brooklyn.

The Indiana Legislature convened at 9 o'clock this morning. The Lien enant-Governor was absent on account of ill health. The Senate organized by the election of J. R. CRAVENS President and by choosing the same Secretary, Assistant-Secretary. Clerks and Doorkeepers as were elected at the extra session.

The Democratic State Convention met here today. Nearly four hundred delegates were present. The Hon. ASA P. CATE, of Northfield, was unanimously nominated for Governor, and Mr. FREDERICK VOSE for Railroad Commissioner. Among the resolutions adopted was the following:

The Academy met in the small Chapel of the University, the President, Dr. J. P. BAT??IELDER, in the Chair. The meeting was a business one, the object being the election of officers. After the minutes were read, the Academy proceeded to the election. Bu lots were distributed and deposited, and, while the Inspectors were determining who were to be the officers for the next year,

WAKELEY.-In this City, on Thursday, Jan. 6, STILES WAKLEY, formerly of Danbury, Conn., aged 70 years. His relatives and friends are invited to attend his funeral, from the residence of his nephew, the Rev. J. B. Wabeley, No. 29 Grove-st., en Saturday morning. Jan. 8, at 10 o'clock. His remains will be taken by the Hud- t son Piver Railroad to Yonkers for interment.

Senator DOUGLAS arrived to-night. He was met at the cars by a large concourse of citizens, who followed bis carriage to his residence. Arrangements were made for a serenade by the Marine Band at 9 o'clock, but in consequence of the sudden decease of Gen. HENDERSON, commander at the Marine Barracks, who was found dead in his garden just at night, the band could not come out.

Our report of Congressional proceedings yesterday will be found quite interesting. In the Senate, the Constitution adopted by the late Convention in Kansas was presented by Mr. SEWARD, and referred to the Committee on Territories. The French Spoliation bill was taken up. on motion of Mr. CRITTenden, who addressed the Senate in vindication of the justice of the claims.

THE TAMMANY GENERAL COMMITTEE ORGANIZATION FOR 1859-ELECTION OF PRESIDENT AND TREASURE R-CONTESTED SEATS. The members elect of the Democratic General Committee for 1859 met at Tammany Hall last evening for organization. There was a full attendance. RICHARD P. CONNOLLY, of the Twenty-first Ward, was chosen temporary Chairman, and WILLIAM M. GILCHRIST, of the Ninth Ward, and C. BAINBRIDGE SMITH, of the Seventeenth Ward, were appointed temporary Secretaries.

THE DEAT?? OF MR. WHITNEY.--We alluded several days since to a statement in one of our exchanges that the late Mr. S. S. WHITNEY died in consequence of having had his windpipe perforated by his attendant physician. At that time, and upon such a knowledge of the facts as seemed to us to warrant the denial, we pronounced this statement a calumnious falsehood.

EVENING SERVICES AT TRINITY CHURCH--THE CHURCH--THE FEAST OF THE EPIPHANY.--Trinity Church was brilliantly illuminated last evening and filled to overflowing by portions of the congregations of probably every Episcopal Church in this City and neighborhood, and many others not communicants, who were curious to see the interior of the edifice by candle-light, and take part in the interesting ceremonies.

REPORT ON THE PROPOSED LOCATION OF QUARANTINY. The quarterly meeting of the Chamber was held last evening at Clinton Hall-P. PERIT, Esq., in the Chair. The attendance was larger than usual. Alter the election of new members, and the transaction of some other unimportant business,

AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY.--At a stated meeting ofthe Managers, held on Thursday evening at the Bible Society, six new auxiliaries were recognized, two in North Carolina, and in Kentucky, Florida, IIlinois, and Connecticut one each. Communications were received from agents and others, showing encouraging prospects in the work at home, not withstanding the continued money pressure, and the need of great exertion to supply immigrants and others with the Holy Scriptures.

EXECUTIVE ADJOURNMENT OF A LEGISLATURE.-Governor CONWAY, of Arkansas, was lately required to resort to the unusual exercise of the authority, conferred upon him by the Constitution of that State, of adjourning the Legislature.

After a delay of a week since the arrival of the first messengers from fort Scott, we learn something of the recent difficulties from the other side. This information throws some light upon the reports that first came to us regarding the murder of Marshal LITTLE by MONTGOMERY'S party.

MARSTON.--In this City, on Thursday evening, Jan. 6, ROBERT C. MARSTON, in the 41st year of his age. His funeral will Lake place from tile house of his mother, No. 169 William-st., on Sunday morning, at 9 o'clock. His remains will be interred at Greenwood. CHAMBERS.--In this City, on Thursday evening. Jan. 6, after a short illness, ORGIANA ELIZA, GORGOA 19 ELICA, daugher of Thomas and Anna Chambers, aged 7 months and 17 days.

We noticed some days since a movement to establish an Astronomical Observatory in this City. We have now received a copy of a correspondence between a number of our most influential citizens and Prof. MITCHELL, in which the latter is invited to deliver a course of lectures in this City, with a view to awaken and extend public interest in the object Prof. M. has consented to do so.

The following communications in reference to the fillibuster schooner Susan have been received at Mobile; BELIZE, British Honduras, Dec. 20, 1858. On the 16th inst., at 3 o'clock in the morning, the schooner Susan, Captain MAURY, from Mobile, was wrecked on Glover's Coral Reef, about 60 miles from the Belize.

Tile late Court of Inquiry, called together at West Point, to investigate certain charges brought against Prof. MAHAN by Lieut. MORTON, has made its report and the result will be officially declared in due course of time.

CONFESSION OF A GAMBLER.--At Philadelphia, Jan. 6, a number of keepers of gambling-houses were arrested, on an affidavit of one George F. Peterman, recently convicted of forging checks on the Kensington Bank. It is alleged that Peterman was induced to commit the forgeries to obtain the means to gratify his passion for gambling; and that the money he obtained on the forged checks was lost at the gamingtable. Mr.

The overland mail, with San Francisco dates of the 13th ult. arrived last night. The news is unimportant. Governor WELLER had offered a reward of $1,000 for the conviction of any parties in the late mobbing of Los Angeles and Columbia.

THE U. S. SLOOP-OF-WAR BROOKLYN.--The Brooklyn was delivered to the commanding officer at the Navy-yard (Commodore BREESE) last week, ready to take on board her armament, crew and stores. This magnificent specimen of a steam war-ship re flects the greatest credit on her designers and constructors. Her superior in strength and in beauty of symmetry probably never floated on the water.

The WEEKLY TIMES for Saturday, Jan. 8, contains the following: POETRY--A New-Year's Lesson--A Douglas to the Fray. LITERARY--Anecdotes of English Lawyers--Origin of the Disraeli Family--Sacred Books of the Hindoos--How the President Lives--Brain Work--Literature and Literary Men--Miscellany.
LATE OFFICIAL DISCOVERIES.--The Washington Union seems to have fairly awoke to the consciousness that there is a Disunion Party in the Southern States.

Learn from the White House that the President has sent to the Senate the nomination of TOWNSEND HARRIS, of New-York, now Consul-General of Japan, to be Minister Resident near the government of the Japanese Empire. This is a judicious and well-merited recognition of the services of the volunteer negotiator of the recent Treaty with Japan.

Petitions were presented to equalize and increase all the fees of Justices and Constables. The bill giving power of suspension and appointment in the State Prisons to Inspectors, Agents and Wardens was reported upon favorably. Mr. PRATT introduced a bill to abolish the office Inspector-General.

The streets, yesterday, were in the most horrible condition that it is possible to imagine. There is, however, no use grumbling over the evil, for it is not one that can be hastily remedied-especially when v heavy thaw, as in the present case, has set in after a heavy snow-storm.

DE ANGELIS--WESTEEVELT.--In Hoboken, N. J., on Thursday, Jan, 6, by the Hon, Geo, W. Morton, Mayor of Hoboken, LORENZO DE ANGELIS, Esq., to MARGATET E. WISTERVELT, daughter of John Westervolt, Esq., all of this City. WHITE-SOHERF.--In this City, on Thursday, Jan. 6, by the Rev. Dr. Vermilye, MICHAEL WHITE to Miss CATHARINE SCHERP, both of this City.

This being private calendar day, much routine business was transacted, among which was a communication from the Secretary of War, covering the report from the Engineer's Bureau, relative to the ground for Federal purposes in New-York.

No UNION OF THE KINGS COUNTY DEMOCRACY. -The Democracy of Kings County have not patched up a union as yet. The plan heretofore published as having been agreed to by the Sub-Committees, representing both factions, has been adopted entirely by the Vanderbilt wing. The Bradley or Taylor men have adopted a part and rejected the balance, so that the party is as wide apart as ever.

From the Washington Union. If we are to credit the telegraph, which, however, has become a very mendacious oracle, the fullbulter cause has had another ridiculous and ignominious contretemps. The course of "manifest destiny." like that of true love, seems not to run smooth.

From the Paris Presse. It has been seen by the relation which we have already given of the great question of the canalization of the Isthmus of Panama, and of the successive phases which this question has assumed, that the idea of such junction of the two oceans did not originate with one person, but, in reality, belongs to everybody.

The large hall of the Cooper Institute was more than half full of people last evening, at 7 1/2 P. M., at which hour it had been announced that Mrs. CORA L. V. HATCH, the spiritual Medium, whose domestic troubles have recently been made public, would lecture therein a trance on any subject that might be presented by a Committee of three, to be selected by the audience.

Nothing of special importance occurred in Congress yesterday, though the proceedings were not devoid of interest. It was private calendar day in both Houses, and considerable routine business was done.

The impending Reform Bill is gradually absorbing public attention, and threatens, like Aaron's rod, to put out of sight and remembrance all inferior pretensions to popular regard. The Party of Resistance has taken courage to speak out its sentiments more freely, since the daring enunciation of its views, last week, by Mr. LOWE of Kidderminster, and their reproduction in the columns of the Times, every morning since.

From the Ayr (Scotland) Advertiser. The funeral of the late Mrs. BEGG took place in Alloway churchyard on Thursday. About 1 o'clock, the company invited, which was necessarily limited, assembled in the parlor at Bridgehouse, where an appropriate prayer was offered up by the Rev. Mr. DYKES. A number of the inhabitants of the town spontaneously jointed in the procession, which started at about 1 1/2 o'clock.

A lecture on "The Orders of Nobility" was delivered last night in Clinton Hall by the Rev. Dr. CHAPIN, before the members of the Young Men's Christian Union, and others drawn thither by the reverend gentleman's reputation, or their interest in the subject. The audience almost filled the Hall.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: If it be not unlawful for a layman to meddle with what properly belongs to professional critics, permit me to make a suggestion concerning the meaning of that "runaway" passage of SHAKESPEARE which Mr. WHITE has brought into such fresh prominence in the literary world.

MR. ELLSWORTH'S BEQUEST TO YALE COLLEGE OVERRATED.--It will have been seen, from the paragraphs copied yesterday from the New-Haven papers, that the statement in the City papers of the. 4th, respecting a bequest by the Hon. H. L. ELLSWORTH, to Yale College, is quite erroneous.

Rossini, says the Courrier de Paris, having returned to Paris for the Winter, gave a grand musical party a few nights ago, at which four original pieces of his composition were executed. One was a grand. scene, the "Catalani," which was sung by Mlle.

INTERESTING TO SHIPOWNESRS.--California KIBLING's case, in the United States- Commissioner's Court, at Hartford, was decided on Saturday, Commissloner SMITH deciding that Captain KIBLING feloniously and pifatically ran' away from the fishing grounds with the bark J. S. Perkins, and the goods and wares on board, with intent to sell the same for his own benefit. said goods and wares belonging to citizens of the United States.
A goodly audience was last night assembled at the Cooper Institute to listen to a lecture, on they knew not what, to be delivered by they knew not whom.

A week ago the Montalembert affair occupied the public attention to the exclusion of almost every other subject. To-day it has fallen into a secondary rank--another example of the evanescence of human glory. The Count pushed his scheme for the honors of martyrdom too far ; the public was already growing lukewarm, when a leader of the London Times gave his cause the coupe de grace.

The question of the protectorate of the Ionian Islands, which the late JOSEPH HUME so often used as one of the best weapons of his armory in his attacks on the British ministry, has of late been receiving a tolerably thorough, though somewhat disagreeable ventilation in England.
In the absence of that invaluable mentor, the Dictionaire des Contemporaires, we venture the assertion that M. FELIX BELLY is a native of Gascony.

THE CITY INSPECTOR.--The most important of our municipal officers, so far as the health of the people and the general condition of the City are concerned, is, undoubtedly, the City Inspector. He is our Health Officer. Great power is placed in his hands to enable him to carry out whatever designs he may consider necessary in the performance of his duties.

London papers announce the death of Doctor Richard Bright, the eminent physician, by which the medical profession has lost one of its most illustrious members. Dr. Bright died on Dec. 16, after a short illness. The lamented gentleman received patients and was out in his carriage on the previous Saturday, after which he complained of indisposition, and retired to his chamber, which he was destined never to leave again alive.

ST. THOMAS, Dec..27.--The following vessels are here in distress: Ship Messenger, has had mainmast put in; ship Partheon, waiting orders; ship Atlanta, waiting orders; ship Flora McDonald, discharging; bark Oasis, discharging ; bark Quincey, taking in cargo ; schooner C. W. Connor, discharging; brig Minnie, condemned ; brig Wander, condemned;

The Assembly was in session for two hours aud a half to-day-the mill running though there was no corn in the hopper. A bill presented by Mr. ANDBUS, of Kings, embodying the provisions petitioned for by five Atlantic-street owners, had its second reading by sections. The bill appoints the following gentlemen:

A new gun, says the London Times, invented by Messrs. Armstrong, of Newcastle, has been satisfactorily tested at Shoeburyness, the projecting power of which completely distances that of any piece of ordinance hitherto known. At an elevation of thirty-three degrees it has sent a 32-pound shot a distance of 9,000 yards, or more than five miles.

Dr. Beck, of Dantzic, has just made a curious discovery. He has found an antidote, or rather a counter-poison, for ardent spirits. It is a mineral paste, which he incloses in an olive, and which, once absorbed, destroys not only the rising effect, but likewise the disastrous consequences of drunkenness. lie tried several experiments on a Pole, an irreclaimable drunkard.

ASSOCIATION OF REAL-ESTATE OWNERS.--We understand that a large number of influential gentlemen, interested in the opening and grading of the streets and avenues of that portion of the City in the neighborhood of the Central Park, have formed an Association for the purpose of pronoting these objects.

THE PARK.--As a public ground for the enjoyment of the people, and contributing to the elegance of the City, the City Hall Park has outlived its usefulness. It has, in fact, become a nuisance. It stands in the way of business, and the convenience of the people demands that it shall remain a park no longer. Take away the railing, and let the whole space be paved.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: With due respect to the State Officers and the Quarantine Commissioners, and their decision upon the new location for Quarantine, may I be permitted to suggest that it would have been well to examine the "Map of New-York Bay and Harbor and the Environs," by F. S. HASSLEE, Superintendent of the Survey of the Coast of the United States, before making their decision.

The bark Azor, at this port, from Faval 15th ult., reports having brought home WM. KENNEDY, the man picked up at sea by the Oread from the house of the ship Margaret Tyson, Capt. MORRIS, from NewYork for San Francisco, before reported lost.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Having read and carefully considered tile article published in your paper of this day's date, headed "The Dangers and Defenccs of our City," I feel called upon to say a few words in defence of an " antiquated European engineer," who seems to have fallen sadly under the displeasure or misapprehension of the writer of that article.
In steamship Africa, from Liverpool--Mr. Lynch, C. Robns, W. O. Farriday, J. C. Farriday, Mr. Meyerheim,

The Kansas Legislature has adjourned to Lawrence, with the sanction of the Governor. The Committee on Contested Seats reported in favor of LEWIS, GRAHAM, ALLISON and STEVENSON, in the Third District, and VEALE, from Marshall County, and the Secretary was requested to administer the oath, which he refused to do, when the Secretary pro tem. was authorized to perform the act, which he did.

Tile fourth anniversary of tile orgallization of the Woman's Hospital Association, was celebrated on Saturday at the Hospital, No. 83 Madison Avenue. Quite a number of medical men, among whom were Drs. HORACE GREEN and BATCHELOR were present, besides twenty-five or thirty ladies, who have taken a deep interest in the institution, and who have labored earnestly to secure its success.

The steamship Quaker City has arrived at NewOrleans, with later Mexican and California news. The former is highly important, extending down to the 26th of December. ZULOAGA had been deposed by the Conservative forces under General ROBLES, and had taken refuge in the house of the British Minister.
Mr. JOHN MORIIISSEY, editor of the Old Colony Memorial, printed at Plymouth, was to-day elected Sergeant-at Arms by both branches of the Legislature.

Tile trade between the Brazils and the United States, already very large and important, is susceptible of still greater extension, to the mutual benefit of the two countries. In the single article of Coffee, the imports from Rio de Janeiro, Bahia, and Santos, will probably amount this year to at least fifteen millions of dollars-while those of Hides from Rio Grande

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A statute was enacted by the Legislature of this State on the 13th of April, 1857, allowing parties to any action or proceeding, in the Courts, to be examined, under certain conditions, in their own behalf, the same as any other witnesses. These conditions were, that the adverse party or person in interest should be living;

GEORGE D. PRENTICE ON OUR PUBLIC MEN.-The well-known editor of the Louisville Journal, lectured on Friday evening in Boston, on American politics and politicians. He does not regard the public men of this country as perfect by any means. Among their little failings, he enumerates atrocious selfishness. and utter cowardice.

The blindness of Fortune was never more conspicuously illustrated than in her dealings with Mr. BUCHANAN. Upon that wry-necked and wry-spirited statesman she showers her gifts with a prodigal profusion which would be senseless, might not one fairly suspect her of a dark design to expose his inherent imbecility the more shamefully to the world at last.

The weather was quite warm here yesterday, with rain, until towards night, when a sudden change took place, the thermometer sinking to zero, and a strong northwest wind springing up. To-day there have been flurries of snow, but not sufficient to bring the sleighs out. We have had no sleighing as yet this Winter.

To the Editor of the N. Y. Time : That portion of territory proposed to be included within the limits of Arizona north of the Gila and west of the 111th parallel of North latitude is, like the country south of the Gila, of which mention has been made, a dreary waste of deserts and mountains, and entirely destitute of water.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : When a lady, however patriotic in feeling or romantic in sentiment, undertakes to cross the ocean with a view to explain to Americans the sufferings and wrongs of Italy, it would be well for her to consider that, although thousands of miles separate the New from the Old World, steam has reduced this distance to a mere trip, and facilitated the intercourse of Italians and Americans.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: When the manufacturers of iron are pressing their claims on the attention of Congress, I hear no effort on the part of those who are interested in having cheap iron. " Everybody's business " is the business of no one in particular, and the public loses Its strength because it has concentrated action.

THE MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION.--The Annual Election for officers of this Institution will be held on Tuesday, Jan. 18. There is just enough rivalry and jealousy existing among the members to make the proceedings interesting and the Society a live and useful one. At the first election, lone year ago, there were some who thought that a select few intended to rule and have their own way about everything.

Our readers probably remember the commotion xcited some ten days since by the rumor that a fresh revolutionary movement was on foot in the Island of Cuba, and that the Government of the Island had applied to France for her intervention and protection.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have read with much interest the several communications in your columns upon railroad management and reform; and, as a stockholder, I am pleased that the subject is receiving so much attention. Involving, as it does, an investment of more than a thousand millions of dollars in the United States alone, there are few, if any, financial questions more deserving the serious consideration of the public.

THE GREAT QUESTION IN CANADIAN POLITICS. -If we may judge from the utterances of Toronto and Montreal papers, the location of the Provincial capital continues to be the leading political topic in Canada. It is now about a year since good Queen VICTORIA, in a peacemaking spirit, designated Ottawa as the future seat of Viceregal majesty.

WHAT ARE WE COMING To.-The House of Representatives refused to cheat the country out of a day's service on Saturday, because General JACKSON defeated the British at NewOrleans some forty-five years ago. This extraordinary decision excited very natural surprise.

THE WRECK OF THE VANDERBILT--SAFETY OF THE CARGO--Capt. JACOB VANDERBILT, one of the principal owners of the steamer Vanderbilt, now ashore on Fisher's Island, returned from the wreck in the Plymouth Rock on Saturday. He reports that ht steamer is not so badly situated as has been represented, and that she is no so much injured as to preclude the hop of getting her afloat.

KELLY.--In this City, on Sunday, Jan. 9. KATIE MANUEL, daughter of Hugh and Virginia P. Kelly, aged 4 years and 6 months. The funeral will take place on Tuesday afternoon, at 8 o'clock, from the residence of her parents, No. 216 2d av. PERRY.-In this City, on Saturday, Jan. 8, SUSAN MERSEINE PERRY, aged 34 years and 3 months.

American ideas and American inventions continue to occupy the public attention in France. The application of electricity in the annihilation of pain durig surgical operations is just now the exciting topic of the hospitals. The idea of employing electricity as a local an??sthetic agent is due, I believe, or at least is attributed here, to Dr. FRANCIS, a dentist f Philadelphia.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The document published in the TIMES of Thursday, from Mr. ASHMEAD, the counsel for CANGEMI, is as remarkable for the unsoundness of its legal positions as for the peculiarity of tile circumstances under which it makes Its appearance.

Tile Speaker laid before the House a Message from the President, inclosing reports from the Secretary of the Treasury and Postmaster-General relative to the claims of CORMACK and RAMSEY for alleged abrogation of their contract for carrying the mail vid Vera Cruz and Acapulco to San Francisco.

FROM VENEZUELA.--By the arrival of the schooner Amy Chase, Capt. BRZVOOR, we have advices from Porto Cabello to Dec. 15. The country is- apparently quiet. There were great preparations being made for the reception of Gen. PAEZ. A great display is anticipated on his arrival. The Venezuelans were criticizing the Americans for making such grand dsmonstrations at his departure from the United States.

Governor MORGAN, in his Message, reiterates the devotion of New-York to the doctrine of Congressional sovereignty over the Territories, -and her persistent demand that Congress shall prohibit, by positive legislation, the extension of Slavery into any portion of the national domain.

The steamship Quaker City, with 120 passengers and San Francisco dates of the 20th of December, arrived here this evening. She was detained at the Coatzacoalcos bar by heavy northerly winds. The dates from the City of Mexico are to the 20th ult.

LOLA MONTEZ iN IRELAND.--As all England appears to be shaking in its shoes just now, for fear of being Americanized by Mr. BRIGHT'S speeches, the lectures of LOLA MONTEZ in Ireland, on the demoralizing influences of Democratic institutions, will be likely to find great favor with all classes of Conservatives on the other side of the Atlantic; for everybody that knows anything

THE ST. GEORGE'S FESTIVAL.--The grand Festival of the St. George's Society takes place to-day and to-night at the Academy of Music. The programme is one of the richest ever offered in this City. There will be a matinee at 1 o'clock, consisting of "La Serva Padrona" and "Martha" (for the first time in Italian.) Mile. PICCOLOMINI appears in the first named work;

A FEMALE FIGHT IN A GERMAN DANCE-HOUSE--ONE WOMAN STABBED.--At an early hour last evening, a quarrel ensued between JOHANNA VENT and CATHERINE BIDDLE, inmates of the German dance-house No. 103 Washington-street, during which Miss RIDDLE was stabbed and seriously injured by Miss VENT.

" YANKEE BLACKGUARDS."--One of the Liverpool papers, in giving an account of the destruction by fire of the New-York packet-ship Isaac Wright, says that, " the Captain was sober, but the crew were all a set of regular Yankee blackguards."

GENTLEMEN: It is my duty to report to you the total loss of the schooner Susan, under my command. We had been forced in on this coast by adverse winds; the vessel not proving at all weatherly in the heavy head sea then running.

The most important business transacted by the United States Senate yesterday was the passage of the French Spoliation bill, by a vote of 26 to 20, after elaborate speeches by Mr. DAVIS against it, and Mr. CRITTENDEN in its favor. Senator DOUGLAS appeared and took his seat for the first time during the session.

The Senate met at 7 P. M., and the President announced the following Standing Committees. On Canals--Messrs. Prosser, Loveland and Mather --Mr. Prosser taking the place of Mr. Stow. On Charitable and Religious Societies--Messrs. Truman, Smith and Prosser. Internal Affairs of Towns and Counties--Messrs. J. A. Willard, O. B. Wheeler, and F. Spinola.

Mr. DOUGLAS appeared and took his seat, upon which there was a slight attempt at applause in the gallery. Mr. CAMERON presented a memorial from the citizens of Philadelphia in favor of the passage of the Old Soldiers' bill.

No.--26. Ross Winans vs. The New-York and Erie Railroad Company. Error to the Circuit Court for the Northern District of New-York. Justice GRIER delivered the opinion of the Court, affirming the judgment with costs.

The annual truce to political conflict which in the worst of times has been agreed to in England during the last week of the year, is bailed this season with pleasure by all sections and parties. The first act of the Reform drama may be said to have closed with Mr. BRIGHT'S speech at Glasgow, which was answered on the part of the conservative Whigs by Mr. MONCRIEFF (the late Lord-Advocate) at Leith.

The chances for an extra session of Congress are now seriously calculated in high quarters. The articles in foreign papers touching the views of England and France have excited a lively interest here. Mr. BARKSDALE'S call for correspondence is designed to ascertain if our Government has been notified of these views as alleged by the Paris Presse.

Canal Commissioner GARDNER this morning was shorn into office by the Secretary of State. The new Canal Board met and organized to-day, after which they adjourned to the 18th inst. The Calendar will be taken up on the 8th of February.

The Kentucky State Convention, on Saturday, adopted a platform indorsing the Cincinnati platform and the Dred Scott decision, encouraging the acquisition of Cuba, denouncing sectional agitation, the North, and Know-Nothingism,--indorsing the Administration, and proposing that the determination of their differences upon minor and unessential points, such as Kansas and Lecomptonism, shall not be permitted to disturb the harmony of the Democracy of Kentucky.

The public will be interested in a brief sketch of the triangular case of the United States vs. JOHN A. SUTTER, which has been occupying the attention of the Supreme Court, and in which the concluding argument has been to-day made by General BUTLER, of Lowell.

FURTHER PARTICULARS OF THE LATEST REVOLUTION IN MEXICO--FALL OF ZULOAGA--INTERESTING FROM THE RIO GRANDE. The dates from Vera Cruz are to the 30th ult., vid Minatitlan. Gen. ROBLES overthrew ZULOAGA on the 23d. Gen. ECHEAGARAY had previously pronounced in favor of ROBLES, and the Constitutionalists at Jalapa and Cordovajoined him.

PRESENTATION OF PLATE--INTERESTING LETTERS OF GENERAL WASHINGTON AND GOVERNOR GEORGE CLINTON. The annual meeting of the Marine Society of the port of New-York was held last evening at the United States Hotel, Captain CHARLES H. MARSHALL, President of the Society, in the Chair.

To the Editor of the New-York Time : Statements calculated to injure the undersigned having appeared in the public papers within the past few days, with reference to the City Inspectorship, I deem it but proper to contradict these misrepresentations by a denial of alleged bargainings, and to say that it has not been,

KANSAS AFFAIRS--DISPATCHES FROM GOVMEDARY.--The St. Louis Republican, 6th, has the following: "Lieut. J.P. JONES, Second Regiment United States Artil ery, arrived in this city on the evening of the 1st, from Kansas, with dispatches from Gov. MEDARY to the President.

CANAL CONVENTION IN OHIO.--A State Convention of gentlemen interested in Canals and Transportation assembled on the 6th instant at Columbus. The immediate cause of this movement was the passage in the Ohio House of Representatives of a bill for the sale of the public works.

An important paper, on the modifications which the ships of the British Navy have undergone during the present century, was read by Mr. REED, naval architect, at the weekly meeting of the Society of Arts, in London, Dec. 15, 1858--Admiral Sir CHARLES NAPIER in tile chair.

The Postmaster-General is a melancholy monument of talents misapplied. He spent the past year in reducing to practice a scheme of overland mail-carriage, which has the novel advantage of costing for the transmission of a single letter from St.

For the last two years all the lions of Paris have been American. Young MORPHY, the chess-player, is the last in the list. The great match between this gentleman and Professor ANDERSSEN, of Breslau, commenced on Monday morning at 12 o'clock. M. ANDERSSEN arrived in Paris Wednesday previous, but Mr. MORPHY was confined to bed with an attack of the influenza.

In a late letter I gave you the history of the triumph of certain modifications in surgery introduced into France by American surgeons. I propose, to-day, to give you a resume of American industry abroad, giving the place of honor, on account of its extent, to dentistry.

The following is a list of tile officers and crew of the ship Margaret Tyson, which sailed for San Francisco in August last, and has been reported lost, no date, by one of the crew named WILLIAM KENNEDY, who was picked up by the whaling schooner Orcad and carried to Fayal.

The cold snap of yesterday took us all by surprise, for the change in the weather was not only very sudden and very great, but the temperature of the atmosphere was lower than it had been before in this City in seventy years.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article published in your journal of the date of Friday last, referring to the loss of the Souud steamer C. Vanderbilt, contains an allusion to the officers of the United States cutter Campbell, which, although doubtless unintentional on the part of your reporter, seems to convey reproach and censure upon the officer who came on shore to us.

VERY FRESH NEWS.--The Evening Post of yesterday republishes from the London Herald the letters, circulars, , concerning the financial operations of Mr. S. HALLETT in Paris and London, together with statements of the manner in which our Ministers in those two cities have become involved in his schemes.

Mrs. Littles, the Rochester murderess, is employed at Sing Sing State Prison in trimming hate. She conducts herself with propriety, and obeys the discipline of the Prison. The forger Huntington, in the same institution, is said to be one of the best of the prisoners. He is employed as book-keeper in the cabinetshop.

KELLY.--In this City, on Sunday, Jan. 9. KATIE MANUEL, daughter of Hugh and Virginia P. Kelly, aged 4 years and 6 months. The funeral will take place on Tuesday afternoon, at 8 o'clock, from the residence of her parents. No. 216 2d av. VOORHEES.--In Brooklyn, on Monday, Jan. 10, PETER VOORHEES, aged 67 years, 2 months and 18 days.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--A regular meeting of the Brooklyn Commun Council was held last evening. CREATION OF NEW TERRITORIES.--There are before Congress so less than six applications for the creation of new Territories. On the one hand it is sought to create out of the southern half of New-Mexico a new Territorial Government, to be called Arizona.

It will be remembered, that some three years ago, we gave an account of the accidental discovery of some old title-deeds to a large landed property in New-York and New-Jersey, which had been lost for years, and which the heirs had been unable to discover; that the property covered by those titles was located in the heart of New-York city, and was of immense value;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I read, in your paper of to-day, an article designed as a reply to the "statement" which the counsel for CANGEMI proposed to read to the Court before sentence was pronounced upon him, a portion of which was published a few days ago in your valuable journal.

The right of petition is a most respectable right, certainly; and although it sometimes proves a sad annoyance to legislators in the discharge of their business or the carrying out of their policy, we. should be sorry to see it tampered with, even in this land of " chartered libertines."

FESTIVITIES-OF THE TAMMANY SOCIETY--ADDRESS OF MR. I. V. FOWLER, THE GRAND SACIIEM-BRILLIANT DEMONSTRATION OF THE DEMOCRACY- OF THE OLD WIGWAM. Regardless of the precedent set by the House of Representatives at Washington, on Friday last, the Tammany-Society of this City resolved to commemorate, by an appropriate fete, the memory of the day on which, forty-five years ago, General JACKSON defeated the British at New-Orleans.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In March, 1856, the Sonora Exploring and Mining Company was formed in Cincinnati, and a party under the direction of Col. C. D. POSTON was sent to Arizona to explore for silver mines. Col. POSTON located with his company at Tubac, a deserted Mexican Puebla, in the centre of the territory, and explored the neighborhood.

Care must be taken not to exaggerate the import of a Message of the President of the United States. To appreciate it exactly, it is well not only to examine closely the nature of the document itself, but also to take into the reckoning the circumstances with which the author is surrounded. A simple and impartial statement of the affairs of the Republic would be received by us without distrust, and accepted without restiction.

We publish to-day several very interesting articles upon the Message of Mr. BuCHANAN, from the ablest journals of France and England. These articles are of importance, not merely as indicating the effect produced by the State paper of which they treat on the most thoughtful and clear-sighted public opinion of Europe, but also as testiimo-

Lord Poltimore is just dead in England, at the age of 72. On the 7th of September, 1831, he was elevated to the peerage by the then Waig Government for zealous services lendered in the cause of Reform. A letter from Lombardy states that M. Rossi, Professor of veterinary surgery at Pavia, was stabbed in the streets on the 10th Dec., d died next morning.

THE MARTYRS OFTHE PRISON SHIRS.--The military of Kings County, in connection with another organization, are making extensive arrangements to crect a suitable monument on Fort Greene to the memory of the martyrs of the prison ships. In this connection Major-General DURYEA has presented a bill to the Legislature for an act of incorporation.
AMERICAN ARTISTS IN PARIS.--Our correspondent "Malakoff," in giving an account of American artists in Paris, made a strange mistake in classing Mr. FAGNANI, formerly of New-York among the sculptors.

The Philadelphia Ledger notices the arrival in that city of a company of sixty railroad laborers, who left New-York on the 17th of November last, in the bark Linda, for St. Jago de Cuba, to work on a railroad. They contracted, it is alleged, to work for $20 a month and found, with a free passage there and back, and to remain six months on the island.

President BENSON, of Liberia, writes, under date of Nov. 15: "I have directed an armed land police of America-Liberians to be stationed on shore at the points up the coast, beyond Cape Mount, from whence the natives are shipped, in order to prevent any more from being sent off to CHEVALIER'S or other French vessels,

re the Editor of the New-York Times: The magnetic needle has been used very generally in this country for determining the directions or bearing of lines in ordinary surveys. The results given by it, particularly those of the earlier surveys, are notoriously troublesome; so much so that many disputes about boundaries involve simply the question of the magnetic bearing of lines.

The State Prison Inspectors have made a repert upon the case of the convict MOORE, who died from the effects of the punishment by shower-bath in the Auburn State Prison. The Inspectors exculpate the officers of tile Prison from all charges of intentional recklessness or brutality, but, in view of the danger attending the use of that means of punishment, decide to abolish the use of the shower-bath.

DEMOCRACY.--We have read speeches spoken by national and sensible men on the dangerous influence of democratic demagogues. We are democracy we plead guilty of democracy. What are it horrois? Will democracy teach men to plunder property? to neglect duties? to be mischievous and violent? They could be, or do, all that even now.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: My reputation for "delicacy" and "modesty" has received so many rude shocks, since I ventured, in 1857, upon the invitation of the Board of Visitors at West Point, to suggest certain improvement in some of the systems and courses of instruction at the Military Academy, that it would be preposterous for me to claim to hive any diffidence on any subject whatever.

THE ONLY WAY TO PROMOTE ART.--Many of us perhaps are under the impression that plenty of schooling will do this; that plenty of lecturing will do it; that sending abroad for patterns will do it; or that patience, time, and money, and seed-will may do it. And, alas! none of these things, put all of them put together, will do it.

BRUTAL ASSAULT ON LEWIS D. CAMPBELL-His LIFE IN DANGER.--We are pained to learn that Mr. CAMPBELL, ex-Congressman, was struck by some ruffian, and seriously if not fatally injured, while on his way from his office to his residence on Tuesday night. Mr. C. says that he left his office between 12 and 1 o'clock, and was struck by some one who came up behind him.

The most remarkable feature in the President's Message is the almost unprecedented absence of expressions of hostility to England.. Only one opportunity has been afforded within the last twelvemonth for the orators and journalists of the Union to air their patriotism by reproductions of the famous Pogrom Defiance, and the President has some pretext for alleging that the right of visit has been abandoned,

A correspondent of the Marion Commonwealth noticing the Africans that passed through Montgomery, Ala., recently, says: "I was carried through 'BROWN'S speculator house,' (so called,) on Perry-Street. In a house in the back lot were huddled together thirty-eight native (Congo) Africans! Don't shudder and say 'The moral sentiments of Chris endom condemn the traffic.'

To all practical intents and purposes we are without a City Government at the present time, and all departments of the public service, except the Police, stand paralysed and disbanded from the failure of the last Common Council to pass the estimates of appropriations for the present year.

The vote in the State Senate to-day for United States Senator resulted as follows: HENRY WILSON, 35; GEORGE BOUTWELL, 3; EDWARD ERERETT and CALEB CUSHING, 1 each. JAMES A. ABBOTT, a well-known lawyer of this city, this morning fell over the bannisters from the third story of the Coolidge House, and was instantly killed. His death is attributed to suicide.

SECORD.--In this City, n Monday evening, Jan. 11, suddenly, Mrs. FANNY SECORD, in the 70th year of her age. The relatives and friends of he family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral service, this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock, at the residence of her son, John F. Secord, No. 281 5th-St. POLLOCK.--In this City, on Tuesday, Jan. 11, ALICE JANE, youngest daughter of John K. and Alice J. Pollock.

I fear, Mr. Editor, that the land of "steady habits" is beginning to lose its calm and quiet steadiness of character; at least the Hartford specimens of Yankeedom have just now been showing some of the real "Boston tea-party" grit. Some things were said last night at the anniversary of the Hartford Tract Society which will interest many ten-thousands of your readers.

DISTINGUISHED POTATOES,--In Gerard's time, 1597, Virginia potatoes, as they were then called, were just beginning to be known. A sweet potato had been previously known, which was used as a kind of confection at the tables of the rich. Of these, Gerard says: "They are used to be eaten rosted in the ashes; some when they be so rosted.

THE NEW BARK A. H. BADGER.--The sight of a new vessel from any quarter has come to be something of a novelty. The interruption in ship-building elsewhere caused by the hard times, do not appear to have produced much diminution in that branch of business in the Pine Tree State.

We learn from Mr. J. S. McCOMB, the bearer of a petition to the Governor of this State, from the citizens of Bates County, Mo., who arrived in this city direct from there to-day, the particulars of another startling outrage, committed by the robber MONTGOMERY and his band, in that County, on the night of the 30th of December.

The United States Mail steamship, Moses Taylor, A. G. GRAY, commanding, from Aspinwall on the 3d inst., arrived at this port about 12 o'clock last night, with the mails, treasure and passengers brought down from San Francisco to Panama by the P. M. Steamship Company's steamer, John L. Stephens, which left San Francisco on the 20th ult.

The Evening Post, of this City, published, the day before yesterday, as "just from Paris," an elaborate account of the part taken by our Ministers at London and Paris in the stockjobbing operations of one Mr. SAMUEL HALLETT, and which had been made familiar to the commercial world some two months ago, through the columns of the NEW-YORK TIMES.

Our feelings in the matter do not warrant us in indorsing this harsh degree of censure.

A block of buildings occupied by the telegraph office, the Exprcss office, insurance offices and a Masonic Lodge, was totally destroyed by fire last night. The loss is not estimated. Dr. WM. ADAMS, on "Daily Wonders." He said that in one of Mrs. BARBAULD'S "Evenings at Home," which were the delight of our childhood, was a chapter entitle "Travelers' Wonders."

IPRVSV A CUURE FOR DELIRIUM TREMENS.-Dr. Gerhard Poali, physician to the Bridewell City Prison, of Chicago, read a paper before the Mcdical Society of that city, a few days since, in which he stated that he bad under his treatment Jast year 160 cases of this disease, 8 of which proved fatal, and this year up to the date of his lecture, 100, of which 4 proved fatal.

THE CITY ISNSPETOR'S DEPARTMENT--Not With standing the warlike manifestoes which were issued yesterday from the City Inspector's office, everything there remains in a perfect state of tranquility. Mr. MOETON receives all callers in his inner office as blandly and courteously as ever.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: As the draft of by-laws and regulations submitted with my communication on Railroad Management and Reform published in your paper of this day) was too long for insertion in your columns, I hand you herewith a brief synopsis of its provisions, which, if practicable, please insert in your next issue.

INGENIOUS DETECTION OF A MAIL ROBBER.Post Office Agent HOLBROOK has been hunting a new mail robber, and of course has caught him. According to the Troy Whig the culprit is a shoemaker, named JOHN MAHAR, employed by the Postmaster at Mcchanicsville, N. Y. His depredations have cxtended over a period of three or four years. For a time his suspicions settled down upon the Mechanicsville office.

Two great causes of disease in New-York have been overlooked. One-the most manageable and easily enough controlled when honest intelligence heads the departments--is the thick layer of miasmatic matter than overlies all the paved part of the town. The acknowledged source of remittent and intermittent fevers is the decay of vegetable and animal matter in moist situations.

PRISON PUNISHMFNTS.-The State Prison Inspectors have made a report on the case of MOORE, the convict who died recently in Auburn State Prison, after undergoing the punishmcnt of the shower-bath. The Inspectors review the facts of the case, arrive at the conclusion that the man really died in consequence of excessive punishment, and yet exculpate the officers of the Prison from blame;

A RATHER CURIOUS SPECTACLE.--Our Law Reports, Yesterday, mentioned what must strike the public as rather a novel proceeding. It will be remembered that about a year ago one PARMELEE was indicted for having robbed a Mr. DIBBLEE, No. 25 Murray-street, of very large quantities of silks, which he sent and sold regularly to a firm in Philadelphia, named FURNISS Co.

We have had interesting times here lately, and the tedious monotony of a residence in these far-off regions has been considerably enlivened by the legal proceedings of the United States District Court, Judge SINCLAIR presiding, For awhile back it has seemed that serious trouble would arise between the Federal officers and the Mormons.

MY DEAR TIMES :-You are usually a very lucid writer, and entertaining and instructive of course ; but in the editorial in your issue of January 1, entitled "The Fillibusters and Tombigbee"--what do you mean by "a meeting held at Tombigbee." There is no town of Tombigbee, nor any political body to styled--therefore there can be no such entitles as " Tombigbee publicists."

By the arrival at Charleston on the Sth, of the British schooners Robert George, Captain SAWYER, and British Queen, Captain JOHNSON, the latter in three days passage, we have advices to Jan. 1. The British schooner A. Canale arrived out from Charleston on the 27th ult, in three days' passage, and having been absent from Nassau only fifteen days for the entire trip.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I sce by the journals of this morning that Mr. GEORGE W. MORTON announces that he shall hold on to the office of City Inspector until his successor is duly appointed. This presents a question worth looking into, and, ifI am not greatly in error, in my examination of the law, quite a job of business is here cut out by Mr. MORTON for the Grand Jury.

BALL AT NIBLO'S FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE ROMAN CATHOLIC ORPHANS.--On Monday night, at Niblo's, the Young Men's Association for the Benefit of the Roman Catholic Orphans, held their fifth annual ball. Of this Association JAMES LYNCH is President, OLIVER SADLIER and JOHN A. McLAUGHLIN Vice-Presidents, DANIEL LALOE Treasurer, and JOHN McCARTEN Secretary.

The MCXICAN news by the Quaker City was wrongly interpreted on Monday. The following is believed to be a correct version of a portion of the New-Orleans dispatch, which came to hand in a some what confused form.--REP. Gen. ROBLES overthrew ZULOACA on the 23d. ECHEAGARAY had previously pronounced in favor of ROBLES and the Constitutionalists at Jalapa and CORDOVA had joined him.

Governor MORRILL'S Message to the Legislature of Maine recommends the policy of canceling the State debt as it matures. The liabilities of the State are: Public Debt, $699,500; Trust Fund, $124,577 62; making $1,124,077 84. The former is payable in unequal sums of not less than $30,000, nor more than $50,000 annually, and all at tile cloe of the year 1876, while annual interest is payable upon the latter for the support of common schools.

The U. S. Mail steamship Moses Taylor, from Aspinwall on the 3d instant, arrived at this port about 12 o'clock last night, bringing the mails, treasure and passengers which left San Francisco on the 20th ult. The treasure list foots up over a million and a half of dollars. The California news has generally been anticipated by the Overland Mail at St. Louis, and by the steamship Quaker City at New-Orleans, vid Tchuantepec.

TRIAL OF THE MACHINERY OF THE WINANS STEAMSHIP.--A day or two since, the Messrs. WINANS, for the first time, put in motion the machinery of their new and novel iron steamer, lying at their yard, Ferry Bar, South Baltimore.

From the Washington States. To the Editor of the States: Since my recent arrival in New-York, I have seen, for the first time, a publication made by the lion. JOHN SLIDELL, denying positively that he authorized, or in any manner countenanced, the statement published in the Press and Tribune, of Chicago, just before the late Illinois election, to the effect that the slaves belonging to my children, in Mississippi, were cruelly and inhumanly treated.

We have received from our Washington correspondent, through the courtesy of the Chairman of the Naval Committee of the Senate, a highly interesting paper, "Notes and Observations on the Review at Spithead, by Commander W. M. WALKER, United States Navy," an extract from which we now lay before our readers, in the belief that the valuable information it contains could hardly have come more opportunely.

Events crowd each other in Mexico. It is but three days ago that we announced the accession of General ROBLES to power at the capital, and the probabilities of an immediate restoration of the Juarez Government.
After two weeks of damp, rainy, foggy, muggy, raw, disagreeable weather, the sun has again peeped forth, and this morning we have such a sunshine as ought to make all kinds of nature glad.

The New-Bedford Whalemen's Shipping List, of Jan. 11, 1859, contains an elaborate statement of the results of last year's whale fishery. As compared with former years it has been generally unproductive, and in many cases disastrous, and there has been a consequent diminution of the number of vessels and tonnage employed in the fleet, amounting to 8,033 tons as compared with the previous year.

We have another snow-storm and the cold is still intense. Heating the hotels by steam is a proven humbug, and in their rooms they rejoice who have large grates or air-tight wood-consuming stoves. A more pinched up, blue-nosed, frozen-eared congregation I never saw gathered than came up from the Southern Counties by the Hudson and Harlem Railroads yesterday.

KIRTLAND.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, Jan. 11, CHARLOTTE KIRTLAND, widow of the late Judge Kirtland, and daughter of the late Gen. R. McCarty. The funeral will take place from her late residence. No. 141 8th-st., on Friday. at 3 o'clock P. M. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend, without further notice.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: The " Officer in the Piedmiontese Army," who, in your paper of yesterday, expresses a belief that citizens of the United States will not be misled by " illusions " respecting Italian political questions, undertakes at the same time to enlighten us on that subject, and especially on the character of the late King of Sardinia, CHARLES ALBERT.

A BOY EATEN BY HIS OWN DOG.--The Laporte (Ind.) Times gives the particulars of a horrible affair in that neighborhood. Several boys started from the residence of a German widow lady, a mile or two from town, to go to Laporte, and among them was the son of the widow.

THE HARBOR, THE ICE, AND THE WEATHER.-The moderated temperature of yesterday was nowhere more apparent than upon the East and North Rivers, and in tne vicinity of the various ferries. There was no new ice of any consequence, although there was an abundance of the old crop, collected during the previous two days and nights.

NO CLUE YET TO HIS WHEREAROUTS--SKETCH OF THE MURDERER--BURIAL OF HIS VICTIM. FELIX SANCHEZ, the young Spaniard who murdered his father-in-law a few days since, and attempted to murder his wife and mother-in-law, has managed thus far to elude the vigilant and unremitting search made for him by the Police.

" UNCLE TOM" IN ITALLIAN--The Paris correspondent of the Boston Traveller writes: "You should get Professor MONTI to translate 'Uncle Tom's Cabin' from Italian into English. Mrs. STOWE herself would not recognize her bantling. The Pope having read 'Uncle Tom,' and being delighted with it, determined to have it done into Italian for the edification of his subjects.

There can be hardly anything more melancholy and disheartening in "a parliamentary sense" than the reports which meet one's eye in every letter from Washington, of the proceedings in Congress. Each of them contains a short and tolerably good summary, not of speeches but of essays, apropos des bottes.

Mr. and Mrs. Wm. Carey, parents of Gen. S. F. Carey, the well-known Temperance lecturer, celebrated their golden-wedding anniversary last week. At the festival one article of furniture attracted much attention, although it was simply a plain, unobtrusivelooking bedstead, manufactured from the wood of a mild cherry tree which Mr. Carey cut upon his own farm, and which has been in use forty years.

SECOND ANNUAL TEA PARTY--SPEECHES BY THE REV. DR. KREBS, HIRAM KETCHUM, THE REV. DR, GILLETTE, PROFESSOR MITCHELL, G. H. STUART, ESQ., MAYOR TIEMANN, The Young Men's Christian Association gave their second annual tea party last evening, in Mozart Hall.

The large tannery of WM. PAGGT CO., situated near the woolen factory in this place, caught fire yesterday noon, originating from overheating the kiln in the drying-room. The building contained a large amount of tanned leather and wool, nearly all destroyed.

QUARANTINE.--Mr. DURYEA, a member of Assembly from Brooklyn, does not quite despair of the common sense and neighborly liberality of New-Jersey. On Monday, he offered a joint resolution that a Committee of three be appointed by the Governor and Senate to meet a like Committee to be appointed by New-Jersey, to confer on Quarantine affairs, which resolution was laid over.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: As a facetious statement in your journal of Monday last, under the caption, " Jenkins in Bad Company," seems, as we think, unfairly to imply negligence or inattention on our part, perhaps you will allow us to say a few words by way of explanation.

On the 6th of January Gov. STEWART transmitted a Special Message to the Legislature of Missouri in reference to the new troubles in Kansas. It was as follows: Gentlemen of the Senate and House of Representatives:

CORNELL-BANTA.-In this City, on Tuesday, Jan. 11, at the South Baptist Church, by the Rev. G. Alexander Peltz, ROBERT G. CORNELL to Miss MARY C. BANTA, all of this City. BRADFORD-GRAHAM.-In this City, on Tuesday, Jan. 11, by the Rev. Dr. Potts, SAMUEL DEXTER BRADFORD, Jr., to REBECCA, adopted daughter of James Lorimer Graham.

IMPORTANT MEETING OF THE KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.-An adjourned meeting of this Board was held in the County Jail yesterday afternoon, SAMUEL SMITH, Esq., President in the Chair. The minutes were read and approved, when the Chair called for communications.

CUBA.--We do not participate in the European objections to the acquisition of Cuba by the United States, on terms to which its present Spanish owners may be willing to agree. As we repeatedly pointed out in connection with the right-of-search question, such a measure is the only possible way of putting a stop to the Slave-trade and all the vexatious questions arising out of it.

THE JAMESTOWN AT SAN JUAN DEL NORTE.-Captain KENNEDY, of the United States sloop Jamestown, was at Aspinwall on the sailing of the Moses Taylor, and reported that the Savannah was lying inside the bar at San Juan del Norte, drawing 21 feet, while there was only 21 feet 8 inches of water on the bar.

The steamship Tennessee is below with dates from the City of Mexico to the 6th ints. General ECHEAGARAY pronounced Dec. 20, at Ayubla was not seconded at the capital. The troops pronounced in favor of General ROBLES, on the 23d, and he issued a call for three delegates from each State to form a junta.

THE KANSAS GOLD REGION.--The Lawrence Herald of Freedom gives a narrative of CHARLES NICHOLS, who has just returned from the gold mines. Mr. N. says there is a country there extending over 300 miles of territory north and south, in which there is some gold, and he has explored the same for a hundred miles from cast and west.

From the Bucyrus (Ky.) Journal. A moving incident came to our knowledge last Week, which we lay before our readers. We suppress names for reasons obvious to every one. Near Louisville, Ky., lives a planter of wealth and standing. He was the possessor ofa hundred negroes, and he was noted for his thrifty, money-making disposition. He had never been married, and was an incorrigible-bachelor of fifty.

Ex-Governor SEYMOUR, of this State, was invited to attend the 8th of January celebration at St. Louis, and wrote the following letter: UTICA, saturday, Dec. 25, 1858. GENTLEMEN: I have received your flattering invitation to go to St. Louis and address its Democracy on the 8th of January next. I regret I cannot gratify myself by visiting your State on an occasion which arouses the patriotism of the American people.

The excution of JAMES MCMAHON for the murder of his sister-in-law ANN McMAHON, on the night of Sept. 19, 1858, in Newark, N. J., took place yesterday forenoon at 11 1/2 o'clock in the hall of the County prison in that city. The murder was the most brutal ever committed in the State of NewJersey, and nothing was left undone by the authorities of Newark to bring the perpetrator to justice.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There are certain officers, called "Sealers of Weights and Measures," who are each year appointed by the City Inspector, and who go round the City once in each year. entering all stores where weights and measures are employed for public use.

DEATH OF ANOTHER MEMBER OF THE HUTCHIN-SON FAMILY.--Mr. JUDSON J. HUTCHINSON, one of the brothers of the celebrated Hutchinson Family, died at Lynn, Mass., on Tuesday, Jan. 11. JUDSON, JOHN and ASA, and their sister ABBY, made their public appearance as a quartette band nearly fifteen years ago, and attracted overflowing audiences in this City and elsewhere for some years.

JOHN BRIGHT has drawn on himself the wrath of all "true-born Englishmen," by certain comparisons which he has instituted between the political institutions of Great Britain and those of the United States, rather invidious to the former.

I can send you but little of interest by this mail. Our negro population have been celebrating the Christmas and New-Year's Holidays in their rough manner, by fandangoes, cock-fighting, foot-races, Church-feasts, and by soaking themselves in aguadiente, while the whites hare been principally engaged in keeping out of the sun and imbibing iced cobblers.

It is snowing again as usual, but the weather is more moderate. Little has occurred in either branch of the Legislature to-day to make a note of. It is understood that the Governor sent in the following nominations to the Senate: For Bank Superintendent--JAMES M. COOK, reappointment. For Commissary General--BENJAMIN WELCH, Jr., of Buffalo, in place of J. H. HOBART WARD.

The editors of the New-York Shipping and Commercial List have published their annual statement of the Sugar Trade of the United States, (exclusive of California and Oregon,) for 1858: "The total receipt of Foreign Unrefined Sugar into the United States for the Year ending Dec. 31, 1858, were 255,100 tons, against receipts in 1857 of 269,180 tons:

THE LABORERS RETURNING FROM CUBA.--The company of laborers who left New-York for St. Jago de Cuba, and were compelled to return, landing at Philadelphia, have published the following statement of their grievances: To his Honor the Mayor of Philadelphia, State of Pennsylvania, United States of America:

THE GALWAY STEAMERS. -- A large and influential meeting was held in Dublin on the 22d ultimo, upon the subject of postal communication with America. Resolutions were adopted declaring that the commercial, social and political interests of the Kingdom demand the most extended facilities for frequent, punctual and rapid communication with America,-- and that the geographical position of Ireland suggests that as the proper point of departure.

Notices were given of bills to regulate the theatres in New-York, and to re-organize the Port Wardens in that City. BILLS INTRODUCED. To Charter the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn and the German Savings Bank of New-York. By Mr. SLOAN, to amend the Usury laws.

The British screw steamship Alps, Captain HACKLE, from Havre, Dec. 25, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She experienced, on her voyage, a succession of heavy, westerly gales. Her advices have bee chiefly anticipated by the Africa. We add additional items of interest.

A telegraph dispatch from New-Orleans gives us at last something definite relative to recent movements in Mexico. The steamship Tennessee has arrived there from Vera Cruz, bringing advices from the capital to the 6th inst., and from the latter city to the 9th.

Mr. SLIDELL'S MODE OF GETTING CUBA.--The honorable Senator from Louisiana desires to get Cuba. In this he is by no means singular. He has a plan to effect that end. On Monday he proposed it to the Senate in the form of a bill. It is simply to renew negotiations for purchasing the much-coveted island. We do not understand that Mr. SLIDELL has taken out patent for his invention.

The San Francisco Herald has been favored with the following letter, written by a gentleman connected with Captain STONE'S Surveying Party: GUAYMAS, Oct. 18, 1858, I write with pleasure from this place to give you a few items of news concerning our survey. We have now been seven months in and about Guaymas, and are all in excellent health and spirits.

The President, in reply to Mr. SEWARD'S resolution, informed the Senate that the Wanderer has landed a cargo of Africans; also, that every effort is being made to bring the guilty parties to justice, but that it is not expedient now to make public the correspondence on the subject. On motion of Mr. HUNTER, of Virginia, the communication was ordered to be printed.

It is almost incredible that any serious assault should be made upon an institution so well established and powerful as the lobby at Albany. For a period so long that the memory of man runneth not to the contrary, but more especially for a dozen years back, bills in which there was money have been controlled by the Third House.

The large stone building, owned by R. E. ROBINSON Co., and occupied by several persons as a flouring mill, furniture wareroom, confectionary and bakery, , was totally destroyed by fire at about 2 o'clock this morning. Loss $30,000; insurance $14,000. Supposed to be the work of an incendiary. FIRE IN ST. JOHN, N. B. ST. JOHN, N. B., Thursday, Jan. 13.

[To SENATORS: It is respectfully suggested to Senators that their voices are inaudible in the gallery when pitched in the same key they were wont to use in the old Chamber. This is especially the case during the morning hour, when, their voices failing to reach the terzo cercinc--the exalted circle assigned to the Press,--the business seems to be transacted in dumb show, and the proceedings have the appearance of a not very expressive pantomime.--REPORTER.]

There appears to be some alarm excited by Mr. MASON'S bill, proposing to confer on the President the power of exacting summary redress from Mexico or any of the Central American Staies, in which an American citizen may happen to sustain any injury, by authorizing him to employ the naval and military forces of the Republic for that purpose whenever he shall deem it necessary.

LETTER FROM THE PRESIDENT REFUSING TO INTERFERE. The Board of Representatives of the Inited Congregations of Israelites of the City of New-York, held a meeting on Tuesday evening at the Greene-street Synagogue Chambers. Ten congregations were represented by delegates. On motion, SOLOMON I. JOSEPH, Esq. was called to the Chair.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara., from Liverpool on the 1St inst., with a week's later news from Europe, arrived at Halifax yesterday forenoon. We received by this arrival the gratifying intelligence of the safety of the steamship Wench, so long overdue at this port. She had put into Queenstown with her pumps choked, and leaking, having experienced a severe hurricane, and being obliged to throw part of her cargo overboard.

A GOOD BEGINNING.--The City Government has authorized the opening of a street across the Park,-connecting Beekman-street with Park-place. This is very good, so far as it goes. It will render useful a portion of the Park, and afford some relief to the crowded travel of Broadway and Fulton-street.

A joke in title Senate has cost them a day, and set the lobby in a terrible flurry. On Wednesday, while in a merry mood, a Senator moved to refer the lobby paragraph of the Governor's Message to the Committeeon Public Buildings, which always is a Committee of leisure. The motion carried.

AN IMPROPER PRESIDENT OF A UNIVERSITY.--The Rev. Dr. DAILY, President of the State University of Indiana, appears to have fallen from grace. The Indianapolis Journal learns that charges have been preferred against him on the following charges:

Governor RANDALL'S message was delivered today. The financial affairs of the State are in a favorable condition, and the Governor thinks that not more than two hundred thousand dollars will be required the present year. Liberal appropriations for completing the Lunatic Asylum and House of Refuge are recommended. The Governor favors the Mortgage Stay Law, which he thinks has been greatly misrep-

Colonel SUMNER left for Fort Leavenworth yesterday, under orders from the War Department. It is thought that his transfer has reference to the disturbances in the southern part of Kansas. JOHN W. GUTHRIE, who left Salt Lake Nov. 27, gives a painful account of the suffering of men and animals on the Plains in consequence of the coldness of the weather.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, Capt. LANG, from Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of Jan. 1, arrived at Halifax at 10 1/2 o'clock this forenoon. The Niagara reports, Jan. 7, lat. 51[Degrees], long. 33[degree], passed the Danish brigantine Adonis, bound west. The screw-steamer Jura, for New-York, sailed on the morning of the 1st.

From the Toronto Globe. Mr. HIND returned from his last exploring expedition to the Northwest Territory about ten days ago, accompanied by Mr. DICKENSON, Engineer; Mr. JOHN FLEMING, Surveyor; and Mr. HIME, Artist. Mr. HIND and his party thoroughly explored the neighborhood of the Assiniboine, and traversed the south branch of the Saskatchewan some hundreds of miles.

The Postmaster-General sent to the Senate today his reply to Senator HUNTER'S resolution calling for a plan which would render the Post-office Department self-sustaining. He first shows that he did not undertake the administration of the office with a view to its being a self-sustaining concern. Mr. CAMPBELL had notified Congress that there would be a deficit of four millions.

POWERS.--In this City. on Thursday morning. Jan. 13, of scarlet fever, JAMES CLARENCE,, youngest child of Jas. G. and Amelia A. Powers, aged 1 year and 6 months. chin The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further invitation, on Saturday, 15th inst.. at 1 o'clock. from No. 163 West 25th-st.

Our Sandwich Islands files give an interesting account of the cruise of the United States surveying-schooner Fenimore Cooper, which arrived at Honolulu Nov. 9, after a trip of 43 days from San Francisco. She had been occupied most of the time in sounding, and in repeatedly sailing over the positions of Cooper's Island, and some seven other reported dangers. She had good weather and light winds the whole time.

KANSAS. The Kansas Legislature met on the 3d of January. Bills were introduced to annex to Kansas that portion of Nebraska lying south of the Platte River; to repeal the Slave Code of the Territory, and to abolish Slavery. The Governor's Message speaks in praise of the natural beauties of Kansas, He regrets the growing disposition in various parts of the Union to overrate the number of votes, and corrupt the

The New-Orleans Picayune has been favored by a commercial house of that city with the following extract from a letter, dated TAMPICO, Thursday, Dec. 23, 1858. The Spanish difficulty was patched up in this place on the 1st inst., though not in a very creditable manner on the part of th Spanish residents of this place.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Are you aware that in your reference to the mismanagement of the affairs of one company, in your editorial of this morning, you were giving the uneveloped history of several other " large and respectable corporations" in our midst ? At the same time you have but too plainly indicated the principal, if not the sole cause, and the most hopeful remedy:

If the threats of the ambitions and clever negro who rules over the destinies of Hayti are of any significance, the period approaches when the people of St. Domingo may expect to be attacked by the troops of SOULOUQUE.

ORCHARD SCHOALS.--The Quarantine Commissioners, it may be recollected, announced a few weeks ago that Orchard Shoals had been definitively selected as the site of the New Quarantine, and advertised for proposals to construct an island five acres in extent in that portion of the Lower Bay.

Mr. SLIDELL of Louisiana wants thirty millions of pocket money for Mr. BUCHANAN, to enable that venerable statesman and Executive to carry out his " great designs" upon the monarchy of Castile. Very good ! but before we pay over the said considerable sum, suppose we settle the equally great Mount Vernon question !

In the existing state of the Federal finances, something must clearly be done at once to raise the national income, at least if Mr. BUCHANAN has no intention of reducing the expenditure. Specific duties have, so far as this object is concerned, one unquestionable advantage, and that is, they protect the Treasury from the frauds of importers and their agents.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your correspondent " Verax," advocates a repeal of the old law, which closed the mouths of the persons best informed, as to matters in controversy in our Courts-the parties themselves. Permit a short review of his argument. 1. He states that tile " law was regarded by many, at the time of its passage, as a startling if not dangerous innovation." Answer:

VALUABLE CONTRIBUTION TO A MEDICAL COLLEGE.--We understand that Dr. THOMAS M. MUTTER, emeritus Professor of Surgery in the Jefferson Medical College, has presented to the " College of Physicians of Philadelphia," the extensive and valuable collection of pathological specimens, used by him in illustrating his lectures while engaged in teaching the principles and practice of Surgery.

SEVERAL PILOTS AND SEAMEN SEVERELY FROSTBITTEN. Yesterday there were twelve pilot-boats wind-bound in the Harbor waiting for an opportunity to get outside. Several of these pilots, who were exposed to the severe weather of Sunday and Monday last, state that they never suffered so much in so short time since they have been engaged in the business.

EXCLUSIVENESS OF GOOD PEOPLE.--We think we scarcely exaggerate the fact when we say that the chief drawback to existence, in the eyes of many very good persons, is the necessity of having to do with persons not quite so good as they are. We commend to all who may be thus afflicted some very sound and wholesome doctrine administered by Mr. BEECHER in an article which we copy in another column.

CITY INTELLIGENCE. SIMTING AND CURLING AT THE GENTRAL PARK. --The pond at the Central Park was covered with steel-snod sportsmen all day yesterday. The ice in the morning was in good order but not in excellent condition. All the night before twenty laborers and several policemen were busily engaged in flooding the Pond with water.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Permit me to call your attention to a piece of Vandalism, which is at present being perpetrated in this City. The lamentable condition and neglect of our Public Squares is well known to every New-Yorker. The Battery, the Park, and Tompkins-square, give evidence of the conscientious care. the abilities, the taste. and the intelligence of the persons intrusted with their control and superintendence.
