Additional advices from Mexico of the 9th inst., state that JUAREZ had refused to listen to the Commissioners from ROBLES. ZULOAGA, before his fall, had approved the propositions from France and England for a settlement of the Spanish question, and the Spanish authorities had expressed their satisfaction.

DURELL.--In this City, on Friday, Jan. 14, Miss JOSEPHINE DURELL. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from No. 41 7th-st., on Sunday, 16th at 3 o'clock P. M. VREELAND.--In this City, on Friday, Jan. 14, EMMA FRANCES, youngest daughter of John C. and Jane E. Vreeland, aged 7 months and 11 days.

" Canada-cold" has been making itself severely felt. Indeed, last Sunday was the coldest day we have experienced for a quarter of a century. The thermometer here was 30[degree] below zero in the night, between Sunday and Monday. At in fact, Kingston it was 29 1/2[Degrees] below. At Hamilton it was 29[degree] below.

PLATFORM OF THE KENTUCKY DEMOCRACY.-The Democratic State Convention of Kentucky adopted the following resolutions: 1. That the resolutions passed by the Democratic National Convention at Cincinnati in June, 1856, and accepted by JAMES BUCHANAN, the nominee of that Convention for the Presidency, contain a true exposition of Democratic faith, and that we prescribe no test of political orthodoxy not contained therein.

The bill introduced in the Senate, on Tuesday, by Mr. DARLING, aims at a much needed reform. It has long been a subject of complaint that the State tax bore unequally upon the counties, owing to different modes of value ation practiced in the assessment, by which the amount levied and paid was out of proportion to the comparative amount of taxable property.

SKETCHES OF ANCIENT ASTRONOMERS-HISTORY OF THE DISCOVERY OF THE LAWS OF MOTION AND GRAVITATION. Last evening the Acadamy of Music was crowded from the parquette to the third tier to listen to the first lecture in the course now being given by Prof.MITCHEL O.CINCINATTI, in aid of a fund for the establishment of an Observatory in Central Park.

THE WEATHER, THE HARBOR, AND THE FOG.-It has been reported that Prof. MAURY lately predicted that there would not be two consecutive days of fine weather during the month of January. However this may be, it is quite certain that the weather thus far is likely to verify the prediction--if it were made.

The steamship Isabel has arrived off Tybee, with Havana dates of the 10th. Sngars were quiet, the holidays not having ended. Freights and Exchange were unaltered. The Slave-trade was active in Cuba; nearly two thousand Africans are reported to have been landed. There had been extensive smuggling of lard under the guise of potatoes, and an order would be issued soon requiring cargoes to be certified by the Spanish Consuls at their port of departure.

A BORDER RUFFIAN COMING TO THE CONFESSIONAL.--We publish, in another column , a letter from Governors WALKER and STANTON, concerning the fraudulent character of the Kansas election of 1857, which deserves general attention. The returns of that election in Oxford County, it will be remembered, were rejected by Governor WALKER, on account of their gross and palpable falsehood, as well as of their lack of legal forms.

SPEECHES, ADDRESSES, ITALIAN EJECTED. The Allgemeine Arbeiter Bund, an Association of European political refugees and Socialists, assembled at their head-quarters, the Steuben House, in the Bowery, last evening, and thence proceeded to the Metropolitan Rooms, in Hester-street, where a meeting for "Liberty, Egality, and Fraternity," at which a" Manifestation of the Solidarityof the Nations" had been announced, was held.

THE CITY INSPECTORSHIP--A SHARP GAME.-Mr. MORTON published a card in the TIMES the other day denying that any understanding had been had with the Aldermen by which the Mayor's nominee for City Inspector was to be rejected, and he himself kept in office.

To the Honorable the Board of Supervisors: GENTLEMAN: The undersigned Commissioners of the New City Hall, appointed in accordance with the act passed April 17, 1858, having entered on their duties, beg leave to present to your honorable body the following report:

Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. WASHINGTON, Friday, Jan. 14. A portion of next week will be set apart for the consideration of territorial business. Rumors are current here to-day of a serious misunderstanding yesterday among some members of the Cabinet, which may lead to the withdrawal of Mr. TOUCKY, growing out of the contract for the machinery of sloop-of-war No. 2. at Philadelphia.

The promised Projet of Postmaster-General BROWN is forthcoming, and we have to confess our disappointment. It is not wholly a mass of incongruities; not wholly without glimmerings of that sound judgment which so seldom makes its way within the General Postoffice.

CHESEBRO'--GAUTIER.--In this City, on Monday, Dec. 27th by the Rev. Calvin Walcott. ALBERT CHESRRO'. Dr to CAROLEEN V., youngest daughter of Samuel p. Gautier, Esq., all of this City. WEAVER--MAGUIRE.--In this City, on Sunday , Jan 9 by the Rev. Mr. Smith, Pastor of the Presbyterian Church, corner of Brcome and Ridge ste., Doctor F. WEAVER TO MISE. H. V. MAGUIRE, both of this City.

Mr. FITZPATRICK, of Alabama, presented a memorial for a line of mail steamers from New-Orleans and Mobile to various ports in the Gulf of Mexico. Referred. Mr. HUNTER, of Virginia, called for the yeas and nays on the resolution to pay $150 for the funeral expenses, and a quarter's salary, of MORTON, the deceased furnace-keeper,and it was carried 33 against 17.

HORRIBLE MURDER--THE MURDERER CAUGHT IN THE ACT.--A dreadful murder was perpetrated at Hamilton, Canada, Jan. 8. The victim was a woman named ELIZA WELSH, said to belong to Toronto, and the murderer is a man named JOHN MEAGHAM, or MITCHELL, who passed as her husband. The murderer has lately been employed in the vicinity of Toronto in the capacity of a railway laborer.

EXTENSIVE OPERATIONS ON THE FREMONT MINES IN BEAR VALLEY.--The Mariposa (California) Gazette has the following: "On the 30th of November Sheriff CHIPPEN executed the writ of restitution, some time since issue, by placing the whole of the Josephine Vein, Bear Valley, in the possession of Col. FREMONT. No opposition what ever was made.

The Presidential movements in Virginia, though conducted with comparative privacy, are nevertheless active and energetic. The friends of the rival aspirants are working strenuously to secure for their respective favorites the vote of Virginia in the Charleston Convention.

BILLS REPORTED FAVORABLY. To provide for the adjustment of the claims of the state against the Bank of Orleans. To incorporate the German Savings Bank, NewYork. To amend the Usury laws. BILLS INTRODUCED. By Mr. MATHER, to repeal the Metropolitan Police act.

MINERAL WEALTH OF THE CALIFORNIA COAST RANGE.--The Santa Cruz (Cal.) Sentinel remarks that the coast range of mountains, extending through the counties of Santa Clara and Monterey, and bounding the western line of the Tulare Valley, is little known to the geologist, mineralogist and paleontologist. This range contains an abundance of minerals. The quicksilver mines of New-Almaden and New-Idra may be mentioned.

The Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER lectured on Thursday night in the Cooper Institute, before a large and admiring assemblage of the members and friends of the Young Men's Christian Association of this City. The subject he selected for his address was "The Burdens of Society." In its treatment, he displayed many of those quaint felicities which form the principal attraction of his style.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You are aware that our immense "Democratic" State Convention has to-day nominated BE RIAH MAGOFFIN for Governor, and Hon. LYNN BOYD for Lieutenant-Governor. This is a pretty strong Democratic ticket. They are both reputed to be sharp politicians and zealous partisans, and, if elected next August, will perform their duties to their State and their party with great acceptance to their admirers and followers.

ARRIVAL OF THE ONLY SURVIVOR AT BOSTON. The bark Azor, Capt. BURKE, from Fayal, arrived at Boston on Tuesday, bringing 45 "Consul's men,' or shipwrecked seamen, who had been collected at that island, Among these is the alleged only survivor of the ship Margaret Tyson, of New-York--"WILLIAM KENNEDY."

A new style of wager was decided during the recent "cold snap" at Southington, Conn. A young man named Ransom Gladding, made a bet that he would walk from 9 o'clock till sunrise the next morning in the open air without an overcoat. An oblong space was staked out 60 by 24 feet, covering the railroad track, and inclosed by a rope.

Mr. B. R. CURTIS, one of the counsel for Lieut. MARIN, appeared before the Judge of Probate to-day and asked for a postponement of the hearing, on account of the engagements of RUFUS CHOATE, his colleague in the case. He also gave notice that the jurisdiction of the Court in the matter would be contested, on the ground that Mr. THORNDIKE was not an inhabitant of Massachusetts.

Mr. CHRISTIE, of Richmond County, tills morning introduced into the Assembly his Quarantine bill. As its provisions are exceedingly important to all your citizens, to Staten Island, Long Island, NewJersey, and the whole mercantile community, I have prepared an abstract of its several sections:

THE CUMBERLAND COAL COMPANY, AND CORPORATIONS IN GENERAL.--We had occasion a few days ago, (as indeed we might have occasion every day in the year.) to utter some home truths in regard to the management by our great commercial corporations of the interests confided to their keeping.

This has been a very dreary day in the market. The run of custom for the leading commodities has been decidedly unsatisfactory to dealers, and in no department has there been less activity than in the meat line. Most kinds have been freely offered at uniform quotations.

THE WATER WORKS.--The water from the Water-Works is being introduced gradually into private dwellings throughout the City. The pipes have been cleaned and the water is clear and pure. Two donkey engines are constantly in motion forcing the water from the pump well into the Reservoir at Ridgewood.

A special messenger from Governor KEDARY to Governor STEWART, arrived at Jefferson City, yesterday. He reports that MONTOOMERY is fortifying himself near the Missouri line ; that United States troops have been sent to that region, and that volunteers are being raised as rapidly as possible. Six hundred muskets passed through Jefferson City, on Wednesday, for Kansas.

The Emperor of the French possesses tile rare talent of doing with eclat everything he undertakes, and of undertaking nothing which will most make a noise in the world. The most astute of politicians and the most skillful of tricksters, he is at once the Machiavelli and the Abracadabra of the century.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your readers who have means and the desire to give to the poor, are often at a loss where to bestow their charity to best effect. We beg to call the attention of such to the sad condition of the poor laboring people near Fortieth and Forty-second streets and Second-avenue.

The Commissioner of the General Lant Office has decided that in all cases where lands belonging to the United States have been regularly surveyed and sold--the proprietorship of the Government therein entirely ceasing--it is not incumbent on the Government to cause a re-survey-to be made, even if the lines, corners, , making the original survey shall become obliterated.

EAARLY IN THE SESSION.--Mr. GODARD offered a resolution in the Assembly yesterday, that the Legislature adjourn, on the 15th March, sine die. This is an early movement. There are some honorable gentlemen whose patriotism, every session, takes the form of a resolution similar to that offered by Mr. GODARD.

THE CANALS.--There are improvements, costing very little, which are capable of materially increasing tile capacity of the canals for business. One of these is specified in a resolution introduced yesterday by Mr. PROSSER, Chairman of the Canal Committee in the Senate. It is simply to add to tile length of tile locks, by removing the rear gates back and extending the side walls forty feet.

It was private calendar day in Congress yesterday. In the Senate, however, the private bills were laid aside by a vote of 34 against 32, to give place to the Pacific Railroad bill, which was the special order. Mr. BIGLER'S amendment, to locate the road between the 37th and 43d parallels of latitude, was voted down, 25 to 19.

SHALL PARTIES BE WITNESSES ?--The bill to repeal tile act of 1857, authorizing parties to be witnesses in their own behalf, was favorably reported in the Assembly yesterday. Two correspondents of this paper have recently expressed opposite opinions as to the merits of the law proposed to be repealed.

In steamship Florida, for Savannan, - Mrs. A. Hoffman, Miss J.N. Hoffman, Master W. E. Hoffman, capt. Griffing, Mrs. Armstrong, Miss E. Smith, H. Atrill, JDO, A. Hardenbergh, Miss Wyeth. Mrs. A. A. Steam fire-engines were first put in use at a fire in Boston on the 12th January. A portion of the granite warehouse of the Chico see Manufacturing Company. Nos. 54 and 56 Federal street was destroyed., but the flames were checked by the engine Eclipse.

The mails by the Niagara, which reached this City at a late hour on Saturday night, bring important additions to the summary received by telegraph from Halifax. We extend the details by the addition of various interesting particulars, embracing extracts from the European journals touching American and general topics.

Mr. SCOTT introduced a bill to amend the Revised Statutes relative to heirs and devisees, andrelative to the proceedings to prevent the commission of crime. By Mr. SPINOLA, to incorporate the Long Island Steamboat Company, with a capital of $2,000,000.

The mails by the Niagara, at Boston, reached this city on Saturday night. On Saturday afternoon the screw-steamship Jura, Capt. MOODY, also of the Cunard Line, arrived at this port. The dates by both arrivals were to Jan.1, and a synopsis of the news has been received from Halifax by telegraph.

The seventh annual business meeting of our National Agricultural Society opened at the rooms in the Smithsonian Institution at 11 o'clock this morning. The President, Gen. TENCH TILGHMAN, in the chair. Ex-President WILDER occupied a place at the President's right, and Senator HALE, of New-Hampshire, the one on the left.

The Charleston papers contain Key West advices to the 10th, received by the Isabel. The United States steamer Metacomet arrived on the 26th ult., with machinery damaged and short of coal. The brig Wingold, from Minatitian bound to NewYork, was in port. The crew had been sick. but were convalescent.

This steamer left Norfolk on the route for Paraguay on the 5th of October. and after a passage of 11 days arrived at Bridgetown, Barbadoes. She remained in that port seven days for the purpose of coaling ship, and left on the 23d of October, and after being at sea 14 days we run short of coal, and put into Ceara to obtain a supply on the 6th at November.

The agitation for a new reform in the representation of Great Britain appears to be rapidly degenerating into an impractical and unwholesome issue of personalities between Mr. BRIGHT, as the leader of the Radicals, and the London Times as the organ of existing order.

When the Doge of Venice espoused the Adriatic, the consent of the bride was taken for granted--no questions were asked; and it is as fair to presume that if the Adriatic had not liked the match, she would have thrown the Venetian ring contemptuously on shore again. No such slight, we believe, was ever put upon the great mediaeval Republic.

THE ANTI-SLAVERY AGITATION IN ENGLAND. -Our London correspondent states that the Palmerston party has revived the Anti-Slavery crusade, as a means of exciting anew popular prejudice against America and thus checking the agitation in favor of the ballot and the extension of suffrage.

A NEW SORT OF CORPORATIONS.--On Saturday a bill was introduced in the Assembly authorising the formation of companies for the apprehension of horse-thieves. The particular class of rogues aimed at is exceedingly unpopular in the rural districts. Hence, doubtless, a law of that kind is deemed necessary.

?? THE LADY KILLED BY A HARLEM RAILROAD TRAIN --VERDICT OF CENSURE.--Coroner O'KEEFE on Saturday held an inquest on the body of Mrs. SYLVIA KINE, Who was run over on Friday by a Harlem Railroad train at 128th-street, and instantly killed. Several witnesses were examined, but their evidence was very contradictory-the opposing statements having reference mainly to the rate of speed at which the train was going when the accident occurred.

Lovely weather, Spring-like, but no sun; a fine, gentle rain, sleighs in the streets, but no visible snow; rivers running down State-street, and almost a quorum of the members running down the River or off on the Central Road. Add together into one vocal aggregate the coughs of the two houses and you would hear something like thunder.

The ingratitude of Princes is proverbial, but there are other Powers upon whom it is equally unsafe to waste the treasure of an unlimited devotion. The people do not always manifest even that cynical form of gratitude known as "a lively sense of favors to come," in dealing with those who have bestowed themselves upon the public service; nor is the Press itself always faithful to its champions.
The Philadelphia, from Havana, on Saturday evening, brings us files of Mexican papers, with dates from Vera Cruz to Dec. 30, and from the City of Mexico, to Dec. 27.

QUESTION OF TIIE CANADIAN SEAT OF GOVERNMENT SETTLED,--A telegram from Toronto states that a report is current to the effect that the Canadian Government has received dispatches from England, containing a command that the Queen's award of Ottawa, as the future Capital, should be carried out.

The grand Chess-match between Alessrs. MORPHY and ANDERSSEN closed on Tuesday in favor of the American. The game stood--MORPHY, 7 ; ANDERSSEN, 2; drawn, 2. The utmost courtesy and good feeling reined during the whole course of the match, and nothing occurred between the contestants to mar the good opinion each had formed of the other before commencing the same.

Our dates from Porto Rico are to Dec. 20. The Gaceta Oficial, of the 14th December, announces that the Government is taking active measures to cover the dificiencies of the revenue : and to that end had summoned a junta to consult upon the best means of attaining that end.

PECK-SLIP FERRY.--A large and enthusiastic meeting was held at the Odeon in the Eastern District, Saturday evening, to devise some measures to prevent the Peck-slip Ferry from being abandoned entirely, or falling into the hands of parties inimical to the general interests of that section of Brooklyn.

The Democratic Senators held a prolonged caucus yesterday relative to SLIDELL'S bill to place 30,000,000 at the disposal of the President, to negotiate for te purchase of Cuba. It is understood that the discussion was animated, and the views of the different speakers widely diverse. They adjourned without coming to any conclusion.

The United States Mail steamship Philadelphia, GUSTAVES HARRISON. ESQ., commanding, left New-Orleans Jan. 5, for New-York, viii Havanna, at which port she arrived on the morning of the 8th, and sailed on the 9th for this port, which she reached on Saturday afternoon.

A Demand for the Liberty of the Press in France-A Cournageous Article. From the Paris Presse. The recent trial of M. DE MONTALEMBERT, in whatever light it may be regarded, may be considered as a symptom and an indication of a situation which has already existed some years, and of which we cannot foresee the duration.

A deliberate and unprovoked murder was committed in the Sixth Ward at an early hour yesterday morning. The Victim was RICHARD OWENS, a master stevedore of worth and respectability, who did business in this City, and resided in Brooklyn.

The schooner North Wind, Capt. HIGGINS, from Gonaives, Jan. 15, is ashore below. Capt. HIGGINS reports that a revolution broke out in Hayti, Dec. 22, between the Haytien Government and a party of Republicans headed by General GEFFARD, one of the Haytien Generals. He took the City of Gonaires, and was proclimed Piesiaent. He entered the city with only four men.

A RAILROAD SEIZED BY ITS EMPLOYES.-The Chicago herald says the Chicago and Alton Railroad Property has been seized by the employes of the company. The men employed south of Bloomington struck on Friday for wages, and the panic extended north to Chicago, Although the receipts of this road have been from $60,000 to $125,000 per month. the mechanies have not been paid for nearly six months.

The Senate is not in session. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. WASHINGTON, Saturday, Jan. 15. Mr. FOSTER, of Maine, asked, but failed to receive consent, to introduce a bill authorizing the Postmaster-General to contract to carry the mails between Banger and Halifax by railroad.

A MYSTERY SATISIFACTORILY SOLVED.--Among the miscellaneous freight landed on Saturday morn ing at the Hudson River Railroad Depot was an oblong box from Rhinebeck, which was labeled dried apples. Some of the Railroad employes thought the box rather heavy, and, suspecting something wrong, had it opened, When they discovered that it contained a coffin, carefully packed in sawdust.

At the last session of the Legislature of this State an act was passed which ought to have been passed fifty years ago, allowing parties in causes to be examined as witnesses on the trial. It was passed in compliance with the general desire of the bench, the bar, and the public.

Rt. Rev. Dr. O'CONNOR, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Pittsburg, preached yesterday in St. Andrew's Church. Duane-street, of which Rev. Mr. CURREN is pastor. The density of the crowd was almost suffocating. A solemn high mass, coram episcope, was celebrated. The singing of the celebrant and the music of the choir, though these are made matters of importance in nearly all Catholic Churches, were on this occasion unusually excellent.

The past two weeks Southern Kansas has been in a state of revolt and human life is sacrificed again to the Moloch of party frenzy. I have been tracing the web of " current reports" the last few days in regard to the material facts in these lower counties that have caused this new outbreak of threatening revolution.

Horatio F. Avcrill, of New-York, and Dennis F Murphey, of Philadelphia, were admitted as counselors. No. 32.--The Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad Commany vs. Philip Quigley.--Error to the Circuit Court of Maryland. Justice CAMPBELL delivered the opinion of the Court, reversing the judgment, with costs, and remanding the cause, with direction to award veuire facias de novo.

In Steamship James Adger, from Charleston--R. F. Rockwell, Crawford Williams, A. H. Abraham, Z. L, Fustner. G. P. Coggshall. J. W. Hinchley, A. H. Chisolm, G. W. E. Wood. Mrs. Augusta Weggle, J. R. Mathews, W. W. Seman, Mrs. Satterly and child. D. L. Kane and lady, A. B. Huntley, Martin Cheeney, Mrs. J. A. Brown, Mrs. Storer. F. Wood,, W. J. Crump. A. P. Smith, J. A.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: How to relieve Broadway is quite an important question to the occupants of the middle and lower parts of our City, and unless it can be done the wholesale business must move above Canal-street, as it is impossible to do any more business with the present facilities, and the trouble is increasing.

The death of Mr. HARRIS, of Illinois, was announced in Congress yesterday, and, consequently, very little public business was done. In the Senate, previous to the eulogies on such occasions, Mr. SEWARD offered a resolution, which was adopted, calling on the Secretary of the Treasury for information relative to the palm-oil trade on the Coast of Africa.

Our diplomatic service is not precisely the strongest point of our public organization. The Legations of the United States in foreign parts are commonly, and not unjustly, regarded less as the outposts of the active political army than as the Chelsea Hospital or Hotel des Invalides of public men.
A passenger in the schooner North Wind, at this port, furnishes interesting details of the new movement in Hayti. For some time it has been supposed at Gonaives that a political rising was intended.
The announcement of a lecture on Meteorology, by Professor HENEY, drew together this morning an unusually large number of persons, many of whom were members of Congress, and some ladies.

The only business of interest done was the introduction of a joint resolution requiring our Representatives in Congress to oppose. an increase of the rates of postage. The bill to punish prize fighting was passed.

The Boston Trancller says: "The important question of jurisdiction has been raised by the counsel opposed to the will of the late AUGUSTUS THORNDIKE. The point that he was not a CITIZEN OF BOSTON IN 1837 HAS BEEN judicially SETTLED, AS WILL BE FOUND BY REFERENCE to the first volume of METOALE'S Report, PP. 242 to 230.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN. INCREASING THE TAX LEVY. The lobby was crowded with spectators last evening, for it was expected that there would be a further debate with regard to the City Inspectorship. That subject, however, was not considered, but to-day it will be before the Committee to which the nomination of the Mayor was referred, which meets at 12 M.

LEAD-MINING AT GALENA-A very large number of men are now at work in mining throughout the Lead Region. From the neighborhood of all the different diggings we hear much the same report. The most of the miners are at work in old digging this winter, and perhaps there is no more prospecting than in common seasons.

To the Editor of the States: In a communication of all 12th inst., addressed to the editor of all Union by the Hon. JOHN SLIDELL, he publishes my name as the person referred to by him in his communication of the 18th of December, in which he says:

The New-Mexican mail of the 27th ult., reached Independence yesterday. It was packed on mules the most of the way, in consequence of bad roads. The New-Mexican Legislature elected AUGUSTUS DEMERELL Public Printer vice S. M. MOST. Nothing had been heard of the missing Neosho Mail party.

After all we are not so bad as we seem here in this great glittering, selfish, sharp-witted Gotham. The world, indeed, is too much with us, and steals away the bloom and freshness of too many hearts; the doubting fiend whose fatal speed Mrs. KEMBLE, in one of her sweetest poems, has so feelingly deplored, o'ertakes too soon the youth of many a generous spirit:

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A new play is always an interesting event at this establishment. It gathers together the loose fragments of the literary world as if by natural laws, and insures an audience at once interesting and critical.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Glancing over the TIMES of yesterday, I noticed an article upon the weather in New-York City and vicinities. You call it cold, thermometer ranging from Zero to 10[degree] below. Pooh! it puts us in a perspiration to conceive it. Come up here where it freezes.

A correspondent of the Austin (Texas) Intelligencer, writing from Lampassas Spring, ways: "Williams" company of rangers had a fight with the Indians, about twenty-five or thirty miles from this Place, on the water of the Cow House creek killed two and severely wounded two other that they did not get.

MUREN.--In Brooklyn, on Sunday morning, Jan. 16, JENNET LAING, widow of the late Parker Maren, aged 64 years. Her friends, and those of her family, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Wednesday afternoon. at 3 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 102 West Warren-st., Brooklyn.

In the Senate, to-day, the acts incorporating the Mercantile Library Association and to prevent and punish prize-fighting had their third reading. Senator PATTERSON offered joint resolutions amendatory of the Stale Constitution with reference to County Judges and Surrogates in the rural parts of the State.

In the ordinary walks of commerce it is common for the party who desires to become the purchaser of a rare or costly article, to observe a certain prudence in approaching the holder thereof. If he takes any pains at all in carrying out his design, it is rather with the object of concealing than of publishing his anxiety to buy.

SIR:--I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of the following resolution, adopted by tile Senate on the 22d December last: Resolved. That the Postmaster-General be directed to report to the Senate such changes in the laws regulating postages and the Post-Office Department as, in his opinion, could make that a self-sustaining department.

By the bark Wilhelmine, Captain DILLINGHAM we have Buenos Ayres papers to the 6th of November. The Commercial Times of that date gives the following amusing account of the "revolutionary movement," a brief reference to which has already ap peared in our columns:
The following news was telegraphed to us on Sunday night, and appeared in Monday's paper, but in so imperfect a shape that we deem its republication essential. We copy from the Boston Herald:

The Senate Chamber was crowded to excess to hear Mr. DOUGLAS pronounce a eulogy on Mr. HARRIS, of Illinois. Mr. SEWARD, of New York, presented the credentials of Mr. WILSON, reflected from Massachusetts, and also the following resolution, which was adopted:

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--A NEW GAS CONTRACT--SINKING FUND REPORT--IMPORTANT MEETING. A regular meeting of the Board of Alderman was held last evening, President KALDFLEISCN in the Chair. The first business under consideration was the gas contract. After considerable discussion the majority reports of the Gas Committee was adopted.

Professor Max Muller, Fellow of All Souls College, Oxford, has been elected a Corresponding Member of the Institute of France. Miss Thompson, of Glasgow, has made a successful debut at the French Opera, Paris, in the role of Mathilde in "William Tell."

By the arrival of the brig T. M. Mayhew, from Berinuda, we have files of the Royal Gazette to Jan. 4. They contain no news of interest. The President's Message had reached the Island, and excited the same surprise as elsewhere. The Gazette in reviewing the history of the year thus refers to the chronicle of Bermuda:

THE OWNERS OF THE WASHINGTON PAY THE EXPENSE. The two English convicts--giving their names as HENRY RICHARDS and WILLIAM SMITH--who were landed here a few days since from the ship Washington, have been compelled to take their journey across the water over again.

The steam-frigate Brooklyn went into Commission yesterday. The officers have all reported, and the crew is ready to be sent on board from the North Carolina. The sloop St. Louis is ordered to Aspinwall to await orders from the Flag-officer of the Squadron. The following is a list of her officers:

THE CITY INSPECTORSHIP.--The probabilities in relation to the length of time Mr. MORTON will manage to retain the office of City Inspector; whether the Board of Aldermen will act upon the Mayor's nomination of Dr. FOSTER during the present session; whether the Mayor will be forced to withdraw the Doctor, and send in another name;

Never, perhaps, has an American Presidential Message drawn from the French Press so many columns of criticism as the late Message of Mr. BUCHANAN, and never certainly was the Press more unanimous in its condemnation. At the moment of departure of the last mail I thought that the discussion had closed, but it had only commenced.

The House Special Committee on the Pacific Railroad this morning voted down all propositions looking to its construction, leaving, to be acted upon by the Committee, only Mr. STEVENSON'S resolution, "that it is impolitic to embark in the construction of any road at this time."

The Tampa Peninsular of the 1st instant, says that Mr. Kilburn, who arrived at that place the day previous, states that the celebrated Seminole Indian Chief Sam Jones, is dead, and that Tiger Tail has been appointed in his stead. The latter expresses a desire to remain in Florida, and is willing to comply with anything the Government may require of him, but asserts that, unless compelled, he will not go West.

Nothing particularly new or startling was developed yesterday relative to the Sixth Ward murder. Mr. DECKER, the proprietor of No. 21 Elm-street, lies at the Hospital, in an exceedingly critical slate, only the slightest hope being entertained of his recovery.

The owners of the above ship--Capt. TYSON, and Messrs. BOYD and HINCKEN--have gathered such facts as it was possible to draw out of the young man KENNEDY concerning her loss and have prepared the customary "Protest" upon the strength of these statements on which to found their claim for insurance.

OVER $30,000 LOSS--EXPERIMENT WITH THE STEAM FIRE-ENGINE. About 10 1/2 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered in one of the upper floors of the large six-story brick building, No. 68 Duane-street, occupied by different persons as manufactories. In a few minutes after the fire was discovered the whole upper portion of the building was wrapped in flames.

THE SLAVE-TRADE DENOUNCED BY A SOUTHERN CHURCH.--One of the South Carolina Churches has held a public meeting, and passed resolutions denunciatory of the importation of the Wanderer's slaves, and speaking as follows of the Slave-trade: "That we have heard with deep regret that a number of these native Africans are in the midst of us.

S., President of the Royal Geographical Society of London, and DirectorGeneral of the Geological Survey of Great Britain and Ireland, in reply to a communication from Mr. SIDNEY KOPMAN, Corresponding Secretary, intimating to him his election as honorary member of the Kane Monument Association:

MY DEAR SIR: It has given me much pleasure to receive the intelligence of your election to the House of Representatives of Indiana, and to be assured of your earnest purpose to throw the weight of your influence in favor of some plan by which more efficient safeguards and checks may be placed around the Treasury and the State Agency and the financial affairs of our State put upon a more secure footing:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There was very little opportunity to give, at any length,to the Chrislian Association of Young Men, at their tea party. my views in respect to what I regard a great want in this City.
If suffering long be in any sense an equivalent for long-suffering, that Christian grace must be fairly predicated of the people of this City.

SPEECH OF HIRAM KETCHUM--A NEW ORGANIZATION PROPOSED-ITS PLATFORM EXPLAINED. The Whig General Committee met at THORP'S, corner of Eighth-strect and Broadway, last evening. The meeting was not large, in consequence, it was stated, of some informality of calling it. Mr. E. H. BROWN, Vice-President,called the meeting to order,

At present quiet reigns in our city. Politics are at a stand still-that is, so far as they are vie wed upon the surface, but underneath, the different leaders, aspirants, cliques and factions are industriously opereating to forward their own separate ends. In the Democratic Party, now sorely disorganized, there is the utmost variety of opinion as to who shall be the fortunate, or unfortunate nominee, of the Charleston Convention.

BRILLIANT ASSEMBLAGE. There are few things more delightful, as Mr. Micawber says of a deviled turkey's leg, than an artist's reception. It is one of the institutions that have sprung up quite promiscuously and naturally within the past three or tour years, and they have been productive of a vast deal of benefit both to Society and Art. There are two of these institutions.

ESCAPE OF LOPARANO-FIFTEEN THOUSAND AS A BRIBE-SENORS MARCO AND BLANCO. A special correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat, writing from Vera Cruz, Dec. 28, gives what professes to be an elucidation of the affair of Mr. FORSYTH and his hidden ingots-a deposit, it will be remembered, that was found concealed in his lodgings near the City of Mexico after his departure, and which has caused considerable speculation.

THE RUSSIAN RAILWAY STORY SET RIGHT.-The National Intelligencer has the following: "A story appeared several weeks ago in some of our newspapers, copied, we believe, from an English or French paper, alleging a great fraud in the official measurement of the railway from St. Petersburg to Moscow, and a consequent over-payment to the American contractors of some scores of thousands ot dollars.

Loss of the British Bark Franklin. THE CAPTAIN'S WIFE AND CHILD DROWNED--PARTICULARS OF THE DISASTER. The packet-ship Manhattan, Captain DIXON, arrived at this port on Monday, bringing the captain, officers and crew of the British bark Franklin, which became water-logged on the passage from Persacola to Queenstown.

The Coroner's Inquest in the case of the Sixth Ward murder was closed yesterday. The Ward Station-house where the inquest was conducted was, as on the previous day, thronged with curious and anxious spectators. Several witnesses were examined, and a majority of them told about the same story regarding the shooting that the witnesses previously examined did.

The anniversary of WEBSTER'S birthday was celebrated this evening by a banquet at the Revere House, and was presided over by the Hon. CALEB CUSHING. Speeches were made by the President, the lion. RUFUS CHOATE, Ex-Governor GARDNER, Professor FELTON, B. F. HALLETT, the Hon. Mr. SEYMOUR, of England, Lord CAVENDISH, and others.

The proprietors of the New-York Shipping and Commercial List have provided us with an advance copy of their annual statement of the Coffee trade of the United States, exclusive of California and Oregon, for the year ending Dec. 31, 1858. From this statement we learn " that the receipts into the port of New-York from all directions, foreign and coastwise, for the year ending Dec. 31,

CELEBRATION OF THE OBERLIN RESCUE AFFAIR.--At Oberlin, Ohio, on the 11th of January, a festival was held to celebrate the affair of the rescue of fugitives from Slavery. The call was signed by "thirty-seven citizens, indicted by the Grand Jury of the United States District Court of Northern Ohio, under the Fugitive Slave act, for tile crime of a conscientious and faithful observance of the higher law of the Golden Rule."

A PROPOSAL FOR A MUTUAL COUNCIL REJECTED. It will be remembered that about a year since twenty of the members of the Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S Church, dissatisfied with tile manner in which he continued to preach on the subject of Slavery, asked for letters of dismission from the Church. Letters were

AMERICAN MEN-OF-WAR--A FIRE AT RIO--MORE RIOTS-MARKETS, ETC. Our files of Rio papers extend to Nov. 23, bringing dates from Para to Nov. 4, from Maranham to Nov. 7, and Pernambuco to Nov. 13. There is no political news at Rio.

YIELD OF COPPER IN MICHIGAN FOR 1858.-The Ontonagon Miner gives some figures relative to the shipment of copper from the Upper Peninsula for the season of 1858. We republish them, as going to show that the product has been very large, notwithstanding the hard times and the scarcity of money.
It appears to me that the exasperation of feeling, which was so evident some months since among our people against the Austrians, and especially against the English, is very far from having subsided.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: We find a native population in New-Mexico, Arizona, Sonora, Chihuahua, and throughout all Mexico, numbering some eight millions, peculiarly Well fitted to develop the great resources of the country. The old Spanish monarchy and the rule of the Jesuits, notwithstanding the abuses with

SHARP PRACTICE.--For some years past the amount of stationery disposed of in the various departments under the City Government has been a subject of criticism, but nothing definitely was done about it until quite recently, when proposals were received for " stationery, books and printing."

New-Orlcans papers of Wednesday last are to hand. In addition to the news brought by the Tennessee. heretofore published, it appears that on the 31st of December the junta popular in the city of Mexico, formed of a great majority of the Conservatives and the clergy, established a programme governmental, which proclaims the inviolability of corporation property, and protests against the alienation or mortgage of national territory.

The statement was erroneous that the Supreme Court yesterday decided that an action for libel could not be maintained against a corporation. The judgement in the case reported was reserved, but upon other grounds. Upon the important point above stated, the Court decided that when a corporation, as such, in the publication of its business, perpetrated a libel, it is responsible.

THE LAW OF EXPRESS COMPANIES.--The Buffalo Republic publishes a card from the Express Company of LIVIGSTON, FARGO Co., explanatory of the recent suit against them, correcting misstatements. They say: "In the month of August, 1852, this Company undertook to forward from this city to Detroit a Package said to contain $4,600 in Michigan State bonds.

The funeral services in commemmoration of the services of thirteen Philadelphians, who perished of yellow fever at Norfolk and Portsmouth, while rendering assistance as physicians and nurses, were held this morning at St. Stephen's Church. After the services by Dr. DUCACIIET, the remains were removed to Laurel Hill for reinterment, under the charge of THOMAS WEBSTER, Jr., Trustee of the Philadelphia Committee of Relief.

We gather from the Boston papers further particulars of the revolution in Hayti, reported yesterday by telegraph. It appears that the leader of the revolutionists, General FABRE GZFFRARD, was formerly Governor of Jacmel, and for several years has been viewed with jealousy by the Emperor SOULOUQUE, who has latterly retaomed him near its person at Portau-Prince.

The overland mail with San Francisco dates of Dec. 24, has arrived. Two passengers came through. The California news is unimportant. Victoria dates to Dec. 14. Fraser's River was frozen below Fort Langley, and it was feared that great suffering would be experienced by the miners in consequence of the cutting off of their supplies. Honolulu advices are to Dec. 2.

THE ST. PETERSBURG AND MOSCOW RAILWAY--LETTER FROM PROFESSOR STRUVE.--The following letter, correcting erroneous statements, appears in the Philadelphia Daily News: Messrs. WINANS, HARRISON WINANS; GENTLEMEN : In reply to your letter of this morning, I have the honor to state:

MARTIN.--In this City, on Tuesday, Jan. 18. of dropsy on the brain, CHARLES E. MARTIN, only son of John K. and Sarah E. Martin. The friends of the family are requested to attend his funeral without further invitation, from the residence of his parents. No. 201 West 22d-st. His remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment, on Thursday, at 1 o'clock P. M.

The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 5th inst., is now due at this port. She had not been seen at Sandy Hook at 11 o'clock last night. Congressional proceedings yesterday were interesting, and somewhat important.

After the presentation of several departmental returns, memorials, , a joint resolution was passed permitting TOWNSEND HARRIS, Consul-General to Japan, and his interpreter, to each accept a gold snuffbox from the Queen of England. Mr. PUGH objected to the custom of American officers receiving presents from foreign, potentates. Mr. PUGH, Mr. HALE, and one other Senator voted no.

No RETURN TO HIGH POSTAGE.--There are revolutions which will not go backwards. Among them is unquestionably the reduction of postage. Congress may call upon the Postmaster-General for advice, and that functionary may protest that he sees no way to help the Treasury out of the deficit caused by his department but to raise the rates and abolish franking.
Two gleams of practical good sense have lighted up the dreary skies of Washington during the present week. In announcing the decease of Mr. HARRIS, a distinguished Representative from Illinois.

Mr. ELHU BURRITT, who used to be widely known as the "Learned Blacksmith," is a gentleman of excellent intentions. Like most men in Free States he is opposed to Slavery, regrets its existence, and ardently desires to abolish it. But, unlike other Abolitionists, he seeks to accomplish this end by persuasion rather than by force.

The news from Hayti-of which we publish fuller details to-day than those previously obtained by telegraph-is as dark for the Imperial prospects of SOULOUQUE as is the Emperor himself. It appears that the whole of the northern portion of the Island has pronounced for GEFFRARD, the Insurgent General, who has reestablished the Republic on the old "one and indivisible" model common to the republics of that class.

BILLS REPORTED To facilitate the formation of agricultural societies Favorably. To amend the act authorizing the creation of town insurance companies, and taxing foreign insurance companies doing business in the state.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The body of a man, supposed to be that of a sailor, was found on the shore of Long Island Sound, opposite this place, on Saturday, the 15th inst., by DANIEL E. DAVIS, Esq. It was lying in a small boat, supposed to be a schooner's yawl.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Cannot the proprietors of our City cars and omnibuses hit upon some plan to accommodate the enormous morning and evening travel ? Now-a-days if one resides below Fourteenth-strect he will find it next to impossible to ride do wn to his business,because every conveyance is crowded before it reaches his corner.

The annual meeting in behalf of this Society was held last evening in the church of the Rev. Dr. CLEAVELAND, in this city. Although there was a Union meeting in a neighboring church, the house was well filled, and deep interest manifested to the close. The Rev. Mr. NOYES, of the South Church, (late Dr. STYLES',) opened the meeting with prayer.

A VISIT TO THE CRAFT-THE SPECULATION-THE LIBEL AGAINST THE VESSEL. A Savannah correspondent of the Philadelphia Press has visited the slave-yacht Wanderer, and writes: " This afternoon, by the courtesy of the officers of the J. C. Dobbin, I was enabled to visit this now too famous craft, the Wanderer. She is a perfect model.

JENEKINS-WILLIAMS.--On Wednesday morning, Jan. 12. by the Rev. Edward Strong, of New-Haven, G. W. ALSTON JENKINS, Esq., of New-York, to Miss CLARA B. WILLIAMS, only daughter of T. W. Williams, Esq., of Janesville, Wis.

SOME PROGRESS IN THE QUARANTINE MATTER. --Yesterday, the bill introduced in the Assembly, by Mr. TUTHILI, of Kings, for the repeal of the act to remove the Quarantine station, had its final passage in that body. There can be no doubt that it will receive the sanction of the Senate also.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The following report of a case recently tried before Justice ROOSEVELT has attracted my attention: SUPREME COURT-SPECIAL TERM-Jan. 12. Before Justice Roosevelt. SEPARATE ESTATE OF MARRIED WOMEN. Henry vs. Bloodgood.--This was an action for goods sold and delivered. The defence was that the goods were purchased by a married woman, and were not for the benfit of her separate estate.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Permit me, through the medium of your valuable journal, to call the attention of the public to the fact that nearly a half-million of dollars is about being expended for the purpose of widening Whitehallstreet, which, it is useless to say, is wholly unnecessary.

THE YELLOW FEVER CASE--ARREST OF THE CAPTAIN FOR RUNNING QUARANTINE.--The Schooner Hiram E. Bishop, Captain Booth, of Greenport, L. I., which arrived here from Matanzas on Sunday, lost one of the crew--GEORGE SEELEY of Greenport by yellow fever, which he contracted at Matanzas.
The Property of the Bay-State Mills, in Lawrence, was sold at auction, to-day, for $500,000. The Washington Mills Company, successors the bay State Company, were the purchasers.

THE RANNEY FUND.--AN' ARTISTS BENEVOLENT SOCIETY.--A few days ago the artists who had contributed to the fund raised for Mrs. RA?NEY met at Mozart Hall, to receive the report drawn up by the Secretary. Mr. N. B. COLLINS. Mr. T. B. STEARNS was nominated chairman for the occasion.

FAILURE TO PAY PROMISED RFWARDS AND DISSATISFACTION OF THE POLICF. Under the old Police law rewards offered for the apprehension of rogues and the recovery of stolen property, were pocketed by the officers who were lucky enough to get on the track of the thieves, and the missing property. The present Police act made an important alteration in this regard.

The screw steamship City of Washington Capt. PETRIE, which sailed from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 5th inst., arrive at this port yesterday. No steamers from this side had arrived out since the departure of the Niagara.

A special meeting of the Academy of Medicine was held last night in the small chapel of the University for the purpose of completing the election of officers for the current year, and the year next succeeding, there having been a failure at the previous meeting to elect the entire list by three Vice-Presidents, one member of the Committee on Ethics, two members of the Committee on Education, and one Trustee.

Tile screw-steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool Jan. 5, arrived here yesterday morning. She brings news of unusual interest. The anticipation of a conflict between France and Austria upon the Italian question has suddenly passed from a possibility to a likelihood; insomuch that tile money markets of Paris and London have sunk beneath the panic, and the Press generally concedes the urgency of the symptoms.

The Philadelphia Press publishes a reminiscence of the days when the citizens of Philadelphia remonstrated against lighting the streets with gas. A petition to the Common Council, dated Nov. 28, 1833, prays that "the lighting our city with oil may be continued," on the ground that the use of gas would produce a bad effect upon the water of the rivers, and poison the fish.

Brooklyn Mercantile Library Association. ELECTION 0F OFFICERS. The annual election for officers of this Society took place on Monday. There was much excitement, and the result was not definitely known until yesterday, when the following were declared elected officially by the canvassers. The whole number of votes cast was 1,576.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: From your condensed report of Professor MITCHEL'S lecture on the" Ancient Astronomers, and the Discovery of the Laws of Motion," the reader would suppose the conjecture that the earth was not the stationary centre of the universe, to be of comparatively modern origin.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: As counsel for the plaintiff in the case of Henryrs. Bloodgood, to which reference is made in a communication by " A Member of the liar," in your paper of this morning. we beg to say that the report of the case to which he refers is entirely erroneous. and does his Honor Justice ROUSEVRLT great injustice.

Commissioner BOWNE has sent in the resignation of his office as Quarantine Commissioner, and it is rumored that Mr. HALL'S resignation has also been sent up, but it has not yet been received at the Governor's room.
Commission Sales of Produce for the week ending Jan. 19, 1859, prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES by PINNEY JOHNSON, Produce Commission Merchants, No. 231 Fulton-street.

In Philadelphia, Jan. 17, a sad case of destitution was discovered. An elderly female named Sarah Ann McLaughlin, applied for relief at the Mayor's Office yesterday morning. She says that she has been living in Ohio for several years. A short time since she lost her husband, and started for the residence of her son, in Rhode Island, having in her possession $962.

MENDELSSOHN UNION.--It will be seen by an announcement elsewhere that this energetic Society has ROSSINES "Moses in Egypt" in preparation, and will produce it for the first time on Thursday next. Mr. ROBERT STOEPEL'S grazed romantic symphony of "Hiawatha" has also been accepted. This work was lately produced in Boston, and obtained a very flattering newspaper success.

As our Policemen do not seem to be specially oppressed by the weight of their duties toward the criminal population of the City, it may perhaps be possible for them to bestow a little attention upon the vagrant pauperism and misery of tile streets.

If anything could justify a feeling of contempt for a people so brave, liberal and honest as the English, it would be the way in which the Press of Great Britain has dealt with the present Emperor of tile French.

The United States ship Cyanc, from Norfolls, arrived here on the 10th inst., officers and crew all well. The squadron belonging to this station are all at Montevideo waiting the arrival of the Sabine and the others. None of the Steamers (Fulton, Water With, North Star, Sec.) have arrived yet at the place.

Among the passengers by the Africa, yesterday was FRANCIS G. YOUNG, Esq., of this City, who goes to London for the purpose of making negotiations for certain Railroad Companies, and will probably remain a year or two in the British metropolis to attend to similar business.

BILLS REPORTED. To regulate the theatres in New-York. Favorably. The resolutions indorsing the memorial of the Canal Board praying for aid from the General Government for the improvement of lake harbors was reported upon favorably, and the report laid on the table. A petition was presented to increase the Directors of the Loan Relief Association.
ACKNOWLEDGMENT.--We are gratified by the handsome manner in which the Christian Intelligencer acknowledges its obligations to the TIMES for "important information concerning Mr. BEECHER."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In a City journal, of a recent date, I find the following paragraph : "It is stated that Dr. O. W. HOLMES has refused an offer from Mr. BONNER OF $5,000 to write half a column weekly for one year for the New-York Ledger."

On motion of Mr. PUGH, of Ohio, a resolution was adopted calling on the Secretary of the Treasury to furnish returns of all the articles exported and imported from Cuba at all the ports in the United State during the past five years.

The Senate, in Executive Session, to-day, conArmed the promotion of Lieutenant-Colonel JOHN HARRIS, of the Marine Corps, to be Colonel, vice HENERSON, deceased. The charges upon which Mr. SHERMAN, yesterday, obtained a Committee of Investigation relative to Navy-yard affairs, are specific and very serious.

It would seem that Allopathie justice is about to be done to Hom??opathie principles. The abiquitous little globules which have hitherto been without a local habitation in this free country, where even Spritualism ha its temples, are at length to be taken in and done fr.

REVIVAL OF WILLETT'S POINT AND FORT SNELLING-- Mr. RICHARD SCHELL, whose participation in the Fort Snelling purchase, and the sale of Willett's Point, can hardly have been forgotten by the public, was a very suitable person to introduce a resolution in the State Legislature, instructing our Congressional delegation to vote in favor of the resolution to place $30,000,000 in the hands of the President towards a preliminary negotiation for the purchase of Cuba.

As the following is a sample of a very considerable portion of our private correspondence, we shall give it a public reply, which will at the same time answer a good many others: DE SORE COUNTY, Miss., Wednesday, Jan. 12, 1859. Please send your valuable paper, gratuitously, t our reading-room. Our Institution is young but growing, and we believe your liberality will be a benefit to both giver and receiver.

There is a fierce discussion going on in England just now as to the merits and demerits of American institutions, which are held up by the opposing factions for the admiration and execration of mankind, alternately.

MACLEAN.--In this City, on Wednesday, Jan. 19, HENRY, infant son of Wm. H. and Emma Maclean, aged 18 days. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the-funeral, on Friday, Jan. 21, from their residence, No. 407 4th-av., without further invitation.

BEALE--AMERMAN.--On Tuesday, Jan. 18, by the Rev. S.D. Brown, C. DAVIS BEALE, of Boston, to Miss HELEN AMERMAN, of New-York. LUCE--BURROUGHS.--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, Jan, 19, by the Rev. J. A. Paddock. Mr. JOHN LUCE to SUSAN A., eldest daughter of the late W m, L. Burroughs, Esq., deceased, all of Brooklyn.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The compensation allowed by law to the subordinate officers of our Navy appears to be inadequate, and claims the serious effort of every of every friend of the Navy to effect an increase. The commanders receive $2,500 per annum, the ?ieuenants. $1,500 per annum, the past midshipmen $1750, the midshipmen $400, the clerks $500, and the forward officers $900.

THE ILLINOIS RAILROAD, STRIKE.--The Chicago Press says of the strike on the Chicago, Alton and St. Louis Railroad: Mr. HASBROUCK DAVIS of this city, as attorney for the bondholders, went to Bloomington on Thursday, to ascertain the condition of affairs. the Committee proposed at once to put his in possession of the whole Road and operate it under his orders, on condition that the earnings should be appropriated to their arrearages of salary.

We glean from the San Francisco journal received from the Overland Mail some further items of news. There had been a riot at Sacramento among some settlers, in consequence of the refusal of Judge TERRY to grant a writ of error from tile State to the Federal Court, in time ease of FERRIS vs. COOVER.

The director of La Seala, at Milan, has been prevented by the monetary crisis which prevails in Lombardy from paying his performers. This is the first time such a failure has occurred there. The King and Queen of Prussia are at Rome Lodging in the Caffarelli Palace. The Princess Maria Alexandrina of Russia had joined the royal suite.

Since the date of my last we have had two revolutions in and near this city. The first took place on the 20th, in the evening, at the village of Ayotla, a few miles from this city. It was headed by General ECHEAGARAY, one of the clergy party's men, who very modestly proclaimed himself President.

No feeling is more common everywhere thaN a desire to see great or famous people. In Europe, everybody turns out to see a victorious general ; many will go far to catch a glimpse at a great statesman or a famous dancer, and there is a perfect mania for a glimpse of the cocked hat or bonnet of a reigning sovereign.

SOMYETHING TO BE LOOKED INTO.-The Grand Jury yesterday called attention to the insecure condition of Eldlridge-street Jail, with special reference to the recent escape from it of one IMAcOMBERl, mnate of the ship Haidee, who was confined there awaiting trial on charge of having been concerned in the slave-trade.

Mr. COLEMMIAN has introduced in the Assembly a resolution having in view an amendment of the Constitution in respect to the organization of the Court of Appeals. He proposes that the Court shall consist of eight Judges, two to be elected each year; instead of being composed, as now, of four elected Judges and four selected, to serve for a year only, from the Justices of the Supreme Court.

S Clark, are invited to attend the funeral services, at 3,1/3 o'clock this afternoon. at her late residence. No. 50 Ciinton-place. Her remains will be taken to Albany for interment, on Saturday. The American schooner Luther Childs, of Dennis, Mass., JOSEPH NICKERSON, master, sailed from Philadelphia on the 20th of last month with a cargo of lumber, bound to St. Kitts, (W.I) On the 26th, at noon, when about 220 miles west of Bermuda, a heavy sea struck the vessel, and Captain NICKERSON, (who was in the act of taking his meridian observations.) was washed overboard.

ADDITIONAL CLERKS AND ROOM FOR THE COMPTROLLER-BELGIAN PAVMENT FOR BROADWAY -THE TAX LEVY PASSED. The Board of Aldermen last evening adopted a resolution In favor of accepting the proposition of the Fire Insurance Companies to furnish a steam fire engine for the City.

FATAL ACCIDENT.--A little boy four years old, whose name the Coroner has not ascertained, was burued to death Wednesday evening by falling into a bonfire on Douglass-street, SWINDLING THE POOR.-A coal-dealer who tills small orders for coal issued to the needy by the Superintendent of tile Poor, has been complained of for cheating in weight.

On the investigation called for by the resolu tion of Mr. SHERMAN, Lieutenant LEE, I understand, will testify to the employment of seventy men at the Philadelphia Navy-yard, for two weeks prior to the City election, when there was nothing for them to do. Commodore KEARNEY has also been summoned before tile Committee.

The House bill for the relief of the Mobil and Ohio Railroad was taken up. Considerable debate ensued on the question whether to pass it or refer it to the Committee on Public Lands. It was finally laid over. The Invalid Pension bill was taken up and passed. Mr. BENJAMIN, of Louisiana, reported a substitute for Mr. MASON'S bill, which authorized the President to use the public forces of the United States.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: The position of the Louisville Journal on the subject before us is that it is the duty of all branches of the General Government to protect and uphold Slavery in all Territories of the United States where Slavejy exists or is carried, and where the settlers orJ "squatters" neglect or refuse to protect and uphold it.

GOVERNOR BANKS ON THE PARDONING POWER -Gov. BANKS of Massachusetts, delivered an address to his new Executive Council, Jan. 11, in which he treated chiefly on prison discipline and the pardoning power. He held that punishment should b as mild as the nature of the crime will admit, but at the same time, it should be executed with as few excentions as the lot of humanity will admit.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your report of the proceedings of the Couneil of New-York you were kind enough, some time since, to speak favorably of my request to be allowed the right of establishing, especially in the lower or business part of the City, a system of publlic urinals. I am well aware of the embarras-ing nature of this project;

Samuel W. Singer, the editor of Cavendish's Life of Wolsey, of Roper's Life of More, of reprints of Spence's Anecdotes, and of two handsome editions of Shakespeare, is dead, at the age of seventy-five. Mr. Singer was the friend of Francis Douce, whose fine library is part of the Bodleian, and he inherited a fair portion of Douce's large fortune.

MURAL. REMAINS--FORTIFICATIONS, ENCLOSURES, AND OTHER ARTIIEN STRUCTURES. Dr. DE HASS delivered tile second lecture of his course on "American Antiquitics," last evening, before the Ethnological Society, in the Lecture-room of the Historical Society. Dr. FRANCIS introduced tile lecturer, who said that those Mural Remains were found in the territory between NewYork and the Mississippl.

The Overland Mail with San Francisco dates of the 27th ult., has arrived. The train brought two through passengers. The President's Message reached San Francisco at 3 o'clock on the morning of the 26th, in nineteen days and twelve hours from St. Louis. The Message hardly came up to public expectation, especially on the subject of the Pacific Railroad.

" This evening his Excellency the Lord Lieutenant received a numerous and most influential deputation on the subject of the Galway Packet Line. at the Vice Regal Lodge. The deputation was composed of peers and members of Parliament, the Lord Mayor and the Lord Mayor elect, members of the town council. bankers, merchants and traders.

From the Evening Post. BONNER is evidently determined not to let the public forget him; he has hardly played out one trump before another is produced equally calculated to awaken surprise. Having, by his donation of $10,000 to the Mount Vernon Fund, allured Mr. EVERETT into the ranks of his contributors, he has tried his seductive art with the same success on subjects still less susceptible.

From the Mobile Register. The enemies of Mr. FORSYTH are extremely restless, if not positively distressed, about his relation to the Government. They can find no solace for their suffering except in diligent search for proofs of inisunderstanding between the Administration and himself. Intelligence has been received from Dr. LIVINGSTONE, up to Oct. 4. Writing on that date from the 'Kongone River" to the Rev. W. THOMPSON, the states: MY DEAR MR. THOMPSON: I could not possib y write you by last opportunity from the Zambezi, but there was so little to communicate you were no loser.

The United States Mail steamship Black Warrior, J. W. SNITH, Commander, from New-Orleans on the 12th, reached Havana on the 14th, and left there at 1:30 P.M. the 15th, arriving here at an early hour y yesterday morning. In Havana the excitement in relation to the future of Cuba, and the discusSions on President BUCHAN AN'S Message, had nearly died out.

The Comptroller submitted a statement of the expense of printing in the following years: 1856,$109,519 04; 1857, $100.935 93; 1858,$124,264 43. The bill to incorporate the Dime Savings Bank, of Brooklyn, was reported favorably. The balance of the morning was occupied in a discussion on the rules.

H0W TO ENLARGE THE CAPACITY OF TIIM EERIE CL.~NAL..-WC noticed briefly, on Saturday last, the resolution of Senator Pioss:nt, which looks to such a modification of locks as shall enable boats ef :)00 tons burden to pass between this City and Buffalo. At present the longest boat which the locks can receive is only ninetyeight feet long.

We have dates from Porto Rico to Jan. 1. The new judicial officers nominated by the Crown took possession of their places on the 31st Dec. Tile Compilador, of Mayaguads, says that the commission merchants of that port have entered into an engagement. with the penalty of $1,000, not to sell goods to speculators otherwise than for paper drawn to order.

The R. M. steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 8th inst., with three days' later European advices, in now about due at this port. Nothing had been seen of her at Sandy Hook at 2 'o clock this morning. Nothing of special importance occurred in Congress yesterday. In the Senate the Invalid Pension bill was passed.

EXPLANATORY.--In a paragraph published a few days since we referred to Dr. BETHUNE as objecting to the publication of "anything so sacred as a sermon in anything so profane as a newspaper." Our impression of his opinion in this particular was derived from a report of a passage in his sermon delivered on last Thanksgiving Day, in which the publication of sermons was referred to.

The Richmond Enquirer denounces vigorous!y and severely the proposition to give Mr. BUICIIANAN thirty millions of dollars towards commencing the purchase of Cuba: We have very little doubt that it will be followed in this, sooner or later, by reflecting Democrats North and South.

THE QUESTION DISPOSED OF BY BEING LAID ON THE TABLE. In the report published yesterday in the TIMES, of the proceedings of the Academy of Medicine at its meeting on Wednesday night, in reference to the case of Mr. SMMUEL S. WHITNET, the discussion was necessarily very much abbreviated.

Another murder has been committed in Philadelphia. The Press, Jan. 17, says: Yesterday morning, Coroner Fenner was notified to hold an inquest upon the body of a man named Patrick Maginn, at his residence in Prosperous-alley. (now Darceystreet,) running from Fitzwater-street to Shippenstreet, between Sixth and Seventh streets, whose death was caused by violence.

Seizure of the Bark LaurenK at New-London --Hor Offlcers and Crow Held for Examination. A gentleinan from New-London, who came up) by the evening train, reports that an event of unusual interest occurred in that quiet town yesterday, which created considerable excitement, viz.: The seizure, by the United States Marshal, of a vessel uon asuspicion that she was a slaver.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It would appear from the language of the Postmaster-General that the Government propose-in order partially to enhance the revenue-that we should retrograde, and apply, or reenact the postage laws of 1845, so that the tariff on a single letter shall be fixed at five cents for distances not over three hundred miles; and ten cents for greater distances, in lieu of the present rates of postage.

Two ACCIIWDNTS ON THE HRDSON RIVER RAIL,ROAD.-On Saturday last, as the Express train which leaves this City at 3.15 P. M., on the Hudson River Railroad, was approaching Schodack, the engineer, who was sitting on his seat, experienced a sudden shock, followed by the splitting and giving way of the scat.

THE EMPEROR SOULOUQUE'S STATEMENT--THE IMPERIALIST ARMY BULLETIN. We have just received the first official bulletin of the army of the Haytien Emperor. It gives a diary of the movements of the army from Dec. 28 to Jan. 3, but contains little worthy of repetition.

LAUNCH OF A SLOOP-OF-WAR,--The Philadelphia Ledger thus notices the launch, at their Navy-yard, on Thursday last, of the first new sloop-of-war: "Sloop-of-war No. I was launched from the lower ship-house at the Navy-Yard at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, in the presence of an immense concourse of persons. The launch was a very beautiful one,.

Persons of very vivid imagination may possibly be able to conceive the sentiment of indignation which will pervade the Court and the aristocratic circles of Teheran, when it shall have become known in Persia that the United States decline to be represented in that country by an Ambassador of the first rank.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Your correspondent "A Member of the Bar," expresses surprise that Mr. Justice ROOSEVELT should contemn the decision of the Court of Appeals, and that he should render his decisions on the assumption that what that learned Court have decided as law in one case they will decide not to be law in another.

The iron steamer, built by the Messrs. WINANS, (the last novelty a float since the Lemathan,) went up on a trial-trip, from the yard of the builders, at the Ferry Bar, to the North Point light house and back. About 9 1/2 o'clock steam was began to be raised, and at near 11 o'clock the steamer turned gracefully from her moorings and was headed down the Patapsco.

The Seat-Of-Government Question has assured yet another phase. Her Gracious Majesty--there seems no reason to doubt-has sent us another dispatch, insisting, in plain terms, that her award in favor of Ottawa shall be carried out at once. This is rather unexpected, and puts quite a new face on the matter. Some say they won't go for Ottawa upon compulsion.

The Europa had not been seen at Sandy Hook at 2 o'clock this morning. She is now in her fourteenth day--having left Liverpool on the 8th inst. Very little business of public interest was done by Congress yesterday, it being private calendar day in both Houses.

In the Senate to-day Senator HUBBELL'S bill to amend the statutes relative to Foreign Insurance Companies doing business in this State, was favorably reported from the Committee on Insurance. It requires that one dollar on the hundred on all premiums received by the agent, broker or correspondent, transacting the business of insurance for any Company pot incorporated by the laws of this State,

THE LAWS, STRUCTURE AND STABILITY OF THE PLANETARY SYSTEM. Prof. MITCHEL delivered the second lecture of his course on "Astronomy" on Wednesday evening,in the Academy of Music. The building was filled with an audience larger, if possible, than that which was in attendance Friday evening.

DIRECT TRADE BETWEEN OUR UPPER LAKES AND EUROPE.--During the past two years ten vessels, with a total tonnage of 3,600 tons, were built at Cleveland, Ohio, and freighted by merchants of that city for English ports, their cargoes being chiefly staves and black walnut lumber. They all disposed of their freight to advantage, and six returned with cargoes of crockery, bar iron, pig iron, or salt.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Governor MORGAN, and your own article of Monday upon the subject of "Territorial Sovereignty," have discussed the subject thoroughly and ably, so far as either has gone; but will you not permit a Republican to state as briefly as possible the ground on which Republicans yet claim that Congress has still, of right, the contro of Slavery in the Territories?

Baron Pennafather has resigned his seat on the Irish Bench. The venerable Judge (who was called to the Bar in 1795) has recently been in a very infirm state of health. For Some years the has been deprived of sight, but his wonderful memory enabled him to discharge his ??dicial daties efficiently, and in latter years some of the heaviest property causes have been tried by him.

[From the Harrisburg Telegraph.] It must be conceded that our worthy President has great versatility of literary talent. Few would have supposed that, amid the cares of State, he could have time or inclination to cast off for a moment the incubus of that Pacific Railroad, or the lingering consequences of the Ostend Manifesto, and turn his colossal mind to whisky. Yet such is the fact.

The Harlem Railroad double-track bill was reported upon favorably. BILLS INTRODUCED. By Mr. DIVEN, to increase the powers and duties of Public Administrators. By Mr. SMITH, to authorize the construction of a railroad in Seventh-avenue and other streets in NewYork.

ELOPEMENT EXTRAORDINARY AND ARREST,--The Pittsburg papers announce the arrest in that city of a man named ANDERSON, under the following circumstances: About two years age he lived in Washington City, and was in Government employ.

TRIAL OF MICHAEL FINN FOR MURDER IN COOK COUNTY, ILL.--The trial of MICHAEL FINN for the murder of NATHANIEL VIAL, in the town of Cicero, a few miles out of Chicago, on the 2d of June last, terminated several days ago. The prosecution was conducted by DANIEL McELROY, Esq., and District-Attorney HAVEN, and is said to have been managed with much ability.

THE BURNING ACCIDENT ON HAMILTON-AVENUE. -The fact that Mrs. JANE ANN DAWSON was badly burned in a house on Hamilton-avenue, near Van Brunt-street, was stated in the TIMES yesterday. She died of her injuries Thursday night. A little while before her death she reiterated her statement that she believed her husband, PATRICK DAWSON, had set fire to her clothes.

Mr. JOHN ELLIOTT, of St. Louis, Mr. WILLIAM A. GREEN, of Chicago, and ROBERT MIDDLETON, arrived in this city last evening, direct from Pike's Peak, having accomplished the journey in seventeen days--the quickest time ever made upon the Plains. About three days previous to leaving Pueblo, a party came in from the Platte, who reported nothing doing, in consequence of the severity of the weather.

THE PARK, it being the only place of the kind within the City limits entitled to that grand appellation. It contained then all the public buildings belonging to the City;

EDITOR STATE JOURNAL : Your readers have been advised of the facts that the alleged rescuers o the slave JOHN, at Wellington, have been indicted, and most of them have voluntarily appeared in Court to answer to the bills found against them. They will perhaps, be interested to hear of a new feature which the case has taken on-the violent ARREST, IRONING and IMPRISONMENT in your county, of one of the parties in dicted.

Mr. KING presented a memorial from citizens of New-York, praying for an increase in the pay of officers of the Navy. The will of the late AUGUSTUS THORNDIKE contested by his son-in-law, Lieut. MARIN, of the Navy, was before the Judge of Probate, to-day, for a hearing. The lion. B. F. THOMAS and JAMES L. ENGLISH appeared for the Will; B. R. CURTIS and RUFUS CHOATE for the contestant. The main question is one of jurisdiction.

MALONE.--In this City, on Friday, Jan. 21. of consumption, JOHN MALONE, in the 34th year of his age. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, front his late residence. No. 363 9th av., on Sunday, at 2 o'clock P. M., without further invitation. SWIFT--In this City, on Friday, Jan. 21. of dropsy, JOHN P. SWIFT, aged 54 years, 3 months and 3 days.

EBENEZER'S SUFFERINGS-HIS OPINION OF NEW-YORK AND ITS THEATERS.--The first time we had the pleasure of seeing Ebenezer since we left that glorious old state, which, although it does not tax strangers for riding on its rails, owes no man a penny, and has well supported Common Schools, was on that memorable Monday on which the thermometer stood 11 ?? below Zero. We haply knew him.

A recontre occurred in the vestibule of the House of Representatives to-day, between the Hon. GEORGE TAYLOR and C. C. WALDEN of New-York. WALDEN was formerly Deputy Collector under SCHELL, and was removed through TAYLOR'S influence. Passing the latter to-day, in company with Lleutenant MEADE, he uttered the words, "You d--d raseal!"

DEAR SIR: Will you be pleased to give me all the Information in your possession in relation to the Territory now proposed to be organized out of the western parts of Kansas and Nebraska, on the Platte River. I wish particularly to be informed as to the number of the inhabitants-the character of the country and its productions, or suitableness for agricultural purposes as well as mineral resources.

The steamship Quaker City is below, with 112 passengers and San Francisco dates of the 5th inst. The Pacific mail steamer Golden Age hits on board 250 passengers and $1,200,000 in treasure for New-York, and $468,000 for Europe.

DECIDEPLY COOL AND QUIET.--We learn from the Journal of Commerce the Mr. Morton, Ex-City Inspector, has urged Mayor TIEMANN to sanction the continuance of the street cleaning and the other sanitary labors connected with the City Inspector's department.

Mr.REILLY reported favorably from the Committee on the New-York Avenue D City Railroad bill. Mr. COBB noticed a bill for the construction of intersectional railroads in New-York City. BILLS INTRODUCED.
