WHAT SHE HAS ON B0ARD. The bark Laurens, which was seized by the United States Marshal at New-London on Thursday lat, is still in custody. The vessel formerly belonged to the estate of PERKINS SMITH. Some time in November an offer was made of $6,500 for the vessel.

Without an opera, save the colored one at Mr. WOOD's, and with scarcely a variation in the bills of the large theatres, the few establishments that offer a change to their patrons during the week deserve, and will undoubtedly obtain, more than an average share of public support.

From the New-York Commercial Advertiser. BONNER AND THE LEDGER,--When, a month since, Bonner announced the Everett Papers, he mysteriously asserted that he should presently submit another evidence of journalistic enterprise, which should be more startling than any former coup d'maitre.
FLOUR firm. WHEAT buoyant at yesterday's rates. CORN dull; Yellow, 75c. d 77c.; White, 75c. PROVISIONS QUIET. WHISKY dull; held at 28c. without buyers.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa., Capt. LEITCH, which sailed from Liverpool at 11 1/2 A.M. on the morning of Saturday, the 8th inst., arrived here on Saturday forenoon. The screw-steamship Circassian was appointed to sail from Galway for New-York, via St. Johns, N.F., on the same day as the Europa.

The Steamship Europe, of the Cunard line, from Liverpool, Jan. 8, arrived here on Saturday shortly before noon. The news is interesting, through not important. No PREACHING IN MR. BEECHER'S CHURCH--There were no services in Plymouth Church last evening, in consequence of a slight indisposition of Mr. BEECHER, occasioned by a cold, and a consequent hoarseness, which rendered it "prudent" for him to forego the regular evening discourse.
Mr. MORRIS, of Pennsylvania, presented the resolutions of the Legislature of that State, relating, he said, to a subject now attracting the attention of the country.

GLOVER--In this city, on Friday, Jan. 21, of consumption, JOHN G. GLOVER, only son of the late Andrew Glover, and grandson of the late John G. Glover, in the 32d year of his age. His remains were interred in Greenwood Cemetery.

The latest private intelligence from Mexico received here from highly intelligent and responsible sources, is very encouraging for the Liberal Party, who continue to gain ground in the good will of the people.

BURTON'S THEATRE.---TWO new stars commenced engagements at this house, last night, and with good success if we may judge by the applause. Miss JULIA DALY is a lady of decided versatility; she cansing, she can dance, and she can talk through her nose. The latter speciality elevated her to the of a delineator of Yankee character.

The Vice-President submitted to the Senate an elaborate memorial from the Legislature of Indiana, setting forth that that State is unrepresented in the United States Senate, and has commissioned no other persons to represent her therein except HENRY S. LANE and WILLIAN MUNROE MACCARTHY, whom therefore the memorialists pray may be admitted as Senators from Indiana in the Federal Senate.

PERSONALITIES IN THE SENATE-A DISCREDITABLE PRACTICE.--We see that Senators DOUGHLAS and FITCH have been exchanging epithets in regard to the president's appointments of Postmasters in the Western States. As the occurrence took place in secret session, we have no authentic report of the terms employed.

Mr. SLIDELL has made his report on the question of the purchase of Cuba. He has contrived to involve the subject in a mist of sophisms without, however, really veiling the intrinsic absurdity and outrageousness of the particular demand made upon Congress at this particular time by the President;

The difficulty between Messrs. DOUGLAS and FITCH was not settled until this evening. It is now, however, disposed of, and to-morrow's Union will publish the correspondence. Last night DOUGLAS' friends decided that FITCH'S second note, containing his hypothetical retractions, was not satisfactory.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: A few weeks since I saw an announcement in one of the New-York papers to the effect that the Atlantic Cable had become practicable for telegraphic purposes. The same notice was published in other papers. At the time I did not believe there was any truth in it. That impression has become confirmed by satisfactory proof.

A MAN CUTS HIS MISTRESS IN THE STOMACH WITH AN AXE. A most brutal and cowardly act was committed on Friday night last in Union-street, Poughkeepsie, about 11 1/2 o'clock. LEWIS GOULD and ELIZA LAWRENCE have been living together for several years as man and wife, and have one child, a girl about 12 years of age, very intelligent.

The Santa Fe Mail of the 5th inst. reached Independence yesterday. Peace had been concluded with the Navajo Indians. The Neosho Mail party arrived at Santa Fe on the 2d. They were detained by slow movements of Lieut. BEALE'S party, in whose company they traveled.

A VOLUNTERR DEFENCE OF AN INJURED MAN. We have no special mission to defend Mr. BUCHANAN against the assaults of his enemies. But common humanity will not permit us to remain insensible to what must be his sufferings under the muck laudations of the Herald yesterday's number of that sheet was particularly severe.

In Compliance with the request of the Burns Club of this City, the Rev, HENRY WARD BEECHER lectured last night in the Cooper Institute on the genius and character of him to whom is awarded the honor of being Scotland's poet par excellence, of whom WORDSWORTH wrote more than fifty years ago "Through busiest street and loneliest glen Are felt the flashes of his pen."

The remonstrance against the proposed change in the law allowing parties to be examined as witnesses on the trial of their own causes, to which we alluded in a recent article, has been presented to the Legislature. It is signed by the Judges, except one, of all the Courts, and by the leading members of the Bar.

THIRTEENTH ANNUAL BALL OF THE NEW-YORK FIRE DEPARTMENT.-The thirteenth Annual Ball of the New-York Fire Department took place, last night, at the Academy of Music, and was so great a success that it added at least five thousand dollars to the fund for the benefit of the widows and orphans of firemen. Rarely, if ever, has the Academy been more richly and tastefully decorated.

SIRE: Providence, whose intervention in the affairs of the world is always apparent to all but the dullest minds, has given a proof of it in placing upon the head of your Majesty the crown of CHARLEMAGNE, at the Moment when events demand, for the safety of humanity, the reconstitution of one of those Imperial influences which have, at all decisive epochs, burst upon the world as a pledge of safety and of resurrection.

In one place, however, you make Mr. WHITNEY responsible for the rumor that Dr. GREEN had perforated his windpipe with the sponge probang, or metallic tube;

Such temperatures as we have been enduring of late show us that more than a bed is necessary for comfort at night. A plenty of "covers" is essential. All the beds of the Newsboys Lodging-house are now full, and boys sleep on the floor near the stove, but more bed-clothing (such as quilts) is much needed for the comfort of those who can get beds.

SMITH. --In this City, on Sunday, Jan, 23, GRACE CAROLINE, wife of Nathan Smith, of this City. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the services, at No. 55 West 11th-st., this (Tuesday) morning, at 11 o' clock. The remains will be taken to New-Haven, Conn., for interment. WATSON.--In this City, on Sunday, Jan. 23 JANE D., wife of William S. Watson.

The Overland Mail with San Francisco dates of the 31sT ultimo, has arrived here. A discredited rumor prevailed at San Francisco that Senator GWIN would resign his seat for the Secretary-ship of the Treasury. In consequence of this, some stir was noticeable among those ambitious of succeeding Mr. GWIN.

After the usual preliminary business had been disposed of, under the special order, the matter of supplying the City with stationery was called up. After considerable talk, the reports on the subject, with the affidavit of NATHAN LANE, and communication of Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies, were ordered printed.

At the Madeleine (Paris) on Christmas Eve, a curious scene occurred. The well-known Abbe Bautain preached In the evening, and as he is one of the most eloquent pulpit orators. as well as one of the most learned theologians of France, a very large conpregation assembled to hear him. Ascending the pulpit, he gave forth no text, but after a pause cried in a so??rous voice." A Saviour is born unto us !"

Alexis de Tocqueville feel less uneasiness as to the state of his health.

McCARTHY, the memorialists allege, are the only persons properly commissioned as Senators.

Last evening it was announced that DAVID PAUL BROWN, Esq., would lecture before the Historical Society. Some three or four hundred persons were in the hall at 7 1/2 o'clock. After waiting for half an hour or more the announcement was made that Mr. BROWN had not as yet arrived. The audience were requested to be patient, however, as there was no telling what a few moments would bring forth.

The Apache nation, now so notorious, is supposed originally to have included several other wild nations-the Navajos, Mohaves, Yumas,

THE NEW JERSEY STATE MEDICAL SOCIETY.Dr. A. K. GARDNER, of New-York City, by special invitation, read a paper before the Society, (the State Medical,) on Monday evening last, on intra-uterine diseases and their treatment. Dr. G. stated that the knowledge of the diseases of the womb was of modern origin, and that not till 1845 was there any great appreciation of their importance as affecting the general health.

THE RESTORATION OF COMMODORE STEWART.--Congress was fairly laughed out at the absurd proposition which was entertained in both Houses of conferring the unmeaning title of Brevet-Admiral on the gallant STEWART, as a recompense to our naval veteran for the wrong done him by the too famous "Retiring Board."

Sir Charles Coldstream, in need of a new Sensation, should have visited this City, in which excitements and sensations appear to be part of the natural atmosphere. Oxygen and rumors ; hydrogen and curious developments ; nitrogen and astounding facts; carbonic and all other chemical gases, with a liberal infusion of those political and social exhalations in which idle people of leisure and ample means do most voraciously delight.

THE HAMILTON-A VENUE BURNING CASE.--Coroner SHELL commenced an investigation yesterday, to discover, if possible, the circumstances attending the death of Mrs. JANE ANN DAWSON, who died in the Long Island Hospital, on Wednesday last, from burns received the same day, at her residence, on Hamilton-avenue, near Van Brunt-street.

GRIFFIN.--In this City. on Tuesday. Jan. 25. of consumption. FREDRICK D. GRIFFIN, son of Geo. M. Griffin, of Savannah, Geo., in the 26th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, form the residence of Wm. H. Dornin, No. 167 West 36th st., this (Wednesday) afternoon. at 4 o'clock. His remains will be taken to Hudson. N. Y., for interment.

A detachment of troops has just been sent below to the disturbed legion of Lynn and Bourbon counties. News has been received here of the action of the Missouri Legislature, and also that the President offers a reward for the arrest of BROWN and MCNTGOMERY. These things create sympathy in favor of these men. Another fight occurred near the border, in Lynn County, several days ago.

Mr. EDWARD E. DUNBAR, of this City, is contributing to the columns of the TIMES a series of articles under the above heading, the seventh appearing to-day. Few men are so well qualified to furnish reliable information about those regions as Mr. D. le is a gentleman whose personal respectability entitles his statements to credit;

The bids for the new Loan sum up thirty millions. The average premium accepted is two and sixty-two hundredths per cent. The average on the last was four and twenty-five hundredths per cent. Three bids from Philadelphia, covering two millions, reached the Department one hour after the time for receiving bids had closed.

Passengers by the Overland Mail report the weather remarkably fine, and the roads in good order. The Indian Agent at Fort Youna had returned from the Mojave villages without accomplishing the release of the woman and children mentioned as captured in a previous report. Col. HUFFMAN had left Fort Tejon with an escort of cavalry to establish a post for his command, the Sixth Infantry.

FATAL SKATING ACCIDENT ON ??.--The skating on the river, which has been excellent, is now unsale, owing to the warmth of the weather and the action of the tides, which have worn the ice so thin as to render it insufficient to bear much weight. Skating upon it has therefore been abandoned for the present. Two or three persons broke through yesterday, but scrambled out in a wet condition.

MENDELSSOHN UNION. The members of this energetic Association will give ROSIN'S celebrated otatorio of " Moses in Egypt, " on Thursday next, at the Cooper Institute. The work has been in preparation for some time, and will undoubtedly be given with the precision for which this Society is celebrated. Mr. ROBERT STOLPEL'S grand romantic symphony of "Hiawatha" now engages the attention ot the members.

Our venerable President, with his usual judgment and discretion, about a month ago, in his letter to the inhabitants of Pittsburg, supplied one most powerful argument to the Spanish Ministry, for their steadfast refusal to sell Cuba to the United States at any price.

ENLARGEMENT OF THE LOCKS.--On Monday Mr. V. R. RICHMOND, the State Engineer, sent in his answer to the Senate resolution, offered by Senator PROSSER, in regard to lengthening the locks of the Eric and Oswego Canals so as to admit the passage of boats 130 feet long, instead of 98 feet, as at present. The State Engineer is unfavorable to Mr. PROSSER'S project.

The bill to increase the powers and duties of the Public Administrator was reported favorably. Mr. FOOTS introduced a bill requiring all Country Treasurers to file in the Country Clerk's office all paler plating to trust funds belonging to infants, The bill to regulate theatres, by prohibiting the admission of young persons alone, was ordered to a hard reading.

The State Engineer sent in yesterday his answer to the resolution of the Senate, (offered by Senator PROSSER, inquiring as to the practicability and expense of lengthening the locks on the Erie Canal, so as to admit the passage of boats 130 feet long, instead of 97 feet long.

THE POUGHKEEPSIE TRAGEDY.--The examination in the case of the Union-street murder, in Pough keepsie, was continued on Monday afternoon, before the Coroner. The evidence shows that FREDERICK LEWIS GOULD, after deliberatley striking ELIZA LAWRENCE with an axe in the stomach, continued to mock and abuse her, and followed her to her room and beat her there.

The Board of supervisors yesterday adopted the report of the Committee on County Officers in favor of paying the bills of Coroners Gamble, Hills, Perry and Connery for services during the quarter ending Dec. 31, 1858, amounting to $3.397 31. The same committee reported that the present location of the Coroner's office pleased the coroners, but that it needed repairs, and recommended the appropriation of $500 therefore. The report was laid over.

To the Editor of the New-York times. May I'crave a small space in your journal for a reply to a most unjust attack on one whose genius and candor have made him a mark for detraction and envy--"HENRY WARD BEECHER," the Goliah of the pulpit! the pioneer of a religion, broad, liberal, based on the law O'perfect love to "God" and man.

The following forthcoming books and announced in London: Liberty, by john Stuart Mill, which is looked for with intense interest by the disciples of Bemham; Extracts from the Works of lean Paul Richter, selected and translated by Lady Chatterton; and a work of Dr. Vaughan, to be entitled Revolutions in English History, the first volume of which will be 'Revolutions of Race."

We find in the Ayr (Scotland) Observer the following letter from CARLYLE, addressed to the Editor of that journal, in reference to the approaching birthday of the Poet: CHELSEA, Sunday, Jan. 2, 1859. DEAR SIR: I very much approve your and Mr. MILNE'S notion about the Misses BEGG, and I hope you will not fail to get it executed with all the energy and skill that are possible, and with corresponding success.

THE ASTOR HOUSE CELEBRATION. One hundred years ago, yesterday, ROBERT BURNS was born. His name and fame are imperishable. He was the poet of humanity, and as such will never fail to secure eternal honor. Circumscribed by no limits of race or clime, the sympathies he excited defy decay.

DWELLING-HOUSE BERNT--HEROIC CONDUCT OF A BUY--On Thursday evening, about 7 o'clock the dwelling- house of Mr.ALEXANDER LOWN, of Colchester, Delaware County, was entirely destroyed by fire, together with its contents, Mr. and Mrs. LOWN were from home at the time, but the children were all in the house. The fire is supposed to have originated from sparks falling upon the roof from the chimney.

The Louisville Commercial Review publishes returns of the Hog crop of each of the last two seasons, which its editors commend as unusually full and reliable, but which some generally well-informed provision merchants represent as having been made up in "short-crop interest." We give the comparative exhibit of the footings of these returns:

MY DEAR SIR: I cheerfully reply to the inquiry contained in your favor of the 9th instant, received a day or two since -- not only in respect to you, but in justice to the memory of Mr. CALHOUN, who, as on many other subjects, has been often and grossly misrepresented. He was never connected with, or, (to use the vulgar phraseology.) "belonged" to any of the denominations of the so-called Christian Church.

The steamship Arago, from Southampton of the 12th inst., with four days' later European advices, is now about due at this port. She had not been heard from at the time of going to press. The steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 15th inst. with a week's later news, is also about due at Halifax. At 11 o'clock last night, the time of closing the telegraph line, she had not arrived.

The Vice-President being necessarily absent for some days, Mr. FITZPATRICK was chosen Chairman pro tem. Mr. PUGH rose to a question of privilege on the subject of the report of the Executive Session which appeared in the New-York papers, and especially in the Herald.

OUR COLORED POPULATION.--A correspondent of the Christian Register, after having made inquiries and observations in relation to the colored population of this City, says the number of names of colored persons in the Directory is 1,849, out of a total of 139,804. The latter number represents a population of at least 750 000; this would give a colored population of ten thousand, assuming the proportion to hold good.

SPEECH OF RALPH WALDO EMERSON . Mr. PRESIDENT AND GENTLEMEN : I do not know by what untoward accident it has chanced--and ?? forbear to inquire-that, in this accomplished circle, it should fall to me, the worst Scotsman of all, to receive your commands, and at the latest hour, too to respond to the sentiment just offered, and which indeed makes the occasion.

THE SEVENTH REGIMENT AT WOOD'S GYMNASIUM, --The members of Wood's Gymnasium, Nos. 4 and 6 East Twenty-eighth -street, gave a compliment-ary exhibition last evening in honor of the Seventh Regiment,. (National Guard,) to which many of them are attached. That portion of the Gymnasium which was set part for spectators was crowded by an audience, many of whom were military men.

TO SIGNOR ALBERTO MARIO--Sir: When replying to a lecture delivered by Signora MARIO, on the 5th of January, inst., I had no intention to enter into any lengthy discussion upon a subject so universally known; as the war of independence of Italy in 1848-49. I did carefully abstain to refer to any other part of Italy but Piedmont and Lombardy, because there was nothing in that lecture which demanded such a discussion.

The State of Virginia is fortunate in possessing the only authentic perfect statue in existence of WASHINGTON. In HOUDON'S famous work which graces the State Capital at Richmond, may be seen a facsimile in marble of the Father of his Country, as he appeared in the later years of his life.

From the Evenings Journal. The following letter will show to what exten the regulation uniform ma be varied. It is addressed to the Commandant of the new Highland Regiment organized in the City of New York: STATE OF NEW-YORK, ADJUSTMENT-GENERAL'S OFFICE. ALHANY, Jan. 20. 1859.

The Compensated Emancipation Society held its session in this city this evening, Dr. NOTT, of Union College, presiding. The Convention was addressed by Dr, NOTT, ELIHU BURRITT, the Rev. Dr. WELCH, and BRADFORD R. WOOD. Resolutions were introduced embodying ELIHU BURRITT'S principle of compensated emancipation, and determining to raise funds to carry out the plan.

A Joint resolution was introduced asking for twenty day's extension of the Legislature of Kansas. Referred to the Committee on Territories. Mr. HAMLIN Presented the credentials of Mr. FESSENDEN as Senator from Maine for six years from March next.

The Rev. Dr. N. MURRAY, better known as "Kirwin," who once wrote some letters to Archoishop HUGERS, delivered a lecture at Clinton Hall, od Tuesday evening, on " Ireland and the Irish," the proceeds of which were appropriated to the benefit of the Second-street German Methoodist Episcopal Church.

It is not easy to understand why our Government has so much difficulty in settling the question of a route across the Isthmus. That we need a route there, for the sake of access to our possessions on the Pacific Coast, and that this route should be speedy, safe and protected from interruption, every one concedes, and none more readily than the commercial powers of Europe.

SURROGATE'S COURT.--A case of some interest has been before the Surrogate for several days past, and was finally submitted yesterday. There are two applicants for the guardianship of two minor children of JOHN LAFFEN, deceased. The mother died in March last, and the father in December, leaving three children; one has since died.

The Committee reported against the bill to limit the tenure of commissions in the militia, on the ground that it conflicts with the Constitution. BILLS PASSED. To incorporate the New-York German savings Bank. To facilitate the formation of Agricultural Societies. Regulating the theatres in New-York, by prohibiting the admission of boys when unaccompanied.

Everybody knows that unlettered ignorance is one of the principal features of our "Boards" of ?? cipal government, and it is no secret that the "lobby" has become one of the settled instructions of ?? political system. ENHANCED PRICE OF SLAVES IN BRAZIL.--One cause of the dissatisfaction now prevailing between the British contractors and the Directors of certain lines of railway in Brazil, in the course of construction, is the enormously enhanced price of labor since those works have commenced.

PARTIES AS WITNESSES--A corespondent of the Albany Atlas and Argus offers as an argument in favor of the repeal of the law permitting parties t be sworn as witnesses in their own behalf, e fact that "the law was voted for by several members of the Legislature who did not know what they were voting for."

Neither the Arag?, the at this port, nor the Arabia, due at Halifax, had been heard from at the time of going to press. The weather was reported clear both at Sandy ILook and at Halifax. Arabia in her twelfth. The proceedings of Congress yesterday were highly interesting.

CAPTAIN MAURY HELD TO BAIL.--Does any one, not familiar with modern heroes, ask "Who is Capt. MAURY?" we will vouchsafe the information that Capt. MAURY was the Commander of the bark Susan, which recently left Mobile with a load of fillibusters, and perished ignominously on a coral reef near the Balize.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Monday, Jan. 24.-The Plain dealer says that, on Friday night last. about 10 o'clock, three men entered the office of tile Treasurer of Coshocton County, and, while one engaged the Treasurer in conversation, the others threw a shawl over his head and held him.

The Committee of Ways and Means are again hopelessly divided on the Tariff question. They are brought to a dead lock, and are unable to secure a majority for any proposition whatever. The Chairman, Mr. PHELPS, was closeted at the Treasury Department to-night with Secretary Conn anti the principle revenue clerks, for another effort to arrange a scheme to captivate the Committee.

The Governor yesterday transmitted at the Senate a report from the Commissioners to establish regulations for the Port of New-York. The Commissioners say they have done ail in their Power to prevent the mischiefs and abuses at which the law of 1848 was aimed.

Nine-tenths of Mr. SLIDELL'S Report on Cu' a, which we publish this morning, is thrown away. It demonstrates what is universally conceded--what Mr. SEWARD himself does not deny,--namely, that Cuba ought to belong, and sooner or later will belong, to the United States. Upon this point there is very little difference of opinion among the people of the whole country.

The following account of the burning of a negro at the stake by a mob, for the murder of his master, is given by a correspondent of the Maysville Eagle. It took place at Troy, Ky. The Prensa of Havana, has recently given some very important and highly interesting statistics of the commerce of that port, from which--since Havana is to Cuba very much what Paris is to France--a fair idea may be formed of the business of the whole island.

General PAEZ arrived at Puerto Cabello on the 4th inst., direct from Cumana, and left the next day for valencia, still unable to walk, in consequence of the accident with which he met in New-York previous to his departure. Otherwise his health is excellent, and he has on all occasions expressed himself deeply grateful to the people and authorities of the United States, which he loves as dearly as his own country.

We mentioned some days since that at the annual letting, the pews in Mr. BEECHER'S church were rented at auction for about $25,000 for the year, and that not far from 400 members of the church found themselves outbidden, and therefore without seats for the coming season.

CURSES COMING HOME TO ROOST.--The Staten Islanders are just now affording a very remarkable demonstration of the truth of the Oriental proverb that curses, like chickens, come home to roost. The respectable inhabitants of Richmond County have applauded the acts of incendiaries, and done what they could to render incendiarism popular, as one of the means of

If Senator DOUGLAS is to be politically ruined, it will not be for lack of good advice. He has it from every quarter,--from friends and foes,--though most plentifully from the latter, poured on in buckets and in barrels full, with every issue of the weelky and the daily press. The Republican organs are especially lachrymose in bewailing the obstinacy with which he refuses to listen to their exhortations.

POPULARITY OF BURNS.--The fact that the birthday of BURNS is kept as a festival in all parts of the world where the English language is spoken and that his hundredth birthday has just been celebrated by an ovation such as was never paid to any poet before, does not indicate that he is the most popular of all poets. It is BURNS the man and not BURNS the poet whose memory the world.

Senator AMES, of the Senate Committee on Commerce, reported the bill, of which you gave an abstract in this morning's TIMES, for the better regulation of the wharves of New-York, compelling masters of vessels to stretch canvas between vessels (when lading or unloading) and the wharf, so as to prevent ballast, coals, manure, , from being dropped into the water; compelling lighters to have their names painted on their sides;

The action of the Senate to-day, of course, will be understood as a positive defeat of the Pacific Railroad. Judge IRWIN, to-day, filed his resignation with the President. The Judiciary Committee will decide tomorrow, probably, whether they will permit the charges against him for impeachment to be withdrawn. It is doubtful whether they can do so, except by special authority of the House.

The Scolsman newspaper relates the followin: curious case of the recovery of a lost marriage ring "About the end of July or the beginning of August last, a woman named Catharine Ferguson, the wife of a miner named McLean, at Clifton, near the head of Loch Lomond, lost her marriage-ring whilst engaged in putting in or building peals, and, notwithstanding that every search was made for it at the time, it could not be found.

An act was passed providing for the payment of the expenses of the Investigating Committees of the House of Representatives. The Secretary of the Navy was directed to furnish all information in regard to Lieut. CRAVEN'S Survey for the Atrato Ship Canal.

If the records of the lower House of Congress may be trusted, the merit of diligence must certainly be ascribed to the Committee upon Postal Affairs. It has heaped the Clerk's table with reports and recommendations. To ocean steam lines, the franking privilege, additional clerkships, its attention has been directed.

CONVICTION OF CORRIE, THE MURDERER.--The Jury in the case of PETER CARRIE, indicted for the murder of Officer RIGDON, yesterday morning returned a verdict against the prisoner of "Murder in the first degree." The verdict meets the general expectation and is the only one that could be justly rendered in a case where guilt was so undoubted, and the necessity for exemplary punishment so imperative.

The social organ of the White House is lending confirmation strong as Holy Writ to the rumors which have already delighted the country of a projected internal improvement in the household of our venerable Chief Magistrate. Mr. BUCHANAN has evidently issued instructions to his domestic Herald in perfect conformity with the moral of the good old song.

The Overland Mail from California, which left San Francisco Dec. 31, arrived at St. Louis Tuesday evening, the 25th inst. The weather during the trip was clear, and though cold at night, very comfortable. There was no snow on the route; and the ice had disappeared at the crossing of the Rio del Norte. The roads were very good as far in as Fort Smith.

The bill prepared by the Commissioners of the Board of Pilots to amend the law for the regulation of the port of New-York, was reported favorably. The following hills were also reported favorably: To amend the law relative to suits against heirs and devisees; to incorporate the Hahnemann Medical College, and to regulate the sale of keg oysters and requiring County Clerks to file reports of all infant trust moneys in their hands.

The Paris correspondent of the Boston Journal communicates the following, under date of Jan. 6. respecting Senator Sumner: "A letter received yesterday from Mr. Sumner gives but little encouragement for his speedy recovery to his numerous friends. The fact of his still being in the South of France is the best indication of his health. He will get away from France and Europe as soon as it is possible.

WRIGHT.--In this City. on Thursday, Jan. 27, at 6 o'clock P. M., ELIZABETH S., wife of Geo. S. Wright, and daughter of Rufus Read, of Cincinnati, Ohio, in the 35th year of her age. The funeral will take place at her late residence. No. 215 West 23d Et., on Sunday, Jan. 30, at 1 o'clock P. M. The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend. Mr. CLAY, of Kentucky, made an eminently sensible suggestion with regard to the laws against the Slave-trade, in the debate in the House on the appropriation to meet the expense of retransporting to Africa the cargo of the Echo, on Wednesday last, and that was, that the punishment attaching to their violation should be made milder.

DODWORTH'S SALOON. Mr. APTOMMAS gave a Harp matinee Yesterday to a large and fashionable audience. The programme contained a number of the best modern productions for this instrument, all of which were interpreted with the rare skill of this fine performer. The great harpists of the world can be counted on the tips of the fingers--Mr. APTOMMAS is one of them.

A shocking murder was committed on Saturday last at the village of White Church, C. W., near Toronto. The name of the victim is Robert Ramsay. a respectable, well?? do farmer, about 60 years of age. The murderer, Wm. Iloghie is also a man advanced in life, being apparently between 50 and 60. They had married sisters and a feeling of jealously seems to have sprung up between them.

The Railroad Convention of the four great lines from the seaboard to the West, now in session here, does not get along very smoothly. The chief points in dispute are the advantages to Baltimore growing out of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's course of redeeming for the place, and the violation of the, St. Nicholas Hotel agreement by the New-York roads.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived here with Vera Cruz dates of the 24th isnt. General FRIES and Admiral ZERNAN are passengers by the Tennessee. The Spanish fleet left Sacrificios on the 20th inst. for Havana. The French English fleets were at Sacrificios.

STRANGE USE OF A CART LICENSE.-Yesterday, a German woman, who for four years past has reposed in happiness in the belief that by due process of law she was entitled to rejoice in the name of SCHMIDT, appeared before Justice WELSH, and more in anger than in sorrow, unfolded a tale of unusual interest.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 15th inst., with one weeks later European news, arrived at Halifax yesterday forenoon. Her intelligence is highly important and interesting. The Continent was still in a state of disquietude, and war rumors were still freely circulated, but the panic in the money market had somewhat abated particularly in London.

Professor WILLIAM H. ELLET died on Wednesday afternoon, of a disease of the heart. He was born in the City of New-York, and graduated in Columbia College in 1824. He studies medicine under the direction of the late Dr. MACNEVEN, and the Doctor's degree was conferred on his by the Rutger's Medical Faculty of Geneva College.

ARREST OF AN ALDERMAN.-- Alderman Bradley, of the Seventeenth Ward, was yesterday brought before Justice QUACKEN?USH, on a charge founded upon the following circumstance; A boy had been son-signed to the Juvenile Asylum, whose liberation the Alderman was determined to effect. He called at the Asylum and demanded the surrender of the boy by Mr. Pearcy, the person in charge. The latter refused to comply until an order was presented from the committing magistrate.

If anything can ever bring about a revolution in tile political system of this country, it will be the perseverance of Congress in the course to which it has of late years surrendered itself of turning its meetings into mere partisan conventions, in which the public business is shamelessly subordinated to the petty personal squabbles of individual ambition and tile open electioneering of rival factions.

About 61/2 o'clock yesterday morning, tile steamboat Sylvan Grove, while making her first trip between Harlem and Peck-slip. ran into and upset one of the ferry barges which plies between Blackwell's Island and the foot of Sixty-first-street, East River. Three of the ten men who were on board were drowned. Their names are MICHAEL GRAHAM, the coxswain of the boat, and THOMAS LEE and DANIEL MAHONY, inmates of the workhouse.

ARCHER.--In this City, on Sunday, Jan. 30, of consumption, Miss MARIA ARCHER, in the 24th year of her age. To the Editor of the New-York Time : SIR: As an act of justice I request your insertion of this reply to an article in your paper charging me, in company with MARK P. KENNY, as guilty of an attempted burglary in Twenty-ninth-street, near Eighth-avenue.

The Mail steamship Arago, from Southampton Jan. 12, arrived here on Saturday morning. Her intelligence has been partially superseded by the telegraphic dispatch from the Arabia, at Halifax, bringing an outline of news to Jan. 15. We furnish, however, many particulars of unusual interest, together with the letters of our European Correspondents.

FIRES.--At about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, a house on Flatbush-avenue, near the town of Flatbush, recently occupied as a hotel by MILES WOOD, was destroyed by fire. The house was one story high, owned by ISAAC SMITH, and unoccupied at the time of the fire. Loss $100; not insured.

To-day is set apart for District of Columbia business. Previous to its being taken up, however, Mr. GWIN, of California, made a motion to reconsider the vote on the Pacific Railroad bill, and prefaced his motion with a few remarks, stating that his object was to make the estimates advertised for more specific, to prevent straw bids, and to include estimates for a branch to Oregon.

The mania for introducing bills is all-pervading.

Our files of Buenos Ayres papers are to Dec. 11. The United States brig of-war Dolphin arrived at that port on Dec. 5, having made the run from Norfolk in forty-five days. The St. Lawrence, the Fulton, Waterwitch, Perry, Bainbridge and Slupply were still at Montevideo.

In consequence of the severe and almost incessant storms which have prevailed for the past five weeks, we had abandoned all hopes of receiving the Message by exPress,and least of all In so short time.

A Man Beats His Wife to Death and Escapes. On Saturday morning ELEZA MURPHY, wife of JOHN MURPHY, died from injuries received from her husband, on the previous Thursday night. The particulars are reported as follows: The deceased and her husband, two brothers of the latter, DENNIS and THOMAS MURPHY, and their wives and their respective children, altogether numbering thirteen persons, occupied two rooms on the first floor of tenement-house rear of No. 33 Oak-street.

At two of the principal Broadway establishments we have pieces that are satisfactory to the audiences, and as a natural consequence draw hugely. Mr. NIBLO'S establishment is devoted to Equestrianism.

We have received the following interesting description of a new city in Salvador, from Her Britannic Majesty's Consul General there, W. G. FOOTE, Esq.: SONSONATE, Sunday, 26th December, 1858. Santa Tecla, or Neuva San Salvador, which was a mere desert in 1854, is fast growing into a city, and will probably be the most populous in the Republic in a few years.

Probable Success of the Revolutionists--Retreat of Soulouque to Port-au-Palace. A private letter of Jan. 10, from Port-an-Prince, received via St. Thomas and Havana, says the Emperor SOULOUQUE had been defeated by Gen. GEFFRARD, and the Imperial troops were running back upon the city. SOUIOUQUE himself was expected every moment, and it was said that GEFFRARD was only a few leagues in his rear.

The Washington Union a day or two since, in commenting upon the general Postal system of the country, remarked: ," To longer neglect fostering ocean mall service, is to abandon it to Great Britain and France; thus mnaking our merchants subservient to, and our Post-Oflice Department dependent upon their steamers.

THE UNDERGROUND TELEGRAPH QUESTION.--Aldermen BOOLE, LYNES and STEPHENS the Committee on Streets of the Board of Aldermen, met at 2 P.M. Friday. Mr. JAMES T. OLIVER appeared before them, and urged the propriety of removing the telegraph poles from the streets. He claimed that they were useless obstructions, and said the Telegraph Companies had under consideration the project of conducting the wires underground.

Letters from St. Petersburg, quoted by the Gazette de Lyon, make known a rather grave incident in connection with the emancipation of the peasants. The Committee of the Government of St. Petersburg, after having terminated its labors, has drawn up a respectful address to the Emperor, praying him, after regulating the condition of the peasants, to occupy himself with a reform of all other classes in Russia, and to convoke the States General of Russia.

THE LIGHT GUARD BALL AT ACADEMY OF MUSIC. --The anual ball of the Light Guard, which took place last night at the Academy of Music, was the finest ball of the season hitherto, nor is it too much to say that it cannot be surpassed hereafter.

SPECHES BY O. C. HELL., MRS. E. L. ROSS, G. VAIL, C. The on ehundred and twenty-second anniversary of the birthday of THOMAS PAINE was celebrated at the Chinese Assembly Rooms, No. 539 Broadway, last evening.The strong-minded of the weaker, and the weak-minded of the stronger sex, were gathered to the number of two hundred. From 8 until II, dancing occupied the time.

The State of New-York greatly needs a Registry Law. No Stae needs it more. No other State so much. Several bills are before the Legislature to supply the lack. They have been introduced by Republican or American memebers, who zealously advocate their passage.

No. 31.--Frederick L. Bareda and Brother vs. Benjamin H. Silsbee et al. In error to the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Maryland. Justice CLIFFORD delivered the opinion of the Court, affirming the judgment of the lower Court, with costs and interest.

An interesting lecture on HERH MILLER, the self-taught Scottish Geologist, was delivered last night in the Cooper Institute for the benefit of the Mechanics Society, by the Rev. Dr. THOMSON. The audience was a large one, and frequently displayed their concurrence in the lecturer's sentiments by warm applause.

The Senate met at 8 o' clock this evening. Debate arose on the question of approving the journal, a motion being made to expunge all relating to Mr. SPINOLA'S remarks at Friday's session. After opposition by Messrs. DOREBTT, ELT and PHAZZ, the journal was approved.

DEATH OF MR. Ws. C. BOND -- A dispatch from Biston, yesterday, announced the death of Mr. Mw. C. Bond the Astronomer, long known as the Director of the observatory at Cambridge. Mr. BOND was 69 years of age; born at Pootiadn, Me.: early aporentieed to a watchmaker, and since 1839 Astronomer at Cambridge.

To the Editor of the New-York Times In common with your other readers, I frequently notice in your journal suggestions for the better accommodation of that numerous class of our population who have home at one end and business at the other of a three-mile stretch. But is appears to me that this matter has resolved itself into a question of time rather than of distance.

CONKLIN.-In this City , on Monday evening , Jan. 31. WILLIAM HENRY, only son of Alfred ?? and Nancy E. Conklin, aged 11 year and 3 months. The funeral will take place this (Wednesday) afternoon. at 2 o' clock. from the residence of his parents. No. 314 East Broadway. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend.

WESTERN HOUSE OF REFUGE FOR JUVENILE DELINQUENTS.--The annual report of the Managers, to the Legislature, has been printed. This institution, situated at Rochester, has proved itself useful and successful in a high degree. At the commencement of the year it had 345 inmates,---at the close, 386. Received, 172; discharged, 131. The House is full, and more than full.

They bring this action (by compliant and supplemental complaint) alleging the following facts among others. Early in the history of the Company, Sherman was eleted a Director. He was moreover appointed one of the Executive Committee, and took an active part in the management of the affairs of the Company.

AFFAIRS AT THE STREET COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.--Street Commissioner SMITH has adopted the rule established, at his instance, by his predecessor, requiring triplicate vouchers for all moneys paid the vouchers are printed forms, on each of which the account in each transaction is copied. One is filed with the Comptroller, one with the Bureau which has charge of the work performed, and one in the street commissioner's Office.

Since the last mail our Territorial Legislatue has convened and organized at Salem, and listened to a message from Governor CURRY, which is published in full in our papers. It contains nothing of interest to Atlantic readers, and I will not bore them with comments on its dullness.

The State Anti-Slavery Convention is now in session here. AARON M. POWELL, of Columbia, is the President. Addresses were delivered by Messrs. POWELL, WENDELL PHILIPS, LLOYD GARRISON and others, in support of the doctrine of State independence and disunion. The addresses were listened to attentively and elicited considerable applause.

The Hon. JOHN LIVINGSTON was to-day admitted as an Attorney and Counselor of the United States Supreme Court. No. 58--The White Water Valley Canal Company vs. Henry Valley. Argument concluded for plaintiffs.

Secretary COBB has been waiting to receive the returns for January before answering the House resolution calling for his opinion as to the sufficiency of the revenue to meet the Government expenses. These returns are now in, and the Secretary's answer will be communicated to Congress on Thursday morning.

THE LATE MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION ELECTION--RESIGNATIONS AND APPOINTMENTS OF TEACHERS. A meeting of this Board was held, yesterday, afternoon, the Hon. CYRUE P. SMITH, President, in the Chair. Alarge amount of business was transacted.

The services at Music Hall, yesterday, drew together a vast congregation, completely filling the spacious edifics. Not only were the seats filled, but nearly all the available standing room was occupied. The announcement that the distinguished scholar and philosopher of Concord, RALPH WALDO EMERSON, would give a discourse, explains the presence of so many hundreds.

The political horizon this side of the Atlantic is just at this moment particularly dark and threatening. An uprising of the peoples of Lombardy, Tuscany, Sardinia and other Italian States, having for its object the expulsion of the Austrians, with VICTOR EMMANUEL at their head, is regarded as almost certain to take place early in the Spring. Another corps d' armee, 30,000 strong, has just been detached from the garrisons of Vienna.

Little Mary Marsh, of the Marsh troupe of juvenile comedians, whose death at Savannah, inconsequence of burns accidentally received, was noticed a day or two ago, lingered for a few hours only. Mrs. Marsh and Miss Georgiana Mousely, and other members of the company, were also seriously burned in attempting to extinguish the flames on the child's dress.

The facts which it reveals are so little to the honor of the house of Romanoff that it was a State necessity to keep them a dead secret.

An adopted son of Mr. Gi?? foreman of the paper Milsl, accidently felt into the river and was earied over the American Fall. We understand that the lad was on the ice, near the mills, where men had ?? runing the d?? from the flame, and accideltly fell into the swift stream.

By several arrivals at the Eastward, we have dates from Port-au- Prince to Jan. 9, from Aux-Cayes to the 6th, Gonaives to the 12th, and Cape Hlaytien to the 14th. The British brig Spitfire at Holmes' Hole, from Port-au-Prince,on the 5th reports that at that date the two armies, commanded respectively by the Emperor FAUSTIN, and Gen. GEFFRARD, are only three miles apart, and that intelligence of a battle was momentarily expected.

CONCERT.--Miss DINGLEY announces her second annual concert for to-night, at the Mozart Hall, no. 663 Broadway, Mr. MAYER, Mr. MACCONKEY, Mr. APTOMMAS. and Mr. GEORGE F. BRISTOW will assist Miss DINOLEY. "HIAWATHA".--The production of Mr. ROBERT STOEPEL'S grand romantic symphony is deferred until Monday, the 21st. Additional rehearsals have rendered this delay necessary.

The Overland Mail brings San Francisco advices of the 7'h inst. The Supreme Court of California had dissolved the injunction to prevent the Fund Commissioners from issuing bonds of 1858. Two indictments had been found against Captain BILLINGS, of the brig Kate Foster, for baratry. Governor WELLER'S message had been read in the Legislature, anil was pronounced a very able State parer.

The bill authorizing the Harlem Railroad to jay a double track in Fourth-avenue and Madison-avenue, and to run locomotives from Forty-second-street, New-York, was debated in Committee of the Whole. The time of using steam was reduced to twenty years, and progress reported on the bill.

After a heavy day's work riding up from their homes, cruising about in suburban places, meeting Committees, reading up the files, members are prepared heartily to enjoy the amusement of a three hours' session in the evening. On rapping for order, Speaker LITTLEJOHN'S clear eye lights upon scarcely a quorum.

The Arabia's advices show that steady progress is making in the organization of the Company for the construction of a ship canal across the Isthmus under the Belly grant. We cannot help thinking that this matter receives, at the hands of our people as well as Government, far less attention than it deserves.

The steamship Kangaroo, now in her fifteenth day out from Liverpool, had not been seen at Sandy Book at 2 o'clock this morning. Further news from Hayti, which we publish this morning, leaves little room for doubt that the Empire of SOULOUQUE has by this time come to an end.

The Anti-Slavery Society continued its session to-day. A gentleman, named CANFIELD, of Mississippi, spoke in favor of the institution of Slavery and in denunciation of the violence of disunion sentiments, advocated by PARKER PILLSBURY, LLOYD GARRISON and others.
AN ARMED POLICE.--A very important regulation has just been adopted by the Police Department, which may possibly lead to some beneficial results in the arrest of nocturnal marauders.

REPRESENTATIVE MEN.--The Washington Union remarks that " if we maintain agents abroad, they are supposed to be the representatives of our industry-of our great agricultural, manufacturing and commercial industry."

Markets by Telegraph. MOBILE, Tuesday, Feb. 1. The sales of COTTON, to-day, were 2,500 hales, the last three days 9.500 bales. Receipts of the same time, 16, 250 bales. STERLING, EXCHANGE 1071/2 @ 108.

A memorial was presented from the Indian Aid Association of New-York, asking Congress not to organize new Territories without consulting the Indians as to what portion of their territory they wish to be located on ; also, asking Congress to grant money for Indian aid.

Cape Ilaytien advices, of Jan. 13, report everything quiet there, but measures were in active progress for the organization and permanent estabishment ot the Republic. The new political movement has enlisted the sympathies and support of the commercial class generally, and important aid had been rendered GEFFRARD.

To the Editor of the New- York rimes: At the commencement of every session of our State Legislature, for many years past, one or more bills are introduced enlarging the causes for which "Divorces maybe decreed and marriages be dissolved," but it seems that every effort in this direction meets with but little encouragement.

The bill to amend the Peter Cooper Institute act, was reported favorably. Mr. WILLARD introduced a bill to abolish tile imprisonment of witnesses. It allows the examination taken by a nagistrate, under oath, to be used as evidence in case the witness does not appear at the trial The witness is then discharged on his own recogni zaace.

KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--An adjourned meeting of this Board was held yesterday, President SMITH in the Chair. The keeper of the Penitentiary reported 278 prisoners under his charge. Males, 185; females 93. Committed during the month of January: males, 91; females, 37; total, 131.

LLOYD GARRISON, WENDELL PHILLIPS Co.--The Abolitionists, pure and simple, are a people of most extraordinary perseverance. For a quarter of a century have they assembled three or four times a year to pronounce the Union "a covenant with death" and "an agreement with hell."

The friends of deceased, his brother, and of the family of Mr. David Baker, are respectfully invited to attend.

He has ruined his own party, and, greatly to his astonishment, does not receive the support of his opponents ! Sunday's Union bewails the disorganization and substantial annihilation of the Democratic Party.

THE DETECTIVE POLICE ON NIGHT DUTY.--FIRST NIGHT'S EXPERIENCES.--ARE MISTAKEN FOR GARROTERS AND SHOT AT.--A new arrangement has just gone into effect by which the Defective Police have had extra night duty imposed upon them. The force numbers twenty-four, and is divided into four equal squads.

M., yesterday, and resumed the consideration of the proposition to remove the telegraph poles from the streets and causing the wires to be conducted underground.

BILLS REPORTED FAVORABLY. To prevent the issue of false bills of lading, and panish the fraudulent transfer of property by shipowners. BILLS REPORTED UNFAVORABLY. To amend the law of divorce providing for a divorce, when people have resided in other States.

Secretary CASS has been closely engaged all day in the preparation of dispatches for Minister LAMAR. The Government discredits the report of Gen. LAMAR'S misconduct. It is now believed that Judge ROOSEVELT will succsed Mr. DALLAS at London.

OVERLAND MAIL ROUTEs.--The Salt Lake Mail courier left St. Joseph, Mo., on the 14th December, with the President's Message, and carried it through to Placerville, Cal., in seventeen days and eight hours, beating the Butterfield Express, with the Message, two days and twelve hours. The distance from St. Louis to San Francisco via Salt Lake is 2,257 miles.

The Academy of Medicine met last Wednesday evening, at 7 o'clock, in the small Chapel of the University, in accordance with the provisions of the new Constitution, which require that henceforth all the stated meetings shall take place on the first and third Wednesdays of every month. The attendance of members was large ; that of non-members, unprecedentedly so.

Mr. WRIGHT OF New-Jersey, presented the memorial of MORA BROTHERS, and NAVARRO and NAVARRO Co., who are about to establish a line of steamers between New- York and Havana, offering to carry the mail at $1 50 per mile by-monthly or oftener at the same rate, Referred to the Post-Office Committee.

THE MAY OF ON LEGISLATIVE INTERFERENCE WITH LOCAL AFFAIRS--THE CITY INTERFERENCE--PROPOSAL TO GROOVE THE RUSS PAVEMENT--THE TAX LEVY LAID OVER. Three communications from the Mayor were read before the Board of Aldermen last evening. The first related to the bill before the Legislature in regard to the construction of railroads in this City.

ANOTHER GUN FROM TRENTON.--It is quite impossible for Spain to guard Cuba with more jealous attachment than is manifested by NewJersey for her own peculiar "brightest jewel." There may be a degree of difference between Cuba and Sandy Hook; but if so the sages of Trenton do not perceive it. To their partial eyes the Queen of the Antilles is not one whit more lovely than their own cherished bank of sand.

CANAL AUDITOR.--The nomination of the present Canal Auditor, NATHANIEL S. BENTON, for reappointment, is a departure from political usages sufficiently marked to attract attenlion, and must be regarded as a recognition of official merit, alike honorable to himself and to Governor MORGAN.

A correspondent of the New-Orleans Picayune writes from Minatitlan, Jan. 19: The gratifying intelligence reaches us overland, via Tabasco, brought thither probably by coasters from Campeachy, that the war of races at Yucatan is near being brought, for the present, to a close. .

The Overland Mail brings San Francisco dates of the 10th ult. The trip was made in twenty-three days, including twenty-two hours detention. PAUL C. SHORE was killed in Santa Clara County, California, on the 6th, by THOMAS SEALS.. There was great excitement in consequence, and the military had to be called out to protect tile prisoner, who was conveyed to prison at San Jose.

He moved a Select Committee--as the State had was to protect fish, flesh and feel, but none to protect this interesting class of our follow men.

We are well aware that nothing is less interesting to a large proportion of tile citizens of New-York than any subject connected with Municipal politics. Take your average-respectable New-Yorker as he comes, and you will find that in nine cases out of ten nothing short of a pestilence or bombardment could make him listen to any proposition involving action, on his part.

No. 37.--Leslie Combas vs. Andrew Hodges, dual Appeal from the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Columbia. Justice CAMPBELL delivered the opinion of the Court, reversing the decree of said Court, with costs, and remanding the cause for further proceedings.

The New - York correspondent of the Philadelphia press says: "I had an interesting chat last evening with Mr. Mi?burn, the blind preacher,' as he is popularly called, who related some incidents of interest about Prescott, the historian. He passed last Wednesday evening alone with Mr. Prescott, in the study of the latter at Boston.

A MURDERER'S PETITION.-Last September one WILLARD CLARK was tried at New-Haven for the murder of RICHARD W. WIGHT, but was acquitted on the ground of insanity. Since the trial he has been confined in the County jail. On the 2d of February he petitioned the Court for a release, on the plea that he had recovered his reason.

It now appears, by the Herald of yesterday, that Mr. BUCHANAN has laid aside the plan of asking for the thirty millions to purchase Cuba, merely to have the subject ventilated, and without any actual intention of raising the money. He has decided upon raising the money first, and ventilating the subject afterwards.

FATAL AFFRAY.--On Sunday last, THOMAS SHIELDS and MICHAEL DWYER, in the employ of JEREMIAH S. DONNELL, contractor, had a difficulty in a stable on Baltic-street, during which DWYER stabbed SHIELDS in the face with a pitch-fork. One prong entered the left eye, inflicting a would which caused death yesterday morning. The wounded man was taken to the Long Island College Hospital, where every attention was given to his case.

CHAMBER OF COMMERCE---AN OBSERVATORY IN THE CITY.--The monthly meeting of the New-York Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday, the President in the Chair, Mr. BROWER moved to alter the by-laws, substituting a viva voice for the ballot form of voting in the election of members. Mr. J. DE P. OGDEN preferred to adhere to the present form. .

The present aspect of affairs in Europe gives the world a particular interest in the position and resources of Austria. The examination of the woman charged with uttering half eagles out of which a considerable quantity of the gold had been extracted by the process of turning them in a lathe and cutting the interior metal out edgewise, and then filling up with solders, was commenced to-day.

The Fort Defiance dates by the Santa Fe mail are to Dec. 21. They say that the Navajo Indians acknowledge losing 200 lives, 20,500 sheep and horses, the destruction of 1,000 huts and an immense quantity of grain, altogether valued at upwards of $100,000, during the late war.

VETOES THE MAYOR--Three messages were sent to the Common Council last evening by MAYOR TIEMANN. The first related to the projects now pending in the Legislature to conter upon sundry eager applicants the right to monopolize the use of our thoroughfares with Railroads,--giving no compensation to the City for these valuable privileges, and coming under no engagements to accommodate the public.

The great aim of Mr. BUCHANAN'S Administration seems to be to bequeath an enormous NATIONAL DEBT to posterity. All its new measures, as well as its execution of old ones, look to that as their grand consummation.

OUR MINISTER IN NICARAGUA.-A telegram from Washington, which we published yesterday, stated that the Administration was inclined to discredit the reports of Gen. LAMAR'S excesses in Nicaragua. We are not surprised to hear it.

PRICHARD.--In this City. on Thursday, Feb. 3. of croup, MARY S., only daughter of Joseph and Sarah A. Prichard, aged 5 years and 7 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her parents, No. 44 Dominick-st., on Sunday afternoon, at 1 1/2 o'clock, without further invitation.

THE GEOGRAPHY AND RESOURCES OF ARIZONA. Lieutenant MOWRY, the Delegate from Arizona to Congress, delivered a lecture on Thursday evening before the Geographical and Statistical Society, on " The Geography and Resources of Arizona. A very respectable audience was in attendance, notwithstanding the stormy weather.

WHEN THE YOUNG MEN'S DEMOCRATIC UNION CLUB WILL TAKE CUBA.--At the meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Union Club, last evening, after a resolution to fire 127 guns on WASHINGTON'S Birthday had been passed, a series of resolutions were offered and adopted, in relation to the matter of taking Cuba.

The Salt Lake mail of the 15th ult., reached St. Joseph on the 31st, six days ahead of the contract time. The United States District Court had adjourned. The Legislature was still in session, but nothing of importance had been done.

Sonora. To the Editor of the New-York Times: Sonora is the land of romance, the land of tragedy, the dream-land of the fillibuster. It is overrated, and yet not so much overrated as misunderstood. In its geological features it is much the same as the western part of Arizona.

ABOLISHING OUR CITY JUDGE.--Although a bill has been introduced in the Legislature providing for the repeal of the office of City Judge, and with it, of course, the utter extinction, judicially, of the too notorious functionary who now occupies the place, yet, for some cause which does not appear, the measure hangs fire.

THE BALTIC-STREET HOMICIDE.--Coroner HORTON impanneled a jury yesterday, to hold an inquest on the body of THOMAS SHIELDS, who died in the Long Island College Hospital on Thursday, from injuries received at the hands of a man named DWYER, in a stable on Baltic-street near Hoyt, on Sunday last.

Lemuel Shattuck, Esq., a well known statistician and historical writer of Massachusetts, recently died at Boston, in his sixty-sixth year. The deceased in 1818 organized at Detroit the first Sabbath School ever opened in the State of Miehigan, and was its Superintendent four years.

NEW RAILROAD MAP.--A new map of all the Railroads in the United States and Canadas, with the stations and distances from one station to another upon the line of each road, has just been published by SAGE SON of Buffalo, and is offered for sale through agents in this City.

EXTENSION OF THE SOUTHERN REVOLT AGAINST THE CUBAN SCHEME--The Louisiana journals are joining the Democratic organs of Virginia in denouncing the President's pet scheme of purchasing Cuba. SPRINKLING SALT ON THE STREETS--The Committee on Streets of the Board of Councilmen me yesterday afternoon, to hear parties interested in the ordinance prohibiting the use of salt to clear snow from the streets. Col. DARLING, President of the Third-avenue Railroad Company, said that railroad companies should be excepted from the action of this ordinance.

CLASSICAL MATINEE.--Messrs. MASON and THOMAS will give their third classical matinee to-day, at Dodworth's Saloon, commencing at 2 o'clock. The programme opens with SCHUMANN'S Senate for Piano and violin, opus 105, followed by one of HAYDEN'S Quarters, an Etude by RUBENSTEIN, and a Quartet by MENDELSSOHN. It does not often happen that so many excellent curiosities are presented in one programme.

FLOUR unchanged. WHISKY, 27C. PROVISIONS quiet. LARD, no sales. BULK SHOULDERS-Sales 120,-OCO pounds, at 6 1/2c. Of Sides no sales were made, and the market closed heavy. A speculative purchase of 1.000 barrels of MESS PORK was made, for delivery in New-York in May an 1 June, at $19.

We have some additional accounts by the Overland Mail. Major DODGE, who had just returned from Pvra mid Lake, reports the weather intensity cold, and there was great suffering among the Indians for want of food and clothing. Fifteen Indians who has stolen some horses, were killed by a party of whites in Eden Valley, Dec. 30.

The steamship Quaker City, with 110 passengers and sun Francisco dates of the 20th inst., has arrived here. The Pacific mail steamer Sonora takes out 175 passengers an over a million and a half of specie, of which one million two hundred and ninety-six thousand is for New-York The weather throughout California was excellent, and the accounts from the mines exceedingly favorable.

The amendmnents made in the Senate to-day to the bill from the House, granting lands to the States for the purpose of endowing Agricultural Colleges, are not likely to jeopardize the consummation of the law. Mr. FORSYTH, our returned Minister to Mexico, finding that the President would neither take the responsibility of removing him formally from his missin, nor consent to his return to Mexico as Minister, has at length filed his resignation. S.

THE WANDERER AND THE NEW-YORK YACHT CLUB.-The New-York Yacht Club, at their usual meeting, held on Thursday last, passed two resolutions, erasing the name of the yacht Wanderer from their list, and expelling her alleged owner, Mr. W M. C. CORRIE, from the Club.

EMINENT DOMAIN FOR SCHOOL HOUSES.--Very curious measures are sometimes introduced in our State Legislature. Of this description was one which occupied the Assembly on Thursday, being a bill to compel the owners of lands pitched upon as sites for school houses. to sell the same for that purpose, upon a valuation by commissioners.

A TOUCHING RELIC OF ROBERT BURNS.--We (Boston Journal) saw to-day an autograph letter of the poet, addressed t Captain HAMILTON, of Damfries, S1 years ago. It is in the possession of a Boston Publisher, who also owns, among other precious originals, one of BURNS' love-letters to "Clarinda," We have been kindly permitted to copy the letter to Captain HAMILTON:

GUARDING THE MORALS OF THE BOYS.--The conscript fathers at Albany are paying particular attention to the boys. One bill, which has been ordered to a third reading in the Assembly, inflicts fine and imprisonment upon all luckless urchina caught in the offence of trespassing on orchards, and appropriating the fruit growing therein.

In spite of " the war," and the "Peace Commission," and the general amnesty, and all the other incidents of the great Utah campaign, things, by the last accounts, contained in the TIMES' correspondence and published yesterday, seem to be in precisely the same condition in the Salt Lake Valley as before the troops marched at all.

The sanguine friends of fair weather who hoped that the European steamers so long overdue, and which arrived last evening, would bring them news of a clear sky abroad, and the impatient birds of ill-omen whose voice was instant for war, have been alike disappointed. The Asia is in her port, but the polities of Europe are still at sea.

BOSTON, Feb. 7.--Four inclies snow fell last night; clear and mild to-day. PORTLAND.--Wind N.; clear and mild. BANGOR.--Wind N. W.; clear and cold. CALAIS.--Wind N.; very pleasant. Clear and Pleasant weather is reported from various parts of New-Hampshire and Vermont. PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7.-Ther. 32??; clear, very little snow left.

We believe there was some property sold to-day at public auction, but, in the absence of necessary information, we can make no reliable report. Mr. EDDY reports the sale of 20 lots. 12 on One Hundred and Nineteenth-street, and 8 on One Hundred and Twentieth-street, commencing 140 feet west from the Fourth avenue, for $10,500.

The Senate met at 7 P. M., but no business of general interest was done. Only private bills on general orders were considered. Adjourned. ASSEMBLY .... ALBANY, Monday, Feb. 7. The Assembly met at 7 1/2 o'clock this evening. A memorial from the Chamber of Commerce of New-York for the repeal of the usury laws was presented by Mr. OPDYKT.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: I have just seen the letter published in your paper of to-day from Mr. and Mrs. BROWNING. I am not aware that any American paper has ever stated that I was recommended by them to lecture on ORSINI and Italian Politics. My letters of recommendation to America were from Professor and Mrs. NICHOL. Mrs. MARY HOWETT. T. D.

The schooner Mercy, which arrived here last night, brings Part-au-Prince dates to Jan. 16. The revolution had extended to nearly all parts of tile Empire. At St. Marc some severe fighting had taken place, both on land and at sea. with cnsiderable loss of life. SOULOUQUE had been compelled to retreat. A naval engagement had taken place off St, Marc, six vessels taking part.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. --A meeting of the Common Council was held last evening. A communication was received from the Mayor vetoing the action at last meeting fixing the pay of Deputy Collectors of Taxes at $ 2 50 per day, for the reason that he does not think it enough, in consideration of the fact that they are each required to give $5, 000 security. Placed on file.

The question is, will our European neighbors permit this acquisition when the joint efforts of England and France alone are sufficient to prevent it? We may safely assume that these two controlling powers will use every effort to prevent this transfer: of territory, if they entertain a reasonable apprehension that it will probably endanger the permanency of their own dominion in the West Indies. Let us examine the grounds for such an apprehension.

Meeting a lion alone on his own mountain is one thing, and entering a menagerie full of muzzled lions is quit another. The Cunard steamship Asia, from Liverpool Jan. 22, arrived here last evening. Her intelligence is one week later. The apprehensions of war upon the opening of Spring have not been allayed; indeed, on the 19th ult., the panic resumed its original violence upon the Paris Bourse, and speedily communicated itself to London.

PAY !--We understand that the Republican majority in the Legislature have at length taken the bull by the horns. It is a bull which gored that Party sadly a year ago last Fall. The animal's name is Taxation-a beast much dreaded by legislative majorities. But when debt exists, the best policy is to pay.

The Cunard steamer Asia reached her dock last evening at 6 o' clock She left Liverpool at 11 1/2 o 'clock. A. M., the 22nd and brings advices one week later than had been previously received. The screw steamship Kangaroo, Captain JEFFERY, which said from Liverpool at 11 o' clock on the morning or Wednesday, the 19th of January, arrived here last night. The news brought by the Kangaroo has been anticipated by the Asia.

Street Commissioner SMITH has transmitted to the Common Council a report of the business transacted in his department since the cutting of the Gordian difficulty between Messrs. CONOVER and DEVILS, by the appointment of Mr. EDWARD COOPER, on the 19th of last April. The report vigorous, full of important suggestins, and bold in its i of the obstacles which still stand in the way of making this Department all that could be desire.

An English paper says: The judges have made their award of the 50-guinea prize offered by the Crystal Palace Company for the best poem in honor of the poet BURNS, though they have not yet sent in their report to the Directors. The number of poems on which these gentlemen have had to pass judgment, has exceeded six hundred. In this vast mass of rhyme there must have been loads of rubbish;

EXCETMENT AMONG OUR COLORED POPULATION. Mr. THOMAS HODGSON, a white man, although of foreign birth, has made and patented a discovery, which is unique, and which, if he meets with the amount of patronage he knows he deserves, will place him beyond the reach of poverty, and assign him a place among the noted tinkerers of human hair, at least two pegs above the greatest of them all.

FACTORY STRIKE IN LOWELL.--We learn that some three or four hundred girls employed by the Massachusetts Corporation in Lowell, struck for higher wages this morning, and it is expected that others will follow their example. Most of those who have struck are Irish. The fillers employed by the Prescott struck on Saturday.

To the Editor of the New York Times: It costs no inconsiderable sum to keep running the necessary machinery of our City, and a tax of two per cent. is about all the pressure we can just now sustain without groaning out aloud. Will not our Albany friends please make a note o this, and not unnecessarily increase the pressure ?

The bill authorizing the adjustment of the claims against the State held by the Bank of Orleans was lost, and a motion to reconsider laid on the table The bill to amend the Revised Statutes relative to the punishment of bribery was passed. Mr. PROSSER introduced a bill relative to the navigation of the canals.

The Navy Department is in receipt of official advices from the Coast of Africa, announcing tile visit, search, seizure and turning of an American vessel by a British cruiser. The follow wing correspondence, for which we are indebted to the courtesy of Secretary TOUCEY, tells the whole story: COMMANDER TOTTEN TO THE SECRETARY OF THE NAVY. UNITED STATES SHIP VINCENNES, Dec. 10, 1858.

The fashionable season was inaugurated last week by a grand reception and ball at the Taileries. The quadrille ?? was thus composed: The Emperor danced with lady COWLEY, the Empress with M. MON, the Spanish Ambassador; or;

Both Houses of the Kansas Legislature have passed a bill providing for the formation of a Constitution and State Government for Kansas. The bill provides for an election on the fourth Monday in March to decide for or against the holding of a Convention.

The Asia brings intelligence of the death of the King of Naples, FEADINAND II., otherwise known as King Bcmbam. His Majesty died at Naples on the 20th of January, at the age of 48, ending a troubled life in a troubled time. King FREDINAND, the son of FABANOIS LM and ISABELLA of Spain, was born in Jan., 1810, and ascended the throne of the Two Sicilies in Nov., 1830.

Mr. PROSSER, the efficient Chairman of the Senate Canal Committee, does not lose sight for a moment of the interests he is appointed to represent. Yesterday he introduced a bill relative to Canal navigation. We have not, as yet, seen a copy of it. It would seem, however, to be mainly designed to encourage the use of steam.

CORRECTION.--In our report of Lieut. MOWREY'S address before the Geographical Society, he is made to say "Tucson Is the only important town in the Territory, and has about 200 inhabitants." His remarks were: "Tucson had at the time of the Gadsden purchase only 200 inhabitants. It has now about l,000, and in the flourishing times of the Spanish Proyince it had 3,000.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have seen a statement going the round of the morning papers, within the last few days, to the effect that the Forty-second Regiment of Highlanders, of the British Army, are now on their way to this port, en route for Fraser's River.
