Monday evening in the House was mostly given to the reception of petitions, of which there came up, by liberal measures, about three pecks for and against the Atlantic Tunnel project, and reams for and against the proposed new Highland County project. There was a liberal supply of bills noticed too:

TICKET-SWINDLING AND HOTEL-EXTORTION.--A man named FRANCISCO DE GAMINDE arrived in this City on Monday from Mexico, on route for Europe. He was met at the Philadelphia boat by a runner, who induced him to go to a hotel, or boarding-house, in Cedar street.

ST. DOMINGO AND HER COASTING TRADE.--The Dominican Republic, in its zeal for measures of improvement, has taken a step ostensibly in that direction, but which is of very questionable public advantage. By a late decree of Gen. SANTANA, coasting voyages are prohibited to foreign vessels.

We have rather exciting news this morning from the coast of Africa, contained in official correspondence of the Navy Department, which will be found in another column. It seems that on the 11th of October last, the American brigantine Rufus Soule which had cleared from Mantanzas for the African coast, was boarded by the British steamer Viper--searched and burned.

SENDING ANTI-SLAVERY MISSIONARIES TO THE SOUTH.--The Tribune appeals to the public to contribute money to enable Mr. W. S. BAILEY to maintain a Free-Soil newspaper in Kentucky. It bases the appeals upon the following grounds:

A ?? attempt at murder was committed yesterday morning in the tenement-house No. 251 Elizabeth-street. A colored woman named LYDIA ROSLY, about 50 years of age, together with her daughter, ANN MARIA, aged 20, occupied apartments in the above premises--the latter living as the ?? of a negro of about the same age, named ELLJAH MARTIN.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: The following communication was addressed to the Editors of the Tribune, to correct a series of gross misstatements made in that paper of the 8th inst., respecting little ELLA BURNS, but they refused to publish it. I now hand it to you, believing that the subject will meet more liberal and fair treatment at your hands.

GENERAL WALKER'S CONVERSION TO ROMANISM.--The Mobile Mercury of the 1st inst. publishes an extremely interesting account of the reception of General WALKER, of fillibustering notoriety, into the fold of the Roman Catholic Church. It is gratifying to know that the General has become a member of any church;

The final explosion of hostilities between Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT and the Pacific Mail Company turns out to be only the opening scene of the fifth act in the Isthmian drama. The denouement is yet to come, and may involve incidents altogether novel, with actors not announced in any programme.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Observing in your Washington correspondence of this morning some statements grossly false and intended to injure me in a business way, I beg that you will have the justice to insert this card in your paper without delay.

At a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of St. Paul, Minnesota, held last week, a geographical report was made upon the Red River and Saskatchewan country, with a view to the development of navigation on the great rivers there abounding. The report appears to have been carefully drawn up from trustworthy sources.

M. Veuillot, of the Univers, has gone to Rome, avowedly to chat with the boy Mortara, and give his own report of the dialogue. In a letter from Rome there are the following statements in reference to the child Mortara: " He entered the school of the regular prebends of St. John of Lateran three weeks since. He appears happy, and expresses no desire to return home.

The following remarks were made in the House by Mr. STOKLES, of this City, in the debate under the "five minute rule," the motion to strike out from the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation bill the sums for the missions to Holland, Naples, Rome and Sardinia:

The Provincial Parliament met a few days ago in Toronto, for the last time, provided the plan settled by the Queen for making Ottawa the capital shall be realized, as there is no reason to doubt it will be. That project contemplates the holding of the next annual session at Quebec, by which time it is expected that the new Government ?? in Ottawa will be ready for occupation.

THE POLITICAL PHYSICIAN WHOSE SANDS OF LIFE, HAVE NEARLY RUN OUT.--Mr. SLIDELL,, the President's overseer in the Senate, gives that illustrious body notice that they must act upon the Thirty million Confidence scheme, or he shall append it to the Appropriation bill. What a nice little tail it would make to that aspiring kite ! How exceedingly consistent and statesmanlike it would be in the Senate to pass it.

A CONVERTED ACTOR'S PLEA FOR RETURNING TO THE STAGE.--Mr. CHARLES II. WEEKS, whose conversion at the New-York revival, and subsequent return to the stage, have already been noticed, addresses an explanatory epistle to the Troy Times, in which he says:

WHOLESALE PRESENTMENTS.--The Grand Jury of the Court of Sessions came into Court yesterday noon, made a return of the business transacted, and were discharged for the term, with the thanks of the Court. This Jury has disposed of a large amount of business;--found a large number of billy against persons for nearly all the grades of clime recognized.
AN OBSERVATORY FOR NEW-YORK, AND THE CHAMBER OF COMMERCE--The Chief Maritime City of the New World ought not to be without an Observatory.

A communication from the Secretary of the Navy was received, expressing the opinion that it is inexpedient to transfer the revenue cutter service to the Navy Department. The House resolution, permitting Lieut. MAURY and Prof. BACHE to receive medals from the Sardinian Government, was referred to the consideration of the Committee on Foreign Relations.

EVIDENE OF A PARTY.--In the trial of Mrs. HARTUNG, at Albany, who was found guilty, on Monday, of the murder of her husband, the principle of a party's credibility in his own ease became curiously involved. The husband died of arsenic. Of this there was no doubt.

Dr. Esdaile, a celebrated mesmerist, died recently in England, aged 50. An English paper says of him: "In 1837, the facts of mesmerism began to be copiously presented to the British public, and reported in the newspapers and medical journals. They attracted his attention; e examined the matter experimentally, and becoming assured of its truth he devoted himself to its study.

From the Philadelphia Daily News. The chief topic of conversation among the upper ten of the West End is the Fry divorce case, recently commenced, and which is now pending before the State Legislature. Mr. HORACE B. FRY is a well-known gentleman of our city, and his bride is a daughter of the wealthy Mr. GRIGG, for many years a partner with Mr. ELLIOTT, in the publishing business.

Tile "British outrage" on the Coast of Africa, Which we reported in yesterday's TIMES, so far as the facts are known to us, is the natural and legitimate consequence of General CAss' admission, in the late discussion on the right of search, that a foreign cruiser boarding an American ship may be likened to a policeman making an arrest.

A petition was presented to repeal the usury laws; also, a petition to equalize the freight tariff of railroads. Mr. PROSSER reported favorably the bill to regulate the navigation of the Canals by steam. Mr. DIVEN reported favorably the bill to pay Governor KING the expenses of the Staten Island troops, with an amendment providing that nothing in the act shall impair the right of the people to recover for the property destroyed.

The steanmship Indian, which left Liverpool on the 26th of January, with four days' later news 'from Europe, is now about due at Portland. There were no signs of Her at midnight. The proceedings of Congress, yesterday, were somewhat interesting. In the Senate, a resolution introduced by Mr. KING, of New-York, directing inquiry into the working of the Reciprocity Treaty, and the propriety of its abrogation, was adopted.

TELFGRAPH WIRES UNIERGROUND.-The Coinmittee en Streets of the Board of Aldermen met at 2 P. M. yesterday and resumed the consideration of the resolutions providing for the removal of the Telegraph poles from the streets. A communication the officers of the Metropolitan Telegraph Company asking for the grant of the exclusive privilege of erecting telegraph poles for transmitting messages throughout the City for twenty-one years was read.

MAY A NEGRO GO TO COLLEGE"?-This question was decided in the negative, a few days ago, at Schenectady. A youngman of sombre complexion presented himself for admission as a student of Union College. His color was in fact so shadowy that it was thought he must be a mulatto, or at the very least a quadroon.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia sailed at noon with 93 passengers for Liverpool and 27 for Halifax, and nearly $70,000 in specie. The Hon. J. E. WARD, Minister to China, and family were among the passengers.

The Senate Committee on Railroads inet this afternoon, to hear parties on the Seventh-avenue Railroad bill. This scheme is in opposition to the proposed parallel road. A large number were present. WM. K. STRONG argued in favor of the bill, anti Wm. A. BCTLER and JoHN J. PHELPS against it.

A lecture illustrative of Dr. GREEN's mode of treating diseases of tile respiratory organs, and explaining in popular terms the case of the late Mr. SAMUEL S. WHITNEY,--a case which has excited so G much debate in the Academy of Medicine and so much public notice othcrwise,-was delivered last night in Ihe Cooper Institute by Dr. Foy.

STATE NORMAL SCHOOL.--The examinations in the several departments of the Normal School which have continued through the week, closed last evening by a very pleasant reunion of teachers and pupils. Yesterday afternoon, the exercises by the graduates were of unusual interest. The papers read, poems recited, , were highly creditable to their authors and to the teachers under whom they have been disciplined.

A STEP IN THE RIGHT DIRECTION.-GOVERNOR MORGAN has taken a step in the right direction in regard to pardons. He has issued a circular to all tile Prisons and Penitentiaries of the State, designed to put a stop to their signing, or making in person, applications for the pardon of convicts under their charge.

HOW TO SAVE LIFE IN CASE OF FIRE.--The melancholy loss of life at the recent fire in Brooklyn suggests several simple contrivances by which the unfortunate persons who perished might easily have been saved. Some of these are specified by a correspondent in another part of this morning's TIMES. They are inexpensive, and would, in most cases, prove effectual.

The Sioux City Register, just arrived, notices tile arrival of Major CULBERSON at that place, direct from the head waters of the Missouri River. He reports the discovery of new gold diggings on the divide between the Missouri and Columbia Rivers, in the neighborhood of Steven's Pass. The gold obtained from these diggings is inferior in quality, being worth only about fourteen or fifteen dollars per ounce, but is said to exist in great quantities.

Nearly ten years past its middle height, we find the whole world wavering still upon the uncertain issues of questions that were authoritatively "settled " long years ago. I am requested to state that the Herald's annoucement of a recent unfriendly correspondence between the Hon DANIEL E. SICKLES and S. F. BUTTERWORTH, is an entire fabrication. No correspondence has taken Place. The gentlemen are, and have continued to be, on the best possible. terms.

INTERESTING FROM TAMPICO--MOVEMENT OF THE LIBERALS UPON SAN LUIS--STATE OF MEXICAN OPINION. The Tampico correspondent of the New-Orleans Picayune, writes on the 18th of January: "We have many rumors afloat here from the Interior and Vera Cruz. It seem that DEGOLLADO has received a severe flogging from MIRAMON, and that the latter is marching rapidly on to San Luis protect that place from an attack by the Federal forces under BLANCO.

This morning General FRY informed Auditor DUBOIS that a kind of canal scrip, of which he had a specimen, was counterfeit. It was soon ascertained that the Fund Commissioner had paid out bonds to the amount of $109,000, to Governor MATTESON for this reputed spurious scrip. General FRY is supposed to be an authority, as it was he who issued the genuine canal scrip.

KINGS COUNTY DEMOCRACY.-The statement made In the TIMES, a few days ago, that the efforts'at unionn of the Democracy in this County had failed, was confirmed on Tuesday evening last, when the Vasderbilt Committee resolved that the Bradley men had violated the terms of agreement by electing a number oi their old Committee, and they accordingly resolved to act independently for the future.

Arrival of the Overland Mail. The Overland Mail, at St. Louis, brings San Francisco dates to Jan. 14--nine days later than the steamer advices. A brief telegraphic summary has already been published. We find some additional items. .

The Present Winter (says the Boston Transcript) has been marked in the rural districts of New-England by many departures from the usual routine of social life in the country. In many places courses of public lectures have been sustained by the professional and cultivated men of the vicinity. In other towns, lectures, debates and concerts have alternatively been given.

The Whig State Convention met in this city this morning, and was very largely attended. WM. BAILARD PRESTON was chosen President. The Committee on Nominations reported for Governor WM. L. GOGGIN, of Bedford. The announcement was loudly cheered, and the report adopted. The remaining nominations will be made t-morrow.

New.Jersey is not alone in repelling Quarantine. Yesterday Mr. SPINOLA, of Brooklyn, gave notice in the Senate, of which body he is a member, that he will presently introduce a bill prohibiting the location of Quarantine on Long Island or on Coney Island.

There are two steamers now due from Liverpool with news from Europe-the Indian, a Portland, and the America, at Halifax-the former with four day's later advices, and the latter with a week's. There were no signs of either at 11 o'clock last night.

Mr. AMES introduced a bill to authorize the At torncy-General to institute a suit to determine the title to the Washington Market ground, so as to dispose of the same, and appropriate the proceeds to the Canal eniargement. A debate ensued on the question of reference, at the close of which, the bill was laid on the table to await the report of the Special Committee on the same subject.

It is currently reported in well-informed circles that Lord LYONS will remain in the country for a few months only, when he will be succeeded by Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELRY. Lord NAPIER has, as yet, received no official intimation of the fact. It is not true that Commissioner DENVER contemplates resigning his position at the head of the Indian Burean.

The telegraph has transmitted throughout the country the intelligence of the burning of William and Many Columns at Williamsburg, this morning. We have here particulars of the fire from parties who left the ?? in this morning's boat. The fire was discovered about 3 o'clock this morning, at which time the burning had progressed to such an alarming extent that all efforts to subdue the flames were unavailing.

He estimates the amount of dust in the hands of miners at Denver City at from $15,000 to $20,000, and states that no sales had been made at less than $20 per ounce. The organization of Arrapahoe Country wan perfected, and public building were bring erected.

The Senate have recently passed, on motion of Mr. DIVEN, a resolution for a reorganization of the Court of Appeals. It is proposed that the Court shall consist of six Judges, to be elected by the State at large, and each to hold office twelve years.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-Mile. PICCOLOMINI will take her farewell of our regular operative audience tonight in DONIZETTI'S sparkling opera of "DON Pasquale, which will be produced for the occasion. It is settled, it seems, that the popular prima donna must return to the inevitable LUMLEY, who is not ruined more than customary at this period of the year.

The head of the Police Department in this City, Deputy-Superintendent FOLK, transmitted to headquarters yesterday the report as to the state and doings of the force under his command, for the quarter ending the 1st inst. By this document it appears that the whole number of arrests was 3,368-of which number 716 were females-a decrease of 779 as compared with the arrests of the previous quarter;

An informal meeting, indeed more of a conversatione than a meeting, of the American Geographical and Statistical Society, took place last night under very interesting circumstances. Hitherto the Society have met in a room of very limited space, and inferior accommodations, in the University Building. Washington-square.

RECIPROCAL TRADE WITH THE BRITISH PROVINCES--PROPOSITION TO ABOLISH IT.--On Wednesday, Mr. KING, of this State, offered a resolution in the United States Senate, looking to the abrogation of the Reciprocity Treaty existing between the United States and the British North American Provinces.

The Utah mail of the 18th alt. has arrived, but the revise is barren of interest. The Instinct Court was expected to adjourn sine die on the 18th. Superintendent FORNEY was soon to leave for the North to hold a conference with the Chief of the Utes Indians.

THE WINANS STEAMER.-MESSRS. ROSS THOS. WINANS, the builders and owners of the Winans steamer, acting upon the improvements suggested by the late trial trip, have concluded to lengthen her 39 feet. This will be accomplished by cutting off 25 feet from the bow, and adding the required number, tapering to the prow.

ANOTHER FICTION.--Our imaginative and poetic neighbor the Herald makes a very desperate attempt to flounder out of the ridiculous hoax to which it fell a victim, about the intended visit of the 47th regiment of the British army to NewYork.

The Moses Taylor arrived last evening from Aspinwall, bringing the California mails of Jan. 20, and specie to the amount of $1,304,000. The news by this arrival has been in part anticipated by the Overland Mail, so that the intelligence is really but three days' later.

JOHN MULLER ON CHANGE.--On Thursday last, a German emigrant, named JNO. ANTOINE RIOURY, arrived in this City by the packet ship Zurich. As soon as he emerged from the Castle Garden Depot he was met by a runner, who induced him to go to a hotel or boarding-house kept by JOHN MULLER, No. 44 Greenwich-st.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The slovenly manner in taking bail at some of our Police Courts, whereby straw bail and escape of the criminal is too often the result, and the dogged refusal of a few of the magistrates' clerks to draw the affidavit of the complainant, in accordance with his statement, in my judgment, calls for some notice from the public Press.

This is strictly a Polyglot Grammar of the principal Romanic Languages. It is the first attempt of the kind we have seen, and the very effort entitles the book of favorable notice.

As a general thing, the Washington Union is stupid: but now and then it hits, with considerable sagacity, upon the truth. Such an instance occurred on Thursday, when it remarked that "pretty much everything" connected with the Administration at Washington, "in the opinion of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, is wrong."

The idea that Mr. BUCHANAN has ever intended to recognise friendships must be dismissed from the minds of those who have been silly enough to entertain it. It is becoming every day more apparent that he never intended to be animated by any regard for the men to whom he has been indebted for distinction, and with whom, in a great degree, he has been associated all his life.

WILLIAM D. KENNEDY appeared voluntarily before the Sherman Investigating Committee to-day. His evidence was very important in its exposition of the system by which the Government is defrauded in ts purchases. He also presented valuable suggesttions as to the mode of effecting thorough reforms.

APPRECIATION OF MERIT.--It is refreshing, in these days when partisanship rules everything, to find personal merit rewarded by politicians. It is stated that the nomination of Mr. N S. BENTON, as Canal Auditor, was unanimously confirmed by the Senate.

Mr. YULEE, from the Committee on the PostOffice, reported a bill to abolish the franking privilege. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill for the purpose of reference, for the payment of the State of Massachusetts, of the balance due of her money expended for the United States, during the War of 1812.

THE DIVORCE LAW IN INDIANA-A HUSBAND'S DIFFICULTIES. The Indianapolis Journal has the following: "In the discussion on amendments to the divorce law in the Senate yesterday morning. a case was revealed wherein a gentleman In Leavenworth, Kansas, had furnished his wife with money to visit her friends in the East, and to travel for the benefit of her health.

At the Brooklyn Navy-Yard the United States steamer Susquekanna is undergoing repairs, having been hauled from her moorings to the dock for that purpose. The Niagara and San Jacinto are also being prepared for service, with all convenient dispatch. The launch of the new gun-boat building at Boston, is announced to take place on Tuesday next.

THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The bona fule sub scriptions to this enterprise already reach $90,000, and two or three gentlemen stand ready to take the balance of the sum proposed to be raised-$150.000-if they are permitted to do so.
The bill extending the Chenango Canal to the Perrsylvania line was reported favorably. The petition for an appropriation to the Colored Homes was reported adversely, and the report laid on the table.

We have not had DONIZETTI'S sparkling little comic opera of "Don Pasquale" played in this City since the halcyon days of Mme. SONTAG. It happens, curiously enough, that under the same management the work is revived, and once more with success. When we speak of success, we mean, of course, that calm and measured sort of artistic success which attends the serious work of Italian comic opera.

The Meses Taylor arrived last evening from Aspinwall, bringing the California mails and specie of Jan. 20. The news from California has been partially anticipated by the Overland Mail at St. Louis, which brought dates to Jan. 17; so that the intelligence by this arrival is really three days later only.

No. 71.--The Board of Commissioners of the County of Knox vs. David C. Wallace. The motion of the counsel for the defendants for a certiorari was granted. No. 284.--Sampson and Tappan, claimants of the ship Sarah vs. Samuel Welsh, et al. Motion of the counsel of the Appellee to dismiss the cause for want of jurisdiction, set down for argument on Friday next.

This morning, Mr. CHRISTIE, of the Committee on Commerce and Navigation, reported a bill amendatory of the act for the removal of Quarantine. Mr. TUTBILL (Chairman) stated that while he had consented to the report, he heartily dissented from the bill reported, and in Committee of the Whole, should move sundry amendments which he deemed necessary to make it safe, just, or prudent.

McCAPPREY.-In this City, on Friday, Feb. 11, of consumption, ROBERT H. MCCAFFREY, aged 34 years, 11 months and 9 days. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have seldom been so impressed with the importance of clear and correct views of great truths as in hearing Professor MITCHEL'S two Astronomical lectures in Brooklyn. My family have become quite a family of Astronomers; and, in place of the idle talk of the city, the vast works of the Almighty have become our theme.

THE GREAT BULLIATD MATCH FOR $10,000.--The challenge of MICHAEL PHELAN of New-York, to play a game of billiaros for $10,000, has at length been accepted by Mr. SEAREITER, of Dotroit, Mich. They agree to play a match of the American four-ball carom game of billiards, coasisting of 2,000 points up,

THE CUBAN SCHEME AT THE SOUTII.-A gentleman who has recently spent some time in Cuba, writes to the New-Orleans Picayune that forty times the thirty millions asked for by the President, would not much facilitate the purchase of Cuba under present circumstances.

THE LATE MERCANTILE LIBRARY ELECTION.--The Special Committee of the Board of Education, Messrs. CROWELL, J. G. BERGEN and PAULDING, appointed to investigate the truth of "certain rumors," to the effect that Mr. A. B. CLARK, Principal of Public School No. 13, had "surreptitiously" induced between sixty and seventy boys attending his school to join the Mercantile Library Association, just before of voting for a particular candidate, met last evening, in the Board-of-Education Room, Red Hook-lane.

REPENTANT WOMEN RECEIVED INTO A CONVENT.-IN Philadelphia a few days ago a curious scene was witnessed at the "House of the Good Shepherd" in Twenty-second-street. Four young women, who have heretofore led a life of depravity, were receive I as penitents into what is called the Third Order of Carmelites.

The Montgomery (Ala.) Confederation publishes the subjoined extract of a letter from an officer of the Navy, attached to the squadron off the African coast, relating to Captain CORRIE and his vessel: "After leaving Bougula, our next anchoring place was the mouth of the Congo River, from which place an expedition, comprising two gun-boats, officered and manned, was sent thirty miles up the river to search for slavers generally, but the Wanderer in particular.

In Senate to-day the Canal Committee was discharged from further consideration of the numerous petitions concerning railroad freight-tariffs, and they were turned over to the Railroad Committee, on motion of Senator Wm. A. WHEELER, and after long debate. The discussion showed that the Senate has no disposition to damage the railroads for the canals' sake.

WHAT STATEN ISLAND PROPOSES TO DO WITH THE QUARANTINE.--Although not partial, in a practical way, to legal enactments, when coming between her and the gratification of her propensities, Staten Island consents to be represented at Albany by a lawgiver of her own choosing, in the person of Mr. ROBERT CHRISTIE. This Sepoy Solon is understood to be specially charged to look after Quarantine affairs.

Advices to Jan. 28, reach us from Merida. The amnesty which the Government had offered to the revolted Indians had been without effect; and it had been found necessary to declare a war of extermination against them. For this object the authorities had distributed arms to the white population, all of when were summoned to take part in the crusade.

The Resignation of Gen, Robles. Our latest advices from Vera Cruz and the City of Mexico, with the exception of the brief dispatch in the TIMES of Monday morning, reach us ?? by the way of Havana, and by the arrival of the Quaker City at New-Orleans. They extend to Jan. 30. Jan. 30.

Our advices from Caracas extend to Jan. 8. The National Convention was deliberating upon two bills--one conferring upon CASTRO the title of "General in chief of the Liberating Army of 1858," with a life-pension of $3,000 a year; the other bestowing upon him the title of "Eminent Citizen," with a donation of $3,600 and a sword.

The Overland Mail that arrived last evening, brings but very little news of any importance, all of which has been telegraphed East this morning. Messrs. J. W. HENDRIOKS, of Sherman, Texas, S. V. BENJAMIN, Fort Chadbourne, C. P. LANE, Fort Smith, and JOHN THOMPSON, St. Joseph, Missouri, were the only passengers.

The bill which proposes to assist mortgagors and mortgagees in arranging for the payment of the taxes on real estate in this City is still, we are sorry to see, before the Legislature, and was discussed last week in due course. It is one of those crude, ill-considered attempts at law-making with which so much of the time of both Houses is at every session taken up.

The very name of Nicaragua has gradually become odious in the ears of our citizens. It has so long been the symbol of incomprehensible perplexities in the world of politics ; of vexatious treaties and counter-treaties, grants and counter-grants ; of disgraceful fillibustering, and diplomacy hardly less disgraceful, that we hardly dare ask our readers' patient attention for a word on the present aspect of Nicaraguan affairs as they affect our communications with the Pacific.

No. 35.--The United States vs. John A. Sutter. Appeal from the United States District Court for Northern California. Justice CAMPBEILL delivered the opinion of the Court, affirming so much of the decree as confirms the grant to Sutter of eleven square leagues of land on the 18th of June, 1841, by Governor ALVARDO, and annulling so much of the decree as confirms a grant to Sutter for twenty-two leagues of

RIGHTEOUS OVERMUCH.--There are saints so uncomfortably good that they always pine for an opportunity to kill somebody. So too there are friends of Freedom who cast about anxiously and continually for occasions to express their hatred of the South's "peculiar institution."

The President to-day stated to a member of Congress, that he should call an extra session to meet about the 1st of August. The overwhelming vote by which the House to-day refused to suspend the rules for the introduction of the Loan bill, is significant of a determination not to increase the public debt. Neither General JEREZ nor the Government here has received any official information of the ratification of the Cass-Yrisarri Treaty.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have read with interest, in your paper of this morning, some useful remarks "how to save life in case of fire." Belleving that any hints on this important subject might be valuable, I now send you the description of a plan which has been tried with great success in London.

The United States revenue cutter Washington, H. D. HUNTER, Commander, arrived at this port last evening, from a cruise in search of vessels in distress. She reports, on the 14th inst.. at 8 o'clock A.M., they observed to leeward a brig with her topsails to the masis.

LECTURES THIS EVENING.--Dr. HENRY MELVILLE delivers the first of a course of five lectures, on the vifal forces and their correlation, this evening, in the Hall of the Historical Society. The subject for this evening will be the blood and its circulation. Dr. M. is recommended by Drs. FRANCIS and MOTT, and the Rev. Drs. HAWKS, ADAMS and others. WM.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Until near the close of October the general belief was that the crop would be limited to 3,250,000 to 3,300,000, and although higher prices were then paid, yet, in view of such a crop, 11c.@11 1/2c. was regarded as a strained value for middling cotton in the Gulf ports.

CONCERT.--Madame LOUISH ABEL, a very accomplished pianist, gives her second concert to-nigh at CHICKERING'S Piano-Forte Rooms. Her personal worth and artistle ability should insure her a good reception. PHILHARMONIC SOCIETY.--The third concert was intercating and successful.

Advices from this Island are to Jan. 27. Prof. MORSE, who has been for some time on the Island, has employed himself in setting up a line of telegraph between the country seat and the warehouse in town of his son-in-law, Mr. LIND at San Juan. The Boletin boasts of having seen a dispatch sent over the wires, and adds:

The Royal Mail steamship America, from Liverpool on the 29th of January, with one week's later advices from Europe, arrived at Halifax at 10 1/2 o'clock last night. She has been delayed by a succession of strong westerly gales during the enti e passage.

Great excitement prevailed in Poughkeepsie on Saturday, caused by a report that a gentleman named KING, a newspaper correspondent, who was stopping at Ruizer's Hotel, had committed suicide by taking prussic acid. This report proved true.

The Overland Mail has arrived with the San Francisco dates to the 21st. The papers of that day are destitute of news. The steamer Uncle Sam had been libeled again for $150,000. The ship Queen of the Pacific sailed on the 20th for New- York.

Mr. LOVELAND, from the minority of the Committee, reported a bill requiring the Canal locks to be closed on the Sabbath, except when breaks or necessary repairs render the closing dangerous. The bill to protect the liberty of witnesses was reported favorably. Petitions were presented for a prohibitory law, and for a law to regulate railroad freight tarif.

ST. VALENTINE'S DAY.--Children and pro?? chambermaids are about the only ones who remain faithful in their allegiance to St. Valentine. Yesterday, those classes of the community were pretly well informed was the day of their patron saint. The windows of the print shops along Nassau-street, up Broadway and along the Bowery, have for weeks been decked out with bits of gaudy paper much in the style of a British man-of-war on the Queen's birthday.

FLOUR firm with a good demand ; sales 3.100 bbls. at $5 50@$5 60 far supertine. WHISKY uncharged ; in fair demand at 26 c. MESS PORK and LARD dull and nominal BACON in fair demand at 7 1/2c, for Shoulder sand 9 1/2c. for ships. BULK MEAYS unchanged. PHILADELPHIA, Monday, Feb. 14.

The ladies of the Hudson River Industrial School Association present themselves once more before a generous public, asking it to aid them in their efforts to educate and partially cloths a class of children, who, but for such means must be left to increase the number of miserable being who are already too often seen in our streets.

THE POPULAR COURSE OF LECTURES.--The next lecture in this course is to be delivered to-morrow evening by HORACE GREELEY, Esq. His subject, as announced, is "Great Men," and we doubt not the lecture will be highly interesting and instructive. Mr. EVERETT was to have followed Mr. GERELEY In this series, and had consented to repeat his Eulogy on WASHINGTON on the evening of tile 22d.

DETECTION OF A POST OFFICE ROBBER.-The Albany Atlas and Argus gives the particulars of the arrest of the mail-robber GEORGE BARTHOLOMEW. Mr. HOLBROOK, who effected the arrest, watched BARTHOLOMEW'S Operations from a secret point of observation, and saw him steal a large package of letters, mailed at Milwaukee for Boston, and put it in his pocket.

PUGH and GWIN introduced the Scnators from Oregon, Messrs. LANR and SMITH, who were sworn, and took their seats.

He proposes to " place, at proper intervals, along the oceanic telegraph line, air-buoys, submerged to the depth of ten or twenty fathoms from the surface, and held at that depth by cables attached to anchors on the bottom;

The Royal mail steamship America, Captain MILLAR, from Liverpool 3 P. M. of the 29th ult., arrived at Halifax at 10.30 P. M. of the 14th inst. The America har experienced a succession of strong westerly gales during the entire voyage. The steamship City of Manchester, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the morning of Jan. 28.

On Dec. 6, 1857, a telegraphic dispatch was received by General NYE, President of the Police Commissioners, from officers of the Colchester Bank, of Colchester, Conn., to arrest SAMUEL F. JONES, Jr., one of the firm of JONES WILCOX, of Barclay-street, who had been guilty of defrauding the Bank out of a large amount of money while acting as Cashier.

The Special District Court, created by a new act of the present Legislature, to sit at Lawrence, and having jurisdiction over Douglas, Johnson, Lykins, Lin?, Bourbon, and Jefferson Counties, will organize next week. The Grand Jury for the same are now in session, and a large number of the older settlers are summoned before them from the Southern Counties.

B. WHEELER is Chairman. This somewhat singular reference has been characterized by those who made it as a piece of "fun."

ABDICATION OF SOULOUQUE. By the schooner Charlotte Minorca we have Kingston, Jamaica, papers to Jan. 29. According to your intelligent Lynchburg correspondent. Vice-President BRROKINRIDGS is deemed by some political speculators and managers in Virginia to have manifested last Fall sufficient Anti-Lecompton proclivities to conciliate northern support, in the event of his nomination for the Presidency by the Charleston Convention.

Arrival of the Philadelphia. The U. S. Mail steamship Philadelphia, GUSTAVUS HARRISON, Esq., Commander, left New-Orleans on the 5th of February for New-York via Havana, at which port she arrived on the 8th. and sailed again on the evening of the same day. She arrived at this port yesterday morning.

The annual report of the "Newsboys" All Association" of Philadelphia shows a prosperous condition of affairs. The house of reception was opened in February, 1858. The number of boarders varies from fifteen to twenty. A Newsboys' Union has recently been formed, embracing both newsboys and new agents.

The America brings the news of the death of this nobleman, once prominent in the polities of England, but who, for several years past, had withdrawn altogether from public life. Lord RIPON was the second son of the Countess DR. GREY, and the younger brothers of the present Earl of that title.

On Saturday last, at the "Monte ?? Ball," at the Apollo Rooms, a rowdy named JOHN REILLY made a disturbance, and officer JOHN CANNON, of the Metropolitan Police, was thereupon called upon to eject him, which he did. REILLY, however, discharged a pistol at the policeman, but missed him;

Mr. DIVEN moved to instruct the Lobby Investigation Committee to allow parties to appear with counsel. Adopted. BILLS PASSED. To extend the charter of the Harlem Railroad, and determine the mode of using the same in the streets of New-York.

From the weekly returns which were read, it appears that the number of inmates in the various institutions is 9 562, of whom 1,283 have been removed by death and imprisonment, and 8,270 remain.

FIRST DAY'S PROCEEDINGS. The members of the Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S Church, who have been so long endeavoring to procure regular letters of dismission from that communion, have as a last resort summoned an ex parte Council to consider their grievances. It assembled yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock, in the small chapel of the University.

It is characteristic of the Buchanan Administration, that the very few salutary measures it has undertaken, it has undertaken in the smallest conceivable way. The possibility of really achieving a good thing seems to be too tremendous to be trifled with, and, accordingly, when a commendable policy is to be entered upon, it is approached with every precaution against success.

About 9 o'clock yesterday morning, a most brutal outrage was committed upon two old ladies named WALTON, near Hatborough, Montgomery County, about sixteen miles above the city. The sufferers are a mother and daughter; the former named CYNTHIA WALTON and the daughter named ELIZABETH. Mrs. WALTON is about eighty years of age, and the daughter. who is a maiden lady, is about sixty years old.

COST OF DINING AND WINING JURIES. At the meeting of the Board on Thursday, the bill of Wm. J. SENATOR HUNTER ON OUR FISCAL POLICY.--There is in Mr. HONTER'S recent speech in the Sonate, on the tariff resolution of Mr. BIGLER, a great deal of sound sense which commends itself to the attention of every reader prepared to regard this important subject independently of party feeling of previous prejudice.

The news by the America is only so far definite as to the advancing complications of matters abroad as to make it plain that France is more full than ever committed to the leadership of Europe on the question of Italy and the East. The attitude of the Emperor NAPOLEON is already producing its natural effect;

CANAL REPAIRS. -- The annual expenses of keeping the canals in repair has not been far from $700,000. Heretofore the expenditure of that money and the oversight of repair have been committed to officers styled Superintendents. Of these there was one for each "section," which term indicated a portion of the canals of convenient extent, say twenty or thirty miles.

The City of Trieste, the New-York of the Adriatic, was long infested with a plague of small dogs. Dogs murdered sleep at night with their unremitting howls; dogs bit stray children in remote courts and alleys; dogs went mad in the Summer heats, and carried terror through the crowded quays and highways of the populous town.

LANE and McCARTHY, to argue their case on the floor of the Senate. The proceedings of Congress yesterday were interesting, and in some respects important. In the Senate, the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation Dill was taken up and debated. A motion, made by Mr. CLAY, of Alabama, to strike out the appropriation of $75,000 for the expense of sending back to Africa the negroes of the slaver Echo, was lost by 40 against 10.

The present application for a preliminary Injunction is in the names of Charles Goodyear, Horace H. Day, and Alexander Hay. Goodyear has no interest in common with the other complainants. He is but a nominal party. The real parties in Interest are Day and Hay. The complainants seek to enjoin the defendants from making, using, or vending any shirred, or corrugated, or elastic India-rubber goods,

A UNIFORM SERIES OF SCHOOL BOOKS.--At the meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Education, yesterday, the question of a uniform series of books for the Schools was called up again. when an angry discussion ensued which caused Vice-President BERGEN to resign his office, and enough members to retire to leave the Board without a quorum before any decision had been arrived at.

The Apaches have just commenced killing whites This morning at an early hour they killed two whit men at "Whetstone Springs," twenty miles from this post and carried their wives and families if captives. The men killed were Sergeant KELLY and BERRY who had just been discharged from the 1st Dragoons, and were on their way into the States, with their families.

The Galway steamship Prince Albert, from Galway on the evening of the 5th inst., arrived at St. Johns, N. F., yesterday. Her advices are fully one week later than those by the America, and are quite interesting. The latest telegraphic dispatches form London, received at Galway just previous to the sailing of the steamer, announce that the political disquietude is increasing.

BECAR--JOHNSON.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday, Feb. 17, at St. John's Church by the Rev. E. M. Johnson, ALFRED BECAR to MARY B., daughter of the Hon. Samuel E. Johnson. GETTY--PADDOCK.--At Yonkers, on Wednesday, Feb. 16, at St. John's Church, by the Rev. A. B. Carter, D. D., SAMUEL EMMET GETTY to SUSAN EMILY, only daughter of the late P. W. Paddock, Esq.

FIRES.--There were three incendiary fires in Williamsburg Wednesday night, ail the work of burglars. The first was in COLBURN'S hunber office in Water-street, near Grand-street. Damage trifling. The second fire was in CRARLES FOWLER'S cooper-shop on Front-street, near North Tenth. The Police of the Sixth Presinet extinguished both of these fires.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--The Board of Aldermen met last evening. A proposal for repaving Broad way was received from WILLIAM FROST, whose plan provides that stones from one to three feet square or oblong, from six to twelve inches thick, shall be laid, with grooves 5 inches apart, 1 1/2 inches wide and 1 1/2 inches deep, running diagonally and cross-cut diagonally. It was referred to the Committee on Streets.

A TIMELY AND JUST REBUKE--We are very 'glad to see by the only City journal which thought it necessary to report the Rev. Mr. KALLOCN'S lecture, that his audience was very small indced. We trust this fact will teach the young gentlemen of the Benevolent Association which invited him here, a lesson which they evidently needed.

An American Convention met in this city to-day for the purpose of nominating State officers. Mr. THOB. G. TUR ER, who was on Tuesday nominated for Governor by the Republicans, was unanimously accepted by the Convention to-day. Mr. ISAAC SAUDERS was nominated for Lieutenant-Governor; Mr. JOHN R. BARTLETT, for Secretary of State; Mr. JEROME B. KIMBALL for Attorney-General; and Mr. SAMUEL A. BARKER, for General Treasurer.

The Territorial Legislature is drawing to a close, this being the last day bills can be presented to the Governor, allowing him the prescribed time to consider them before giving his signature. This has stimulated the members to act with dispatch, and the most important bills have become laws during the last few days.

JONES, the alleged defaulting cashier of the Colchester Bank, Connecticut, who is held on a warrant issued by the Recorder, on a charge of obtaining $1,600 under false protences, from Mr. WARREN LELAWD, of the Metropolitan Hotel, was taken to the Recorder's chambers for preliminary examination.

One of the Rochester Banks sued a leading business man of that city on a note, or notes, for $15,000, borrowed money.

General Order day in the Assmbly ; one local bill passed to a third reading, and the States Prison bill considered through some ten or twelve pages thereof. This last bill is a codification of the State Prison laws, which intends to alter no salary, nor to make many radical amendments. But the amendments were piled in upon it by the Committee of the Whole, and all of them discussed with ardor, energy and fulness.

Copies of Yesterday's TIMES were plentiful on the desks of members of the House to-day, and its charges of corruption were generally canvassed. Everybody conceded that an investigation is unavoidable. Mr. LOVEJOY, of Illinois, had a resolution ready, ordering a Select Committee to investigate, but he could not get the floor to offer it.

The Screw steamship Prince Albert, Captain WATRRS, From Galway on the evening of the 5th inst., has arrived at this port. The Prince Albert had a boisterous passage, and is slightly damaged. She has nearly a full complement of passengers, amount them WILLIAM SMITH O'BRIEN, of Ireland, and WM. MULLOY, of New-York--all well on board.

Frederick W. Sargent, et al., vs. Elijah Burdick. -This is the suit against a colored man, a tailor, to recover the value of goods said to have been stolen from plaintiffs and sold to him. It was reported in yesterday's TIMES. The jury found a verdict for plaintiffs for $509.

MOST SURPRISING !-Our Washington correspondent yesterday advised us that our venerable Secretary of State " expresses great surprise at receiving no dispatches from Nicaragua." He adds that "regrets are expressed that we have permitted England to take the lead in Central American affairs." This is very amusing.

BOUNDARIES OF OREGON.--The error appears to be current that the boundaries of the new State of Oregon are coincident with those of the former Territory. Even the Philadelphia Inquirer, noted for its accuracy, gives the limits as reaching from the Pacific to the Rocky Mountains, and from the 16th to the 42d parallel of North latitude, an area of 227,000 square miles, only a fraction less than that of Texas. The error is material.

AFRICAN EXPLORATIONS.--At a recent meeting of the Royal Geographical Society, a communication from the notes of Captains BURTON and SPEKE on Lake Ujiji, in Central Africa, was read. These notes contained very brief accounts of the Eastern Exploring Expedition, and their arrival at and survey of the Lake Ujiji, which lies to the west of Zanzibar, and train the space occupied on the map is about 200 mites long and 27 mile broad.

The French projectors of a canal through Nicaragua have demonstrated, to the satisfaction of capitalists, the physical possibilities of a cut through the Isthmus. MORTALITY.--The Health Officer reports 97 deaths as the total for the week ending Saturday last. They are classified as follows: Men, 14; women--; boys, 26; girls, 31; adults, 40; children, 59; males, 42; females, 55; colored persons, 2; 20, or about one-fifth of the whole, were more than 50 years old, and 58, or about three-fifths, were under 21 years of age; one at least died of old age; 71 were natives.

To-day has been witnessed the closing scene in the Territorial Assembly. They adjourned to night at midnight. The usual bustle and confusion incident to the last hours of a stormy session have been witnessed. Every bill of importance has been signed by the Governor, except the one prohibiting Slavery in this Territory. That was a very important measure, and the Governor still holds it in his pocket.

Since the date of my letter of the 19th ult. we have had two complete changes in the Government of this capital. The Robles clique completely disappeared on the 20th ult. by the arrival of General MIRAMON, who took up his lodgings in the Castle of Chapultepec and dictated terms to the revolutionary elements of this capital.

THE ARIZONA EMTGRATION SCHEME.--We have received the cicular of the " Arizona, Mexican and Central American Emigration and Colonization Association,"--which has for its subject settlement in any of the extensive regions enumerated in the long title of theCompany. Gen HENNINGSEN is the general director of the Association, which has a capital of three millions

A case of Rank bribery in the Missouri Legislature has come to light. In the House, Feb. 15, Mr BILKINGTON stated that he had information that the Banks had voted ten thousand dollars, fine days' ago to force the Richardson bill through the House. He gave Mr. OWEN, of Franklin, as authority, who in turn, stated he had it from a Bank Director.

The Pittsfield (Mass.) Eagle announces the death of Cyrus Stowell, of Peru, For fifty years he held a commission as Justice of the Peace; for twenty sessions, between 1803 and 1811, he held a seat in the General Court, and in 1820 was a member of the Convention to revise the Constitution. Dr. JOSE W. SMITH, of Acapulco, has arrived here from Mexico with highly important dispatches, and is stopping at WILLARD'S Hotel. He is the personal friend of General ALVAREZ, who is now ready for the field with six thousand men, if he had arms and ammunition. He converses freely and frankly relative to affairs in Mexico.

MURDER AND SUICIDE BY AN ARMY OFFICER.--The Davenport (Iowa) Gazette gives the particulars of a bloody affair which occurred at Brooklyn, Poweshick County, Iowa, on the evening of the 11th of February. It appears that on the evening before a man get out of the state at Brooklyn.

THE TROUBLES IN DR. CHEEVER'S CHURCH.--The Rev. Dr. CHEEVER, last evening, at the Church of the Puritans, Union Square, preached the third of a series of sermons with regard to the iniquity of Slavery. Every seat in the Church was occupied. The 18th and 19th verses of the 18th chapter of Genesis constituted the text :

The Jacmel advices to the 30th ultnno, by the schooner Abbie Forest, at Homes' Hole, state that all the excitement of the revolution had passed by, and business had revived to its former briskness. Coffee was coming in freely from the coast and the interior. The most enthusiastic demonstrations followed the abdication of the Emperor and downfall of the Empire.

Important dispatches have been received by the State Department from the Hon. WM. M. CHURCH-WELL, of Tennessee, who was some time ago sent out to Mexico as the Special Agent of the Government, to ascertain as nearly as possible the precise condition of affairs in that agitated country.

CHARTERED RIGHTS OF THE CITY.-The point Committee of the Common Council, appointed to inquire what means might be adopted to protect the chartered rights of the City from further Invasion by the Legislature, held an adjourned meeting last evening in the chamber of the Board of Aldermen.

FOOLISHLY THIN-SKINNED.-Our neighbor of the Hcrald is needlessly excited by a recent announcement in one of our Washington letters that his " wife and eldest son were expected at Washington." What there was in that simple statement which should stimulate him to such unusual indignation, we are not aware.

THE FRY DIVORCE CASE.--Mr. HORACE B. FRY has put in an answer to the memorial of JOHN GRIGG, father of Mrs. FRY. He recites the charges brought against him, and denies them. The sharpest point in the answer is the following: "Mr. GRIGG informs me of a crime I have committed-the arrest of a love-letter, written by my wife to another man.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--THE BOARD OF EDUCATION.--A regular meeting of the Brooklyn Common Council was held last evening. By the way of Havana we receive dates from San Domingo to Jan. 21, and from Santiago de los Caballeros to Jan. 23. The official Gazette of Santo Domingo inserts memorials from every class of society, from the political Governor ad interim, and tile chiefs of the army, down to private citizens, against the proposition of Chevalier RAYBAUD, in regard to submission to Hayti;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I observe in your paper of the 16th inst. an editorial article commenting upon the project of the State taking from the Savings Institutions unclaimed deposits as wrong, and commending the plan by which moneys now in Court for the benefit of infants and costuique trusts are preserved.

ASSEMBLY BILLS. FRAUDS BY GAS COMPANIES. Mr. GOVER'S bill to prevent frauds upon gas consumers provides, that the Supervisors of New-York shall appoint ten, and the Supervisors of Kings five Inspectors of Gas Meters for the respective counties, and to allot districts to each in which to inspect all gas meters.

The excitement over the first rescue of S. F. JONES, the Colchester Bank defaulter; the second attempt to get him into this State, and the pursuit of the officers who hall him in charge by a large body of armed New-Yorkers is at length ended by the intelligence of his safe arrival at Norwich, whence he ill to-day be taken to Colchester for examination.

The production of an original musical work is an event of some importance in any count r, and especially so in this, where it is attended with difficulties of a more than usually disheartening character. The guardians of our lyrical muse lack that energy and enterprise which we find in almost every other class of public caterers.

There is no order of talent that receives such instant recognition in Congress, which at once places its fortunate possessor on so elevated pedestal, and gains him so sure an audience and so many friends, as the talent, pous faire rire. It takes a Senator a long while and repeated efforts to gain consideration as a serious debater, so as to win the attention and confidence of all parties.

At the date of my last there were rumors of General GEFFRARD'S having met and defeated the Emperor's forces at Larcahaie, a small place about midway between Port-au-Prince and Gonaives, rumors which were made a certainty on the 9th inst., when the Emperor reentered the city, after an absence of about two weeks, in anything but a triumphant state.

Another strange, though by no means surprising, turn in the Mexican wheel, is foreshadowed in our special dispatch from Washington this morning. Our Correspondent learns, on what he considers excellent authority, that two Commissioners have been dispatched to St. Thomas by MIRAMON, with instructions to invite SANTA ANNA again to take charge of the Government.

Senior MATA has not yet arrived, so that the question of his reception as the representative of the Juarez Government is not formally made yet. BRODIE.--In this City, on Sunday morning, Feb. 20. HELEN PRINCE, wife of John Brodie, in the 59th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on Tuesday, 22d inst., at 9 o'clock A. M., from No. 81 Morton St., without further notice.

The best site for all practical purposes of an Observatory is on Washington Park, Brooklyn, generally known as Fort Green, which, for natural advantages, cannel be surpassed; being less than half the distance from the Battery to the Central Park, of easy access, high elevation, firm, solid foundation, and would be a land-mark to mariners at sea.

Unless the intelligence from Washington deceives us, we may expect from the forthcoming report of the Special Committee on Naval Contracts some startling revelations of the extent to which the public welfare is made subordinate to party interests in the practical administration of the Government.

THE ILLINOIS FRAUD--A NEW LEAK--The investigation into the circumstances of the great fraud upon the State of Illinois is progress. A. number of witnesses have been examined; among them Mr. JOSIAH McROBERTS, late State Truetee, who testified to direct dealings in the Canal Bonds with Governor MATTESON.

FINCH--EADIE.--In this City, on Thursday evening, Feb. 17, by the Rev. Hugh H. Blair. Mr. EZRA FINCH to Miss ISABELLA R. EADIE, all of this City. KINGMAN--STOUT.--In this City, on Thursday, Feb. 17, by the Rev. L. Covell, Mfr. SUMMER A. KINGMAN to Miss EMILIE, daughter of Mr. Richard Stout, all of this City.

Sales at auction by Mr. BLEECKER: One lot on the northwest corner of First-avenue and One Hundred and twentieth-street, 25 feet 5 inches by about 80 feet--$725; the lot adjoining, nearly full--$600; gore on opposite corner--$350. All T. W. MARSHALL.

The Island of St. Domingo is now in a condition which should excite friendly interest and attention on the part of the United States, if our Government could be brought to attempt anything of a practical character in respect to its neighbors. SOULOUQUE'S overthrow is a fortunate event-not for Hayti alone, but for tile other end of the Island as well.

It is now certain that we are to have a court at the Palais Royal: the marriage of the Prince NAPOLEON with the Princess CLOTILDE, of Savoy, is officially announced to take place, on Sunday next, at Turin. The ceremony will be attended with a good deal of pomp, and In presence of tile representatives of the different foreign governments at the Court of Sardinia.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: That portion of our community interested in insurance are being aroused by the rumors which have been recently multiplied relative to bogus insurance companies, and I beg the privilege of an oppotunity through your columns to point out the remedy for the evils which cause so much just complaint.

The pressure of advertisements and the current news of the day upon our columns has thrown considerably in arrears our notices of the new publications of the day. Fortunately, though numerous enough, they have not been of striking importance, though the list comprises several works of standard and permanent value.

Some days since we called attention to the claim of Mr. JOHN PETTIGREW against the City, as one of the one hundred and sixty-six judgments which had been obtained, and which Mr. Comptrolle? HAWS asks the Common Council to pay immediately.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The proposel reorganization of the Court of Appeals is generally approved of in all sections of the State ; and the particular feature which calls forth more remark from the Press, and meets the most hearty response from the public mind, is that which proposes to exclude a Judge from sitting in a cause where his own decisions, In a Court below, are in review.

The anniversary of WASHINGTON'S Birthday will be observed in this city, to-morrow, very generally. The Legislature have adjourned over till; Wednesday; banks and insurance offices will be closed, and all our daily newspapers will suspend publication until Wednesday noon; Governor BANKS is to deliver an oration before the Mercantile Library Association; a great gathering of children in Fanueil Hall;

The Vice President and Mr. GREEN presented memorials from citizens of St. Louis, praying for an Assay Office there. Referred. Mr. HUNTER wished the motion of Mr. SIMMONS, to reconsider the vote by which the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill was passed, considered at once, so that the bill might be finally passed.

The steamer Polomska, from New-York for New-Bedford, struck on the rocks of Mishaun Point at 9 A. M. yesterday, during a thick fog and heavy gale. She soon knocked a hole in her and filled and sank. The captain and crew got ashore in safety and arrived at New-Bedford last night. The Potomska had thirty-five hundred barrels of flour and provisions on board.

There is truth as well as beauty in the axiom which promises good as the ultimate result of every occurrence. When FRRDINAND of Naples was ill and likely to die, millions of persons in Europe and America looked to the consummation of that apparent probability for the only favorable result of which it was capable.

The Royal Mail steamship Africa, NEIL SHANNON, Esq., Commander, from Liverpool, on Feb. 5, arrived here yesterday morning. The leading traits of the news have been received by telegraph from St. Johns, the Prince Albert having brought thither intelligence to the same date.

The Royal M...steamer Africa, from Liverpool Feb. 5, arrived here yesterday morning. Her dates are no later than those supplied by the Prince Albert at St. Johns, but the details are of profound I interest. The debate in both Houses of Parliament upon the Royal address brought the pacific policy of the Government prominently forward.

The steamship Quaker City arrived this evening with San Francisco dates of the 5th inst., and one hundred and three passengers. The Pacific mail steamship John L. Stephens. which left San Francisco on the 5th, had on board ?? 100,000 in treasure, of which $1,096,000 was for New-York, and the balance for England.

The friends of Professor James R. Lowell, in Boston, gave him a dinner at the Parker House, in that city, yesterday, on the occasion of his fortieth birthday. A few months since, the friends of Professor Agassiz entertained him at a dinner, at the same place, on his arriving at his fiftieth birthday.

Mr. KING presented a memorial from JOHN REEVES, naval architect, Brooklyn, asking that our Ministerr at Constantinople be instructed to urge his claim upon the Turkish Government. Referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations. Mr. FITCH, from the Committee on Printing, moved to reconsider the resolution to print 5,000 extra copies of the Coast Survey for distribution along the sea board.

ENGLISH CAPTURE OF CHINESE FORTS--THE U. S. FRIGATE MINNESOTA. We are in receipt of files of papers from Singapore to the 18th of December. The Straits Times of that date mentions the arrival at that port, on the 16th, of the United States steam-frigate Minnesota, having on board His Excellency Mr. REED, Minister Plenipotentiary to China.

THE PROPOSED ASTRONOMICAL OBSERVATORY IN THE CENTRAL PARK.--It is generally known that at the close of the course of lectures by Professor MITCHEL, a Provisional Board of Trustees was appointed, with instructions to obtain an estimate of the probable cost of a first-class Observatory, to mature a plan of operations, to obtain an Act of Incorporation and receive subscriptions to the Observatory fund.

The Nichols Investigating Committee nearly completed the taking of testimony to-day. The chief facts charged were positively sworn to. The witnesses for the defence contradict the testimony in some minor points, and the usual threats of arresting some of the prosecution's witnesses for perjury are uttered. The report will probably be made on Thurs day.

We chronicle in our columns this morning another painful case of a defaulting bank officer. There is nothing specially exciting in the affair, and, unhappily, it is not so novel an occurrence that any sensation is likely to be created by it in Wall-street, and the circumstance will probably pass out of the memory of the public before the end of the week. The greater the pity.

DEFALCATION OF A BANK TELLER IN BROOKLYN.--The first teller, or paying clerk, of the Atlantic Bank, Brooklyn, not making his appearance at his desk at the accustomed hour, suspicions were excited that there must be something wrong in his accounts. It was found that he left his home in Sackett-street, where be kept house, at his customary hour, that he took leave of his family in the usual manner, but had not since been seen.

He proposes do declare that whenever Spain may be willing to part with Cuba, the United States stand ready to treat for the transfer;

THE LAST SANDS.--This session of Congress draws to an end. An immense amount of business remains to be done, much of which must inevitably be neglected. Nothing has yet been accomplished towards adjusting our foreign relations or placing our domestic affairs on a better footing.

COLLINS--In this City, on Tuesday. Feb. 22, of scarlet fever, NASON B., only child of Nason B. and Louisa S. Collins. aged 1 year and 10 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Thursday, 24th inst.. at 1 o'clock P. M., from the residence of his parents, No. 23 West 32d st., without further invitation.

THE WASHINGTON CELEBRATION--ORATION OF THE HON. MR. BOTTS.--WASHINGTON'S birthday was celebrated yesterday with considerable eclat. The military companies were out in fall force, sundry patriotic orations were delivered, and the day went off with the noise and confusion usually attendant upon such celebrations.

He claimed that the benefits of the treaty in question are of the "jug-handle kind," meaning that they

HAVEMEYER.--In this City, on Monday, Feb, 21. of croup, ADA DIEDRICH HAVEMEYER, youngest daughter of the late Diedrich M. Havemeyer, aged 3 years and 10 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from her late residence, No. 199 West 14th it., on Friday, 25th inst., at 1 o'clock, without further invitation.

The Vice-President laid before the Senate the annual report of the Smithsonian Institution. Mr. HOUSTON, of Texas, gave notice that he would ask the indulgence of the Senate on Monday, to make a personal explanation. Mr. HUNTER, of Virginia, introduced a resolution that the Senate again meet at 11 o'clock daily. Laid over.

LAKE VESSSELS FOR THE OCEAN TRADE.--The initial attempts at direct trade between the Lake ports and Europe having been attended with so much success, Western shippers are preparing for enlarged enterprises during the coming season. A firm in Detroit advertise for the charter of twenty first-class vessels for the English, Hamburg, and British West India ports direct.

To the Senate: In reply to the resolution of your Honorable Body, requesting me to communicate whether any reports of Pardons or reprieves have been made from the Executive Department, as provided by section 5, article 4, of the Constitution, I have the honor to state that there is nothing on file or on record in this Department which would enable me to answer this inquiry.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Many unsuccessful attempts have been made by the friends of the Navy, that great arm of our protection, to have the law regulating the pay of our Navy officers so amended by Congress as to retain the most valuable officers and hold out an inducement for Americans to enter the service.

We have already called public attention to the recent decision of judge DAVIES in the case of the Cumberland Coal Company against SHERMAN and others. But the leading principle of that decision is one of so much importance, in its application to the general management of Corporations, that it merits more general attention that it has received.

THE MINT.--The annual amount of nonsense was ventilated on Tuesday in the Senate about the Mint in New-York. Pennsylvanians seem to labor under the chronic conviction that without the Mint Philadelphia would instantly become extinct-- and gentlemen from other sections apparently imagine that its location in New-York is considered indispensable to the prosperity of this City and State.
USURY LAWS IN OHIO.--The Ohio Legislature has just been exercising its wisdom upon the difficult subject of Usury. It has repeated the 10 per cent, and restored the 6 per cent. law. By the former,

HOPE CHAPEL.--Exhibitions of art are seldom neglected in a city, where a single picture creates an excitement. Sometimes however a very worthy exhibition may be overlooked by the public, or passed by from a district of its character. Such appears to be the case with "Illustrations o Washington and his Campaigns," at Hope Chapel.

The United States Mail steamship Fulton which left Liverpool on the 9th inst. for this port with four days' later European advices, is now in her fifteenth day, and fully due. She will bring intelligence of a highly important character, on which will probably depend the question of peace of war in Europe. The Royal Mail steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 12th, is also now about due at Halifax.

The news of the week is full of interest. The first subject that claims attention is that relating to the affairs of the Hudson's Bay Company. Some two years ago, public opinion in Canada was directed to the Northwest Territories, and it was thought desirable that colonization should be extended thither. So a special Delegate--A Canadian Ambassador--was sent to England, to get the claims of the Hudson's Bay Company set aside.

SPECIAL ELECTION IN THE TWENTY-NINTH SENATE DISTRICT.--In compliance with the requirements of t he statute, Governor MORGAN has ordered a special election in the Twenty-ninth Senate District, composed of the Counties of Genesee, Orleans and Niagara, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of the Hon. HORATIO H. Stow.

THE COLCHESTER BANK DEFALCATION--EXAMINATION OF CASHIER JONES.-The Norwich (Ct,) Bulletin of Feb. 22, says: JONES, the Colchester Bank cashier, was taken to Colchester yesterday afternoon, by Sheriff PAYNE and Deputy Sheriff CHAPELL for the preliminary examination.

Interesting Decisions. SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM-- FEB. 23. In the case of James Gallagher, convicted of the murder of Hugh Kelly on the 30th of June, 1857, at No. 12 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, a new trial has been granted. Opinion by Judge EMOTT. Gallagher was sentenced to be executed, but obtained a stay of proceedings just in time to save himself. He is continued in the Kings County Jail.

The present relations between the Ionians and their protectors display an amount of naivete on the part of the islanders, and an amount of good nature on the part of the British, that in these days of greed and astuteness are really quito refreshing.

The opening of the Boston Shoe and Leather Exchange in Codman Building, Hanover-street, took place to-day, and attracted a large crowd to the spacious focus. A collation was served, and speeches made by Governor BANKS, the Hon. AMASA WALKER. and various gentlemen interested in the shoe business. Mr. WALKER said the aggregate annual shoe trade in the State reached $50,000 000.

ARE WE A SHAROP PEOPLE, OR ARE WE NOT?.--Americans enjoy the reputation of having their eye-teeth pretty well developed, and are duly flattered thereby. The idea of being victimized in any business transaction is abhorrcut to Jonathan's nature. Of the two, if driven to so deadful an anlternative, he would rather cheat than be cheated.

The Daily News, in its issue of Jan. 27, announces that "The Emperor NAPOLEON has 400 000 at his command; but that if we deduct from this number 130.000 which he needs at Paris, a considers ?? force at Lyons, and the 70.000 men engaged in Algeria, there remain to him only 136,000 men to take the field in the event of war."

GILES--JONES.--In this City, on Tuesday. Feb. 22, by the Rev. Dr. Burchard, RICHARD GILES to Miss JOANNA. JONES, only daughter of S. W. Jones, Esq., all of this City. QUINTARD--ADAM,--In this City, on Wednesday, Feb 23, at the Rutgers St. Church. by the Rev. M. T. Adam, J. F. QUINTARD to MARY J., daughter of the officiating clergyman, all of this City.

The State Temperance Society have adopted resolutions condemnatory of the present Excise law. They have also issued an address, the main feature of which is the declaration that inasmuch as the State Administration has claimed and now exercises supreme authority over the police regulations of the City of New-York, and has established an army there, it is bound to enlorce the laws and put a stop to their gross violation.

The Organic Committee of the International Company of the Nicaragua Canal have dispatched two superior officers in the service of Her Britannic majesty, as Extraordinary Commissioners in Central America. These officers, with their state, left on the 2d of February, by the Southampton packed, proceeding directly to San Juan de Nicaragua, (Greytown) and thence to the presence of Generals MARTINEZ and MORA, Presidents of the two Republics of Nicaragua and Costa Rica.

Just at this time of the year, when we are about entering on the active Spring business, with three months' accumulation of fifth in our streets, the old subject of street cleaning naturally comes uppermost in the thoughts of the people of the City.

COURSE OF EVENTS IN THE INTERIOR. By the steamship Tennessee, we have in addition to our correspondence already given, newspaper accounts from all parts of the Republic. Those from the capital give a clear and connected narrative of the exciting events that have recently transpired therein They are as follows:

Congress seems determined to consume the remaining few days of the session in squabbles over amendments to the Appropriation bill. The debate in the Senate to-day on Kansas has been very fierce and interesting, chiefly between DOUGLAS and his friends and the Lecomptonites.

DEATH OF CHARLES PHILLIPS.--Mr. Charles Phillips died suddenly at London on the 31st January, in the 73d year of his age. He was a native of Sligo, Ireland; was a barrister at law, Commissioner successively of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Courts, and an Irish forensic orator whose early speeches attracted a good deal of attention in their day.

SEPULTURE OF AMERICANS IN ROMAN CATHOLIC COUNTRIES.--Mr. JAMES O. PUTNAM, who is travelling in Southern Europe, furnishes in a letter to the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser some interesting facts relative to the sepulture of our countrymen who happen to die in Spain. He found a beautiful cemetery in the outskirts of the City of Malaga, belonging to English Protestants.

THE ATLANTIC BANK DEFALCATIONS.--The teller of this Bank has not yet been arrested. He was with the cashier of the Bank until 4 o'clock P.M., Monday, at the Bank building, and then started for New-York, so that he must have been too late for the California steamer. Some of his friends think that he has committed suicide.

The Administration is in the receipt of letters from a high official source in Europe, expressing the opinion that a general war is almost certain. Popular opinion in England is opposed to war, but if forced to take a part, she will break up the grand alliance and unite with Russia.

The Corporation Counsel has responded to our demand for information concerning the one hundred and sixty-six judgments which have been obtained against the City. He sent to the Common Council last night a communication on the subject, which will be found in another column. It is a timely document,

The R. M. steamship Canada, Capt. LANG, from Liverpool at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 12th inst., arrived here at 6 1/2 o'clock this evening. Her dates are one week later than those already received. the Canada reports that on the 13th inst. she passed the Europa off Fastness. The steamship City of Washington, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool at 1 o'clock in the afternoon of the 11th inst.

Nothing of real interest transpired during the morning hour. Mr. HUNTER'S Motion that the senate meet daily at 11 o'clock was agreed to. The Chair laid before the senate a communication from the secretary of the Interior, inclosing a report of the wagon roads constructed under the authority of the United states.

On Wednesday evening the House was thin, but a good working order. Members refreshed with their vacation, but exhausted by their tedious ride back, sat unusually quiet, The variation had cleared their judgement and they saw more easily the right and he wrong, but they were too tired to talk, so they simply voted for or against, killing doubtful projects forthwith, and putting through what was proper with marvelous speed. The prayer was short.

Mr. PATTERSON presented a memorial from the State Temperance Society, asking for the repeal of the Excise law, and for protection against intemperance. BILLS PASSED. To authorize the Troy and Boston Railroad to construct a track in the City of Troy. To appropriate the proceeds of the State for the support of schools.

We learn that his proposition is in accordance with suggestions of leading insurance men, who consider such a department calculated to hinder the formation of bogus Companies,

MATTEES IN KANSAS.--Political and other affairs in Kansas seem to be setding down into a condition of quiet and general contentment. The people, as we predicted last Winter, do not seem specially anxious for admission into the Union, and will probably be very well satisfied to wait until their population shall come up to the mark required by the law of last year.

ARRESTED AND JEWELRY FOUND.--On Monday night last a fire occurred in a bedroom of the fourth story of the dwelling house No. 124 West Twenty-fifth-street, occupied by GEO. A. DE FRIETAS, which was soon extinguished. During the same night, and a short time after the fire, a quantity of diamond jewelry, valued at $1,500, was missed from the house.

The accompanying letter has been sent to the Ladies of the Mount Vernon Association, by C. H. Marshall Esq. NEW YORK MONDAY, Feb. 10, 1859. Mrs. PHILIP HAMILTON-Dear Madam: Some time since i sent you my contribution to the fund, a check for $50, to be applied to the noble object of purchasing the "mount Vernon Estate", so that the remains of the Father of his country may be preserved inviolate for ever.
