J., to HARRIET ELEANOR, daughter of the late Samuel Howard Fay., of Savannah, Ga.

THE NORTHERN BULL CORES THE SOUTHERN ON.--Our Southern brethren were very fond of Squatter Sovereignty when the Cincinnati Platform was constructed, and for some time afterwards. They were entirely willing that the Kansas settlers should manage matters as they pleased, so long as it seemed likely that a majority would be slaveholders.

AN AGREEABLE PIECE OF NEWS.--We learn from the Pennsylvania Inquirer that "Post-master-General BROWN has shown more than ordinary capacity in dealing with some of the great practical questions of the day." What the standard of ordinary capacity may be on the banks of the Delaware we do not know, but we should infer that it was not by any means high.

TERRIBLE GAS EXPLOSION.--A singular accident occurred at the south end of Rush-street Bridge on Saturday evening, about dusk, as the lamplighter was lighting the gas at the east side of the south abutment. The gas had escaped from a leak in the pipe, and had filled the space, some thirty feet long, in depth increasing from six to twelve feet and about six feet in width between the outer and inner wall of the abutment,

BLUSTERING WEATHER--DEATH OF AN OFFICES OF THE BRITISH ARMY--THE STEAM TRANSPORT SHIT MELBOURNT. Our file of the Sleeping compartment extends to Feb. 9. The month had been inaugurated by severe weather, with heavy gales--the first touch of genuine Winter the Islanders had experienced.

Three hundred thousand pounds of medium and one hundred thousand pounds of the finer sorts of wool were sold at auction, to day, by Messrs. BINGHAM, JOY CO. Purchasers were present from New-York, Philadelphia, Albany and other cities. The sales were brisk and the prices considered good.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada arrived at Halifax last evening, bringing at week's later intelligence from Europe. She left Liverpool on the 12th inst. The proceedings of Parliament had been unimportant. Affairs on the Continent appear to be still in a very unsettled condition.

The steamer Prince Albert, Captain NICHOLSON, from Galway on the 5th inst., and St. Johns N. F., on the 19th, arrived at this port yesterday morning, shortly after 10 o'clock. Among her passengers was Mr. WM. SMITH O'BRIEN, whose coming had already been announced by telegraph from St. Johns.

Yesterday was an exciting day in Congress, and the proceedings were in the highest degree interesting. The Cuban bill was taken up in the Senate, after the passage of the Post-routes bill, and very fully discourage Arrangements were agreed upon for an all night session, it being understood that sixteen speeches were to be made on the subject on the Republican side alone.

Congressional legislation is considered at an end for the present cession. The war of the factions defeats business, and the chances are that the several appropriation bills will fail. Many members have avowed their determination to vote against every thing, Mr. PHELPS, to-day, charged PHILLIPS, of Pennsylvania, with having declared his intention to vote against every Appropriation bill.

The Panama Railroad Company's rig E. Drummond, Captain CONWAY, arrived yesterday from Aspinwall, making the passage in 17 days. she brings advices from the Isthmus, Central America and South America four days later than those brought by the steamer Mosts Taylor.

BAKER.--In this City, on Friday morning, Feb. 25, the Rev. THOMAS BAKER, aged 59 years; for 20 years a local preacher of the M. E. Church, and for nearly 30 years connected with the Methodist Book Concern in this City. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the Greene st. M. E. Church, on Sunday afternoon, at 3 o'clock.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There are somewhat more than five millions of Germans in the United States, almost all belonging to the most useful classes of our population, distinguishing themselves by hard working in all branches of agriculture, the mechanic arts and commerce, generally moderate in their manner of living, and comparatively well educated.

The Senate has acted upon the Postage question more suo. Instead of responding to the popular demand for cheaper postage, it has passed a bill restoring the abandoned schedule of the act of 1845, and obliging the people to pay an average of one hundred per cent. more for the transmission of letters.

M., in the Lecture Room of the North Dutch Church. The Rev. MATTHEW HALE SMITH conducted the services, which consisted of reading of the Sculpture, an appropriate address singing and prayer.

AN INDEPENDENT CANDIDATE FOR CONGRESS.--The Hon. EZRA CLARK. Republican Member of Congress from the First (Hartford) District of Connection-out, has published a letter to his constituents offering himself for reflection. He claims that the delcgates who met in Convention a short time ago and nominated Mr. DWIGHT LOOMIS, misrepresented their constituents through the influence of a clique at Hartford.

CHAIRMAN AND GENTLEMEN OF THE COMMITTEE: As Counsel for those who have made application to the legislature for permission to establish this railway, I am to lay before you the reasons which they conceive should induce you to grant it. Business continues rather depressed, at al although in anything there hail been improvement until the occurrences of the last few days. News has been received here of an outbreak in Copiape. This took place amount the 5th inst. among the city police, who are a military body ; the extent of this movement is at present uncertain. The steam frigate Esmeralda has been dispatched with troops to quell the revolt.

The most startling incident in the news of the morning is the dreadful homicide of PHILIP BARTON KEY by the lion. DANIEL E. SICKLES, of this City. The details of this sad affair will be found in our special dispatches from Washington. They give all the facts essential to the case. Mr. KEY had inflicted upon Mr. SICKLES the greatest injury and the most intolerable dishonor possible.

To the Editor of the New-York Times; When all execution against the property his been returned unsatisfied, the law of our State allows an examination of the judgment debtor. under oath, to discover what property he has. Such examination may be had before a judge, out of Court, or before a referee.

ENFORCING THE POLICE LAWS. -- It is reported that the Police Commissioners have at length determined to enforce the rules adopted for the government of the Police Department. It is said that smoking while on duty, being off heat at roll call, or visiting saloons to obtain refreshments will, if reported, be followed either by a fine or dismissal from the service.

LIFE INSURANCE--A NOVEL DEFENCE.--We publish a communication in another column calling attention to the peculiar character of the defence set up in Court by a Life Insurance Company of this policics. It seems that the Company had insured the life of a wife for the benefit of her husband, and had continued for five years to receive the premium therefor.

No. 189 East 19th-st., on Tuesday, March 1, at 11 o'clock A. M. The remains will be taken to New-Haven for interment. Hartford and New-Haven papers please copy.

The following is Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSMLEY'S speech on presenting his credentials to the President of Niearagua: The Queen, my august Sovereign, has graciously confident to me the agreeable duty of cementing the good feeling, and of making known the sentiments of friendly interests that have always animated Great Britain towards the State that you Excellency so worthily presides over, concluding a treaty which, it is calculated, will produce the best effect.

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--A colored lady named ALEXANDER VANDERVEER, accompanied by several white boys, attempted to steal to ride on the New Jersey Railroad, yesterday afternoon, by getting on top of the cars of an outward-bound train. On arriving at the Hackensack Bridge, the train stopped on a side track to allow an inward-bound train to pass as there is a single track at this point.

The voice of the law has yet to be heard upon the true character, as before the justice of the land, of the terrible transaction which, on the day before yesterday, stained the Sabbath of the National Metropolis with Passionate blood Passionately shod, and made a Legislator of the Union, sworn to calmness, wisdom, Self-restrain, the slayer of his fellow-man.

THE PRESIDENT'S VETO OF THE AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE GRANTS,--We Publish the Message of the President vetoing the act of Congress making donations of the public lands to the serveral States for the establishment of Agricultural Colleges. The views which it sets forth, in a difluse, inelegant and obscure style, strike us as sound, sensible and timely.

IMPORTATION OF CHINESE SEEDS. --The Washington Union learns that dispatches have been received by the Commissioner of Patents, from Mr. BOBERY FORTUNE, bearing date at Shaughae, as recent as the Oils of December, inclosing bills of lading for large quantities of tea seeds packed in earth; Yangmae the and its seeds; seeds of the Camphor, tree, Tung-oil tree, and the "On-dang."

ELLSWORTH, in February, 1851, by which will M. E. bequeaths two-tenths of his property equally to Wabash. College, Yale College, the american Bible Society and the American Colonization Society. CONTINUED RAINS--NEW TREATY--NAVIGATION OF THE AMAZON -- A TRAGEDY -- THE COFFEE MARKET. Our files of Rio Papers extend to Jan. 13---five days later. The rains continued and had inflicted serious damage in the suburbs of the city.

There was large meeting of the Deaf Mutes of Boston and Vicinity in Tremont Temple. on Tuesday evening, to consider the best manner of proceeding in the matter of the petitions to the General Court for a State Institution for the Deaf and Dumb, now under consideration by the Committee on Charitable Institutions. Charles Barrett presided.

In the House, on the 24th inst., Mr. NICHOLS, from the Select Committee which was appointed to investigate charges against a member of the Committee on Accounts, made in the Washington correspondence of the NEW-YORK TIMES, made the following report: The Committee in executing the order of the House, brought before them the witnesses whose testimony is here with appended.

The steamboat Princess from Vicksburg for New-Orleans, exploded her boiler, caught fire and burned to the water's edge at Conrad's Point, near Baton Rouge, on Sunday morning. Four hundred passengers were on board of her at the time, two hundred of whom are lost and missing-mostly residents of Louisiana and Mississippi. A large number of those on board were ladies.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I want the Privilege of saying a few words in your columns about the City Hall Park, while there is pending, I believe, some proposition to alter it. First--I don't own a foot of land within a mile and a half of it, and never expect to. Second--It is a nuisance. The trees are a nuisance,

To the House of Representatives of the United States: I return, with my objections, to the House of Representatives, in which it originated, the bill entitled "An act donating public lands to the several States and Territories which may provide colleges for the benefit of agriculture and the mechanic arts." presented to me on the 18th inst.

The screw-steamship City of Baltimore, Capt. LEITCH, which sailed from Liverpool at about 10:30 on the morning of the 16th of February, arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning. The steamship Europa arrived out at Liverpool at 8:20 P. M. on the 14th.

Mr. ELY reported complete the bill relative to reorganizing the Health Department of New-York under medical officers. The bill was ordered to a third reading. Mr. CHALEE. introduced a bill to extend the time for the collection of taxes in the whole State. The bill was intended to obviate the difficulty of the Governor's vote.

An invitation was sent to Mr. EVERETT some time ago, by prominent citizens, to repeat his lecture of FRANKLIN, recently delivered in Boston, in this City, to which he has returned the following reply: BOSTON, Friday, Feb. 25, 1859. GENTLEMEN: Your old-gang communication, dated the 3d February, was transmitted to me a day or two since, I shall have much pleasure,

STABBING IN MOTT-STREET.--Thomas Farrell, residing at No. 71 Mott-street, after leaving a drinking saloon in his vicinity on Sunday night, fell upon the pavement. Upon regaining his feet Farrell accused Patrick O'Mally of having tripped him. Patrick denied the charge, and upon Farrell reiterating it, became indignant and stabbed his accuser twice,

The bill known as the "Certain Punishment Bill"--Providing for the trial of Staten Island Incendiaries, was reached in Committee of the Whole this morning. Mr. JOHNSON, of Delaware, made a long and strong speech in its favor, reviewing the constitutional objections. Mr. CHRISTIE, of Richmond County, followed, overhauling the arguments that had been made by its friends.

SEQUESTRATION OF PROPERTY OF SOULOUQUE'S MINISTERS---GEFFRARD STILL POPULAR--COMPLIMENT TO THE FRENCH CONSUL---THE ORIGIN OF THE REVOLUTION. By the brig S. Bouler, at Boston, We have received Hayti advices to Feb. 5, with over a week's later intelligence.

INTERESTING MEETING OF THE SABBATH COMMITTEE---ADDRESSES BY MESSRS COOK, DODGE TRACY AND DR. ADAMS. The attendance at the meeting in behalf of Sabath Observance, at the Cooper Institute on Sunday evening, was large, with an unusual proportion of our more prominent citizens.

BURNING OF THE UTICA THEATER.--The Utica Theatre, at Utica, N. Y., was destroyed by fire on Sunday, Feb. 27; loss $18,000. The house was occupied on the previous evening by the Zavistowski juvenile troupe, and was closed at midnight. It is supposed that by some accident fire was communicated to the scenery.

THE NOVEL DEFENCE OF AN INSURANCE COMPANY,--We noticed on Monday the extraordinary course of the Unites States Life Insurance Company in contesting payment of one of their policies, on the ground that it insured a wife's life for the benefit of the husband, and that it was therefore a mere bet,--and as a gambling transaction, not entitled to the protection of the law.

Ten thousand bags of linseed, 1,000 bales of cotton, 200 bales of gunny bags, and 150 bales of gunny cloth were destroyed, as also a large quantity of saltpetre In the U. S. Warehouse cellar adjoining by water.

We published yesterday morning, a full summary of the leading items of intelligence brought by the steamer City of Baltimore. We add this morning such extracts from our foreign files as seem to have special interest or importance:

The most interesting feature in the intelligence by the City of Baltimore is the debate in the House of Lords upon the Right of Search and the suppression of the African Slave-trade. There is a most gratifying unanimity of opinion among all parties that the Right of Search, as generally understood, has no foundation in international law, and can never be maintained

Galignani says: "The marriage of M. Roths-child, Jr., with the daughter of M. Anspach, judge of the imperial Court, took place at the synagogue in the Rue Notre-Dame de Nazareth. The signature of the contract took place on the previous day at the Hotel Rothschild, in presence of the number of distinguished personages. The synagogue was filled up in a very superb manner for the occasion, and the altar was dazzling with lights.

The Evening Post of this City, recoiling from the natural indignation provoked by its manner of dealing with the recent tragedy at Washington, now seeks to vex still further the public feeling by a sort of polemic in favor of adultery, as compared with assassination, in which we have not the least disposition to interfere.

THE ITALIAN EXILES.--We are very glad to see that the Italians resident in the City are taking steps to receive and welcome the Neapolitan exiles now on their way to this port; and that they seem far more anxious to extend to them needed aid and comfort than to make a parade over their sufferings or their services.

A boat arrived from the wreck of the Princess bringing a number of the wounded. It was foggy at the time of the explosion, and the Princess being behind time had too much steam on. A Baton Rouge dispatch says the engineer is reported to have said he would reach the engineer is reported to have said he would reach New-Orleans certain on time or blow up.

A new claimant for the ancient Irish title and Barony of ?? in about to appear in the person of Mr. FIRZ-JAMES O'BREES, of this City, on the death of the last Marquess of THOMOND, Sir LUCIUS O'BRIEN, brother to the distinguished patriot Mr. SMITH O'BRIEN, resumed the title of Lord INCHIQUIN without authority from the Herald's College or the Crown.

Etymologists have long been puzzled to decide why the name of levees should be given to the occasions on which his "Highness the President of the United States and Protector of their Liberties" (how beautifully appropriate this title would have been to the actual occupant of the White House ?? receives the sovereigns of thirty-three States and the "casual inhabitants" of any number of Territories.

Count DE SALTIGES, the French Minister, is removed, and the Visconte DE SEREE, at present at Carlsbad, near Baden, is appointed here. He is, like Lord LYONS, a bachelor. Nicaraguan dispatches arrived this morning, for the Government, to the 29th ult., and for Gen. JEREZ to the 27th. Both the English and the American Treaties wee pending before the Nicaraguan Congress--neither of them having been confirmed.

The Senatorial Investigating Committee met again this afternoon. HIRAM M. EATON was examined. He testified he had called on W. D. MURPHY, Clerk of the Committee, in order to discover if he was the party influencing the Chairman of that Cornmittee, and if so, what his motives were. He offered him five hundred dollars to use his influence to suppress the investigation.

One of the crying evils, which for years there have been desperate but unsuccessful efforts to reform, is the outrageous inequality of the taxes which counties of equal resources are compelled to pay into the State Treasury. In the County of New-York and Kings, property is assessed by the assessors at, as near as may be, the price which it would fetch at auction.

The bill to provide for the enlargement of the Clinton Prison was reported favorably. On motion of Mr. MATHER, the bill to repeal the Metropolitan Police act was made the special order for Tuesday next. Mr. BRANDRETH inquired whether any results have been attained by the Committees of Investigation on the alleged corruption of the Legislature.

THE ANCIENT BRITON'S BENEFIT SOCIETY.--This Society. Instituted May 5, 1805, celebrated its Fifty-fourth Anniversary yesterday, at St. David's Hall, Canal-street. The President (W. M. JONES, Esq.) called the Society to order at 1 1/2 o'clock P.M., when the Secretary presented the fifty-fourth annual report, from which we gather the following facts:

The dreadful tragedy of Sunday still continues to agitate the community here. There are few additional facts relative to the ead affair. Mrs. SICKLES' parents both visited Mr. SICKLES in jail to-day. He had an interview with his own father also, which was affecting in the extreme.

POSTAL ARRANGEMENTS.--A bill passed the House of Representatives a day or two since which ought to meet the prompt concurrence of the senate. Its object was to regulate the payment of postage on newspapers and periodicals. It provided that dealers in newspapers and periodicals might receive such quantities of either as they may require, and pay postage

The Senate, on assembling, went into Executive Session till 12 o'clock, after which Mr. SHIELDS presented the credentials at Mr. DOUGLAS, reelected for six years. The Post-Office Appropriation bill was taken up. Mr. YULEE, from the Committee, appended to this bill a clause similar to that on the Post Routes bill, raising the rate of postage to five cents, and abolishing the franking privilege. Agreed to, Yeas. 29 ; Nays, 28.

There was a call of the House this morning, at 10 1/4 o'clock. A German made the opening prayer, and some forty members were present. The Clerk began to read the Journal, but it being evident that no quorum was present, a call was ordered. The Speaker ordered the lobbies cleared and the doors closed.

HENRY J. IRVIN was examined to-day before the Committee, to investigate the passage of the Albany Bridge Bill. He testified that he was a member of the Legislature of 1857, and that he had no personal knowledge of any improper influences, or of any money being used to secure the passage or the defeat of the Albany Bridge bill in 1850, or the amendment to it in 1857.

FRIVOLOUS CAUSES OF DIVORCE--We do not think that the general public will find much reason for congratulation in the frequency with which divorce cases are brought before them. Indeed, it may be said that suits of this character are painfully common.

NEGRETE, recently in command of centralist troops at Perote, stood. The St. Joseph correspondent of the Republican, under date of the 27th alt., says, that a special message from, Platte City brings information that DAY and his son, who were confined on the charge of running off negroes, were forcibly taken from the jail last night by a mob of three hundred men and hung.

Mr. SEWARD explained that if he had been present at the vote on the Naval bill, he should have voted against Mr. HAMMOND'S amendment to increase the appropriations for the Navy-yards at New-York and elsewhere. Mr. THOMPSON, of Kentucky, presented the credentials of LAZAHUS W. POWELL, as his successor.

MELANCHOLY SUICIDE IN BALTIMORE.--About 8 o'clock yesterday morning, a young man, who, from papers and clothing in his possession, is supposed to be named ORLANDO F. PARSONS, is supposed to be named boarding house of Mrs. ELIZABETH WILSON, No. 64 South Eutaw-street, by shooting himself through the right side of the head with a small ride barreled pocket-pistol.

THE CITY COURT.--The Law Committee is whom was referred matters relative to the City court, reported : That they met on the 25th February, and examined JOHN RYERSON and SAMUEL L. HARRIS, Clerk of the City Court, from whose testimony it appears that the Judge of the City Court has been in the habit of excusing Jurors from Jury duty on payment of sums of money,

LEGISLATIVE DOINGS IN CANADA.--On Monday the House of Assembly, at Toronto, resolved, by a vote of 43 to 10, that the per diem of members should be increased from $4 to $6. This action is denounced by the Globe, Opposition, organ, as being "to the shame of the Government." There is little hope left, that papers says, of even ordinary retrenchment at the present session.

An old political feud has existed for some time between THOMAS S. LOW, of Hawesville, and CICERO MAXWELL, of Hartford, Ky., the prosecuting Attorney for that District. Mr. Low had threatened to cowhide Mr. MANWELL on meeting him. To-day, while Mr. MAXWELL was addressing the Court at Hawesville, he was interrupted by Mr. Low, denouncing him in gressly insulting language.

RICHMOND COUNTY.--The Legislature is apparently disposed to gratify Staten Island, by removing the Quarantine, whether a new place to put it can be found or not. That body recognizes as natural and proper the aversion of our insular neighbor to the proximity of Yellow Jack.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Like the old woman who had been "enjoying had health for many years," I may introduce myself as one who has long enjoyed the most dismal experiences of City law and City lawyers. It has been my unhappy fortune, every day, to sec fundamental provisions of the Charter contemptuously ignored;

ACADEMY OF MEDICINE--DELETERIOUS EFFECTS OF WELL-MILK.--At the regular meeting of the Academy of Medicine last night, a report was presented on behalf of the Committee to whom had been referred the matter of preparing a reply to Mayor TIEMANN'S inquiry as to the effect on the human system of the milk of swill-fed cows. The report was read by Dr. SAMUEL R. PERRY.

A DIVORCE EPIDEMIC IN PITTSBURG.--The Pittsburg Gazette says: "Judge M'CLURE took occasion on Saturday to refer to the increasing number of applications for divorce that come before him. He says there as hardly a Saturday, at least, when he does not early home a pocket full of depositions in eases which are absolutely too outrageous and disgusting to be called up before the Court.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 16th ult., with three days later advices from Europe, is now about due at this port, Nothing had been seen of her at Sandy Hook at 2 o'clock this morning. The proceedings of Congress, yesterday, were highly interesting and important,

HANCOCK AND WASHINGTON.--In spite of Mr. HAWTHORNE'S doctrine that men should live intents, and that each generation should burn the bones of its predecessor, the world, even the world of America, refuses to believe that the universe really came into being the day before yesterday, and obstinately persists in setting a certain value on all that is associated with the sorrows and the glories of the dead.

A distinguished member of the Bar in this City happened some time since to be dining with P. BARTON KEY, Esq., who has just ended his career at Washington. After dinner the conversation turned upon the constancy of women, and Mrs. KEY expressed and defended with great warmth the opinion that women were naturally inconstant,

It has been quite evident for a long time that the action of the President has completely disorganized the Democratic party. No such thing as confidence in Mr. BUCHANAN has been evinced by the party that placed him in power since his remarkable tergiversation on the Kansas question.

The usual bill, making appropriations for the Ocean Mail service, has been killed the House of Representatives. As the time is extremely short between this legislative achievement and the close of the session, it appears likely that the postmaster--general will lack his ordinary resources for subsidizing the packet service,

Prof. W. W. Mather, acting President of the University of Ohio, died at Columbus, Feb, 20. He was educated for the army, graduated at West Point in 1828, was appointed First-Lieutenant in 1834, but resigned his commission two years later, and afterwards turned his attention wholly to scientific pursuits.

Postmaster-Gen. BROWN is probably in a critical condition. He has been ill for several days of pneu- a monia, but this afternoon appeared much Improved. To-night, however, hemorrhage set in, from which It is feared he will die before morning. Such, I am assured, is the opinion of his medical advisers. The latest advices from him state that he Is somewhat easier, but his physicians give little hope of his surviving this illness.

The State Temperance Society, which ?? its annual meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday of last week , at the city of Albany, made a slight dip into polities--whereat the Tribune is rejoiced, and the Evening Journal displeased.

CASE OF MRS. HARTUNG.--The wretched woman recently convicted at Albany of the murder of her husband has been denied a new trial by the Supreme Court, and it is Scarcely likely that an appeal will be made. Indeed, it is difficult to see how she could be benefited by a rehearing.

Our Territorial Legislature is still in session at the seat of Government, though it was confidently expected that their labors wold be cut short this week by the news of our admission. Though our adopted Constitution expressly prohibits Slavery, a nice little experiment is being made by certain restless agitators, who have petitioned the Legislature for the passage of a law protecting slave property in this Territory.

DEAR SIR: You are doubtless aware that the "American Tract Society" was originally organized at Boston in 1814; eleven years before the Institution of the same name in New-York. It was at first designated as the "New-England Tract Society," which name was changed by an act of the Legislature, in 1823, to that it now bears. During these eleven years it was In vigorous and successful operation.

We have kept our readers tolerably well advised of the changes in English law as to divorce. Many advantages have followed from this reform, but one which was confidently anticipated from it has not yet flowed therefrom.

As much speculation has been indulged in regard to the return by Mr. SICKLES to his wife of the wedding-ring, the following detail may possess interest. It appears that Mr. SICKLES was called upon by the clergyman and informed that Mrs. SICKLES was in great mental agony, and under extreme physical suffering, and that if such a state of feeling continued long to exist, it would probably end in mental aberration or, perhaps, self-destruction.

Mr. FERDINAND RETCHAROT, a German artist of ability, has been making a tour through this country with the object of illustrating its most striking features, in a series of engineerings, shortly to the published. The drawings and paintings which he has thus accumulated are now on exhibition at the rooms of the National Academy of Design, in Tenth-street, and will deserve a visit.

Our "Opposition" State Convention met in this city on the morning of the 22d, and adjourned yesterday noon, after a harmonious and otherwise quite remarkable session. Its delegates represented the Opposition of eighty odd Counties of Kentucky, and mustered to the number of about a thousand.

The Post finds it convenient to change the nature of its dastardly insinuations against the TIMES. It began by alleging that we were the " Apolegists of Assassination," because we did not emulate the ferocity of its own denunciations of a man who had slain the seducer of his wife.

WIFE-MURDER AT COHOES, N. Y. --A WOMAN CHOPPED INTO PIECES.--The Albany Evening Journal says that on the night of March 1, at Cohoes, an Irishman named MICHAEL O'BRIEN, employed in SIMMONS' axe-factory. murdered his wife. Her body was found chopped into pieces. Her head had apparently been cut open with an axe or batchet.

THE STORM.--The blustering northwesters of the first three days of the week got tired of piping oil of that quarter, and, during Wednesday night, changed to the eastward, and a certain "raw" and hazy condition of the atmosphere, yesterday morning, gave unmistakable symptoms of " a spell weather."

KINGS COUNTY BIBLE SOCIETY.--The eighteenth anniversary at this Society was to have been celebrated last night, but owing to the storm the exercisos were postpored until next week. THE LIQUOR CASES.--It is understood that the Court of Sessions will procces with the trial of parties for sclling liquor without license to-day.

The President has determined to appoint Hon. HORERT MCLANE, of Maryland, as Minister to Mexico. The nomination Is expected to be sent to the Scnate on Saturday. The programme is to send him out without instructions restricting him as to his course, but leaving it to his discretion to recognize either The Church party or the Liberals, or neither.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There is a character in " Jack Easy," if we recollect aright, who insists that everything that occurs is only a duplicate of the events that took place thousands of years ago. Nor is the theory so utterly wanting in proof as at the first glance may be supposed.

Before Justice Ingraham. Petition of Michael Quinin.--This is a habcas corpus, on which a husband claims the care and custody of the children, now in the charge of the wife. The wife answers that she and her husband have separated ; that the causes of the separation were differerces in religion ;

THE EXECUTIVE AND THE SABBATH.--Gov. MORGAN is reported to have asserted a prerogative which few sensible people will regard as either tyrannical or unwarranted. He claims his Sundays as his own. On that day the door of his private dwelling is inexorably closed to the demands of business and politics.

The President, it appears, has got over the difficulty of selecting an suitable person to succeed Mr. FORSYTH as Minister to Mexico, and has determined to appoint the Hon. ROBERT McLANE. of Maryland, to that position. He is to be sent out untrammeled by instructions, and with full liberty to recognize whichever Government he may think proper, or neither, in his own discretion.

The California Mail arrived here to-day with California dates of the 7th ultino. There were no through passengers. The steamer Hermann had been sold by the United States Marshal for $10,000, to Captain GEO. WRIGHT.

THE MURDER AT COHOES.--ARREST OF THE MURDERER.--The man O' BRIAN, who murdered his wife, at Cohoes, N. Y., and day or two since, has been arrested. The testimony taken at the Coroner's inquest developed the follow murder: The murder was perpetrated before midnight, on Tuesday, March 1. O'BRIAN Called at the house or Mrs. FITZSIMMONS, about 11 o'clock on Tuesday night, and told her that NELLY (the deceased) was dead."

PUBLIC BILLS PASHED. An act giving the assent of Congress to a law of the Missouri Legislature for the application of the reserved two per cent. funds of said State. An act to protect the land fund for school purposes in Sarpy County, Nebraska Territory. An act to confirm the land claim of certain Pueblos and towns in the T'erritory of New- Mlexico. An act providing for keeping and distributing all public documents.

The President of the United States, If we are to take him at his word, is in a chronic state of surprise. He precisely reverses the mental condition of Mr. Micawber; for whereas that buoyant gentleman was constantly expecting something to turn up, in the case of Mr. BUCHANAN nothing that ever turns up is the thing that he expected.

The telegraph announces the execution of Dr. Doy and his son, of Kansas, by a Missouri mob. The Albany Evening Journal says of the elder Doy: "Dr. Doy was for several years a citizen of Roeheater. He was among the earliest emigrants from Western NewYork to Kansas.

It is a lamentable proof of the imperfect idees vie all have of civilization and proper mental cultivation, that in proportion as education and civilization are supposed to be progressing among us ?? is also on the increase.

Two judgments have recently been rendered against City Railroad Corporations, at the suit of parties by whom severe injuries were sustained, in consequence of the carelessness or recklessness of agents or officers of the Companies. These cases will hereafter serve as precedents.

Immediately after the adjournment of Congress to-day, the Senate commenced its extraordinary Executive Session, in accordance with the proclamation of the President. The new Senators, whose credentials had previously been presented, were sworn in.

BOSTON JOURNALISM.-The BOSTON Courier, in a business prospectus, states that since it went into the hands of its present owners its circulation has increased three-fold. Its managing editor is Mr. JOHN CLARE, and his principal writing assistants are Messrs. Gro. S. HILLARD and GEO. LUXT. Both these gentlemen are scholars, men of thought and culture, and brilliant writers.

MAYCOCK.--In this City, on Friday, March 4, after a short illness, SAMUEL MAYCOCK, Esq.. in the 59th year of his age. His relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, at his late residence, No. 621 2d av., between 37th and 38th st., on Monday. 7th inst., at 11 o'clock A.M. without further invitation. His remains will be taken to Trinity Cemetery for interment.

BILL FOR EQUALIZNG TAXES.-Taxes constitute one of the most delicate an difficult subjects which can fall under legislative cognizance. The Legislature at Albany is laudably engaged in an attempt to comply with a recommendation of the Governor that some remedy be found for the present inequitable mode of making assessments.

The R. M. steamship Europa, which left Liverpool on the 19th of February, for this port, with three day's later European advices, is now fully due. She had not been signaled at Sandy Hook at 2 o'clock this morning. Congress continued in session until 12 'clock yesterday noon, when it expired by limitation, after being constantly at work during the last sitting for about 25 hours.

Judge INGERSOLL has sent down a decision in the following case, heard before him last month: Solomon B. Ellithorps vs. J. W. Robertson et al.--This was an application for a decree. Robertson was the only defendant on whom the subpoena was served and he made default so that the bill was taken proconfesso against him.

The investigation of tile complaint preferred against Office WYNKOOP, by Sergeant BERNRY, was resumed at 11 A. M., yesterday, before Police Commissioner BOWEN. A large number of Policemen, iuterested in tile proceedings, were present. Officer L. Place was examined-He knew nothing pertinent to the issue; he had received $50 once to put in the Fund for the Relief of Widows and Orphans of Policemen.

To the Hon. EDWARD EVERETT: DEAR SIR: We respectfully request that, if consistent with your engagements, you would favor our citizens, at an early day, with the address you have recently prepared upon the " Character of FRANKLIN," and, if agreeable to you, under the auspices of the Mercantile Library Association of this City.

BASKIN, of New-York, the nearest friend of Mr. SICALES."

A perusal of the Sixth Annual Report of the Children's Aid Society strengthens the conviction we have repeatedly expressed that, for tile working of great practical and permanent good, this enterprise deserves the front rank among the reformatory movements of the day.

The sales of COTTON, to-day, were 2,025 bales, market closing with an advancing tendency. Sales of the week, 9,500 bales. Receipts of the week, 5,200 bales, against 12,500 in the corresponding week last year. Increased receipts at this port, 182,000 bales; do, at all the ports, 958,000 bales. Stock at Savannah, 59,500 bales.

" A VERY DRAB"--The "last word" is proverbially the privilege of scolds and slanderers, and we therefore gladly concede it to the Evening Post. That journal made its first stealthy allusion to the dreadful exposure it might make of the TIMESes, were it only cruel enough to do so, under the reservation that in so doing it might " perhaps do injustice."

The execution of FLEMING, the Telegraph operator and O'LEARY, who were both found guilty of murder, at the last assizes, took place to-day in presence of a vast number of spectators. O'LEARY was attended by a Catholic clergyman, and read a short confession on the gallows. FLEMING was attended by a Protestant clergyman.

Quite a large meeting of the German population assembled at the Turner Hall last night, and adopted resolutions denouncing the measure requiring two years' residence, after naturalization, before being allowed to vote. The speeches were mostly in German CHARLES SAMPSON, of the publishing firm of PHILLIPS SAMPSON, died yesterday at his residence in Bro ok line, of consumption, at the age of 41 years.
PUTNAM--MENDELL.--In this City, on Thursday, on Thursday, March 3, by the Rev. E. T. Hiscox, D.D., Mr. O. H. SWIFT to JULIA A., second daughter of William Conklin, Esq., all of this City.

THE HON. EDWARD EVERETT'S ORATION ON WASIHINGTON-An immense throng was in attendance at the Academy of Music last evening to hear the lion. EDWAED EVRRETT repeat his oration on the "Character of WASHINGTON." No sooner were the doors of the building thrown open than every eligible seat was occupied.

Had the late unlamented KEY really produced the lines you are asked to accept as his, in this day's issue of your paper, he might be esteemed as even more of a poet than his father. The truth is, the verses are not translated from the Castilian of anybody, nor are they KEY'S.

BALTIMORE.--Weather clear and pleasant. WASHINGTON.--Weather clear and pleasant. PETERSBURG.--Weather clear and pleasant. NORFOLK.--Therm. 58[degrees]; wind S. W. WILMINGTON.--Clear and pleasant. CHARLESTON.--Clear; therm.53; wind N. E. AUGUSTA.--Weather pleasant. SAVANNAH.--Clear; therm. 53[degree]; wind W. S. W.

JAMES Y. McCGUFFIE, of Georgia, has been appointed Superintendent of Indian Affairs in California, vice HENLY, removed. Colonel G. W. GROLSON, of Mississippi, has been appointed Governor of Washington Territory, vice McMULLEN, resigned.

NEW SCHOOL BUILDING.--The Board of Education has recently completed a Public School building at the corner of Navy and Concord streets, No. 14, on the site of the former building of that number destroyed by fire something more than a year ago, when several children were suffocated, which was opened with appropriate exercises yesterday.

THE COLCHESTER BANK CASE--THE EXAMINATION OF JONES POSTPONED,--On the 2d inst. the examination of JONES, the defaulting cashier of the Colchester Bank, was postponed at Colchester for two weeks. Before the adjournment, Mr. SHARP, the book-keeper of the bank, was called to make a correction in his evidence given the day before.

Mr. SEWARD will receive the thanks of all friends of justice and humanity for his successful resistance of the attempt made in the Senate on Thursday night to pass a billremoving the remains of the Confederated Irequois of this State from their ancient seats to now and strange abodes in the far West.

The testimony is voluminous. The prosecution brings proof to show that the pretence of fitting out the ship as a whaler is set aside by the exposure of the character of her outfit. One witness.

DEATH OF MR. MARRON.--The death of JOHN MARRON, Esq., Third Assistant Postmaster-General, which took place last Friday at Washington, will cause a very wide regret. Mr. MARRON has for many years, and under several Administrations, held his place, and had the practical guidance of the financial affairs of the Postal Department.

The following have passed both branches of the Indiana Legislature: A license law regulating the sale of liquors; law submitting the question of holding a Constitutional Convention to the vote of the people at the next October election; an act directing the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund to purchase $400,000 to $500,000 worth of five and two-and-a half per cent.

The steamship Tennessee, Captain FORBES, from Vera Cruz Feb. 22, arrived at New-Orleans on the 25th. The extraordinary, which should have left the capital the morning of the 20th. to connect with the Tennessee, had not arrived up to the hour of her departure, 6 P. M. the 22nd.

The screw-steamer Jura, Captain MOODIE, of the extra Cunard line, from Liverpool on the morning of Feb. 18, arrived at this port about 8 o'clock A.M., yesterday. On the 19th ult., in lat. 51[degrees] 34[minutes], long, 8[degrees] 25[minutes], she passed the Royal Mail steamship Arabia, bound to Liverpool.

The Postmaster-General is believed to be dying, The President and Cabinet are with him. General HOUSTON declined the Mission to Mexico. Mr. McLANE'S nomination will be sent in to-morrow, Mr. THRASHER was telegraphed to come to Washington, with a view to his appointment as Secretary of Legation, but a difficulty has arisen, and a gentleman from the Attorney General's office gets the appointment.

The revolutions which elsewhere in the world are the fruits of political speculation, in Mexico are purely pecuniary in their character. A voluntary subscription among capitalists of shrewdness and enterprise, very often sets them in motion;

ITEMS.--JAMES McGINNISS was thrown from a wagon at the corner of Myrtle-avenue and Falton-street, Saturday, and severely, but not dangerously, injured. He was taken in charge by the First President Police.... MARY C. DIXON, a crazy woman from Kittingly, Conn., was found wandering in the streets by the Sixth Precinct Police Saturday night,

The village of Magnolia, forty-eight miles from here on the Wilmington and Welion Railway, was burnt last night. ROAD'S warehouse, lad of goods, MERRIMAN'S store, and three or four dwellings, were destroyed. The loss is heavy, probably over $70,000, on which there was some insurance.

The forger obtained $4,100 by a skillful imitation of the signature of the firm, and has escaped with his booty.

As the Rahway train, on the New-Jersey Railroad, which should have reached Jersey City at 7:40 A.M. Saturday, was approaching the Jersey City Depot, the switchman let the switch turn on to a side track, on which there was a drill engine, attached to a train of cars. A severe collision was the result.

The president seems at last to have awakened to a sense of the condition into which our Mexican relations have been drifted by his extraordinary inactivity in the midst of the sharp contest now going on for supremacy between the factions of anarchy and monarchy in Mexico.

A PAWNBROKER IN TROUBLE.--W. J. JACKSON, the well-knew pawnbroker, made complaint at the City Hall Police Court on Saturday against ARTHUR DONNELLY, carpet dealer, No. 98 Bowery, whom he charges with having defrauded him out of $20 under false pretences.

The Overland Mail of the 11th ult., has arrived. There were no through passengers. The steamer Uncle Sam left San Francisco for the Colorado on the 11th with 300 troops of the Siath Infantry to chastise the Mohave Indians. An additional section of the California Central Railroad had been put under contract.

DEATH OF COLONEL SANDFORD IN VENEZUELA.--General SANDFORD has received the following letter from General PAEZ: VALENCIA, in the Republic of Venezuela, Feb. 10, 1859. To Major-General Charles W. Sandford, New-York: MY DEAR FRIEND: When this letter reaches your hand, you will, probably, have been informed through the public journals of the deplorable event which now occupies my thoughts.

The rumor that the Count DE SARTIGES has been removed proves to be wholly untrue. About two months 'since the Count requested leave of absence in consequence of protracted ill health. This was at firs refused, but subsequent dispatches represented the Ministry as more favorably disposed, and there is now a probability of his request being granted, but an yet he has received no permission to return, although it is confidently anticipated by the Europa.

Mr. SPINOLA'S arraignment of the Metropolitan Police in the State Senate is now spoken of in letters from Albany as a minority report, for which no Committee is responsible, but which embodies merely Mr. SPINOLA'S individual views, interests and hatreds.

The Courts of Law are to the morale of commerce in a great city what Broadway is to the material movement of our metropolitan traffic. As the street is choked by the very number of the vehicles which give it is importance, so are our Courts by the multitude of the cases which make them a vital element in our prosperity.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : A good deal of public attention is directed to the discussion growing out of the defence interposed by the United States life Insurance Company, in the action against them upon the Tasker policy. The Board of Directors, it seems, repudiate the attempt to prevent a recovery on the ground of want of " insurable interest" in the husband.

Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

COMMON COUNCIL.--An adjourned meeting of the Brooklyn Common Council was held last evening, President KALBFLEISCH in the chair. The first matter of interest introduced was the appointment of members of the Board of Education. The following were finally appointed: A. B. Baylis, De Hart bergen, james Hall, George Field, George W. Parsons, John M. Phelps, charles F. tuttle.

The Royal Mail steamer Europa, Capt. LEITCH, trem Liverpoolon the morning of Feb. 19, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The screw steamship Aetna arrived at Southampton on the forenoon of the 18th February. This arrival brings advices but a single day later, the Jura having furnished an outline of the intelligence to the 18th ult. We add, however, various facts of interest occurring during the week.

Board of Aldermen. WANTED , A MILK INSPECTOR--NEW PERRY AND STAGE ROUTES--A RAILROAD IN BROADWAY--THE SINKING FUND, The Board of Aldermen met last evening. A petition asking that an Inspector of Milk at the Harlem Railroad Depot be applied was referred to the Committee on Ordinances.

The United States Mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOCH, Commander, from New-Orleans via. Havana, arrived here yesterday morning, having left the latter place on the evening of the 21 inst. She brings no intelligence of special interest. The feeling still continues strong with regard to Mr. SLIDELL'S bill.

THE LORRY INVESTIGATION AT ALBANY.--Senator O. B. WHEELER'S Committee has finished its work, and the result is by no means what the public anticipated. It was generally imagined that there was a lobby every Winter at the State Capital which injuriously influenced legislation. This opinion the Senate has shown to be a popular error.

CANADIAN AFFAIRS.--A Toronto letter to the Montreal Gazette denies that the Canadian Parliament has invited Queen VICTORIA to open the first Witanagemote at Ottawa. A correspondent of a Western journal only suggested that Her Majesty should be invited to inaugurate the new Government buildings. Mr. CAMERON, the member for VICTORIA, has not yet returned from England; Mr. DAWSON,

A new penny paper called the Press, has been started in Cincinnati by Henry Reed, formerly of the Cincinnati Commercial. it is worked on a hoe lightning double cylinder press, driven by one of Ericseon's Calorle Engines. It has now been In operation something over a week, so that a fair opportunity has been had for testing its merits and advantages.

SEPOY MEETING AT STATEN ISLAND.--On Friday evening, the 4th inst., there was a meeting of the incendiary elements of Staten Island held in the vicinity of Rocky Hollow which was numerously attended. The object of the meeting was to decide upon the propriety of again demolishing the Quarantine buildings, and to fix upon the time for making the attack. RAY TOMPKINS is said to have been the leading spirit.

AN ESCORT EXTRAORDINARY.--The good people who think it hard the "effete monarchies" should look askance upon our foreign policy, and suspect us now and then of "miching mallcuho" which means mischief, are invited to consider the manner and form of Mr. McLANE'S departure for Mexico, as reported by telegraph.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--Mr. BRISTOW'S Benefit on Monday light was a success in every sense of the word. The house was handsomely filled, and the performance went off with rare precision. A man of Mr. Burarew's abilities should come more frequently before the public. The narrow pathway of art is so choked with impediments that it is not easy, we know, for the best men to make their way on it.

THE FIRST DAY OF LENT.--To-day is the first day of Lent--Ash Wednesday--which, in the olden time of the Church, meant the day of humiliation of the worshipper, a figurative clothing of the body in sackcloth, and dealing of the skin with ashes. Our Catholic and Episcopalian friends still keep the season, which lasts for forty days, with solemn observances;

THE PUBLIC SERVICE.--The Albany Evening Journal, noticing the retirement of Senator BELL, of Tennessee. says: "It is a striking and significant fact, that while the North is generally sending to the Senate Statesmen better qualified to maintain the high character of that body, and to defend her interests, than their predecessors were--the South is losing her old prestige of legislature ability, by filling her seats with second-rate politicians."

The African Coast-Guard Squadron, sustained at an annual cost of nearly one million of dollars, forced cut of the pockets of the American people by the Ashburton Treaty of 1842, have their rendezvous at this Island of St. Jago, one of the group of the Cape de Verds. Three of the cruisers are now here--the flagship, the ever-moving Dale, and the Marion. The Vincennes is expected next month.

Mr. McLANE left this afternoon for Mexico, and was escorted to the Southern boat by a distinguished filibuster. The Liberals here regard Mr. McLANE'S appointment as an important step in the right direction. Mr. McLANE, I hear, objected to Mr. THRASHER as Secretary of Legation, in consequence of certaly, antecedents which might give coloring to the Mission.

The Hon. AARON VENABLE BROWN, Postmaster-General, died at Washington yesterday, in the 64th year of his age. As State Legilslator, Member of Congress, Governor of the State of Tennessee, and Postmaster-General of the United States, Governor BROWN has for nearly forty years occupied prominent public positions. He was a native of virginia, born Aug. 13, 1795, of the old Revolutionary stock.

Two steamers are now expected from Europe--the North Briton, due at Portland, and the Arabia, due at Halifax. The North Briton left Liverpool on the 23d ult., and the Arabia on the 26th. There were no signs on either at 11 o'clock last night. The Hon. AARON VENABLE BROWN, Postmaster-General, died yesterday at Washington, at the age of 64. He was a native of Virginia, but emigrated in early life to Tennessee,

MARKET VALUE OF PRIME YOUNG MEN--Prime young men are always in good demand in this part of the country, and they are so rare a commodity that their value can hardly be quoted, for they are, in fact above all price. The great business of life rests upon the shoulders of our prime young men.

ARREST OF THE CONSPIRATORS--A BOGES BANK IN INDIANA--$60,000 OF WORTHLESS BILLS--CURIORS DEVELOPMENTS. By the aid of St. Louis Detectives, parties engaged in an enormous fraud upon the public, through the agency of a bogus banking institution in Indiana, have been caught and committed for trial. The St. Louis Democrat gives a long history of the case.

English papers announce the death of Lieutenant-General James Claud Bourchier, Colonel of the 3d Dragoon Guards, He was in the 79th years of his age, and entered the service in 1797. In the early part of his military career he was actively engaged, having been under Sir Robert Abercromby in the Campaign in Egypt of 1801, in the Peninsular campaigns of 1811 and 1812.

An "Immigration Bill," so called, which recently passed the Jamaica Legislature, was awaiting the sanction of the Home Government at the date of our latest advices from England. The idea of caricaturing the face of the carth is one of the latest of the Parisian modes. An artisan, at once a maker of maps and of fun, has just made an attempt of this novel character, drawing, printing and coloring a "Map of Europe in 1860," in which sundry changes, not at all discernible in any existing Atlas, are introduced with immense effect.

EXCITEMENT ON THE BORDER.--The political excitement that has plagued our western border for some years is quite a tame affair compared with the gold fever now raging. We learn from an intelligent resident of Missouri that very large preparations are making in that State for emigration to Pike's Peak so soon as the Spring shall open.

The building was tolerably well filled, but the audience was by no means as numerous as that which assembled in the same hall Friday evening,

THE PARENTAL HERALD.--That domestic dragon, the Editor of the Herald, who is ready to vomit fire and fury upon any scape grace journalist who shall so much as mention the existence of his household, or barely hint at scarlet satin and Wiesbaden, has just exhibited his views of private rights and parental instinct in a very pleasing and natural light.

The Hon. Sylvester Mowry, of Arizona, arrived in this City yesterday from Washington, and has taken rooms at the New-York Hotel. Bishop Simpson has so far recovered his health as to be able to leave Pittsburgh to attend the meeting of Conference at Baltimore.

The Hon. JOHN LETCHER, tile Democratic candidate for Governor of Virginia, opened the canvass at Woodstock, Va., on Monday last, in the presence of a large crowd, who manifested much enthusiasm. Mr. LETCHER said he appeared to render an account of his stewardship. He had heard of no disappropation among his constituents, yet as his opponents had attacked his Congressional career, he must vindicate himself from their aspersions.

HAYTI AND ITS PRESIDENT.-The conqueror of SOULOUQUE is experiencing the difficulties which befall all moderate men in seasons of public excitement. While in the field, at the head of his revolutionary troops, he met fully the expectations of his friends. His courage was equal to the task of driving FAUSTIN from the capital,

The Inspector-General or Finance Minister has ust introduced his new Tariff. and, as he is humanly ertain to carry it through the House, it is not out of place to comment on it now. We have hitherto had a mixed Tariff of specific and ad valorem duties--or, as you say down East, a vertical, a horizontal, and an inclined scale. The new Tariff Imposes ad valorem duties on everything, excepting whisky.

Mr. AMES reported for the consideration of the Senate a bill to authorize the sale of the Washington Market property, the avails to go for the benefit of the general funds of the State. Mr. ELY also introduced a bill from the Select Committee, of which he is Chairman, confirming the title of the property above referred to in the Commissionors of the Sinking Fund of the City.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Captain STONE, from Liverpool at 2 1/2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 26th ult., arrived at Halifax at 9 o'clock on the morning of Thursday, March 10. The screw-steamship Etna was to sail at about the same time as the Arabia, for Boston and New-York. The screw-steamship Kangaroo, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool on the night of the 25th.

The arrival of the steamship Arabia, at Halifax, furnishes European advices to Feb. 26--one week later. The intelligence is of a more pacific character than that brought by the Europa. The funeral of tile late Postmaster-General took place to-day. The funeral-procession firmed at the President's House at 12 1/2 o'clock. The corpse lay in state in the East Room, and was viewed by many thousands of persons. The body looked quite natural, though emaciated. The Senate was in attendance, headed by Mr. FITZPATRICK.

Dr. PARKER'S Church (corner Fourth-avenue and Twenty-second-street) last evening. Quite a numerous audience was in attendance. The Faculty and Trustees of the College, with invited guests, occupied seats in the spacious pulpit.

In times gone by the name of Kentuckian has been justly regarded as a synonym for all that is brave and chivalrous in our nature. Men met their foes warned and armed--man to man, and upon an equal footing; and when the tight was over, they would as soon have struck a woman in the travail of childbirth as raised a hand against a disarmed and wounded antagonist.

SHELDON.--In this City. on Friday. March 11, CRAW FOR B. SHELDON, aged 59 years and 9 months. His remains will removed to Delhi, N. Y. for interment. AUSTEN.--In this City, on Thursday night, March 10, at the residence of Edward Austen, Esq., JOHN youngest son of George and Caroline Austen, of Baltimore, aged 11 years and 6 months.

A VERY REMARKABLE REVELATION.--The veteran commodore STUART sent a letter to President BUCHANAN yesterday, as we learn from our Special Washington Correspondent, revealing the very remarkable fact that the flotilla of gunboats built by President JEFFERSON, for the ostensible purpose of guarding our line of sea-coast, were actually intended to be used in making a descent upon Cuba, with the purpose of conquering that long-coveted island and annexing it to the Union.

It was presented to the Legislature March 8, accompanied by a Special Message from Governor CHASE.

FALLING OF THE FLOOR OF A CHURCH--FOUR LIVES LOST.--The following particulars of the calamity of the 9th. at St. Mary's Church in Oswego, are given by the Palladium: "The Church was literally packet with people. The exercises of the evening had just commenced, or were about to commence, when about one-third of the floor, immediately in front of the altar, gave way from the immense weight.

A highly-interesting letter from Commodore CHARLES STEWART was to-day handed to President BUCHAHAN, disclosing an item of secret history never before divulged. President JEFFERSON'S gun-boat Navy, which was the subject of much ridicule, was ostensibly built for the protection of our sea coast. One hundred and eighty of these boats were sent southward.

By an arrival at Philadelphia we are placed in possession of our Rio files to Jan. 19. The Intelligence is of secondary moment. THE WEEKLY PRESS.--The Saturday Press has a striking poem this week by STODDARD, besides a variety of sharp, spicy and telling literary matter. The Press is the ablest of the literary weeklies--and almost the only one which possesses any very salient peculiarities of character and tone.

The steamship North Briton, from Liverpool, Feb. 23, arrived at Portland at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. She reports having been detained by head winds. Passed the Canada, from Boston, for Halifax and Liverpool, on Thursday, and the City of Manchester, from New-York, for Liverpool, a few days ago.

The late session of Congress has had an important effect upon the coming Presidential canvass. It has modified the calculations of both political parties and has seriously damaged the prospects of the Democracy. Nothing, indeed, could be more disastrous than the results of the session upon that section of the Democratic Party which is identified with Mr. BUCHANAN'S Administration.

BOGUS CANVASSERS FOR A BUSINESS DIRECTORY.--Three young men, giving their names as Chas. Dunbar, Wm. Young and Chas. Van Valkenbureh, were yesterday arrested on a charge of obtaining money under false pretences. They were actively canvassing the lower part of the City to secure advertisements of merchants and other business men for the next issue of "Wilson's Business Directory."

The wharf-owners of this City and Brooklyn are urging the Legislature to pass a law doubling the rates of wharfage now established, and adding some new charges for the modern appliances used in loading and discharging cargoes. Their application is of course opposed with great vehemence by the ship-owners and shipping merchants of the City; and the question promises to take up not a little time and thought at Albany.

An Italian refugee, Joachimo Baffi, died recently in England, aged ; 37. At the commencement of the Italian Struggle in 1848 he abandonel the pen for the musket, and jointed a corps of volunteers In Lomardy. When Austrian suremac was restored, Biffi propceded to Venice, and took part in the hereoic efforts of the Venetians.

INTERESTING FACTS FOR TAX-PAYERS -- "THE TWENTY-FIVE-DOLLAR ORDINANCE." Mr. WM. B. LEWIS, Comptroller of Brooklyn, has recently prepared his annual statement of the financial department of the city for the last fiscal year. The Comptroller. in his communication to the Common Council, calls the attention of that body to some facts of interest, especially to tax-payers.

The late Henry S. Geyer, ex-United States Senator from Missouri, died at the age of 60. He occupied for many years a prominent position in the politics of Missouri; sat in the Constitutional Convention; was a member of the Second General Assembly from St. Louis County; and was elected to the United States Senate in 1851, as successor to Col. Benton.

The proposed Registry law would be a violation of the Constitution of the State--as it would demand of the elector qualifications, without the possession of which the Constitution has declared he "shall be entitled to vote."

The amount of specie by this arrival is small, being but $924,000. The news has been in part anticipated, as usual, by the Overland Mail and the Tehuantepec arrival.

A MASSACHUSRTTS CANDIDATE FOR THE PRESIDENCY, --The Boston Journal, which occupies somewhat of an independent position in political affairs, has been reviewing the probabilities of all the prominent candidates of all parties for a nomination for the presidency, and it arrives at the conclusion that Governor BANKS "occupies a very strong position." Mr. SEWARD, the Journal thinks.

THE REV. DR. CHEEVER ON SLAVERY.--The Church of the Rev. Dr. CHEEVER, in Union Square, was filled last evening to listen to a discourse---the fifth of the series--on the subject of American slavery. He read portions of the 34th and 36th chapters of Jeremish, which to expounded, showing how perfectly they portrayed the sins of this nation, and foreshadowed the judgments of God which would fall upon us for oppression.

On the 23d of June, 1853, the Legislature passed "An Act to aid in the erection of a monument commemorative of the Declaration of American Independence," which act provided for the appointment of a trustee or agent who should join with the like trustees or agents on the part of other States, not less than eight in number of the original thirteen,

THE SANITARY CONDITION OF THIS CITY.--At this healthiest season of the year, when there has been no sudden increase of our population by immigration, the last three reports of our City Inspector hare exhibited an alarming increase in the bills of mortality. Last week the increase was ten deaths over the week previous, and the week before the increase was twenty.

She had a large quantity of freight and some one hundred passengers, which, for the first trip, and upon so short a notice, was considered a large number.

NEW-HAMPSHIRE ELECTION.--The returns from New-Hampshire give the following summary of the result of the election in that State: The Republican vote of this State, so far as heard from, 35,721; democratic, 31,926; making GOODWIN'S majority 3,795. The whole vote of the State is about 00,000. The vote of last year was, HAILE, 36,333, CATE, 31,591; HAILE'S majority 4,732.

THE BuSINESS SEASON.--Our advertising friends show an eager desire to monoplize our columns, which is somewhat embarrassing, though not positively unpleasant. They are encroaching upon our reading space to a disastrous extent. We always expect a treshet in the Spring, but it comes this year at least a month earlier than usual.

The propeller Erustus Corning reached here last night from New-York. She made the trip in 26 hours. The propeller Corning left here for New-York at 5 o'clock this afternoon, with a load of cattle and rolling freight. The river is entirely free from ice, and all the steamers are preparing for business.

Mr. WILLARD introduced a bill to permit Supervisors to act as Commissioners of Deeds. Mr. PROSSER introduced a concurrent resolution to amend the Constitution so as to allow a loan of $3,500,000 to complete the Canals of 1801. Mr. SPINOLA introduced a bill to authorize the construction of a Railroad in Grand-Street, Bushwick, Meeker, and Metropolitan avenues, Brooklyn.

There is probab'y nothing which exercises so much influence, not only upon the political but social condition of England as her property laws,--the manner in which the landed estates are held, settled, conveyed and transmitted.

MURDER OF COL. JOSEPH ROND. MACON, Ga., Monday, March 14, March 14. A letter has just been received from Albany announcing the murder of Col. JOSEPH BOND, of this city. He was killed on Saturday, near Aloany, by LAUGH'S BROWN. The difficulty, It is believed, originated in Brown whipping one of Bond's negroes.

AMENDING THE CONSTITUTION.-Three propositions are before the Legislature for amending the Constitution. One proposes to reorganize the Court of Appeals, reducing the number of judges from eight to six, and causing them all to be elected by general ticket, instead of taking part from the Supreme Court Bench. This is practical, sensible and necessary.

NIBLO'S THEATER .--Mr. VAN AMBURG'S celebrated performing animals were exhibited here last night for the first time this season. The house was much fuller than usual, and we may therefore reasonably conclude that the "varmints" draw. Their exhibited by the gentleman who enjoys their snarls is evidently a desperate and exciting thing.

We have no public sales of property in the City to report to-day. Messrs. RAYNOR BLACKWELL, have sold four lots on the south side of One Hundred and Thirty-fourthstreet, about 200 feet west of Fifth.avenue, at 1400 per lot. Seller, G.H. PECK. Also, four lots on the south side of Sixtieth-street, about 200 feet east of Fourth-avenue, at $1,200 per lot. Seller, F. Hornby.

The Grand Jury examined twelve witnesses in the Sickles case to-day, but it is a singular fact that Mr. BUTTERWORTH, who had testified before the extending Court, was neither examined nor subpoenaed as a witness before the Grand Jury. A bill will probably be returned to-morrow, and the trial set for Monday next.

I a sorry to write still of political disturbances; and there is no knowing when or what the end will be. I informed you two weeks ago of the outbreak in Atacams. That is not quelled. The report that Caldera had been sacked was exaggerated. Fourteen thousand dollars belonging to the town treasury were seized by the rebels, and $5,000 belonging to the Custom-house. But private property was respected.

THE PRESIDENT AND THE DEMOCRACY-- A letter from Washington represents Mr. BuCHANAN as denouncing the Democratic Party in unmeasured terms. He accuses them of having deserted him and left him utterly without the means of carrying on the government. The reproach is not wholly undeserved.

The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 2d inst., with four days later European advices, is now about due at this port. This Sandy Hook Telegraph reported "no signs" at 11 o'clock last night. By way of Havana, we have details of news from Vera Cruz to Feb. 27. The city was in a state of siege;

The New-York Democracy assembled, last night, in Tammany Hall, for the purpose of expressing their views as to the policy of extending "the Area of Freedom," apropas of the movements regarding the acquisition of Cuba.

The California Overland Mail of the 18th ult., has arrived. One through and five way passengers came in the stage. Several tribes of Indians are reported at the Apache Pass for the purpose of making treaties. The Camanches had stolen 80 mules from a drove belonging to the Mail Company designed to supply their stations.

The United States mail steamship Philadelphia, GUSTAVUS HARRISON, Esq., Commander, left New-Orleans March 5, for New-York via Havana, at which port she arrived on the morning of the 9th, and sailed same day for this port, arriving yesterday morning. The Philadelphia landed and transferred 75 passengers at Havana, and brings 77 passengers and a fair cargo for New-York.

TOO MUCH FOR ONE.--It is frequently amusing to the metropolitan public to witness the vanity with which rural politicians imagine that New-York intelligence is to be bamboozled by the twaddle which is popular in the out-of-the-way places of the interior.

The Grand Jury have as yet brought in no bill. One is said to have been found against Mr. SICKLES, but differences exist as to Mr. BUTTERWORTH--a majority being opposed to any action as regards him, The Grand Jury have confined themselves entirely to witness present at the affray.

We have the Royal Gazette alludes to rumors to the effect that Governor WODEHOUSE is about to leave the colony, having been promised a lucrative office in the East Indies, and that KER BAILLIE HAMILTON, Governor of Antigua and the Leeward Islands is to assume the Government of British Guiana.

The fuller news from Mexico is still more favorable for the Liberal cause than even its friends had permitted themselves to hope. MIRAMON, who would seem to be more impulsive than competent, had intended to reach Alvarado, where he would have recruited his troops, and whence he was to have marched northward towards Vera Cruz.

That best of authorities, "Our own Correspondent," has reason to believe that the President does not apprehend any action on the part of the British and French squadrons now lying before Vera Cruz, that will either conflict with the Monroe doctrine, or seriously affect the political institutions of Mexico.

TERBOSS.--In this City, on Tuesday, March 15. CATHARINE, widow of the late Isaac Terboss, aged 70 years. 6 months and 9 days. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 145 Hudson-st., St. John's-square, on Thursday, March 17, at 9 1/2 o'clock A. M. Her remains will be taken to Tarrytown Cemetery for interment.

MR. JONES REFUSES TO BE MADE A MINISTER.--Some days ago the President tendered to Ex-Senator GEORGE W. JONES, of lowa, the mission to New-Granada, and, extraordinary as it may seem, Mr. JONES has declined the appointment. Such conduct is not often seen at Washington, where it is without precedent, and incredible that any man should refuse an office.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In Monday's issue of your paper there are several very erroneons statements calculated to do my character great injury, and, therefore, I take this means of stating the truth. A paragraph has been going the rounds of the papers for a fortnight now, stating that a Mr. B., of New-York, was violently in love with Mrs. SICKLES during the Session of Congress a year ago, , ,

RAILROAD RESPONSIBILITY.--At Cincinnati a Judgment has just been affirmed in the General Term of the Superior Court Which is of in crest to travelers and railroad companies. A gentleman purchased a ticket in Washington from a general agent of all the lines, through to Cincinnati,. When he arrived there his baggage was missing, and he subsequently send the Little Miami Railroad Company for its Value, and a judgement was recovered in the Court below.

Through the mist and rain of this Spring morning, the sun shone so feebly that the gas lights were kept burning for several hours. And, under the stimulus of gas-light, the House worked with great rapidity and ordered scores of bills to a third reading. It was general-order day, but, by unanimous consent, Mr. WEEKS introduced a bill in relation to the planting of shell-fish in Jamaica Bay.

OUTRAGEOUS ASSAULT BY A MYSTERIOUS FEMALE -ESCAPE OF THE ASSAILANT. The neighborhood of Broadway, near Bleeckerstreet, witnessed, on Monday afternoon, the enactment of a strange and exciting scene, which, for the time being, caused great commotion, and which has since given rise to much curious conjecture.

SPEECH OF THE BRITISH CONSUL--OUTBREAK AT JEREMIE--PROGRESS OF THE REPUBLIC. We have received files of Hayti papers to Feb. 26, with over a week's later intelligence. Captian PHAYRE, of the British war vessel Basilisk, who had come to protect the interest of British residents, was presented, on the 4th ult., to President GEFFRARD by Mr. BYRON, English Vice-Consul, who took the opportunity of making a long, congratulatory speech to the new President.

PALMERSTON AND BUCHANAN.--The London correspondent of a City paper relates a "good story" of Mr. BUCHANAN'S first interview with Lord PALMERSTON, when His Lordship introduced the newly-arrived Minister to Lady PALMERSTON and her children. Mr. BUCHANAN, wishing to say a civil thing, remarked on the strong resemblance they bore to their father.

A visit to the interior of the dismal temple of Justice in Centre-street, when the rays of sunlight struggle through the little windows of the cells, and glimpses of blue sky are caught by the inmates, gives one but a feeble idea of the Egyptian gloominess of the City Prison when the rain is falling on the roof, as it did yesterday, and everything within wears a lead colored hue,

The arrest and examination of several counterfeiters of gold and silver coin, in Essex County, by Deputy United States marshal SCHUYLER HUBBARD, has revealed some curious facts. Upon the person of JAMES H. FARNSWORTH, one of the persons arrested, was found a certificate of membership in a certain "Mystic Circle of Alchemy."

GEFFRARD, though not by any means an aged man, would appear to deserve the distinction accorded by the Cockneys to the Haytian Ambassador, whom those worthy people are accustomed to call "the man of 80;" or, in the Cockney vernacular, "'Aiti." GOVERNORS OF THE ALMSHOUSE.--From the weekly statement submitted at the meeting of the Board yesterday afternoon, it appears that 7,991 inmates remained in the different institutions on the 12th inst. During the week preceding that date 1,428 were admitted, 24 died, 1,368 were discharged, 102 were sent to the Penitentiary, and 10 to the State Prison.

The Steamship City of Washington, now in her fourteenth day, had not made her appearance off Sandy Hook at 2 o'clock this morning. A northwest gale was blowing. The question of the Extra Session of Congress has not yet been decided by the President, though a conclusion will undoubtedly by arrived at before the sailing of the next California steamer.

Advices from Washington are conflicting and contradictory in respect to a called session of Congress. One day it is asserted that the President has stated to a Senator that he shall certainly convoke Congress at an early period; and the next gives birth to a statement equally positive that he has utterly refused to do anything of the sort.

The extraordinary success which attended a recent sale in this City of pictures by American artists, contributed as a fraternal offering to the family of the late WILLIAM RANNEY, was but one of many pleasant signs everywhere discernable of the increasing interest which our people take in Art.

COMPLETION OF THE STATE CANALS.--The concurrent resolution offered in the Senate on Monday, by Mr. PROSSER, proposes to amend the Constitution so as to permit a new six percent loan of $3,500,000, for the completion of the canals.

THE AUTOCRAT OF THE BREAKFAST TABLE.--An excellent photograph from Mr. BARRY'S picture of "The Schoolmistress," one of the best associates of "The Autocrat" at the "Breakfast Table," whom the Professor has since made his companion for life in the holy bonds of matrimony, has been published by Mr. CHAS. H. BRIANARD, of Boston.

The screw-steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool March 2, arrived here yesterday. Her news is of importance. The long-promised bill for a reform of parliamentary representation was introduced into the House of Commons on the 28th ult., Mr. DISRAELI, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, entering into an extended analysis of the measure.

Ex-Mayor WOOD's twin organs, the Herald and the News, are excessively clamorous for the instant repeal of the Metropolitan Police Law and the restoration of the old system. Their eagerness in the matter, and the desperate use they make of Mr. SPINOLA'S Report, betray a motive with which the public does not sympathize.

THE MARSHALSHIP OF NORTHERN ILLINOIS.-Mr. C. N. PINE, United States Marshal for Northern Illinois, publishes in his paper, tile Chicago Herald, a very elaborate defence of his character against the charges filed at Washington by D). B. MARTIN. Ills reply is addressed to the President, and is backed by numerous affidavits. Mr. MARTIN is denounced as " a speaking, thieving scoundrel," and his list of charges is analyzed, and each separately denied.

Yet Mr. MRERITT, the Chairman of our Parliamentary Committee on Trade and Commerce, declares this to be the fact.
