THE PRESIDENT AND MEXICO.--Our readers pobably remember that some times since it was announced that Mr. CHURCHWELL, of ennessee, had been appointed a Commissioner to Mexico, and that the action of the President upon Mexican affairs would depend on the report which he might make.

The Committee reported the Canal Appropriation bill, Mr. MATHER dissenting from it, on the ground that it did not contain the desired amendment, giving six feet of water this year and seven feet next year. A large number of petitions against the increase of wharfage rates were presented. Mr. MATHER introduced a bill to provide for the protection of the grounds of the New-York Protestant Episcopal Public School.

THE STEPHENS TRIAL--THE BENCH AND THE BAR.--The trial of STEPHENS, on charge of poisoning his wife, drags its slow length along, and promises to last a week or ten days longer. There is a great deal about it that is repulsive, and much which we shall not sully our columns by reporting.

The examination of the Sickles case before the Grand Jury has taken a new turn, and may occupy a week more. It was the wish of Mr. SICKLES' counsel to have a pro forma indictment from the Grand Jury, and to leave the facts to be developed before the Court. Such was also the public expectation.

PARAGUAY ACCEPTS BRAZILIAN MEDIATION--JESUITS EXPELLED FROM MONTEVIDEO--RIO MARKETS. The English papers contain a telegraphic dispatch from the Brazilian steamer at Lisbon, with Rio dates to Feb. 7. There is no political news from Brazil. The cases of fever were few.

Since my letter to you by the Illinois there has been a dearth of news. The weather here and at Panama has continued to be most delightful, it being our "dry season." The bark David Lapsley, from Philadelphia, with coal for thee steam vessels of the United States Home Squadron upon this coast, and which vessel was supposed to be lost, arrived at this port on the 21st ult.

MATHER.--In this City, on Wednesday morning, March 16, MARIA AUGUSTA, wife of J. W. Mather, aged 26 years. M., from the residence of her mother, Mrs. Mohan, No. 336 Broome St. Her remains will be taken to Connecticut for interment.

J. Buchanan Henry, Esq., the President's nephew and private Secretary, has resigned his office, with a view to practicing law in this city. A public meeting of citizens of Nashville, Tenn., was held last week, in memory of the late Postmaster General.

Arthur et al., to recover $168 72 " for something done" by the plaintiffs in regard to the Seventh Ward Schools.

The people of this county and vicinity have been thrown into a high state of excitement on account of a minister of the Gospel being suspected of poisoning his wife. The circumstances of the case are as follows: The wife of the clergyman in question. residing near this place, died very suddenly on Tuesday evening last, she having previously been in good health, which excited suspicions.

The Registry bill came up to-day for a third reading. Mr. TOMLINSON moved to recommit it, and then addressed the House for about half an hour in opposition to it. He hung about the line of his arguments a profusion of flowers, but did not damage the bill. Major SCHOLEFIELD responded happily, after which the motion to recommit was withdrawn and the Registry act carried by Yeas, 85 ; Nays, 21.

Dr. GEORGE ABBOTT, United States Vice-Consul at Cairo, died at Alexandria in January ;last, as was duly announced when dispateches from Egypt reached us. He was a brother of De. HENRY ABBOTT, the collector and proprietor of the renowned :Abbott Collection of Egyptian Antiquities," eulogized by Sir GARDINER WILKINSON and other European savans, and which is well known to the public of New-York.

For one thing at least the actual holders of power in Great Britain owe the Emperor of the French a debt of gratitude. He has rescued them from the worst perils of their position by flinging the apple of foreign discord into the English councils on the very eve of a great domestic movement.

The Countess of Sandwich, sister to Lord Cowley, the Special British Eavoy to Vienna, died in London, Feb. 21, after a short illness. The deceased Countess was the second daughter of the late Field-Marshal the Marquis of Anglesey, by his second marriage with Lady Charlotte Cadogan. Her Ladysip was born on the 16th of June, 1812. and married on the 6th of September, 1838, the Earl of Sandwich.

A STRAIGHT TICKET NOMINATED--NO UNION WITH THE REPUBLICANS. The American City Convention met last evening, in Granada Hall, Myrtle-avenue. The organization was perfected by electing the following officers: Chairman--JAMES A. VAN BRUNT. Secretaries--JOHN Q. ADAMS. ALEXANDER W. RUSSELL.

The Grand Jury will to-morrow morning bring in an indictment against Mr. SICKLES for killing Mr. KEY. Before determining on this action to-day, they unanimously acquitted Mr. BUTTERWORTH of any and all participation in the affair. Even Mr. B. OGLE TAYLOR expressed his entire conviction of Mr. BUTTERWORTH'S innocence.

THE CUBAN SCHEME.--Senator BROWN does not seem to be backed by. the Administration in his Cuban speech at Tammany Hall. The Union takes exception to his declaration that he wants Cuba for the extension of Slavery.

The tradition that St. Patrick's Day must of necessity bring a rain with it. was thoroughly overset. yesterday. Our Hibernian fellow citizens had come to regard a wet jacket as one of the penalties attaching to the pleasures of their National Anniversary, as surely as the Friend looks for a wet blanket upon the occasion of his Yearly Meeting in May, but the fates were kind this year.

The Senate continued in session until nearly 5 o'clock this morning, the struggle being carried on with unceasing bitterness up to the adjournment. He accuses PINE of weather-cock tendencies in political matters: says he has been, in turn, Know-Nothing Anti-Lecompton and Lecompton: charges him anew with malfeasance in office;

Messrs. Routledge are about to announce a new Illustrated natural History. in shilling monthly numbers, by the Rev. J. G. Woods, author of Common Objects of the Country and Sea Shore. The book may be expected to supply the want of a comprehensive and accurate work on the natural history of the animal kingdom, which has long been felt.

It apparently exists in great abundance, and large quantities may be picked from the ground without the trouble of excavating. A place weighing thirty or forty pounds has been exhibited in McKinney, and subjected to a few experiments.

CLOSE OF THE AUCTION, SALE OF PICTURES. The auction sale by LEEDS Co., of GOUPIL'S collection of paintings was concluded last evening at the rooms of the National Academy of Design. Men who were weak in the back and shaky In their knees, physically or financially, found that the auction room was no place for them.

By a stroke of tile pen Paris has been converted from a city of twelve hundred thousand population into one of sixteen hundred thousand. All, or nearly all, Continental cities, possess an octroi wall--that is to say, they charge duty upon all articles of provisions entering the city, and, to guard against the introduction of contraband goods, are obliged to throw around the city a wall which is thus called.

Yesterday morning the court-room of the Common Pleas was deluged by rain. Spittoons had to be placed here and there over the carpet to catch the droppings from the ceilings, and business had to be carried on very much as if the Judge was seated on a hill-top, or a cromlech after the fashion of our ancestors, instead of in a modern hall of justice, in the midst of a wealthy metropolis.

On the reading of the Journal Mr. MATHER re-rewed his attempt to obtain a correction of the record by inserting the protest of the Democratic Members on Mr. MANDEVILLE'S cast. The Chair decided it was not in order. An appeal was taken, and the Chair again sustained.

DEMOCRATIC STATE CONVENTION AT HARRISBURG.--The Democrats of Pennsylvania held a Convention on Wednesday, partly to nominate candidates for Auditor-General and Surveyor-General, but chiefly to "support the Administration." Both objects were accomplished. RICHARDSON L. WRIGHT, of Philadelphia, was named for Auditor;

The Churchman states that a project is on foot for the " establishment in this City of a new daily paper, to be conducted on strictly religious principles." The Churchman says that if those engaged in it will make it "a support of the true Catholic Church," they may obviate the necessity of carrying out the project of starting a new daily, which the Churchman itself has long entertained;

THE RECENT FORGERIES IN VIRGINIA--ARREST OF THE SUPPOSED FORGER IN THIS CITY.-A letter from the correspondent of the TIMES, in Petersburg, has recently given the particulars of a bold forgery committed on Messrs. PAUL HERTON, brokers of that city; the forged check being cashed by Messrs. ENDERS, SUTTON Co., of Richmond. The amount obtained was $4100.

Mr. Thackeray has been visiting Harrow for the Purpose of delivering a lecture before the school on "The Court and Times of George the Third." The whole school was present, together with a select party of visitors, who filled every vacant corner of the speech-room. Mr. Thackeray was enthusiastically cheered before and after his lecture, which was listened to with admiring attention by an audience of more than 500.

The screw steamship Weser, of the Bremen line, having touched at Cork, brings us European advices to the 6th inst. Further changes had taken place in the British ministry; while others, indicating the withdrawal of the Lord Chancellor, and of the Colonial Secretary were confidently announced as on the eve of occurrence.

CORONER'S INQUEST CONCLUDED-VERDICT APOPLEXY, INDUCED BY VIOLENCE. Coroner O'KEEFE concluded the investigation of the cause of the death of MIKE WALSH yesterday morning at the Sixteenth Precinct Station-house. The room in which the inquest was held was crowded with people, most of them friends of the deceased.

ELEVENTH DAY, COURT OF ER AND TERMINER. Before the Hon. Judge Roosevelt The interest of this trial continues to increase and yesterday a larger crowd was assembled at the doors of the Court room. than has attended on any other day, since the commencement of the proceedings.

PATRICK, of whom we are told, on the best legendary authority, that he not only "came of decent people " in point of origin, but was himself a " gentleman" in point of character, must have smiled approval upon the style in which the people of his protection have just celebrated his festival-day in this good City of New-York.

As the twelfth of April approaches the interest in the great Billiard-match between SEREETER, of Detroit, and PHELAN, of this City, increases. Both gentlemen are busily engaged in preparing for the contest. In Detroit, where SEREETER is known and PHELAN is not, except by reputation, there is perfect confidence that the former will carry off the stakes.

The screw-steamship Weser, of the Bremen line, JOHN HEINRICH GABTJEN, Esq., Commander, from Queenstown, Ireland, March 6, arrived at this port last evening. On the 4th inst., the inhabitants of Cork presented an address to Captain GABTJEN, felicitating themselves upon the accident which had brought his magnificent vessel into their port, and expressing a hope that the owners would decide to make it an established waystation.

There goes about a rumor which seems to be well-founded, that the Court of Appeals, at their consultation last Thursday, decided the thrice-argued question (the Court twice being equally divided) by a vote of five to three; that the old Police, by joining Wood and RUSSELL, did not withdraw from the effect of the Metropolitan Act in their favor.

MIRAMON RUMORED TO BE AT THE GATES OF VERA CRUZ. The New-Orleans papers contain additional news of interest brought by the Quaker City from Minatitian, By advices from the City of Mexico of the 23d ult., it appears that General MIRAMON was marching on Vera Cruz with an army of 2,500 men, and a reserve force of 2,000.

The Cabinet are still resisting the movement for an extra session, but their resistance is all in vain. The President's mind was made up on Saturday last as stated in Monday's TIMES, and his Proclamation may issue to-morrow. Attorney-General BLACK took the position that, as the Post-office Department would inevitably be dishonored in a few weeks, an extra session would come too late to save the credit of the Government.

POLITICAL.--It is understood that neither GEO. HALL nor C. C. SMITH, the former nominated by the American Convention for Mayor, and the latter by the same Convention for Treasurer, will accept the nomination.

BAY STATE TEMPERANCE.--Under the operation of their Temperance Law, the people of Massachusetts have become critical respecting their drink, systematically rejecting all liquors suspected of adulteration or impurity. And, in order to secure a regular supply of really good whisky and gin, they have a State Agent who furnishes the whole Commonwealth. There are subordinate agencies in the several towns, for the convenience of general distribution.

The credentials of GEORGE D. LAMONT as Senator elect from the Twenty-ninth District, were received. BILLS REPORTED FAVORABLY. By Mr. SPINOLA, to incorporate the New-York Railroad and Steamboat Accident Company.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, Captain LOTT, from Liverpool at 10 A. M. of Saturday, March 5, reached this port early on Saturday morning. The screw-steamship Borussia, Capt. TRAUTMANE, from Southampton the same day, arrived here on Saturday evening.

POSITION OF THE MEXICAN QUESTION.--The Washington Union assures us that England and France have no disposition to interfere in the political affairs of Mexico, and that the fleets of those countries are acting in concert with our own naval force in the harbor of Vera Cruz. This information, evidently emanating from the State Department, comes at a favorable moment.

ACCIDENT FROM A FALLING SIGN.--A man by the name of CHADBURN, who is in the employ of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company as an officer of one of their steamers, was seriously, and it is feared fatally, injured by the falling of a sign upon his head while passing through Fulton-street at 9 1/2 o'clock Saturday morning.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: On the 21st of September last, the lease for five years of the Pier and North Battery at the foot of Hubert-street, for several years leased and occupied by the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, was told at auction on the premises in behalf of the City, by Mr. MILLER, auctioneer.

SERVED RIGHT.--Brooklynites, with ladies, are frequently annoyed, while riding from some of the uptown places of amusement in New-York to Fulton Ferry, by a species of young men designated "fast," who, presuming upon the fact that there are several of them together, use language highly unbecoming, in the presence of ladies at least, if not directly insulting. A case occurred on Saturday night last.

UNCLAIMED DEPOSITS IN SAVINGS BANKS.Mr. OPDYKE, of this City, a careful and judicious legislator, has introduced in the Assembly a new bill in respect to deposits lying unclaimed in Savings Banks, for a period so long as to raise the presumption that no claimant will ever appear. That gentleman reports the measure in question as Chairman of the Select Committee, appointed to investigate the subject of such unclaimed deposits.

A new MISSION TO JAPAN.--Arrangements are in progress, under the auspices of some of the churches of this City, to establish a new mission in Japan. The primary object will be the introduction of Christian civilization;--the means to be used will be of a practical and educational character. The mission will consist of six persons--two of whom, the Rev. S. R. BROWN and the Rev. G. F. VERHECK, are clergymen; ;

AMERICAN PRODUCE AND FOREIGN TARIFFS.--Some of the alterations which have been made in European tariffs during the last eighteen months have an important bearing upon American commerce. Russia, by an ukase of April, 1858, imposed an additional rate of 5 per cent. on the import and export duties on all articles, except sagar.

In one respect, at least, the Chivalry of the South differs from the Chivalry of the Middle Ages. Had BAYARD been detected in robbing a hen-roost, or Du GUEACLIN in picking a pocket, either of those heroes would unquestionably. have sought a refuge from the shame and black disgrace of his deed in some hermit's cell, or in the sad silence of the suicide's voiceless grave.

THE COLONIAL ELECTION--BURNS CELEBRATION--THE SMALL POX--INVALIDS FROM INDIA. By the arrival of the bark Fleet Eagle at Boston, we have advices from the Cape of Good Hope to Jan 25. An election was going on throughout the colony for members of the Legislature, with some excitement, but no breaches of the peace.

There are several projects before the Legislature for making new Liquor Laws, for amending our City Charter, for regulating the sale of liquor on Sunday, and for various other worthy and desirable objects. But they are all utterly superfluous and even mischievous. They do harm, by withdawing public attention from the real remedy needed for all our existing abuses.

Our tiles of papers received from Buenos Ayres to January 20, contain a remarkable correspondence between the Secretary of State of that Government and the American Consul, Mr. W. H. HUDSON. It appears that the Buenos Ayrean executive had taken offence at the entrance of the American war-vessels into the Parana without its consent previously obtained, and had requested our Consul to signify so much to Commodore SHUBRICK.

The Chicago Times says that Governor Bissell will call an extra session of the Legislature, and that the day of meeting will be about the 1st of May. It may not be till July, but an extra session it is concluded is necessary. The reorganization of the Vermont Volunteer Militia has been commenced. Orders are issued by Adjutant-General Kellogg for the formation of three regiments of Infantry. The First Regiment willcom prise companies already organized.

A DEFERENCE OF THE EX-EMPEROR, OF HAYTI BY CHEVALIER RAYBAUD.--We publish a letter addressed to the Editor of the Presse from a gentleman better informed as to the history and policy of the late Emperor of Hayti than any other European.

Our advices from Caracas extend to March 5. The country was in a disquieted condition; revolutionary movements on foot in every direction, insomuch that the Executive had invested President CASTRO with extraordinary powers, and suspended the guarantees of the Constitution. The source of these troubles was the extreme unpopularity of certain measures of Gen. The Extra Session question is still undecided, though it will be settled to-morrow in time to telegraph for the California steamer. By the arrival of the schooner Amy Chase, Captain BREVOUR, we have received advices from the above port to March 4. The province of Cora, and two other provinces, are in a state of revolt. Three hundred troops left Porto Cabello on the 4th inst. (the day the Amy Chase sailed) for Cora.

It has been read twice, reported favorably from the Committee on Charitable and Religious Societies, and committed to the Committee of the Whole.

A COUNTY SCHOOL--We depart from our usual custom, in directing the attention of parents who wish to place their children in a country school for the Summer months, to the school of Mme. RUTTKAI, at Cornwall, near Newburg. Mme. R. is a sister of KOSSUTH, and a lady of high accomplishments and most estimable character.

The Boston Traveller, of Monday, says the troubles at the Eliot school seem to be nearly at an end. To-day (says the Traveller) about sixty scholars returned, in addition to the number which came back yesterday, so that in all about two hundred absentees who participated in the rebellion have resumed their connection with the school, and their allegiance to its rules and regulations.

CANADIAN REBELLION.--A circular has been largely distributed in Canada, which handles the present Government sharply, and boldly advocates a separation from the Home Government in the event of the success of some of the measures urged by those now in power.

HILL--In this City, on Monday, March 21, of consumption, GENNETT HILL wife of Alexander Hill, deceased, In the 44th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectittally invited to attend the funeral, from her late residence, corner of 57th st. and 2d-av., on Wednesday, the 23d inst., at 1 o'clock.

CITY POST-OFFICE AGAIN.--It is stated that a fresh movement is on foot to secure the erection of a new City Post-office up-town. In the present state of the Department it is not probable that anything will be done towards the building of a Post-office anywhere.

CONSUL AT HAVRE.--We see it stated that General MORRIS, of this City, has been appointed Consul at HAVRE. We should be very sorry to believe that the report is true, because would involve the ejection from office of Mr. W. H. VESEY--one of the most competent, accomplished and popular gentleman in the oregin service of the Government.

THE CAYUGA MARSHES.-For so many long years have the Canals of this State been in process of construction and tile subject of legislative action, that there would seem to be no possible topic connected with them which is not capable of being made a party question. Just at present the division at Albany is on the matter of the Cavuga Marshes.

Mr. JOHN D. WILLARD reported favorably the bill to provide for the descent of lands to aliens. Mr. CHARLES H. SHERRILL, Canal Commissioner, presented a communication stating that the aggregate cost of raising the canal bridges to the height of nineteen feet, on the Eastern D. vision will be $25,000, and urging the work, as demanded immediately by the necessities of navigation.

DESCENT OF LANDS TO ALIENS.-There is a bill pending in the Senate, which was yesterday reported favorably upon, providing that lands may descend to aliens in like manner as to citizens. It is one which ought to pass There is no practical reason for the distinction in this respect which the statutes make, and the theoretical reason has no application to our existing society.

THE FRASER RIVER GOLD MINES.-Mr. NUGENT's report, as special agent of the United States, recently Sent to Vancouver's Island and British Columbia, is now published, and is of much interest on account of the information it contains as to the resources and prospects of that region. He does not regard the gold fields of the Colony, hitherto prospected, as valuable.

THE OUTBREAK IN AUBURN STATE PRISON.The outbreak of the convicts in Auburn State Prison, noticed by telegraph, was a serious affair. It occurred on Saturday afternoon, March 19, in the hame-shop, some of the prisoners there employed having resisted the officers and threatened their lives. A convict ordered to the dungeon for punishment, broke away from a keeper, rushed back into the shop, and called upon the prisoners for assistance.

ASSAULT BY MARSHAL RYNDERS--REFUSAL 01' A POLICE JUSTICE TO ENTERTAIN A COMPLAINT.-Mr. W. G. DUBELL, a resident of White Plains. and in the employ of the Harlem Railroad Company, was assaulted by United States Marshal RYNDEES, Tuesday, while sitting in the office of that functionary. Mr. DUBELL is crippled from the effects of an injury received not long since, two fingers of his right hand having been fractured.

The arrival of the steamship Nora Scotian at Portland, yesterday morning, furnishes European advices to March 9-four days later than previously received. The news is of a more pacific character. An article of that tendency in the official Moniteur, coupled with the sudden resignation of the Ministry of Algeria and the Colonies by the Prince NAPOLEON, had considerably diminished the apprehensions of war, and exerted the most animating influence upon the stock markets.

The Palais Royal, of Paris, has long been for the kinsmen of the sovereign of France what Leicester House was for GEORGE IL. in the lifetime of his son FREDERIC-a "pouting-place of princes." From the Palais Royal the unprincipled EGALITE fanned the rising flame of the French Revolution.

HELP FOR BROWN.-The ingenious Mississippi Senator, who declared in Tammany Hall, with a candor truly charming, that for himself he desired Cuba for the purpose of strengthening Slavery, having been somewhat unhandsomely treated by the Washington Union and the Journal of Commerce, we are gratified to perceive that the Charleston Mercury steps promptly to his aid.

The call for a new State Convention in Pennsylvania has greatly alarmed the Administration and its partisans. As an indication of the future it is certainly an event of great significance. It is the first open and distinct proclamation that the Democratic Party cannot be coerced by Executive dictation into an abandonment of its principles and its pledges.

Several members of the Washington Bar held a meeting a few evenings since, to consider the propriety of appointing one of their number to aid in the prosecution of Mr. SICKLES. Another meeting will be held to-morrow, and the impression is that Mr. CAELISLE or Mr. BEADLEY will be selected. It is an unprecedented proceeding against a member of their own fraternity.

This morning the counsel for Mr. SICKLES appeared in Court, and Mr. CHILTON requested to know whether any action would be taken by the Court in the case of Mr. SICKLES, who was extremely anxious that his trial should be proceeded with at the earliest possible moment.

The politicians, during the past two or three weeks, have been extremely busy; nor is there likely to be a cessation of political excitement until after our municipal election in May. The People's Party have nominated two candidates for municipal offices. The first, Mr. BROWN, for the office of City Treasureran important and responsible position.

Winter in this quarter is by no means a dreary or inhospitable season of the year. The cold is not excessive, the air is dry and bracing, the temperature is uniform, the snow constant and sufficient for capital sleighing, the sky clear, and the atmosphere of a transparency which gives scope to the vision by day and splendor to the stars at night, such as is unknown at the southward and eastward.

Hunter and others, took seats upon the platforms.

EX-Governor Robinson, of Kansas, was assaulted in the streets of Lawrence, K. T., a few days since, by Martin F. Conway, who hit the Governor on the head with a cudgel. The Governor writes a letter to the Herald of Freedom, in which he tells how he retorted: "I seized him as soon as I could overtake him,

A LITTLE TOO BAREFACED.--The Board of Aldermen last night returned the nomination of Mr. PURDY for City Inspector to the Mayor. The reason they give for this is, that the Charter requires that every nomination should either be confirmed or rejected by the Board: -and that Dr. FOSTER's nomination has been neither confirmed nor rejected, and cannot be withdrawn.

MORE WASHINGTON MONUMENT.--A "Washington National Monument Society" has just been organized at the Federal capital, under a charter granted by Congress at its recent session. The Society was formed, it seems, twenty-five years ago,--yet it has only just obtained a charter, and has raised the Monument to about one-third of its proposed height.

COMFORT IN RAILROAD TRAVELING.-Sleeping cars are gradually coming into use on the various railroads throughout the country. Upon the New-York Central they have been used for several months and have proved very acceptable to the traveling community. They are also now introduced upon the Baltimore and Ohio road, though we infer from the description that the kind of couches used are different from those in this State.

Every member, except Alderman STARE, was in his seat in the Board of Aldermen last evening, and that portion of the Aldermen's Chamber which is set apart for spectators was filled with people.

The famous father of the more famous son, Jo, GEIMALDI, Sen., was as quaint a fellow off as on the stage. He worshiped times and seasons, was never last at a feast or first in a fray paid all his every in the quarter-day, and expected everybody and everything in the world to be as precise. as punctual and as inevitable as himself.

It embodies interesting and valuable information, and is perhaps as reliable as any that has appeared in the journals of the country:

ABOLISHING GRAND JURIES.--There has of late been a good deal of discussion, in tile Press and out of it, in respect to the policy of dispensing with the agency of Grand Juries in our criminal jurisprudence, and the project was greeted with pretty general favor.

The bill relative to the reorganization of the Health Department of New-York, which was recommitted last night, was again reported without any amendment and sent to the Committee of the Whole.

The mails by the Nova Scotian, from Liverpool, on Wednesday, March 9, were received in this City last evening. We add to the telegraphic synopsis published yesterday details of interest. The first meeting of the Cabinet, since the new arrangement, took place on Saturday, March 5. 5.

THE HON. JOSHUA R. GIDDINGS IN BROOKLYN--Notwithstanding the prevalence of the storm, some fifteen hundred persons assembled in Plymouth Church. last evening, to listen to the Lecture of Hon. J. R. GIDDINGS, upon the trial of JOHN QUINCY ADAMS before the House of Representatives of the XXVIIth Congress.

A dreadful accident happened to the machine last night, but this morning, newly braced and better oiled, it ran well. This was the way it happened: For weeks the Internal Affairs Committee had been brooding over certain bills touching liquor, excise, and all that, gloomily presaging that the House wouldn't meddle with any bill that would suit them, yet hating to have the odium of strangling the bills while under their nursing.

Among the foreign celebrities duly chronicled in the list of recent arrivals on these shores, there appeared, some days since, the name of Mr. James Massey from England. Mr. Massey, having achieved a high professional position in his native country, found, like all heroes, that ambition has no limit. lie longed for a new world to conquer.

MEXICO.--Dispatches have been received here from Mr. CHURCHWELL, agent of this Government in Mexico, direct from Vera Cruz. He reports the Juarez Government as gaining strength. and expresses confidence in its ability to hold cut against MIRAMON. He does not believe the latter can take Vera Cruz, and states that such is a general opinion in that city.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Among the many evils that menace the prosperity of Railways, none is more unfortunate and unnecessary than the attempt of well meaning but short-sighted persons, to prove that the management of our roads is exactly right, and that the greater engineering success of European roads is wholly due to every possible cause but better management--to any means but these which can teach the great infallible Yankee Nation.

The steamships Niagara and Alps, from Liverpool on the 12th inst., with three days' later news from Europe, are now in their thirteenth day out from Liverpool, and fully due at Halifax. They had not been hard from at 11 o'clock last night. The mails by the Nora Scotian, with European files and correspondence to March 9, reached this City last evening.

CORONERS AND THEIR JURIES.-The verdicts rendered by Coroners' Juries are too often worse than farces. Whenever there is influential raseality to be whitewashed, or the misconduct of wealthy parties to be smoothed over, as against the obscure and poor, a Coroner's inquest is one of the most convenient tools ever invented.

THE TWELFTH REGIMEST DIFFICULTY.--SPECIAL ORDERS FROM THE COMMANDEE-IN-CHIEF-THE CONSOLIDATION TO BE ENFORCED,--While the Twelfth Regisent are on a visit to Albany to protest against the conselidation of their Regiment with the Tenth, special orders from the Commender-in-Chief, dated 23d March, have reached this City, revoking the order temperarily suspending the order of consolidation, and enforcing the original order for the consolidation of the two gregiments.

THE PROHIBITORY BILL KILLED.--Yesterday the Prohibitory bill came up in the Assembly for final action, when that body placed an extinguisher upon its brief candle. Considering the fate of the measure of like character passed a few years ago, and the failure to enforce existing laws in respect to the liquor business, it is difficult to see what encouragement could be found for the introduction of a prohibitory bill at the present session.

INDEPENDENCE FOR CANADA. - "Train up a boy, and away he will go." This, though scarcely an accurate reading of a familiar passage in the Proverbs of Solomon, nevertheless expresses the experience of many a parent - Mr. John Bull among the number.

SEVENTEENTH DAY. COURT OF OVER AND TERMINER. Before the Hen. Judge Roosevelt Mr. Ashmead addressed the Jury for the defence in the forenoon, yesterday. After the morning recess Mr. Chauncey Sharper replied for the prosecution in a most vigorous and masterly speech.

DOWN TOWN lMPROVEMENTS.-The owners of property in the First Ward are again petitioning the Legislature to authorize sundry improvements in their streets, which are absolutely essential to the convenience of that portion of the City and the accommodation of its business.
Nehemiah Cutter, M. D., died at Pepperell, Mass, on the 15th inst. His wife also died on the 23d February. Dr. Cutter was a native of Jaffrey. N. H., and a graduate of Dartmouth College.

The Standing Committees reported favorably on the bills relative to the construction and use of local railroads; relative to costs in actions on notes given to mutual insurance companies, and to increase the rates of publication of legal notices.

THE QUARANTINE REMOVAL.--The Assembly took final action yesterday on the Quarantine Removal measure, passing it by a vote of 99 to 9. Just before the bill was put upon its passage an amendment was adopted, by consent, forbidding the new site to be located within one mile of Kings County.

THE STATE PRISON DIFFICULTY AT AUBURN--The two convlets wounded at Auburn in the attempt to quel the late rebellion, have died. The Corner's Jury justified the conduct of Warden KIRKPATRICK. The names of the deceased comics are HENRY LOOP and ALBERT C. GILBERT.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have noticed, in your issue of Monday last an article in which it is stated the steamer City of Hartford ran ashore on Thursday night last, also allucing to the supposition that she had been cut through by ice, and to the danger of her going in princes in the position in which she was then placed.

A CHURCH PARSONAGE ROBBED.-A daring robbery, and probably murder, was committed early on Thursday morning in Baltimore. The pastor's residence attached to the Church of the Immaculate Conception was broken into by burglars.

THE BROOKLYN WATER-WORKS BONDS-BUSINESS IN THE COMPTROLLER'S DEPARTMENT--At this time, a statement relative to Brooklyn City Bonds and the business in the Comptroller's Department will be of peculiar interest to the tax-payers and all others interested in the prosperity of Brooklyn.

Mr. ALBERT A. BLISS, EX-State Treasurer of Ohio is cut in the Cleveland Leader with an elaborate defence of himself against the accusations of the Senate Investigating Committee. He declares that the Committee's report shows malice, is full of misstatements and insinuations, and denies all the allegations.

The public schools of Cleveland seem to be in a bad way. On the one hand teachers have been obliged to leave their schools, from inefficiency in sustaining an orderly government over their pupils. Other have been censured for a rigid enforcement of their rules. On Friday, a teacher named Ford, was waylaid and beaten, in that city, even to the peril of his life, for having chastised a rebellious pupil.

A BOY'S ADVENTURES.-A Mr. PHILLIPS, of Providence, arrived here on Wednesday morning in search of his son, a lad of about 14 years of age, who had been missing from his home for a week. For the first two or three days Ihe parents suffered the greatest distress, fearing that their son was drowned.

The Legislature of New-Jersey, at the session which closed on Wednesday last, were obliging enough to furnish a very striking illustration of the extreme partisanship that marks and disgraces American politics. The facts are interesting enough to deserve distinct record.

THE LATEST CANARD.--That infallible authority, a "private letter from Paris," supplies somebody with the statement, which is duly forwarded to New-York, that LOUIS NAPOLEON is about sending an agent to Nicaragua to secure to French citizens there tile right to employ Asiatic and African apprentices in mining and other pursuits.

The public mind was not prepared for a verdiet of guilty in the case of STEPHENS. It cannot be claimed that he has been proved beyond all doubt to have murdered his wife. The evidence is wholly circumstantial, and far from being perfectly conclusive.

Mr. FAYETTE ROBINSON, the second victim of the poisoning affair at Mrs. BETHAM's boarding houses in Fourteenth-street, was a gentleman of consideration literary reputation. He was a native of Virginia highly educated and talented. Some twelve or fourteen years ago, after a long period of travel, be came to this City and accepted an engagement in the office of the Tribune.

BUYING STEAMSHIPS SHORT.-In the last budget of news from the Rio de la Plata, comes the word that none of the steamers chartered by the Navy Department had yet arrived at the mouth of that river. They were long enough out to have doubled Cape Horn;

To the Editor of the New-York Times : Since the destruction of the Quarantine Hospitals, residences and offices last September, and especially since the commencement of the present session of the Legislature, the people of this port, and of the State at large, have felt no little interest as to the questions involved in the project of removing Quarantine.

The Cuhard steamer Karnak, from Havana and Nassau, N. P., arrived at this port about 1 o'clock on Saturday morning. Among her passengers from Havana is Mr. SAMCEL DUNBAR, who has communicated the particulars of a most disastrous shipwreck which occurred near Jamaica, W. I., on the 4th inst., and the probable loss of forty out of sixty persons constituting the crew of the vessel.

On Saturday last, Mr. TEN EYCK, the recently elected New-Jersey Senator, was complimented by his neighbors with a congratulatory visit at his residence in Mount Holly, on which occasion he made a brief and very sensible speech. In the course of his remarks he mentioned several subjects which should receive his attention in his new capacity.

State Prison Inspector BAILEY writes to the Albany Evening Journal in relation to the last revolt in Auburn State Prison. He justifies the extreme measures adopted by Warden KIREPATRICK, believing that they were forced upon him by an issue which the convicts themselves had made up with their keepers. Mr. BAILEY adds:

The Grinding Committee has become the chief attraction of the Capitol for a season. Legislation is stupefied and slow both in the Senate and the Assembly chamber. But the wheel of the Committee of Nine turns perpetually, and the local bills are already almost exhausted. Unless the bridges, and tunnels, and City railroads go in, there will be nothing whatever to feed their mill with in a few days.

From the New-Orleans Picayune, 18th. This morning HEINRICH HAAS, JOSEPH LINDSAY and PETER SMITH, all convicted of murder, suffered the penalty of death by hanging. At an early hour a large crowd besieged the gates of the prison, eagerly seeking to obtain a sight of the terrible spectacle. This morbid craving was not, however, satisfied, and none could obtain admittance.

The contract for carrying tile mail from Leavenworth to Coraville, Pike's Peak region, was made under the act of 1825, authorizing the estahlishment of special Postoffices, to be sustained from their ret proceeds ; and such is the arrangement in this case that the compensation is in no event to exceed $500 per annum.

PHILHARMONIC SOCIETY,-The fourth Concert of the season took place on Saturday evening, at Nible's Garden, and attracted the usual dense throng of fashion and taste. The programme opened with a symphony by Mr. G. F. BRISTOW, in F sharp minor, a work of meritorlous execution in a technical point of view, but frequently weak and ill-sustained.

We are still without any notification of the arrival of the expected European steamers, the Niagara and the Alps, at Halifax. The line of telegraph between Bangor and points further east was reported down last night, with no prospect of immediate repair. The latest advices from Halifax are to Saturday evening, at which time the steamers had not been heard from.

THE UNDERROUND RAILROAD.--An Associa tion, composed of the colored people of Canada West,the object of which is to erect a depot at Sandwich for the reception of passengers over the Underground Railroad from the Slave States, and the more efficiently to aid those who prefer freedom to slavery in their efforts to reach Canada, has been formed.

SOUTHERN AID SOCIEY.-Religious services were held, last evening, in the Cooper institute, under the auspices of and for the purpose of enlisting support for the Southern Aid Society. After prayer, HOBACE HOLDEN, Esq., the President, opened the meeting by some remarks, in which he stated that he neither opposed Slavery or denounced Slaveholders.

The Naples correspondent of the Times writes of King Bomba. The intelligence which reaches me from Bari is to the effect that the King is suffering from a disease in the articulation of the thigh bone, producing such extreme pain as to render life almost insupportable. This disease arises from an attack which his Majesty had some years bask.

THE WANDERER'S NEGROES AND THE GOVERNMENT--A statement in the Savannah Republican, said to be from reliable authority, brings home to the Government at Washington some serious responsibility in the disposition of the negroes imported in the Wanderer.

VERBRYCK -In this City, on Sunday, March 27, at his late residence. No. 17 East 18th.st., of a lingering illness, PETER A. VERBRYCK, in tile 50th year of his age. The friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend the funeral ceremony, on Tuesday evening, at 7 o'clock. The remains to be taken to East Chester for interment, on Wednesday morning, at 9 o'clock A.M.

To the Editor of the New-York-Times : I avail myself of the first agreeable opportunity to give you a faithful statement of my experience in crossing the Tehuantepee route. We left San Francisco at 5 P. M. of Feb. 19, with 132 passengers on board of the Golden Age, and with but one incident worthy of note, made the usual pleasant run to Acapulco, arriving there at about 6 A. M. on Sunday, the 27th.

By Captain ATKINSON, of the bark Venus, from Curacoa, arrived yesterday, we have dates, to March 11: Venezuela is again disturbed. The province of Cora has declared in favor of a Federal Government, and has taken up arms in the cause. Several Exiles have left Curacoa to join their friends.

The R. M. steamship Niagara, Capt. MILLAR, from Liverpool at 2 P. M. of the 12th, arrived at Halifax at 1 P.M. of Sunday, the 27th. The Niagara experienced strong westerly gales during the first eight days of her passage, and was detained off Halifax harbor 41 hours by fog.

To Charles Stewart, Esq., Commodore: In reading the speeches and comments made in relation to the acquisition of Cuba, I have been struck with the fact that Ho mention is made of the intention of Mr. JEFFERSON to make a descent upon that island before the war of 1812, and for this purpose had caused to be built a large number of gun-boats, afterwards so much ridiculed as useless.

A KENTUCKY COMMUNITY JUSTIFYING ASSASSINATION--The brutal murder of THOMAS S. LOWE by a mob at Hawesville, Ky., has been made the subject of comment in various quarters and the conduct of the assassins who were guilty of the murder of Mr. LOWE while he was defenceless, has been severely criticised.

To the Editor of the New- York Times : I read in the TIMES of the 25th of March an avticle headed "How to Get to Pike's Peak," professing to give. through your valuable journal, " reliable" information regarding the most practicable routes to the Pike's Peak gold mines.

The steamships Niagara and Alps, of the Cunard line, from Liverpool March 12, arrived at Halifax shortly after noon on Sunday, the 27th. Their news is three days later, and is of interest. The ministerial measure in regard to Church rates was rejected in the House of Commons, March 9, by a vote of 254 to 171. Among various notices of amendments to the Government Reform bill introduced in the House,

THE MOCK-AUCTION BUSINESS.--We should like to know from some competent authority whether the mock-auction business is a legal calling or not. It is carried on openly, and without any attempt at concealment, and cases are constantly occurring in which complaints are made against them by their victims.

THE HABITS OF THE "WANDERER "NEGROES.--A. Correspondent of the Southern Recorder. writing from Jacksonville, Ga., gives the following account of the "wandering Africans" that were recently in duress, for some days, at that place: "The most of these negroes are very likely, and are from six to twenty-one years old: there is only one woman among them.

UNSETTLED ACCOUNTS--COMMUNICATION FROM THE COMPTROLLER--THE STEAM FIRE ENGINES--PIPES AND SLIPS--ASSESSMENTS FOR WIDENING DUANE AND READE STREETS--EXTRA CLERKS FOR THE STREET COMMISSIONER, C. The Board of Aldermen met last evening at 5 o'clock; in the absence of the President, Alderman BEADLET being in the chair.

TESTIMONIAL TO MR. GIDDINGS.--There was a very large and enthusiastic meeting of the colored people of New. York and Brooklyn. last evening, at the Shilch Presbyterian Church, for the purpose of doing honor to JOSHUA R. GIDDINGS, and of presenting to his a testimonial for his long and consistent defence of the rights of the colored men in the halls of congress.

A curious divorce case is pending in the California Courts. Mrs. CAROLINE H. WAND sues for a divorce from her husband, on the ground that he is a Jew, and has endeavored to bring up her child in the Jewish faith, and, also that he has been guilty of cruelty towards her.

The following address has been for warded to the Neapolitan exiles on their arrival in England: BROTHERS: During the last month we have been expecting your arrival day by day, anxious to testify by hear tv welcome the affection and reverence that we feel for your sublime fortitude, your heroic suffering in behalf of liberty in our common father-land.

JOHN MULLAN recently left this city to commence the construction of the wagon-road from For Benton, on the Missouri, to Fort Walla Walla, on the Columbia River. He will be assisted by A.M., ENGER and T. H. KOLEGKI, Topographers; C. HOWARD, Civil Engineer; G.C. TALLSFEBRO, JOHN A. SMITH, W. JOHNSTON,

To the Editor of the New-York-Times: Mr. MCLANE, the newly-appointed Minister to Mexico, with other passengers bound for Vera Cruz per steamship Tennessee, returned to this city to-day. That steamer sailed Wednesday morning, 10th inst., at 8 o'clock, and at 3 P.M. on that day ran aground in attempting to go through the Pass a POutre, at the mouth of the river.

Mr. BLKECKER sold as follows: One lot 20 feet 5 inches by 80 feet, on the northwest corner of Forty. Fifth-street and First-avenue. JAMES CUNNINGHAM, $2,200. The next adjoining, 20??60 feet. G. FOUNTAIN, $1,725. The next, came size. Same, $1,525. The next, same. JAMES HUNES, $1,575.

Governor HUNT'S speech to the Old Whigs last week excites a good deal of attention throughout the country. It is regarded, at all events represented, as a great and significant political demonstration. What there is either in the speech itself, or in the circumstances under which it was made. to warrant such a view of its importance we cannot discover.

RESTORING THE CAT IN THE STATE PRISONS-A few years ago the use of the whip in our State Prisons was prohibited by law. It is now likely to be restored. On Friday the bill codifying and amending the State Prison Laws passed the Assembly by a vote of 74 Yeas. to 14 Nays, and is regarded as likely to become a law.

The Neapolitan exiles who carried an American ship from Cadiz into Cork by the force of their own will and of the captain's humanity, have fully explained themselves. They took the ground that the contract entered into with the captain of the David Stewart by the Neapolitan authorities, according to which they were to be conveyed from Spain to America,

THE MEXICAN LEGATION AT WASHINGTON --The Washington States says that "Mexico has no legation" at Washington at present,-that, "RUBLES the late Minister, who is now acting Lieutenant-Colonel of artillery under MIRAMON, left a few servants here in charge of his furniture"

The reselutions respecting the reduction of canal tolls, being the special order, were discussed and postponed till Wednesday. Several bills of no general interest were passed. The bill restricting costs in actions brought by Mutual Insurance Companies came up for its third reading. On motion it was recommitted in order to make it entirely prohibit such actions in the case of bankrupt companies.

There would appear to be an unaccountable reluctance in certain quarters to produce tile promised report as to the merits of the si?? hundred and twenty-five judgments obtained against the City during the last year.

A bill was reported in the Assembly yesterday, to reorganize our City Government. The synopsis of its provisions which is all that has yet reached us, leads us to believe that in some important respects it is a decided improvement upon our present charter. Its leading feature seems to be the consolidation of power and responsibiity,-and this is precisely what we need most.

COTTON--Sales to-day, 2,500 bales; middling. 12c. @121c.; sales of the week, 19,500 bales. Receipts of the week, 11,145 bales, against 12,000 in the corresponding period of last year. Increased receipts at bales. Freight on Cotton to Liverpool 3/4d. STERLING EXCHANGE, 1081, @ 108 3/4.

THE WOMAN WHO NEVER EATS.-For a twelve-month past Mrs. HAYES, of the town of Chester, Warren County, N.Y., has been made known to the public, through the medium of the Press, as a very wonderful woman. The community was certified that she had lived two years without eating. It was a very great marvel.

THE RIGHT OF SEARCH AGAIN.--The Herald has been favored with a piece of exclusive intelligence from the Executive departments at Washington. It announces, with a great flourish of trumpets, that in regard to the disputed right of search, "the French Government have stepped in and submitted a project to the English Government which our Government have adopted, and which will probably settle the vexed question.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL--A regular meeting of this body was held last evening. A communication was received from the Commissioners of the Sinking fond, nominating EDMUND DEIGGS, JOHN BROACH and THOMAS COTREL to act with them to adjust, compromise and settle all liabilities and claims now existing in favor of parties against the late village or city of Willamsburgh for local improvements therein. The communication was said on the table.

WILSON.--In this City, on Tuesday, March 29, SOPHIE, only daughter of John and Sophia Wilson, in the 9th year of her age The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, at No. 75 Christopher-st, on Thursday, the 31st, inst., at 3 o'clock P. M.

FURTHER AND AUTHENTIC PARTICULARS OF THE CALAMITY. The Corrco, of Trinidad de Cuba, for March 19, contains confirmation of the report that the British gunboat Jasour had foundered near the coast of Cuba, ard that a large portion of its crew, it was feared, had been lost. We translate:

FATAL STABBING AFFRAY IN WORTH-STREETJEALOUSY THE CAUSE.--A man named John Van Voort, a boiler-maker by trade, was fatally stabbed about 91/2 o'clock on Monday evening, in Worth-sreet, by a sailor named William Eday Moore. It appears that Moore, some time ago, married a woman named Lizzie Hughes, and soon after became jealous of attentions paid to his wife by Van Voort.

the Cochituate Viaduct at Newton, Lower Falls burst at an early hour this morning, carrying a way portions of the embankment, and causing quite a flood in the vicinity. Several factories at the Upper Falls, by the accumulation of back water, were threatened with an overflow.

PERUVIANS.--The Commissioner of the Pension Office states that the amount necessary to satisfy the immediate demands against the Bureau is $29,769.710; that the average sum annually requisite thereafter would be about $8,800,000 for ten years.

NEXT TO A MIRACLE.--Mr. BUCHANAN'S Administration has done what everybody, until within the last few months, deemed absolutely impossible. It has incited a large number of its friends to look to General PIERCE as a Presidential candidate.

COLLISION AND LOSS OF LIFE ON THE HUDSON. -About 81/2 o'clock Monday evening, one of the Hudson River steamers (supposed to have been the North America) came into collision with the sloop Stephen Raymond, of Hastings, near that village. The crew, consisting of three persons, had not time to escape from the vessel before she went down, and were all drowned.

BROOKLYN COURTS.--City Court--Calendar for March 30--Nos. 38, 45, 46, 47, 49, 50, 52, 53, 12, 55, 57, 58, 6, 59, 60, 61, 24. SUPREME COURT--NOTICE TO THE BAR.--The Kings County Special Term for the first Monday of April will be held on that day at 10 o'clock in the forenoon, by Judge INGRAHAM of New-York.

The Legislature of this island are engaged at present in revising the tariff, and some of the changes made will interest those of your readers who are engaged in West India commerce. The mostimportant reduction is that in the duty on codfish, from eight to four cents the quintal.

The present session of the Legislature commenced on the 4th of January, and, accordingly, but fifteen days of the Constitutional hundred are left. Most of that period will be busily occupied in passing bills selected by the Grinding Committee, into whose hands a very important power is committed.

Before Justice Clerke. MANDAMUS AGAINST THE MAYOR. The People excel George W. Morton vs. Daniel F. Tiemann, Mayor, alternative mantamus has been issued by Justice CLERKE to require Mayor Tiemann to countersign the Comptroller's warrant for the payment of City-Inspector Morton's salary for the months of January and February last.

A number of enthusiastic American citizens, now residing in the new British colony of Victoria, have just published an address " To the World," in which they set forth, with sophomoric magnificence of style, certain frightful injuries which they have endured at, the hands of Gov. DOUGLASS, of that colony.

The mail steamship Granada, Lieut. 0. H. BERRYMAN, U. S. N., Commander, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing the mails received from the Illinois, disabled at Havana. We are thus furnished with highly interesting intelligence from the Western Coast of South America, from New-Granada, Central America, California, and the Northern Pacific Ocean.

THE REVOLUTION IN CORO-MISHAP TO A REBEL LEADER. The Boletin Offcial of Caracas, of March 10. states that the enemies of the existing order of things, who had levied civil war in Coro, and who hoped to extend it to other points, were redused to the last extremity.

Private letters from a highly responsible source have been received here from Mexico, giving the details of a secret treaty between MIRAMON and the Government of Sardinia, by which the former grants to Sardinia the States of Tabasco, Tehuantepec and Chiapa, (or five millions of dollars-France advancing one million, and guaranteeing the payment of the balance. Sardinia is to send out emigrants,

The mails from the Isthmus, Western Coast of South America and North Pacific, brought by the Illinois from Aspinwall, March 19, and transferred to the Granada, at Havana, in consequence of an accident to the former steamer, arrived in this City yesterday, in the afternoon.

Tile bills chartering the South Pacific American Mail Steamship Company; authorizing the American Express Company to sell certain real estate; to incorporate the New-York Observatory Association, and to increase the rates of publication of legal notices, were ordered to a third reading.

We are now hemmed in here most completely. and are suffering a tyranny of the most despotic character. The last mail for the States from here was seized by MIRAMON. By the way of England, we are placed in possession of our files of papers from Rio to Feb. 9, and from Buenos Ayres to Jan. 28 We add details to the telegraphic summary forwarded from Lisbon. The news from Rio Janeiro is without importance. From Montevideo, Jan. 30, we have a statement of the grounds for the expulsion of the Jesutts.

A PRECIOUS COMMODITY OF EPITHIETS.--The Washington Union has been sold to general BOWMAN, who is to take charge of the President's organ on the 11th of April; but, the present Editor appears determined to make use of the little time left him, to work off all his bad blood and acrid bumors, while he has an outlet at his command for ventilating his bilious feelings.

Mr. SICKLES is busily engaged with his counsel in preparing for his defence. The impression is that the District-Attorney will have no assistance, as he needs none, the case on the part of the Government being entirely simple. The facts to be presented by the District-Attorney are few and easily proven-the fact and the manner of foe killing, and the identity of the accused.

The London Times continues to express the opinion, in which we have little doubt that it speaks the mind of the majority of intelligent Englishmen, that the Reform bill of the Derby Ministry is substantially as sound and good a measure as can be fairly hoped for in the present aspect of English affairs.

The Royal Mail steamship Persia, Captain JUDKINS, from Liverpool, March 19, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Kangaroo, Captain JEFFREYS, from Liverpool, March 16, arrived a few hours previously. The Cunard steamship Africa, from New-York, arrived out at Liverpool at 7 o'clock on the morning of the 14th, and the screw-steamer Saxonia, from NewYork, reached Southampton on the same morning.

THE NEW GAS COMPANY.-There is much re joioing at the action of the City authorities on Monday night last, in giving permission to the Citizens' Gas-Light Company to lay gas mains throughout the city, and enter into competition with the Brooklyn Gas-Light Company, for supplying citizens with gas. The old Company has the contract for supplying the public buildings and streets for the next five years,

The latest move of Gen. PESQUIERA, the Governor of Sonora, is the estalishment of a colony in that State, recruited from california. The Eco del Pacifico publishes the following extract from a letter adressed by the Governor to a Spanish gentleman in San Francisco. The date is Alamos, Dec. 10, 1858: "I have written to day to the Mexican Emigration Society in Los Angeles to aid them in their labors,

We have received Hayti files to March 5. President GEFFRARD had issued a circular to the Governors of the various Departments in the Republic, advising a mild as sell as firm administration of justice, and discouraging the severe bodily punishments in vogue during the Empire. Various police and other local reforms occupy the attention of the citizens of Port-au Prince.

Events seem bastening towards a crisis in Nicaragua. The British Minister has secured the ratification of his treaty; the Frenchman, M. BELLY, has entered upon the construction of his canal; President MARTINEZ is alarmed at rumored invasions of fillibusters,-and our Government seems likely to be absolutely driven from its attitude of indifference and supineness.

The columns of the New-York Times, this morning, contain intelligence of extraordinary moment from almost every quarter of the globe. By the arrival of the Persia, the Kangaroo and of the Niagara at Boston we are furnished with details of European intelligence for nine days ending upon March 19, with later news from India and China.

BALDWIN--SMITH--In this City, on Wednesday afternoon, March 30, by the Rev. Wm. P. Carbit LUTHER BALDWIN. Esq., to Miss THRODOSIA SMITH, all of this City. WOODWARD--FREELAN--In this City, on Wednesday. March 30, by the Rev. J.P. Covey. NIMROD WOODWARD. Jr., to M. A. FREELAN, all of this City. DE LA GRANGE--DELMONICO--In this City, on Tuesday, March 29, at St. Ann's Church, by the Rev. O. Cauvin.

IMPRISONMENT OF WITNESSES.-Whatever bills may be left over by the present session, we trust the one designed to abolish the imprisonment of witnesses, will not be of the number. Let the Grinding Committee see to it. We have a maxim that even in the case of persons charged with crime, it is better to allow ten guilty to escape than to punish one who is innocent.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In an editorial article in your issue of yesterday, about judgments against the City, you mention my name as one of those who have largely drawn on the City Treasury by means of fraudulent suits. Now, this does me very great injustice,as I have not now,nor have I had at a any time to which your remarks can refer. any judgments against the City.

A TOUCRING SCENE.-After his usual Wednesday evening lecture, last night, the Rev. Mr. BEECHER presented to his congregation the case of a slave mother in Virginia who had been freed with her five children by the will of her deceased mistress,-but whom the heirs, availing themselves of legal technicalities, had again reduced to slavery.

England has risen like one man to welcome to her free and hospitable shores the exiles of Neapolitan tyranny. POERIO, SETTEMBRINI, and their companions, men whose only crime, proved against them in the most merciless of courts, and after the most cruel of inquisitions, was this, that they mistook a Bourbon for a gentleman,

The Northern Light, of the Vanderbilt new line of California steamships, E. L. TINKLEPAUGH, commanding, from Aspinwall on the night of the 22d, with 670 passengers, and $136,820 in treasure--brought by the steamer Orizaba from San Francisco on the 5th instant, to Panama--arrived at her dock last evening at 8:45.

The bil to charter the New-York Observalory was ordered to a third reading. The Grinding Committee put forward several bills, among them the New-York Western Dispensary bill. A large number of reports were presented by the various Committees, but none of general interest. The bill to protect the liberty of witnesses was taken up in Committee of the Whole.

ANOTHER FATAL. STABBING AFFRAY.-About 9 P.M., on Tuesday, as Officer LAWRENCE was or duty in Second-avenue, near Thirty-second-street, a man named WM. BOLAND came running up to him, and asked him to go round to his house in Thirty-second-street, and arrest a man who had been quarreling with himself and family.

LIMPING LOGIC.-A correspondent of the Savannall Republican is mildly afflicted because the TIMES denounces the Slave-trade and the recent landing of African negroes on the Southern coast. As the TIMES, says the writer, approves the. Personal Liberty bill pending at Albany, and encourages the underground railroad operations, it has no business to censure Southern Slave-traders. We might make an argument in reply to this logic.

A private letter received at Washington from Fort Yuma, bearing date of March 4, speaks in very discouraging terms of the prospect of the gold diggers in that vicinity. In short, the writer says that the mines are one of the grandest humbugs of the day, and those who go there expecting to amass fortunes in a few weeks or months will be wotully disappointed.

A NEWSPAPER IN ARIZONA.-The Weck ly Ari zonian has been started at Tubac. It is a small sheet, published weekly. The initial number corrects the reports that six hundred men are at work in the mines; the fact being that the number does not exceed three hundred at the highest estimate, and, moreover, that most of these are barely clearing expenses.

" SENSATION PREACHERS."-One of the religious weeklies has an article censuring the preachers who select topics and adopt a style calculated to attract a crowd and make themselves personally conspicuous.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I regret to see, in your issue of the 28th, an article headed, "Partisanship in New-Jersey," which is not characterized by that candor and fairness which generally pervades your paper. It is an exceedingly grave error to suppose that the appointments of Chancellor was a contest between the two political parties in the State,

We mentioned a day or two since the enormous order for books for the State of Ohio, received by one of our leading houses. We understand that Ohio annually appropriates about $82,000 to the purchase of school apparatus and books for her school libraries. This large amount is raised by a tax of one-tenth of a mill on the dollar of the entire property valuation of the State. Under this law, the lion.

The California papers contain elaborate reports of the difficulties between the miners and the Chinese. The grudge against the Chinamen appears to have broken out in new acts of violence. Recent accounts from Shasta tell of violent proceedings taken by miners to expel Chinese working in the mines of that County.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There are several facts in your article headed "Partisanship in New-Jersey," which are mis-stated; and as you say " the facts are interesting enough to deserve distinct record," it is important they should be stated with accuracy. First. You state, " there was nothing in the char aoter or the legal ability of Chancellor Willimson to recommend him to reappointment."

The lack of efficiency in the arrangements of our City Post-office prevented our receiving most of our correspondence by the Northern Light which arrived on Wednesday evening in time for our edition of yesterday morning. We append such items from it as still have interest: ASPINWALL, Tuesday, March 22, 1859.

THE ACCIDENT TOT HE COCHITUATE WATER WORKS.--The work of repairing the damage to the Cochituate Aquedeuct at Newton Lower Falls, is progressing with all possible dispatch. Nearly two hundred men were engaged during yesterday in filling up the deep gulley caused by the break, and Mr. SLADE, the City Engineer, estimates that water can be supplied from the Aqueduct through one of the three pipes by Saturday, or Sunday at the farthest.

The Broker's Board of New-York have just afforded us a new and instructive commentary upon the spirit in which the enormous Railway interest of the United States with all that it involves of national and individual prosperity has of late years been treated by the legalized speculators in this sort of property. The Michigan Southern Railroad is one of the great arterial lines of the country.

General orders from headquarters at San Antonio, issued March 3 and 5,

SIDELL, Esq., a select party of influential Mexican citizens and some Americans, including the Consul, proceeded in company with him to the spot selected.

COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. Before Judges Roosevelt, Ingraham, Davies and Clerke. It was perhaps well that Deputy-Superintendent Carpenter sent twenty-five policemen to this Court yesterday morning, on the application of the Sheriff,to preserve order, at the expected sentence of Stephens, for certainly such a crowd has not been collected around the entrances of the brown-stone building in tile Park, as was witnessed on this occasion.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Every American returning from England and the Continent must feel at once the difference and discomfort of railroad traveling in this country, and, therefore, many a one must have perused with pleasure the article in your wide-spread paper of March 25, as a move in the right direction.

KING--DOREMUS.--In this City, on Thursday, March 31, by the Rev. Dr. Macauley. EDWARD DE LA ROSEE KING, M. D., of North Carolina, to HENRIETTA HAINES, daughter of T. C. Doromus, of this City. MENEILL--COWL.--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, March 30, by the Rev. Mr. Van Dyke THOMAS A MEINELL to M. JOSEPHINE COWL, all of Brooklyn.

We, lend no faith to the charges brought against the Administration of favoring the reopening of the Slave-trade. They are partisan in their motive and evince the usual unscrupulousness of partisanship in distorting and exaggerating facts so as to give them plausibility. There has clearly been laxity and remissness in enforcing the law against slave-dealers, in cases which have recently attracted the public attention.

THE MISSIONARY BRIG MORNING STAR A FAILURE,-There are sorry accounts from the Sandwich Islands concerning the brig Morning Star, the missionary packet lately built by the contributions of the Sunday School children in the Atlantic States. The Honoluiu Commercial Advertiser says she had put Into that port for repairs.

MOVEMENT OF THE NEW GOVERNMENT--GENERAL CONTENT--AMERICAN SHIPPING. By the arrival of the brig John Bogart from Port at Prince, we have advices from Hayti to the 15th inst. Captain BLYE reports the place as being very quiet. We have received a copy of the Feuille du Commerce, dated Port au Prince, March 12, but it contains little of importance.

DEAR SIR: Without hesitation, I reply at once to yours of the 15th inst., received yesterday, by deciaring that I do " intend to support Mr. LETCHER for the office of Governor;" and, upon the hypothesis that he would adhere to the State and National platform of Democratic principles, I have never intended otherwise.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I chain the privilege of saying to your readers that the statement in your paper yesterday in referance to Mrs. HATCH and myself is in every essential particular false. The facts are these: I attended her lecture Sunday last, and quietly took my seat in the audience without having any conversation with any one, and though Mrs. H. was in the ante-room fifteen

To the Editor of the New- York Times: An edition of JOSEPH RPD,AM DRALE'S DRAKE'S poem, " The Culprit Fay," having been recently issued by a publishing-house in this City, and extensivelv advertised for sale, I hereby announce that the edition was published without the consent of the family of the late Dr. DEAKE, and that the sale is peremptorily stonned.

MATRIMONIAL BROKERAGE.-Tuesday evening Officer MASTERSON arrested PRESOOTT F. HARRIS. alias Prescott Fitzallen, on a charge of swindling, preferred by J. WILSON SIMPSON. According to Mr. SIMPSON'S story, his attention was attracted some two months since to an advertisement stating that the advertiser wished to meet with some gentleman whose means would er able him to educate liberally two of his nieces. Mr. S sought an introduction to the ladies. They improved upon acquaintance.

Reecher, and the Exempt Firemen are invited to attend his funeral, on Friday, April 1, at 21/2 o'clock, from No. 72 Columbia st. McLOUGHLIN.--In this City, on Thursday, March 31. JAMES McLOUGHLIN, in the 21st year of his age.

THE BOSTON POST-OFFICE DIFFICULTY.--The Postmaster-General has written a letter to Colonel SCHOULER, of the Boston Committee of Remonstrants against the removal of the Post-office, stating that the Government must be indemnified for the extra expense incurred by the recent action of Postmaster CAPEN. Mr. HALL says:

The Italians seem to be fully of our way of thinking, as expressed in these columns, two months ago, about the propriety of acting under the auspices and guidance of Sardinia in the coming struggle. Every mail brings fresh evidence of the determination of all classes and conditions in every part of the country to sink for the present all minor differences, and range themselves under the Sardinian flag.

An important report was presented, signed by the Lieutenant-Governor and all the Commissioners of the Canal Fund, setting forth the fact that the surplus fund for the payment of the interest on the Canal debt is entirely exhausted, and that to pay the interest and the deficiency of the debt $1,039,000 will be needed. This amount, they intimate, must be provided for by the Legislature,

Mr. DAWSON, the President of the Northwest Transportation Company was in England, recently, and offered to convey the ma is for Fraser's River and China across British American territory, instead of having them sent, as at present, by Panama or by the Mediterranean.

The Administration doubts the report that MIRAMON is in collusion with Sardinia and France, but doubts do not alter the facts. Chiapas is known to be in open revolt, and Guatamala, Honduras and Salvador are aiding her. The next steamer may bring information that the Central American States have joined MIRAMON, to crush out American enterprise in that region.

TOWN ELECTIONS IN WESTCHESTER COUNTY.On Tuesday the annual election for Town officers was held in Westchester County. Mr. WILLIAM CAULDWELL (Democrat) was unanimously reflected to the office of Supervisor in Morrisanla, receiving 728 votes. In the Town of West Farms, Mr. JOHN BASSING (Democrat) was also reelected to the office of Supervisor, by a majority of two votes over the Republi can candidate, C. W. BATHGATE.

THE VERDICT ON THE CANADIAN RAILWAY DISASTER.--The Coroner's Jury in the case of the last accident on the Great Western Railroad, in Canada have rendered a long and curious verdict. They first censure the Company for the faulty construction of the embankment at the point where the accident occurred: state that no sufficient drainage was provided to carry away the surface water;

A band of fifty-two Seminoles, belonging to Wild Cat's people, who have been in Mexico for some years, have applied to Capt. Caldwell, at Fort Duncan, for an escort to enable them to traverse Texason their way back to their tribe, settled on the Arkansas frontier. Capt. Caldwell has grented the request.

THE STATE OF VERA CRUZ-GUADALAJARA AND MEXICO IN A STATE OF SIEGE-MOVEMENTS OF MIRAMON. By the arrival of the mails by the Quaker City from Minatitlan, March 19, we have Vera Cruz papers to the 14th, five days later than we had by the Tennessee direct.

THE OHIO TREASURY FRAUDS--ANOTHER STATE MENT.--The recent report of the Senate Investigating Committee, of Ohio, on the frauds in the Treasury Department has raised a general breeze. The parties implicated in the report are constantly appealing in their own defence.

Something like a dramatic revival seems likely to follow the not altogether lamented decease of our discomfortable cousin at Miss LAURA KEENE'S. A lady, well-known to Metropolitan audiences as Miss DAVENPORT, has taken the building lately leased by Mr. BURTON, and, under the name of the "New Metropolitan," will open it on Monday evening with a company selected by herself and Mr. BROUGH.

FIDUCIARY INSURANCES.--On the 19th of last month the Insurance Committee of the Assembly, of which Mr. OPDYKE is Chairman, reported favorably a bill authorizing the organization of companies to insure the fidelity of clerks, agents, and other persons holding places of trust, the passage of which is of no slight importance to the great interests concerned.

THE WATER CELEBRATION.-The Water Committee are perfecting their arrangements for the water celebration, and it is already estimated that the procession will be some six miles in length. The Fire Department will make an imposing display in the city demonstration during the day, and will besides have a torchlight procession in the evening. The Committee yesterday appropriated $650 for the use of the firemen;

One of the earliest, and not the least reliable, indications of increased activity in business on this side of the Atlantic is the general uprising of mechanics to quarrel with their bread and butter in the attempt to obtain more butter to their bread.

Mr. DIVEN, from the Finance Committee, reported the bill authorizing a loan of $2,500,000, to pay the floating debt, and it was ordered to a third reading. Mr. PROSSER reported favorably the Assembly bill to provide for the payment of the interest on the Canal Commissioners' drafts.

To the Editor of the New-York times : Quite a number of letters and editorials have appeared in your and other papers, against the bill dividing the Sixth Judicial District, now before the Legislature at Albany. If you will allow a small space for the other side. I think I can show that no fair-minded man can possibly be in favor of having things stand as they are.

The dispatches of Minister LAMAR to the State Department, corroborated by those received at the British Legation, announce the ratification of one of the Ouseley Treaties with Nicaragua, and at the same time explain the cause of the failure to ratify the Cass-Yrisarri Treaty.

HOLLY.--In this City, on Thursday, March 31, MARY EMMA, daughter of David W. and ALNA C. Holly, in the 11th year of her age. Her relatives, and the friends of the family, are invited to attend her funeral this day. (Saturday) at 3 o'clock P. M. from the residence of her parents, 51st st., near the 8th av. Her remains will be taken to Trinity Cemetery.

ANNEXATION DECLINED--We have been for state time in doubt whether we should or should not accept the offer of marriage, made to us in anticipation of the coming Leap-year, is our lovely neighbor of Canada.
