On Thursday the Commissioners of the Canal Fund, viz, the Lieutenant-Governor, Secretary of State, Comptroller, Treasurer and AttorneyGeneral, startled the Senate by a communication calling attention to the fact that if the Legislature would preserve the State from dishonor, arrangements must be made before the close of the present session to raise more than a million of dollars.

An incident occurred at the last act in the Stephens' tragedy yesterday, which brings forward so prominently once more the peculiar style of " practice" to which Mr. ASHMEAD resorts in his defence of prisoners, that we cannot help commenting upon it.

Mayor TIEMANN has put the responsibility of the shameful continuance in office of Mr. City Inspector MORTON upon the proper persons, by his letter which we to-day publish, returning his nomination of ELIJAH F. PURDY to the Board of Aldermen for their action.

LETTER FROM SENATOR DOUGLAS.--The Hartford Post publishes a letter from Senator DOUGLAS, in reply to one from the editor, from which we make the following extracts: "I sincerely regret that circumstances over which I have LO control have rendered it impossible for me to visit Connecticut during your present canvass.

THE WHARF INTERESTS OF NEW-YORK.--What is to be done with our wharves? The session of the Legislature is fast waning; and New-York waits with natural anxiety to know whether her wharf-owners are to be driven by a senseless adherence to an antiquated tariff into abandoning all notion of improving the condition of our wharves,

CONNECTICUT ELFCTION.--The annual election in Connecticut for State officers, members of Congress and of the Legislature takes place on Monday next. Unusual Interest is felt in the result, not only in that State, but throughout the Union, on account of its supposed bearing upon the national canvass of 1860. The following are the leading nominations:

FIRES--At 11 o'clock, Thursday night, the furactory of ADOLPH SEYBOTH, on Walton-street, near March-avenue, was destroyed by fire Mr. S. estimates his loss at $6,000, upon which there is an insurance of $3,000. The building belonged to SAMUEL WISWELL, and was valued at $1,500.

A misunderstanding has occurred as to the disposal which shall be made of the money received from the sale of tickets to admit spectators to the great Billiard match which is to take place week after next at Detroit. Some time since the statement was made that the surplus, after paying expenses, was to go to Mount Vernon. Fund.

General LAMAR announces in his dispatches the ratification of one of the Ouseley Treaties. The Mosquito Treaty is now under consideration. The British Legation, I understand, has dispatches to the same effect. The cause of the ratification of the Ouseley and the postponement of the Cass-Yrisarri Treaty is of easy explanation.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--This establishment will open on Monday next with a good company under the management of Miss DAVENPORT. A new version of SCRIDE'S "Czarina" is the attraction. MLLE. LAMOUREUX.--This distinguished artist has recently returned from Havana and Matanzas where her triumphs have been unequivocal.

On Monday evening last, about 8 o'clock, the steamers Nathaniel Holmes, bound from Pittsburg for St. Louis, and the David Gibson, from New-Orleans for Cincinnati, came in collision a short distance Below Petersburgh, Ky., and two miles above, and in sight of Aurora, with such force as to sink the former instantly, and the latter in a few minutes.

THE LATE COLLISION AT THE STATEN ISLAND FERRY.--An examination was commenced Saturday by Justice OSBORN at the Lower Police Court regarding the late collision of the Staten Island ferry boat Hunchback and one of the Government barges attached to the Customer house, by which TIMOTHY DONOVON, one of the bargemen, was drowned.

The Hon. Edward Everett left Boston April 1, on a short tour to the South, He is under engagement to repeat his discourse on Franklin at Baltimore on tile 4th inst., and at Richmond on the 8th. The following week he delivers his address at Wilmington and other places in North Carolina.

A NEW CONSTITUTION FOR CANADA.-- On Tuesday of last week the Hon. JAMES MORRIS gave notice in the Legislative Council at Toronto, that early in the ensuring session he would move resolutions to the effect that Her Majesty be pleased to authorize the Governor General to call a Convention of twenty-four delegates,

A UNIVERSITY IN AMERICA. - The Boston Atlas says: " We are gratigied to learn that some stops have at length been taken to found a University in this country, and from the character of the parties interested in the enterprise, are led to believe that success will crown their efforts.

BRANCH AGAIN.--STEPHEN H. BRANCH gives a lecture with accompaniments tonight at Hope Chapel. That it will be saigeneris is made sufficiently certain by the fact that it is his:--It may safely be predicted also that it will not lack amusement, whether it be instructive or not. Mr. BRANCH has figured in various ways before the public and has been engaged in enterprises of many kinds.

THE NURSERY.--We can requested to state that the article in the Sunday Atlas, headed "A case of inhumanity--How our charitable institutions are managed," has been written under a gross misrepresentation of the facts, and the institution alluded to courts and earnestly desires a thorough investigation into its management,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A prominent topic of discussion in this great commercial emporium at the present time is, the mudlumps at the mouths of the Mississippi. The hindrance they cause to commerce and trade is becoming more and more apparent, day by day. At a late moment of he last session of Congress,

DEATH OF OSCAR W. STURTEVANT.--OSCAR W. STURTEVANT, who occupied a very prominent position in political affairs in this City a few years since, died suddenly at the Astor House on Friday night. He was 49, years old. He was born in Vermont, and came to this City when a boy, and followed the sea for several years until he rose to be mate of a ship.

As the day approaches when the strength of parties is to be tried in Parliament, on the question of Reform, curiosity increases as to the course which various minor sections, as well as particular individuals will take. In spite of all the outward show of unanimity on the part of the Whigs, there still prevails much of the old dissension and distrust.

Colonel LOCKRIDGE, of fillibustering fame, has it appears, lost all affection for his beloved Nicaragua, and is now intent upon extending the blessings of his presence to Arizona, with the view, as he states, of peacefully colonizing that delightful region.

The following Assembly bills were reported favorably : To charter the American Missionary Association. To charter the Woman's Library of New-York. To provide for ascertaining and collecting the damages caused by the destruction of the Marine Hospital buildings at Quarantine. For the removal of Quarantine.

In 1858, Herr VON VINCKE, addressing the Prussian Assembly as an advocate of the Western Alliance against Russia, declared that Prussin was made the "postboy and letter-carrier of Europe ;" that instead of taking part with emphasis and dignity in the great Areopagus of the nations, she was merely running from one Power to another with propositions for making everything smooth ;

NEW-YORK. April 2, 1859--No. 239 Fifth-avenue. THE NEW-YORK TIMES of this morning contains an editorial article severely reflecting on my professional and personal conduct, in the management of the Congemi and Stephens trials, and calculated greatly to Injure my personal and professional character. The charges made in the article against me are wholly false, and I will institute at an early day appropriate legal proceedings for the injury.

BENNETT. - At Westport, Conn., on Sunday, April 3, Mrs. ELIZABETH BENNETT, widow of Wm. Bennett, aged ??2 years. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, at her late residence, on Tuesday, 5th inst., at 2 o'clock P. M. WOODRUFF.--In this City, on Sunday morning, April 3.

The schooner Hartford, of Bangor, Teage, from Boston for South Carolina, came ashore yesterday forenoon. The crew were saved, and the vessel will probably be got off. The schooner Susan and Mary, Whitmore, from Calais for Norfolk, Virginia, came ashore here yesterday morning. Crew saved, Vessel tight.

The new City Charter and the City Railroad bill are among the matters of importance, touching the City interests, which await the action of the Legislature. Both encounter the preliminary objection that the City should be left to make her own laws and attend to her own affairs.

A curious story of conjugal affection is told by an Illinois paper: "Five years ago a carpenter moved from Bucyrus, ohio, to Missouri, where he sold a pair of horses to a stock buyer, receiving all his pay in bills on a kentucky bank.

The steamship Indian, from Liverpool on the 23d of March, with four days' later news from Europe, is now about due at Portland. Her advices are looked for with much anxiety, as it is quite likely they will decide the question of peace or war. A very important move in Nicaraguan affairs is anticipated at Washington.

The Albany Evening Journal says: "Last Fail indications were discovered in the vard of the clinton Prison, of the presence of iron ore under the surface. Excavations were commenced, and have since been vigorously prosecuted, under direction of Inspector Everest, Which have resulied even more favorably than was anticipated.

WORDSWORTH, who has been justly commended by a sparkling writer as the " great poet whom all of us respect and none of us read," has somewhere observed, In moralizing upon the fall of Venice, " Men are we, and must grieve when even the shade of that which once was great doth pass away ;"

Rome is bright and sunny. the apricots and violets are in blossom, the trees along the road to the Pinclan are in the blushing life-phase of budding, and the birds and love making beneath my open casements. Yet, but a few days since, Winter, in his northward journey, took a look over his shoulder and dispelled Spring time musings from Roman and Stranger.

MURDEROUS AFFRAY.--A fight took place, yesterday afternoon, between two men, at the corner of Hudson-avenue and Do Kalb, when one struck the other with a cleaver on the side of the head, inflicting a serious wound and cutting off a portion of the check bone. The injured man was taken to the City Hospital.

Paris is rapidly becoming the rendezvous of the world's royalty. Several first sons of unknown Eastern kings have lately arrived here to obtain their education, while the number of fallen kinds and queens, dictators and presidents, is only counted by dozens.

The trial of Mr. SICKLES for the murder of PHILIP BARTON KEY, commenced yesterday at Washington--or rather the case was called on yesterday, and the attempt to obtain a jury was commenced. A panel of thirty was exhausted, out of whom but five were sworn--four of the others being peremptorily challenged, and twenty-one being set aside for cause.

The Charleston Mercury, discussing the steadily increasing tendency of political parties towards a purely sectional organization, expresses some doubt as to whether the Charleston Nominating Convention will ever meet, and say that if it does, the Democratic Party can only be properly represented in it by Southern delegates.

Our Southern fellow-citizens continually insist upon it that it is we of the North who provoke all the discord which now vexes the union of the States. They point to our Abolitionist Conventions, to our Anti-Slavery journals, to our Free-Soil parties, as the perpetual instigators of ill-blood and hostile feelings between the two great sections into which the country is divided by its social institutions.

Board of Aldermen. President McSPEDON and Aldermen ADAMS and OWENS were the only members of the Board present when the hour of meeting arrived yesterday, and the Board was declared adjourned for want of a quorum. The day for the next meeting is not fixed ; the Board will meet again at the call of the President.

The Brooklyn water hill was reported complete by Mr. ANDRUS this morning. As amended, the power to substitute a closed conduit for the open canal east of Baiseley's Pond, is struck out. ACCIDENT TO AN AMERICAN SAILOR--THE MARKETS. Our files of Rio papers to Feb. 19, have been received. The news is of no moment. JOHN RYLANDER, pilot of the American bark S. W. Porter, was killed on the 15th February while aiding in unloading the vessel.

A telegram from Harrisburgh, published yesterday, announced the arrest of a "fugitive slave in that city on the 1st April. The Harrisburgh Telegraph, of Saturday, gives the following particulars: "Considerable excitement was created, this morning, by the capture of a quiet and inoffensive colored individual, in the Market-house, by United States Deputy Marshal JENKINS, assisted by two other officers.

THE SLAUGHTER OF THE INNOCENTS.--The Grand Jury recently discharged in the Court of Over and Terminer, mad a presentment which was found on file yesterday. They visited the County buildings in Flatbush, and found them in a commendable conditions as to cleaniness and the health of the females except the nursery.

A WICKED YOUTH AND A FOOLISH DAUGHTER.--Some time since Charles Fairchild, a young man about nineteen, formed the acquaintance of Louisa Church, a flaxen-haired and rosy-checked girl, fourteen years old. The father of Louisa is the proprietor of a shoe-store in Hudson-street, and the daughter was employed as an assistant to wait on customers.

Mr. MULLER sold, by order of the Executors of THOMSON PRICE, deceased, te four story brick house and lease of lot No. 3 Canal-street, north side, near Jefferson street. The lease in from the Ratgers Estate, and has nine years to run, $98 per annum ground rent, with the usual convenants for renewal at a fair valuation, or buildings to be paid for.

SCARCTIY OF CITY LOTS.--Some enthusiastic statistician has been making an estimate of the number of City lots which can hereafter be brought into the market, and the result of his calculation is that not more than thirty-five thousand can be added to the number now available for building purposes.

STARRING MATCH AT HOYM'S THEATRE. The ?? exciting exhibition of the season, in the way of sparing, took place at Hoym's Theatre last evening, the ?? attraction being the announcement that the two most distinguished Champions of the Ring, M?? and HERMAN, would take part in the performances.

Miss JANE DAVENPORT kept her word last night with an admiring public by welcoming them to a regenerated house, new properties, elaborate costumes, and a thrilling new play in five acts, done from the French of SCRIBE into the English of Mr. O. S. LELAND. The "New Metropolitan Theatre" has been famously furbished up since those last dwindling days of the Burtonian dynasty, in which it had become a very "Anatomy of McIancholy."

THE WOMAN WHO LIVES WITHOUT EATING.-- A correspondent at Glen's Falls, noticing our recent paragraph concerning the detection of the imposture said to be practiced by Mr. HAYS who pretends to live without eating, denies the fact of such detection. He says that the Committee appointed to investigate the matter instituted a watch of six persons, who were to continue twenty-one days unless sooner convinced of the imposture.

STEAMER C. VANDERBILT.--This steamer, which at one time was considered as totally lost on Fisher's Island, has now been about one month on the ways at Hunter's Point. Her bottom was found to be badly chafed, but there was not a timber broken. New timbers are being put in to replace those found to be any was defective, and an entire new bottom will be put on.

ARRIVAL OF THE CAHAWBA--A PRUSSIAN PRINCE COMING TO NEW-YORK. The U.S. Mail steamship Cahawba, J. D. BULLOOH Commander, for New-Orleans aid Havana, arrived here yesterday morning, having left the latter place on the evening of the 30th ult. The gay season at Havana is nearly over ; and, as a natural consequence, people are leaving for the North.

A. L. LAMAR and others.

The three Special Committees on the New-York Railroad bills, met in joint session to-night. Mr. L. B. LYON was Chairman, and Mr. JAMES B. RRILLY, Secretary, A. OAREY HALL and other in behalf of roads, and Messrs. OPDIGER, J. BARLEY and MYERS in opposition. After hearing the arguments, the Committee adjourned until to-morrow morning.

The trial of Mr. SICKLES commenced this morning, and the scene in the court-room has been intensely exciting. Mr. SICKLES was escorted from the jail on foot by a number of friends and a great crowd of idle spectators. He took position in the prisoner's box, and there remained during the proceedings, exhibiting no unusual marks of agitation, but appeared as one of the lookers-on.

The bill to authorize the removal of the New-York Mining Company was ordered to a third reading. The Brooklyn Local Assessment bill was sent to be reported complete. Mr. NOXON called up the bill regulating the rates of wharfage in New-York and Brooklyn, and the report of the Committee was agreed to and the bill ordered to a third reading.

Mr. RAN RUNNELS, the newly-appointed Consul for San Juan del Sur, left Washington this afternoon to go out in to-morrow's steamer, and will bear dispatches to General LAMAR. It is said Mr. MIX, Chief Clerk of the Indian Bureau, has offered the Commissionership, but that he declined.

REMOVING HACKNEY COACHES FROM THE PARK.--The Committee on Ordinances of the Board of Councilmen met yesterday afternoon to consider the propriety of removing the hackney coaches from the west side of the Park to the other stands designated by the Common Council. Ex-Councilman REYNOLDS and a large number of hackney coachmen were present.

FIRE.--At an early hour, yesterday morning, a row of four two-story frame buildings, on Broadway near De Kalb-avenue, were destroyed by fire. Three of the buildings were owned by Mr. BOND, and one by Mr. MEAD CAMP. Loss $8,000, partially insured.

By the arrival of the screw steamship New-York of the Bremen line, from Southampton on the 22d ult., we have European advices three days later than by the Persia. The news thus received vibrates to the side of peace.

It is rumored that Governor MORGAN has determined not to interfere to prevent the execution of the sentence of death against MARY HARTUNG for the murder of her husband. The rumor has an apparent foundation, but the fact will not be made known until to-morrow.

The Philadelphia North American, April 5, says there was a regular popular tumult at the United States Court, Fifth-street, when it was understood that the slave case would be held there. The crowd, which had surrounded Mr. LONGSTRETH'S office, at Seventh and Morris streets, rushed across from Seventh to Sixth street, and then through the Square to the United States Court building.
The screw-steamship New-York, Captain VON SANTEN, from Southampton, March 22, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The steamship Canada arrived at Liverpool Monday morning, March 21.

The Courrier des Etats Unis repeats its assertion that a new expedition for the conquest of Cuba is now on foot in this City. It states, with precision and emphasis, that a part of the destined "liberators" have already sailed, and that within a very few days the whole affair will be made public.

The COTTON market to-day, under the advices per the New-York, fully recovered from the effect produced by the Persia's news. The sales add up 24,000 bales, the market closing with an advance of ??c. The sales of the last three days foot up 32,000 bales, and the receipts 12,000 against 27,500 bales for the same time last year.

THE SICKLES TRIAL.-- The trial of Mr. SICKLES makes slow progress. Up to the adjournment of the Court yesterday only eight jurymen had been sworn, out of 104 who had been summoned. Nearly all who were called upon did not hesitate to avow decided sympathy with the prisoner, and to contess their consequent disqualification for the office of juryman.

While the House was agitating the Averill Ore Bed claim, last evening, the three select Committees of Five were jointly in session in the Court of Appeals, listening to arguments pro and con. the City Railroads. Mr. BLISS sat in the seat of Chief Justice SCOTT, Major SCHOLEPIELD adorned Judge STRONG'S seat, Mr. GOVER occupied Judge DEMIO'S place, Mr. FITZGERALD modestly sat in the Clerk's desk.

NAPOLEON III, has made another step towards the moral dominion of Europe. He has forced Austria to accede to a Congress for the Five Powers, for deciding those very questions of Austrian policy in Italy upon which the Cabinet of Vienna has steadily and haughtily protested that Austria could hear no discussion and accept no suggestions from abroad.

By the Overland Mail at St. Louis, we have received dates from California to March 7, two days later than steamer advices. On the 6th March, ship Intrepid arrived at San Francisco in 132 days from New-York, and ship John Clark in 170 days from Baltimore.

The fugitive slave case was continued this alternoon, There was no abatement of the excitement of the excitement in regard to it, and a large police force was in attendance to preserve order.

FIRE IN BROADWAY--DAMAGE $12,000.--At 81/2 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the rear of the third floor of the building, No. 547 Broadway. The dispatches sent to General LAMAR are, it is represented, of the most positive character. They instruct him to demand from Nicaragua and apology, restitution and indemnity, on a failure to comply with which he is to ask for his passports.

THE HAVRE CONSULSHIP.--We understand that Gen. GEORGE. P. MORRIS declines the Consulship at Havre, which was tendered to him by the President. The inadequacy of the salary, and the arduous and confining nature of the duties of the office, which are not at all congenial to the habits and tastes of a literary gentleman, have decided him to this course.

AN EXAMPLE TO CONGRESSMEN.--As the politicians of this country seem of late years to have taken the pugilists for their preceptors "guides, philosophers and friends," it is to be hoped they will not slight the virtues and continue their imitative talent to the vices only of their models.

ZOOLOGICAL MUSEUM IN CAMBRIDGE.--Some time ago Professor AGASSIZ proposed to deposit his large collection of zoological specimens in a museum for the use of the public, provided such an institution should be established. No offer more truly munificent could proceed from any scientific man, and it has been met with prompt liberality by the people and Legislature of Massachuseits.

BROOKLYN INTELLIGENCE. THE CHARTEN ELKCION.- The charter Election, on Tuesday, resulted in the complete sucess of the Democratic party. They not only elected their candidate for mayor, comptroller, auditor and Treasurer, but maintain their majority in the Board of Supervisors and Common conncil.

STRIKE AMONG THE LABORERS ON THE STATEN ISLAND RAILROAD.--Some 60 Irish laborers, employed on the Staten island Railway yesterday refused to work for the pay they were receiving unless a reduction of one hour was made in their day's work. They are required to work eleven hours per day.

PROXIES IN RELIGIOUS SOCIETIES.--The Christian Intelligencer severely denounces the bill pending in the Legislature authorizing members of religious and benevolent societies to vote by proxy. It states that the bill was drawn and taken to Albany by JOHN JAY, Esq., who has long been an active and influential Abolitionist, and that its immediate objects is either to revolutionize or destroy the American Tract Society.

The Hon. John Allen died in this City on Saturday, April 2 aged 64. Mr. Allen was a native of the North of Ireland. he came to this country in 1824, and engaged largely in the construction of the Erie Canal, chiefly In the vicinity of Lockport. Afterwards he removed to Rochester, and for many years was prominent as a forwarder.

POLITICAL MISTAKES.--The Washington States is a very good paper within its proper sphere. But when it becomes older it will learn that it has no more to gain from undue pretensions on its own part than from attributing unfounded assumptions to its contemporaries.

The Court of last resort has affirmed the decision of the Court below, to the effect that one JAMES McCUNE, who was a Policeman under the act of 1853, continued to be such under the act of April 15, 1857, commonly called the Metropolitan Police law, and that he is Policeman still, entitled to pay as such.

The Journal of Commerce thinks the Navy Department has been most fortunate in its selection of names for the eight new steamers now constructing at the serveral Navy-yards. These new names are Mohican, Narragansett, Iroquois, Seminole, Pawnce, and Dahcolah.

DEMONSTRATION OF THE ORDER OF CADETS OF TEMPERANCE.--The hall of the Union, at the Cooper Institute, was well filled last night, on the occasion of a Demonstration of the Order of Cadets of Temperance. From three to four hundred members of the Order occupied the stage, and the seats immediately fronting it, in the body of the building.

The steamer Indian, from Liverpool at 7 o'clock on the morning of the 23d ult., arrived here at 11 o'clock this afternoon. Her dates are one day later than those already received.

THE CASE OF THE DOYS IN KANSAS.--The trial of Dr. DOY and son on a charge of enticing slaves from the State, commenced at St. Joseph, Mo, on the 25th March, a change of venue having been granted from Pratte City. On the 29th CHARLES DOY was discharged, and his father was held to billing the sum of $5,000, to take his trial at the next term,

PREACHING AT THE ACADEMY.--The Rev. Dr. PLUMBER, Prof. of Theology in the Western Theological Seminary at Pittsburgh, is to preach at the Academy of Music to-morrow evening. He is one of the most eloquent and effective preachers of the Presbyterian Church.

It has been fashionable to compare unfavorable the works of this country with those of Europe. To such an extent has this been carried that it is not unfrequently said that we have to look to England or the continent for most of our examples. We are continually told by travelers of the great extent, beauty and durability of the continental works, and of the enormous strength of the English structures.

The untied States frigate Niagara has been taken into the dry-dock at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, for the purpose of inspecting her bottom. The accident which occurred to her when coming out of the harbor of St. Johns. Newfoundland, was more serious in its effects than was at first supposed.

The Court was opened at 10:10 this morning. The pressure for admittance into the Court room was greater than on previous days, and in a few moments after the doors were opened, the space reserved for the audience was completely filled. Mr. Butterworth is in town but has not yet appeared in Court.

AN EXAMPLE FOR AMBITIOUS POLITICIANS.-Very few of our politicians have over given any evidence of being influenced by a more exalted motive in entering public life than a thirst for personal distinction; and they have rarely consented to accept what they regarded as an inferior position for the mere sake of an opportunity to serve the public.

THE CASE OF DEPUTY MARSHAL TYLER.--The Canadians are still exercised about the case of Deputy U. S. Marshal TYLER, just convicted at Detroit of man slaughter for killing the Captain of a brig. It is contended that the offence was committed in Canadian water, and that TYLER should be surrendered under the Ashburton Treaty.

A bill has been introduced in the Legislature to commute the sentence of death passed upon Mrs. HARTUNG, for having poisoned her husband, and whom the Governor has refused to pardon. This is a decided novelty in the disposition of criminal cases; so far as we are aware, it is the first Instance in which a Legislative body has attempted to exercise the pardoning power.

CANDIDATES FOR PRESIDENTIAL NOMINATION.--The West is disposed to be heard on the question of Presidential candidates, both parties, through some of their journals in that section, proposing names for the consideration of the people.

LOW WATER IN THE HUDSON,--The long prevalence of the northwest winds, and the consequent low tides, have caused some obstruction to steamboat navigation. The sandbars at Castleton and Saugerties have brought up several boats, during past two or three nights, obliging them to remain until a rise in the rides.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Away in the North Pacific Ocean are the islands of Nippon at Japan. These islands possess every variety of climate, from the perpetual shows of the north, to the sunny vales of the south, where the banana and palm grow luxuriantly. The soil is productive, and is cultivated with taste, the valleys and plains not only, but the terraced hillsides as well.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Capt, LANG, from Liverpool at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 26th ult, arrived at Halifax at 10 o'clock on the morning of Friday the 8th inst. She experienced very heavy weather during the passage. The Canada reports March 31, lat. 49 [degree], lon. 27[degree], passed steamship Lebanon bound west ; April 2, lat, 46[degree], lon. 38[degree], passed American ship Hibernia bound west.

The sale [of the Union newspaper] was an odd enough arrangement. WENDELL has been suffering terribly for months under the load of debt which the publication of the Union entailed upon him, the President, who suspected him of worshiping after faise gods, and of his being opposed to his renomination at Charleston, having refused to allow him the usual printing patronage hereto fore enjoyed by that paper.

THE IONIAN PROTECTORATE--CYPRUS--GEOLOGICAL DISCOVERY--THE STUDENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY AND THE "AGE." The question of the practicability of annexing the Ionian Islands to the dominions of King Or? is exciting scarcely less interest in Athenian circles than among those who seem to be most vitally concerned.

THE LATE COLLISION AT STATEN ISLAND FERRY.--Several additional witnesses were examined yesterday before Justice OSROENE, In regard to the collision on the afternoon of the 31st ult., between the Staten Island ferry-boat Hunchback and a Custom-house barge, in which one of the bargemen was drowned. The testimony was principally corroborative.

DOMESTIC MARKETS. The moverdents in Wool, in the New-York market, during March, have been reviewed by Messrs. TILLKAMPF KITCHING, thus : " The market, through the month of March, has been quiet for all kinds,. of domestic Fleece and Pulled Wools, but prices remain unchanged ; If any . it is in favor of the buyer.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The world is full of heathen. Don't misunderstand me. I am not going to preach a missionary sermon. You need not go to China or Japan to find them; and don't imagine I refer to that degraded class who live in lanes and alleys, where domestic missionaries are so useful. Not at all.

The news brought from the Old World by the Canada, is fraught with evil tidings for tile American advocates of the African Slavetrade. The only Sovereign in all the world who sympathized with their objects and would have actively furthered their designs, is no more. The tomb of the African capulets has received his Majesty the King of Dahomey.

THE PROPERTY QUALIFICATION FOR JERORS.--The fact developed in the Sickles trial, that jurors in the District of Columbia are required by law to own eight hundred dollars worth of property, has been treated by Washington correspondents as both anomalous and outrageous. The former it certainly is not ;

DIFFICULTIES ABOUT THE TEUUANTIPEC SURVEY--A Minalitian correspondent of the New-Orleans Picayune writes that there is trouble among the parties appointed to survey the Tehuanlepec Isthmus. The agent wanted the Mexican engineers to work under his direction and instructions, but they resigned, The best, under such circumstances, the agent could do was to send out into the field three ?? Swiss engineers. ers.

It is stated in the New-York papers, and apparently with entire ignorance of the bearing of the admission, that the formidable expedition which is organizing their and else where, is designed for Arizona, and not for Cuba, as has been erroneously supposed. Curiously enough, the explanation in the Journal of Commerce, which was intended to relieve this enterprise of suspicion and elslavor, furnishes the best reasons for both.

On Tuesday, 8th instant, the United States District Court, Second District in this Territory, commenced a session in Provo City, Utah County, Judge CRADLEBAUGH presiding. After the swearing in of the Grand Jury, His Honor proceeded to deliver his charge.

The opera commences to-night. A brief and brilliant season is all that can be expected for the moment. Mme. GAZZANIGAM it is understood, will return to Europe after the four performances announced for this week. To night she appears in the "Travlata." the opera wherein she made her debut and wherein she is without an equal.

The fate of the controversy between the Church and Liberal parties in Mexico is probably determined, The news we have by the latest arrival announces the failure of the reactionary expedition against Vera Cruz, Gen. MIRAMON having drawn sufficiently near the heroic city to estimate its means of defence, and then commenced a rapid retreat toward the capital. A large body of Constitutionalists

A POLITICAL MOVEMENT IN MARYLAND.-On Wednesday last, the American Party of Maryland held a "State Council" in Baltimoro, "to make arrangements for the complete organization of the opposition to the present Federal Administration." A large number of Delegates, from all quarters of the State, is reprosented to have been present.

NIRLO'S GARDEN.--Mr. DAN RICE, a humorist who has his friends, received a complimentary benefit here to-night. All the attractive artists of NIXON Co.'s Equestrian Troupe assist, and much auxiliary aid is brought to the reseue.

A NEW RELIGIOUS MOVEMENT.--Yesterday afternoon, the initial sermon, in connection with a movement which has been set on foot for the establishment of an "Independent Society," having for its object the practice of religion, apart from any specific greed, was preached by the Rev. GEORGE F. NOVES, late of Chicago, in Hope Chapel, Broadway.

A BRITISH LEGISLATOR IN ILLINOIS.--Mr. JAMES CAIRD, a member of the Imperial Parliament, visited the United States last Fall, and is publishing the results of his observations in a series of letters in the London journals. He extended his journey to Illinois, and looked in upon its State House at Spring-field.

DESTRUCTION OF THE CHAPEL AND TOWER AT THE CEMETERY OF THE EVERGREENS BY FIRE. The tower or observatory, and chapel erected on the high land in the Cemetery of the Evergreens, about eight years ago, were entirely destroyed by fire on Saturday afternoon last.

The news we receive from Mexico is of the highest interest. The formidable expedition of President MIRAMON against Vera Cruz had proved a failure. The main body of the reuctionists had advanced within nine miles of the city, when MIRAMON advanced on the 18th ult., with 300 men to reconnoitre. The sight of the preparations for his reception seems to have discouraged him.

Mr. J. D. WILLARD noved a resolution fixing the final adjournment on Thursday, the 14th inst. Laid on the table. The Special Committee on the Now-York Charter bill was announced, namely: Nixon, Diven, Ely, W. A. Wheeler and Mather.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your domestic market review, last Saturday, you mentioned that prunes were extensively used as a substitute for dried peaches and dried appeals. You also mentioned that those from Turkey were the best, but you did not mention the fact, which ought not to be overlooked, that there is a great difference in the qualities of Turkish Francs.

By the Quaker City, Vera Cruz dates of April 1 have been received. The news is important. General MIRAMON appeared before Vera Cruz on tile 18th ult. with an advanced guard of three hundred men. He reconnoitered the place and retired, to his main army, which was encamped near Mediline, nine miles off.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Ultra Abolitionists maintain that the only way to stop the Slave-trade is to abolish Slavery in the United States. When it is recollected that few or no slaves have been brought to the United States from Africa since 1808, (to public knowledge, at least,) it is hard to see the point of this argument.

The new City Charier has a rough time in the Legislature. Everybody concedes that something of the kind is needed,--and also that the fundamental principle of this bill is just and wise. But each faction, each class, and nearly every man interested, wants some "little amendment" in its provisions.

The mails from Europe by steamship Canada, at Boston, on Saturday night, reached the New-York Post-Office yesterday morning. To the telegraphic abstract we add letters and extracts of unusual interest. OUR LONDON CORRESPONDENCE.

ALBOTT.--In this City, on Monday morning, April 11, WALTER L., son of Wm. D. and Agnces A. Abbott, aged 1 year. ?? months and 2 days. The funeral will be attended this day, (Tuesday,) at 11 o'clock, from the chapel of St. Genrge's Church, 16th st., neared 3d av. The remains will be interred in Greenwood. The friends of the family are invited to attend.

The Court-room was again crowded to excess. Mr. SICKLES was looking better than on Saturday. A pamphelt containing the opinions of Judge Crawford in murder cases tried in this Court has just issued from the press here, and was distributed in the Court-room.

The "ECHO" SLAVE CASK-INDICTMENT OF THE CREWS OF THE "ECHO" AND THE U.S. FRIGATE "NIAGARA."-The United States Cireuit Court, Judge WAYNE presiding, met at Charleston on the 7th of April, and the Court charged the Grand Jury in reference to the case of the slave-brig Echo.

OPENING OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMY.--The N. A.'s last evening gave a private view of their paintings to a few privileged friends, to the number of some three thousand, previous to throwing their rooms open to the public. It is altogether impossible to look at pictures with a critical eye in the midst of such a brilliant crowd as thronged the rooms of the Academy last night.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived at New-Orleans from Vera Cruz, brining highly important Mexican advices. The Juarez Government had been recognized by Minister McLANE, and this action on the part of our Minister was followed by the greatest rejoicing. MIRAMON had returned to Orizaba. From the Capital we learn that on the 2d inst.

THE OLD MAN WHO WAS STONED TO DEATH.-An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner GAMULE In the case of JACON BERTRAND, the old man who died from injuries received from stones and brick-bats thrown at him by two German peddlers, as heretofore reported. The evidence corroborated the story already published.

At 12 o'clock, to-day, the Governor had signed 220 bills. Among those approved to-day are the following: To amend the Poughkeepsie Mutual Fire Insurance Company. Extending the act authorizing the sale of the State arsenals in New-York and Albany, to provide for the purchase of the New-York Arsenal property by the City, and making appropriations.

The arrival of the steamship Apa at Rio de Janeiro, Feb. 22, supplies the Carreio Mercantil, with its Montervideo correspondence to the 16th previous. The Apa, It will be remembered, proceeding to Pernambuco, furnished to a vessel bound to the United States, tidings already received of the pacific termination of Mr. BOWLIN'S mission.

There are few things in City life more agreeable than the hutter of a firs night at the Academy, and especially is this the case after a long abstinence from wha has become a national and prized amusement. Despite the bronchial inlimidation of the weather yesterday and last night, there was a brilliant atendance to great Mme. GAZZANIGA on hor return from Havana.

COMMON COUNCIL PROCEEDINGS.--The Board of Aldormen held a regular meeting last evening. A report of the Committee on Opening Streets in favor of opening Myrtle-avenue from Broadway to the city line was adopted by unanimous consent. The Grading and Paving Committee reported in favor of directing the Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies to take the necessary steps to raise the grade of Flat- bush-avenue near Fifth-avenue.

We publish, to-day, fresh and highly important news from Mexico. Mr. McLANE, whose istructions are said to have restricted him to a recognition of the Liberal Government only in the event of its success being assured, or obviously near at hand, has fully acknowledged JUAREZ as the actual President of the Republic.

INSURANCE DEPARTMENT BILL-This measure passed the Assembly yesterday, after being amended so as to require, by express provision, that the entire cost of the Department shall be borne by the Insurance Companies. Such was the understanding and design from the beginning. Yet it can do no harm to make the act say so in terms.

LATER FROM RIO--THE COFFEE MARKET--AFFAIRS ON THE RIVER PLATE. Files of papes from Rio de Janeiro, to Feb. 23 have been received. There was no news of interest at Rio. The sales of Coffee on Feb. 23, amounted to 23,500 bags, all destined for the United States, Ouncos were ouoted at 32 milrols.

A VERY QUESTIONABLE REFORM.--An amendment offered in the State Senate on Saturday night to a bill making some small practical modifications in the constitution of the Board of Commissioners of the Central Park, provides for entirely abolishing the present Commission, and giving to the Supervisors the appointment of a new Board of six.

The Personal Liberty bill was reported from the Assembly. Mr. LAMONT moved a reference to the Select Committee. Carried by 13 to 12. Messrs, DIVRN, JOHNSON, NOXON, WETMORE, and O. B. WHEELEE voting with the Demoerats in the negative, five Democrats absent.

MOLLER-LIVINGS,-In this City, on Wednesday, April 6. by the Rev. Dr. Price. Mr. CHRISTOPHER MOLLER to Miss ANNIR B. LIVINGS, all of this City. JACKSON-MOSES-at Harleru, on Thursday, March 24, by the Rev. E.H.Gillette, DAVID T. JACKSON to Miss Jo.SEPHINE C. MOSES, only daughter of Joseph C. Moses, Esq., all of Harlem.

The steamship Tennessee has arrived here with Vera Cruz dates of the 6th Inst. Mr. McLANE, U. S. Minister, had recognized the Juarez Government, and there was great rejoicing in consequence of it. The dates from the City of Mexico are to the 4th inst. On the 2d General DEGOLLADO attacked the Capital, but unsuccessfully.

Another bold British Nimrod has come to his end in the way "natural" to men who pass the greater part of their lives on horseback and in jumping over five-barred gates. The City of Baltimore brings news of the death of the Marquis of WATERFORD, who was killed by a fall from his horse while hunting in Ireland.

STEVENS' FIFTH-AVENUE HOTEL, NEW-YORK,-- We learn that the new and elegant hotel, to which we have already more than once alluded, as being about to be opened in New-York, by Mr. PARAN STEVENS, mine host of the Revere and the Tremont, of Boston, will be ready for guests by the first of the coming August.

THE REVIVAL OF ART.--Mr. LORD lectured Monday evening to a large audience in Clinton Hall on "MICHAEL ANGELO and the Revival of Art," and presented this truly great man in the several aspects of sculptor, painter and architect. He dwelt, however, chiefly on architecture, which he thought was greater than painting or sculpture, because more impressive, more enduring and more useful.

The Clay Festival Association last evening celebrated the eighty-first anniversary of the birth of HENRY CLAY by a dinner at the La Farge House. At 8 o'clock about one hundred guests sat down in the dining-hall of the hotel.

ARREST FOR POISONING.--Officer LEACH, of the Ninth Precinet, arrested a German named JOSEPH HAGGART, in New Brooklyn, yesterday, on suspicion of having poisoned FRANK HAAS, a boy 6 years old, son of FEANOIS HAAS. The accused boarded in the family of Mr. HAAS, whose business required his absence from home at night.

The screw steamship City of Baltimore, Capt. Lurea, which sailed from Liverpool, at 9:30 on the morning of the 30th March, arrived here yesterday morning. The screw steamship Lebanon, of the same line, from Liverpool March 26, also arrived yesterday. An outline of the intelligence she brings was given in a portion of our morning issue of yesterday.

MACFARLANE.--In this City, on Monday morning, April 11, of congestion of the brain, GEORGE WASHINGTON, son of John and Margaret Macfariane, aged 16 years and 6 months. His friends and acquaintances, and those of the family, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Wednesday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from his father's residence, No. 27 Christopher-st.

WHAT'S IN A NAME?-The Washington Union is hereafter to be called the Constitution. Tho new proprietors and conductors of the Government organ have certainly shown a degree of sensitiveness in reference to the unsavory antecedents of the journal which has passed into their hands, which may be regarded as a hopeful promise for the future.

Lord Lyons, on being presented to President BUCHANAN to-day by Secretary CASS, made the following remarks: Mr. PRESIDENT : My first duty in addressing you, as the Envoy of Her Britannie Majesty, is in obedience to Her Majesty's express command, to assure you of her esteem, and regard for you, and of her hearty wishes for the welfare of the great nation of which you are the Chief Magistrate.

Governor MORGAN has approved the following bills among others this morning: Appropriating for the Canal debt and the maintenance of the Canals, for the fiscal year commencing Oct. 1, 1859, and to supply a deficiency in a former appropriation.

Mr. Ould and Mr. Carllate having examined them, admitted the handwriting. Mr. Brady remarked that the first is directed by Mr. Key to Mr. Sickles, and dated March 20, 1858, and indorses six letters, one of them written by Mr. Key and the other written by different persons to him.

The bills to provide for the completion of the New-York Arsenal; to settle the disputed Connect-out boundary; to authorize the reduction of the capital stock of Banking Associations; to protect gas consumers, and to provide a monument to the Walls-bout martyrs, were all ordered to a third reading.

In a part of our first edition of yesterday morning, the arrival of the screw-steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 30th of March, was announced. The news by this arrival is not of signal importance.

THE REV. DR. SCUDDER'S LECTURE.--It should not be forgotten that the Rev. Dr. SOUDDER delivers a lecture on India, to-morrow evening, at the Academy of Music, for the benefit of the Woman's Hospital. The Doctor is an eloquent man, and thoroughly conversant with the interesting subject which he proposes to discuss.

In connection with the ball, I may remark that it does not fit the Derringer pistol picked up in the street some twenty-five minutes after the affray of the 27th February. I saw it tried. The evidence goes to show that SICKLES had a revolver, and only used a revolver, and the consequent presumption is, that the Derringer, which had an exploded cap on when found, belonged to Key.

General News from the Central American States. By the arrival of the steamship Star of the West, from Aspinwall, we have received very late and important intelligence from Central America. The subjoined letters from our correspondents give a full summary of the latest news.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The second of Mad. GAZZANICA'S farewell performances attracted another fine house, albeit the opera was the "Trovatore," which has certainly been done repeatedly, if not too much so, Mad. GAZZANIGA is, as every one knows, a good leonora; in some respects the best we have had here. The last act is superbly dramatic, and is rendered with electrical force by the lady.

GOV. WISE UPON THE PRESIDENT.--There has just been published from Gov. WISE a characteristic letter to the Hon. DAVID HUBBARD, of Alabama. Gov. WISE says: "The President bids high, To fillibusters he offers Cuba and Isthmus and North Mexico--to the West, Pacific Railroad--to the North, protection to iron and coarse woolens--and to the great commercial countries, the power of centralization by obvious uses and abuses of a bankrupt act to apply to State banks.

COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION.--The weekly statement which was submitted at the meeting of the Board of Commissioners, yesterday, gives 7,855 emigrants as having arrived at this port to the 13th inst.; 662 of this number came in during the last week. To the same date last year, 8,480 arrived. There are 900 inmates in the Institution on Ward's Island, and 50 in the Marine Hospital.

From the Paris Constitutionnel. France and England are at this moment engaged in a common quarrel with Mexico. They demand satisfaction for acts of violence, oppression and extortion, of which subjects of the two countries have been the victims.

On the 28d ult., died in Paris, Count sigismund Krastnski, a Polish noble, hero and poet. He was related to the royal houses of Saxony and Piedmont, and his godfather was the Emperor Napoleon, who appointed him on the day of his birth aide-de-camp to the King of Rome. Count Sigismund's was an agitated and sorrowful existence.

COURT OF APPEALS, April 13.--Nos. 16, 67, 144. Submitted. No. 79.--Methodist Episcopal Church vs. Pickett.--Argued, J. H. Reynolds for appellant.: No. 80 --Ely vs. Carndly.--Argued. J. H. Reynolds for appellant ; C. H. Smith for respondent.

AN EMPHATIC NEWSPAPER.--The new Administration organ came out yesterday, according to the announcement, under the title of the Constitution. It is very much like the old organ in appearance and sentiment, but Mr. BOWMAN, the "sole editor and proprietor," makes the novel declaration that the Constitution shall be "emphatically a newspaper."

REFORMS OF OUR CITY GOVERNMENT--We have received a very long report of a speech made by Judge EDMONDS before the Senate Committee at Albany against the proposed amendments to the City Charter. It is one of three or four speeches of the kind, made by three or four lawyers, who have been retianed and are paid b somebody to defeat all attempts that may be made to give us a good City Government.

The Tribune represents the Democratic Senators at Albany as determined to defeat the bill permitting proxy votes in the management of religious and benevolent societies, in order to protect the "interests of their party." This may, or may not be so; but the less the Tribune has to say on the party aspects of the subject the better.

A letter from Rome says: "An anecdote which was recently related to me shows in another form how averse the Papal Government is from letting too much light into the public mind. The gas-pipes in the Plazza del Popolo were being examined not many mornings since, when a stranger observed, 'So you are letting in light upon the Popolo.'

THE ENGINEER DIFFICULTIES AT TEHUANTEPEC.--The impression prevails that the misunderstandings originating with a portion of the Engineer Corps, engaged in the survey of the isthmus of Tohuntepec, affects the party employed under the direction or Mr. SLIDELL, the Chief Engineer of the Louisiana Tehuantepec Company. Such, however, is not the case.

Mr. David Page writes: "I hereby affirm (and the proofs of this affirmation He before me fresh and incontrovertible as they did a dozen years age) that Mr. Robert Chambers is the sole and responsible author of the Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation, Dr. James Cox writes to a contemporary with reference to the statement that his uncle, George Combe, was the author or the work.

HARSH TREATMENT OF A PHILADELPHIA OFFICER IN ALABAMA--MOB LAW.--A few weeks since special Officer SCMLEMM, of the Mayor's Police, of Philadelphia, went to Huntsville, Alabama, in pursuit of a man named JOHN QUINCT ADAMS CARTER, who was changed with having obtained from PETER WAPLES Co., clothing dealers, goods to the amount of $1,560 on false Distances.

When the Vandalism of revolutionary patriots converted the private apartments of a King of France into mere offices for the discharge of public business, pious legitimists held up their hands in horror and wondered that no bolts from Heaven punished the unpardonable sacrilege.

The Forty-first anniversary of the New-York Port Society was held last evening in the large room of the Cooper Institute, and was numerously attended--very few seats being vacant. To add to the attractions of the meeting, the band from the receiving ship North Carolina was stationed on a temporary platform in front of the speakers, and performed several pieces, at intervals, during the evening.

AN INDIAN RESERVE IN TEXAS TO BE BROKEN UP.--Th people of Texas, despairing of relief from the Government against the attacks of the Indians, are about to take summary measures. A Belknap correspondent informs the Dallas Herald that great excitement exists on the fronlier, and that that Lower Indian Receive, twelve miles east of Belknap, is to be broken up and utterly demolished by the whites of the different frontier counties.

In recognizing the Juarez Government, immediately upon his arrival at Vera Cruz, Mr. McLANE appears to have somewhat astonished the President and Cabinet. His instructions, it is understood, were conceived in that spirit of hesitation and tlmidity which hascharacterized Mr. BUCHANAN'S foreign policy throughout.

From the London Saturday Review. It is only common justice to Sir JOHN PAKINGTON to admit that he has performed with courage and candor the most humiliating task that ever fell to the lot of a British Minister. For the first time in the history of this country it has been officially proclaimed that the many of England is inferior to that of France.

The Post-Office Department is having printed blank forms, to be severally filled up with amounts of indebtedness to mail contractors. They are in the nature of certificates, intended to serve as a basis for loans until Congress shall relieve the present pecuniary embarrassment of the Department.

SALE OF CORPORATE PROPERTY TO TRUSTEES OF THE CORPORATION. Humphreys vs. The Dauphin and Susquehanna Coal Company.--(Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, for the Eastern District.)--This was a petition to confirm a sale of certain premises on foreclosure of a mortgage. The Petition alleged that at the sale the highest and best price bid for the said premises was $370,000, subject to another mortgage of $97,000 ;

The controversy as to the authorship of The Vestiges of Creation, which has been warmly carried on in the scotch papers, receives a new contribution in a letter on the subject, in the Caledonian Mercury from Mr. David Page. Alluding to the report that Mr. George Combe was the author of the work in question, he says: be was the author of the work in question, he says:

THE FALLING BUILDING IN WEST-STREET.--The flour warehouse of Messrs. MANNING Co., No. 97 West-street, the partial falling of which was noticed in Tuesday's TIMES, is now little better than a ruin. The first floor gave way yesterday morning with a tremendous crash, and was soon followed by the upper floors and the roof. The walls are still standing, but it is believed they will have to be torn down.

The American State Council of Maryland met a Baltimore on the 6th inst., full delegations being present from nearly all the Councils, "to make arrangements for the complete organization of the opposition to the present Federal Administration." The Hon. JAMES B. RICAUD called to order, and E. H. WEBSTER was chosen President.

From the London Daily News. BRADBURY VERSUS DICKENS--HOUSEHOLD WORDS. This was a motion for an injunction to restrain the publication of an announcement relative to the periodical entitled Household Words, and the parties to the suit were Messrs. BRADBURY EVANS, publishers and printers, the plaintiffs, and Mr. CHARLES DICKENS and Mr. WILLIAM KING WELLS, the defendants.

Ex-Governor ROBINSON, of Kansas, communicates to the Lawrence Herald of Freedom a statement of his connection with the Kansas Relief Fund. He says: "In the Winter of 1855 and 1856, a Protection Fund Committee was constituted to receive and disburse any money that might be forwarded for the protection of the people of Kansas.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN NEW-ORLEANS.--LOSS $250,000.--The fire which occurred in New Orleans April 7, noticed in our telegraphic dispatches, destroyed the Hale Warehouse, on St. Joseph-street, and seven dwelling houses. The Montgomery Warehouse and the Pork Inspection, where over half a million of dollars' worth of pork was stored, narrowly escaped. The Delta says:

The U. S. Mail steamship Star of the West, Capt. GRAY, arrived at this port last evening, from Aspinwall April 4 ; bringing the California malls and specie of March 21. The Star of the West left in the port of Aspinwall the United States frigate Roanoke ; an well on board.

The arrangements for the great billiard match, to be played in this city on Tuesday the 12th inst., are being rapidly and harmoniously perfected. Mr. PERLAN arrived here last Friday, and is in fine health and spirits, and in excellent playing conditions. SEEREITER, his competitor, is equally well prepared for the contest, and the friends of each party are anxious for the trial.

BEALE,--In this City, on Wednesday, April 13, GEORGE EDMUND, son of George W. and Phoebo H. Heale aged 1 year, 4 months and 13 days. The funeral will take place from the residence of his father, No. 15 Cottage-place, this afternoon, at 4 o'clock. Friends are invited to attend, without further notice. MOORE.--In this City, on Wednesday, April 13, KUTU, infant daughter of Thomas and salary Moore, aged 3 months and 1 day.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the Herald of the 11th inst. is an article without signature, under the above head, to which editorial reference is made with the laudatory remarks: "It will be found full of interest, and replete with valuable information relative to the character of coast defences, the range and power of the different kinds of artillery known to us, and the topography of our barbor and adjoining shores.

ANOTHER DOMESTIC TRAGEDY,--A man named JOHN HENDEIX, residing in the town of Rockland, Sullivan County, recently committed suicide. For several days he had been laboring under the most intense excitement, in consequence of an alleged intimacy between his wife and a man named JAMES EVANS.

THE STATE BANK OF ILLINOIS-FRA??LEST TRANSACTIONS.--A Springfield (III.) correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette says the official report of the old State Bank of Illinois has been completed, and shows fraudulent transactions. The report says:

Nothing could more agreeably illustrate the change which has come over the style and temper of the loading English journals in dealing with all matters relating to America than the comments which have been made by the more responsible portion of the London Press upon that sad story of crime and vengeance at the Capital, which still occupies so much of the attention and enlists so much of the sympathy of the American people.

(Art. 4, Sec. 5,) an act of the Legislature commuting the seatence of MARY if ARTUNG would be unconstitutional.

The war panic is over, and now people look at each other and say, "It was you that was frightened, not me I" But the funds don't go up, because there are people who still believe in war, and who persist in getting up false reports to suit their own ends. The interminable mystery that hangs over the illness of the King of Naples is the harp on which they oftenest play.

MARY HARTUNG.--MARY HARTUNG, convicted of the murder of her husband, is to be executed at Albany, on Wednesday, the 27th instant, according to sentence. It is said that she received the announcement of the Governor's decision with that indifference which has characterized her demeanor throughout the many trying incidents of her arrest, trial and conviction.

THE HAWESVILLE TRAGEDY IN KENTUCKY.--There is another phase of this affair. The Louisville Journal recently published a statement, purporting to emanate from responsible citizens of Hawesville, justifying the assassination of THOMAS S. LOWE. It now appears that the "Card" was a forgery, and that the Journal was imposed upon. The Louisville Courier of the 7th says:

ARRIVAL OF THE PHILADELPHIA--AN AMERICAN PLEASURE YACHT AT HAVANA. The United States Mail Steamship Philadelphia GUSTAVOS HARRISON, Commanding, left New-Orleans, April 5, 1859, for New-York via Havana, at which port the arrived on the morning of the 8th, and sailed at noon of the same day, She reached this port yesterday morning.

From the London Chronicle. Some of our cotemporaries have given currency to a report respecting Mr. SIOKLES which we are enabled to state is as unfounded as it is calumntons. The report in question is, that Mr. SICKLES, when attached to the American Legation, insulted her Majesty by presenting a lady of bad character at the Court.

COLLISION OF THE PERSIA WITH A BRIG.--The brig Agnes, STEWART, of Glasgow, on her passage from Troon for St. Vincent, was run into on Saturday night week, about 10 o'clock, off Tuskar, by the steamship Persio, on her outward voyage from Liverpool for New-York.

The Star of the West brings the California mails and treasure of March 21. The receipt of specle is $1,400.000. The news from California by this arrival is only seven days later than advices received by the Overland Mail. Some new diggings, of remarkable richness, bad been discovered in the South, and mining prospects generally were favorable.

Since Photography has become so acknowledged a power in the land, It has monopolized to itself, In a great measure, the dignity and wisdom and beauty of the country. It has framed and ticketed tile heads of the Heads of the People, and it keeps them constantly on show; and tile best of it all is that it exhibits them free, gratis, and for nothing.

The National Intelligencer publishes the following letter, written by LOUIS NAPOLEON to President VAN BUREN, previous to the embarkation of the president Emperor for Europe, in 1837 : NEW-YORK June 6, 1837. Mr. PRESIDENT: I am unwilling to leave the United States without expressing to your Excellency the regret I feel in departing without having gone to Washington to make your acquaintance.

Tile Legislature has acted on tile notion of the lion. Mr. MERRITT, to which the NEW-YORK TIMES devoted a leading article a few days since, and, by common consent, after hearing his speech and that of the Premier's in reply, tile resolutions in question were put at the foot of the list of orders--not to be discussed again this season.

INSECURITY OF THE CITY PRISON--THE TROUBLES AT BELLEVUE HOSPITAL. The Board met on Tuesday afternoon. From the weekly statement it appears that there are 7,500 inmates in the different institutions; being a decrease of 121 since the date of the last report. During the week ending April 9, 1,568 were admitted; 40 died; 133 were sent to the ??, and 1,516 were discharged. ed.

The season for sporting is very lively. Preparations are going forward at the Long Island Race-Courses for the Spring Meetings, to open in May, and some excellent matches have been made, Some of these we noticed several days since. Others are in progress. The reported race between Nicholas I. and Tar River, both crack horses, for a purse of $20,000, still hangs fire.

BILLS PASSED. To amend the act relating to assessments in New-York, for opening and improving streets. To Incorporate the New-York Preparatory School of Medicine. To provide for the closing of the Atlantic-street tunnel in Brooklyn. The bill to provide for the completion of the State Arsenal, New-York.

[The following letter, although its intelligence has been anticipated, will still be read with interest.] ROSARIO, Friday, Jan. 7, 1859. We arrived here on the 4th last., the Commodore's flag-steamer Fulton towing the brig Dolphin, to which, from the Island of Martin Garcia to this place, I transferred my broad pennant, on the invitation of Captain CHARLES STEADMAN, whom I desire to recommend as the prince of naval hosts.

NATIONAL TYPOGRAPHICAL CONVENTION.--The annual Convention of Delegates from the various Typographical Unions in the United States, is to assemble in this city on the first Monday in May. The occasion will no doubt he one of interest. Prominent among the festivities will be a grand banquet at the Revere, at which all the prominent personages who are now or have been connected with the printing business will be present.

Mr. CARLISLE answered, to-day, the positions of Messrs. GRAHAM and BRADY, who yesterday offered in evidence the statement of Mrs. SICKLES. Mr. CARLISLE contended that the evidence was only admissible under an allegation of absolute insanity. He said that whenever the defence put in such plea, the prosecution was ready to meet it.

By the arrival of the Margaret and Eliza and the Anna Wellington from Buenos Ayres we are in possession of our correspondence and exchanges from that port to the 21st of February. We have an interesting account of the reception of Commissioner BOWLIN by President LOPEZ, and of the speech made on the occasion.

THE POTATO CROT-TELRGRAPH AROUND THE ISLAND. Our files of the Bermuda Gazette Extend to March 10. The Gazette says: "Men who know assure us that the growing crop of potatoes prosenis the most encouraging appearance. To the timely and moderato rains of February, and the absence of high winds up to the present date, may be attributed the beautiful condition of the cultivated tracts in every part of the country;

NATIVE WINKS.--Dr. UNDERHILL, whose vineyards at Croton Point are universally known and appreciated, has recently entered upon the manufacture of wines, which he offers for sale at his depot in Broadway.

RECOGNITION OF SENOR MATA BY THE PRESIDENT--A telegram from New-Orleans announces that Senor MATA, who has been for some time in that city, received a dispatch on Wednesday from Gen. CASS, informing him that President BUCHANAN was now ready to receive him as the Mexican Minister at Washington.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--A meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held Wednesday evening. The newly elected members from the County towns Messrs. RYDER of Flatbush, SCHENCK of New-Lots, STRYKER of Gravesend, and GROFSEY of New-Utreacht, presented their credentials, and were admitted to seats.

The Mobile Register is in great tribulation about the Personal Liberty bills that were ponding in several of our State Legislatures. It regards the whole North as hopelessly given over to the most radical Abolitionism, and as desperately and deliberately resolved on a war ofextermination against Southerninterests and Southern rights.

The Grand Lodge of the Unitexd States, of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows, composed of representatives from overy State in the Union, have directed a public thonksgiving to be made in this City on the 26th of the present month. On that day forty years will have elapsed since THOMAS WILDEY, In concert with four other members of the Order, formed the first Lodge in the United States, known as Wash.

The cross-examination yesterday tended to prove that Mrs. SICKLES did not leave Washington during the month of January. The clerk at Barnum's Hotel, in Baltimore, is said to be summoned to prove that SICKLES' name was registered at that hotel early in January, with that of Mrs. SICKLES.

FIELD.--In this City, on fifth day, April 14, of paralysis, JORIAN FIELD, aged 84 years. His friends and acquaintances, and those of the family, are invited in Orchard st., on sixty day, the 15th inst., at 4 o'clock P. M. His remains will be taken to Purchase meeting house. Westchester County, previous to interment on seventh day, at 12 o'clock M.

The Margaret Eliza and the Anna Wellington, from Buenos Ayres, arrived here yesterday, bringing advices to February 21. At the departure of the latter vessel nothing definite had yet been received regarding the close of the negotiations between Commissioner BOWLIN and President LOPEZ.

Recommitting the Quarantine Removal bill to a Committee, last evening, when the question was on coneuning with the Senate's amondments, can hardly, be construed into anything else than killing it. The recommitment was carried by the votes of those who originally and always opposed the removal bill, with the aid of those who had voted for it on condition that the Certain Offences and the Staten Island Assessmont bills first passed.

SUPERANNUATION FUND.--The idea of Governmental provision for public servants who have grown old in office seems amusingly strange in this country, where we do not, as a general role, permit our functionaries to remain long enough to learn their duties. Yet this very matter is at present engaging the attention of the Canadian Parliament.

The Senate had an executive session this evening at which the Police Commissioners were continued, and a strong effort was made to confirm Mr. HUTCHINSON in place of EDGAR McMULLEN for Port Warden but failed.

The following paragraph is from an editorial article on Mrs. HARTUNG'S case in yesterday's Courier and Enquirer: "There exists among a portion of our people an opposition to the hanging of woman. On what tenable ground such an opposition can be based, is some what difficult to imagine.

COOKS--POWROH,--In this City, on Tuesday, Feb. 12, at the residence of the bride's father, No. 201 West 31st st., according to the order of the religious soolaty of Friend', WILLIAM COOKS to SARAH BOWRON, daughter of Henry C. Bowron.

THE SLAVE-TRADE.-Our State Assembly, by a very strong vote, has passed the following resolutions in regard to the reopening of the Slave-trade: "Resolve, If the Senate concur, that the citizens of this State look with surprise and detestation upon the virtual opening of the Slave-trade with the Federal Union;

THE NEW CANAL LAW OF OBIO.--Among the important acts passed bythe legitature of Ohio is one providing for the leaso of the Public Works. It provides for a notice of tyhe leasing to be published in the papers of the principal cities of the State and the cities of Boston, New-york, Philadelphin and Baltimore.

COOPER INSTITCTE.--The Mendelsshon Union gave an excellent performance of Mr. COSTA'S " Eli" last evening. Three years have almost elapsed since the same Society gave the work for the first time in America, It was imperfectly done then, and without orchestra. Tile solos were Intrusted to members of the Society who were searcely adequate to the task of interpreting them with tile dramatie force and squareness which they required.

The mails by the Quaker City, at New-Orleans, from Vera Cruz, April 1, arrived here yesterday. We glean the following particulars of the arrival and retreat of MIRAMON, and the reception of Mr. McLANE, the American Minister, from the New-Orleans papers. THE RETREAT OF MIRAMON. The correspondent of the New-Orleans Cresent writes, April 1:

The fact of the meeting of the American Commissioner and the Paraguay Chief no longer rests upon the flourishing dispatch of General URQUIZA. Our Own Corrospondent not only bears witness to the earlier stages of the intercourse, but furnishes us the literal text of the addresses exchanged by the pair at the outset, agreeably to that courteous usage in deference to which the knights of the diplomatic lists lower their lances before assuming their places.

The New-York Tax bill, on motion of Mr. MATHER, was referred to the New-York delegation. Mr. NOXON reputed the three New-York Railroad bills. Mr. W. A. WHEELER moved to lay the report on the Seventh-avenue bill on the table. Carried by 15 to 15, the President casting his vote in the affirmative.

PENNSYLVANIA AND THE ADMINISTRATION.-- The Democratic crusade against Mr. BUCHANAN'S treacherous, imbecile, and sectional policy has opened with decided vigor. Mr. HICKMAN'S speech, which we publish this morning,--delivered at the opening of the State Convention,--is as sharp and resolute a specimen of political invective as we have seen for a long time.

The Now-Orleans Delta deserves its name. It is more prolific, and of more wonderful things, than its namesake of old Nile. What waters have overflowed it with their fertilizing power does not clearly appear, but they were evidently strong waters, the strongest probably in their kind.

At the Democratic (Anti-Buchanan) Convention which assembled at Harrisburgh, Penn., on the 13th, Hon JOHN HICKMAN, Member of Congress, made the following strong and severe speech in reference to the National Administration: Mr. PRESIDENT: I am glad to meet you to join you upon an occasion so interesting and important as the present one.

LAUNCH OF THE NEW STEAM SLOOP INOQUOIS,--The new United states screw steamer Iroquois was launched from the Brooklyn Navy Yard on Tuesday, in the presence of a small company, who had socidentally loarned that the launch would occur on that day.

THE POLICE COMMISSION.--Governor MORGAN has disregarded political considerations and made two very excellent appointments to fill two vacancies on the Police Commission. Judge ULSHOEFFER, who takes General NYE'S place is one of our oldest and most respected citizens, an able lawyer, and a man of unimpeached integrity.

The following letter from MAZZINI was received a few days ago by the Principal of a private school in the vicinity of this City: LONDON, March 21, 1859. DEAR SIR: I beg to apologize for being so late in acknowledging the receipt of $112 09, Subscribed by you and others at the and of the lecture delivered at your Institution by my friend, Mmc, JESSE M. WHITE MARIO, towards our Italian school

FINANCIAL MEASURES-MUNICIPAL IMPROVEMENTS AT PORT-AU-PRINCE-BUSINESS. Our files of papers from Port-au-Prince extend to March 26. They contain little of interest. The Revue de Commerce has an article on the paper money, which closes with a plan of relief by urging upon the mercantile community to exchange all small notes for large ones of $1,000 at the Treasury, the bills to be taken by payment for duties, , of course subject to some restrictions.

The condition of our foreign relations generally with the exception of those pertaining to Nlearagus, is represented in reliable quarters to be highly ?? factory; official intelligence from Nicaragua is awaited with deep interest; assurances continue to be gives that stringent measures will be taken toward that Republic, in the event of its refusal to render such a satisfaction and guarantees as our Government demands.

AN IMPORTANT CITY RAILROAD GRANT.While the whole City has been in a fever of excitement about City Railroad grants, the Harlem Road has quietly secured a most valuable franchise at the hands of the Legislature.

C., in opening the April Term, 1859, by the Honorable JAMES M. WAYNK, one of the Associate Judges of the United States Supreme Court, and presiding Judge for the Sixth Circuit.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The thanks of all the friends of good order and conservative principle are due to the TIMES for the sensible, impartial, and manly views which it has taken of this question. The true analogy of the proxy proposed to be foisted upon the charitable societies, is not between them and money corporations, but, as the TIMES suggests, between them and legislative bodies, wherein proxies are utterly inadmissible.

The Hon. Samuel H. Woodrnff, formerly Judge of the County Court, died at Tariffville, Conn., April 11. He was 70 years of age. Judge W. was well known to the Bar of Connecticut. It is three or four years since he retired from the active duties of his position.

Views of the Roman Catholic Church on Education and Secret Societies. The following interesting suggestions are from the Pastoral Letter of the Most Rev. J. R. PURGELL, D. D., Roman Catholic Archbishop of Cincinati recently issued : "The cause of education must ever enlist the sympathies and excite the lively solicitude of every order of the clergy, as well as of the parents and friends of youth.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your notice of my Dictionary of Congress, you have given me two or three critical blows, which l beg you to let me parry with a few facts. You scold me, in the first place, for giving a meagre account of the late Mr. MIKE WALSH. I made three attempts. by circular letters, to obtain some particulars of his life, but was unsuccessful.

A LIBERAL CHURCH.--The Rev. F. G. CLARK preached his seventh anniversary sermon last Sunday in the West Twenty-third-street Presbyterian Church, During his pastorate the congregation have erected a house of worship at a great cost, and have displayed unusual liberality in meeting the expense.

BODIES FOUND.--The body of an unknown man was found in the water at the foot of Clinton-avenue Thursday afternoon, and was taken in charge by the Coroner. The deceased appears to have been between 35 and 40 years old, 5 feet 8 inches high, and had on a pea-jacket, dark cassimere pants and vest, and Congress gaiters.

IMPROVEMENT IN FIRE ARMS.--The recently revived story or Captain THISTLE, who made himself quite notable in the Seminole war by the number of weapons he always carried about him, eg., two double, barreled guns, two double-barreled pistols, , , which he used with great expertness, suggests to one the thought that his case affords a very good illustration of the great improvements made in fire-arms within a few years.

In do not aspire to be a political letter writer. I know how much information such people obtain at second hand--how much they often presume and suppose and guess, without knowing anything about it. And I have not knowledge enough to give a really valuable opinion on the "State of Europe," nor impudence enough to offer a worthless one.

OUR HARBOR DEFENCES.--We published in the Times of Thursday a very interesting letter from Major BARNARD, of the Engineer's Corps, upon the Defences of the Harbor and City of New-York.

Signor PEREY, of Nicaragua, arrived here this evening with the amended Cass- Yrissari Treaty. Postmaster CAPEN left Washington to-day with, it is said, orders from the Postmaster-General to remove the office back to State-street.

WILSON.--In this City, on Thursday, April 14, the Rev. BIRD WILSON, D. D., LL. D., in the 83d year of his age. His relatives, brethren of the clergy, and friends of the family, are invited to attend his funeral, from St. Peter's Church, West 20th-st., on sunday afternoon, at 6 o'clock. BA??R--Gone to the spirit world, ELEANOR ANN, wife of Henry O. Baker, in the 30th year of her age.

From the Albany Evening journal. The several cases involving the VAN RENSSELAEA claim to rents from lands conveyed in fee, in this county, have been decided by the Court of Appeals. The decision is adverse to the Tenants: All the Judges concur in the opinion that the rents and arrears must be paid.
