The local authorities have called in their forces from all quarters, until now we have about 6,500 effective troops, and two or three thousand more who are the produce of the leva, (press-gang.)

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The article published in the NEW-YORK TIMES of April 7, contains the following misstatements or errors. It is true that Comptroller CHURCH was heard before the "Grinding Committee" of the Assembly, on the bill to create an "Insurance Department," but it is not true that "the Comptroller opposed it on distinct party grounds."

The Senate remained in session till near morning. Mr. DIVEN made his motion definite to arraign Mr. SPINOLA for words spoken, and gave the offensive words to the Clerk. Mr. SPINOLA, on the words being said, denied that they were his.

DONIZETTI'S opera of "Luerezia Borgia," was played here last night, bringing the farewell performances of Mme. GAZZANIGA to an end, so far as the evenings of this week are concerned. The role of Lucrecia is one of the most powerful in Mme. GAZZANIGA'S repertoire.

When it was ascertained that the Democracy had gained the day, in December, 1856, Mr. BUGHANAG sent for Gov; WISL. The Governor remained with him a Wheatland several days, and there was a perfect understanding in regard to certain matters of policy, Kansas was to come fairly into the Union, with or without Slavery, and the people were to make their own Constitution.

From the St. Louis Democrat. TO THE PUBLIC. Business reasons constrain me to resign the place of editor in this journal. It were almost needless to add that it is with extreme reluctance I dissolve a connection which has lasted so loog, and to which the best years of my life have been dedicated.

EDITOR STATES: Our attention having been called to an article in the States of to day, under the head of "Napter Ball, pay up," which would seem to reflect upon us as not meeting our obligations in matters relative to the Napier ball. In justice to ourselves, we desire you will give a statement of the facts.

The election in Jersey City for city officers, on Wednesday, resulted as follows: Mayor--Dudley S. Gregory, Republican, by 495 majority, Water Commissioner-Wm. Birkbeck, Republican. School Superintendent--Abram S. Jewell, Independent. Assessors--James Fleming and Stephen Qualfe, Republican.

The Anniversary of the Birthday of THOMAS JEFFERSON was celebrated in Boston on the evening of April 13, by a banquet at PARKER'S. The Hon, GEORGE BOUTWELL presided, and made the opening speech of the evening. He was followed by John P. Hale, Henry Wilson, Carl Schurtz, F. H. Underwood, Attorney-General Philips and others.

ANOTHER KEY AND SICKLES CASE--A SEDUCER SHOT.--A correspondent of the Louisville Democrat, writing from Madison, Indiana, says: "An affair, in which there was shooting somewhat similar to the SICKLES affair, took place in this city last Saturday night, April 9. It seems that Mr. ISAIAH CHRISTIE, a saddlery merchant of this place, had lately become suspicious of improper intimacy between his wife and Mr. MARTIN MULLEN.

I send you what army news there is for our friends at the East. This is General HARNEY'S head-quarters, and we have a large force here, most of which was engaged in Col, WRIGHT'S Indian Expedition last Summer. It is though that Gen, HARNEY will be relieved and go East. If not, he intends to open a milltary road of six hundred miles, from the Dalles to Salt Lake.

SUPERIOR COURT--GENERAL TERM. Campbell vs. The International Life Assurance Society.--This was a controversy submitted without action, and decided a month or two since. It involved the question whether when the last day for paying a premium falls on Sunday, the accused may claim the right to pay on Monday; or whether in order to save his policy he must pay on the Saturday previous.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I wish to call your attention to a bill which has just passed the Assembly, and is now before a Committee of the Senate. I inclose a copy of the bill. SANITARY AFFAIRS.--The third annual meeting of the Quarantine and Sanitary Convention is to commence in this City on the 27th of the present month, Its sessions are to bo held at the Cooper Institute. Delegate are expected from various sections of the country.

WATER IN THE CANALS--The Rochester Democrat of Wednesday says: "The water was four feet deep yesterday on the Fourteen-Mile Level, extending from Pittsford to Macedon, and it is now passing castward very freely. It is possible that by Saturday the banks may be pretty full to the eastward, as far as the water can be led from this city.

UPSHOT OF THE REGISTRY MOVEMENT.--A bill has passed both houses of the Legislature entitled "An Act for ascertaining by proper proofs the citizens which shall be entitled to the right of suffrage, and to prevent fraudulent voting." It is not a Registry Law, and does not call itself such.

Mr. MCLANE, ENVOY Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from the United States, has recognizes BENITO JUARFZ and his Government as the Government de jure and de facto of Mexico, presented his credentials, and is now the accredited Resident Minister from the United States to this Republic.

South American affairs are not usually very attractive to North American readers. Our people have no objection to Rio coffee when they cannot procure old Java or Mocha. They admit the value of Buenos Ayrean hides, and are perfectly willing that Montevideo should export as much tallow as Russia.

By the arrival of the Orchilla at this port on Saturday last, we are in receipt of our correspondence and other intelligence from Buenos Ayres to the 21st of February. The letters and documents which we publish below give interesting details concerning the progress of the negotiations with Paraguay, and confirm the previous rumor that the difficulty had been settled through the intervention of General URQUIZA.

THE LEGISLATURE.--The State Legislature will, probably, adjourn to-day. It has already remained in session longer, after the expiration of Its hundred days, than any of its predecessors. There are several bills of importance to be acted on--the New-York Charter, the Railroad grants, the Quarantine bill and the Canal Draft bill among them.

ACCURATE JOURNALISM.--In the report of the sickles trial as published in the Herald, the name of JOHN GRAHAM is uniformly stricken out, and "Counsel for the defence" substituted. The reason of this is found in the fact that some years since, Mr. GRAHAM, and the editor of the Herald had a personal difficulty in Broadway.

Though private advices from Apalachicola, we learn that the suspected Slave-bark E. A. Rawline, recently captured by the United States steamer Vixen, Lieutenant Dups, Commanding, in St. Joseph Bay, has been placed in charge of the United States Marshal at that place, and the second Monday in May appointed in the day upon which to try her case. The crew are still on board, confined as witnesses.

THE POISONING CASE.--The body of the boy FRANK HAAS, supposed to have died from the effects of poison, was disinterred on Saturday last and a pos.-mortem examination made under the direction of Coroner HORTON, No case of poison of any kind was found, A man named JOSEPH HOOARTY, arrested on suspicion of having poisoned the deceased, will therefore be discharged.

BROOKLYN DISPENSARY.--During the last two months 1,007 persons were treated in this institution, to whom 2,265 prescriptions were gratuitously dispensed. The diseases treated were as follows; Eye and ear. 01; surgical. 132; females, 45; children and skin, 160; vaccination, 51; heart, throat and lungs, 179; digestive and nervous system, 208; dental surgery, 141. Natives of the United States, 3-8.

THE MASSACHUSETTS TWO YEARS' AMENDMENT.--On the 9th of May an amendment of the constitution of Massachusetts, requiring a period of two years after naturalization to elapse before adopted citizens will be allowed to vote, is to be submitted to the people for ratification or rejection.

The Hon. WILLIAM C. BOUCK, Ex-Governor of this State, died at his residence in Schoharic County, on the 19th April, at the age of 73. Gov. NEW-ORLEANS, Wednesday, April 20. COTTON--Sales to-day 3,500 bales at unchanged prices. The receipt of the Arabia's advices had not effect upon the market. FREIGHTS--Cotton to Liverpool, 1/2 d.@5.-16d. STERLING EXCHANGE--100@109 1/2; Drafts on New-York at sight at par @1/2; ?? cent. discount.

CONCERNING THE POLICE COMMISSIONERS.--The Police Commissioners met pro forma yesterday at 11 A. M., and adjourned to the same hour to-day without transacting any business. The Commissioners are awaiting official notice of the decision of the Court of Appeals in the case of the Municipal Police.

The Jury impanneled in the Fourteenth-street poisoning case, after having waited nearly three weeks for the analytical report of Dr. Doremus, reassembled, yesterday morning at 9 1/2 o'clock, at Eighteenth Ward Station-house, The testimony of several additional witnesses was taken, and was followed by the report of Dr. Doremus,

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia arrived at Halifax yesterday at 10 A. M., having left Liverpool on the 9th inst. at 1 P. M. The intelligence by this arrival is highly important, the prospect of a war between France and Austria being regarded as inevitable, and the preparations for the threatened contest in both Austrian Italy and France being on the most extensive scale.

It was a decided disappointment to the frequenters of the Academy that the "Favorita" was not performed last night. One of those innumerable difficulties which spring up so prolifically in all musical communities, and seem in point of fact to spring naturally to lyrical soil, prevented the promised representation.

HOOENCAMP.--In this City, on Thursday, April 21, after a short but painful illness, ELLA FRANCES, youngest daughter of Daniel and Olarista Hogenesmp, aged 2 years 5 months and 7 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral service, this (Friday) afternoon, at 4 o'clock P. M., without further invitation. The remains will be taken to Rockland County for interment.

In the SICKLES case, yesterday, the whole day was occupied by the prosecution in the production of rebuting evidence, principally relating to the papers and articles found on the person of Mr. KEY, and to the apparent condition of Mr. SICKLES at the time of and subsequent to the killing.

The weather here is a funny sarcasm upon Spring. Snow is three feet deep, and the ice in the Bay is as fire as during the Winter solstice. I see by the pressure on your advertising columns, that you have room only for short stories, so that I shall gives you what I have to say in few words.

DIMON--HANDY.--In this City, on Wednesday, April 20, at the residence of the bride's father, by the Rev. Dr. Lord, of Brooklyn, Mr. BENJAMIN R. DIMON to Miss LILLIE S. HANDY, daughter of Parker Bandy, Esq., all of this City. CAMACK--BENSON--At Flab hill Landing, on Tuesday, April 19, by the Rev. J. H. Suydam, Mr. JOSEPH CAMACK, of San Francisco Cal., to Miss JULIA H., daughter of Capt. Wm. Benson of Fishkill Landing, N. Y.

As we announced in the TIMES of yesterday morning, the Untied States revenue-cutter Harriet Lane, Captain FAUNCE, arrived at Quarantine on Wednesday evening. Yesterday she came to the Navy-Yard, where she is now anchored in the stream.

PUBLIC DOCKS, PIERS AND SLIPS LEASED AT AUCTION.-The right to collect and retain the Wharfage for the use or occupation of certain Docks, Piers and Slips, for the term of five years, from the 1st of May next, was sold at public auction, in the Governor's Room at the City Hall, yesterday, at 12 o'clock M. SIMRON DEAPER was the auctioneer, and by his side stood Comptroller Haws.

QUARANTINE TROUBLES--LETTER FROM THE HON. ROBERT CHRISTIE. The Board met on Wednesday afternoon at usual hour. The weekly statement which was submitted gives 393 as the number of emigrants arrived during the past week, making a total for the year of 8,218, against 9,111 to the same date last year.

If anything could reconcile us to the failure of the Atlantic Telegraph it would be the consideration that an hourly communication with Europe, in these times of warlike preparation and political excitement, would make the transaction of business impossible on this side of the Atlantic.

THE CENTRAL PARK COMMISSION.--We are a little surprised, in view of all that they have said upon the subject, that the central park Commissioners should have been in such haste to fill two vacancies in their number.

The usual crowd was in attendance this morning, and the same Interest continues to be manifested in the proceedings. Among the letters received by the counsel on either side, from various parts of the country, one was received tits morning by Mr. Brady from a lady signing herself, in Greek characters, "Olympia Alken," and describing herself as "one of the order of frailtyone of the simple waiters for the wave of some masculine pocket handkerchief."

A Washington journal announces this morning that the Cass-Yrissari Treaty contains no stipulation allowing the United States to land forces within the Territory of Nicaragua, except for the purpose of suppressing fillibuster enterprises, and that it also de?? to the United States the right of transporting troops across the Isthmus, except with the consent of the Nicaraguan Government.
The latest and loftiest of Boston "notions," is a story set afloat by some journalist in that restless little city, of a project for the establishment of a grand American University.

The Baltimore Patriot makes a very strong and sensible protest against the conduct of the Southern fanatics who are endeavoring to re-open the Slave-trade. The Savannah Republican joins in the denunciation of this flagrant outrage against law and the public sense of right, and declares that "a countless majority of the people of Georgia are opposed to all attempts to re-open that trade."

The death of NAPOLEON MUSARD, the founder of the celebrated Promenade Concerts at Paris, is announced by the Saxonia. M. MUSARD was born in 1789, and, devoting himself to music, became quite early life a favorite leader of orchestras for balls and private assemblies.

We mentioned not long age that thirty-six of the African Regroes brought over by the Wanderer had been seized in Telfair County, Ga., under authority of the United States Marshal, and committed to prison to await further proceedings.

State Senator JOHN DOHERTY died at Congress Hall, Albany, Wednesday evening last, Mr. DOHERTY, for two years past, had represented, as Senator, the Seventh District of New-York city, which includes the Twelfth, Nineteenth, Twentieth, Twenty-first and Twenty-second Wards--the District formerly represented by the Hon. ERASTUS BROOKS.

THE "MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM" AT MISS LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE. To ask of any manager or of any stage, an exact adherence to historical truth in the representation of such a play as the "Midsummer Nights Dream" would be as absurd as to insist upon seeing King Lear in a costume which would meet the approval of SHARON TURNER or Anglo-Saxon JOHN KEMBLE.

For a man whose pride it is to represent the extreme Pro-Slavery doctrines of the South, the Democratic candidate for Governor in Virginia presents a curious record. When first spoken of as a candidate, a portion of his own party objected to him on the ground that some twelve on fifteen years ago he sanctioned and aided in publishing a pamphlet written by the Rev. Mr. RUFFNER, in which Slavery was denounced.
Judge CAMPBELL delivered a long and able charge to the Grand Jury of the U. S. Circuit Court for the Southern District of Alabama at the opening of the Court on the 12th inst.

SUCCESSFUL SURGERY.--Mr. HENRY D' AUBIGNON of, Georgia, who was shot about twelve months since, on the Savannah Race Course, by C A. L. LAMAR, of Wanderer notoriety, recently came on to this City for the purpose of having the ball extracted.

Governor HAMMOND, of South Caroline, has written a letter to the Cotton Planters' Convention, at Macon, Ga., expressing his sympathy with Southern efforts to secure direct trade with Europe, and his confidence that it will eventually he brought about.

To the Senate: The bill entitled "An Act in edition the duties of the Assistant Clerks of the New-York Police Courts" imposes upon them ?? duties, but raises their compensation about $4,000 in the aggregate. The present salaries were lived only a year since by the Supervisors of the county, and the same body possesses full power to increase them.

It has been understood, ever since the return of Mr. FORSYTH, that he was dissatisfied with the manner in which the Administration sustained his efforts in Mexico, and in a recent letter to some friends at Columbus, Ga., who had invited him to a public dinner, he states explicitly the grounds of that dissatisfaction.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your correspondent's story of Miss RICHARD- set's shipwreck and three years' incidence on an uninhabited island on Lake Saperior, northweat of fole Royal, cannot be true, from the following facts which are within my personal knowledge.

THE TYLER CASE IN DETROIT.--Attorneys-General HOWARD, of Michigan, writes to the Detroit Advertiser, in reference to the case of Deputy-Marshal TYLER, who was recently tried for the murder of Capt. JONES, that there is a question of jurisdiction involved in that question. He has strong doubls of the power of the U. S. Circuit Court to try causes like this, which properly belong to the State Courts.

NEW MUSIC.--We have received from Messrs. WM. HALL BON, No. 043 Broadway, the following places of vocal and instrumental music: I. "The Welcome-Light," a transcription for the plane of J. R. THOMAS beautiful balled, "Some One to Love," by FREDERICK BRANDING--a brilliant and effective piece for advanced players, 2, "Kelvin Grove," transcribed by W. V. WALLACE--easy and excellent, S.

From the Washington Constitution. This gentleman, it appears, has declared war against the Administration. This declaration has seen considered sufficiently important by some one, we know not whom, to be announced in a telegraphic dispatch, now on a journey, through the public pa??, dated the 15th inst., at Augusta.

The steamer Fulton, from Southampton, brought as yesterday the following interesting letter from our Correspondent in the Paragnay Expedition, which should have reached as in advance of the letter published yesterday. Its-narrative of events and notices of personages concerned in these negotiations, however, will still be read with interest.

CORONER'S INQURIT AND VERDIOR. A painful case was yesterday brought to the notice of one of the Coroners' of the death of a man by the hand of his brother. The victim is MICHAEL MCDONALD, a dirt cartman. a little over 30 years old and unmarried. JOHN MCDONALD, a brother, two years younger, also unmarried, who earned his livelihood by driving a dirt-cart, accised of leaving choked his brother to death.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A due regard for the integrity of "GOLTON'S Map of the United States," impels the to state that I fear you have been imposed upon by your "Chicago correspondent," whose pretty story of "A Female Robinson Crusoc" I see in your issue of this morning. The writer of it evidently did not like semi-front the to study the geography of the Lakes to make his "yarn" oven plausible.

The mails by the steamship Arabia, at Boston from Liverpool, at an early hour yesterday, were received here last evening. They furnish us with unusually important details of European affairs at this critical juncture, and with a variety of interesting correspondence.

A care of swindling, similar to that which occurred recently in Western New-York, has been discovered in Midnight. As in New-York, the victims were to be the farmers. A company of fellows, equipped with fictitious mortgages, caused unsuspecting agricultural people to sell their farms and live stock for the return of a worthless mortgage.

Affairs In Albany. THE CASE OF MRS. HARTUNG--LAWS PASSED AD THE RECENT SESSION. ALBANY, Friday, April 22, W. J. HAPLY, of this city, counsel for Mrs. HAUNTING, will make an application to-morrow at 10 o'clock at Blancard's Hotel before the Hon. W. B. WRIGHT, Supreme Court Judge for this District, now in New York, for a wit of error and a stay of execution in the case of Mts. HARTUNG.

BUSTKED--In Brooklyn, GEORGE WASHINGTON Bug TEPL, aged 73 years. The funeral will take place from his late residence, Rent-av., four does from Myrtle av., Brooklyn, at 10 o'clock this (Saturday) morning. The friends of the family are invited to attend. FAITOUTE--On Friday, April 22, GEORGE W. FAJTOUTE, son of the late Rev. George Faitoute, of Jaaica, L. I., after a short illness, age-1 72 years.

AN APPARITION STEAMSHIP.--The Commercial Advertiser announces that Commodoro VANDILT'S new steamship, the Ocean Queen, of 4,000 tons, will depart on her first voyage to Liverpool on the 21st of next month.

The case of the Thirty-seven persons, chiefly students of Oberlin College, and including a Professor of that institution, for the rescue of a fugitive slave in September last, has been before the United States District Court at Cleveland for the past week. SIMEON BUSHNELL was the first to be tried, and on Saturday he was convicted.

THE "JUNIOR" MUTINY.--A CONVICTED MUTINEER'S OBJECTIONS TO THE SENTENCE OF DEATH.--CYRUS W. PLUMMER, the Junior mutineer, condemned to death at Boston for the murder of Captain MELLMN, put in a written statement, in which he says: "I object to sentence of death being passed upon me: 1st, Because I am not guilty of the death of Captain A ROBIBALD MILLEN. His blood does not rest on my hands.

The mails by the Arabia were received from Boston last evening. the particulars of European intelligence thus afforded us, greatly strengthen the belligerent tone of the news as for warded from Halifax by telegraph. The latest advices bear very little hope of the meeting of a Peace Congress, in the absence of which war is, even by the most reluctant, admitted to be unavoidable.

To the Editor of the True Southern: In your daily issue of the 13th, I observe and article headed "The Douglas Pamphle.," embracing an extract, from the Cincinnati Enquirer, in which such injustice is done me as to make it proper that i should ask the courtesy of being allowed very briefly to reply. Of course I do not more to intimate that you have done me any international injustice.

SENATORS BROWN AND DOUGLAS.--Senator BROWN, of Mississippi, has written a letter, which we publish in another column, protesting against the inference drawn by Senator DOUGLAS, from some of his speeches, that he had ever indorsed the principle of popular sovereignty.

While the over-crowded condition of Barbadoes has tended to keep her laboring population in a subservient position, a deficient system of education has done much to prevent the circulation of general intelligence.

The Board of Managers held their register meeting, at their rooms, No. 275 Broadway, Wednesday afternoon. Two new schools were admitted into the Union, making 212 in all. The receipts for the month show an excess of $507 43 over the corresponding month of last year.

An evening with LEIGH HUNT--a night, at the Cosmopoliton Club--a breakfast with R. MONCRTON MILNES--a dinner at the Royal London Yacht Club--a dinner with the American Association--a dinner at (the late) Crockford's--a dinner at the Oxford and Cambridge Club--and last and best of all, a dinner at the Hon. Mrs. NORTON'S.

From the Memphis Avalancke. MESSRS. EDITORS: Since the killing of PHILIP BARTON KEY by Mr. STICKLES, mention has been frequently made of the duel in which Mr. KEY'S older brother lost his life, and In every statement that has reached me the circumstances connected with that unfortunate affaire have been incorrectly stated.

From the London Times: A short time ago the captain of a merchant vessel forfeited his life on the public scaffold for a cruel and barbarous murder committed on one of his crew. It was hoped that so terrible an example would produce a permanent effect, and that the tyranny notoriously common on board merchantmen might be brought under some salutary control.

SPEECHES BY THE HON. G. A. GROW, THE HON. HORACE GREELEY AND OTHERS. There was a large attendance, Wednesday, at the meeting of the Young Men's Republican Control Committee. Mr. DUTCHER, the President, occupied the Chair, Judge PEABODY, of the General Committee, also occupying a seat on the platform.

Prof. Gardner, the New-England soap man, is among the recent arrivals in town, We believe he sells good soap, and he certainly has an original way of doing it. Being a fluent spaker, sharp-witted, humorous and never lacking self possession, he makes speeches aud delivers lectures of which Soap is the ostensible subject and the real object-but which go over the whole range of public affairs.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is evident that a large portion of the business community, as well as the professional men of this country,-including even those who avail themselves of the benefits of Life Insurance, - are not well informed as to the sources of profit (or more properly surplus) from which dividends are made.

THE CASE OF MARY HARTUNG.--The Albany Atlas and Argus, April 21, says: "We are reliably informed that Sheriff VAN ALSIYNE had an interview with Governor MORGAN yesterday morning for the purpose of ascertaining whether there was any probability of a respite being granted, and was assured that he was fully determined to let her suffer the full penalty of law.

THE HON. JOHN FORSYILL--Dear Sir: The undersigned, representing a large number of your friends in this city, desire to offer you some testimonial of their appreotation of your private character, and mobile especially, of the ??lity ?? which you discharged your official duty while in the service of the United States as Minister to Mexico. .

HORTICULTURE FOR WOMEN-Ingenuity seems to be busy in devising new fields for the industry of women. The events of the last year or two have made the demand for additional modes of employment more generally known, and have fixed public attention upon the sosolute necessity of devising some remedy for existing evils.

Brooklyn has been thrown into a perspiration by the curious appearance of her "Water bill," as certified by the Secretary of State. Her local papers print what purports to be the new law, with Mr. Secretary TUCKER's certificate attached.

As we were led to antieipate, on receiving the news of the defeat of Lord DERBY'S Government upon the question of Reform, the Conservative Premier has not thought it necessary or desirable to transfer his lease of power immediately into the hands of any one leader of the heterogeneous Opposition, which contrived to put him into a momentary miaority.

A REMARKABLE CASE.--The St. Louis papers notice the return to her family of a young lady of that city, Miss EUPHBASIA WINSLOW, who disappeared mysteriously seven months ago, and was supposed to have wondered off under a temporary derangement. On Saturday, 16th April, after an absence of seven months, she returned to her uncle's residence.

Not long ago the Academy of Sciences, of this city, was occupied with that inteminable question, the raining of roads. You will hardly believe it, but the published proceedings stand there as proof of the fact.

REPORTED COLLISION BETWEEN UNITED STATES TROOPS AND THE MORMONS. The St. Louis Republican has dates from Utah to March 15. A rumor of collision between troops stationed at Provo and Mormon citizens, prevailed at Salt Lake City on the 10th. The troops were stationed there by order of Judge CRADELBAUCH, during the session of his Court.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I ride four times a day in the cars of the Eighth avenue Railroad, disbursing therefor the sum of 20 cenis per diem, or $1 40 per week, which is at the rate of $72 60 per annum. To that extent do I enrich the revenues of the Company. But there of us who pay our money do not have our choice.

Some twenty well-known citizens propose to establish in the Fourth Ward a rival to the grog-shops which so greatly abound in that locality, and which entice so many thousands of young men into habits which end in their degradation and ruin.

By the time that my last letter reaches you, saying, if I remember rightly, that war is inevitable, you will receive through the telegraph from Paris, the news that "the danger is now over." Don't believe either statement. The danger may be over in Pairs; but the storm which the Emperor has raised is not so easily laid.

The House of Assembly has been treating itself to a long sitting of upwards of forty consecutive hours, The subject of the discussion was the Ministerial measure for abolishing entirely the feudal tenure of land in Lower Canada, which all the Lower Canadian members favor, and to which a majority of Upper Canadians are opposed.
The Tribune, which is generally in the depths of despair touching the prospects in life of all classes and conditions of the people, at last sees a how in the clouds.

It is in contemplation on the part of the defence to agree to dispense with the summing up speeches on both sides, and to let the case go to the jury after the evidence is closed. If the offer is made on one side it will probably be accepted on the other.

The trial of Mr. SICKLES draws to a close: The testimony on both sides has been mainly put in, though one or two witnesses on minor points remain to be examined. It has been proposed by the counsel for the defence to submit the case, as it stands, without argument to the Jury: but no reply has yet been made to this suggestion.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: By a proposed enactment of our rulers at Albany it is intended that the wrongly-supposed discharged policemen, whose just salaries have been withheld by those State officers, the Metropolitan Police Commissioners, can sue and recover the same from the Mayor, Aldermen, , of our patient, fat and long-suffering City.

A MISSION FROM JAPAN.--A letter from an officer of the United States steam filgate Pilokatan, dated at Hong Kong on Feb. 14, states that the steam frigate Mississippi had been detached from the equadron by Com. TATNALL to bear the Japanese Commission to this country by way of the Pacific.

RAILWAY WAR.- The battle of bulletins now waging between the Central Railroads of New-York and of Pennsylvania, is indicative of another and more effective conflict in which these mighty Corporations are engaged. Their positions respectively tend to make them rivals for the trade and travel between the seaboard and the West, - a fact which naturally, perhaps, but not necessarily, begets enmity.

New-Yorkers like to show their British breeding by growling at what once annoyed them long after they have got used to the annoyance, and have come rather to enjoy it. Dirt, for instance, and dirty streets, once were an eye-sore and a blemish, but for years back they have been essential elements in our City civilization--the central source of profit to whole classes.

G. W. BROWN, ESQ--Dear Sir: Yours of the 9th inst. was received yesterday. I have had little time to consider the important subject upon which you seem desirous of eliciting my views. But is has not been customary with me to conceal by views, and I can, therefore have no objection to stating them briefly, although I may not claim for them the weight to which the results of matured reflection would be entitled.

" O, NO, WE NEVER MENTION HIM!"--In the Address which the democratic members of the Legislature issued, according to usage, at the close of the session, no mention whatever is made of Mr. BUCHAMAN, though the signers must have known that he was elected-President of the United States by their party in 1856.

POLITICS IN KANSAS.--The Hon. F. P. STANTON has written a letter of considerable interest upon the organization of political parties in Kansas. He declares that he cannot act with the republicans, nor wit the Democrats as at present represented by the Administration.

Should the Dictator of Paraguay have the curiosity to turn over files of the official organs of the American Government, in order to ascertain in what temper the news of the Treaty of Asuncion has been received, he will possibly be surprised at the rudeness of the Northern barbarians.

Mr. OULD will follow for the presecution, and will occupy an hour and a half. The Judge will then either deliver his instructions or defer them to Tuesday, which latter is most probable.

MASTER SUNDAY.--The happy Easter season is not duly honored in New-York, we fear, with many colored eggs, whites doves and multitudinous clangour of bells, as it is in the older ciities of the older world. Our children do not dabble like those of Europe and the South, for weeks beforehand in dyes of all kinds;

From the Sunday Times. A ghoul, among the old fantasies of oriental romance, was a mythic demon who prowled about the graves of the dead at night, disinterred the mouldering corpses from their place of repose, and feasted on the hideous rottenness of human decay. The newspaper ghoul of the present day, however, is a reality, though he is not quite so patient as his ancient prototype. He does not wait for the actually defunct.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Atlas of to-day contains the following paragraph: "THE ARIZONA EXPEDITION--We understand that Gen. C.F. HENNINGSEN, President of the Arizona. Mexican and Central American Emigration and Colonization association, has been disappointed in his expectations, and will not be able to fulfill his engagements with the Trustees and members.

THE OPERA-- A NEW CANDIDATE FOR FAVOR . Now that the most righteous of opera-goers feels himself at liberty to peruse the amusement columns of the daily papers with a view to casual gratication, it will be pleasant to find, as he can to-day, that the Academy of Music throws open its ample doors to welcome the penitent.

JEWETT--GARRISON.--In Brooklyn, on Sunday, April 21, at the Church of the Holy Trinity, by the Rev. Wm. H. Lewis, WM. CORNELL JEWETT, of the firm of Jewett Co., New-York, to ESTHER GARRISON, daughter of the Hon. C. R. Garrison. California and St. Louis papers please copy.

THE HERALD STILL HARPING ON WASHINGTON HEIGHTS.--Since Prometheus was chained so cruelly upon the frosty Caucasus, no mortal has been so ill-treated, upon any elevated region, as is the Editor of the Herald upon Washington Heights. It is his desolate doom to be forever slipping away from that bleak exposure, and to be forever arrested upon the slope.

The testimony in the Sickles case was closed on both sides on Saturday--Ex-Senator BRODHEAD being the last witness examined. Nothing material was elicited. The points on which instructions to the Jury are asked for were then submitted, and Mr. CARLISLE proceeded to argue the case for the prosecution. He was followed by Mr. STANTON, for the defence, at the close of whose argument the Court adjourned.

BEDFORD.--In this City, on Sunday, April 24, AUGUSTUS BEDFORD, aged 45 years. Relatives and friends of the family are respecifully invited to attend the funeral, from the Dutch Reformed Church, corner of Bleecker and West 10th (Amos) sts., on Tuesday, April 26, at 2 o'clock, without further invitation.

The screw steamship City of Washington, Cap, PETRIO, which sailed from Liverpool at fouro'clock in the afternoon of the 13th of April arrived here at four o'clock yesterday afternoon. The cunard steamship Asia, from New York, arrived at Liverpool at 2 P. M. on Sunday, the 10th of April.

The Sickles case will no doubt be submitted to the jury to-morrow, as in the arguments on his instructions prayed for, both sides have presented the case to the jury. Mr. STATION'S argument on Saturday is the theme of universal praise, while Mr. BRADY to day fully met the public expectation.

SEVENTY-THIRD ANNIVERSARY OF THE ST. GEORGE'S SOCIETY.--The St. George's Society Celebrated its seventy-third anniversary yesterday. In the morning services were celebrated at St. Thomas Church, corner of Broadway and Houston-street, The Right Rev. Blessed are the peace-makers."

A Canadian magistrate, Mr, Elisha S. Gauson, of Aylmer, is under arrest for committing a murderous assault upon a man named Frost, whose offence was, that he took possession of a piece of land, the proprietorship of which was disputed between Mr. Gausan and another party. Frost received a mortal wound on the head with an ax.

Lord LYONS has hold several long interviews with Secretary CASS relative to the Clayton-Bulwer Treaty and other questions pending between the Governments of Great Britain and the United States. His Lordship has made a decidedly favorable impression here.

The long agony of the SICKLES' trial is over. The case was submitted to the jury about 3 P. M., yesterday, and the verdict of acquittal was rendered after an hour's deliberation. An extraordinary scene of excitement occurred in the Court-room on the verdict being rendered, the friends of Mr. SICKLES having borne him from the room almost before the judge had time to discharge him.

It has been remarked that Sir E. C. LYTTON has not attended in this place in Parliament for some days. The reason of his absence is understood to be the failure of his health, owing to the assidulty with which he has unremittingly discharged the duties of his office, and which has rendered imperative a temporary withdrawal from public affairs.

The town of Brighton, (Mass.,) has been in an excited state for the past few days in consequence of some ejectment proceedings in connection with a family of that town, the particulars of which are of a somewhat romantic character.

The elegant Church edifice just built at the intersection of Broadway, Sixth-avenue and thirty-fourth-street, for the congregation of the Old Broadway Tabernacle, was dedicated to divine service on Sunday morning. A description of the building has already been published in the TIMES.

To the House of Commons , on the 6th inst., Mr. HORSTALL, the December for Liverpool, moved for some correspondence in regard to the intended mail service between Galway and America. This service, he complained, had been assigned to a particular line of steamers, the Galway Packet Line, without the usual advertisement for public tenders.

Yesterday was the Fortieth Anniversary of the institution of the Independent Order of Old-Fellow's in the United States. At sunrise flags were flying from the City Hall; citizens and strangers wearing those insignia which have been so familiar on all public occasions, were traversing the streets in every direction on the way to their various headquarters, and knots of people were gathered here rally.

The closing scenes of the Sickles' trial were exceedingly impressive and exciting. The Jury retired at precisely ten minutes before 2 o'clock. The room was crowded with spectators, and instinctively every eye was turned towards the clock. Every minute that passed by was set down as fresh proof presumptive of a disagreement. The crowd gradually broke up into groups.

Those of our readers who are not given to riding on horseback will find an excellent substitute for that exercise in reading Governor WISR'S letter, which we publish in another column. If they are invalids--feeble in body or weak in mind--we advise them to avoid it; they might survive it, but they would suffer cramps and neuralgia for a month.

The Post-office authorities of New-York having been sorely taken to task by many of our merchants and others, on account of continual losses of the letters delivered at the office, have retorted upon these remonstrants, by proving that in very many cases the duty of collecting their mails is imposed by men of business upon mere boys, quite incompetent, in point of age and experience, to its faithful discharge.

It will be remembered that upon the trial of Mrs. MARY HARTUNG, it was made to appear on the part of the prosecution, that only three days before her husband's death, she had purchased a quantity of arsenic. As the death was clearly shown to have been caused by arsenic, the fact of this purchase was of course a strong circumstance against the prisoner.

The Right Rev. GEORGE WASHINGTON DOANE Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New Jersey, died at his residence in Burlington, yesterday, aged sixty years. Bishop DOANE, the son of JONATHAN DOANE, an industrious carpenter of Trenton, was born in 1799, received his education at Union College, whence he graduated at the age of 19, and immediately commenced the study of Theology.

SMITH, then and now part owner of the Morse Patent, sneeringly remarked that his Durham bull would carry one thousand words from Boston to New-York in much quicker time than the same number could be transmitted over the Printing Telegraph wires.

WATER FOR BROOKLYN.--The City of Brooklyn holds an ovation to-day over the completion of her water-works. It is an event which fully deserves the pomp with which she proposes to celebrate it. Pure water, next to pure air, and equally with wholesome food, concerns the health and happiness of the people. The want of it has been hitherto the chief lack of Brooklyn:

The Joiners employed in the Charlestown Navy-yard have presented to Commodore Stringham a handsome gold headed cane, valued at $50. It was made form a piece of the old Constitution. Yesterday there was a steady stream of people pouring into Brooklyn from New-York by way of the various fories. Those who had the whole day at their disposal went over early in the morning, and many others, who had not the entire day at command, postponed their departure until evening, when they hoped to see the private and public buildings sparkling with transparencies, and the square in front of the City Hall brilliant with fire-works.

The widow of Gen. Arthur O'Connor, daughter of the Marquis de Condorcet, has died in retirement on her estate, in France, where she has been Interred in privacy. Her husband, the Irish rebel, was from Bandon, and was brother to Roger, who rented Dangan Castle from the Wellesleys, and who begat Feargus O'Connor, the Chartist, to whom the Norwich folks are erecting a statue. The dynasty is now extinct.

THE ENGLISH ADMIRAL'S FARM IN MASSACHUSETTS.--The Boston Traveller publishes another side of the story about Admiral COTTON'S farm in Brighton, Mass, about which there is a legal controversy ?? It appears now that the aforesaid farm was not originally purchased by Admiral COFFIN for his servant PARRISSON, as has been stated, nor, we are assured, was a life interest given to PARKINSON for saving his master's life.

Secretary FLOYD received to-day voluminous dispatches from Col. JOHNSTON, commanding in Utah. This officer gives a floomy account of the conflict here between himself and Gov. CUMMING, and between the Governor and the Judiciary, fully confirming the accounts contained in the Special Correspondence of the TIMES.

There is said to be a project on foot, in the South at present, for the holding of a Convention at Vicksburg, Miss., to form a new Southern party, upon the basis of opposition to those laws of the United States which there is no chance of having repealed in the ordinary way ; amongst others, the neutrality laws, the Slave-trade laws, and the navigation laws.

THE REV. RUSSELL S. COOK: DEAR SIR: Attacks against the system of the American Traot Society, in the production and circulation of its publications, have lately been made and widely circulated, as you doubtless know. After the arrival of the opposition steamer Northern Light, should she bring nothing in the shape of dispatches to prevent, the Ranoke will leave for San Juan del Norte, the Jamestown remaining to protect the harbor.

DEATH OF MADAME BOSIO. - Madame BOSIO, whose earliest artistle triumphs were won in this country, on the operatic stages of Boston and New-York, and for whose return in the ripened beauty of her singular lyric abilities all the lovers of Italian music among as had long been hoping, died suddenly at St. Peters-burgh, on the 12th instant.

LAW AND PUBLIC OPINION.--The Southern journals are just beginning to realize the difficulty of enforcing a law which is directly contrary to the sentiment of the community in which it is to be executed.

Yesterday we heard the rolling of drums and the clanging of steel in the streets; to-day the olive is paraded in triumph. Since the famous New-Years' speech of the Emperor we have not had such a week of agitation and of political emotions.

THE TRIBUNE'S ARGAL.--When Mr. CHOATE was once rebuked rather tartly by a Chief Justice of Massachusetts more noted for his law than for his politeness, he turned to a brother lawyer and observed, in a "stage whisper," "Our Chief Justice is not much of a lawyer, but he certainly is a perfect gentlemen."

The intelligence was greeted with no manifestations of even station, anywhere or by anybody.

FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT OF THE TRACT SOCIETY. - We publish this morning a letter from the Rev. R. S. Cook in vindication of the colportage system of distributing books and tracts from complaints which have been made against it in various quarters.

DEATH OF LADY MORGAN.--The London Globe announces the death of Lady MORGAN, an event which must have occurred suddenly, as no previous announcement had been made of her illness. This celebrated woman was almost the last survivor of the literary celebrities whose productions gave a tone to English thought in the beginning of the present century.

SUPPOSED FOUL PLAY.-At a late hour Thursday night the Police found a man named JOHN WINNE, lying insensible upon the sidewalk In Atlantic street, near the ferry. He had apparently been beaten. He was taken to the City Hospital, where he tiled yesterday morning. Coroner HORTON has taken charge of tile case and will commence an investigation to-day.

DEATH OF THE KENTUCKY GIANT. - James D. Porter, well known as the "Kentucky Giant, " though born at Portsmouth, Ohio, was found dead in his bed at his residence, near Louisville, on Monday, April 25. He was 19 years of age, seven feet nine inches in height, and when in good health weighed three hundred pounds.

The bark Emigrant arrived at this port to day, being the first vessel from Europe since the resumption of navigation. The ship Pride of Canada, from Liverpool, passed the telegraph-station at River du Loup yesterday.

NYE, as before, conducted the examination of the witnesses against McCUNE. The great Amateur performance, concerning which young New-York has been in a tremor of expectation for some months past, came off on Thursday night, and was, as every one know it would be, a success. It is gratifying to record that an entertainment, having for its end the material assistance of a deserving charity, has thus accomplished all that its most sanguine friends expected.

Our latest advices, in regard to the high water in the Lower Missiasippi, are of an alarming character. The numerous crevasses have resulted in the overflow of large tracts of the lower country, and the destruction of stock, crops, and improvements, to an almost incalculable amount. From Momphis down, the river is described as spreading like a poa, and the marks of desolation are everywhere visible.

THE COLCHESTER BANK CASE SETTLED.--The New-Haven Register says: "SAMUEL F. JONES, the defaulting cashier of the Colchester Bank, whose recent conveyance to this State made so much excitement, has finally seen the end of his legal troubles, JONES has paid some $25,000 to the Receivers of the Colchester Bank, enough to redeem the circulation and cover the Receivers' and State's expenses.

DENIAL OF THE WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS. The Supreme Court of Ohio has denied the application for a writ of habeas corpus in the case of SIMEON BUSENELL and others, indicated for the rescue of the fugitive slave JOHN at Oberiln, on the ground that it is not legally competent for a State Court to interfere with a process of the Federal Court while the Proceedings against the prisoners are still pending and undermined.

Since then the noise and smoke of war have been heaped upon us, with the result of leaving us just where we were a month ago--the Government of this Capital a loser as compared with the Federalists.

HORTICULTURAL SCHOOL FOR FEMALES,--Philanthropy of a direct and practical character deserves the applause of all communities. A lady of this City, Mrs. PHELPS, has devised a scheme whereby woman's sphere of beautiful usefulness may be largely extended. This liberal and kindly lady proposes to establish on Long Island an establishment for training young orphan girls in the art of Horticulture--an art demanding patient care rather than physical strength.

A catastrophe of a most appalling nature occurred this morning on the Pennsylvania Railroad in the vicinity of Greensburg. It appears that the ballast train was in services as usual, and that while on its way cast, and within a short distance of Greensburg the locomotive exploded with a tremendous report, killing three men and shattering the engine to pieces.

THE STOCKBRIDGE INDIANS' CLAIM.-A Party of Stockbridge Indians have made their appearance in Columbia County, and claimed some land. The owners protested, and a trial was the result, which was decided in lavor of the present owners.

This attention is not directed so much to the traits of the more dignified families of animals as to the oddities and whimsicalities of nature; to the curiosities of her handiwork in the humbler branches, along the very twigs of the tree of life;

Nothing is yet known as to the bids for the Pacific mail service, nor will there be any communication on the subject by the Post-office Department until the decision is made. It is reported but the delay in awarding the contract is owing to difference in the Nicaragua Canal Company.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--The first meeting of the new Board of Supervisors was held in the county Jail yesterday afternoon." Twenty-three of the 24 members composing the Board were present. The first business Introduced was that of electing a Chairman.

THE WEEKLY STATEMENT-CASTLE GARDEN AND THE RAILROADS. The Board met, yesterday afternoon, at the usual hour. The weekly report sates that 1,466 emigrants arrived during the week ending yesterday, making a total for the year of 11,194, against 12,487 to the same date last year. There are 824 inmates in the institutions on Ward's Island, and 36 in the Marine Hospital.

HIS OPINIONS ON THE CONDITION OF THE IRISH IN AMERICA. Mr. SMITH O'BRIEN arrived in Detroit on Thursday, from his trip through the Southwest, and had an enthusiastic reception. He was escorted to the Biddle House, where an address of welcome was delivered by Mr. Wm. GRAY.

A NEW CHURCH TROUBLE IN PRUSSIA.--Professor HENOSTERNDERG, the spiritual chief of the orthodox Lutheran party in Prussia, has been form formally accused of insulting the OBER-KIHCHEN-RATH, or highest constituted authority of the established Church of this country. The circumstance is most remarkable in its way.

The Hon. J. PHILLIPS PHOENIX died at his residence in this City yesterday morning. Mr. PHOENIX was a native of New-Jersey, but passed most of his life in this City, where he was for many years engaged in mercantile pursuits. He took an active partin politics, and was elected to Congress by the Whigs of the lower District of New-York in 1843, and again in 1849.

OHIO AND THE SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES.--We predicted some days age that the Supreme Court of Ohio would not follow the example of that of Wisconsin in disregarding the authority of the United States Supreme Court: and the result has been in accordance with our expectations.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. One means which is sometimes very successfully employed to bring about a desired end seems now to be in general use on both sides of the Atlantic. It is to set afloat, and keep upon the surface of the general mind the phantom "Inevitability." War is inevitable, men cry. So is doomsday, might be the answer.

Our anticipations of an unusually early Spring, based on the mild weather of February, have not been realized. We have had but little warm weather for the last three weeks, and still have SHOW on the ground.

A BOY OF TWELVE CONVICTED OF MANSLAUGHTER.--An extraordinary and sad spectacle was witnessed in the Court of Oyer and Terminer on Tuesday. THOMAS MILLER, a lad of twelve, was tried on an indictment for manslaughter. On the 7th of March, he had stabbed another boy with a shoemaker's awl, so that he died.

THE UTAH MASSACRES.--The Commissioner of Indian Affairs is in receipt of a letter dated at Provo City, March 18, 1850, from Superintendent FORNEY, having charge of Indian affairs in Utah. The Suprintendent reports that he left Salt Lake City to visit the southern Indians, and bring back 17 children saved from the massacre of September, 1857.

THE CAMPAIGN IN TENNESSEE--The Washington correspondent of the Philadelphia North American says: "The Democrats in Tennessee write despondingly to their friends here of the prospect in that State next August. They do not presend to claim any of the former majorities in the Congressional Districts, and really fear losses which they are not yet willing to confess openly.

Simultaneously with the retirement of Commodore STRIEGHAM from the command of the Charleston Navy-yard, certain developments are made, which implicate a man named J. A. BARLETT,--who, for three years has filled the post of confidential Secretary to the Commodore,--in a series of swindling operations, in which not only the Government, but numerous private individuals and firms have been vitimized.

By the Quaker City's mails we have intelligence from Port-au-Prince to April 16. The brig African, from New-York, arrived there on the 12th with 35 fillibusters and 240 guns, and other munitions of war, having failed to land them at Nuevas Grandos, Cuba. The attempt was made on the 7th ult., but the boats were swamped and the munitions in them lost.

THE NEW COMET.-From the observations of the present comet made at the Observatory in Cambridge during the first week of its appearance, (April 23-29,) Mr. SAFFORD, of Cambridge, has calculated the elements of its orbit, and its course for the rest of the time when it will be seen. It is now moving nearly south, and will continue to do so until it is lost In tile sun's says.

SCOTT, by means of which sounds may be made to record themselves, whether these sounds are those of musical instruments, or emitted by the voice in singing or speaking.

A projected elopement from Havre to New-York was recently nipped in the bud. A letter from Havre says: On Saturday a lady and two gentlemen alighted at a hotel, and took tickets for their passage to New-York on board the Mercury. On the same day, while the party were preparing to visit the town, a telegraphic dispatch arrived from Amounts.

FREQUENCY OF FORGERIES.--Those forms of crime which minister to avarice are fearfully on the increase, and among offences of this sort forgery takes the lead. It is the felony which gentlemen commit, as distinguished from pocket-picking and burglary.

The annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday. The first business bring the election of officers, Mr. ROYAL PHELPS moved the PELETIAH PERIT be unanimously reflected for the coming year, as, without unanimous consent he could not, according to the laws of the chamber, retain the office.

The brig Tanner arrived on Wednesday from Buenos Ayres, having sailed from that port on the 8th of March. THE CASE OF U.S. MARSHAL TYLER IN DETROIT.--The Detroit Free Press learns that the Attorney. General of Michigan has ordered another trial for U. S. Deputy Marshal TYLER, lately convicted of manslaughter, for killing the captain of a vessel. The Sheriff of St. Clair County has been directed to rearrest TYLER when his term of imprisonment expires, which will be very soon.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In August, 1846, the Hon. GEORGE BANGROFT, then Secretary of the Navy, issued a "General Order," conferring upon the medical officers of the service an assimilated rank with the officers of the line, ranging from that of Commander to that of Master.

The following notice appears in the daily papers of this date under the bead of washington news: "General JEBEZ, the Nicaragun Minister, on the 26th inst., notified Mr. YELVERTON, President of the American Atlantic and Pacific Ship Canal Company, that their charter had been declared forfieted by the Congress of Nicaragua, on the ground that the Company had failed to fulfill its obligations, and he likewise notified Secretary CASS to the same effect."

VIEW OF THE NEW CANADIAN CAPITAL TO BE PRESENTED TO THE QUEEN.--The loyal inhabitants of Ottawa have caused a handsome pleture of their fortunate little city to be engraved and framed as a present to Her Majesty, in testimony of their gratitude for her selection of Ottawa as the seat of Government. The frame of the picture is an elaborate piece of work.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, from Halifax, arrived at Boston this afternoon. Her mails were dispatched South by the afternoon train, and reached New-York at midnight. The newspaper bag for the Associated Press, having been by some mistake slowed away among the cargo, was not found in time to be forwarded with the mails.

The R. M. steamship Niagara, whose advices we published yesterday morning as telegraphed from Sackville, N. B., arrived at Boston yesterday afternoon. Her regular mails reached this City at midnight, over the New-Haven Railroad, and will be ready for delivery this morning.
